title: The Talk of Camden
description: There are no supermarkets here. There are no car dealerships - the last one closed at the end of April. There are no movie theaters.

title: The Region; Mushroom Warning Widened by Albany
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Health Department warned consumers not to eat mushrooms from any four-ounce cans produced by Oxford Royal Mushroom Products Inc. of Kelton, Pa., because of a possibility of botulism contamination. An earlier warning had spoken only of cans produced in April and May.

title: Mauch's New Dugout
description: THE best baseball managers never appear to be comfortable in a suit and tie. They don't look like themselves unless they're wearing a baseball uniform with those silly knickers and a peaked cap. And they are never comfortable in an office. Only in a dugout.

title: SLUMPING COSMOS LOOKING FOR WINGERS
description: Victories over the Cosmos have helped two teams the last two Saturdays, and now the Cosmos need help themselves. They have four losses in their last five games - three in the North American Soccer League and the other in an international match against Anderlecht of Belgium. They have beaten only the Dallas Tornado.

title: Commodities; The Rising Interest in Heating Oil
description: IF necessity is the mother of commodity futures markets, then price volatility must surely be the father. Without the presence of either factor, there would be no need for a futures market. This relationship is perhaps nowhere more evident than in the market for No.2 heating oil futures traded on the New York Mercantile Exchange, where both the open interest - the number of open contracts - and the daily volume set records last week.

title: CECIL TAYLOR AND NEWEST UNIT PERFORM AT PUBLIC
description: CECIL TAYLOR calls his band a ''unit,'' and for the group's only New York appearances this year, Friday and Saturday at the Public Theater, he unveiled a new edition. It consisted of himself on piano and Jimmy Lyons, a 20-year veteran of the Unit, on alto saxophone.

title: Syria Stages War Alert; Warns of Israeli Attack
description: Syria staged its first civil defense exercise today since the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, and an official radio commentary warned that an Israeli attack was ''expected at any time.'' It was the first of a series of such exercises.

title: MEDICAL MALPRACTICE INSURANCE CRISIS NEEDS GOV. CAREY'S ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: VILLENEUVE FIRST AT MONTE CARLO IN FERRARI AS ONLY 7 OF 20 FINISH
description: Gilles Villeneuve of Canada won his first Formula One auto race in almost two years today, driving his Ferrari to a dramatic victory at the 39th Monaco Grand Prix.

title: 100,000 IN LONDON PROTEST BRITISH ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: A 30-day march across England by several hundred unemployed workers protesting the British Government's economic policies ended today with 100,000 people taking part in a demonstration.

title: KING LEADS THE SPANISH IN HONORING ARMY
description: King Juan Carlos presided over an armed forces parade today that underscored the sensitive role that the military establishment has assumed in Spain's political life lately.

title: Morgenthau Drops Case Of '79 Bomb 'Sculpture'
description: A criminal charge against a SoHo artist accused of planting a bomb atop a tower of the Brooklyn Bridge in August 1979 has been dropped at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: Andrea Farkas Bride of Jeffrey M. Krupen
description: Andrea Lee Garner Farkas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robin Lewis Farkas of New York, was married at the Plaza yesterday to Jeffrey Marc Krupen, son of Gertrude Krupen of Howard Beach, Queens, and the late Ira Krupen. Rabbi Norman Kahan, first vice president of the New York Board of Rabbis, officiated.

title: CARDINALS FALL TO CARLTON AGAIN
description: One of the greatest mistakes the St. Louis Cardinals have made was trading Steve Carlton to the Philadelphia Phillies for Rick Wise in February of 1972. Carlton keeps reminding the Cardinals of their error.

title: VIDEO SALES MAY PASS PREDICTIONS
description: Sales of television sets and other video equipment are expected to set records this year and surpass forecasts made as recently as six months ago, according to industry executives interviewed here today at the start of the summer consumer electronics show.

title: MUSIC: BASICALLY BACH'S B MINOR MASS
description: PERFORMANCES of Bach's big choral works come in all shapes and sizes in these days of musical ecumenism. Richard Westenburg and his Musica Sacra Chorus have never espoused the more radical positions of what is today considered Baroque purism - authentic instruments, tiny performing units and the like - but they happily take a convincing middle course, keeping an eye on the main order of business, which is to make the notes sound as expressive as possible within a scholarly informed context.

title: AMID THE ANARCHY OF BEIRUT, 8 DIE IN SHELLING ON A BEACH
description: The beaches were jammed this afternoon, as they always are here on Sunday, when the Lebanese try to enjoy the sun and the Mediterranean, two of the few gifts they have left.

title: McCann Frankfurt Officer To Move to Detroit
description: Gerald C. Atkin, 45 years old, will leave McCann-Erickson's Frankfurt office, where he was General Motors coordinator, to take over the Detroit office, whose major client is G.M.'s Buick, on Aug. 1. He will replace William A. Murphy, 42, who was in the job for a year as executive vice president and general manager.

title: Tigers 5, Orioles 4
description: Trailing 4-0, the Tigers rallied with five runs to hand the Orioles their eighth loss in nine games played on Sundays this season. Baltimore saw its lead in the Eastern Division cut to two games over the Milwaukee Brewers.

title: GAMBLERS IN BRONCO INQUIRY
description: Members of the Colorado Organized Crime Strike Force say that persons involved in area gambling were also involved in an investigation of alleged cocaine use by Denver Bronco players.

title: Japanese Report Dismissal Of Submarine Skipper
description: Japanese news reports said today that the captain of the United States nuclear submarine that sank a Japanese freighter in a collision April 9 had been relieved of his command.

title: AIR FORCE OFFICER SAID TO HAVE GIVEN RUSSIANS TITAN DATA
description: The Air Force missile officer accused of making unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy here gave Soviet diplomats information about Titan missiles that was sensitive enough to require the Air Force to change targets, codes and other systems, according to military officials.

title: FOR BOOK HUNTERS, BONANZA
description: From Maine and Arizona and points between, ready with shopping carts and guided by maps, on the lookout for first edition classics and pulp tear-jerkers, 25,000 bibliophiles descended last week on the Brandeis Used Book Sale, billed as the largest in the world.

title: RORER GROUP, MAKER OF MAALOX, WIDENS BASE TO KEEP GROWING
description: For the Rorer Group Inc., an international health care company based in Fort Washington, Pa., there is, despite the Rolaids TV commercial, only one way to spell relief: M-a-a-l-o-x.

title: Advertising; Tests Set For Line of Fragrances
description: ROTH, the well-known hosiery-making subsidiary of Gulf and Western, will announce this week that it will go into test market this autumn with a line of men's and women's mass-market fragrances.

title: FIRST GOLF VICTORY FOR MISS REYNOLDS
description: Cathy Reynolds gained the first victory in her three years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour today, and it was a family achievement.

title: Relationships
description: E LIZABETH TAYLOR isn't exactly the first one to give sibling rivalry a bad name - when, as Regina Giddens in ''The Little Foxes'', she and her stage brothers Ben and Oscar undo one another with cold hatred and hot avarice. After all, Cain and Abel did less for the institution of brotherly love than they might have, back in the household of Adam and Eve.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albertson's Inc., Boise, Idaho, has elected to its board James E. Bruce, chairman and chief executive officer of the Idaho Power Company

title: THIS IS DEALING FROM STRENGTH?
description: The Reagan Administration appears to have declared as nonproblems the so-called global concerns over which the Carter Administration briefly agonized: what to do about the catastrophic world food situation, the instability of the world monetary system, the sharing of resources under the sea, the mounting debts of poor countries, the growing rivalries within the developed world over access to scarce resources, and the environmental consequences of such rivalries.

title: Around the nation; Dissident Teamsters Pledge Candidate to Lead Union
description: Dissidents in the teamsters union, angered over the candidacy for the union's presidency of Roy L. Williams, who was indicted May 22, pledged today to offer an alternative candidate and to fight for several changes in the union constitution.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The street will serve as a constant reminder of the persecution of men and women like Anatoly Shcharansky.

title: Paula Schehr, Teacher, Wed To Steven Morvay, Ad Man
description: Paula Schehr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schehr of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven Morvay, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Morvay of Millburn, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Temple Israel Center in White Plains.

title: BARBARA WARD, BRITISH ECONOMIST, DIES
description: Barbara Ward, the British economist and author, died today at her home in southern England after a long illness. She was 67 years old.

title: Emily F. Frank Bride of Edward Berkowitz
description: Emily Frances Frank and Edward David Berkowitz were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Jerome David Frank of Baltimore. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Monroe Berkowitz of Bound Brook, N.J., and Bear Creek, Pa.

title: 1973 CAR INSURANCE REFUND LAW NEARS A SHOWDOWN IN NEW YORK
description: In 1973 the New York Legislature enacted a law requiring automobile insurance companies to return their ''excess profits'' to policyholders. But so far drivers have not received any refunds, and a dispute has arisen between consumer representatives and insurance companies over whether they should.

title: STATE IS ASKED TO PROSECUTE FUND SOLICITORS IN ATLANTA
description: The Governor's Office of Consumer Affairs has requested that the state prosecute the Committee to Stop Children's Murders on both civil and criminal charges of violating Georgia's law dealing with charitable solicitations.

title: THOUSANDS RALLY FOR SOVIET DISSIDENTS
description: Waving pictures of imprisoned Soviet dissidents and singing songs of hope, thousands of New Yorkers marched in mid-Manhattan yesterday to join in a rally held across the street from the United Nations in support of Jews who have been kept from emigrating from the Soviet Union.

title: The Region; Darien Officer Dies After a Gun Battle
description: A 34-year-old Darien police officer was fatally wounded in a gun battle with a man believed to be a burglar outside a restaurant early yesterday, authorities said.

title: Laura Drager, Lawyer, Is Bride of Martin Barr
description: Laura Ellen Drager, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Drager, was married yesterday to Martin David Barr, son of Vivian Barr and the late Herman Barr. Both families live in Manhattan.

title: Needham, Harper & Steers Wins Dorsey Account
description: Thanks to expertise in cold remedies acquired while working on Bristol-Myers's Congespirin, a four-way product, Needham, Harper & Steers, New York, has won a $5 million assignment from Dorsey Laboratories, of Lincoln, Neb.

title: OUTDOORS: NEW WAVE IN WATER SPORTS
description: IN America there are not many companies with products to sell that keep their telephone numbers unlisted. Stan Stunik runs one, Apple Line of Scotia, N.Y., which manufactures canoes and kayaks, plain or fancy. ''We can make about 1,000 a year, and we get requests for 12,000,'' Mr. Stunik explained. ''So we hide. Otherwise we'd be on the telephone all the time saying sorry, maybe next year, and never get any work done.''

title: Canadian Said to Meet Castro
description: The leader of Canada's New Democratic Party, Ed Broadbent, met with President Fidel Castro of Cuba last night in Havana, a well-informed diplomatic source said. Mr. Broadbent arrived in Cuba Friday and left today for Panama. There was no official word in Havana about the meeting, but the source said that Latin American affairs and the situation in El Salvador had been discussed.

title: PRIME RATE NOW ELUDES DEFINITION
description: Banks have hardly been bashful about trumpeting the frequent changes in their prime lending rates, traditionally considered the lowest rate available to the most creditworthy corporations. But ask a banker what that rate represents today and he suddenly becomes tongue-tied, ducking behind definitions scarcely aimed at shedding light on the issue.

title: Jorky Captured Trot Easily in Stockholm
description: The French-owned trotter Jorky, driven by Leopold Verroken, moved to the front at the head of the stretch and held on for an easy victory today in the $164,000 Elite race.

title: Boorum & Pease Head
description: William I. Thompson, 59, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of the Boorum & Pease Company. He succeeds Alexander R. Noble, who retired at the age of 62.

title: No Headline
description: CAR BOMB KILLS BRITON IN ULSTER: British soldiers inspecting the wreckage of a booby-trapped car that exploded, killing an army demolition expert who was trying to defuse the bomb. In Belfast, a policeman standing guard inside a hospital was shot to death at point-blank range by a trio that escaped after the shooting.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Saturday on Harley Lippman, a freelance writer, Joshua Muravchik was incorrectly identified.

title: A Bad Time for Women?
description: A columnist reporting recently on an argument between two writers quoted the following dialogue:

title: THEATER: ONE-ACTERS BY NEWCOMERS
description: THREE hopeful new playwrights are introduced in the Ensemble Studio Theater's second round of one-act plays in ''Marathon 1981,'' and none of the debuts is auspicious. However, as is often the case at the E.S.T., each of the plays is improved by the performance.

title: HARVARD IS SWEPT BY YALE
description: It was Yale's day at last on the Thames River today as the Elis won all three races from Harvard in the renewal of the oldest intercollegiate sports event, the Harvard-Yale regatta.

title: Giants 6, Astros 1
description: Tom Griffin and Al Holland combined to hold the Astros to six hits and the Giants took advantage of wildness by Nolan Ryan (4-3). Ryan walked six batters, threw three wild pitches, committed a balk and gave up eight hits in seven innings.

title: Braxton Knocks Out Rossman in 7th
description: Dwight Braxton won today and talked about tomorrows filled with title fights and money, money, money. ''Bring on King Kong,'' said the happy winner.

title: NEW ISSUES STAY HIGH
description: Interest rates for notes and bonds have come down substantially from the record levels of early May, but many corporations continue to defer long-term financing. About $600 million of new issues are scheduled for public sale this week. According to data from Salomon Brothers, about $1.1 billion of new issues are scheduled for the month.

title: NEW DEMOCRATIC COALITION BACKING BARBARO FOR MAYOR
description: The New Democratic Coalition, a liberal reform group that Mayor Koch had described with a ''yecchh,'' rejected Mr. Koch in turn yesterday and endorsed Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro for the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: THE 'EARNINGS TEST'
description: Amid all the controversy over the approaching insolvency of the Social Security system and President Reagan's thus far unsuccessful attempt to reduce benefits to future retirees under 65 and other beneficiaries, it is dismaying that his plan includes an extremely ill-considered, inequitable, expensive, and wasteful increase in benefits. I have in mind the proposal to abolish what is called the ''earnings test'' but is more properly labeled the ''retirement test.''

title: Around the nation; North Carolina Official Investigated by the State
description: Lieut. Gov. Jimmy Green is under investigation for allegedly accepting $9,600 worth of free paving work from a company involved in bidding on state highway paving contracts, The Greensboro Daily News reported today.

title: Help Wanted
description: Wanted, Presidential speechwriter. Strong-willed enough to resolve foreign-policy differences of European-Schmidten Haigsmen and Helmswary Reaganites, skilled enough to impose cohesion of thought while retaining the relaxed Reagan style. Passion for anonymity required. Low pay, little prestige, but big payoff on memoirs.

title: TWO-WAY GAMES CHANNEL IS COMING TO CABLE TV
description: A promotional brochure for a games channel, one of a dozen new services announced at the annual cable-television convention this weekend, enticed cable operators with this bit of intrigue:

title: Hard-Hitting News
description: When Jack Tatum was an all-America defensive back at Ohio State in the 1960's, a teammate, Rex Kern, said, ''he always said he wanted to hit people - and he does a pretty good job.'' So good that one season Tatum knocked out three Big Ten quarterbacks with clean hits.

title: The Masonry's Shaking Italy
description: No one can possibly make sense yet of Italy's revelations about a secretive Masonic lodge that may have been a cover for power brokerage, criminal activities and perhaps even a rightist plot to keep Communists from power. What is clear, and even more important, is that the scandal has opened a new power struggle between Christian Democrats and Socialists in the governing center-left coalition - only three weeks before tell-tale local elections.

title: Index; International
description: For Nicaragua, the price of revo- lution continues to grow A2 King leads Spaniards in honoring the military A3 Disillusionment Threatens Bonn Coalition A3 Strike by French-speaking Cana- dians draws little attention A4 Around the World A5 Syrians stage a war alert A6 Jerusalem issue resurfaces as Sadat-Begin meeting nears A6 Liberal South African paper dis- misses its editor A9 Pope, in message, calls Cardinal Wyszynski ''keystone of unity'' A10 Government/Politics Queens District Attorney seeks changes in immunity law B2 New Coalition drops Koch, en- dorses Barbaro for Mayor B3 General Reminder on a Mississippi main street A11 Confusing warnings on radio-TV called peril to evacuation plans A11 Around the Nation A12 Rate of homicides among Cubans in Florida found above average A12 Four sons of a New Jersey doctor die in a fire at home B2 Obituaries Barbara Ward, British economist B6 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Villeneuve wins Monaco Grand Prix C11 Baseball: Yankees lose to In- dians, 7-2, as May falters again C1

title: The City; Delay Is Expected In Chapman Trial
description: Mark David Chapman, who is charged with having killed John Lennon, the musician and composer, in December, is expected to appear at a hearing this morning in State Supreme Court in Manhattan at which Justice Dennis Edwards Jr. is to rule formally on an adjournment of the case until June 22.

title: MILK BUYERS TO GET A MILLION IN DAIRYLEA PRICE SETTLEMENT
description: Dairylea Cooperative Inc., one of the New York metropolitan area's largest milk distributors, has agreed to return $1 million to its customers over five years to settle price-fixing charges, Attorney General Robert Abrams announced yesterday.

title: Hard Times
description: Imagine in the area of a college baseball conference that includes such traditional powers as Southern California, Arizona and Arizona State, this headline: Gonzaga Wins Pac-10 Baseball Title. Or, Portland State Places 5 on Pac-10 All-Star Team.

title: Bonus for Golfers
description: The sponsors of the $160,000 McDonald's Classic, to be played June 4-7 at White Manor Country Club near Philadelphia, have announced a bonus arrangement which could add $100,000 to the winner's purse in the Ladies Professional Golfers Association event. Should the McDonald's winner also win the following week's L.P.G.A. Championship, the winner will be given the bonus. Because the L.P.G.A. first prize is worth $22,500, the same as the McDonald's event, the winner of both would collect $145,000 for two weeks of golf.

title: FROM 1932, A REMINDER ON A MISSISSIPPI MAIN STREET
description: At 6 A.M., the town looks more ghostly than usual. The business district, once a booming cotton-trading center, now a single block of tattered storefronts where old wooden awnings tilt like pictures imperfectly hung, is nearly deserted.

title: Watts, Jets' 8th Pick, Signs With Ottawa
description: J.C. Watts, an eighth-round draft selection of the New York Jets, signed a two-year contract today with the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 1, 1981
description: International The Government of Bangladesh said it had crushed a rebellion by army officers in the port city of Chittagong. The Government radio said that Maj. Gen. Manzur Ahmed, who was responsible for the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, had fled from the Chittagong district. The radio said the two-day rebellion by General Manzur and other officers had been ''vanquished completely.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Rocket fire in Beirut shattered a lazy day on a sunny beach, killing at least eight people and wounding about 60. While it was yet another of the many assaults the Lebanese capital has come to expect, it was perhaps the worst incident in a violent weekend in which 33 people were reported killed. The city is settling into a permanent state of anarchic war. (A1:4-5.)

title: France's Communist Dilemma
description: The U.S. is making appropriately friendly noises to the new Socialist Government of France. And they are reciprocated. But Washington has already begun warning that admission of any Communists to the Government after June legislative elections would inevitably cloud the relation.

title: Hanoi Calls U.S. Tie Welcome
description: Deputy Foreign Minister Vo Dong Giang says that Washington is welcome to open an embassy in Hanoi immediately despite the Reagan Administration's ''shameful'' attempts to deny Vietnam international development aid. The statement was made in an interview Friday. Technical difficulties held up transmission until today.

title: Dodgers 16, Reds 4
description: The Dodgers pummeled their closest contenders for first place in the Western Division with an 18-hit attack that dropped the Reds five and half games behind Los Angeles. The Dodgers spotted the Reds a 4-0 lead on a two-run double by Dave Concepcion, a run-producing single by Ray Knight and Mike O'Berry's first homer of the year.

title: 20 JERSEY CANDIDATES MEET IN FINAL FORUM
description: Twenty of the 21 candidates for Governor of New Jersey in Tuesday's primary election participated today in the final candidates' forum sponsored by the League of Women Voters.

title: Notes on People; Martha Mitchell Memorial Unveiled in Her Hometown
description: A life-size bronze bust of Martha Mitchell was unveiled yesterday in her hometown of Pine Bluff, Ark., on the fifth anniversary of her death. The committee for the memorial had collected $10,000, mostly in donations of a dollar or two.

title: REGULATORY UNCERTAINTIES PERMEATE CABLE MEETING
description: If any issue is intruding on the generally high spirits of the cable industry at its crowded annual convention here, it is the uncertainty over what regulatory role the Government will play in cable during the next several years.

title: NICARAGUA SEEKS UNITY AT HOME AND FRIENDS ABROAD
description: Faced with an acute economic crisis and a country increasingly divided along ideological lines, Nicaragua's Sandinist rulers have started a two-pronged offensive aimed at appeasing domestic critics and winning new friends abroad.

title: STADLER, WITH 68-270, WINS BY SIX STROKES
description: Craig Stadler, a 27-year-old Californian in his sixth year on the PGA Tour, ran away with the 14th Kemper open this afternoon, winning by six strokes. Because no one was able to challenge him, the final round was more a contest for second place.

title: Putting Around
description: Some days, as golf professionals discover almost every day, are not so good as others. Take the example of Dale Douglass in the second round of the Kemper open last week on the Congressional Country Club at Bethesda, Md.

title: Houston Ballet Ensemble To Leave for China June 14
description: (UPI) - Members of the Houston Ballet will go to China this month to perform as part of the cultural-exchange program between the United States and China, the troupe has announced.

title: 30,000 File Past Body Of Miss Soong in Peking
description: More than 30,000 mourners today filed past the body of Soong Ching-ling, widow of the revolutionary leader Sun Yat-sen, as it lay in state in Peking's Great Hall of the People.

title: Columbia Bidding For Outlet Co.
description: Columbia Pictures is negotiating to buy the Outlet Company, the television and radio broadcaster, industry sources disclosed Friday, describing the talks as ''preliminary.''

title: Notes on People; Kansas Gets a First Lady
description: Kansas has a new first lady following the weekend marriage of Gov. John Carlin and Karen Bigsby Hurley, a former member of his political staff.

title: CONFUSING RADIO-TV WARNINGS TERMED PERIL TO EVACUATION PLANS
description: Radio and television broadcasts of disaster warnings that are confusing to citizens threaten the effectiveness of nuclear evacuation plans, according to research presented at the convention of the American Association for Public Opinion Research here.

title: PAM SPENCER BREAKS HIGH-JUMP RECORD
description: Pam Spencer broke the women's American high jump record yesterday with a leap of 6 feet 5 1/4 inches at the Track and Field Association-USA national championships.

title: Washington Watch; U.S., Europe And Trade
description: WASHINGTON THE hot line between Washington and Brussels is pulsating with talk of trade warfare these days as the governments of the United States and the Common Market countries step up their campaigns to preserve jobs by expanding exports.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RED EYE SPECIAL

title: FRENCH CANADIANS DISAPPOINTED AS QUEBEC TAKES STRIKE IN STRIDE
description: In February, two television journalists from Montreal invaded the Toronto studios of the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, smeared Vaseline on the camera lenses and delayed the start of English-speaking Canada's most popular news program for 14 minutes.

title: Tottenville Girls Win P.S.A.L. Track Title
description: Tottenville of Staten Island ended the four-year domination of Brooklyn Tech when it won the team title yesterday at the Public Schools Athletic League girls outdoor track and field championships at John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx.

title: CORPORATE MARRIAGES ARE AT RECORD LEVELS
description: The announcements, properly heralded in conservative tombstone advertisements, tell of the constant marriages and divorces in corporate America: American businesses are changing partners, selling some divisions and buying others, at a dizzying pace.

title: REAGAN'S ACTS RENEW, WITH VIGOR, NATION'S DEBATE ABOUT FEDERALISM
description: One of the most serious debates this century about the condition and course of American Federalism is under way in Washington and in state capitals and city halls all around the United States.

title: MOVE TO GAIN WHITE READERS SEEN
description: The editor of The Rand Daily Mail, the opposition newspaper that has been most vehement in criticizing the Government from a liberal standpoint, was dismissed today in what appeared to be an effort to attract more white readers by lowering its political profile.

title: News Analysis
description: With reports that a Cabinet-level advisory committee has completed its charter for restructuring this country's immigration policy, the Reagan Administration has taken a critical and long-awaited first step toward resolving a problem that, after decades of inattention, is fast assuming the proportions of a national crisis.

title: Tsongas Says Levefer Prospects For Rights Post Are Deteriorating
description: Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, said today that there was little Administration support for Ernest W. Lefever as President Reagan's chief human rights adviser and that prospects for Mr. Lefever getting the job were deteriorating.

title: Drea Besch, a TV Producer, Is Married to Dave Herman
description: The marriage of Drea Besch of New York, a television and radio producer, to Dave Herman of New York, a disk jockey for WNEW-FM, took place in Newtown, Conn., yesterday.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 1, 1981; Industry
description: Sales are expected to exceed previous forecasts for television and other video equipment, according to industry executives attending the summer consumer electronics show in Chicago. But one analyst, noting that manufacturers already operate on thin margins, cautioned that sales do not always translate into profits. (Page D1.)

title: Miss Kessler Bride Of Robert Horowitz
description: Karen Joy Kessler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Kessler of Westfield and Deal, N.J., was married in Deal yesterday to Robert Stephen Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Horowitz of Toms River, N.J. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff performed the ceremony at the Kessler home.

title: U.S. SEEKS ANGOLA COMPROMISE AS PRICE FOR ACCORD ON NAMIBIA
description: Reagan Administration officials say they have decided on a strategy of tying final agreement on independence for South-West Africa to a withdrawal of Cuban forces from Angola and a commitment by the Marxist leaders in Angola to share power with Western-backed guerrillas. The officials say they believe that key black-ruled African countries will have no choice but to go along.

title: Linda Jeanne Ripps Is Married to Rabbi Avram Kogen
description: Linda Jeanne Ripps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman David Ripps of West Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Rabbi Avram Kogen, son of Rabbi and Mrs. David C. Kogen of New York. Rabbi Alan Silverstein officiated at Temple Agudath Israel in Caldwell, N.J., with Rabbi Kogen, the bridegroom's father, who is vice chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary in New York.

title: POLISH CHURCH AND STATE PAY TRIBUTE TO WYSZYNSKI
description: More than a quarter of a million mourners gathered in Victory Square today to attend a requiem mass for Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, an organist's son who became the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland and leader of the church here for nearly 33 years.

title: JOHN CAMPO: MASTERMIND OF TRIPLE
description: AFEW yards from the 155-year-old white pine in Belmont Park's paddock, John Campo gives last-minute riding instructions to Jorge Velasquez.

title: Marlow of U.S. Wins Turin Triple Jump
description: Mike Marlow of the United States won the triple jump, and Gerd Nagel of West Germany triumphed in the high jump at an international track and field meet today.

title: FOR WEST GERMAN'S GOVERNING COALITION, A TIME OF DISENCHANTMENT AND INSTABILITY
description: May was the month of resignations, both threatened and real, in West German politics. It was one of the most troubled and unstable periods for the Government since the coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats began running things here in 1969.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt OUTSIDE OVER THERE. By Maurice Sen- dak. Unpaginated. Harper & Row. $12.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of editing errors, an article Saturday on the National Endowment for the Arts incorrectly stated two items. A freeze on $32 million in the endowment's 1981 budget might affect the New York Philharmonic's free park concerts in the summer of 1982. Also, President Reagan is considering a proposal to cut the $32 million from the budget.

title: CANDIDATE CHALLENGES JERSEY PRIMARY COVERAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. GEORGINA GATES
description: Dr. Georgina Stickland Gates, a former psychology professor at Barnard College and the author of a book on cats and their relationship to humans, died Saturday at her home in Montrose, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Around the nation; U.M.W. Chief Tells Miners New Contract Offers Gains
description: Sam M. hurch Jr., president of the United Mine Workers, told Alabama miners today that the union had a lot to gain by ratifying the tentative contract that could end its strike, now in its 66th day.

title: Twins 5, Royals 4
description: The Twins ripped Dennis Leonard for four runs on five consecutive singles in the fifth inning to tag the Kansas City right-hander with his sixth loss against five victories. Hosken Powell drove in two of the runs, and Rick Sofield and Rob Wilfong knocked in the other two runs.

title: RATE DECLINE CLOSELY WATCHED
description: ''Peak fever'' has struck the credit markets again, and predictions that interest rates will continue the decline that began in early May are growing louder. Analysts explain that yields are higher than in January and that the outlook for inflation is much improved.

title: Brewers 5, Red Sox 2
description: The Brewers, who have won four of their last five games and 13 of their last 17, kept up their winning play. Jim Gantner hit the second pitch from Steve Crawford (0-4) for his first home run, and the Brewers never trailed.

title: Notes on People; Walter Kaisers Divorced
description: The former son-in-law of David Rockefeller, Walter J. Kaiser, will receive $529,760 under terms of his no-fault divorce from Neva Rockefeller Kaiser. The couple, married in 1966, were given joint custody of their two children, David, 11 years old, and Miranda, 9, by the decree granted Friday in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Volpini Paces United
description: Carlos Volpini scored three goals as New York United defeated the Rochester Flash Saturday night, 4-0, in United's home opener in an American Soccer League game at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: Amax Shareholder May Lead Challenge
description: George W. Schiele, a 49-year-old private investor and consultant who heads the newly formed Amax Shareholders Committee, was quite distressed when Amax Inc., the diversified natural resources producer, rejected a $4 billion takeover bid by the Standard Oil Company of California last March. Now, he and his associates on what he calls an informal committee intend to do something about it.

title: CURB URGED IN IMMUNITY GIVEN TO JURY WITNESSES
description: On a bright May afternoon in 1978, Delores Taylor was found strangled in her apartment in Far Rockaway, Queens. Ten months later, detectives believed they had solved the case with the arrest of Joseph Williams, a casual friend of Miss Taylor's who, authorities said, confessed to the crime.

title: TIGHTER SECURITY RULES FOR ADVANCES IN CRYPTOLOGY
description: The Japanese Navy was defeated in World War II largely because American code-breakers had deciphered Japanese intentions before the pivotal Battle of Midway. Cryptography played a key role several other times in that war.

title: CONFRONTING THE MORAL AND LEGAL ISSUE OF MARITAL RAPE
description: In Redding, Calif., last year, a 24-year-old man, choking and threatening his wife, forced her into sexual relations several times during the night as she stifled her cries to keep from waking their three children. In the early morning she broke away, ran to a neighbor's house and called he police.

title: NEED FOR LAWYERS IN CAPITAL CUT
description: Job prospects for lawyers who practice in Washington are dimming markedly as the Administration presses its assault against the proliferation of the Federal Government.

title: Iranian Says Secret Agency Isn't Like Savak Under Shah
description: A senior Iranian official said today that Iran has a new intelligence agency but that it is not like the Shah's hated Savak secret police since it is run along Islamic lines.

title: No Headline
description: PROUD PAPA: Prince Rainier III of Monaco stood to take a picture of his son, Prince Albert, at the Amherst College commencement in Amherst, Mass. The gradu-ate's sister, Princess Caroline, also recorded the event on film, while his mother, Princess Grace, beamed. Albert received a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science.

title: Melville Unit's President
description: The Melville Corporation has established for the first time a footwear manufacturing division and named Edward S. Fitzgibbons, 59, as its president. The division - which encompasses the J.F. McElwain Company, the Blue Ridge Shoe Company and Miller Shoes - has an annual volume of approximately $130 million.

title: Notes On people; Sister of Missing Hero of Holocaust Accepts an Award
description: Perennial gratitude sweetened painful memories at yesterday's ceremony in Temple Emanu-el awarding the $10,000 Roger Joseph Prize to Raoul Wallenberg, the missing Swedish hero of the Holocaust. Mr. Wallenberg is credited with saving 20,000 Hungarian Jews directly and many others indirectly.

title: Peking Leader to Visit Pakistan
description: The Chinese Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow for four days of talks with President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, officials said today. Mr. Zhao will be the first Chinese leader to visit Pakistan in 16 years.

title: GIUSEPPE PELLA, 79,AN ECONOMIST WHO WAS ITALY'S PREMIER IN 1953
description: Giuseppe Pella, a Christian Democratic legislator and economist who briefly served as Prime Minister of Italy as well as Foreign Minister, died today at Gemelli Hospital after a brief illness. He was 79 years old. ---- Son of a Sharecropper By JOSH BARBANEL

title: It's the Pitts
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers have had three and a half dozen players from the University of Pittsburgh on their rosters since the team was formed in 1933, so a couple more would not have lifted any eyes. But another half dozen have brought to attention just how talented the 1980 Panthers were.

title: Niagara U. to Get New President
description: The Very Rev. John Gerard Nugent will become the 21st president of Niagara University on Aug. 1, it was announced today. Father Nugent, who is 59 years old, is replacing the Very Rev. Gerard Mahoney, 48, who will become provincial superior of the Eastern Province for the Vincentian Fathers in Philadelphia.

title: News Analysis
description: A combination of politics, pique and opportunity led to the abrupt reversals last week of the positions of Governor Carey and the legislative leaders on how to aid public transportation.

title: VALENTINE WELCOMED AT SHEA
description: Ellis Valentine, the Mets' latest acquisition, arrived at Shea Stadium from Montreal yesterday afternoon as his new teammates were beating the Cubs, 3-2.

title: Kim Johnson, Art Director, Is Wed to David Earl Gross
description: Kim Christine Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Glenn D. Johnson of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Johnson, was married yesterday to David Earl Gross, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Gross of Shaker Heights, Ohio. Rabbi Harlan Weschler performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Etienne Boegner in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Market Place; Seven Areas Of Investment
description: WHEN a successful mutual fund restructures itself and sails against the prevailing investment winds, that's news. Pro Fund Inc., a $50 million mutual fund, has done it. Pro Fund has decided to concentrate on just seven areas of investment instead of continuing to look for promising stocks among the entire spectrum of issues.

title: Dr. Irving R. Hayman, 69, Headed Anethesiology at Jersey Hospital
description: Dr. Irving R. Hayman, who had been director of the Department of Anesthesiology at the Barnert Memorial Hospital Center in Paterson, N.J., died yesterday of cancer at the hospital. He was 69 years old and a resident of Ridgewood, N.J.

title: The Reading Recovery
description: For the second year in a row, second through ninth graders in New York City public schools have improved their reading scores. Better yet, the city passed an elusive milestone by raising 50.7 percent of its pupils to or above grade level.

title: FOUR BOYS KILLED IN BLAZE AT HOME OF JERSEY DOCTOR
description: Four young sons of a New Jersey osteopath were asphyxiated and the boys' parents suffered burns and other injuries early yesterday when a fire of undetermined origin swept through their two-story home in an affluent section of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: TELEX MURDER STUDY FOCUSES ON JAI ALAI
description: This article is based on reporting by William K. Stevens and Jeff Gerth and was written by Mr. Stevens. TULSA, Okla., May 31 - He had it from the start, the classic entrepreneur's drive that springs as much from the love of dealmaking as from the love of money. As a boy in Reading, Mass., he published a neighborhood newspaper, ran a vegetable stand and organized a stamp-collecting service.

title: Bell Blames City Boards For Education Problems
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell said in an interview published today that local school boards were ''mainly responsible'' for poor education and that busing to achieve desegregation was a mistake.

title: Ex-Oiler Ashby Dies
description: Don Ashby, who played center for the Edmonton Oilers at the start of the 1980-81 National Hockey League season, died yesterday in a hospital here from injuries suffered in a traffic accident near this Okanagan Valley community. A spokesman for the police said Ashby's car was in a head-on collision with a pick-up truck earlier yesterday. Ashby's wife, Terry, a passenger in the car, was reported in good condition.

title: PHILARMONIC: ROMANTICS WITH GALAWAY AS SOLOIST
description: THE second program of the New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' series Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall - to be repeated tonight - balanced two sides of the Romantic sensibility, the earnestly important and the gracefully unimportant. It was an honorable, interesting program, honestly conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi. But it fell short of significance, given the lack of really important lesser-known music and really convincing interpretations of the known music.

title: Notes on people; Busy Weekend for Zubin Mehta and Son at Colgate
description: It was Christmas in May, as well as commencement weekend for Zubin Mehta and his son, Merwan, at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y. With 14 members of the Mehta family in town for the event, the conductor received an honorary Doctor of Fine Arts degree yesterday at outdoor ceremonies beside Taylor Lake on the Colgate campus.

title: JERUSALEM ISSUE AGAIN COMES UP AS A SADAT-BEGIN MEETING NEARS
description: With only four days remaining before the meeting of Egyptian and Israeli leaders in Sinai, the touchy issue of Jerusalem has again clouded relations between the two countries.

title: The City; Hearings Set for Men Linked to F.A.L.N.
description: Hearings have been set for June 9 in Chicago for two men suspected of being members of a terrorist Puerto Rican group, Fuerzas Armadas de Liberacion Nacional, known as F.A.L.N.

title: Getting Started
description: Nearby rivers popular with whitewater canoers, for competition or recreation, include: Farmington River, Tariffville, Conn.; Bantam River, Bantam, Conn.; Housatonic River, Cornwall Bridge, Conn.; Miller's River, Miller's Falls, Mass.; Esopus River, Phoenicia, N.Y.; Caroga Creek, Ephratah, N.Y.; Schroon River, Chestertown, N.Y.; Brandywine River, Wilmington, Del.; Savage River, Luke, Md.

title: Freedom Fella First
description: Freedom Fella scored a narrow victory last night in the $54,000 Big Apple pace at Yonkers Raceway.

title: DANCE: DEBUTS IN BALLET THEATER'S 'LA SONNAMBULA'
description: THE American Ballet Theater production of George Balanchine's ''La Sonnambula'' has a very different look from that of the New York City Ballet. Closer to the high theatrics of opera than City Ballet's coolly surrealistic nightmare of a ballet, this ''Sonnambula,'' staged for the company by John Taras, is tremendous fun. And one of the best things about its performance last Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House was Victor Barbee's debut in the role of the Poet, who strides into the midst of a party at a mysterious manor and dies by its end.

title: MUCK'S MONUMENT TO FREEDOM
description: How could anyone have objected to the Minnesota law that the Supreme Court struck down 50 years ago today? It said obscene, lewd, lascivious, malicious, scandalous or defamatory newspapers and magazines were a public nuisance ''and all persons guilty of such nuisance may be enjoined'' from printing or selling them. Who but a liar or rascal could object when the law so generously exempted anyone who printed the truth with ''good motives and for justifiable ends?''

title: FLAWED HUMAN RIGHTS APPROACH
description: To the Editor:

title: Pitt May Have Edge in Gathering Quality Football Recruits
description: NOW that the 1981 college football recruiting season has ended and the incoming freshmen are signed, it is generally conceded that Notre Dame, under its new head coach, Gerry Faust, had about the best results. Michigan attracted several well-regarded high school stars, and Pittsburgh seems to have done almost as well as Notre Dame and Michigan and possibly a bit better than its rival, Penn State.

title: A'S BEAT BLUE JAYS, REGAIN FIRST PLACE
description: After having suffered 10 straight losses on the road and four straight defeats over all, the Oakland A's finally regained the form that had sent them to the top of the American League Western Division race early in the season.

title: Mariners 5, Rangers 3
description: Seattle's Dan Meyer made four hits and Joe Simpson drove in three runs with three hits, including his first home run of the season.

title: Padres 5, Braves 1
description: Luis Salazar, a 25-year-old rookie third baseman from Venezuela, lashed four straight hits, lifting his batting average 17 points to .299.

title: 800,PUTTING BEST FOOT FORWARD, ATTEND A GALA AGAINST METRICS
description: The fairy lights in the rafters of the Battery Marine Terminal were about a foot apart, and under them danced a melange of people in everything from black tie to torn T-shirt. The band pounded away at old numbers like ''When I Grow Too Old to Dream.'' Outside, in the Saturday night quiet of South Ferry, limousines purred on the deserted streets.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a doubles match, a tennis player returns a ball at such an extreme angle that, even though the ball lands fair, his opponent has to go outside the court boundary to reach it. His return, because of the angle, does not pass over the net, but also lands fair. Is the return legal?

title: Marlene Caron Brown Bride Of Edward Bennett Schimmel
description: At Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood, Pa., yesterday, Marlene Caron Brown, a social worker at the Delco Child Day Care Association in Darby, Pa., was married to Edward Bennett Schimmel, an executive news producer at WPVI-TV of Philadelphia.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Managerial Decision

title: STAGE: PANTHER GLASS MEETS RILKE IN 'THE PANTHER'
description: ''THE PANTHER'' is an amalgam of a score by Philip Glass and a play by Manuel Lutgenhorst, who is also responsible for the evening's design and direction. This ''madrigal opera'' was first presented last month at the Houston Grand Opera and is now in a limited engagement at La Mama Annex. As a theatrical event, it is marginal, an experimental exercise in disparate artistic currents.

title: Public Critical of Formula Vote
description: State Department officials said today that the United States vote opposing the World Health Organization code on infant formulas had drawn an unusually large amount of mail, 90 percent of it critical of the Administration's policy.

title: THE MOVEABLE TROUBLES OF THE PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: AN IRWIN SHAW PACKAGE ON CHANNEL 13
description: ''THE Girls in Their Summer Dresses,'' on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 8, is one of those teasing productions that you keep hoping will get better. It does, to a degree, but not enough to merit lusty cheers.

title: Around the Nation; Transit Authority in Illinois Takes Over Railroad Line
description: With three suburban transit systems already idled by a lack of money, the Regional Transportation Authority today took over a commuter railroad in efforts to keep Chicago-area transit operating this week.

title: Norstan Industries Goes To Posey, Pary & Quest
description: Posey, Pary & Quest of Greenwich, Conn., is now the agency for Norstan Industries, which makes apparel under the Time & Place, Marc Steven, Time & TimeAgain and Half-Time labels.

title: KINGMAN HELPS METS WIN, 3-2
description: Dave Kingman hit his 11th home run of the season, and Randy Jones earned his first victory with the help of relief pitching by Pete Falcone. The result was a 3-2 victory by the Mets over the Chicago Cubs yesterday at Shea Stadium before 17,524 fans.

title: De La Rose Wins by 6 1/2 Lengths on Grass
description: Henry deKwiatkowski's De La Rose, the 3-year-old filly who cost $500,000 as a yearling, continued to thrive on the grass yesterday by winning the $59,000 Saranac at Belmont Park.

title: Quake Jolts Western Greece
description: A strong earth tremor shook western Greece early today, the Athens Seismological Institute said. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

title: ELIZABETH DANIELS WED TO J.P. SOREFF
description: Elizabeth Miriam Daniels, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Farrington Daniels of Pelham, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Paul Soreff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Soreff of Freeport, L.I. The Rev. James Wentz, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Mount Vernon, N.Y. The church, which dates from before the American Revolution and is on the National Register of Historic Places, is maintained by the National Park Service.

title: MAY POUNDED AS YANKS LOSE, 7-2
description: Rudy May pitched his seventh consecutive game without a victory today as his slump continued in a 7-2 loss to the Indians.

title: Bridge: Martin and Company Beat Wei Team in the Reisinger
description: The most exciting final in more than half a century of Reisinger knockout team play ended Saturday night in victory for a foursome led by Phillip Martin of New York. Martin and his teammates - John Lowenthal of New York, Chuck Lamprey of White Plains and Kit Woolsey of Arlington, Va. - won by two international match points against Kathie Wei, Ron Andersen, Mike Becker, Ron Rubin and David Berkowitz, all of New York, and Harold Lilie of Woodmere, L.I.

title: NEW RISKS FOR GERMAN BUILDERS
description: The Hochtief construction company has built a bridge over the Bosporus to link Europe and Asia and an airport at Jidda, Saudi Arabia, and has moved the tombs of the Pharaohs at Abu Simbel when the waters behind Egypt's Aswan Dam threatened to destroy them.

title: Sadik, Director, Quits National Portrait Gallery
description: The resignation of Marvin Sadik as director of the Smithsonian's National Portrait Gallery, effective July 1, has been accepted ''with great regret'' by S. Dillon Ripley, the Smithsonian's secretary.

title: Cycling to Torelli
description: Claudio Torelli of Italy edged out a pack of 16 other cyclists today to win the 16th stage of the Tour of Italy. A fellow Italian, Silvano Contini, retained the overall leadership. Torelli completed the 173 kilometer run from Milan to Mantua over the flat Po River valley of northern Italy in 4 hours 46 minutes 35 seconds for an average speed of 37.227 k.p.h. The 17th stage begins tomorrow.

title: Mavericks Unlikely To Trade No. 1 Pick
description: Norm Sonju, general manager of the Mavericks, said today that his team has had talks with several other clubs regarding Dallas's No. 1 selection in the National Basketball Association's June 9 college draft but that a trade was unlikely.

title: JOHN PAUL EULOGIZES WYSZYNSKI AS 'KEYSTONE OF UNITY'
description: Pope John Paul II, his voice sounding fatigued, today praised his mentor, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, as ''the keystone of the unity of the church in Poland'' in a tape-recorded message played to thousands of pilgrims at St. Peter's Square.

title: No Headline
description: Red Smith Truculent Weekend

title: PSYCHIATRISTS AND INVESTIGATOR ARE COMPILING DETAILED STUDY OF HINCKLEY'S LIFE
description: Government investigators are compiling a life history of John W. Hinckley Jr., not only to prove that he shot President Reagan but also to answer questions they consider likely to be asked in the future by historians and skeptics.

title: CITY PARK CONCESSIONS FACING REVIEW
description: Concerned that the process of turning over park facilities to private operators may have gone too far, the city's Parks Commissioner, Gordon J. Davis, yesterday announced the formation of a special four-man panel to study the situation.

title: LEFEVER DESERVES TO BE CONFIRMED
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHUB WINS CLIBURN PIANO COMPETITION
description: Andre-Michel Schub, the 28-year-old pianist from New York, has won the Sixth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. With his victory goes a cash award of $12,000, a recording contract and two years of important solo and concerto appearances in the United States, Europe and the Far East. It will be a springboard to international fame for Mr. Schub, already a wellknown artist in his own right. The jury made its decision about the six finalists this morning shortly before

title: The Region; Indian Pt. 2 Resumes Production Again
description: Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was producing electricity at partial capacity after an interruption in its effort to regain full capacity following a seven-month shutdown.

title: BANGLADESH ASSERTS OFFICERS' REBELLION IN PORT CITY IS OVER
description: The Bangladesh Government said this morning that it had regained control of the southeastern port city of Chittagong, crushing a rebellion by rebel army officers there.

title: The U.N. Today; June 1, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: High-Level Committee on the Review of Technical Cooperation Among Developing Countries - 10:30 A.M.

title: Voice: Rumania's Cleopatra Melidoneanu
description: CLEOPATRA MELIDONEANU, prima donna of the Bucharest Operetta, brought a touch of Rumania to 57th Street early Saturday evening with a Carnegie Recital Hall program of Enesco, Popovici, Constantinescu, Dragoi, Tanasescu, Alessandrescu, Dendrino and nine ''Doina'' folk songs.

title: Ellen S. Dickstein Is Bride of William Kominers, Lawyer
description: Ellen Simeon Dickstein, who received a law degree last week from the Georgetown University Law Center, was married yesterday to William Kominers, a lawyer with Linowes & Blocher of Silver Spring, Md., and Washington. Rabbi Roger Herst performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Washington.

title: Peggy Stuart Coolidge, Composer and Pianist
description: Peggy Stuart Coolidge, composer, pianist and conductor who was a soloist with the Boston Symphony Orchestra, died of cancer at her home in Cushing, Me., on May 7. She was 67 years old.

title: The Washington Star
description: The Federal loan program for disaster victims, burdened by violations and defaults, is itself in need of a major rescue effort, according to Government auditors.

title: Views of Religious Right Are Assailed by Carter
description: Former President Jimmy Carter has told a group of Baptist writers and editors that the measuring rod for Christianity of the so-called ''religious right'' is a ''distortion'' and will not long prevail.

title: Expos 5, Pirates 1
description: The Expos remained within half a game of Philadelphia, the Eastern Division leader, as Andre Dawson cracked his 12th home run and Gary Carter delivered three hits, including a two-run single. Steve Rogers (6-1) allowed only six hits, the most damaging of which was the second homer of the season by Bill Madlock.

title: Cockfight in Vermont Is Raided
description: The state police raided a cockfight, seizing 73 fighting roosters and arresting about 30 persons from five states, the authorities said today.

title: Algeria Foreign Minister Suffers Injuries in a Plane Crash in Mali
description: Foreign Minister Mohammed Ben Yahia of Algeria, a key figure in winning the release by Iran of the 52 United States hostages, suffered multiple fractures in a plane crash near here today.

title: Mears Plans Surgery On His Facial Burns
description: Rick Mears, who suffered firstand second-degree facial burns in the Indianapolis 500 last Sunday, will undergo surgery tomorrow at the Sherman Oaks (Calif.)

title: PIANIST: CAROLINE STOESSINGER
description: In all of the music Caroline Stoessinger played during her piano recital at the 92d Street Y on Saturday night there was the same curious sensation. The dynamics were all within a mezzo-piano range, the rhythms were all moderately declaimed, the contrasts all muted, and the music emerged with a gentle rolling motion, a lulling rocking, like the sound of waves on a shore.

title: Miss Rinaldi Gains French Quarterfinal
description: Kathy Rinaldi, the 14-year-old from Florida, staged another upset today and reached the quarterfinals of the $600,000 French open tennis championships.

title: Former Foundation Chief Joins Sports Sponsors
description: Edgar A. Roll, who has been a consultant since leaving the president's chair at the Advertising Research Foundation, has become a principal and vice president of the International Society of Sports Sponsors, which is what it sounds like it is: an organization for companies either involved in promoting through sports or in sports themselves. It is just starting, but the society already has a seminar scheduled for June 16 and 17 at the Sheraton Center.

title: Norman, on 67-273, Takes British Golf
description: Greg Norman of Australia shot a five-under-par 67 today to win the $150,000 British Masters.

title: CAREY SUGGESTS A PLAN FOR 74 NEW JUDGESHIPS TO EASE CASE BACKLOG
description: Governor Carey today proposed creating 74 judgeships at a yearly cost of $4.7 million to cut into the criminal and civil caseloads that have built up in the state.

title: MIAMI HOMICIDE RATE 5 TIMES ABOVE USUAL AMONG CUBAN EXILES
description: Cubans who fled to Florida in last year's boatlift are ending up the victims of homicides at a rate five times higher than the general population, the authorities report.

title: CAMPUS DATING: WHAT GOING COED HAS DONE
description: The dating game at Princeton, Williams and Vassar as the school year draws to a close seldom includes romantic displays in public, long commitments between the sexes or indiscriminate sleeping around. The public style of students at the three campuses is friendly and cool, affectionate yet detached: a hand-holding pair is almost never seen.

title: THE REGION
description: A 22-year-old White Plains man was fatally injured when he tried to jump aboard a Harlem line commuter train as it pulled away from the the Mount Kisco station, the police said.

title: P.L.O. Official Is Slain in Brussels
description: A high-ranking representative for the Palestine Liberation Organization, Naim Khader, was killed on his way to work today by a gunman who fired six bullets into him at close range. One police officer called it ''the job of a professional.''

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
A LAWYER AND AN EDUCATION AIDE
description: Theodore Fred Kuper, a lawyer and a Jefferson scholar who as law secretary of the New York City Board of Education battled Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia to keep the board's independence, died Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital in Whittier, Calif. He was 95 years old and lived in Whittier.

title: NEW YORK'S ADVICE ON RUNNING A CITY VALUED IN POLAND
description: Poland has asked for advice from New York City, a town renowned for many things but not necessarily for the quality of its municipal services.
