title: TEAMSTERS OPEN CONVENTION WITH REAGAN MESSAGE
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters opened its 22d convention today with Roy L. Williams, the union's interim president, vigorously defending himself against Federal criminal charges, and President Reagan, in a filmed address, warmly praising the union and saying he hoped to work with it in meeting the nation's economic problems.

title: LONG DELAYED U.N. PARLEY ON CAMBODIA SET FOR JULY
description: Fresh efforts to press for a withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia are about to be made at the United Nations, Asian diplomats said today.

title: Hempstead Girl Dies After Bath Scalding
description: A 4-year-old girl died after her mother, reportedly annoyed with her for not eating, put the child into a bathtub filled with scalding water, according to the police.

title: Brady Reported 'Alert' And in 'Good Spirits'
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, is ''alert and in good spirits'' and showing signs of continued recovery from an attack of pneumonia, his doctors reported today.

title: 40 YEARS AFTER FIRINGS
description: ''They seated him in such a way that, as the light entered the window, it struck him in the eyes with a kind of glare, so that he was very uncomfortable and had constantly to shift his position. He said that of these two (questioners) one sat at a desk and stared intently at him while the other walked back and forth behind his back.''

title: CABLE TV PRESSES HUNT FOR SHOWS TO FILL AIR TIME
description: The cable-television convention ended here yesterday, but Robert J. Wussler stayed on today for a series of meetings. He scheduled nine in all, and eight were with people eager to pitch him ideas for cable programs.

title: 21 ARE ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGE IN SEVERAL RAIDS
description: Leaders of what law-enforcement officials called a major heroin ring operating out of an apartment on Manhattan's Upper East Side were held in bail as high as $1 million yesterday after a series of raids involving more than 60 Federal agents.

title: TERROR ROMANTICIZED BY IRISH-AMERICANS
description: To the Editor:

title: 8% India Output Rise Seen
description: India's industrial growth is likely to rise 8 percent in the period from April 1981 to March 1982, according to the nation's Ministry of Industry. Growth was 3.6 percent last year. The Industry Minister, Charanjit Chana, told reporters that companies making transport equipment, machinery, chemicals, metals and electrical equipment are likely to achieve a production increase of as much as 15 percent in that period.

title: I.B.M., GOVERNMENT REST IN ANTITRUST SUIT
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department rested their cases yesterday in the six-year-old trial and 12-year-old antitrust suit brought against I.B.M. by the department.

title: PHILIP D. BLOCK JR. OF INLAND STEEL
description: Philip D. Block Jr., the chairman and chief executive officer of the Inland Steel Company from 1967 to 1971, died Thursday at his home in Chicago. He was 74 years old.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
CANAVERAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $25,246 for the qr and $56,482 for the 6 mos

title: 2 EX-SOLICITORS GENERAL OPPOSE BILL TO CURB ABORTIONS
description: Two former Solicitors General, Archibald Cox and Robert H. Bork, told a Senate panel today that proposed legislation seeking to make abortion illegal was unconstitutional, a view met by strong disagreement from some other legal experts.

title: TV: BARBARA WALTERS AND 'WOMEN OF THE YEAR'
description: Just when she might be expecting to run out of superstars for her popular series of prime-time interview specials, Barbara Walters comes up with another dazzling combination of guests. Tonight's edition of ''The Barbara Walters Special'' on ABC-TV has Katharine Hepburn, Lauren Bacall and Nancy Reagan, in that running order. The theme, of course, is ''Woman of the Year.'' Miss Hepburn starred in the film. Miss Bacall is playing in the Broadway musical. Mrs. Reagan has the reality.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
U.S. FUEL OFFICIAL TO JOIN TENNECO
description: Robert T. Blakely, an investment banker who was picked as the first vice president for finance of the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation last January, resigned Friday to become chief financial officer of Tenneco Inc. He will assume his post at the diversified Houston company, 80 percent of whose operating income is derived from energy, in mid-July.

title: AN ECONOMIC MAELSTROM AROUND MRS. THATCHER
description: Powerful political winds are buffeting Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, and no early improvement in the weather seems likely unless she changes her economic policies in ways that she has sworn never to do.

title: Q & A
description: Q. What is the danger in insect stings?

title: WOMAN IS STABBED TO DEATH IN HER FLUSHING APARTMENT
description: A 19-year-old Queens woman was stabbed to death early yesterday in her apartment, apparently by a burglar who smashed through a bedroom window that was accessible from an adjoining garage roof.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NEW THEORIES OF DEPRESSION HOLD PROMISE OF SIMPLER REMEDY
description: As a graduate student experimenting with animals, Martin E.P. Seligman, now professor of psychology at the University of Pennsylvania, unexpectedly came upon a phenomenon he later called ''learned helplessness.'' The concept he developed ultimately suggested that human depression grows out of the destructive ways that people learn to view their experiences.

title: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times; Her Caddie Is Her Husband
description: EARLY a year ago, Donna Caponi decided to skip the Lady Keystone open in Hershey, Pa., which left her cheerful caddie, Dana Derouaux, without a bag to carry that week. So he asked Cathy Reynolds if he could work for her.

title: IOWA BEEF REVOLUTIONIZED MEAT-PACKING INDUSTRY
description: In laying out some $800 million in stock to purchase Iowa Beef Processors, Occidental Petroleum is acquiring a company that did for the American meat-packing industry what Henry Ford did for automobile assembly.

title: THE TECHNOLOGY GAP
description: In the 1960's, Europeans and Japanese expressed alarm over the widening technology gap between the United States and other industrial countries. Today, in many industries our technological leadership has vanished. Why? Is it the fault of our scientists, our Government, our schools -or our managers?

title: Birmingham Buses Roll, But New Cuts Are Possible
description: Some city buses rolled again today after being parked for three months because of a budget crisis. ''Medium to light loads'' were reported by Frank Martin, general manager of the Birmingham-Jefferson County Transit Authority.

title: Regan May Not Go to Europe
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan may cancel his scheduled Friday appearance in Switzerland for a meeting of the International Monetary Conference, a Treasury Department spokesman said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canadian National Railway Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $150 million of sinking fund debentures due in 2006, to be sold through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: FED'S GENERAL COUNSEL EXPECTS DRAMATIC ERA
description: Michael Bradfield, a former assistant general counsel for international affairs at the Treasury Department and for the last three years an adjunct professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced Study, has been appointed general counsel of the Federal Reserve Board. He succeeds Neal L. Petersen, who is joining the Washington office of the Los Angeles law firm of Manatt, Phelps, Rothenberg & Tunney.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of the economist Barbara Ward yesterday incorrectly identified the founders of the International Institute for Environment and Development. It was founded in 1971 by Robert O. Anderson, chairman of the Atlantic Richfield Company, and Joseph E. Slater, president of the Aspen Institute.

title: LESSONS ON THE ARTS: DANCE, DANCE, DANCE
description: ''Have no fear,'' Mayor Edward Koch announced to the crowd attending the National Dance Institute's annual benefit performance last night at the Felt Forum. ''It is next year that I dance.''

title: Cities Service Sues Canadian Interests
description: The Cities Service Company said today that it had begun legal action to block purchases of its stock by Canadian interests that it says are trying to ''strong-arm'' United States companies into selling Canadian oil and gas holdings.

title: Transit Rebellion
description: About 100 passengers refused to leave a subway train bound from Queens to Manhattan yesterday morning, preventing the crew from taking the train out of service, Transit Authority police said. The crew decided to take the train out of service after discovering a broken window pane in one car, a spokesman said. After a conductor and motorman argued with the passengers for about 15 minutes, the train finally finished its run to Times Square, skipping its last stops.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES JUDICIAL CANDIDATES BILL
description: The Assembly approved a bill today that would allow candidates for judgeships in New York State to speak out on political issues. The debate that preceded the 94-to-49 vote crisscrossed party lines and was one of the most passionate exchanges of this year's listless legislative session.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
description: B-After $390,000 net loss from operation subject to disposition and $1.9 million pretax gain from the sale of shrs of Pay Less Stores; sales for the latest first qr include results of Sav-On Inc, which was acquired last November

title: BRONCOS' DRUG USE DESCRIBED AS SOCIAL
description: Drug use by three Denver Bronco players who are the focus of a cocaine-marijuana investigation was strictly social, and they had no ties with organized crime, according to a man identified as the their drug supplier.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard COCKTAILS AT SOMOZA'S, a reporter's sketch book of events in revolutionary Nicaragua. By Richard Elman. 195 pages. Apple-wood Books. $10.95 NICARAGUA. June 1978-July 1979 by Susan Meiselas. Edited with Claire Rosen- berg. Illustrated. Unpaginated. Pan- theon. Hardcover, $22.95; paper $11.95.

title: MUSIC: 20TH ANNIVERSARY OF YOUNG CONCERT ARTISTS
description: IN every center of musical importance there are groups that somehow become central to the city's artistic life, while other organizations - some of them better publicized and heavier of pocket - are satisfied to grow fat and smug as cultural ''institutions.'' Young Concert Artists, which celebrated its 20th anniversary season last night with a gala concert at Alice Tully Hall, is of the former type. The group, under its director, Susan Wadsworth, has made a remarkable reputation for itself since 1961, when she had the quixotic idea of establishing a nonprofit management organization to help youthful musicians gain a foothold in the battlements of the concert world.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Fills Executive Gaps
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising did not waste much time filling the executive gaps caused by the recent promotions of Abbott C. Jones and Norman Brown in the New York and Chicago offices.

title: HAYDEN N. SMITH, 78, A LAWYER SPECIALIZING IN UTILITY COMPANIES
description: Hayden N. Smith, a New York lawyer who was a deputy assistant chief of staff of the United States armed forces in Europe during World War II, died Sunday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 78 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: J.P. Stevens Closings
description: J.P. Stevens & Company said that it will close two South Carolina textile plants, in Jonesville and Great Falls, sometime this year, idling 425 workers.

title: Newmont Stake
description: Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd. and its wholly owne United States subsidiary, Amcon Group Inc., held some 2.1 million shares, or 8.1 percent, of Newmont Mining Corporation at the close of business May 29, a Consolidated Gold Fields statement said. In late April, Consolidated said that it had acquired about a 7 percent stake in Newmont and would seek more shares. A Consolidated spokesman added that the company still intended to acquire at least 25 percent of Newmont, but less than 50 percent, if shares were available at appropriate prices.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 2, 1981; The Economy
description: No more compromises will be made on the tax program, President Reagan vowed in a meeting with the Democratic Congressional leadership, after agreeing to reduce the size of the first year's cut to 5 percent, rather than the 10 percent sought, and to delay the starting date from Jan. 1 to Oct. 1 of this year. The meeting split the Democrats on whether to continue negotiations or prepare for an all-out fight. (Page A1.)

title: Owners and Players Talk, but to No Avail
description: Two days before they are scheduled to appear in United States District Court in Rochester, N.Y., labor representatives of baseball's club owners and players spent more than three hours at the Doral Inn yesterday and emerged with the familiar refrain: no progress.

title: 3 Writers' Groups Support Coast Strike
description: The Dramatists Guild, the Authors Guild and the Authors League of America, with a combined membership of 10,000 writers, yesterday publicly affirmed their support of the strike by the Writers Guild of America against motion-picture and television producers. The two guilds and the league recommended that their members and all authors support the strike and ''not render services as film or television writers to struck companies.''

title: 11 SCHOOL PRINCIPALS ACCUSED OF VIOLATING IMMUNIZATION STATUTE
description: The principals of 11 public, private and parochial schools were summoned yesterday before the New York City Health Department's administrative tribunal because, the department says, they permitted students to be in school without proof of immunization.

title: A BILL REQUIRING BOTTLE DEPOSIT IS LIKELY TO DIE
description: Governor Carey tonight renewed his opposition to a bill that would require deposits on all beer and soda containers sold in New York State, apparently killing the measure for this session of the Legislature.

title: MEDAL IS DENIED TO ONE HOSTAGE HELD BY IRANIANS
description: The Army has denied Staff Sgt. Joseph Subic Jr. a medal for his performance while he was held hostage for more than a year in Iran, saying today that he ''did not behave under stress the way noncommissioned officers are expected to act.''

title: THE ALLURE OF HUDSON'S BAY
description: In 1869 the Hudson's Bay Company, founded in England in 1670 as a fur trading concern based in Canada, was granted by Queen Victoria one-twentieth of all lands surveyed for 50 years in the area north of the United States, east of the Rockies and west of Lake Winnipeg.

title: REFINERS SHUN COSTLY CRUDE OIL
description: Oil companies have begun pressing petroleum producing countries to reduce prices substantially, with some companies refusing to accept oil they consider too high-priced, petroleum industry analysts and oil traders said yesterday. Such pressures have already provoked price reductions or elimination of special surcharges by Kuwait, Iraq and Egypt.

title: DEMOCRATS ASK 'TARGETED' CUTS
description: When the Speaker of the House, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., emerged from a White House meeting today with President Reagan he denounced the President's tax proposals as ''a windfall for the rich'' and said the Democrats were concerned with ''the working class.''

title: DEVELOPING AN IDENTITY AT MCCANN
description: AFTER about a month on the job as general manager of the New York office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, James D. Kuras has decided that, because it shares 485 Lexington Avenue with corporate headquarters, it has an identity crisis.

title: Dr. Herman A. Brusson, A Chemist and Inventor
description: Dr. Herman A. Brusson, a former vice president of the Olin Corporation of Connecticut who had 400 patents credited to his name, died Sunday in New Haven Hospital. He was a resident of Woodbridge, Conn., and was 79 years old.

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Caribbean Airline Sold
description: Dorado Wings, a regional airline with service in the Caribbean, has been sold for an undisclosed price, the new owner has announced. Nicholas Apostol of Wilton, Conn., president of Crownair System Inc., a Puerto Rican corporation, said that he had purchased the airline from Henry G. Wolf, who founded it in 1963. The airline, with 17 planes, operates a scheduled service linking Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands and the British Virgin Islands.

title: 4th Chicago Bus Line Closes Because of Money Shortage
description: A fourth bus line of the Chicago area's financially troubled mass transit system closed today because it ran out of fuel money.

title: RAPID AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Net loss after $1,087,000 tax credit

title: HARTFIELD-ZODY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
ADDICTION NEEDS MORE, NOT LESS, ATTENTION
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS BEAT INDIANS
description: Doug Bird, pressed into service as a starter, won his eleventh consecutive game when the Yankees beat the Indians, 5-3, tonight to end a week-long road trip with a 3-4 record after three straight losses in Baltimore.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: People
description: * E. Wyatte Hicks and Robert G. Minicus, executive vice presidents of Creamer Inc./New York, have been elected to the board of Creamer Inc.

title: Pet Agrees to Sell Musselman Unit
description: IC Industries Inc. said that its Pet Inc. subsidiary had agreed to sell its Musselman fruit products unit for about $35 million to MFP Enterprises Inc., a company owned by Mark T. Concannon.

title: SHORT PANTS HIT THEIR STRIDE
description: The early hot weather has nourished a new fashion crop: short pants. Not running shorts or tennis shorts. Some call them walking shorts or, more accurately, working shorts.

title: COUNCILMAN URGES USING SOME SURPLUS ON SUBWAY
description: The chairman of the City Council Finance Committee proposed yesterday that New York City spend $200 million of its anticipated 1981 budget surplus to refurbish subway stations and rebuild sewers and highways.

title: BANGLADESH OFFICER WHO LED REBELLION IS SAID TO BE KILLED
description: A report on Bangladesh radio said this morning that Maj. Gen. Manzur Ahmed, who led the unsuccessful 48-hour rebellion against the Government, had been killed.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS BAN ON LIVE ENTERTAINMENT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that communities that permit commercial activity may not use their zoning powers to exclude live entertainment.

title: 125 Workers at a Louisiana Plant Treated for Inhaling Chlorine Gas
description: About 125 construction workers required hospital treatment after poisonous chlorine gas leaked at the BASF Wyandotte Corporation plant here today, medical officials said.

title: '82 N.B.A. Final In Live TV Slot
description: CBS-TV, which has the national contract to televise National Basketball Association games, announced that it would carry next year's championship series live and during prime time.

title: Prosecutor in 3-Hour Summation In Bribery Case Against Blanton
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton took a $23,000 bribe to help a political contributor get a lucrative liquor store license in an exclusive area, a Federal prosecutor charged today.

title: STABILIZED RENTS IN NEW YORK CITY MAY GO UP 11%
description: Findings that could lead to large rent increases for tenants in 300,000 New York City apartments were announced yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which said the cost of operating a rentstabilized building rose by 13.1 percent between April 1980 and last April.

title: Smith Says His Testimony Focuses on King, W.B.A.
description: Harold Smith, under subpoena, will testify here tomorrow before the Federal grand jury investigating boxing. His testimony, he said, would mostly concern Don King and the World Boxing Association.

title: ISRAEL ACCUSES SYRIA OF ENLARGING FORCE IN LEBANON
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Syria recently moved additional troops into Lebanon and the Lebanese-Syrian border region.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY MOBILE HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change

title: Addenda
description: * Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, and the Campagnani, Aleman y Quelquejeu Agency in Panama City, have announced a working agreement.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Topics; URBAN IMAGES; The Killer Game
description: Anyone ever humiliated at a chessboard will be delighted with the story of the Black Bishops, a group of black teen-agers in Philadelphia. They recently won their fifth national junior high school chess championship; successive members have captured seven city titles and six state titles.

title: Gerber's Net Up by 18.5%
description: Gerber Products, the world's largest producer of baby foods, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter ended March 31 rose 18.5 percent, to $10.9 million, or $1.22 a share, from $9.2 million, or $1.04 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales slipped two-tenths of 1 percent, to $172.4 million, from $172.8 million.

title: 'Incurable' TB Patient Barred From Going Home
description: Louis Semerano, a tuberculosis patient whose drug-resistant illness has defied months of treatment at a Denver hospital, was barred today from returning to his home in Ohio.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
SOVIET SAID TO SHIP MANAGUA ARMS
description: American intelligence sources continue to report the imminent, or at least expected, arrival of major Soviet military equipment in Nicaragua, including heavy tanks, a high State Department official said tonight.

title: PONDEROSA SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 21
Argentina Devalues Peso
description: The two-month-old military Government of President Roberto E. Viola has decided to devalue the peso by 30 percent, the official press agency, Telam, reported today. It would be the third major devaluation this year and would make the United States dollar twice as valuable here as it was on Jan. 1.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $788,000 charge from an accounting adjustment

title: Article 140462 -- No Title
description: Pimlico officials had an idea the man meant business when he asked that a security guard accompany him to the window.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 2, 1981
description: International The end of a revolt in Bangladesh was confirmed 48 hours after the attempted coup had begun. Maj. Gen. Manzur Ahmed, who initiated the army rebellion with the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman, was arrested, and Government troops regained control of the only area that had been held by the rebels. (Page A1, Column 1.) The Saudis will lead peace efforts in the crisis between Syria and Israel over the presence of Syrian missiles in Lebanon. Reagan Administration officials said that Saudi Arabia had agreed to increase its diplomatic role after Syria refused to accept any proposals that seemed to have originated in Israel or the United States. (A1: 2.)

title: CANCER AGENCY FACES QUESTIONS ON WASTE AND ABUSES
description: Ten years after the Government began to pour billions of dollars into the National Cancer Institute to make ''war on cancer,'' a committee of Congress is beginning to raise questions about what the money has bought and whether it has been properly spent.

title: NEW USE OF BLOOD TEST IS DECISIVE IN PATERNITY SUITS
description: A new blood testing procedure is revolutionizing the way courts determine the identity of a child's father in paternity cases, medical and legal experts say.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $3,628,000 extraordinary charge

title: IDEAL TOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeronca Inc., Pineville, N.C., has named J. Lamont Crosby vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: RIGHT TO AID IN CUSTODY CASES IS UPSET
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that indigent parents do not have an automatic constitutional right to free legal assistance in a court proceeding on terminating their legal relationship with their children.

title: SINKHOLE, ATTRACTIVE NUISANCE, LURES CURIOUS FLORIDA TROURISTS
description: The sunburned tourists, their children in tow, press against a chain-link fence to take snapshots of Florida's newest and most natural attraction -the Winter Park sinkhole.

title: Cabby, 43, Acquitted Of Slaying Prostitute
description: A 43-year-old cab driver was acquitted of murder and weaponspossession charges in the 1979 murder of a 19-year-old Queens prostitute whose body was dismembered and dumped.

title: KUHN'S BIG K STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
description: B-Including $162,000 accounting adjustment credit; yr-ago results have been restated for a change in the method of accounting

title: Drive Is Started to Block Tuition Credit on Taxes
description: A campaign against providing tax credits for tuition paid to private schools was begun today by a coalition of education and civil rights groups.

title: TAMAR DE SOLO POOL, 90, AUTHOR AND FORMER HEAD OF HADASSAH
description: Tamar de Sola Pool, an author and educator and a former president of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In Defense of Wall Street
description: Considering the magnitude of the nation's economic problems, we could understand the Reagan Administration's radical abolition of Lord Keynes's General Theory and even its reverence for Arthur Laffer's amateurish curve. We began to worry when it also took the position that budget deficits don't really count in battling inflation and that rapid growth could occur while the Federal Reserve Board is officially encouraged to curb it, through high interest rates.

title: Fed's Action Curbs Drop in the Prime
description: Several leading banks opened business yesterday by lowering their prime lending rates, but what had been widely expected to develop into an industrywide trend evaporated when the Federal Reserve Board unexpectedly drained money from the nation's banking system.

title: FOR JERUSALEM, MAYOR TURNS 70 AND IT PAYS OFF
description: In honor of Mayor Teddy Kollek's 70th birthday, 50 Americans have contributed $5.5 million to an endowment for this city and other Americans have given valuable works of art to its museum.

title: Atlanta Better Business Bureau Gets Queries About Fund Raising
description: The city area's Better Business Bureau said today that it had received many inquiries about a fund-raising group headed by mothers of some of the city's 28 slain young blacks.

title: New York; SHARING THE GOODIES
description: ''It looks bad. It looks like we're giving away money to firms who don't need it. It looks like we're underwriting the expansion costs of firms who would be willing to assume them on their own.''

title: Union Oil Output
description: The Union Oil Company of California said that production had begun from two new projects in the Gulf of Mexico and that by early 1982 they should reach 6,800 barrels of oil and 47 million cubic feet of natural gas a day. The projects include a site about 80 miles southeast of Galveston, Tex., and another 55 miles southeast of Houma, La. Union serves as operator in both fields and holds substantial interests in them in partnerships with the Mobil Oil Corporation and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation.

title: LET'S VOTE ON ABORTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Publisher Fined $500 In Threat to Official
description: Herbert S. Bauch, 68-year-old publisher of The Sentinel, the newspaper of the Civil Service Retired Employees Association, was fined $500 yesterday after pleading guilty to attempted larceny by extortion.

title: ROBERT PENN WARREN ON CREATIVITY AND DEATH OF 'AMBITION'
description: There was laughter in the poet's weathered eyes. How did it feel to receive a foundation award of $60,000 a year for the next five years simply to go on living the life he loves?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TRY, TRY AGAIN

title: Anomalously Angry at Libya
description: On the face of it, Libya's Muammar el-Qaddafi is giving a good name to the Reagan Administration's campaign against terrorism. There is nothing paranoid about charges that Libyan gunmen have in the last year killed a dozen exiles in Western Europe and the Middle East. And it now appears that an American mercenary was hired by Libyans to try to kill a Libyan student leader who turned against the Qaddafi regime. According to the F.B.I., 20 more students were on the colonel's murder list.

title: Japanese Steel Drop Forecast
description: Four of Japan's leading steelmakers reported high earnings last year, but Fippon Steel, the world's largest steelmaker, said its profits were cut by a third and next year might be even worse.

title: Allied, Mitsui Tie
description: The Allied Corporation said that it had received Japanese Government approval to form a joint venture with members of Japan's Mitsui Group to market Allied's amorphous metals in Asia. Allied said that it would hold a 50 percent interest in the new company, which will be called Nippon Amorphous Metals Company Ltd. and will be in Tokyo. The other 50 percent will be shared by four major Japanese companies of the Mitsui Group - Mitsui Petrochemical Industries Ltd., the Toshiba Corporation, the Japan Steel Works and Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding Company Ltd.

title: CARL VINSON, 97, EX-CONGRESSMAN WHO WAS WITH HOUSE 50 YEARS, DIES
description: Former Representative Carl Vinson, who served in the House longer than anyone else and was a powerful proponent of military might, died early today. He was 97 years old.

title: NEGRO ENSEMBLE WINS AN OBIE
description: The Negro Ensemble Company, a force in the American theater since its founding in 1967, won an Obie award last night for the ''sustained achievement'' of its work. The award carries with it a gift of $1,000.

title: ALBERTA CUTS OIL OUTPUT AGAIN
description: The province of Alberta stepped up its pressure on the federal Government for higher oil prices today by cutting its oil production by a further 5 percent.

title: Mears Has Burn Surgery
description: Skin-graft surgery was performed today on Rick Mears, the driver who was burned in an accident in his pit at the Indianapolis 500 last week. ''We actually won't know the outcome for three days, but Rick should be able to return home to Bakersfield by the end of the week,'' said Dr. Richard Grossman of the Sherman Oaks Burn Center. Dr. Grossman said Mears would not be able to race for at least three weeks, and that he wouldn't be fully recovered for six to eight months.

title: CONOCO SETS HUDSON'S BAY SALE
description: Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, agreed yesterday to sell its controlling interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company to Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Canada for $1.68 billion, mostly in stock.

title: FAST-FOOD GAIN IS FORESEEN
description: Beset in recent years by financial and marketing problems, after a period of heady growth, the $28 billion-a-year fast-food industry is starting to show signs of recovery. Many of its problems, notably the steep price increases in beef, chicken and gasoline (which curbed store traffic) have abated, and sales this year are expected to outpace inflation.

title: s; Witness Tells of Effects Of Rams' Shift to Anaheim
description: The former president of the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission accused the National Football League today of playing favorites by permitting the Los Angeles Rams move to nearby Anaheim but forbidding the Oakland Raiders to replace the Rams.

title: Chess: 'Uneven' Trade for a Queen Proves to Be a Wicked Deal
description: When you see a strong player give up three minor pieces to capture a queen, you know something's up. Other things being equal - no perpetual check, no pawn weaknesses, no loose pieces -the queen is at a slight disadvantage against three pieces that can attack a single target in concert.

title: Candidates on Ballot In Jersey Primary
description: On the ballot for Governor today in the primary elections in New Jersey are the following candidates: DEMOCRATS

title: East German Leader Returns From Visit to Japan
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, returned from his first state visit to Japan today and said that while the trip was a political success, he had been unable to conclude all the business deals he had hoped for.

title: BLACKS WOULD FEEL EXTRA IMPACT FROM CUTS PROPOSED BY PRESIDENT
description: This is the first of two articles on economic and political forces affecting black Americans. By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

title: Wang Center's Cost
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., a Lowell, Mass., producer of computers and related equipment, announced that it would spend $30 million to build a new technology center.

title: Topics; URBAN IMAGES; Swine and Soigne
description: Not many years ago it was hard to imagine a sharper contrast than Manhattan and Secaucus, N.J. On one side of the river stood gleaming towers, marking the very latest in soigne sophistication. On the other side were the swine, 250,000 of them in 55 Secaucus piggeries.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid May 22

title: Agriculture Dept. Aide Selected
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today named John W. Bode to be deputy assistant secretary for food and consumer services.

title: C3 INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MORE-FLEXIBLE ANNUITY PLANS
description: INFLATION and taxes - problems faced by every investment program - are particularly bothersome in annuities, which have been among the most inflexible of investment plans.

title: A.T.&.T PLANNING PUBLIC STOCK OFFER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the most widely held company in the world, said yesterday that it plans to sell at least 15 million shares of common stock later this month, the company's first public offering of common stock in four years. If interest is strong, the company said, it would be willing to add another 1.5 million shares, bringing the total to 16.5 million shares.

title: The U.N. Today; June 2, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WITH SMALL CARS PROLIFERATING, THE SEARCH FOR SAFETY INTENSIFIES
description: When the Federal Government published ''The Car Book'' last December, putting its weight behind an implied charge that small Japanese cars were less ''crashworthy'' than some small American cars, the first to cry foul were the auto barons of Detroit.

title: NEVER UNDERESTIMATE THE U.S. MARINE CORPS
description: To the Editor:

title: End to 2 Shoe Quotas Suggested
description: An inter-agency trade advisory group has recommended to President Reagan that he terminate quotas on shoe imports from Taiwan and South Korea, which account for 50 percent of the footwear shipments into this country, an Administration official said today.

title: Dodgers 5, Braves 2
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Fernando Valenzuela, the Dodgers' rookie lefthander, became the major league's first nine-game winner.

title: WORLD'S BIGGEST 'YO-YO' MAY SETTLE OZONE LAYER DEBATE
description: PREPARATIONS are under way for initial tests of a stratospheric observing system that promises to become the world's biggest yo-yo - an instrument package repeatedly lowered 12 miles through the stratosphere from a balloon and hoisted up again, as a yo-yo is, by energy stored during its descent.

title: EX-SUFFOLK G.O.P. CHIEF CONVICTED
description: A former Republican leader of Suffolk County was found guilty yesterday of having evaded $46,000 in Federal income taxes for 1973 and 1974.

title: Royals 3, Mariners 2
description: George Brett drove in two runs with a triple and a single for Kansas City.

title: South Korean Exports Up
description: South Korea's exports in May increased 24.9 percent, to $1.76 billion, from the level of a year earlier, the Commerce and Industry Ministry reported today. Exports in the first five months of this year grew 23.6 percent, to $8.06 billion. The gains were attributed to rising shipments of textiles and other goods to the United States, Japan and Western Europe.

title: Captain of Submarine Relieved of His Command
description: The captain of the United States submarine that sank a Japanese freighter in a collision April 9 has been relieved of his command and given a letter of reprimand, the Navy announced today.

title: FORT WAYNE TRIES TO REGAIN FAIR IMAGE
description: Until a few years ago, few people outside Indiana had heard much about Fort Wayne, and that was just fine with its residents.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Jan 1981

title: Tigers 4, Brewers 3
description: DETROIT (AP) - A single by Lynn Jones in the 12th inning scored Mick Kelleher with the winning run for Detroit.

title: No Headline
description: A.T.& T. acknowledged today that it could not increase its rates for Wide Area Telecommunications Service, or WATS, by 16 percent and avoid pushing the company's earnings above the authorized maximum.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4 percent stock divd paid Jan 15

title: OWENS, MINOR & BODEKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
A QUALIFIED O.K. FOR THE FOURTH AMENDMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: A COMING OF AGE CEREMONY FOR SEVEN OLDER WOMEN
description: It was evident that Pearl Kushner was nervous, though just a touch. Her smile was a bit tentative and her left hand, curled around the paper on which was printed her well-rehearsed speech of thanks to the rabbi, shook a bit when she was asked what she thought of her own rather extraordinary achievement and that of her six friends in the Central New Jersey Jewish Home for the Aged here.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $70,000 net income for the qr and 9 mos from discontinued operations and losses of $176,000 for the qr and $278,000 for the 9 mos from equity in unconsolidated subsid C-Including net income from discontinued operations of $12,000 qr and $170,000 for the 9 mos and $82,000 loss for the qr and $ for the 9 mos from equity in unconsolidated subsidiaries; sales are sales from continuing operations

title: Injured Partez Is Out; Field at 9 for Belmont
description: The probable field for Saturday's Belmont Stakes was reduced to nine yesterday when Partez was withdrawn because of an ankle ailment. Partez, who was flown to New York after having finished third in the Kentucky Derby and then fifth in the Preakness two weeks ago, has a ''slight strain in his left front ankle,'' according to his assistant trainer, Jeff Lukas.

title: Proving Discrimination at Large
description: Blacks are a third of the population of Mobile, Ala., but they have never elected a city commissioner. Why? Because the city elects all three commissioners at large rather than by district. Why is that? The explanation is either racially neutral or rooted in discrimination against black voters.

title: Origin of Aversions
description: A basic problem in human behavior is the origin of likes and dislikes, be they for people, foods, colors or art forms. One approach is to explore conditioned social aversion in animals.

title: STRIKE ALERT SET AT POLISH FACTORY
description: Eight hundred workers at a factory in southern Poland called a strike alert today in support of a 13-dayold hunger strike by five Solidarity union members demanding the release of political prisoners.

title: Curb on State Spending Of U.S. Funds Is Upset
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here overturned a lower court ruling today that would have prohibited the state from spending Federal funds without legislative approval.

title: July Issue of Intro Makes Magazine National
description: Suzanne Douglas, who manages to publish her magazine despite almost constant appearances on TV and radio talk shows, will see her magazine Intro reach national distribution with the July issue. Intro is the magazine for singles who want to meet the opposite sex, and an important feature of each monthly issue is the paid personal classified ads - one for boys and one for girls.

title: DAY IN BEIRUT: STEADY SHELLING, SONIC BOOMS AND A BOY ON A SKATEBOARD
description: This city began its third month of continuous shooting and killing today with a daylong barrage of artillery fire that finally eased by sunset.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS OFF 2.7% IN APRIL
description: Spending for new construction of all buildings, factories and homes in the United States fell 2.7 percent in April to an annual rate of $244.6 billion, the third consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Campbell Resources Modifies Skye Offer
description: Campbell Resources Inc. of Toronto said that its previously announced offer to acquire all the stock of Skye Resources Ltd. on the basis of 1.125 Campbell shares for each Skye share would proceed on a modified basis.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There have been concessions.'' -Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, after meeting with President Reagan on taxes.

title: COMMUNIST CHINA PUBLISHES ITS FIRST NEWSPAPER IN ENGLISH
description: China Daily, the first English-language national newspaper in this Communist land, officially began publication today. As the eight-page newspaper was distributed to newsstands, a Dutch correspondent was preparing to leave China at the request of the Government for having ''behaved inappropriately'' in a way that was not defined. It was the first time in four years that an accredited foreign journalist had been, in effect, expelled.

title: Charges Against 6 Dropped In Illinois Prison Riot Trial
description: Charges against six of the seven remaining defendants in the Pontiac prison riot murder case were dropped today. Thomas Breen, special state prosecutor, said that further prosecution of Larry Hoover, 30 years old, John Bailey, 21, Anthony Gilberry, 31, Robert Harris, 27, William Ozzie, 28, and Ike Taylor, 30, would be ''unwarranted.''

title: DelBello Veto Upheld On Reapportioning
description: The Democratic minority on the Westchester County Board of Legislators yesterday sustained County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's veto of a reapportionment plan approved May 20 by the Republican majority, thus effectively killing efforts this year to redraw the board's district lines.

title: OPEC Freeze Until '83 Urged
description: Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, called today for an oil price freeze by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries until the end of 1982.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Results reflect foreign currency translations that reduced net income by 21 cents a shr and 24 cents a shr for the latest qr a mos respectively, and increased net income by 1 cent a shr and a shr for the previous qr and 6 mos respectively

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
TROUBLED THRIFT UNIT MERGES WITH ANCHOR
description: Two Federal banking agencies, fearing a default at the New York and Suburban Federal Savings and Loan Association, forced it to merge with the Anchor Savings Bank yesterday.

title: ALLEN-BRADLEY NAMES CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICERS
description: Claude R. Whitney, 57, has been named vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Allen-Bradley Company. As chief executive, he succeeds I. Andrew Rader, 66, who continues as chairman, a post he has held since 1966. J. Tracy O'Rourke, 46, succeeds Mr. Whitney as president and chief operating officer.

title: Panel Says Bani-Sadr Violated Constitution
description: A special commission established by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini formally warned President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today that he had violated the Constitution and the orders of the Ayatollah.

title: Bridge: Smoking Curbs Spreading; Some Clubs Issue Total Ban
description: The increasing militance of nonsmoking players who object to tobacco fumes has had growing consequences. In tournaments the two groups are often segregated, while many clubs have established some tables as ''nonsmoking.''

title: U.S. MEDIATION ROLE REJECTED BY SYRIANS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Syria had refused to accept any plan that might seem to have originated in Israel or the United States and that this had left it to Saudi Arabia to take the lead in trying to resolve the crisis in the Middle East.

title: MAKING A TRADITION OF THE NONTRADITIONAL
description: When she finished high school, the former Marie Wassil was recalling yesterday, the Depression was on and college was out of the question. So she went to work, then married and raised a family.

title: OCCIDENTAL TO ACQUIRE IOWA BEEF
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to purchase Iowa Beef Processors, the nation's largest beef processor, for an estimated $795 million in stock.

title: COLUMBIA PUBLIC HEALTH SCHOOL CUTS ACADEMIC YEAR TO SAVE ON PAY
description: To cope with threatened Federal budget cuts, Columbia University's School of Public Health has reduced its faculty's school year from 12 months to nine instead of granting salary increases.

title: Curfew Set in Indian City Where 5 Died in Rioting
description: Authorities proclaimed an indefinite curfew today in the northern Indian city of Aligarh after five persons were knifed to death and nine were injured in an apparent flare-up of Moslem-Hindu rioting, the United News of India reported.

title: Prize-Winning South African Bishop Denied a Passport
description: His outspoken demands for racial equality have made Bishop Desmond Tutu, the general secretary of the South African Council of Churches, a hero to those opposed to his country's apartheid policies. At the same time, they have made him a controversial figure to the South African Government.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
AWARD GIVEN TO ARCHDIOCESE
description: Mayor Koch will present the Municipal Art Society's Certificate of Merit to Terence Cardinal Cooke at ceremonies tomorrow at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The award, which honors the Archdiocese of New York for what the society called its ''painstaking'' yearlong cleaning of the cathedral, is one of 10 awards for ''improving the quality of life in New York City'' that the Municipal Art Society will make at its annual meeting.

title: Watts Changes His Mind, Says He'll Quit Football
description: J.C. Watts, the former Oklahoma quarterback, reversed his field today and said he would not play with the Ottawa Rough Riders of the Canadian Football League.

title: DIVIDES DEMOCRARTS
description: President Reagan vowed today to make no compromise beyond an adjustment in the starting date and initial size of his tax-cutting plan. The statement, made at a meeting in the Oval Office with the Democratic Congressional leadership, split the Democrats on whether to continue negotiations or prepare for an allout fight.

title: HOSPITAL MORTGAGE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MINERS' PRESIDENT RECEIVES PRAISE ON TRIP PROMOTING NEW COAL PACT
description: When Sam M. Church Jr., president of the United Mine Workers, came here nine weeks ago to urge ratification of his first proposed settlement with the coal operators, he was heckled, booed and shouted at. On March 31, 77 percent of the miners here rejected the agreement.

title: UNITED MCGILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
FIRST NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $801,000 for the qr and $849,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including $308,000 extraordinary credit for the qr and 6 mos

title: Japan's Germany Car Sales
description: Importers of Japanese cars sold 26,300 vehicles in West Germany in April, compared with 26,700 in March, giving Japanese manufacturers 10.5 percent of the German market in the first four months of the year, compared with 8.3 percent a year ago. The Federal Motor Office reported that Japanese makers have sold 95,200 units in the first four months of this year. The Volkswagen/Audi Group remained the leading domestic car manufacturer, although its sales of 267,600 cars in Germany in the first four months were down from 309,300 in the same period of 1980.

title: AMTRAK TO CUT HEADQUARTERS STAFF OF 1,400 BY 25%
description: Amtrak, beset by threats of cuts in Federal subsidies, disclosed today that it would reduce its 1,400-member headquarters staff here by 25 percent.

title: Some Expert Commentary on Shuttles
description: To the skirl of bagpipes, John W. Young and Capt. Robert L. Crippen, the crew of the Columbia space shuttle, were greeted on the steps of City Hall yesterday, and Mayor Koch took them inside to give them keys to the city.

title: BROOKS AGREES ON TERMS, WILL COACH THE RANGERS
description: Herb Brooks and the Rangers have finally agreed on the terms by which Brooks, the architect of the United States' Olympic hockey victory last year, will become the team's coach next season.

title: Military Analysis
description: With its southern frontier with Egypt now secure, Israel has complete freedom of action against Syria and other potential Arab enemies.

title: JEFFERSON LIAISON IS DISPUTED AGAIN
description: THE controversy over whether Thomas Jefferson kept a slave named Sally Hemings as his mistress, as alleged in a well-known 1974 biography and in a popular novel published in 1979, has been rekindled in a book by a prominent Virginia journalist. The book, ''The Jefferson Scandals,'' by Virginius Dabney, which rebuts the allegations made against the Founding Father, bears the endorsement of a number of prominent historians.

title: McEnroe, Connors in Quarterfinal
description: Yannick Noah of France provided an exciting 15 minutes on center court today when he completed a 6-2, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4 upset of Guillermo Vilas in the $600,000 French open tennis championships.

title: Auto Output To Rise in June
description: United States auto makers plan to build about 713,000 cars in June, a 34 percent increase from June 1980 and the highest monthly total in 20 months, an industry journal reported today.

title: Two Killings Raise Fears Along Appalachian Trail
description: The fatal stabbing of a young woman and the gunshot death of her companion on the Appalachian Trail have raised fears among some who hike the 2,050-mile-long wilderness footpath.

title: U.N. PLAN SUBSIDIZING FOREIGN PRESS GETS RELUCTANT SUPPORT FROM U.S.
description: The United States has joined other industrial nations in endorsing a plan under which the United Nations has indirectly subsidized foreign newspapers that publish articles promoting United Nations views on aid to the third world.

title: Pope Resumes Exercise After a Three-Day Pause
description: Pope John Paul II rested in an armchair and took a short walk in the hall of Gemelli Hospital today for the first time in three days, the Vatican radio said tonight.

title: MARTIN BAN SET AT WEEK
description: Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, decided yesterday to set Billy Martin's suspension at a week and fine him $1,000 for bumping and then throwing dirt at Umpire Terry Cooney in a game at Toronto Friday night.

title: DEFENSE, IN FINAL STATEMENT, ACCUSES POLICE OF LYING AT MET MURDER TRIAL
description: The defense attorney for Craig S. Crimmins charged in a five-hour closing statement at Mr. Crimmins's murder trial yesterday that various detectives had lied under oath, submitted ''fabricated'' notes of purported interviews with witnesses and created a ''phony confession.''

title: No Headline
description: Lieutenant Cooke's mother and brother, who visited him on Friday, released statements from him today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that its Eltra Corp. unit had agreed to acquire HB Electrical Manufacturing Co. of Mansfield, Ohio, through the merger of HB into Eltra in an exchange of about $4 million of Allied common stock.

title: AFTER ASSASSINATION ATTEMPTS, THOSE UNRELIABLE EARLY REPORTS
description: Suddenly the shots ring out. The leader falls. Sirens wail as the ambulance races to the hospital where doctors begin the battle to save the leader's life. Meanwhile, scenes of the attempted assassination are shown on television almost instantly and repeatedly. And in the next few hours, the public is confused by many conflicting and often erroneous reports.

title: New Jersey Man Gets 50 Years In Kidnap and Assault of Student
description: A 33-year-old New Brunswick man was sentenced today to 50 years in prison for kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 21-year-old Douglass College student.

title: JUTICE DEPT. OPENS INQUIRY IN SOVIET CONTACT BY OFFICER
description: The Department of Justice, at the insistence of Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, shifted its position today and started an investigation to see whether an Air Force officer accused of unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy here had violated espionage laws.

title: DEALING WITH MOSCOW
description: There are two positions that the United States can take on negotiating with the Soviet Union. The first is that negotiation is impossible with ''cheaters and liars.'' Despite a quantity of rhetoric along these lines over the years, that has never been the United States Government's position, even in the days of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles, when some significant agreements were reached.

title: Angels 3, Blue Jays 0
description: TORONTO (AP) - California's Ken Forsch pitched a three-hitter, and Butch Hobson and Dan Ford hit homers.

title: KORVETTE'S CITES OFFER FOR 3 STORES
description: Joseph A. Ris, the chairman and chief executive officer of Korvettes Inc., announced his resignation yesterday after spending a year in closing down the once-successful discount chain and reported negotiations that might dispose of at least three Korvettes stores remaining in New York City.

title: TOWARD A NEW U.S.-PAKISTANI RELATIONSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Borg-Warner Gain
description: The Borg-Warner Corporation said that it had agreed to reduce its ownership in its joint venture with Aisin Seiki Company Ltd. to 10 percent from 50 percent.

title: News Analysis
description: The disagreements over the tax cut battle that appeared today among Democratic Congressional leaders illuminate a series of fracture lines running through the party as it grapples with the programs of a popular President and tries to outline an alternative platform that can attract votes in the Congressional elections next year.

title: METS LOSE
description: Neil Allen, the Mets' premier relief pitcher, failed again in the late innings tonight as the Phillies rallied for two runs to beat New York, 5-4.

title: CAN'T A 'MERE' SCHOOLTEACHER BE A SCHOLAR, TOO?
description: TO amend an old saying: It's not what you know, but who knows what. On May 4, a report on the front page of The Times said that, according to a new theory, the Exodus of the Israelites from Egypt coincided with a volcanic eruption on the island of Thera, 70 miles north of Crete. The resulting tidal wave, the theory went, inundated low coastal lands and thus cut off or drowned the pursuing Egyptians. The author of the theory was Dr. Hans Goedicke, chairman of the department of Near Eastern studies at Johns Hopkins University.

title: Spanish Price Index Up 1%
description: Spain's consumer price index rose a provisional 1 percent in April, down from March's 2 percent increase and in line with the 1 percent growth in April 1980, officials of the Industry and Commerce Ministry said. On an annual basis, the increase was 15.7 percent.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart accompanying a Business Day article last Friday on the efforts of Dome Petroleum Ltd. to acquire control of the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company from Conoco incorrectly described Conoco's petroleum production. Conoco produces 458,000 barrels a day, of which Hudson's Bay contributes 69,000 barrels.

title: Quaker Sells a Unit And Buys Clothier
description: The Quaker Oats Company, a leading food processor, announced the sale of its Needlecraft division to a group of unidentified private investors for about $19 million in cash and notes and said that it had purchased Jos. A. Bank Clothiers Inc., a Baltimore clothing marketer. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed.

title: Fact-Finding Backed In Mead Price-Fixing
description: The Supreme Court refused today to block a proceeding that could force the Mead Corporation to pay up to $1 billion for fixing prices on corrugated containers.

title: SYRIAN CONTENDS U.S. SHOWS BIAS FOR ISRAEL IN EFFORTS ON MISSILES
description: Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam today denounced the United States current Middle East diplomacy as warped in favor of Israel and contended that Saudi Arabia was not a mediator between Syria and ''the Zionist foe.''

title: SILVER STUDY WARNS OF REPEAT OF CHAOS
description: The sharp rise in silver prices early last year and their subsequent sudden collapse, a situation that shook the nation's financial markets because of the huge losses suffered by the Hunt brothers of Dallas, could well be repeated unless further regulatory safeguards are put in place, according to a year-long Government study just delivered to Congress.

title: CITY SAYS LITTER LESSENS, DESPITE MOUNTING EVIDENCE
description: Stepping over littered gutters, past mounds of garbage outside apartment houses and around open boxes of refuse that clog the sidewalks in front of stores and restaurants, a New Yorker in the late spring of 1981 might not realize the city is a bit cleaner than it was this time last year, but city officials insist that it is.

title: KING HASSAN SAYS HE'LL PROPOSE 'SOLUTION' TO WAR IN WESTERN SAHARA
description: King Hassan II of Morocco said today that he would attend next month's meeting of the Organization of African Unity in Kenya and propose ''a solution'' to his long and costly war against the Polisario guerrillas for control of Western Sahara.

title: PAYSAVER CATALOG SHOWROOMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
NOTES ON FASHION
description: O NE was tempted, at first, to ask him who he thought he was, anyway. Instead, it was more productive to ask one of the world's most commercially successful novelists, Harold Robbins, what he knew about fashion, since he had never written about it and since his latest novel, ''Goodbye, Janette,'' is, says the publicity with characteristic effulgence, a ''dazzling dramatization of the fashion world.''

title: G.T.E. Announces Switching System
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation said that it had developed an integrated voice/ data switching system that will use existing private automatic branch exchanges without modification, allowing for a substantial saving in data transmission costs.

title: Nighthawks Hockey Club Will Stay in New Haven
description: The New Haven Nighthawks of the American Hockey League will stay in New Haven for at least two more seasons, but team officials said today they had not yet decided whether the team would keep its affiliation with the New York Rangers.

title: RATE HOPES SEND DOW UP BY 6.21
description: Hopes of a crest in interest rates sent stock prices higher yesterday, but the market ran into profit-taking after the Dow Jones industrial average climbed above 1,000. The indicator closed at 997.96, up 6.21 points.

title: The Washington Star
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today that sloppy draftsmanship of new Federal laws by members of Congress was in part to blame for the ''double-digit inflation'' of caseloads clogging Federal courts.

title: Aching Palmer Pitching Well
description: One afternoon during spring training, Manager Earl Weaver sat in the Baltimore Oriole dugout answering questions about reports that Jim Palmer's pitching career might be over. Weaver, who has had a running feud that is part farce with his Cy Young Award-winning pitcher, laughed slyly. He would worry, Weaver said, when Palmer stopped complaining.

title: PRICES MOVE SHARPLY LOWER
description: The credit markets were battered yesterday as dealers and traders were caught off balance by a sharp rise in the interbank lending rate, known as the Federal funds rate, to 21 1/2 percent from 18 percent last Friday. This is also the rate that banks charge dealers for financing their inventories of Government and other securities. And yesterday was the day when many dealers had to pay for the new Treasury and other issues they bought last week.

title: Reagan Favors An Air Merger
description: A merger of Western Airlines and Continental Air Lines was approved today by President Reagan. Because of developments since the deal was proposed, however, the merger now ''is somewhat of a moot point,'' a Continental spokesman said.

title: FOUNDATION TRIES TO RESCUE THE HUMANITIES
description: For Carl Estabrook, who has a doctorate in history from Harvard, a postdoctoral fellowship at Brown University, financed by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, was ''a godsend.'' The financial realities of his profession are such, he said, that ''plenty of folks with Ph.D.'s in the humanities are living a hand-to-mouth existence and driving taxicabs.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CANDIDATES FOR GOVERNOR IN JERSEY END CAMPAIGN
description: After a final splurge of handshaking yesterday, the 21 candidates for Governor of New Jersey turned their campaigns over to the telephone-callers, pamphlet-dispensers and poll-watchers who, politicians agree, probably hold the key to the primary elections today.

title: In the Nation; THE POLITICS OF TAXES
description: In the tax-reduction dispute between President Reagan and a Congress still partly controlled by the Democrats, the Democrats appear to have one chance in six to come out even a partial winner - odds that emphasize the sometimes disputed dominance of the President in the American system of divided powers.

title: HOW DOES HOLLYWOOD DECIDE IF A FILM IS A HIT?
description: How can you tell if a movie is a hit? Why does the Hollywood grapevine insist that one film is a failure because it made $4 million its opening weekend, while another is a success because it also made $4 million that weekend?

title: U.S. Volkswagen Raises Car Prices
description: Volkswagen of America said it was increasing prices an average 1.1 percent on its VW models and an average 2.1 percent on its Audi models.

title: Rapid-American Reports Gain
description: The Rapid-American Corporation reported yesterday that it had a net income of $939,000 in the first fiscal quarter of 1981, which ended in April, compared with a loss of $3.2 million in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales increased 6 percent, to $604.5 million, from $570.3 million.

title: Ongais, Hurt in Indy 500, Will Be Treated on Coast
description: Danny Ongais, injured when his Interscope racer hit the third-turn wall at the Indianapolis 500, was flown today to Laguna Beach, Calif., where he will be treated by his private physician.

title: Around The nation; Baker and Alexander Bar Deal on Knoxville Journal
description: The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., and Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee have decided against making any immediate purchases of shares in The Knoxville Journal, the Gannett Company said yesterday in announcing completion of its acquisition of the paper.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE ritual of wine service in restaurants often seems intended to intimidate and confuse the customer rather than to get the wine on the table with dispatch, and sometimes the ceremony annoys Michael Rowan, the wine maker for the Jordan Vineyard and Winery in Healdsburg, Calif. So he has developed a technique that enables him to disarm pretentious wine stewards and amuse his companions. He did it the first time on the spur of the moment.

title: Notes On People; Grasp of Geometric Shapes Brings Very Palpable Reward
description: Dr. Dennis P. Sullivan, a 40-year-old topologist whose mathematical specialty is so abstract that state education officials are hard-pressed to define it, much less explain it, was named yesterday to an Albert Einstein Chair in Science at Queens College and the Graduate School of the City University of New York.

title: The U.N. Today; June 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: REVERING HOMER BEATS ORIOLES, 5-3
description: One week after their humiliating series in Baltimore, the Yankees settled a grudge or two last night in Yankee Stadium when they rallied to tie the Orioles in the ninth inning and defeated them in the 11th, 5-3.

title: A PLACE FOR LEBANON IN THE WESTERN CAMP
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York
description: The Bellerose section of Queens is the New York City tourists almost never see, a city of Cape Cod houses, aluminum siding, hedges, rose bushes and summer evenings by putting lightning bugs in jars and pasting the whirligigs that fall from maple trees to their noses. It is a New York in which hardly anyone brunches or gallery hops, and in which ''the city'' is loosely defined as Manhattan.

title: Move by Fed Sends Rates Up; 20-Day Bills Bring 17.946%
description: An unexpected move by the Federal Reserve yesterday to drain funds from the banking system contributed to sharp swings in Treasury bill rates, which ended up rising slightly on the day. Prices of longerterm Treasury and corporate debt issues finished down almost a full point.

title: Ray H. Williams, 49, Ex-Policeman Who Became Lawyer and Teacher
description: Ray H. Williams, a New York City policeman who became a lawyer and an associate professor at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, died last Thursday after a fall at his home in Brooklyn. He was 49 years old.

title: OVERREGULATING THE REGULATORS
description: Reform of our nation's regulatory agencies is in danger of being overregulated. We need to reform the regulatory system and lessen our reliance on regulation as a means of controlling business. In the past, we thought a vastly better society could be achieved if only we could specify, in enough detail, the procedures that business had to follow in a number of critical areas: what information companies had to give their stockholders, how much they could charge their customers, what markets they could enter, etc.

title: Nissan's Earnings Off 1.8% for Year
description: The Nissan Motor Company, maker of Datsun vehicles and Japan's second-largest auto maker, said today that its consolidated earnings slipped 1.8 percent in the year ended March 31, despite a 10.1 percent rise in sales.

title: SSC&B's Coast Office Gets an Influx of Billings
description: The Los Angeles office of SSC&B, formerly Erwin Wasey, dropped considerably in billings when New York headquarters decided to absorb much of the Carnation work it had been doing.

title: HOUSE BACKS AID IN DEFOLIANT CASES
description: The House unanimously passed today a bill directing the Veterans Administration to provide hospital care and medical attention to Vietnam War veterans whose health problems may have arisen from exposure to the herbicide Agent Orange.

title: Around the nation; Atlanta Mothers Group Registers as a Charity
description: A group run by the mothers of some of 28 young blacks found slain in this area in the past two years registered as a charity today after coming under pressure to do so from the state consumer affairs chief, Tim Ryles.

title: Lani Misenas, Coloratura, Sings Mozart and Debussy
description: By the time Lani Misenas reached the songs of her native Philippines at the end of her Carnegie Recital Hall debut Saturday afternoon, she was thoroughly at home. The coloratura soprano displayed a spirited, flexible voice tempered with musical intelligence and dramatic sensitivity.

title: Litton's Net Rose 19.9% in Quarter
description: Litton Industries, a major defense and industrial electronics manufacturer, said its net income in its third fiscal quarter, ended April 30, rose 19.9 percent, to $89.1 million, or $2.22 a share, from $74.3 million, or $1.85 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on May 21 about the day's stock trading incorrectly described the ownership of a videotex system known as Telidon. It is a Canadian operation not associated with Teledyne Industries.

title: F.T.C. WON'T HALT SOHIO KENNECOTT BID
description: The Federal Trade Commission decided yesterday not to block the $1.8 billion takeover of the Kennecott Corporation by the Standard Oil Company (Ohio). In doing so, sources close to the Government agency said, the four-member panel rejected, by a 3-to-1 vote, a staff recommendation to sue Sohio on antitrust grounds.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's taken nearly 25 years to right one of history's great wrongs, and we're not going to stop until we have our Dodgers back. What's Romeo without Juliet? What's Niagara without the Falls? What's Hershey without chocolate? What's Brooklyn without the Dodgers?'' - State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz, Democrat of Greenpoint. (B1:3.)

title: RIKERS SALE PROPOSAL 'DEAD,' COMMISSIONER ASSERTS
description: New York City's Correction Commissioner, Benjamin Ward, told a City Council hearing yesterday that a plan to sell parts of the Rikers Island jail complex to the state was ''dead and buried.''

title: Keep a Federal Eye on Federal Aid
description: For its next budget trick, the Reagan Administration proposes to pour a series of valuable domestic programs into one hat and pull out conservative rabbits called block grants. And where Government aid has already been thus transformed, as in so-called community development grants for cities, the White House wants to prove that the animal can be safely let off the Federal leash.

title: A Nice Muddle Of Meddle
description: Q. As the Minister of Clarification, sir, will you spare me a moment? A. Delighted, my muddled friend. Always delighted to clarify the waters. Out with it. Q. My question goes back to 1977 when Moscow criticized President Carter's human rights policy as mistaken and obnoxious. Remember that?

description: Former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai said today that a test explosion in 1974 was not a nuclear one as reported but was a powerful conventional blast. India's atomic energy authority dismissed the assertion.

title: The Region; Guardsman's Widow Files $4 Million Suit
description: A woman whose husband died in the crash of an Air National Guard fighter plane almost two years ago filed a $4.1 million damage suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan, contending that the aircraft was defectively designed and improperly maintained by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: SECURITY IS STEPPED UP IN ULSTER DURING VISIT BY RELATIVE OF QUEEN
description: The police stood guard inside the church and British troops poured into surrounding Catholic sections as Princess Alexandra, a cousin of Queen Elizabeth, arrived in Ulster today to attend the consecration of a Protestant cathedral.

title: CULTURE OF TAIWAN'S ABORIGINES ERODING AS MODERN WAYS SEEP IN
description: During their colonization of Taiwan, the Japanese turned the small island of Lan Yu into a private anthropological museum with living exhibits and severely limited admission. With Chinese Nationalist rule, the world of the 20th century has been allowed in and threatens to sweep away the culture of its population.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of the most fascinating aspects of this column is the comments from readers making special requests for various kinds of foods for menus. Some of them are wholly surprising.

title: Credit Needs Cited For Oil Industry
description: The petroleum industry will require more than $700 billion from world credit markets in the 1980's to meet oil demand, according to a Chase Manhattan study released here today.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF PUSHES MEMBERSHIP IN NATO
description: With little national debate and only muted protests from the opposition Socialist and Communist parties, the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo is moving toward making Spain the 16th member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: OPERA: GIORDANO'S 'LA CNA DELL BEFFE'
description: The Amato Opera Theater is reviving a production of Giordano's ''La Cena Delle Beffe'' as its final offering of the season. Based on a play by Sem Benelli - an English version called ''The Jest'' once served as an effective vehicle for Lionel and John Barrymore - ''La Cena Delle Beffe'' dates from 1924. Like all of Giordano's scores after ''Andrea Chenier'' and ''Fedora,'' the work has pretty much vanished from sight, probably because the composer used up all his hit tunes in those early operas.

title: F.D.A. AIDES DENY FAVORITISM
description: Two officials with the Food and Drug Administration whose relationship with a manufacturer of contact-lens solutions has been under Congressional investigation said today that their actions, which benefited the company, were in no way influenced by their ties to its management.
