title: KEY DEMOCRATS DRAFT TWO-YEAR BILL TO CUT TAXES 5%, THEN 10%
description: In a challenge to the Reagan Administration, Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began drawing up a new two-year tax relief bill today that the committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, said he hoped ''all Democrats'' would support on the House floor.

title: Janis-Rozena Peri Sings Rachmaninoff and Bizet
description: Throughout Janis-Rozena Peri's recital at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night there was the feeling that for this soprano, the use of her voice is no mere vocation. One was always conscious of both the pleasure she took in singing and her earnestness.

title: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-After a $2,775,174 charge representing the cumulative effect of a change in accounting results reflect the acquisition of investor-owned franchises

title: Manila Kills Ads In U.S. Magazines
description: Philippine Airlines, a Government-owned carrier, canceled advertising schedules in Pacific-area editions of both Time and Newsweek magazines following coverage of a visit by Pope John Paul II that apparently upset the administration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, it was learned this week.

title: BASIC EARTH'S CUT IN RESERVES
description: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC., the public offering of which drew pension money from the International Business Machines Corporation and the Bankers Trust Company six months ago, has just made drastic reductions in the oil and gas reserves cited in its prospectus.

title: Intravenous Feeding Is Ended for Pope
description: The doctors of Pope John Paul II took him off @intravenous feeding today and sharply reduced the quantity of drugs he has been receiving since he was shot nearly three weeks ago, Vatican Radio reported.

title: Around the nation; Appeals Court Rejects Suit, By Indians Over Black Hills
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected an Indian lawsuit that sought $11 billion and possession of the 7.3-million-acre Black Hills region of South Dakota.

title: 4 Concerts by Choral Society
description: The New York Choral Society will present four concerts at Carnegie Hall next season conducted by Robert DeCormier. The programs will consist of Dvorak's ''Requiem''; a Christmas Celebration with Peter, Paul and Mary; Beethoven's Mass in C, Bernstein's ''Chichester Psalms'' and the Bach B Minor Mass.

title: 65 New Zayre Stores
description: The Zayre Corporation said that it intends to open about 65 new stores this year. Maurice Segall, president and chief executive officer, told the annual meeting in Boston that the new stores would include about 35 Hit or Miss units, which is Zayre's off-brand name women's apparel chain, and 18 to 20 T.J. Maxx Stores, the company's off-price family apparel chain. Mr. Segall also said Zayre plans to open 10 to 12 department stores and intends to close about 15 Hit and Miss stores this year. The company operates discount department and apparel stores.

title: ROSE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
William Meyerowitz, 85, Artist Depicted the Lower East Side
description: William Meyerowitz, a painter and etcher who worked in New York, Gloucester, Mass., and Israel, died last Thursday in Manhattan. He was 85 years old.

title: SUB PEOPLE item; Notes On People; The Barry Rosens Sign a Book Contract
description: Since their release from Iran in January there has been a scramble among some of the 52 former hostages and their families for book contracts.

title: A BRINK'S GUARD IS SHOT TO DEATH IN BRONX ATTACK
description: Two Brink's guards were shot, one of them fatally, after thieves trailed an armored truck into a busy shopping center parking lot in the north Bronx and fired as soon the guards opened their rear door to deliver cash to a bank.

title: FACTORY ORDERS OFF 0.8% IN APRIL
description: New orders for the nation's manufactured goods fell eighth-tenths of 1 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted $163.3 billion, the steepest decline since last May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
BASICALLY BACH: CANTATAS
description: FOR its second concert, Monday night, the Basically Bach Festival moved from Avery Fisher Hall to the Central Presbyterian Church at Park Avenue and East 64th Street. This relocation had a double significance.

title: BRITISH AEROSPACE: SHOWPIECE
description: Amid Britain's economic gloom stands one shining success story for which Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has received credit. British Aerospace Ltd., reborn as a publicly traded company, has become a symbol of the free enterprise spirit the Government hopes to encourage in Britain.

title: CONCERT: MUSICAL ELEMENTS
description: The new-music concerts presented by the group Musical Elements are distinguished by a willingness to combine new pieces with classics of the 20th-century repertory. Monday's program at Carnegie Recital Hall had its ups and downs, the downs relating mostly to one not very interesting new piece and some occasionally insecure violin playing that troubled music that should have sounded secure and serene.

title: COSMOS 2-1 VICTORS ON CABANAS'S GOALS
description: Roberto Cabanas's second goal of the game, 2 minutes 56 seconds into overtime, gave the Cosmos a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Manic at Olympic Stadium tonight before 38,667, the largest crowd to attend a North American Soccer League game in Canada.

title: HEAD OF CAREY TRANSIT PANEL CAUTIONS ON RAISING FARE
description: Kenneth S. Axelson, the chairman of the Governor's panel on transit, said today that he had no objection to action by the State Legislature ''to contain fares at a reasonable level and prevent a runaway fare.''

title: COURT BACKS A RULING GIVING TENANTS BROAD SUBLET RIGHTS
description: In a ruling that could benefit thousands of New York City tenants, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has ruled that a landlord may not refuse a tenant permission to sublet an apartment without giving a reason. If he does not give a reason, the court said, the landlord has, in effect, consented to the sublet.

title: REAGAN'S TAX CUT ISN'T INFLATIONARY
description: With all the headlines and speculation about ''compromise'' and ''no compromise,'' the central question remains, What would be the impact of President Reagan's proposed tax cuts?

title: BOMBING PLOT TRIAL NEARS END ON COAST
description: Closing arguments began today in a Federal Court trial that defense lawyers have depicted as a cause celebre for 1930's-style union activism and that prosecutors have depicted as simply a case of three dissident employees who allegedly plotted to blow up part of a shipyard.

title: Steel Output Off in Week
description: Steel production in the United States was 2.49 million tons last week, a 3.7 percent drop from the previous week's 2.59 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. Last week's output amounted to 83.2 percent of capacity, down from 86.4 percent. Production so far this year totals 54.5 million tons.

title: DISTRIBUCO INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 28
COOKING SCHOOL SUMMER CLASS
description: Last week's listing of summer cooking courses in the city inadvertently omitted Rose Levy Beranbaum at Cordon Rose, 110 Bleecker Street, Apartment 7D, New York 10012. 475-8856.

title: ROCKABILLY, A GENRE THAT HAS FOUND CHIC
description: Rockabilly, the volatile mixture of country music and blues that was spearheaded by Elvis Presley in the 50's, was never chic. It changed the course of popular music by introducing millions of white teen-agers to the ''big beat'' of rock-and-roll, but it was too sullen and proletarian and greasy to be chic.

title: RATE JITTERS CAUSE STOCK DECLINE
description: Interest rate jitters touched off a sharp decline in the stock market yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 10.48 points, to 987.48. Energy, technology, fast-food, railroad and airline issues joined blue chips in showing weakness.

title: Airline Talks Open in Geneva
description: Executives from about half the member airlines of the International Air Transport Association opened a two-day meeting today in an effort to find ways to improve their bleak financial outlook.

title: TELEX PRESIDENT ADDS CHIEF'S POST
description: Stephen J. Jatras, the 55-year-old president of the Telex Corporation, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer of the Tulsa, Okla., electronics company. He succeeds Roger M. Wheeler, 55, the entrepreneur who was shot to death last Wednesday. Mr. Wheeler, who numbered Telex among his many oil, gambling and other business activities, with his family owned 10 percent of the electronics company.

title: NEW WAVE OF JOBLESS IMMIGRANTS REVERSES OLD PATH FROM SOUTH
description: The story is an American epic: Millions of working people, unable to make ends meet in their native Southland, moving northward in wave after migrating wave, seeking a living in the factories and mills of the Middle West.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including $654,000 or 19 cents a shr extraordinary gain

title: LET THE PEOPLE MAKE THE CASINO DECISION
description: To the Editor:

title: MONETARISM: DISSENT GROWS
description: THE struggle between President Reagan and the Democrats in Congress over the tax bill has become a war of maneuver for political advantage more than a debate over economic policy. Mr. Reagan appears to have dug in deeply on the ''principle'' of three consecutive years of tax cuts, to which he committed himself during the election campaign. The Democrats are split by uncertainty over whether they can maximize their potential political gains (or minimize their potential losses) by fighting the President or compromising with him.

title: CITY HILTON CANCELS PLANS FOR EXTENSION
description: The New York Hilton Hotel has canceled plans to build a 43-story, 800-room extension that would have made it the largest hotel in the country. It blamed inflation and rising construction costs.

title: KEAN, IN HIS ACCEPTANCE SPEECH, BEGINS AN ATTACK AGAINST FLORIO
description: In a rousing, forceful speech to supporters in the Holiday Inn on Route 10 tonight after he won the Republican nomination for Governor of New Jersey, Thomas H. Kean challenged the Democratic nominee, James J. Florio, to a series of debates.

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Borg, Pecci Advance To French Semifinal
description: After dropping the first set and falling behind by 4-1 in the second, Victor Pecci righted himself today and overpowered Yannick Noah, 3-6, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4, to reach the semifinals of the French open tennis tournament. He will play Bjorn Borg, who eliminated Balazs Taroczy, 6-3, 6-3, 6-2.

title: Welfare Fraud Brings Sentence
description: A 28-year-old Pomona woman who collected more than $105,000 in welfare benefits for 30 nonexistent children was sentenced yesterday to serve 16 months in state prison. Superior Court Judge Everett Ricks imposed the sentence on Yvonne Miller.

title: Haig to Meet Japanese Aide
description: Japan's new Foreign Minister, Sunao Sonoda, will meet with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Manila on June 19, the Foreign Ministry announced today. Both men will be in the Philippine capital to attend a meeting of foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

title: Early OTB Bets Set for Belmont
description: The New York City Gfftrack Betting Corporation announced yesterday that beginning Friday it would accept advance wagers on Saturday's Belmont Stakes.

description: B-Including $298,000 or 24 cents a shr net gain on the sale of real estate; shr earnings have been adjusted for a 6 percent stock divd to be paid this month

title: NURSING HOME HOSTAGES FREED IN NEW HAVEN
description: Armed with a shotgun and an automatic handgun, a 59-year-old man held 16 staff members of a convalescent home hostage for seven hours before he was subdued by the police in a struggle that left one nurse seriously wounded by a shotgun blast.

title: Hercules Venture
description: Hercules Inc., said it will join the Hexcel Corporation to make graphite fiber in Europe starting in the second quarter of 1982. The company did not disclose financial details or the site of the new venture. Production will be about 100,000 pounds a year.

title: Martin Gets a Reprieve
description: The American League said yesterday that Manager Billy Martin of the Oakland A's had appealed his seven-day suspension and $1,000 fine for bumping Terry Cooney, the home-plate umpire, during a game at Toronto Friday night.

title: U.S. TO STUDY EFFECT OF OFFSHORE DRILLING ON SEA LIFE
description: Special biological studies will begin soon in the disputed oil leasing areas of the Georges Bank off the New England coast, and exploratory drilling will be carefully monitored to insure that no harm is done to marine life, Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced today.

title: FIRST AVE. MERCHANT KILLS ROBBER
description: The owner of an Upper East Side card and gift shop wrestled a gun away from a holdup man yesterday and killed him with several shots, the police said.

title: ANOTHER ENTRY IN THE ANALS OF FAD DIETS
description: LAST week, another in a seemingly endless stream of fad diets hit the best-seller list. If as many Americans as bought these miraclepromising books actually lost a significant amount of weight and kept it off, the market for future fads would soon disappear.

title: SOME NEAR TITAN BASE CITE STRAINS IN CREWMEN'S LIFE
description: If they remember him at all, his neighbors recall Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke as a quiet person who kept to himself, someone who prefered tinkering with his red Corvette to mixing with any of the other unmarried people who live in the Sundance apartment complex here.

title: 2 Rikers Inmates Flee In Truckload of Bread
description: Two inmates assigned to a prison bakery on Rikers Island escaped yesterday by hiding in a Parks Department truck as it was picking up a load of stale bread for the animals at Flushing Meadows Zoo, a Department of Correction spokesman said. The police were still seeking the fugitives late yesterday.

title: CUISINE BOURGEOISE OUT WEST
description: BERKELEY,Calif. WHERE American gastronomy is concerned, there is one commodity that is rarer than locally grown black truffles or homemade foie gras. That is a chef of international repute who was born in the United States. Even rarer is such a celebrated chef who is a woman.

title: IN CLAM CHOWDER COOK-OFF, BATTLES ARE WON BUT WAR RAGES ON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Bryan Miller is a freelance food writer who lives in Connecticut. By BRYAN MILLER

description: B-After $12.6 million pretax loss provision associated with consolidation of operation

title: 13th Texas Flood Victim Found
description: The body of a man missing since flash floods swept the city a week ago has been recovered from Lake Austin, raising the official death toll to 13 and leaving at least one more person unaccounted for. The police said searchers found the body of Arthur Raiford, 35 years old, of Austin, on Sunday.

title: INSYTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The Region; Air Force to Close Hancock Field
description: SYRACUSE (AP) - Air Force Secretary Verne Orr announced that Hancock Field would be closed by the end of the year, but local business leaders were optimistic that another use could be found for the facility.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO BOLSTER RIGHTS NOMINEE
description: President Reagan, told by supporters in the Senate to expect a tough confirmation fight over Ernest W. Lefever's nomination as the Administration's chief human rights official, said today that he would not retreat ''one inch.''

title: Top Management Shifts Made at Volume Shoe
description: S. Lee Pozez, 55, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Volume Shoe Corporation, a leading chain of selfservice footwear stores, effective Aug. 1. He will succeed his cousin, Louis Pozez, 59, who was appointed chairman of the executive committee of the Topeka, Kan., company.

title: Sugar Contract Changes
description: The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange said yesterday that it was increasing the margin requirements for world sugar No.11 and domestic sugar No.12 contracts by $500, effective immediately. Contract prices will now range from $2,500 to $4,600, depending on volume purchased, the exchange said.

title: A Good Time to Remember Rachel Carson
description: Environmentalists are rightly apprehensive about the Reagan Administration, but they can't claim it hasn't done anything for them. The U.S. Postal Service has just issued its latest Great Americans stamp, honoring the late Rachel Carson.

title: BEEF INDUSTRY SEEKS LEANER GRADING RULES
description: WASHINGTON Another change in the Agriculture Department's beef-grading standards, the guides that consumers use to judge meat quality, has been suggested by cattle raisers.

description: B-Including $59,000 extraordinary tax credit...C-Net loss; per shr figure is fully diluted

title: Teck Oil Venture Talks Under Way
description: The Teck Corporation, a Canadian mining and petroleum company, and the Copperfields Mining Corporation, said that negotiations were under way with the Aquitaine Company of Canada to form a joint exploration company that would develop Aquitaine's extensive holdings in the Beaufort Sea, in the Davis Strait and off the east coast of Labrador.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Rev figures are from continuing operations

title: Cooper Tool Plant
description: The Cooper Hand Tool Group, a unit of Cooper Industries, said that it would open a manufacturing plant employing more than 500 people in Monroe, N.C., just south of Charlotte. The plant will be in a 290,000-square-foot building formerly used by the Monroe Combining Company, Cooper said. The facility will produce hammers and axes and will be remodeled and expanded at a cost of $15 million, the company said.

title: RICHARD HARRIS BRINGING 'CAMELOT' TO BROADWAY
description: Richard Harris will make his debut on Broadway next October in ''Camelot.'' Mr. Harris went on stage in ''Camelot'' in Los Angeles in April, replacing Richard Burton, an old friend, who underwent surgery for a degenerative disease of the spine in March. ''Camelot,'' which would have ended its run with Mr. Burton next week, has had, in effect, a resuscitation.

title: PATRICK WOULD HAVE KEPT RANGER JOB IF BROOKS HADN'T ACCEPTED
description: Craig Patrick said yesterday that if his good friend Herb Brooks had not accepted the Rangers' coaching job Monday then Patrick would have remained as coach while also running the team as its operations director.

title: U.S. Agrees to End Laser Antitrust Suit
description: The Justice Department filed a proposed agreement to end its civil antitrust case against Spectra-Physics Inc. and the Laserplane Corporation.

title: Karla De Vito Takes Over Ronstadt Role in 'Pirates'
description: Karla De Vito replaced Linda Ronstadt at last evening's performance of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' at the Uris Theater.

title: Bridge: Combined Trump Quantity Outweighs Trump Quality
description: Beginners learn, often with surprise, that total trump quantity in the combined partnership hands is more important than total trump quality. Experts know better, but not much better. Although they know in theory that a 4-4 fit may be more remunerative in particular circumstances than a 5-4 fit, or a 4-3 fit than a 5-3 fit, they rarely uncover the fact in the bidding. The facts come to light belatedly in the post-mortem.

title: U.S. Loan Pact Set With China
description: China has agreed to arrangements for borrowing from the United States Export-Import Bank that will enable it to greatly increase its American imports, the United States Embassy announced today.

title: Runaway Blimp Finds Way to Nearby Airport
description: A gubernatorial candidate's campaign blimp yesterday floated away from a hotel where it had been moored and found its way to nearby Newark International Airport.

title: American Home Joins Sanofi Venture
description: The American Home Products Corporation and Sanofi of France said that they had agreed to form a joint venture company in the United States to develop and market pharmaceutical products developed by Sanofi's research operations.

title: U.S. CONSIDERING VENEZUELAN BID FOR JET FIGHTERS
description: The Reagan Administration is ''on the brink'' of approving the sale of advanced fighter planes to Venezuela, a step that would reverse longstanding American policy against the introduction of advanced arms into Latin America, Government officials said today.

title: DELEGATES AT TEAMSTERS' CONVENTION VOTE TO INCREASE SALARIES OF UNION'S LEADERS
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters today voted to raise the salary of its president to $225,000 a year in a move to increase the power of the union leadership, a level of control that is already immense.

title: Reserves Fall In Britain
description: Britain's reserves of foreign currency, gold and special drawing rights in the International Monetary Fund fell $1.5 billion last month because of early repayment of overseas loans, the Government announced today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MIME

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about a United Nations conference on the Vietnamese presence in Cambodia incorrectly identifed the Cambodian faction that Secretary General Kurt Waldheim refused to invite. China and the Association of South East Asian Nations had asked for an invitation to representatives of former Prime Minister Pol Pot.

title: PACESETTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Notes On People; Difficult Times for Rita Hayworth
description: Because she is suffering from senile dementia, Rita Hayworth is no longer able to care for her health and financial needs, her lawyer, Leonard H. Monroe, told a Superior Court judge in Los Angeles.

title: 'ALAMBRISTA!'
description: ''Alambrista!'' was shown as part of the 1979 American Independent Films Series. Following are excerpts from a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times on Sept. 23, 1979. The film opens today at the Art Theater, Eighth Street east of Fifth Avenue.

title: HUSSEIN CONDEMNS ISRAEL, SLIGHTS SYRIA
description: Denouncing Israel for its part in the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon, King Hussein of Jordan assessed the situation today as ''very delicate, disturbingly dangerous and explosive.''

title: Sharp Rise Seen in Copper Price
description: Copper producers and analysts said today that prices for the metal could go much higher and possibly double in the next two years in anticipation of a strengthening of domestic and international economic activity.

title: THAT-OFF-THE SHOULDER LOOK IN T-SHIRTS
description: Every year, with the advent of warm weather, the T-shirt and the sweatshirt put in appearances under a new guise.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE spring-summer fruit season is under way. Prices are expected to decline in the next few weeks for items such as peaches, plums, melons and nectarines. Bing cherries from California are in peak production and selling at 89 to 98 cents a pound in many supermarkets. Canteloupe melons from Arizona, California and Texas are arriving in heavy supplies at moderate prices.

title: N.B.A. Restricts Contacts With Collegians
description: National Basketball Association teams will no longer be permitted to have contact with an undergraduate before he applies for the college draft.

title: Yugoslav Priest Is Imprisoned
description: A Yugoslav court sentenced a Roman Catholic priest to 50 days in jail on charges of having ''insulted leading personalities,'' illegal under Yugoslav law, a Belgrade newspaper reported today. The newspaper Vecernje Novosti said The Rev. Vjenceslav Kujundzic, 27 years old, had asked students in his religious classes to remove stickers from their school uniforms that referred to Tito. It said the priest, who denied the charge, was sentenced May 5.

title: Soviet Union Is Establishing An Embassy in Zimbabwe
description: A Soviet diplomatic team has arrived in Zimbabwe to set up an embassy and formalize relations with the Government of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, whom the Kremlin refused to support during the seven-year civil war.

title: FRENCH SOCIALIST, ON BONN VISIT, SAYS MOSCOW MUST TRIM ARSENAL
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France, making his first foreign trip on behalf of President Francois Mitterrand's new Government, met with West German leaders today and said the Soviet Union must reduce its arsenal of middle-range nuclear missiles aimed at Western Europe.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $1,196,000 or 33 cents a shr extraordinary credit; yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3 percent stock divd declared Oct 21, 1980

title: Police Say They Lack New Clues To Killer of P.L.O. Aide in Brussels
description: The police said today they had no new clues about the identity or whereabouts of the gunman who killed a top representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: ARE FAIRS OBSOLETE?
description: Is it time to end world's fairs? Scholars of fairs, gathered at a symposium last fall at the Queens Museum, in Flushing Meadows, N.Y., commemorating the 1939-40 New York World's Fair, agreed that ''The World of Tomorrow'' - the theme of that fair - was the boldest in a succession of world's fairs dating back to London's Crystal Palace Exhibition of 1851.

title: B.B.D.O. Executive Joining Ted Bates
description: Larry Light, frequent speech giver and an executive vice president of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, is leaving his only employer since college to join Ted Bates & Company as an executive vice president.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE MAPMAKERS. By John Noble Wil- ford. 414 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $20.

title: WIDER ROLE FOR LIBERAL ARTS MAJORS
description: THE invitation read: ''Bankers Trust Company and Sotheby Parke Bernet Inc. request the pleasure of your company at a Forum on Antiques and Fine Arts.''

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: Recently Eugene Raskin was entering the 79th Street station of the Broadway IRT, when he observed, he writes, ''a lithe young man so opposed to authority that he jumped over the turnstile - on the way out.''

title: Brodie, Ex-49er, Winner In British Amateur Golf
description: John Brodie, former San Francisco 49er quarterback, defeated David Murchie of Scotland, 3 and 2, in the first round of the British Amateur golf championship today.

title: Music at Seaport Museum To Begin This Weekend
description: There will be music under the stars and by the water this summer at the South Street Seaport Museum, beginning Friday at 8 P.M. with a free jazz concert by the Saheb Sarbib Multinational Big Band. The performance is the first in the ''Summerpier Series'' of free concerts that will run weekends through Aug. 29.

title: NEW BRITISH PARTY TESTS ITS STRENGTH
description: Britain's new Social Democratic Party, which broke away from the Labor Party because of Labor's drift to the left, has been given its first chance to show its political muscle.

title: New Heart Monitors Developed by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced development of new computer-assisted electrocardiographic equipment to help physicians in quick detection of abnormalities associated with heart disease.

title: Seoul Jails 9 Students for Leading A Demonstration Against Regime
description: Nine students of Seoul National University were given prison sentences of one to three years today for having led an anti-Government demonstration on the university campus last December, court officials said.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PLOTTERS ARRESTED, BANGLADESH ASSERTS
description: The Bangladesh Government announced tonight that it had arrested 20 army officers involved in the plot last weekend to overthrow the Government and that three of them, including the leader, had been killed shortly after being taken into custody.

title: The Region; Appeals Court Stays Order on Nassau Jail
description: A three-judge Federal appeals court stayed a lower-court order that would have required a reduction in the number of inmates in the Nassau County Jail of nearly 30 percent.

title: 1. Sandals Go Soft
description: Fans of the Scholl exercise sandals should be pleased to know that the company is introducing a new, more comfortable model. Rather than the usual wooden sole, the sandal has a shaped, composition sole made with a rocker back that is much softer and more flexible than wood. The lining and strap are leather and there's a bit of foam padding under the buckle. The Scholl Foot Comfort Shop, 376 Fifth Avenue (35th Street) has the sandals for $16.99 in white, beige and navy.

title: SAUL S. LEVY
description: Saul S. Levy, founder and retired president of the Simon Textiles Company of Manhattan, died of a heart attack last Saturday in North Miami Beach, Fla. He was 66 years old and had moved from Valley Stream, L.I., to North Miami Beach in 1978.

title: AIR FORCE ACCUSED OF ERROR IN INQUIRY ON MISSILE OFFICER
description: Justice Department officials said today that the Air Force had mishandled the initial investigation of an officer accused of making unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy here.

title: Transactions; BASKETBALL
description: Signed Guy Frazier, line- b acker draft choice. KANSAS CITY - Announced that Scott W edman, free-agent forward, had signed an o ffer sheet to play with Cleveland. N.B.A. - Board of Governors ratified sale o f San Diego Clippers to Donald T. Sterling, L os Angeles lawyer.

title: CHILDREN'S PLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
REAGAN AND BRADY HOLD FIRST REUNION
description: President Reagan and his press secretary, James S. Brady, held an emotional reunion today, their first meeting since both were shot in an attempt on the President's life March 30.

title: Burmah Oil Sues Bank of England
description: Britain's Burmah Oil Company filed suit against the Bank of England for $2.5 billion in what analysts here called ''one of the most spectacular legal cases of its kind.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corporation, Morris Township, N.J., has elected Nicholas A. Cameron a vice president.

title: Food Aid for Salvador Refugees
description: The United Nations World Food Program has allocated $1.3 million in emergency food relief for 50,000 Salvadoran refugees who have fled from political violence in their homeland to other Central American countries, an agency spokesman said today. He said Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica had requested the emergency food aid.

title: French Nuclear Tests Will Resume After Review
description: France will resume nuclear tests on the South Pacific atoll of Mururoa after giving itself time for a thorough review of the program, the country's top defense official said today.

title: Article 142082 -- No Title
description: Bank auditors and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents checked the records of the Crocker National Bank today in an effort to determine the whereabouts of some $7 million.

title: JEFFREY STEINBERG, 34, INNOVATIVE PUBLISHER, FOUNDER OF STONEHILL
description: Jeffrey Joshua Steinberg, founder and publisher of Stonehill Communications, died yesterday at Nassau Community Hospital in Hempstead, L.I., of injuries suffered in an automobile accident on May 23 on the Long Island Expressway. He was 34 years old and lived in New York and East Hampton, L.I.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
ANADITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Q & A
description: Q. You always recommend in recipes for fish stock using fish heads with gills removed. I am a fisherman and I have made the stock with gills intact, and the flavor is quite acceptable. Why do you remove them?

title: CLASH MELEE POINTS UP DANGER OF OVERSELLING
description: The Clash concerts at the Bond's International Casino, West 45th Street and Broadway, have been causing quite a stir, and not because of the British rock band's political lyrics and incendiary performing style. Bond's was closed by the city Department of Buildings on Saturday after the Clash played to a crowd estimated at 3,640 people; the club's legal capacity is 1,800.

title: BILL ON GUARDIANS FOR CULT MEMBERS GAINS IN ALBANY
description: A bill that would allow courts to appoint temporary guardians to remove people from religious and other cults was reported favorably from the Assembly's Mental Health Committee today. It moved despite objections by Dr. James A. Prevost, the State's Commissioner of Mental Health.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
CRIME MOST FOUL ON THE DIAMOND
description: IT has been observed here before now that no matter how deficient an umpire may be in physical beauty, personal charm and social grace, he is infallible on balls and strikes and matters of faith and morals. His carcass is also sacrosanct, more zealously protected from molestation than the whooping crane.

title: LESLIE FAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-After net losses from discontinued operations of $284,000 for the qr and $3,138,000 for the yr; results are for 52 weeks for the latest yr and 53 weeks for the previous yr

title: LDB CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $878,000 for the qr and $2,423,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $587,000 for the qr and $1,781,000 for the 9 mos

title: The Region; Army Private Called Ready to Stand Trial
description: BUFFALO (UPI) - Army Pvt. Joseph Christopher has been found mentally competent to stand trial in the shooting deaths of three black men in the Buffalo area last September, the soldier's attorney said.

title: SWING OF PENDULUM IN ALBANY: THE LEGISLATURE GOES ITS OWN WAY
description: The increasing independence of the State Legislature and what Governor Carey acknowledged today was a weakening of his power to sway it have stalled the legislative session and left most major issues unresolved.

title: Rains Cause Floods in Indonesia
description: Vast areas of rice paddies have been destroyed in Indonesia's south Kalimantan (Borneo) province, where torrential rains have caused the worst flooding in 50 years, the national news agency Antara said today. In some areas the flood water was more than 12 feet deep, Antara said.

title: Mitchel E. Hadad, 84, Executive Active in Middle Eastern Affairs
description: Mitchel E. Hadad, vice president of the Collegiate Manufacturing Company, a Manhattan textile concern, and a philanthropist who was active in Lebanese-Syrian affairs, died Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and had moved to Greenwich several years ago from Rye, N.Y., where he had lived more than 40 years.

title: HEAD OF CANCER AGENCY DEFENDS AWARD OF GRANT TO ACCUSED SCIENTIST
description: The director of the National Cancer Institute today defended his agency's award last year of a $910,000 research grant to a scientist accused of falsifying data under a previous research project on the ground that the charges against the scientist had not yet been proven.

title: FLORIO AND KEAN WIN RACES IN NEW JERSEY WITH LARGE MARGINS
description: Displaying surprising strength in all sections of the state, Representative James J. Florio of Runnemede won the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey last night and Thomas H. Kean of Livingston the Republican nomination.

title: STAGE: SNODGRASS'S 'FUEHRER BUNKER'
description: For W.D. Snodgrass's ''The Fuehrer Bunker,'' the American Place Theater looks bombed out. Rows of seats have been removed and platforms thrown up in the middle of the audience. For all purposes, we are within the bunker, sharing the last days of Hitler and his henchmen.

title: LIFESURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Operating earnings...C-Net income

title: Free-Agent Dispute Goes to Court Today
description: With the possibility of a negotiating development in the background, and with Commissioner Bowie Kuhn expected to be in the foreground, baseball's club owners and players take their labor dispute to United States District Court in Rochester today.

title: 'Ambitious' Campaign Set For Gordon's Dry Gin
description: In an effort to get a bigger piece of the imported gin market, Renfield Importers is about to run what it describes as ''one of the most exciting and ambitious advertising campaigns ever embarked upon by a manufacturer of spirits'' for its Gordon's Dry Gin. Grey Advertising is the font of the excitement.

title: 7 PAN AM EXECUTIVES LOSE JOBS
description: Pan American World Airways, suffering the severest losses in its history, let go seven of its 42 vice presidents yesterday in a move to improve efficiency, company sources disclosed. Three other vicepresidential slots were vacated by voluntary departures.

title: CONFEREES TIGHTEN RULES THAT RESTRICT MEDICAID ABORTIONS
description: House and Senate conferees tonight ratified the most stringent restrictions ever placed on Medicaid abortions after rejecting a measure passed by the House that would have forbidden medical insurance payments for abortions for Federal employees..

title: A Short Cut to Coal Power
description: By converting its Salem Harbor, Mass., generating plant to coal, New England Power could save both money and imported oil. But like many other electric utilities, the company is hard pressed to raise the needed capital. Now, thanks to an innovative financing plan, one that could be applied to dozens of other plant conversions, New England Power may get its wish.

title: MAKERS OF MATERIALS FOR SEMICONDUCTORS HURT BY SLOW SALES
description: High inventories and soft sales are squeezing the suppliers of materials used by the semiconductor industry.

title: LASER BEAM WEAPON FAILS IN TEST TO DESTROY AN AIR-TO-AIR MISSILE
description: The Air Force failed in its first attempt to shoot down an air-to-air missile with a high-intensity laser beam weapon fired from a modified Boeing 707 jetliner, a spokesman for the Air Force Systems Command said today.

title: IN BROOKLYN, FANS DESIGN A COMEBACK FOR DODGERS
description: One of the most wistful of Brooklyn dreams - the return of the borough's baseball Dodgers to their home turf - received a daylong elaboration in parties and proclamations yesterday.

title: TV: LILLI PALMER AS SARAH BERNHARDT
description: ''Sarah in America,'' part of the ''Kennedy Center Tonight'' series on public television, stars Lilli Palmer as the French actress Sarah Bernhardt. The Divine Sarah was, according to all accounts, tempestuous, exotic, vibrant, irresistible and thoroughly impossible. Unfortunately, this television portrait, which can be seen this evening, is merely impossible.

title: House Unit Acts to Trim Social Security Benefits
description: A measure to eliminate the $255 death benefit now paid to Social Security recipients who have no surviving beneficiaries was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee, voting 11 to 6, in a step that it is estimated would save the system $200 million in the fiscal year 1982.

title: BLACK POLITICAL INFLUENCE IS LOWEST IN TWO DECADES
description: The political influence of blacks in America has fallen to its lowest level in two decades. Black leaders, confronting a popular Administration that is determined to cut the Government programs they hold dear, lack wholehearted support from liberal allies they once counted on.

title: WORTH THE LISTEN
description: Even sticklers for exhibitions being seen and not heard, ought to lend an ear to these: Musical Instrument, the Metropolitan Mu- seum.

title: The Region; Marriott to Build At Lake Minnewaska
description: The Marriott Corporation won permission from New York State to build a $78 million hotel and condominium development at Lake Minnewaska in Ulster County.

title: CITY'S GREENMARKETS GO INTO SIXTH SEASON
description: This Saturday formally marks the start of New York's sixth Greenmarket season, with the opening of the Union Square, East 67th Street and Gansevoort Street sites. The site at Queens Plaza opened last Saturday. Between June and December, New Yorkers will be able to shop at 16 outdoor markets for the fresh produce grown and trucked into the city by farmers.

title: OXYGEN LOST TO ORGANIC MATERIAL
description: Two hundred thousand freshwater fish have died in a lake here in what state environmental officials call the worst such incident in the metropolitan area in the last decade.

title: IN HEBRON, MEANNESS INVADES THE PLAYGROUNDS
description: Occupied West Bank - In this holy city, at the frontier of Arab-Jewish relations, meanness insinuates itself into life like the gritty dust that sifts in with the hot desert winds.

title: American in Britain Faces Charge Of Menacing Charles and Fiancee
description: An American living illegally in Britain was charged today with threatening to kill Prince Charles and his fiancee, Lady Diana Spencer, and with sending a dummy bomb to Queen Elizabeth.

title: Amnesty Group Reports On Mission to Vietnam
description: Amnesty International issued a report yesterday on a 1979 mission to Vietnam and a subsequent exchange of memorandums in which it urged Hanoi to close ''long-term re-education camps'' for thousands of prisoners still detained without formal charges or trials.

title: THEY TRAVEL IN SAME WINNER'S CIRCLE
description: James Washington says that Pleasant Colony will win the Belmont Stakes. He also says he has been pretty sure of it since the Preakness, but he became thoroughly convinced on Sunday afternoon. That's when the colt ''pinned me upside the wall and tried to crush my head. Just playing, you know. He's ready.''

title: Itel Loss Narrows
description: The Itel Corporation, which on Jan. 19 of this year filed for reorganization protection under Chapter 11 of of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, reported yesterday that its loss in 1980 narrowed to $62.1 million, from $443.3 million in 1979. The San Franciso-based financial-services concern and marketer of transportation equipment attributed the loss in the latest three months primarily to high interest expense and lower operating revenues from its continuing operations.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $61,000 or 2 cents a shr for the qr and $140,000 or 5 cents a shr for the 6 mos...C-Including $59,000 or 2 cents a shr from discontinued operations

title: SOVIET SAID TO SHIP TANKS TO NICARAGUA
description: The State Department said today that it had received unverified reports that Soviet T-55 tanks might have been shipped from Cuba to Nicaragua.

title: CALM HEUBLEIN AUCTION
description: Relative calm prevailed at the 13th annual Heublein auction of rare wines, held recently in New Orleans, and the level of prices appeared somewhat lower than in previous years. A four-bottle case of Burgundies from the 1865 vintage brought the highest price, $8,800, or $2,200 a bottle.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1981; The Economy
description: Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee began drawing up a new two-year tax relief bill in a challenge to the Reagan Administration. The committee's chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, indicated after a caucus of committee Democrats that they were preparing for a test of strength with the Administration on the House floor. The Democrats were said to be mapping a cut of 5 percent in the first year and a further 10 percent reduction in 1982. (Page A1.)

title: Inmates Allow a Search of Wing They Seized at Honolulu Prison
description: About 300 inmates took over a cellblock of the overcrowded Oahu Community Correctional Center today, but they later agreed to withdraw so riot-equipped guards could search for contraband, officials said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Affiliated Bankshares of Colorado Inc. said it had completed the acquisition of six banks in western Colorado for $30 million.

title: Betty-Jean Hagen Offers Three Violin Concertos
description: Most soloists come to recitals armed with an accompanist. For her Sunday afternoon of violin music at the 92d Street Y, Betty-Jean Hagen brought an entire chamber orchestra.

title: MEXICO CUTS OIL PRICES BY $4 A BARREL
description: Mexico slashed its crude oil prices by $4 a barrel yesterday, the first major oil producer to do so since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries froze prices last week in Geneva in the face of weakening worldwide oil demand.

title: Pirates 16, Cubs 3
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - Steve Nicosia went 4-for-5, driving in four runs, and Dave Parker, Bill Madlock and Mike Easler had three runs batted in apiece to highlight a 19-hit attack for Pittsburgh in a game played despite a strike by Three River Stadium personnel.

title: Belmont List Now Seen at 10
description: After a series of defections in recent days, the probable field for Saturday's Belmont Stakes rose from nine starters to 10 yesterday when Stage Door Key was named to take part in this mile-and-a-half finale to the Triple Crown series.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Head of Munsingwear Becomes Chairman, Too
description: Raymond F. Good, 52, president and chief executive officer of Munsingwear Inc., has been appointed to the additional post of chairman, effective June 30. He will succeed A. Byron Reed, who will retire at the age of 65.

title: FLORIO SAYS NATION'S ATTENTION WILL FOCUS ON JERSEY'S ELECTION
description: When it was clear tonight that he was going to be the Democratic nominee for Governor of New Jersey, James J. Florio wrote out a statement that reflected the direction his campaign in the fall would take.

title: NEW PLANS TO CUT MEDICAID AND WELFARE RAISE ALARMS
description: House and Senate committees have quietly approved proposals that would make sweeping cutbacks in welfare and health care for the poor, changing 15-year-old formulas by which these programs have been financed.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER MORTGAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $24,373 extraordinary income

title: IDEA OF HELP FOR THRIFT UNITS GAINS BACKING
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board and representatives of the savings industry today backed the general concept of a recent Treasury proposal to provide letters of credit to ailing thrift institutions to bolster their net worth.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp. is offering 775,000 units of common stock and warrants at $21.50 a unit, to be sold through a Thomson McKinnon group.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock spli effected in the form of a 50 percent stock divd on Nov 21, 1980

title: Iran Reportedly Arrests Member of Bani-Sadr's Staff
description: Authorities in Iran have arrested a member of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr's staff and 15 others on counterrevolutionary charges, Tehran radio reported today.

title: G.M. AND FORD PRESS U.A.W. ON LABOR COSTS
description: Linked to what was until recently an immensely profitable industry, the United Automobile Workers union has been one of the nation's leaders in winning wages and benefits for its members.

title: THEY TRAVEL IN THE SAME WINNER'S CIRCLES
description: When T.M. Evans talks, people listen. In 50 years of yelling ''buy'' and ''sell,'' the 70-year-old financier has taken over at least 80 companies while amassing a fortune of $100 million and a reputation for getting almost anything he wants. But on Saturday, it will be up to a floppy-eared colt to win Evans a place in history.

title: UTILITY ASKS RECORD RISE FOR RATES IN CONNECTICUT
description: Northeast Utilities announced today that it would seek a record $239 million increase in electricity and natural gas rates in Connecticut.

title: Most Large Banks Cut Prime to 20%
description: Most of the nation's largest banks swung into line yesterday on a half-point cut in the prime rate, to 20 percent, amid uncertainty over the trend of interest rates.

title: PROSECUTION IN OPERA MURDER TRIAL CALLS MEDICAL TESTIMONY A 'DETOUR'
description: The prosecution in the trial of Craig S. Crimmins, a former stagehand at the Metropolitan Opera House accused of murdering a musician there, told the jury yesterday that the defense testimony by psychiatrists and psychologists about Mr. Crimmins's intelligence and ability to make decisions had been ''a frolic and a detour to take your mind off the basic question and the basic issues in this case.''

title: Farm Prices Again Fall 0.4%
description: High interest rates and a slowdown in export sales of United States crops combined to depress farm prices by fourth-tenths of 1 percent in May, according to the Department of Agriculture.

title: NON-CATHOLIC JAMES I
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: A DRAMA IN COURT, 'THE MEANING OF WORDS'
description: Abortion, as politicians never cease to remind us, is an issue that arouses unduly hot passions. That's why one must admire the selfcontrol of Mark Eichman, a writer who has tackled the subject with absolute cool-headedness in a play called ''As to the Meaning of Words.'' This courtroom drama, now running at the American Theater of Actors, has no particular ax to grind; both sides get equal say. The audience hears the arguments - indeed, the audience sits in the figurative jury box of Gerard P. Bourcier's imposing set - and then comes to its own conclusions.

title: 2D PROPOSED COAL PACT IS VIEWED WITH FAVOR AS MINERS' VOTE NEARS
description: The tentative agreement to end the coal strike was given a generally respectful, if not enthusiastic, hearing here today by nearly 500 local officers of the United Mine Workers' largest and most militant district.

title: Dutch Parliament Ends a Treaty On Cultural Ties to South Africa
description: The Dutch Parliament gave final approval today to a measure ending a 30-year cultural treaty with South Africa because of that country's policy of apartheid, or racial separation.

title: MOSCOW IS PUBLICIZING A HARD-LINE POLISH STATEMENT
description: The Soviet press, in giving prominent attention to a document drawn up by Polish Communists in Katowice, has suggested Kremlin support for the thesis that the Polish party is in the grips of ''revisionism and opportunism'' and incapable of controlling events.

title: POP: 'DEEPSPACE HOME'
description: ''DEEPSPACE HOME'' is James T. Anderson's musical tribute to the L-5 Society, an organization that looks to the future colonization of space. Monday's premiere at St. Peter's Church showed a work directed more earthward than toward the stars - its parts forming a common denominator of Indian, black American, African, rock and European styles.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's attempts to improve relations with Argentina come when there are few tangible benefits for the United States. The intangible ones are difficult to measure.

title: PHILLIES SUBDUE METS, 9-7
description: The Mets could not keep Pete Rose off base four of the five times he batted tonight, and that failure helped the Philadelphia Phillies win, 9-7.

title: Witness Denies Charge Davis Was to Receive Mansion
description: The National Football League tried to prove in court today that a Beverly Hills mansion was part of the lure for Al Davis to bring his Oakland Raiders to Los Angeles.

title: Communication Bill Blocked
description: The Senate Commerce Committee succeeded today in blocking referral to the Judiciary Committee of a bill designed to spur competition in the international communications field.

title: 3 Ford Fund Aides Sue On Age Discrimination
description: Three officials of the Ford Foundation who were recently told their contracts would not be renewed filed a complaint yesterday with the Federal Equal Employment Opportunities Commission.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
description: Results for the latest period reflect an unspecified adjustment for LIFO accounting

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS'S KEY TO SUCCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: president of the Los Angeles Newspaper Guild and a labor militant who was convicted of attempting to overthrow the Government, died here May 20. He was 77 years old.; ----; Case Tested Conspiracy Act
description: Philip (Slim) Connelly was Los Angeles editor of a West Coast Communist newspaper, The People's World, when he was arrested and jailed in July 1951 in a roundup of Communist Party leaders in California. After a six-month trial, in 1952 he and 13 other men and women were found guilty of having violated the Smith Act of 1940, which made it a crime to conspire to teach or advocate the overthrow of the Government by force.

title: HARVESTER LOSS SEEN UNTIL EARLY IN 1982
description: The best that the International Harvester Company can hope for this fiscal year is to break even, according to a report by the consulting firm of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1981
description: International Unity against Libyan interventionism was proposed by the Reagan Administration, which said it would support all African countries that want to resist such activities. A high State Department official said that Libya was training guerrillas and terrorists from many countries. (Page A1, Column 4.) The sale of advanced jets to Venezuela will soon be approved by President Reagan, according to Administration officials. The step would reverse longstanding American policy against the introduction of sophisticated arms in Latin America. The officials said that the decision to sell a limited number of F-16 fighters had been endorsed by senior officials at both the State and Defense Departments. (A1:5.)

title: U.S. PLEDGES TO AID COUNTRIES IN AFRICA THAT RESIST LIBYANS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the United States would support all African nations that want to resist ''interventionism'' from Libya.

title: ALLIED MAINTENANCE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After $721,000 extraordinary charge related to the settlement of civil antitrust litigation

title: 2 AIRLINE ACCOUNTS SHIFTED
description: BOZELL & JACOBS won the $45 million American Airlines account yesterday after Doyle Dane Bernbach, the carrier's agency for 20 years, dropped out of the running and came up with the $35 million Pan American World Airways account.

title: ISRAELI JETS RAZE GUERRILLA CENTER IN LEBANON RAID
description: Israel struck at a Palestinian target in Lebanon today in another of the air raids it has resumed since the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, left for Washington for consultations on his mission to ease tensions between Israel and Syria.

title: E.E.C.-Japan Talks Snagged
description: The European Economic Community's top trade negotiator said today that talks with Japanese officials had amounted to ''pretty much near zero,'' and urged the 10 Common Market countries to take new action to put pressure on Japan to moderate exports.

title: FOOD PROCESSORS: EVALUATING THE BIG 2
description: WHEN the dispute broke into public view in advertisements and news stories, it had all the passion of a marriage gone sour. And that, of course, is precisely what it was.

title: HOME SALES FELL 13.5% IN APRIL
description: Sales of new single-family houses plunged 13.5 percent in April, the biggest drop in a year, as rising mortgage interest rates continued to plague the housing industry, the Federal Government reported today.

title: A CULINARY SAMPLER OF A BOSTON LANDMARK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sheryl Julian is food editor of The Boston Phoenix. By SHERYL JULIAN BOSTON FANEUIL HALL MARKETPLACE in downtown Boston has more than one million people passing through its stalls and shops each month, and during the lunch hours, especially on weekends, it feels as though all million visitors are there at once.

title: THE REFUGEE EXPERIENCE
description: The driver of the limousine that recently took me home from an evening meeting in New Jersey was a political refugee from Spain, a Basque physician. When not chauffeuring he was cramming for examinations to qualify for medical practice in the United States.

title: The Region; Defendant Denies Threatening Reagan
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - Edward M. Richardson, accused of threatening to ''bring to completion Hinckley's reality,'' pleaded not guilty to charges of threatening the life of President Reagan. He was arrested April 6 in New York, a week after John W. Hinckley Jr. was charged with shooting the President in Washington.

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $116,000 for the qr and $750,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $3,375,000 income from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the disposition of a nursing home in Novemb 1980; the company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: STATE BANKS FAVOR PAYING HIGHER RATES
description: Even the smallest bankers in New York State have come around to the conclusion, long held by the state's biggest bankers, that for their own sake they must begin paying higher interest rates to consumers.

title: Around the nation; Arms Ship Under Tow After Oil Fuel Fire
description: The ammunition ship Nitro was under tow and bound for a Cretan port today after a fuel oil fire that injured six sailors, the Navy said.

title: U.S. ROLE IN BUILDING UP IN CITY
description: A GOAL of city government in New York is to encourage economic development in designated areas outside Manhattan. Downtown Jamaica in Queens is one of them, and elected officials have their hats in the air over progress toward construction of what will be the largest office building in Queens, on Jamaica Avenue at Parsons Boulevard near the landmark building that formerly housed the First Reformed Church of Jamaica.

description: Results for the latest periods include a writedown of properties and investments of $1,589,000

title: No Headline
description: Tito Steiner of Brigham Young, who won the decathlon in 1977 and 1979, won it again Wednesday with 8,279 points for the 10 events. Mark Anderson of U.C.L.A., the 1980 champion, was second with 8,171. Both bettered the collegiate record of 8,124 set by Steiner, an Argentine, in 1979.

title: Mrs. King Skips Wimbledon
description: Billie Jean King, who has won a record 20 Wimbledon tennis titles, will not play in the tournament starting June 22, Fred Hoyles, the Wimbledon referee, confirmed today. Her surprising entry in next week's Surrey grass tournament in Surbiton, England, had aroused speculation that she would compete at Wimbledon.

title: Brinks Offers a Reward Of $100,000 in Killing
description: Brinks Inc. announced a $100,000 reward yesterday for information leading to the arrest and conviction of robbers responsible for what it called the ''senseless assassination'' of one armored-car guard Tuesday and the wounding of another in the Bronx.

title: UGANDA LTD.
description: I was struck the other day by a comment made to me in Uganda by a black Ugandan: ''If we were allowed to vote on whether or not to invite the British back to run Uganda, there would not be enough boxes in the country to contain the 'yes' votes.''

description: A study comparing the health of smokers who have stopped smoking and smokers who continue provides new evidence that kicking the cigarette habit will cut in half the risk of dying of heart disease.

OFFICER KILLS MAN HOLDING TOY GUN
description: An off-duty New York City police lieutenant shot and killed a man on a South Bronx street yesterday. The police said the man had pointed a gun at the lieutenant that proved to be a toy.

title: Islanders Sign 2 Swedes
description: The Islanders have signed two Swedish players, Anders Kallur, a forward who has been with them two years, and Tomas Jonsson, a defenseman who has not played for them, to multiyear contracts.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly reported a government action to reduce money available to banks and incorrectly stated the decline in the money supply for the latest reporting week. The Treasury Department acted on Monday to reduce deposits at several commercial banks. The money supply fell by $1.2 billion in the week ended May 20.

title: LOUIS E. ROGERS
description: Louis E. Rogers, former president of the Fontainebleau Hotel in Miami Beach, died Monday in Clearwater, Fla. He was 52 years old and had suffered from diabetes for several years.

title: Soviet Planner Reports Abortions Slightly Exceed Births Each Year
description: There are slightly more abortions than births in the Soviet Union every year, a Government planner said today.

title: REAGAN SEEKS TO DELAY ACTION ON TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: The Reagan Administration assured Congress today that it fully supported tuition tax credits for parents of students in private schools, but it urged that such legislation be delayed until action is completed on President Reagan's proposed budget cuts and tax reductions.

title: Bridge: A Defender and a Declarer Excel, and on the Same Deal
description: Good plays by a defender are rather uncommon and by a declarer are equally so. To find both, as in the diagramed deal, from a recent rubber bridge game at the Regency Whist Club, 15 East 67th Street, Manhattan, is a rare pleasure.

description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Orlando Sanchez tripled to open the 11th inning and scored on Tommy Herr's single.

title: The Region
description: A Roman Catholic priest called for greater use of the death penalty as an estimated 2,000 police officers and firefighters paid their last respects yesterday to a Darien policeman shot to death Sunday by a burglar.

title: Foreign Airlines Seek Fare Rises
description: Fifty-two international airlines, predominantly from Europe, Asia and Africa, agreed today to seek permission from their governments for 5 percent passenger fare increases on most international routes.

title: AFRICAN POLICY: NEW DIRECTION
description: As the State Department tries to put together the jigsaw puzzle that would become a policy on southern Africa, the key officials see nothing but pieces that do not fit: South African politics and strength, the struggle for independence in South-West Africa, the civil war in Angola and American domestic politics.

title: CONNORS BOWS TO CLERC IN 5 SETS
description: An umpire overruled a linesman at a critical moment, and the replayed point sent Jimmy Connors into a tailspin from which he could not recover today.

title: May O' Donnell Dancers At the Public June 10-14
description: The May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company will appear at New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater from Wednesday to June 14 in a program of modern-dance pieces that spans 38 years of the choreographer's career.

title: DESIGNER FURNITURE ON PERMANENT SALE
description: MUCH of the designer furniture available is usually sold in showrooms of furniture importers to which only designers and architects normally have access. This means that only when these concerns have their annual or twice-yearly warehouse sales can people who are not in the design trade have the possibility of buying a discontinued sample or a slightly damaged piece at a reduced price - and without waiting for a longterm deliveries.

title: ITALY IS EXPLORING SINDONA LINK IN MASONIC SCANDAL
description: Magistrates in Milan, Florence and Rome as well as parliamentary commissions are continuing to interrogate witnesses and sift through trunkfuls of documents in an attempt to get to the bottom of the affairs of Licio Gelli, the grandmaster of an illegally secret Masonic lodge.

title: SATURDAY REVIEW'S NEW EDITOR
description: Stephen B. Shepard, national affairs editor of Newsweek, has been named editor of the Saturday Review magazine, replacing the departing Carll Tucker. Mr. Tucker, who is 29 years old, announced last month that he was resigning July 1 because he found the role of employee foreign to his nature. He had owned the literary magazine, along with some other investors, until he sold it a year ago to Macro Communications Inc.

title: A PRESIDENTIAL ASSAULT ON THE ARTS
description: To the Editor:

title: By Sports of The Times; Dodgers and More Nicknames
description: FONDLY, thoughtfully, some of the old Dodgers came back to Brooklyn, but one of them wuz robbed. Carl Erskine, Russ Meyer and Sandy Amoros of the 1955 World Series champions were among those at various festivities Tuesday in Brooklyn to promote a politician's dream and an author's novel about returning the Dodgers to the Borough of Churches. But somebody forgot to inform two holdup men, who put a gun in Russ Meyer's face in the darkness before yesterday's dawn. They took his cash, his watch and, worse, much worse, his two World Series rings.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 4, 1981
description: International France's minimum wage was raised by 10 percent and pension benefits were increased sharply by the new Socialist Government, which said that banks, oil companies and the rich would face higher taxes next year to help finance the programs. In their first major policy announcements, the Socialists also said they were abolishing some controversial authoritarian security practices that had been criticized by non-Gaullists. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Francois Mitterrand believes that the nations of the world are not making progress toward military or economy security, but he is philosophical about it. In his first interview since his election as President of France, he said that he favored a balance of power with Soviet forces in Europe and that he planned to nationalize some French industries. (A1:1.)

title: Veterans Unit in Senate Votes Limits on Benefits
description: The Senate Veterans Affairs Committee voted today to limit burial and dental benefits for veterans to meet Congressional budget-cutting goals.

title: Charter to Close Dayton Press Unit
description: The Charter Company, a diversified petroleum, broadcasting and insurance concern, said it would close Dayton Press Inc., its unprofitable printing unit, and take a one-time, pretax write-off of about $41 million in the second quarter.

title: Angels 17, Blue Jays 6
description: TORONTO (UPI) - California pounded five Toronto pitchers for 19 hits, including five by Rick Burleson.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH FRANCOIS MITTERRAND
description: Following are excerpts from an interview Monday with President Francois Mitterrand by James Reston, as translated by the French Government and reviewed by Mr. Mitterrand for publication:

title: Dome Petroleum Rig
description: British Shipbuilders Ltd. said today that its Cammell Laird Shipbuilders Ltd., Birkenhead, subsidiary would build a $125 million semisubmersible drilling rig for Dome Petroleum Ltd. The rig, which will be capable of drilling in water up to 3,000 feet deep, will be completed by 1983, the statement added.

title: Martin Is Charged With Assault
description: Manager Billy Martin of the Oakland A's was charged in Ontario Provincial Court today with common assault in connection with his on-field bumping of the umpire Terry Cooney in a game here against the Blue Jays last Friday night.

title: The U.N. Today; June 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Intergovernmental Committee on Science and Technology for Develop- ment - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PLEASANT COLONY TURNS ON SPEED IN FINAL WORKOUT
description: Pleasant Colony yesterday strengthened his status as the certain favorite for Saturday's Belmont Stakes by whistling through his final workout for the race and then returning to the stable in excellent condition. He breezed half a mile on the wet main track at Belmont Park in 46 1/5 seconds and galloped out an extra eighth of a mile for a final clocking of 59 1/5.

title: Fluor Earnings Rise
description: The Fluor Corporation reported yesterday that earnings for the second quarter, ended April 30, rose to $37.5 million, or 77 cents a share, from $36 million, or 75 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Sales rose 27.3 percent, to $1.4 billion from $1.1 billion.

title: MEAD SAYS IMPACT OF SUIT IS EXAGGERATED
description: The Mead Corporation said yesterday that the potential effect of the Supreme Court's recent announcement in the long-running corrugated-container antitrust case had been misrepresented in news reports.

title: FLORIO AND KEAN AGREE TAXES ARE KEY ISSUE
description: The winners of New Jersey's primary election for Governor of New Jersey agreed yesterday that their disagreement over whether there should be a state tax cut would be the major issue in the fall campaign.

title: JURY STARTS DELIBERATIONS IN BLANTON EXTORTION TRIAL
description: A Federal court jury of seven women and five men deliberated today but reached no verdict in the corrupt practices trial of former Gov. Ray Blanton and two of his top assistants.

title: ISRAELI SHIPS SHELL PALESTINIAN BASE IN NORTH LEBANON
description: Israel struck again at Palestinian guerrilla positions in Lebanon today as its gunboats bombarded a camp in the far north more than 100 miles from the Israeli border.

title: Summing Primed to Duplicate Earlier Victory Over Campo's Colt
description: In Barn 59 at Belmont Park, there is a horse who can, if history repeats, beat Pleasant Colony Saturday and deprive him of a Triple Crown.

title: A MANSION CEILING RESTORED
description: PEOPLE who had worked at the French Embassy's cultural services in Manhattan for as long as 20 years were surprised when Jacqueline d'Amecourt, a professional art restorer, first explained what she intended to do. Then they looked up, possibly for the first time. ''Ceiling?'' they asked. ''What ceiling?''

title: ABBIE HOFFMAN IN JOB RELEASE PLAN
description: Abbie Hoffman, a convicted drug seller and former Yippie leader, has been transferred to a minimum-security state prison in Manhattan to participate in a work-release program, state prison officials announced today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Beatrice Foods Co., Nashville, has elected to its board Angelo R. Arena, president and chief executive officer of Marshall Field & Company, and Goff Smith, chairman of Amsted Industries.

title: Campbell, in Reverse, Says He Won't Press Demands
description: Earl Campbell, who threatened to sit out the 1981 season unless his contract was renegotiated, says he will report to the Houston Oilers' training camp next month with neither bitterness nor a raise.

title: At Least 40 in Denver Area Are Injured by Tornadoes
description: A powerful storm system spawned a dozen or more tornadoes in the Denver area today, injuring at least 40 persons. Many of the victims were in the path of a twister that smashed through part of Denver and three suburbs, severely damaging a suburban shopping center, officials said.

title: GEORGE O. SMITH, 70, SCIENCE-FICTION WRITER AND AN ENGINEER, DIES
description: George O. Smith, a science-fiction writer and electronics engineer, died May 27 at his home in Rumford, N. J. He was 70 years old. At the 1980 world science-fiction convention, Mr. Smith was given the first ''Fandom Award'' for his contribution to the genre. Mr. Smith's first published story appeared in Astounding Science Fiction in 1942.

title: Japan Home Costs Rise
description: The average price of a new home in the three main metropolitan areas of Japan shot up 23 percent last year, to $139,000, the Urban Development Association, a private real estate group, said today. An association official also said condominiums in the metropolitan areas of Tokyo, Osaka and Nagoya sold at an average price of $102,500, up 22 percent from 1979.

title: OFFICER REPORTEDLY KEPT JOB DESPITE CONTACT WITH SOVIET
description: The Air Force permitted Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke to continue serving on a Titan nuclear missile crew for five months after learning that he had allegedly violated regulations by visiting the Soviet Embassy here, according to military officers.

title: ARGENTINE DEVALUATION FAILS TO STILL CRITICS
description: Argentina's newest military Government is scrambling to keep the economic policies that were initiated by the previous regime from unraveling, amid mounting criticism.

title: WALKER-SCOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Business Digest; THURSDAY, JUNE 4, 1981; The Economy
description: House Ways and Means Committee Democrats agreed on the broad outlines of a two-year tax-relief bill. The White House promptly mounted a counteroffensive organized around a three-year tax bill as both sides jockeyed for support of conservative Southern Democrats. The Democratic proposal would cut tax rates by 5 percent in 1981 and 10 percent more in 1982. (Page A1.)

title: RIGHTISTS AND LEFTISTS ARE ARRESTED
description: Major department stores and office buildings in central Athens were gutted by firebombs today, bringing the city center to a standstill and causing millions of dollars in damage. The incidents were similar to the destruction of two large stores last Christmas.

title: STAIRS AND BRIDGES FOR THE ADVENTUROUS
description: TO some people, there's nothing to a space unless there's somewhere else to go - upstairs, downstairs, around or under. Changing levels is one of their pleasures. Although few city apartments or lofts lend themselves to this kind of design exhilaration, the exceptions offer both spatial solutions and a sense of drama.

title: THE HIGH COURT'S ROLE: MANY ISSUES, FEW DECISIONS
description: In the current public debate over whether Congress should restrict the Supreme Court's jurisdiction, the Court is often portrayed as an assertive, if not an aggressive, body, reaching out to bring the most sensitive disputes of the day under the cloak of judicial review.

title: ROSTENKOWSKI: TAX PRAGMATIST
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski is a big, broad-shouldered, gregarious politician from the school of Chicago's late Mayor Richard J. Daley. In his youth, he had a chance to play big league baseball but chose politics instead. Like most athletes and politicians, he is often fired by the will to win, but never more than now.

description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. CODD TO RUN ON LIBERAL SLATE
description: Mary T. Codd accepted the Liberal Party's designaton for Mayor of New York City yesterday, charging that Mayor Koch had ''brought the bosses back to City Hall.''

title: The Region; 30 Felled by Fumes In an Aerosol Plant
description: Thirty workers were hospitalized and more than 200 others were forced to leave an aerosol plant here because of the spread of noxious fumes from a paint remover.

title: Bond Prices in Modest Advance; 15-Day Bills Yield 18.48%
description: The credit markets stabilized in quiet trading yesterday after two days of volatility. At the close, short-term rates were basically unchanged, while bond prices showed small gains for the first time this week.

title: No Headline
description: Rudolf Skvortsov, a Soviet consul general in Poznan, died from self-inflicted gunshot wounds last night.

title: NEW FIXTURE IN THE HOME: THE COMPUTER
description: HE era of the electronic cottage is dawning. So says the author Alvin Toffler, who wrote ''The Third Wave'' on his home computer in Manhattan. So say computer manufacturers, who have sold nearly a million personal computers to families, professional people and educators. The $200 to $3,000 home computer is being marketed as a video game that can also teach foreign languages and balance a checkbook. But this is just sugar coating, intended to lure the consumer into the intellectually stimulating world of computers, say experts.

title: MANY HODGKIN'S VICTIMS FOUND ABLE TO HAVE NORMAL CHILDBIRTH
description: Many young women apparently retain the ability to have normal children after treatment with heavy doses of radiation or drugs for the form of cancer called Hodgkin's disease, according to a report from Stanford University Medical Center.

title: 2 INJURED AS SOUTH AFRICAN POLICE BREAK UP PROTEST
description: Policemen trying to break up a student demonstration today fired tear gas and attacked the students with clubs and whips, witnesses said. At least 2 protesters were hospitalized and 59 were arrested.

title: COLUMBIA DEDICATES NEW SUITES AND TOWN HOUSES FOR STUDENTS
description: Columbia University dedicated its new East Campus student residence complex yesterday, thereby achieving a milestone in its campaign to improve the quality of student life. The complex has rooms for 651 students in apartment-like suites and town houses.

title: BOOM IN SUN BELT BYPASSES OLDER INDUSTRIAL TOWNS IN SOUTH
description: The economic story in this small rural Southern town is similar to that in the old industrial cities of the North. Double-digit unemployment has persisted so long that it has become a way of life. The opening of new businesses has hardly matched closings. Uncertainty abounds.

A COMPUTER GLOSSARY
description: C.P.U. Stands for central processing unit, the brains of the computer. Receives information, makes calculations, comparisons, alterations and transmits the results. Memory There are two basic types of memory: ''Read only memory'' (ROM) refers to knowledge permanently built into a computer. ''Random access memory'' (RAM) refers to the computer's capacity to store information while it is turned on. If the information is to be reviewed at a later time, it must be transferred to ''mass storage'' (see below); otherwise, the information will be lost when the computer is turned off.

title: 12 KOCH CRIMINAL-REFORM CHANGES BACKED AND 10 DISAPPROVED BY BAR
description: A special committee of the New York State Bar Association said yesterday that it had approved 12 and disapproved 10 of Mayor Koch's 33 legislative proposals to reform the criminal-justice system. It did not make recommendations on the 11 others.

title: The Region; Lower Utility Rates Offered to Concerns
description: ALBANY (UPI) - The State Public Service Commission approved reduced electricity rates for businesses that decide to locate in six economically distressed areas of Brooklyn or the South Bronx.

title: WESTERN BEEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Carson Pirie Sets Plan to Reduce Debt
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago department store chain, said it planned to sell a department store, two resorts and some common stock to reduce debt incurred from the acquisition of Dobbs Houses Inc. last year.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Berry Is Coach Of Canadiens
description: Bob Berry, who resigned last month as coach of the Los Angeles Kings after a contract dispute, became coach of the Montreal Canadiens today.

title: HARTFORD ASSEMBLY GOES HOME AFTER LONG DISPUTE OVER TAXES
description: The General Assembly this evening ended a legislative session marked by protracted wrangling over taxes and spending. It adjourned with the assessment of Gov. William A. O'Neill that ''we have made the best of a no-win situation.''

title: A NEW POLICY ON AID FOR CARIBBEAN WINS REAGAN'S APPROVAL
