description: President Reagan has approved a new policy for the Caribbean and Central America that calls for increased economic and military assistance to combat poverty and counter what the Administration says is Cuban and Soviet subversion.

title: The City; Visiting Ex-Dodger Held Up on Street
description: Russ Meyer, a pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1950's who came back to the city to help promote the return of major league baseball to Brooklyn, was held up at gunpoint and robbed of, among other valuables, the two rings he won for his appearances in the 1953 and 1955 World Series.

title: A COURSE ABOUT CO-OPS
description: A six-week course, ''For Members of Co-op Boards and Condo Associations: Functioning As An Effective Member'' will be offered at the New York University midtown center, 11 West 42d Street, starting Monday evening.

title: EXPERT TESTIMONY
description: To the Editor:

title: Counts Against Sears Dismissed
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a 13-count indictment against Sears, Roebuck & Company after accusing a Government prosecutor of misconduct.

title: MITTERRAND AT ELYSEE: POET AND PRACTITIONER
description: Francois Mitterrand is the first Socialist President of the French Fifth Republic, and he seems perfectly cast for that particular role. In American eyes, he looks like a solid muscular French peasant called Frank, who has just taken over Elysee Palace. After the imperialist de Gaulle and the elegant Mr. Giscard d'Estaing who preceded him, the new President seems vaguely out of place in his plain blue Sunday suit, sitting somewhat uncomfortably on a green cut-velvet couch in the palace Gold Room.

title: Carter Hawley Sees Real Estate Gains
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. said after its annual meeting in Los Angeles that it expects to gross between $58 million and $70 million this year from the sale of real estate in Los Angeles and Chicago.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A BRIDGE KNOWN AS RAMAZ SCHOOL
description: THERE is a double challenge to designing a school building in Manhattan. It is difficult enough any place to make an environment that will interest and excite children, but in the middle of New York, where building costs are high and construction sites are tightly squeezed between every which kind of other building, the challenges are enough to frighten off almost any architect. Could that be the reason that so few talented architects have ever had anything to do with the design of school buildings?

title: Red Norvo at Michael's Pub
description: The xylophonist Red Norvo, who played with the Paul Whiteman Orchestra in the 1930's and led his own trio in the 1950's, will begin a four-week engagement next Tuesday at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street. Mr. Norvo will be backed by Tal Farlow, the guitarist, and the bass fiddler Steve Novasel. Performances will be Tuesdays through Saturdays at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. There is a $10 minimum for food or drinks, but no cover charge. Reservations: 758-2272.

title: PIANIST: MICHAEL MAY
description: A PIANO recital that features Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik,'' the finale to Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and Mendelssohn's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' music is obviously going to be a bit out of the ordinary. Such transcriptions of orchestral works were standard fare in the 19th century, but they turn up on recital programs infrequently nowadays.

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH THE COUNTRY GARDENER
description: Annuals For quick display in patio tubs, window boxes and borders near the house, rely on seedlings rather than starting from seed this late. Remove first flowers from petunias, zinnias, marigolds, etc., to encourage branching; use a weak dilution of water-soluble fertilizer to spur root growth. Snap off old geranium flowers promptly to prevent fungus diseases. Check lantana and fuchsia frequently for white fly and control with synthetic pyrethrum sprays available in readyto-use dispensers.

title: TAKING OVER AN ELDERLY PARENT'S HOUSEHOLD
description: SOMETIMES it happens suddenly: an accident, a heart attack, a stroke. Sometimes it's the consequences of gradual aging. The result is often the same. When an elderly parent is no longer selfsufficient, an adult child is called upon to step in and take over the running of the household.

title: Indians 4, Red Sox 1
description: CLEVELAND (AP) - Toby Harrah knocked in three runs with two homers and scored three runs to lead Cleveland.

title: METS DEFEAT PHILS, 6-2
description: Greg Harris, making only his fourth major league start, pitched two-hit ball for seven innings, then Pete Falcone and Neil Allen finished in relief as the Mets beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-2, tonight in Veterans Stadium.

title: Burlington Northern Seeks to Cut Lines
description: Burlington Northern Inc., the railroad and natural resources concern based in St. Paul, announced that its railroad unit would file with the Interstate Commerce Commission later this month for abandonment of about 100 branch lines within the next three years.

title: NOTABLE TURNOUT FOR ANGIER BIDDLE DUKE
description: NEIGHBORS gaped out their windows, possibly transported back to the times before income taxes. Tuesday night at Fifth Avenue and East 78th Street there was a traffic jam of limousines, the extra-long variety, and their elegant occupants well suited the Beaux Arts architecture of the James B. Duke House.

title: Last Holdouts Are Sought In Canadian Prison Riot
description: Troops and the police, with most of the rebellious inmates in a fire-ravaged prison in custody, began searching today for about 30 convicts who remained hidden in the burned-out buildings.

title: Equity's New President Reactivates Old Mines
description: When his promotion to president of Equity Gold Inc. of Louisville, Colo., was announced yesterday, Robert E. Brooks, 49, was down in one of his company's mines watching some of his employees pull out ore. ''Things are starting to happen again,'' he said, when he came to the surface and reached a telephone.

title: Gardening; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH THE CITY GARDENER
description: Street Tree Care Dog cleanup laws are still in force, but negligent owners may need a friendly reminder. One dog repellent that seems to work is blood meal combined with black pepper, placed in a ring along the outer edge of the pit. Restore soil for trees planted within six to eight years by mixing in several trowels of moistened sphagnum peat moss and a handful of limestone. Loosen and turn the soil to a depth of about six inches. Feed the trees with any water soluble all-purpose plant food following package directions precisely.

title: PAN AM TO SEEK WAGE CUTS
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it was cutting 112 management jobs and that it had asked all employees to make salary and wage concessions to stem the worst losses in the company's history.

title: Telefunken Software Stake
description: AEG-Telefunken, West Germany's giant electronics concern, said today that it would expand its computer software business by taking a 50 percent stake in the West German software concern G.E.I. -Gesellschaft fur Elektronische Informationsverarbeitung. Last month AEG formed its own software subsidiary, AEG Telefunken Software Technik. No financial details of the latest transaction were given.

title: Rangers 6, Twins 3
description: Bump Wills knocked in three runs with a triple and a single, and Rick Honeycutt won his fifth game in six decisions for Texas.

title: A's 8, White Sox 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Wayne Gross belted a three-run homer in the first inning and Brian Kingman pitched a seven-hitter to pace Oakland.

title: Going Out Guide
description: WEST SIDE

title: Notes on People; Anita Bryant May Move
description: When last heard from in September, Anita Bryant, having ended her marriage of 20 years, had left Miami and returned to her native Oklahoma.

title: EL SALVADOR'S PLIGHT TEARS A FAMOUS FAMILY APART
description: The extent to which El Salvador is a country at war with itself is reflected in the experiences of the Morales family, one of the best known in the capital city.

title: Pipes and Knives Seized After Prison Riot in Hawaii
description: Helmeted prison guards seized clubs, pipes and home-made knives in a shakedown today of the main cellblock that 300 inmates controlled in a 90-minute rampage.

title: TIPS ON BUYING
description: ERE are some buying tips gleaned from interviews with the following computer experts: Dr. Arthur Luehrmann, who helped develop the BASIC programming language; Dr. Ludwig Braun, a professor of engineering at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and Dr. Robert P. Taylor, associate professor of education at Columbia University's Teachers College. All three specialize in the educational applications of computers.

title: D. Gorton
description: ANXIOUS MOMENT AT AWARDS CEREMONY: President and Mrs. Reagan reacting as a boy fainted during an award presentation by Frank Sinatra yesterday in the Oval Office. The boy left the office and soon recovered. Yesterday was the first full work day for the President since the attempt on his life two months ago. Page B15.

title: The Program
description: VAL, James Conlon, conductor; Emanuel Ax, pianists; John Aler, tenor, and chorus conducted by Amy Kaiser. At Avery Fisher Hall. Piano Concerto No. 2 ...........................Chopin ''Faust'' Symphony ..............................Liszt By DONAL HENAHAN

title: Bonn Industry Orders Up
description: West German manufacturing industry incoming orders rose a provisional 7.2 percent, seasonally adjusted in value, in April, after falling 3.2 percent in March, according to Economics Ministry figures released today. A monetary value was not disclosed.

title: Bangladesh Military Court To Try 17 in Aborted Coup
description: A military court will try 17 army officers on charges of complicity in the unsuccessful coup in which President Ziaur Rahman was assassinated, Government officials announced today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. said it had acquired an 8.7 percent interest in Vulan Inc. for an undisclosed price.

title: Pattern of Profits At Wall St. Firms
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange doing business with the public had aggregate earnings of $342 million in this year's first quarter, the exchange reported yesterday. That was a sharp increase from $97 million in the first quarter of 1980 but a slight decline from $357 million in last year's fourth quarter.

title: COLUMBIA-TV: FROM FLOP TO TOP IN SERIES SALES TO NETWORKS
description: A year ago, when the three networks bought new television series for the 1980-81 season, Columbia Pictures Television could not sell one of its eight pilots to any network. That catastrophe - ''0 for 8'' in the baseball language used by dismayed Columbia executives - cost Larry White, president of Columbia-TV, his job.

title: Tigers 4, Brewers 1
description: DETROIT (AP) - Richie Hebner, who entered the game batting .206, had two hits, scored a run and drove in another to pace Detroit.

title: MUSIC: SCHUBERT-BARTOK
description: BARTOK was missing from the main concert Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall's Bartok-Schubert Festival Concerts series: Insufficient rehearsal time had necessitated the deletion of the one Bartok work on the program as well as another on the early-evening ''Perspective'' concert in the Recital Hall.

title: No Headline
description: NOT everyone is rooting for President Reagan's efforts in behalf of the economy. Take Jeffrey P. Feinman, president of Ventura Associates, for example. He says that his business is countercyclical, ''in exact disproportion to the economy.''

title: News of Music; KITCHEN PLANS 2 FUND-RAISING CONCERTS
description: LIKE many American cultural institutions these days, the Kitchen - New York's leading center for video art and experimental music - has a clouded future because of threatened budget cuts at the National Endowment for the Arts. But the Kitchen is persevering, not only with ambitious plans for its 1981-82 music season, but also with two nights of benefit concerts on June 14-15 at the Bond International Casino, in Times Square. The benefits will celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Kitchen.

title: DR. JOHN POWERS
description: Dr. John Powers, surgeon in chief emeritus at Bassett Hospital in Cooperstown, N.Y., died Tuesday at the hospital.

title: STAGE: 'THE BUTLER DID IT'
description: ALTHOUGH summer is still officially three weeks away, the summerstock season is already here. ''The Butler Did It,'' which opened at the Players Theater last night, is exactly the sort of show that one might expect to find in a musty New England playhouse during the dog days of August. Typical of such straw-hat trifles, this whodunit is flimsy, brisk and mindless; it isn't about to interfere with any theatergoer's digestion or sleep. Were there only a star's name above the title, the whole production could ship out for Maine tonight.

title: CATHOLICS TRY NATURAL FAMILY PLANNING
description: The Roman Catholic Church in the United States and abroad is vigorously promoting ''natural family planning'' a birth-control method that has been endorsed by Mother Teresa but whose actual effectiveness is still debated within the medical community.

title: KUHN'S ROLE ISSUE IN TALKS
description: Representatives of baseball's club owners and players spent a day in United States District Court today engaged in a tug-of-war over the status of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: The City; An Intruder Murders Woman in Bay Ridge
description: A 51-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Brooklyn apartment yesterday, apparently the victim of an intruder who broke in through a rear window and ransacked the first floor apartment.

title: N.Y.U. PLANNING TO OFFER A MASTER'S IN FOLK ART
description: The Museum of American Folk Art and New York University have announced that a master's degree program in folk art studies will be offered this fall by N.Y.U.'s department of art and art education. It is the first American university program of its kind.

title: Home Beat
description: IF only because more than five million people see it each weekday, the new set of ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America'' (seen locally from 7 to 9 A.M.) is bound to be, if not influential, at least noticeable as far as interior design is concerned. ''We've tried to give it a home look, and make it more contemporary, change it a bit from the country look it used to have,'' said John Braden, the designer of the elaborate set that allows the show's hosts, David Hartman and Joan Lunden, to work and be seen in different seating situations. The new set was not smoothly introduced: The specially designed leather chairs turned out to be uncomfortable for Mr. Hartman. The arms were promptly ripped off, and readjusted along with the seat. ''If the chairs are not comfortable, we look self-conscious,'' said Mr. Hartman, who is tall. Other areas included in the redesign were ''a single-chair confrontation'' area near the fireplace for serious interviews, and further afield, a sofa grouping for ''celebrity'' chitchat. There's also a metal spiral staircase, carpeted, leading to nowhere but meant to give the impression that the ''house'' has a second floor; a mock greenhouse addition to the living room that is full of seasonal plastic flowers; a grandfather clock; a small library with floor-to-ceiling shelves crammed with books and such tsatskes as a china zebra's head, what was once a Bible stand and is now topped with a wooden eagle, and a kitchen for Julia Child, still being decorated.

title: WHITE HOUSE WEIGHS VOTING RIGHTS SHIFT
description: The Reagan Administration is weighing proposals that Congress make major changes in sections of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, scheduled to expire next year.

title: Bank Venture By Europeans
description: The Dow Banking Corporation of Zurich and three other banks, Sundsvallbanken of Sweden, Bank of Helsinki Ltd. of Finland and Forretningsbanken A.S. of Norway, said today that they had started a joint venture bank called Dow Scandia Banking Corporation Ltd.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Results for the latest period reflect a $241,000 approximate pr on the disposal of the southern stores; the yr-ago results have restated to reflect an accounting change

title: Mississippi High Court Upholds Robbery Conviction of Teen-Ager
description: The Mississippi Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of Robert Earl May, a teen-ager whose original 48-year sentence attracted national attention.

title: Kuwait Petroleum In U.S. Oil Venture
description: The Kuwait Petroleum Corporation and AZL Resources Inc., a United States agribusiness conglomerate, yesterday announced the formation of a $100 million joint venture that will explore for oil, natural gas and minerals in the United States.

title: REAGAN STEPS UP HIS WORK SCHEDULE
description: More than two months after the attempt on his life, President Reagan today passed a milestone in his recovery by churning through a crowded day of working and ceremonial events that kept him to the longest, busiest schedule since he returned to his job.

title: Soviet Seeking Japanese Loan
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan said today that the Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, Viktor Ivanov, is expected to visit Tokyo next Tuesday to seek a loan of about $400 million from the bank to finance imports of 750,000 tons of Japanese large-diameter steel pipes .

title: 10 ARE ACCUSED OF PLOT TO BURN STORES OF RIVALS
description: Ten men involved in operating supermarkets and grocery stores were accused yesterday by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office of conspiring to set fire to seven competing stores.

title: DR. CONRAD STRITZLER
description: Dr. Conrad Stritzler, a dermatologist and retired professor of dermatology at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York, died Monday at the Deepdale General Hospital in Queens.

title: Dow Advances 2.23; Volume Still Heavy; Energy Issues Hold Ground
description: Led by airlines, consumer and technology issues, the stock market rallied late yesterday to produce gains in some popular indicators. A critical factor in the rebound, analysts said, was a token recovery in the energy group that has sustained huge losses this year.

title: Harvard Divinity School To Get a $3 Million Gift
description: A 73-year-old businessman who describes himself as a self-made millionaire plans to leave his estate of about $6 million to Harvard Divinity School and three other colleges, primarily to provide scholarships for students planning to enter the ministry.

title: Advertising; Hanover Klondike Revives Ice Cream Pop Sans Stick
description: Some of the older crowd remembers the pre-ice-cream-pop days, before someone thought to plop a stick into the chocolate-covered confection. Around here they called them Eskimo Pies.

title: GERMANS DEBATE BIG CUTS IN SPENDING
description: West Germany, long a pillar of fiscal stability in Europe, is locked in heated parliamentary debate this week on the need for deep Government spending cuts in the face of a mounting national budget deficit and sharply higher borrowing.

title: Amtrak's Last Chance
description: President Reagan wants to limit Federal subsidies for intercity passenger trains to $613 million next year, about $400 million less than the Carter Administration would have provided. But according to Amtrak's managers, such a reduction would require eliminating all trains except those between Boston and Washington. Running a national rail service and getting fair use from hundreds of millions of dollars worth of new equipment, they contend, depends on a subsidy of at least $850 million.

title: Brascan Lifts Stake In Consumers Glass
description: Brascan Ltd., a Toronto-based investment and minerals company, said it had increased its interest in the Consumers Glass Company to 20.5 percent from 15.7 percent through the purchase of 248,850 shares in May.

title: LEGISLATIVE LEADERS ATTEMPT TO RESOLVE KEY ISSUES
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, has informed the Democratic leaders that the Senate will not pass a new permanent tax to aid mass transit before the Federal courts act on challenges to the state's gross-receipts tax on oil companies.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: B-Net loss including $2,905,000 gain from discontinued operatio C-Including $222,000 gain from discontinued operations which in $124,000 gain on the disposal of the discontinued operation...D $980,000 income from discontinued operations; the yr-ago result been restated for discontinued operations

title: Martin Charged With Assault
description: Billy Martin was charged in a Canadian court with common assault in connection with the bumping of an umpire in Toronto last week. Page D21.

title: NATO WANTS NO RELIABILITY GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Mrs. Reagan Will Attend Prince Charles's Wedding
description: The official word from the White House yesterday was that Nancy Reagan wouold attend the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer, but the President will not accompany her to Britain.

title: UNUSUAL LOAN IN WHEELER CASE
description: The First National Bank of Boston utilized unusual banking practices in arranging and financing the gambling interests of Roger M. Wheeler, the chairman and chief executive officer of Telex Corporation, who was shot and killed last week in Tulsa, Okla., according to government and bank records.

title: Business People; Nationwide Selects General Chairman
description: John E. Fisher, 51 years old, has been given the title of general chairman - as well as chief executive officer - of the Nationwide Corporation, a group of insurance, financial services and other companies with total assets of $6 billion, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Dean W. Jeffers, who will retire at the age of 65 from the Columbus, Ohio, corporation.

title: U.S. LETTING THE DOLLAR FLOAT
description: As pledged by the Reagan Administration, the United States has allowed the dollar to float freely in foreign-exchange trading since March, according to a report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

title: THREE QUIT ANTIABORTION GROUP OVER POLITICAL 'HIT LIST'
description: A Senator and two Representatives resigned in protest today from an advisory board of the National Pro-Life Political Action Committee after it designated nine members of Congress as targets for defeat in 1982.

title: SENATE APPROVES HOUSING MEASURE PENALIZING CITIES FOR RENT CONTROLS
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would make major slashes in federally subsidized housing programs and withhold some of the remaining funds from cities that maintain rent control programs, including New York City.

title: SOCIALIST CABINET IN FRANCE RAISES MINIMUM PAY AND SOCIAL BENEFITS
description: President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist Government today raised France's minimum wage by 10 percent, increased social security benefits and told banks, oil companies and the rich that they face higher taxes.

title: CHEAPER OIL FROM LIBYA IS REPORTED
description: A trade report circulated yesterday that an agent for Libya, which is often aggressive in raising oil prices, had offered to sell Libyan crude for $4 a barrel less than that nation's official prices. Oil buyers, however, responded with skepticism.

title: U.S. PLANS TRANSFER OF IRAN ASSETS
description: The Treasury Department plans to issue new regulations in the next week ordering banks and others to surrender to the Government most of the approximately $4 billion in Iranian assets that are still tied up by court orders in the United States, a spokesman said today.

title: DR. HENRY HERMAN ESTERLY
description: Dr. Henry Herman Esterly, professor emeritus of social science at the New York City Technical College of the City University of New York, died in a car crash on May 24 in Fairfax, Va.

title: JOHN WADDINGTON, 70, JERSEY AIDE
description: John A. Waddington, former New Jersey State Senator and director of the State Division of Motor Vehicles, died Monday at the Salem County Memorial Hospital in Salem, N.J. He was 70 years old and lived in Salem.

title: Hers
description: WILLIAM SHOCKLEY is at it again. For those possessed of short memory or a subnormal ability to hold a grudge, Shockley is the Nobel Prize laureate who last year made a deposit in a sperm bank dedicated to the proposition that all men should not be created equal. Believing that humankind has a duty to work against ''excessive reproduction of the genetically disadvantaged,'' Shockley, the brilliant Stanford professor who invented the transistor, opened a sperm bank account so that women would be able to bear children who will offset the ''backward evolution'' he fears is upon us.

title: Correction
description: In an article Tuesday about Senate hearings on abortion legislation, a witness was incorrectly identified. Victor Rosenblum is a professor of law and political science at Northwestern University Law School.

title: NETTLES HOMER TOPS ORIOLES
description: With a different cast of stars but an identical story line, the Yankees staged their second straight smash last night when they defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 2-0, on an 11th-inning home run by Graig Nettles.

title: CHICAGO INCHES NEAR TRANSIT SHUTDOWN
description: With state legislative leaders still deadlocked over how to cope with the financial problems of regional public transportation, the city is inching closer to a likely shutdown of its transit system by the end of the month.

title: Reagan to Honor Canadian Who Helped Six Flee Iran
description: President Reagan will present a special gold medal on June 16 to Kenneth Taylor, the Canadian diplomat who helped six Americans escape from Iran, Congressional sources said today.

title: AARON COPLAND AND MISS ARROYO HONORED AT CITY U. CEREMONIES
description: Aaron Copland and Martina Arroyo were honored yesterday with Doctor of Humane Letters degrees in separate commencement ceremonies at two colleges of the City University of New York.

title: GLOOMY ISRAELIS IN SOUTH SINAI HOPE TO HAVE MEETING WITH SADAT
description: occupied Sinai, June 3 - Israeli residents of southern Sinai said today that they hoped to meet with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt when he visits here tomorrow to press him to open the borders and allow free access to the area after it is returned to Egyptian control next April.

title: POLISH LEADERSHIP DENOUNCES HARD-LINE PARTY GROUP
description: Distancing itself from the Soviet Union, the Polish leadership has openly condemned a small and somewhat mysterious hard-line party organization in southern Poland.

title: Arco Moves to Sell Montana Property
description: The Federal Trade Commission said that the Atlantic Richfield Company was seeking permission to divest its Heddleston, Mont., copper properties, with Asarco Inc. getting them.

title: Cosmos Acquire Wegerle from Aztecs
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the leading scorer in the North American Soccer League and team leader of the Cosmos, said yesterday that the club was ordinary and not good enough to repeat as N.A.S.L. champions.

title: CALENDAR: DESIGN DISPLAY AND ROSES
description: Thirty-Fourth Annual Student Exhibi- tion, New York School Of Interior De- sign, 155 East 56th Street.

title: Rangers To Train In Europe
description: Herb Brooks's first game as Ranger coach will be reminiscent of his Olympic coaching days last year at Lake Placid. The Rangers will hold their training camp in Scandinavia in September, and they will participate in a tournament against Finnish and Swedish national teams.

title: WALKING UNAIDED FROM HOSPITAL, JOHN PAUL RETURNS TO THE VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II walked out of the hospital unaided today, blessing patients and members of the medical staff who were crowding the balconies, and was then driven home to his apartment in the Vatican. It was exactly three weeks after he was shot in Saint Peter's Square.

title: MEGO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-Net income; the yr-ago results have been reclassified to conf to current yr presentation

title: Four Plead Not Guilty in Bribery
description: Three union officers and a public official indicted in the latest Texas labor bribery investigation pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to influence healthinsurance contract awards. The pleas were entered before United States Magistrate Frank Waltermire by L.G. Moore, regional director of the International Union of Operating Engineers; Sherman Fricks, business manager of the Pipefitters Union Local 211; Harold Grubbs, local pipefitters education director, and Houston Port Commissioner John Garrett.

title: MANHATTAN RIVERS ARE BECKONING
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfa Romeo Executive Kidnapped Near Milan by the Red Brigades
description: Terrorists posing as policemen kidnapped Renzo Sandrucci, an executive of the Alfa Romeo automobile company today.

title: Abrams Charges Fraud In Rustproofing of Cars
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams charged yesterday that New York State consumers who purchased dealer-applied rustproofing for their cars were being defrauded of at least $11 million a year.

title: Racal Halts Decca Sale
description: Racal Electronics Ltd. said today that the Tatung Company of Taiwan and Tatung U.K. Ltd. had refused to complete a contract for the purchase of Racal's Decca Ltd. radio and television business. As a result, the sale of the business, including certain fixed assets, will not now take place, it said. Racal will close Decca's plants and begin layoffs, it added.

title: DANCING GIVES DEAF AN UPBEAT REACTION
description: This particular dance number, called ''Broadway Lights,'' is jazzy, fast-paced, high-stepping. Step, kick, arms to the right, arms to the left. The entire auditorium is throbbing to the beat.

title: Panel of Atlanta Mothers Promises Report on Funds
description: After coming under fire for failing to register as a charity, a committee run by mothers of some of Atlanta's 28 slain blacks has promised to report on its work within a week.

title: MITTERRAND SAYS WEST MUST STEP UP EFFORTS FOR WORLD'S SECURITY
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France thinks the nations of the world are not making progress toward military or economic security, but he refuses to be pessimistic about it.

title: Funeral Rites Are Held in Georgia For Vinson, Former Congressman
description: Funeral rites were held today for Carl Vinson, a major architect of the United States armed forces, who died Monday at the age of 97 years after serving more than half his life in Congress.

title: Home Improvement
description: MANY homes depend on sump pumps to keep the basement dry and prevent flooding in wet weather. These pumps sit in a sump or lined hole in the basement floor and automatically kick on to pump out the water when a sensing device measures a water depth that exceeds the preset maximum.

title: Car Cost in Study Is 24.8 Cents a Mile
description: The American Automobile Association reported yesterday that the cost of owning and operating a car averaged 24.8 cents a mile in the first quarter of this year, 3.4 cents higher than a year before. The latest figure was eight-tenths of a cent above the average for the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: West Europe's Inflation Rises
description: Consumer prices in the 10 countries of the European Economic Community jumped 1.6 percent in April, the most in a year, the Common Market's statistical office reported today.

title: New-Building Values Off
description: The value of new construction in April dropped 6 percent from March as the recession in the construction industry worsened in a period of tight credit, the F.W. Dodge Division of McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: A U.S. COURT UPHOLDS RIGHT OF SECT TO BEG FUNDS AT FAIR
description: A rule restricting religious solicitation on the New York State Fairgrounds was held unconstitutional yesterday by a Federal appeals court. It overturned a lower-court decision and agreed with the contention of the Hare Krishna movement that its First Amendment rights had been violated.

title: Soviet Honors Castro's Brother
description: Gen. Raul Castro, the Cuban Armed Forces Minister and younger brother of President Fidel Castro, has been awarded the Soviet Union's order of the October Revolution, the newspaper Granma said today. Granma said the award was given for General Castro's ''great contribution to the development and reinforcement of the friendly relations between the armed forces of the Soviet Union and of Cuba and on the occasion of his 50th birthday.''

title: Grote Sparks Royals
description: Jerry Grote of the Royals drove in a club-record seven runs tonight with a double, single and grand-slam home run - his first homer since 1976 - to lead Kansas City to a 12-9 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: The City; The Crimmins Jury Adjourns for Night
description: Jury deliberations began at noon yesterday in the murder trial of Craig S. Crimmins, and the seven women and five men adjourned six and a half hours later without reaching a verdict.

title: Favorite First at Epsom
description: Shergar, the 10-11 favorite, won the $300,000 Epsom Derby today by 10 lengths, the race's biggest winning margin this century.

title: Helpful Hardware; SIMPLE FURNITURE KNOBS
description: HARDWARE of the appropriate design can enhance almost any piece of simple furniture and impart country charm to it. However, finding such knobs in the right proportions and materials is not an easy matter.

title: G.M. DISPLAYS CAR FUELED WITH COAL DUST
description: The General Motors Corporation, in a technical exercise intended to hint at the automobile industry's future independence from dwindling petroleum supplies, has developed a car fueled by powdered coal.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 30
HOUSE-SENATE UNIT AGREES TO CUT $35 MILLION FOR PUBLIC BROADCASTS
description: A House-Senate conference committee, in a major defeat for public broadcasters, has agreed to cut $35 million from the fiscal 1983 budget for the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

title: Technology; New Elegance For Polaroid
description: THE new instant cameras Polaroid will market this summer may not justify the investment it took to develop them, some analysts say, but there is unanimous feeling that they are, in the words of one expert, ''technologically elegant.'' The key is sophisticated electronics.

title: Court Is Told State Erred On Runaway Soviet Boy
description: Parents have a ''fundamental right'' to raise their children, a right that was violated when a juvenile court decided to make a 13-year-old Ukrainian boy a temporary ward of the state, an attorney for the American Civil Liberties Union charged today. The boy, Walter Polovchak, ran away from home last July rather than return with his parents to the Soviet Union.

title: WHERE TO SHOP
description: GROWING number of individual specialty stores, computer franchise dealers, manufacturer's outlets and some hobby shops and department stores are selling computers. Harder to find than a store is a salesman with the time and knowledge to help you select the best computer.

title: ST. BARTHOLOMEW'S TO PROCEED ON LEASE
description: The rector and the vestry of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church on Park Avenue said yesterday that they intended to go ahead with plans to lease part of the church complex for construction of an office or hotel tower. They hired a leading architect to advise them on which plan would be most esthetically acceptable.

title: Cleveland Considers Fare Rise
description: Transit officials are considering raising express transit fares to $1 from 50 cents next year, The Cleveland Plain Dealer said today.

title: REAGAN AIDE DEFENDS LEFEVER AND POLICY ON RIGHTS
description: Edwin Meese 3d, President Reagan's counselor, defended the Administration's policy of ''quiet diplomacy'' in human rights today and in that context reiterated White House support for Ernest W. Lefever, the nominee to be Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs.

title: Notes on People; No Reagan Yacht Now
description: ''It's been put on the back burner'' was the way Larry Speakes, spokesman for President Reagan, put it yesterday when he was asked about the White House's search for a yacht for the President's use.

title: 2-YEAR TAX CUT BILL GOAL OF DEMOCRATS IN KEY HOUSE PANEL
description: Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee reached informal agreement today on the broad outlines of a two-year tax-relief bill designed to appeal to the party's conservative wing.

title: Salazar Running From Fame
description: It has been more than seven months since Alberto Salazar, running the distance for the first time, won the New York City Marathon. He is still on an emotional high, he said today, and he is looking forward to next October's marathon because he expects to be in much better shape then.

title: Dutch Fighter Plane Crashes
description: A Dutch Air Force single-seater F-16 fighter plane crashed into a lake in the north of the country today but the pilot ejected safely, the Defense Ministry here said. It was the second Dutch F-16 plane to crash since the first supersonic fighter was delivered to the air force in June 1979.

title: Vietnam Renews Offer to Thailand For a Partial Pullout in Cambodia
description: Vietnam renewed its offer today to withdraw some of its 200,000 troops in Cambodia if Thailand severs ties with Communist guerrillas fighting the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian regime, Radio Hanoi reported.

title: Geneve Seeks Board Seat
description: The Geneve Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was seeking representation on the board of directors of the E.F. MacDonald Company. If a corporate relationship acceptable to Geneve was not achieved by July 1, Geneve said, it would seek either to dispose of its shares of MacDonald stock or seek control of the company. Currently Geneve owns 886,610 shares of MacDonald, or 23.6 percent.

title: Notes on People; A One-Man Show With Many Parts, 38 to Be Exact
description: What set the late Brendan Behan apart from most of the inspired bar habitues of Dublin was that when the drinking and the talking were done, Mr. Behan managed to write down at least some of what he had heard and part of what he had said.

title: New Jersey Lucks Out
description: Fortune smiled on New Jersey Tuesday. Primary voters found their way through the confusion caused by 21 candidates to two distinctly worthy nominees for Governor.

title: Gluts To the Gluttons
description: The time is ripe to crack the OPEC cartel. For nearly a decade, oil producers have combined to force the rest of the world to pay all that the traffic would bear. An international monopoly has helped inflict a raging inflation on the world, stunted the growth of the poorest nations and brushed off all criticism of its price fixing with a cool ''business is business.''

title: Business People; Dave DeBusschere Finds Business Is a Pleasure
description: Dave DeBusschere, 40, the former star basketball player for the New York Knicks, is deeply involved in the world of business these days - more so than most athletes after their retirement from competitive athletics. But to Mr. DeBusschere, his corporations, partnerships and salaried positions are all involvements that he enjoys as much as he enjoyed his playing days.

title: Advertising; Ad Revenues Increased In U.S. Daily Newspapers
description: The country's daily newspapers were up an estimated 15.6 percent in ad revenues during the first four months of this year, to $5.36 billion, compared with the same period last year, while magazines belonging to the Publishers Information Bureau were up 6 percent, to $966.1 million.

title: Catholic Panel Assesses Restrictions on Women
description: The exclusion of women from full participation in the Roman Catholic Church is a ''serious matter'' and may be increasing alienation of women from the church, a report by a joint committee of bishops and women said yesterday.

title: Polish Cardinal to Visit Rome
description: Franciszek Cardinal Macharski, interim head of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland after the death of Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, will go to Rome this week and is expected to meet with Pope John Paul II, Western diplomatic sources said today. Cardinal Macharski visited the Pope in Rome about two weeks ago after Cardinal Wyszynski's condition worsened. Cardinal Wyszynski, the Polish Primate and Archbishop of Gniezno and Warsaw, died last Thursday of cancer.

title: Q&A
description: Q. There are rust stains on my concrete patio that I would like to remove. My local hardware store suggested covering the stains with sand, then pouring bleach over the sand -but this did not work. They also suggested a strong acid etching solution (sold for use on concrete) but I am afraid to try this because it might kill the plants and shrubs nearby. Can you suggest a safe and effective way to remove the rust stains? - D.S.L., Kensington, Md.

title: NUCLEAR NEWS IN MOSCOW
description: A noted American physicist, Victor F. Weisskopf of M.I.T., has just had an unusual experience with the Soviet system. It could suggest an opening for arms control negotiations of the kind that President Reagan has repeatedly said he wants: talks looking to actual reductions in nuclear weaponry.

title: Norway to Join Pro Boxing Ban
description: Professional boxing will be banned in Norway before parliament starts its summer recess June 15.

title: HENRY GEORGE'S IDEA ON LAND TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You think you can now boast that you made a new person, But I'm the same rascal I have always been.'' -Pope John Paul II. (A8:4.)

title: Amcon Increases Newmont Holding
description: Amcon Group Inc. and Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., its parent, said they had increased their stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to 2.11 million shares, or 8.1 percent.

title: SOONG CHING-LING IS EULOGIZED BY DENG
description: The man widely expected to be China's next Communist Party chairman, Hu Yaobang, presided over funeral services today for Soong Ching-ling before 10,000 mourners, including the present party chairman, Hua Guofeng.

title: Tampa Selected as Host For Super Bowl in 1984
description: Tampa was awarded the 1984 Super Bowl by the National Football League owners at the conclusion of their two-day meetings today.

title: Notes on People; Trying to Compare Works of the Greats
description: When he gets some free time, Martin Vidnovic was saying yesterday, there's nothing he likes better than to hop down to, say, Bermuda, for ''a little fishing, a little snorkeling and a little body surfing.''

title: BLACK UNION ENDS STRIKE AT SOUTH AFRICAN AUTO PLANTS
description: One of the newest and most assertive black labor unions decided today to end a two-week strike against the two largest American companies in South Africa, Ford and General Motors. The union had called the strikes with the unusual aim of getting the two companies to put pressure on a third, Firestone, to take back some dismissed employees.

title: U.S. Says That 6-Man Navy Team Of Technicians Has Left Salvador
description: A six-man United States Navy team of maintenance specialists and instructors has left El Salvador, reducing the number of American military technicians there to 50, the Defense Department said.

title: THE U.N. ROLE IN THE PUBLICATION OF NEWSPAPER SUPPLEMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Haig Gives Javits a Special Post As an Adviser on Foreign Policy
description: Jacob K. Javits, the former Republican Senator from New York, has been appointed a special foreign policy adviser to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., the State Department announced today.

title: Dance Series June 11-26 In the Financial District
description: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council will present ''Dance Around Downtown,'' a two-week season of free lunch-time dance concerts in the parks and plazas of the financial district from next Thursday to June 26.

title: HOUSES TO VISIT: FOUR NEARBY TOURS
description: Freeport House Tour Committee, 255 South Ocean Avenue, Freeport, L.I.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Dame Antoinette Sibley To Dance Ophelia at Met
description: Dame Antoinette Sibley will be Ophelia in Robert Helpmann's ''Hamlet'' with Britain's Royal Ballet during the first week of its season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: South Korean Police Arrest Man Holding 26 Hostages Inside Bank
description: The police stormed a bank today and arrested a man who was holding 26 people hostage for about $730,000 in ransom.

title: Auto Sales Fall in Japan
description: Japan's auto sales fell in May, chiefly because of price increases and a sales tax rise, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. Vehicle registrations fell to 272,456 units last month, down 24.9 percent from April and down 15.9 percent from a year before.

title: Austria and Jewish Fund Give Awards to Balanchine
description: George Balanchine, choreographer and artistic director of the New York City Ballet, has received the Austrian Decoration of Honor for Science and the Arts, awarded in recognition of Mr. Balanchine's interest in choreographing to music by Austrian composers.

title: Carey Renominates Judge
description: Governor Carey has nominated Judge Gerard M. Weisberg of Manhattan for reappointment to the state's Court of Claims.

title: WESTCHESTER TOWN BATTLING PHOENIX HOUSE SCHOOL FOR EX-ADDICTS
description: Phoenix House, the Manhattan-based drug treatment foundation, plans to open an education center in the Westchester County community of Yorktown this summer that would house 350 recovering drug addicts. The town and thousands of its residents have pledged to keep Phoenix House out.

title: AUTO SALES UP BY 9.8% IN LATE MAY
description: Sales of new cars by the nation's Big Three auto manufacturers rose 9.8 percent in the final 10 days of May from the very low sales rate in the similar period last year, the companies reported today.

title: Weinberger Said to Ask New Force in 18 Months
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the Joint Chiefs of Staff to have the Rapid Deployment Force organized into a separate command within 18 months, military sources said today.

title: Critic's Notebook; EFFECTS A WRITER GETS, BUT DIDN'T INTEND
description: THE reviewer had never pretended to be intimately acquainted with Holy Scripture. Once he'd even had the courage to deny such intimacy under awkward circumstances. He'd just unburdened himself of a lighthearted and completely nonreligious lecture on the New York literary scene before a group of scowling women at a club in Shreveport, La. On the way to the airport, he became aware that the president of the club was subjecting him to intense scrutiny. When he turned to look at her questioningly, she beamed and said: ''Suh, I can tell you are a man of intimate acquaintance with the Holy Scriptures. Now don't deny it. I can see it in your eyes.''

title: THEATER: CALDERON'S 'LIFE IS DREAM'
description: ''LA Vida es Sueno'' by Pedro Calderon de la Barca is a 17thcentury Spanish classic with modern overtones. The play's hero, trapped between reality and illusion, is a man who cheats fate, asserts his individual will and learns to control his own destiny. As its contribution to a festival of Hispanic arts, the Intar theater is presenting Maria Irene Fornes's new adaptation of the play under the title ''Life Is Dream.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bell Canada filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $150 million of debentures, due in 1991, to be sold in the United States through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: Overcharge Laid To Western Union
description: ITT World Communications Inc., an international telecommunications concern and a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, contended it had been overcharged $2 million by the Western Union Telegraph Company, and asked the Federal Communications Commission to force Western Union to refund the money.

title: COURT UPHOLDS MONETARY CLAIM FOR MEDICAL FINDING
description: A jury's verdict that Dr. John C. Saunders should get monetary recognition for the scientific discovery of a drug treatment for depression has been upheld by New York State's Court of Appeals, the psychiatrist's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Potential Takeovers
description: SOME months ago it was possible to make money by investing in companies that had publicly agreed to a takeover. The difference between the offering price and the market was sufficiently wide to allow for a profit. But spreads have narrowed considerably and carrying costs have soared to record levels.

title: Advertising; N.W. Ayer Dominates The Andy Awards Night
description: N.W. Ayer Inc., made the finest showing last night at the annual Andy Awards festivities of the Advertising Club of New York held in the Sheraton Center. It picked up seven of the pewter Andy statuettes, far outshining the closest competitors, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Boston's Humphrey Browning MacDougall.

title: SHANNON OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Coe Wins Fast 800
description: Sebastian Coe, Britain's 800-meter Olympic champion, ran the fastest 800 in the world this year at a four-nation track meet at the Crystal Palace stadium tonight.

title: DOING THE HOMEWORK
description: OR a neophyte, stepping into a computer store can be an exciting but disorienting experience. The salesmen speak in acronyms and the variety of equipment is confusing. To make shopping trips more meaningful, it is a good idea to do a little homework. Read a book on home computers, leaf through a few computer magazines and learn something about the major brands of computers.

title: E. Harper Cummings, Co-founder Of Advertising Agency, Dies at 89
description: E. Harper Cummings, co-founder and former officer of William Esty Company Inc., a New York advertising agency, died Tuesday of a heart attack at the Scarsdale Golf Club. He was 89 years old and lived in Scarsdale and Naples, Fla.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 16 weeks to Apr 25
description: B-Including $72,700 pretax gain on the sale of securities... C-After $10,400,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Violence in Sri Lanka Brings Emergency Rule
description: The Government imposed emergency rule and a dusk-to-dawn curfew today on the northern region where separatist minority Tamils have been blamed for a new outbreak of violence.

title: WOMEN'S BENEFITS: DEBATE IS REKINDLED
description: President Reagan's proposals to cut some Social Security benefits in order to keep the retirement system solvent were criticized at a Congressional hearing today as threatening the already precarious economic security of older women.

title: TAIWAN DISAPPOINTED IN REAGAN POLICY
description: In the fifth month of President Reagan's Administration, the Taiwan Government's great expectations are wearing thin, and worry shows through official affirmations of continuing confidence.

title: COUNCIL MAP GETS MINORITY-GROUP BACKING
description: Two black and two Hispanic New Yorkers who said they represented more than 100 civic groups went to City Hall yesterday to endorse the City Council's redistricting plan, which has been criticized for slighting minority groups&

title: Product Safety Is a Valid Concern
description: Among Federal regulators, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has long been the weak sister. With a budget of barely $40 million, it can deal directly with only a modest number of small risks - cribs that kill 50 babies a year or unstable refuse bins that have killed seven children in three years. So in the name of economy, the Reagan Administration has asked Congress to weaken it further or kill it altogether.

title: LET'S BAN SCHOOL VIOLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN QUESTIONED IN ATLANTA KILLINGS
description: A suspect was questioned by the police and Federal agents in Atlanta last night in connection with the slayings of 28 young blacks over the past 22 months, law enforcement officials said early today.

title: CANADIANS ARE PURSUING FOREIGN OIL COMPANIES
description: Foreign oil companies in Canada today find themselves increasingly the targets of a corporate big game hunt with billions of dollars at stake.

title: ANTOINETTE E. SCHULTE
description: Antoinette E. Schulte, an artist, died of cancer at her Manhattan apartment on May 26.

title: Silver Price Dips Below $10 Level
description: The price of silver dipped below the $10-an-ounce mark yesterday for the first time in almost two years as the metal continued to be buffeted by high interest rates, a strong dollar and the impression that inflation was moderating.

title: PERCY AND MAJORITY OF SENATE PANEL ARE EXPECTED TO REJECT RIGHTS CHOICE
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has apparently decided to vote against the nomination of Ernest W. Lefever as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs, and the majority of the panel is expected to follow suit.

title: The Polish Factor
description: Poland is now entering the most dangerous period for survival of its independence and reform movement since last summer.

title: Around the Nation; Russell Little Is Acquitted Of Slaying on Coast in 1973
description: Russell Little, a member of the Symbionese Liberation Army, was acquitted today of the murder of Marcus Foster, the Oakland School Superintendent, in 1973.

title: Arco, Santa Fe Get Oil Permit Off China
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company and the Santa Fe International Corporation announced an agreement with China to look for oil and gas in the South China Sea.

title: The Region; Reservoir Is Shut Following a Fish Kill
description: Mayor Joel Shain of Orange cut off the city's reservoir-fed water supply following a fish kill he said he believesd was caused by Essex County's gypsy moth spraying program.

title: JoAnne Carner Shares Lead at 68
description: JoAnne Carner, seeking her 30th tour victory, shot a four-under-par 68 today for a share of the first-round lead in the $150,000 Kids' Classic.

title: CRIMMINS FOUND GUILTY OF MURDER AS THE JURY ACCEPTS HIS CONFESSION
description: Craig S. Crimmins was found guilty yesterday of murdering a violinist at the Metropolitan Opera House last July 23. The 22-year-old former stagehand remained impassive when the verdict was announced, but his girlfriend, Mary Ann Fennell, wept loudly. After Mr. Crimmins had been led away, she kept repeating, while sobbing and saying: ''They're wrong, they're wrong. He didn't do it.''

title: BUSINESSMEN ARE CRITICAL
description: Representatives of business organizations yesterday criticized President Reagan's decision to withdraw some of his previously proposed changes in depreciation laws in order to win support for his proposal for personal income tax cuts over three years.

title: NEW YORK STATE IS PLANNING A WAR ON THE DRUNK WHO KILL WITH CARS
description: Last year 2,639 persons died in automobile accidents in New York State, more than any state except California and Texas. Almost half of them were killed by drivers who had been drinking.

title: Bridge: Look to Past for Assistance With Inflated Book Prices
description: In everyday life it is hardly possible to counter inflation by trying to find yesterday's prices. But buyers of bridge books can sometimes do just that with spectacular results.

title: Notes on People; Celebration and a Deft Plea for Aid at Yeshiva
description: They knew he was coming to Yeshiva University, so they arranged to have a birthday cake for Jan Peerce, the tenor who turned 77 Wednesday.

title: KATHARINE HEPBURN AND FRIENDS
description: RICHARD A. COLLA'S ''Olly, Olly Oxen Free,'' an extremely whimsical comedy starring Katharine Hepburn, is having its New York premiere today at the Thalia Theater although it was made in 1978. It's not a lost film exactly. Rather it's the kind of film that can easily be overlooked, being so soft-spoken and gentle that bland is its dominant style. If you pay attention to it, as you might to a small child, it offers some gentle, soft-spoken rewards.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The conversion of the British pound into U.S. Dollars was based on an exchange rate of two American dollars for each pound

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After a gain of $151,000 from the issue of 80,000 shrs of Camchib Resources for the qr and 9 mos and a gain of $6,158,000 from equity of inverness Petroleum and $785,000 from Sky Resources from inverness for the 9 mos

title: JERSEY'S RIGHTS TO SHORE PROVE COSTLY TO THE CASINOS
description: New Jersey, which claims the right to any land washed by the tide, is charging up to millions of dollars an acre for the rights to develop such land. The situation is causing concern among Atlantic City casino developers and owners of thousands of shorefront homes.

title: Walter Mitty in the Schoolroom
description: There is a Walter Mitty in most of us struggling to come out and triumph when others fail. So we understand the kind of impulse that John Silber, Boston University's flamboyant president, demonstrated by proposing that Boston turn its crisis-ridden public schools over to his university to run, better and cheaper. What we don't understand is how he thinks he could, short of union-busting, accomplish that boastful goal.

title: Baseball Decision Is Put Off
description: Lawyers on both sides of the baseball case in United States District Court agreed today that the matter was extraordinary, and the judge concurred. How extraordinary?

title: Denying the Mentally Ill
description: It was a familiar story: A New York City transit patrolman roused a man sleeping on a subway platform. The man grew belligerent, somehow got hold of the officer's nightstick and beat him savagely. Arrested, the suspect turned out to have a long record of admissions and releases from a mental hospital, despite findings that he was ''potentially dangerous.''

title: WORLD BANK POSTPONES ENERGY LOAN EXPANSION
description: Deep divisions within the Reagan Administration on whether to support an expanded World Bank energy-lending program led the bank yesterday to postpone a decision on the program. The bank will take up the issue again before the board adjourns in August, in hopes that Washington will have resolved the differences by then.

title: Medtronics Net Slips
description: Medtronics Inc., the maker of implantable medical devices, said earnings for its fourth fiscal quarter, ended April 30, fell to $10.9 million, or 70 cents a share, from $12.3 million, or 80 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose to $80.8 million from $75.2 million.

title: PENNSYLVANIA JOINS FIGHT TO EASE HARRISBURG WOE
description: Since Jay Waldman came to this state capital as Gov. Dick Thornburgh's general counsel and chief of staff, burglars have struck his home twice. The home of the Secretary of Legislative Affairs, Richard A. Stafford, has been burglarized once. Both live in Bellevue Park, one of the city's better neighborhoods.

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Advertising; Lenox Ad Budget Up 40%
description: Lenox, the china company, is raising its ad budget a healthy 40 percent from the $2.3 million of last year . And, if you look, you will be seeing the Leber Katz Partners advertising beginning Aug.18 in magazines including Architectural Digest, House Beautiful, Good Housekeeping, Better Homes and Gardens, House and Garden, McCall's, The Ladies' Home Journal and The New Yorker. More than 100 full, four-color pages will running in four months.

title: ATLANTA MAN, DETAINED 12 HOURS, DENIES ROLE IN ANY OF 28 KILLINGS
description: As investigators searched today through material taken from his home and car, a man held for questioning about the slayings of 28 young blacks denied any involvement in the crimes and accused the authorities and the press of slandering him.

title: ILC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 5
News Analysis
description: Despite earlier pledges to keep its tax legislation lean and simple, the Reagan Administration has engaged in a flurry of adding ''sweeteners'' to capture crucial votes.

title: The Region; High Court to Hear Restitution Cases
description: TRENTON (AP) - The New Jersey Supreme Court has agreed to hear two related appeals concerning monetary restitution by a convicted criminal as a condition of parole.

title: UPGRADING A BROOKLYN BUILDING TO CONVERT IT INTO A CO-OP
description: ''ANYTHING that is to have a positive social impact must be on a sound economic footing.'' That has become a kind of credo for Marc J. Leavitt, a lawyer who is active in many housing rehabilitation efforts in the city.

title: Around the World; Christian Democrat Backed As Mayor of West Berlin
description: After weeks of suspense, the impasse over the formation of a city government for West Berlin appears to have been overcome, with four rebels among the liberal delegates announcing that their choice for Mayor is Richard von Weizsacker, the 61-year-old Christian Democratic candidate.

title: Around the World; Pope Visits Buffalo Woman Shot in St. Peter's Square
description: Ann Odre, the 58-year-old Buffalo woman wounded in the attack on Pope John Paul II, today had a tearful, 20-minute meeting with the Pope in his private Vatican apartment.

title: Attorney for Unser Says Andretti Was in Violation
description: An attorney for Bobby Unser attempted to show today that Mario Andretti, awarded the victory in the Indianapolis 500 after Unser was penalized one lap, had also committed a violation during the race and that it was ignored by the United States Auto Club.

title: THE TEAMSTERS' NEW CHIEFTAIN
description: ''I said rules,'' Roy L. Williams, head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said this week as he led debate at the union's convention through a shoals of confusion. ''I didn't say Robert's rules.''

title: No Headline
description: Books: Doomed Mission By Jack Sullivan THE PARACHUTISTS. By Edward Klein. 392 pages. Doubleday. $12.95.

title: Roderick Wary Of Coal Accord
description: The chairman of the United States Steel Corporation said today that he regards the tentative wage agreement reached last week by negotiators for the soft coal industry and the United Mine Workers as inflationary.

title: MILITARY AID FOR CHINA CONSIDERED AS HAIG PREPARES TO VISIT PEKING
description: In preparing for the visit of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to China next week, the Reagan Administration is moving toward decisions that will give more of a military cast to Chinese-American relations.

title: American League; White Sox 4, A's 2
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Chet Lemon singled home the tie-breaking run in a two-run eighth inning for Chicago.

title: YANKS WIN, 12-3, TO SWEEP ORIOLES
description: One week after their sad retreat from Baltimore, the Yankees won a full measure of revenge last night when they hammered the Orioles, 12-3, and swept the three-game series at Yankee Stadium. The victory also moved the Yankees within four percentage points of the Orioles, the occupiers of first place in the American League's Eastern Division.

title: MAY WE NEVER LOSE OUR SELF- DOUBT
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: MET PRESENTS AFRICAN ANTHOLOGY
description: FOR the second time in less than a year, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has gone deeply into a field with which not everyone associates it: that of African tribal art. After having given good space and a very handsome installation to ''Treasures of Ancient Nigerian Art'' last fall, the museum has now given a much larger space - the Sackler Wing - to examples of African art from the collection of Paul and Ruth Tishman. In all, 150 objects from all over Africa are included in the show, which is called ''For Spirits and Kings,'' and an international and multiracial pool of no fewer than 71 distinguished scholars has contributed to the catalogue, which costs $35 clothbound and $14.95 in paperback.

title: NATO Electronics Group
description: A group of electronics companies from NATO countries are to set up a joint subsidiary to work on the NATO Air Command and Control System, the French Thomson group announced today.

title: STAGE: 'THE MEEHANS,' SINGING IN THE STATION HOUSE
description: ''THE MEEHANS,'' at Theater for the New City, is a hard-boiled musical with a somewhat soft center. The show shifts from a police station, where tough cops sing and dance about their daily war against perpetrators, to a more familiar scene of domestic intranquillity. During off-duty hours, the evening suffers from sentimentality. Nevertheless, ''The Meehans'' is a show of considerable musical freshness. For that, credit the composer, the late Sam Pottle, and the lyricist-author, Charles Choset, both of them musical veterans of ''Sesame Street.''

title: 'REVERSE COMMUTING: GOING AGAINST THE FLOW
description: Last August, Ruth Bendetovich seized what she felt was an exceptional opportunity - to join General Telephone and Electronics. But the corporate headquarters is in Stamford, Conn., and Dr. Bendetovich, who manages investment portfolios, lives on Manhattan's Upper West Side. And so, to catch the 7:05 out of Grand Central Terminal, she sets her alarm for 5:45 A.M. each weekday morning.

title: PROMOTERS OF VIOLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: 20% NORANDA STAKE ACQUIRED BY BRASCAN
description: Brascan Ltd. of Toronto, an investment management company controlled by the interests of Edward and Peter Bronfman, raised its interest in Noranda Mines Ltd. today to about 20 percent through the open-market purchase of 5.5 million shares for approximately $190 million (Canadian).

title: TV Weekend; TONYS, BARYSHNIKOV AND CIRCUS TALE
description: PRODUCED by Alexander H. Cohen, the Tony presentations often seem to be the jewel of award shows. For one reason or another, Broadway manages to project a lot more class than Hollywood. The 35th annual Tony Awards will be carried live Sunday from 9 to 11 on CBS-TV. Ellen Burstyn and Richard Chamberlain will be the hosts. Songs will be offered from ''42d Street,'' ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' ''Tintypes'' and ''Woman of the Year,'' all nominated musicals. There will be a special Tony for Lena Horne and a special salute to women of the theater. And, needless to say, stars will be glittering all over the place.

title: Article 144927 -- No Title
description: A price support program for milk that could cost taxpayers more than $1.1 billion next year was approved today by the House Agriculture Committee.

title: Advertising; Marschalk Getting Thompson Brand
description: Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, has become the third agency for the Thompson Medical Company.

title: St. Luke's Concert
description: The St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble will perform tomorrow night at 8 at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Credit Markets; SHORT-TERM INTEREST RATES UP
description: Short-term interest rates rose yesterday in response to a the continued high level of the Federal funds rate. The funds rate, which is the cost of money that banks lend to each other overnight, traded around 20 percent, as it had Wednesday. Market analysts had expected the funds rate to ease with the start of the bank statement week yesterday, but the overnight cost of money remained high and pushed up all short-term rates.

title: Fire Engines in Newark
description: More than 50 antique fire engines and trucks, including one from 1898, will be displayed Sunday at the annual muster at the Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street in Newark.

title: Energy Watch
description: MAY 29 Crude oil stocks inched ahead to 406.8 million barrels, while crude oil imports remained unchanged.

title: 'SEA WOLVES'
description: ''THE SEA WOLVES,'' apparently inspired by a true World War II story, is an elaborate expensive-looking adventure film that has less life in it than almost any line read by Gregory Peck, one of its stars and not an actor who invests anything he says with unbridled spontaneity.

title: Notes on People; Kuralt Fined $260.50
description: Charles Kuralt, the CBS newsman who was charged with driving while under the influence of alcohol during a vacation in California last Februrary, has been fined $260.50 after pleading no contest to a reduced charge of reckless driving.

title: Business People; Arrow Electronics Names President
description: Alfred J. Stein, a 48-year-old veteran electronics executive, has been named president and chief executive officer of Arrow Electronics Inc., effective July 1. The position has been filled on an acting basis since last December by John C. Waddell, 43, who remains chairman of the Greenwich, Conn.. company.

title: MAYOR RECEIVES G.O. P. SUPPORT FROM BROOKLYN
description: The Brooklyn Republican organization last night endorsed Mayor Koch and thus gave a Democratic mayor, for the first time, the support of four of the city's five Republican county organizations.

title: Pfizer Closing Unit
description: Pfizer Inc., a major producer of chemical, pharmaceutical and medical products, said that it would close its medical scanner business and was considering its divestiture. The unit, part of Pfizer's health care segment, lost $4 million after taxes during the first four months of this year. As of April 30, total assets connected with the scanner line were about $112 million, including about $60 million in inventories and $34 million of receivables.

title: Around the World; Group at U.N. Said to Want To Invite Phnom Penh Chief
description: A Southeast Asian diplomat said today that the Association of Southeast Asian Nations wanted to invite Heng Samrin, head of the Vietnamese-installed Government in Phnom Penh, to a United Nations conference on Cambodia tentatively scheduled to begin here on July 13.

title: Circus in Brooklyn
description: The big top of the Big Apple Circus, the city's resident one-ring circus, will be set up through next weekend in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, in the parking lot of the Wollman Skating Rink, Parkside and Ocean Avenues.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that a preliminary count of the shares tendered in its offer for Bunker Ramo Corp. showed that the offer had been oversubscribed.

title: 'ALLIGATOR'
description: IT is 1968, and the Kendall family, while on vacation in Florida, visits an alligator farm where 12-year-old Marisa buys a 10-inch-long baby alligator as a pet. Back home in their large Middle Western city, which sometimes looks like Chicago, sometimes like Detroit and sometimes even like Los Angeles (though it's supposed to be in Missouri), Dad Kendall becomes fed up with Marisa's attachment for Ramon, which is the name she's given the little alligator, and flushes him down the toilet.

title: SEMTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Plane Builders in Airbus Race
description: An international race to develop a new small Airbus - with the promise of a vast and lucrative world market for the winner - began today.

title: The Spirit Of 13 Lives
description: The spirit of Proposition 13 is alive and well in this city, as its citizens showed this week when they overwhelmingly rejected a plan for a small property tax increase to pay for nearly 1,400 more police officers.

title: Fairs Take to the Streets in City and Suburb
description: ''Murray Hill Goes Country,'' the ninth block party sponsored by the Murray Hill Committee, will feature country and western dancing and singing, hayrides, ethnic foods, a flea market and an auction. It's tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. on 35th Street, between Lexington and Fifth Avenues.

title: CITY SEES $30 MILLION SAVING IN A RULING ON POLICE SALARIES
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled today that New York City did not have to pay police lieutenants and sergeants who were given supervisory positions more money simply because of their new designations.

title: Gretzky Voted Most Valuable
description: For the second straight year, Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers was named today as the recipient of the Hart Trophy as the most valuable player in the National Hockey League.

title: BACH: 'MUSICAL OFFERING'
description: EVEN if it is unclear whether Bach ever intended for his entire ''Musical Offering'' to be performed all at once, it is sometimes presented complete, and such performances are almost always events. The reason is that despite the vagueness that exists about the instrumentation and the sequencing of these 13 fugues, canons and other pieces, the music is so grand that it must make a profound impression.

title: JAMES EARL RAY IS A STAB VICTIM IN PRISON ATTACK
description: James Earl Ray, serving a 99-year prison term for assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was stabbed 22 times today but was expected to recover, the authorities said.

title: American League; Red Sox 6, Indians 5
description: CLEVELAND (UPI) - Carney Lansford hit his third homer of the year and scored two runs to spark Boston.

title: A RIGHT TO KNOW IS UNDER ATTACK
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Jazz; A SUMMER OF CONCERTS BEGINS AT SEAPORT
description: NEW YORK boasts a number of attractive settings for live music, but the South Street Seaport, situated at Fulton Street and the East River, is probably the most spectacular. The lights of the Brooklyn Bridge glitter to the north, the skyscrapers of Lower Manhattan shine to the south, and the collection of historic sailing ships, which range from small schooners to the four-masted barque Peking, ride at anchor up and down the Seaport's Pier 16. Listeners bring blankets, cushions or chairs and sit on the pier for the concerts. And this summer there will be plenty of them.

title: Mrs. Begin Is Hospitalized
description: Aliza Begin, wife of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, was hospitalized here today with respiratory and circulatory difficulties, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Advertising; Norcliff-Thayer Spot TV
description: Jordan, Case & McGrath is taking over the job of agency of record for spot television buying for all Norcliff-Thayer brands. It is already the agency for Tums, the recently assigned antacid, while its subsidiary, Specht, Gilbert & Partners, handles the Oxy line of acne treatment products. Now it will also do the spot buying for the brands assigned to Marschalk and Compton Advertising.

title: A SHOOPING SHOWCASE
description: For a quarter of a century, Lord & Taylor had an area called Fantasia that served as a showcase for some of its choice fashion ideas. When the main floor was remodeled in 1975, Fantasia disappeared, to the disappointment of women who used to check it out regularly for unusual things. Fantasia returned this week in a new location on the third floor and the woman who dislikes plowing through racks of look-alike clothes should love it.

title: BUILDERS ARE URGED TO FORGE ONE PLAN FOR TIMES SQUARE
description: City and state officials today formally asked for proposals to transform the Times Square jumble of sex emporiums, fast-food shops and X-rated movie houses into a sweep of gleaming office buildings, restaurants and legitimate theaters.

title: HIRING OF FIREFIGHTERS TO AWAIT PENSION PLAN REVISIONS
description: New York City has not hired any firefighters since February and does not plan to do so until the State Legislature approves a new pension plan for the Fire Department, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Marjorie Feldman, Teacher, Bride of David Lewis Jacobs
description: Marjorie Fay Feldman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eli Feldman of West Newton, Mass., was married yesterday to David Lewis Jacobs of Washington, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Milton Jacobs of Newton, Mass.

title: IACOCCA SEES A CHANCE FOR A PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, held out some hope today of a return to profitability in the second quarter.

title: Advertising; Bookings For Hotels, Exclusively
description: ACCOMMODATIONS INTERNATIONAL, the new client at Anesh, Viseltear, Gumbinner, is convinced it has created a new product. After eight months of preparation, it will officially go into business Monday as a hotel booking agent for business travelers, dealing only with luxury hotels.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; 54 ONSTAGE HOURS ON 43D ST.
description: While it is possible to see only one play at the Quaigh Theater this weekend, that would mean passing up dozens of other shows. Starting at 7 tonight, the theater, in the Diplomat Hotel at 108 West 43d Street, will offer a ''dramathon'' - 50 plays and 10 variety acts, one after another, nonstop for 54 hours, some of them new works, others revivals, some short, some long. It starts with ''Benny,'' a 15-minute comedy by Renee Taylor and Joseph Bologna about two loners who meet on a park bench, starring Frank Biancamano and Suszan Telcher. Then it continues with Dorothy Parker's ''Here We Are.'' Tom Stoppard, William Saroyan, Anton Chekhov, Peter Shaffer and Eugene O'Neill are just a few of the other playwrights represented. Tickets are $4 for one show, $10 for six hours, $15 for 12 hours and $25 for the whole lot through 1 A.M. on Monday. Reservations: 221-9088. ROSES ARE BIGGER IN BROOKLYN

title: POLISH UNION SETS WARNING STRIKE
description: Leaders of the independent trade union approved plans today for a brief warning strike in four northern cities next week. It would be the first industrial protest since Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski instructed Parliament on April 10 to outlaw strikes for two months.

title: BEGIN GREETS SADAT AT SINAI SETTLEMENT
description: Occupied Sinai, June 4 - President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt asked Prime Minister Menachem Begin today to halt Israeli attacks on Palestinian guerrilla bases in Lebanon and to place no deadline on diplomatic efforts toward a peaceful solution of the crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon.

title: Boy Feels 'Better' After Fainting At Presentation at White House
description: Eight-year-old Brian Wagner, who fainted at the White House presentation of awards yesterday to the Multiple Sclerosis Mother and Father of the Year, said today that he was ''feeling better.''

title: POUND FALLS TO $1.9385 IN EUROPE
description: The pound sank to $1.9385 at the close of European trading today, continuing its dramatic plunge against the American currency amid expectations of a cut in the price of North Sea oil and a belief that the current high level of United States interest rates would be maintained.

title: LOLITA CABRERA GAINSBORG
description: Lolita Cabrera Gainsborg, pianist and composer, died on May 23 in Danville, N.J. She was 85 years old. Miss Gainsborg, a former child prodigy, made her New York debut at the age of 14 in Mendelssohn Hall. After 1924, Miss Gainsborg was a featured pianist on the NBC radio network, and resumed her concert career, which she gave up after her marriage. She also composed many songs and solo piano works.e.

title: Advertising; Addendum
