description: * Dancer Fitzgerald Sample International announced that Iconic, a Mexico City-based advertising agency, will be its representative in Mexico.

title: Auto Output Up for Year
description: United States auto production will break the three-million mark this week with companies planning to build 163,772 vehicles, 30.7 percent above the production level for the comparable week a year ago, an industry publication reported today.

title: COMMUNIST ROLE IN PARIS CABINET DIMS
description: The prospect of Communist participation in the Government of President Francois Mitterrand became more remote today after long discussions between leaders of the Socialist and Communist Parties ended without resolving major policy disagreements.

title: RIDE OF THE LA FOUR: SAMBA TO BE-BOP TO CLASSICAL
description: THE LA Four, which is making its first appearance in a New York jazz club (through Sunday, at Fat Tuesday's), is, as its name would indicate, a quartet from Los Angeles. But when the group started in 1974, the LA in its name was not a reference to a city but to Laurindo Almeida, the Brazilian guitarist, around whom the quartet was formed with Bud Shank on flute and alto saxophone, Ray Brown on bass and Chuck Flores on drums.

title: CAREY PANEL URGES 2 TAX RISES TO HELP M.T.A. WITH DEFICITS
description: Governor Carey's transit advisory panel yesterday proposed a plan to finance Metropolitan Transportation Authority deficits with increases in the sales tax in areas served by the authority and in the statewide tax on oil-company receipts. It also asked for the creation of a new financial control board to monitor the agency.

title: Wolf of Princeton Has Large Talents
description: August Wolf, Princeton sophomore, former clarinet player, former tropical fish entrepreneur and self-styled weakling, started his competition tonight in the 60th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships.

title: Art People; Rodin among the clouds.
description: POSSIBLY the country's most elevated art gallery is the new B.G. Cantor Sculpture Center on the 105th floor of 1 World Trade Center. Devoted to the sculpture of Rodin, it's an elegant, 4,000-square-foot facility designed in discreet tones of beige by George Sadek, dean of the school of art at the Cooper Union. Windows to the east and south give a wide-angle view of New York as if from a plane about to land. The view inside is no less spectacular, with some 100 works by the 19th-century French master deployed around the gallery, fronted by a bronze cast of a renowned Rodin heavy, ''The Thinker,'' weighing 1,200 pounds and sitting more than six feet high.

title: RITA REYS, FIRST LADY OF EUROPEAN JAZZ
description: RITA REYS, a Dutch singer who is known as ''Europe's First Lady of Jazz,'' is not exactly a stranger to New York audiences but she is not a frequent visitor, either. She made her first appearance here 26 years ago at Birdland and has since returned from time to time.

title: BUSINESS TEAM GOES PROSPECTING IN WASHINGTON ON BEHALF OF CITY
description: David Rockefeller led a delegation of businessmen to Washington this week to explain what the group - members of the New York City Partnership - thinks Washington should be doing for mass transit and other local problems.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $420,000 from life insurance proceeds

title: Caroline Hood Carlin Dies at 72; Ex-Rockefeller Center Executive
description: Caroline Hood Carlin, retired vice president and public-relations consultant of Rockefeller Center Inc., died yesterday at the New England Medical Center in Boston. She was 72 years old and lived in Harwich Port, Mass.

title: Ex-Im Loan to B.W.I.A.
description: The Export-Import Bank said today that it would help finance the sale of two Lockheed L-1011 jets worth $82.6 million to British West Indian Airways. The bank will provide a 10-year loan of $24.8 million at an annual interest rate of 9.25 percent to the Ministry of Finance of Trinidad and Tobago; the rest of the money will come from a private loan and a cash payment.

title: LEFEVER IS FINE
description: There are two principal reasons why sincere people of good will oppose Ernest W. Lefever's nomination as President Reagan's Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights.

title: CITIZENS GROWTH PROPERTIES (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Current per shr figure not available

title: Around the Nation; Bail Is Denied for Suspect In $3 Million Bank Robbery
description: A 34-year-old man charged in the thefts of $2 million in jewelry was ordered held without bond today after a prosecutor told a Federal judge that the man was ''a suspect'' in a $3.3 million bank robbery in Tucson, Ariz.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Air Florida Systems will redeem all of its issued and outstanding $2.40 series B cumulative convertible preferred stock on June 29.

title: REAGAN BUDGET CUTS ARE CRITICIZED AT 330TH HARVARD COMMENCEMENT
description: Derek C. Bok, the president of Harvard University, sharply criticized several of the Reagan Administration's proposed cuts in student aid programs and in funds for higher education today but opposed Congressional efforts to pass a tuition tax credit for the parents of college students.

title: SOLDIERS ARE VILLIANS IN SALVADORANS' TALES OF HORROR
description: Seated on sacks of rice and powdered milk at a refugee camp, the farmer from the embattled northern state of Cabanas said he had been an army sympathizer until troops came to his town in March, burned a man alive on a pyre of sticks in the main square and killed a pregnant woman with a machete.

title: U.S. Will Extradite a Key Witness In 'French Connection' Drug Case
description: Josette Bauer, a 45-year-old Swiss woman whose testimony helped the United States authorities crack the ''French connection,'' a heroin-smuggling operation in the late 1960's, is scheduled to be extradited to Switzerland this Saturday to complete a prison sentence, the State Department said today.

title: Notes on People; Conductor Faces Long Journey Before Concert Starts
description: It promises to be a long day's journey into night today for Julius Rudel. He plans to interrupt his season at the Vienna Staatsoper, where he's conducting ''some Carmens, Bohemes, and Cav/Pags,'' to lead the National Symphony Orchestra in the season's opening concert at Wolf Trap Park just outside Washington tonight.

title: DRUG SUSPECT AND 8 INDICTED IN SLAYINGS
description: A reputed major drug dealer in Harlem and eight other persons, including two youths 15 and 16 years old, were indicted yesterday in connection with six killings and four attempted killings since February 1980. Three other men were being sought.

title: REAGAN'S NEW PLAN CUTS BUSINESS TAX AID
description: The Reagan Administration proposed a revised tax package today that, if adopted by Congress, would reduce by $50 billion over six years the tax savings that President Reagan had originally proposed for business.

title: Q. WHAT DO SCHUBERT AND BARTOK HAVE IN COMMON? A. A FESTIVAL
description: Two chamber music concerts tonight and Sunday offer a fascinating comparison of different composers in search of success. Both events are in Carnegie Hall's 13-part Schubert-Bartok festival and both - with the exception of the Bartok ''Contrasts'' for clarinet, violin and piano on Sunday -deal exclusively with Schubert.

title: Index; Index; International
description: Japanese leftists and unionists protest return of U.S. carrier A3 Reagan to attend North-South talks, Mexicans say A4 Acting President of Bangladesh pledges election on schedule A5 Around the World A7 Polish union votes brief warning strike for next Thursday A9 Government/Politics Harrisburg having trouble with crime and exodus A10 House panel approves plan to speed nuclear plant openings A12 Suspended sheriff asks Carey to investigate DelBello B2 Esposito running his mayoral campaign on a shoestring B3 City defers hiring firefighters until pension fund is approved B6 New York explores buying the 160 buses it has leased B16 General Around the Nation A10 Atlantans changing summer plans as fear continues A12 Jersey riparian rights costly to casinos B2 Rockefeller leads business group from city to Washington B3 Nine indicted in drugs and murder case B6 Education/Welfare Religious groups back tuition tax credits at hearing A13 Reagan proposals criticized at Harvard's commencement B4 City University confers advanced degrees on 236 B4 N.Y.U. holds 149th commencement exercises B4 Features/Notes Man in the News: Roy L.
