title: CHASTIY'S PLEASURES
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR SOME ALASKA OFFICIALS, OIL BRINGS PROBLEMS AS WELL AS WEALTH
description: No one wants to give the money back, but Alaska's oil wealth has become more a source of worry than a pleasure to the people in public life here. At least, that is what some officials say as they near the end of a nearly six-month budget struggle, a legislative record in Alaska.

title: Highlights of New Tax Plan
description: The revised tax plan announced today by the President includes these highlights:

title: B.P. CUTS NORTH SEA OIL OUTPUT
description: The world oil glut, coupled with the high official price for crude oil from the British sector of the North Sea, has forced the British Petroleum Company to reduce production from its Forties Field there by 17 percent during the second quarter of this year, the company said yesterday.

title: ETHNIC MUSIC FROM A, FOR ARMENIA, TO Z, FOR ZAGREB
description: Tomorrow the sound of the accordion will be heard in Astoria. And so, from noon to midnight, will the sounds of such instruments as the bagpipe and fiddle, the tambourine and guitar, as well as a Yugoslav bell-shaped clarinet known as the taragot.

title: A 'LITTLE GUY' ENTERS THE MAYORAL FRAY
description: Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens Village, a conservative Republican, says he believes Mayor Koch's bid for cross-endorsement ''threatens the existence of the Republican Party in the U. S. of America'' and intends to stop the immensely popular Democratic Mayor.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 5, 1981
description: International Egypt sought to ease the crisis in Lebanon at a meeting in the Sinai. President Anwar el-Sadat asked Prime Minister Menachem Begin to halt Israeli attacks on Palestinian guerrilla bases and to place no deadline on diplomatic efforts for a peaceful solution of the dispute over Syrian missiles in Lebanon. Mr. Begin insisted that the attacks were essential to Israel's security, but he agreed to give Syria more time to withdraw the missiles. (Page A1, Col. 1.) The sale of advanced weapons to China is being considered by the Reagan Administration as it prepares for a visit to Peking next week by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. Administration officials said there was rising interest in providing China with such technology as antitank missiles and the engine and electrical equipment from the new F-16 jet. (A1:3-4.)

title: Verderosa Defeats Solis, Retains U.S.B.A. Title
description: Johnny Verderosa, who at 5 feet 5 inches and 130 pounds managed to play two years of football at Curtis High School in Staten Island, was never tackled as much as he was last night in defending his United States Boxing Association junior lightweight championship with a unanimous decision over Enrique Solis of Puerto Rico.

title: U.S. HEARS OF NEW MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND BUT IS WARY OF 'CRYING WOLF'
description: Reagan Administration officials expressed concern today over reports that the Soviet Union and some of its allies might be planning another set of Warsaw Pact maneuvers around Poland to intimidate the Poles as their crucial July congress of the Communist Party approaches.

title: Home Loan Rates Climb
description: Interest rates on home loans for new single-family houses soared to an average of 16.1 percent last month, the highest since the all-time record of 16.59 percent in April of last year, the Government reported today.

title: DANCE: MISS GAMSON AND 3 GUESTS
description: BECAUSE early in this century Isadora Duncan danced at Carnegie Hall, it was historically appropriate for Annabelle Gamson, a contemporary specialist in Duncan dancing, to perform there Wednesday night. And because Miss Duncan worked with noted musicians, it was esthetically appropriate that Miss Gamson's pianist was Garrick Ohlsson. Their collaboration thoroughly deserved the ovation it received.

title: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES PLAN DESIGNED TO SPEED ATOM PLANT OPENINGS
description: A House committee voted today to allow the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to issue interim licenses for new nuclear power plants, even though public hearings have not been completed.

title: Phillips Unfazed By Rogers's Visit
description: Coach Bum Phillips of the New Orleans Saints said today that he is not worried about the way the Montreal Alouettes are wooing George Rogers.

title: Broadway; Psychiatrist gets to be femme fatale in a new mystery play.
description: THE question, asked endlessly, is where are the new playrights? One answer is, on stage in the theater. Warren Manzi, who is the understudy to Tim Curry in ''Amadeus,'' has written ''Perfect Crime,'' which Morton Gottlieb will produce next fall. It is a four-character play in which the star part is that of a woman psychiatrist, who practices sex with her patients and who murders people as well. Exactly whom she has murdered, however, is unclear. Anyway, Mr. Gottlieb says, it's a naughty play.

title: THE ENDURING STRENGTH OF DRUG TRADEMARKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dutch Journalist Ousted by China After Forming Ties to Dissidents
description: A Dutch newspaper correspondent, Willem E.C. Van Kemenade, departed today for Taiwan, complying with the Chinese Government's request that he leave because of ''inappropriate'' behavior.

title: KEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
MARION TULLY DIMICK
description: Marion Tully Dimick, a Washington philanthropist, died Tuesday at her home here after a heart attack.

title: Peaches Debt Filing
description: Peaches Records and Tapes, a Los Angeles-based record chain with 35 stores, filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The company, citing $20 million in debts, attributed its problems to a sharp decline in demand for phonograph records.

title: Postal Equipment Contracts Issued
description: The United States Postal Service said that it had awarded contracts totaling more than $188 million to Pitney Bowes Inc. and the Burroughs Corporation for the production of new scanning equipment for automated sorting of mail.

title: THEATER: AL PACINO IN 'AMERICAN BUFFALO'
description: IF Dreiser had lived in the age of Beckett, he just might have written ''American Buffalo.'' Like many of Dreiser's novels, David Mamet's brilliant play is a violent vision of the dog-eat-dog jungle of urban American capitalism. But if Dreiser sent his doomed proletarian losers loping through sprawling narratives and largerthan-life events, Mr. Mamet does the exact reverse by following the fashions of modern drama. ''American Buffalo'' is as reductivist as ''An American Tragedy'' is expansive. Instead of a big story and torrents of grand prose, Mr. Mamet's play provides only an inconsequential anecdote and declarative sentences of one-syllable words. Yet by the time ''American Buffalo'' is over, it, too, has pounded away at the American dream of success until it is left in soiled, hideous tatters.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS ACT TO EASE HOUSING CUTS
description: Democrats on a key House committee agreed today on a legislative package that would soften some of the more drastic cuts in public housing programs backed by the Reagan Administration and passed yesterday by the Senate.

title: Estimate of Farm Income Is Cut
description: The Agriculture Department, sharply paring its previous estimate, now says farmers may earn no more this year than they did in 1980.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Veterans Who Collapsed Press for Reagan Interview
description: Two veterans of the Vietnam War who collapsed in their hunger strike vowed today to go without food until President Reagan listened to their demands for action on veterans' problems.

title: 58- STORY NEEDLE PLANNED ON 52D ST. NEAR '21' CLUB
description: What might be the world's most slender building is expected to rise this fall in the middle of the block between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas on 52d Street. It would house both offices and apartments.

title: CITIZENSHIP BILL GAINS IN BRITISH PARLIAMENT OVER MINORITY PROTESTS
description: Britain's House of Commons tonight passed a nationality bill attacked by immigrant groups as racially discriminatory.

title: PRESIDENT ACCEDES TO MAJOR REVISIONS IN TAX-CUT PACKAGE
description: President Reagan announced major revisions in his tax-cut plan today, reducing the benefits that he had promised business and adding tax breaks for individuals. The move was a step toward winning bipartisan Congressional support for his proposed three-year reduction in personal income taxes.

title: PERSONAL STEREO MARKET SWELLS
description: At first the Walkman walked alone. And jogged alone. And bicycled alone. And rollerskated alone. Now it has been joined by a stampede of competitors. Since late 1979, when the Sony Corporation introduced the Walkman - a $200 stereo cassette player to be worn on a belt or around the neck and heard through featherweight headphones -the device has become the rage of outdoor athletes and one of the fastest-growing products in audio electronics. 'Major Trend' Predicted

title: Senator Helms Reported In Deal on Nominations
description: Senator Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican, has withdrawn his opposition to the Senate confirmation of Chester A. Crocker to be Assistant Secretary of State for African affairs, the Senate Majority Leader, Howard Baker, said today.

title: PANEL OF DEMOCRATS MAKES LOYALTY PLEA
description: The executive committee of the Democratic National Committee unanimously called on House Democrats today to support party leaders and not back President Reagan's tax legislation, which it called ''welfare programs for the wealthy.''

title: Around the World; Churchmen of 2 Faiths Pray for Peace in Ulster
description: The Protestant leaders of the Church of Ireland and the Church of England knelt with Ireland's Cardinal in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic cathedral today to pray for peace in this British province.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Aoki Posts 67, Leads Atlanta Golf by Shot
description: Isao Aoki, a Japanese golfer who is a member of the American pro tour, birdied four straight holes today on his way to a 67 and the first-round lead in the $300,000 Atlanta Classic.

title: THIS IS JUMP HED Mrs. Lloyd, McEnroe Lose in France; Mrs. Lloyd Defeated; McEnroe Also Bows
description: After winning 64 consecutive matches on clay, Chris Evert Lloyd was soundly beaten on that surface today and eliminated from the French Open tennis tournament, 7-5, 6-4, by Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia.

title: TUNES SET TONE AS N.Y.U. CLASS GETS DIPLOMAS
description: Purple and white balloons floated high over Washington Square Park yesterday at the conclusion of the 149th commencement exercises at New York University, which for several of the 7,500 degree-winners was a family affair.

title: Outside Post Drawn For Pleasant Colony
description: Pleasant Colony drew the outside post in the field of 11 named yesterday for the 113th running of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. ''What's the difference ?'' was the reaction from Johnny Campo, trainer of the colt who could become the 12th winner of thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown for 3-year-olds by taking this mile-and-a-half test. ''The post position won't make no difference,'' Campo said. If he's capable of winning it, he will. If he's not, he won't.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BEST SELLER. By Geoffrey Bocca. 233 pages. Illustrated. Wyndham. $12.95.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: The yr-ago figures were restated to reflect the sale of 450,000 shrs of common stock

title: SHERIFF ASKS FOR INQUIRY ON DELBELLO AND HIS POSSIBLE REMOVAL BY CAREY
description: The suspended sheriff of Westchester County called on Governor Carey today to investigate the administration of County Executive Alfred B. DelBello ''with a view towards determining the question of removing'' him from office.

title: At the Movies; Dyan Cannon has plenty to laugh about.
description: DYAN CANNON doesn't do many interviews, partly because over the last few years she's been amassing material for an autobiographical book of her own, and she doesn't want to give it away. But she's playing the wife in the upcoming movie version of the stage thriller ''Deathtrap,'' with Michael Caine, Christopher Reeve and Irene Worth, and making movies is a business, so once in a while, she'll sit still for a few questions.

title: Market Place; Continental's Stock Plan
description: CONTROL of Continental Air Lines by an Employee Stock Ownership Plan could markedly enhance the carrier's profits in the years immediately ahead. That, at least, is an argument offered in support of the labor-management effort to issue and sell shares to an employee trust.

title: RENEWAL THRIVES AT ASPHALT GREEN
description: Viewed from the 90th Street bend in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the soaring parabolic arch of the old Municipal Asphalt Plant suggests a big brown barrel-section resting on its side. For 40 years a motorists' conversation piece and a magnet for artists, it has been unused as city property since 1976.

title: 236 AWARDED ADVANCED DEGREES BY CITY UNIVERSITY
description: Advanced degrees were presented to 236 graduates of the City University of New York Graduate Center yesterday. Walter Cronkite, a college dropout, was one of three who received honorary degrees. ''That you have achieved so much without benefit of a college degree makes us wonder how essential we are,'' said Arthur Schlesinger Jr., a professor at City University, who read the citation. Mr. Cronkite, the former CBS anchorman, left his studies as a youth at the University of Texas to go to work full time as a reporter for The Houston Post.

title: MEDTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Sports of The Times; Reluctant Yankee Trouble Shooter
description: CLYDE KING does not want to be the Yankee pitching coach. He makes this declaration whenever George Steinbrenner delegates him to work with the pitchers. All things considered, King says, he would rather be on the road, scouting the Yankees' next opponent.

title: FOREIGN BANKS LIKE REAGAN
description: President Reagan may still be struggling to sell his economic package to the United States Congress, but his economic policies and general leadership are winning praise from at least one important foreign group - bankers.

title: Auctions; Old masters at three houses.
description: MURILLO'S ''The Virgin of the Swaddling Cloth'' is described by Sotheby Parke Bernet as the most important old master painting it will offer for auction next week, a period when hundreds of old masters will be up for sale at three of New York's leading auction houses. Paintings by the 17th-century Spanish artist rarely appear at auction. Rarer still are works by him that carry a well-documented pedigree. ''The Virgin of the Swaddling Cloth'' was owned by King Louis Phillipe of France from 1838 to 1850 and was exhibited at the Louvre in 1840. The 1598 oil on canvas, which depicts the Virgin and Child enveloped in a golden atmospheric background, will be in the 10:15 A.M. session of Sotheby's sale next Thursday (an afternoon session begins at 2 P.M.) at the auction house's Madison Avenue galleries, at 76th Street.

title: U.S. House Panel Votes To Honor Wallenberg
description: A special subcommittee of the House of Representatives voted today to confer honorary United States citizenship on Raoul Wallenberg, a Swede credited with saving the lives of 100,000 Hungarian Jews at the end of World War II.

title: Advertising; Crunching to the Beat Of a New Musical Game
description: If you love bingo, you are going to adore C.R.U.N.C.H., a new game with lots of prizes coming our way from the Nestle candy bar of the same name.

title: 16 INDICTED OVER UNION FUND USE
description: Two alleged leaders of organized crime, Santo Trafficante Jr. and Anthony Accardo, and 14 other persons have been indicted in connection with kickbacks involving the Laborers International Union of North America, Federal officials said today.

title: BABY'S FATHER AGREES TO WITHDRAW HIS SUIT OVER SURROGATE BIRTH
description: A Rochester, N.Y., man today withdrew his suit to gain custody of a child who was born to a surrogate mother under a contract. The man acted after a judge agreed to place his name on the infant's birth certificate.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Notes on People; Congressman Has a Complaint About the White House
description: A complaint was voiced yesterday by Representative Thomas J. Downey, a Long Island Democrat, that the Reagan Administration had deprived him of one of a Congressman's cherished perquisites - the allocation of up to 10 tickets a week for V.I.P. tours of the White House to be doled out to constituents.

title: TCHAIKOVSKY OPENER: CHAOS AND PIZZAZZ
description: THE Tchaikovsky Festival, everyone predicted, would never get off the ground. Chaos reigned backstage at the New York State Theater, it was said, for weeks ahead. But the New York City Ballet has a way with festivals. And somehow this one opened on schedule last night with the right - though decorous - pizzazz, just as the Stravinsky Festival had in 1972 and the Ravel Festival three years after. Guests began to arrive at 6:30, making their way up to the First Ring cocktail party in a surge of tuxedos and frothy evening gowns.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 21 about a Senate hearing on bills to curtail the role of Federal courts incorrectly identified a witness. Telford Taylor, an emeritus professor at Columbia University, is a faculty member of the Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University.

title: BROOKS'S STAMP IS WAITING FOR RANGERS
description: Herb Brooks's eyes narrowed, and they seemed to blaze. He was about to say something serious, something that recalled the intensity of that speech he used to make to his underdog Olympic Games hockey players, the one that started this way: ''We'll go up to that tiger and spit in his eye.''

title: The Region; School Bus Owner Admits Tax Cheating
description: NEWARK (AP) - The first person to be charged in connection with a continuing statewide Internal Revenue Service investigation of New Jersey school bus contracts pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal tax evasion.

title: RETURN OF THE MIDWAY TO JAPAN STIRS PROTESTS
description: The American aircraft carrier Midway returned to the United States naval base at Yokosuka today after protest rallies by left-wing students and a march by several thousand trade unionists last night outside the base.

title: BROOKLYN MOTHER, 19, CHARGED WITH MURDER IN DAUGHTER'S SCALDING
description: A 19-year-old mother was arrested last night and charged with placing her two young daughters in a pot of boiling water, killing one and seriously scalding the other, ''to teach them a lesson,'' the police said.

title: PHILADELPHIA IS HARRIS'S STORY
description: In the aftermath of his second straight impressive pitching performance against the Phillies, Greg Harris took time this afternoon to assess his new role with the Mets, who traveled here for a weekend series.

title: CETUS CHARTING A BROAD COURSE
description: The Cetus Corporation, the country's oldest, largest and most highly capitalized genetic engineering company, is charting its course across a broad range of chemicals, foods and fuels that can be produced with recombinant DNA, known as gene-splicing.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Cardinals 4, Expos 1
description: ST. LOUIS (UPI) - Dane Iorg went 3 for 3, drove in a run and scored twice to back the seven-hit pitching of Lary Sorensen and lead St. Louis.

title: GOVERNMENT'S DEBT TO SOCIAL SEURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Paper Board To Buy Back Shares
description: The Federal Paper Board Company of New York announced an agreement to purchase from the Reliance Group Inc. a block of 1,855,000 of Federal Paper Board's common shares for a total of $74.2 million, or $40 a share.

title: ART: EXPRESSIONISM FROM ITALY ARRIVES
description: IT looks as if one of the features of the American art scene in the 1980's is going to be a heightened interest in the new art now emerging in Europe. More and more ''young'' European artists - young, that is, either in age or reputation -are attracting serious attention in this country, and the tendency to believe that contemporary American art is somehow uniformly ''better'' than its European counterpart, dating from the worldwide acclaim of American art in the 1960's, no longer commands the credence it once did.

title: The Region; A V.A. Security Chief Indicted in Jersey
description: NEWARK (AP) - The chief of security at the Veterans Administration in East Orange was indicted on charges that he illegally wiretapped conversations of other hospital security officers last September.

title: Mrs. Truman's Condition Gains
description: Bess Truman, 96-year-old widow of President Truman, was moved from intensive care today to a private room at Research Medical Center. Dr. Wallace Graham said that it was another step in her recovery from hip surgery nearly a month ago.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
ACTING PRESIDENT IN DACCA PROMISES NEW ELECTIONS
description: Abdus Sattar, the acting President, today reiterated his caretaker Government's determination to hold a presidential election on schedule and ''to foil any conspiracy to disturb the democratic process in the country.''

title: Fred Meyer Inc.  To Consider Offer
description: Fred Meyer Inc., a diversified West Coast food retailer, said that it had received an unsolicited offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, an investment firm, for a leveraged buyout of the company's 7.3 million common shares at $53 each, or a total of $386 million.

title: Eastern Airlines Settles Suit
description: Eastern Airlines will pay more than $20,000 a year for life to a small boy partly paralyzed when the airliner in which he was traveling with his mother flew into turbulence and he was bounced to the ceiling, the family's lawyer. T.G. LaGrone, said today. In an out-of-court settlement, Eastern admitted that its crew had not informed passengers of the risk of turbulence. The victim, Chad Wojcik, now 5 years old, was three months old at the time of the accident.

title: No Headline
description: Ayub Kalule, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, has signed to fight Wilfred Benitez, the World Boxing Council super welterweight champion, in a title unification bout this fall.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $39 million

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Sports World Specials column in SportsMonday this week, the director of player personnel for the Pittsburgh Steelers was incorrectly identified. He is Dick Haley.

title: REAGAN TO ATTEND FALL CONFERENCE ON THE THIRD WORLD, MEXICANS SAY
description: President Reagan has agreed to join the leaders of 21 industrialized and developing nations at a meeting in Mexico this fall to discuss the economic problems of the third world, Mexican officials said today.

title: Clyde on 5-Game Streak
description: David Clyde, the 1973 schoolboy sensation with the Texas Rangers who ran into arm trouble last season, is continuing to enjoy success in his comeback in Class AA baseball with Columbus of the Southern League. Clyde, who is 26 years old, has pitched 19 straight scoreless innings and won five games in a row without a defeat for an 0.70 earned run average.

title: Reagan to Name General Walters To Be an Ambassador at Large
description: Vernon A. Walters, a retired lieutenant general who has already made several unannounced foreign trips for the Reagan Administration, will be nominated to be an ambassador at large, the White House announced today.

title: M.A.C. Planning A New Placement
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York completed private placement of $237 million of second resolution M.A.C. bonds yesterday. And it will make another private placement of $324.7 million of bonds by Dec. 31, it was announced by Stephen Weinstein, M.A.C.'s deputy executive director.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW NOVEL IN THE WORLD OF JOHN IRVING
description: AT a recent dinner party given for John Irving by his publisher, Dutton, to celebrate his coming novel ''The Hotel New Hampshire,'' the author said, ''It's a pleasure to know that people are anticipating a book of mine.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the quietest corner in the world - an Israeli-Egyptian border.'' - Prime Minister Menachem Begin. (A8:3.)

title: Metromedia Obtains Two Radio Stations
description: Metromedia Inc. announced that it had traded a radio station in San Francisco for one in St. Petersburg, Fla., and purchased a Denver station for $15 million.

title: MY TOWN NEEDS THE MX
description: We are often asked why this little town in southwest Utah, with a population of less than 1,500, supports the MX missile so enthusiastically. Why would we want the Air Force and construction crews to swarm over our community and our desert valleys? The answer is complex.

title: SCENE STEALING FORCES FILM DIRECTOR TO RESHOOT
description: The theft last month of 2,000 feet of crucial parade-scene footage for the movie ''Blow Out,'' has forced its director, Brian DePalma, to recall thousands of movie extras, cameramen and technicians to Philadelphia to reshoot the scene this weekend.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JUNE 5, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan revised his tax plan, lessening benefits for business and adding tax breaks for individuals, as a step toward winning bipartisan Congressional support for his proposed reduction in income-tax rates. (Page A1.) The new package would reduce by $50 billion over six years the tax savings for business that Mr. Reagan had originally proposed. (D3.) Despite earlier pledges to keep its tax legislation simple, the Administration has added a flurry of ''sweetener'' provisions to capture crucial votes. (A1.) Business leaders were critical of the changes. (D2.)

title: A WEEKEND OF FILMS WITH NEW YORK CITY AS STAR
description: Film has always had a lot to say about New York, sometimes by accident and sometimes by intention. There have been films shot in New York that were about love and crime and money and ambition that ended up being as much about the city as about any of these other things, and there have been other movies that never made any bones about telling any story except that of the city itself.

title: S-A-R-C-O-P-H-A-G-U-S SPELLS FIRST PRIZE
description: Her voice breaking with emotion, 13-year-old Paige Pipkin of El Paso, who was last year's runner-up, correctly spelled ''sarcophagus'' today to win the 54th National Spelling Bee.

title: American League; Twins 7, Rangers 3
description: Ron Jackson got three singles and two runs batted in, and Dan Goodwin hit a two-run single to pace Minnesota.

title: Restaurants; Beguiling Thai food skillfully prepared.
description: WITH its spicy and aromatic counterpoints of flavor, and the lively textural contrasts it affords, the food of Thailand is certainly one of the world's most entertaining and engaging cuisines. Influenced by India in the use of herbs and spices, and borrowing cooking techniques from the Chinese, the Thais over the centuries have added innovations that resulted in an original and diverting collection of dishes. At the Siam Inn on Eighth Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets, dozens of beguiling Thai specialties are skillfully prepared and attractively presented by a shyly gracious and efficient staff. If some of the kitchen's efforts are lackluster, most of the dishes offered are skillfully seasoned with onions, coriander, crushed roasted peanuts and fiery chilies, mellowing garlic and cooling cucumber and the highly perfumed juices of lemons and exotic Kaffir limes. Basil, lemon grass and brassy curry spices also give Thai food its character and the basic stir-fry, steaming and grilling techniques are competently performed.

title: Business People; A Top Citicorp Officer Resigns for New Post
description: George J. Vojta, who was in the running to succeed Walter B. Wriston as chairman of Citicorp, has resigned to become senior vice president and chief financial officer of the Phibro Corporation, according to sources in the banking industry.

title: Around the Nation; 11 Haitians Are Deported As U.S. Steps Up Hearings
description: After a major step-up in Immigration and Naturalization Service hearings, 11 of the Haitians who fled to this country by boat were deported today.

title: Navy to Build New Cruise Missile That Can Strike Deep Into Soviet
description: The Reagan Administration has authorized the Navy to build its new cruise missile with a long-range capability to strike deep inside the Soviet Union, the Pentagon acknowledged today.

title: TUITION TAX CREDITS BACKED AT HEARING
description: The leader of Moral Majority joined rabbis and Roman Catholic bishops today in endorsing proposed tuition tax credits for private education.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois High Court Bars Release of an Unborn Child
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today refused to order the release of an unborn child whose mother is in jail.

title: Assets Increase At Money Funds
description: After four weeks of decline, assets of the nation's 122 money market mutual funds rose $680.5 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $118.4 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: U.S. ENDING FOUR RACIAL BIAS SUITS
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, reached a settlement today terminating four lawsuits in which the company had been accused of discriminating against blacks and Hispanic Americans.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''I 'VE been waiting for this party for three years!'' 27-year-old Marie Chiment said the other night as she sat on a white wrought-iron bench next to the gurgling fountain in Oliver Smith's grassy garden in Brooklyn Heights.

title: CHEECH & CHONG BACK IN THE STONED AGE
description: CHEECH MARIN and Thomas Chong have been blowing the same old smoke rings for so long that their antics have become stale - right? Not right, at least not in ''Cheech and Chong's Nice Dreams,'' the latest of their delirious adventures. As their marijuana-haze humor becomes more and more dated, Cheech and Chong have developed a venerable air. They may not be elder statesmen, but some day they'll be the last two hippies on earth. For the time being, they're the funniest.

title: Business People; Sun Company Chooses Chief Operating Officer
description: Robert McClements Jr., 52, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Sun Company, the nation's 11th-largest petroleum corporation. He moves up from executive vice president, succeeding Theodore A. Burtis, 59, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, with headquarters in Radnor, Pa.

title: CABLE TV CONCERNS FINDING 'REAL ESTATE' IN SPACE IS SCARCE
description: A severe shortage of transponder space on satellites used by cable television networks to beam programs across the country has vastly inflated prices for available slots, according to satellite specialists.

title: Anaheim Center Hit by Blast
description: A bomb exploded in a plastic trash can at the Anaheim Convention Center, blowing out large windows and nearby doors minutes after 5,000 people there ended a religious gathering, the Kenneth Copeland Crusade, the police said today. Police officer Dennis Fair said that no injuries were reported in the blast, which occurred yesterday about 10 P.M.

title: Hirsch Advances in Scotland
description: Joel Hirsch, a Chicago businessman, defeated Donald DuBois of Arizona State today, 3 and 2, to advance to the quarterfinals of the British Amateur championship.

title: CITY BALLET OPENS ITS TCHAIKOVSKY FESTIVAL
description: TRUE to form, the New York City Ballet opened its eagerly awaited Tchaikovsky Festival last night at the New York State Theater in a grandly wayward City Ballet manner.

title: 13.75% Mortgages Sell Out in an Hour
description: Connecticut home buyers yesterday exhausted an offering of $40 million of 13.75 percent mortgages within an hour after they were made available through a new state program.

title: Advertising; People
description: * William S. David named advertising director of Rolling Stone magazine.

title: COUNTY KINGS IS PLAYING HOST TO A SQUARE MILE OF IRISH FAIR
description: AMODEST parade tomorrow morning at 10, including two pipe bands, Connemara ponies, Mayor Koch, Governor Carey and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, will inaugurate a new New York event in an old New York place - the Great Irish Fair on the historic Brooklyn waterfront. Tomorrow and Sunday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., between the Brooklyn and Manhattan bridges, the outdoor festival will celebrate things Irish, from both the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland. There will be a strong emphasis on arts and crafts, but there will also be Irish food, Celtic sports, Irish music, antiques and a Corkstyle flower market.

title: Economic Scene; Dangers Put In Perspective
description: THESE are days when many people, great and humble, have the sensation of living under a volcano. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany has again declared that high interest rates in the United States are undermining Europe's economy and could lead to a world depression.

title: Advertising; Alberto-Culver Products Shift to D'Arcy-McManus
description: D'Arcy-McManus & Masius of Chicago will be doing the creative work for three established Alberto-Culver brands as well as a number of new products.

title: Japan to Limit Cars for Canada
description: The Japanese Government has decided to voluntarily limit car exports to Canada in the fiscal year 1981 ending next March to about 6 percent below 1980's level, Government sources said here today.

title: Policy Shift Set on Iran Assets
description: Treasury regulations issued today threatened American banks and others holding $2 billion to $4 billion in Iranian financial assets with criminal prosecution unless they transfer the assets to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York by June 19.

title: ONE KILLED, ONE HURT IN JERSEY CHEMICAL PLANT BLAST
description: One employee was killed and a second was burned yesterday afternoon in an explosion and fire at a chemical processing plant of the American Cyanamid Company near Bound Brook, N.J. The cause of the blast was not immediately determined.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Restated to reflect accounting changes to LIFO from FIFO; the yr-ago shrs earnings figure adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid in January

title: COSMOS AND SAO PAULO TIE, 2-2
description: The Cosmos played a cohesive and imaginative soccer game tonight only to be tied, 2-2, by Sao Paulo of Brazil, which gained the equalizer with 1 minute 25 seconds left.

title: Topic; DUBIOUS ECONOMIES; Uniprop
description: The folks at the United Nations can't understand why anyone should question the propriety of their soliciting private funds for paying the ''expenses'' of newspapers and editors willing to publish special supplements that promote the world organization's views on aid to poor countries.

title: Johns-Manville Cut
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said it had lowered the Johns-Manville Corporation's senior debt ratings and all of that company's publicly rated, pollution-control revenue bonds to Single-A from Single-B-plus, and has cut the company's preferred stock rating to Triple-B from Triple-B-plus, while maintaining the company's A1 commercial paper rating. Among reasons for the changes, Standard & Poor's cited a decline in the company's financial flexibility related to uncertainty about litigation over the health hazards of asbestos, a major Johns-Manville product.

title: DOW OFF 2.97 IN CAUTIOUS MARKET
description: Energy stocks finally showed some strength yesterday, but the rest of the market finished virtually on an even keel as investors remained sensitive to interest-rate changes and other concerns. Japanese issues that have constituted one of the market's strongest sectors were hit by profit-taking.

title: Velsicol Merger Halt
description: A Federal judge, acting on a motion by the Federal Trade Commission, has issued a temporary restraining order halting a nearly $30 million takeover of the Velsicol Chemical Corporation's bromine manufacturing process. United States District Judge Frank J. McGarr issued the order to prevent the takeover by the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation, the nation's largest producer of elemental bromine and brominated flame retardants, and set a hearing for June 29. Great Lakes, based in Lafayette, Ind., had planned to purchase the Chicago-based Velsicol operation for an estimated $29.7 million.

title: Advertising; 'The Best Years Guide' Is Expanding Westward
description: Richard J. Roll is a 29-year-old publisher who probably is also the country's, and perhaps the world's, youngest expert on retirement planning. Have you seen ''The Best Years Guide,'' which ran twice last year as an advertising supplement in The New York Times and Newsday? That's what he publishes.

title: Topic; DUBIOUS ECONOMIES; Naval Maneuver
description: Claiming that its Brooklyn Bush Terminal offices are unsafe, the U.S. Navy's Ships' Stores headquarters wants to remodel and move into the old buildings of Fort Wadsworth on Staten Island - a disturbing idea, because the fort and its grounds are designated to become a choice part of Gateway National Park.

title: The U.N. Today; June 5, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FEAR ALTERS ATLANTANS' SUMMER PLANS
description: Soon after her four children finish their school year tomorrow, Thelma Malone will take off from work without pay so that she and the children can join a busload of neighbors for a weekend to get away from the fear and frustration of black family life here.

title: CITY EXPLORED BUYING LEASED BUSES
description: The New York City Transit Authority, looking for reserve buses to shore up its depleted fleet, explored the possibility of buying the 160 aging buses that it has leased for the last five months from Washington, transportation officials said yesterday.

title: Tyco Heinicke Stake
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc. said that it had purchased 686,500 shares, or about 24 percent, of the outstanding common stock of Heinicke Instruments Company, a maker of medical laboratory equipment and jet engine parts. Tyco said it had paid between $11 and $12.50 a share for the stake, putting an indicated value on the transaction of about $8 million. Tyco, a manufacturer of fire protection systems, said the shares had been purchased primarily from Rudolf Israel, a director of Heinicke Instruments and Rolf Franz, president of Heinicke.

title: MATHEMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: The current yr net includes a $90,000 income tax credit

title: BONDS HURT ON FIRST PLAY AS CUB
description: Bobby Bonds's comeback bid took an unfortunate turn tonight when he broke a finger fielding the first ball that came his way in his first major league game since last season.

title: Hawes Signs With Hawks
description: The Atlanta Hawks announced the signing of Steve Hawes to a multiyear contract today, the first signing of a free agent under the National Basketball Association's policy of right of first refusal.

title: HAYDEN WALLING
description: Hayden Walling, an architect and builder known for the homes he designed on Cape Cod, died Sunday at his summer home in Wellfleet, Mass. He was 64 years old and lived in Warwick N.Y.

title: News Analysis
description: To the surprise of some pessimists, Bangladesh has weathered the all-important first stage of its present political crisis, which is one of the gravest it has had to face in its precarious decade of independence.

title: Around the World; South African Police Clash With Students
description: Riot policemen clashed with students at another mixed-race high school today, leaving three injured. The police commissioner vowed to ''hit harder'' and said protesters would not win the release of Aziz Jardine, a student leader jailed without charge.

title: Republic Acquisition
description: The Republic Steel Corporation announced that its Republic Hogg Robinson affiliate had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Penn General Agencies Inc., a subsidiary of Penncorp Financial Inc., for about $42.5 million.

title: The Crime of Scientific Zeal
description: The reprimand by the National Institutes of Health of a California scientist who performed improper gene-splicing experiments has broad symbolic importance. More is at stake here than the misconduct of Dr. Martin Cline of the University of California at Los Angeles - apparently the first scientist to insert controversial ''recombinant DNA'' molecules into humans.

title: No Headline
description: A rather unusual television crew appeared yesterday in the great herd of cameramen, soundmen and lighting technicians who invaded this remote desert settlement for the meeting between Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt.

title: REBUFFED IN SENATE, LEFEVER PULLS OUT AS RIGHTS NOMINEE
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13 to 4 today to recommend that the Senate reject the nomination of Ernest W. Lefever as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights. Five hours later, Mr. Lefever withdrew from consideration for the post.

title: CONTAMINATED WELLS CAUSE ANXIETY IN A SMALL TOWN IN PUTNAM COUNTY
description: Every day, housewives in the hillside neighborhood around Cottage Road in this small Putnam County community drive to the homes of friends or relatives, sometimes miles away, to fill big jugs or gallon containers with water.

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times A Gourmet of Collapse By ANATOLE BROYARD Oh! By Mary Robison. 209 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: TRANSIT UNIT CAN'T SAY HOW 300 BUS DRIVERS SPEND WORKING DAYS
description: Officials of the New York City Transit Authority are unable to say what 300 bus drivers have been doing since last December when Grumman buses were taken out of service for repairs.

title: RETAIL SALES CLIMB 10.3% IN CITY
description: The value of retail sales in New York City in May rose 10.3 percent from the level of May last year in a continuation of a trend that began in March, according to a spot check of seven major retailers.

title: Warnaco Sells Unit
description: James C. Walker, chairman and chief executive of Warnaco Inc., Bridgeport, Conn., producer of apparel and sports equipment, announced yesterday that the company's wholly owned subsidiary, Jerry Silverman Inc., had been sold to an investment group for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes. The group includes Harold Farkas, executive vice president of the subsidiary. Mr. Walker also announced that Warnaco had signed an agreement with Christian Dior to market women's active sportswear under the Dior label.

title: 2 GUILTY IN DEATH OF PEARL RIVER GIRL
description: A handyman from Arkansas and a delicatessen clerk were found guilty of murder today in the stabbing death last October of 16-year-old Paula Bohovesky, a high school student and aspiring actress.

title: CAREY PROPOSES STATEWIDE LAW FOR FIRE SAFETY
description: Citing a need to ''eliminate the confusion and conflict'' created by various state and local fire codes, Governor Carey submitted legislation today that would require municipalities to adopt a uniform statewide fire-prevention and building code by Jan. 1, 1984.

title: MITTERRAND'S PROMISE
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH TIME FOR NEW YORK CITY TO THINK RECYCLING
description: To the Editor:

title: VIETNAM IN FICTION
description: Anyone enticed into seeing ''Search and Destroy'' by the two nastylooking sluggers on the movie's poster is going to be sorely disappointed. ''Search and Destroy,'' which opened yesterday at the Cinerama 1, is reasonably tame. Aside from one of the more anticlimactic endings in cinema history, it has little to make it memorable. Oh, yes -there's the moment when the hero hands his imperiled girlfriend a gun and tells her ''If anything happens, just pretend it's a camera and shoot.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Baker Mining Equipment Co., a unit of Baker International Corp., agreed to acquire all of the outstanding stock of Coppinger Machinery Service, in return for an undisclosed number of shares of Baker Mining common stock.

title: 5 MEMBERS OF CAREY TRANSIT PANEL VISIT SUBWAY AND BUS OPERATIONS
description: Five members of Governor Carey's transit advisory panel rode subways and buses early yesterday morning on a tour that provided them with a bleak glimpse of New York City's deteriorating transportation system.

title: Julia Ireland Wed To K.B. McCollum
description: The marriage of Julia Ireland, a stage and television actress, to Kevin Boyd McCollum, an associate with the New York law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, took place at St. James Episcopal Church yesterday. Horace W.B. Donegan, retired Bishop of New York, performed the ceremony.

title:
RED SMITH;
Campo's Barnyard Talk
description: JOHN CAMPO, the Buddy Delp of 1981, was holding court in misty sunshine outside Barn 48 at Belmont Park. He wore corduroy slacks, an orange polo shirt that bulged comfortably and a baseball cap of red and white quarters with the name ''Ferrara'' in script on the crown. The Ferraras, he said, are friends of his, nice people.

title: KILLINGS BY GUARD TEST SPANISH REGIME
description: An investigation into the deaths of three young men at the hands of the Civil Guard is turning into a major test of the independence of the Spanish judiciary and the credibility of the Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo.

title: Borg, Lendl In Final
description: Bjorn Borg spiced his game with volleying today and defeated Victor Pecci of Paraguay, 6-4, 6-4, 7-5, to reach the final of the $600,000 French Open tennis tournament.

title: 2 THEATERS' TENANTS ACCEPT PORTMAN BID TO VACATE EARLY
description: Developers of the proposed Portman Hotel complex near Times Square expect to take possession within the next few days of two theaters - the Helen Hayes and the Morosco - that are to be demolished.

title: Gilman New President of PEN
description: Richard Gilman, Yale professor and drama critic, has been installed as president of PEN American Center, succeeding Bernard Malamud, the novelist. Mr. Gilman is the 26th president of American PEN, the largest of the 82 centers of International PEN, the only world association of writers. Past presidents include Booth Tarkington, Robert Frost, Jerzy Kosinski and Muriel Rukeyser.

title: Treasury Details Tax Relief Plan
description: Treasury officials said today that the threephase tax relief plan proposed yesterday by President Reagan applied to withholding taxes, not to the tax tables that will be used to calculate tax liability for 1981, 1982 and 1983.

title: REAGAN JOINS A KENNEDY REMEMBARNCE
description: For a moment today, the Kennedy clan was center stage at the White House again, capturing the limelight with a special mixture of politics, history and glitter.

title: GROWTH REALTY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net income including $3,083,408 extraordinary credit

title: 3 Free in Killing of Youth Found in Alabama Tree
description: Three white men charged with killing a black youth whose body was found hanging in a tree were released today after a grand jury concluded that the case against them was based on perjured testimony.

title: Miss Burnett Will Aid 2 Journalism Programs
description: Carol Burnett said yesterday that she would give part of her $800,000 libel award from The National Enquirer to journalism programs at the University of Hawaii and the University of California at Berkeley.

title: CARPET FIBERS BEING STUDIED FOR LEAD IN ATLANTA INQUIRY
description: Carpet fibers found in material confiscated from the home and car of a man questioned in the murders of 28 young blacks are similar to those found on the bodies of five of the victims and are the only physical evidence linking the man to any of the cases, according to law-enforcement sources.

title: Tkaczuk Named Assistant Coach
description: One day after having introduced Herb Brooks as the new coach, the Rangers yesterday named Walt Tkaczuk an assistant coach.

title: VOLKER'S HOPES FOR U.S. POLICY
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, expressed optimism today about the direction of American fiscal policy, just one day after President Reagan endorsed a new plan to reduce taxes.

title: FOR 2 WITH TRANSPLANTS, A FUTURE
description: Mary D. Gohlke, who received the heart and lungs of a 15-year-old boy 89 days ago, and Charles Walker, who underwent a similar heart-lung transplant on May 1, met with reporters today at Stanford University Hospital for the first time since their operations.

title: Judge Tells Chicago Agency To Continue Transit Service
description: The Regional Transportation Authority board must use ''all its discretionary powers,'' including raising fares, to keep mass transit going in the Chicago area, a judge ordered today.

title: MACK TRUCKS CITED IN PRICE-FIXING SUIT
description: Mack Trucks Inc., the nation's second-largest manufacturer of heavy-duty trucks, has been charged in a classaction suit with illegally fixing the prices of truck parts.

title: Leonard L. Frank Dies; Built 8,000 L. I. Homes
description: Leonard L. Frank, who with a partner built more than 8,000 private homes across Queens and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties after World War II, died Wednesday at his home in Roslyn Harbor, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: BUT SOME BLACKS AND LIBERALS FAIL TO GIVE SUPPORT
description: Mayor Koch will have overwhelming support from the Democratic establishment when he announces formally next week for a second term, party leaders said yesterday.

title: An Appraisal
description: There was quite a flutter here recently when the winner of the nationwide competition to design a memorial to veterans of the Vietnam War was announced. The competition, the largest design competition ever held in the United States, was won not by a nationally known architect, or even by a practicing architect at all, but by a 21-year-old architectural student from Yale University.

title: Bridge: England's Bridge Magazine Has New Editor and Format
description: There is room for argument about the answer to the following question of bridge history: Which is the world's oldest magazine? The Bridge World, published here in New York, has had 51 years of continuous publication, starting in 1929. England's Bridge Magazine began in 1926, but was out of business for almost a decade thanks to World War II.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including tax credits from foreign operations of $35,000 for the qr and $135,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: Energy Stocks Help Dow to Rise by 7.05
description: Strength in energy issues helped the general market - with the notable exception of precious-metal stocks - to move ahead yesterday. Scoring gains in excess of a point each were Exxon, Atlantic Richfield, Standard Oil (Indiana) and Standard Oil (Ohio).

title: POSTAL SERVICE GOVERNORS PLANNING BIGGER POLICY ROLE TO SPUR FINANCIAL GAINS
description: The Board of Governors of the Postal Service, accused in recent years of failing to take charge of the agency's direction, is stepping in now to shape policies as the agency struggles to gain financial footing.

title: IT'S 4:10.  HERE COMES THE M-1B
description: Three hours and 10 minutes to go before M-1B. Relative quiet on the vast trading floors of the giant investment house of Salomon Brothers. People are lunching. Thomas Strauss, who heads Salomon's government securities department, is polishing off a salad.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY UP $100 MILLION
description: The financial markets were buoyed late yesterday following an announcement by the Federal Reserve System that the key measure of the nation's money supply had increased a modest $100 million in the latest week.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET SET MEETING ON MISSILES
description: Washington, June 5 - The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to begin talks in Washington in the next few weeks to prepare for nogotiations later in the year on limiting each side's mediumrange nuclear missiles in Europe, Administration officials said today.

title: Concepcion Hits 2 as Reds Top Expos, 6-3
description: Dave Concepcion hit two home runs, the second breaking a 3-3 tie in the sixth inning, and the Cincinnati Reds went on to defeat the Montreal Expos, 6-3, tonight.

title: Navy's Crew Qualifies for Final
description: Navy won the right to defend its Varsity Challenge Cup title by outstroking Cornell and four other eightoared shells today in the repechages of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship regatta.

title: 13-1 Wayward Lass Wins Mother Goose
description: Wayward Lass, a 13-1 shot, upset Woody Stephens's hopes of taking New York's filly triple crown by scoring a neck victory over the Stephens-trained Heavenly Cause yesterday in the $111,200 Mother Goose Stakes at Belmont.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Boy Survives in Flooded Sewer, But 3 Die in Texas and Louisiana
description: Tornadoes lashed parts of Texas and Louisiana yesterday, injuring several people, as a rainstorm drenched central and southeastern Texas for a second day, spawning widespread flooding.

title: MARLINE OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss; the yr-ago results have been restated

title: DANCE: CAROL CONWAY
description: Last Sunday afternoon's program by the Carol Conway Dance Company at the Theater of the Riverside Church suggested that Miss Conway is interested in both pattern and drama. And her new ''Gesture of the Heart'' attempted to make the pattern dramatic.

title: Reagan Picks Chicago Financier As Next Ambassador to Canada
description: President Reagan today nominated Paul Robinson, a Chicago financier, to be ambassador to Canada, replacing Kenneth M. Curtis, who has resigned.

title: 38 ISLAMIC COUNTRIES CALL FOR CEASE-FIRE IN LEBANON
description: Foreign ministers of 38 Islamic countries called today for an immediate cease-fire in Lebanon and backed Arab League efforts to restore peace there.

title: AS SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 38. 1. ''You think you can now boast that you made a new person, but I'm the same rascal I have always been,'' someone said to his doctors. Who made the remark and what were the circumstances?

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Indonesia's Oil Earnings
description: Indonesia earned $14.82 billion from oil exports and $2.1 billion from liquefied natural gas sales during the past fiscal year, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Canadian Pacific Ltd. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $75 million of Equipment Trust Certificates Series X, due in 1996, to be sold through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: WILLIAM L. WALSH
description: William L. Walsh, retired president and chairman of the board of the former Quebec Iron and Titanium Corporation, died Wednesday at the Parkview Memorial Hospital in Brunswick, Me. Mr. Walsh, a resident of Greenwich, Conn., for many years, was 70 years old and lived on Bailey Island, Me., and in Ocala, Fla.

title: MUSIC: 2 CONCERTS FOCUS ON SCHUBERT
description: Schubert once again dominated the proceedings at Thursday night's pair of Carnegie Hall Festival concerts. Paul Sperry was in charge of the ''perspective'' concert in Recital Hall at 5:45 and, resourceful programmer that he is, the tenor arranged a selection of Schubert songs that really did help put a perspective on the series.

title: SUNSET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NEW YORK UNEMPLOYMENT DROPS
description: The unemployment rate dropped in New York City and the state as a whole in May, but held nearly steady in New Jersey, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title:
Patents;
Instrument Monitors Vital Physiological Signs
description: An instrument invented for University Patents Inc., Norwalk, Conn., is equipped to display a variety of vital physiological signs about a patient's condition.

title: NIGERIA, EQUADOR SAID TO CUT OIL PRICE
description: World oil prices apparently slipped again yesterday. Industry officials reported that Nigeria was offering discounts of about $2 a barrel on noncontract sales of its oil and that Ecuador was cutting its crude price by $3.80 a barrel, to $35.50.

title: WALESA ADDRESS CHEERED AT I.L.O. MEETING
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of Solidarity, Poland's independent trade union, warned today against any foreign interference in the ''profound social and political transformation'' that he said the movement had triggered in Poland.

title: YANKEES WIN, 6-5, IN 12 INNINGS
description: Manager Gene Michael, concerned that the slumping Reggie Jackson would be humiliated, removed Jackson for a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning last night before the Yankees beat the White Sox, 6-5, in 12 innings at Yankee Stadium.

title: NEW TAMAYO MUSEUM: A MONUMENT TO HIMSELF?
description: The opening of the Rufino Tamayo Museum here on May 29 was one of the social events of the season, with only a select group of Mexico's wealthy, prominent and powerful receiving the signed invitations to its inauguration attended by President Jose Lopez Portillo.

title: Lewis Wins Long Jump, Sprint
description: Bill Lewis knew something was up. ''Carl called us and asked us to come down for this meet,'' said Carl's father. ''It's a funny thing about kids. When they say to come, you come.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A headline in some late editions of Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly indicated the developer of a 58-story tower planned for 52d Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Telex Assisting Inquiry On Slaying of Chairman
description: The Telex Corporation has hired private investigators to investigate the slaying of the Telex board chairman, Roger M. Wheeler, a detective said today, and a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent confirmed that a gun had been found in Mr. Wheeler's car.

title: U.S. ORDERS OPEN HEARINGS
description: The immigration authorities in Miami have begun mass deportation proceedings against newly arrived Haitians, processing 35 cases a day in locked courtrooms from which private lawyers have been barred.

title: STAGE: A QUALIFIED 'NO'
description: Black roots and black rage are at the heart of Alexis De Veaux's ''No.'' This tapestry of stories, poems, music and motion has been given a stylish production by Glenda Dickerson. As adapter and director, she unifies a company linked with their author in a community of shared commitment. After an earlier showcase run, ''No'' is now in an extended engagement at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater.

title: Salvadoran Troops Attack Rebels Dug In on Volcano
description: Government troops backed by artillery and air strikes fought their way up the Chicontepec Volcano today in an operation aimed at dislodging about 500 leftist guerrillas, a Salvadoran military spokesman said today.

title: COAL STRIKE MAY END, BUT MINERS STILL FEAR FUTURE
description: Members of the United Mine Workers of America are to vote today on whether to end their 10-week national strike. But whether they accept a new contract, as expected, or reject it, their union remains in desperate straits.

title: JOBLESS RATE ROSE TO 7.6% IN MAY, FIRST SIGNIFICANT CLIMB IN A YEAR
description: In what Labor Department officials described as the first significant increase in a year, the nation's unemployment rate rose to 7.6 percent in May from 7.3 percent the month before.

title: KOCH SIGNS CONTROVERSIAL COUNCIL REDISTRICTING BILL
description: Mayor Koch signed the City Council redistricting bill yesterday afternoon after a two-hour hearing in the morning at which speakers alternately praised and damned the measure, which has been criticized as unfair to members of minority groups.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
DUNLOP-PIRELLI TIRE BREAKUP SYMBOLIC
description: When Dunlop of Britain and Pirelli of Italy, both tire manufacturers, announced that they were going to form a union, it was seen as a symbol of the impending economic integration of Europe.

title: TEXT OF LETTER SENT BY LEFEVER
description: Following is the text of a letter sent to President Reagan today by Ernest W. Lefever asking that his name be withdrawn from consideration for the position of Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights and Humanitarian Affairs: My Dear Mr. President:

title: U.S. DELAYS STEEL UNIT'S SALE TO J.&L.
description: The Justice Department yesterday asked the McLouth Steel Corporation, which is in need of cash, to postpone the sale of its stainless steel division to the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation. The department said the merger would substantially reduce competition in the stainless steel market.

title: First 'Test-Tube' Twins Are Born in Australia
description: The first twins conceived in a laboratory were born at a hospital here early today but one baby was reported to be in serious condition, Queen Victoria hospital officials said.

title: 3-WEEK THEATER FESTIVAL OPENS TODAY IN BALTIMORE
description: About the three-week international theater festival that begins in Baltimore today with 200 performers in companies from Canada, France, Britain, Ireland, Israel, Japan, South Africa, Spain, and even the State of Kentucky, theater people in Washington and New York are wondering: How come Baltimore could bring it all together?

title: YARDNEY ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: The yr-ago results include gains of approximately $16,000 for t and $171,000 for the 6 mos on the sale of silver metal inventor the company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange

title: CITY BALLET: FIRST NIGHT OF TCHAIKOVSKY FESTIVAL
description: True to form, the New York City Ballet opened its eagerly awaited Tchaikovsky Festival Thursday night at the New York State Theater in a grandly wayward City Ballet manner.

title: Key Rates
description: Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Your Money; Higher Yields From Banks
description: IN an effort to fight back against money market mutual funds, banks are suddenly offering a host of new products to the consumer. None of the new products quite match the liquidity of money market funds, where cash can usually be withdrawn at any time simply by writing a check. Like the money funds, however, some of the new instruments do pay higher interest rates and provide greater liquidity than traditional savings vehicles: passbook accounts or certificates of deposit.

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After $152,000 net foreign currency translation loss which in unrealized currency translation losses...C-Including $76,000 fo currency translation gain

title: Downeast Chamber at the Y
description: The Downeast Chamber Orchestra will perform works of Scarlatti, Vaughan Wiliams, Debussy and Ginastera tonight at the Kaufman Concert Hall of the 92d Street Y at 8 P.M. Burton Kaplan, music director of the Youth String Ensemble, will conduct.

title: About New York; THE RUNNING PIED PIPER OF JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL 117
description: This is a story about running for everyone who is sick to death of discussions of distances, carbohydrate loading, the Boston Marathon, Bill Rodgers and the Central Park Reservoir.

title: Gavin Is Received in Mexico
description: John Gavin presented his credentials today as the new American Ambassador to Mexico to President Jose Lopez Portillo, who is flying to Washington this weekend for talks with President Reagan. The appointment of the 50-year-old actor was not well received in Mexico, where he had gained fame for television spots advertising rum. But Mr. Gavin speaks excellent Spanish and appears to have convinced skeptics in the American business community that he knows Mexico as well as most of them.

title: IN THE HURRICANE'S EYE ON SOCIAL SECURITY CUTS
description: Representative J.J. Pickle has been a successful politican for a long time and, like all good politicians, the Texas Democrat likes doing things for people. But now, as a result of economic forces outside his control, the legislator has been charged with a most unenviable task: trimming the Social Security program to keep it solvent.

title: High Norway Oil, Gas Estimates
description: The Ministry of Oil and Energy said today that Norway's North Sea block area No.31 off Bergen holds more recoverable gas and oil than all other Norwegian petroleum fields now operating combined.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks Planned
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that he expected United States and Soviet negotiators to hold preliminary talks on a new long-term grain agreement when they meet in London next week.

title: Senate Panel Trims $900 Million From the School Lunch Program
description: Some $900 million was cut from the nation's school lunch and breakfast programs today as the Senate Agriculture Committee tried to comply with strict budget targets for the fiscal year 1982 that have been approved by Congress and President Reagan.

title: BANI-SADR ASSOCIATES SAY HE MAY BE LOSING POWER STRUGGLE IN TEHERAN
description: Associates of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr appear convinced that he is losing his struggle against political foes and that his ouster may be near. But the President, although increasingly isolated by the Shiite clergy that dominates the Government, vows to ''remain in his post'' no matter what.

title: Transactions; FRIDAY; BASEBALL
description: NEW YORK YANKEES (AL) - Restored B ob Watson, first baseman, to active roster f rom disabled list; sent Bill Castro, right- h anded relief pitcher, to Columbus in Inter- n ational League. Larry Wahl, public rela- t ions director, resigned to take post in p ublic r elations with American Broadcasting Com- p anies. NEW YORK METS (NL) - Activated E llis Valentine, outfielder obtained from M ontreal Expos in trade May 29; he had b een on disabled list with pulled hamstring m uscle in left leg. Optioned Ed Lynch, pitch- e r, to Tidewater farm team in International L eague. CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Bobby Bonds, o utfielder, on 21-day disabled list; recalled T y Waller, outfielder, from Iowa of Ameri- c an Association.

title: WEI WEI, AND KWANG
description: I received a letter from Wei Wei the other day. She tells me that she has just seen ''The Sound of Music'' three times, at her university in Wuhan, China. ''I am much attracted by this heroine,'' she writes. ''She has the mind to vanquish her so many difficulties. Her energy and self-confidence impress me goodly. So too, her struggle for love, which to me is like swimming the Yangtze during a time of flood. I like this image for girl of China in 1980's.''

title: Baseball Talks Fruitless
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners and players returned to the bargaining table yesterday, but they never made it to the same table. They had what Marvin Miller, the players' union chief, called ''one of our traditional non-meetings'' at the Doral Inn.

title: Benjamin M. Robinson, Founder of a Law Firm
description: Benjamin M. Robinson, a New York City lawyer, died yesterday at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was a resident of Bronxville, N.Y., and maintained homes on Martha's Vineyard and on Barbados in the West Indies.

title: UNITED STATES SUGAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
RYAN SUBDUES METS
description: When Nolan Ryan is on his game, it's no disgrace to lose to him. He was on tonight and shut out the Mets, 3-0, struck out 10 and issued only two walks.

title: Stake in Newmont Grows
description: Amcon Group Inc. and Consolidated Gold Fields Ltd., its corporate parent, said they had increased their stake in the Newmont Mining Corporation to a little more than 2.1 million shares, or 8.1 percent. Their latest purchases, they told the Securities and Exchange Commission, totaled 266,000 shares in April and May for $16.9 million. They said they ''desire to develop working relationships with Newmont management.''

title: PLEASENT COLONY TRIES FOR TRIPLE CROWN IN THE BELMONT
description: After Gallant Fox won the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes in 1930, the Daily Racing Form columnist Charles Hatton dubbed the victories a ''Triple Crown.'' No jewelled headgear goes to the victor, only an inverted pyramid of silver presented to the winning owner by the Thoroughbred Racing Associations. But horse owners covet it as if it were an obelisk of gold.

title: MEXICANA AIRLINES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
RESEARCHER SUES 5 FOR CONSPIRACY
description: A cancer researcher accused several years ago of falsifying data filed a $33 million lawsuit today against five of his former co-workers, charging they had conspired to discredit his work.

title: MEASURING OUTRAGE OVER FOOD PRICES
description: If you notice anyone going up and down the aisles of your local supermarket looking at prices and muttering (or even, perhaps, shouting),''Outrageous! Outrageous!'' you might direct such person or persons to the offices of the Food Marketing Institute in Washington. A trade association representing supermarket owners and food wholesalers, the institute collects perceptions of outrageousness over food prices. It has just issued its annual Outrageous Food Price Index as part of the report, ''Trends - Consumer Attitudes and the Supermarket, 1981 Update,'' conducted by Louis Harris Associates.

title: Notes on People; No 'Badge of Privilege'
description: The trouble with many journalists today, one of the nation's top broadcast news executives said yesterday, is that they have an inflated view of their own importance.

title:
Patents;
Rules Allow Restudy of Inventions
description: WASHINGTON BEGINNING July 1, anybody can file a request for a re-examination and possible limitation of any patent in force. Each application must be accompanied by a check for $1,500, subject to a partial refund in certain circumstances.

title: BUDGETS OF U.S. ARTS AGENCIES UNFROZEN
description: Officials of the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities said yesterday that they had been informed by the Office of Management and Budget that most of the money allocated but not yet spent from their 1981 budgets, which had been frozen May 19, was available to be spent.

title: READING OF ORIGINAL POEMS AT BANK ST. PIER TODAY
description: ''A Celebration of the River,'' a reading by adults and children of original poems with river themes, will take place from noon to 6 P.M. tomorrow at the Bank Street Pier in Greenwich Village.

title: SPIRAL METAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $137,000 for the qr and $655,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $270,000 for the qr and $47 for the yr and after $90,000 loss from discontinued operations qr and yr

title: TO GENERATE ENTERPRISE--AND JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 6, 1981
description: International Ernest W. Lefever withdrew from consideration for the post of Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights after the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's 13-4 vote to recommend that the Senate reject his nomination. In a letter to President Reagan asking that his name be withdrawn, Mr. Lefever said he was ''blameless of the charges and innuendoes against my integrity and my compassion.'' (Page 1, Col.5-6.) Preliminary arms discussions between the United States and the Soviet Union have been agreed upon, according to Administration officials. The purpose of the discussions, which are slated to begin in Washington this month and continue through the summer, is to pave the way for negotiations in September between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko concerning limitation of each side's medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe. (1:6.)

title: NEW JERSEY PLAN ON AUTO RATES BLOCKED IN COURT
description: New Jersey's order to auto insurance companies to stop calculating rates according to a driver's age, sex, marital status, scholastic achievement and hometown was temporarily blocked in court today.

title: REPUBLICAN CHIEFS JOIN 'BANDWAGON' IN CHOOSING KOCH
description: New York City Republican leaders contended yesterday that in their endorsement of Mayor Koch, a Democrat, they were following a bandwagon, not necessarily leading it.
