title: Red Sox 4, A's 1
description: Carl Yastrzemski and Jim Rice hit consecutive homers in the eighth inning, and Frank Tanana (2-4) allowed five hits in eight and a third innings for Boston.

title: CAREY OFFERS BILL TIGHTENING LAW ON CO-OP SWITCH
description: Governor Carey proposed legislation today that would require at least 51 percent of the tenants of an apartment building to approve any plan to convert it to cooperatives or condominiums before tenants could be evicted. The law now requires that such conversion plans be approved by 35 percent of the tenants.

title: GLASROCK MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 29
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the qr and $421,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $77,000 for the qr and $185,000 for the yr

title: ONE CAUGHT
description: Two men awaiting trial for armed bank robbery escaped last night from the Federal Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan, according to the police and prison officials.

title: Amax to Sell Units To Fairweather Gas
description: Amax Inc., the diversified natural resources producer, said its board had approved the sale for about $213 million (Canadian) of Amax's two wholly owned Canadian subsidiaries to Fairweather Gas Ltd., a Canadian company owned by the B.C. Sugar Refining Company. The two subsidiaries are Alaxo Petroleum Ltd. and Amax Petroleum of Canada Ltd.

title: Notes on People; Master's for Magruder
description: Among the 247 graduates of the Princeton Theological Seminary this week was Jeb Stuart Magruder, who served a seven-month prison term for his part in the Watergate case.

title: WARSAW FREES 4 DISSIDENTS UNTIL TRIAL
description: A Warsaw court ordered the release today of four political dissidents but said they must appear for trial on June 15 on charges of antistate activity.

title: Margot Fonteyn With La Scala Dame
description: Margot Fonteyn will appear with the La Scala Opera Ballet in its American debut season at the Metropolitan Opera House, from July 13 through Aug. 1. The English ballerina will perform the role of Lady Capulet in Rudolph Nureyev's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' which will feature Mr. Nureyev and Carla Fracci in the title roles. The ballet will be performed July 13 to July 16, July 18 (matinee and evening), July 30 and 31 and Aug. 1 (matinee and evening).

title: Lightning, and Light, in Ireland
description: Surely without intending it, the hunger strikers in Northern Ireland may have opened a path for a rational approach to unifying Ireland. Since 1921 the province's one million Protestants have dismissed as unthinkable any political association with the Catholic Irish Republic. But it is no longer unthinkable to the British, weary of the burden and the odium of policing what the world sees as a Protestant stockade.

title: Phillies Denounced on Drugs
description: State Attorney General LeRoy Zimmerman sharply criticized some members of the Philadelphia Phillies today for ''unethical'' and ''deplorable'' conduct during a state investigation last year into whether they had received illegally prescribed amphetamines. He suggested that baseball investigate what he said could be widespread use of amphetamines.

title: Eazor to Receive Employee Loans
description: About 95 percent of the 900 employees of Eazor Express Inc., have agreed to lend the financially troubled company 15 percent of their wages in an effort to keep it in business, a company official said.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Harvester Advances Debt Restructuring
description: Plans of the ailing International Harvester Company to restructure its debts are progressing, with banks representing 95 percent of the refinancing indicating approval of the package, according to Harvester's chief financial officer, James Cotting.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
3 Gunmen Kill Ulster Militiaman And Flee Toward Irish Republic
description: Three gunmen killed a Protestant militiaman in County Fermanagh today, then fled in the dead man's delivery truck toward the Irish Republic 10 miles away. The police said the gunmen shot a member of the Ulster Defense Regiment as he was delivering coal to a house near the village of Lisnaskea.

title: RISE SMALLEST IN '81
description: Prices of finished goods rose by only fourtenths of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department reported today, providing more evidence that inflation is slowing down.

title: A CLOUDLESS JUNE DAY, THE BRIDE WORE WHITE, DANCING, CHAMPAGNE, AND
description: For all present, it a brief return to another era. The occasion was a wedding, traditional in every respect, with all the required ingredients: a 72-degree, cloudless June day; a bride in white eyelet; male attendants in grey cutaways; bridesmaids in blue tulle and streamered straw leghorns.

title: MUSIC: BACH WITH DANCE
description: No one knows precisely what instrument or instruments Bach had in mind for his Art of Fugue, a monument of contrapuntal composition he left unfinished at his death. It can be performed on harpsichord and organ and by ensembles of various kinds and, in any case, must always be given in a practical arrangement devised by someone other than the composer.

title:
Patents;
Diagnostic Device For Motor Vehicles
description: A diagnostic and monitoring device for motor vehicles, with a memory for any faults, has been invented for the General Motors Corporation. The equipment is in 1981 G.M. gasoline vehicles.

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Results do not include operations of the new Playboy Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City which opened in Apr and in which Elsinore has a 46 percent interest

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I wish to declare from this international platform to all the people and all the countries of the world that the Poles are capable of settling their internal affairs among themselves and by themselves.'' - Lech Walesa. (3:1.)

title: Why Sell the Trade Center?
description: Now that New York's tallest buildings are finally showing a profit, the air is full of cries that they should be sold. For some rarefied reason, the taxpayer is told he should own only that which loses money.

title: HOW DEPRECIATION IS USED
description: Depreciation is an important tool that businesses use to reduce their Federal taxes. Each year, they deduct from their taxable income a portion of their spending for plants, equipment and other assets. The bigger the depreciation deduction, the lower the taxes that a business has to pay.

title: Italy's Premier-Designate Denies He Was a Mason
description: Prime Minister-designate Arnaldo Forlani, striving to stay clear of the scandal over a secret Masonic lodge that toppled this country's Government 10 days ago, denied today that he had ever been a Freemason.

title: G.I. Kills 4 Americans At Base in South Korea
description: An American soldier opened fire on other United States soldiers at rifle practice today, killing four and seriously wounding a fifth.

title: THE GROWTH IN CONSUMER DEBT SLOWS
description: American consumers bought $2.33 billion more on installment credit than they paid off in April, a 25 percent decline from the expansion of credit in March but still one of the highest recent monthly totals, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: HENRY C. BOHACK JR.
description: Henry C. Bohack Jr., retired president of the H. C. Bohack Realty Corporation and vice president of the former Bohack food chain, died May 23 at a nursing home in Delray Beach, Fla., after an illness of several months. Mr. Bohack, who lived in Boynton Beach, Fla., and Woodhaven, Queens, was 85 years old and had retired two years ago.

title: Thoresen Rejects Terms and Will Not Join Cosmos
description: The Cosmos will not acquire Hallvar Thoresen, the Norwegian wing with whom they have been negotiating.

title: SCREEN: A DOCUMENTARY ON VIETNAM
description: Robert Richter, who narrates his film ''Vietnam: An American Journey,'' has a boyish voice filled with curiosity and enthusiasm. His film is a record of a voyage that, as Mr. Richter conceives it, smacks of adventure. In 1978 Mr. Richter spent seven Governmentsupervised weeks in Vietnam, examining social and physical changes wrought by the war. His record of the trip is an interested but somewhat unquestioning documentary, filled with evidence of damage, painful memories and proof of a concerted national effort to rebuild.

title: Girard Sets 21% Prime
description: The Girard Bank of Philadelphia raised its prime lending rate yesterday by a point, to 21 percent, only half a point below the peak reached last December. No other major bank, however, followed the move by Girard, the nation's 52d-largest banking organization.

title: Publisher Purchases Stock of McCaw
description: Affiliated Publications Inc., the publisher of The Boston Globe and the owner of a number of radio stations, said it had purchased 45 percent of the voting stock and 34 percent of the nonvoting stock of McCaw Communications Companies for $8 million.

title: Suspect in Casino Case Freed
description: A man accused of threatening to poison the water supply of a Lake Tahoe casino has been found not guilty by a District Court jury. The jury acquitted Harry Leland Leach, 33 years old, late yesterday. Mr. Leach, of Mountain View, Calif., was charged with one count of extortion in the threat last October to poison the water at Caesars Tahoe unless a $10 million ransom were paid.

title: Soft Coal Output Down in Nation
description: The National Coal Association reported today that last week's soft coal production was 8.69 million tons, slightly below 9.05 million tons a week before and well below the 14.12 million tons of the comparable 1980 week.

title: U.S. Ends Citizenship Fight Against Suspected Nazi
description: The Justice Department today dropped efforts to strip a Philadelphia man of his United States citizenship, saying it lacked evidence to sustain allegations that he concealed his involvement in Nazi persecutions in World War II.

title: Navy Admits That Its Recruiters Helped Cheaters in Vermont Test
description: Navy officials admitted today that military recruiters had helped recruits cheat equivalency testing session in February at a Middlebury high school.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: The yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change yr-ago shr earnings restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split p Oct 10, 1980 and a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan 27, 1981

title: Notes on People; Nixons House Hunting
description: Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Pat, reportedly have been houseshopping in the suburbs for a summer and weekend home, most recently in northern New Jersey around Franklin Lakes and Saddle River.

title: Namibia Rebel Chief Rejects U.S. Plan Tied to Angola
description: Any move by the Reagan Administration to link a final settlement on independence for South-West Africa to the withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola is unacceptable, a leader of guerrillas seeking South-West Africa's independence said here today.

title: Time to Put Westway Away
description: The fight for and against Westway has gone on so long that it has come to resemble nothing so much as an ideological war, the urban equivalent of doves versus hawks on Vietnam.

title: WHITE HOUSE SOLICTING TAX SUPPORT
description: The White House sought today to placate businessmen unhappy with the new version of President Reagan's taxrelief plan. But business representatives said they hoped the President would reverse or modify his decision to scale back from the business tax measures he had promised in February.

title: Masekela and Pearl Primus To Aid Ghanaian Relief
description: Hugh Masekela, the South African-born trumpeter, will perform Sunday at a benefit concert sponsored by Friends of the Ghana Medical Relief Society Inc. Pearl Primus, the choreographer and anthropologist, and Dr. Kwame Anyane-Yeboa, assistant professor of pediatrics at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, will be the speakers. The program will be at the Cooperative Auditorium, 566 Grand Street, on the Lower East Side, from 1 to 6 P.M.

title: Nu-West Increases Cities Service Stake
description: Nu-West Group Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said it had increased its holding in the Cities Service Company to 7.2 percent from 6.3 percent with the purchase of 492,000 common shares for $22.5 million.

title: COMMON SENSE VS. THE MX MISSILE
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunger Strikes People, Not Places
description: Under pressure to reduce the total food stamp budget, the Senate Agriculture Committee is proposing special cuts for poor Americans in Puerto Rico. We hope Congress demurs; it is people, wherever they may be, who get hungry, not places.

title: Vesco Said to Disappear Again; F.B.I. Is Skeptical About Report
description: The Bahamian authorities have reported that Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, disappeared last week, but the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that he still might be somewhere in the island nation.

title: WOMAN HURT IN POPE'S SHOOTING IS MOVED TO A HOSPITAL IN BUFFALO
description: Ann Odre, the Buffalo woman wounded by a bullet that pierced Pope John Paul II, returned home tonight in need of further medical care and protection from potential publicity seekers.

title: Andretti Testifies He Saw Unser Make Illegal Move
description: Mario Andretti, who was awarded first place in the Indianapolis 500 race after Bobby Unser had been penalized one lap, testified today that he saw Unser illegally pass the line of cars as he left the pits during a yellow caution flag.

title: And They Painted The Room
description: Later, World War II seemed to have been about John Wayne. It wasn't. On the 37th anniversary of D-Day, here are a few voices from a land of long ago speaking in their letters of life in America during the war years:

title: French Aide, in Talk With Reagan, Tells of Concern Over U.S. Policy
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France talked with President Reagan today and emphasized France's concern about United States fiscal policy and its effects on Europe, according to French officials.

title: U.S. READY TO SUPPORT WALDHEIM FOR A THIRD TERM
description: Reagan Administration officials have indicated their support for Kurt Waldheim's hopes for re-election as Secretary General, thereby removing the main barrier to his becoming the first third-term executive to preside over the Secretariat.

title: A PARTY FOR BROOKLYN AT AGE 356
description: Thursday night it was chic to say you grew up in Flatbush, but at the end of the birthday party - celebrating Brooklyn's 356th year - many of the limousines headed back to Manhattan. A birthday ball, given by the Foundation for the Restoration of Borough Hall, was held in the borough's former divorce court, now restored and used as a ballroom.

title: AS SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS FIGHT FOR SURVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Claude Lewy Dies at 75; Forged Ties With France
description: Claude Lewy, a leader of cooperative efforts in French-American culture and education and a practicing lawyer in both Paris and New York, died May 30 of a heart attack in Paris. He was 75 years old and lived in Paris and Manhattan.

title: WILLIAMS SPEAKS OF PERILS TO LABOR AS TEAMSTERS ADJOURN
description: ''A strong labor movement is the only way to fairly distribute wealth,'' Roy L. Williams, new general president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, asserted today shortly before the union adjourned its 22d convention.

title: VALLE'S STEAK HOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Valentine, on 65-133, Leads by 2 in Atlanta
description: In the steaming heat of his hometown, Tommy Valentine scored a seven-under-par 65 today and took a two-stroke lead over Raymond Floyd in the second round of the $300,000 Atlanta Classic.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Pope John Paul II, on his release from the hospital, three weeks after he was shot in St. Peter's Square. 2. Opposition to the adoption of the metric measure. 3. $32 million, or $3,000 a square foot. 4. He won the Sixth Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. 5. He was deputy commander of a Titan missile silo in which the intercontinental missile was on the alert, and he held one of the two keys that could activate the missile. He allegedly made unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy in Washington and gave diplomats sensitive information about the missile.

title: JUDGE RULES THAT SIAMESE TWINS WERE NEGLECTED IN HOSPITAL STAY
description: A Vermilion County circuit judge concluded today that month-old Siamese twin boys had been neglected in their eight-day stay at a Danville hospital. He refused to give the parents custody.

title: TERRA MINING & EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PIONEER IN SOCIAL ANTHROPOLOGY
description: Dr. Carleton S. Coon, one of the last of the great general anthropologists, died Wednesday at his home in Gloucester, Mass. He was 76 years old.

title: FIVE-WEEK CARPENTER'S STRIKE IN JERSEY HALTING MANY MAJOR PROJECTS
description: A five-week carpenters' strike in New Jersey, complicated by pressures from Atlantic City casino projects where work is continuing, has stopped construction at many other major commercial projects valued by contractors at more than a billion dollars.

title: DR. DAVID KAIRYS
description: Dr. David Kairys, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: S OME 15 mental health professionals meet to discuss their work with alcoholics. But they don't just sit around and talk about methods of treatment. In groups of three, they collaborate on drawings.

title: COMMON SENSE VS. THE MX MISSILE

title: News Analysis
description: Japan is a nation enormously attached to formality, decorum and to a politeness that verges on the exquisite. There is a way to do things and a way not to. Anyone who steps out of line is likely to get into trouble. ''The nail that sticks out shall be hammered down,'' a proverb says.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
AIR SHOW'S HIGH HOPES
description: Against a backdrop of screaming jets and popping champagne corks, the international aerospace industry began a hard-sell campaign at the opening of the Paris Air Show today.

title: DEMOCRATS PLAN SMALLER MEETING IN '82, RESTORING LEADERS' POWERS
description: The Democratic National Committee, arguing without getting angry, today voted to cut down the size of its 1982 National Conference and to put it more firmly in control of party regulars than previous sessions have been.

title: Bishop Tutu Wins Greek Prize
description: Bishop Desmond Tutu of South Africa was awarded a $100,000 prize today by the Onassis Foundation for his struggle against apartheid. Bishop Tutu was unable to attend because his passport has been withdrawn. President Constantine Caramanlis of Greece handed the prize instead to a member of the Onassis Foundation, who will pass it on to Bishop Tutu.

title: ORCHARD STREET: A BARGAIN BAZAAR
description: She is the last of the capital's grandes dames, ruling her domain with what one of her admirers, former Associate Justice Abe Fortas, calls ''a whim of iron.''

title:
Patents;
Uranium Mining Method Keeps Deposits Permeable
description: Uranium is a valuable material the principal use of which is to provide fuel for nuclear power plants. It is often mined from under the ground by a leaching process, but the deposits lose their permeability.

title: 3 Convicted in Bombing At a San Diego Shipyard
description: Three former employees of the National Steel and Shipbuilding Company were convicted today on all counts of conspiring to bomb the shipyard's electrical transformers last fall.

title: Going Out Guide
description: EYED

title: Dumping Ruling Upsets Japanese
description: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry today expressed ''serious reservations'' and surprise about a ruling by the United States International Trade Commission that Japanese television makers are still ''dumping'' their products in the United States in violation of international trade laws.

title: Black Muslim Group Linked To James Earl Ray Stabbing
description: Members of a Black Muslim group are believed to be responsible for the prison stabbing of James Earl Ray, the director of the State Bureau of Investigation says.

title: Swann Oil Delays Refinery in Virginia
description: Swann Oil has delayed indefinitely plans to build a 26,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery here and may scrap the controversial project, a company official said.

title: Release of Cuban Refugee From Penitentiary Blocked
description: A court blocked the release of a Cuban detained at the Federal prison here today, half an hour before the man was to have been freed.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS SET UP PROTEST CAMP
description: Tony Reyes went to Vietnam when he was 18 years old. Sixteen years later, he said today, he still has nightmares in which he sees babies whose heads have been blown off.

title: Delay Reported in Conrail Sale
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis is considering an 18-month postponement of his plan to sell Conrail to see whether the subsidized system can be profitable, Senator John Heinz said today.

title: 'RADICALS' TAMPERING WITH THE CONSTITUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $9,717,000 extraordinary credit representing a gain the exchange of debentures

title: Trusthouse Forte
description: Trusthouse Forte Ltd. has raised its stake in Savoy Hotel Ltd. to 37.3 percent, including 60.7 percent of savoy ''A'' shares and 12.5 percent of the ''B'' shares. Trusthouse said its tender offers will be extended until June 19, and will not be increased. Trusthouse's offer, which was raised May 1, consists of 126 of its shares or $387.51 cash for every 100 Savoy ''A'' shares, and 15 Trusthouse shares or $45.79 cash for every two Savoy ''B'' shares.

title: Texas Instruments Unit Selling Assets
description: The Texas Instruments Supply Company said it was selling certain assets of its domestic distribution network to Kierulff Electronics, a subsidiary of Ducommon.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JUNE 6, 1981; The Economy
description: Prices of finished goods rose by four-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department reported, providing more evidence that inflation is slowing down. This advance in the main Producer Price Index was half that of April and the smallest so far this year. Falling prices for most kinds of energy and steady prices for food made the biggest contribution to what economists now regard as a well-established trend of reduced inflation. (Page 1.)

title: Bowman Rejoins Sabres
description: Scotty Bowman, who two years ago ended a successful coaching career with the Montreal Canadiens because of his wish to become a general manager, said today that he had reluctantly decided to go back behind the bench as coach of the Buffalo Sabres.

title: UA-Columbia Takeover Closer
description: The attempt by United Artists Theater Circuit Inc. and Rogers Telecommunications Ltd. to acquire UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. has apparently moved a step closer to fruition.

title: BUSINESSMEN DISAPPOINTED WITH TAX SHIFT
description: Business leaders expressed disappointment yesterday with the Reagan Administration's decision to reduce benefits in its tax package that had been designed to aid business. But, many executives said, they will still support the President's program.

title: THE MAN WHO BET $100 THAT HE WOULD NEVER MARRY
description: When my relatives gathered in the backyard for ham sandwiches and beer after my sister's wedding last summer, there was an irritating amount of attention paid to the absence of a gold band on the finger of the eldest son. Irritating to me, that is. They slipped into the topic as though it were a familiar sweater and proceeded to get comfortable. In fact, a couple of aunts, wishing at all costs to keep the conversation going, worked around to my side and struck up a spirited defense.

title: U.S. PLANS PROTEST OVER NEWSPAPER PAYMENTS BY U.N.
description: The United States said today that it would formally protest the distribution of funds by the United Nations to newspapers that printed supplements promoting United Nations views on aid to the third world.

title: Kennedy's Prendergrass Sets Record in Hurdles
description: Boris Pendergrass of John F. Kennedy, the Bronx, set a meet record of 14.18 seconds tonight in a heat of the 110-meter high hurdles at the state high school outdoor track and field championships at Cornell.

title: Norm Thompson
description: Norm Thompson Outfitters, a mail-order clothing concern that caters to sportsmen, will return to Oregon, the president of the company said. John Emrick said that company management had bought, for an undisclosed price, Norm Thompson from the Parker Pen Company of Janesville, Wis., which acquired the business in 1973.

title: WELLS BENRUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $2,000 income from discontinued operations, $964,00 gain on the restructuring of debt and $299,000 tax credit... C-Including $10,000 income from discontinued operations and $58 tax credit

title: REAGAN DECIDES TO RELAX CURBS ON CHINA TRADE
description: The Reagan Administration has decided on a series of measures to lift trade restrictions against China imposed over the years because of its Communist Government, and also to hold extensive talks on possible sales of military equipment.

title: A PROVINCE OF WHOLESOME PLEASURES
description: The houses and fishing shacks are daubed mint green, dandelion yellow, lobster pink and a palette of other hues. The church steeples are blindingly white, like the freshly laundered sheets flapping on the lines. The beaches come in two colors, white and red; the red, they say, makes better sand castles. Prince Edward Island, Canada's smallest province, is a vacationland by Technicolor, a panorama of wholesomeness that might make Disneyland seem risque.

title:
COMMENT;
INFLATION FEVER CURE
description: When I suggested to a recent meeting of the Conference Board that current interest rates were too high, weakening the economy but not curbing inflation, a top business executive retorted that I was focusing on the fever instead of the underlying flu.

title: BONN VOTES A DEFENSE BUDGET BELOW NATO GUIDELINE
description: The rate of increase in West German defense spending this year will fall slightly below that of the budget as a whole, and markedly below that of several categories of social outlays.

title: U.S. Has Lowest Pedestrian Toll
description: The United States has the lowest pedestrian death rate in the world, on the basis of vehicle miles traveled, according to a University of Michigan study. The study, conducted by the university's Highway Safety Research Institute, found that there were 0.61 pedestrian deaths for every 100 million miles driven in the United States in 1977.

title: HOUSING OPTION DEBATED IN SALE OF SCHOOL
description: VALLEY STREAM THE proposed sale of a school that was closed because of declining pupil population has stirred a controversy in this community. The School Board of District 24 voted last month to sell the William F. Donahue school property to Avon Park Management Inc., which intends to build 62 condominium apartments and town houses on the site. The price was set at $1,075,000. The builders will pay the school district $112,500 at the end of each year for the first two years while the district retains title to the property. At the closing, the title would change hands and Avon would pay the remaining $850,000.

title: Peter Andrew Gray Weds Karen Dirkes in Manhasset
description: Karen Dirkes and Peter Andrew Gray, graduates of Stonehill College in Brockton, Mass., were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank Johnston and the Rev. John Dennistron, a Roman Catholic priest of Rye, N.Y.

title: NEW COAL CONTRACT RATIFIED AND SIGNED AFTER UNION VOTING
description: The United Mine Workers and the bituminous coal industry signed a new contract here tonight that will put miners back on the job at 12:01 A.M. Monday after a 73-day strike.

title: Music; A SEASON IS OVER, BUT MUSIC PLAYS ON
description: BEFORE discussing some of the highlights of the state's summer music season in this column next Sunday, let's deal with a few more finales, including postseason concerts by two major orchestras and a showcase for some of the most gifted young pianists in the state.

title: No Headline
description: Michael Norman's article was loaded, four to one, on the side of men ''preoccupied with guns.''

title: MOTHERS' TIES TO DAUGHTER
description: A new study reveals that the typical mother-daughter relationship may be much better than has been thought. According to the findings of Grace K. Baruch and Rosalind C. Barnett, research associates at Wellesley College's Center for Research on Women, only about 20 percent of relationships between mothers and their grown daughters are especially troubled.

title: MR. REAGAN GIVES BUSINESS JOLT
description: Ronald Reagan, the darling of the business community, has given business its first great surprise. The man who has delighted a generation of businessmen with his free-enterprise ideology has offered his tax compromise to conservative, deficit-conscious Democrats, and it comes largely and unexpectedly at the expense of business.

title: Right of Counsel; Left to States; In Custody Cases
description: Acknowledging that losing custody of one's children is a ''unique kind of deprivation,'' the Supreme Court last week nevertheless ruled that indigent parents do not have an automatic constitutional right to free legal assistance in proceedings on custody termination.

title:
Antiques;
BOUGES, BUDGETS, POCKETS
description: HARTFORD WHEN ancient man began to think in terms of future need, he began also to devise small receptacles in which to store or transport his valuable possessions. More often than not, one small bag or box sufficed. Similarly today, a small case of credit cards is about all one needs to travel across town or around the world. In the process of coming full circle back to such simplification, while discarding baggage we also have dropped exact descriptive terms from our vocabulary.

title: TEAMSTER DELGATES ELECT WILLIAMS: ANY OBJECTIONS?
description: It was a compelling, often confusing, at times disturbing spectacle: 6,600 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and their wives and guests coming to Las Vegas, city of drink, good times and gambling.

title: A LUNCHROOM'S HAMBURGER LEGEND
description: generation owner and operator of Louis Lunch, the self-proclaimed birthplace of the hamburger sandwich, remembers helping his grandfather grind meat before he was school age. According to Mr. Lassen, his grandfather, Louis, whipped up a hamburger sandwich for a busy customer one day back in 1900, and so far, Mr. Lassen said, no one has come forth with proof of an earlier one.

title: Another Ratchet; For Stabilized Rents
description: In tying rent increases to inflation, the Rent Stabilization Law has stabilized New York rents to about the same degree that helium holds down balloons. Last year dwellers in some of the city's 900,000 rent-stabilized apartments paid record increases of as much as 17 percent.

title: Sarah Armstrong, Fund-Raiser, Wed To Lucian Leone
description: Sarah Armstrong, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Irwin Armstrong of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lucian Joseph Leone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lucian A. Leone of Herkimer, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Donald V. Roberts performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Long Islanders; SPACE-AGE ARTIST BOOKS FOR THE SHUTTLE
description: IF everything continues the way he hopes it will, Mort Kunstler of Oyster Bay will be the first artist in space. He's got a request in to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and his qualifications are more than slightly appropriate for making the journey when space travel is opened to newsmen and artists.

title: ON TAX CUTS, THE PRESIDENT GIVES WHILE THE GETTING IS GOOD
description: WASHINGTON AFTER the Rose Garden announcement of President Reagan's hastily revised tax-cut legislation, a reporter asked the President if he had the votes in Congress to pass the measure. ''I said we wouldn't take any questions, and I'm glad I said it,'' Mr. Reagan quipped in his amiable way as he headed back toward the Oval Office. In an aside to an aide, he was heard to murmur that no one ''really knows the answer to that question.''

title: Things Get Nasty; As Congress Nears
description: Poles kept one eye on the calendar and the other on Moscow last week as tensions rose in anticipation of next month's crucial party congress.

title: STUDY URGES PLAIN LANGUAGE FOR JURY INSTRUCTIONS
description: The average juror may understand no more than half of a judge's instructions on the law, resulting in ''lawless verdicts'' on a defendant's guilt or innocence, a Justice Department study concludes.

title: Curing Hodgkin's,; Preserving Fertility
description: A diagnosis of Hodgkin's disease, a cancer that attacks the lymphatic system, is no longer a death sentence; some 70 percent of its victims live normal lifespans. Now, researchers at Stanford University say, the sentence of childlessness that was believed to be the lot of women treated for Hodgkin's may be gone too.

title: At Home
description: FIVE years ago, fairly new to suburban life and full of happy ignorance, my husband and I joined the ranks of Little League parents. All we thought we had to do to successfully fulfill our new roles was to attend every game armed with good cheer and throat lozenges. We were wrong.

title: GUILD HALL AND THE GREENING OF EAST HAMPTON
description: It has been called ''the abstract Woodstock,'' ''the rich man's Provincetown,'' even ''the cradle of American art,'' and there is a certain truth to each of these epithets, for the last few decades have seen the avatars of the avant-garde as well as some of the foremost practitioners of landscape painting settle on that narrow strip of land known as the South Fork or East End of Long Island. There, amid the dunes and wastes of scrub oak, such artists as Willem de Kooning, the late Jackson Pollock, Lee Krasner, James Brooks, Adolph Gottlieb, Franz Kline, Roy Lichtenstein, Alfonso Ossorio, Larry Rivers and James Rosenquist made their homes and built their studios, and it was there that they helped redefine American - and 20th-century - art.

title: SOME TASTY GREENS TO GROW IN WARM WEATHER
Dance View; IMPACT OF THE FUND 'FREEZE'
description: The Federal Government's recently announced freeze on grants already approved by the National Endowment for the Arts for the current cycle of its fiscal year has left at least two major dance organizations uncertain about their immediate plans. One is the American Dance Festival, which opens its six-week season next Saturday in Durham, N.C. The other is the Joffrey Ballet, now on the first leg of a tour vital to its financial existence. In the long run, this uncertainty alone stands to affect the future of both institutions, including the Joffrey's junior company, Joffrey II - one of whose dancers is Ron Reagan, the President's son.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; President of Arab Emirates Sees No Threat From Soviet

title: SEARCH GOES ON FOR PRISONER WHO USED SHEETS TO ESCAPE
description: The police and United States marshals were searching yesterday for one of two prisoners who escaped from the Metropolitan Correctional Center in lower Manhattan Friday night by using tied bedsheets to lower themselves from a ninth-story window.

title: THE HIGH COST OF STARTING OUT
description: Howard Husock is a writer and television producer with a longtime interest in urban affairs. He has been awarded a fellowship to work with the Princeton Urban and Regional Research Center. By Howard Husock

title: PATTERN OF REGION'S OFFICE GROWTH SHIFTS
description: Housing availability and the presence of a labor market are becoming increasingly important criteria when corporations select suburban office locations, according to developers and real estate brokers.

title: CROWDING
description: ONCE again Nassau County is turning to the state in an effort to resolve the controversy over crowded conditions in the County Jail at East Meadow. The overcrowding, which has existed for several months, has led to tension-filled situations among prisoners as well as lawsuits and court clashes.

title: Long Island Journal
description: AFTER 28 years in business - it is one of the Island's oldest performing arts presenters -the Roslyn Music Group came close to folding last winter. Audiences for the chamber music series had dwindled, and the volunteer staff could not keep up with the fund-raising needed to survive. Enter the Friends of the Arts, which in a decidedly friendly mood has taken over the operation.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; COZY TOUCHES, HOME COOKING
description: DANBURY IT is reassuring that in this age of fast foods, new restaurants devoted to fresh, home-cooked dishes continue to open and, in many instances, thrive. Such a one is Heart to Hand in Danbury. Like many of its genre, Heart to Hand is small, with a refreshingly limited menu. The restaurant began as a craft shop-and-restaurant, but the crafts have receded to mere decorative touches on shelves and walls. The restaurant is lodged in a white frame house, trimmed with bright red and with red hearts painted on front and side. Inside, three minuscule dining rooms are decorated in gingham - one in brown, the second in blue, the third in yellow and green. Paintings and handthrown stoneware pots line the walls and shelves. The net effect is homey.

title: Family Service Ready To Aid in Abuse Cases
description: We applaud the article by Susan S. Turner on the problem of sexual abuse of children (''Sexual Abuse of Children: A Problem Not to Be Ignored,'' April 5). Her statements indicating that this type of abuse reflects the broad attitudes of society toward women, children and sexuality aptly describe the problem.

title: MORE ON A PROPHET BELATEDLY HONORED IN HIS LAND
description: Two or three years ago, W. Edwards Deming was little known in American business circles, much less to a wider audience. Now Ricoh of America is invoking the name of this American to personify Japanese quality. The American subsidiary of the Japanese copier company is boasting in full-page ads that it won the Deming Prize only ''a few short years ago'' - in 1975, as it turns out.

title: CONDEMNATION ISSUE ON THE WEST SIDE AROUSES DISPUTE
description: Two housing developers, one a former public official, are embroiled in a dispute involving their purchase of a warehouse building bordering New York City's convention center project.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: PUBLIC TV OFFICIAL TELLS OF INTERFERENCE
description: ranking New Jersey officials have tried to get favorable publicity on the four stateowned UHF television stations, according to the head of the state's Public Broadcasting Authority.

title: GOOD COUNSEL, AND NONE; Mothers, in Law
description: The Supreme Court says, 5 to 4, that lawyers are not essential to the fairness of a proceeding to strip a mother of her parental rights. But the majority could not answer the dissent of Justice Harry Blackmun.

title: MAREE RUNS AWAY WITH 1,500
description: Sydney Maree of Villanova wanted to run fast tonight, and he didn't think anyone was prepared to join him. So he made the 1,500-meter final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor track and field championships a solo race, winning by 18 meters and setting a meet record of 3 minutes 35.30 seconds.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The Spirit of '81. It's a fortnight now since the last publisher dismantled his booth in the vast exhibition hall of the Georgia World Congress Center and the last convention-goer made it home from the 81st annual meeting of the American Booksellers, held Memorial Day weekend in Atlanta. What does the affair bode for everyone for whom the book is a staff of life? As the fortunes of the paperback nowadays are inextricably intertwined with those of the hardcover, most of our observations apply to both kinds of books. To wit:

title: Banker Is Fiance Of Patricia Rand
description: Patricia Rand, director of fragrance development for Estee Lauder Inc., will be married on Sept. 26 in Nantucket, Mass., to Barrett Burns, a vice president of Citibank N.A.

title: ART
description: We've seen a lot of the later work of Milton Avery (1893-1965), whose gifts as a colorist made him one of the foremost American painters. Now, a new show at Bard College reveals some of the early work of this born landscapist, who also painted figures and portraits.

title: CON MAN IN WHITE HAT
description: THE STING MAN Inside Abscam. By Robert W. Greene. Illustrated. 268 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $13.50.

title: MARIAN STASTNY DEFECTS, JOINS BROTHERS IN CANADA
description: Marian Stastny, a Czechoslovak hockey player, defected to Canada today to join his two younger brothers who sought and found asylum last year and signed with the Quebec Nordiques of the National Hockey League.

title:
Dining Out;
On the Other Side of the Delaware
description: Bucks County has the idyllic scenery that tourists usually go to Europe to find. Winding country roads edging the Delaware River or cutting through lush green hillsides give the impression that the modern-day world is far away. This area of Pennsylvania also contains some of the most interesting and attractive restaurants at which the food - good, bad or indifferent - takes second place to the atmosphere.

title: Realty News; FLOOR IN G.M. BUILDING
description: Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, an investment research and management firm, has leased the entire 22d floor at the General Motors Building at 767 Fifth Avenue with 30,587 square feet of ofice space for 10 years.

title: Backing Jetty Plan For Westhampton Beach
description: Peter F. Cohalan's reasoning for turning down the jetties in Westhampton Beach is certainly lacking and discriminatory (''Beach Jetty Plan Blocked''). Mr. Cohalan claims the Suffolk taxpayer will be paying in part to protect the barrier beach of Suffolk County, and the part that will be protected is owned by people who also live outside Suffolk County.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear and Fact On Hempstead Plant
description: I recently wrote an Opinion Page article entitled ''Fear, Too, Is a Form of Pollution.'' In expressing my personal opinion, it was not my intention to engage in a running dialogue. However, the responses to the piece (Letters to the Editor, May 10) must be answered.

title: HOUSE PANEL IS TOLD CUBA AND U.S. MAY BE ON VERGE OF A RADIO WAR
description: A House panel has been told that American radio stations may be on the verge of a war of broadcasting signals with Cuban transmitters in the AM band.

title: ARGENTINA SIGNS ECONOMIC AID PACT WITH SALVADOR
description: Argentina has concluded an agreement to extend $15 million in economic aid credits and technical assistance to El Salvador.

title: It's Florio, Kean; And 19 Also-Rans
description: Considering the volatile combination of 21 candidates, nearly as many media consultants, $6 million in state campaign funds and an electorate that was thought to be too weary or too confused to show an interest, the result of last week's gubernatorial primaries in New Jersey was something of a surprise. The favorites won.

title: Liberia Sentences 13 Soldiers to Death as Plotters
description: Thirteen Liberian soldiers have been sentenced to death by a special court-martial after the latest of a series of alleged plots to overthrow the 14-month-old regime of Master Sgt. Samuel K. Doe, the presidential office announced today.

title: CRITICS CHOICE
description: JAZZ Any appearance in New York by Red Norvo, the masterful jazz vibraphonist, is cause for celebration. Now 73 years old, Mr. Norvo lives in California and rations his trips to the East.

title: Power Company; Asks 19% More
description: The price of oil may be dropping, but the rates of the region's oil-consuming electric companies aren't, as last week's request for a record increase of about 19 percent by Connecticut's Northeast Utilities attests.

title: IN CAMBODIA THE SOUND OF BELLS
description: In Cambodia, after a decade of war, spent cartridges litter the ground like bottle caps after a picnic. Khmer peasants gather the bits of metal, melt them down, and fashion them into the tiny cowbells that encircle the necks of their oxen and buffalo. In the countryside, the pleasant jingle-jangle of these bells gives a rhythm to the tranquility. Bells made from bullets - the transformation is no less elegant in its symbolism than Isaiah's biblical admonition to beat swords into plowshares.

title:
Gardening;
WHY ROSES NEED EXTRA CARE THIS YEAR
description: ATRIP to California in early spring can be a mind-boggling expererince when it comes to the vast array of flowers in bloom. Having lived there while studying horticulture, I was well aware of the great diversity of plants, yet I was unprepared for the mass of colorful flowers on display in the San Francisco area early last month. I had somehow forgotten the hillsides covered with blooming succulents, the roadsides planted to groundcovers flowering in bold lavender and reds and the geraniums as large as rhododendrons.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The unidentified producer who states that the nonprofit theaters ''have never discovered even one Tennessee Williams'' is forgetting that playwrights Sam Shepard, Michael Cristofer, Lanford Wilson, David Rabe, Michael Weller and Thomas Babe all have evolved out of the nonprofit institutional theaters. These playwrights certainly can be considered the artistic peers of Mr. Williams, and three of them have won the Pulitzer Prize for drama.

title: GRADUATES HEAR VONNEGUT ON WHEN IT'S HONORABLE TO BE A 'WISE GUY'
description: The following remarks are from a speech at the Southampton College commencement last month by the writer Kurt Vonnegut Jr., who has a home on the East End.

title: N.B.A. HOLDS ITS DRAFT TUESDAY, LOOKING FOR ONE SPECIAL PLAYER
description: Every year National Basketball Association teams go to the market place - the colleges - looking for that one elusive player, the overpowering center, the playmaker, the power forward, who can turn a loser into a winner.

title: SKEPTICISM RISING ON REAGAN PLAN FOR INCREASES IN MILITARY SPENDING
description: The Reagan Administration has begun to feel the first resistance to its ambitious plans for national defense as Congress prepares to debate proposals for a new fleet of bombers, the MX intercontinental missile and the large sums to be appropriated for the 1982 military budget.

title: PETER J. DONGHUE, 72, RETIRED FAMILY COURT JUDGE
description: Peter J. Donoghue, a retired Family Court judge in Queens, died Thursday in North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a stroke. Mr. Donoghue, who was a resident of Point Lookout, L.I., was 72 years old.

title: JAPAN LEFTISTS CONTINUE PROTEST OVER U.S. WARSHIP
description: Japanese leftists continued their protests today over the presence of the United States aircraft carrier Midway with a rally in Tokyo that authorities said involved 24,000 people. Organizers put the crowd at 90,000.

title: OUTPOST OF LEARNING FOR JAPANESE YOUTHS
description: SATURDAY morning may be a time for Little League, piano lessons or just relaxing for most elementary school students, but for the 447 children who attend the Japanese Weekend School in New Rochelle, it is a special day. Their families, for the most part, are in the United States on business assignments, and the children attend American public schools. But the Japanese Weekend School is their link to the Japanese curriculum and language skills, to help them make a smooth transition on returning to Japan.

title: L.I. TO FEEL IMPACT OF INSURANCE RISE FOR MALPRACTICE
description: IF New York State's 21,000 physicians are required to pay the proposed increases in malpractice insurance premiums ranging from 71 percent to 367.8 percent, the impact will be felt significantly on the Island, where doctors will pay the highest rates in the state and very likely will pass some of the costs along to their patients.

title:
Gardening;
WHY ROSES NEED EXTRA CARE THIS YEAR
description: A trip to California in early spring can be a mind-boggling expererince when it comes to the vast array of flowers in bloom. Having lived there while studying horticulture, I was well aware of the great diversity of plants, yet I was unprepared for the mass of colorful flowers on display in the San Francisco area early last month. I had somehow forgotten the hillsides covered with blooming succulents, the roadsides planted to groundcovers flowering in bold lavender and reds and the geraniums as large as rhododendrons.

title: OWNERS REJECT PLAYER-POOL IDEA
description: A player-pool idea developed by the players' labor representatives was rejected yesterday by the owners' negotiators at the latest bargaining session in the baseball dispute.

title: Atlanta Finds a; Lead, and Loses It
description: For a few frantic hours last week, it appeared that after almost two years of searching the investigators of the Atlanta murders might have a solid lead. And then it seemed to dissolve.

title: HARTFORD
description: Following are some of the major issues dealt with by the 1981 regular session of the General Assembly, which adjourned Wednesday:

title: Nursing a Tenuous; Mideast Peace
description: The flame under the five-week-old crisis over Syrian missiles in Lebanon flickered a bit lower last week. Prime Minister Menachem Begin boasted that Israel could ''destroy those missiles in two hours,'' but after meeting with Egyptian President Anwar el-Sadat, he agreed to allow more time for diplomatic efforts.

title: WHEN YOUR HEALTH PLAN GETS SICK
description: When people consider whether to join a health maintenance organization - a prepaid health plan -they typically debate the pros and cons of medical coverage under the plan versus the coverage available with traditional types of medical insurance.

title: THE ROAD FROM CLASSROOM TO CAVE
description: SPRING used to mean peacefully relishing the clouds of dogwood and lilacs. Now we merely pass them on our way to endless town meetings and referendums on budgets, in particular the school budget. This year, the cutters and preservers are further apart than ever, more vociferous and less tolerant of opposing views, as everyone tries to preserve his eroding dollar.

title: Camera; A LOOK AT POLAROID'S NEW CAMERAS AND FILM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper, and the author of several book on photography. By JACK MANNING

title: LEGISLATORS REFLECT ON 'VERY DIFFICULT SESSION'
description: HARTFORD A FEW nights before the General Assembly went home last Wednesday, the State Senators gathered at a nearby country club for their annual pre-adjournment dinner and presented T-shirts to each other that seemed graphically to sum up the legislative session.

title: Morin Bowling Victor
description: Jeff Morin of Cleveland rolled three consecutive strikes late in the final match and captured his first Professional Bowlers Association tournament today. He defeated Larry Laub of Santa Rosa, Calif., 224-210, in the $90,000 Seattle Open. Joe Berardi of Brooklyn, N.Y., finished third.

title: OPEN HEARINGS ARE URGED ON DISCIPLINING LAWYERS
description: The chairman of the committee that disciplines lawyers in Manhattan has called on the State Legislature to lift partially what he describes as the ''shroud of secrecy'' covering lawyer disciplinary proceedings.

title: 2 PHILADELPHIA MENTAL HEALTH CENTERS IN CASH CRISIS
description: Two publicly financed, nonprofit mental health centers failed to pay their employees last month, and city officials said their financial problems were so severe that a private management consultant was called in to help solve the problems.

title: ARTS PROJECTS WIN WIDER SUPPORT FROM INDUSTRY
description: TRADITIONALLY considered stepchildren when it comes to sharing the largesse distributed by generous corporations, local cultural institutions finally have begun to make important inroads in forging a viable partnership between the arts and industry on the Island.

title: G.M. PLANT STRESSES WORK QUALITY
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN ALONG line of X-body cars in production winds through the cavernous General Motors assembly plant here six days a week, like some gigantic amusement-park ride without customers.

title:
Art;
PRE-COLUMBIAN SHOW IN GREENWICH LIBRARY
description: GREENWICH ABEAUTIFUL but puzzling exhibition called ''Pre-Columbian Art from Mesoamerica'' will be on view at the Hurlbutt Gallery in the Greenwich Library through June 20. It is a large show -the catalogue lists 128 objects - and it has some very fine things in it.

title: ECOLOGICAL RESEARCH HELD SCANT
description: DESPITE the ecological sensitivity of much of New Jersey's land and water, and despite the extent and seriousness of the contamination that continues to show up, environmental research being done in the state is, in the view of many scientists and environmentalists, ''woefully inadequate.''

title: F.B.I. Continues Watch at Home Of the Man Questioned in Atlanta
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the police continued their surveillance today of a man questioned in the slayings of 28 young blacks.

title: KICKBACKS ARE INVESTIGATED IN OKLAHOMA AND TEXAS
description: Oklahomans for decades had heard stories that some county commissioners were wheeler-dealers, using public money for personal gain. The reports were never confirmed, however, until this week.

title: Yael Susan Simpson Bride of Ian C. Fletcher
description: Yael Susan Simpson, daughter of Robert H. Simpson of New York and Sharon, Conn., and the late Geraldine Simpson, was married in Salisbury, Conn., yesterday to Ian Christopher Fletcher, son of Dr. and Mrs. Willard Allen Fletcher of Newark, Del. Justice of the Peace Barclay W. Prindle performed the ceremony at the White Hart Inn.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: "There is no one who can be set to music so well as he," said Beethoven - and perhaps no one was. The texts consciously aspired to the condition of music; hardly a composer could resist, including Mozart, Mendelssohn, Schubert, Schumann, Liszt, Brahms, Wolf, and Mahler.

title: BANGLADESHI KEEPS EYE ON WEATHER, NOT POLITICS
description: "What matters here is the rain," said Mr. Mustaf, a subsistence rice farmer, automatically casting his eyes up to the leaden sky in the traditional June ritual of waiting for the all important monsoon rains to begin falling.

title: THE CURE MONEY CAN'T BUY
description: Since the passage in 1971 of the National Cancer Act, the Federal Government has put $8 billion into the effort to conquer cancer. With the money, however, the cancer research establishment has received repeated reprimands from Congressional and consumer watchdogs for failing to make dramatic inroads against the leading cancer killers. Where, observers ask, is the promised cancer cure?

title: HOMES LOSING APPEAL
description: Home ownership as a hedge against inflation, greatly valued in the 1970's, seems to be losing its allure. High interest rates and prices have depressed sales of existing single-family homes.

title: DEE HOCK'S COSMIC VISTA FOR VISA INTERNATIONAL
description: IN the beginning was the committee. At its head was a country banker, and although no college diploma graced his office wall, he had something better: a grasp of the wonders contained in a sliver of plastic.

title: HOPEFUL HOMEBUYERS CAMP OUT IN CONNECTICUT'S MORTGAGE-RUSH
description: Eager homebuyers camped out on sidewalks in front of banks and then caused a telephone overload this week, as they snapped up mortgages offered by the state on favorable terms.

title: U.S. Technology
description: To the Business Editor: As a material-handling engineer and someone familiar with new developments in the textile industry, I can attest that the story of the re-industrialization of the American textile industry (''Textile Industry Shakes Itself Up,'' May 10) can be told without apology for the role played by American technological know-how.

title: Patricia A. Fisk Is Bride Of Michael Butterworth
description: Patricia Ann Fisk and Michael Anderson Butterworth were married yesterday at Christ Church United Methodist. The Rev. Roderick Dail and the Rev. William Stillwell, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: THE PENTAGON PAPERS A DECADE LATER
description: Shortly after 7 o'clock on the evening of June 14, 1971, President Nixon spoke by telephone with his Attorney General. They agreed upon the text of a telex, which was immediately dispatched to the offices of The New York Times in New York. Respectful in tone, its substance was ominous.

title: CONCERT: ANDREW DAVIS FIRST RUSSIAN PROGRAM
description: Andrew Davis is conducting two programs during the New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' series at Avery Fisher Hall, and both are all-Russian. On Friday night, he put together a grouping of Borodin-Glazunov, Jules Conus and Rimsky-Korsakov, and next Thursday and Friday it will be an all-Tchaikovksy bill.

title: SPRING FLOW OF MAPLE SYRUP BOTH RICH AND SWEET
description: A bumper crop of maple syrup in New York State and the United States this spring was announced today by the Crop Reporting Service here.

title: BIRD PITCHES YANKS TO SIXTH STRAIGHT
description: Bird, whose flexibility and consistency have been invaluable to the injury-riddled Yankees, has a 1.51 earned run average in three starts. He has allowed three runs in 17 innings.

title: The Unathletic Get Short Shrift, Too
description: To the Sports Editor: Allen Sack's article ''College Sports Must Choose: Amateur or Pro'' (The New York Times, May 3) failed to note some other questions that might be asked. He writes ''If sport is educational, what possible academic justification can there be for denying this aspect of education to women? Wouldn't (this) be tatamount to saying that men should have more microscopes, laboratory facilities and library privileges than women?''

title: Sound; MATCHED SYSTEMS BECKON BUYERS
description: If doubt about your own wisdom and expertise in choosing stereo components has hitherto kept you on the sidelines, you may now come into the fold. You no longer have to pick each component individually - turntable, receiver, speakers and tape deck. And you no longer have to worry whether the components really match each other to best advantage. Complete pre-matched systems in all price ranges are now being offered in reputable brands. All you have to tell the dealer is how much you want to spend, and you walk away with a set of components compatible in terms of capability and cost - usually all from the same manufacturer.

title: Everyone Loses In Bangladesh Coup Attempt
description: If there are worse places than Bangladesh these days, much credit goes to Ziaur Rahman. From his rise to power in 1975 until his assassination last weekend, General Zia instilled new motivation in the New England-sized nation of 92 million people to produce more food and fewer children.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 5 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 9 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase across two continents. 3 3 7 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 4 4 7 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 5 5 33 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 6 7 8 TAR BABY, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $11.95.) A black fable of race and eroticism set on a Caribbean island. 7 6 10 CREATION, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $15.95.) A journey through that greatest of all ages, the fifth century B.C., in the company of a man critical of it all.

title: No Headline
description: The plot was so bizarre and the conspirators so ill-assorted that the newspaper here called it a ''comic-book escapade.'' In New Orleans, where even the Federal judge hearing the case isn't sure how to pronounce ''Dominica,'' they call the affair the ''Bayou of Pigs.''

title: Art View; HELEN FRANKENTHALER'S ART IN THE 50'S
description: the so-called ''second generation'' of the New York School - that was noted for winning a place for itself in the limelight far more quickly than had been common for American artists in the past, the sheer velocity of Miss Frankenthaler's career was unusual. Her first solo exhibition took place in 1951; her first museum retrospective, in 1960.

title: CHOOSING A CITE FOR AN ARTS COMPLEX
description: The prospect of a complex for the performing arts is an exciting one. Another possibility for a site, in addition to Dr. Calderone's suggestion of Hempstead, is the thousand-odd-seat Bay Shore Theater in that village on Montauk Highway.

title:
Stamps;
NEW 18-CENT ISSUE WILL HONOR GEORGE MASON
description: The stamp that undoubtedly will be the most widely used for firstclass postage has received only passing mention here because of the torrent of new issues, so it is time to rectify this before the issue gets too far away.

title: Maria Fisher Wed To William Pollak
description: Maria A. Fisher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Fisher of Larchmont, N.Y., and William L. Pollak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander H. Pollak, also of Larchmont, were married yesterday at the Carlyle. Rabbi Roy A. Rosenberg of the Temple of Universal Judaism performed the ceremony.

title: A VISIT WITH NADINE GORDIMER
SYRIA'S PRESS URGES NEW APPROACH BY HABIB
description: The controlled Syrian press said today that, unless Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, changed his approach, Syria would not be interested in his mission.

title: THE CONNAUGHT IS LIKE THE HOME OF A RICH FRIEND
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- RONA JAFFE, the novelist, has a new book, ''Mazes and Monsters,'' coming out in September. By RONA JAFFE

title: LaBonte Captures Pole
description: Terry LaBonte of Corpus Christi covered the Texas World Speedway's two-mile oval track in an average speed of 167.543 miles per hour today to earn the pole position for tomorrow's Nascar 400.

title: Connecticut Housing; GROUP PRESCRIBES HOUSING REMEDY
description: IS it still possible to provide an adequate supply of safe and decent housing for people of modest means at a time of Federal spending cutbacks, escalating construction costs and high interest rates?

title: SAVE THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM BY PHASING IT OUT
description: A recent news article stated that the current proposals by President Reagan regarding Social Security were the first attempt in 30 years to reduce Social Security benefits.

title: Antiques; HISTORY CAPTURED IN POTTERS' ART
description: For 6,000 years, potters have shaped clay into vessels and figures to satisfy man's needs and his pleasure. Any comprehensive survey of pots would produce an impressive history of civilization in which man's wit and accomplishments would be revealed. Even focusing on certain periods down through the centuries provides insight into the societies that bred these wares, for the sophistication of design and quality of craftsmanship achieved in the forms and glazes reflect the economic and esthetic standards of the people who made them.

title: Margaret Sheridan Wed
description: Margaret Sheridan of Rumson, N.J., widow of John M. Sheridan, was married yesterday in South Bend, Ind., to Michael R. Hays of Middletown, N.J., president of the Personal Products Company, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson in Milltown, N.J. The Rev. Chester Soleta performed the ceremony in the Log Chapel at the University of Notre Dame. The bridegroom's first wife died.

title: THOSE WHO 'SURVIVE' WITHOUT TV
description: It is a typical upper-middle-class Manhattan apartment. Hundreds of books, prints on the walls, an Eames chair, a stereo system and stacks of recordings. A wine rack is full of interesting bottles, and current magazines are scattered about.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN BUSINESS
description: CORPORATE CONTROL, CORPORATE POWER A Twentieth Century Fund Study. By Edward S. Herman. 432 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $18.95. EXECUTIVE By Harry Levinson. With the Assistance of Cynthia Lang. 370 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.50. MANAGING THE PUBLIC'S BUSINESS The Job of the Government Executive. By Laurence E. Lynn Jr. 211 pp. New York: Basic Books. $14.95.

title: TO FRESH AIR YOUNGSTERS, PARADISE ISN'T JUST A TOWN NAME
description: Wonnor Yee is a Queens mother who will be sending her children to Paradise this summer. To Paradise, Pa., that is, where 8-year-old Arden Yee and 11-yearold Christina Yee will be the guests of Fresh Air Fund families for two weeks in July.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Sunken History
description: One hundred fifteen years after the Confederate ironclad Georgia sank in the Savannah River, apparently scuttled when Savannah was captured, the Army Corps of Engineers was considering salvaging the vessel.

title: About Long Island
description: BIFF! Zap! Zowie! Love at first sight! The jet snarls over a jagged landscape, pulverizing swarms of alien craft with laser beams and smart bombs. It swoops down, soars, reverses on a dime. When really threatened, it goes into hyperspace.

title: Gabriel Wins the 400 At State Track Meet
description: Nigel Gabriel won a title today at the New York State Interscholastic outdoor track and field championships. That was nothing new. Boris Pendergrass and Ken Wilson also were winners at the meet held in Cornell University's Schoellkopf Stadium. That was new.

title: TEAMSTERS' DISPUTE WITH CONTRACTORS GOES TO COURT
description: A Federal judge will begin hearing arguments tomorrow in a dispute between a teamsters union local and a contractors' group that could affect construction costs in the city and minority-group employment at construction sites.

title: RUSHING TO RESCUE THE CITY'S TRANSIT
description: With the Legislature threatening to delay action on New York's mounting transit problems until the fall and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority threatening to impose a 95-cent bus and subway fare next month, an advisory panel chartered by Governor Carey evidently decided that time was not on its side. Releasing its findings nearly a month early, the panel reported last week that the M.T.A. faced a deficit of $560 million next year, substantially higher than the agency's own ''worst case'' estimate.

title: INDONESIA PUTS AIRFIELD ON ISLAND SOUTH OF VIETNAM
description: Indonesia has taken another important step in strengthening its perimeter defenses by opening a new airfield in the remote Natuna Islands south of Vietnam and Cambodia in the South China Sea.

title: TWO-TIME MURDERER ACCUSED OF KILLING A PRISON GUARD
description: An inmate serving two life sentences for murder was charged by the state police yesterday with the slaying of Donna Payant, a correction officer who was strangled while on duty last month at the Green Haven State Correctional Facility at Stormville, N.Y.

title: Jennifer Hoffman Married
description: Jennifer Hoffman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Hoffman of Southbury, Conn., was married there yesterday in the United Church of Christ to Kristjan Lugus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hans Lugus of Lebanon, Conn. The Rev. Gary W. Hall performed the ceremony.

title: Rosemary Frazier Wed To Phillip Slott on L. I.
description: Rosemary Frazier and Phillip Slott, who are with Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom in East Hampton, L.I. Town Justice Shepherd Frood performed the ceremony.

title: Laws on Flare Pistol A Conflict in Boating
description: On this, the first day of National Safe Boating Week, New York boating enthusiasts have a big problem because of a new Federal safety requirement that conflicts with state law.

title: No Headline
description: The assessment of black theater and its contribution to the Great White Way's current prosperity was distressing.

title: Lucy G. Gelb Wed To Frank M. Sisto
description: Lucy Gates Gelb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Gelb of New York, was married in Stamford, Conn., yesterday to Frank M. Sisto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Sisto of Clifton, N.J. The Rev. Richard Earl Mayberry performed the ceremony in St. Francis Episcopal Church.

title: U.S. AND FRENCH CONCUR AT TALKS ON WORLD ISSUES
description: The Reagan Administration and the Socialist Government of France concluded their first talks today in general agreement on their assessment of most international issues, but with the French stressing their unhappiness with the impact on Western Europe of the high interest rates in the United States.

title:
Art;
A NOSTALGIC LOOK AT HUDSON REGION
description: ON-HUDSON A MODEST but entirely engaging exhibition of Hudson River School landscapes is on view at the Gallery of Hastings-on-Hudson through June 28. Don't go expecting the blockbuster paintings one can see at the Metropolitan Museum or the New-York Historical Society. But if you feel any nostalgia for the way this region used to look, you really ought to see the images assembled here.

title: BASEBALL UMPIRES: A BESIEGED FEELING
description: Lunchtime in Manhattan. The waiter is doing his Don Rickles imitation, sneering and pouting and dropping insults to make four customers feel right at home in New York. Eventually he addresses them as ''You farmers.''

title: No Headline
description: If William B. Ruger, the gun manufacturer, indeed thinks that ''guns are a great and brilliant example of the individuality of our citizens, just like owning an automobile,'' must he not also concede that gun ownership should be registered and gun users licensed? WILLIAM J. DONAHUE, Bradford, Vt.

title: SUFFOLK INMATES OFTEN HAVE TO SLEEP IN HALL
description: IN Suffolk County's two jails, overcrowding is a way of life. Jail officials are faced daily with the task of finding places to house the men and women remanded to the correctional facility in Riverhead or the Yaphank minimum security jail, which are filled way beyond capacity.

title: ALAKANS MEET AS STOCKHOLDERS AND STRUGGLE TO KEEP TRIBAL WAYS
description: Slowly but steadily, the lives of the Eskimos, Aleuts and Indians in Alaska are being changed in fundamental ways by a law passed to compensate them for loss of the land their ancestors used.

title: Margaret Croyden writes that, ''unlike the days of Kaufman and Hart, when the audience was fairly solidly middle class or well-to-do, Broadway now entertains more than 200,000 weekly.''
description: The Broadway audience is still largely middle class and white. This affects the whole range of producers' choices, but is, for some of us, a limitation to be struggled with. PAUL LEAVIN

title: Elizabeth McCabe Is a Bride
description: Elizabeth McCabe, a lawyer's assistant, was married yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Salisbury, Conn., to Douglas Blount Keith 3d, a land manager for Ike Lovelady Inc., Midland, Tex., oil exploration and production company. The Rev. Joseph F. Forte performed the ceremony. The bride who is with the oil and gas division of Lynch, Chappell, Allday & Alsup in Midland, is a daughter of Mrs. Hadley Case of Salisbury and Naples, Fla., and the late Ambrose Church McCabe. Mr. Keith is a son of Mrs. Mary Richards Keith of Bossier City, La., and Douglas B. Keith Jr. of Little Rock, Ark.

title: Behind the Iron Curtain
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; HELP FROM THE OFFENSE
description: In the past decade the United States has been represented in world open team championships by a relatively small number of players: 20 in ten events. In the previous decade the number was more than twice as much.

title: OILIN DOWS, ARTIST KNOWEN FOR HIS MURALS, DIES AT 76
description: Olin Dows, an artist known for his murals and watercolors, died yesterday in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 76 years old and lived in Rhinebeck.

title: FIRST ALBANY'S DEFENSE STOCK NICHE
description: With defense stocks in the investing spotlight, a small regional brokerge firm has been building a reputation among the big institutions for its research, particularly on the smaller military contractors that over time could benefit handsomely from President Reagan's arms buildup.

title: GOOD TIMES FOR TOWELS
description: Things could have been a lot worse in home textiles last year. The economy posted declines in personal income and housing construction, two components that ordinarily generate demand for textiles, and those declines could have hurt sales severely.

title: DOES REAGAN HAVE A MANDATE?
description: THE ELECTION OF 1980 Reports and Interpretations. By Gerald M. Pomper, Ross K. Baker, Kathleen A. Frankovic, Charles E. Jacob, Wilson Carey McWilliams, Henry A. Plotkin. Marlene Michels Pomper, editor. 199 pp. Chatham, N.J.: Chatham House. $15. RONALD REAGAN His Life and Rise to the Presidency. By Bill Boyarsky. 205 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: Music Noted in Brief; 2 Dramatic Quartets For Strings by Schubert
description: Carnegie Hall's Festival Concerts turned to chamber music Friday night. The program was entirely devoted to Schubert, and it featured two of the composer's most somber and dramatic string quartets, the one-movement torso in C minor (D. 703) and ''Death and the Maiden'' in D minor (D. 810).

title: CAREY OFFERS PROPERTY TAX PLAN WITH CITY'S RATES TIED TO INCOME
description: Governor Carey today proposed major changes in New York State property taxes, including a provision to link them in New York City to household income.

title: Koch Makes a Key Connection in His 'Fusion' Candidacy
description: If in politics one hand washes the other, Mayor Koch's should be clean enough to eat out of. That, arguably, is what the Brooklyn Republican organization did last week in endorsing the Democratic mayor for re-election.

title: AIRCRAFT TAKING OFF FROM PARIS FOR RACE TO U.S.AND BACK
description: LeBourget airfield in France to New York State and back

title: JERSEY RACE TO TEST PRESIDENTS'S POLICIES
description: With the nominations of Thomas H. Kean and James J. Florio, the voters of New Jersey have assured that the coming gubernatorial campaign will also be a key test of the Reagan Adminstration's economic policies.

title: A GOLDEN OPPORTUNITY BUT TIME IS LIMITED
description: Are there profits to be made in baubles and bibelots? For Stephen Brown, Ephraim Shreibman and J. Steven Williams, apparently the answer is yes. But the bauble business is not without its complications. The New York Postal Inspector's Office, the Better Business Bureau and the Federal Trade Commission are not too happy with the way they do business.

title: Around the Nation; Suspect Admits Conspiracy In Smuggling of Aliens
description: Alfonse Interial, whom the authorities called the leader of an alien-smuggling operation, pleaded guilty yesterday.

title: Editors' Choices
description: 50. PRISONER WITHOUT A NAME, CELL WITHOUT A NUMBER, by Jacobo Timerman.

title:
Numismatics;
A RECORD HIGH PRICE FOR A TERRITORIAL GOLD COIN
description: A rare coin from California's historic gold rush days may soon make some history of its own. The coin, an 1855 $50 gold piece that was issued privately by the San Francisco firm of Kellogg & Company, is being offered by Stack's of New York for $275,000 - a price which apparently would make it the highest-priced territorial gold coin ever to change hands in a private sale.

title: TENDER LOVING CARE FOR GOATS AT DAIRY
description: BANTAM CYNTHIA B. WILLIS'S kids have a reputation for mischief. But, she says, with the exception of a few bad habits, such as occasionally spitting, camel-style, at visitors or nibbling on coat buttons, they have been unfairly maligned.

title: A NEW FRENCH FACTOR IN EUROPE'S EQUATION
description: By the time Claude Cheysson, France's new Foreign Minister, was ushered into the White House Friday, the reassuring statements about foreign policy ''continuity'' that have been emanating from Paris since Socialist Francois Mitterrand's election had reached a crescendo.

title:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
A TELLING FALLACY IN FORECASTING OIL
description: In economics there are not many instances where forecasters are wrong. The lawyer can be wrong when his client is given the death sentence, as is the executive when his company losses money while the rest of the industry shows record earnings. But the economist is not essentially wrong when his forecast, while shockingly inaccurate, is overrun by crop failures or political crises outside his model or system. Now, however, we have two forecasts on the energy outlook that are clearly wrong. The reasons for error provide lessons for future energy policy.

title: NEW PRODUCTS FOR THE PHOTOGRAPHER
Music: Debuts in Review; Nashville Brass Quintet Has Contemporary Sound
description: The short crescendo ending with a blasting sforzando is one of those musical gestures that the brass quintet thrives on. There were quite a few of those bright build-ups Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House as the Nashville Contemporary Brass Quintet made its New York debut - particularly because the contemporary program was more percussive than lyrical.

title: IN A MODEST CHURCH IN POLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WORK and love, said Freud, are the things to which life is reducible. They also are the things that will concern the Assembly tomorrow, when the lawmakers are expected to wrestle with these irreducibilities.

title: AT SOVIET USED-CAR LOT, WHISPERED DEALS PRODUCE HUGE PROFITS ON VINTAGE VEHICLES
description: The closest thing to a bargain is an aging subcompact going for the same amount it cost when new. Late-model sedans can command almost double the original new price. The sky's the limit on foreign cars.

title:
On The Isle;
ON WHEELS
description: There's something about the automobile that catches the fancy of man -even with the high price of gasoline -and today, car fanciers have three different opportunities to appreciate what the mechanical age has wrought.

title: Laura Cannamela Is Married To James Thomas Costello
description: The marriage of Laura Jean Cannamela, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent J.
