Cannamela of Metuchen, N.J., to James Thomas Costello, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Costello of Niagara Falls, N.Y., took place yesterday at St. Francis Roman Catholic Church in Metuchen. Msgr Dominic Turtora, assisted by the Rev. David Hillier, performed the ceremony.

title: CONSUMER RATES
No Headline
description: If, in any sense, ''bop'' means ''pop,'' or worse, ''go bang,'' the nuclear power industry had better reconsider its acronym for that part of a nuclear plant commonly referred to as the balance of plant. PETER KUSHKOWSKI, Haddam, Conn.

title: Future Events Diversity of Diversions
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Wrap It Up June 10 - There's no knowing just what will happen at ''Wrap an Auction,'' a fund-raising ploy on the part of the American Friends of the Israel Museum/Associate Division, at the Lotos Club from 6 to 9 P.M. Christo, the artist known for such feats as wrapping a mile of the Australian coast in plastic film and hanging a mammoth orange nylon curtain across a valley in Colorado, will be on hand to give a brief address, as will Henry Geldzahler, New York City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs. Guests will sample cocktails and hors d'oeuvres, then get down to the serious business of bidding on 111 lots, including tickets to the World Series, consultations at Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., the certified public accountants, and art works by Miro, Indiana, Rosenquist and Christo, represented by ''Two Lower Manhattan Wrapped Buildings,'' a framed print of conservative dimensions. Entrance fee, $30.

title: ABBOUD'S PLAN
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced plans last week to acquire Iowa Beef Processors, and A. Robert Abboud, president of Occidental, had a ready explanation for the unexpected $795 million diversification.

title: Miss Salmons, S.C. Moody 3d Have Nuptials
description: Elizabeth DeVries Salmons, daughter of Mrs. Irving Calander Jennings of South Norwalk, Conn., and William Martin Salmons of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to S. Clarke Moody 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moody Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J. The ceremony was performed in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn., by the Rev. Walter Taylor. He was assisted by the Rev. Donald Emig.

title: Politics; FOR POST, LITTLE TIME FOR SITTING IN THE SUN
description: HARTFORD FOR most of the legislators who left the State Capitol last week with the adjournment of the General Assembly, it was time to reintroduce themselves to their children or their law partners or to just sit in the sun for a while.

title: 2-YEAR MORATORIUM ON CO-OP CONVERSIONS PROPOSED
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, announced today that he would introduce legislation that would place a two-year nationwide moratorium on the conversion of rental housing to cooperatives or condominiums. During that time, Mr. Rosenthal said, a Presidential commission would study the practice to determine if restrictive laws were needed.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Florida's Sun Power
description: It appeared to be an idea whose time was overdue: the Florida Division of Recreation and Parks proposed last November to use the state's ample sunshine to produce electricity in more than 30 parks. The division was reported to have won approval of a $216,658 Federal grant to put in solar lighting and water heating.

title: Fashion; FOR SUMMER IN THE CITY
description: For Summer in the City No matter how fresh a woman may look and feel when she heads out in the morning, a few minutes on sweltering city streets can make her feel as though she's about to melt upon the pavement. But there is no reason that she has to look that way.

title: Design; BOXES ABLOOM UPON CITY SILLS
description: Window boxes are a bargain. Inch for inch and effort for effort, they deliver more impact than any other type of garden possibly could. With just an armful of plants, a bag of potting soil, a daily dose of water and regular feeding, a window box should flourish, giving a significant lift to both the inside and the outside of the house and to the entire street.

title: FAREWELL TO JEAN RATELLE: A HOCKEY PLAYER WITH CLASS
description: JEAN RATELLE. His name brings to mind three qualities - consistency, a conservative nature and class. All you had to do is look at his goal production (six 20-goal seasons, six 30-goal seasons and two 40-goal seasons) to know what to expect from him. When you look at his record - 1,267 points in 1,281 games. I don't know how you can be any more consistent. Ratelle scored practically a point a game in a 20-year career.

title: Nancy Craig, Interviewer On Home Service Shows
description: Nancy Craig, who broadcast radio and television home service shows that included the daily ''Women of Tomorrow'' programs on WABC-TV from 1951 to 1956, died Friday of cancer at Parson's Hospital in Flushing, Queens. She was a resident of Bayside and was 67 years old.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Ensemble for Early Music Examines Bach's Millieu
description: Friday's installment of the Basically Bach festival at Central Presbyterian Church was basically not Bach at all. Instead, Frederick Renz and his Ensemble for Early Music put themselves in the composer's place and looked out at the musical life that surrounded him.

title: AD POLICIES TESTED IN NEWSPAPER CASE
description: THE Darien News has promised state consumer protection officials that in the future it will label as advertising restaurant ''reviews'' that are paid for or controlled or written by the restaurant. While the agreement resolves a specific complaint brought against the newspaper for a restaurant-review column published in an advertising suppplement last June, it leaves unsettled a much broader issue - the potential conflict between state laws governing fairtrade practices and newspapers' rights under the First Amendment to publish what they choose.

title: A Few Words Settle; Discrimination Suit
description: If last week's job discrimination settlement between Sears, Roebuck & Company and the Federal Government seemed like a mountain of litigation for a molehill of a solution, Sears would be the first to agree.

title: Buffalo Coach Suspended
description: The State University of New York at Buffalo has suspended its varsity baseball coach, Bill Monkarsh, until the 1982-83 academic year. The school said Monkarsh was suspended for confirming details of a game that was never played and for twice allowing ineligible players to participate in games under assumed names.

title: CONDOS AT SHIRLEY RECEIVE GO-AHEAD
description: SHIRLEY OVERRULING the recommendations of the Suffolk County Department of Planning, the Brookhaven Planning Board and the land-use committee of the League of Women Voters, the Brookhaven Town Board recently approved zoning that would permit the building of 28 luxury condominiums at the foot of the Smith's Point Bridge. The bridge joins Shirley and Fire Island at the foot of the William Floyd Parkway.

title: WHEN AFRICANS VIEW THE WORLD THEY SEE NAMIBIA, APARTHEID
description: In Washington, officials like to see the big picture, but from other continents, the landmarks look different. True, people everywhere are concerned about Soviet-American rivalry, if only because the superpowers, with their nuclear arsenals, can make life or death decisions for the globe. Beyond that, however, the issues that loom large are much closer to peoples' homes. A recent tour of West Africa made clear that East-West conflict is by no means the glass through which Africans see the world.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL: MORE STATE REGULATION IS NEEDED
description: FEW people would mistake garbage collectors for physicists, as Thomas H. DeLorenzo, president of the New Jersey Trade Waste Association, said in an Opinion Page article on May 17, but it is necessary to clarify some statements made by him.

title: Anne Helwig To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Helwig of West Chester, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Harlow Helwig, to Bailey Clark Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy J. Adams of Washington. A September wedding is planned.

title: Marianne Margulies Is Married on L. I.
description: Marianne Browne Margulies and Stephen W. Shepherd were married yesterday The Rev. George Busler of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I., performed the ceremony there at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter P. Margulies.

title: THE DRILL AT JACKASS BAY
description: JACKASS BAY, La. This is the biography of an American oil well, one of the 70,000 that will likely be drilled in the United States this year. It is a story played out every day in places as remote from one another as the jagged hills of Tennessee, the jackrabbit plains of Texas, the boardrooms of Houston and the canyons of Wall Street.

title: PIANOS STILL STIR COMPOSERS' SOULS
description: Twentieth-century composers have expanded their sonic horizons in many directions over the past 50 years, altering the sound-producing capacities of regular instruments, inventing new ones and exploring a whole range of electronic possibilitiec. Perhaps the entire process has even been too rapid for most listeners to keep pace. In fact, many composers of late have cast a glance behind to see who is following them and found virtually no one there, which may account for the trend toward a new accessibility that has arisen in certain quarters recently.

title: Around the Nation; Investigator Doubts Gun Was Used to Kill Executive
description: A gun found in the car of Roger M. Wheeler, the slain chairman of the board of the Telex Corporation, is not the weapon that killed him, although both guns are .38-caliber pistols, the police said yesterday,

title: Renee Beauchamp Bride Of Frank John Keogh 3d
description: Renee Page Beauchamp, daughter of Mrs. Edward F. Beauchamp of Lighthouse Point, Fla., and the late Mr. Beauchamp, was married yesterday in St. James' Episcopal Church to Frank John Keogh 3d, son of Mrs. Keogh Jr. of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., and the late Mr. Keogh. The Rev. Hays H. Rockwell, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: WORLDWIDE TOTAL OF REFUGEES IS PUT AT 12.6 MILLION
description: A total of 12.6 million people were refugees from their homelands or displaced from their homes within their native countries at the beginning of 1981, according to a report by the U.S. Committee for Refugees.

title: Congress Favors The Pentagon in Budgetary Triage
description: While much of Washington's attention was focused on tax-cut proposals and strategems last week, Congress was enmeshed in the workaday business of living within a budget. As is often the case these days, the Pentagon made out fairly well; the have-nots, by and large, didn't.

title: ARIZONA STATE TOPS SOUTH CAROLINA, 10-7
description: Kendall Carter, a freshman, tied an Arizona State record for victories in a season as the Sun Devils defeated South Carolina today, 10-7, and stayed in contention in the College World Series baseball championships.

title: THE SINGLE-MINDED OBSESSION OF THE CONSERVATIVE
description: Peter H. Schuck makes a typically conservative error in attempting to equate ecology, a scientific concept, with liberalism, a political attitude ("Rethinking Liberalism," op-Ed May 31).

title: CHRISTIE MYSTERY BETTERED BY ITS HANDLING
description: EAST FARMINGDALE THE summer season of the Arena Players gets off to a ripping start with an adaptation of Agatha Christie's ''A Murder Is Announced.'' Dame Agatha's mysteries - the best, the middling and the worst - are commonly called crowd-pleasers. This one, which is dedicated to ''delicious death,' ' is middling, but it is played here as though it were of the best and most delicious variety.

title: Barbara Dau Bride Of Robert Hendren
description: Barbara Elizabeth Dau and Robert Bruce Hendren, 1978 graduates of Dartmouth College, were married yesterday in the First United Presbyterian Church of Pottstown, Pa. The Rev. Carl Rosenblum, minister of the church, and the Very Rev. H. Lawrence Whittemore, dean of the Episcopal Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: AUCTIONS: ART RECORDS SET IN MAY
description: During the month of May, record prices and some reversals were registered in the art auctions conducted in New York by Sotheby Parke Bernet and Christie's. And when the gaveling ended, Sotheby's had sold $48.6 million in art and Christie's $25.5 million.

title: Music View; ON BEING AN 'ACCESSIBLE COMPOSER'
description: It is quite possible that the names of Gian Carlo Menotti and Ernst Krenek have never, until this instant, been mentioned in the same breath. Why should they be? These two composers - Mr. Menotti the musical populist whose annual audiences number in the millions, Mr. Krenek the intellectual virtuoso who is idolized by a happy, happy few - make as unlikely a pairing as Laurel and Hardy or Mr. and Mrs. Jack Sprat. But events have conspired to push their names together this season: Mr. Menotti will celebrate his 70th birthday next month; Mr. Krenek, who is 80, will be present at Carnegie Recital Hall tonight when the Thouvenel String Quartet gives the world premiere performance of his Quartet No. 8, his first venture in the medium in almost 40 years.

title: A New Use for the Super Bowl
description: The National Football League has used its showcase, the Super Bowl, to impress or gain advantage in many walks of life, among television moguls, corporate executives, government officials, local politicians or even college football coaches. Anyone who gets a ticket to a game or an invitation to a party usually takes away a pleasant memory.

title: Photography View; ROBERT HEINECKEN- ASKING PROVOCATIVE QUESTIONS
description: Given the elan and virtuosity with which Robert Heinecken has combined photography with print-making and other media over the last two decades, one might expect him to have attained a measure of renown approaching that of Robert Rauschenberg, whose work Heinecken's superficially resembles. His reputation, however, is not nearly as widespread, nor has his work been as thoroughly examined. In part this is because he has chosen to be identified as a photographer, despite his training in the traditional fine arts and his position as a professor of art at U.C.L.A. The distinction is not incidental. As the Museum of Modern Art's John Szarkowski - one of the few to compare Heinecken's and Rauschenberg's work - noted in ''Mirrors and Windows,'' Rauschenberg's prints absorb photographs, while Heinecken's allow a ''precipitate of fact'' to cling to them.

title: Habib, on His Way to Middle East, Stops Off in Paris for Discussions
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, conferred here today with officials of the French Government, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: Ethics Hearing Set on Williams
description: The Senate Select Committee on Ethics announced today it had scheduled hearings starting July 14 to consider disciplinary action against Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, over his conduct in the Abscam investigation. The Senator was found guilty by a Federal jury May 1 of bribery and conspiracy charges in connection with the corruption inquiry, conducted by inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title:
Dining Out;
WHERE THE FISH IS KING
description: THE Ocean House (the erstwhile Fish House) in Chappaqua is a paradigm of fishing shack genre: a maritime atmosphere pervades in the pulleys, thick ropes, crates and other dockside paraphernalia. A complementary roughness seems to be the restaurant's stock in trade - depressingly dim overhead lighting; menus printed on food-stained, limp brown paper bags; sawdust on the floor, and newspapers covering the tables - all as unpretentious as the shack of Hemingway's Santiago, perhaps a heavy-handed indication to diners that in a place like this fresh fish can't be far away.

title: Nancy O'Connor, Engineer, Married
description: The marriage of Nancy O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph O'Connor of Glenmont, N.Y., to John Joseph Evans 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans 3d of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Center Harbor, N.H., took place in Albany yesterday. The Rev. Richard Hamlin performed the ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: There's No Business ...
description: Any Easterner who has ever yawned his way into the early-morning hours with the annual marathon that is the Academy Awards telecast may have wondered if there is such a thing as a tight, orderly awards show. Take it from Hildy Parks, the answer is no. At least not from where she stands.

title: Headliners Ray Stabbed by Inmates
description: James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was himself the victim of a murder attempt last week. He was jumped by four other inmates at Tennessee's Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary, where he is serving a 99-year sentence, and stabbed 22 times with a homemade knife.

title: No Headline
description: In Switzerland, each citizen by law must keep a weapon and ammunition in the home, and the Swiss have next to no gun crimes. ''But this is New York,'' you cry.

title: MORE STRESS IN ECONOMY IS PREDICTED FOR NORTHEAST
description: Hampered by a population that is growing older but not larger, the Northeastern United States probably faces a continuation of the economic problems that have plagued it in recent years, according to Government and private demographers who have studied 1980 Census figures.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Prank and Prejudice
description: It was his first court offense: desecration of a synagogue. Standing nervously last February in District Court in Mineola, L.I., 16-year-old Joseph McCloskey was fined $150 and ordered to give 100 hours of service to his hometown church, St. Brigid's Roman Catholic in Westbury, L.I.

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE REAGANS
description: ''DONORS Give Over $375,000 to Refurbish White House.'' That headline gave the total, to date, donated to the private fund established for redecorating Ronald and Nancy Reagan's living quarters in the White House, and a nice start it was, indeed.

title: THE FUR TRADE: PAYING TOP DOLLAR FOR PELTS
description: The prices are ''crazy, crazy,'' one man mumbles. A second man drops out of the bidding, chomping glumly on his cigar. But Joseph Charles Reich, sitting in the center of the auction room, raises a manicured, gold-braceleted hand and buys another bundle of pelts. By the end of the two-day auction, Charlie Reich will have bought some 60,000 mink pelts, nearly one-third of the total number sold, and he will have spent $3.5 million.

title: Politics; 'OFF-YEAR' CONTESTS SHOW SIGNS OF CONSEQUENCE
description: ''OFF-YEAR'' elections, when neither state nor national political offices are at stake, are supposed to be dull. This year should be an exception in Westchester, with two interesting mayoralty races apparent even at this stage, an important county legislative election and the County Executive race itself -and all of those races linked in different ways.

title: 37 Years Later, D-Day Is Marked in Normandy
description: The 37th anniversary of D-Day, when the Allies landed in France during World War II, was marked by quiet ceremonies today.

title: Crafts
description: HANDCRAFTED works that complement or relate to nature, especially that which flourishes in backyards and on patios, are currently featured at two Bergen County galleries.

title: DRIVERS' RULE TO BE TIGHTENED AFTER INDY
description: In the wake of last month's Indianapolis 500 some of the sanctioning bodies of auto racing in the United States are looking at the rules that govern competitors' actions on the track and in the pits during emergency situations. In the Indy race Bobby Unser was penalized a lap for passing during a caution period, and his victory was given to Mario Andretti the morning after.

title: MEXICO HAS HIGH HOPES FOR U.S. RELATIONS UNDER REAGAN
description: MEXICO CITY WHEN Ronald Reagan was elected, many Mexicans predicted that the conservative surge in the United States would lead to clashes between the two countries over policy toward Central America. Only a few remembered that United States-Mexican relations have usually been better under Republican than under Democratic administrations.

title: Back Talk on Business Schools
description: To the Business Editor:

title: No Headline
description: FORSCH HURLS 5-HITTER, ANGELS ROUT ORIOLES

title: FREEDOM OF THE PRESS
description: Fifty years ago this month the Supreme Court decided the great case, Near v. Minnesota, that breathed life into the First Amendment's guarantee of press freedom in this country. Ten years ago, daring to test that freedom on the sensitive issue of the Vietnam War, The New York Times began printing the Pentagon Papers - and won in the Supreme Court when the Government tried to stop publication.

title: Silver
description: To the Business Editor: Two technical points in the article ''The Picture on Silver'' (May 24) bear correction. In the description of ''silverless film,'' the article says that more of the silver is removed and replaced by dyes in the processing and more is available for commercial recovery.

title: After 17 Years,; A Share of Glory
description: With vindication, it's better late than never, even if it comes after a protracted battle, as it did for Dr. John C. Saunders.

title: ANOTHER BARRERA IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: A folder of newspaper and magazine clippings in the press office of the New York Racing Association carries a parenthetical note after the name of Luis Barrera.

title: Chicago Transit; Nears a Dead End
description: With four suburban bus lines already shut down, three commuter rail lines on the brink and the Chicago Transit Authority due to run out of money by mid-June, political leaders in Illinois exhausted themselves and public patience last week in haggling over how to raise new money to save the nation's second largest public transit system.

description: Moscow's only used-car market is a seller's dream 3 Syrian press wants Habib to take different approach 3 Around the World 4 A Bangladesh farmer worries about rain, not politics 5 Japanese leftists continue pro- tests against U.S. carrier 6 Argentina signs economic aid ac- cord with El Salvador 7 Ghana's President appeals for economic help from U.S. 8 Indonesia opens airfield in remote Natuna Islands 10 World refugee total put at 12.6 mil- lion people 12 Unicef, going against U.N. trend, plans big increase in budget 13 West Germany's 1981 defense budget below NATO guidelines 15 House panel told Cuba may plan a war of radio signals with U.S. 16 New Franglais dictionary has the French in a tizzy again 19 Government/Politics Substantial cuts made in Medi- care by Congressional panels 22 Widespread kickbacks are investi- gated in Oklahoma and Texas 29 Experiment in ''packaging'' com- munity help called a success 31 Two mental health centers in Phidelphia face fiscal crisis 33 A national moratorium on co-op conversion is proposed 37 Bronx insurgent Democrats split on barring Simon renomination 42 More stress in economy is pre- dicted for Northeast 42 PUERTO RICAN DAY PARADE The Puerto Rican Day Parade will begin today at noon. title: Exit Lefever,; With a Nudge
description: Confirmation of Ernest W. Lefever as Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights would have been ''an unfortunate symbol and signal do the rest of the world,'' Charles H. Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said last week. Most of his fellow Republicans and all the committee's Democrats evidently agreed and voted against Mr. Lefever, who thereupon asked that his name be withdrawn.

title: PALM BEACH SALES ENRICH THE RICH
description: Not even ''millions'' could lure him back to New York and city living, he says. Here his usual business dress is a pink cotton shirt with epaulets and rolled-up sleeves, khaki trousers and tasseled Belgian loafers. He wears no socks, and his face and body are bronzed by the sun.

title: AT HOME
description: FIVE years ago, fairly new to suburban life and full of happy ignorance, my husband and I joined the ranks of Little League parents. All we thought we had to do to successfully fulfill our new roles was to attend every game armed with good cheer and throat lozenges. We were wrong.

title: U.S. Trimaran Leads Start Of England-Newport Race
description: Bonofacio, an American trimaran, led the fleet away from the line at the start of the 3,000-mile, doublehanded trans-Atlantic race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, R. I., today.

title: USING THE SUN TO CUT THE COST OF LIVING
description: PRINCETON PROSPECTIVE homeowners now have standing proof that a properly designed three-bedroom house can be heated and cooled for comfortable living in New Jersey at a cost of less than $100 a year.

title: ROCKEFELLER AS VILLAIN
description: CRISIS IN THE MAKING The Political Economy of New York State Since 1945. By Peter D. McClelland and Alan L. Magdovitz. 522 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $24.95.

title: DRIVE EXPECTED; Military Analysis
description: Iraq has reportedly assembled a large tank-backed force for a final push to take the Iranian oil refinery center of Abadan, which its troops have held under siege since shortly after the war began in September. American and British military analysts say they believe such a drive could begin in the next few weeks. British sources put the size of the Iraqi force at 60,000 men and 1,000 tanks. These figures, analysts say, may be inflated, but they report signs that Baghdad is stressing that Abadan must be taken.

title: Westchester Housing; BLOCK WATCHERS CUT CRIME
description: HOMEOWNERS may be victimized, if they are not careful, by burglars this summer, when lush foliage conceals doors and windows and families are vacationing.

title: Fighting Them; On the Beaches
description: New Jersey may be blessed with miles of beautiful beach, but according to Stanley C. Van Ness, the state public advocate, it is cursed with property owners who refuse to let anyone else on it. Last week, Mr. Van Ness suffered a setback in his long fight to open beaches along the Jersey shore.

title: Virginia G.O.P. Picks Candidate To Oppose Robb for Governor
description: Virginia Republicans nominated state Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman to run against the Democratic candidate for Governor, Lieut. Gov. Charles S. Robb, in the November general election.

title: HERE COME THE RIVER RAFTS
description: BELVIDERE IF EVERYTHING goes off on schedule, 65 rafts of assorted shapes and sizes will splash into the water today at Smithfield Beach, Pa., five miles north of the Delaware Water Gap.

title: STATE BUDGET PAINFUL FOR CITIES
description: IN city and town halls across Connecticut, early warning systems are detecting signs that a new and more contentious relationship is developing between the state and local governments.

title: No Headline
description: Regarding Hugh Southern's statement that the TKTS booth is used by a ''strictly under-30 crowd,'' all I can say is, that's the nicest thing anyone has said to me all year: I use it all the time, and I turned 50 last December. HARRY L. LICHTENBAUM, Wethersfield, Conn.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Music:Debuts in Review; Donald Gren, Pianist, Performs Berg and Liszt
description: Although it seemed at first as if Donald Gren was approaching the piano with a subtle musicianship in his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night, it soon became clear that his careful shapings of long phrases were marred by curiously wayward senses of rhythm, tempo and drama. Mr. Gren, who recently completed his graduate education at the University of Iowa, has an obvious love for rich piano sonority - but it was used to no determined end.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: BOWERY MEN REBUILD LIFE AND A BUILDING
description: Around the corner from the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Hanson Street in the Fort Greene section stands an apartment building whose terraced penthouses look out over the Atlantic Ocean, the Verrazano Bridge, the World Trade Towers and verdant Fort Greene Park. Should the building go co-op this fall - a question that stirs emotion - its penthouses and 101 other apartments will sell for $250 each.

title: Carey's Labor Nominee Pledges Help to Workers
description: Lillian Roberts, Governor Carey's nominee to head the State Labor Department, pledged yesterday that she would act to improve conditions for workers and the unemployed in New York.

title: THE ROCKET EXPLOSION AND OTHER NONEVENTS
description: RED STAR IN ORBIT By James E. Oberg. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: MANHATTAN'S STRENGTH
description: Although New York City's economic health appears to be reviving, the recovery is overwhelmingly dominated by Manhattan. A recent analysis by Rona B. Stein, a regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, shows that activity remains low in the city's four other boroughs.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE, 7, 1981
description: International Britain will cut its oil prices by $2 a barrel, enhancing the prospect of a substantial reduction in world oil prices. The move by one of the major producers of oil from the North Sea will lower the official price to $37.25 a barrel and add to the already intense pressure being felt among other exporters to reduce their prices. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: RICCI VACATES TOP SCHOOL POST
description: TRENTON P. Paul Ricci, who has presided over far-reaching and controversial changes in state education since 1978, announced last week that he would not seek nomination for another term as president of the State Board of Education.

title: 'PAY TO PLAY' SPLITS HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIALS AND SPORTS COACHES
description: WILTON IN recent years, about 90 boys have turned out for spring football practice at Wilton High School. But since this year's spring drills began May 26, only about half that number have reported, even though Wilton has had winnning teams for the last seven years, including a state championship team in 1978.

title: NYET IS A DANGEROUS RUSSIAN WORD
description: REFUSENIK Trapped in the Soviet Union. By Mark Ya. Azbel. Edited by Grace Pierce Forbes. Illustrated. 513 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: HEARTBREAK AND BUDGET CUTTING FOR LIBERALS IN THE HOUSE
description: ''We were forced to be executioners, with a gun pointed to our heads, with the knowledge that if we didn't do it, somebody else would do it more savagely,'' said Representative Ted Weiss, Democrat of Manhattan.

title: Victoria Ann Robinson Married
description: Victoria Ann Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Robinson of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to Kenneth Robert Watterworth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watterworth of Waterbury, Conn. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony in the Second Congregational Church.

title: IN BERLIN, CULTURAL ACTIVITIES WITH A PRUSSIAN ACCENT
description: Visitors to West Berlin this year should not be surprised to find placards and bumper stickers proudly declaring ''Ich bin Preusser'' - ''I am a Prussian.'' Germans are in the midst of a year-long reassessment of their Prussian heritage, and many events this summer and fall will have a strong Prussian accent.

title: LOOKING FOR ROOTS
description: GENERATION WITHOUT MEMORY A Jewish Journey in Christian America. By Anne Roiphe. 221 pp. New York: The Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $11.95. By ELI N.EVANS

title: Bopping Down To the Races
description: William Safire goes to great lengths to trace the origins of ''bop'' as a verb (''Just Bopping Along,'' On Language, by William Safire, May 10).

title: MODERN SETTINGS
description: FROG SALAD By Sally George. 210 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $10.95 IN SHELLY'S LEG By Sara Vogan. 248 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95

title: Stage View; PERFORMANCES THAT LINGER IN THE MIND
description: There comes a subtle moment - so subtle and so unpredictable that half the time you miss it - when a performer passes over from being a half-unidentified hireling to a defiant, unbudgeable presence, part-owner of the stage he stands on. As I say, no one ever knows quite when, or if, it's going to happen, least of all the performer himself. Every actor, every actress, knows that he or she may slave for a lifetime and never get beyond the ranks of the merely employable, though regularly employed. And every actor, every actress, is still in the business on the off-chance that the magic moment will turn up after all.

title: Iran's Politics Is a; Long Instant Replay
description: Iran's ruling Islamic Republicans no longer have a captive America to harangue, but they still have President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. The question last week was for how long.

title: Indiana Files Census-Count Suit Challenging Loss of House Seat
description: The State of Indiana filed suit in Federal court today in an effort to regain a Congressional seat it lost as a result of the 1980 census.

title: Debra Goodman, Editor, Bride of Dr. Charles Glassman
description: Debra Susan Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Goodman of Harrison, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Charles Norman Glassman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Glassman of Scarsdale and South Salem, N.Y. Rabbi John Haddon performed the ceremony at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: TRUE TALES OF CONSULTING FOR THE FEDS
description: In its first hours in office, the Reagan Administration ordered Federal agencies to cut their expenditures for outside consultants by 5 percent. The order was in part a reaction to charges, many of them substantiated, of widespread waste and abuse in Federal consulting.

title: Jersey G.I. Charged With Murder In Slaying of 4 Soldiers in Korea
description: A New Jersey soldier has been charged with murder for turning his M-16 rifle on five fellow G.I.'s, killing four of them and injuring the fifth at a rifle range in South Korea, military officials said today.

title:
Speaking Personally;
FORGET THE FOOD FOR THOUGHT--LET'S EAT!
description: CAN you put away a pint of Haagen-Dazs faster than a speeding bullet? Are you able to leap into bakeries in a single bound? When passersby notice you popping pistachios, do they exclaim, ''Look! It's Supernosher!''?

title: FUNDS ARE PACKAGED TO AID COMMUNITIES
description: What began as an experiment in New York, packaging funds from corporations and philanthropies for selected South Bronx self-help groups, has spread across the country, astonishing its most ardent sponsors.

title: PRINCETON: THORNS AMONG THE IVY
description: PRINCETON WHEN the Class of 1981 gathers Tuesday on the campus of Princeton University, 80 black students (42 of them women) will receive bachelor's degrees, as will 48 white Hispanic students, 39 Asians or Pacific islanders and three American Indians.

title: William Stewart Daley Weds Sally Anne Peters
description: Sally Anne Peters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Johnson Peters of East Williston, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Community Church to William Stewart Daley, son of Robert Stewart Daley and Mrs. L. Vogt Daley of Worcester, Mass. The Rev. Paul Sandin and the Rev. John Davis performed the ceremony.

title: HOW OLD MOVIE SERIALS INSPIRED LUCAS AND
description: SPIELBERG By JANET MASLIN

title: Food; FANCY FOODS ON EAST END
description: SOUTHAMPTON NEXT to each other on Jagger Lane in Southampton are two shops that just may prove indispensible when it comes to satisfying summer appetites. One, Le Chef, is thoroughly French, and the other, East End Quality Fruits, is committed to freshness.

title: SOUNDS OF MUSIC FROM OLD FOUNDRY
description: EAST HADDAM The rectangular brick building straddling Succor Brook bears little resemblance to its Victorian neighbors across Norwich Road. The road doesn't look much like New York City's Shubert Alley, either, but travelers along it these days are treated to the showbusiness sound of cleats tapping out Gershwin tunes.

title: CAPITAL GRANDE DAME WITH WHIM OF IRON
description: She is the last of the capital's grandes dames, ruling her domain with what one of her admirers, former Associate Justice Abe Fortas, calls ''a whim of iron.''

title: Title Rowing Postponed
description: Strong thunderstorm winds hit Onondaga Lake today, forcing a postponement until tomorrow of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship races.

title: VALLEY FORGE TO BROADWAY
description: MURFY'S MEN By Gerald Green. 332 pp. New York: Seaview Books. $12.95.

title: Connecticut Guide; 'EXHIBIT A'
description: Winston Churchill and Dwight D. Eisenhower found it relaxing and fulfilling. So do Louis Nizer, Henry Fonda and many other celebrated people who become absorbed in painting or sculpture as a means of creative expression and as a relief from the demands of their professions.

title: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S 19TH-CENTURY CAPITALISM
description: Future historians will be challenged to explain the Reagan phenomenon, especially why he has been so successful in winning support in Congress with the public.

title: COLLEGE ROLE GIVES MCGOVERN CHANCE TO KEEP POLITICAL VIEWS SHARP
description: ''I've had a love affair with college students for 30 years,'' says former Senator George McGovern, and the attraction seems to be mutual.

title: Practical Traveler; GETTING SATISFACTION WHEN YOU AND YOUR HOTEL DISAGREE
description: Melody Lukaszak is a ski buff. She and her husband, Phillip, live in Orland Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, so for their winter vacations they have a choice of two major ski regions that are almost equidistant from their home: the Rockies or New England. This year they and two friends, Jackie and Paul Dziubek, chose Killington, Vt., and sent a deposit of $100 a couple to reserve two rooms for the week of Feb. 22 to March 1 at the Grey Bonnet Inn there.

title: QUIET-SUNDAY TOWN
description: PROSPECT PARK ITEM: Sabino Losco was mowing his lawn here one recent morning when a police car pulled up and the officer gave Mr. Losco a warning. Put the mower away immediately, Mr. Loso was told, or pay a $25 fine.

title: R.A. Savage Fiance Of Leslie Bergman
description: The engagement of Leslie Ann Bergman to Robert Alan Savage has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Lewis Bergman of Westport, Conn., and Karl G. Bergman of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Elizabeth Costello, a Nurse, Married to Thomas Belthoff
description: At St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Oradell, N.J., yesterday, Elizabeth Mary Costello, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Costello, was married to Thomas Francis Belthoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Belthoff. Both families live in New Milford, N.J. The Rev. Jerome Hahn, assisted by the Rev. Robert Lozinski and the Rev. Paul Farber, performed the cermony.

title: BAD SMUT
description: GOODBYE, JANETTE By Harold Robbins. 382 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95. SIRENS By Eric Van Lustbader. 478 pp. New York: M. Evans & Co. $13.95. By PETER ANDREWS

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: MANY New Jerseyans may still be unaware that some of the country's most notable professional theaters are only a short drive from home. The state is attaining the prominence of a dramatic center by alternating the classics and revivals of well-established works with world or American premieres of plays and musicals.

title: Art; PHOTOGRAPHY: TWO FINE SHOWS
description: TRENTON AN OBSERVER of ''Jersey Evidence'' at the State Museum can easily feel like a gate-crasher at a family party. Five of the photographers involved - Benedict Fernandez, Brian Lav, Dennis Simonetti (and his wife, Naomi) and George Tice - are on the faculty of the New School for Social Research in New York City and one, William Abranowicz, was a student there. And, as Mr. Abranowicz explains in the catalogue, all the exhibitors, including the late Richard Bruggemann, have been friends for some time.

title:
CRITICS CHOICE;
DANCE
description: Miss Comfort has appeared with such experimentalists as David Gordon and Kenneth King, but her own work has none of their distancing irony and cerebration. Out of such homely experiences as pregnancy, deaf-signing and taking photographs, she creates vividly personal dances that welcome the viewer, too, into those experiences. Miss Comfort will perform a Danspace in St. Mark's Church starting Thursday.

title: The Lively Arts; ANOTHER FOR WILSON'S TALLY
description: ''CAN Lanford Wilson Score on Broadway?'' was a headline in The New York Times last year when Mr. Wilson's ''Talley's Folly'' was uprooted from its nonprofit Off Broadway birthplace and thrust into the commercial mainstream. Artistically, the answer was resoundingly affirmative. The play won the Critics Circle Award and the Pulitzer Prize - but not the Tony for which it was nominated.

title: PROTECT THE ENDANGERED UMPIRE
description: TOLERANCE. It's your hallmark. You're a major league umpire. It's bred into you and then refined and developed through the many years you spent in the minor leagues.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Tough Manana for Mexico

title: INDIANS 5, MARINERS 3 Seattle (AP) - Mike Hargrove singled home the to-ahead run in a three-run ninth inning for Cleveland.
description: Bert Blyleven (7-3) was the winner with ninth-inning relief help from Mike Stanton, while the reliever Shan Rawley (0-3) took the loss.

title: 500,000 CHOICES: EATING YOUR WAY AROUND TOKYO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- RICHARD HALLORAN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By RICHARD HALLORAN

title: Donna Bascom Wed to Paul A. Biddelman
description: Donna L. Bascom and Paul A. Biddelman were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York. The bridegroom's brother, Cantor Mark J. Biddelman, performed the ceremony.

title: CHINAGLIA WIELDING POWER OVER COSMOS
description: Giorgio Chinaglia is becoming more involved in all facets of the Cosmos -both on the field and in the front office. He has always had the reputation as the only ''playing general manager'' but events this season show that he is more than that.

title: No Headline
description: PEETE, VALENTINE LEADING

title: About Westchester
description: ARMONK AROUND the turn of the century, the Brundage blacksmith shop, located near what is now Route 22 here, was put on rollers and hauled by a team of oxen to property across the street from where it had originally stood. In the mid-1960's, the same shop - a 20-by-30-foot wooden structure - was dismantled piece-by-piece and shifted to the Silver Lake section of Harrison. Now it is about to be disassembled and reconstructed again, when it is removed from its present site and returned to this hamlet.

title: SKEWING AFFIRMATIVE ACTION'S PURPOSE
description: As a former Georgian, I am proud of my lengthy devotion to civil rights. I fought the racially motivated electoral system in Georgia for 14 years until the United States Supreme Court finally affirmed the principle of one man, one vote.

title: A SALUTE TO LOCAL IN STRATEGY OF 1781
description: MOUNT KISCO TWO hundred years ago, the French General Jean Baptiste Rochambeau, with 5,000 men, rested in this historic Westchester community for three days before moving south to join forces with George Washington's troops at what was then known as Philipsburg Manor.

title: FRENCH CROWN WON BY MISS MANDLIKOVA
description: Hana Mandlikova , the 19-year-old Czechoslovak who on Thursday became only the second player in almost eight years to beat Chris Evert Lloyd on clay, completed her march to the French Open tennis championship today by defeating Sylvia Hanika of West Germany, 6-2, 6-4, in the final.

title: Common Sense?
description: For right-thinking lawyers, ethical questions ought to be relatively easy to figure out. Or are they? What is the duty of a defense counsel whose client hands him a gun used in a crime? The not-so-apparent answer: turn it over to the prosecutor, lest the lawyer become party to obstruction of justice.

title: A NEW LOOK FOR THE LEGISLATURE
description: THE state's most expensive primary-election campaign, which ended Tuesday with the nomination of Thomas H. Kean of Livingston as the Republican candidate for Governor and Representative James J. Florio of Runnemede as the Democratic candidate, also forecasts dramatic changes in the ranks of the 120-member State Legislature next year.

title: Diana Gwynn Dent Is Married
description: Diana Gwynn Dent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Baily Dent of Spartanburg, S.C., was married here yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church to Theodore Alexander McGraw Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGraw of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Hays Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: SAGER-BACHARACH LOVE SONGS
description: Carole Bayer Sager, who will be appearing with Burt Bacharach at the Bottom Line tonight and tomorrow, is a phenomenally successful song lyricist who has parlayed that success into a recording career. ''Sometimes Late at Night'' (Boardwalk FW 37069), her third album in four years, is a collaboration with Mr. Bacharach who co-produced, co-wrote, and arranged most of the songs. The album, which took eight months to complete, is one of the most elaborate and expensive pop records ever made. In terms of the time and money spent, it is a major investment in Miss Sager's so-far unsuccessful recording career.

title: GYPSY MOTHS SHOCK FORECASTERS
description: MILLIONS of gypsy moth larvae have been stuffing themselves on the leaves of Long Island oak trees for the last three weeks, and now the hungry army has decided to continue its feast with a second course of maple or rhododendron foliage, or even plain grass.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: A GROWING COMPANY IS TETHERED BY ITS IMAGE
description: HARTFORD FROM a newly refurbished plant on the fringes of Hartford's downtown business district, two entrepreneurs are trying to make a success of their small business, Apex Publishing Printing Corporation. In so doing, Ron Dunson, president, and Silas Shannon Jr., vice president, confront not only the problems common to all small businesses, but also the special problems of minority enterprises, for both co-owners are black.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: COMMUTERS who ride the buses in Hartford, New Haven and Stamford may have cheered in February when a judge ordered the repeal of a March 1980 increase in fares, but most have not asked for the refunds that are due them. The refund period has been extended, but that may not solve the problem.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm tired and I'm sad, but I'm not bitter. But I got a drubbing that few other public servants ever got at this low level and largely without justification.'' - Ernest W. Lefever, on the battle that led him to withdraw as the nominee for Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights. (14:1.)

title: Mamie Tam Is Married To Michael C. Chen
description: Mamie Tam, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kwong Tai Tam of New York, was married yesterday to Michael C. Chen, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Y.S. Chen of Harrington Park, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer by the Very Rev. Paul A. Walsh.

title: HAITIAN REFUGEES IN MIAMI ARE WARNED OF IMMIGRATION ARREST THREAT
description: Community agency workers took to the streets with bullhorns here yesterday to warn Haitian refugees that the Immigration and Naturalization Service had begun arresting new arrivals who apply for work authorization papers.

title: CON ED OFFERS PLAN TO HELP CUSTOMERS BUDGET BILLS
description: A 12-month ''level billing'' plan is being offered by the Consolidated Edison Company to its residential electricity and gas customers throughout New York City and Westchester County.

title: Three Marines on Okinawa Held In the Fatal Stabbing of Another
description: Three United States Marines have been charged with homicide in the death of a Marine Corps corporal who was stabbed to death in Okinawa this week, a Marine Corps spokesman said today.

title:
Style;
COLLECTORS GETTING A FEEL FOR TEXTILES
description: SOUTHAMPTON DAILY familiarity with textiles - on our bodies, over our tables, under our feet - has often bred disregard. In recent years, however, almost every genre of textile has become collectible, valued for both its workmanship and design. This interest has developed because of a variety of factors, among which is the recognition that architects have given fiber by using large-scale hangings to humanize cold, towering high-rise structures.

title: Blythe Jones Bride Of James E. Lyons
description: At the Shadyside Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh yesterday, Blythe Mitchell Jones, a staff consultant with International Energy Associates Ltd. in Washington, was married to James Edward Lyons of Alexandria, Va., managing editor of the University Press of America. The Rev. Jeffrey Cave performed the ceremony.

title: Passaic River Dumping Admitted
description: The owner of a Kearny chemical company pleaded guilty today to Federal pollution charges involving discharges of industrial wastes into the Passaic River in 1977. The owner, Charles Hauck, 63 years old, of Spring Lake, faces up to three years in jail and a $75,000 fine. He is the president of Syncon Resins Inc., which produces synthetic resins used to manufacture paint.

title: JORDAN REMAINS ALOOF
description: JERSEY CITY DESPITE all the frenetic campaigning in the race for Mayor of this intensely political city, one prominent local resident has kept aloof from the fray.

title: Jill L. Porvancher Married in Jersey To John C. Rau 3d
description: Jill Laurie Porvancher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Porvancher of Saddle River, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to John Charles Rau 3d, son of Margaret Rau of New York and Bellevue, Iowa, and the late John Rau 2d. The ceremony was performed at the Old Stone Dutch Reformed Church in Upper Saddle River, N.J. by the Rev. Robert Minick.

title: YESHIVA CAREER LEADS TO A SHOT AT THE PROS
description: NOT everyone gets to be the topic of a question in The New York Times at the age of 22, but then again, not every athlete's story is as unusual as mine. My name was made as Yeshiva University's first National Basketball Association draftee.

title: Britain's Laborites:; A House Subdivided
description: A series of largely pessimistic projections last week for the success of Margaret Thatcher's tight economic policies should have given Britain's opposition Labor Party plenty of political ammunition. But party members were too busy turning the cudgels on each other to take advantage.

title: MITCHELL BUTLER SALES URGED BY CAREY AT MARKET VALUE
description: For the first time since the creation of Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing, Governor Carey has proposed legislation to let owners sell the apartments at market value, instead of the original low purchase price.

title: ASTROS DEFEAT METS, 6-2
description: Houston, June 6 - Pat Zachry, who has three of the four complete games by the Mets' pitching staff, was battered by the Houston Astros tonight in the Astrodome. The Astros, beating the Mets for the second consecutive night, made 12 hits, including Jose Cruz's ninth home run of the year, to score a 6-2 victory.

title: BRITAIN TO CUT PRICE OF OIL, RAISING HOPE OF WORLD REDUCTION
description: Britain, a major producer of oil from the North Sea, has agreed to cut prices by $2 a barrel, enhancing the prospect of a substantial downward move in world oil prices.

title: By Sports of The Times; Duran Wants to Fight
description: UP in the ring, the chunky boxer in the white T-shirt, blue sweat pants and the white boxing shoes was peering out from beneath a big, brown-leather headgear at the sparring partner across from him. Every so often he would batter the sparring partner and then step back to nudge the headgear up out of the sweat that had dripped into his eyes. In the steamy, scroungy New Garden Gym on West 30th Street, dozens of people were gazing up at the boxer in the ring more in curiosity than admiration when a newcomer strolled in.

title: No Headline
description: The Handgun Debate I most thoroughly enjoyed Mike Norman's article on gun control (''The American Duel Over Guns,'' May 3). It has long been a mystery to me how any supposedly civilized person can be opposed to even the simplest limits on handguns.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMS OF 'EMPLOYABLE' ELDERLY
description: MEMBERS of the ''baby boom'' generation face a bleak future when they retire. Americans born in the late 1940's through the mid-1960's were warned of this recently in news reports that retirement at age 65 is now a receding goal and that 35-year-olds may need to work until age 70 for financial reasons. The reports, describing demographic patterns and economic trends, noted that ''most Americans must lower their expectations about the time and conditions of their retirement and the Government and private employers must begin planning now to cushion the blow.''

title: The Best Vital Sign:; Pope Goes Home
description: With a quip and a blessing for his 15 doctors and nurses, Pope John Paul II walked out of Rome's Gemelli Hospital last week and went home to the Vatican. ''You think you can boast that you have made a new person,'' he told physicians, ''but I am still the same rascal I have always been.''

title: GHANA'S LEADER ASKS U.S. AID FOR AILING ECONOMY
description: President Hilla Limann has appealed to the United States to help make Ghana ''a model and a showcase of pluralistic democracy.''

title: No Headline
description: ,; Seaver Gains His 251st Victory

title: 50 Injured in Bangkok Bombings
description: Three bombs exploded almost simultaneously in busy shopping centers here today, injuring more than 50 people, the police said. Five of the injured were reported in serious condition. It was not immediately known who was responsible.

title: Piggott Rides Blue Wind To Victory in Oaks Stakes
description: Lester Piggott won his fifth Oaks Stakes and 25th classic race today when the American-owned Blue Wind won the mile-and-a-half fillies classic.

title: Lori Beth Halpern Becomes a Bride
description: Lori Beth Halpern and Charles Michael Macaluso were married yesterday at the Players Club. Kings County Criminal Court Judge Louis R. Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: Leisure; SOME FLOWERS CAN BE DRIED AND KEPT INDOORS INDEFINITELY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lynda D. Gutowski is a freelance writer. By LYNDA D. GUTOWSKI

title: Between Transit Chaos and a $1 Fare
description: New York's transit riders have another date with destiny on July 1. Law as well as prudence require the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to start its fiscal year with a balanced budget, although it is now $500 million in the red. If state and city subsidies can't shrink the deficit, fares would have to leap from 60 to 95 cents, with proportionate increases on commuter trains. Even that extraordinary increase would do little for the reliability and comfort of transit. Still other revenues are needed to buy new cars and buses and to rebuild the deteriorating system.

title: Lighting Up Broadway
description: Your excellent cover photograph says it all for us: Mickey Rooney in ''Sugar Babies,'' Jane Seymour in ''Amadeus'' and Gregory Hines in ''Sophisticated Ladies'' (''The Box Office Boom,'' by Margaret Croyden, May 10). These actors and their shows have ''lured television viewers away from the home screens'' and ''Broadway now entertains more than 200,000 weekly.'' What we want and what Broadway gives us in fullest measure is what Robert Whitehead calls ''show biz.'' ARISTIDES GEORGE LAZARUS, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Prison Riots Cost at $5 Million
description: Riots that broke out in three Michigan prisons last month caused at least $5 million in damages, state officials estimate. Worst hit was the Michigan Reformatory at Ionia, parts of which are more than 100 years old, which sustained about $2.23 million in damage. Also damaged were the State Prison of Southern Michigan in Jackson and the state's maximum security prison in Marquette.

title: June 7, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE CHINESE OF AMERICA. By Jack Chen. 13 CORPORATE CONTROL, CORPORATE POWER: A Twentieth Century Fund Study. By Edward S. Herman. 11 CRISIS IN THE MAKING: The Political Economy of New York State Since 1945.

title: Artist Disagrees With Review
description: In her review ''Film-Video Success at the Thorpe'' (May 17) Vivien Raynor attempts to deal with my video work ''Spring 1981.'' I would like to refer to a specific sentence in this review, which describes part of my installation: ''Superimposed on these still images are, respectively, a triangle and a rectangle, also green.''

title: Hope of Better Life; Often Ends in Death
description: If there is safety in numbers, the Cubans who fled to Florida in last year's ''freedom flotilla'' should be fairly secure. Between 80,000 and 105,000 settled in Dade County at the edges of the area's established Cuban community, creating their own ethnic home away from home where neither language nor customs render them strangers.

title: TV View; WHEN 'BASED ON' LOSES TOUCH WITH REALITY
description: Fact versus fiction: The debate has been revived with an almost shattering urgency in the wake of a Pulitzer Prize being withdrawn from a Washington Post reporter who conceded that portions of her story about an 8-year-old drug addict were not completely factual. Not long after, a New York Daily News writer was dismissed for quoting nonexistent persons in dispatches written from Northern Ireland. The techniques of the ''new journalism,'' especially the creation of composite characters, are being scrutinized with renewed concern. Needless to say, the issues are hardly limited to the print press.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
HOUSING THAT CATERS TO THE 'PRE-RETIRED'
description: THE 1960's certainly had their ''youth market.'' You remember the saying, ''Don't Trust Anyone Over 30''? You remember how seriously Madison Avenue treated the post-World War II baby boom, acting as though anyone over 25 simply marched off the side of a cliff, never to be heard from again?

title: Notes on the U.N.
description: James Grant, the chief of the United Nations Children's Fund, wants to enlarge his staff by 384 over the next two years. He would take on three new $85,864-a-year assistant secretary generals, increase his payroll by $26.8 million and expand the agency's 1,872 jobs by slightly more than 20 percent.

title: THE TROUBLED ALLIANCE
description: The Economist, which is not a frivolous publication, said this week: ''The relationship between Western Europe and North America is in the early stages of what could be a terminal illness. The alliance has been in trouble plenty of times before, but this time is the worst yet.''

title: Notes; ADVENTURES, EXPEDITIONS AND OUTINGS IN FARAWAY PLACES
description: If you have a taste for the exotic and the faraway, you will find no lack of offerings this year. Among them are cruises to the Amazon, expeditions to Australia's Great Barrier Reef and a birding tour of Iceland.

title: Valerie Sarantos Is Bride of James Cruice Jr.
description: Valerie Ann Sarantos, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S.R. Sarantos of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday to James Seth Hopkins Cruice Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cruice of Greenville, Del., and Hobe Sound, Fla. The Rev. Albert M. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain..

title: Nancy Jane Goldner a Bride
description: At St. Therese's Roman Catholic Church in Cresskill, N.J., yesterday, Nancy Jane Goldner, diabetes nurse educator at the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital, was married to George Matthew Zoebelein, an auditor with the international accounting firm of Main Hurdman & Cranstoun in New York.

title: Cardinals 11, Padres 1
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Keith Hernandez walloped a grand slam, Sixto Lezcano drove in two runs with a pair of singles and John Martin, a rookie, pitched a seven-hitter in the St. Louis rout.

title: STATE RAISES ITS FEE ON VARIOUS LICENSES
description: Fees for marriage licenses, birth certificates, death certificates and a host of other state services have been increased by the State Legislature.

title: AT HOME
description: FIVE years ago, my husband and I, fairly new to suburban life and full of happy ignorance, joined the ranks of Little League parents. We were of the opinion that, to fulfill our new roles successfully, all we had to do was to attend every game armed with good cheer and throat lozenges.

title: LEFEVER SAYS CRITICS TWISTED HIS RECORD
description: Contending that he had been the victim of ''grotesque caricature'' aimed as much at President Reagan as himself, Ernest W. Lefever said today that his rejection by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee ''might have been quite different'' had the Republican chairman, Senator Charles H. Percy, ''behaved differently.''

title: Another View On Tuition Tax Credits
description: As one who has taught on every level of the school system as well as in college and Army instructor training programs, I may be able to add some perspective to the controversy over tuition tax credits.

title: KILLING FOR HORNS IS A CONCERN
description: The horns of the rhinoceros have always been sought, but the various species of rhino, which have been relentlessly pursued by poachers, are no longer numerous. Hence the interest in the horns of elk, deer and moose.

title: Around the Nation;
description: A jury has awarded $800,000 in damages to the survivors of three persons whose bodies were frozen because the Cryonics Society of California, which deep-froze dead persons for future revival, allowed the bodies to thaw.

title: WHEN THEY DANCE, THE ISLAND HAS A ROLE
description: ''MAY, what are you looking for?'' called a young member of the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company to the tall, willowy figure in black leotard, tights and long nylon practice skirt who was sliding through boxes and bags in her Lafayette Place loft studio last week. After more than 40 years in the dance world, the choreographer, whose company opens a five-day season at the Public Theater in New York next Wednesday through June 15, seemed as preoccupied and anxious as any newcomer to the trials of last-minute preperformance problems.

title: OSSINING PRISON LINGERING SOURCE OF DISCONTENT
description: OSSINING IN 1825, inmates from New York's first state prison were barged down the Hudson River from Auburn to begin work on their new home here. They quarried local limestone and built on the edge of the river the first cell block for what was to become the state's second prison.

title: Bangungut
description: Long before there was a Stephen King or a William Blatty or a string of movies shot in the dark and celebrating knives, there was an Anglo-Irish writer named Sheridan LeFanu. LeFanu lived in Dublin in the mid-19th century and wrote novels like ''Uncle Silas'' -about a girl who didn't know whether her enemies were in her home or in her head.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN YOUNG ADULTS 'BOOMERANG' HOME
description: WITH all due respect to Thomas Wolfe, young people today may have to go home again - because they can't afford to live anywhere else. Launched from the nest several years ago, the last of the baby boom are now flocking back home, following graduation from college or graduate school or a too-costly stint of living on their own.

title: DAM OWNERS HEAR GOOD AND BAD NEWS
description: NEWARK OWNERS of small dams sat in a crowded ballroom at the Hilton Gateway here last Wednesday, listening to descriptions of the risks and promises of committing their money to hydroelectric facilities.

title:
BEACHES GEARED FOR RECORD;
CROWDS
description: IN the wake of recent weekends on which people flocked to Long Island beaches in record numbers, recreation and park personnel are gearing to handle an overflow of beachgoers this summer. The anticipated surge in attendance is attributed to the price of gasoline and the effect of tight money on consumers' pocketbooks.

title:
Gardening;
WHY ROSES NEED EXTRA CARE THIS YEAR
description: ATRIP to California in early spring can be a mind-boggling expererince when it comes to the vast array of flowers in bloom. Having lived there while studying horticulture, I was well aware of the great diversity of plants, yet I was unprepared for the mass of colorful flowers on display in the San Francisco area early last month. I had somehow forgotten the hillsides covered with blooming succulents, the roadsides planted to groundcovers flowering in bold lavender and reds and the geraniums as large as rhododendrons.

title: BRONX INSURGENT DEMOCRATS SPLIT ON BARRING SIMON RENOMINATION
description: A combined effort by Hispanic and so-called reform Democrats to challenge the renomination of Stanley Simon, the Bronx Borough President, is foundering on charges of ''deals''and ''sellouts '' in the insurgent ranks.

title:
Gardening;
WHY ROSES NEED EXTRA CARE THIS YEAR
description: ATRIP to California in early spring can be a mind-boggling expererince when it comes to the vast array of flowers in bloom. Having lived there while studying horticulture, I was well aware of the great diversity of plants, yet I was unprepared for the mass of colorful flowers on display in the San Francisco area early last month. I had somehow forgotten the hillsides covered with blooming succulents, the roadsides planted to groundcovers flowering in bold lavender and reds and the geraniums as large as rhododendrons.

title: FOR DANIEL O'HERN, A RAISE IN PAY, TOO
description: TRENTON WHEN Daniel Joseph O'Hern was named Commissioner of the state's Department of Environmental Protection in 1978, his children, the story goes, were astonished to learn that he was taking a big pay cut from what he might have earned in private law practice.

title: LITTLE LEAGUE OUSTER LINKED TO SEX BIAS
description: TWO women who were the first to manage a Little League team in the Glenwood Landing-Glen Head division on the Island are calling their dismissal ''foul ball.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA AFTER REVOLUTION
description: JULY'S PEOPLE By Nadine Gordimer. 160 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.95.

title: Laura H. Cotton Is Married To Benjamin Bloom at Pierre
description: Lauren H. Cotton, daughter of State Supreme Court Justice Wallace R. Cotton and Mrs. Cotton of New York, was married last evening to Benjamin Bloom, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Bloom of Kings Park, L.I. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: FOR WHARTON A CAR, FOR JAMES A GO-CART
description: THE following selections have been taken from ''The Oxford Book of American Literary Anecdotes,'' edited by Donald Hall, to be published by Oxford University Press next September. The introductory material to the anecdotes was written by Mr. Hall. --------------------------------------------------------------------- FRANK HARRIS 1856-1931

title: Reading and Writing; THROUGH FOREIGN EYES
description: A few weeks ago, the New York Institute for the Humanities celebrated the 150th anniversary of Alexis de Tocqueville's arrival in New York City. As everyone knows, he went back to France and wrote ''Democracy in America,'' which told us more about ourselves than most of our own writers did. Reading his book is like having the Grand Tour come to us. To be interpreted by authors from other countries is one of the luxuries of living in the United States.

title: Second Chance on Human Rights
description: Ernest Lefever was wise to withdraw as the Administration's nominee to head the human rights office in the State Department. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee roundly rejected the appointment, by a vote of 13 to 4. And despite some ambiguity, the vote expressed widespread doubt not just about Mr. Lefever but also about the Administration's purblind view of human rights.

title: PERENNIAL FEAR
description: In recent months I have begun to suffer old bouts of deja vu - small seizures of that apprehension I felt on Fifth Avenue almost exactly 30 years ago. It is not yet alarm I feel, by any means; it is another indefinable uneasy sensation which I last felt in the mid-60's, when our vanguard of troops in Vietnam - known by their ludicrous euphemism, ''advisers'' - began to number in the hundreds, then the thousands.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of a League/ISCM concert published last Sunday incorrectly identified the pianist in Stockhausen's ''Kontakte.'' He was Eric Ewazen.

title: Caroline Franklin, Writer for Teen-Agers, Wed to Dean Berry, Harvard Law Student
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls yesterday, Caroline Noel Franklin and Dean Caldwell Berry, who were graduated magna cum laude with the class of '79 from Harvard College, were married by the Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church.

title: J.F. McDermid And Miss Byrd Wed in South
description: The marriage of Westwood Beverley Byrd, an account executive with Wheat First Securities in Washington, to John Fairbanks McDermid, general counsel for International Business-Government Counselors Inc., took place yesterday in Millwood, Va. The Rev. E. Guthrie Brown performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Eloise Winter Nelson Married
description: Eloise Winter Nelson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Winter Nelson of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday in the First Congregational Church to Henry William Streeter 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Streeter Jr. of Elmira, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Samuel W. Fogal performed the ceremony.

title: Audrey Owens Coxe a Bride
description: Audrey Owens Coxe, daughter of Eckley B. Coxe 4th of New York, and Mrs. Charles Eugene Kew of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Lawrence Hayden Cadwallader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Cadwallader, also of Greenwich. The Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich.

title: Mother Is Acquitted of Murder
description: A mother who contended that she cut the heart from her 4-year-old daughter to save herself and the world from the ''demons'' that she said possessed the child has been found not guilty of murder on the ground of insanity. Jurors said they took three votes yesterday to determine that Patricia Ann Frazier was not responsible for her actions in February 1980, when she killed her child. State District Judge Keith Nelson ordered her held for a hearing Monday to determine whether she should be committed to a mental institution.

title: ICH BIN EIN HERRENVOLKER
description: Sunday Observer/By Russell Baker

title: WILLIAM BORDERS
description: If the population of the entire world were squeezed into the continental United States, that land would be about as densely populated as Bangladesh is now.

title: Westchester Guide; CARAMOOR AND MOZART
description: Caramoor opens its 36th season June 27 with an evening of Mozart featuring the pianist Misha Dichter and the Caramoor Festival Orchestra under the direction of James Conlon.

title: QUINTERO TAKES ON AN EARLY O'NEILL
description: ''It's a flawed play. It is purple-hued. It's crude. But it is shining in its relentless honesty.'' Jose Quintero shifts his long, lean frame, flung into a classroom chair, waving his arms expressively as he talks. It is a lazily hot Saturday afternoon and the rest of the building is nearly deserted, but down a dark flight of stairs two members of the tech crew are putting the finishing touches to the day's rehearsal.

title: Food; FOR RHUBARB LOVERS ONLY
description: A native of Asia long believed to be a palliative for stomach and lung disorders, rhubarb is foremost among love-it-or-hate-it foods.

title: Bronx Man, 28, Slays 3 In Broadway Apartment
description: A 28-year-old man shot his girlfriend and her two brothers to death and critically injured her mother yesterday in the family's upper Manhattan apartment, the police said.

title: 27 Food Establishments Fail Sanitary Inspection
description: New York City's Department of Health cited 27 food establishments for violations of the city's health code. After reinspections at establishments cited earlier, one was found to have corrected violations, two were reopened and one was closed.

title: AS MORE CALL 911, FEWER ARE HELPED
description: Calls for police help in New York City pour in at a peak rate of 800 an hour. But most of these calls to 911 - the Police Department's emergency telephone number - no longer result in the speedy dispatch of officers in a radio patrol car.

title: Theater; LEONARD'S 'A LIFE' PLAYS LONG WHARF
description: IF you saw ''Da,'' the play that brought Hugh Leonard success in America, you may remember the name Desmond Drumm, a secondary character in that play. ''A Life,'' which will be at the Long Wharf Theater through next Sunday, examines Drumm in close-up.

title: ALIEN WORKER PROGRAMS ARE EASIER TO START THAN CONTROL
description: WASHINGTON WHEN President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico arrives to confer with President Reagan this week, their agenda is likely to include discussion of a ''guest worker'' program that would legalize the flow of migrant labor through issuance of visas to at least some of the Mexicans who want jobs in this country.

title: SAVE THE SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM BY PHASING IT OUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: IN the midtown streets outside his fourth-floor window at 347 Madison Avenue, automobile traffic crawls as usual. But Charlie Stewart, the Hudson Division dispatcher, is not paying it any mind. His thoughts are on the traffic along 110 miles of railroad track running between Croton-on-Hudson and Albany.

title: 5 Teachers Dismissed in 1950's Ruled Eligible for Reinstatement
description: The father of the actor Alan Arkin, dismissed as a school teacher in the early 1950's for refusing to say whether he belonged to the Communist Party, should have been reinstated, a judge has ruled.

title: Film View; WHEN MOVIES TAKE PRIDE IN BEING SECOND RATE
description: In an era in which so many second-rate endeavors are celebrated in the mistaken notiion that they are first-rate, it's not surprising that there should be a comparatively small but intensely loyal public for a kind of movie that means to be as rotten as possible, that exemplifies a sort of weightless, all-embracing skepticism, and that attempts to neutralize criticism by being its own severest critic.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: THREE of New York City's leading universities have new leaders. John Brademas, the former majority whip in the House of Representatives, will become president of New York University July 1. Donna Shalala, a political scientist and former assistant secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, is winding up her first year as president of Hunter College and Michael I. Sovern, a labor relations specialist, is completing his first year at the helm of Columbia University.

title: RED TAPE CLOGS HYDRO POWER
description: GREAT MEADOWS JAMES KELSEY is one of a number of people who say that inevitably rising energy costs will some day make hydroelectric power a wise investment.

title: Congressmen; Draw the Line at; New 'Hit List'
description: The National Pro-Life Political Action Committee last week unlimbered its political guns for next year's Congressional elections - and promptly shot itself in the foot. Within hours after the group published a list of ''targets'' for defeat, four members of Congress on its advisory board, including two of the most outspoken Congressional opponents of abortion, resigned in protest.

title: Artists and Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine; A TOAST TO ALSATIANS
description: The men in tuxedos and the women in colorful gowns are assembling in the blacktopped parking lot in front of Chickotsky's Gourmet Delicatessen a few steps away from the Froman Dance Studio. They sip Champagne and white table wines, glance warily at the overcast sky above Fort Worth and wonder about tornadoes, for it is the season when giant twisters sometimes appear on the Texas horizon and lay waste to the countryside.

title: FESTIVE MOOD ON THE TRACK'S BIG DAY
description: Under threatening skies they came to relax and beat the odds. They came in cut-off jeans and custom tailored suits, in T-shirts and no shirts, in slacks and pedal pushers. And though the day was muggy, they bounced on the balls of their feet and screamed and groaned and whooped as Summing sprinted away in the stretch of the Belmont Stakes to deny Pleasant Colony the most coveted of equine accomplishments, the Triple Crown.

title: Eileen Anne Finn Is Wed
description: Eileen Anne Finn, a personnel manager for Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm, was married yesterday to William Robert Milne, a senior planning analyst with the American Express Company.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MILAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: Behind the Best Sellers; JOHN GARDNER
description: John Gardner wrote a best-selling spy novel in England some 20 years ago titled ''The Liquidator,'' and he has written 22 novels since, including ''The Nostradamus Traitor,'' ''The Werewolf Trace'' and ''The Dancing Dodo.'' Mr. Gardner made the best-seller list in this country for the first time two weeks ago, and if his name is still not familiar to American readers - except to those who might confuse him with the American writer of the same name - the hero of his ''License Renewed'' bears a name that is indeed well-known: James Bond. Yes, James Bond, 007, that bold, urbane creation of the late Ian Fleming. Fourteen years have elapsed since the last Bond book, and although the world's most famous spy has not aged a day in that time, the James Bond of the 1980's drinks moderately, smokes low-tar cigarettes and drives a fuel-efficient Saab 900 Turbo instead of a Bentley. (Bond only drove Aston Martins in the movies.)

title: H. Conrad Meyer 3d Weds Sarah Stevens
description: Sarah Kemmer Woodruff Stevens, daughter of Mrs. Charles W. Stevens of Fort Myers, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to H. Conrad Meyer 3d, son of Mr. Meyer Jr. of Harlesville, Pa., and Marian B. Meyer of Doylestown, Pa. The Rev. James W. Kennedy performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension.

title: WASTE DISPOSAL: MORE STATE REGULATION IS NEEDED
description: WHEN the subject of chemical or toxic wastes arises in the state, the image that springs to mind immediately is that of thousands of rusting barrels and drums strewn carelessly behind chain-link fences bordering the northern portions of the New Jersey Turnpike.
