title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: New Jerseyans
description: ''YOU'VE got to have a little ham in you to be a teacher,'' said Herman A. Estrin, explaining how he had enlivened a conference - and had a good time himself - with a demonstration of ''body language.''

title: DEBUTANTE BALLS COMING OUT ANEW
description: SOME consider the debutante ball a thing of the past; others insist that it is making a comeback. But in the county, it is a custom that has remained an important part of the social scene.

title: Susan C. Harvey Is Married To Mark D. Scanlon on L.I.
description: The marriage of Susan C. Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Harvey of Oyster Bay, L.I., to Mark D. Scanlon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald P. Scanlon of Syracuse, took place yesterday at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay.

title: Janet Wilkov Wed To T. N. Twomey
description: The marriage of Janet Louise Wilkov, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Wilkov of Stamford, Conn., to Thomas Nathan Twomey, son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Twomey of Aurora, Ky., formerly of Stamford, took place yesterday. Superior Court Judge Sidney Landau performed the ceremony at the Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn.

title: At Home
description: FIVE years ago, fairly new to suburban life and full of happy ignorance, my husband and I joined the ranks of Little League parents. All we thought we had to do to successfully fulfill our new roles was to attend every game armed with good cheer and throat lozenges. We were wrong.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Business Supplies At Two Locations
description: When an office-equipment concern in White Plains began business, it used the initials of the company' s three founders, NBB. It now calls itself National Business Brands because, the owners say, so many of the catalog's 22,000 items are widely advertised products.

title: No Headline
description: It seems to me that Robert Whitehead should let the numbers speak for themselves.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN GOLD BOOM HAS DIVERSE IMPLICATIONS
description: After a year in which it earned its most spectacular profits, South Africa's gold mining industry has reclaimed a position of dominance in the nation's economy and embarked on a multibillion dollar expansion program.

title:
Art;
A NEW LOOK AT STIEGLITZ'S ROLE
description: SOUTHAMPTON NOT long ago, most American art of the 1930's was regarded with indifference, if not downright disdain. Recently, however, as both the distance of time and the mists of nostalgia have softened our harsh perceptions of the Depression decade, scholarly inquiry and critical re-evaluation have encouraged us to see this misunderstood period in a new and more favorable light.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SOUVENIR DE FLORENCE' BY JOHN TARAS
description: A ballet festival in tribute to Tchaikovsky that omits his three complete ballet scores is a festival with a mind of its own, and this is indeed one of the most important aspects of the New York City Ballet's current Tchaikovsky Ballet Festival.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Robert Schubert, Violinist With Brooklyn Players
description: The violinist Robert Schubert, who made his debut Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, clearly has a pleasant and intelligent musical disposition. Its expression, though, was generally thwarted - by physical problems more than by musical misjudgment.

title: Training for The Presidency
description: In his article, ''A Test of the Man and the Presidency'' (April 26), Steven Weisman writes, ''Mr. Reagan's accomplishments seem all the more remarkable for having come from one of the most improbable figures ever to assume the Presidency - a one-time baseball announcer, B-movie actor and television pitchman, who has had to force the Establishment to take him seriously.''

title: A CHINESE GARDEN GROWS AT THE MET
description: A Chinese scholar's garden is not just a garden. More than a vista to delight the eye, it is a landscaped symphony of rocks, plants, pavilions, water and bridges orchestrated to vibrate with mystic symbolism.

title: Air Force Is Baffled
description: The case of Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke - accused late last month of making unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy in Washington - took yet another strange turn last week. It was disclosed that Lieutenant Cooke continued to serve as deputy commander of a Titan II nuclear missile crew for nearly five months after the Air Force first learned he had broken a regulation by contacting the embassy. Military spokesmen had no immediate explanation for the apparent lapse, all the more striking because the lieutenant is accused of handing classified information about the Titan system to Soviet diplomats.

title: Around the World; Manila Seizes Eight It Says Plotted Widespread Terror
description: The office of President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today that eight people had been arrested in what it said was a terrorist plot prepared by a fugitive opposition leader with aid from Libyan-based Moslem rebels.

title: Diane Corbin Is Married to Robert M. Moss
description: Diane Corbin and Robert M. Moss were married yesterday by Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Kolin.

title: Miss Ashley Wed Upstate
description: Charlotte Chandler Ashley and Dr. James Lincoln Clarke were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Cooperstown, N.Y. Canon George F. French, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Home Clinic; STEPS TO TAKE AGAINST BURGLARIES
description: FOR many homeowners, summer means vaction travel - leaving an unoccupied house vulnerable to burglary. In addition, summer is a time when many people spend days or evenings at parks, beaches or clubs - again leaving the house susceptible to a break-in.

title: SUMMING TAKES BELMONT AS PLEASANT COLONY IS THIRD
description: The prediction of Johnny Campo that Pleasant Colony would become the 12th winner of thoroughbred racing's Triple Crown was shattered yesterday as Summing scored a neck victory in the $284,300 Belmont Stakes.

title: THE SMITHSONIAN PUTS ITS SEAL ON COUNTRY MUSIC
description: In the booklet accompanying ''The Smithsonian Collection of Classic Country Music,'' an impressive eight-record boxed set that was released earlier this week by the Smithsonian Institution, the historian and country music scholar Bill Malone notes two ''strongly opposing impulses'' that have been a source of tension within country music since it began. He describes these impulses as ''the deification of home and the glorification of the wanderer,'' and he traces them back to the ''respectable'' Carter Family and the sometime-rambler and hobo Jimmie Rodgers, who made their first recordings during the first four days of August, 1927 and became country music's earliest stars.

title: Candice Marino Married To Brian Gregory Steller
description: Candice Lynn Marino and Brian Gregory Steller were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. The Rev. Frederick Hoesli, assisted by the Rev. Francis Hamill, performed the ceremony.

title: TROUBLES CONTINUE FOR L.I. ACCELERATOR
description: Budget cuts and development difficulties have so hampered construction of a machine designed to produce the world's most powerful subatomic collisions that a high-level review panel is considering radical changes in the project.

title: GOODBYE FOR NOW, ENERGY CRISIS
description: I was interested to read that the C.I.A. no longer stands by its projection of four years ago of an insufficiency of oil production in the Soviet Union relative to national demand.

title: Around the World; 100 Reported Dead in Attack On Salvador Rebel Position
description: A Government assault on a guerrilla stronghold on and around the Chichontepec volcano southeast of the capital has cost at least 100 lives in two days, military sources said.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: SCHOLAR'S WINDFALL TO CONTINUE PROJECTS
description: WHEN billionaire executive John D. MacArthur died last year, he left much of his estate to a private foundation set up in his name. Last month, the foundation awarded millions of dollars in grants to scientists, artists and educators around the nation, and among the most surprised of the winners was Prof. Henry Louis Gates Jr. of Yale University.

title: New Jersey Guide; PRINCETON HOSPITAL BENEFIT
description: ''Fabled Fete,'' the 28th annual fund-raising event for Princeton Hospital, will be held Saturday. Last year, $100,000 was raised, and with good reason, for the attractions include a wide variety of food and shops, sporting events, entertainment and an auction featuring American Primitive antiques, English and American historical china, Meissen, sterling silver, Victorian furniture, jewelry and furs.

title: Follow -Up on the News; Controlling Gulls
description: Terns were being crowded out by black-backed gulls and herring gulls on Monomoy Island, off Cape Cod, when the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service stepped in a year ago to balance the scales of survival. The service spread margarine and DRC 1339, a poison that causes kidney failure, on chunks of bread and put them in 1,400 gull nests.

title: Chess; THE NOT-SO-LOWLY PAWN
description: The pawn has always come in for a lot of maudlin sympathy - which it absolutely does not deserve. You hear about ''the lowly pawn'' and ''just a pawn in the grip of fate,'' but in reality the pawn is a monster.

title: A NARROW VIEW OF THE DUKE'S 'LADIES'
description: Duke Ellington made several attempts to reach Broadway with shows using his music. They were all unsuccessful, although the fault could never be laid at the doorstep of his music. With ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' however, the Duke has finally had a posthumous Broadway success, a revue in which his music, most of it from his earlier period - the first 25 years of a 50-year career as a band leader and composer - is used as the basis of a show that has no dialogue. ''Sophisticated Ladies'' is all singing and dancing and, for an Ellington fan, it provides an opportunity to hear a significant part of the Ellington repertory which the Duke neglected in his later years played with a verve that reflects the early Ellington spirit and is much more in keeping with the music than the occasional reorchestrations that the Duke later made of the more popular of these early works.

title: Around the World; Vatican Names Archbishop In China, First Since 1955
description: The Vatican today named Msgr. Dominic Tang Yiming, who was freed last year after 22 years in a Communist prison, as its first archbishop in China since 1955.

title:
RED SMITH;
The Derby and the Belmont
description: AS long as racing records are kept, they will testify that in 1981 Pleasant Colony won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness for John Campo, his trainer, and Summing won the Belmont Stakes for Luis Barrera, his trainer. That isn't the way Luis Barrera saw it.

title: Choosing a Site For an Arts Complex
description: It is hard for the informed Long Islander to accept the fact that any study for the location of a proposed arts complex could ignore the glaring fact that Hempstead could not be successful as the location regardless of the availability of old theaters there.

title: Art; PHOTOGRAPHIC 'FEAST' ENDING 3-YEAR TOUR
description: HARTFORD A SHOW that has been touring North American museums for three years, ''Photographs From the Collection of Sam Wagstaff,'' is making its last stop at the Wadsworth Atheneum here. Those who have postponed their visits are reminded that the closing date is very soon - next Sunday.

title: Graduates Hear Vonnegut on When Its Honorable to Be a Wise Guy
description: The following remarks are from a speech at the Southampton College commencement last month by the writer Kurt Vonnegut Jr., who has a home on the East End.

title:
LOVE AND DEATH IN THE GULAG;
INTRODUCTION
description: At the time of her arrest in 1937 on false charges of terrorism, Eugenia Ginzburg was 31 years old, an idealistic member of the Communist Party and a teacher of history at the University of Kazan. After her conviction by a military tribunal, she spent 18 years in a succession of penal camps in what has come to be known as the Gulag Archipelago and in ''permanent exile'' in Siberia. For many of those years, she worked outdoors at hard labor in temperatures of minus 40 degrees centigrade. And yet, the German novelist Heinrich Boll notes in his introduction to the second volume of her memoirs, ''Within the Whirlwind,'' to be published tomorrow, ''this astonishing woman ... never lost her sense of humor (as) she was shunted about between a number of hells and a few dots of 'heaven.' ''

title: THE 'CALL' OF VOCAL CHAMBER MUSIC
description: The flowering of chamber music in our generation is causing musicians everywhere to rethink their techniques - to realize that along with the sweeping gestures of the solo artist are the equally difficult matters of balance and tuning, in other words, the kinds of creative listening by which all small ensembles succeed or fail.

title: THE WORLD ACCORDING TO MEL BROOKS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mel Brooks's latest film, ''History of the World - Part I,'' opens Friday. By MEL BROOKS

title: IN NEW JERSEY, THE PARTY IS THE SECOND PART
description: Weakened in recent years by scandals, squabbles and the advent of publicly financed campaigns that enable candidates to run for high office without organizational blessing, New Jersey's political parties are in sorry shape. Last week, as they savored victories in the gubernatorial primaries and planned their campaigns, Republican Thomas H. Kean and Democrat James J. Florio set about to rebuild them.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: French-Algerians now living in Provence, Asian Moslems expelled from Uganda and now living in London, Yugoslavs now working in Sweden, Communists in Italy - portrayed to exemplify the discontent and dislodgments of contemporary Europe. These pieces, originally published in The New Yorker, are remarkable for their description, evocation and superb attention to detail, but hesitant in their consideration of the far-reaching implications of migration.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE MAN FROM THE CAVE By Colin Fletcher. Illustrated. 352 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: REAL AND HONORARY IRISH CELEBRATED AT A FAIR
description: What proponents hope will be an annual Brooklyn tradition - an ethnic fair on the waterfront between the Brooklyn and Manhattan Bridges - received a brave inauguration yesterday with the first of the species, the Great Irish Fair.

title: CITIZENS PANEL ASKS BAIL REFORMS TO PROTECT PUBLIC
description: The Citizens Crime Commission of New York, a nonprofit organization financed by business, has urged that bail procedures be changed to protect the public from crimes committed by suspects while awaiting trial.

title: CARNIVALS DRAW POLICE SCRUTINY
description: FROM the pitch of the barker to the stickiness of the cotton candy, the carnival midway is an alluring summer entertainment in Connecticut. More than 100 carnival shows set up in the state each season, but while the vast majority operate in strict conformance with the law, some, according to the State Police, take advantage of the unsuspecting.

title: Dr. Carolyn Riester Wed To Dr. William O'Connor
description: Dr. Carolyn E. Riester and Dr. William H. O'Connor, senior residents at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married yesterday at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in New Hope, Pa. The Rev. Leonard Seyler performed the ceremony.

title: Unser Starts in First Row In Championship Car Race
description: Bobby Unser, who finished first in the Indianapolis 500 last month but was disqualified, will start in the first row in tomorrow's 150-mile Rex Mays Classic.

title: Dining Out; FOOD AND WINE THAT FEW CAN MATCH
description: IN Glen Cove, an area with perhaps the highest concentration of better restaurants in Nassau County, Restaurant Zanghi is in a class by itself. On all of Long Island, in fact, there are few restaurants that can match its food, wines and service.

title:
Antiques;
PORCELAIN TREASURES IN CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN A COLLECTION of 500 porcelain pieces dating mostly from 1750 to 1850 will be on exhibit at the Campbell Museum here through Aug. 21. That century was particularly important in the history of porcelain because of the rise and fall of European and American trade with China and the cross-fertilization of Oriental and Western design.

title: Music Noted in Brief; New Quadro Barocco In 'Tribute to Telemann'
description: ''The members of Quadro Barocco,'' a recent news release said, ''have been making music together since 1971.'' Well, not really. The group, which is in residence at the Hebrew Arts School, appeared Thursday night for a concert in the school's Abraham Goodman House concert hall.

title: THE PLAYERS IN CAMPAIGN '82 ARE ALREADY INTO REHERSALS
description: To an audience of about 100 here yesterday, Democratic Party experts explained how to get a candidate on television with a concise, 20-second answer to a question, the perils of overscheduling, and how to find and work target precincts.

title: Marolyn Drescher Bell Bride of John Hatch 3d
description: Marolyn Drescher Bell of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday in Middletown, Conn., to John Davis Hatch 3d. The Rev. Allan J. Burry, a Methodist minister and chaplain of Wesleyan University, performed the ceremony at the University Chapel.

title: AMERICAN SUCCESS STORY
description: THE CHINESE OF AMERICA By Jack Chen. Illustrated. 274 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: Around the Nation; James Earl Ray Transferred To a Hospital at Prison
description: James Earl Ray has been discharged from Oak Ridge Hospital and transferred to the infirmary at the Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary, officials said today.

title: Astrid de Farkas, State Aide, Wed to Hubert J. Horan
description: Astrid Gray de Farkas, widow of Tibor De Farkas, and Hubert J. Horan were married yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church. The rector, the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, performed the ceremony.

title: SEEKING FAMILY HISTORY ON A VISIT TO THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
description: SETH S. KING is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. By SETH S. KING

title: 8-YEAR NATIONWIDE SERIES OF 'TOWN FORUMS' OPENS
description: Some said the country urgently needed a dialogue, several advocated opening lines of communication and a few proposed reaching out to one another. But all seemed to agree with one participant that ''America is going to hell in a handbasket'' and that special interest groups had better start talking to each other about the larger needs of society.

title: LINING UP ON THE QUESTION OF RICKOVER'S
description: RETIREMENT By RICHARD HALLORAN

title: COLUMBIA NAMES A DEAN AT SCHOOL OF SOCIAL WORK
description: Dr. George A. Brager, professor of social work at Columbia University and a specialist in the design of programs to combat poverty and delinquency, has been named dean of the university's School of Social Work.

title: BIRDS OF PREY SOAR IN ART AT OSSINING
description: ''THE owl looks like it's going to fly right off the paper,'' said Mark Spreyer, a naturalist at the Teatown Lake Reservation who was describing a painting by Louis Agassiz Fuertes of a saw-whet owl, one of 30 watercolors depicting birds of prey on exhibition through June 21 at the Ossining nature center.

title: Lisa A. Castellani Engaged to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Attilio N. Castellani of Atlantic City of the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Anne Castellani, to Oliver Knowlton, son of Winthrop Knowlton and Mrs. Thomas H. Wyman, both of New York.

title: Alouette Fans Hail Ferragamo
description: They didn't wait for the announcer to introduce Vince Ferragamo, in French or in English. Instead, the fans at the Claude Robillard Arena stood today and applauded the big-name quarterback who jumped from the National Football League to Canada.

title: ALLEGHENY'S ANGEL IS A HOMETOWN BOY
description: George W. Tippins, president and owner of the Tippins Machinery Company, and Richard P. Simmons, president of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation, waited with suspense in the law offices of Buchanan, Ingersoll, Rodewald, Kyle & Buerger on the 57th floor of the United States Steel Building in downtown Pittsburgh. Flanked by a group of lawyers, both men were eager to close a deal for Mr. Tippins to buy Allegheny, the nation's largest stainless steel producer, from its parent, Allegheny Ludlum Industries.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Soprano Duo Performs Premiere of 'Opera Skit'
description: Two sopranos - Carolyn Marcell and Brionna McMahon - made their debut Wednesday night as a duo at the Goodman Concert Hall and gave the premiere of an amusing 20-minute ''opera skit'' by Seymour Barab.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Discount Offered On Butcher Blocks
description: Great North Woods Ltd., a Manhattan factory, usually sells its 25-inch-wide butcher block at three New York City stores and in Westport at $25 a lineal foot for kitchen countertop remodeling. Beginning June 15, the first countertop sale offers a 40 percent discount only at the the Westport shop and until June 30. The new price is $15 a lineal foot, reducing the usual cost of $300 on a 12-foot counter by $120 in washable or oiled finishes.

title: On Language/By William Safire Speakerspeak; Kimble Mead
description: ''A folk hero,'' grumbled Tip O'Neill, Speaker of the House, about Ronald Reagan. ''He can dialogue with the American people. He comes on the tube so beautiful. He could sell anything.''

title: A CHICKEN, OVERTURES AND 'PLAY BALL'
description: When the Denver Symphony Orchestra took the field here yesterday evening, the bass trombones were playing close to the line at first, the string section was holding the bag at third and the conductor was standing behind home plate, dressed like a chicken.

title: SENSE OF PACE WINS FOR JOCKEY
description: George Martens, the 22-year-old jockey who grew up five minutes from Belmont Park, said he couldn't believe it when he finished first aboard Summing yesterday in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Susan Dallas, Designer, Is Bride
description: Susan Crane Dallas, daughter of Mrs. Ralph Langstaff Crow of Bridgewater, Conn., and the late Hughes Dallas, was married in Bridgewater yesterday to Henry Paul Jacobson, son of Mrs. Henry Davis Minot Jr. of Ridgefield, Conn., and Henry Samuel Jacobson of Redding, Conn. The Rev. Byron Stuhlman performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: REAGAN' CHOICE FOR CIVIL RIGHTS POST
description: For a person who will head the civil rights division of the Justice Department, a lack of experience in civil rights cases might seem a liability. Reagan Administration officials saw it as an asset in

title: U.S. EXPECTING TALKS TO STRENGTHEN TIES WITH MEXICO
description: The Reagan Administration hopes that the two days of talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico will strengthen communications between the United States and Mexico at a time when several issues have been causing strains between the two countries.

title: JEWELRY AS WORKS OF ART
description: The 107-year-old Kennedy Galleries, dealers in American art of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries,seem and unlikely place to buy a pair of earings. And normally you wouldn't find anything resembling jewelry there- just oils, water-clors, bronzes, etchings and the like.

title: BOND RALLY VIEWED CAUTIOUSLY
description: After a week of highly nervous trading, the bond market seized upon a nominal rise in the nation's money supply figures to stage a broad and sharp advance late Friday. While obviously pleased by the strong price rise that ended the week, many dealers and market analysts said the real test will start this morning.

title: AMEX PACE RECALLS THE 60'S
description: When securities analysts talk about the American Stock Exchange these days, they often recall the ''go-go'' years of the 1960's, when owners of hot stocks often saw their investments double or triple.

title: HOCKEY GOING FOR YOUTH
description: Call it the National Hockey League's children's draft: 18-year-olds who will be plucked from the ranks of juniors on Wednesday.

title: METS TRIUMPH OVER ASTROS, 3-1
description: Mike Scott held the Houston Astros to one hit over six innings and pitched the Mets to a 3-1 victory tonight. The triumph closed out New York's six-game, two-city trip with a 2-4 record. It also prevented the Astros from sweeping the series.

title: MX OPPOSITION GAINING IN UTAH AND NEVADA
description: When the Carter Administration proposed basing the MX missile system in the Great Basin of Utah and Nevada, most people here seemed prepared to agree with the plan or at least to give the Federal Government the benefit of the doubt.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Aide Is Pessimistic After Talks With Veterans
description: A lawyer for the Veterans Administration said today that he was pessimistic after meeting with Vietnam War veterans who are insisting on a meeting with President Reagan before they end their 17-day hunger strike and sit-in at a Los Angeles hospital.

title: BANKERS OF WORLD OPTIMISTIC
description: An optimistic mood permeated a meeting this past week of the world's leading bankers, who surveyed the economic situation with unusually good feelings.

title: FINDING A SLEEPER FOR PROS TO DRAFT
description: ON May 26, 1977, three New York City schoolboy basketball stars - Albert King of Fort Hamilton, Rolando Blackman of Grady Vocational and Franklin Edwards of Julia Richman - played for the Public High Schools All-Stars and beat the Catholic and Private School All-Stars in Queens.

title: CONRAIL ACTS TO UPGRADE QUALITY OF HARMON SHOP
description: ON-HUDSON, N.Y. - The sign atop Conrail's Harmon Shop here, where trains serving 45,000 riders of the Hudson and Harlem lines get their basic maintenance, says simply, ''We Care.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report in some late editions Saturday incorrectly described the participation of the Democratic county leader of Manhattan, Herman D. Farrell Jr., at a meeting to endorse Mayor Koch for re-election. Mr. Farrell presided at the meeting and abstained on the vote.

title: Southland Royalty
description: The Southland Royalty Company said Friday that its directors had authorized the purchase of up to 1.4 million of its common shares, or 3 percent of its 46.6 million shares outstanding. The company said the purchases would be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The oil and gas exploration and production company said that the amount and timing of the purchases would depend upon market conditions and other factors.

title: LEON SPINKS IN SEARCH OF HIMSELF AND TITLE
description: THE old brown Labrador retriever was lying peacefully on the grass at Leon Spinks's hideaway training camp - very peacefully considering that her master was pulling porcupine quills from her face with a pair of pliers.

title: Cornell Captures Cup in Rowing
description: The Varsity Challenge Cup went to Cornell's varsity crew at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta today.

title: N.C.A.A.  Gets TV Challenge
description: The College Football Association, which consists of 62 of the major powers most frequently seen on Saturday afternoon telecasts, challenged today the right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to negotiate multimillion-dollar football TV contracts as it has in the past.

title: STAGE: LUDLAM'S LATEST 'LOVE'S TANGLED WEB'
description: AS he most abundantly demonstrated in this season's ''Reverse Psychology,'' Charles Ludlam has a true gift for the dicey art of writing a farce. He knows that such plays must be built like complex mathematical constructs: you create as many batty variables as possible and then link them together in a narrative equation that ultimately pays off in a perfect comic explosion. In ''Love's Tangled Web,'' the new Ludlam production at his Ridiculous Theatrical Company playhouse in Sheridan Square, the delirious elements are all once again in place - but the structure, sad to report, is askew. This time, Mr. Ludlam just hasn't quite worked out the math.

title: MUSIC: THE THOUVENEL STRING QUARTET
description: ERNST KRENEK is the very model of a type of composer who cannot really be said to exist much before our century: a master craftsman who has commanded the highest respect of his colleagues but throughout a long and fruitful career has been unable to attract a following outside narrow professional circles. Many important composers, as readers of music-appreciation guidebooks all know, have had to wait for a couple of decades for recognition, but most have seen their music accepted well before their deaths.

title: Commodities; Hedging Fluctuation In Interest
description: IT'S hardly news that financial instrument futures now account for about half of all commodity contracts. One reason for this is that most raw-materials prices have been stagnant, and futures traders love volatile and highly liquid markets. Financial futures provide both.

title: The Region; Gas-Well Fire Causes $2.5 Million Damage
description: A natural-gas well being drilled near here caught fire, burned out of control for eight hours and caused $2.5 million in damage, authorities said.

title: Indian Musicians Will Give 'Summer Solstice' Concert
description: Five artists from northern and southern India will join with their accompanists for a six-hour ''Summer Solstice'' festival concert June 21 at Town Hall starting at 5 P.M.

title: The Region; 2 Teen-Agers Killed In L.I. Accidents
description: Two teen-age pedestrians were killed in separate Long Island accidents early yesterday, one of them involving a hit-and-run driver.

title: WRONG PERSON
description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Post Wins
description: Sandra Post recovered from a thirdround collapse to win the $150,000 McDonald's Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament today by two strokes.

title: 2 AMBASSADORS TEST THEIR MARRIAGE
description: He gets the Hindu cloth painting. She gets the Persian miniatures. He gets the two Lhasa Apso dogs. She gets the textiles from Iran.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED AT AMERICAN STORES
description: Thomas W. Field Jr., 47 years old, has been named president of the American Stores Company, which operates supermarket and drug chains under different names throughout the country.

title: Fruit Labeling Law Upheld
description: The Florida Citrus Commission may legally require that grapefruit products processed in the state and sold elsewhere carry a Florida label, the state Supreme Court has ruled.

title: Puffs of Ignorance
description: Implausible as it sounds, there are still millions of Americans who aren't aware that cigarette smoking endangers health. Some 20 to 24 per cent of the nation's heavy smokers don't realize - or believe - that cigarette smoking is dangerous. And even those who have heard of risks don't understand their extent. The Government's warnings cannot be thought successful or adequate.

title: NEW OFFERINGS MAY SOUR IF INTEREST RATES SOFTEN
description: The credit market is bracing for another flood of new corporate offerings this week if, as expected, interest rates soften. But bond dealers said the bulk of the new offerings will continue to be negotiated deals, rather than being sold through competitive bidding.

title: Around the world; Iranian Prosecutor Bans President's Newspaper
description: Iran's revolutionary prosecutor today banned the newspaper of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, which has criticized the clergy-dominated Government, and tonight Mr. Bani-Sadr called the action an effort to eliminate him from power.

title: DOWNES TAKES RUN
description: Tom Downes of the Warren Street Social and Athletic Club captured the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Queens Day Festival five-mile run yesterday in 24 minutes 58.9 seconds at Flushing Meadows Park. Jean Whiston of the Atlanta Track Club won the women's title in 28:43.6. Both qualified for the finals of the five-borough challenge series July 26 in Central Park.

title: Judi B. Gitlin Wed To Ross C. Rizley
description: Judi Beth Gitlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Gitlin of East Meadow, L.I., was married yesterday to Ross Collier Rizley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Quentin Rizley of Perryton, Tex. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Old Westbury (L.I.) Golf and Country Club.

title: Rangers 9, Blue Jays 0
description: Buddy Bell hit a grand slam and Al Oliver had four hits, including three doubles, to support the four-hit pitching of Danny Darwin.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 8, 1981
description: The Economy

title: Amy Bridges, Professor, Wed to Richard Kronick
description: Amy Beth Bridges, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Warren Bridges of Flushing, Queens, was married yesterday to Richard Gray Kronick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Kronick of Brooklyn. Civil Court Judge Kristin Booth Glen performed the ceremony in the Rose Garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Marcy Zimbel, Thomas Vogel, Bank Officers, Are Married
description: Marcy Zimbel and Thomas H. Vogel, assistant treasurers of the Chase Manhattan Bank, were married yesterday at the Robert Treat Paine House in Waltham, Mass.

title: William L. Hamm Sr., 67, Lawyer Who Specialized in Maritime Law
description: William L. Hamm Sr., an attorney who specialized in maritime law and represented foreign countries before the Federal Maritime Commission, died yesterday at Long Island College Hospital after a long illness. He lived in the Brooklyn Heights section of Brooklyn and was 67 years old.

title: Body of an Ailing Woman Rejects Kidney Transplant From Her Son
description: Doctors said an ailing woman's body had rejected a kidney transplant from her teen-age son, Anthony Letcher, 17 years old, who won a court battle to donate one of his kidneys on May 27.

title: Dodgers 7, Cubs 0
description: The Dodgers, with the best record in major league baseball, broke a four-game losing streak. Bob Welch (4-3) gave up only six hits, walked none and struck out a career-high 11 batters as he turned in his first complete game of the season.

title: PURETO RICANS PARADE IN CHEER AND SUN
description: On 44th Street yesterday, departing guests emerged from the Algonquin Hotel to find not a rank of yellow cabs, but a large orange-and-white parade float festooned with plastic flowers and Puerto Rican families and a banner hailing the ''Instituto de la Familia Puertorriquena.'' The guests marched west to the Avenue of the Americas to get a cab.

title: MANAGERS EMPLOY UNUSUAL TECHNIQUES AT IDEMITSU
description: Idemitsu Kosan, Japan's second-largest petroleum refiner, does not operate like most Japanese companies: There is no labor union. There are no time clocks. There is no mandatory retirement age. There is no overtime pay. Married workers earn more than single workers doing the same job.

title: ARAB PEACE ENVOYS 'RACING AGAINST TIME' IN LEBANON
description: An emergency Arab League committee met in the Lebanese mountains today in an effort to get this battered country's heavily armed factions to agree on a plan to end the bloodletting.

title: FIBER MATCHES REPORTEDLY FOUND
description: T e authorities continued their investigation today into the background and activities of a young black man who was detained for 12 hours last week and questioned about the mysterious deaths of 28 other young blacks in the last 22 months here.

title: MITLEMAN REPEATS 100-MILE RUN VICTORY
description: From a distance early yesterday morning one could make out shadowy figures moving quietly in the night around the two-and-a-quarter-mile lake in Flushing Meadows Park. The paved path on which they moved was lit dimly by lampposts and, at short intervals, by candles burning in brown bags, as if part of a strange nocturnal rite.

title: HAUGHEY VS. FITZGERALD
description: When the Republic of Ireland goes to the polls Thursday, it will be the first time that the personal credibility of the two main party leaders will be put to a direct electoral test. The contest also marks the first time in Irish politics that a campaign has been fought with American Presidential-election style and vigor.

title: FRENCH AIR TEAM IS FIRST TO LAND IN CANADA IN TRANS-ATLANTIC RACE
description: A twin-engine craft piloted by the French team of Helen Lacour and Nicole Duval became the first of more than 60 light airplanes to touch down on the North American continent in the Paris-New York-Paris trans-Atlantic air race, organizers said today.

title: Eric Levine Weds Terri Simon
description: Terri E. Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Simon of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Eric B. Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Levine of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler performed the ceremony at the Simon home. The bride, an associate with the New York law firm of Gold, Farrell & Marks, will keep her name. Mr. Levine is an associate with Murray, Hollander, Sullivan & Bass, lawyers in New York.

title: ALL-AMERICAN BRAIN LAUNDRY
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The unexpected resignation last night of Jorge Diaz Serrano as head of Mexico's oil monopoly was the climax to a long and bitter campaign by both Cabinet ministers and outside critics who felt that the company, Petroleos Mexicanos, had become a state within a state.

title: DEPORTATION OF HAITIANS FROM MIAMI CENTER ON RISE
description: There is resigned stillness these days at the Immigration and Naturalization Service's Krome Avenue Detention Center, which is home to some 800 refugees, mostly Haitians.

title: MANNIS NEUMANN
description: Mannis Neumann, an attorney in New York City for more than 35 years, died yesterday at the Florida Medical Center in Lauderhill, Fla. He was a resident of Margate, Fla., and was 70 years old.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I think he has very, very selfish people around him, people only of the upper echelon of the wealth of this nation."

title: THE ZANY SEARCH FOR BLUES
description: BLUEFISH on a feeding rampage inspire some surf anglers to intense and often bizarre behavior. Indeed, if a psychiatrist has a man who fishes for blues as a patient, he would do well to observe that person's activities on the beach when the blues are hitting, because it is then that traits which might remain hidden after weeks of quiet probing in the office emerge with startling clarity.

title: U.S. Will See to Wastes Left at Three Mile Island
description: The Federal Government plans to take responsibility for the high-level radioactive wastes left by the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant, resolving a major problem in cleanup operations.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard GOVERNING AMERICA. An Insider's Re- port from the White House and the Cabi- net. By Joseph A. Califano Jr. 474 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Has any man ever held the world record in the mile, lost the record and then regained it?

title: About Washington
description: The Senate began deliberations the other day with a chaplain praying that the deity ''strengthen'' the lawmakers ''against relentless pressure from constituents, lobbyists and special interests.''

title: NEW YORK CITY LANDLORDS SEEK RECORD INCREASES FROM RENT PANEL
description: Landlords of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City yesterday proposed record monthly increases for the 290,000 apartments due for renewals in the 12-month period starting Oct. 1.

title: FRENCH AIR TEAM IS FIRST TO LAND IN CANADA IN TRANSATLANTIC RACE
description: A twin-engine craft piloted by the French team of Helen Lacour and Nicole Duval became the first of more than 60 light airplanes to touch down on the North American continent in the Paris-New York-Paris transAtlantic air race, organizers said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amerace Corporation has elected to its board Thomas R. Berner, a New York lawyer.

title: Sylvia C. Greenbaum Bride of Dr. Andrew M. Goldmann
description: Sylvia Carol Greenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Greenbaum of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Milton Goldmann, son of Mrs. Herbert M. Goldmann of Alexandria, Va., and the late Mr. Goldmann of Buffalo. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Woman's Club of White Plains.

title: Creamer Acquisition
description: Creamer Inc., which made a small agency acquisition in Chicago on Jan. 1, has reached an agreement to pick up another one out there. It is the Chicago office of Barkley & Evergreen of Overland Park, Kan., and its contribution of about $5 million will bring Creamer's C hicago size to about $13 million.

title: DAIRYLEA WINS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK INVESTS PENSION FUNDS IN MORTGAGES FOR HOME BUYERS
description: New York State invested $85 million of retirement funds in residential mortgages this spring in an effort to assist the state's flagging home construction industry, and it plans to invest $200 million more this year, the state's Comptroller said yesterday.

title: The Tax Battle: Already Lost
description: For all the tough talk and Rose Garden theatrics, the contest of the Reagan tax bill versus the Democratic tax bill is turning into dull political football. No matter who wins, it already seems inevitable that the national economy will lose.

title: Rogers Agent Says Pro Decision Is Near
description: The agent for the running back George Rogers said yesterday a decision would be made within 10 days on whether the Heisman Trophy winner would sign with the New Orleans Saints of the National Football League or with a Canadian Football League club.

title: Hammering the Ball
description: Imagine going to a hardware store to buy a new sledgehammer and having your choice of the Bucky Dent model or the Dave Winfield model.

title: ACID RAIN IN ADIRONDACKS DISRUPTS THE CHAIN OF LIFE
description: Brook trout no longer crack the glassy surface of Big Moose Lake here in the western Adirondacks. They have vanished, along with crayfish and frogs, loons, kingfishers and most of the swallows. The chirping tree frogs called peepers have largely disappeared or stilled their voices, and blights are killing the beech and yellow birch, spruce, tamarack and pin cherry trees.

title: U.S.-SOVIET GRAIN TALKS OPEN TODAY
description: The first round of trade talks that the United States hopes will lead to resumption of Soviet grain purchases will begin tomorrow in London.

title: Pae Beats Pedroza
description: Pae Sok-chol of South Korea won a 12-round split decision from Rafael Pedroza of Panama today, gaining the right to meet Argentina's Gustavo Ballas for the newly created World Boxing Association junior bantamweight championship.

title: DISSIDENT TEAMSTERS COUNT SOME GAINS DESPITE CONVENTION LOSSES
description: ''I didn't indict you,'' Diana Kilmury, a dissident delegate, cried out at the convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters in a discussion on the insurgents' proposal for an ethical practices committee.

title: TIMERMAN'S VIEWS BRING DEBATE ON RIGHTS POLICY AND ARGENTINA
description: When the personal story of the two-and-a-half-year imprisonment and torture of Jacobo Timerman, the Argentinian newspaper publisher, first appeared in the United States, the public response was thoroughly sympathetic. He was hailed as an eloquent witness to a system of torture, murder and institutionalized anti-Semitism in Argentina.

title: Promotions by Knapp
description: From out of the West comes the word that Knapp Communications, publisher of Architectural Digest and Bon Appetit magazines, has promoted John M. Decker, 47 years old, who had been publisher of both, to group publisher of Knapp Communictions and named publishers for both magazines: George H. Oestrich, 59, is in at Architectural Digest and Ernest M. Walker, 44, is at Bon Appetit.

title: Yanks Win, 3-1, for 7th in Row
description: An exuberant Yankee team ended a week-long home stand yesterday with a 3-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox, a seven-game winning streak and an indication that Rich Gossage was ready to intimidate opposing batters for the first time since his back injury last month.

title: THE WORLD IS AUDIENCE AT THEATER TRIBAL RITUAL
description: Broadway celebrated itself last night, gathering its members in the Mark Hellinger Theater, giving some of them Tony Awards, and televising everything to the world. ''Britain sees it on Wednesday,'' said Alexander H. Cohen, the Broadway producer, who also produces the television spectacle. ''Australia, Hong Kong, Nigeria, every inhabited continent in the world after that - an audience of 100 million people.''

title: MOSLEY TAKES REX MAY RACE
description: Mike Mosley charged from the back row and scored an easy victory today in the Rex Mays 150-mile race for championship cars.

title: Lyle Shoots 71-280 And Wins by 2 Shots
description: Sandy Lyle, a 23-year-old Scottish golfer and the leading money winner in Europe for two years, shot a 71 today for a 280 total and won the $120,000 Lawrence Batley international tournament by two strokes.

title: Workers End Strike At Pirates' Ball Park
description: Striking ushers, ticket takers and maintenance workers at Three Rivers Stadium returned to their jobs last night after a tentative contract agreement was reached.

title: News Analysis
description: The recent deaths of four hunger strikers in Northern Ireland have raised questions about the position of the Roman Catholic Church on whether death from such fasting as a form of protest constitutes suicide.

title: SMALL BAND TAKES ON PARK'S LITTER
description: A beer bottle here, a soda can there, a paper plate somewhere else - it takes at least 100,000 Central Park visitors pitching in for a full day to create, bit by bit, a Sunday's accumulation of litter.

title: Advertising Trouble for Packaged Goods
description: IS SOMETHING happening to packaged goods marketing in America? Generally speaking unit sales are flat, only revenues are up and that's because of inflation. Television advertising no longer works wonders. New product successes are harder to come by than ever. For these and other reasons Fred L. Lemont, former agency and advertiser executive, and now a consultant, says, ''The marketing revolution is over.''

title: NEW YORKERS IN DALLAS: GETTING THEM ALL TOGETHER
description: Edith Axelrod's former neighbors in Manhasset Hills, L.I., would not know what to make of her. ''I listen to country and western music, I date a lot of men who drive pickups and I go target shooting,'' said Mrs. Axelrod, who moved to Dallas eight years ago. ''I'm also into metaphysics. I leave my metaphysics class and go country dancing. But I still feel like a New Yorker. I think like a New Yorker. I believe I live in Dallas, Long Island, New York.''

title: Parsons on Top
description: Benny Parsons pulled his Ford away in the final four laps today and won the Nascar 400 stock-car race at Texas World Speedway.

title: WATSON TAKES PLAYOFF IN GOLF
description: Tom Watson captured his third PGA Tour victory of the year today, defeating Tommy Valentine on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff to win the $300,000 Atlanta Classic.

title: Egypt Getting Nuclear Plants
description: The United States signed a $2 billion agreement today to supply two nuclear power stations to Egypt with a combined capacity of 2,000 megawatts. The United States also will provide Egypt with the necessary enriched uranium fuel and train Egyptian scientists in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, officials said.

title: Around the Nation; Coast Man Killed by Police After Slaying 2 Officers
description: A man who, the police said, fatally shot two officers was killed yesterday after a half-hour gun battle at his home with a dozen other officers.

title: Around the Nation; High Chicago Police Official Shot to Death in Restaurant
description: James J. Riordan, Deputy Superintendent of the Chicago Police Department, was fatally shot last night after he tried to break up a disturbance in a downtown restaurant. A 36-yearold man apprehended moments later was charged with murder.

title: No Headline
description: HUNDREDS BELIEVED DROWNED AS TRAIN TUMBLES OFF BRIDGE IN NORTH INDIA

title: The Region; Arson Called Cause Of 2 L.I. Fires
description: An Elmont luncheonette and a two-family house in Hempstead were heavily damaged by fires, both caused by arson, the police said.

title: Computer's Failure Delays Race Results
description: About 129 yachts competed in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's Whitmore and Endymion series today and yesterday on Long Island Sound.

title: Gillette, Scripto To Settle Suit
description: The Gillette Company and Scripto Inc. said they had agreed on terms for the dismissal of a civil suit brought by Gillette against Scripto in Federal court in Boston last June.

title: F.D.A. RULE AND LENS CLEANERS
description: The introduction of the soft contact lens more than a decade ago proved a boon to the companies that made them. And like lots of other new products, the soft contact lens was a boon as well to ancillary industries - in this case, the business of helping wearers to clean their thin little shells of plastic.

title: Around the World; Soviet Psychiatrist Is Reported Sentenced
description: Anatoly Koryagin, a Soviet psychiatrist arrested after declaring that a dissident sent to a psychiatric hospital was sane, has been sentenced to the maximum term of seven years in prison and five years of internal exile, dissident sources said today.

title: Hemingway Award Bestowed
description: Joan Silber's ''Household Words,'' published by the Viking Press, has won the sixth Ernest Hemingway Foundation Award as the best first book of fiction by an American writer in 1980. The $6,000 award is administered by the PEN American Center. ''Childhood and Other Neighborhoods,'' a collection of short stories by Stuart Dybek, also published by Viking, won a special $1,500 award.

title: CANADA'S SCRUTINY OF FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: Changes in the way Canada's controversial Foreign Investment Review Agency operates will be introduced in Parliament next fall if Herb Gray, the Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce, has his way. Such action has been sidetracked by the Government's recent concentration on constitutional and energy questions.

title: Stan the Man On Pete Rose
description: IN their big-league careers, they passed like ships in the night - Pete Rose a second baseman in his rookie season, Stan Musial a legend in his last season. But on the last day of that 1963 season in the old Busch Stadium in St. Louis there was a momentary connection for posterity. From his corkscrew stance, Stan Musial slashed a sharp grounder off Jim Maloney of the Cincinnati Reds past Pete Rose into right field. It was Stan the Man's last hit, his 3,630th hit, the National League record that Pete Rose is approaching.

title: TONYS TO LAUREN BACALL, 'AMADEUS,' '42D STREET'
description: ''Amadeus,'' Peter Shaffer's black comedy about Mozart and his rival Salieri, was named best play of the 1980-81 theater season last night and ''42d Street,'' the show about a chorus girl who steps in for a star, was named best musical as leading lights of Broadway gathered at the Mark Hellinger Theater for the American Theater Wing's 35th annual Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards presentation.

title: Padres 5, Cardinals 1
description: The Cardinals, who had won four straight to take over first place in the Eastern Division, dropped into second place, half a game behind Philadelphia, as they were stopped by Chris Welsh (3-4). St. Louis got its only run on the ninth homer of the season by George Hendrick, in the sixth inning. But by that time, the Padres had established a 5-0 lead off Bob Shirley (4-3), who gave up seven hits in the three and two-thirds innings he worked.

title: A TRUNK, A JET AND A STOWAWAY
description: The trunk on the Delta Air Lines jet bore an ''I H N Y'' sticker and contained a small tank of oxygen, a battery-operated fan, a bottle of water, a screwdriver and a woman hoping to get to New York from Atlanta.

title: DEEP CUTS IN A-ARMS
description: President Reagan has asserted several times that he wants to negotiate a deep cut in nuclear weapons to the point where neither the Soviet Union nor the United States threaten each other's survival. But he has been either indulging in political rhetoric or has been receiving very poor advice from his staff.

title: UNLIKELY VOLUNTEERS IN INDIA'S BIRTH CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: BUFMAN AND BOGART PLAN JOINT VENTURES
description: Zev Bufman, the Broadway producer of ''The Little Foxes,'' and Neil Bogart, president of the Boardwalk Entertainment Company, who produced the movie ''Midnight Express'' as head of the now-defunct Casablanca Record and Film Works, will join forces to present entertainment projects for films, theater, television and records.

title: JORDAN EXHORTS 1,819 GRADUATES AT CITY COLLEGE
description: Speaking at yesterday's commencement exercises of the City College of the City University of New York, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, challenged New Yorkers, the college and its graduates to continue the institution's tradition of educating the city's disadvantaged.

title: THE TERROR, THE COURAGE AND THE DIGNITY OF ULSTER
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL GLUT'S INVIATATION TO PRICE ROLLBACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: 3d Stastny Brother Joins the Nordiques
description: The Quebec Nordiques' Stastny set is now complete, and Marian Stastny will once again be playing with his brothers.

title: Notes On People; A Summer Camp Where 'Play' Has Two Meanings
description: At the age of 81, Joseph Fuchs would seem to be a bit too old to be going to summer camp. But he's off for camp this week, and it's one he decided to start himself, exclusively for music students.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico arrived in Washington for two days of talks with President Reagan aimed at reaching some accord over their differences over Central America. The two leaders also hope to broaden cooperation on trade and migration problems. (Page A1, Column 3.) In Poland, amid a sense that a crisis may be nearing once again, the Communist Party Central Committee has scheduled a meeting to discuss the country's situation. According to the Associated Press, a West German television network reported that the Soviet Party's Central Committee sent an "ultimatum" to the Polish Central Committee to get the situation in hand and that that message was the principle reason for the meeting. (Al:1-2.)

title: Artful Ballplayers
description: It would take a bundle of money to buy - or pay for - a ballplayer the caliber of Pete Rose or Hank Aaron with the market running the way it is these days.

title: Notes On People; Helen Hayes Out of a Role
description: Helen Hayes says she was dismissed from the White House Conference on the Aging, then was asked to stay on but decided against it. The 81-year-old actress, who was appointed to the conference by Jimmy Carter, said that she received a letter last March telling her she was ''being fired'' from the advisory body.

title: SLAUGHTER IN SALVADOR: 200 LOST IN BORDER MASSACRE
description: There are lovely little mountain towns in Latin America, but La Virtud is not one of them. The wall painter who sketched ''Palacio Municipal'' on the town hall facing the rutted main square and the military garrison enclosed the words in elaborately curlicued quotation marks as if to suggest that no palace could exist in a place like this.

title: BELZBERG BID EXTENDED
description: The Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation of Toronto, Canada's third-largest trust company, had delayed an unwelcome $300 million (Canadian) takeover bid by the Belzberg family interests of Vancouver.

title: JACOB'S PILLOW TO OPEN JUNE 30
description: The first performance of Ballet Today, a company formed by Brett Raphael and Luk de Layress, on Aug. 4, will highlight the eight-week Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Lee, Mass. The festival, founded by Ted Shawn, the modern-dance pioneer, is in its 49th year.

title: PHILS, ON 14 SINGLES, TOP BRAVES AND MOVE PAST CARDS INTO FIRST
description: It was not just that his Philadelphia Phillies hopped over the St. Louis Cardinals into first place in the National League Eastern Division yesterday, but the way they did it that pleased Manager Dallas Green.
