title: RELIGIOUS CHOICE FACES A CHALLENGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide
description: THE AMERICAN WAY

title: KOCH'S PRIORITIES IN BUDGET FOUND CLOSE TO BEAME'S
description: Despite the improvement in New York City's finances over the last four years, Mayor Koch's spending priorities are not much different from those of Abraham D. Beame in his last year as Mayor, according to a report prepared by a major civic organization.

title: Help-Wanted Ads Down in April
description: The Help-Wanted Advertising Index fell 7 points, to 118 (based on 100 for 1967), in April, from 125 in March, for the second consecutive monthly drop, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Chandler, Ring Champion, Arraigned on Drug Charge
description: Jeff Chandler, World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, was arraigned on drug possession charges today. The police said he had been stopped for a traffic violation, and a small quantity of marijuana and a white powder believed to be cocaine had been found on him.

title: CARING FOR THE HOMELESS MEN NOBODY WANTS IN HIS NEIGHBORHOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES OVERRULE I.R.S. ON MEALS AND LODGINGS
description: The Supreme Court today handed a defeat to the Internal Revenue Service, ruling by 6 to 3 that the meals and lodging provided for thousands of workers by their employers were not ''wages'' for the purpose of computing Social Security and Federal unemployment taxes.

title: The Economy
description: Reductions in the price of crude oil continue to shake the already unsettled international petroleum markets, and further drops in price are expected. Some spot prices have plunged to $32 a barrel. Oil analysts expect this trend to reduce retail gasoline prices and, possibly, break the grip of OPEC. (Page A1.)

title: Q & A
description: Q. If you were immersed in water of exactly the same temperature as your body, would it feel warm or cold?

title: WALLACE BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings figures reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective in

title: Notes On People; HARRIS INTRODUCES BURTON FOR A SURPRISE APPERANCE; Burton Takes a Bow
description: The curtain went down on the final Los Angeles performance of the touring revival of ''Camelot'' Sunday, and Richard Harris stepped forward to make a farewell speech.

title: PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE AT CHUBB NOW CHAIRMAN, TOO
description: Henry U. Harder, 56, president and chief executive officer of the Chubb Corporation, has been named to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds William M. Rees, who retired from the New Yorkbased insurance holding company at the mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: PENNEY STORE CLOSES IN FOUNDER'S TOWN
description: Here, where James Cash Penney was born and reared, his memory is very much alive. But after 57 years the town's J.C. Penney store isn't.

title: BALLET THEATER: REVIVALS, MACMILLAN 'S 'CONCERTO '
description: THE American Ballet Theater's eclecticism was particularly evident at its Friday night performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. The program included revivals of two works by Jerome Robbins, a major cast change in a ballet by George Balanchine and a repetition of Kenneth MacMillan's ''Concerto.''

title: Coca-Cola Ruling Altered by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission said that it was reducing the terms of a consent order that it had imposed on the Coca-Cola Company in 1976.

title: MATHEMATICIAN'S FINAL EQUATIONS PRAISED
description: AN American mathematician has discovered in an English library a manuscript containing more than 600 equations that represent some of the final work of Srinivasa Ramanujan, one of the giants of 20thcentury mathematics.

title: Sugar Price Rises Spur Meeting
description: The executive committee of the International Sugar Organization held a short emergency meeting today to consider rising world sugar prices, but it deferred major decisions until June 23.

title: TENANTS BACK RENT RISES, BUT ONLY IF NEED IS PROVED
description: Politicians and tenants' organizations urged New York City's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday to permit increases in rent-stabilized apartments in the coming year only when a landlord can prove he is suffering hardship under the current guidelines.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
description: B-Including $323,000 or 22 cents a shr gain on the sale of a Canadian manufacturing facility

title: Talking Business with Lewis W. Lehr and John M. Pitblado of 3M; New Approach For the 80's
description: It is hard to define 3M. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company produces more than 45,000 different products, from suntan lotion to sandpaper, from skin staples to Scotch tape. ''3M's business is not producing any one product,'' says Ty Govatos, who follows the company for Bache Halsey Stuart Shields. ''Its business is inventing new products. For years the whole structure of the company has been designed for that purpose.''

title: Exxon to Sell Unit
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said that it had reached an agreement in principle with the Exxon Corporation to acquire the Star Systems division of Exxon Enterprises, a division of Exxon, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Star Systems, which is in Pasadena, Calif., has been developing optical systems for the storage and retrieval of data since 1978.

title: Nkomo's Party Sweeps Elections In Second-Largest Zimbabwe City
description: The Zimbabwe African People's Union, led by Joshua Nkomo, easily won all 15 seats in municipal elections here that had been delayed twice because of violence, election officials said today.

title: ASSEMBLY BACKS TOUGH BILLS TO CONTROL DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: The Assembly passed two bills today that would toughen the state's laws on drunken driving, including a measure intended to prevent the State Department of Motor Vehicles from issuing licenses to drivers while they are on probation for driving while intoxicated.

title: PUTTING IMMIGRATION INTO PROPER FOCUS
description: To the Editor:

title: Indian Trade Deficit Soars
description: India had a record trade deficit in the fiscal year 1980-81, ended March 31, the Government said today. Provisional trade figures released by the Commerce Ministry showed the trade deficit during the year soared to $6.5 billion, up from the previous year's deficit and previous record of $3.06 billion. India exported goods worth $8.23 billion and its imports stood at $14.73 billion in the fiscal year 1980-81, the agency said.

title: Phillies Defeat Astros
description: Larry Bowa drove in three runs with a pair of singles tonight to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-3 victory over the Houston Astros in the season's first meeting of last year's National League division champions.

title: CHOCK FULL O' NUTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $705,000 for the qr and $2,594,000 for the 9 mos and $350,000 income for the 9 mos from excess of assets over the value of vested benefits of a terminated pensio plan covering the former employees of a previously discontinued manufacturing facility...C-Including tax credits of $378,000 fo the qr and $1,361,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results exclude a $ reduction of Federal income taxes as a result of completion of examination by the IRS

title: By Sports of The Times; Discovering You're No. 1
description: WHEN the Dallas Mavericks announced Sunday evening that Mark Aguirre would be the No. 1 choice in today's National Basketball Association draft, he was at 30,000 feet on a flight with George Andrews, his agent. A few hours later they checked into the Grand Hyatt Hotel, where the draft will be held, and somebody asked if they were aware of the developement.

title: Boy, 10, Found Guilty Of Holding Up a Bank
description: The 10-year-old boy charged with robbing a midtown bank last Feb. 25 was found guilty yesterday in Family Court in Manhattan. The boy, identified in court papers only as ''Robert M.,'' went up to a teller in the New York Bank for Savings, 1230 Avenue of the Americas, waved what appeared to be a gun, demanded money and was given $118.

title: TAIWAN IS PLEASED BY WIDENING TRADE
description: While trying hard not to boast, in order not to embarrass countries that have broken diplomatic relations with Taiwan to establish them with Peking, officials here are clearly delighted with the substantial and expanding ties that link Taiwan to nations that do not recognize its existence as a state.

title: H. WARD PINNEY
description: H. Ward Pinney, a former State Representative who held many town posts in 30 years of public service, died Saturday at his home.

title: Port Pay Without Anchor
description: For most Americans, workers' compensation pays the medical bills for job-related injuries and replaces a modest portion of lost wages. Things are different, however, for a million workers employed at or near ports. Thanks to the Federal Government, their compensation program has become an incredibly expensive welfare system, wide open to cheating. Congress ought to clean up the mess.

title: Jackson Earning $750,000 on TV
description: Reggie Jackson's earnings for television appearances have reached approximately $750,000 a year, $150,000 more than he earns playing baseball for the Yankees, TV Guide reported today.

title: No Headline
description: ARIZONA STATE NINE WINS N.C.A.A. TITLE

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Notes On People; Yeshiva Solves a Problem
description: He is one of the city's leading businessmen and has a long history of civic service, especially to higher education and Jewish causes, so to Yeshiva University, J. Peter Grace seemed just the executive to serve as guest of honor and receive a distinguished service award from the university at its fourth annual ''corporate'' dinner on June 16.

title: MILITARY TANGLED IN ITALY'S SCANDAL
description: The Italian Defense Ministry announced today that it had asked for the voluntary suspension of all the generals and admirals on active duty whose names were on a list of alleged members of an illegal Masonic lodge.

title: Wegerle Has Operation, Will Be Out Two Weeks
description: Steve Wegerle, whose league debut with the Cosmos lasted 17 minutes in a game against the Atlanta Chiefs Sunday, underwent surgery for two hours for a broken wrist late Sunday night and will be out two weeks.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Your May 27 editorial ''Multiple Choice on Immigration'' calls for swift action to stop the flow of illegal immigrants across the Mexican border. You indicate that our Border Patrol doesn't have the men or vehicles to function, and you predict that new funds will not be forthcoming in this budget-cutting climate.

title: DESOLATE BLACK AREA MUST GIVE ITS SONS TO THE MINES
description: For about 1,500 blacks a year, the route to South Africa's gold mines starts in a desolate rural area near here that is inside one of the seven fragments of an officially independent black state called Bophuthatswana.

title: PHYSICIST'S SOLAR AIRPLANE SET TO CHALLENGE THE ENGLISH CHANNEL
description: LOS ANGELES PAUL MACCREADY, the California physicist who proved in 1977 that human muscles alone can power an airplane in sustained flight, plans to try shortly to prove that sunshine alone can propel a plane from Paris to London.

title: HIGH COURT DECLINES ROLE ON IRAN ASSETS
description: The Supreme Court today declined a chance for immediate involvement in the legal dispute over the President's authority to take control of billions of dollars of frozen Iranian assets.

title: Algerian Leader Visits Soviet
description: President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria arrived in Moscow today for talks that are expected to focus on Soviet proposals for an international conference on the Middle East.

title: Extension on Saccharin Supported by Schweiker
description: The Reagan Administration endorsed legislation today to allow the sale of saccharin for two more years. An exemption expires June 30 that has allowed the popular artificial sweetener to be sold despite tests indicating it is a weak cancer-causing agent.

title: BRAUNSTEIN NAMED HEAD OF COWARD, MCCANN
description: The Putnam Publishing Group yesterday named Donald Braunstein, formerly a vice president, as president of Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. He succeeds Patricia B. Soliman, who resigned.

title: Angels 10, Indians 2
description: Butch Hobson drove in three runs with a bases-loaded double in the second inning and hit a run-scoring single in a six-run eighth to spark the California victory.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: A Telex Corporation official today offered a $100,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the killer of Roger M. Wheeler, Telex's chairman.

title: Cards' Financial Problems
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies, owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, said today that it needed to buy Busch Memorial Stadium from a publicly held redevelopment corporation because of the ''serious'' financial problems that Busch said threatened the team's future.

title: The City; 5 Boroughs Hooked To New Fire System
description: Starfire, the Fire Department's new, $15 million computerized dispatching system is now operating in all five boroughs, Fire Commissioner Charles J. Hynes announced yesterday.

title: Market Place; Winning With Bargain Stocks
description: IN 1939, as war broke out in Europe, a young man named John Templeton became convinced that stocks were cheap. He went to his broker and ordered $100 worth of every stock selling for no more than $1 a share on each of the two major exchanges.

title: NUCLEAR PANEL REJECTS CLAIM OVER THREE MILE ISLAND
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission yesterday rejected a $4 billion damage claim from the Three Mile Island utility that charged the agency with negligence leading to the 1979 reactor accident.

title: SCRIPTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
TERMS SET AT 53 YEARS
description: Two men who were convicted in absentia of international trade in weapons with terrorist organizations were each sentenced yesterday to 17 2/3 to 53 years in prison. They are believed to be out of the country.

title: Deputy Minister Wins Youthful
description: There was a distinct Canadian flavor to the 68th running of the $56,400 Youthful Stakes for 2-year-olds at Belmont Park yesterday. Deputy Minister, who remained undefeated by beating favored Ringaro by 1 1/4 lengths, was bred north of the border.

title: Sidney Kahn, Surgeon; Aided A-Bomb Victims
description: Dr. Sidney Kahn, a specialist in reconstructive surgery who operated on people who had been disfigured in the nuclear bombing of Hiroshima, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. A former chief of plastic surgery at the Beth Israel Medical Center in New York City, he was 68 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: U.S. DEPORTATIONS OF HAITIANS HALTED
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would suspend deportation proceedings against Haitians pending a review of the procedures that govern such hearings.

title: HAZARD FROM DEBRIS CONSIDERED LIMITED
description: If, as appears possible, 25 pounds of highly enriched uranium was in storage at the Osirak reactor site near Baghdad, some of that radioactive material may have been scattered locally when the facility was bombed Sunday by Israeli planes. The hazard, however, would be far less than that from the bombing of a working reactor.

title: Khomeini Attacks Bani-Sadr In Warning to Opponents
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, apparently denouncing President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr again, warned today that he would remove any politician from power who continued to challenge Iran's Islamic authorities.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
BURNS, R L, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $462,000 for the qr and $858,000 for 9 mos...C-Net loss

title: Housing Fund Shift Averted
description: Democrats on the House Banking Committee barely defeated a Republican move today to shift about $440 million from housing aid for low-income families to the Export-Import Bank, which subsidizes overseas business loans.

title: The Region; 3 Children Killed In Newark Blaze
description: NEWARK (AP) - Three young children died early yesterday in a onealarm blaze.

title: Notes On Fashion
description: One sunny afternoon Alexander Liberman, the editorial director of Conde Nast, which owns Vogue, Glamour, Self and Gentlemen's Quarterly, sat in the gray stillness of his office serenely fielding questions on the transformation of Mademoiselle. Many readers feel that the fashion publication has taken on a tone closer to that of Cosmopolitan.

title: The City; Dog Owners Face Hounding on Litter
description: Members of the sanitation police will expand to the streets a crackdown on dog owners who do not clean up after their pets in the parks, the city has announced.

title: FREED EX-BATISTA OFFICIAL CRUSADES AGAINST CASTRO
description: In his dark, vested suit, quiet maroon-and-blue rep tie and immaculate white shirt, Ernesto de la Fe looks much more like a banker than a man who has spent much of the last 22 years as a political prisoner, breaking marble in the sun-blasted quarry of the Cuban prison on the Isle of Pines or growing pale and gaunt in the dank galerias, the long, casement-like dungeons in the old Fortress of La Cubana in Havana.

title: Ulster Hunger Strikers Change Their Tactics
description: A fifth prisoner joined four others today in a hunger strike at Maze Prison as the Irish Republican Army announced new tactics to increase pressure on the British Government.

title: NEW PRESIDENT SETS TALON GOAL OF TURNAROUND
description: Sidney Merians, 54, has been named president of Talon Inc., the zipper manufacturer based in Meadville, Pa. William J. Davis, 51, has been elected chairman.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: Winners of Tony Awards for the 1980-81 Broadway season are: PLAY: ''Amadeus'' by Peter Shaffer. MUSICAL: ''42d Street.'' BOOK OF A MUSICAL: ''Woman of the Year,'' by Peter Stone.

title: Mariners 2, Red Sox 0
description: SEATTLE (AP) - Floyd Bannister hurled a two-hitter and Gary Gray clouted his 13th homer of the season in leading Seattle's victory.

title: Notes On people; Sears Climber Fined $35
description: The man who climbed to the top of the world's tallest building was fined $35 yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL POST FILLED AT SEAGRAM
description: 13Edward F. McDonnell, 45 years old, has been appointed president of Seagram International, effective next Monday. He will thus fill a new post at the Seagram Company, a huge liquor and wine concern with headquarters in Montreal. Mr. McDonnell, who will be based in New York, will be responsible for all Seagram activities outside the United States and Canada, except for the company's French wine business.

title: Bankers Trust Prime 20%
description: The Bankers Trust Company, the nation's eighth-largest bank, lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, where it had stood since May 22.

title: Bridge: Neglect of Rule on Discards Helped Opponents to a Title
description: Discarding in defense is a difficult area, but there is a golden rule that is not always understood: A defender should try to keep length in any suit in which the declaring side also has length.

title: CITY BALLET: D'AMBOISE 'S OPUS 42'
description: THE latest premiere in the New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival is a a brief little piece of fun by Jacques d'Amboise entitled ''Scherzo Opus 42.''

title: Bohack Wins Suit Against Iowa Beef
description: Iowa Beef Processors Inc., the nation's largest beef packer, and Waldbaum Inc., a major New York supermarket chain, have been found guilty in a price-fixing suit brought in 1977 by the Bohack Corporation, formerly a leading supermarket chain in the metropolitan area.

title: STORE CHAIN PLANNED BY TECHNOCOLOR
description: Technicolor Inc., a major processor of professional motion-picture and consumer film, said yesterday in Los Angeles that it planned to enter the retail photographic finishing field with a new division, Technicolor One Hour Photo. The company said that it would spend $150 million to open about 1,000 stores by June 1986 that will develop and print film within one hour.

title: HAYES TO THE ROCKETS
description: In a move to strengthen their backcourt, the New Jersey Nets yesterday obtained Otis Birdsong from the Kansas City Kings in exchange for Cliff Robinson, a promising 21-year-old forward.

title: PLAY EASES THE FEARS OF HOSPITALIZED CHILDREN
description: BOSTON IN the summer of 1965, when she was 6 years old, Donna Williamson cut her hand on a broken milk bottle. During her hospital stay, which she disliked intensely, there was one pleasure: the kindness shown to her by an attentive college student working as a volunteer in the hospital.

title: Bid a Record For Oil Tract
description: The Interior Department said today that a record single-tract bid of $333.6 million had been made jointly by the Phillips Petroleum Company and Chevron U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, for California offshore oil and natural gas leases.

title: Stockholder Ends Century Bank Bid
description: Marvin L. Warner, a Florida investor, announced through an attorney that he had ended his offer of May 4 to purchase up to one million common shares of Century Banks Inc., a bank holding company. The offer expired last Friday.

title: MEXICAN BACKS REAGAN ON CARIBBEAN AID
description: President Reagan won an agreement in principle from President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico today to participate in a long-term economic development plan for the Caribbean region aimed at strengthening the ''political and economic freedom'' of the countries there.

title: RCA's Ratings Lowered by S.&P.
description: The rating of RCA Corporation bonds, commercial paper and preferred stock was lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, in part, S.&P. stated, because of the ''low profitability'' of RCA's broadcasting arm - NBC.

title: No Headline
description: Red Smith Is Honored By Sports Editors' Unit

title: SOUTHERN BAPTISTS SET FOR CONSERVATIVE-MODERATE FIGHT
description: The annual convention of the Southern Baptists is normally a combination of a homecoming and a revival meeting, but as thousands of delegates arrived today for this year's sessions, a major ruckus threatened to dampen the usual folksiness.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For a long time, we have followed with grave concern the construction of the Osirak nuclear reactor.

title: Freight Routes Acquired
description: The Copenhagen-based East Asiatic Company announced today that it had acquired, from Norway's Knutsen Line, freight routes between the North American West Coast and the Far East and Western Australia. An East Asiatic announcement said the agreement was reached last week. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed.

title: JUSTICES WIDEN RANGE OF WOMEN'S PAY SUITS
description: The Supreme Court, in a decision likely to encourage a new round of sex discrimination lawsuits, ruled today that women who are paid less than men are entitled to sue their employers, whether or not the jobs performed by the two sexes are identical.

title: ARAB MISSION IN LEBANON SEEMS IN VAIN
description: Arab League efforts to bring peace to Lebanon appeared to be foundering tonight on the long-entrenched hostility between the heavily armed militiamen of the right, led by the Lebanese Christians, and the predominantly Moslem left.

title: Agency Seeks Backing To Sponsor Fire Ads
description: Leo Greenland, chairman of Smith/ Greenland, volunteered his agency's services in the city's fight against fire-caused deaths. And Christine Godek, deputy commissioner for program and policy development, took him op on it.

title: AN ABORTION VOTE VS. PUBLIC WILL
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 MEN CHARGED IN AIRPORT THEFTS OF CARGO GOODS
description: Five men were charged yesterday with theft and possession of stolen goods in the first indictments following a three-and-a-half-year undercover investigation of air-cargo thefts at Kennedy International Airport.

title: The City; 2 Men Shot in Face In 'Village' Home
description: Two men were shot and seriously wounded by an unknown assailant last night when they answered a knock at the door of their Greenwich Village apartment, the police said.

title: A.T.&T. to Raise Share Offer's Size
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would offer at least 16.5 million shares of its stock to the public later this week, up 1.5 million from what had been planned.

title: Chess: 4 Californians Take Laurels At Swiss Open in Burbank
description: Two grandmasters - Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., and Larry Christiansen of Modesto, Calif. - and two international masters - Jon Peters of Los Angeles and Nick DeFirmian of Oakland - tied for first place in the Memorial Day Open Tournament in Burbank, Calif., each scoring 5 1/2- 1/2 in the Swiss System competition.

title: Atlanta Official Says Police Lack Evidence for an Arrest
description: The law-enforcement authorities lack sufficient evidence to arrest Wayne B. Williams, who says the Federal Bureau of Investigation called him a suspect in some of the slayings of 28 young blacks, a prosecutor said today. But the prosecutor, District Attorney Lewis Slaton of Fulton County, said that the police would not be rushed by public pressure into either clearing or arresting Mr. Williams.

title: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
1-PIECE SWIMSUITS, MORE OR LESS
description: * One-piece swimsuits are outselling bikinis six to one.

title: ISRAELI AND IRAQI STATEMENTS ON RAID ON NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Following is an unofficial translation of the text of a statement issued today by the Israeli Government describing its attack on an Iraqi atomic reactor:

title: Pakistan and India Agree To Try to Smooth Relations
description: Pakistan and India agreed today to try to rebuild their strained relationship and to hold more frequent consultations to prevent misunderstandings.

title: WE WILL NOT LET THE POLES ALONE, RUSSIANS WARN
description: The Soviet Communist Party has told the Polish leadership that it is not acting resolutely to stem a tide of counterrevolution and warned that Soviet-bloc countries ''will not leave Poland alone'' in its crisis, reliable Polish party sources confirmed today.

title: FIRST OF THREE TRIALS OF JERSEYAN IN PROSTITUTE-SLAYINGS NEARS END
description: The first of three trials of a New Jersey man in connection with the slayings of four Manhattan prostitutes and an X-ray technician is nearing an end here in State Superior Court.

title: THEATER: 'TWISTER, 'STORY OF A LITTLE GIRL IN A BIG WIND
description: A TORNADO threatens to level a small Kansas town in Pat Staten's ''Twister,'' at the Academy Arts Theater Company, but the greatest peril comes from our old friend deja vu. As the evening unfolds - with the leisureliness of a cat napping in the sun - we realize that we have visited here before in works ranging from ''The Wizard of Oz'' to the plays of William Inge.

title: Bristol Myers Settles Suits
description: The Bristol Myers Company said yesterday that it had reached a preliminary settlement of antitrust suits pending since 1970 regarding ampicillin, an antibiotic drug.

title: Spinks Says He'll Fight Holmes From in Close
description: Leon Spinks said today that he planned to cling to Larry Holmes ''like a T-shirt'' in their World Boxing Council heavyweight title fight Friday at Joe Louis Arena.

title: MCGUIRE APPRAISES POLICE AND OUTLINES SOME GOALS
description: In a recent two-hour interview, Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire talked with Barbara Basler of The New York Times about the strengths and weaknesses of the Police Department and his hopes for improving it. Following are excerpts from the interview:

title: Chrysler May Seek Perkins Engines Tie
description: The Chrysler Corporation today confirmed reports that it is negotiating with Perkins Engines Inc., a British subsidiary of Massey-Ferguson Ltd. of Toronto, for the production of diesel engines at a Chrysler plant in Canada.

title: Phillips Petroleum Buys Stake in Salk
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said that it had purchased a $10 million equity interest in the Salk Institute Biotechnology Corporation, previously a wholly owned subsidiary of the Salk Institute, a private nonprofit biological research concern in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Former Iowa Policeman Indicted In Death of High Chicago Official
description: A former Iowa police officer was indicted today on charges of murdering a top official of the Chicago Police Department.

title: O'NEILL TV APPEARANCES MAJOR SHIFT IN STRATEGY
description: Most politicians would almost kill to appear on national television, but not Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House. When he appeared yesterday on the ABC News program ''Issues and Answers,'' denouncing President Reagan as someone ''who has no concern for the little men of America,'' it was the Speaker's first appearance on a network interview show in three years.

title: Israel's Illusion
description: Israel's sneak attack on a French-built nuclear reactor near Baghdad was an act of inexcusable and short-sighted aggression.

title: Protesting Veterans Vow To Carry On if Evicted
description: Apparently resigned to eviction, Vietnam veterans fasting in tents at the Wadsworth Veterans Administration Medical Center said today that they would not fight, but would regroup at nearby St. John's Church and carry their protest to Washington, demanding a meeting with President Reagan.

title: No Headline
description: 11 Journalists Selected For Nieman Fellowships

title: Joint Irish Venture For Foster Wheeler
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation, designer and builder of processing and steam generating plants, said it would establish a joint venture in Galway, Ireland, to produce components for steam boilers.

title: BONN SEEKS CHANGES IN JAPAN TRADE RULES
description: West German trade officials, dismayed at Europe's failure to negotiate a restraint of Japanese imports, are mounting a final attempt to convince Japan to moderate its exports and relax its import barriers or face European import restrictions.

title: NEW GROWTH BUSINESS- ARMING CARS
description: Richard C. Medlin is a man with a light-hearted approach to a grim business. The calling card of his Custom Armor Manufacturing Company carries three miniature holes above a diagram of spent cartridges, and his favorite parting shot for a client leaving his shop with one of his custom-made bulletproof vests is, ''If you have any trouble with that thing, you give me a call.''

title: Bendix and Enertech
description: The Bendix Corporation, the diversified aerospace and electronics concern, said that it had acquired a 30 percent equity interest in the Enertech Corporation, a manufacturer of small windmills, by converting an existing $750,000 loan into shares of Enertech stock. Bendix noted that under certain agreements it would make further loans to Enertech and had the option to acquire additional shares of Enertech stock in the future.

title: DANCE: BUSY PEOPLE OF DAVID WOODBERRY'S 'EDGES'
description: THE members of David Woodberry's Running and Rolling Foundation did their share of running around and rolling on the floor in ''Edges,'' Mr. Woodberry's new hourlong work presented Sunday night at the Kitchen. They even ran backward.

title: 3 Free Downtown Walks Offered by Poets Academy
description: The Academy of American Poets will offer three free walking tours this month. ''Tracking Walt Whitman Through Manhattan in the 1840's: A Walk Through Printing House Square and Environs'' will take place on Thursday at 5:30 P.M., beginning at St. Paul's Chapel, at Fulton Street and Broadway.

title: SCM Says Rockwell Will End Proxy Bid
description: The SCM Corporation said that it had reached an agreement with Willard F. Rockwell Jr., the retired former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, to end his second proxy fight for control of SCM, a major industrial complex with operations ranging from food to telecommunications equipment.

title: AT SOUTH AFRICA'S MINES, RACE BARRIERS ARE RIGID
description: For eight decades, the mining houses that dominate South Africa's gold mining industry offered no significant wage increases to the black migrant laborers who accounted for at least 85 percent of the work force. Now the corporations point with pride to 880 percent increases given to the migrants in the last 10 years as part of a general effort to improve the workers' conditions.

title: ATTACK CONDEMNED BY U.S.  AND ARAB NATIONS
description: Israeli planes yesterday bombed and destroyed an atomic reactor near Baghdad that would have enabled Iraq to manufacture nuclear weapons, the Israeli Government announced today.

title: A QUIET RETREAT FOR CITY'S HOMELESS and barracks at the Chester,New York facility, with women's prison
description: About 11:30 every morning, a forest-green school bus rumbles out of lower Manhattan bound for Camp La Guardia, a cluster of buildings on 270 acres of a broad, rolling hilltop here in Orange County.

title: Youngblood To Be Out Two Weeks
description: Joel Youngblood, who injured his left knee while sliding into third base in Houston on Saturday night, will probably be lost to the Mets for at least two weeks.

title: BACH:FIRST SUITE AND FOURTH BRANDENBURG
description: IN a charming excerpt from Lewis Thomas's ''The Lives of a Cell'' reprinted in the program of the final Basically Bach concert on Saturday night in Avery Fisher Hall, Dr. Thomas suggests that our first communication with extraterrestial life should be made by streaming Bach's music into space. ''We would be bragging of course,'' he adds.

title: YANKEES BEAT ROYALS, 8-3, FOR 8TH STRAIGHT
description: The Yankees' San Diego Alumni Association of Dave Winfield, Oscar Gamble and Jerry Mumphrey proved highly productive tonight as the Yankees beat the Kansas City Royals, 8-3, for their eighth straight victory.

title: Moonbeam For The Senate
description: Some say Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. has been chastened by his disastrous 1980 Presidential campaign. Maybe so, but an interviewer still had better have one good question ready; that's all he's likely to get during what may be the most interesting nonstop discourse in contemporary American politics.

title: NETTLES FOR REAGAN
description: The Israeli air attack on Iraq's nuclear installation has presented the Reagan Administration with its first sharp confrontation with Israel and raised new obstacles for the Administration's overall strategy in the Middle East.

title: DOllAR'S THREAT TO U.S. EXPORTS
description: American exports, aided by the falling dollar in 1977 and 1978 and more aggressive sales efforts, have grown handsomely in the last three years, bolstering profits and creating new jobs.

title: NEW STUDY ACCUSES CUBA ON GUERRILLAS
description: The United States is facing a sustained political and military effort by Cuba to establish Communist regimes in the Caribbean and Central America, the Assistant Secretary of State-designate for Inter-American Affairs told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

title: Kennedy Urges Party to Hold to Convictions
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy delivered a stinging attack on the Reagan Administration today and called on Democrats not to sacrifice their political convictions for ''the convenience of the hour.''

title: Toll From Train Crash Reaches 215 in India
description: The death toll in a train accident in India's northeastern Bihar State rose to 215 today, The United News of India reported.

title: The U.N. Today; June 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Preparatory Committee for the Energy Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Advertising; Taylor Set To Test Its Light Wine
description: NEXT Monday in 13 test markets, Taylor California Cellars will begin to test-market its innovative ''Light Chablis'' with ''25 percent fewer calories than our regular Chablis.''

title: The Region; Woman Is Charged In Abduction of Boy
description: A former mental patient who abducted a small child for a time last fall was arrested with a 3-year-old boy taken from Belmont Park race track on Sunday, according to the Nassau County police.

title: Race Trimaran Overturns; U.S. Skipper, Mate Saved
description: An American and his British-born crewman competing in the trans-Atlantic yacht race were rescued by a British helicopter today when their trimaran overturned in heavy seas and gale-force winds some 300 miles west of Land's End, race organizers said.

title: PERIL OVERHEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH SELL COMMUTER AIRLINERS
description: British Aerospace Ltd. has won a second order for the four-jet 100-passenger plane that it hopes will become a staple for the shorthaul commuter and feeder airlines whose numbers are growing rapidly in this country and abroad.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NATIONAL DEFENSE. By James Fallows. 204 pages. Illustrated with charts. Ran- dom House. $12.95

title: ACTIVE IN CHARITIES
description: Oscar M. Lazrus, a lawyer who was a co-founder and a former president and chairman of the Benrus Watch Company, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old.

title: White Sox 6, Blue Jays 2
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Bill Almon and Greg Luzinski delivered two-run singles, and Chet Lemon hit a home run for Chicago, which extended Toronto's losing streak to eight games.

title: M.T.A. HEAD SAYS RISE COULD BE APPROVED FOR FARE ON JULY 2
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday at the first of three days of mandatory public hearings that the agency's board would convene on July 2 to approve an almost certain transit fare increase of 15 cents. The authority is also considering what to do about a new token, an agency spokesman said.

title: MOVE TO LOWER RATES IS STALLED
description: The monthlong decline in interest rates was at least temporarily stalled yesterday when the credit markets were unable to maintain the most recent move to lower rates, which began late Friday.

title: RUSSIANS FIND SHOW OF MODERN ART REVOLUTIONARY
description: ''Moscow-Paris 1900-30,'' the first art exhibition in the Soviet Union to chronicle in detail Russia's remarkable contribution to modern art, opened at the Pushkin Museum last week to gasps from Soviet viewers and indignant charges of censorship from French collaborators.

title: Harris Credit Pact
description: The Harris Corporation said that it had signed a seven-year, $150 million revolving credit and term loan agreement with a group of 12 American and European banks, with Citibank N.A. acting as agent. Harris said that the financing measure would provide standby financing for the initial phases of the company's current five-year growth plan and would replace a previously arranged $100 million revolving credit agreement.

title: PERNOD HOPES TO SELL SWEET-TOOTHED U.S. ON ITS BITTER PASTIS
description: It's difficult to spend five minutes in a French cafe without hearing at least three people order pastis. Now the French are planning to hook Americans on the chalky white, anise-flavored drink that is the French workingman's favorite aperitif.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Your Money column in Business Day on May 2 incorrectly stated one of the conditions for use of the American Express gold card Associate Club Program. Gold card holders can use the clubs situated more than 50 miles away from their homes or offices.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 9, 1981
description: International Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad that would have enabled Iraq to manufacture nuclear weapons, the Israeli Government announced. Prime Minister Menachem Begin justified the attack by Israeli jet fighters as essential to prevent the ''evil'' President Saddam Hussein of Iraq from attacking Israeli cities with atomic bombs similar to the type dropped on Hiroshima during World War II. (Page A1, Column 6.) The United States criticized Israel for the bombing and said that it may have violated its aid agreement by using American-made warplanes in the attack. In the sharpest criticism of Israel yet by the Reagan Administration, the State Department said that ''the unprecedented character'' of the surprise raid ''cannot but seriously add to the already tense situation in the area.'' (A1:5.)

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change to the LIFO method of inventory valuation

title: THE INVISIBLE FLYING CAT
description: THE late Paul Gallico, a distinguished sports journalist and writer of short stories, believed in the vital importance of something he called ''The Feel.'' To acquire ''The Feel'' of one aspect of prizefighting, for instance, Gallico once went into the ring with Jack Dempsey and got knocked flat. As a result, he wrote, ''I knew all that there was to know about being hit.''

title: LIZ HOLTZMAN COULD RUN AGAINST KOCH
description: To the Editor:

title: ELEANOR MORRIS THACHER
description: Eleanor Morris Thacher, who was active in civic and charitable work in New York City and Philadelphia, died Friday at her Chestnut Hill home in Philadelphia. She was 99 years old.

title: COAL MINERS' STRIKE ENDS AMID SCATTERED CONSTRUCTION WORKER PICKETING
description: Most of the 160,000 striking coal miners returned to work today amid scattered incidents of picketing by mine construction workers, whose separate contract is still in negotiation here.

title: Continental Air Takeover Fight
description: Texas International Airlines said today that it had asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to block a plan by Continental Air Lines employees to buy control of Continental until the C.A.B. has ruled on the employee stock ownership plan.

title: No Headline
description: Eddie Mae Wyatt was one of seven children born to parents who picked cotton for a living. ''They made a dollar a day plus dinner,'' Mrs. Wyatt recalled, ''and we all went to school with notes saying we had to be let out at noon so we could go to work in the fields.''

title: The Region; Driver in Death of 3 Ruled Unfit for Trial
description: Robert Kabolowsky, who was charged with killing three persons last year in Wantagh while at the wheel of a stolen car, was found mentally unfit to stand trial.

title: Money Market Fraud Alleged
description: An employee of a Washington-based money market mutual fund managed to steal $1.55 million in a bank wire fraud scheme, court papers uncovered today alleged.

title: CHANGING SAN FRANCISCO IS FORESEEN AS A HAVEN FOR WEALTHY AND CHILDLESS
description: Soaring housing costs, urban violence, shifting ethnic patterns and an increase in childless adults living together may be turning San Francisco, which the Chamber of Commerce likes to call ''everybody's favorite city,'' into a haven for the young, the old, the wealthy and the childless.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Abitibi-Price Inc. agreed to sell its fine paper mill at Thorold, Ontario, to Fraser Inc. for an undisclosed price.

title: Notes On People; Why Cole Porter's 90th Birthday Is Celebrated Now
description: In his Yale class book he listed his birth date as June 9, 1893, and most standard reference works say he was born in 1892. So why have a number of singers jumped on the bandwagon this week to celebrate Cole Porter's 90th birthday?

title: POLICE TRY RECORDINGS IN '911' CALLS
description: For the first time, starting today, some callers to New York City's police 911 number who do not have an emergency to report may be switched by a dispatcher to a recorded announcement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amfac Inc., Honolulu, has named Jerry L. Dugan president of its Amfac Electric Supply Company.

title: Steel Output Off 0.1%
description: Steel production fell to 2.487 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of one-tenth of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.49 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: CALIFORNIA PORTLAND CEMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $9,000 for t and $273,000 for the yr and $7,688,000 extraordinary credit for yr on the sale of securities...C-After $3,173,000 extraordinary from the settlement of an antitrust suit; shr earnings have bee for a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid on June 15; the yr ago rev restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: No Headline
description: Roger Neilson, the Buffalo Sabres' former head coach, was named today as associate coach of the Vancouver Canucks for next season and will become head coach for the 1982-83 season.

title: Mexico-Portugal Oil Pact
description: The Mexican state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, has reached preliminary agreement to supply Portugal with 10,000 barrels of crude oil a day starting in August, company officials said today. The state company, generally known as Pemex, said the contract will last until the end of this year and will then be replaced by a long-term contract.

title: Phillips Collection's Art Traveling to 4 Museums
description: The Phillips Collection, the first museum of modern art in the United States, has announced that 75 of its master paintings would be seen in four American museums during the next 18 months in a traveling exhibition.

title: Mummified Cats as Offerings
description: At the end of the last century, excavations at Bubastis and other Egyptian sites produced so many mummified cats that they were shipped out by the boatload, either as ballast or to be spread on fields as fertilizer. Yet, according to two researchers from the British Museum (Natural History), there have been only modest efforts to examine the mummies and explain their vast numbers.

title: ERO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $20,000 gain from discontinued operations and $7,000 tax credit

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $113,000 income for the qr and $412,000 loss for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $74,000 for the qr and $58,000 for the 9 mos; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: 2 SENATORS GIVEN 100,000 LETTERS OPPOSING TUITION TAX-CREDIT PLAN
description: More than 100,000 form letters opposing Federal tuition tax credits for parents of children in private schools were delivered yesterday to the Manhattan offices of New York's two United States Senators.

title: Plane Lands Safely on Road
description: A small plane lost power in one engine on takeoff near downtown Dallas today, but the pilot, Bob Starr, managed to land safely on a big traffic island, then skid harmlessly down a busy thoroughfare, according to the co-pilot, Bob McMillan. He told witnesses that the plane, leased to U.S. Air Transit to carry unprocessed film to Oklahoma City, was about 200 feet above Love Field when it began swerving to the right. Mr. Starr headed for it for the traffic island. ''We made it here, the only safe place to go,'' Mr. McMillan said.

title: Not-Guilty Plea in Trail Killings
description: A convicted sex offender suspected of killing hikers on Northern California trails pleaded not guilty today in two fatal shootings and a wounding.

title: The Region; Jersey High Court Backs Public Prayer
description: TRENTON (AP) - The State Supreme Court today upheld as constitutional the practice of opening public meetings with a prayer. The court rejected a challenge by Paul Marsa, an atheist from Metuchen, who contended that an invocation, prayer or silent meditation at the beginning of Borough Council meetings involved the local government in establishing a religion.

title: BASEBALL COMPENSATION IMPASSE CONTINUES
description: With the judge's decision on an injunction request due this week, the parties in baseball's compensation dispute failed again yesterday to move toward a negotiated settlement.

title: Saudis Devalue Riyal
description: Saudi Arabia devalued its riyal to 3.40 to the United States dollar from 3.39, effective immediately, the Saudi Arabian monetary agency said today.

title: MORE OIL PRICE CUTS SEEM LIKELY AS GLOBAL OVERSUPPLY CONTINUES
description: Day after day, reductions in the price of crude oil have been shaking the already unsettled world petroleum markets. And further price erosion seems inevitable, oil analysts and oil company officials said yesterday.

title: U.S. AND STATES MOVE ON PROGRAM TO PROTECT TAHOE
description: In 1969, Ronald Reagan hailed a new compact between California and Nevada as ''the vehicle whereby men of good will can resolve the environmental problems facing Lake Tahoe.'' He was so moved by these problems as to coin a word to capsule them: ''despoilization.''

title: 'Wally's Cafe' to Open Friday
description: ''Wally's Cafe,'' the play by Sam Bobrick and Ron Clark starring James Coco, Rita Moreno and Sally Struthers, will have its opening Friday at 6:30 P.M. at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. The comedy, directed by Fritz Holt, was delayed when Mr. Coco became ill. He returned to the cast last night.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ASENIOR vice president of the Bank of America in San Francisco once told a group of school superintendents: ''Dream with me for a minute. Suppose we had a million-dollar pot.''

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Figure in Wells Fargo Suit Held For Extradition in Forgery Case
description: The boxing promoter Ross Fields, also known as Harold J. Smith, was ordered held without bail today pending extradition to North Carolina to face forgery charges.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
REPUBLIICANS CONSIDER 2 AS KOCH'S RUNNING MATES
description: A real-estate man from Manhattan and an Assemblyman from the Bronx are likely to be Mayor Koch's running mates on the Republican line, politicians said yesterday.

title: CITY PLACES COST OF DISREGARDING GENERIC DRUG LAW AT $10 MILLION
description: Consumers may have paid $10 million more than they had to for prescription drugs last year because the state's generic-drug law was not complied with, New York City's Commissioner for Consumer Affairs charged yesterday.

title: AT CITY DAY CAMPS, BUSY DAYS,N09
description: Registration is under way for a variety of summer day-camp programs in New York City. In its 110th day-camp season, the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue (53d Street), offers a blend of gymnastics and the arts for children 3 to 12 years old, as well as an intensive gymnastics course for those 7 to 12. All children take swimming lessons. There is also a daily gymnastics workshop for those 13 to 16.

title: The Sparrow Circus
description: Chipping sparrows like to line their nests with horsehair. If a farmer has no horses, they will sometimes pull hair out of his cowdog as it sleeps in the yard.

title: FOX FILM MERGER SET
description: Shareholders of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation approved by a wide margin today the $800 million acquisition of the diversified entertainment concern by Marvin Davis, the Denver oil millionaire.

title: TEAMSTERS' LAWYER CITES ROLE IN I.C.C. NOMINATION
description: A Washington lawyer who represents the International Brotherhood of Teamsters before the Interstate Commerce Commission said today that he had been instrumental in the selection of Reese H. Taylor Jr. as President Reagan's nominee for the chairmanship of the I.C.C.

title: Smith a Padre Consultant
description: The San Diego Padres have hired Tal Smith, the former Houston Astro general manager, as a consultant. Smith was dismissed last October after Houston had won the first division title in its 19 years. He recently formed a consulting firm.

title: No Headline
description: Rod Gilbert's 21-year association with the New York Rangers, for whom he produced more goals, assists and total points than any other player, has quietly ended in the club's housecleaning.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for 10 weeks to May 23
SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: A Field Guide to the Atmosphere By Vincent J. Schaefer and John A. Day. 359 pages, illustrated. Houghton Mifflin, Boston. $13.95.

title: PANELS DEEPEN REAGAN MEDICARE CUTS
description: Two key Congressional panels have gone beyond President Reagan's proposals and voted substantial cuts in Medicare programs, which aid the elderly.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Comdisco Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed offering of $50 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2001.

title: U.S. Orders Exxon Refund
description: The Department of Energy said today that it had issued a proposed remedial order calling for the Exxon Corporation's United States subsidiary, the Exxon Company, to refund $70.2 million, plus interest, to settle an overpricing action.

title: Softball And Democracy
description: There are days when one has to step back from weighty discussions of taxes and crime and potholes and the tragicomedy of politicians in election heat to seek relief and possibly reflection.

title: Natomas Oil Flow
description: The Natomas Company said that its Farida No.4 well in Indonesia's Sumatra contract area had flowed oil in two tests, confirming a 10th oilfield in the area. The well flowed at a cumulative rate of 3,303 barrels daily, the company said.

title: POLITICS AN ISSUE IN TEXAS DISPUTE
description: AUSTIN, Tex. IF it had not been for Kathleen Kelleher, what some people see as the latest chapter in a continuing controversy over academic freedom at the University of Texas might never have burst into the open.

title: Chicago Fare Hike Barred; Taxi Drivers Go on Strike
description: The Illinois Supreme Court today temporarily set aside a Circuit Court order that could have forced Chicago to raise fares to maintain bus and train service, and about 3,000 union taxicab drivers went on strike, adding to the city's transit problems.

title: Indonesia Coal Mining
description: The Indonesian Government will allow open coal mining to be opened to private companies, including joint ventures with foreign partners, the Mines and Energy Ministry said today.

title: MOORE, A PITCHER, NO. 1 IN DRAFT
description: The Seattle Mariners, who had the worst record in baseball last season, went for pitching help in the draft of amateur players yesterday, making Mike Moore, a right-hander from Oral Roberts University, the first selection.

title: Environmental Suit Filed Against MX Missile System
description: Opponents of the MX missile, led by two Utah state senators, filed suit today accusing the Air Force and other Government agencies of violating environmental regulations in developing plans to deploy the weapons system in Utah and Nevada.

title: TV: BEHIND THE GLITTER OF THE TONY AWARDS SHOW
description: ELIZABETH TAYLOR didn't win a Tony but she very nearly stole the show at the Mark Hellinger Theater Sunday evening as she prepared to hand out the award for best musical. Reading off the long list of nominated producers, Miss Taylor proceeded to mangle names with a good-natured grace that brought a welcome note of ''real people'' to the formal proceedings. As is usual in these affairs, she went on a bit too long. She managed, however, to keep the audience charmed.

title: CROWDUS BAKER, EX-SEARS OFFICER
description: Crowdus Baker, who capped a 40-year career at Sears, Roebuck & Company with the presidency of the company in the 1960's, died Saturday in a convalescent home in Deerfield, a Chicago suburb. A resident of Northfield, Ill., he was 75 years old.

title: CONSERVATIVE PRESIDENT RE-ELECTED BY SOUTHERN BAPTIST CONVENTION
description: The Rev. Bailey Smith, a conservative Oklahoma preacher, was re-elected as president of the Southern Baptist Convention today in a contest that many viewed as a further sign of the growing impact of fundamentalism in American churches.

title: WASHINGTON HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Metropolitan Diary
description: LOIS GOULD was walking on 56th Street west of Fifth Avenue the other day when she encountered a curious message written on a chalkboard outside a bar and restaurant. The establishment is called Food Among the Flowers and the sign said: ATTITUDE ADJUSTMENT HOUR 3 to 7:30 P.M.

title: WRITERS AWAIT NEW FILM OFFER
description: A major breakthrough in the eight-week-old Hollywood writers' strike is expected late today or tomorrow when the producers present a new proposal in the thorny area of pay television.

title: Business People; GRAND UNION PRESIDENT
description: James J. McCaig, 36, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Grand Union Company, an 855-unit chain of supermarkets based in Elmwood Park, N.J. As president, he succeeds Patrick A. Deo, 50. Mr. Deo, who has been appointed chairman, will continue as chief executive officer of the company, a unit of Cavenham Ltd. of Britain.

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
BUCK WILLIAMS SAYS HE'S A TEAM PLAYER
description: Buck Williams was doubly delighted yesterday to wind up with the New Jersey Nets, the team of his choice, and to be the third player selected in the college draft.

title: Jerome Ellison, Author And Ex-Collier's Editor
description: Jerome Ellison, author and former managing editor of Collier's, died yesterday in the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 73 years old.

title: REFUGEE & ALSO-RANS; Basques' Exit
description: A silly old line warns about the danger of putting too many Basques in one exit. It has a sour meaning these days for Spain's democratic leaders as they struggle against a tiny army of Basque separatists.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including gains of $18.5 million for the qr and $27.8 million for the 9 mos from dispositions of investments in securities an net losses of $16.9 million for the qr and $19.2 million for th 9 mos reflecting provisions for the closing or sale of unprofit or marginally unprofitable operations; yr-ago shr earnings are presented on a comparable basis reflecting subsequent conversio of convertible debentures

title: RESCUE MASS TRANSIT BUT GO EASY ON THE TAXPAYER;
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE BANKING COMMITTEE REJECTS CURB ON RENT CONTROLS
description: The House Banking Committee today rejected a Senate-passed proposal to withhold Federal subsidies to localities that impose rent controls on new housing or on housing that becomes vacant.

title: NEW CHIEF OF MANHATTAN G.O.P. IS BULLISH ON HIS JOB Republican candidate
description: After taking his five-mile morning jog through Central Park and before driving to Albany to attend a meeting of the State Senate, Roy M. Goodman paused in his Fifth Avenue apartment the other day to talk about reviving the Republican Party in Manhattan.

title: Going Out Guide
description: 90, LIKE NEW

title: AT THE GREAT WALL, CHINESE TOURISTS JOIN THE CRUSH
description: When the 14th foreign tourist group in five days arrived at the Suan Feng Tea Production Brigade shortly after lunch today, San Mei Juen put on her winning smile, served tea and began reciting production statistics. But she had xuexi in her eyes.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 16.832 percent was set yesterday at its auction of 91-day commercial paper, compared with 17.320 percent last week.

title: 1,074 RECEIVE DEGREES IN PRINCETON TRADITION
description: Princeton University today awarded bachelor's degrees to 1,074 members of the class of 1981 at the university's 234th commencement.

title: Notes on People; Memory of Casals Honored at His Birthplace
description: He died in 1973, but Pablo Casals continues to be honored, particularly in the Spanish province of Catalonia, where he was born. Over the weekend, in Vendrell, the small town in which the legendary cellist was born and is buried, his widow, Marta Casals Istomin, took part in the dedication of a new 500-seat Pablo Casals Auditorium.

title: Trial in Kidnapping of Two Boys Who Later Fled Begins on Coast
description: Kenneth Parnell, the drifter accused of kidnapping two young boys seven years apart for sexual purposes went to court yesterday for trial in one of the cases.

title: Deregulation Betrayed
description: ''I am not a political payoff ... I was not chosen by the Teamsters,'' says Reese Taylor, President Reagan's nominee to head the Interstate Commerce Commission. But that is only Mr. Taylor's opinion. Others, including one of the union's lawyers, believe the Teamsters' blessing had more than a little influence on the selection.

title: FREE BANKING ZONES AUTHORIZED AS LURE TO FOREIGN BUSINESS
description: The Federal Reserve Board today authorized banks to set up facilities in the United States to compete for much of the international banking business that now goes to London, Singapore, Nassau and other foreign banking centers.

title: LAWYER, 34, IS NAMED FOR INVESTIGATIVE POST BY TRANSIT AUTHORITY
description: The New York City Transit Authority has established a new office to uncover any corruption, incompetence or waste and has appointed a former deputy counsel of the State Investigation Commission to head it.

title:
RED SMITH;
Brucker of A's
description: WHEN Connie Mack sent Earle Brucker his first contract as a catcher for the Philadelphia Athletics, Brucker wrote back that although it had long been his dream to play ball in the major leagues, he owed it to his family to stay in the minors, where he could earn a decent living. ''Why, that Bruck,'' Connie said afterward. ''He was a holdout the first year I got him!''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: F.T.C. Forces Sale Of Kennecott Unit
description: The Kennecott Corporation has agreed to sell a division that makes industrial air pollution-control equipment after the Federal Trade Commission alleged antitrust violations, the F.T.C. announced today.

title: Option Trading Power Is Cited
description: Philip Johnson, newly appointed chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, said today that the commission had clear jurisdiction over all financial instrument options.

title: MCDERMOTT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
2 Pitching Sensations At White House Lunch
description: President Reagan, a Hall of Fame pitcher in the movies, today met Fernando Valenzuela, a rookie pitching sensation from Mexico who has Los Angeles Dodger fans predicting that he, too, will make it to Cooperstown.

title: SCHOOLS ENDING CHAPTER IN U.S. DESEGREGATION SAGA
description: Schools closed here and in numerous other school districts around the country today, completing another chapter in the history of efforts to desegregate the nation's public schools.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA AND U.S. REACH INTEGRATION ACCORD
description: South Carolina and the United States Department of Education reached an oral agreement yesterday on the state's $19.5 million desegregation plan for state colleges and universities.

title: REDS GET 4 IN NINTH AND BEAT METS BY 8-4
description: The Mets showed all their strange flair for pursuit and selfdestruction last night when they made four errors, surrendered four runs in the ninth inning and lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 8-4.

title: Barclay Menthol Marketing Set
description: The big spenders at Brown & Williamson Tobacco are giving their well-pampered and successful new cigarette brand, Barclay, a brother later this month. It will be called Barclay Menthol - another ultralow-tar brand.

title: PANEL WARNS L.I. POLICIES MAY IMPERIL WATER SUPPLY
description: A state legislative commission warned today that haphazard practices, particularly the disposal of solid wastes in landfills and imprudent land use, might damage Long Island's entire water supply.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 10, 1981
description: International Israel defended its bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor, with Prime Minister Menachem Begin saying that ''Israel will use all of the possibilities at its disposal'' to halt other attempts by its enemies to make weapons of mass destruction. ''There won't be another holocaust in history,'' he said at a news conference. ''Never again, never again.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) The White House is working to decide what to do about Israel if it finds and reports to Congress within 48 hours that the Israelis violated their aid agreement by using American-made warplanes in its attack on Sunday against Iraq's nuclear reactor. An arms embargo, one of the available options, could threaten Israel's security. But to do nothing might cause the Administration to lose credibility with the Arabs, a senior official said. (A12:1-2.)

title: Bob Herget, 56, Choreographer, Director of Stage and TV Shows
description: Bob Herget, a director and choreographer, died Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 56 years old. Mr. Herget began his career as a dancer on Broadway in ''Allegro,'' ''High Button Shoes'' and ''Lend an Ear.''

title: Notes on People
description: McG. Thomas Jr.The Boswell Sisters Live On in a New Musical

title: ATTACK COMPLICATES NEW REAGAN POLICY
description: Israel's decision to destroy an Iraqi nuclear reactor has introduced a new complication into the Reagan Administration's effort to formulate a policy intended to prevent the spread the nuclear weapons.

title: BREZHNEV DENIES ARMS-TALK GAIN
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that the United States had taken no concrete steps to resume talks on arms control.

title: THE ABUNDANT VARIETIES FROM FRANCE
description: CHEVRE, that tangy, aromatic cheese formed from pure goat's milk, is suddenly in vogue. As if out of nowhere, a staggering and mysterious variety of chevres have appeared on the scene, replacing Brie as the imported cheese in demand. Why the popularity? There are a range of reasons. In the United States, at least, economics is one of them. Since the beginning of last year, quotas have been imposed on all imported cheeses, except for soft - ripened products such as Brie and Camembert, and except for 100-percent goat, sheep or buffalo milk cheese, which provide virtually no competition to American cheese makers. The French, who produce almost all of the world's goat cheese, have been quick to encourage export, while importers have been quick to capitalize on the opportunity to offer Americans something new and different.

title: TV: SCOFIELD IN 'THE AMBASSADORS'
description: Henry James, long a frustrated playwright, has been served surprisingly well by television dramatizations of ''The Golden Bowl'' and ''The Spoils of Poynton,'' not to mention the lovely film version of ''The Europeans.'' On public television, though, the lucky James streak runs out with a rather wretched adaptation of ''The Ambassadors.''
