title: COLGATE W. DARDEN JR. DIES
description: Colgate W. Darden Jr., a former Governor of Virginia and president of the University of Virginia, died yesterday at his home in Norfolk, Va. He was 84 years old.

title: ROSE MOVES WITHIN A HIT OF MUSIAL'S MARK
description: With two hits against the Houston Astros tonight, Pete Rose moved within one of Stan Musial's record for most hits in the National League. Rose, the 40-year-old first baseman for the Philadelphia Phillies, knows that sooner rather than later he will surpass Musial's total of 3,630. But when, and against which pitcher?

title: Hunt Oil Says Financing Is Not for Use of Brothers
description: Four new cash-raising agreements totaling $436 million, announced yesterday by financiers for the Hunt Oil Company, have ''nothing to do'' with recent business transactions by the Hunt brothers, officials of Hunt family businesses said yesterday.

title: EX-GOVERNOR OF TENNESSEE AND 2 AIDES CONVICTED IN LIQUOR LICENSE CASE
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee was convicted in Federal District Court tonight of extortion, conspiracy and mail fraud in the alleged sale of liquor store licenses during his administration.

title: EFFIES AND CLIOS AWARDED
description: IT was a big awards day yesterday for Doyle Dane Bernbach, which at a luncheon picked up four Clio statuettes for creativity in its print work and then last night took two gold Effies (one being one of two Grand Prizes) and three silver certificates for advertising effectiveness.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
MANY DEMOCRATS FROM 'SAFE' DISTRICTS FACE HOUSE REDISTRICTING THREAT IN '82
description: Population losses in big cities have left Republican Congressmen with constituencies larger than those now held by Democrats and will compel redistricting changes that threaten dozens of ''safe'' Democratic seats in the House of Representatives, according to a detailed, district-by-district study released yesterday by the Census Bureau.

title: SONG: 'RODGERS & HAMMERSTEIN'
description: ''THE Sounds of Rodgers and Hammerstein, Part II,'' the latest in the King Cole Room's salutes to Broadway, is a 26-song revue that finds a workable balance between a dramatic and a cabaret setting for one of the most beloved catalogues in modern popular music. Like other programs in the King Cole series, it also offers a revealing overview of an important long-term theatrical collaboration.

title: Hampton at Seaport Museum
description: Lionel Hampton and his orchestra will perform tonight at 7:30 o'clock at the South Street Seaport Museum, Fulton Street and the East River.

title: SPECTRA-PHYSICS HITS A SNAG IN PROFITS FROM LASER SYSTEMS
description: During the 1960's, few technological advances captured the imagination like the laser beam. Here was a device that would send messages into space, pierce diamonds, and - one might have thought - strongly affect American industry.

title: 1982 ELECTION IS A FACTOR IN TAX-CUT MANEUVERING
description: In one of his innumerable meetings with the press, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House of Representatives, said, ''This ball game ends on the first Tuesday of November of 1982, and that's what we're gearing up to.''

title: About New York
description: There are a number of things that give New Yorkers a sense of well-being. One is passing a long queue at a token booth with a token already in pocket. Another is entering a crosstown bus in July that has seats to spare and air-conditioning. A third, and, naturally, the most important, is seeing a police officer walking a beat.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Burroughs Reducing Computer Facilities
description: The Burroughs Corporation said it will close its computer-systems plant at Goleta, Calif., on Friday and will reduce employment at three Michigan plants and at Carlsbad, Calif.

title: The City; No Water for 5 Days In a Tudor City Unit
description: Residents of a building on Manhattan's East Side have been without regular water service for five days because of problems with pumping equipment in their 15-story building, according to United Press International.

title: RAIDERS UNDETECTED BY U.S. RADAR PLANE
description: The United States was unaware of the Israeli air strike into Iraq until four hours after it took place, despite the presence of American radar planes in Saudi Arabia and other intelligence resources in the region, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Best Buys; FAMILY FOOD COSTS INCREASE BY A PENNY
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four rose by a penny to $103.87 in the two-week period of May 25 to June 5, according to the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid $9.32 more for food than in the corresponding period last year.

title: KNICKS GET NETS' NEWLIN FOR WOODSON
description: The Knicks went into yesterday's draft of college players without a first-round choice and thus with little hope of acquiring the truly dominant power forward they have long sought. But they did have a new shooting guard.

title: Timken to Acquire Perkins Ohio Plant
description: The Timken Company, a producer of roller bearings and rock bits that is based in Canton, Ohio, said it had signed an agreement to purchase a plant in Canton owned by the Perkins Diesel Corporation, a subsidiary of Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the Canadian agricultural and industrial machinery manufacturer.

title: Portuguese Enact Law on Terror Despite Opposition From Leftists
description: Parliament last night approved antiterrorist legislation proposed by the ruling Democratic Alliance despite opposition protests that it would limit fundamental rights.

title: IRRELEVANT STATISTIC
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PREPARES TO EXPEL 76 HAITIANS AFTER FINDING RIGHTS WERE HEEDED
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it had reviewed last week's hearings on 76 Haitians in this country and would expel them as soon as travel documents were issued by the Haitian Government.

title: IFS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After net gains from the sale of property of $88,886 or 3 cen a shr, for the later period and $1.6 million or 47 cents a shr the previous period

title: America Can't Be Colorblind Yet
description: In signaling the Reagan Administration's retreat on affirmative action and school busing, Attorney General Smith says he yearns for the day when the Constitution can be applied in colorblind ways. Who doesn't? But in working toward that day, a humane society simply cannot forget its obligations to the victims of that earlier form of color-consciousness, segregation.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: Yr-ago sales include other income of $503,000

title: Moslem Extremists in Iran Counter a Bani-Sadr Rally
description: Moslem extremists massed outside Teheran University today to prevent an illegal demonstration in support of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr.

title: Newsday Announces Promotions;
description: Schwartz Is the Executive Editor

title: MEXICO'S LEADER ENDS VISIT ON BRIGHT NOTE
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that talks between President Reagan and President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico had produced ''a great deal of progress'' on the Administration's ''guest worker'' plan for Mexicans to work legally in the United States.

title: Arbour Considering Quitting as Coach
description: While the Stanley Cup gleamed in the background, Al Arbour of the Islanders disclosed today that he might step down as head coach, take a year's vacation, and return to the Islanders in another job.

title: RECORD INDUSTRY'S UPHEAVAL
description: In the summer of 1953, Elvis Presley stepped into a studio and recorded his first song, a ballad that helped propel the retail record industry into a multibillion-dollar business and that now describes it perfectly as it enters middle age. The song was called ''That's When Your Heartaches Begin.''

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES STABLE
description: Many traders are expecting a decline soon in short-term interest rates, and their willingness to hold securities in advance of the lower rates helped keep long-term bond prices stable yesterday, while encouraging slightly higher prices for shorter maturities.

title: S.J. PERELMAN IS ABOUT TO HAVE HIS 'LAST LAUGH'
description: By HERBERT MITGANG

title: HOW THE WEST MAKES FRIENDS FOR THE EAST
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistani Air Hijacker Is Hanged
description: A man convicted of attempting to hijack a Pakistani airliner three years ago was executed today, the Government said.

title: Swiss Arrest Suspect in Murder Of Aldo Moro, Ex-Italian Premier
description: A 41-year-old Italian who is wanted in Italy in connection with the 1978 kidnapping and murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was arrested yesterday in Lucerne, Switzerland.

title: U.S. TRYING TO DETERMINE IF ATTACK VIOLATED ACCORD
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they expected to notify Congress formally within 48 hours that Israel may have violated its arms supply agreement with the United States by using American warplanes in its attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: Hunts Accuse Agency on Silver
description: The Hunt family, viewed by many as the main target of a Commodity Futures Trading Commission investigation of price fluctuations in silver early last year, charged late yesterday in Dallas that material in the resulting report supported their claim that prices were manipulated by governors of the commission's board who were attempting to protect their own investments.

title: BANTAM ISSUING A BOOK ON VALENZUELA
description: Bantam Books is taking another step in its Spanish publishing program by issuing a a mass-market paperback about Fernando Valenzuela, the Mexican-born rookie pitcher who has won nine baseball games for the Los Angeles Dodgers so far this season.

title: ALLEN LUDEN DIES
description: Allen Ludden, host of the ''G.E. College Bowl'' and ''Password'' television game shows, died of cancer yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 62 years old.

title: ANATOMY OF AT.&T.'S OFFERING
description: At 4:01 yesterday afternoon, it was settled: the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, whose stock is the most widely held in the world, would proceed today with a offering of its common at $57 a share.

title: The City; Grade Bribe Charged
description: A City College clerk has been charged with accepting a bribe to fix grades, and college officials say an investigation has uncovered about 20 incidents in which grades or transcripts have been altered, United Press International reported.

title: The Region; Connecticut to Install Mrs. Grasso's Statue
description: A statue of Gov. Ella T. Grasso will be installed in the Capitol, Gov. William A. O'Neill announced yesterday.

title: Marsteller in Right Place For National Steel
description: Marsteller's Pittsburgh office has discovered that just being there is half the battle, at least as far as winning the National Steel account goes.

title: Consumers' Confidence Up
description: Consumer confidence in the American economy continued to improve in May for the third consecutive month, the Conference Board, a business research organization, said yesterday in New York.

title: Chowder Skirmish
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In regard to those four chowder recipes (''In Clam Chowder Cook-Off, Battles Are Won but War Rages On,'' June 3), each specifies quahogs, those rounder, hard-shelled clams, which New Englanders know are pronounced ''cohogs.'' Herman Melville, in fact spelled them ''quohogs,'' but he was a New Yorker.

title: RESCUE MASS TRANSIT BUT GO EASY ON THE TAXPAYER
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Lloyd, Despite Injury, Eager to Enter Wimbledon
description: Chris Evert Lloyd said today that ''it would take a broken leg'' to keep her out of the Wimbledon championships starting June 22. A knee injury suffered during the French Open forced her to withdraw from this week's Surrey grass tournament, a tuneup.

title: SERVED 32 YEARS IN COAST GUARD
description: Vice Adm. Harold Conklin Moore, who retired from the Coast Guard in 1959 after 32 years of service, died Friday in the Virginia Beach Hospital at Virginia Beach, Va.

title: Wine Talk; IF A RESTAURANT WINE SEEMS LESS THAN RIGHT
description: THE man was becoming a frequent visitor to Sparks Steak House on Manhattan's East Side, but he was troublesome. He would order an expensive wine each time, then reject it after the first taste and order something else. This was arousing the ire of Pasquale Cetta, the proprietor.

title: SCHRADER, ABE, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Jerusalem And The Bomb
description: The Israeli bombing of the Iraqi nuclear installation raises some general questions about the control of nuclear weapons, and a specific question about how the Reagan Administration will react to it.

title: SON'S JAILING RACKS SOUTH AFRICAN M.P.
description: On his way to Parliament this morning, Alex Boraine stopped by the security police headquarters to ask about his son. Even before he put the question about where his son was being held he knew what the answer would be.

title: CROCKER CONFIRMED IN AFRICA POST
description: The Senate voted, 84 to 7, today to confirm Chester A. Crocker as Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. His nomination had been delayed for 85 days by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina.

title: COMPROMISES ARE OFFERED BY GOVERNOR ON MEDICAID
description: Governor Carey today sent to the State Senate majority leader a list of major compromises on his proposal for the state to take over local Medicaid costs. The majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, Republican of Binghamton, has blocked the plan for months as too costly.

title: Business people
description: Richard J. Loughlin, who is 49 years old, has been appointed president of the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation, a concern based in Irvine, Calif., that franchises real estate brokerages throughout the country. He succeeds James E. Cummings Jr., 38, who resigned last Friday from Century 21, a subsidiary of the Trans World Corporation since 1979.

title: Loews Buying Hotel
description: The Loews Corporation said it had reached tentative agreement to acquire a 600-bed Holiday Inn hotel on the east end of Bermuda, which would bring the Loews chain of hotels to 15.

title: Ford and Toyota Talks
description: The Toyota Motor Company said today that it would not reach agreement on joint production of small cars with Ford Motor this month despite earlier predictions.

title: PHOENIX FINDS THAT BICYCLES CAN GET THE MAIL DELIVERED
description: It's 9:15 A.M. on a Friday, and Bob Hesler, a United States letter carrier, is 30 minutes into his northwest Phoenix delivery route, gliding from mailbox to mailbox on a bicycle.

title: San Francisco Bank Sold
description: C.L. Yip, A Hong Kong businessman, has purchased the Commercial Bank of San Francisco for a price in excess of $10 million, or $24 a share, it was announced today. William A. Meyer, chairman of the bank's board of directors, said Mr. Yip has extensive interests in finance, manufacturing and real estate in Hong Kong.

title: Around the Nation; Handguns Are Outlawed, By a Suburb of Chicago
description: Officials of this Chicago suburb of 24,000 people have voted to outlaw handguns in a move that is expected to touch off a legal battle.

title: Personal Health; WAYS TO REDUCE WEAR AND TEAR ON FEET, THE BODY'S MOST USED PART
description: MILLIONS of Americans who might otherwise heed the advice of health experts to let their feet, rather than their fingers, do the walking are discouraged from doing so by aches and other discomforts in those lowermost appendages. ''My feet are killing me'' may well be the most common health complaint.

title: No Headline
description: Nathaniel J. Palzer, a lawyer in New York for six decades and an early leader in the movement to combat voting fraud, died Sunday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 86 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens.

title: U.S. TELLS SOVIET BIG GRAIN SALES CAN START AGAIN
description: Citing ''an important first step in normalizing grain trade with the Soviet Union,'' the United States paved the way today for additional large grain sales to the Russians over the next few months.

title: Aaron Nussbaum Dead; Started Amnesty League
description: Aaron Nussbaum, the founder of the Amnesty League of America and an assistant district attorney in Kings County for more than 20 years, died Saturday at Coney Island Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: JHIRMACK ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Around the Nation; Top Executives of U.A.W.  Vote to Rejoin Federation
description: Top executives of the United Automobile Workers voted unanimously today to reaffiliate with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations as early as July 1, ending their 13-year separation.

title: WASHINGTON - The Israeli air strike against the Iraqi nuclear reactor near Baghdad demonstrates the grave dangers that are posed by nuclear-arms proliferation in the Middle East. The bold Israeli move eliminates the immediate threat while it adds uncertainty to an always volatile Middle East.
description: But I believe that the Reagan Administration should have tried harder to understand Israeli motives before issuing an unqualified condemnation of the Israeli action.

title: Business People; WHITHER HIRSCHFIELD?
description: The takeover of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation by Marvin Davis, a Denver oil millionaire, that stockholders approved on Monday has set off speculation about the future of one of the film industry's most peripatetic talents, Alan J. Hirschfield.

title: REV. WOLODYMYR GAVLICH
description: The Rev. Wolodymyr Gavlich, pastor of St. George's Ukrainian Catholic Church in the East Village, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: BROWN, PLEASED BY DRAFT, SHAPES LINEUP
description: At 10 minutes before 1 P.M. today, a loud cheer went up in the small room near the Giants Stadium press lounge. Coach Larry Brown of the Nets was deliberating there with Al Menendez, director of player personnel; Bill Blair and Mike Schuler, assistant coaches; Bob MacKinnon, general manager; Alan Cohen, board chairman, and Joe Taub, the team's principal owner.

title: Nu-West May Buy More Cities Service
description: The Nu-West Group Ltd., a Calgary, Alberta, real estate developer and energy concern, said that it might raise its interest in the Cities Service Company of Tulsa, Okla., to 7.8 percent from 7.3 percent through the purchase of up to 480,000 additional shares of Cities Service stock.

title: Bucyk, Mahovlich, Stanley Elected to Hall of Fame
description: Johnny Bucyk and Frank Mahovlich, left wings, and Allan Stanley, defenseman, have been elected to the National Hockey League Hall of Fame. They will be inducted Sept. 9 in Toronto with the former referee John Ashley, whose selection in the builders' category was announced in April.

title: A VETO IS URGED FOR CAREY BOARD ON M.T. A. PACTS
description: Governor Carey today proposed that the Metropolitan Transportation Control Board he is seeking have virtually complete veto power over any labor contract negotiated between the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Transport Workers Union next year.

title: Win, Place and Sue
description: Scientists, like everyone else, are motivated by more than the search for truth. They lust after reward and recognition and frequently dispute the credits that are distributed.

title: Navy's '81 Captain Resigns
description: Jon Ross, a three-year letter man and co-captain of Navy's football squad for next season, resigned from the academy today after he was found guilty of cheating on an examination, academy officials said. Ross, 21 years old, a native of Phoenix, Ariz., who played as a defensive back and returned kicks, was found guilty of violating the academy's honor code by having handwritten notes in the text of a book being used in a final examination in one of his courses this past semester.

title: MURPHY, G C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: HOLMES AIMS TO STOP SPINKS BUT SETS HIS SIGHTS ON RETIREMENT
description: It beats driving trucks or washing cars, which Larry Holmes has also done, but after a while, when a man wants to quit working, being heavyweight champion is like any job that goes on and on with no end in sight.

title: The U.N. Today; June 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: United Nations Development Pro- gram Governing Council - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I am always mystified when I read recipes that call for half a chicken breast. After skinning and boning, one is often instructed to split or halve the breasts. My wife insists that ''cutting in half'' means slicing the breasts horizontally while holding the knife parallel to the cutting surface. Is she correct?

title: Why Make a Good Co-op Law Worse?
description: Everyone hates to pay rent, most of all more rent than the month before. That proposition is obvious to lawmakers. Inevitably, therefore, as more cities with significant apartment populations try rent control, the fear of it pushes the owners to try to sell. But the same fear discourages professional buyers. And so there is a nationwide swing toward converting rental apartments to cooperatives or condominiums, in which the residents are left to cope with rising costs.

title: NEW CHINA PACT PUSHED IN SENATE
description: The Reagan Administration called today for Senate ratification of the first treaty to be negotiated with China since full diplomatic relations between Peking and Washington were established in 1979.

title: JERSEY OPPOSES CASINO LICENSE FOR WEBB CORP
description: New Jersey's Attorney General asked the Casino Control Commission today to deny the Claridge casino a permit to open in Atlantic City.

title: ARTIST CHUCK CLOSE: 'I WANTED TO MAKE IMAGES THAT KNOCK YOUR SOCKS OFF'
description: CHUCK CLOSE'S giant mug shots are done on such a scale that they might be called facescapes, with every pore and wrinkle appearing as a geologic incident. Their Rolleiflex fidelity is achieved not with a camera, however, but with paint. As casual as passport photos, and chummily titled with such names as ''Phil,'' ''Bob,'' ''Kent,'' ''Leslie'' and ''Linda,'' the billboard-size images have made their creator, a 41-year old painter from Monroe, Wash., an idol of the Photo-Realist movement.

title: People
description: * Donald Dillon has been appointed president of McCann-Erickson Worldwide's Philippines operation based in Manila.

title: NEW YORK AREA REPRIEVE BY CONGRESS ON $15 MILLION IN AID
description: New York City and the metropolitan area are once again in line to reap more than $15 million in Federal grants for projects that had been frozen by the Reagan Administration and were in danger of being killed.

title: And Sausage on The Side
description: Building the MX Pentagon system, friends, is not all cakes and ale. Here, for example, is a letter just arrived from the White House. ''Could you explain more clearly what your MX Pentagon system is? Does it have something to do with the MX missile system?'' ''Dear Mr. President,'' I have answered, ''How many times do I have to explain the MX Pentagon before it gets through? The MX missile system will keep H-bombs in motion through Southwestern deserts to confuse the Russians, right? What is the point of keeping our bombs in motion if our Pentagon is left like a sitting duck on the Potomac? So what do we propose? We will build 250 fake Pentagons so like the real Pentagon that a Russian can't tell the real from the bogus.

title:
Notes On People;
Shhh, Zoo Partygoers, Don't Disturb the Babies!
description: This is how 2,000 people became displaced by four kittens: For two years, the date of tonight's semiannual benefit for the Bronx Zoo and the New York Aquarium had been set. A ''Salute to Noah'' theme had been selected; the band and caterer hired, and the tickets sold, all 1,000 of them.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apache Corporation, Minneapolis, has named Albert B. Perlin senior vice president and general counsel.

The two plaintiffs, the Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation, now a division of Schlumberger Ltd., and the Digidyne Corporation, a small privately held San Diego computer maker, had asked for a combined total of approximately $100 million in damages, which, under Federal antitrust law, would be tripled to $300 million. description: THE nomenclature of various dishes is fascinating, for things are, to borrow a phrase, seldom what they seem. There is a crisp puffpastry dessert called pig's ears; a Mont Blanc is a ''mountain'' of pureed chestnuts; and eggs in the snow, or les oeufs a la neige, are poached meringues floating in a vanilla custard.

title: THEATER: 'KEY EXCHANGE' BY KEVIN WADE AT THE WPA
description: EVEN if its cast did not contain that smart and pretty actress Brooke Adams, there would still be several good reasons to see ''Key Exchange,'' a modest new romantic comedy at Off Off Broadway's WPA Theater. Look away from Miss Adams for a moment - admittedly not an easy task - and you will notice that her two co-stars, Ben Masters and Mark Blum, are just as disarming as she is. Listen carefully to the quiet, off-hand dialogue, and you'll discover that Kevin Wade, the playwright, has some wise observations to make about being in love and 30-ish in present-day New York. This is a tiny play - it has the ambling, anecdotal quality of a New Yorker short story - but it does what it wants to do extremely well.

title: BALLET: CYNTHIA GREGORY AND BUJONES IN 'QUIXOTE'
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV'S restaging of Marius Petipa's ''Don Quixote'' made a jolly return to the American Ballet Theater repertory Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the performances of Cynthia Gregory and Fernando Bujones in the leading roles of Kitri and Basil were nothing short of sensational. In fact, they were so sensational that they even prompted a rather perverse question. Can dancing be too brilliant?

title: IRAQI REPRISAL: FEW OPTIONS
description: Iraq's options for effective retaliation to the Israeli raid on its nuclear reactor near Baghdad appear extremely limited. But United States and NATO military analysts, as well as some Arab military sources, believe Iraq is unlikely to accept the humiliation of the attack without attempting some form of reprisal. The possibility that reprisal action might lead to a another Arab-Israeli war is a major concern. A related issue is whether the Israelis intend to establish a nuclear monopoly in the Middle East.

title: Turk Slain on Geneva Street; Armenian Suspect Arrested
description: A Turkish diplomat was shot and killed on a downtown street today.

title: Curly Endive Salad With Bacon, Goat Cheese and Walnuts
description: This is a variation of the traditional French salade frisee aux lardons, prepared with frizzy-tipped chunks of French-style bacon, or lardons, and plenty of vinegar. Try to find slab bacon if you can, otherwise use the best quality thin-sliced bacon you can find. Any moderately firm goat cheese can be used, such as Montrachet or Bucheron. 6 ounces slab bacon, cut into 1/2-inch cubes 1 quart fresh greens, washed and dried (use either curly endive or a combination that might include curly endive, watercress, arugula and red-tipped lettuce) 1/4 cup red wine vinegar 1/2 cup olive oil (or to taste) 4 ounces moderately firm goat cheese, with rind trimmed, cut into 1/2-inch cubes 3/4 cup walnut halves Freshly ground pepper to taste.

title: SECRETARY OF STATE HELMS
description: During the election campaign, Republicans attacked the Carter Administration for its inability to state and follow a coherent, effective foreign policy. They charged, correctly, that such a policy was not possible so long as the Administration continually changed its foreign policies to placate domestic political constituencies. Yet the Reagan Administration already appears to have fallen into the same trap. Nowhere is this more evident than in the growth of Senator Jesse Helms's power and the influence he has been able to exercise in foreign policy.

title: BUYING, STORING AND SERVING
description: THE best goat cheese is found in specialty shops, where a careful buyer has done some preselecting, and where the salespeople can give some knowledgeable advice. Start sampling with the youngest, freshest chevre you can find, then work toward the increasingly pronouced flavors and aromas. Don't buy more than you will use that day or the next: Chevre is delicate and not for long-term storage. Store at 45 to 50 degrees, the same temperature of most professional aging cellars and of the humid vegetable bin of most refrigerators. Below 45 degrees the cheese will toughen.

title: O'Neill Signs Bill to End Price Floors for Liquors

title: Carbon Dioxide Kills 3 Workers
description: Three men were killed and three others injured today in an accident involving the release of toxic gas from a carbon dioxide firefighting system at the Sun Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here. A spokesman for the parent Sun Company said that the accident occurred at 1 P.M. aboard the S.S. Lash Atlantico in drydock. The dead workers were identified as Alexander Wideman, 53 years old; Fredrick Radtke, 59, and Dominic Lacava Jr., 53.

Checks have been held up since last Thursday, when the state announced that welfare funds had run out because of the lawmakers' refusal to appropriate funds before recessing last week.

title: COUNTRY MUSIC: FLOYD TILLMAN
description: FLOYD TILLMAN is a 66-year-old country-music singer and composer who has enjoyed a few hits as a singer over the last 45 years and even more as a writer, as he watched other artists, both country and pop, ''cover'' his songs. But although hits of any sort haven't come recently, and he even retired a few years ago, Mr. Tillman has been performing recently in Houston and Austin clubs, and last Thursday night he made it all the way up to the Lone Star Cafe for two sets.

title: Discoveries; TELLING TIME, IMPROVING TRAVEL, WARDING OFF THE SUN; 1. A Versatile Wristwatch
description: It does everything but whistle ''Dixie'' and its myriad dials should fascinate a scientific or gadget-minded father. The new BMW Motorsport Chronograph is a wristwatch that tells time in the ordinary way, plus the day of the week and the time digitally. It has an alarm and an hour signal and works as a stopwatch to the split second, and its digital display is said to adjust automatically to the varying lengths of months. The case and band are of stainless steel and the face is gray with white numerals. Apropos, at 575 Madison Avenue (between 56th and 57th Streets) has the watch, priced at $695.

title: 'MESSIDOR,' 2 SWISS HITCHHIKERS
description: JEANNE (Clementine Amouroux) wears her hair cut in the boyish style of Jean Seberg in ''Breathless,'' a film you suspect she has seen more than once. She's a history major at a university in Geneva, bright, caustic, fed up with school and the young man she lives with. Out of boredom she takes to the road. Marie (Catherine Retore), born and brought up in a small Swiss village, has been visiting her father in Lausanne and, en route home, loses her train ticket. Rather than pay twice for the same ride, she begins to hitchhike.

title: James Nelson, 78, a Promoter Of Television and Radio for NBC
description: James Nelson, an advertising and promotion executive in radio and the early days of television, died of a brain tumor Saturday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Atlantic Highlands, N.J

title: F.B.I. STUDIES MISUSE OF DISCOUNT COUPONS
description: Federal agents say they are investigating a nationwide practice, involving up to $250 million, in which grocery stores redeem counterfeit or stolen newspaper coupons.

title: N.B.A. DRAFT: FOR NETS, FIRST ROUND WAS FIRST RATE
description: The Nets, perennial losers in the five seasons since they entered the National Basketball Association, were big winners in yesterday's college draft.

title: Bridge: Preparing for Rain Is Wise, Even When Sun Is Shining
description: The chronic worrier who carries an umbrella on a cloudless day is a subject for ridicule, at least until it rains. The bridge player who guards against an unlikely event earns more respect.

title: OFFICERS CHARGED WITH HIRING OUT TO 'DRUG DEALER'
description: Five New York City police officers were indicted yesterday on charges that they hired themselves out to protect from arrest a man they believed was a drug dealer.

title: American Crew Is Leading In Trans-Atlantic Air Race
description: An American crew flying a fiberglass airplane led the single-engine class tonight as the first fliers finished an 8,000-mile course from Paris to Stratford, Conn., and back again.

title: The Pop Life; KID CREOLE: HE MIXES A HEADY BREW OF STYLES
description: ''I AM a part of all that I have met,'' said August Darnell, quoting Tennyson. Mr. Darnell was born in Montreal, grew up in the Bronx, studied English literature at Hofstra University, was a founding member of Dr. Buzzard's Original Savannah Band and, more recently, has been performing widely, under the alias Kid Creole. And Kid Creole he is. He grew up in neighborhoods where both English and Spanish were spoken and where he was bombarded by all sorts of popular music. Now he is making music that is as much a cultural goulash as New York City, where his band Kid Creole and the Coconuts is a popular club attraction.

title: SALVADORAN REFUGEES PURSUING NEW LIVES
description: In the last year and a half, thousands of Salvadorans have settled in the New York metropolitan area, most of them illegal aliens who consider themselves political refugees from the violence of their native land.

title: Economic Scene; Savings Units: Pressure Grows
description: THE nation's savings and loan associations and other thrift institutions are facing a serious threat to their survival. Unless interest rates come down sharply - and stay down - in the coming year, hundreds of thrift institutions will either have to be rescued by the Federal Government or allowed to go under.

title: No Headline

title: GREECE GIVES U.S. A MONDAY DEADLINE ON BASES PACT
description: Greece has given the United States until next Monday to accept its terms for a new agreement on American bases, according to Foreign Ministry sources.

title: Transway Unit Joins Hidro Gas Venture
description: The Transway International Corporation said that one of its subsidiaries and Hidro Gas, a Mexican liquefied petroleum gas company, had agreed to form a Panamanian company to market liquefied petroleum gas in Central America. The new concern will operate in Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua.

title: More Food Aid Seen for Uganda
description: Crop failure in a drought-stricken northern region of Uganda may require an extension of emergency food aid beyond its August expiration date, relief officials said. They said that no one was starving in the region now, but that another crop failure appeared inevitable.

title: Japan Ex-Im Bank Signs Soviet Loans
description: The Export-Import Bank of Japan signed a contract today to provide the Soviet Union with bank loans totaling $949 million for two Siberian development projects.

title: TRADING IS UP
description: The stock market, despite a cut in the prime rate by a major bank, only managed to end mixed yesterday in stepped-up trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range throughout the session, closed down 0.56 point, to 993.88. At 11 A.M., it was ahead almost 4 points. However, gainers on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered losers by 915 to 647.

title: Notes on People; Miss Taylor Out Again
description: Once again, Elizabeth Taylor has had to cancel some performances of ''The Little Foxes,'' her Broadway hit, because of illness.

description: HOME C10

title: Music Noted in Brief; Cappella Nova Offers A Concert of Des Prez
description: Devoting an entire evening to the music of Josquin des Prez creates immense problems for both performer and audience. In its twohour program, ''Music in Honor of the Virgin Mary'' at St. Joseph's Church on Sunday, the Cappella Nova bore the cumulative stress of Josquin's mazelike weights and counterweights with admirable concentration.

title: TESTED RIDERS TEST THE HINO easier exit, on the Hino bus
description: This is Theresa Perez Abella, with the good news: ''You can actually see the sun! O Hallelujah!'' This is Viola Anderson, with the bad news: ''The seats aren't very wide. There's going to be a problem if you get two fat people.'' Mrs. Abella and Mrs. Anderson delivered their spontaneous assessments yesterday soon after stepping on board a Hino, the Japanesebuilt bus that Governor Carey hopes will help solve some of New York's transit and employment problems at the same time. If tests of two models provided by Hino Motors Ltd. are successful, Mr. Carey will seek a deal for Hino to assemble buses in New York State for local use.

title: KOCH ENTERS BID FOR RE-ELECTION AS 2-PARTY MAN
description: Mayor Koch pledged yesterday to improve city services ''vastly'' as he formally announced his candidacy for the Democratic and Republican nominations for a second term.

description: James B. Williams, 48, has been elected president of the Trust Company of Georgia. The post has been vacant since 1977 when Robert Strickland, 53, became chairman and chief executive officer of the Atlanta corporation.

title: MITTERRAND TO RAISE TAXES ON THE RICH

title: By Sports of The Times; The Baseball Strike Situation
description: NOW that Judge Henry F. Werker has denied the National Labor Relations Board's request for an injunction, a baseball strike appears to be imminent. It's just as well. The issue of free agent compensation has to be decided sooner or later. It might as well be settled now. If an injunction had been ordered, the club owners would have procrastinated for another year, anyway.

title: THE COLLAPSE OF A SMALL REFINER
description: Five years ago, workers here at the oil refinery of Energy Cooperative Inc. were given a new lease on their jobs when the consortium of eight agricultural cooperatives bought the aging complex, an unprepossessing conglomeration of tanks, pipes and smokestacks, from Atlantic Richfield for $80 million.

The missiles would be shuttled among 4,600 hardened shelters, requiring Soviet military planners to target all 4,600 in order to destroy the system.

title: STAGE: KRAFT'S POP SOPHISTICATION
description: based singer, song writer and pianist who appeared last Friday and Saturday at the Bottom Line, is one of several talented entertainers who is unabashedly infatuated with a late-40's image of pop sophistication. Mr. Kraft's songs blend the suave pop stylishness of performers like Peter Allen with the cool, jazz nostalgia of neo-hipsters like Rickie Lee Jones, Tom Waits, and the Manhattan Transfer. And with his devil-may-care stage manner and warm, breathy voice, Mr. Kraft comes very close to embodying an archetype of pop elegance.

description: Daniel Smith's bassoon concert at Carnegie Recital Hall was mostly a set of footnotes to Baroque and Rococo history. The 20th-century touches were Elgar's verdant little Romance for Bassoon and Piano and James Cohn's eclectically Neo-Classic Sonata Robusta; but the workmanlike 18th-century virtues of men such as Graupner, Fasch and Reicha predominated here.

description: Dr. Matthew J. Brozyna, senior surgical attendant at St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic, N.J., died Tuesday at the hospital after a brief illness. He was 65 years old and lived in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: ISRAELIS INSIST AIR RAID ON IRAQIS WAS JUSTIFIED
description: Gradually, and in a spirit of sober satisfaction, Israel is beginning to assess the long-term costs and benefits of its destruction of an Iraqi nuclear reactor. Despite international condemnation, officials and foreign affairs specialists are confident that the air attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor being completed outside Baghdad is receiving quiet applause in many capitals, including those of Arab countries hostile to Iraq. Furthermore, there is some hopeful speculation - admittedly slender - that the dramatic raid may jar some Western countries out of a pattern of willingness to provide technology and fuel to any wealthy Special to the New York Times dictatorship that wants to have its own bomb.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My wood floors were scraped and shellacked, but I am having a problem with them - the finish keeps coming off every time water is dropped on them, including a little water dripping off the dog's beard or a few drops that fall when I water my plants. I have a great deal of furniture, and these are areas that are constantly being walked on, so I cannot have the floors scraped again. I cannot have the floors coated with fresh shellac because I understand that then the floors cannot be walked on for 24 hours. Is there something I can use to strip the finish off and then coat the floors with wax which I can then buff, or do the floors need some kind of sealer? And if so, is there a quick drying one? - R.B., Brooklyn, N.Y.

description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today that the United States, with its huge capacity for food production, has ''one of the most valuable tools in foreign relations that it has ever held.''

title: 'Piaf' May Close At Sunday Matinee
description: ''Piaf,'' starring Jane Lapotaire, will close Sunday afternoon at the Plymouth Theater unless business improves. Only last Sunday, Miss Lapotaire, a British actress making her Broadway debut, won the Tony Award as best actress for her performance as the French chanteuse.

title: GOLDBLATT BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
FRENCH 'CIBISTES' BABBLING AWAY AS THE CB RADIO FAD TAKES HOLD
description: ''Break, break, break. Ici Coconut 3.'' It's not exactly the language of Racine or Corneille, but it is French, sort of. In fact, it is CB language, French style. It means, more or less: ''I want to cut in on your transmission. This is Coconut 3.''

title: The City; U.N. TENANTS DENIED RENT LAW COVERAGE
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled that the city's rent stabilization law did not protect apartments leased by governmental missions to the United Nations because those apartments are not permanent residences.

title: Hers
description: FOR the last few months I have been living without a television. Not out of any highbrow convictions but because, as W.C. Fields used to explain to his movie wives when he came home from a bender, ''Things happened.'' As a result I may be the only person in America who doesn't know who shot J.R.

title: Postmodern Festival Set At the Brookyn Academy
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will produce a festival of postmodern dance, opera and music next season, ''The Next Wave: New Masters at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.''

title: PIONEERED IN TUTORING OF GUIDE DOGS IN U.S.
description: Elliott S. Humphrey, an animal breeder who trained the first guide dogs for the blind used in the United States, died last Saturday at a nursing home in Phoenix. He was 92 years old.

title: Dome Petroleum Bid
description: Jack Gallagher, chairman of Dome Petroleum Ltd. in Calgary, Alberta, said the company had completed the exchange of 22 million shares of Conoco Inc., a major oil concern, together with $245 million in cash, for Conoco's 52 percent interest in the Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company. Earlier, Dome confirmed that it had purchased 22 million Conoco shares for $1.43 billion, out of 54 million tendered, following a $65-a-share tender offer. From the outset of its offer, Dome said it was purchasing the Conoco shares with the aim of exchanging them for the Hudson's Bay oil stock.

title: COSMOS BEAT STRIKERS IN OVERTIME, 2-1
description: The Cosmos defeated the Fort Lauderdale Strikers, 2-1, on a goal by Fran-,cois Van der Elst 4 minutes 3 seconds into sudden-death overtime tonight at Lockhart Stadium.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In responding to this incident we will make clear the seriousness with which we view the obligations of foreign countries to observe scrupulously the terms and conditions under which the United States furnishes defense articles and defense services.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (A14:3.)

title: KANIA AFFIRMS ROLE AS POLAND'S LEADER AFTER SOVIET LETTER
description: Stanislaw Kania, the Polish Communist Party leader, overrode a challenge to his leadership early today during a divisive emergency meeting of the policy-making Central Committee.

title: BRENNAND-PAIGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2.5-for-1 stock split in Oct 1980

title: China Approves U.S. Envoy Before He Is Announced
description: China announced today that it had approved Arthur W. Hummel Jr., a longtime diplomat born in China, as the next United States Ambassador to Peking.

title: BUSINESS SPENDING PLANS PARED
description: Businessmen are reducing their plans for total dollar spending on new buildings and equipment as the nation's recovery from last year's recession slows, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Ex-Soviet Astronaut Sees Need for a Space Shuttle
description: The Soviet space program must develop a low-cost transport vehicle like the American space shuttle Columbia, a former Russian astronaut says.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Corfu Festival to Present Work Honoring Schippers
description: ''Oratorio on the Ode of Pindar,'' a world premiere by Manos Hatzidakis, will open the annual Corfu Festival in Greece next Thursday. Performed by the Greek Radio Orchestra, the work is dedicated to the late Thomas Schippers, conductor of the New York Philharmonic who had a home on the Greek island.

title: Critic's Notebook; A PROFUSION OF BACALLS: WHICH ONE IS MOST FUN?
description: FOR musical-comedy fans, this is the season to be merry. In recent weeks the original cast albums of ''Sophisticated Ladies,'' ''The Pirates of Penzance'' and ''Woman of the Year'' have finally hit the record stores. Pick them all up - as well as the previously released album of ''42d Street'' - and you don't have to leave your house for at least one whole weekend. Unless, that is, you care to listen to ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' or William Finn's score for Off Broadway's ''March of the Falsettos.'' Until these two shows are on record, confirmed addicts will just have to beg, borrow or steal tickets to every performance they can.

title: RAID ON SLOT MACHINES IN PHILADELPHIA PARISH STIRS EMBARRASSMENT
description: Eighteen old but functional slot machines locked up in the headquarters of the Police Department's organized crime team here have become a source of controversy and some embarrassment for a City Councilman, a Roman Catholic parish priest and a reputed gambling figure in organized crime.

title: Bridge: A French Theorist Devises Law for Playing of Trumps
description: One of the most interesting contributions ever made in the difficult area of competitive bidding is called the Law of Total Tricks. It is the invention of a leading French theorist, Jean-Rene Vernes, and can be stated like this: When each side has a good trump fit, the total number of trumps available in those contracts is roughly equal to the total number of tricks available.

title: SAUDIS SET INVESTMENT COMPANY
description: Prince Mohammad al-Faisal al-Saoud of Saudi Arabia announced here today the incorporation in the Bahamas of a holding company named Dar al Maal al Islam, or ''the house of Islamic funds,'' to conduct a wide range of banking, investment and insurance activities with a projected capital of $1 billion.

title: CRITICS' AWARD TO 'ALOES' AND 'CRIMES OF THE HEART'
description: Athol Fugard's ''A Lesson From Aloes'' was chosen as the best new play of the 1980-81 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting yesterday in the Alqonquin Hotel. The critics also named Beth Henley's ''Crimes of the Heart'' as the best new American play and voted not to choose a new musical. Instead, two special citations were awarded - to ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music'' and the New York Shakespeare Festival production of ''The Pirates of Penzance.''

title: U.S. SEEKS PLAN TO AVOID SALES OF BUTTER TO SOVIET
description: At the request of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Reagan has rejected an Agriculture Department recommendation that the United States dispose of its surplus butter in the open market, where it might be purchased by the Soviet Union.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Advetising; Dick and Bert Entries Win Five Clio Awards
description: Dick and Bert, the fabled team of radio commercial creators, far outshone their competition during the last year, if the Clio luncheon yesterday was any indication.

title: Technology; TRADITIONAL LP IS UPGRADED
description: IN the late 1940's, CBS introduced the long-playing record, which became the industry standard. Now it is introducing a system that might help save the LP from becoming obsolete.

title: 4 GOVERNORS IN PACIFIC PROTEST WATT'S SELECTION OF ISLAND AFFAIRS AIDE
description: The governors of Hawaii and three United States dependencies in the Pacific today sent a joint letter to President Reagan and Interior Secretary James G. Watt objecting to the naming of a Caribbean specialist to be the Administration's official in charge of island affairs.

description: HOME C4

title: De Rigueur Guns
description: To talk about gun control is to talk about the urban household handgun, an item whose popularity has expanded dramatically in recent years as fearful city dwellers armed for self-defense.

title: American League; Tigers 4, Twins 2
description: Steve Kemp made three hits, including a home run, and John Wockenfuss hit a bases-empty homer to lead Detroit and help make Jack Morris (9-3) the American League's first nine-game winner.

title: COW BEARS CALF FROM LAB TEST IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: For the first time a cow has given birth to a calf derived from an egg cell fertilized ''in vitro,'' in a laboratory dish. The development clears the way for a new line of experimentation to improve the success rate in this form of human reproduction, which is used to cope with a common form of sterility.

title: BROOKLYN COLLEGE DEAN EMERITUS
description: Dr. Edwin H. Spengler, a dean emeritus and founder of the School of General Studies at Brooklyn College, died Monday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 75 years old.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JUNE 11, 1981; The Economy
description: Another record winter wheat crop was predicted by the Agriculture Department. Production is expected to be 2.01 billion bushels, 6 percent above last year's record crop but 3 percent below last month's estimate. The forecast follows by a day a United States offer to resume grain sales to the Soviet Union. (Page D1.) President Reagan, at the request of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., rejected an Agriculture Department recommendation that surplus United States butter be sold on the open market, where it might be bought by the Soviet Union. (D16.)

title: HOUSE PANEL IS COOL TO 2 BABY-FORMULA PROTESTERS
description: Two former Government officials received a generally unsympathetic hearing when they testified before a House subcommittee today against the recent United States vote opposing a voluntary international code on the marketing of infant formula.

title: CONDUCTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Comparable figures for yr-ago periods are not available since the company was only formed in Sept 1980

title: CLANCY IS STEPPING DOWN AS GARDEN'S MATCHMAKER
description: Gil Clancy resigned yesterday as the boxing matchmaker at Madison Square Garden to work full time as a ringside commentator for CBS.

title: SENATE, 77 to 17, VOTES $1.8 BILLION CUT IN FOOD STAMPS
description: The Senate tonight overwhelmingly approved legislation that would cut $1.8 billion from the food stamp program, the largest Government program aiding needy Americans. Nearly one million of the 11 million people now receiving food stamps would be taken off the rolls, and all of those remaining would get reduced help. The vote was 77 to 17.

title: The City; PROBATIONARY OFFICER CAPTURES 2 ROBBERS
description: Three robbers jumped an off-duty probationary policeman in a Queens building, but the officer fought off a knife attack, shot one of the assailants and captured two, the police said.

title: HOMEMADE PESTICIDES THAT WORK EFFECTIVELY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Wickers is a garden writer who lives in England and the United States. By DAVID WICKERS

title: SOTO STRIKES OUT 12 AS REDS BEAT METS Traveras stand over him
description: The Mets, who have made 71 errors in 50 games, behaved rather respectably in the field for a change last night in Shea Stadium. But they still suffered a 2-0 loss to the Cincinnati Reds because of a pair of unarguable events: a six-hit shutout with 12 strikeouts pitched by Mario Soto and a mammoth home run hit by George Foster.

title: TRUCE EASES STRAINS IN CENTRAL PARK Drive in Central Park
description: Advocates of private cars, taxis, horse-drawn cabs, bicycles, roller skates and running shoes have reached a truce on the roads of Central Park.

title: Ohio Town Drops Police Force
description: The City Council has voted to abolish the Police Department Aug. 1 and to contract with the county sheriff for protection. The action, which surprised residents of this community of 13,400 people in east-central Ohio, was characterized as a matter of economics and efficiency.

title: TV: 'ADVENTURES OF NELLIE BLY,' STRUGGLING REPORTER
description: ''THE Adventures of Nellie Bly,'' tonight's television movie on NBC at 9, is evidently part of a proposed series called ''Classics Illustrated.'' Make that ''Classic Comics,'' which more accurately describes the level of this undertaking. It is introduced as a ''true story,'' which in television entertainment usually means that any resemblance between the dramatization and the facts is purely accidental. Sure enough, a printed advisory, flashed briefly on the screen, notes that some ''dramatic license'' has been used and that the names of certain characters have been changed.

title: UNITED STATES ANTIMONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Advertising; Product Introductions Set Records in May
description: May turned out to be the heaviest month for new product entries in the 18-year history of the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, according to Martin Friedman, its founder and publisher, who suggested that part of that record-making was because manufacturers introduced new items at food and tobacco conventions held during the month.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 6

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC PLAYS MAHLER AND VIEUXTEMPS
description: MOST people probably attended the New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' concert Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall for the Mahler Fourth Symphony, and if they did, they probably went home content. But it was the Vieuxtemps Violin Concerto No. 4 in D minor (Op. 31) before the intermission that was the more unusual piece, and the one that received the slightly better performance.

title: MILLION STUDENTS FACE LOAN LOSS IN A HOUSE PLAN
description: As many as a million college students would become ineligible for federally guaranteed educational loans under budget restrictions approved today by the House Education and Labor Committee.

title: MARINE BANK SETS 19 1 2% PRIME
description: The Marine Midland Bank, the nation's 13th-largest commercial bank, cut its prime lending rate yesterday to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent. No other major banks immediately followed suit, but bank economists predicted that the 19 1/2 percent rate would soon spread throughout the industry.

title: Peoples Jewellers Raises Zale Holdings
description: Peoples Jewellers Ltd. of Toronto, Canada's largest publicly owned jewelry retailer, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had increased its stake in the Zale Corporation of Dallas, the United States' largest retail jewelry concern, to 1.2 million common shares, or 17.5 percent of Zale's outstanding stock, through the purchase of 93,000 additional shares.

title: Driver of Gypsy Cab Found Slain In Apparent Robbery in Harlem
description: The driver of a gypsy cab was found shot to death in his car in Harlem in an apparent robbery, the police said.

title: Notes on People; One Good Turn Deserves Another
description: A round-robin of page-turning was one of the more amusing unbilled attractions at the Carnegie Hall Festival Concert Tuesday night. That was when winners of the hall's 90th Anniversary Sweepstakes were treated to a star-studded chamber music performance.

title: BAPTIST LEADER IN CONTROVERSY
description: At a news conference yesterday, after his re-election as president of the Southern Baptist Convention, the Rev. Bailey E. Smith was asked whether he still agreed with his remark last summer that ''God Almighty does not hear the prayer of a Jew.''

title: American League; Royals 7, Blue Jays 4
description: TORONTO (UPI) - Amos Otis went four for four and drove in four runs and George Brett hit his first home run of the season for Kansas City, which gave Toronto its 10th straight loss.

title: New York State Oil, Gas Exploration
description: The Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation of Charleston,W. Va., and the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company of New Orleans announced plans to explore for natural gas and oil on 300,000 acres in northeastern New York and two adjacent states.

title: Issue in Baseball Dispute
description: The issue that has brought major league baseball to the brink of the second regular-season player strike in the last decade is the quality of compensation that a team should receive when one of its players fulfills his contract, becomes a free agent and signs with another team.

title: VORNADO POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys discount stores, announced yesterday that it had lost $7.66 million in its first fiscal quarter ended May 2. The announcement came a day after Vornado said that it was closing the remainder of its food operations in the Two Guys chain.

title: Food Stamps Fighting Welfare
description: When New York belatedly increased its basic welfare payment by 15 percent, it called it an ''energy assistance payment'' to spare the recipients a loss in their food stamps. Now the Reagan Administration has been alerted to this fiction, and poor people are likely to get a little less than they need and deserve. It is a sad lesson in the folly of making competitors of benefit programs that should be complementary.

title: CHANCES OF IRAQIS ON BOMB DOUBTED
description: The consensus among United States intelligence officials is that it would have taken Iraq until 1985 or 1986 to build a nuclear weapon unless it took some kind of overt and extraordinary action.

title: U.N. SAYS ITS AGENCIES SUBSIDIZE THE PRESS
description: The United Nations said today, despite earlier denials, that at least eight of its agencies had contributed to subsidies for foreign newspapers that published articles reflecting United Nations views on economic aid.

title: Notes on People; Expanding Disco Sees Better Nights Ahead
description: Is disco dead? someone was wondering at Xenon on Monday night. ''What?'' Howard Stein shouted back over the din of several hundred dancers celebrating his disco's third anniversary.

title: MAJOR RELIGIONS PROTEST PROPOSAL RESTRICTING CULTS
description: Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders spoke out yesterday against the so-called ''anticult bill'' before the New York State Assembly. They contended that the legislation would require the courts to determine the validity of a religious experience.

title: Nigerian Oil Output Down
description: Nigerian crude oil output fell in March by 3.6 percent from February, and by 13.4 percent from March 1980, to 57.8 million barrels, or 1.87 million barrels a day, the Nigerian National Petroleum Company said today.

title: Helpful Hardware; SUMMER ITEMS FOR DOGS
description: HOME C2

Advetising;
General Foods Is Planning Large Coupon Promotion
description: In August, General Foods, the country's second-largest advertiser after Procter & Gamble, will mount what it characterizes as ''the largest multi-brand promotion'' in its history - an enormous coupon effort that will benefit 20 of its best-known brands as well as the Muscular Dystrophy Association.
