title: NUCLEAR PERIL THE GRAVEST, BROOKLYN GRADUATES TOLD
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, speaking at Brooklyn College's graduation ceremonies yesterday, said that nuclear weapons were the greatest danger now facing mankind.

title: Navy Supply Ship Runs Aground
description: A 795-foot Navy supply ship ran aground today in Chesapeake Bay. The Navy said that barges were unloading fuel from the U.S.S. Detroit so that it could be pulled off a sandbar near Hampton Roads.

title: LUM'S HOMER HELPS CUBS DEFEAT GIANTS CHICAGO, June 10 (AP) - Mike Lum hit a home run and two singles and Bill Buckner and Jerry Morales drove in two runs each today to help the Chicago Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants, 7-4.
description: The Cubs also won, 2-1, in the completion of yesterday's game, which had been delayed by rain and finally suspended because of darkness with the Cubs leading, 2-0, in the top of the sixth inning.

title: THE BATTLE TO STEM SCHOOL DROPOUTS
description: School has generally been a ''sometime thing'' for the pupils in the dropout prevention classes at Thomas A. Edison High School on this city's poverty-blistered north side.

title: Hail to the Nuclear Entebbe; by William Safire
description: Israel has done the world two enormous favors: it has denied an aggressive dictator the ability to inflict atomic terror, and it has enabled the rest of the world to indulge in an orgy of hypocrisy.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
U.S. ABLE TO COMBAT NUCLEAR BLACKMAIL
description: Government officials said today that they had achieved a sophisticated technological ability to detect, in most cases, whether a terrorist blackmail threat involving nuclear materials was genuine or a bluff.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 25
description: There were 12 weeks in the latest third qr and 13 weeks in the previous third qr

title: PROFESSOR OF HISTORY AT CALIFORNIA
description: James Ralston Scobie, professor of history at the University of California, San Diego, whose area of expertise was Latin America, died last Thursday at his home in Del Mar, Calif. He was 51 years old.

title: U.S. AND DISTANT CONFLICTS: EUROPE FEARS MILITARY SHIFT
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger's directive that the Rapid Deployment Force be established as an individual command in 18 months rather than in three to five years reflects the Pentagon's desire to endow American strategy with a mobility and flexibility needed to honor new military commitments. But the emphasis on these new commitments and the major expansion of American military power planned by the Reagan Administration may well increase the difference in power between the United States and its NATO allies and lead to doubts about the solidity of the American resolve in the defense of Western Europe.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
BONN ALSO IN AUTO PACT WITH JAPAN
description: Japan and West Germany have reached an agreement to limit the growth of Japanese automobile exports to Germany to 10 percent annually. The accord was announced here today by the Bonn Government at the beginning of talks between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan.

title: Advertising; McCann-Erickson Sage Revises His Ad Estimates
description: Things - ad-wise - are looking up, according to Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and popular pundit at McCann-Erickson Worldwide, who updated his 1981 forecast yesterday in the pleasant precincts of the Princeton Club.

title: UA- COLUMBIA BOARD TO STUDY TAKEOVER
description: The proposed $297 million acquisition of UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc. by Rogers Cablesystems Inc. and United Artists Theater Circuit Inc. will be considered by the UA-Columbia board this morning, the cable company announced yesterday.

title: BOWNE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed June 10, 1981; yr-ago results have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in August 1980

title: Interest Tied to Stock Volume
description: Oppenheimer & Company Inc. announced plans yesterday to sell $18 million in 20-year subordinated debentures with a floating interest rate that is pegged, indirectly at least, to the health of the brokerage company.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SEASONING

title: Bordering on Triumph
description: It could have been an embarrassment. Relations between the United States and Mexico have not been wonderfully smooth. Putting aside irritation with Jimmy Carter-style lecturing, Mexico openly disagrees with important positions already taken by the Reagan Administration. It has championed Nicaragua, maintained civil relations with Cuba and befriended the Salvadoran guerrillas. And yet this week's meeting between Presidents Reagan and Lopez Portillo at Camp David appears to have been a mutual political triumph.

title: JAZZ: RED NORVO AND FRIENDS
description: THE very gentle but persuasively swinging music produced 30 years ago by the trio in which Red Norvo's vibraphone and Tal Farlow's guitar were joined by the bass of the late Charles Mingus was revived Tuesday evening at Michael's Pub, where Mr. Norvo and Mr. Farlow, with Steve Novosel on bass, will be playing through this month.

title: Man Detained Last Week Eludes Atlanta Police Watch
description: Wayne Williams, who remains under police surveillance after being questioned last week in connection with the slayings of 28 young blacks, briefly eluded officers tonight, apparently with the help of his father.

title: Canadian Socialist Assails U.S. Aid to Salvador Junta
description: Ed Broadbent, the leader of Canada's New Democratic Party, a Socialist organization, said today that American support for the ruling junta in El Salvador ''can only mean the continuation of great suffering'' for the people there.

title: ABRAMS URGES KEEPING VOTE ACT
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York said today that failure to extend the special provisions of the 1965 Voting Rights Act could diminish the voting power of minorities and send a signal ''that voting equality is no longer a top national priority.''

title: CALIFORNIA'S INLAND AREAS FACE WAVE OF MIGRATION
description: On the western slopes of the High Sierras, a new regional electronics industry and new towns are taking root where California's Forty-Niners searched for gold more than a century ago.

title: USING BOOKS AS SALES PREMIUMS
description: Buy some Kraft cheese and get a free copy of ''The Complete Cheese Cookbook.'' Pick up five packages of Viva towels, send in 50 cents and get the ''Better Homes and Gardens Cookbook.'' Scoop up three packages of Nabisco snack crackers, mail in 35 cents and get James Beard's ''Hors d'Oeuvre and Appetizers.''

title: Spanish Boxer Dies
description: Santiago Monzon, a 27-year-old Spanish lightweight boxer who had been in a coma since a knockout 18 months ago, died today of cardiac arrest. Doctors said he had suffered a cerebral concussion in a bout at Tenerife.

title: 4 Suppliers Set For Oil Reserve
description: The Defense Fuel Supply Center today announced $178.4 million in contracts to four companies to provide more than 5.5 million barrels of crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.

title: Greek Premier Doubts Pact On Bases Before November
description: Prime Minister George Rallis expressed doubt today that an accord on American bases in Greece could be signed before this country's November elections even if the United States met a deadline of this weekend for agreeing to terms.

title: G.& W. Lifts Stake In General Tire
description: Gulf and Western Industries reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it now owns 4.52 million shares, or 18.8 percent, of the common stock of the General Tire and Rubber Company.

title: When Poles Go Abroad, More Now Remain There
description: There has been a steady increase this year in the number of Poles seeking new homes abroad, according to the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration.

title: PROLONGING THE LIFE OF WICKER FURNITURE
description: HOME C3 --------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: American League; Rangers 12, Brewers 5
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI) - Leon Roberts, Buddy Bell and Jim Sundberg each hit a home run and drove in 10 runs between them for Texas. Bell made two hits and drove in five runs. Sundberg drove in three runs on three hits and Roberts had two hits and two r.b.i.

title: Most Interest Rates Off Slightly; Fed Funds Rise Slows Buying
description: Interest rates declined in early trading yesterday, but uncertainty about their future direction was so great that much of the decline was erased before trading ended.

title: REBUFFED BY 2 PARTIES
description: Prime Minister-designate Arnaldo Forlani, a Christian Democrat, abandoned attempts to form a new cabinet tonight after being unable to persuade the Socialist and Republican Parties to enter into a coalition.

title: 34 IN NEW YORK GIVEN DEGREES IN OSTEOPATHY
description: The New York College of Osteopathic Medicine graduated its first class today, awarding degrees to 26 men and eight women.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Dennis Keene Presents Bach Organ Compositions
description: In Dennis Keene's organ recital Sunday at the Church of the Ascension, Bach again proved to be a most inspired and inspiring of organ composers - for the player as well as the listener. Mr. Keene played a Fantasia on ''Komm, heiliger Geist'' (BWV 851) and two chorale preludes with a concentrated sensitivity; patterned accompaniments and contrapuntal lines were apt comments on one another.

title: JAPAN'S OIL FIND IN CHINA COULD STIMULATE TRADE
description: An oil discovery off China this year by a Japanese drilling company, part of the first major foreign oil exploration in Chinese territorial waters since the Communist revolution, appears likely to galvanize trade between the two nations, trade officials said here.

title: Filly Likely Favorite
description: For the first time in the 27-year history of the event, a filly looms as the favorite in the $284,701 Yonkers Trot Saturday night.

title: WHEN 80% CAST BALLOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. RACE IS SHRINKING TO JUST KOCH VS. ESPOSITO
description: Bernard Rome plans to announce today that he will abandon his campaign for the Republican mayoral nomination, clearing the way for a straight contest between Mayor Koch and Assemblyman John A. Esposito of Queens in the primary.

title: The City; HOSPITALS AGENCY REPORTS A SURPLUS
description: The city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, which ran $92 million in the red last year, will end fiscal 1980 with a $23 million surplus, according to a spokesman for the agency.

title: STAGE: 'OH COWARD!' REPRISE DISPLAYS SOME OLD FAVORITES
description: THE public figure that Noel Coward presented as singer and actor - very crisply British, waspishly witty and highly sophisticated - lingers so firmly in the mind that it can still come as somewhat of a shock to realize how broadly his creative talents ranged. ''Oh Coward!,'' the collection of songs, bits of dialogue from his plays and excerpts from his memoirs put together by Roderick Cook, first seen here in 1972 and now back in town at OnStage, stays primarily with the lighter side of Coward's work, but even within this limitation his variety, while possibly not infinite, is impressive.

title: ROCK: SYL SYLVAIN AND THE TEARDROPS
description: AS two stylistically backward-looking rock bands, Syl Sylvain and the Teardrops, showed at the Bottom Line on Tuesday, successful rockand-roll is more a matter of chemistry than of talent. One band has the chemistry, the other doesn't.

title: JERSEY WILL ADMIT CAMERAS AND TV TO COURTROOMS
description: After a two-year experiment, the New Jersey Supreme Court today made permanent an order allowing news organizations to use cameras and tape recorders in all state courts.

title: Coe's 1:41.72 Breaks 800 Mark
description: Britain's Sebastian Coe, using a powerful finishing kick, set a world record with a time of 1 minute 41.72 seconds in the 800-meter run today at an international track meet.

title: Guard and 5 Prisoners Are Hurt In Van Accident in White Plains
description: A correction officer and five prisoners being transported from the Westchester County Jail for appearances in County Court suffered minor injuries today in a traffic accident, authorities said.

title: United Technologies
description: The United Technologies Corporation's Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group said it had received a $110 million order for its JT9D engine to power Nigeria Airways' new fleet of Airbus Industrie A310 light-body twin-jets. The company said Nigeria had ordered four of the jets and took options on four more, all equipped with Pratt & Whitney's JT9D power plants, which produce 48,000 pounds of takeoff thrust. Aircraft deliveries are scheduled to begin in late 1983, the company said.

title: WHEN UMPIRES NEED TO BE UMPIRED
description: To the Editor:

title: PANELS IN CONGRESS LIMIT REAGAN PLAN FOR BLOCK GRANTS
description: Committees in both houses of Congress moved today to restrict severely President Reagan's ''new federalism'' proposal, which would transfer power to the states by providing them with block grants of Federal aid.

title: 8 Killed in Kuwaiti Helicopter Crash
description: A Kuwaiti Air Force helicopter crashed today while landing at a base in this Persian Gulf nation, killing eight soldiers and injuring nine, the Defense Ministry reported.

title: Rangers Beaten to Top Prospect
description: The Rangers failed to make history today, and so did the Hartford Whalers as the National Hockey League's amateur draft was staged at the Forum.

title: POP: VAL ANTHONY SINGS SINATRA-ORIENTED PROGRAM
description: VAL ANTHONY, a singer and pianist, who is appearing all this month with his trio at Jimmy Weston's, 131 East 54th Street, used to play at Jilly's, which was once a home away from home for Frank Sinatra, who has called Mr. Anthony ''the finest working saloon singer in New York.''

title: Farrah Fawcett Double Sues Over Stunt Injury
description: A 23-year-old stuntwoman who was crippled when she doubled for Farrah Fawcett, the actress, in a 1980 filmed car crash has filed a $35 million lawsuit against all of the film's principals, including the actor Burt Reynolds.

title: KOCH LOBBIES FOR JUSTICE PROGRAM
description: Mayor Koch, lobbying among state legislative leaders tonight for his criminal-justice proposals, conceded that though he would not ''get everything he asked for,'' he was counting on a ''substantial'' number of the provisions in the package.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Rosalind Rees, Soprano, Kimball Wheeler, Mezzo
description: Although two sopranos need not be better than one, they do bring with them a wonderful and rarely heard repertory. At Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday, Rosalind Rees, soprano, and Kimball Wheeler, mezzosoprano, sang a rich blend of Purcell, Monteverdi, Morley, Brahms and Tchaikovsky, plus three premieres by American composers.

title: Dance Premiere June 20-21
description: Douglas Dunn and Dancers will present the world premiere of Mr. Dunn's ''Walking Back'' on June 20 and 21 at the Midtown Y.M.- Y.W.H.A., at 344 East 14th Street. Mr. Dunn, a leading member of the experimentalist post-modern dance movement, performed with Yvonne Rainer, Merce Cunningham and the Grand Union improvisational dance company. ''Walking Back'' is set to an electronic score by John Driscoll and consists of 20 ''frames,'' or movement, tableaux. Performances will be at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $5; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: 279-4200 (after 1 P.M.)

title: Black Stars Magazine Ends
description: Johnson Publications, the nation's largest black-owned publishing company, has ceased publication of its monthly Black Stars magazine and dismissed 51 employees in a cost-cutting move, company officials said today.

title: Japan Units in Pact On Kuwait Desalting
description: Three Japanese companies have signed a $386 million contract to provide Kuwait with 12 desalting plants by April 1985, Mitsui & Company announced.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4 percent stock dividend payable July 1

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * House and Garden magazine to Wyse Advertising. People

title: U.S. BUDGET POLICIES IMPERIL APARTMENT AID FOR CITY
description: The Federal program that has helped to provide privately built new or rehabilitated rental apartments for low-income people in New York City has almost come to a halt as a result of the Reagan Administration's budget policies, city officials said yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; June 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Gardening; CITY ROSES: SELECION, PLANTING AND CARE
description: HOME --------------------------------------------------------------------- Linda Yang is a regular contributor of gardening articles to The New York Times. By LINDA YANG

title: Advertising; WOMEN'S OUTERWEAR CAMPAIGN
description: LONDON TOWN, a subsidiary of Interco, already knows the effectiveness of brand names in rainwear, thanks to its London Fog division. Now it is going to test the concept with women's coats and outerwear. Its Clipper Mist division, with a licensing agreement from Wolverine Wide World, will be marketing them under the Hush Puppies label.

title: The Region; DEPUTY CHIEF KILLED
description: The deputy chief of the Essex County Sheriff's Department was shot and killed by two unknown assailants in the parking lot of his apartment building at 158 High Street.

title: Advertising; Cadwell Davis Savage Gets Sotheby Parke Bernet
description: Cadwell Davis Savage, a subsidiary of Compton Advertising, will be doing advertising for Sotheby Parke Bernet, the auction house.

title: Judge Says Utah County Can Try Man in the Killing of Two Blacks
description: A state judge ruled today that Salt Lake County could try Joseph Paul Franklin for the murders of two black joggers even though a Federal jury had already convicted him of civil rights violations involving the same killings.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
40,000 Coal Miners Still Idle; Builders' Pickets Bolstered
description: By The Associated Press Striking coal-mine construction workers expanded their picket lines in seven states yesterday, keeping more than 40,000 miners from working after their own 10-week walkout.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Biotech Capital Corp. agreed to purchase 23 percent of Allomedic Inc., a San Francisco-based company that manufactures dental systems using a patented process for implanting and fusing teeth to a patient's jawbone.

title: TWO DRIVERS AT HEARING OPPOSE PENALTY TO UNSER
description: Passing cars as a driver exits from the pits under the yellow caution light is a common practice, Al Unser and Johnny Rutherford testified today in backing Bobby Unser's contention that he should not have been penalized during the May 24 Indianapolis 500 race.

title: Notes on People; New Prince in Jordan
description: It's a prince for Jordan's King Hussein and his American-born wife, Queen Noor al-Hussein.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Sitting in the upper deck at Yankee Stadium this past Sunday witnessing the abuse being distributed by the guests from Cleveland, your names came up among the assembled devotees of the home team in connection with your editorial ''Yankee Justice.''

title: LANG DANCERS OPEN WEDNESDAY
description: New dances set to the work of the Yiddish poet and balladeer Itzik Manger will highlight performances by the Pearl Lang Dance Company at the Public Theater from next Wednesday through June 21. Miss Lang will also present her new ''Notturno,'' a dance commissioned by Lukas Foss and the Brooklyn Philharmonia and set to music by Irving Fine, and a revival of her 1960 signature piece, ''Shira.''

title: Notes on People; The Relaxed Edsel Ford
description: His name is on the building, and for a while the junior executive seemed driven with ambition to reach the top of the family company. Now, however, Edsel Ford 2d, the 32-year-old son of the Ford Motor Company's former chairman, Henry Ford 2d, says he's given up long hours and become something of a clock watcher.

title: Notes on People; Amy and All the Carters Adjusting to Life in Plains
description: It is not easy being uprooted in the middle of a school year, but after a rocky transition, 13-year-old Amy Carter ''finally seems happy'' with her new life in Plains, Ga.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
AGENCY LISTS ITS 69 MOST DETERIORATED SUBWAY STATIONS
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in a list that came to light yesterday, has designated what it calls the 69 stations most in need of repair in the New York City subway system.

title: Hyatt International Appoints Executives
description: Colgate A. Holmes, 45 years old, has been named president of the Hyatt International Corporation. He succeeds Jay A. Pritzker, the 58-year-old chairman of the Chicago-based company, who continues as chief executive officer.

title: HAITIANS REPRIEVED FROM DEPORTATION
description: A group of 76 Haitians scheduled for deportation to Port-au-Prince by charter flight at 6 A.M. today got a reprieve late last night from Federal District Judge Eugene P. Spellman, who granted an emergency stay until a hearing could be held on a motion to stop the deportations.

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Jury in Nicaragua Convicts Nine in Publisher's Slaying
description: A jury convicted eight men and one woman today in the 1978 slaying of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a popular newspaper publisher whose death helped touch off the revolution that overthrew the dictatorship of Anastasio Somoza Debayle.

title: STOL PLAN, IN A TEST, CRASH-LANDS IN JERSEY
description: An experimental plane with nine persons aboard crash-landed today on a test run at the Federal Aviation Administration's Technical Center.

title: Notes on People; Baraka to Begin 90-Day Jail Term
description: Two years and two days after the police charged Imamu Amiri Baraka with slapping and struggling with his wife on a Greenwich Village street, the Newark-based writer was ordered yesterday to begin serving a 90-day jail term next Wednesday.

title: Poland Meets Payments
description: Poland's Bank Handlowy has met all interest payments on a $30 million, five-year, floating-rate note that fell due today and has a further 10 days under the original terms in which to repay principal, according to the lead manager, Banque Nationale de Paris. Bankers have been watching Poland's performance on this loan as commercial banks try to agree on a debt-rescheduling package for Warsaw. A group of bankers is to discuss restructuring Poland's 1981 commercial bank debt, which totals $2.4 billion, June 24 in Paris.

title: Advertising; Warren Pfaff Campaign Features Media Directors
description: Warren Pfaff Inc., hard-working agency for the Magazine Publishers Association, has come up with a tough new campaign that features everybody's favorites, the media directors.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE, 11, 1981
description: International ''A substantial violation'' by Israel of its arms agreements with the United States may have been committed when Israel bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig said in a letter to key leaders in the Senate and House on behalf of the President. Mr. Haig said the delivery of four F-16 fighter-bombers to the Israelis was being held up pending a review. (Page A1, Column 6.) Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was dismissed as commander in chief of Iran's armed forces by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The action appeared to suggest that Mr. Bani-Sadr's removal from the Presidency might also be near after a day in which he suffered several other blows in his fight to remain in office. (A1:6.)

title: News Analysis
description: On a slate-gray New Year's morning in 1978, Edward Irving Koch took the oath of office as New York's 105th Mayor and embarked on what he called in his inaugural address ''the important work of saving the city.''

title: ASA EDWARD SNYDER
description: Asa Edward Snyder, president of Snyder Associates, an engineering and management consultant concern of Essex, Conn., died Tuesday at Stanford University Hospital, Palo Alto, Calif., while on a business trip. Mr. Snyder, who was a resident of Essex, was 58 years old.

title: New Citibank Office
description: Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, today dedicated its new credit card division offices, which were moved from New York to South Dakota to take advantage of a state law that eliminated interest-rate ceilings on consumer loans.

title: THOUSANDS OF YOUNGSTERS IN PARADE FOR CHRISTIANITY parade
description: Several thousand students of Christian schools came by bus and plane from across North America to march in New York City yesterday. For two hours, to the thump and brass of such selections as ''Onward, Christian Soldiers'' and ''The Marine Corps Hymn,'' the youngsters and their teachers paraded down Central Park West, some in coats and ties.

title: Ickx-Bell Team Is Fastest In LeMans Race Practice
description: Jacky Ickx of Belgium, a four-time winner, and his co-driver, Derek Bell of Britain, drove their Porsche 936 yesterday to the fastest lap time in the first official practice session for the Le Mans 24-hour race, which begins Saturday.

title: PUBLISHING: MALONE RESTS AT END OF JEFFERSON SERIES
description: HE is 89 years young now, and the sixth and final volume of his biography of Jefferson is about to be published, so Dumas Malone is taking it easy. ''I'm more or less resting at the moment, because it's been a long journey,'' he said with a chuckle, alluding to the 33 years since publication of the first volume, ''Jefferson the Virginian.'' That first ''Jefferson the Virginian.'' That first volume was published on the anniversary of Jefferson's birth, April 13. The last one, ''The Sage of Monticello,'' will be published by Little, Brown on the Fourth of July, the anniversary of Jefferson's death.

title: Lockheed Reports 15 Orders for C-130
description: The Lockheed-Georgia Company, the aircraft manufacturing subsidiary of the Lockheed Corporation, said that Egypt, Indonesia and Morocco had ordered 15 of its C-130 Hercules transport propjets in contracts valued at more than $200 million.

title: PHELPS PHELPS, 84 AMBASSADOR AND ALBANY LEGISLATOR
description: Phelps Phelps, a former New York State Senator and Assemblyman who later served as Governor of American Samoa and Ambassador to the Dominican Republic, died Wednesday in Wildwood, N.J., at the age of 84. A lawyer and had lived in Wildwood for six years and nine years before that in Jersey City.

title: News Analysis
description: The Polish Communist Party has now defied Moscow and runs the risk of being branded a renegade in the Soviet bloc. By keeping Stanislaw Kania as party leader, the Central Committee$ in effect, turned its back on a warning from the Soviet Union that a new leadership must be installed to halt the course that Poland was following.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
NEW PRESIDENT FOR SARAH LAWRENCE
description: Dr. Alice Stone Ilchman, a former dean of Wellesley College and for three years a Carter Administration official, was named the eighth president of Sarah Lawrence College yesterday.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD BARS CONTRACTS ON FOSTER CARE
description: In a surprising setback for Mayor Koch only one day after his announcement that he would seek re-election, the Board of Estimate voted last night to reject more than $200 million in contracts for 72 foster care agencies in the next fiscal year.

title: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. CHARGES SOVIET IS MEDDLING IN POLAND
description: The United States, for the first time since Poland's political and economic crisis began last year, accused the Soviet Union in a public statement today of ''interference in the internal affairs of Poland.''

title: Weekly Vehicle Output Up 41%
description: Car and truck production for the year will break the 4-million mark this week, an industry publication reported today.

title: IMPROVISATIONAL COMEDY THRIVING IN FIRST CITY
description: IMPROVISATIONAL comedy is essentially impudent madness. Because virtually all of it is created at the moment, often out of current experience and usually at the suggestion of audiences, it has little time for such niceties as taste and taboos. Improvisational comics must be fast on their feet and quick with their tongues. Inventiveness and situations count, not gags.

title: Hawks' Matthews Facing Marijuana Possession Case
description: Wes Matthews, the Atlanta Hawks' guard, faces a June 24 court appearance on a charge of possession of marijuana.

title: No Headline
description: EXPOS DEFEAT BRAVES, 7-0, TO SWEEP SERIES

title: VOTING IS HEAVY IN IRELAND'S PARLIAMENTARY ELECTION
description: Irish voters turned out in substantial numbers today for a parliamentary election in which Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey was seeking a five-year mandate for his program of ''providing better living standards for all'' and of trying to negotiate with the British some constitutional initiative in Northern Ireland.

title: Broadway; Chodorov-Panama mystery to star Claudette Colbert.
description: CLAUDETTE COLBERT will star in ''A Talent for Murder,'' a mystery by Jerome Chodorov and Norman Panama, which will arrive on Broadway in September. Obviously, everyone has heard of Miss Colbert. If she were famous for nothing else, she would be famous for her charm. Presumably, everyone has heard of Mr. Chodorov and Mr. Panama. If they were famous for nothing else, they would be famous for the length of their careers. Unless you pay attention to big business and philanthropy, however, you have not heard of the producer, Edwin S. Lowe. Mr. Lowe began manufacturing bingo games in 1934 - concidentally, the year Miss Colbert won an Oscar for ''It Happened One Night'' - and went on to other games (Yahtzee, Scribbage) and other businesses (banking, real estate, television) after that. Mr. Lowe read ''A Talent for Murder'' in late April, and got the production together in weeks. No one told him it could not be done that fast.

title: The High Cost of Politics
description: Here's a measure of how costly politics has become in a major urban state: Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb, who leads the polls for the Republican gubernatorial nomination here next year, has $2 million in the bank already. He's budgeting $3 million for an expected primary race against Attorney General George Deukmejian, plus $5 million for a general election campaign against the expected Democratic nominee, Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. Said to Lag On Oil Cases

title: ART: EIGHT PORTRAIT BUSTS BY HOUDON AT THE FRICK
description: THERE is nothing like a small exhibition to concentrate our attention on the nuances of an artist's style. But it takes an extraordinary artist, of course - and one whom we have not lately paid much attention to, perhaps - to sustain the kind of attention that is appropriate to a small exhibition. In the work of the 18thcentury French sculptor Jean-Antoine Houdon (1741-1828), the Frick Collection has found an ideal subject for such an exhibition, and its new exhibition of ''Eight Portrait Busts'' by this artist certainly qualifies as a very small exhibition indeed. I found it both immensely pleasurable and highly instructive.

title: BARGAIN- HUNTER'S KEY TO THE MARDETS
description: A browser's and bargain-hunter's guide to flea markets in the metropolitan area: New York City 1. Jan Hus Presbyterian Church, 351 East 74th Street, 535-5235. Tomorrow and June 20, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; 44 dealers. 2. Annex Antiques and Flea Market, Avenue of the Americas and 25th Street, 243-5343. Sundays through Oct. 25, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M.; 100 dealers. Admission: 75 cents; children, free. 3. New York East Antiques and Flea Market, 145 East 23d Street, 777-9609. Year-round, Mondays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M., closed Saturdays and Sundays; 16 dealers. 4. Walter's World Famous Greenwich Village Emporium, 252 Bleecker Street, between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, 255-0175. Year-round, Thursdays and Sundays, noon to 8 P.M.; Fridays, noon to 9 P.M., Saturdays, noon to 10 P.M.; 52 dealers. 5. SoHo Canal Flea Market, 369 Canal Street, at West Broadway, 226-8724. Year-round, daily except Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; 45 dealers. 6. Canal Street Flea Market, Canal and Greene Street, 226-7541. Saturdays and Sundays through Dec. 20, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.; 50 to 70 dealers. 7. Essex Street Flea Market, 140 Essex Street, 673-5934. Year-round, Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; 85 dealers. 8. Pratt Institute Fair, 200 Willoughby Avenue, Brooklyn, 636-3572. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to dusk; 75 booths. Rain date, June 20. 9. Seventh Heaven, seventh annual fair, Seventh Avenue from Flatbush Avenue to Ninth Street, Park Slope, Brook yn, 789-1659. Sunday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., rain or shine; 125 dealers. 10.

title: Rating Is Lowered on Nuclear Bonds
description: Moody Investors Service yesterday lowered the rating for about $2.25 billion of the Washington Public Power Supply System's nuclear revenue bonds for projects No.4 and No.5 to Baa-1 from A-1.

title: MAY RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.2% AFTER BIG APRIL DROP
description: Sales by the nation's retailers rose by two-tenths of 1 percent last month following a 2.1 percent decline in April that was the biggest dip in more than seven years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MISS POST TIED FOR 2D IN L. P.G.A.
description: Sandra Post started her attempt at achieving the richest payday in women's professional golf when she shot a five-under-par 67 today in the opening round of the 27th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship. But Lynn Adams, who has never had a big payday, was a shot better than Miss Post with a 66 and held the first-round lead.

title: The Truly Needy, Continued
description: At last, the Senate has done a little repair work on the holes in Ronald Reagan's famous social safety net. That, it will be recalled, is how the Administration described its concern for the truly needy, even as it attacked Federal spending with long knives and sharp hatchets. In fact, the Administration's social welfare proposals cut gaping holes in the net.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
House Panel Bars Oil Exploration In 4 Areas Off Northern California
description: The Interior Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee voted today to bar James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, from leasing four disputed basins off northern California for oil and natural gas exploration.

title: STUDIES BACK CON EDISON COAL USE
description: The Consolidated Edison Company, stepping up a long campaign to burn less costly but dirtier coal in place of foreign oil at three New York City power plants, released two studies yesterday endorsing its approach. The utility estimated a shift to coal at the three plants could save customers $4 billion by 1990.

title: RASHISH CONFIRMED AT STATE DEPT.
description: The Senate confirmed the nomination of Myer Rashish as Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs today by a vote of 91 to 4.

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $250,000 for the latest period and $1.7 million for the previous period

title: The City; Ex-Councilman Gets A Year for Larceny
description: ALBANY (AP) - Vincent A. Riccio, a former New York City Councilman and State Assemblyman convicted of taking kickbacks from no-show jobs on a state commission, was sentenced in State Supreme Court to serve a year in the Albany County Jail.

title: Appeal Panel on Indy 500 Is Adjourned Until July 29
description: Roger Penske, owner of the car Bobby Unser drove in this year's Indianapolis 500, began his testimony today before the special panel hearing the appeal by Penske and Unser of the ruling that overturned Unser's victory.

title: New Aetna Funds
description: In an effort to offer a broader range of personal financial services, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company said it planned to introduce a money market fund and a real estate fund. Donald G. Conrad, an executive vice president and chief financial officer at Aetna, said the real estate fund would probably be available this autumn, and the money fund early next year. He said that the funds would be offered first to the company's insurance customers and later to the general public.

title: COMMUNISTS ARE HOPING TO PICK FRUITS OF MITTERRAND'S TRIUMPH
description: All around this Picardy town, the posters are up for the rival candidates in Sunday's first-round legislative elections. Maurice Bambier's display an affable, corpulent man under a big headline that reads: ''Candidate of the United Left Majority.'' In the bottom right-hand corner, and in very small type, there is the additional notation: ''Presented by the Communist Party.''

title: SUSPECT IN STOLEN TORAHS IS ARRESTED
description: The owner of a shop in lower Manhattan that sells yarmulkes was arrested Wednesday night and charged with possessing stolen Torahs, law enforcement officials announced yesterday.

title: At the Movies; Meet 'Zorro' Hamilton, swashbuckler.
description: THE other day, George Hamilton skyed in from the coast, as S.J. Perelman used to say. Mr. Hamilton was on his way to London to make a movie with George Segal (if another strike doesn't happen, and the directors don't go out) and he stopped briefly in New York. Just long enough to talk about ''Zorro, the Gay Blade,'' which will open here in mid-July.

title: Bay Gelding Takes Title For Conformation Hunters
description: Henry the Hawk, an eight-year-old bay gelding who made a sweep of the four classes for regular conformation hunters yesterday at the Paine-Webber-Ox Ridge Horse Show, was first and second in the two events today and won the championship.

title: AMERICAN RESOURCES MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Five Oil Concerns Cut Gasoline Price
description: Five major oil companies have reduced gasoline prices this week as competition has intensified, company officials confirmed yesterday. The cuts, ranging up to 3 cents a gallon but generally only a penny, were made by Standard Oil (Indiana), Shell Oil, Gulf Oil, Mobil and Phillips Petroleum.

title: UNISHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including $1,072,000 or 11 cents a shr extraordinary credit.. C-After $525,000 or 3 cents a shr extraordinary credit

title: KLM ROYAL DUTCH AIRLINES reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
Carter Named Hawks Aide
description: Fred Carter, who played eight years in the National Basketball Association -with Baltimore, Philadelphia and Milwaukee - yesterday was named an assistant coach of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: New Edition of Guide To City's Museums on Sale
description: The second edition of ''A Guide to New York City Museums'' is available for $1.50 in all the 157 cultural institutions mentioned in the brochure and in major metropolitan bookstores.

title: Letters; VULNERABLE GAINS OF THE WOMEN'S REVOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Howard Miller Resigns As State's Budget Chief
description: Howard F. Miller, who joined the state's Budget Division in 1956 and rose to Budget Director, resigned for health reasons today, effective next week.

title: A MAY O'DONNELL DANCE FESTIVAL
description: The new and the familiar, some music, fugitive memories - all these prompted ''Three Nocturnes and a Quartet,'' a new piece by May O'Donnell that will be performed by the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company tonight, tomorrow and Sunday nights at 8 at the Public Theater's Newman Theater together with a retrospective of dances that the celebrated choreographer has created over the last 38 years. (Tickets are $10 and $12; reservations, 598-7150.)

title: Postal Talks Will Begin As Bolger Loses Appeal
description: The National Labor Relations Board today rejected an appeal by Postmaster General William F. Bolger that the board designate one of four unions as the chief bargainer for 670,000 postal workers, whose contract expires on July 20.

title: White-Volvo Pact
description: The American Truck Dealers, a division of the National Automobile Dealers Association, said that it had asked Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, to extend a new sales agreement to all dealers for the White Motor Corporation before the sale of White to Volvo was approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court in Cleveland. Volvo has agreed to buy nearly all of White's truck manufacturing assets for about $75 million.

title: Advertising; TBWA Wins Account Of Granada TV Ltd.
description: The TBWA agency has just picked up another one, this time at the expense of Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky.

title: Notes On People; Powell Says Carter Did Not Seek PX Privileges
description: Jody Powell, spokesman for Jimmy Carter, chided the Reagan Administration yesterday for what he called a ''basically false'' report that Mr. Carter had applied for the privilege of shopping at low-cost post exchanges on military bases.

title: Sequel To Hiroshima
description: Israel's destruction of the nuclear reactor near Baghdad raises again the whole complex of issues posed by the atomic bomb.

title: SENATOR CONDEMNS I.R.A. AS MARXIST
description: Senator Jeremiah A. Denton said today that the Irish Republican Army was not a legitimate national liberation organization but a terrorist group that had been ''subverted and perverted'' and ''taken over'' by Marxists.

title: SMALLER CUTS FOR ARTS BACKED
description: A House Appropriations Subcommittee agreed today to recommend that fiscal 1982 budget appropriations be set at $157.5 million for the National Endowment for the Arts and $144.06 million for the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Volkswagen Adds Two Diesel Models
description: Volkswagen of America introduced two new models in its product line - a diesel-powered Rabbit that the auto maker says will get 7 percent better fuel efficiency than earlier models, and a diesel version of the company's Jetta sports sedan. Prices were not disclosed.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Associated Madison Companies and its subsidiary, National Benefit Life Insurance Co., bought 5.8 percent of the outstanding common stock of Fidelity Trust Co., Stamford, Conn.

title: Senate Approves Pact to Permit Killing of 30,000 Alaska Fur Seals
description: The Senate today ratified an agreement allowing the killing of about 30,000 Alaskan seals a year, but it required a study aimed at reducing the kill.

title: Don't Write Off Bangladesh
description: At first glance, the recent news from Bangladesh seems only to confirm that nation's pathetic image. Born out of a fracturing of Pakistan only a decade ago, Bangladesh early on gained a reputation as an international ''basket case,'' a metaphor for misery and hopelessness.

title: TV Weekend; MANSON AND TITLE BOXING
description: TONIGHT at 12:30 A.M., in a special edition likely to trigger some controversy about television-network practices and policies, NBC-TV's ''Tomorrow Coast to Coast'' features Tom Snyder, the show's host, in a longer than 50-minute interview with Charles Manson, serving life sentences in California for his involvement in the 1969 murders of Sharon Tate, the actress, and eight other persons. Taped in a small parole-board room at the prison, last Saturday, the interview ran about two hours.

title: SUNNY SKIES PUT COAST GUARD ON ALERT
description: With sunny days and tingling breezes beckoning boaters to weigh anchor, the Coast Guard and local marine safety officials have once again strengthened their patrols to help guarantee smooth sailing in waterways throughout the metropolitan area.

title: BAPTISTS CALM THEIR DIFFERENCES AND AFFIRM PLURALISM
description: Southern Baptists wound up their annual meeting today by appealing for unity and taking steps to appease moderates who have been locked in a struggle with conservatives for control of the 13.6-million-member denomination.

title: Around the World
description: 225 LEFTISTS ARE SAID TO DIE IN FIGHT AT SALVADOR VOLCANO

title: Advertising; Oui Magazine Sold To Goshen Litho Inc.
description: Oui magazine, the less prosperous companion publication to Playboy that was founded to combat inroads being made by Penthouse, was sold yesterday and got a new publisher, Irwin E. Billman, former executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Penthouse Group.

title: POP: MISS WILLIAMS IN A NEW STYLE
description: DENIECE WILLIAMS'S rousing performance at the Savoy on Tuesday showed that the difference between a singer's recorded voice and her live presence can sometimes be immense. On record, Miss Williams is a demure, kittenish soprano with a squeaky coloratura, and she exudes a dreamy sweetness that has been labeled ''cotton-candy soul.''

title: MAYOR'S BUDGET FOR BOSTON WOULD CUT OUTLAYS IN HALF
description: Mayor Kevin H. White is expected to outline a city budget tomorrow cutting operating expenditures to barely half of the current level as a result of the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; SOFTWARE OF HISTORY
description: All kinds of ''historical confetti'' have been tucked away in the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue at 42d Street over the years, and a fair sample will be tossed out for viewing in Astor Hall at the main entrance starting today. Speakeasy cards, a leaflet declaring ''Save the 15-cent fare!'' Tom Thumb's greeting card and anti-Nazi literature from the German underground concealed in packets of tea are just a few of the items displayed in ''Typographical Small Wares: Ephemera From the Collections.'' Impossible to catalogue, the items are filed in scrapbooks and envelopes that are seldom exhibited. The earliest item in the display is a Roman Cathoic indulgence, sold by the Church in 1480 to laymen who wanted absolution for their sins. ISLE OF GREECE IN HEMPSTEAD

title: The City; Chapman Case Judge Refuses to Bar Public
description: A judge refused to bar the public and press from watching selection of a jury to hear the case of Mark David Chapman, who is accused of killing John Lennon.

title: Japan's Premier in Italy
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for a three-day visit to Italy, the second of six nations on a West European tour. He arrived from West Germany and will also visit Belgium, Britain, the Netherlands and France.

title: BASEBALL PLAYERS GO OUT ON STRIKE AFTER TALKS WITH THE OWNERS FAIL
description: Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, announced early today that the players were on strike.

title: CORRECTION
description: The time of the Beethoven Society concert scheduled for tomorrow was listed incorrectly in last Sundays's Arts and Leisure Section. The concert, to be performed by the New York Vocal Arts Ensemble, Robert White, tenor, and the Aspen Soloists, will be given at Alice Tully Hall at 3 P.M.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's hopes for a ''new federalism,'' in which the Federal Government would turn back much of its power to the states, suffered a serious setback yesterday when committees on both sides of Capitol

title: SAUDIS WANT TO TRANSFER U.S. ARMS TO THE SUDAN
description: The Reagan Administration has told Congress that Saudi Arabia wants permission to transfer $9 million worth of American-made weapons to the Sudan. The Saucan-made weapons to the Sudan.

title: Armenians Stage Paris Protest
description: Fifteen Armenian militants and French sympathizers occupied the Paris office of Turkish Airlines for 90 minutes today. A spokesman for the militants, most of whom were members of the Organization for the Liberation of Armenia, said the occupation was to protest ''recent outrages against Armenians in France.'' They were removed by the police.

title: Werblin to Get Award
description: David A. (Sonny) Werblin, president and chief executive officer of Madison Square Garden, yesterday was named recipient of the National Football Foundation's Distinguished American Award for 1981.

title: $50,000 IN CASH STOLEN
description: Two armored car guards were shot and seriously wounded yesterday by three gunmen who ambushed them at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx and fled with $280,000 in cash and checks, the police reported.

title: Notes On people; Mayor of Albany Since 1942 to Seek Yet 4 More Years
description: Who, someone was wondering yesterday, was Mayor of Albany before Erastus T. Corning 2d?

title: Ex-Im Bank Resignation
description: Donald E. Stingel, a Republican appointed to the board of the Export-Import Bank during the Carter Administration, said today that he would resign around the end of July.

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HE Museum of Modern Art's Spring Benefit this year, ''An Italian Festival,'' was well under way the other night when Italy's Consul General, Alessandro Cortesede Bosis and his wife, Marina, walked into the museum.

title: 'Raiders of the Lost Ark'
description: FROM the first moments, when the star-circled mountain in the Paramount Pictures logo fades into a similarly shaped, fog-shrouded Andean peak, where who knows what awful things are about to happen, ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' is off and running at a breakneck pace that simply won't stop until the final shot, an ironic epilogue that recalls nothing less than ''Citizen Kane.'' That, however, is the only high-toned reference in a movie that otherwise devotes itself exclusively to the glorious days of the B-picture.

title: LEADERS OF U.S. JEWISH GROUPS RALLY TO ISRAEL'S SIDE
description: Leaders of major American Jewish organizations rallied to Israel's support yesterday, criticizing the Reagan Administration's delay in shipping four fighter-bombers to Israel and insisting that the Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor had been justified by self-defense.had been justified by self-defense.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-Including tax credits of $72,900 for the qr and $86,400 for t yr...C-Including tax credits of $127,300 for the qr and $614,30 for the yr; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect capita of leases

title: Economic Scene; A Tax Policy For the Rich
description: SIDE economics, the doctrine that tax cuts should provide incentives for those who will save money, make investments and spur economic growth, has provided President Reagan and his supporters in Congress with the rationale for writing tax legislation deliberately calculated to provide the greatest benefits to the wealthy.

title: SEAVER, REDS TOP METS, 5-2
description: Tom Seaver, 36 years old and still going strong, returned to the New York stage with the old flair last night and pitched the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-2 victory over the Mets.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 3
ART: PRINTS OF ALECHINSKY IN MODERN RETROSPECTIVE
description: Looking at a new print by Pierre Alechinsky is like getting a letter from someone we know well and cannot hear from too often. We know the handwriting, we know the turn of phrase, we know the probable sequence of ideas. Even the marginalia fall just where we expect them to. Familiarity has staled none of this. If our friend has more to say at some times than at others, and if occasionally he repeats himself - well, those things are a part of friendship, and we're certainly not going to hold them against him.

title: CENVILL COMMUNITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated

title: Advertising; 'The Chase Is On' With a New Theme
description: Another new campaign that makes its debut on Monday - and this one is worldwide - will be coming your way from Chase Manhattan with an assist in America and Europe from Wells Rich Greene and in Asia from Bate Advertising in Singapore.

title: A RED NORVO TRIO REUNION
description: THIRDS of a trio that is regarded as one of the classic small groups of jazz - the Red Norvo Trio of the early 1950's -has come together for the first time in more than 25 years, at Michael's Pub, where the group will be playing this weekend and through the month.

title: THE DEPRESSED SILVER BUSINESS
description: As the price of silver declines on commodity exchanges, the price tags on those proverbial silver spoons - not to mention knives and forks - are also slipping.

title: The Region; Indian Point Getting 2 More Inspectors
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said it would double to four the number of inspectors at the two Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: Letters; Reading Relativity
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arkansas Best Corporation announced the renewal and amendment of its $35 million to $40 million unsecured credit agreement with Citibank and four other banks.

title: Auctions
description: THERE were major disappointments and some pleasant surprises yesterday for Sotheby Parke Bernet at its Madison Avenue galleries during an auction of old-masters paintings. Bidding on many paintings was extremely slow, and the two most important - Murillo's ''The Virgin of the Swaddling Cloth'' from 1660 and a 1599 oil-on-metal painting by Jan Bruegel the Elder, ''Saint John the Baptist Preaching in a Wooded Landscape'' - which were expected to bring at least $700,000 each, did not find buyers.

title: Index; International
description: Voting is heavy in Irish parlia- mentary election A2 Senate confirms Rashish in State Department post A3 East German paper uses dispar- aging style for Polish leader A4 Around the World A5 U.S. envoy ends talks with Botha on Namibia A6 U.S. Jewish groups rally to Is- rael's side A8 Visit to Egypt by Peres, Israeli op- position leader, is put off A10 French Communists hope to pick fruits of Mitterrand victory A10 Teheran demonstrators call for trial of Bani-Sadr A11 Government/Politics Regents upheld in denying ac- creditation to Moon sect school B2 New York City Republicans meet to endorse Koch B3 Republican leaders are promised a wider role in filling U.S. jobs B5 Rights panel suggests ''state- hood'' for Indians D14 Energy Two studies support Con Ed's plan to convert three plants to coal B3 General Around the Nation A12 Coast Guard cautions boaters in metropolitan area B4 The trial of several people on drug charges started Manhattan D14 Education/Welfare Sarah Lawrence College picks ex- Carter aide as eighth president B2 Religion Baptists calm their differences and affirm pluralism D14 Features/Notes Notes on People B4 About Washington: The other gov- ernment B6 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Flea markets in season all over the region C1 Improvisational comedy thriving in New York C1 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard LIEBLING ABROAD. The Road Back to Paris, Mollie & Other War Pieces, Nor- mandy Revisited, Between Meals. By A.J. Liebling. Introduction by Ray- mond Sokolov. 672 pages. Playboy. $17.95. THE PRESS. By A.J. Liebling. Introduction by Jean Stafford. 555 pages. Pantheon. Paperback, $6.95. HE good news this morning is that when A.J. Liebling went to Europe and North Africa, he was a better war reporter than any other American I've read. It is as if Hemingway had been smoking a Popsicle instead of a cigar, and all the rest of them were Ernie Pyle. What a strange mind Liebling had. A specialist in lowlife - prizefighters, newspaper reporters and kept women - for The New Yorker, he was equally at home with Romance philology, gourmet cuisine, medieval huggermugger and military history. He made a point, just before the fall of France to Hitler, of talking to French generals, who got everything wrong, and of listening to cab drivers, barkeepers and nightclub go-go girls, who didn't have the vaguest idea what was going on.

title: Business People; Standard Register Adds To Executive's Duties
description: Roy N. Linton, the 64-year-old president of the Standard Register Company, has been named to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective July 1. He will succeed Donald F. Whitehead, 65, who continues as chairman.

title: German Technology Show
description: A bicycle from 1817 and an 1883 experimental model of a Daimler gasoline engine are among the devices on display in an exhibition of 19th-century German technology at Goethe House, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 83d Street.

title: ZOO MAKES CHARITY LOOK EASY event
description: There is no truth to the rumor that most charity parties are zoos. There is only one major one that fills the bill, and most of the animals are incidental guests and do not pay admission.

title: Around the Nation; ILLINOIS COURT VOIDS ORDER TO KEEP TRANSIT RUNNING
description: The threat of a mass transit shutdown increased today as the Illinois Supreme Court overturned a ruling by a judge who had ordered the Regional Transportation Authority to keep trains and buses running at all costs.

title: BROOKS'S 'HISTORY OF THE WORLD'
description: MEL BROOKS'S ''History of the World - Part I'' shows its stripes right from the opening scene. In this Dawn of Man episode, apelike creatures rise up from the mud, learning to stand erect and reaching nobly toward the heavens. Then they begin bumping, grinding, rutting, gyrating and otherwise slipping back to the slime from whence they came. The movie, like these primitives, delights in being lowdown. Even by prehistoric standards, Mr. Brooks's latest comedy is especially crude.

title: Assets Set Record At Money Funds
description: Going after the higher yields temporarily available in money market mutual funds, investors put $1.58 billion of new cash into such funds in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: STEVE AND EYDIE PLAYING 8 DAYS AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Three significant debuts will take place at Carnegie Hall tonight - or possibly it will add up to only two debuts, if you consider the husband-and-wife singing team of Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme as a single entity. The other Carnegie debutant is George Segal, the actor, who will appear with his banjo on his knee as leader of the Beverly Hills Unlisted Jazz Band. They will all perform at Carnegie Hall for eight nights - tonight through Sunday and next week Wednesday through Sunday.

title: STAGE: 'SHAY DUFFIN AS BRENDAN BEHAN' AT ASTOR PL.
description: AT bottom, Brendan Behan was an entertainer, a performer whose notoriety, as well as much of his charm, was based on a lethal predilection for bringing out the worst in himself. Early in life he wrote awfully well; later in life he became everyone's favorite drunk. He died at 41, his public decline attended by enchanted journalists and other voyeurs, and he left behind him not so much a body of work as a reputation for being what he most certainly was not. For all the posturing about life, he was in love with death.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The threatening tone of the recent letter from the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, a text of which has just become available, amounts in our view to interference in the internal affairs of Poland.'' - David Passage, the State Department spokesman. (A3:4.)

title: Notes On People; 2 Who Couldn't Make It to Graduation for Good Reason
description: Trini Alvarado couldn't be present for her high school graduation in New York yesterday, nor could Jennifer Henson. Miss Alvarado was on the West Coast, filming ''Star Struck'' for ABC-TV, following up on her success as a star of the movie ''Rich Kids.''

title: Bache Shareholders Back Prudential Bid
description: Shareholders of the Bache Group Inc., parent company of one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, voted by a 7-to-2 margin at a special meeting yesterday to approve the merger of Bache into the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: VAST CAPITAL NEEDS FORGED THE MERGER OF 2 CANADA BROKERS
description: In 1889 A.E. Ames founded a brokerage firm here bearing his name; in 1901 George Cox, Mr. Ames's father-in-law, founded a competing brokerage, Dominion Securities Ltd., which grew over the years into one of this country's leading firms.

title: Bridge: A Simple Bid Gets Difficult When You Are Not Dealing
description: Hands containing four spades, a long minor and minimum opening-bid strength are simple to bid if you are the dealer. But they can be distinctly difficult if an opponent fires the first salvo.

title: Letters; NEW YORK DISCOVERS HIGHWAY RECYCLING
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPLEX ISSUE IS HOW TO CUT EXPORTS TO U.S.
description: Japanese auto makers, facing restrictions on exports to the United States, are locked in tough negotiations with their Government over just how many cars are to be shipped during the next few years.

title: A CO-OP IS CREATED ON CITY ISLAND WITH REBUILT COTTAGES
description: Ira Scherr is an advertising copywriter. Virginia Scherr, his wife, runs a business that processes hospital medical records for physicians. She has 47 employees and an office in a converted garage. The Scherrs have three teen-age sons.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $35,000 for the latest period and $3 for the previous period

title: FACES A 30-YEAR TERM
description: The alleged leader of a heroin-smuggling ring who was among the passengers on a hijacked Pakistani jetliner in March pleaded guilty yesterday to international drug-trafficking charges that could bring him up to 30 years in prison.

title: UA CABLE MERGER APPROVED
description: As expected, UA-Columbia Cablevision Inc.'s board approved a definitive agreement yesterday providing for a merger with a joint venture of United Artists Theater Circuit Inc. and Rogers Cablesystems Inc.

title: Restaurants; Teacher-author-chef turns restaurateur.
description: IT is one thing to teach the art of perfect cooking in a school or to develop and explain perfect recipes in a cookbook, but quite another to lay it on the line by opening a restaurant. A teacherauthor-chef who was willing to take this risk is John Clancy, whose ''eclectic seafood restaurant,'' John Clancy's Restaurant, opened eight weeks ago on the corner of Seventh Avenue South and 10th Street, just off Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JUNE 12, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan appealed to 350 supporters to help win Congressional passage of the Administration's tax bill. He told the group, which had helped muster support for his budget, that he needed another ''vital bipartisan piece of legislation'' - his 25 percent, phased-in reduction in tax rates. Earlier, Mr. Reagan told labor leaders he would not compromise on the cut. (Page A1.)

title: The City; Educator Backed For U.S. Judgeship
description: Leo Glasser, the Brooklyn Law School dean whose 1980 appointment to the Federal bench fell victim to political maneuvering, has been recommended for another Federal judgeship.

title: CITING LA GUARDIA, KOCH ACCEPTS G.O.P. SUPPORT
description: Invoking the name of Fiorello H. La Guardia in justification of his ''fusion'' campaign for re-election, Mayor Koch accepted last night an official invitation from the citywide Republican organization to seek the Republican nomination as well as the Democrat nomination in next fall's election.

title: with a Chinese embassy official Associated Press  HAIG BEGINS TWO-WEEK TRIP:
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., and his wife, Patricia, saying goodbye to Chinese Embassy officials in Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Haig will visit Japan, Hong Kong, China, the Philippines and New Zealand during the 27,000-mile trip. A major purpose of the trip is to demonstrate the Reagan Administration's intention to continue normalized relations with China. President Reagan may visit China in 1982.

title: HARRY HALPERN, 82, JEWISH LEADER, DIES
description: Rabbi Harry Halpern, an educator and leader in philanthropic affairs in Brooklyn and a former member of the New York City Human Rights Commission, died Wednesday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital in Connecticut. He was 82 years old and lived in Southbury, Conn.

title: NATIONAL, FOREIGN UNITS ARE MERGED AT MORGAN
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday that it had merged its national and international banking divisions and that Peter B. Smith, executive vice president, would head the combined unit.

title: IAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results were restated for an accounting change relating to the translation of foreign currency assets and liabilities

title: JACKSON TELLS YANKS THAT A STRIKE IS ON
description: Saying they had been told a strike had begun, the Yankee players gathered their luggage and went their own way at 11:45 P.M. tonight after a 3-2 loss to the White Sox.

title: PLAYERS WONDER ABOUT THEIR NEXT MOVE
description: A mood of mass confusion settled over the Mets and the Cincinnati Reds at Shea Stadium last night as they played their final game before the baseball strike.

title: EAST GERMAN PAPER REFERS TO KANIA, POLISH LEADER, IN DISPARAGING STYLE
description: The East German newspaper Neues Deutschland made what appeared to be an unusual, disparaging reference today to Stanislaw Kania, the Polish party leader, by calling him simply ''S. Kania,'' without his titles.

title: Nets Send Jones To the Pistons
description: The Nets announced today that they had sent Edgar Jones, a reserve center, to the Detroit Pistons for future considerations.

title: Dutch Joblessness Rises
description: Dutch unemployment rose to a new postwar record of 363,900 in May from 353,500 in April and 232,400 in May, 1980, according to Social Affairs Ministry figures released today. The figures are seasonally adjusted.

title: RIGHTS PANEL URGES STATE-LIKE POWERS FOR INDIAN TRIBES
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights urged Congress today to recognize the nation's Indian tribes as a collective legal entity similar to a state for the purpose of apportioning Federal funds.

title: Business People; New President Picked At Howell Petroleum
description: James M. Richardson, 51 years old, has been elected president of the Howell Petroleum Corporation, an exploration and production company. The slot had been filled on an interim basis by Paul Howell, the 62-year-old chairman and chief executive officer of the Houstonbased corporation.

title: ISRAELIS ARE CRITICAL OF U.S. DECISION TO HOLD UP F-16'S FOR RAID ON IRAQ
description: Israel said today that the Reagan Administration's decision to suspend delivery of four F-16 fighterbombers was an injustice that failed to appreciate the defensive nature of the air strike on Iraq's nuclear reactor center last Sunday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Burlington Industries named James Gravalis president of Burlington House Area Rugs.

title: TRIAL BEGINS FOR MAN SUSPECTED OF ORGANIZING DRUG-SELLING RING
description: Opening statements were heard yesterday in a Manhattan trial involving charges that a defendant headed a major narcotics ring, that several others participated in it and that a lawyer helped invest the profits in legitimate businesses.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio air play. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.
