title: HEALTH CHIEF GIVES PLANS TO CUT COSTS
description: The Reagan Administration, seeking a ''totally new direction'' in the nation's health-care programs, announced plans today to promote greater competition among medical insurers and hospitals, to blunt rising costs.

title: 7 Die in Moscow Subway Fire
description: At least seven people died in a subway station fire believed to have been caused by a faulty escalator, witnesses said today.

title: Irish Tower's Entry Still Denied
description: A Federal District Court in Manhattan refused yesterday to grant a temporary restraining order that would have permitted Irish Tower to start in Sunday's $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park. But the court ordered a hearing for this morning to act on a motion for a preliminary injunction that would accomplish the same thing.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an error by the Associated Press, a caption in Monday's paper misidentified a general pictured with the late President of Bangladesh, Ziaur Rahman. He was Maj. Gen. Mir Shawkat Ali.

title: STAGE: 'A TALE TOLD,' PART 3 OF TALLEY FAMILY STORY
description: THERE are a dozen characters in ''A Tale Told,'' Lanford Wilson's long-awaited third play about the Talley clan of southern Missouri, but I'm afraid only one of them is worth caring about. I'm equally sorry to report that the single exception, Sally Talley, isn't on stage too long. Sally pops up only in the play's waning moments, when she sneaks into her family's mansion to grab a suitcase and skip town.

title: Soyer Donating Graphics To the Hirshhorn Museum
description: Raphael Soyer of New York, the 81-yearold painter and printmaker, is giving a complete collection of his graphics to the Smithsonian's Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden.

title: Keith Meyers Police Department Presents Medals, Some Posthumously
description: Ruby Walton, widow of Detective Abraham Walton, with her son, Brian, yesterday during the awards ceremony at Police Headquarters. Detective Walton was off duty when he was killed trying to stop a holdup at a Queens social club last July. Eight police officers were awarded the Medal of Honor yesterday, seven of them posthumously.

title: 'CLASH OF TITANS' WITH OLIVIER AS ZEUS
description: IT is, one gathers, just another day on Mount Olympus. The gods and goddesses are hanging around the throne room waiting for Zeus (Laurence Olivier), who wears silver curls and an unreliable expression, to do something arbitrary and mean. Hera (Claire Bloom), Mrs. Zeus to the servants, looks worried. Aphrodite (Ursula Andress) looks as if she would prefer to be watching television. Only Thetis (Maggie Smith) is attending to the there and then, and she's seething with fury.

title: Leon Spinks Holmes 4-1 Pick to Beat Spinks
description: Leon Spinks promises to be on time tomorrow night and Larry Holmes promises to knock him out in a heavyweight title fight that both promise will be even more intense than their impromptu dance contest at a Las Vegas party nearly three years ago, when more than a hundred people stood on tables and chairs to watch.

title: The Region; Slain Deputy Chief Had $1,000 in Cash
description: The deputy chief of the Essex County Sheriff's Department, who was shot and killed in an apparent robbery attempt,had $200 in his wallet and $800 more under the seat of his car when he was attacked, officials said.

title: Art People; Loft bill target of artist-tenants.
description: THE continuing battle between artists and landlords over loft rentals in New York has again reached fever pitch. An emergency state moratorium passed in November that prevents evictions and rent hikes for loft tenants will expire June 30, and as yet there has been no move to extend it. The moratorium was passed so that the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development could have time to draft its Loft Legalization-Rent Stabilization Bill (S-6795), just submitted in Albany. Its stated aim is to legalize residential loft buildings and bring tenants under the protection of rent stabilization, but loft tenants have some serious quarrels with it.

title: Excerpts From President's Talk
description: Following is a partial transcription of remarks by President Reagan to a group of supporters in the East Room of the White House yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News: I came to pay tribute to you - the new superstars of American grass-roots politics. You represent a cross section of Americans from all backgrounds, different regions across this country. In fact you remind me very much of that one special-interest group that I mentioned on Inauguration Day, the one special-interest group that has been neglected and needs help - that is, we, the people.

title: H.W. RODNEY, GUARDED PRESIDENTS
description: Henry W. Rodney, a former Secret Service agent who was part of the Presidential protection team for Herbert Hoover, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: Meir Kahane's Party to Run
description: The Israeli High Court in Jerusalem today rejected an appeal to bar Rabbi Meir Kahane and his Kach Party from the elections on June 30. The petitioners, five Jerusalem lawyers, said the Kach platform, such as a proposal to outlaw sex between Jewish women and gentile men, was racist. The three justices on the bench said the court had no competence to disquality a party that had been cleared by the Central Elections Committee.

title: REAGAN VOICES REGRET TO ARABS, BUT ASSURES ISRAEL ON TIES
description: President Reagan told a group of Arab ambassadors today that he ''appreciated'' their concern about Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor. But he also assured Israel that his displeasure over the raid would not lead to any ''fundamental re-evaluation'' of the American-Israeli relationship.

title: 'RAIDERS OF LOST ARK'
description: FROM the first moments, when the star-circled mountain in the Paramount Pictures logo fades into a similarly shaped, fog-shrouded Andean peak, where who knows what awful things are about to happen, ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' is off and running at a breakneck pace that simply won't stop until the final shot, an ironic epilogue that recalls nothing less than ''Citizen Kane.'' That, however, is the only high-toned reference in a movie that otherwise devotes itself exclusively to the glorious days of the B-picture.

title: Yacht Chasseur Is Winner Yacht Chasseur Is Winner
description: Frank Snyder of Greenwich, Conn., sailing the 44-foot cutter Chasseur, was declared the overall winner today of the 940-mile single-handed yacht race from Newport, R.I., to Bermuda. John Carson of Seattle, aboard Freedom, finished second over all, followed by W. Barrett Holby of Stamford, Conn., in Troll Fjord.

title: 2 REAGAN ECONOMISTS SEE GROWTH LAG
description: Two top Administration economists predicted yesterday that there would be little or no economic growth in the second and third quarters, a considerable slowdown from the 8.5 percent inflationadjusted economic growth rate in the first quarter.

title: Ashland Acquires U.S. Filter Stock
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said that it had acquired the remaining 35 percent of all outstanding voting stock of the United States Filter Corporation for about $129 million.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
description: B-Including $42.5 million net gain from the sale of real proper and $18.3 million extraordinary credit from gain on debt restru and tax credit...C-Including $29.4 million gain on property sal $32.6 extraordinary credit from gain on debt restructuring

title: CANCER AT LOVE CANAL FOUND NEAR RATES FOR REST FOR REST OF STATE
description: Former residents of the chemically contaminated Love Canal area in Niagara Falls show no higher cancer rates than other residents of New York State, according to a State Health Department study.

title: SIAMESE TWINS' PARENTS ACCUSED OF ATTEMPTED MURDER
description: The parents of Siamese twins and the babies' doctor were charged today with attempting to murder the infants by starving them.

title: STAGE: JEWISH REP'S 'INCIDENT AT VICHY'
description: THE Jewish Repertory Theater has been doing a revival of Arthur Miller's drama ''Incident at Vichy'' down at 14th Street. It will close after Monday and, because it is an extremely good production, that is a pity. This play opened in 1964, directed by Harold Clurman for the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater, and it has lost none of its force in the intervening years.

title: S.M.U. Put on Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association announced yesterday that Southern Methodist's football program had been placed on two-year

title: THE METROPOLITAN CELEBRATES NEW CHINESE ADDITIONS
description: The opening of the Astor Chinese garden court was just part of the goings-on at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night. A black-tie celebration introduced the court, Brooke Astor's latest contribution to the city, and the Ming furniture room, also made possible by Mrs. Astor, and the Douglas Dillon Galleries for Chinese paintings. Mr. Dillon is chairman of the museum.

title: Letters; THE IMPORTANCE OF THE FRENCH INITIATIVE FOR ARMS-CONTROL TALKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Jazz; CUBAN JAZZ FINDS HOME IN 52D ST. LOFT
description: NEW YORK'S Latin music, or salsa, as it is sometimes called, blends influences from a number of Latin cultures, but its most important styles and rhythms have generally been Cuban in origin. Musical communication between the United States and Cuba has a long history, but the latest chapter is being written at a performance loft called Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street, near 10th Avenue. Some of New York's most formidable Latin musicians and several remarkable players who have recently arrived in this country from Cuba are meeting there regularly to express themselves through the common language of jazz.

title: FACING U.S. CUTS, MONTCLAIR TRIES NEW WAYS TO RAISE SCHOOL FUNDS
description: This is how Ronald Reagan hoped it would be. Facing cuts of about $600,000 in Federal funds for the 1981-1982 school year, educators here say they will make up the deficit locally and drop not one program or teacher.

title: Letters; AN EVENHANDED PLAN FOR CAPITAL RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: NIXONS ARE PREPARING TO BUY $1 MILLION HOUSE IN SADDLE RIVER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon plan to buy for $1 million a modern home on a quiet cul-de-sac near a peach orchard in this small, wealthy community in northern Bergen County, an aide to the former President said today.

title: Violla Rubber, Producer Of Theater Shows, Dead
description: Violla Rubber, a theatrical producer, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. The British-born Miss Rubber was associate producer of Tennessee Williams's ''Night of the Iguana,'' which starred Bette Davis and Margaret Leighton in 1961.

title: What the Camera Didn't Show
description: The videotape that figured so prominently in the Metropolitan Opera murder trial apparently conveyed enough to satisfy the jury that Craig Crimmins, a 22-year-old stagehand, had voluntarily confessed to abducting Helen Hagnes, a violinist, backstage and wantonly killing her after an attempted rape. But equally significant is what the film did not show: Mr. Crimmins's actual confession and, still more important, how it was obtained.

title: IRAN DEMONSTRATORS WANT BANI-SADR OUSTED AND TRIED
description: Demonstrators calling for the resignation, trial and execution of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr roamed through the streets of Teheran today as a special session of Parliament was scheduled for Sunday.

title: Seagram Net at Record
description: Seagram Company Ltd.'s operating results set records for the threemonth and nine-month periods ended April 30, the company reported yesterday. Net income for the three months totaled $72.4 million, or $2.07 a share, up 37.9 percent from $52.5 million, or $1.49, in the 1980 quarter. For the nine months, net income was $1.4 billion, or $40.71 a share, due to extraordinary gains, against $113.3 million, or $3.23, in the like year-ago period.

title: Letters; BEHIND A STATISTIC ON BLACKS' INCOME
description: To the Editor:

title: PIERRE SOUPART, PIONEER IN LABORATORY FERTILIZATON
description: Pierre Soupart, the first researcher to publish scientific evidence of successful human fertilization in the laboratory, died yesterday of lung cancer. He was 58 years old.

title: TREADWAY COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NATIONAL TECHNICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-3 stock split paid Apr 30

title: 'RICHARD'S THINGS'
description: IF it does nothing else, ''Richard's Things'' illustrates what dire trouble an actress can land in when she works with a director with no understanding of her talents. Liv Ullmann, who can be so very sensitive and authentic, is this time called on to play a preposterous soap-opera queen. Looking doughy and frumpy, wearing a perpetual hitme expression, Miss Ullmann is cast as a widow who does little but sulk and tremble.

title: ADMINISTRATION SUPPORTS BILL TO INCREASE PHONE COMPETITION
description: The Reagan Administration, after weeks of delay, endorsed in general terms today a controversial Senate bill that would foster competition in the telephone industry and restructure the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Around the World; CHINA ASSAILS APPOINTMENT OF ARCHBISHOP BY JOHN PAUL
description: China's Roman Catholic Church said tonight that Pope John Paul II's appointment Saturday of Msgr.

title: Broad Raises Stake
description: Eli Broad, chairman and chief executive officer of Kaufman and Broad Inc., said he had increased his stake in that firm to 2,830,934 shares, or 23.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Broad said that he had most recently purchased 518,300 shares on June 5 at $14.375 a share. In his filing, Mr. Broad said that he may acquire additional shares in the future.

title: Market Place; Technology And High P/E's
description: WHEN is a high price/earnings multiple justified? Fans of Frequency Electronics say this New Hyde Park, L.I., atomic clock company justifiably carries a multiple of 50 - a multiple higher than that accorded to all but the most promising of companies.

title: Wilson Sees Commissioner In Effort to Play Football
description: In what he called a last-ditch effort to persuade the Big Ten Conference to allow him to play football this fall without pursuing the matter in court, Dave Wilson, the Illinois quarterback, requested and received a private meeting with Commissioner Wayne Duke.

title: EVE QUELER RESCUES ANOTHER OPERA COMPOSER FROM OBSCURITY
description: The names of Rossini and Bellini, Verdi and Donizetti shine brightly in every opera house today, but who among us knows of Saverio Mercadante? If history were just, we would. Mercadante lived alongside the luminaries of 19th-century Italian opera; and for one span of his life, he outshone them all. If there is one commanding link between Rossini and Verdi, it is certainly he.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 12, 1981
description: International Sanctions against Israel were urged by Arab foreign ministers and the Arab League in an appeal to the United Nations. The Arabs also called on the United States ''to work seriously'' to deter Israeli ''aggression and expansionism.'' Officials of the league, which is composed of 20 Arab nations and the Palestine Liberation Organization, met in an emergency session in Baghdad to condemn the Israeli air strike that destroyed a nuclear reactor plant in Iraq. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel said that Washington's decision to suspend the delivery of four F-16 jet fighters this week was unjust in that it failed to appreciate the defensive nature of the Israeli air strike in Iraq. The Israeli Foreign Ministry contended that the attack had been conducted after the failure of a long series of diplomatic efforts. (A1:4-5.)

title: Letters; H.U.D. CHANGES ITS COURSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Most Interest Rates Up Slightly; One-Year Bills Sold at 13.15%
description: Interest rates in general rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday. Securities dealers said that speculative buying of long-term issues slackened, while investors were not eager to add substantially to their holdings.

title: 13.54 RISE PUTS DOW AT 1,007.42
description: A growing conviction that interest rates have peaked touched off a rousing rally in stock prices yesterday in heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 13.54 points, to close at 1,007.42, going above the 1,000 level for the first time since April 29.

title: The Region; Jerseyan Convicted Of Slaying Prostitute
description: Richard Cottingham, a 34-year-old computer operator accused of preying on Manhattan streetwalkers, was convicted of 15 charges, including murdering one prostitute and kidnapping two others and a cocktail waitress.

title: FUMES AFFLICT 63 ON TRAIN
description: At least 63 people aboard Amtrak's Broadway Limited from Chicago to New York became sick today after they were exposed to a nontoxic chemical that had spilled from a freight train.

title: About Washington
description: It must be remembered that this is a city of two governments and of two vastly different levels of reality. There are the fine marble and cut-glass environs of the Capitol, where Congress is rushing this week to spell out the historic cuts in social budgeting, and there are the drab municipal offices of the District of Columbia government, where local officials seem dazed as they struggle to track what is happening to their budget lines just down the block - but far beyond their reach - in the handsome, busy Capitol.

title: Issue in Baseball Dispute
description: The issue that has brought major league baseball to the brink of a strike is the quality of compensation that a team should receive when one of its players fulfills his contract, becomes a free agent and signs with another team.

title: BERGEN BRUNSWIG CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
PRESIDENT IMPLORES SUPPORTERS TO HELP IN PASSING TAX BILL
description: Dusting off the cadences of the 1980 election campaign, President Reagan appealed today to 350 of his supporters to help win Congressional passage of the Administration's tax bill.

title: Advertising
description: THE first advertising campaign from Young & Rubicam for the Jamaica Tourist Board, seeking to sell the American traveler on the feeling of civility and gentility on the island, will begin to run Monday on television in seven markets.

title: GUARDS TERMED CORRUPT IN GREEN HAVEN INQUIRY
description: The State Commission of Investigation charged today that ''corruption on a large and regular scale'' had become ''institutionalized'' at Green Haven prison. And it called in a report for a special commission to make an investigation of the entire New York State prison system.

title: Conrail Cuts More Grain Rates
description: Conrail, the ailing, federally owned railroad, yesterday announced steep cuts, of 50 percent and more, in its intrastate grain-hauling rates.

title: CADLE'S 67 LEADS BY STROKE AT WESTCHESTER
description: George Cadle reversed an unpromising start today and shot a four-under-par 67 to lead the first round of the Westchester Classic. Cadle is as hard on putters as that television gorilla is on luggage, but he put his reassembled putter to work today and knocked off six birdies.

title: WALESA DENIES WORKERS PUSH FOR POLITICAL ROLE
description: Lech Walesa, the Polish union leader, today rejected criticism by the Soviet Union and Polish hard-liners that his union was counterrevolutionary or anti-Communist.

title: AMMONIA LEAK NEAR MINNESOTA HIGHWAY HURTS 30
description: Up to 50 tons of deadly anhydrous ammonia leaked from a storage terminal and floated across a highway, blinding, choking and burning at least 30 people. Eight of the injured were in serious condition today.

title: HAPPY WARRIORS BATTLE ON CITY SURPLUS
description: The battle lines over New York City's budget were distinctly drawn yesterday, with differences centering both on how much to spend in the next year and on what to do with an anticipated surplus for the 1981 fiscal year that ends June 30.

title: SLOW CLEANUP AFTER FLASH FLOOD
description: Residents of Cranberry, in northwestern Pennsylvania, clearing away silt left in the wake of a flash flood. Thunderstorms struck parts of Texas, Kansas and Missouri yesterday, flooding streets and causing some residents to evacuate their homes.

title: Around the Nation; A.M.A. BOARD CALLS FOR END OF U.S. TOBACCO SUBSIDIES
description: The policy-making board of the American Medical Association today urged the Federal Government to eliminate subsidies for tobacco growers. The decision came a day after the delegates refused to order that the association's tobacco company stocks be sold.

title: DENIAL BY REGENTS OF ACCREDITATION TO MOON SECT SEMINARY IS UPHELD
description: New York State's highest court ruled today that the Board of Regents had acted properly in denying accreditation to the Unification Theological Seminary, the school associated with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: Notes On People; WHERE THE PRINCE FITS IN
description: Where Prince Charles Stands in the Wedding Stamp The reason Prince Charles stood on a box to have his picture taken for a postage stamp honoring his forthcoming wedding to Lady Diana Spencer was not, you see, to make him look taller than his fiancee.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADERS PROMISED WIDER ROLE IN U.S. JOB RECOMMENDATIONS
description: The Reagan Administration today promised each of the 50 state Republican party chairmen that they could make five ''must-hire'' recommendations for Federal jobs in an apparent effort to assuage the state leaders' anger over what they see as a failure of the operation of the White House personnel office.

title: TENOR SAXOPHONE: GATE BARBIERI
description: born tenor saxophonist who appeared Wednesday at the Bottom Line Wednesday, has come a long way since the 60's, when he was a free-jazz innovator. Having pioneered in the fusion of African and Latin music during the following decade, he has more recently commercialized this fusion in formats that are closer to pop than to jazz.

title: Mine Union Resumes Bargaining As Construction Workers Picket
description: Industry and union negotiators resumed bargaining today for a new contract for striking mine construction workers, whose picket lines have shut roughly half the Eastern and Middle Western coalfields.

title: BELSCOT RETAILERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Riggins Returns to Redskins
description: Eleven months after he had left training camp in a salary dispute, John Riggins returned to the Washington Redskins today to participate in a minicamp. ''I'm bored, I'm broke, and I'm back,'' said Riggins, formerly one of the National Football League's top running backs.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title:
RED SMITH;
Pals in the Bear Pit
description: DETROIT IN the ring, Larry Holmes will endeavor to detach Leon Spinks from deavor to detach Leon Spinks from his intellect while Leon responds in kind. In the corners will be two lifelong friends - Eddie Futch, who trains Holmes, and his pal Del Williams, who handles Spinks. When they were kids sparring in the basement of Del Williams's brotherin-law, Holman Williams, it did not occur to Eddie or Del that, 40 years later, give or take, they might be in opposite corners with half the heavyweight championship of the world at stake between them.

title: More Thrift Units Cited as 'Problems'
description: The agency that regulates the nation's 4,700 federally chartered savings and loan associations said today that the list of institutions in financial trouble serious enough to warrant special scrutiny by examiners was continuing to grow.

title: Around the Nation; FIGURE IN ATLANTA INQUIRY CITED FOR TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS
description: A 23-year-old man questioned in the slayings of 28 young blacks was charged with five traffic violations today after he briefly eluded the open stakeout at his home last night.

title: energywatch
description: JUNE 5, 1981 Crude oil stocks fell to 404.5 million barrels, despite a rise in imports and decreased refinery output.

title: Ford Plant Retooling Set at $36 Million
description: BUFFALO June 11 (AP) - The Ford Motor Company plans to spend $36 million at its Hamburg stamping plant, just south of Buffalo, to prepare for new models and retool for existing car lines, the company said.

title: Auburn Ex-Coach Hired As Mississippi State Aide
description: Doug Barfield, former football coach at Auburn, has been hired as an assistant at Mississippi State, where he will work with receivers and running backs.

title: Paula Mattlin, 48, a Senior Editor
description: At Western Publishing Company

title: Around the Nation; FIRST CUBAN DETAINEE FREED BY COURT ORDER LEAVES JAIL
description: Amid cheers and shouts of congratulations, Genara Soroa Gonzales today became the first Cuban detainee freed from the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary by a court order.

title: Jersey Casinos' 'Win' at Record
description: The Atlantic City casino hotel industry reported a record ''win'' in May, taking in $89.2 million, or an average of $2.9 million a day, at its gaming tables and slot machines, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said yesterday.

title: Around the World; INDIA INVESTIGATES RAIL CRASH AS TROOPS SEARCH FOR BODIES
description: A Government inquiry into India's worst train accident opened today amid confusion over the death toll and the cause of the wreck.

title: U.S. ENVOY ENDS TALKS WITH BOTHA ON THE INDEPENDENCE OF NAMIBIA
description: West Africa, June 11 - Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark ended talks with Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa today and prepared to head for this disputed territory where he is due to meet tomorrow with leaders of a score of political parties.

title: WEST BERLIN GOVERNMENT FORMED
description: The West Berlin Parliament today elected a Christian Democrat, Richard von Weizsacker, the city's Mayor, moving the Social Democrats into the opposition for the first time in the postwar period.

title: Canada Store Chain Selects a President
description: Robert M. Herber, 46 years old, has been named president of Holt, Renfrew & Company, an 18-unit group of specialty stores in Canada, succeeding Lenard M. Shavick, 59, who continues as chief executive officer. Holt, Renfrew is owned by Carter Hawley Hale Stores, a major retailing organization in the United States.

title: Open Road Races Debut June 28
description: The world's first series of open running competitions, offering prize money directly to those who earn it and wish to accept it, will begin June 28 with the Cascade Runoff road race in Portland, Ore.

title: The Region; Sex Education Bill Fails in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Assembly dealt a setback yesterday to opponents of a state order requiring that sex education be taught in every public school in New Jersey.

title: Protracted War on Cancer
description: Has the decade-long ''war on cancer'' brought real progress against the dread disease, or has it been an extravagant $7.5 billion misfire?

title: New Proposals In Canada Rift
description: Optimism about an end to the long dispute between the Canadian Government and Alberta over energy prices and revenue sharing has increased after an agreement yesterday to step up the pace of negotiation.

title: 2 Yachts Report Trouble In Race Across Atlantic
description: The two French boats in the leading bunch of the trans-Atlantic yacht race to Newport, R.I., reported problems today as the fleet prepared for gales forecast in the North Atlantic.

title: RENEWS EFFORT IN ITALY
description: Giovanni Spadolini, head of the Republican Party, announcing attempt to form the 41st government since the end of World War II.

title: New Farm for Rangers
description: The Rangers announced yesterday the signing of a full working agreement with the Springfield (Mass.) Indians of the American Hockey League for the 1981-82 season. Since the 1976-77 season, the Rangers had been affiliated with the New Haven Nighthawks of the A.H.L. The Rangers shared a similar relationship with Springfield from 1958 through 1961.

title: Council Calls 'Reckless' Voice's Story on Slaying
description: The National News Council yesterday described as ''reckless and speculative'' a Village Voice news story about former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein and the man accused as his killer, Dennis Sweeney.

title: NOW, MITTERRAND'S SECOND HURDLE
description: France's legislative elections, which begin Sunday, will determine how far the new, Socialist President, Francois Mitterrand, is allowed to go with his radical economic program and whether or not Communist ministers will join his Cabinet.
