title: VISIT TO CAIRO BY PERES IS PUT OFF IN WAKE OF ISRAEL'S RAID ON IRAQ
description: A planned visit to Egypt by Shimon Peres, the Israeli opposition leader, has been put off in the aftermath of Israel's bombing of the nuclear reactor center in Iraq last Sunday.

title: Miss Comaneci's Coaches To Take Oklahoma Posts
description: The Rumanian gymnastics coaches who led Nadia Comaneci to 1976 Olympic gold medals arrived in Tulsa yesterday after signing contracts to coach the women's team at the University of Oklahoma and work at a private gymnastics club in Norman, Okla., officials said.

title: Around the World; AFGHAN LEADER NAMES ALLY TO SUCCEED HIM AS PREMIER
description: President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan gave up the post of Prime Minister today and gave the job to a close ally in a major Government shake-up.

title: G.O.P. IN HOUSE BEGINS TO DRAFT BUDGET TRIMS AS FOES PLAN TO FOIL W RIGHT EFFORT
description: House Republicans today began drafting their own package of $36 billion in budget cuts out of a total of $655 billion in current spending for the fiscal year 1981 as House Democrats weighed strategies to prevent such a package from reaching the floor.

title: Bridgeport Hails Barnum
description: The showman P.T. Barnum, who came from Bridgeport, Conn., and who was once mayor of that city, will be honored at the 33d Barnum Festival in Bridgeport, which runs through July 4.

title: The U.N. Today; June 12, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FLEA MARKETS IN SEASON AGAIN ALL OVER REGION
description: THIS is the month of flowering roses, flights of June bugs and a bonanza of flea markets, collectibles shows, antiques fairs and street bazaars. And this weekend may be the time when such events peak throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, attracting thousands of the curious and challenging the most compulsive collectors.

title: HIGH COURT TO RULE ON IRAN ASSETS
description: The Supreme Court, setting the stage for an important test of Presidential authority, agreed today to decide whether the White House had the legal and constitutional right to fulfill the financial agreements with Iran that led to the release of the American hostages last January.

title: BRIGHT FUTURE IS SEEN IN UNDERGROUND DEVELOPMENT; EARTH ON THREE SIDES AND THE TOP
description: The development of underground space for residential and commercial uses is increasing, and an organization that is promoting this trend says it may have important implications for cutting energy consumption, reducing pollution and traffic congestion and meeting the housing and food needs of developing nations.

title: SELLERS AND AZNAVOUR AS WORLD WAR II PRISONERS
description: NOT every adventure story lends itself to screen treatment, and ''The Blockhouse'' is a case in point. This 1976 film, previously unreleased and having its premiere today at the Thalia, is about seven men who were trapped underground for six years, four of which were spent in total darkness. The movie is grim, gray and almost as claustrophobic as the situation.

title: ARAB LEAGUE URGES SANCTIONS ON ISRAEL FOR ATTACK ON IRAQ
description: Arab foreign ministers and officials of the Arab League called today on the United Nations to impose ''binding sanctions'' on Israel, and they urged the United States ''to work seriously'' to curb Israeli ''aggression and expansionism.''

title: THE AGE OF SPITE
description: Albert An affable President who radiates good humor and personal warmth is leading the nation into an Age of Spite.

title: BALLET: ROBBINS CREATES 'PIANO PIECES' FOR FESTIVAL
description: Festivals make strange bedfellows. If George Balanchine, the New York City Ballet's artistic director, had not dreamed up the company's current Tchaikovsky Festival, Jerome Robbins and Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky might never have gotten together in public. And Mr. Robbins would not have created another major ballet, ''Piano Pieces,'' which sent a public into a cheering ovation at its world premiere Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: House Passes Nuclear Arms Bill With Funds for Neutron Warhead
description: The House of Representatives yesterday approved $5.06 billion for nuclear weapons programs after overwhelmingly rejecting an effort to delete money for the neutron warhead.

title: Letters; IN CASE OF EMERGENCY, YOU'RE TRAPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; NIXONS TO GIVE UP MANHATTAN TOWN HOUSE
description: Only hours after word got out that Richard M. Nixon and his wife were buying a $1 million modern house in New Jersey, the Nixons decided they would also give up their town house in Manhattan.

title: New York; EIGHT ISN'T ENOUGH
description: One of the best recent examples of politics as usual was the City Council's redrawing of its district lines to conform to the results of the 1980 census.

title: PAKISTAN IS BEING OFFERED THE F-16 AS PART OF A U.S. MILITARY AID PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to offer 15 and possibly more American-built F-16 fighter planes to Pakistan as part of a five-year economic and military assistance package, Administration officials said today.

title: Peking Facing a Severe Drought
description: The Peking area is facing its worst drought in 100 years, Vice Mayor Chen Xitong said today as he issued an appeal to city residents to conserve water. No substantial rainfall has fallen for 21 months, he said, and the amount of water in the city's two biggest reservoirs is down 85 percent from last year.

title: McNeil Signed by Jets
description: The Jets announced yesterday the signing of Freeman McNeil, the team's No. 1 draft choice, and three other picks. McNeil, a running back from U.C.L.A., was signed Thursday night in Los Angeles by Steve Gutman, the team's administrative manager.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NOVO GETS CLEARANCE FOR INSULIN TRIALS
description: Novo Laboratories Inc., a subsidiary of Denmark's Novo Industri A/S, said yesterday that it had received clearance from the United States Food and Drug Administration to begin second-phase clinical trials with human insulin-equivalent for treatment of diabetics.

title: HEARINGS ON RULE IN VOTING ACT END
description: The last of two public House hearings on an extension of a Voting Rights Act provision ended here today, and a Republican Congressman who has opposed such legislation said that monitoring of some states' electoral changes might still be necessary.

title: GILBERT AND THOMPSON LEAD BY SHOT AT 136
description: Two tour veterans, Gibby Gilbert with a 66 and Leonard Thompson with a 65, surprised themselves today and shared the lead at 136 after the second round of the Westchester Classic.

title: Police Kill a Man Wielding a Gun At Housing Project on East Side
description: An unidentified man who was threatening passers-by with a handgun was fatally shot last night by police officers summoned to a Lower East Side housing project, the police said.

title: EXPORTS OFF FOR TOYOTA AND NISSAN
description: The two largest car makers in Japan, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, said yesterday that their production and their exports to the United Stattes had dropped in May from a year earlier, partly because of export restraints.

title: Letters; A FREEWAY REFUGE APPRAISES THE M.T.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: FANS ARE DISILLUSIONED BY BOTH SIDES
description: The feelings of 30 people sampled randomly in midtown yesterday brought forth two consistent reactions to the baseball strike: The issues are not clearly understood, even by those who consider themselves fans, and the true victims of the play stoppage are the fans.

title: OPERA: 'AN ACTOR'S REVENGE,' BY MIKI
description: The attempt to blend Western musical traditions with those of the Orient has a rich history. Such composers as Debussy, Puccini, Holst, Britten, Mahler and Webern have expropriated Eastern musical ideas while still holding to an unmistakably Western viewpoint. A few Oriental composers, such as Toru Takemitsu, have approached from the other direction, in hopes of retaining the integrity of their own heritage while making its essence accessible to Western audiences. That is what the contemporary Japanese composer Minoru Miki has tried to do in ''An Actor's Revenge,'' his ''Kabuki opera,'' which was given its American premiere last night by the Opera Theater of St. Louis.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
HOUSE PANEL BACKS FUNDS FOR LAND FOR NATIONAL PARKS
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt's plan to stop buying more land for national parks and instead use the money to rehabilitate existing parklands has been rejected by the House Interior and Insular Affairs committee.

title: ALASKANS SEE A DELAY IN GAS LINE
description: An increasing number of Alaskans are coming to the conclusion that construction of a natural gas pipeline from Prudhoe Bay to the Canadian border will not begin within the next year or two, mainly because of financial and political problems.

title: therapist FOR 2 WOUNDED OFFICERS, IT IS A PAINFUL ROAD BACK
description: A few minutes before noon last March 5, a Manhattan bank robber fired two shots at Police Officer Fred Marinovich. The first bullet hit the officer in the arm, spinning him completely around; the second pierced his back just below his bulletproof vest.

title: WACHOVIA REALTY INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
No Headline
description: STICKY SITUATION IN HAGLER FIGHT

title: Teamsters' President Pleads Not Guilty to Conspiracy
description: Roy Lee Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four other men today pleaded not guilty to charges that they had conspired to bribe a United States Senator to influence trucking legislation.

title: Strike Issue Has Basis in Past
description: The issue that put the baseball players of the major leagues on strike yesterday - the extent to which a club owner possesses the right to a player's services - has rankled the game for nearly a hundred years.

title: SHINING'S OUT IN ARMY TEST OF NEW BOOT
description: Across this vast Army post, the swamps of Florida, the snows of Alaska and a small base in Maryland, soldiers are testing a new combat boot.

title: Miss Caponi Ahead by a Stroke
description: Donna Caponi, who won the Ladies' Professional Golf Association championship two years ago here at the Jack Nicklaus Golf Center, took the lead by one shot today halfway through the 27th edition of the same tournament.

title: HOLMES KNOCKS OUT SPINKS IN 3D ROUND AND RETAINS HEAVYWEIGHT TITLE
description: It was short and violent in the way heavyweight championship fights are supposed to be, and Larry Holmes won it in the way heavyweight champions are supposed to win. Withstanding the bruising pressure of Leon Spinks until he could spot the opening he needed, the undefeated Holmes scored a technical knockout at 2:34 of the third round before an estimated crowd of 10,000 at the 21,000-seat Joe Louis Arena tonight.

title: The Region; Spy Ship Off L.I.  Awaits Trident Sub
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - A Soviet intelligence-gathering ship is cruising in international waters off Long Island, where the first Trident missile-carrying submarine will conduct sea trials for the first time next week, Administration sources said yesterday.

title: MILLIONS IN ITALY WATCHING BID TO SAVE BOY IN WELL
description: In a rescue drama that brought the President of Italy to this hilly community 12 miles from Rome, a 6-year-old boy who fell into a well three days ago slipped deeper into the shaft last night as rescue workers broke through an adjoining tunnel.

title: QUALITY CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: B-After $2,775,174 charge representing the cumulative effect of accounting change; yr-ago results have been restated to give ef acquisition as poolings-of interests and to the change in the m of accounting for revs from investor-owned franchises

title: HALSTON'S EASY-TO-WEAR
description: The mad fashion designer has a role in contemporary folklore similar to that of the mad scientist. Instead of developing potions to destroy the world or create a race of robots, the designer creates bizarre apparel that makes women look weird and inhibits mobility.

title: Mounties Accused of Illegal Acts Against Parti Quebecois in 70's
description: The Quebec government has charged 17 serving or former members of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police with involvement in illegal operations against Quebec separatists in the early 1970's, a Justice Department official said today.

title: TRUDEAU SAYS HE WILL STEER SUMMIT MEETING IN JULY TO BASIC ISSUES
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, who will preside over the summit meeting here next month of seven leading industrial nations, said today that he would seek to force a choice between ''papering over differences'' or seeking basic agreements that would allow the West to ''manage'' political and economic crises in the world.

title: Observer; FLICKING THE DIAL
description: Saturday afternoon with the TV set: ''... and that's the scene here at the 12th hole in Dubrovnik, where Watson has just birdied his five iron to fall two runs behind Mario Andretti. Now we go to Lake Ladoga for the quarter-final competition in water skiing where beautiful Amanda ...''

title: SUMMER HAVEN FOR FUR COATS
description: THE annual ritual of sending furs to a cool climate is on. While there is nothing that can regenerate a fur coat's natural oils, constant cold does help to retain them. Fur storage vaults, where the temperature is maintained between 38 and 45 degrees and the humidity is around 50 percent, are the most sensible places to keep furs pliable (most experts also recommend an annual cleaning), free from moths and larva and, last but not least, safe. The following is a listing of fur storage vaults (most are not on the store's premises) and charges around town.

title: FUEL OIL PRICE IS CUT AGAIN BY VENEZUELA
description: Venezuela's state oil company announced yesterday that it had reduced the prices of its heavy fuel oil by $2.50 to $3 a barrel, the second major reduction in two weeks. These and other price cuts are expected to show up soon in lower electricity bills for consumers when fuel-adjustment clauses are applied.

title: F.C.C. HEAD VOWS EASED TV RULES
description: The new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission promised today to pursue the deregulation of the television industry and strongly hinted that he might support repeal of rules ranging from ownership and licensing restrictions to the fairness doctrine.

title: The Region; Dentist Testifies In Slaying of Guard
description: The teeth of a man accused of murdering a prison guard match bite wounds found on the guard's body and on the body of a Schenectady woman the same man was accused of murdering, a forensic dentist testified.

title: JAPANESE NOODLES AS FAST FOOD
description: The palate dulled by greasy burgers may savor more exotic fast food these days. At least that is the hope of the Larmen Dosanko, a chain of New York fast-food restaurants serving a northern Japanese cuisine based on the buckwheat noodle.

title: OUTLOOK FOR PLAYERS: WORKOUTS, WAITING
description: Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox said he was going fishing. And he will work out with his son's team in the Cape Cod League. Pete Rose of the Philadelphia Phillies, one hit shy of breaking the National League record for hits, headed home to Cincinnati. He will work out on some school field until he gets the chance to swing for No. 3,631.

title: CDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $29,000 income for the qr and $69,000 loss for the discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinued of $78,000 for the qr and $435,000 for the yr; yr-ago results h restated for a change in accounting for compensated absences

title: chairman of its executive committee A CHANGE AT TROUBLED VORNADO
description: In the debris-strewn history of American discount retailing, Vornado Inc., operator of the Two Guys chain, always loomed as a survivor - scarred perhaps, but durable.

title: 8 VIE FOR MISSISSIPPI SEAT VACATED BY REP. HINSON
description: ''Up in Washington, the Democrats need something to crow about,'' Britt Singletary, a 30-year-old white lawyer, told a group of blacks gathered at poolside last night for a beer and catfish rally for his Congressional campaign.

title: The U.N. Today; June 13, 1981; ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL
description: Unicef Executive Board - 11 A.M.

title: PENRIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
News Analysis
description: The Taiwan Government is looking toward Peking with greater nervousness than usual. With the arrival there June 14 of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., Taipei is anxiously awaiting the first official declarations of the Reagan Administration's China policy.

title: REAGAN FORCES SEEKING TO RESCIND CUT
description: The House Education and Labor Committee has maneuvered the Reagan Administration into the awkward position of having to plead with Congress to continue aid to schools serving large numbers of children of military personnel.

title: JURY INVESTIGATING ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL OVER CHARGES TO SPACE AGENCY
description: A Federal grand jury in Los Angeles is investigating allegations that Rockwell International Inc., the prime contractor for the space shuttle, mischarged the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for work actually done for the Air Force, according to law enforcement officials and court papers in Los Angeles.

title: Seoul Reports Fishermen Seized
description: A South Korean fishing boat with 21 crewmen aboard was seized yesterday by North Korean naval patrol craft near the western sea border, the Office of Fisheries said today. Officials said the South Korean ship had lost its direction in dense fog but had not crossed the sea border.

title: Yanks Get Reuschel for Bird
description: The Yankees' long quest for an experienced right-handed starting pitcher ended only hours before the baseball strike started. In a trade completed Thursday night and announced yesterday, the Yankees acquired Rick Reuschel from the Chicago Cubs for the pitcher Doug Bird and a minor league player to be named, presumably Pat Tabler, a second baseman.

title:
Patents steel as demonstrated by John C. Walling;
Laser With Alexandrite For High-Power Uses
description: A laser regarded as useful in defense communication, isotope separation, photochemistry and other fields was patented this week for the Allied Corporation, Morris Township, N.J. Patent 4,272,733 was obtained by John C. Walling, Robert C. Morris and Otis G. Peterson, scientists, and Hans P. Jenssen, a consultant.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including gains on the sale of recreational leases of $237,73 latest first qr and $37,188 for the previous first qr

title: TENANTS NEED BARGAINING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TRADE CONFLICTS OF U.S. AND EUROPE and jagged upward climb of the economy
description: The United States and the European Economic Community are trying to deal with a sudden rash of trade disputes erupting from long-running economic problems on both sides of the Atlantic that have sharpened competition for exports and jobs.

title: The Region; 2 Allegedly in Mobs Accused of Extortion
description: NEW HAVEN (UPI) - Two reputed underworld cousins were arrested yesterday on charges of conspiring to extort money and ''valuable rights'' from Wayne Newton and Lola Falana, the entertainers, through threats, violence and fear.

title: Nigel Winfield Denied License
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board refused yesterday to grant an owner's license to Nigel Winfield and began proceedings to revoke the license of his father, Malcolm.

title: P
description: Yesterday, on the first day of the major league baseball strike, the effects of the work stoppage were already being felt by team owners and hotdog vendors, television executives and airline companies, players and fans.

title: ENVIRONMENT AGENCY CHIEF ANNOUNCES REORGANIZATION
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced today a major reorganization of the agency, including the elimination of its Office of Enforcement.

title: SOL LIPMAN
description: Sol Lipman, a New York City real-estate broker and developer, died Thursday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 87 years old. Mr. Lipman was part of a real-estate syndicate that negotiated the land sale leading to the construction of a bus terminal in Jamaica, Queens. He served in the Army in World War I.

title: The City; Dr. Cahill Is Named To Board of Health
description: Dr. Kevin M. Cahill, once one of the more powerful members of Governor Carey's political inner circle, was named by Mayor Koch to the five-member New York City Board of Health.

title: U.S. Exports to China Rise
description: Exports of manufactured goods to China totaled $319 million in the first quarter of this year, up sharply from the $251 million sent in the first three months of 1980, the Commerce Department said today. Among the major exports to China, the department said, were polyester yarns, paper and paper-base stocks, phosphate, mining and drilling equipment, scientific and controlling instruments, chemical elements and compounds, kraft liner board, and iron and steel products.

title: LONG STRIKE IS FEARED AS BASEBALL SHUTS DOWN
description: Major league baseball's 650 players, engaged in an 18-month-old labor dispute with team owners, struck regular-season games yesterday for only the second time in history.

title: NAMIBIA SOLUTION HAS APPARENTLY ELUDED U.S. MISSION
description: West Africa, June 12 - A high-level American mission appeared likely today to return to Washington without having won South Africa's agreement to a set of proposals to revive the stalled international effort to bring this disputed territory to independence.

title: DANCERS BILLS IN PROSPECT PARK
description: Seven dancers and modern-dance companies will participate in a four-day dance segment of the second annual Celebrate Brooklyn performing-arts festival in Prospect Park, July 9-12, at the Prospect Park Ninth Street Bandshell at Ninth Street and Prospect Park West.

title: IS CHINA IMPEDING WESTERN REPORTERS?
description: Several Western broadcast news organizations, including the British Broadcasting Corporation and a CBS crew led by Walter Cronkite, have experienced difficulty with the Chinese Government in negotiating to film stories there in recent months. In each instance, the Chinese have requested substantial payments in return for permission to do the stories.

title: British 'Nicholas Nickleby' Coming to U.S. TV in 1982
description: The Royal Shakespeare Company's original production of ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' a hit in London for the last two seasons, will be presented in the United States on the Mobil Showcase Network in December 1982.

title: Notes on People; 'TAX REBEL' SENTENCED
description: William Greene, the wealthy, self-styled ''tax rebel'' who wrote a book called ''Welcome to the Tax Revolt,'' has been sentenced to two years in prison and fined $20,000 for evading payment of $97,000 in income taxes for 1973 and 1974.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
The Region; Tuition Rise of 18% Approved at Rutgers
description: The Rutgers University board of governors approved a tuition increase of just over 18 percent for undergraduate and graduate students for the next academic year.

title: BALLET: ROLE-DEBUT PARADE
description: American Ballet Theater's richness of repertory and young talent was demonstrated, once more, at performances last Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Debuts by Johann Renvall and Ronald Perry in an afternoon performance of Glen Tetley's ''Sphinx'' were both rewarding and provocative. Unsurprisingly, Mr. Renvall had no problems with the slithering pyrotechnics of Anubis, divine companion to the Sphinx.

title: SMITH URGES MIAMI BUSINESSMEN AS HEAD OF IMMIGRATION SERVICE
description: Attorney General William French Smith has asked President Reagan to nominate Norman Braman, a 48-year-old Miami businessman, to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.

title: INTERCOLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr ago results have been adjusted for a change to the LIFO accounting method in July 1980; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1981

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
THE VANISHED FLAVORS
description: Unlike the Proustian madeleine that evoked memories of an entire segment of society, a toasted almond Good Humor ice cream pop that was bitten into recently evoked nothing more than memories of other toasted almond Good Humor ice cream pops bitten into long ago. And with the recollection came the sudden realization that much of what was considered junk food in the 1930's would be labeled ''gourmet'' today.

title: India Ends Its Search At Rail Accident Site
description: Search operations at the scene of a rail accident ended today with the official death toll at 248, but reports persisted that the toll was far larger.

title: Bank Cuts Prime to 18 3/4%
description: United Missouri Bancshares said it had lowered its prime rate to 18 3/4 percent from 19 1/2 percent, effective today.

title: Mamby Keeps Title on Decision
description: Saoul Mamby, who had been told he would be fighting a southpaw, won a clear-cut 15-round decision from a righthander named Jo Kimpuani tonight and retained his World Boxing Council superlightweight championship.

title: Bridge: New York Team Is Favored In Grand National Playoffs
description: Zonal Grand National Team playoffs in Washington today and tomorrow will qualify one team for the national quarterfinals in Boston in July. The New York foursome of Brian Glubok, Michael Rosenberg, John Lowenthal and Phillip Martin has recruited Michael Becker and Ron Rubin, the country's most successful partnership in the past year. This sextet will be favored to beat teams from Washington and Pennsylvania.

title: Small Party in Italy Gains In Attempt to Form Cabinet
description: Senator Giovanni Spadolini, the head of the small Republican Party who is trying to become Italy's first non-Christian Democratic Prime Minister in 35 years, got off to a better-thanexpected start today in his first consultations with other parties.

title: DR. FLORENCE HALPERN
description: Dr. Florence Halpern, clinical professor of psychology at the New York University School of Medicine, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan after a brief illness.

title: Chicago Commuter Railroad Ordered to Keep Running
description: A Federal appeals court decision today averted a threatened weekend shutdown by a major commuter railroad that services 25,000 Chicago-area commuters.

title: About New York; A BRONX VALEDICTORIAN 60 YEARS IN THE MAKING
description: Lillian MacBain gave the valedictory address at Bronx Community College yesterday, and although she mentioned dedication and the pursuit of knowledge and all those other bromides that have reverberated through commencement ceremonies this month and seemingly for all eternity, she did give the 800 graduates something new to think about. ''Exercising the brain delays senility,'' Mrs. MacBain said with conviction.

title: TALKS RECESS IN COAL MINE STRIKE
description: Spokesmen for 11,000 striking mine construction workers reported that ''very little, if any'' progress was made today in negotiations to end the walkout, which has shut down most of the nation's soft coal mines. The talks were recessed until tomorrow. The construction workers have been on strike since March 27, when their contract expired.

title: The City; 2 Executives Admit Food Stamp Swindle
description: Two food wholesalers at the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx pleaded guilty to charges that they illegally obtained and redeemed millions of dollars in food stamps.

title: BEGIN GAINS IN ISRAEL POLL AS TOUGH IMAGE PAYS OFF
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin expanded his lead over the opposition Labor Party in a series of public opinion polls published today.

title: Belgrade May Seek $2 Billion in Loans
description: Yugoslavia's national bank has begun negotiations with banks in Arab oil-producing countries, Western Europe and the United States to borrow $1.8 billion to $2.1 billion to cover its 1981 balance-of-payments deficit, banking sources here said today. They had no further details about the talks.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: Vought Layoffs
description: The Vought Corporation said it was laying off between 50 and 60 employees at its Dallas and Grand Prairie plants as a result of slowdowns in commercial aircraft building. The company, which has 10,000 employees in the Dallas area, manufactures on a subcontracting basis the tail sections for the Boeing 747 and the horizontal stabilizers for the McDonnell Douglas DC-10.

title: HAIG, IN HONG KONG, SAYS SITUATION IN POLAND IS 'SERIOUSLY DETERIORATING'
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. held a news conference here today to express concern about ''the seriously deteriorating'' situation in Poland.

title: U.N. COUNCIL MEETS ON ISRAELI ATTACK
description: The United Nations Security Council met here this evening in an emergency session on Israel's attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: DELMEGAN, LEADING FILLY, IN YONKERS TROT TONIGHT
description: Del Miller couldn't remember whether it was Shakespeare or Kipling who wrote ''the female of the species is more deadly than the male,'' (it was Kipling), but he used the quotation today to point up the strong possibility that a filly would win the tomorrow night's Yonkers Trot, the first leg of harness racing's triple crown for 3-year-old trotters.

title: Emirates' Oil Output Off
description: Oil production in the United Arab Emirates fell 6.3 percent in 1980 but oil revenues nearly doubled as a result of price increases, the Emirates' central bank said today. Output in 1980 fell to 627 million barrels from 677 million in 1979, while income rose to the equivalent of $19.62 billion from $13.35 billion. The official Emirates news agency, which published the figures, said production fell as a result of Government-ordered cuts in January and August.

title: The City; City to Pay $25,000 In Woman's Death
description: New York City agreed to pay $25,000 to the mother of a 24-year-old woman who was killed four years ago when a boy dropped a rock through the window of a car in which she was riding on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the mother's lawyer said.

title: Humana Expansion
description: The Louisville-based Humana Inc. hospital company said it would seek regulatory approval to build an $11.5 million, 100-bed hospital in Hardin County, one of Kentucky's fastest-growing areas. Humana owns 90 hospitals in 23 states and two foreign countries.

title: PENNEY ADDS SATELLITE SERVICE
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the New York-based retail chain, has become the 21st company to sign on as a customer for the private-line satellite communications service of Satellite Business Systems, based in nearby suburban Virginia.

title: MICHIGAN FAMILY CHASES AMERICAN DREAM IN TEXAS
description: Pat Wahrenbrock has already sold the big sofa. Bob has found a buyer for the old stereo. One of the neighbors wants the plants. The living room is beginning to look a little bare, and it is a look that gives Mrs. Wahrenbrock a little twinge.

title: PANELS IN CONGRESS MEET GOALS IN CUTTING BUDGET
description: Fiscal leaders of the House and Senate reported today that their rival versions of budget cuts, while differing substantially in detail, had as a whole met or exceeded by as much as $2 billion President Reagan's goal of $36 billion in cuts next year.

title: The Party's Not Over Yet in Poland
description: Make no mistake about it: the poison pen with which the Kremlin has now addressed Poland's leaders is but the other end of a terrible sword. The pen, too, aims to force the Polish people to abandon their revolutionary experiment. The Russians appear to have decided that the top Polish leaders - Stanislaw Kania, the party chief, and Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Prime Minister - are weak-willed and heterodox and must be replaced. Yet for the moment, Warsaw has demurred and called instead for a concentration on economic revival under the direction of the present leaders.

title: DOME PETROLEUM BUYS CANDADIAN SHIPBUILDER
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, moving aggressively in a new direction, today acquired Davie Shipbuilding Ltd., whose shipyard at Lauzon, Quebec, is the largest marine shipyard in Canada, Dome announced.

title: THE STAGE: 'WALLY'S CAFE,' A COMEDY
description: If you're sick and tired of watching television situation comedies in the lonely privacy of your own home, there's now an alternative on Broadway. For the price of a theater ticket, you can go to ''Wally's Cafe,'' the Sam Bobrick-Ron Clark play that opened at the Brooks Atkinson last night. But why, you ask, would anyone in his right mind pay for what he can get for free? Look at it this way: ''Wally's Cafe'' is four times as long as a half-hour television show, is bereft of both laughtrack and commercials, and contains a smattering of four-letter words that are still forbidden on the major networks. With tickets scaled to a $27.50 weekend top, this production just won't settle for less.

title: Commonwealth Oil Accord May End
description: The financially troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining Company disclosed that the Esso Standard Oil Company of Puerto Rico, an Exxon affiliate, plans to terminate in June 1982 a crude oil and product purchase agreement between the two companies.

title: CITY NEAR ACTION ON BILL REQUIRING SMOKE UNITS IN MANY APARTMENTS
description: A bill that would require the installation of smoke detectors in more than a million apartments in New York by next Jan. 1 was passed by the City Council's Committee on Housing and Buildings yesterday.

title: SOVIET SHOWS DETERMINATION TO KEEP PRESSING POLAND
description: The Soviet Union today demonstrated its determination to maintain pressure on Poland's Communists, giving prominent display to a letter sent to Polish leaders and focusing press attention on tough resolutions passed by the Central Committee in Warsaw.

title: Books of The Times; The Fiction of Money
description: MONEY TALKS: Language and Lucre in American Fiction. Edited by Roy R. Male. Foreword by Ronald Schleifer. 149 pages. University of Oklahoma Press. $14.95.

title: KELLER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Remington Rand Plant to Arab Group
description: 's HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands, June 12 (AP) - An Arab business group has acquired the Remington Rand typewriter plant here, which was 54 percent owned by Claneil Enterprises Inc. of Plymouth, Pa., after workers' protests and last-minute negotiations with the United States owners failed to save the plant from closing.

title: 2 POLICE OFFICERS ARE SUSPENDED IN ROBBERY CASE
description: Two New York City police officers were suspended from duty yesterday as a result of a complaint made by a man who alleged that one of the officers, while in uniform and on duty, robbed him at gunpoint in a Harlem grocery last December while the other officer stood by.

title: Atlanta 'Suspect' Sues Over Recent Publicity
description: A 23-year-old man who has said he is ''a prime suspect'' in some of the slayings of young blacks here filed a Federal lawsuit today seeking to block law-enforcement agents and news organizations from publicly linking him to the cases.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Business People column on Wednesday, the name of the president of the Grand Union Company was incorrect. His name is Joseph J. McCaig.

title: New Datsun Model
description: Nissan U.S.A., the marketer of Datsun automobiles in the United States, said it had introduced a diesel-powered model of the luxury Maxima into its lineup.

title: J.A. Avellar Weds Amey C. Winterer
description: Amey Cutler Winterer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Steele Winterer of New York, was married at home yesterday to Joseph Anthony Avellar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Avellar of Brooklyn. Family Court Judge Mara T. Thorpe performed the ceremony.

title: Two Quakes Strike California
description: An earthquake jolted an area in the Santa Susana Mountains just northwest of the San Fernando Valley late yesterday, and another temblor shook the southern desert near the Salton Sea today, but there were no reports of damage or injury.

title: ATOM ARMS SPREAD WORRIES PRESIDENT
description: The White House emphasized today that President Reagan was committed to preventing the spread of nuclear weapons, especially in the Middle East, and that the Administration had expressed its concern before this week to the countries supplying nuclear material to Iraq.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $290,000 net provision for possible loss on a contract. C-Net income

title: Canada Oil Rift Imperils Project
description: Work on a $12 billion oil-sands project in northern Alberta will probably halt if that province and the federal Government in Ottawa cannot break their impasse over energy prices by the end of this month, a project spokesman said today.

title: QUAKE VICTIMS ARE QUICKLY BURIED AS IRANIANS TRY TO AVOID EPIDEMIC
description: The state radio reported today that the bodies of 1,400 people killed in yesterday's earthquake in southeastern Iran had been buried in individual and mass graves. The death toll was estimated to be more than 3,000.

title: AVANT-GARDISTS IN MIDTOWN FOR BENEFIT
description: Benefit concerts, like the ones being held for the avant-garde Kitchen Center tomorrow and Monday nights at the Bond International Casino in Times Square, are often as interesting as statements about the group of artists involved as they are for any individual performance one might see.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I did what I had to do. It is up to you to worry about the future of the Islamic revolution and your country and resist.'' - President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran. (16:1.)

title: THEOLOGIANS SPLIT OVER ABORTION ISSUE
description: Theologians expressed opposing views on the abortion issue today as a key Senate supporter of a bill to bar abortion predicted a new round of hearings on what he called a ''deeply emotional issue.''

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JUNE 13, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's basic money supply dropped $2.9 billion in the week ended June 3. The decline, larger than expected, caused interest rates to drop as traders anticipated further weakness in rates. Treasury bill rates fell, with three- and six-month issues quoted at 14.12 percent and 13.62 percent, respectively. (29.)

title: Letters; EAST-WEST IRREVERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POETRY

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Frontier Airlines filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $40 million in convertible subordinated debentures due in 2006, to be sold through a Kidder, Peabody group.

title: A.T.&T. Offering Raises $1 Billion
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company became the first company ever to raise $1 billion in a new stock issue yesterday when underwriters exercised an option to raise the issue to 18.15 million shares from 16.5 million.

title: CUOMO AT ODDS WITH GOVERNOR, IS REVIVING CAMPAIGN COMMITTEE
description: Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who has been in a public war of words with Governor Carey, but says they have not spoken privately since February, has reactivated his independent campaign committee in preparation for next year's statewide elections.

title: BANI-SADR SAYS EFFORT TO OUST HIM IS UNDER WAY, THREATENING HIS LIFE
description: 14 TEHERAN, Iran, Saturday, June 13 (Reuters) - President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr said last night that a coup was under way to deprive him of the Presidency and of his life.

title: INTEREST COSTS HURT FISH LURE MARKETS some of the company's fishing lures in the Akron, Ohio plant
description: As president of the Fred Arbogast Company, one of the country's top manufacturers of artificial fishing lures, Richard J. Kotis can usually be found by the water, at the lake where he lives, at a major fishing contest or sportsmen's show to demonstrate his products, or lecturing to or advising local fishermen.

title: IRANIANS FORCE SHIFT AT KRUPP
description: The supervisory board of Krupp Stahl has acceded to the demands of Iranian stockholders and has substantially revised its original plan to restructure the financially ailing steel company, which could have cost perhaps 5,000 jobs.

title: Danish Printers' Strike Ending
description: Striking printers at 48 Danish newspapers voted today to end their 11-week walkout, and most newspapers should resume publishing Tuesday, press sources reported. They said the country's 11,000 printers voted by a narrow margin to accept an agreement.

title: AN EGYPTIAN PREMIER AND CAREER DIPLOMAT
description: Former Prime Minister Mahmoud Fawzi of Egypt, who also served as Vice President and Foreign Minister in a career that spanned 58 years, died here today, the official Middle East News Agency reported. He was 81 years old.

title: Ann Brockway Married To Paul A. Murtaugh 3d
description: Ann Elizabeth Brockway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Brockway of Seattle, was married there yesterday at the University Congregational Church to Paul A. Murtaugh 3d. The Rev. Dale E. Turner performed the ceremony.

title: The Right to Ban Arms
description: When we got through to Fred Huber, village administrator of Morton Grove, Ill. (pop. 24,000), he had just finished interviews with British and Australian radio stations. The reason the news media artillery was homing in on this village just outside Chicago is that its trustees have voted to ban the sale and possession of handguns, making Morton Grove the first jurisdiction in the nation to do so.

title: Japan Issues Trade Report
description: The Government said today that Japan must step up direct overseas investment in other advanced nations and promote industrial and technological cooperation with them in order to stave off growing trade protectionism around the world.

title: Dow Off 1.14 At 1,006.28; Volume Up; 888 Stocks Gain As 680 Decline
description: Stock prices moved in a narrow range yesterday in accelerated trading and ended mixed in contrast to the market's sharp advance the day before.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Motors Corp. said it will resume operations at a stamping plant in Milwaukee on Aug. 17, for the first time since September. * Bentley Laboratories Inc. said it was seeking a buyer.

title: COURT OVERTURNS CENSUS DECISION IN NEW YORK SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned a ruling that had required the Census Bureau to compensate for a ''disproportionate undercount'' of minority groups in New York City and State.

title: Conservative Replaces Convicted Councilman
description: Michael R. Long, Conservative of Brooklyn, joined the City Council yesterday as a replacement for Vincent A. Riccio, the Councilman at Large and former Assemblyman who was sentenced Thursday to a year in jail for accepting kickbacks from no-show jobs on a state commission.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
TIMES CONVERTS A PRESS TO OFFSET
description: The New York Times has completed the conversion of a seven-unit letterpress press to offset printing, The New York Times Company announced yesterday.

title: BURRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 1
Soviet Sets Trial for Dissident
description: Viktor Brailovsky, a Jewish activist who was arrested last Nov. 13, will go on trial next week, his wife, Irinia, reported today. Mrs. Brailovsky said she was told the trial would start Wednesday. The 45-year-old computer scientist reportedly faces a charge of ''defaming the Soviet state,'' punishable by up to five years in prison.

title: Notes on People; SOPRANO TRIES KABUKI, AND LEARNS TO CROSS HER EYES
description: There are only two female characters in ''An Actor's Revenge,'' the Japanese composer Minoru Miki's Kabuki opera, but Cynthia Clarey, a soprano, was the only woman in the cast of the opera, sung in English, at its American premiere scheduled for last night in St. Louis.

title: Brezhnev Accuses U.S.  Of Indifference on Arms
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, accused the United States today of having no real interest in entering negotiations on arms controls and of seeking to tilt the European balance of power in Washington's favor.

title: TEXT OF BANI-SADR STATEMENT APPEALING TO THE IRANIAN PEOPLE
description: Following, in unofficial translation from the Persian, are excerpts from a statement tonight by President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr to the Iranian people:

title: Billy Carter's Property Is Seized For $105,000 in Back U.S. Taxes
description: The Internal Revenue Service has seized all of Billy Carter's property in Plains and his some and 56 acres in Buena Vista because he owes the Government $105,000 in back taxes and official said today.

title: DR. GEORGE R. READ
description: Dr. George R. Read, a urological surgeon and director of the departments of urology at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J., and Community Hospital in Montclair, N.J., died Wednesday in Mountainside Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived in Essex Fells, N.J.

title: IRISH PREMIER IN TIGHT ELECTION CONTEST
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey's Government was locked in an extremely close contest for its survival today in returns from the Irish parliamentary election.

title: PREMIER OF POLAND RESHUFFLES CABINET, ORDERS CRACKDOWN
description: The Prime Minister of Poland shuffled his Cabinet today and vowed to crack down on people resisting the party's leadership or engaging in activities against the Soviet Union.

title: 2 Human Plague Cases Linked to Domestic Cats
description: Two recent cases of human plague, including one that was fatal, were caused by domestic cats, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today. One cat infected her owner, possibly by scratching her, and the other bit a veterinarian.

title: OIL SPILL IN QUEENS LEADS TO EAST SIDE TRAFFIC JAM
description: An oil spill from an overturned tank truck on the Long Island Expressway in Queens backed up eastbound traffic for eight miles into Manhattan yesterday and led briefly to the closing of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel and an East Side traffic jam that lasted throughout the afternoon.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SUBSIDIZING OF STRATEGIC MINERALS
description: The Reagan Administration, concerned about the nation's heavy dependence on foreign sources for many strategic minerals, is considering a plan under which the Government would in effect subsidize the creation of domestic sources of supply.

title: by Robert Bendiner; HUN TINGTON, N.Y. - One of the more obscure, and not altogether unfortunate, consequences of World War II was that dozens of bombed-out zoos from the Netherlands to Japan had to be rebuilt from scratch.
description: Faced with the job of restocking, zoo people everywhere became acutely aware of what the wisest of them already knew: that populations in the wild, which were alarmingly low, could go only lower as animal habitats disappeared. If zoos were to have a future, they would have to change from being consumers of wildlife to producers. They would have to become in fact potential rescuers of entire species.

title: STUDY DISCOUNTS VASCETOMY PERIL
description: A new study disputes reports that vasectomies may cause heart disease or other serious health dangers for the 250,000 American men who are sterilized each year.

title: FLORIDA'S GENERATIONAL STRIFE SEEN AS OMEN FOR NATION
description: A few days ago, when the Florida Legislature was debating a bill to make it easier for the police to jail juvenile delinquents, a circuit judge, William Gladstone, said he detected in the debate a ''hysteria that wants to lock every kid up.''

title: GENERAL AND HIS ARMY WAGING WAR WITH WORD, PRAYER AND SONG Army
description: Gen. Arnold Brown has the erect posture and punctual manner of the professional soldier. He has been an officer for 46 years, but there are no battle ribbons on his military tunic, and while most armies now train with the technological devices of modern warfare, General Brown's troops pride themselves on the fact that their weapons and battle plans have not changed in more than 100 years.

title: John Sotomayor Flag Day Parade in New York ...
description: Two Days Early Students marching on Water Street in lower Manhattan in the Flag Day parade. Flag Day is actually tomorrow, but the Sons of the American Revolution and the Down-town Lower Manhattan Association chose to mark the occasion with a parade yesterday through the financial district to Fraunces Tavern, at Pearl and Broad Streets.

title: Policeman in Fatal Raids Ousted
description: A police officer named in five brutality lawsuits against the city and accused of using excessive force against blacke was dismissed today. The officer, Steven Reboul, was one of 14 who took part in two raids in which three blacks were killed during the investigation of another officer's murder.

title: U.S. and Greece Said to Adjourn Negotiations on Bases Until Fall
description: Negotiations on the future of American bases in Greece have ended in disagreement and will be postponed until after the country's general elections in November, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

title: POLITICALLY TINGED DEBATE ON FOSTER CARE FLARES ON
description: The Board of Estimate sought in vain yesterday to end a politically charged debate over foster care that produced a surprising defeat for Mayor Koch the night before and left him for a while in what aides described as a ''very upset state.''

title: Federal Jury Convicts 2 On Pornography Charges
description: Two New York City men were convicted today by a Federal jury on charges of transporting obscene films across state lines.

title: Farm Teams On Cable TV
description: The Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, a cable television service, announced today that it would carry International League games ''for the time being'' during the baseball strike.

title: U.S. Restores Livestock Funds
description: About $3 million has been made available to restore full Federal indemnity rates paid to farmers who suffer losses when livestock are killed to control the spread of brucellosis, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Detroit Businessman Is Chosen To Head U.S. Jobs Commission
description: President Reagan today picked William M. Bell, president of a personnel consulting company that specializes in placing women and members of minorities, to be chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

title: Why Weapons for Either China?
description: Secretary Haig's visit to Peking is not just your ordinary diplomatic foray. It signifies that even the most conservative of recent Presidents now accepts the strategic value of doing business with a country he used to dismiss as Marxist and godless. A lot of right-wing dogma has been silently interred as Mr. Reagan ''normalizes'' ties with China. But those ties may yet be unglued by a campaign promise to upgrade American relations somehow with Taiwan.

title: HERBERT W. GREENBERG
description: Herbert W. Greenberg, a partner in the New York law firm of Greenberg & Greenberg and a professor of law at the Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University, died Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness.

title: CITY TO LOSE 400 JOBS UNDER F.A.A. COST-CUTTING PLAN
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced a plan yesterday to consolidate its regional offices, and, as a result, New York City will lose more than 400 Federal jobs.

title: The Region; Jury in Westchester Notes Political Feud
description: A grand jury report said the operations of the Westchester County Department of Public Safety Services were hampered by an ''atmosphere of politics'' and a ''long-simmering feud'' between County Executive Alfred B. DelBello and Thomas J. Delaney, the Commissioner/Sheriff he suspended in February.

description: Mackie CLEVE LAND - Before voters in cities approve increases in their city income taxes, they should ask local officials to demonstrate increased productivity by their workforces.

description: Air Canada has scaled back its purchase plans for the new Boeing Company 767 wide-body jetliners in a decision that represents a potential revenue loss to the plane maker of nearly $300 million.

description: Two young men were arrested in connection with the death of William J. McGuirk, deputy chief of the Essex County Sheriff's Department, officials said.

description: ''GOING OUT for BUSINESS, up to 50% OFF,'' read the large sign in the window of the Silver Box Boutique on Maiden Lane in downtown Manhattan.

description: Turkish officials indicated today that their country would not be available for bases to support an American rapid deployment force if the United States took unilateral action in the Persian Gulf area.

title: Sports of The Times; Bleakly Looms the Summer
description: CHICAGO MARK DIDTLER knew there was a baseball strike yesterday, but he had to come to Wrigley Field just the same. He has been walking to the ball park since he was 6 years old, 14 years ago, and he couldn't let a strike keep him away.

description: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, said that Marvin Miller committed a ''harmful, even ridiculous'' act by failing to take part yesterday in negotiations between the players association and the major league baseball club owners.

description: A top Treasury official bluntly told the nation's foreign trading partners today that they could expect stiff retaliation from the United States if they acted, no matter how subtly, to restrict free trade.

Patents;
Spacecraft Wobbling Controlled
description: WASHINGTON EQUIPMENT invented by an RCA aerospace engineer will be installed in an unmanned spacecraft to keep it from wobbling when it takes off next month on an exploring mission.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 13, 1981
description: International Poland's economy faces ''chaos,'' Prime Minister Wojciech Jaruzelski told members of the Polish Parliament, who also heard him promise a crackdown on opposition to the regime and acts against the Soviet Union. Mr. Jaruzelski also reshuffled his Cabinet, as expected. (Page 1, Column 6.) Iraq assailed and Israel defended the Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor on Sunday. Representatives of the two nations clashed in debate in the United Nations Security Council. (1:3.)

title: GAMBINO CRIME 'FAMILY' REPORTED DOMINANT NOW
description: A Police Department expert on organized crime said yesterday that the Gambino ''family'' had apparently taken control of two other local crime organizations to become ''the dominant crime group'' in the city and possibly the country.

title: DR. RICHARD J. MAGEE
description: Dr. Richard J. Magee, director of research and development for the agricultural research division of the American Cyanamid Company in Princeton, N.J., died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Dr. Magee, a resident of Princeton, was 54 years old.

title: DAYTON MALLEABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Net loss after $3,691,000 loss from the closing of a foundry

title: Notes on People '; Royal Baby Named Zara
description: They've finally gotten around to naming the daughter that Princess Anne of Britain gave birth to on May 15.

title: COUNTERFEITING EQUIPMENT SEIZED AND 3 MEN ARRESTED IN BROOKLYN
description: The United States Secret Service said yesterday that it had arrested three men in Brooklyn and smashed a counterfeiting operation that had flooded New York, New Jersey and Las Vegas with bogus $20, $50 and $100 bills.

title: Your Money; Outdated Stock May Yet Pay
description: THE yellowed stock certificates tucked away in attics and rusted strong boxes are attracting increasing attention from investors. While few such discoveries will turn out to be the stuff of riches, some may have an actual or a collector's value.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $2.9 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday afternoon that the nation's basic money supply dropped by $2.9 billion in the week ended June 3. The decline was larger than analysts had expected and set off a sharp drop in interest rates.

title: Russell (Lucky) Hayden, Romantic Film Cowboy
description: Russell (Lucky) Hayden, known for his role in the Hopalong Cassidy movies, died of viral pneumonia Tuesday at Desert Hospital. He was 70 years old.

title: Mattel Cites Net Loss
description: Mattel Inc., the diversified toy manufacturer, said today that a sharp decline in sales of hand-held electronic games contributed to a net loss of $4.2 million in the first quarter ended May 2, compared with net income of $1.5 million in last year's first quarter. Sales for the three months rose to $191 million from $187 million a year earlier. Mattel attributed the first-quarter loss to significantly decreased shipments of highmargin, hand-held electronic game products.

title: GOING BACKWARD
description: Kazin I was astonished on May 18 to discover that the President of the United States, speaking at the Notre Dame University commencement, heralded such private universities as the only independent universities. ''If ever the great independent colleges and universities like Notre Dame give way to and are replaced by tax-supported institutions, the struggle to preserve academic freedom will have been lost.'' The President paid the tribute customary on such occasions to our Founding Fathers: ''A group so unique we've never seen their like since they rose to such selfless heights. They gave us more than a nation.''

title: VARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
CONCERT: BELLA DAVIDOVICH
description: The New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' series continued Thursday with an evening of Tchaikovsky at Avery Fisher Hall. Andrew Davis conducted, Bella Davidovich was soloist in the second Piano Concerto in G; as a counterweight to the familar Fourth Symphony, there was ''Voyevoda,'' an almost forgotten ''Symphonic Ballad'' written two years before the composer's death.

title:
On The Isle;
STRAWBERRY TIME
description: The time is ripe for strawberries on the Island, and rushing in with their annual festivals are St. George's Church, 319 Front Street in Hempstead, which from 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. today will serve the delectables, with or without ice cream and cake, along with a crafts show (donation $2; children under 12, $1); and All Saints Church, 855 Middle Neck Road in Great Neck, which for the 65th year will offer the berries (again, plain or with fixings; price to be determined), lunch, dinner and a carnival from 10 A.M. to dark on Friday.BUSY OLD BETHPAGE

title: FRENCH BEGIN VOTE FOR ASSEMBLY TODAY
description: Having elected Francois Mitterrand as President a month ago, the French will begin a two-stage vote tomorrow to determine the composition of the National Assembly.

title: Executives Say Federal Cutbacks Could Hurt New Jersey Rail Lines
description: New Jersey business leaders say the loss of Federal financing for railroads could be a setback for revitalizing downtown Newark and efforts to export coal through the state's ports.

title: WINE OUTSELLS SPIRITS
description: Americans have begun to drink more wine than liquor for the first time, according to a study of beverage shipments. Wine shipments last year continued their long upward trend, gaining 7.1 percent, while shipments of distilled spirits fell 3.7 percent, reported Impact, a newsletter that follows the alcoholic beverage industry. It said shipments of distilled spirits declined to 455 million gallons while wine shipments rose to 475.8 million gallons.

title: Littler, Barber Tie for Lead By 2 Shots in Seniors Golf
description: Gene Littler shot a 3-under-par 67 today and tied Miller Barber for the lead after 36 holes of the Peter Jackson champions golf tournament for seniors.

title: HYPERTENSIVE POLICE OFFICERS AIDED BY PRIVATE FUND
description: Four hundred police officers in the Bronx and upper Manhattan have begun taking treatment for hypertension as a result of a screening program that found an unusually high incidence of the disease among members of the police force.

title: Italian Party Leader Says He Has Accord on Coalition
description: Senator Giovanni Spadolini, who is trying to form the first government not headed by a Christian Democrat in the 35-year history of the Italian Republic, said today that he had reached agreement with the other parties in a prospective coalition.

title: SHEIL-SMITH TEAM IN JERSEY CITY FACES SHOWDOWN
description: JERSEY CITY VOTERS here have been to the polls twice in the last month, but they still must go one more time - on Tuesday - to finally elect a Mayor.

title: IN PRAISE OF TENNIS DOUBLES
description: LIKE so many of us who once enjoyed the atmosphere and tradition that was embodied in the United States Open when it was held in Forest Hills, I have considerable sympathy with the efforts the last three years to establish another major tournament there. I think that could be done, but not in the way that it has been attempted.

description: To the Editor:

title: BIG AS A BURGER, FASTER THAN LEMONADE SALES IN JULY
description: What's cookie on the top, cookie on the bottom, vanilla ice cream in the middle and chocolate chips all around? The Chipwich, the sellout offering of Richard E. LaMotta, 16 years a video engineer for CBS and now a brand new entrepreneur.

title: HELP FOR THE ELDERLY: WORKING FOR TAXES
description: THREE years ago, I had the opportunity to speak to a 75-year-old native Scarsdale resident. He was in good health and had lived in the same home all his life.

title: Topics; REINVENTING THE WHEEL
description: The village is 40 miles north, or south, of London. It has a pub, a fishmonger's, thatched cottages, a 14th Century church, some dotty old ladies, a few dashing young ones and a homicidal maniac.

title: Meta Herr Is Bride Of Judd Anderson
description: Meta Evelyn Herr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Herr Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday in New York to Judd Payne Anderson, son of Mr. Byron Edgar Anderson and Mrs. John Edward Schwarz, both of Edina, Minn. The Rev. Paul F.M. Zahl performed the ceremony in Grace Episcopal Church.

title: EFFECTS ON CHILDREN OF MARITAL BREAKUP
description: FIVE years after his parents' divorce, the 14-year-old author of a paper on the subject concluded: ''We all know that marriage is the major cause of divorce. But this is no joke - especially where children are concerned.''

title: 3 Men Deny Defrauding Producers of Five Movies
description: A local teamsters' union official and two other people have pleaded not guilty in an alleged scheme to get the producers of ''The Brinks Job,'' ''Oliver's Story'' and three other movies to pay salaries to workers who did not exist.

title: June 14, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE BACKBENCH DIARIES OF RICHARD CROSSMAN. Edited by Janet Morgan. 1 THE CHILD SAVERS: Juvenile Justice Observed. By Peter S. Prescott. 12 EDITH SITWELL: A Biography.

title: HOUSE HEALTH PANEL MAY CREATE A SEPARATE INSTITUTE FOR ARTHRITIS
description: The first tentative steps toward the creation of a separate national institute for arthritis, to focus more public funds and attention on the nation's most prevalent crippling disease, were taken this week in the House of Representatives.

title: The Nation in Summary; RUSSIA WEIGHS U.S. GRAIN OFFER
description: The United States last week offered the Soviet Union an extra six million metric tons of wheat and corn this season, making good on President Reagan's cancellation of the grain embargo imposed after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, but the Russians didn't say if they would be buying.

title: U.S. GETS SOUTH AFRICAN 'COMMITMENTS' ON NAMIBIA
description: West Africa, June 13 - Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark said today that South Africa had made ''commitments'' to the United States on steps it would take to end the impasse on independence for this territory, also known as Namibia, but he declined to say whether the pledges went far enough for the Reagan Administration to pursue its efforts to reach a new agreement.

title: About Long Island
description: SEARINGTOWN THE bar mitzvah is the father's coming of age. It is his announcement to the world: Look what I've done. So next Saturday everyone will be coming to that handsome temple, the Shelter Rock Jewish Center, thinking they are celebrating my son Mark's bar mitzvah. Little will that congregation know that it is also my bar mitzvah as a Long Islander.

title: Ootacamund Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Best Sellers; 'IF THERE BE THORNS'
description: The face of a frightened child, surrounded by a swirl of thorns, gazes from a cutout on the book's cover. ''This is the novel millions have been waiting for,'' says the come-on below. And then the title, ''If There Be Thorns,'' by V.C. Andrews. The cover pops open to show the whole picture, almost Dali-like in its technique: The child sits on the lap of a veiled woman, a sinister butler stands behind them and a pale nimbus is over all. It is the artistic introduction to what promises to be the hottest, biggest selling novel of the summer of 1981.

title: Music; SPECIAL HUDSON REVIVAL TREAT
description: TO attend any of the first three annual Great Hudson River revivals was to be reassured that our folk process is still alive and well. This year, the two-day festival, again sponsored by friends of the Hudson River sloop Clearwater as a benefit for its many environmental and ecological programs, runs from about 11 A.M. to dusk next Saturday and Sunday at Croton Point Park.

title: CRISIS IN POLAND: SOVIET FORCES FORMIDABLE
description: Although there have been no Soviet military moves of substance during the last week, the consensus among United States and other NATO analysts is that Soviet ground and air strength in and around Poland would be sufficient to deal with Polish resistance even should it take the form of a national rising.

title: Connecticut Housing; ECONOMICS BRING BACK THE LODGER
description: Arestaurateur, recently separated, has taken an airline pilot as a boarder in his 200-year-old colonial home in Wilton ''to defray some of the costs of keeping up the place,'' he said.

title: Connecticut Guide; BROADWAY FAVORITES
description: The Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam continues to revive sturdy old Broadway musicals with ''Funny Face,'' opening Wednesday and running through Sept. 12.

title: Article 156206 -- No Title
description: Fool's Prayer, benefiting from a 13-pound weight advantage, scored a four-length victory over the heavily favored Winter's Tale in the $54,500 Nassau County Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: MO BANDY IS RULED YONKERS TROT VICTOR
description: Keystone Triton finished first but went offstride just before the wire tonight and Mo Bandy was declared the winner of the $279,701 Yonkers Trot, first leg of harness racing's triple crown.

title: SOVIET WAR MEMORIAL IS DEFACED IN POLAND
description: White paint was poured over the 20-foot-tall Soviet war memorial in the main square of Lublin today. Lech Walesa, the union leader, calling the act a ''provocation,'' sent workers to clean up the mess.

title: Judy P. Briggs Married to Erik von Bucher
description: Judy Pierce Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Briggs of Naples, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Erik Peter von Bucher, son of Joan B. von Bucher of Greenwich, Conn., and the late H. Peter von Bucher. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Gordon Pearsall in the Naples Presbyterian Church.

title: CHINA CAUTIONS U.S. ON ARMS FOR TAIWAN
description: China has hardened its public opposition to United States arms sales to Taiwan, warning before the arrival tomorrow of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that the development of strategic relations between Washington and Peking could not progress if the sales continued.

title: Nancy Baird Has Bridal
description: Nancy Williams Baird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fitz Baird of Toronto and Harbor Springs, Mich., formerly of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday in Manhattan to William Whittingham Harwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roberts Harwood Jr. of Baltimore. The Rev. Ann Brewster Jones performed the ceremony in St. James Episcopal Church.

title: WHEN A PIANIST'S FINGERS FAIL TO OBEY
description: It was a bright October afternoon in 1979. On her way out of the house, Naomi Graffman stopped to look in on her husband, the pianist Gary Graffman, as he finished practicing the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2. The strange mistakes that had crept into his playing over the past year made the music almost unbearable to hear. As the last notes sounded, she invited him to come out for a walk. He was reluctant. There was a Beethoven concerto still to work on. ''Oh, Gary, please come out,'' his wife coaxed. ''It's such a gorgeous day.''

title: Pakistan Protests to Afghanistan Over a Violation of Its Airspace
description: Pakistan has protested to Afghanistan over the violation of its airspace and a rocket attack on a bus by three Afghan aircraft last Wednesday, a Foreign Ministry statement said today.

title: Melinda Rose Is a Bride
description: Melinda Gordon Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Rose Jr., of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to William Newsome Eichorn 3d, son of Col. William N. Eichorn 2d, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Eichorn, also of New Canaan. The Rev. Alfred Whisler performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church. The bride is a graduate of Mary Baldwin College. Mr. Eichorn, a graduate of the United States Military Academy at West Point, is a systems engineer trainee with the International Business Machines Corporation in New York.
