title: Realty News; John Street
description: Fundamental Brokers Inc., a commodities brokerage company, has leased the entire 4th floor and part of the 3d floor at 90 John Street for 15 years at an aggregate rent of more than $10 million. It occupies about 38,000 square feet of office space.

title: THE WORLD DEMANDS TOO MUCHFROM THE JEWS
description: Timerman ,2,475,0TEL AVIV - When news of the destruction of the nuclear reactor in Iraq reached Kibbutz Ein Shemer, where I was spending two days, the spontaneous burst of joy was unanimous -warm, earthy, expansive.

title: Caroline T. Watson Is Married
description: Caroline Trowbridge Watson and Wayne Paul Morong of Warren, Me., were married yesterday at the Old German Church in Waldoboro, Me. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr., minister of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: The World in Summary; Lopez Portillo Pays A Neighborly Visit
description: The relationship between Presidents Carter and Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico got off on the wrong foot and stayed there. The one between President Reagan and Mr. Lopez Portillo has been publicly less awkward, despite their greater ideological divergence.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Blanton's Uncle Sentenced
description: Jake Blanton, uncle of former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee, was sentenced yesterday to a five-month, 29-day term for bid-rigging and mail fraud. He is a vice-president of the family-owned B.& B. Construction Company of Adamsville.

title: POLAND MAY FIND MOSCOW ALL BUT IMPOSSIBLE TO PLEASE
description: The day after the Polish Communist Party Central Committee ended a meeting with no change in the moderate leadership but with a battery of resolutions promising to go on the offensive against ''forces hostile to socialism,'' the Soviet reaction could be read in a six-line dispatch by Tass.

title: Nancy W. Hoffman Married
description: Nancy Walker Hoffman and Peter Alan Seggel were married yesterday at Faith Lutheran Church in Lavallette, N.J. by the Rev. Kenneth Dorkof. He was assisted by the Rev. Philip C. Miller. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Hoffman of Lavallette. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Seggel of Panther Valley, N.J.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photographs on the cover of today's New York Times Magazine are incorrectly identified. On the left is Edwin P. Wilson; at right, Frank E. Terpil.

title: Letters; A DISHEARTENING PATH
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN conjunction with the first World Gathering of Holocaust Survivors commemorating the 36th anniversary of the liberation of people from Nazi concentration camps, which takes place tomorrow through Thursday in Jerusalem, the Jewish Community Council of Long Island in Plainview will pay tribute to five Righteous Christians, who endangered their own lives when they aided Polish Jews, hiding and sustaining them and helping them to escape from their oppressors.

title: Headliners; COLLEGE GETS ITS WOMEN
description: After a year's search, Sarah Lawrence College found its eighth president last week. She is Dr. Alice Stone Ilchman, a former dean of Wellesley College who served in the Carter State Department and, most recently, has been an adviser on international programs to the Smithsonian Institution. Dr. Ilchman indicated that her personal orientation toward things international will be reflected at Sarah Lawrence in a ''cosmopolitan curriculum.'' She'll take office on Aug. 1.

title: Djibouti Re-elects President
description: President Hassan Gouled was reelected yesterday, receiving 98,082 votes, or 84 percent of the ballots cast, official returns showed today. The President, who was unopposed, has led this Red Sea country since independence from France four years ago.

title: PARTIES IN COURT CASE IGNORE COMMON TIE
description: LAWRENCE THE issue of a violation of the village zoning laws has developed into a court case that involves an unusual cast of characters. The prosecuting attorney for the village, Howard Legum, is the chairman of the board of trustees of Congregation Beth Sholom. The opposing defense counsel is Mr. Legum's rabbi, Dr. Gilbert Klaperman, who also is a lawyer. The judge, Calvin Polivy, is the former chairman of the board of the same congregation.

title: Crafts
description: LAYTON ASSUMING that the kiln gods meet the schedule, hundreds of pots that make up the first body of work fired in the Peters Valley Craft Center's new anagama - that's a Japanese word for ''cave kiln'' - will be unveiled for public view next Sunday.

title: Letters to the Connecticut Editor; Capital Gains Tax Counterproductive
description: In her article, ''State Firms Follow Customers to Florida'' (May 10), Eleanor Charles states that a capital gain of $50,000 in Connecticut would be taxed at $3,500 at the current rate of 7 percent. This is incorrect.

title: FOR MORAL MAJORITY: A STEP TOWARD '82
description: ''The group that votes in the lowest percentage is the religious community.'' ''Recruiting volunteers is not proselytizing for your church or saving souls.'' ''Our task is not to Christianize America, it's to bring about a moral and conservative revolution.''

title: SCHOOLS HELP YOUTHS JOIN VOLUNTEER FORCE
description: WITH the recent development of a number of school-sponsored community-service programs in the county's public and private high schools, teen-agers are becoming a significant part of Westchester's volunteer work force. According to Ann R. Miller, coordinator of the High School Student Program of the Volunteer Service Bureau of Westchester, it is important to reach this age group and give them an idea of the concept of volunteering. ''It is a form of education for the future,'' Mrs. Miller said.

title: BALLPLAYERS ARE SEEN KEEPING IN CONDITION
description: By Steven Crist

title: THE 'THREAT' OF CREATIONISM
description: Isaac Asimov, a professor of biochemistry at Boston University School of Medicine, is the author of 232 books, including science fiction, books on literature, history, science, mathematics and the Bible. By Isaac Asimov Scientists thought it was settled. The universe, they had decided, is about 20 billion years old, and Earth itself is 4.5 billion years old. Simple forms of life came into being more than three billion years ago, having formed spontaneously from nonliving matter. They grew more complex through slow evolutionary processes and the first hominid ancestors of humanity appeared more than four million years ago. Homo sapiens itself - the present human species, people like you and me -has walked the earth for at least 50,000 years.

title: 2 MILITARY CHALLENGES REAGAN IS AVOIDING
description: In his graduation address at West Point, President Reagan re-emphasized his determination to spend more money for defense. Sustaining the political momentum for such increases may prove difficult; still, it will be easier than facing two fundamental military challenges that the Administration has so far chosen to avoid.

title: British Trimaran Leads Ocean Race to Newport
description: Chay Blyth and Rob James of Britain were reported to be nearly 100 miles ahead of their nearest rivals in the Observer trans-Atlantic yacht race today.

title: 37 Food Establishments
description: Fail Sanitary Inspection

title: HOSPITALS CHALLENGED ON TIES TO CHARITY
description: WHEN St. John's Episcopal Hospital in Smithtown opened its doors 15 years ago atop a rolling hill off Route 25A, it was largely with the financial help of the Church financial help of the Church Charity Foundation of Long Island.

title: Stage View; AL PACINO'S SUPERCHARGED 'BUFFALO'
description: Al Pacino comes into David Mamet's ''American Buffalo'' like a hand grenade. For the first few moments of Arvin Brown's Long Wharf production of the play, now established at the downtown Circle in the Square, the junkshop in which the piece takes place has been placid enough. Two petty criminals are planning a heist, true. But Clifton James, proprietor of the shop and presumed mastermind of the caper, has a bit too much belly on him to move around all that much. And he is, in any case, tolerantly fond of his flaky, curly-headed young companion, Thomas Waites. Though the lad is capable of uttering a sentence only after he has memorized it by rote, Mr. James is going to let him do the breaking and entering that may net them both a valuable coin collection. A conversation beneath the old bicycles and French horns that hang from the ceiling is muted, the plotting subdued.

title: KATHLEEN WINKLER, VIOLINIST, IN TULLY HALL DEBUT
description: As the recent winner of Denmark's Carl Nielsen International Violin Competition, Kathleen Winkler of Philadelphia came highly recommended to her New York debut at Alice Tully Hall Friday evening.

title: MONEY MEN ARE MINDING THE STORE
description: A MERICAN retailing, which some people persist in believing has mostly to do with merchandise, hasn't as much anymore. It is just possible that in these churning times, a retailer might make more money from financial wizardry than from the selling floor. The financial manager, not so long ago relegated to the back office and considered a dampening influence on the zeal of the merchants in the driver's seat, is rising straight to the top of the corporate ladder.

title: Amy H. Lord Bride Of Bruce Wilkinson
description: Amy Holliday Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Lord of Sheffield, England, and Mystic, Conn., was married yesterday to Bruce Echols Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Wilkinson of McLean, Va. The Rev. R. Francis Johnson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother, Mrs. Albert C. Lord, on Masons Island in Mystic.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: MEMORIES OF MERION AND BOBBY JONES GRAND SLAM
description: FOR $2.50 you could have seen Bobby Jones complete golf's only Grand Slam in 1930. That was the last day's charge for the United States Amateur Championship on a breezy Sept. 27 at the Merion Cricket Club's East Course near Philadelphia. For all six days a ticket cost only $6; gross gate receipts were a record $55,319 for 35,350 spectators. This week the United States Open championship will be played at Merion. If you don't already have a ticket, you will not be admitted - it's sold out. A limit of 18,500 paying spectators a day was fixed because Merion is small, but the gross admissions income is $1,654,516; prices ranged from $18 daily to $85 for the tournament.

title: DEVELOPMENT OF A BUILDER: POTATO FIELDS TO MAIN STREET developments along Route 107 in Hicksville, L.I.
description: ''Twenty-five years ago this was a dusty twolane road and nobody seemed to want to build anything but houses here,'' said Jerry Spiegel one recent afternoon as he maneuvered his car through traffic on North Broadway, Hicksville's six-lane thoroughfare. ''Today this is one of the main commercial and industrial corridors in Nassau County and now anyone who wants to be here today has to come to me.''

title: Nancy Grant and Jonathan Barns, Dancers, Are Married
description: Nancy Margaret Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Randolph Grant of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Jonathan Prescott Barns, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Frederic Barns of Westmoreland, N.Y. The Rev. George Pera of the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony at the Grant home.

title: THE G.O.P. BID FOR MAJORITY CONTROL
description: Adam Clymer is a national political correspondent for The New York Times. By Adam Clymer The elections of 1980 were a Reagan-Republican landslide, and Congressional votes on the budget this spring seem like reenactments. But those defeats of liberal lawmakers and programs may be only the overture to a far more fundamental political change in the United States. If Republicans capture the House in 1982 - something they plausibly hope to do and Democrats realistically fear - for the first time in half a century, or since Ronald Reagan grew old enough to vote, they may bring about a major and enduring political realignment, replacing the Democrats as the dominant party in the United States.

title: The Nation in Summary; COURTS GROUND A FLIGHT TO HAITI
description: Seventy-six Haitian refugees were all ready to take a free plane trip last week - until the courts intervened. Acting on a motion filed by attorneys from the American Civil Liberties Union and the Haitian Refugee Center Inc., a Federal District judge in Miami grounded the flight, which was to have returned the refugees to Haiti as deportees.

title: Letters; IS ISRAEL ALONE FORBIDDEN TO PROTECT ITSELF?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-SUPPLIED WEAPONS PLAY KEY ROLE IN MIDEAST
description: Israel's use of American-supplied warplanes in its attack on an Iraqi atomic reactor this week and the possibility of an Arab retaliatory strike have highlighted the role that United States arms and military equipment play in Middle East conflicts.

title: Baker, With 8-Strike Run, Beats Aulby in Coast Final
description: Tom Baker rolled eight consecutive strikes starting with the fifth frame today and defeated Mike Aulby, 247-205, to capture a $125,000 Professional Bowlers Association event, sponsored by Pennzoil.

title: HOBOKEN TO SEEK SAFETY OFFICERS
description: HOBOKEN DESPITE heated opposition from policemen and firemen here, Mayor Steven Cappiello is going ahead with his plan to create public safety officers, which would make firemen function as police officers as well.

title: Film View; PLAIN FOLKS ARE PLAIN TOUGH
description: We are under siege by ordinary people. Those aren't ''Dawn of the Dead'' ghouls stalking our movie screens in ever-increasing numbers but comparatively common folk who are coping, in one way and another, with a lot of the problems the rest of us face. The uncommon truth about these films is not that there are so many, but that so many of them manage to be as good as they are - making respectable films about ordinary people isn't easy. The two newest on the scene: Alan Alda's often funny, completely uncritical ''The Four Seasons,'' about three married couples who are seen entirely in terms of the vacations they take together, and Jan Egleson's ''The Dark at the End of the Street,'' a very good, beautifully acted, independently made film about blue-collar life in and around Boston.

title: Court in Albany Weighs a Motion Barring Additional State Inmates
description: A State Supreme Court justice reserved decision today on a request that the state prison system refuse to accept any more inmates until overcrowded conditions are eliminated.

title: Meg Ziegler Is Married to Harry Ferguson
description: Margaret Dana Ziegler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Ziegler of Billings, Mont., was married in Concord, N.H., yesterday to Henry Closson Ferguson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Ferguson of Loudonville, N.Y. The Rev. Theodore Yardley performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Chapel of SS. Peter and Paul at St. Paul's School, from which the couple were graduated in 1977.

title: FIGHTING AND LOSING THE GYPSY-MOTH BATTLE
description: FOR five years, we have been trying to teach our son about the subtlety, beauty and mystery of nature. We have tried to teach him to be kind, gentle, thoughtful and respectful to all God's creatures.

title: FREE- FORM JAZZ LOOKS BACK TO JUMP UPS
description: Before there were blues, there were jump ups. Back in the 19th century, when guitars had not been seen or heard very much in the Deep South, black people expressed themselves musically by singing spontaneous, loosely structured songs about their disappointments, their aspirations, and the life they saw going on all around them. When the guitar became popular, musicians began composing relatively formal accompaniment for their jump ups, and the free-flowing structures of the jump ups gradually solidified into what we know as blues.

title: RIGHTS 1, LEFEVER 0
description: The defeat of the unfortunate Ernest W. Lefever's nomination to the human rights post at the State Department ought to give pause to this insouciant Administration. Mr. Lefever for all his curious ethics was but one of many Reagan counter-candidates: men dedicated to dismantling the very offices to which they were appointed. That Mr. Lefever was the only one of these to be defeated is due less to his personal peccadillos than to the widespread bipartisan support that human rights enjoys in the Congress and the nation.

title: Nancy Traver Bride in West
description: Nancy Jane Traver and Andrew Mark Rosenthal, reporters with The Associated Press in its Denver Bureau, were married yesterday at the Mount Vernon Country Club near Golden, Colo. Judge Robert Fullerton of the Colorado District Court in Denver performed the ceremony.

title: FRASER: WHAT MUFFLED DRUM?
description: William SERRIN is a reporter who never lets the facts get in the way of a good story. His latest effort contends labor unions lack sufficient militancy and shun strikes in these difficult economic times.

title: TERRORS AND GESTURES
description: EDITH SITWELL A Unicorn Among Lions. By Victoria Glendinning. Illustrated. 393 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: A WAY IN AND A WAY OUT
description: I ALWAYS say that as far back as I can remember I wanted to be a writer. Is my story true? I tell it anyway. It's the writer's job to mythicize. What better place to start than with herself?

title: Teachings on the Mystery of Nature
description: FOR five years, we have been trying to teach our son about the subtlety, beauty and mystery of nature. We have tried to teach him to be kind, gentle, thoughtful and respectful to all God's creatures.

title: Hogan Takes 4th Title
description: Marty Hogan of San Diego won his fourth consecutive national pro racquetball championship today by beating 11th-rankedCraig McCoy, 21-9, 21-12, in the final of the $100,000 Leach National Pro-Am championship. Hogan, the nation's top-ranked player, won the $25,000 first prize and became the only pro racquetball player to win four straight titles.

title: Music View; IF WE LISTENED ANONYMOUSLY
description: Every so often, simply to keep us all on our toes, somebody should give a concert or two with the performers behind screens, the way some orchestras audition their prospective players. In fact, there might be something to be said for an occasional program in which not only the identity of the performers would be protected but that of the composers as well. Imagine the state of mind of the music lover who had to sit through an entire evening without knowing for certain whether the orchestra he was hearing came from Boston, Chicago or Indianapolis, and whether the conductor was the much-admired Maestro X or the generally despised Maestro Y. Imagine how much more keenly he might listen.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''While it is conceivable that the industry is being safely operated, the plain truth is that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission inspection program is not now capable of ascertaining that fact one way or another.'' - From a report by the House Government Operations Committee. (44:1.)

title: THE FALLOUT FROM BAGHDAD
description: The meaningful censure of Israel for the attack against Iraq should occur not in the den of its enemies, the United Nations, but in the minds of its most ardent friends in the United States.

title: Cousineau Joins Camp;
description: Tom Cousineau, the middle linebacker, reported for the final two days of the Montreal Alouettes' training camp in Victoriaville, Quebec, yesterday, but the Canadian Football League team still was awaiting the arrival of the wide receiver James Scott.

title: CHARMINGLY DATED
description: PHILADELPHIA Patricians and Philistines 1900-1950 By John Lukacs. Illustrated. 358 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.50.

title: Grand Jury to Investigate Killing Of a Brooklyn Man, 20, by Officer
description: A grand jury will investigate the killing of a man who reportedly threatened two police officers with a pistol, the police said yesterday.

title: THE LOYAL OPPOSITION
description: THE BACKBENCH DIARIES OF RICHARD CROSSMAN Edited by Janet Morgan. Illustrated. 1,136 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $35.

title: HOW CAN A UNIVERSITY THRIVE WHILE A CITY DECAYS?
description: WHEN I was a student at Rutgers Newark in the 1960's, there was barely a college or university to speak of: A few office classrooms, the converted Y.M.C.A., a renovated brewery and a razor-blade factory. But there was a city, a city still vibrant and interesting.

title:
Gardening;
POISON IN THE GARDEN: OVERRATED HAZARD
description: CONSIDERABLE controversy has arisen in recent years over the poisonous nature of certain plants, some of which are commonly found in our homes and gardens. It seems that stories of assumed plant poisonings have aroused a reaction in journalists similar to that of ''man bites dog'' stories.

title: No Headline
description: What the American economy needs are some positive incentives to encourage saving, rather than punitive measures designed to curtail spending, which ultimately seem only to increase the pitch of the inflationary spiral. More people will begin saving more money when it becomes profitable to do so. MARCELLE A. GILLOTT, Montreal

title: Racing of Aussie 18's Is Dazzling Newport
description: The sailboats rushed by at 25 knots as crews, standing on racks several feet off the sides, stretched out to keep their craft upright. As they whizzed by, the sails bore their commercial messages.

title: Antiques; BRONZES ATTRACT RENEWED INTEREST
description: Decorative bronzes - be they nymphs or elephants - are back in fashion resulting in a bullish market. European and American 19th-and early 20th-century figures and groups are once again being collected with something of the same enthusiasm as when they were new.

title: HOSPITAL FINDING NICHE AT STONY BROOK
description: STONY BROOK THE opening last year of University Hospital, which complements the Medical School at the State University at Stony Brook, has resulted in growing pains, not only for the hospital staff, but also for local physicians.

title: Natalie Cole Wed to William Smith Selby
description: Natalie Brenda Cole, daughter of Mrs. John B. Delaney of Harrisburg, Pa., and Alexander D. Cole of New York, and William Smith Selby, son of Dr. Cecily Cannan Coles and Dr. Henry M. Selby, both of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Bowers performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: The Region in Summary; A TOUGH CHOICE IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: New Jersey casino regulators have long been torn between the lure of Las Vegas-sized revenues and the fear of Las Vegas-style scandals, but perhaps never more so than last week. Just as the Del E. Webb Corporation, Nevada's biggest operator, was putting the finishing touches on what it hoped would be Atlantic City's eighth casino, the company went on trial in Las Vegas on charges it had defrauded a teamsters' union pension fund of about $1 million.

title: JUDGE WARNS AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLERS AGAINST STRIKE
description: A Federal judge in a court where strikes by air traffic controllers have been under injunction since 1970 has warned controllers who have threatened a nationwide strike on June 22 that they would be risking severe penalties.

title: THE 'NAUMBURG'-STILL A FORCE
description: Ellen Freilich is a freelance writer with a special interest in music. By ELLEN FREILICH

title: Article 156148 -- No Title
description: City officials have proposed a $218 million budget for 1981-82 that projects a $24 million gap and follows a fiscal year that showed the first deficit since Yonkers nearly went bankrupt in the mid-1970s.

title: COSMOS ACT TO BOLSTER DEFENSE
description: The Cosmos are the No. 1 team at the halfway mark of the North American Soccer league season although they have had their problems in recent games. In the last four games, the Cosmos have taken the lead and allowed their opponent to tie them.

title: THE LIFE AND EXCEEDINGLY HARD TIMES OF SUPERMAN
description: LOS ANGELES When ''Superman II'' opens in 1,354 American and Canadian theaters next Friday, it will already have sold $100 million worth of tickets on the planet the comic-book character has saved more than 100 times during the last 43 years.

title: SALEM II PLANT GOES ON LINE
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK AT 4:43 A.M. on June 5, before dawn warmed the bleak, marshy lowlands along the lower Delaware River and highlighted the hulking forms of the two reactors here, another nuclear station, Salem II, silently slid on line. Finally licensed on May 20 after a 25-month delay - and at a time when no new nuclear plants have been started and plans for more than half a dozen throughout the country have been canceled - approval of the Public Service Electric & Gas Company's Salem II unit may be something of an anomaly.

title: Dina Wallach Block, 98; Co-Owner of Newspaper
description: Dina Wallach Block, who was one-third owner of The Toledo Blade Company and a director of the newspaper for 40 years, died Friday in her Manhattan apartment after a brief illness. She was 98 years old.

title: Wedding Held For Miss Reed
description: Elizabeth Clarke Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Mason Reed Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Theodore William Gramkow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Warfield Gramkow of Woodbine, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith in the Congregational Church in New Canaan.

title: FINANCIAL DIFFICULTIES IN SIGHT FOR N.B.A.
description: The huge salary offers made to free agents under the new right of first refusal, coupled with a shocking report of increasing losses, has stirred fear among National Basketball Association owners. Reports say that several teams are for sale and that owners, for the first time, are openly worried that several franchises may fold unless buyers are found. Among the teams reportedly for sale are the Indiana Pacers, Denver Nuggets and Detroit Pistons.

title: Spider Spruced Up
description: IF you have never driven a Fiat Spider, the experience is something akin to learning a new word and suddenly seeing it all over the place. In the Fiat's case, of course, it is not so much a question of newness as it is of finally noticing just how many of these little cars are on the road.

title: U.S. CARIBBEAN PLAN TO STRESS PRIVATE INVESTMENT
description: An Administration trade official said yesterday that the United States role in a proposed international economic development program for the Caribbean and Central America would emphasize private investment and trade without asking Congress for more aid money.

title: Long Islanders; WAR EXPERIENCES MOTIVATE EDUCATOR
description: IN Nuremberg, Germany, in the autumn of 1945, a young American sergeant stood guard over a devastated city. At night, he presided over a moonlit panorama of rubble. By day, he witnessed a procession of the homeless, hauling their belongings in little carts and rummaging through refuse cans in search of food.

title: CENSUS HOUSING FIGURES SHOW 2 SIDES OF NEW YORK CITY
description: New York City distinguished itself from the rest of the country in two important housing categories in the 1980 census - one of them indicating poverty and the other, wealth. Government and private analysts say that taken together, the findings show that the city has some serious housing problems, including a growing gap between housing for the poor and housing for the rich.

title: No Headline
description: ''Ignominious failure'' well describes the past sports scene in Philadelphia, which Leslie Bennetts mentions in her article. As an editor working on a book about the subject, I thought I'd share some of the incredible Philadelphia believe-it-or-nots which have characterized that painful fandom.

title: PRIVATE-JOB EMPHASIS URGED FOR CETA
description: MINEOLA FOLLOWING the recent layoff of nearly 2,000 CETA public service employees in Nassau and Suffolk Counties because of budget cuts by the Reagan Administration, local government and business leaders are calling on Washington to create a ''new'' CETA with the emphasis on private industry.

title: DISCOVERIES OF SUMMER BECKON FRESH AIR CHILD
description: Michael Conley had never been to the country before he first went to stay with a family in Pennsylvania as part of the Fresh Air Fund's Friendly Town Program. The closest he had come was Central Park.

title: Plane Crashes in a Jersey Field
description: The pilot of a small plane escaped serious injury today when he crashed into a field and roadway about a mile and a half from Robbinsville Airport in Washington Township, Mercer County. Airport officials said that they did not know what caused the crash at 5 P.M. but that the pilot, 18-year-old Mark DiArchangel of Englishtown, N.J., walked away with only a few scratches.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL HAS YET TO SET THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT ON
description: FIRE By ROBERT PEAR

title: Peggy Rosenthal Is Fiancee of David Schneiderman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rosenthal of Harrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Peggy B. Rosenthal, to David A. Schneiderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schneiderman of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title: Reagan Selects Hummel As New Envoy to China
description: A career diplomat, Arthur W. Hummel Jr., was nominated by President Reagan today to be the next United States Ambassador to China. The announcement came four days after the Chinese Government publicly endorsed his selection.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on May 31 on the marriage of Carla R. Dragan to Chauncey Greene Olinger Jr. incorrectly identified the church. The ceremony took place at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: TWO DEATHS MAR LE MANS RACE
description: The Le Mans 24-hour auto race opened on a tragic note today when a driver and a race marshal were killed in separate accidents during the early hours of the 49th running of the event. Jean-Louis Lafosse, a 41-year-old French driver, dies en route to a hospital after his Rondeau crashed and disintegrated for unknown reasons.

title: Dance View; BALLET THEATER IN TRANSITION
description: Overall, Mikhail Baryshnikov has done an excellent job in his first year as artistic director of American Ballet Theater. There are many matters on which one can take issue with him, but the eight-week season that closed last night at the Metropolitan Opera House never lost sight of one crucial aspect. That was the very idea of an artistic standard by which the company's activities could be measured.

title: Riding High in Bermuda
description: To the Editor:

title: GARY BONDS HITS A NEW NOTE
description: UNTIL recently, Gary U.S. Bonds was a popular attraction at certain Long Island rock clubs, where audiences paid to hear him perform his well-known hits of 20 years ago such as ''Quarter to Three'' and ''New Orleans.'' Although artistically unsatisfying, playing the socalled oldies circuit proved lucrative enough for Mr. Bonds to live comfortably in Wheatley Heights.

title: Food; MAKING THE MOST OF LOBSTERS
description: Michael Geiger MAKING THE MOST OF LOBSTERS ver the years, many readers have asked whether the carcasses of lobsters, whose flesh has been used for anything from soup to salad, could not be put to some tasty use; the answer is emphatically yes. In fact, not long ago we made a delectable lobster salad with pieces of mango and red onion rings and served it slightly warm on a bed of lettuce leaves. After the meal, we retrieved the carcasses of the lobsters and, for dinner that night, converted them into a bisque flavored with tomato, spices and vegetables and thickened lightly with rice. It makes an elegant first course or, served with bread and cheese, a main course for brunch.

title: The Region in Summary; FED GIVES BANKS AN INTERNATIONAL BREAK
description: Although New York City has long been recognized as an important center of world commerce, Federal Reserve Board rules have denied it the international banking status of London, Singapore and other foreign money centers. Last week, after several years of study, the Fed delighted the city's bankers by voting to change those rules.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
A GOOD BET: SECOND MORTGAGES
description: SEVERAL years ago, Michael Zepralka had an idea for a company that would provide a range of services for condominium and cooperative developments. But with only one contract in hand, he recalled the other day, ''The banks didn't think it was such a good idea.''

title: David W. Maurer Is Dead at 75; An Expert on Underworld Slang
description: David Warren Maurer, a professor of English Literature at the University of Louisville and an expert on underworld slang, has been found dead at his home, the apparent victim of a self-inflected gunshot wound. He was 75 years old.

title: Wendy Fleming Wed to S. P. Cunningham
description: The marriage of Wendy Carroll Fleming, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Holt Fleming Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, to Stephen Patrick Cunningham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Joseph Cunningham of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Southampton, L.I., took place yesterday in Pepper Pike, Ohio. The Rev. Georoid O'Donoghue, a Roman Catholic priest and uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Garfield Memorial United Methodist Church.

title: U.S. MIDEAST ENVOY, HIS MISSION CLOUDED, VISITS SAUDI ARABIA
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, traveled to Saudi Arabia today after five quiet days in Beirut, his Middle East peace efforts cast into doubt by the Israeli bombing of an Iraqi nuclear plant.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC When Elvis Presley was making his first records, when he was still billed as ''the hillbilly cat'' and unknown outside the mid-South, Charlie Feathers was there. Mr. Feathers wrote songs for Mr. Presley, and he made records of his own that are some of the strangest and most distinctive examples of the fusion of blues and country music that is called Rockabilly.

title: THINGS ARE LIVELY AROUND A CORNER HOUSE
description: A house on a corner seems to invite the unusual. Baldur and Friederike Peter, who purchased their Smithtown, L.I., home eight years ago from a doctor, say that former patients frequently ring the bell because they remember the corner, but do not remember that the doctor has moved.moved.

title: BACH AND SOME ORGANS OF HIS DAY
description: In the first few decades of recording history, the pipe organ figured insignificantly. Recording equipment was neither sophisticated enough nor flexible enough in those early years to deal satisfactorily with gigantic non-portable instruments in their natural habitats, which were churches, for the most part, some of them vast and extremely echo prone.

title: DEMOCRATS BEGIN GUERILLA WAR ON THE REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: It was out of the Rose Garden and into the Capitol Hill briar patch last week for the President's tax-cut legislation. Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee, who had earlier endorsed a two-year variant of the Reagan formula, with a cut of 5 percent the first year and 10 percent the second, were decidedly unaccommodating. After a caucus, they announced that across-the-board reductions would not do. As tax-cut hearings finally got under way, they hammered at the theme that, under the President's bill, high-income Americans would get a break but those making less than $10,000 a year would be in for a hosing and would, in fact, wind up paying more combined Federal taxes in 1981. What the Democrats had in mind were cuts targeted at those who make between $10,000 and $50,000.

title: LEGISLATURE ADVISED ON ITS IMAGE
description: HARTFORD PEOPLE who enjoy sausage or law, a political observer of the last century once suggested, should never watch either being made. A fivemonth study of the General Assembly completed earlier this month reached a related conclusion: The sight of the legislature in session inspires little confidence in its output.

title: ZIMBABWE EXODUS IS GREATER NOW THAN IN WAR
description: More people - predominantly from the white minority - are emigrating from Zimbabwe in peacetime than they did when the country was at war and called Rhodesia, according to official figures made available this week.

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Pamela Harper is a professional photographer and writer. By PAMELA HARPER

title: Elizabeth Lauer Danzig Wed
description: Elizabeth Lauer Danzig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allison C. Danzig of Huntington Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Frederick F. Pascucci, son of Mrs. Louis Pascucci of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Mr. Pascucci.

title: Gonzalez, Down in Third, Beats Ganigan on Decision
description: Rodolfo (Gato) Gonzalez of Mexico City, the World Boxing Council's No. 2 ranked lightweight contender, survived a third-round knockdown today and scored a 10-round split decision over Andy Ganigan of Honolulu.

title:
Stamps;
HE PIONEERED THE PRESERVATION OF BLOOD PLASMA
description: The pioneering work of Dr. Charles R. Drew made possible the preservation of blood plasma and the establishment of the now familiar blood banks, and he is being accorded long-delayed philatelic recognition by a just-issued 35-cent stamp in the Great Americans Series.

title: Typhoon Floods Kill 2 in Taiwan
description: A mother and daughter were drowned today when flash floods unleashed by a typhoon swept through a watermelon field where they had been picking fruit, the police said. The torrential rains in southern and eastern Taiwan forced China Airlines and Far Eastern Airlines to cancel all domestic flights and interrupted highway traffic in many cities.

title: The World in Summary; Khomeini Signals An Open Season On Bani-Sadr
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, a leftist educated in Europe, apparently made the mistake of believing Iran's revolution was about ideology. In fact, it was primarily about power, and last week Mr. Bani-Sadr lost his.

title: Notes; A ROUNDUP OF TOURS AND ATTRACTIONS IN THE NORTHEAST
description: As the summer vacation season begins, many travelers heading for the beaches, lakes and small towns of the Northeast are planning to slow down and make contact with the ways and customs of the past. The region offers plenty of opportunities to do so - crossing Lake Champlain on a ferry that has its origins early in the 18th century, for example, or riding on a new attraction, a Cape Cod train whose coaches evoke the 1920's. In Maine, a vacation package has been built around antique transportation - car, plane and schooner.

title: NEW JERSEY IS AN ARTISTIC GUSHER
description: IF THE advocates of a state symphony orchestra remain bitter that big New Jersey money (business, industrial and private) has failed to come forth to save and perpetuate the New Jersey Symphony, perhaps they should stop to consider the unique character of this state. They might then decide that it was miraculous the orchestra survived as long as it did.

title: REDISTRICTING: SLIPPAGE FOR DEMOCRATS
description: ALMOST like dishes slipping precariously on a tray, the Democratic Party's urban base was shown sliding away toward the South, the West and the Republicans in the latest Census Bureau study of Congressional districts. Of the 20 House districts that would need the most people added to bring them up to one man-one vote standards, all are held by Democrats.

title: GET TO THE BOTTOM OF BILLY MARTIN
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Jersey Guide; SO LONG TO SHORT
description: Bobby Short, the nightclub pianist-singer who has held forth in Manhattan's Hotel Carlyle for some dozen years, plans to take a year's leave of absence, starting the end of this month. However, before he does, Mr. Short will give a benefit concert for the Newark Community School of the Arts, a nonprofit institution school offering instruction in music, dance, drama and visual arts.

title: Linda Fox Cabot Bride Of Dr. John Jacobey 3d
description: Linda Fox Cabot was married yesterday to Dr. John Arthur Jacobey 3d of Port Washington, L.I., and Denver. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I., by the Rev. Frank N. Johnston, the rector.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Westchester Housing which is trying to find uses for it; OUTLOOK FOR SAVING OLDER BUILDINGS
description: ''DON'T be apologetic about old houses,'' James Piccone, architect and preservationist, told a group of real estate agents recently, as they sat in the chestnut-paneled living room of the 200-year-old John Jay Homestead in Katonah.

title: WINDSURFING RIDES THE L.I.
description: TIDE By MURIEL FISCHER PORT WASHINGTON THE seascape of Manhasset Bay, once purely a montage of white sails, blue skies and distant greenery, is vividly alive with new dimensions of color and form these days.

title: AN OLD HUDSON RIVER RITE: WAITING FOR THE SHAD RUN
description: EDGEWATER THE first white settlers in the New World found Indians perched along the banks of the Hudson River, waiting for the buds of trees to bloom. The blooming buds meant that the yearly run of shad had begun.

title: IMPOSTERS IN UNIFORM WORRYING NEW YORK'S POLICE
description: The recent robbery of a subway-token clerk by a man in a police officer's uniform has heightened concern among city authorities over the problem of criminals posing as officers.

title: BLANKS FIRED AT QUEEN AS SHE RIDES HORSE TO CEREMONY
description: An unemployed teen-ager from southern England ran up to Queen Elizabeth II today and fired several pistol blanks at her as she rode horseback along The Mall to the Trooping the Color ceremony marking her official birthday, the police said.

title: MISS CAPONI AHEAD BY 2 SHOTS ON 70-270
description: By Gordon S. White Jr.

title: Recordings; UNUSUAL ITEMS FOR OFFENBACH FANS
description: Admirers of the delectable operas bouffes of Jacques Offenbach must have been a bit disappointed that the centenary of the composer's death last year did not inspire more activity among record companies. Just prior to the event, complete versions of four popular operettas did appear in fairly close succession - ''Orphee aux Enfers'' (Angel SZX 3886), ''La Grande Duchesse de Gerolstein'' (CBS M2 34576), ''La Vie Parisienne'' (Angel SX 3839) and ''La Perichole'' (RCA FRL 2-5994, already deleted) - and these generally admirable performances were apparently deemed a sufficient representation of Offenbach's 100-plus stage works.

title: Topics; A PARLOR GAME; A Parlor Game
description: They are not averse to snuggling on chill winter nights. They are not fussy eaters unless one starts them off with veal kidneys and chicken breasts, in which case there's no turning back.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; ALL IS NOT HARMONY AMONG THE BAPTISTS
description: Love and forbearance figure high in the lexicon of Baptist virtues, but at this year's annual convention of Southern Baptists, held in Los Angeles last week, some serious rifts disrupted the mood.

title: THE LESSONS OF CAPITOL HILL LIFE ARE NOT WASTED ON THE YOUNG L. Dorgan
description: THE 97th Congress may be remembered as much for its relative youth as for its combativeness over budgets and taxes. Most senators are in their first terms; most members of the House have served less than six years. The Week in Review asked four members of Congress - three of them brand new to Capitol Hill, one fresh to the Senate - to discuss some of the implications of the change. The four were Senator Slade Gorton, a moderate Republican from Washington; Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a liberal Democrat from Connecticut and a former Representative; Representative Bobbi Fiedler, a conservative Republican from California and Representative Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat from North Dakota who sometimes calls himself a ''prairie populist.'' The following are excerpts of their discussion with Martin Tolchin and Francis X. Clines, Washington correspondents of The New York Times, and Michael Wright, an editor of The Review:

title: PERFECT VILLAIN PAYS AN UNWELCOME CALL suburban area
description: GIVE me back my house. Give me back my yard. Go away. I don't want you around here. The sight of you makes my skin crawl. I saw two of you yesterday on the towels I took down from the line in the back. I flicked you off and I did not recognize you. You looked like tiny inch worms except you were black, so you fooled me. Oh, I don't know, maybe I wanted to be fooled. Who wants to think of you coming back here like you did last year and in other years?

title: SUMMER STYLE AT A PRICE
description: SUMMER STYLE AT A PRICE Here are several suggestions for updating a woman's summer wardrobe with separates and accessories priced at less than $35 each. Photographs by Tito Barberis; hair and makeup, Arnold Meakin Pipkin.

title: Theater in Review at C.W. Post; A "SHADOW" OF LEAR RECEIVES ITS MOMENT UPON THE STAGE
description: BROOKVILLE TAKE King Lear out of ''King Lear,'' give Shakespeare's tragedy a happy ending, and you might wind up with a playable play. Such is the conceit of the C.W. Post Center's chairman of theater and film, Stefan Rudnicki. His ''streamlined'' version of ''King Lear,'' tellingly titled ''Lear's Shadow,'' is alternating with ''Reunion'' and ''Dark Pony,'' a double bill by the contemporary playwright David Mamet, during the June Summer Arts Festival, of which Mr. Rudn@icki is also artistic director. (The festival includes opera workshops and performances of a new opera based on ''Frankenstein.'')

title: Nancy Schade, R.B. Hearne Jr.  Marry on L. I.
description: Nancy Susan Schade, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Rolland Schade of Freeport and Gilgo Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert Bickford Hearne, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hearne of Dedham, Mass. The Very Rev. Robert V. Wilshire, dean of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, L.I., and the Rev. John J.T. Schnabel performed the ceremony at the cathedral.

title: Ceil Chapman Atlanta Bride Of Physician
description: Ceil Michele Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Peter Chapman of Silver Lake, S.I., and granddaughter of the late Ceil Chapman, the fashion designer, was married in Atlanta yesterday to Dr. Charles Michael Besharian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Besharian of New Milford, N.J. The Rev. Steven Sloop performed the ceremony at the Emory Presbyterian Church.

title: Yea, Synfuels
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Why Didn't Reagan Simply Kill Synfuels?'' (May 31), John A. Hill attributed Presidential budget director David A. Stockman's reluctance to eliminate the Synthetic Fuels Corporation to a combination of political naivete and cowardice. This analysis possibly short-changes other possible reasons for Mr. Stockman's actions, which are basically economic.

title: Anne Buck Vernon, Teacher, Married
description: Anne Buck Vernon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ruppert Vernon of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Nicholas Joshua Campbell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Campbell of White Plains.

title: Cardinal Cooke Assails Ruling on Pornography
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke has assailed a New York State Court of Appeals decision that struck down a law prohibiting portrayals of sexual activity by children in books, films, photographs or plays.

title: No Headline
description: Lester Thurow correctly identifies a number of problems with the Reagan brand of economics. However, his proposal to save $8 billion by cutting veterans' benefits is questionable.

title: JUDGE DENIES CONNALLY SUBPOENA IN TRIAL OF 3 ALLEGED MERCENARIES
description: New Orleans, June 13 (UPI) - The Federal authorities said today that John Connally, former Governor of Texas, and Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, had no connection with a plot to overthrow the government of a Caribbean island, despite a lawyer's request that they be subpoenaed for the Federal District Court trial of three alleged mercenaries.

title: HAGLER RETAINS TITLE
description: Marvin Hagler, recognized as champion by both the World Boxing Council and the World Boxing Association, retained his middleweight championship tonight with a technical knockout in the fifth round over Vito Antuofermo of Brooklyn in the Boston Garden.

title: THROUGH LUCK AND DOGGED WORK, AGENTS DISRUPT A TOP COCAINE RING
description: A special task force of Federal drug agents and New York City and State police has uncovered and disrupted a nationwide ring of cocaine smugglers said to be among the country's top suppliers of the drug.

title: PATENT FILINGS BACK UP
description: Last year was a busy one for United States patent examiners. A record 105,000 applications were filed for patents on inventions, the first significant yearly increase since 1971.

title: Topics; SEIZING THE
description: YOUNG Seizing the Young

title: NEWARK ACCUSED OF SKIMPING ON FUND FOR SCHOOLS
description: New Jersey's Attorney General has charged the state's largest public-school district with using a budget ''grossly insufficient to provide a thorough and efficient education in Newark.''

title: The Nation in Summary; EARLY SETBACKS FOR WATT'S PARKS PLAN
description: As ''the cathedrals of American civilization,'' the national parks have long inspired an almost religious fervor among legions of outdoor-minded citizens. Last week, Interior Secretary James G. Watt found out the feeling runs right through to Capitol Hill.

title: Schoolboy Wins 2 Titles
description: Adrian Ward, a senior at Northwestern High School in Baltimore, won the 400-meter run and the 400-meter hurdles tonight at the United States junior track and field championships at Tom Black Stadium.

title: HISTORY MADE ON CONNECTICUT
description: FOR the first time in about two centuries, an adult is swimming in the Connecticut River somewhere above Bellows Falls, Vt. There was a time when Atlaftic salmon, more than any fish, perhaps, a symbol of clean, cold, fast and untrammeled waters, ascended the Connecticut system all the way to the lakes at the northernmost tip of New Hampshire. Impassable power dams ended all that, and gross pollution further desecrated the stream.

title: Moses Wins Easily; Streak at 62 Races
description: Edwin Moses, the holder of the world record, extended his winning streak in the 400-meter hurdles to 62 races today and Steve Scott defeated Sydney Maree and John Walker in the mile at the Brooks Invitational Track and Field Meet.

title: No Headline
description: Lester Thurow wrote about the nation's economic dilemma without once mentioning the effect of military expenditures. Ostrich economics! I. D. ROBBINS, Blairstown, N.J.

title: THEATER: 3 NEW WORKS DISPLAYING ORIGINALITY
description: In its monthlong season of one-act plays, ''Marathon 1981,'' the Ensemble Studio Theater has saved its best evening for last, three new works, by Arthur Kopit, Shirley Lauro and Peter Maloney. Unlike a few of the other plays in the 13-play series, these three have both definition and originality, and one of them, Mrs. Lauro's contribution, ''Open Admissions,'' is a small powerhouse.

title: Chevron Loses Gas Leak Case
description: In a verdict that could cost Chevron USA Inc. up to $200 million, a Federal jury has found the company liable for gasoline leaks from a neighborhood station that set off sewer line explosions and three evacuations last year. Odell Barry, Mayor of the city of Northglenn, where the explosions occurred, hailed the verdict last night. The six-member United States District Court jury found Chevron guilty of negligence, trespassing, nuisance and posing an ''ultra-hazard.''

title: LEADERSHIP AT STATE CAPITOL LOSING ITS GRIP
description: HARTFORD NOT many years ago, a person trying to figure out what the legislature was likely to do on some issue would only have to check three offices in the state Capitol -the Governor, the Senate majority leader and the Speaker of the House.

title: A Letter To Atlanta
description: The Teaneck Board of Education declared May 7, 1981, a ''day of awareness'' in recognition of the tragic devastation and loss to the families of the children slain in Atlanta (''Leading the Hunt in Atlanta's Murders,'' by M.A. Farber, May 3). I shared Myron Farber's article with my third-grade students on that day.

title: DANCE: NEW 'NOCTURNES' BY O'DONNELL TROUPE
description: When some choreographers turn to Chopin, their dances are often sweet. And since Chopin's music can be charming, such dances are not to be despised. But there is also a turbulence to Chopin, and it is to this quality that May O'Donnell responded when she choreographed ''Three Nocturnes and a Quartet'' for the May O'Donnell Concert Dance Company.

title: Patricia Gedney Is Married
description: The marriage of Patricia E. Gedney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Gedney 3d of Crugers, N.Y., to Richard A. Boig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Boig of East Brunswick, N.J., took place yesterday in Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Morton Talbot, a Lutheran pastor of Croton, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University. The couple are graduates of Lehigh.

title: 200 Haitians Arrive in Florida
description: Two 40-foot wooden boats packed with about 200 Haitian refugees landed today at Cape Florida on Miami's Key Biscayne. The police and border officers rounded up the Haitians for transfer to a refugee camp west of Miami.

title: Police Try to Save Department
description: Police officers are leading a petition drive here to repeal an ordinance abolishing the city's 12-man police department on Aug. 1. The City Council voted last week to abolish the 12-man department and to contract with the Coshocton County Sheriff's Department for law enforcement because of various problems, including a $1 million police brutality suit against the town.

description: PLAYHOUSE FUND-RAISERS

title: WURZBURGER IS INSTALLED BY SYNAGOGUE COUNCIL
description: Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger, professor of philosophy at Yeshiva University, has been installed as president of the Synagogue Council of America, succeeding Rabbi Arthur J. Lelyveld of Fairmount Temple in Cleveland.

title: THE METAMORPHOSIS OF LIFE IN SUBURBIA
description: BILLIONS of gypsy moth caterpillars are crawling across the metropolitan area, defoliating thousands of acres and making people squirm. Entomologists report that the pests are more numer-ous this year than last not only throughout New Jer-sey, but also in New York and Connecticut.

title: Jane Meryl Hershcopf Wed To Donald Wilson Schreck
description: Jane Meryl Hershcopf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Thea Hershcopf, was married there yesterday to Donald Wilson Schreck, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Schreck of Cape Coral, Fla. The ceremony was performed in the Terrace Room of the Plaza Hotel by Rabbi Martin Zion of Temple Israel.

title: The Nation in Summary; HOUSE THROWS ITS WEIGHT BEHIND BUSING BARRIER
description: Congressional opponents of busing for desegregation last week moved to make de jure a policy that is already de facto. By an overwhelming 265 to 122, the House of Representatives voted to prohibit the Justice Department from pursuing school desegregation cases that could result in busing.

title: NEW SHOWS, BIG STARS, EAGER NOVICES LIGHT UP STRAW HAT CIRCUIT
description: Not everything is ready yet. With the summer theater season about to begin, director Robert Johanson still hasn't finished casting his new revue, ''King's Tapestry,'' which is due to open July 13 at the Cape Playhouse in Dennis, Mass.

title: THE PARIS AIRSHOW: WINING, DINING AND DEALING FOR MILITARY MIGHT
description: LE BOURGET, France F OR the first time in many years, military aircraft flying at the 34th Paris Air Show are loaded with simulated weapons. Defense is in again. The American contractors and their competitors are flexing their muscles in export markets with new intensity.

title: Kuwait Says Iran Planes Fired Upon a Border Post
description: Kuwait said that Iranian planes violated its northern airspace today and opened fire over a border outpost close to the main battle zone in the Iraqi-Iranian war.

title:
Long Island Housing;
CONDO OR CO-OP: THE DIFFERENCE
description: A DECADE after they first appeared on the market, condominiums have become an accepted and popular form of home ownership. Cooperatives are still relatively rare on the Island except in the Great Neck area, but that is also changing. Figures compiled by the State Attorney General's office indicate that conversions of rental buildings to cooperatives are on the increase.

title: REAGAN LOSES THE LUXURY OF LEISURE ON FOREIGN POLICY
description: WASHINGTON OCCASIONALLY American Presidents have managed to craft and pursue well-conceived diplomatic strategies to achieve their foreign policy goals. The Marshall Plan became Harry Truman's blueprint for dealing with postwar Europe; Henry Kissinger's triangular diplomacy with Peking became Richard Nixon's route to Soviet-American detente.

title: Editors' Choice
description: 50. SAND RIVERS, by Peter Matthiessen. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a safari into a wild southern Tanzanian game preserve that becomes a strange, bittersweet journey back into time.

title: PRINCETON MINORITIES HAVE MANY VOICES
description: PRINCETON THE Third World Center that was established on the Princeton University campus 10 years ago - it was one of the first such centers in the country - is a focus of activity for black and Hispanic students, as well as those from underdeveloped countries.

title: HERB BROOKS TAKES HIS STYLE TO PROS
description: I T was only his first day on the job, but Herb Brooks - the new coach of the Rangers - was already giving a pep talk. They listened, many of them nervous about what he was saying. There are traditions in the National Hockey League, niceties to be observed. Why, this man - an American, yet - was virtually a blasphemer. And no one had ever pushed them like this before, demanding, probing, questioning.

title: The Region in Summary; RAISING THE RENT RAISES THE ROOF
description: Last year, tenants in one-third of New York City's 900,000 rentstabilized apartments had record rent increases, but building owners complained that they weren't high enough. Last week, apparently in a bid to make up for that, the landlords' Rent Stabilization Association asked the Rent Guidlines Board to grant the highest increases ever.

title: Revolution About Westchester By Lynne Ames
description: NEW ROCHELLE BIG, sleek coffeetable books might not be as common as travel brochures when it comes to publicizing places, but an opulent hardcover volume is exactly what David Finn has come up with in his ongoing promotion of this city.

title: Future Events Of Dining and Dancing
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. A Royal Occasion June 17 - The presence of Prince Charles will add a fillip to an evening-long celebration of the Royal Ballet's 50th anniversary at Lincoln Center, an event no self-respecting Anglophile would dream of missing. Performance at the Metropolitan Opera House of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' starring Jennifer Penny and David Wall, is sandwiched between a reception on the Promenade at Avery Fisher Hall and a supper ball with, appropriately enough, ''The Enchanted Forest'' as its theme, in a tent at Damrosch Park. Nancy Reagan will join Prince Charles for the ballet and supper and there'll be a glittering array of diplomats and social figures with a sprinkling of peers of the realm for good measure. Proceeds will go to the English-Speaking Union of the United States, the Metropolitan Opera Association and the American Friends of Covent Garden and the Royal Ballet Inc. Tickets, $1,000 for entire evening, $600 for performance and supper, $100 to $200 for ballet alone.

title: Salvador Denies Rebel Claim Of Killing 140 Soldiers
description: Guerrillas asserted in clandestine broadcasts yesterday that they had overrun the northern town of Arcatao near the Honduran border and killed 140 soldiers.
