description: To the Editor:

title: RESERVED PARKING IS SET FOR DISABLED
description: Owners of many shopping centers will be required to reserve some of their parking spaces for handicapped drivers under a bill signed by Governor Carey this week.

title: KENNEDY CENTER FOCUSING ON AMERICAN PERFORMERS
description: The Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is charting new directions, concentrating on American performers rather than imports.

title: GETTING WATER WHERE IT'S NEEDED IN
description: JERSEY By ROBERT HANLEY

title:
Crafts workship in Scarsdale;
Y THROWING A 3-DAY CLAY ART FESTIVAL
description: WHILE June is traditionally the time of year when schoolchildren start chanting ''No more teachers, no more books,'' it is also a time when many adults decide to take to take a course or a workshop class. For pottery enthusiasts, eager to acquire new skills, this month provides one last opportunity to take advantage of the Mid-Westchester YM-YWHA's well-received Clay Art Festival.

title:
Antiques;
HARTFORD MANSION IN GARDEN SETTING
description: HARTFORD TO the north, east and west are empty lots strewn with broken bricks and bottles amid sparse thatches of high grass and weeds. Just 50 feet to the south, cars and trucks speed by on Interstate 84.

title: Municipal Electric Energy Co-op in Groton UTILITIES ON A SMALLER SCALE Woodbury Telephone By JOHN S. ROSENBERG
description: WOODBURY WHILE huge companies provide most of the telephone and electric service in Connecticut, a few small, independent utilities are still scattered around, providing the same services as the larger concerns. Most of the independents date from the turn of the century, when numerous companies competed to string telephone lines and electric cable. Others are active in rural communities where low population densities made the prospects and profits seem too limited for most large investors.

title: HOLMES DRAWS RAVES FOR ROUTING SPINKS
description: Larry Holmes knocked three times on the door of the Lake Erie Suite in the Detroit Plaza this morning and inside a happy 1 1/2-year-old voice responded, ''Daddy, daddy.'' After last night, maybe the rest of the world will recognize the heavyweight champion as easily as his daughter, Kandi, does.

title: BALLET: PREMIERE OF 2 WORKS BY DUELL
description: ''Introduction and Fugue,'' the latest new work in the New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival, looks every bit as disconnected as its title, but the parts of the sum have been very well fashioned by Joseph Duell, the company's youngest choreographer.

title: Council Lists Activities At City Hall This Week
description: The City Council and its committees have scheduled the following sessions at City Hall this week: MONDAY - Committee on Consumer Affairs to consider bills, 11 A.M., Committee Room.

title:
RED SMITH;
Baddest Man in the World
description: DETROIT LARRY HOLMES entered the interview room preceded by his wife Diane, who took a chair at the end of a table overgrown with microphones, facing the assembled press. Larry stopped two chairs away from her and remained standing.

title: HOW MOST OF THE SPECIES LIVES
description: VILLAGES By Richard Critchfield. Illustrated. 388 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $17.95. By NICK EBERSTADT

title: 'SHAKESPEARE' OPENS THURSDAY
description: A Shakespeare multimedia ''company of players'' from the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington will open an engagement next Thursday in New York at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: TESTS OF MAGNETIC BACTERIA ILLUMINATE POLARITY'S ROLE
description: Laboratory tests have revealed that certain bacteria perform a Uturn when a switch that reverses the local magnetic field is thrown. They are magnetic bacteria, first discovered in 1975, and similar species are now known to occur in equatorial regions as well as in mid-latitudes.

title: Frenchtown Antiques show ATLANTIC CITY SHOW ATTRACTS 200 DEALERS By CAROLYN DARROW
description: ATLANTIC CITY PEOPLE will be flocking to this resort next Saturday and Sunday to take a chance at the tables, in this case the tables of 200 antiques dealers at the Atlantic City Antiques Show and Sale at Convention Hall.

title: TEXAS AIR: LET THEM ORGANIZE
description: Regarding the article ''Where Are the Pickets of Yesteryear?'' (May 31), some of organized labor's eclipse is due to successes that severely retard economic progress and consumer welfare. Consider the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: A.J. Arader Weds Anne C. Sherrerd
description: Anne Compton Sherrerd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J.F. Sherrerd of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Alexander John Arader, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. Arader of Radnor, Pa., were married yesterday at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder and the Rev. Patrick J. Powers officiated.

title: ROGEERS: HONOR THY CONTRACT
description: The following reply to Mr. Bakes' letter was invited by The Times. Far from being an exemplary innovation, New York Air is an airborne ''runaway shop'' created with Texas International money, planes and management personnel. The four corporate entities headed by Francisco Lorenzo - Jet Capital, Texas Air, T.I. and New York Air - are one and the same.

title: Miss Damon Rides Pueblo To Victory at Ox Ridge
description: Two weeks ago, Brendan Damon of Honolulu, a history major, was graduated from Yale. Today she went to the head of the class at the Paine Webber Ox Ridge horse show, riding Pueblo to victory in the $2,000 Insilco, a jumping competition of amateur owners.

title: CARS: YOU JUST CAN'T LIVE COMFORTABLY WITH THEM...
description: BACK in 1970, Mrs. Mitchell had a glimpse of what an empty nest would look like. Seven-year-old Ryan, her youngest son, was in school on a full-time basis. Her other boys, George, 14, Tommy, 12, and Mark, 10, were also away at school all day.

title: SOME FIND ALTERNATIVES TO ABSENCE OF BASEBALL
description: Although there are no baseball games in the majors this weekend, life is going on for players, owners, coaches and fans. Dave Winfield of the Yankees, who has profited most handsomely from the free-agent system that is under dispute, carried out a charitybegins-at-home plan of sorts. He had promised $4,500 worth of tickets to 1,500 youngsters from his home town of St. Paul for the game scheduled between the Yankees and the Minnesota Twins in Bloomington Friday night. Because of the strike, he could not fulfill that promise. Instead, he went to St. Paul to help sponsor health examinations for youngsters needing checkups. He saw to it that 200 children received the exams and then were treated to dinners at his old high school, St. Paul Central.

title: Leslie A. Conway New Jersey Bride Of Robert C. Regan
description: Leslie Alice Conway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Granville Elliot Conway of New Vernon, N.J. was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Robert Christopher Regan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John MacVeigh Regan of New York and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. of St. John-on-the-Mountain Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: DEPARTING TANZANIANS SURE UGANDA WILL MANAGE
description: Jinja, Uganda, June 13 (Reuters) - More than half way through the Tanzanian withdrawal from Uganda, Tanzanian Army officers say they are confident that Uganda can handle its own security problems.

title: Judith Underwood, Bennett Stewart 3d Wed in Greenwich
description: Judith Underwood was married in Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday to G. Bennett Stewart 3d. The Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony.

title: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS
description: We are witnessing a major political struggle between the Administration and Democrats about the size and structure of a tax cut bill. Although both sides have recently made compromises to attract votes, the major philosophical differences remain almost as starkly as they were between candidates Carter and Reagan. Many ask: Are these genuine economic issues? Or is this mainly a show of Democratic political defiance, Pepsi challenging Coke?

title:
Numismatics;
MEDAL ISSUED FOR GATHERING OF HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS
description: Thousands of survivors of the Holocaust begin a ''world gathering'' in Israel today in an effort to insure that mankind will never forget what they and their brethren endured - and to help make that memory more permanent a medal has been issued to commemorate the occasion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Sunday, May 31, on the marriage of Diana Marina Carulli incorrectly identified the bridegroom. He was Bryan Robert Dunlap. The ceremony was nondenominational.

title: Reading and Writing; CATHEDRALS
description: Though ''The Age of Cathedrals'' by Georges Duby (University of Chicago Press) is not easy reading, it does us good now and again to expose ourselves to high thinking. And there is no higher thinking than the kind inspired by the subject of cathedrals. Consider Mr. Duby when he says that ''the universe, born of an irradiance, was a downward-spilling burst of luminosity.'' This luminosity ''appealed to the soul to make the transference from the tangible to the ineffable.''

title: U.S. Expects More Maneuvers
description: The State Department said today that normal Soviet-bloc military exercises were expected before next month's congress of the Polish Communist Party, but that there was no evidence of more significant maneuvers being planned.

title: MERION A PERILOUS CHALLENGE FOR U.S. OPEN ASPIRANTS
description: By Donald Janson

title: CLIBURN WINNER BASKS IN FAME
description: It has been two weeks since Andre-Michel Schub won the sixth Van Cliburn International Competition. He himself, sitting uncomfortably on the stage that evening of May 31, knew that he was not going to win. When his name was announced as prize winner, he was in a daze. In a way, he still is in a daze.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE WITH GYPSY MOTHS
description: Roger Swain, science editor of Horticulture magazine, is the author of ''Earthly Pleasures: Tales From a Biologist's Garden.'' By Roger Swain I may be accused of being a gypsy-moth sympathizer, of being soft on caterpillars, but gypsy moths are here to stay and we'd best learn to live with them. Gypsy moths have never been well received, and when their numbers increase, as they do periodically, people become alarmed and begin to talk about an end to the landscape as we know it. Throughout the Northeast this year, people have been getting up at town meetings and demanding to know what preventive measures are being taken, while privately they worry about property values going down.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; THIS TIME, IT'S A CLOSE CALL ON ANTI-ABORTION
description: BILL By BERNARD WEINRAUB

title: Somalia Says Air Raids Killed 30
description: At least 30 people were killed and 53 wounded in Ethiopian air raids on two provincial capitals in central Somalia over the past two days, the Somali Government said today. The raids were said to have taken place in populated areas near the the border with Ethiopia's disputed Ogaden region.

title: Making Sense of The Economy
description: Lester Thurow's article, ''Undamming the American Economy'' (May 3), is the first constructive criticism of the Reagan Administration's economic policies that I have seen.

title: ALTERNATIVES SOUGHT FOR WASTE DISPOSAL
description: INCREASED solid waste and lack of landfill space is forcing many municipalities in western Connecticut to turn to compactors and recycling plants for garbage disposal.

title: YARD-SALES EXPERTS MOVE INSIDE AND UP Salisbury
description: SALISBURY FROM a cigar box full of change and a backyard bargain table to a multi-thousand-dollar business with a crew of appraisers and cashiers - that's where Elizabeth H. Fitch and Sarah F. Kain have taken the tag sale.

title: REPORTER'S SLAYING REMAINS A MYSTERY
description: Five years after Don Bolles, a reporter for The Arizona Republic here, was killed by a bomb that had been placed under his automobile, the authorities say they doubt they will ever be absolutely sure of the motive for his killing.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe, Gottfried In Grass Court Final

title: DEATH PENALTY LAWS RETURN AMID RISING DEBATE IN U.S.
description: The death penalty, invalidated nationwide in 1972 by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 decision, has been making a comeback.

title: A U.N. Agency Says 420 Million Don't Have Enough Food to Eat
description: About 420 million people throughout the world do not have enough to eat, an official of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization said yesterday.

title: A CITY BUDGET SURPLUS, AND NO END OF WAYS TO SPEND
description: IT By CLYDE HABERMAN

title: STATE'S DEBUTANTES STILL HAVE THEIR DAY
description: SOME consider the debut a thing of the past. Others insist that it is making a comeback. But in Connecticut, particularly in Fairfield County, it has survived the lean years and shows healthy signs of growth. To be sure, the Holly Ball sponsored by the Junior League of Hartford folded in 1969, and the Darien-New Canaan Autumn Cotillion is no more, but the Fairfield Debutante Ball, held in Westport Friday night, is holding its own. Sixteen young women from Fairfield, Southport, Westport and Easton were presented at this summery party outdoors in a yellow and white striped tent at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gerard Reiss.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SPOKANE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- WILLIAM STIMSON is managing editor of Spokane Magazine. By WILLIAM STIMSON

title:
Camera;
PHOTOGRAPHING PETS
Chicago Jaycees Change Name in Legal Settlement
description: The Chicago Jaycees have changed their name to the Chicago Junior Association of Commerce and Industry as part of a settlement of a legal dispute with the United States Jaycees and the Illinois Jaycees.

title: LEAGUE OF VOTERS: WHAT IT IS ABOUT
description: WE have all reached a time when people are like pilots flying by instrument. We are always being told what is happening to us. In the good old days, we ''knew what was up.'' Our feet actually touched springtime and earth now and then, and not just asphalt, concrete and the accelerator pedal. Today the experts tell us what they think we need to know - whether we are in a depression or recession - and one hardly knows if he is a good or bad credit risk until some computer says so.

title: No Headline
description: It seems to me that Lester Thurow overlooked the most obvious way to stimulate savings - namely, to exempt all interest income from Federal and state income taxes. Germany and Japan (and, more recently, Canada) owe their substantially higher savings rates to just this fact and not to a more public-minded attitude on the part of their citizens.

title: Headliners; MARRIAGE AT A DISTANCE
description: Aleksei Semyonov, stepson of the exiled Soviet dissident Andrei D. Sakharov, last week married the girl he left behind in Moscow. In a ceremony in Butte, Mont., one of the few states that recognize proxy marriages, Mr. Semyonov joined hands with a stand-in for his fiancee, Liza Alekseyeva, and took the marriage vows. Mr. Semyonov, who emigrated three years ago, hoped the marriage would make it easier for Miss Alekseyeva to get Soviet permission to join him.

title: BANKS SQUARE OFF AGAINST THE FED
description: For years, bank-holding companies and their large banks have been quietly obedient to the Federal Reserve Board, which has enjoyed largely unquestioned adherence to regulations through its powerful grip on the banking industry.

title:
INVESTING;
AN I.R.A. IN EVERY PORTFOLIO
description: WASHINGTON

title: THE QADDAFI CONNECTION
description: Seymour M. Hersh, a former New York Times reporter, is now at work on a book about Henry Kissinger to be published by Summit Books. By Seymour M. Hershive years ago, two former operatives of the United States Central Intelligence Agency - Edwin P. Wilson and Frank E. Terpil - made a business deal with Col. Muammarel-Qaddafi, the ruler of Libya. In essence, the former C.I.A. men, who had become partners in an exportimport business, agreed to sell Colonel Qaddafi their accumulated years of American intelligence-agency contacts, experience and expertise. Theirs was a product that could not be purchased on the open market. The colonel, who boasts of supporting terrorism in the Middle East, Europe and Africa and who has been attempting to set up his own new federation of Arab and Moslem states, was willing - and able, because of his vast oil wealth - to pay dearly.

title:
Speaking Personally Footbridge' to get to 'The Island' in Jersey City;
A FOOTBRIDGE TO FANTASY IN JERSEY CITY
description: ''THE FOOTBRIDGE'' on Waldo Avenue in Jersey City is scary looking. It is dark, narrow, littered, tar black and covered with graffiti, with ripped holes in its aluminum sideboards. Wire mesh crisscrosses at the top.

title: Letters; HAZARDOUS GUESSWORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Follow-Up on the News; 'Teleport' Idea
description: The plan called for the world's first ''teleport'' - a communications center for businesses in metropolitan New York that would link them by satellite to other businesses around the world. Subscribers would be able to communicate by voice, computer or television.

title: Beil and Zahringer in L.I. Final
description: Although he barely made the qualifying round cut, Randy Beil scored two more victories in match play today to advance to the final of the 58th annual Long Island Golfers' Association amateur championship at the Old Westbury Country Club.

title: AND THE NEED FOR A NEW NUCLEAR SHIELD
description: Whatever one's view of Israel's destruction of Iraq's nuclear center, it was a clear vote of no confidence in the international ''safeguards'' that were meant to confine it to civilian duty. Iraq is not among the naysayers, like Israel, who have rejected international nuclear controls. By current standards, Iraq has been a model nuclear citizen. It signed the Non-Proliferation Treaty, swore not to develop nuclear weapons and opened its installations to inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency.

title: Mets Sign Five Players Chosen in Amateur Draft
description: The Mets have signed five draft picks from the recent free agent amateur draft, including Gail Arnold, a right-handed pitcher from Brigham Young, the No. 2 choice in the secondary phase.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
For Father's Day, Silver At 30% to 50% Discount
description: Sterling silver flatware, silver plate holloware, pewter and brass manufacturers, long-established in New England, have factory outlets in Wallingford with quite suitable gifts for Father's Day at 30 and 50 percent off. The hours are factory hours, however, and there is no weekend shopping except before major holiday seasons.

title: ARSON STIRS FEAR IN A LAOTIAN COMMUNITY IN ILLINOIS
description: Bounhevang Sonkesak, a refugee from Laos, opened her apartment door and saw smoke. ''I wasn't scared, just surprised,'' the widow said through an interpreter. ''I said, 'Why did it happen to me?' ''

title: Philadelphia Stories
description: I read with interest Leslie Bennetts's tale of a revitalized Philadelphia, and carried her tantalizing images with me on my first trip to the City of Brotherly Love less than a week later (''The Philadelphia Story, Updated,'' May 10). Wandering from the enclosed wall of my conference at Temple University to a busy neighborhood a few blocks away, I looked in vain for Miss Bennetts's images in the laughs of men in their autumn years, sitting on a church pew in a vacant lot.

title: Susan Jamieson Married To David Chapin White
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Susan Lee Jamieson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Andrew Jamieson of Greenwich, was married to David Chapin White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. White of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Lon M. Prunty, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS FOCUS ON EDUCATION
description: ONE of the accomplishments of the last 10 years cited by the environmental movement is the evolution of grass-roots educational efforts now under way throughout much of New Jersey. It may be changing the way many people perceive their surroundings.

title: HOSPICE LEADER AIDS EFFORTS HERE
description: DR. CICELY SAUNDERS, who is considered the founder and leader of the international hospice movement, has made frequent visits to the United States to encourage the development of this type of care for terminally ill patients. Her current visit included a stop in the county, where she was the keynote speaker at a seminar on hospice care.

title: HERMAN WOUK: 'A FAITHFUL ADAPTATION'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Herman Wouk, the author of ''The Winds of War'' and ''War and Remembrance,'' is working on a new novel. By HERMAN WOUK

title: 3 Drown as Pleasure Boats Go Over Dam in Ohio River
description: Three persons drowned and three others were reported missing today after two small recreational boats went over a dam on the Ohio River, the authorities said.

title: Lynne Sillcox Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Lynne Sillcox, daughter of H. Allen Sillcox of Palm Beach, Fla., and Southampton, L.I., and the late Lynne Russell Sillcox, to John S. Stewart of New York took place yesterday at the Sillcox home in Southampton. The Rev. Dr. John Andrew of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York performed the garden ceremony.

title: MURDER CONVICTION REVERSAL LAID TO JUDGE'S ERROR
description: A Federal District Court judge has reversed the 1976 murder conviction of a Manhattan man on the ground that Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court incorrectly instructed the jury in the case.

title: REAGAN GROUP PREDICTS CURBS ON REGULATORY AGENCIES WILL SAVE BILLIONS
description: The Reagan Administration, which has focused on relaxation of the Federal regulatory burden as one of the key elements of its economic recovery program, said in a progress report today that its relief actions taken to date would save consumers and businesses up to $6 billion in annually recurring costs.

title: Lawyer Weds Miss McCoy, Ph.D Student
description: Marsha Brooks McCoy, a candidate for a doctorate in ancient history at Yale University, and Mark Stephen Campisano, a lawyer, were married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Brooklyn Heights.

title:
A GUIDE TO THE 1981 STRAW HAT THEATER SCENE;
New York
description: NEW YORK CITYThe New York Shakespeare Festival Delacorte Theater Central ParkJune 26, The Tempest, with Raul Julia. Directed by Lee Breuer. July 31, Henry IV - Part One, with Mandy Patinkin. Directed by Des McAnuff.Westbeth Theater Center, Inc. 151 Bank StreetToday - June 28, Progress! title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: The World in Summary; France Gets a Peek At Mitterrand Hand
description: French voters got a preview last week of what they can expect from Francois Mitterrand if they give the Socialist President a compatible parliamentary majority in elections today and next Sunday.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: Hill, $7.95.) A reexamination, by a British television producer, of just about all the material currently available about the assassination of President Kennedy. In reviewing it, Thomas Powers observed that this wellwritten study does not ''prove'' anything, but it is quite valuable for calling attention to the omissions of the Warren Commission Report resulting from its failure to look into the C.I.A.'s involvement in an underworld conspiracy to overthrow Fidel Castro.

title: YUGOSLAVIA ADDS POLICE IN TROUBLED ALBANIAN AREA
description: Belgrade, Yugoslavia, June 13 (Reuters) - Yugoslavia has announced plans to strengthen the security forces in Kosovo Province, the southern region jolted by nationalist rioting in March and April by ethnic Albanians.

title: COOKING IN FRANCE WITH ISLAND ACCENT school in Paris
description: PARIS WITH an oversized white apron endlessly draped around her tiny waist, Jane Sigal listened intently as her instructor, Claude Vauguet, a French chef, reeled off a mammoth list of ingredients for tarte a la julienne de legumes - a vegetable quiche made with a buttery yeast dough shell. When Miss Sigal asked the chef, ''Est-ce qu'il faut tamiser la farine?'' - if it was necessary to sift the flour - her French accent gave few clues that her childhood was spent on the Island in Oceanside.

title: A U.S. PANEL FAULTS NUCLEAR INSPECTION
description: A Congressional committee that looked into last October's water spill at the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant at Buchanan, N.Y., has concluded that the existing Federal inspection system ''is not capable of offering genuine assurance that the nuclear power industry is being safely operated.''

title: SEES A MUTUAL GOAL TO RESIST RUSSIANS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived here today for three days of talks with the Chinese leaders. He intends to stress to the Chinese that there is ''a strategic imperative'' for the United States and China to establish closer political, security and economic ties because of a growing Soviet military threat to both nations,

title: OFFICIALS IN ATLANTA SUGGEST F.B.I. MISHANDLED KEY LEAD IN SLAYINGS
description: The policeman was huddling on the bank of the Chattahoochee River in the clear post-midnight darkness when he heard a loud splash. Calling into his radio to officers in chase cars waiting near the ends of the bridge above, he set in motion a series of events that many thought would end the long nightmare of mysterious murders of Atlanta's black children and young adults.

title: MRS. GANDHI'S SON FAVORED IN INDIAN VOTING TODAY
description: As an airline pilot, Rajiv Gandhi, the 36-year-old son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, has flown over this backward area in Uttar Pradesh many times.

title: MOTH WAR ESCALATES IN SUBURBS
description: THE New York metropolitan area is crawling with billions of gypsy moth caterpillars that are defoliating thousands of acres and making people squirm. Entomologists report that the pests are more numerous this year than last throughout the area, increasing as much as tenfold in parts of Connecticut.

title: Carey Proposes Plan To Aid Race Tracks
description: Governor Carey proposed today the formation of a public benefit corporation to assume the mortgage on the Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga race tracks. Under the proposal management of the tracks would be left to the New York Racing Association, which has had considerable difficulties raising enough revenue to pay its debts and restore the deteriorating race tracks.

title: Mason, Ex-Arizona Coach, Goes on Trial Tuesday
description: The former University of Arizona football coach, Tony Mason, charged with receiving money from the school for trips never taken, goes on trial Tuesday in the second courtroom drama involving a major coach in the state this year.

title: PICTURES OF CHANGE
description: NICARAGUA June 1978-July 1979. By Susan Meiselas. Edited with Claire Rosenberg. Illustrated. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $11.95. VISIONS OF CHINA Photographs by Marc Riboud, 1957-80. Introduction by Orville Schell. Illustrated. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $30. Paper, $14.95.

title: MIME: FRENCH DUO AT THE COLONNADES
description: Theatre du Mouvement, a French mime duo that performed Thursday at the Colonnades Theater, doesn't bother with the usual displays of technique and park-bench parables. Claire Heggen and Yves Marc go further, plunging into Surrealistic fable with zany, comfortable humor and an eye for the horrific image. Falling somewhere between improvisation and set piece, their mime has the freshness of the unconsidered expert gesture.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; UNITED NATIONS GETS WHAT IT PAYS FOR
description: The much-discussed ''new world information order,'' it appears, is just one part of the United Nations effort to influence world journalism. Another, first disclosed last month, was a United Nations-directed program of subsidies to 16 major newspapers, none in the United States, to print articles favorable to United Nations positions on economic aid to developing nations.

title: NEW ROLE FOR CATHOLICS
description: HARTFORD ROMAN Catholics who are over the age of 40 were raised to think that the church pretty much took care of itself. So long as the Pope was in charge, the bishop oversaw the diocese, the pastor ran the church and the nuns taught the parochial school children, things seemed pretty normal.

title: OBSTACLES TO WOMEN IN EDUCATION
description: In what was billed as ''the single largest gathering of female college administrators in the New York area,'' more than 300 women got together at Pace University last week to discuss such matters as the discrimination they face, the politics of higher education and getting ahead through ''networking.''

title: Bridge; PERPLEXING QUESTIONS ABOUT PLAYING THE PERCENTAGES
description: Many bridge-related questions do not directly concern the technique of bidding or play but still require considerable experience to answer. Most experts are deceived by the following question - unless they operate on the principle that the obvious answer must be wrong for the question to be asked at all. If your partner opens one club, using standard bidding methods, is he more likely to have exactly three clubs or exactly six clubs?

title:
Gardening;
POISON IN THE GARDEN: OVERRATED HAZARD
description: CONSIDERABLE controversy has arisen in recent years over the poisonous nature of certain plants, some of which are commonly found in our homes and gardens. It seems that stories of assumed plant poisonings have aroused a reaction in journalists similar to that of ''man bites dog'' stories.

title: China Executes Killer of Seven
description: A policeman who killed seven people when he ran amok over the disgrace of the so-called Gang of Four has been executed after being displayed before a crowd of 50,000. Wang Xiwen stole a gun, sprayed houses with bullets and threw grenades in the northern town of Handan, a provincial newspaper said, just before the trial of China's former leaders began last November.

title: Patricia Rice Has Wedding
description: Patricia Susie Rice, daughter of Mrs. H. Edison Rice of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Mr. Rice, was married yesterday to Steven Bernard Kutzer, son of Mary Friel Kutzer of Abington, Pa. and Theodore Charles Kutzer of Philadelphia. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Insulated Windows Offered at Discounts
description: The end of cold weather prompts some homeowners to consider actions to reduce fuel bills next winter. One popular measure is the installation of permanently insulated windows, especially as replacements for storm windows that need putting up and taking down in exchange for screens season after season.

title: LEAK FROM PENTHOUSE STIRS RANCOR IN CO-OP ON PARK
description: Penthouse H at 15 West 81st Street is like a country estate. High above the noise of Manhattan, it boasts a terrace -complete with a greenhouse and cherry trees in planters - that basks in the sunlight so precious to those below.

title: Music; IT'S SUMMERTIME AND FESTIVALS BLOOM
description: T HERE was a time when warm weather signaled a recess in Connecticut's musical activity, but no longer. Summertime is concert time all over the state, with a couple of major festivals already under way, and most of the others busily getting ready for opening day.

title: Boston Alternative Paper Folds
description: The Real Paper, a Boston weekly alternative newspaper, went out of business yesterday after eight years of publication. Ralph Fine, the newspaper's president, said the paper was folding because of growing losses since January 1980.

title: Letters
description: On Repair Costs To the Editor:

title: Art Harbor; A CUT ABOVE MOST NATURE ART
description: ANIMAL art, especially in painting, is not one of the most felicitous forms of visual expression. Whether they are living or dead, animals usually appear dead in art, as if they had been stuffed, placed on an incongruous stage amid artificial scenery and then painted.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Babies in Prison
description: Ruling that ''an infant should remain with his mother if possible,'' a Circuit Court judge ordered the Florida Correctional Institution in June 1980 to provide a joint cell for an imprisoned mother and her newborn son. The mother was 31-year-old Elizabeth Miller, who had been convicted of grand larceny and was reported eligible for parole in January 1982.

title: Soviet Cotton Crop in Jeopardy
description: Farmers in key cotton-growing areas of Soviet Central Asia are fighting to save their crops after a month of cool, stormy weather, according to regional newspapers. The Uzbekistan newspaper Pravda Vostoka said the southern districts of Bukhara, Karakul and Sverdlov had received about 60 percent of their average annual rainfall in one month.

title: Headliners; A TERM FOR BARAKA
description: It started two years ago as a domestic quarrel on a New York City street.

title: The Nation in Summary; A TOUCH TOO MUCH DIVIDING THE SPOILS
description: After a seven-week trial that was as unusual at times as his administration, Ray Blanton last week was convicted of Federal charges of extortion, conspiracy and mail fraud in the sale of state liquor licenses during his term as Governor of Tennessee. Two co-defendants also were convicted of conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: EDUCATOR PREPARES FOR STAMFORD CHALLENGE
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. ALMOST from the day he became Superintendent of Schools here, there were rumors that Jerome B. Jones would be leaving for a job elsewhere. The rumors seemed generated by the wishful thinking of some and by an assumption that no official would endure for long in a system that was, in significant measure, opposed to his appointment.

title: BOARD TO ASSESS UTILITY TAKEOVER IN UPSTATE TOWN
description: TWO years ago, Westchester voters decided by a margin of 130,192 to 104,708 to reject a proposal that would have authorized the county to establish a public-utility service system for the purpose of distributing electric energy in the county, effectively replacing Consolidated Edison.

title: The Region in Summary; NO FINAL VERDICT ON LOVE CANAL CANCERS
description: Their lives having been thoroughly disrupted by the chemical dumping disaster in their neighborhood, the last thing that former Love Canal residents needed was another inconclusive study of their health. But that's what they seem to have gotten last week.

title: Corrections
description: An article May 3 on the Digital Switch Corporation, its underwriter, John Muir & Company, and a July 1980 offering of Digital's common shares and warrants contained several errors.

title: Sound; CAR STEREO FINALLY REACHES MATURITY
description: Since the days of ''The Canterbury Tales,'' entertainment en route has counted among the pleasures of travel. Today, songs of the open road - as well as songs of the traffic jam -both benefit from the maturation of car stereo. This maturity was long in coming.

title: Karen A. Larson Wed To Larry Alan Wentz
description: Karen Astrid Larson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Orvin P. Larson of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday to Larry Alan Wentz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Wentz of Livingston, N.J. Town Justice Mercator Kendrick of Southampton, L.I., performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Freeport.

title: Customs and Currency
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: ''EVERY issue is a women's issue,'' Michele Aisenberg said this week, ''but you've got to be there minding the store. Nobody takes care of your business like you take care of your business.''

title: Dining Out; CONSISTENTLY APPEALING DISHES
description: FOR dining in pleasantly unpretentious surroundings on food that is fresh and prepared with simple honesty, Michael's in East Hampton is a place to remember. Its location in Maidstone Park at the end of Three Mile Harbor Road, a short distance from the water, has inspired an emphasis on fish and seafood.

title: SALUTE TO ISRAEL PARADE
description: The Salute to Israel Parade today marking the 33d anniversary of Israeli independence will begin at 11 A.M. at Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, move to 86th Street and then to Third Avenue.

title: 'GAIJIN'-PORTRAIT OF THE OUTSIDER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf, who teaches at Yale, is writing a book on film and the Holocaust through a Rockefeller Foundation fellowship. By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: Joan Buckman, Nurse, Wed
description: Joan Marie Buckman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl R. Buckman of Toms River, N.J., was married there yesterday to Vito Joseph Corasaniti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Corasaniti of Bayonne, N.J. The Rev. David J. Casazza performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Phillip A. Lowery assisted. The bride is a nurse at New York Hospital. Her husband is a lawyer in Totowa, N.J.

title: Track Robbery Triumphs In Handicap at Hollywood
description: Track Robbery took a long early lead and held on to win by 1 1/4 lengths in the $106,800 Beverly Hills Handicap at Hollywood Park today.

title: SAUDI STRATEGY DULLS THE OIL WEAPON'S EDGE
description: IMMEDIATELY after Israel's surprise attack on the Iraqi nuclear reactor last week, Western leaders were concerned that the Arab nations might retaliate with another oil embargo against the United States and other friends of Israel. As the dust settled, however, the indications were that the oil weapon - for the immediate future at least - would remain sheathed.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING A BOLL W. Stenholm and Dan Daniel
description: WEEVIL By STEVEN V. ROBERTS

title: Home Clinic; REMOVING UNSIGHTLY MILDEW FROM HOME EXTERIORS
description: HOMEOWNERS discovering that the paint on the outside of their house is gray and dirty looking in several places - especially if the paint is a light color - often conclude that the discoloration is a result of air pollution or windblown dirt and that, short of washing off the dirt, there is little that can be done.

title: BLACK FILM FESTIVAL SET
description: NEWARK THREE New Jerseyans are among the contributors to the 1981 Newark Black Film Festival, which begins Wednesday and will continue every Wednesday evening through July 22. Curtain time is 7 o'clock.

title: LAHORE, A SURVIVOR WITH A BITTERSWEET HISTORY
description: History has dealt the lovers of Lahore more than their share of broken hearts. This graceful and cultured city, with a history that stretches by some accounts back into the days of the epic Ramayana, passed through many conquering hands - Hindu, Mogul, Persian, Afghan, Sikh and British -on the way to becoming an intellectual center of the Indian subcontinent, only to be relegated with the partition of British India to the status of a provincial Pakistani capital.

title: Patricia Morgan Lewis Wed to R. S. Kauffman
description: At Christ and St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Norfolk, Va., yesterday, Patricia Morgan Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Morgan Lewis of Virginia Beach, Va., was married to Richard Scott Kauffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Linton Kauffman of Washington Crossing, Pa. The Rev. Irwin Morgan Lewis Jr., brother of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Peter Mixter Weds Nancy G. Schaefer
description: Nancy Griffin Schaefer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Albert Schaefer of New Canaan, Conn., was married in the garden at her parents' home last evening to Peter Jason Mixter, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Mason Mixter of Darien, Conn. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Seymour St. John, former headmaster of the Choate School, of which the bridegroom is a graduate.

title: Valarie Ann Eramanis Wed to Peter M. Carver
description: Valarie Ann Eramanis and Peter Maxwell Carver were married yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles G. Newbery.

title: Art; HELEN LEVITT PHOTOS SHOWN AT ATHENEUM
description: HARTFORD T AKING up photography in the 1930's, Helen Levitt had her first solo exhibition in 1943, at the Museum of Modern Art. Her black-andwhite prints of New York City scenes quickly won her a small but select circle of admirers that included the late James Agee, who later wrote the text for her book, ''A Way of Seeing'' (1965).

title: TV View; A FIVE- PART EXAMINATION OF U.S. DEFENSES
description: In an unprecedented scheduling arrangement, CBS News is presenting on consecutive evenings at 10 P.M. five hour-long documentaries on the single subject of ''The Defense of the United States.'' The first, subtitled ''Ground Zero,'' will be telecast tonight. The project was announced last September by Bill Leonard, president of CBS News. Recently, Mr. Leonard said: ''Since we began this project, the issue of coping with the nuclear age has become even more critical. The arms-limitations talks have broken down, and the new Reagan Administration has pledged to spend $1.3 trillion on defense over the next five years. The fundamental decisions this country is about to make on defense spending and defense strategy will have a momentous impact on American foreign policy and domestic policy for the remainder of this century.''

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE KILLING OF KAREN SILKWOOD The Story Behind the Kerr-McGee Plutonium Case. By Richard Rashke. Illustrated. 407 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $11.95.

title: Barbara T. Bennett, a Painter, Married to Thomas N. Moore
description: At the First Congregational Church of Darien, Conn., yesterday, Barbara Therese Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James G. Bennett Jr. of Darien, became the bride of Thomas Nelson Moore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Moore of Greenwich, Conn.

title: 20 More Train Victims in India
description: Search parties have found 20 more bodies in a river into which seven coaches of a passenger train plunged last Saturday, the Press Trust of India reported today. Officials have said the death toll may reach up to 800 in the accident in Bihar state, though only 268 people have so far been accounted for.

title: THE BENEFITS OF COSTLY OIL
description: While most analysts agree that, on balance, rising energy prices have been a drag on the economy since the Arab oil embargo of 1973-74, there have nevertheless been some benefits. Since 1973, total employment in coal, oil and natural gas, the basic extraction industries, has risen by more than 400,000, or more than 90 percent.

title: DEMOCRATIC DIFFICULTIES
description: GOVERNING AMERICA An Insider's Report from the White House and the Cabinet. By Joseph A. Califano Jr. 474 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title:
Art Wave Hill in Riverdale;
SCULPTURE AND SITE BLEND AT WAVE HILL
description: AREALLY extraordinary show of outdoor sculpture is now on view at Wave Hill, the mansion with arboretum and gardens in Riverdale, just a short distance from Westchester County. It contains only nine works by as many artists, along with assorted preparatory studies and other works installed in the house itself, but seeing it is to experience contemporary sculpture in an unusually affecting and moving way.

title: MAYORS CONFERENCE IN RIFT OVER BUDGET
description: The United States Conference of Mayors opened its annual convention here today in an acrimonious atmosphere, its once cohesive and influential membership sharply divided over whether to support President Reagan's economic program.

title: Pelham Manor EARLY every Saturday morning, Cosmo Paone leaves the Cape Cod home in the center of this Westchester community with his wife, Marilyn, and children, Tricia, 13 years old, and Vincent, 9.  They head for the Yonkers Raceway.
description: The races don't start until 8 o'clock at night, but Mr. Paone doesn't squire his family to the historic track off Yonkers Avenue to watch races. He takes them there for two reasons: one he calls therapy for his health; the other he calls togetherness.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; CONGRESS MOVES TOWARD A STUDENT CREDIT CRUNCH
description: Just about everybody agreed with the principle - that the Federal student loan program could use trimming - but just about nobody seemed happy with the methods that emerged in Congress last week.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 6 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 10 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 4 8 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 4 3 8 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 5 5 34 THE COVENANT, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Fifteen thousand years of South African history. 6 11 5 XPD, by Len Deighton. (Knopf, $12.95.) The British and the Russians race to get proof that Churchill once did business with Hitler. 7 9 22 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a hidden treasure.

title: FIGHTING AND LOSING THE GYPSY-MOTH BATTLE
description: GIVE me back my house. Give me back my yard. Go away. I don't want you around here. The sight of you makes my skin crawl. I saw two of you yesterday on the towels I took down from the line in the back. I flicked you off and I did not recognize you. You looked like tiny inchworms except you were black, so you fooled me. Oh, I don't know, maybe I wanted to be fooled. Who wants to think of you coming back here like you did last year and in other years?

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE AND QUEBEC SIGN PACT MAJOR POWER SUPPLY LINE
description: Hydroelectric power from Canada could begin flowing into New England within four years under an agreement that has been reached between New Hampshire and Quebec.

title: ITALIANS DESPAIR AS BOY IN WELL IS REPORTED DEAD
description: Workers abandoned their effort today to save a 6-year-old boy trapped in a muddy artesian well after an amateur cave explorer reported at dawn that the child's body showed no signs of life.

title: THE NEW RIGHT: A LIBERAL VIEW
description: WHEN the Democratic Town Committee of Westport asked me to speak at Staples High School on June 28, my first reaction was appreciation at being asked. Many political organizations are - understandably - more interested in hearing from incumbents than from former Senators.

title: DELANEY READIES HIS DEFENSE ON DELBELLO CHARGES
description: MOUNT VERNON IN the basement of Thomas J. Delaney's neat brick house on North Columbus Avenue here is a huge pool table. But there are no balls to be seen, no cue sticks, nor even any green felt. The table is smothered with file folders, one for each of the 46 charges proffered against the suspended Commissioner/Sheriff by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: The Region in Summary; CAREY SETTLES FOR INTERIM SOLUTION ON MASS TRANSIT
description: Concluding that the recommendations of Governor Carey's transit advisory panel weren't worth the blue ribbon they were wrapped in, legislative leaders in Albany worked out their own, admittedly temporary, solution to New York City's transit troubles last week. The Governor, persuaded that their plan was better than no plan, indicated he would accept it.

title: ALASKANS DELAYING ON SHIFT OF CAPITAL
description: Seven years have passed since Alaska's voters adopted an initiative that ordered the state capital moved from Juneau, and once again the Legislature is due to adjourn without having started the move.

title: Pakistani Aide Confers With Buckley on Weapons
description: Foreign Minister Agha Shah met today for six hours with James L. Buckley, Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, and said later that they had discussed ''general principles'' of arms aid rather than specific requests for American weapons.

title: MARCOS ELECTION FOE PRESSES FOR U.S. STATEHOOD
description: Bartolome C. Cabangbang, one of the handful of opposition members of a National Assembly dominated by President Ferdinand E. Marcos's New Society Party, celebrated the Philippine Independence Day yesterday with a rousing speech against the independence of his country.

title: In Milwaukee, Table Baseball Is New Pastime
description: A two-run, seventh-inning rally keyed by Greg Luzinski's double down the first-base line gave the Chicago White Sox an imaginary 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers today.

title: Kim Schmidt Wins Title
description: Kim Schmidt of Westfield, N.J., a Drew University senior, successfully defended her Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women Division III singles tennis championship today with a 6-1, 6-0 victory over Jean Marie Sanders of Occidental College at Mercer County Park. The 22-year-old champion lost only eight games in four matches during the four-day event.

title: The World in Summary; Irish Voters Split Their Differences
description: Violence-wracked Northern Ireland was not a central issue in last week's Irish parliamentary elections, because all three main parties have similar positions in favor of uniting north and south by peaceful means. But by nominating nine men serving in Northern Ireland jails - and having two of them elected - the nationalists won new attention for their cause.

title: MASS CASUALTIES: A TEXTBOOK CASE
description: ''IAM not an expert at this; there aren't any,'' said Alexander Butman, publisher of educational materials, about his newest venture. It involves the production of a textbook on mass casualty training.

title: HIGH SALARIES HURT MINOR LEAGUERS
description: To the Sports Editor:
