title: No Headline
description: Third world and Soviet-bloc nations repeatedly denounced Israel in the Security Council today for destroying an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: TEACHER ATTENDANCE BONUS IS CONTESTED
description: STAMFORD SOME old-timers here remember how, in another era, substitute teachers were a rarity in the Stamford public school system, as they were in most other Connecticut cities and towns. Back in the 1920's, 30's, 40's and 50's, they recall, regular staff teachers hardly ever seemed to miss a day of school.

title:
Gardening;
POISON IN THE GARDEN: OVERRATED HAZARD
description: CONSIDERABLE controversy has arisen in recent years over the poisonous nature of certain plants, some of which are commonly found in our homes and gardens. It seems that stories of assumed plant poisonings have aroused a reaction in journalists similar to that of ''man bites dog'' stories.

title: THE CASE FOR A TOCKS DAM
description: IT'S appropriate that the Delaware River was made famous by a soldier-engineer named George Washington. The Mississippi had its Mark Twain, the Nile had its Cleopatra and a little stream called the Shannon has numberless tenors perpetuating its myths.

title: HENRY VIII WAS THE MAN TO SEE
description: THE LISLE LETTERS Edited by Muriel St. Clare Byrne. Illustrated. 3,952 pp. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. Six volumes. $250 until Dec. 3l, 1981; $300 thereafter.

title: UNCERTAIN VOTE LEAVES IRELAND IN CONFUSION
description: The Irish political scene was plunged into confusion today by a parliamentary election that was so close as to be inconclusive.

title: THE ULTIMATE ART BOOK, SELLING DIVINELY AT $6,000 THE SET
description: The two volumes weigh 55 pounds, cost $6,000, and stand as the definitive photographic record of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel frescoes.

title: LEE IACOCCA'S HEIR APPARENT
description: IN the spring of 1979, Gerald Greenwald was Ford's man in Caracas. He was president of Ford de Venezuela, which earned $100 million for the parent company in the United States. His wife was an art critic and feature writer for the Caracas Daily Journal, an English-language paper, and their children enjoyed life abroad.

title: THE POLISH AWAKENING
description: Back when Poland was a different country -which is to say, eight months before the strikes of last year set off a chain of events that is shaking Poland's foundations and posing the most serious threat to the Soviet Union in decades - an exhibition called ''The Polish People - Self-Portrait'' ran at the National Gallery in Cracow. It drew huge crowds. People came from all over to see it, and they waited in line, a thousand at a time.

title:
Dining Out;
WHERE THE DECOR TAKES A BACK SEAT
description: SOMETIMES it seems that the quality of the cuisine in suburban Chinese restaurants is in inverse proportion to the plushness of the decor. Hunan, a popular family restaurant in Berkeley Heights, near Summit, is a case in point.

title: On Language By William Safire Psyche Delly Kimble Mead
description: A delicatessen in my neighborhood calls itself the ''Psyche Delly''; such parody is proof that the word ''psychedelic'' has earned its place in dictionaries. People who get spaced out on hot pastrami may be interested in the coinage of the word:

title: Brabham's Lola Qualifies For Front Row at Mosport
description: Geoff Brabham of Australia turned in the fastest qualifying time today to join Teo Fabi in the front row for tomorrow's Can-Am challenge race at Mosport Park. The 60-lap final is the first event of the nine-race North American circuit this year.

title: MODERN WESTERN ART IN VAST COLOGNE SHOW
description: Evoking memories of shocking Rhenish displays of contemporary art before World War I, Cologne this summer is staging a vast exhibition of modern art from 1939 to the present called Westkunst, or Western Art.

title: PROPERTY SWAPPED TO SAVE TAXES
description: In the beginning there was a law that allowed a couple of farmers to trade fields Maybe they wanted a shorter walk to their respective barns. By trading, instead of buying and selling the two fields, they avoided paying capital gains taxes. That was decades ago.

title: MY BROTHER'S KEEPER
description: Sunday ObserverBy Russell Baker Baker Headline to Come Patrick McDonnell

title: ACUPUNCTURE USED TO TREAT DRUG ABUSE
description: The muscular young man on the narrow cot winced visibly as an acupuncturist, Hansen Mok, removed and reattached the hair-thin needle with the electrodes attached to it.

title: Washington; REAGAN AND THE ATOM BOMB
description: For over a generation, the control of nuclear weapons has been recognized as the most important question before the human family. If they cannot be controlled and their apocalyptic power is used to settle the unavoidable disputes between nations, then none of the other questions - of hunger and ideology and a livable world - can be resolved.

title: A PANORAMA OF THE AMERICAN PAST IN THE NORTHEAST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PATRICIA BROOKS is the author of the book, ''Best Restaurants of New England.'' By PATRICIA BROOKS

title: EAGLETON TO CONDUCT A PRIMARY AUTOPSY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK A''POSTMORTEM'' conference on New Jersey's recent gubernatorial primary - the meeting is titled, ''Would They Still Have Won - And, If So, By How Much?'' - will take place Wednesday at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.

title: SUMMER ACTIVITIES LIGHT UP THE ISLE
description: DESPITE some budget cutting, the Island will still be a summer festival of performing and visual arts this year. Everything is on tap, from the New York Philharmonic and New York City and Metropolitan Opera Companies to such home-grown talents as the Long Island Symphony, the Long Island Philharmonic, the Eglevsky Ballet and the American Concert Band, with a heavy helping of entertainment from more local musicians and performers.

title: Dining Out; A CRITIC'S CHOICES FOR CHINESE
description: CUISINE By M. H. REED

title: JUDGE BACKS TEACHING OF EVOLUTION TO A CREATIONIST
description: California did not violate the religious rights of a child with fundamentalist beliefs by teaching the theory of evolution, according to a judge who was preparing to issue a written final ruling in a trial involving so-called creationism.

title: ULTRALIGHT PLANES: FLYING VERSION OF THE 5-CENT CIGAR
description: Three years ago, John Chotia decided that what America needed and wanted was a 160-pound, one-man airplane that comes in a ready-to-assemble kit, looks a little bit like a flying lawn chair and does not require a pilot's license to operate.

title: Paperback Talk
description: On tour. No matter where you are in the United States this month, if you turn on your television or radio set, read a newspaper or a magazine, you're apt to come across Gay Talese discussing his book ''Thy Neighbor's Wife,'' Erica Jong her novel ''Fanny,'' Martha Weinman Lear her memoir ''Heartsounds,'' Adrien Arpel her ''How to Look Ten Years Younger'' and Craig Claiborne his ''Craig Claiborne's Gourmet Diet.'' They and a score of other writers of recently released paperbacks are on coast-to-coast tours, carrying on a tradition established a generation ago by Jacqueline Susann and Mickey Spillane - a tradition founded on the notion that an author's job isn't over once he's written his book, but that it behooves him to get out there and help sell it when it's published.

title: WIESENTHAL DENIES SLIGHTING TIMERMAN
description: Simon Wiesenthal, the hunter of Nazi war criminals, said yesterday that quotations attributed to him in a recent syndicated column by William F. Buckley Jr. questioning the integrity of Jacobo Timerman, the critic of Argentina's rulers, had been partly fabricated.

title: RENOVATION OPPOSED FOR CATHEDRAL
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE IN preparation for next year's 25th anniversary of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Long Island, St. Agnes Cathedral in Rockville Centre will undergo $1.5 million in renovations. A small group of laymen, nuns and priests, however, believe that the event would be better commemorated if the money were used for human rather than for building needs.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WHY would anyone want to be William Finnigan? That's what William Finnigan wants to know. Mr. Finnigan, who runs the Parts Department at the GTE-Sylvania service center in Carlstadt, is apparently the victim of an impersonation deep in the heart of Texas.

title: ATLANTIC CITY FOCUSES ON CONVENTION HALL
description: ATLANTIC CITY and Casino Control Commission officials, striving to recommend a plan to revive convention business, are off in different directions as the July 1 deadline for a common proposal nears.

title: SUMMERTIME IN AN ISLAND KINGDOM
description: MARIE ANTOINETTE casts a worried glance at her husband. Poor Louis is tres distraught. ''Is it the onset of summer here on Long Island?'' she asks. ''Of course, it's the onset,'' he says, adjusting his crown. ''It's practically here - the barbecuing on the palace grounds, the crabgrass in the formal garden. All those things that happen in summer are upon us.''

title: JeanneMarie Boisselle Wed
description: JeanneMarie Boisselle and Armand M. Patella Jr. were married yesterday at St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. William T. Smith performed the ceremony.

title: STORIES AND NOVELS
description: WINTER COUNT By Barry Holstun Lopez. Illustrated. 112 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $9.95.

title: Chess; EASING A CASE OF CRAMPS CAN SOMETIMES BE RISKY
description: The problem peculiar to the strategy of playing to cramp the enemy position is that to make the advantage in space count, line-opening pawn exchanges are necessary, but these will often relieve the defender's difficulties. On the other hand, if one goes on crowding the opponent's formation without making a provision for open lines, there may come a point when he can block the struggle completely, transforming the superiority in space into a paper tiger.

title: CO-OP SALES FEES ARE FOCUS OF DEBATE
description: In an attempt to attract a share of the dwindling number of cooperative apartment listings, Laurence Cox is offering to sell apartments for a 4 percent commission, or up to a maximum of $5,000, instead of the usual 6 percent brokerage fee.

title: Elizabeth Greason Bride of Executive
description: Elizabeth McClelland Greason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gray Greason of Lincroft, N.J., was married yesterday to John Pharr Holmes Jr., son of Mrs. Gray Thoron of Ithaca N.Y., and the late Mr. Holmes. The Rev. Dr. Bryant M. Kirkland performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: MATH MADE FUN AND INSTRUCTIVE Herricks Community Center
description: NEW HYDE PARK MORE than 700 schoolchildren jammed the gymnasium at the Herricks Community Center, where dozens of exhibits demonstrating mathematical concepts were on display for the opening of the Nassau County Mathematics Museum.

title: Television Week
description: Lest We Forget When the World Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors this week in Israel brings together thousands upon thousands of victims of facist barbarity, the Public Broadcasting Service will cover the event on a daily basis.

title: CONCERTS: COMBINATION OF SCHUBERT AND BARTOK
description: In 1904, Bartok planned to perform his own Piano Quintet in concert. At the last minute, Schubert's ''Trout'' Quintet was substituted. ''It was a work full of interest, as evocative and imaginative as his other compositions,'' wrote a newspaper reviewer, who believed the work to be Bartok's. ''Here we had evidence of the warmth of his Hungarian heart as well as the wide knowledge he brought to the writing of the music.''

title: WIDER ZONING PLAN FOR MIDTOWN URGED
description: The city's proposed revision of midtown zoning should be expanded to cover a larger area, according to several civic organizations that have released reports on the draft proposal.

title: Czech Party Daily Fears Polish Social Democracy
description: Czechoslovakia said today that the Communist Party congress scheduled for July 14 in Poland could deal a fatal blow to Soviet-style Communism there and establish a Social Democratic system.

title: ARGENTINA REJECTS NEW OFFER FOR TIMERMAN PAPER
description: An Argentine Government commission has rejected a bid by a provincial publisher to buy the plant of La Opinion, the newspaper seized from Jacobo Timerman four years ago.

title: IS THE CHALLENGE NOW THE BOTTLE OR THE GENIE?
description: WASHINGTON DURING his campaign, Ronald Reagan said he didn't think nuclear proliferation was ''any of our business.'' Last week, after Israel implemented its own unconventional nonproliferation policy, White House aides said Mr. Reagan had been misunderstood. Said a State Department spokesman: ''Preventing the spread of nuclear weapons and explosions is a fundamental objective of United States policy.''

title: Food; TAILS, YOU WIN
description: ISLAND PARK ''OUR busiest time of year is Christmas,'' said Charles Jordan, one of the owners of Jordan's Lobster Farm in Island Park. ''But the summer months, from May through September, are when lobsters are likely to be cheapest because they are most plentiful then. The weather is good and the fishermen can go out.''

title: Leigh Keith, Daniel Cohen Are Married
description: Leah Thompson Keith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Keith Jr. of Little Rock, Ark., was married in St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Cathedral there yesterday to Daniel Hays Cohen, son of Richard N. Cohen of Stamford, Conn., and Dr. Judith Levinson of East Hampton, L.I. Msgr. B. Francis Devitt performed the ceremony.

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER The seven actors in Caryl Churchill's comedy ''Cloud 9,'' at the Theater De Lys, must be happy people. They've been asked to rise to a demanding occasion, and rise they most certainly do.

title: 'Heebie Jeebies' Opening Is Postponed to Thursday
description: ''The Heebie Jeebies,'' a musical about the Boswell sisters, the singing trio of the 30's, has postponed its opening to Thursday at the WestSide Arts Theater. Today's issue of The Guide, which lists the musical as opening today, went to press before the schedule change.

title: Politics; ALBANY EX-AIDES AND L.I.
description: WHAT started as a created refuge on Long Island for a Carey appointee has grown into an operation embracing several positions. The post of Carey administration liaison to the Island was created two years ago to provide a job for Judith Hope, the former East Hampton Supervisor who was leaving her Albany position as the Governor's patronage dispenser. Miss Hope was paid $36,000 a year.

title: BOND AND COMPANY
Dancers in Repertory Debut
description: Dancers in Repertory will make its debut peformance Saturday in the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of Japan House, 333 East 47th Street.

title: SOGGY COURSE OFFERS LESSON TO SALLY LITTLE
description: Sally Little, the defending champion, could not move up among the leaders of the rain-delayed Ladies Professional Golf Association Championship today, but she was just a bit more knowledgable about golf than she was yesterday.

title: Annie R. Gronningsater Is Bride of Builder
description: Annie Reyburn Gronningsater, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arne H. Gronningsater of New York and Westport, N.Y., was married yesterday to Schelling McKinley, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert McKinley of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and Benson, Vt. The Rev. Samuel Whitney Hale, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the outdoor chapel of Camp Dudley in Westport.

title: HOW THE SUPREME COURT READS CONGRESS'S
description: MIND By LINDA GREENHOUSE

title: WORLD AUTO OUTPUT FALLS
description: If misery loves company, then American auto producers should take comfort from depressed conditions in leading markets around the world. With the exception of Japan, no major auto-producing country managed to manufacture and sell more cars, trucks and buses during this year's first quarter of 1981 than it did in the first quarter a year ago. Worldwide, production in the quarter fell more than 800,000 units, or 9.7 percent, according to a survey conducted by Ward's Auto World.

title: Iraqi Office in Beirut Attacked
description: A small rocket damaged the Iraqi Airways office here overnight, Iraqi sources said today. They said gunmen later exchanged fire with the office's guards, but that no one was hurt in either incident.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: IT'S official: Anthony 'Toby' Moffett is running. The only question is, for what? Mr. Moffett's campaign headquarters opens tomorrow in Farmington, which a spokesman noted is ''within the confines of the Sixth District,'' which the 37-year-old Democrat now represents in Congress. But the function of the office is to explore the possibility of a statewide campaign next year, when the term of Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. expires, and the Governor, William A. O'Neill, will have to seek a term in his own right, if he wishes to continue in office.

title: No Headline
description: We are in the midst of an economic downturn. Our basic industries are faltering, to say nothing of the satellite industries that are dependent on them.

title: HOW TWO TAXPAYERS TURNED THE TABLES ON THE I.R.
description: S. BY LESLIE WAYNE

title: THE ROYAL BALLET - FRISKY AT 50
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington frequently reports on the arts in Britain. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON An image of the Royal Ballet: It is the climax of a special 50thanniversary program they have mounted at their Covent Garden home. Extracts from some 38 ballets have been given in four hours. Jubilation is tinged with exhaustion. Suddenly, at the end of numerous calls, the crimson curtains part once more, the orchestra strikes up a waltz and there is Ninette de Valois, the company's founder, dancing with choreographer Kenneth MacMillan, Frederick Ashton with Margot Fonteyn, Norman Morrice, director of the company, with Alicia Markova. A wave of communal joy links auditorium and stage.

title: BUSINESS AS USUAL IN THE MINORS
description: It was classic: two outs, bases loaded, bottom of the ninth, the home-team Columbus Clippers behind, 8-5, to the Tidewater Tides, and two strikes on the batter, Andre Robertson. If there is a single moment in sports, a moment most pregnant with anticipation, it is this one. Everything hung in the balance.

title: Two Wounded by Ulster Snipers
description: A policeman was shot in the neck and seriously wounded by a sniper today in a Londonderry shopping district, the police said. They added that a sniper had also wounded an off-duty British soldier in an ambush west of Belfast.

title: Dancers Bills in Prospect Park
description: Seven dancers and modern-dance companies will participate in a four-day dance segment of the second annual Celebrate Brooklyn performing-arts festival in Prospect Park, July 9-12, at the Prospect Park Ninth Street Bandshell at Ninth Street and Prospect Park West. The performers are the Joyce Trisler Danscompany and Dyane Harvey (July 9); Diane McIntyre's Sounds in Motion Dance Company and Diamond (July 10); Bowyer and Bruggeman (July 11); Baker's Half Dozen, Okra and the Al Perryman dance companies in an all-Brooklyn program (July 12). The concerts, which are free, will begin at 8 P.M. Information: 643-7116 or 788-0055.

title: S. L. Smith Weds Kathleen A. Brown
description: In the Holy Family Roman Catholic Chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent, N.J., yesterday afternoon, Kathleen Ann Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Brown Jr. of Convent, was married to Stephen Laurence Smith. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Smith Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Brussels.

title: Jeannette M. Smith marriedin Dallas
description: Jeannette Marcus Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Milton Smith 2d of Dallas, was married there yesterday to Lyman Kevin Dann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Lewis Dann of Painted Post, N.Y. The Rev. Marcy Punnett, a Presbyterian minister of Big Flats, N.Y., and the Rev. Stephen Swann, an Episcopal priest of Dallas, performed the ceremony at the Perkins Chapel on the campus of Southern Methodist University.

title: PARIS, June 13 (Reuters) - King Khalid of Saudi Arabia discussed the Arab-Israeli conflict and other problems with President Francois Mitterrand today and left saying that he was satisfied with the talks.
description: ''We are leaving with very good impressions,'' said Prince Sultan, the King's brother, who also took part in the talks. ''We believe that President Mitterrand will lead France on the road to progress, prosperity and happiness.''

title: Dining Out; MIX OF CHINESE REGIONAL FAVORITES
description: MIDDLETOWN REGIONAL consistency is not a strong suit of most of Connecticut's Chinese restaurants, and diners seem to like it that way. A restaurant's name may suggest Peking, Hunan or Sichuan cooking, but it is more than likely the menu will be a melange of various regional dishes, drawing on favorites from all parts of China.

title: DEFENDING THE WAY
description: I have just finished reading ''When Amway Opportunity Knocks'' (May 31) by Matthew L. Wald. I was drawn to read the article because of the word Amway. I am one of the 750,000 Amway distributors that Mr. Wald wrote about.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE CONFIRMS ACCESS TO SECRET FUND
description: A White House official has confirmed that Ronald Reagan has access to a secret military fund, reportedly used for years to finance Presidential perquisites, but the official says he swears that the President will not misuse it.

title:
Architecture View;
FUTURISM'S DIRECTION TODAY? FULL SPEED BACKWARD
description: Whatever happened to the future? I mean, the world of the future, as it was envisioned in those future-happy days just after World War II. The promises and visions began, actually, during the war, when the architecture magazines were filled with dreams that were supposed to become reality as soon as the fighting stopped and construction could begin. The illustrations featured boldly cantilevered and streamlined saucers and spirals connected to other futuristic wonders by skyways and bridges. There were always bubble-domed automobiles of the future in the streets.

title: Art; CELEBRATING BRYANT AND THE HUDSON PAINTERS HE ENCOURAGED
description: acre, luxuriantly glorious landscape known as Upland Farm, which now makes up part of the large estate where the museum is situated. When he died in 1878 at the age of 84, he was buried in the Roslyn cemetery, which is contiguous to the museum property. And the Bryant Library in Roslyn is named for him.

title: Priscilla Anne Coker Is Bride Of David Townes in Bermuda
description: Priscilla Anne Coker, daughter of Col. and Mrs. D.H.E. Coker of Aldham, England, was married in Hamilton, Bermuda, yesterday to David Keith Townes of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Townes of Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: By Sports of The Times; As Empty As An Empty Ball Park
description: ITS proper name might be stadium but in baseball, it's always a ball park. To see a football game, people go to a stadium. To see a baseball game, they go to a ball park.

title: Ex-Agnew Adviser Drops Lawsuit In Return for a Letter of Apology
description: A former legal adviser to Spiro T. Agnew has agreed to drop a $17 million defamation suit against the former Vice President in exchange for a letter of apology, a lawyer in the case said today.

title: A LABEL THAT HITS BELOW THE BELT
description: AMERICA'S propensity for Belts - Sun Belt, Growth Belt, Bible Belt and so on - has recently emerged on Long Island, now described by some public-relations officials as ''the Sun Belt of the Northeast.'' As a long-term Long Island businessman, executive, administrator, educator, resident and taxpayer, I have mixed emotions about that phrase.

title: David Storey's 'Early Days' To Be Taped for CBS Cable
description: The critically acclaimed production of David Storey's ''Early Days'' at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington will be taped for the CBS Cable network, which will start operations next October.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC This is supposed to be the off season for classical music, but by a curious fluke Tuesday night offers a density of interesting concerts that puts the regular season to shame. On the Great Lawn in Central Park, the Metropolitan Opera is offering the first of its free concert-opera performances in the city's parks - ''Tosca'' with Renata Scotto, Placido Domingo and Sherrill Milnes, conducted by James Levine.

title: Design; A YOUTHFUL APPROACH TO OLD CHINTZ
description: Say ''chintz'' to the average person, and the type of decor that pops to mind is a grandmotherly melange of floppy slipcovers, bibelots and plants. Charming, but hardly the thing for a young man intent on a carefree summer holiday. Yet, when the designer Tim Romanello first saw the Southampton rental cottage shown here, he immediately thought of chintz.

title: ISRAEL'S RAID ON IRAQ PRODUCES HEAVY CLOUD OF DIPLOMATIC FALLOUT delegation at the United Nations Security Council
description: When sabotage in a warehouse near Toulon destroyed the core of a French research reactor bound for Iraq in 1979, French intelligence agents thought their Israeli counterparts were responsible. Israel was also suspected when Iraq's senior nuclear scientist was killed in Paris last year.

title: DEGNAN IN WASTE DISPUTE
description: THE letter from the Congressman to John J. Degnan, New Jersey's former Attorney General, began simply enough. As chairman of a House subcommittee investigating the performance of New Jersey's Hazardous-Waste Strike Force, former Representative Bob Eckhardt wanted Mr. Degnan to answer a few questions ''to complete the hearing record of Dec. 16, 1980.''

title: Cooney's Action Called Unjustified
description: To the Sports Editor: Terry Cooney is unjustified in bringing legal action against Billy Martin for his alleged ''assault'' on the umpire earlier this month. Cooney was not injured and should have been satisifed with the decision of the American League president, Lee MacPhail. Sending Billy Martin to jail for a possible term of six months would just hurt the whole American League. JULIE DENT

title: Letters; THE ENEMY IN CLEAR VIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMEN, THE LOSERS IN PENSIONS
description: Despite the growth of private pension plans - which are designed to help workers and their families avoid indigence in old age - retirement for millions of women is synonymous with pgverty.

title: 3 COSTA RICA CIVIL GUARDS KILLED WHEN THEY STOP CAR
description: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 13 (AP) - Four men in a car driven by by a woman killed three civil guardsmen today, then mortally wounded a taxi driver who tried to stop their weapons-laden vehicle, officials reported.

title:
Beauty;
FACING UP TO SUNNING
description: One of the most important cosmetics on the market today is the high-potency sunscreen. Why? Because most of the changes that one associates with aging - wrinkles, sagging, excessive dryness, broken blood vessels, blotchiness, transparent skin - are caused not by some inevitable deterioration over the years but by chronic sun damage. It is a cumulative process, and an insidious one, as the visible signs usually appear on the surface of the skin 10 or 15 years after the destruction of the skin's underlying layers is well under way.

title: 3 KILLED AND 53 INJURED AS TORNADO STRIKES OHIO TOWN
description: Three persons, one of them an infant, were killed this afternoon when a tornado smashed through the center of this small town, uprooting trees, crushing cars and tearing roofs off buildings. At least 53 other people were injured, the authorities said.

title: SALE OF PHILADELPHIA CAB BRINGS HOPE OF IMPROVED SERVICE
description: As M. Walter D'Alessio tells the story, after he and a developer from Dallas recently got into a cab in Center City, the driver stepped on the accelerator and the engine ''threw a rod.'' The next taxi had ''no springs at all.''

title: NO GROWTH NOW
description: Administration officials gave their first specific predictions last week of what they think the economy will do in the current quarter and the third three months of the year.

title: BANI-SADR, FEARING FOR LIFE, IS REPORTED TO BE IN HIDING
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who charged last night that his fundamentalist opponents had begun an effort to remove him from office and murder him, was reported to be in hiding in Teheran today, protected by his supporters.

title: GRAIN SALES TO SOVIET GET THE GREEN LIGHT
description: Soviet grain purchases from the United States may resume in the next few months. Under an accord reached in London, the Russians will be able to purchase up to 6 million more metric tons of corn and wheat before Sept. 30. The agreement was seen as a first step toward normalizing grain trade after the end of the embargo imposed when Soviet troops entered Afghanistan.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Selling 'Evil' Beer
description: On the theory that evil sells, the Pearl Brewing Company of San Antonio began last October to market J. R. Ewing's Private Stock, a beer named for the heinous star of the television show ''Dallas.''

title:
Art;
CAPTURING THE VALENCE AND AMBIVALENCE OF ABSTRACT FORCE
description: PORT WASHINGTON VALENCE, the dictionary tells us, is the degree of combining power of an element. Ambivalence means simultaneous attraction and repulsion, the quality of things being drawn together while at the same time being forced apart. These two terms are used by the sculptor Robert Vesely to describes his works in stone, being shown at Gallery Odin through June 30.

title:
Photography View;
BEYOND REPORTAGE TO ART
description: No doubt the war photographs of Don McCullin are reportage, and no doubt they are also something more. They are reportage because they record incidents that occurred or sights that were seen during the past two decades in Cyprus, Vietnam, Africa, the Near East and Ulster. Most of them were taken for The Sunday Times of London, for which McCullin is a staff photographer, and they were published in that and other periodicals with the usual journalistic accompaniments of headlines, captions and texts.

title: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL EXPANDS
description: The 15th Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center will expand its length from six weeks to seven and will offer 42 performances this summer. The season will begin July 13, when Leonard Slatkin will conduct the Mostly Mozart Orchestra with Alicia de Larrocha as piano soloist.

title: POLAND RESPONDS TO ITS PEN PALS IN MOSCOW
description: The Soviet Union last week tried to get rid of Stanislaw Kania, the Polish Communist leader, and failed. In a facedown many feared could be a prelude to Soviet military intervention, the Polish Central Committee voted overwhelmingly to endorse Mr. Kania and his 11-member Politburo, and tried to placate the Russians with promises of only minimal trims in liberalized policies.

title: 3 MEN DIE TRYING TO RESCUE BOY FROM SEPTIC TANK
description: Three volunteer rescue workers died today and a fourth was injured while saving the life of an 8-year-old boy who had fallen into a septic tank filled with poisonous gas.

title: Irish Tower Gets Clearance to Run
description: Irish Tower will be allowed to run in the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup tomorrow, but one-quarter of any of his earnings in the race would be impounded because of an ownership question in New York State, a member of the California Racing Board said today.

title: CHURCH'S PROGRAM FOR HOMELESS UPSETS ITS NEIGHBORS
description: A Manhattan church's program to help homeless people is being criticized by neighborhood groups that contend that the church is attracting derelicts and ''bag ladies'' to a residential neighborhood.

title: BATTLE INTENSIFIES OVER GYPSY MOTH
description: THE New York metropolitan area is crawling with billions of gypsy moth caterpillars that are defoliating thousands of acres and making people squirm. Entomologists report that the pests are more numerous this year than last throughout the three-state area, as much as tenfold in parts of Connecticut.

title: 2-Hitter in All-Star Game
description: Brian Smith of Massapequa and Bob Greenlee of Uniondale combined on a two-hitter to lead the Nassau Conference I-II baseball all-stars to a 6-0 victory over the III-IV stars today at Eisenhower Park. Bob Cona of Mepham High led the winners' attack with a double and two singles.

title: POCONOS PLAY HOSTS TO PRIESTS
description: FOR the first time in 40 years, all priests in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark gathered in a convocation that ended last Thursday with a mass concelebrated by Archbishop Peter L. Gerety and 649 priests.

title: Japan's Premier Rests in Geneva
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived here today for what was described as a weekend of relaxation between stops on his current European tour. Mr. Suzuki has just spent three days in Italy, and plans to travel to Belgium on Monday.

title: Jane Howard and Clarence Martin Jr., Law Students, Wed
description: Jane Elizabeth Howard was married yesterday to Clarence Augustus Martin Jr. at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Richard L. Gressle of Fort Lee, N.J. performed the ceremony.

title: Nile Train
description: To the Editor:

title: BEGIN'S AIDES SAY MUCH MORE WAS AT STAKE THAN ELECTION strike on Iraq's nuclear reactor
description: JERUSALEM THE day dawned clear - good flying weather. The jet fighters and the crack pilots were in position. If their movements aroused any curiosity in this small country, the assumption was that they were bound for Lebanon, where Syrian antiaircraft missiles had been deployed six weeks before. That was where the Middle East's attention was riveted that bright Sunday a week ago, on Lebanon, not on a nuclear reactor in Iraq.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Every museum likes to put its best foot forward. Besides, visitors feel cheated if they find that something that they have heard about for years is not on view.

title: CLINIC SEEKS CURE FOR SLEEP DISORDERS
description: IN a small white frame house in Derby a group of doctors have been quietly working on a troublesome but little publicized health problem that is said to affect as much as 20 percent of the population: sleep disorders.

title: Airline Is Ordered to Hire Men in Sex-Bias Court Case
description: Southwest Airlines has lost a Federal civil rights lawsuit in which it claimed a right to exploit female sexuality.

title: Karen Eschenlauer, Wellesley '81, Bride Of Douglas Macrae, a Software Engineer
description: At the Community Congregational Church of Short Hills, N.J., yesterday, Karen Decker Eschenlauer and Douglas Bruce Macrae, 1977 graduates of the Pingry School, were married by the Rev. Kenyon Wildrick. He was assisted by the Rev. Walter Bell of St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Belvidere, N.J.

title: Caroline Bickel Wed to Hollis McLoughlin
description: Caroline Croft Bickel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Croft Bickel of Chattanooga, Tenn., and Hyannis Port, Mass., was married yesterday to Hollis Samuel McLoughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. McLoughlin of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Ben Haden performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in Chattanooga.

title: LAST 9 GACY VICTIMS, STILL UNIDENTIFIED, ARE BURIED
description: The skeletal remains of nine unidentified victims of John Wayne Gacy Jr., convicted of murdering 33 boys and young men, were buried yesterday in separate cemeteries, under stones bearing only the inscription, ''We Are Remembered.''

title: GRAFTED SKIN AIDS BURN VICTIMS BUT THERE IS A NEED FOR DONORS
description: Skin removed from a dead person and grafted onto a severe burn vicitm is the best covering for the victim, a burn research official says, but not enough skin is being donated to meet the need.

title: NJ TRANSIT CHANGING DOZENS OF BUS ROUTES
description: ON A map, the No. 82 Watsessing bus route resembles a great question mark, an appropriate symbol for the sparsely used line that meanders through Bloomfield, Belleville, East Orange and Newark in a way that defies logic.

title: Headliners; SUBURBAN WELCOME
description: ''I'd be happy to have him in the neighborhood,'' one homeowner said.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES FOR QUAKE VICTIMS
description: Residents of Golbaf, Iran, lifting a body from the rubble left by Thursday's earthquake. Officials estimate that more than 3,000 people have been killed but fear that 5,000 may be found in the southeastern province of Kerman. More than 1,600 people have already been buried in that region.

title: FOUR PENNSYLVANIANS SPEAK OUT ON FRUSTRATION WITH U.S. TAXES
description: It looked like just another hearing with another army of bureaucrats detailing facts and figures on tax protesters, but it ended with four angry citizens speaking from the heart.

title:
Dance collection;
FILM EVENT WITH A TWIST
description: GENEVIEVE OSWALD of Scarsdale is well known in dance circles as the woman who @singlehandedly organized and is now curator of the largest dance archive in the world - the New York Public Library dance collection. Sitting in her Lincoln Center office the other day, Miss Oswald discussed her latest project, an international dance-film and videotape festival and conference that opens tomorrow and runs through June 20.

title: Elise McDonough Wed To Robert D. Redmond
description: Elise Marie McDonough and Robert Driver Redmond were married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. John P. McGovern concelebrated the nuptial mass with Msgr. Harrold A. Murray, the Rev. Charles B. McDermott and Bishop John J. Dougherty of Newark.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWELL, MASS., TO HONOR ITS VETERANS ON FLAG DAY
description: The American flags so carefully folded after military services at a veteran's funeral are generally left to gather dust and memories on a closet shelf, never again to wave in the breeze. But not in Lowell.

title: Hanoi Proposes Renewed Talks With Peking Over Border Tension
description: Vietnam called on China today to resume negotiations on the tense situation along the border between the two countries.

title: DEAD END
description: THE CHILD SAVERS Juvenile Justice Observed. By Peter S. Prescott. 244 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 14, 1981
description: International Philip C. Habib went to Saudi Arabia from Beirut, Lebanon, where he had been for five days, continuing his efforts on the the behalf of the United States toward a peaceful solution to the dispute between Syria and Israel over the Syrian missile installations in Lebanon. He is expected to urge the Saudis to exert a moderating influence on the Syrians. (Page 1, Column 6.) Israel was repeatedly denounced by third world and Soviet-bloc countries in the Security Council of the United Nations for its bombing of Iraq's nuclear reactor. Insisting that condemnation was not enough, they demanded that the Council place an embargo on any trade that strengthened Israel's ''aggression.'' (1:5.)

title: Bromley Smith Jr. Weds Kimberly Remsen Hickok
description: Kimberly Remsen Hickok, who was graduated cum laude from Georgetown University last month, was married yesterday to Bromley Keables Smith Jr. The ceremony was performed in the Great Choir of the Episcopal Cathedral of SS.

title: BASEBALL CLUB OWNERS STAYING CLEAR OF ACTION ON STRIKE
description: The major league club owners are scheduled to meet in Kansas City June 24. The subject: the major league broadcasting agreement. The American League held a meeting in Chicago last Thursday. The subject: the 1982 schedule. ''Our man who was there tells me six or seven owners were there and not a word was mentioned about labor or anything but the schedule,'' Peter Bavasi, president of the Toronto Blue Jays, said yesterday, speaking about the Chicago meeting.

title:
Gardening;
POISON IN THE GARDEN: OVERRATED HAZARD
description: CONSIDERABLE controversy has arisen in recent years over the poisonous nature of certain plants, some of which are commonly found in our homes and gardens. It seems that stories of assumed plant poisonings have aroused a reaction in journalists similar to that of ''man bites dog'' stories.

title: AFTER 50 YEARS IN POLITICS ROSSETTI CALLS IT A CAREER
description: Frank G. Rossetti's half-century of service with the Democratic Party is ending where it began - at the corner of First Avenue and 116th Street.

title: COLLEGE: 19-YEAR-OLD TELLS HOW TO GET IN
description: WHEN his book, ''The Ten Point Plan for College Acceptance,'' comes out later this month, Lawrence Graham will be among Westchester's youngest published authors. Mr. Graham, 19 years old, has just completed his sophomore year at Princeton University and a second book is already under way.

title: SUNDAYS ARE SUPER ON HIGHLIGHTS FILMS
description: In 22 minutes a team's many highs of the past season and a few of its lows can be seen on a local television program, at a Rotary luncheon, a group ticket sales meeting or at a media conference. They can be seen on a highlight film which Art Modell, owner of the Cleveland Browns, describes as ''the most valuable selling tool in all of pro football.''

title: Follow-Up on the News; Jailhouse Decor
description: After taking a course in ''Body Chemistry and Offender Behavior,'' Lieut. Paul Becker, commander of the Santa Clara County Jail in San Jose, Calif., wondered if colors could be used as a calming influence in prisons.

title: Practical Traveler; STRATEGIES FOR COPING WITH THE NORTHEAST TRAVEL BOOM
description: If you are planning to pile into your family car and roam around the Northeast on vacation this year, you may be in for some disappointments. If you do not plan carefully - two words that until recently were rarely in the travel vocabulary of visitors to the region - you may find interminably long lines at some destinations and restaurants, and difficulty in obtaining a convenient motel room.

title: CAUTIOUS ATTACK ON DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: FOR three consecutive years, while drunken-driving statistics in the state rose, efforts to bring Connecticut laws closer to the sterner measures in effect in at least 40 other states have died in the Judiciary Committee of the State House of Representatives.

title: MSGR. JOHN V. M'GAVICK
description: Msgr. John V. McGavick, pastor emeritus of Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in New Dorp, S.I., died Thursday in Staten Island Hospital.

title: STADLER BIRDIES 18TH FOR WESTCHESTER LEAD
description: By John Radosta

title: Darren Walker Wins 100
description: Darren Walker, a freshman at the University of Maryland, won the 100-meter dash in 10.46 seconds yesterday at the 10th United States men's junior track and field championships, held at the Tennessee's Tom Black Stadium. Walker defeated Anthony Ketchum, a senior at Needville High School in Texas, who clocked 10.47, and Herschel Walker, the Georgia football star, who also clocked 10.47 for third place. Dave Volz of Indiana set a meet record in the pole vault of 18 feet one-half inch.

title: Patricia Rubenstein Wed
description: Patricia E. Rubenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Rubenstein of Syracuse, was married there yesterday to Jonathan Samuel Becker, son of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Becker of New York. Rabbi Theodore Levy and Rabbi Philmore Berger officiated at the Persian Terrace of the Hotel Syracuse.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Soviet Spy Ship Waiting To Observe Trident Test
description: The Russians have stationed a spy ship off the coast of Connecticut to study the first Trident submarine, which is scheduled to begin sea trials next week, American intelligence sources said.

title: The Wrong Pipeline
description: To the Business Editor: Neil Orloff's ''Rethinking Environmental Law,'' (May 10) points out an important problem of environmental policy: the myriad laws and regulations that have to be satisfied for energy development projects. It was concerns such as his that led to Congressional consideration of ''fast-track'' legislation and President Carter's proposal for an energy mobilization board.

title: No Headline
description: In his book, ''Puritan Boston and Quaker Philadelphia,'' Dr. E. Digby Baltzell (who might not refer to himself as ''Doctor'' were he Quaker) couldn't possibly have left out an acknowledgment of the tremendous accomplishments and contributions to the entire Philadelphia area in the field of mental and physical health, in education (excellent Quaker schools of all levels abound in Philadelphia, including at the Quaker-founded University of Pennsylvania, where Dr. Baltzell is a member of the faculty) and in social concerns in general. I will concede Dr. Baltzell's point that personal gain was not a motive. PENNY HONKER STEIN, Pennsburg, Pa.

title: A REPUBLICAN'S LOT IS NOT AN EASY ONE
description: JERSEY CITY PITY the poor Hudson County Republican who has the temerity to run for office. People laugh. Doors slam. Money hides. And political patronage, the civic coin of the realm around here, is almost nonexistent.

title: Abroad at Home; THE TIMERMAN AFFAIR
description: The Argentine military arrested Jacobo Timerman, tortured him, taunted him for being a Jew, held him in confinement for two and one-half years. In all that time the colonels and generals could think of no charge to bring against him.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; LAWYERS GROUP DEFENDS LEGAL AID
description: Last week, the New York Lawyers Committee to Preserve Legal Services delivered to members of Congress a 100-page brief on the Legal Services Corporation - the latest in a series of statements by the legal establishment defending the 16-year old program which dispenses Federal funds for legal aid to the poor.

title: REAPPORTIONMENT POINTS UP RIFT IN SUFFOLK G.O.P.
description: ALTHOUGH the Suffolk County Legislature approved a reapportionment plan last week, in the process it touched off what is likely to be a summer of court actions challenging the redrawing.

title: Harriet Perlmutter Is Wed To Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik
description: Harriet Perlmutter of Short Hills, N.J., widow of Milton Perlmutter, was married yesterday to Rabbi Ely E. Pilchik of West Orange, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the sanctuary of Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, where the bridegroom had been rabbi for 34 years before his recent retirement.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Defeats Gottfried in Final, 7-6, 7-5

title: 'The Comfort of Strangers'
description: Colin and Mary are on a European holiday in an unnamed city that is obviously Venice. Mary is divorced, the mother of two and an out-of-work actress. Colin wanted once to be a singer, but has settled for something else. They haven't been living together, but they have been seeing each other for seven years. We are told:

title: L.I. Woman, 72, Killed by a Train
description: A 72-year-old Bay Shore woman was killed this morning when she stepped in front of a Long Island Rail Road train, the police said. The police said the woman - Agnes Drumm Taylor of 29 Benjamin Street -stepped off a platform at the Bay Shore station at 9 A.M. and into the path of an eastbound train.

title: CITY TO SEEK CUT IN BANK'S TAXES DESPITE A PROTEST
description: The Koch administration has decided to seek a cut in taxes on commercial banks despite some internal opposition, and is expected to reach agreement with the state on specific legislation later this week.

title: SUPERPOWERS URGED TO KEEP ARM TREATY
description: An international panel of senior statesmen devoted to promoting disarmament concluded a two-day meeting in Moscow today urging the United States and the Soviet Union to preserve the treaty on the limitation of antiballistic missile systems, which is scheduled for review next year.

title: ANOTHER CRIME REPORT
description: Caplan WASHI NGTON - When it comes to predicting how this latest crime commission - the one appointed by Attorney General William French Smith to study violence - will fare, I am pessimistic.

title: JEWISH MUSEUM PROPOSAL REVIVES LANDMARK ISSUE
description: A tentative proposal to build a 25-story building on upper Fifth Avenue next to the turn-of-the century mansion that now houses the Jewish Museum is causing concern in the neighborhood and a renewal of efforts to have the mansion given landmark status.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.L. Laboratories Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., appointed Kenneth V. Kolberg vice president for finance and treasurer.

title: Genscher Urges Soviet To Withdraw SS-20's
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany today urged the Soviet Union to agree to a gradual withdrawal of SS-20 nuclear missiles in Europe so that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization could review plans to deploy new missiles itself.

title: WHAT UGANDA NEEDS-AND DOSEN'T NEED
description: To the Editor:

title: TREVINO IS AILING, BUT HOPES TO BE UP TO PAR FOR OPEN
description: DALLAS LEE TREVINO has not visited Merion since he won the United States Open there in 1971 in a playoff against Jack Nicklaus. But for the last few weeks he has, in his imagination, played that splendid little golf course many times. He's had plenty of time to do so, what with three days in a Houston hospital and bed rest at home in Dallas, taking care of an ailing back that will trouble him the rest of his life.

title: Marlene Grossman Bride of Physician
description: The marriage of Marlene Grossman, a senior clinical nurse at Mount Sinai Hospital, to Dr. Todd Feinberg, a resident in neurology and psychiatry at Mount Sinai Hospital, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Dr. Paul Steinberg, dean of Hebrew Union College, participated in the ceremony, which was performed by Rabbi Harold Furst.

title: AVERAGE U.S. AUTHOR' WRITINGS BRING IN LESS THAN $5,000 A YEAR
description: Despite the big movie and paperback deals that convey an impression of glamour and prosperity, the average author in the United States doesn't live on Easy Street. He or she earns less than $5,000 a year from writing, and has to make ends meet with the help of other jobs - or a working spouse. These are among the results reported in a major pioneering study to be issued today by Columbia University's Center for the Social Sciences about the economics, and frustrations, of professional authors in this country.

title: CLINCH RIVER'S KEY ROLE IN THE FUTURE OF AMERICAN NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: TRUE GOOSENECK LAMPS
description: The idea came to Bob Vogel one night in what he termed ''a flash of brilliance.'' Mr. Vogel and Michael Dinunzio are partners in a San Francisco-based company called Central Casting, a manufacturer of flexible arm lamps. ''They used to be called pharmacy lamps,'' Mr. Vogel said, ''but at some point, maybe because of the way their necks stuck out with those small round shades on the end, they were referred to as gooseneck lamps.''

title: East Berliners Vote in Defiance Of the Four-Power Agreements
description: East Berliners elected delegates to the East German Parliament today in defiance of the four-power agreements.

title: ZIJLSTRA CRITICIZES U.S.
description: Jelle Zijlstra, chairman of the B.I.S. and head of the Dutch central bank, today termed the Federal Reserve's policy on interest rates perverse.

title: Japanese Fishing Vessel Seized After 200-Mile Chase
description: A Japanese fishing vessel that led the Coast Guard on a two-day, 200-mile chase off the Aleutian Islands before surrendering is being detained for violating United States law by fishing for salmon within the 200-mile limit.

title: High Draft Choice
description: Not since Swede Halbrook, who is 7 feet 4 inches tall, played in the National Basketball Association in the early 1960's has the league had a player who stood higher than the world record in the high jump at the time he played. And who could remember, if ever, when the N.B.A. had a player who was heavier than the biggest man in pro football?

title: HAIG AND CHINA AIDE CALL FOR CLOSER TIES TO COUNTER SOVIET
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China concluded the first of three days of Chinese-American talks today in apparent agreement on the need for closer strategic cooperation to counter Soviet activities around the world.

title: FOR TWO AVERAGE PLAYERS, BASEBALL STRIKE BRINGS UNCERTAINTY
description: DYAR MILLER, relief pitcher and farmer, took a long look at the baseball strike this weekend and figured that his economic salvation might be lying back home in Indiana on those 60 acres of corn.

title: DEMOCRATS CONFRONTING THEIR OWN TAX DISPUTE
description: Representative Ed Jenkins, a Democrat from a district of small farms and businesses in north Georgia, says he hopes the Ways and Means Committee ''can stick with across-theboard'' cuts in personal income tax rates.

title: 200 Evacuated as Rail Car Falls Into a River and Leaks Toxic Gas
description: A refrigerated Boston & Maine Railroad freight car carrying potatoes, one of as many as seven that fell from a bridge into the Connecticut River yesterday evening, leaked Freon, a toxic refrigerant gas, local officials said.

title: BEGIN SAYS ATTACK ON IRAQIS MADE HIM 'FEEL A FREE MAN'
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel's successful air attack on Iraq's nuclear reactor one week ago had ended the most burdensome two years of his life, liberating him with all the feelings of a man released from jail.

title: COSMOS RALLY AND TOP BLIZZARD
description: The Cosmos, who have the best record in the North American Soccer League, fell behind in the first half but rallied in the second to score a 4-3 victory today at Giants Stadium over the Toronto Blizzard, the team with the second-worst record in the league.

title: Jo Ann Treitman Married
description: Jo Ann Treitman of Tuckahoe, N.Y., daughter of Mrs. Arnold Treitman of Woodmere, L.I., and the late Dr. Treitman, was married yesterday to Roger Joseph Drawec, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Drawec of East Longmeadow, Mass. Rabbi Mark Goldman performed the ceremony at the Oceanside (L.I.) Country Club.

title: Kathryn Anne Gilbert Is Wed
description: Kathryn Anne Gilbert, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Gilbert Jr. of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert E. Ruffolo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Ruffolo of Huntington Bay, L.I., and New York. The Rev. Paul McKeever performed the ceremony in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: TORONTO PAPER CONCEDES ARTICLE ON GOVERNMENT GRAFT WAS FALSE
description: Faced with a large libel suit and denunciations in the House of Commons, The Toronto Sun newspaper acknowledged last week that it had no documentation to substantiate its published charges that a member of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Cabinet benefited from stock manipulations through inside Government information.

title: DIFFICULT TASK FACES CHAIRMAN OF C.F.T.C.
description: When Philip F. Johnson was sworn in as the third chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission last Monday morning, no one had to introduce him to the staff or take him on a tour of the handsome Washington offices of the agency. Nor will anyone have to introduce him to the commodity industry, which has been unable to conceal its glee at his appointment.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You have come at a time when the international situation is tense and turbulent.

title: Hanoi and Two Allies Reject U.N. Parley on Cambodia
description: Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia announced today that they ''once again categorically reject the convening'' of next month's United Nations-sponsored international conference on Cambodia.

title: Jan Rise Liss Married to James Coddington
description: Jan Rise Liss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour H. Liss of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to James Littlefield Coddington, on of Mr. and Mrs. Parker L. Coddington of Sudbury, Mass. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton, L.I.

title: OUTDOORS: RECREATIONAL ROWING IS FOR STOUT OF HEART
description: PILOTS of traffic helicopters skimming over Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx and other waterways in the metropolitan area early each morning often see men and women flexing their muscles in racing shells. The rowers work out for a couple of thousand meters before going to their jobs. They do this the way other people jog.

title: Dollar Slips 3 Yen
description: The dollar dropped sharply today against the Japanese yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market, opening at 222.80 yen compared with Friday's close of 225.60.

title: Principal Charged With Assault on Boy
description: The principal of a Queens junior high school was charged with third-degree assault of a 14-year-old boy, the Nassau County police said. Both live in Rockville Centre.

title: FOR OTHER PLAYERS THE GAME GOES ON
description: THE power-hitting third baseman had declared himself a free agent. His team demanded compensation. A strike was threatened and the future of the game seemed in doubt. After protracted negotiations, a bargain was forged: The team that had lost its slugger would henceforth get four outs an inning. The game resumed.

title: Miss Sklias Bride Of Guy Garrett Jr.
description: Constance Maria Sklias of New York was married yesterday to Guy Thomas Garrett Jr. of New York and Canaan, N.Y., at the bridegroom's Canaan home. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Baughan of the Universalist Unitarian Church of North Adams, Mass.

title: Susan Lee Rubin Is a Bride
description: Susan Lee Rubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Rubin of Penn Valley, Pa., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Michael S. Silberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Silberman of Blue Bell, Pa.

title: Frank Smothers, Chicago Writer And World War II Correspondent
description: Frank A. Smothers, a Chicago journalist who covered gangland violence in the 1920's and reported on World War II in both Europe and Asia, died yesterday after a brief illness. He was 80 years old.

title: People
description: * James S. Berrien has been appointed advertising director of Field and Stream magazine.

title: Senator Doubts Report
description: Of Insufficient Crime

title: Advertising; TV Spots Recognized With Clios
description: A WEEK of Clio-giving hit its peak on Friday with ceremonies in both New York and Los Angeles to honor the American television advertising winners.

title: Emily Diane Porter Is Bride Of Lawrence Kolker on L.I.
description: Emily Diane Porter, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Porter of New York, was married yesterday to Lawrence Paul Kolker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Kolker of Halesite, L.I. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan.

title: Public Service Building in Newark Is Demolished for a Public Plaza
description: Blasted off its support columns by strategically placed explosive charges, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company's former headquarters collapsed in a heap of rubble yesterday in Newark. The utility has moved to a new headquarters nearby and plans to construct a public plaza on the newly vacant lot.

title: BANK PLANS FOR EUROMARKET
description: Banks will not seem much different. They will be able to transact the new business from their old headquarters, using the same offices and the same personnel, at least for a while. But the new business represents an enormous opportunity.

title: Ex-Banker Elected Trinity College Head
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - James English Jr., vice president for finance and planning at Trinity College, has been elected president of the school.

title: The Police Blotter
description: A 32-year-old man was shot dead as he was parking his car in Brooklyn in what the police called a ''gangland-type slaying.'' The victim, Sebastian Fenoccio, was shot once in the head and twice in the chest as he was locking up his garage at West 12th Street and Avenue U in the Bensonhurst section. ... Luis Rodriguez, 20, was found fatally stabbed in the hallway of an apartment building at 4024 Eighth Avenue in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. ... In a dispute on the corner of Scholes Street and Union Avenue in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section, Celestino Luiano, 18, was fatally shot and a friend, Dennis Ortez, 20, was wounded. Mr. Luiano was listed in serious condition at Greenpoint Hospital with multiple gunshot wounds. ... James Perry, 48 was found dead in his apartment at 146-32 Farmers Boulevard in Queens shortly after he was stabbed in a dispute 30 blocks away.

title: WAR INVADES A BEIRUT HOSPITAL, A HAVEN FOR VICTIMS OF ALL SIDES
description: The heroes and the heroines were fed up. They had been doing their jobs under fire for six years, but this was just too much. The gunfire and hatred and insanity that had swept Lebanon from one end to the other now invaded one of the country's last sanctuaries, the American University Hospital of Beirut.

title: WILLY BRANDT EMERGING FROM THE POLITICAL SHADOWS
description: The blue suits and the shirts of hypertensive white are gone now, replaced by beiges and greiges and narrow lapels. The face has its angles back, and the jawline has re-emerged as if from hiding. Even his hair is different, shorter, and, using a phrase Lyndon Johnson once found to describe his own new coiffure, much fluffier-looking.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VIVA VOCE

title: KANIA ELECTED AS POLISH PARTY DELEGATE
description: Stanislaw Kania, the head of Poland's Communist Party who survived a power struggle with hard-liners in the Central Committee last week, was elected at a regional party conference in Cracow today to be a delegate at the national party congress scheduled in July.

title: Disabled Yacht's Crewmen Rescued
description: Crewmen of the Swedish yacht For Fun, which had been feared lost at sea in the 3,000-mile trans-Atlantic yacht race, were rescued today.

title: Civella Sent to Leavenworth
description: Nick Civella, alleged head of organized crime in Kansas City, was taken to the Federal prison at Leavenworth, Kan., yesterday to serve a four-year sentence for bribery conspiracy after having his appeal bond revoked by Federal District Judge Scott O. Wright. Mr. Civella was convicted last July of conspiring to bribe a Fort Worth prison warden to arrange the transfer of his nephew from a Federal prison in Texarkana, Tex. to the Fort Worth facility.

title: I.R.A. Says It Failed in Effort To Kill Ex-Lord Chancellor
description: The Irish Republican Army said today that it made an unsuccessful attempt yesterday to assassinate Lord Gardiner, a former British Lord Chancellor, using a bomb attached to the car that he had been expected to use at Queen's University here.

title: 2 Wheelchair Riders Finish 150-Mile Trip
description: Two disabled persons who had set out from Albany on a wheelchair trip to prove the strength of the handicapped rode triumphantly into Central Park yesterday.

title: SWIFT MOVEMENT OF THE '82 BUDGET COULD FALTER ON FLOOR OF THE HOUSE
description: The Congressional budget process swept through its committee phase last week, producing one of the broadest packages of legislative changes in the nation's history as well as a victory for the Reagan Administration and the House and Senate Budget committees.

title: 2 Dead and 33 Hurt In Upstate Collision
description: A collision between a bus and a pickup truck has left two people dead and 33 injured, according to the police in this Niagara County city.

title: Elaine R. Sisman Wed To Martin S. Fridson
description: Elaine Rochelle Sisman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving E. Sisman of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday to Martin Steven Fridson, son of Mariann R. Fridson and the late Harry Y. Fridson of Detroit. Rabbi Henry Glazer performed the ceremony at the Greenwich Village town house of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Gillen.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE COMFORT OF STRANGERS. by Ian McEwan. 127 pages. Simon & Schust- er. $9.95

title: Controversy Surrounds Hagler's Victory
description: Marvin Hagler kept his world middleweight boxing championship by scoring a fifth-round technical knockout over Vito Antuofermo last night in a fight that was complete with blood, prefight controversies and postfight charges by the challenger's camp of an intentional butt by Hagler.

title: Conference Services Names President
description: Thomas A. Silvestri, 40 years old, has been named president of Harrison Conference Services, which, through a subsidiary, owns or manages eight conference and corporate education centers. He succeeds Walter A. Green, 41, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, which is based in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: U.S. Agency Says Harvard Should Pay Back $2.1 Million in Grants
description: The Inspector General's Office of the Department of Health and Human Services said that a three-year audit had found that the Harvard School of Public Health had ''inappropriately charged'' $2.1 million against $37.1 million in Federal grants received from 1975 through 1979.

title: Question Box S. Lee Kanner
description: QUESTION: An outfielder tips a long fly with his glove and the ball goes over the fence. Is this a home run or a double? Is he charged with an error? What happens if he catches the ball cleanly and then falls over the fence? Is the batter is out or is it a home run?

title: LANDLORDS SEEKING INCREASE IN MONTHLY FUEL SURCHARGE
description: Landlords have proposed higher fuel surcharges for tenants of 260,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City whose present temporary $8 monthly surcharges expire June 30.

title: A Surprised Richard Thomas Springs His Own Surprise
description: It may come as a shock to those who grew up with ''The Waltons,'' but Richard Thomas, the original John Boy in the popular television series, turned 30 Saturday.

title: Oh Men! Oh Women!
description: That gentlemen of a certain age often prefer ladies who've gone less than half their distance is a fact. That the attraction is mutual is also a fact.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR'S RACE STARTING WITH PROSPECT OF A FULL TREASURY
description: Michael J. Beasley, a Laborers' Union member who is now seeking work in the Prudhoe Bay oil fields, will campaign for Governor next year on the promise that he will distribute money to the voters out of the state's multibillion-dollar annual oil revenue.

title: WHO KNOWS THE MEANING OF ABORT?
description: The first time I ever heard of an abortion, I was too young to understand the procedure, too young even to quite understand how one got pregnant. The person having the abortion, however, was even younger: she was 12 - an odd, lonely child who was just the kind to be detoured on her way home from grade school by a promise of affection.

title: A CONGRESS OF MEN ASKS EQUALITY FOR BOTH SEXES
description: Declaring that men as well as women are victims of sexual stereotyping and of a serious, pervasive sexual discrimination that flows from it, delegates from 21 states launched this weekend what they hope will become a national men's liberation movement.

title: A Couple's Script for Keeping Their Act Together
description: Show business marriages are fragile as the actress Lucie Arnaz well knows. Her parents, Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, were divorced when she was a child.

title: THREE SUFFOCATE SAVING BOY IN SEPTIC TANK
description: Rescuers entered an abandoned septic tank one by one in efforts to rescue 8-year-old Benjamin Walker yesterday. The boy was saved, but three who entered the tank, one a teen-ager, died, suffocated by methane gas.

title: JESS KAGEL
description: Jess Kagel, who operated family-owned women's apparel stores in midtown Manhattan and later became a stockbroker, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Kagel, who lived in Manhattan, was 84 years old.

title: This is the second in a series of articles that will follow one Middle Western family as it searches for a new life in the Sun Belt.
description: Robert Wahrenbrock approached Dallas from the east after nearly three days of driving in the rain, and the sight of the city rising shiny and new in the Sunday afternoon sun brought a smile to his face.

title: Bad Break for Keystone Triton Is Fortunate One for Mo Bandy
description: For fleeting seconds last night, Max Buran and Abe Farber had a hint of the sweet taste of success that comes to few owners of harness horses. They saw their colt, Keystone Triton, cross the finish line first in the final of the $279,708 Yonkers Trot and left their table in the track restaurant for the winner's circle festivities.

title: Co-Founder Of Sony to Get Aspen Award
description: Masaru Ibuka, the 73-year-old co-founder and honorary chairman of the Sony Corporation of Japan, will receive the first humanism and technology award of the Aspen Institute for Humanistic Studies. The award will be presented to Mr. Ibuka at a ceremony in Aspen, Colo., on July 3.

title: Let George Handle It
description: INSTEAD of chastising Marvin Miller for withdrawing from the players' panel in the baseball negotiations, George Steinbrenner should take command of the club owners' side of the labor dispute that has stopped the season.

title: Barber Beats Littler On First Extra Hole
description: Miller Barber shot a par 4 on the first playoff hole and defeated Gene Littler today in the $200,000 Peter Jackson Champions golf tournament for seniors. Barber, 50 years old, won $30,000.

title: WINNERS OF TRANSATLANTIC AIR RACE
description: Russ Hancock of Nashville, left, and Boyd Munro of Bermuda at Le Bourget, France, after their twinengine Piper Navaho took top honors in the two-way crossing at the Paris Air Show.

title: Fiat Expects Loss on Cars
description: Fiat S.p.A. expects its automotive business to report a loss this year, although the group as a whole still expects to break even in 1981, Umberto Agnelli, vice chairman, said in an interview last Friday.

title: L.I. Wins Lacrosse
description: The Long Island Lacrosse Club defeated Mount Washington of Baltimore, 21-12, today to retain its United States Club Lacrosse Association championship at Adelphi University. Mickey Menna and Frank Cutrone led Long Island with four goals each and Phil Marino got three. Mount Washingon was led by Dave Cottle with three goals and John Lamon with two.

title: WRITERS AND PRODUCERS BREAK OFF TALKS AGAIN
description: For the second time in two days, negotiations between movie and television producers and Hollywood writers on strike have broken off. Talks ended angrily at 3 A.M. yesterday after two days of bargaining, during which the producers presented their new formula for dealing with original programming for pay-television, video cassettes and videodisks. But in a surprise move, the writers asked for a new session this afternoon and the two sides met briefly with little result. No date has been set for further meetings.

title: Dancers in Repertory Debut
description: Dancers in Repertory will make its debut peformance next Saturday in the Lila Acheson Wallace Auditorium of Japan House, 333 East 47th Street.

title: WATT SPEEDS REORGANIZATION OF STRIP MINE AGENCY
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt has abruptly ordered that the most controversial part of his plan to reorganize the Federal Office of Surface Mining go into effect tomorrow, at least on paper.

title: STAGE: 'HUNTING SCENES FROM LOWER BAVARIA'
description: AT the Manhattan Theater Club, where it opened last night, Martin Sperr's ''Hunting Scenes From Lower Bavaria'' is every bit as deadly dull as its forbidding title might suggest. But I'm not at all sure it had to be that way. Mr. Sperr's 1966 play - yet another exercise in contemporary German self-flagellation - is nasty to a fault, and such uncompromising nastiness can be effective as theater. Just how chilling ''Hunting Scenes'' might be, however, is difficult to judge. In its American premiere, this work has been all but dismantled by an inept production.

title: Beil Is Victor Over Zahringer
description: Randy Beil completed a string of upsets in the 58th annual Long Island Golf Association amateur championship today with a 8-and-6 victory over George Zahringer at the Old Westbury Country Club.

title: FLOYD'S 275 WINS WESTCHESTER GOLF
description: Raymond Floyd, enjoying the best season in his 19 years on the PGA Tour, won the 15th Westchester Classic today and took off for this week's United States Open brimming with confidence.

title: Knight-Ridder Hires Classified Ad Director
description: Knight-Ridder Newspaper Sales, which is the representative for 34 papers in 23 markets, has hired James A. Moss, ad director of Black Enterprise Magazine, and put him in the new position of classified advertising director.

title: TO ATTACK THE PROBLEMS OF ADOLESCENT SEXUALITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan, After Church, Announces Conference
description: President Reagan attended church services today for the first time since being shot by an assassin March 30 and promised reporters that he would answer all their questions at a news conference.

title: JOE TORRE LENDS HIS PERSPECTIVE TO STRIKE
description: JOE TORRE'S Chevrolet pulled into the nearly empty parking lot at Shea Stadium on Saturday and the Mets' manager stepped out of the car with his arm draped lightly around Alex Trevino's shoulder. Despite the major league baseball strike, Torre and his young catcher had spent the morning signing autographs at a Suffolk County shopping mall, where Torre jokingly told one young fan, ''Don't blame me, it's Alex's fault.''

title: Dr. Edith Ann Schear Is Bride Of Alan D. Pilzer, Accountant
description: The marriage of Dr. Edith Ann Schear, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Burt E. Schear of Dayton, Ohio, to Alan David Pilzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Pilzer of New York, took place yesterday at Temple Beth Abraham in Dayton.

title: LONG STRUGGLE OF BOTTLE BILL IN ALBANY: BATTLE WAS LOST, BUT SUPORT
description: GAINED By E. J. DIONNE Jr.

title: TV: STILL'S OPERA OF THE SOUTHLAND, 'A BAYOU LEGEND'
description: WILLIAM GRANT STILL was a black American composer who died in 1978 at the age of 83 after a career that began with arrangements for W.C. Handy and other jazz greats and then moved on to writing symphonies, operas and other music of a more classically standard nature. Tonight at 9, his opera ''A Bayou Legend'' will be shown in its television debut on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: Marijuana Cache Found in Home Of L.I. Man Shot by Holdup Men
description: A Hempstead man who had more than $100,000 worth of marijuana in his house was in critical condition today after two men apparently entered the home and shot him twice, the police said.

title: Yoko Ono's Film Tribute To Lennon on Cable TV
description: ''Walking on Thin Ice,'' Yoko Ono's film tribute to John Lennon, will be shown on Manhattan Cable and Teleprompter Channel J on Thursday evening at 9:30.

title: Linda Tatar Is Wed Upstate
description: Linda G. Tatar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Tatar of Gloversville and Sacandaga Park, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark M. Landau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Landau of Jackson Heights, Queens. Rabbi Milton Feierstein performed the ceremony at the Canfield Casino in Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

title: Raeanne Rubenstein Married to Richard Gordon Burns
description: Raeanne Rubenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Rubenstein of Silver Lake, Staten Island, was married yesterday to Richard Gordon Burns.

title: By Jim Benagh
description: Sports World Specials Keeping With Tradition

title: Bangladesh Gas Field
description: A new gas field with possible reserves of one trillion cubic feet has been found at Feni, about 80 miles from here, acording to the Bengali Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources, said.

title: U.S. COURT JOINING DEBATE ON COVERAGE OF ATLANTA MURDERS
description: The debate over the role of news organizations in the case of the 28 missing and murdered young black people here moves into a new arena tomorrow, the courtroom.
