description: Willy Brandt emerging from polit- ical shadows A2 Kania wins party delegate elec- tion in Poland A3 U.N. predicts world population will stabilize by 2110 A4 Around the World A5 Argentina is about to buy $180 mil- lion in arms from Austria A6 Commission urges U.S. and Soviet to resume arms talks A7 4,000 Holocaust survivors gather in Israel A8 P.L.O. is barred from attending the next World Bank meeting A8 African aides, unhappy with U.S. policy, begin talks in Kenya A8 Ayatollah says Bani-Sadr can con- tinue in office A9 Toronto paper admits article was false A10 Begin describes feelings after raid on Iraqi reactor A10 Saudi aide bids U.S. change its policy toward Israel A10 General Around the Nation A16 A Detroiter asking about work finds answers in Dallas A16 Court will enter debate over coverage of Atlanta deaths A20 Storms and tornadoes cause deaths, injuries and damages A21 Efforts renewed to have Jewish Museum site made landmark B1 Video games provoke dispute in Westchester village B1 The Region B2 Commuters' club on L.I.R.R. looks at brighter side B2 The City B3 Concern over Israeli raid domi- nates New York salute to Israel B3 Roberts defends jury instructions in case that was reversed B4 New York City landlords proposed rise in fuel surcharges B8 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Ickx wins record fifth 24 Hours of LeMans C8 Baseball: For some ballplayers, the game goes on C1

title: Fire at School Is Investigated
description: Officials searched today through a school destroyed by a fire a few days before a report was due on repair of fire-code violations. The fire, in the Shaarei Torah of Rockland County School, was labeled suspicious because it had spread so quickly.

title: Duncan Robinson to Head Yale Center for British Art
description: Duncan Robinson, keeper of paintings and drawings at the Fitzwilliam Museum at the University of Cambridge, England, has been appointed director of the Yale Center for British Art. He will begin at on Yale Sept. 1.

title: Elayne Wasserman Is Wed
description: Elayne Wasserman, an art lecturer and illustrator, was married in East Norwich, L.I., yesterday to Elliot B. Flax of New York, a widower and president of Flax Advertising Inc. Rabbi Michael Klein-Katz performed the ceremony at the bride's home. Mrs. Flax is the daughter of Mrs. Sam Goldkopf of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Mr. Goldkopf. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. The bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Max Flax.

title: Ruling on Blackjack Draws Gamblers' Ire
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP) - A Dixieland band played ''I Surrender Dear'' and demonstrators paraded down the Boardwalk yesterday to protest against the state's decision to waive the ''surrender rule'' at this city's blackjack tables.

title: FRANCE'S SOCIALISTS WIN BY LANDSLIDE IN ASSEMBLY VOTE
description: The Socialist Party won a landslide victory today in the first round of elections for France's National Assembly. Its showing was so strong that, barring an unexpected upset, it should hold a majority in the Assembly after the second round of voting next Sunday.

title: No Headline
description: MISCALCULATION REPORTED IN STUDY ON CANCER IN WIVES OF SMOKERS

title: WORLD BANK BARS P.L.O. FROM MEETING
description: The executive board of the World Bank, after an intense lobbying effort by the Reagan Administration, has effectively barred the Palestine Liberation Organization from attending the bank's next meeting as an official observer, foreign and Administration officials said today.

title: TREASURY PLANNING $7.5 BILLION OFFERING
description: The lull in financings of Treasury notes and bonds since early May has made it easier to sell corporate bonds, and the volume of such issues has grown rapidly in June.

title: Tyco Increases Heinicke Stake
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc. said it had increased its stake in the Heinicke Instruments Company, a Hollywood, Fla., manufacturer of instruments and jet-engine components, to 1.01 million shares, or 35.3 percent.

title: Study of Soviet Oil Challenged
description: A recently revised Central Intelligence Agency forecast may be ''unduly pessimistic'' in predicting a significant drop in Soviet oil production by 1990, according to a Library of Congress study released today.

title: CITY BALLET GIVES ITSELF A PARTY
description: Dancers, choreographers, musicians, stagehands and friends of the New York City Ballet celebrated the end of the Tchaikovsky Festival last night in a party backstage at the New York State Theater.

title: ALLURE OF RISKY DEALS IN METALS
description: ''Projections are that it will go up 40 to 50 times,'' said Alan Leavitt, a salesman for Strategic and Industrial Metals Inc. of Hallendale, Fla., as he described to a telephone caller the advantages of buying cobalt.

title: Daphne Hurford and Sanford Padwe, Editors, Married
description: Daphne McLaughlin Hurford and Sanford Padwe were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Simons in Manhattan. The ceremony was performed by M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the American Ethical Union and the Brooklyn Ethical Culture Society.

title: EQUAL RIGHTS PROVISION ADDED TO CONSTITUTION IN SWISS REFERENDUM
description: Swiss voters approved an amendment to the Constitution today strengthening guarantees of equality between the sexes in education, industry and in the home.

title: CABARET: PORTER BY WHYTE
description: ON the week in which the late Cole Porter would have reached his 90th birthday (or, because the records are confusing, it might have been his 88th, 89th or 91st), an appropriate place to celebrate was at Peacock Alley in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where Porter's piano is a centerpiece. Ronny Whyte plays on it and sings, and the songs he sings are very often Porter's.

title: Hall of Flags Opens At Ferry Termimal
description: Flags from 85 states, territories, and steamship companies were put on display in New York City's newest tourist attraction: the Staten Island Ferry National Hall of Flags.

title: International
description: The Reagan Administration's strict monetarist policy is causing serious problems for other nations, the Bank for International Settlements said in its annual report. High interest rates in America are contributing to a recession in Europe that threatens international economic cooperation, the bank said. (Page D1.)

title: ARGENTINA TURNS TO AUSTRIA FOR $180 MILLION IN ARMS
description: Argentina is on the verge of concluding an unannounced $180 million contract to buy 57 tanks from Austria, according to sources close to the negotiations.

title: ROBERTS DEFENDS HIS INSTRUCTIONS TO JURY IN A CASE LATER REVERSED
description: Justice Burton B. Roberts of State Supreme Court yesterday defended his instructions to the jury in a 1976 murder trial, instructions that were recently found incorrect by a Federal District Court judge who reversed the conviction.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1981
description: International France's Socialist Party won by a landslide in the first round of voting for the National Assembly, and barring an unexpected upset it should gain a majority in the second-round elections next Sunday. The party's victory confirmed the shift to the left that began with the election as President last month of Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist leader. The vote appears to guarantee that President Mitterrand will be able to introduce the economic and social changes he has promised without serious opposition. (Page A1, Column 6.) China seemed receptive to U.S. efforts to bring about closer strategic cooperation between the two countries to counter Soviet expansionism. The American position is being presented in Peking by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who believes that closer ties with China are a ''strategic imperative.'' After a meeting between Mr. Haig and Foreign Minister Huang Hua, an aide to the Secretary said there was ''a great deal of unanimity'' that the main problem in the world today is ''Soviet hegemonism.'' (A1:3.)

title: Waltrip Captures Auto Race on Coast
description: Darrell Waltrip went from third place to the lead in the next-to-last lap and held off Dale Earnhardt's challenge on the final lap to win the Warner W. Hodgdon 400-kilometer Nascar race today. Waltrip averaged 98.103 miles per hour in a race slowed by six caution flags, and won by six-tenths of a second.

title: Buckley Ending Talks in Pakistan On $2.5 Billion U.S. Aid Proposal
description: James L. Buckley, Under Secretary of State for Security Assistance, met with Foreign Minister Agha Shahi today to discuss plans for $2.5 billion in American economic aid and military sales for Pakistan.

title: EUROPEANS ASK CURBS ON JAPAN
description: Soaring Japanese exports to Europe have created an intense trade dispute that has resulted in widespread calls within the Common Market for import restraints.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Advertising's self-regulatory body concluded some particularly interesting investigations of national advertising claims in April. And in six of the nine complaints handled by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus the advertisers either dropped or changed their claims.

title: Martha Graham to Receive $25,000 Life's-Work Award
description: Martha Graham will receive the first Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award. The $25,000 award, established to honor choreographers for lifelong contributions to American modern dance, is believed to be one of the largest to be offered regularly in the performing arts.

title: Shirley Brand Konheim, 67, Dies; Fashion Designer for Teen-Agers
description: Shirley Brand Konheim, a dress manufacturer and designer who specialized in fashions for young teen-age girls, died Friday at her home in Manhattan after a brief illness. She was 67 years old.

title: Washington Watch; Coordinating Job Training
description: WASHINGTON CONGRESS is being asked to look at the so-called shadow education system of employer-provided job education and training and to develop Government policies to encourage the private sector to invest even more in human capital.

title: Accounts
description: * Texas Boot Company, Lebanon, Tenn., a division of the United States Shoe Corporation, to Leber Katz Partners for its men's and women's lines of Texas Brand boots and its Women's Capezio West line.

title: Baseball Offices Are Still Operating in Full Swing
description: First thing this morning, the electric typewriters will be humming, the coffee pots perking and the telephones ringing in the offices at Shea Stadium and Yankee Stadium despite the major league baseball strike.

title: India Holds an Election Seen as Test for Mrs. Gandhi
description: The country voted today in elections that were seen as the first major political test for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi since she returned to power in January 1980.

title: Della Femina Wins Air Freight Client
description: At a lower billing level, Della Femina, Travisano & Partners last week repeated the dramatic Doyle Dane Bernback-American Airlines-Pan Am caper.

title: NEW YORK FED CHIEF CAUTIOUS ON INFLATION
description: American officials recognize European complaints that high interest rates in the United States harm the European economy, but so far they are not promising any relief except to say that rates will come down when inflation and credit demands subside.

title: Ickx Wins for Record 5th Time at Le Mans
description: Jacky Ickx of Belgium and Derek Bell of Britain drove their Porsche 936 to a 14-lap victory today in the Le Mans 24-hour endurance race.

title: Construction of Housing Surged In Spring, Connecticut Reports
description: New home construction in Connecticut experienced a springtime surge despite a continued climb in mortgage interest rates, the State Housing Department reported yesterday.

title: Getting Started
description: The city's Parks Department operates 535 tennis courts, 14 golf courses and innumerable other public recreation facilities, but offers no ramp from which to launch a boat and do real rowing. There are dozens of private boating clubs and marinas throughout the metropolitan area, however, that can be used as a sculling base.

title: A Long-Distance Speech to the Folks Back Home
description: About 300 people at a Yeshiva University fund-raising dinner in Nyack, N.Y., heard speeches the other night from two members of Congress who were, in fact, about 35,000 feet in the air.

title: JOHN C. WISE, FINE-ARTS DEALER AND PRE-COLUMBIAN EXPERT, DIES
description: John C. Wise, a dealer in fine arts who specialized in the pre-Columbian period, died Saturday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. Mr. Wise, who had homes in Manhattan and Cornwall, Conn., was 79 years old.

title: Eleven Stitches Victor on Coast
description: Caterman, a 16-1 shot, crossed the finish line first today in the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup at Hollywood Park but the stewards ruled interference against him in the stretch and gave the victory to Eleven Stitches, who finished second.

title: AFRICAN OFFICIALS MEET IN NAIROBI FOR TALKS LIKELY TO CROTICIZE U.S.
description: Foreign Ministers from nearly 50 African countries began arriving here today amid tight security for tomorrow's scheduled opening of the annual meeting of the Organization of African Unity.

title: SUMMER AIRLINE FARE SKIRMISHES BEGIN
description: Sky wars are raging this summer as airlines fight to undercut one another's fares in a competitive fray led by several upstart airlines.

title: Talks; Sought
description: As the baseball strike passed through its third day, Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, was working to bring the negotiators for the club owners and the players back to the bargaining table today.

title: ST. LOUIS OPERA: DELIUS'S 'FENNIMORE'
description: ST. LOUIS PRODUCING an opera by Frederick Delius must be like trying to catch moonbeams in a bottle, but Frank Corsaro and Roland Chase have succeeded at it again. The director and multimedia designer who brought ''A Village Romeo and Juliet'' to life at the New York City Opera a few seasons back by translating the work into a quasi-filmic fantasy now have given a similar interpretation to ''Fennimore and Gerda,'' Delius's last opera.

title: No Headline
description: SAUDI URGES U.S. TO CHANGE POLICY

title: NEW YORK'S '65 DROUGHT
description: All New Yorkers should be happy that the city has relaxed some restrictions on the use of water. But those who interpret that decision as a signal that the drought has ended are mistaken. It is only the emergency that has eased.

title: THE ADMINISTRATION'S PROVOCATIVE WORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Committee Decision Injures New Yorkers' Title Chances
description: Three close matches left a zonal Grand National Team title up for grabs at the conclusion of yesterday afternoon's play in Washington. The New York representatives would have led if a crucial committee decision on Saturday had gone in their favor.

title: 212 'Boat People' Are Rescued By a U.S. Seventh Fleet Warship
description: A United States warship rescued 212 starving, dehydrated Vietnamese refugees aboard three boats in the South China Sea, the Navy reported today. The rescue brought to more than 2,100 the number of so-called boat people saved by the Seventh Fleet since January, a spokesman said.

title: Coke Food Division Assigned to Marschalk
description: Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies, will become the sole agency for the foods division of the Coca-Cola Company on Sept. 1.

title: U.NN PREDICTS WORLD POPULATION WILL LEVEL AT 10.5 BILLION IN 2110
description: A United Nations report issued today predicted that the world's population would stabilize at 10.5 billion by the year 2110, reflecting a view of the world's ability to curb its own growth that is ''less alarmist'' than earlier forecasts.

title: INSIDE DENG'S MIND
description: And so another American Secretary of State comes to visit our Middle Kingdom, trailing the running puppies of the media who obey his orders to identify his views as those coming from a ''senior official.''

title: Matz Finishes 1, 2 In Grand Prix Event
description: Michael Matz, a member of the United States Equestrian Team since 1974, gave a demonstration of riding in the Paine Webber Ox Ridge Grand Prix today on the grounds of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club that long will be remembered.

title: Peace Group to Continue Fight Over Air Base Rules
description: A peace group barred from presenting its case for nuclear disarmament today at an open house of Offutt Air Force Base, home of the Strategic Air Command, plans to continue its fight for free speech, the group's attorney, Michael Gooch, said today.

title: REGAN ASSAILS CITY PROPOSAL TO HIRE 24,000
description: New York City's plan to hire nearly 24,000 new employees in the coming fiscal year will create financial strains on the city's budget for years to come, according to a report issued yesterday by the office of the State Comptroller.

title: PARADE FOR ISRAEL REFLECTS FEARS OVER REACTOR RAID
description: Concern over the Israeli raid on a nuclear reactor in Iraq dominated New York's annual tribute to Israel's independence yesterday as thousands gathered for the event on Fifth Avenue.

title: Michigan Officials Cautious About Prison-Riot Report
description: State corrections officials responded cautiously to a report published today on events surrounding recent riots at Southern Michigan Prison.

title: TROUBLES THAT BESET THE CANCER INSTITUTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Charity Raffle Helping Owner Sell His House
description: A boys' club in a Washington suburbs has sold more than 450 chances, at $100 each, on a five-bedroom house worth $115,000.

title: RIFT AT MAYOR'S MEETING GROWS OVER BUDGET CUTS
description: Asserting that some Democrats had been engaging in partisan politics, White House officials and Republican mayors began a verbal counterattack here today in an effort to persuade the United States Conference of Mayors to support President Reagan's proposed budget cuts.

title: MONETARISM IS CITED AS THREAT
description: The Reagan Administration's stringent monetarist strategy aimed at curbing inflation in the United States is causing serious difficulties for other countries and could lead to a breakdown of economic cooperation that would spell disaster, the Bank for International Settlements warns in its latest annual report.

title: Alan B. Rummeslburg Weds Kimberley Anne Sweedler
description: Kimberley Anne Sweedler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Sweedler of Westport, Conn., was married at the Birchwood Country Club there yesterday to Alan B. Rummelsburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Al S. Rummelsburg of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Naples, Fla.

title: HOLOCAUST SURVIVORS ON 'PILGRIMAGE OF REMEMBERANCE'
description: W HEN Sam Bloch and Lilly Czaban were married in 1949, they were accompanied to the huppah, the Jewish wedding canopy, by Josef and Hadassah Rosensaft. The wedding was in Bergen-Belsen, the concentration camp that became a displaced persons camp after World War II. All four met there and became friends as well as colleagues in a lifetime effort to honor victims of Nazism. Twenty-eight years later in New York, their children, Menachem Rosensaft and Jean Bloch, were married.

title: The Other Pension Drain
description: Those concerned about the crisis in Social Security finance might set aside a little fretting time for the Federal Government's other pension program, the Civil Service Retirement System. While Civil Service Retirement is small potatoes by comparision, it, too, faces serious long-term financial problems.

title: Red Smith Player Goals Fading Away
description: TOM SEAVER won his sixth straight victory the other day, giving him seven for the 1981 season and a total of 252 in the major leagues. That's more games than Bob Feller won, or Carl Hubbell or Ted Lyons or Bob Gibson, all enshrined in the Hall of Fame. Four active pitchers lead Seaver in games won - Steve Carlton, Ferguson Jenkins, Jim Kaat and Gaylord Perry.

title: Ward Scores Double In Junior Track Meet
description: Adrian Ward, a senior at Northwestern High School in Baltimore, won the 400-meter run and the 400-meter hurdles last night at the United States junior track and field championships at Tom Black Stadium.

title: The U.N. Today; June 15, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Iraq. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Scout's Away Game
description: When General Manager Frank Cashen of the Mets instituted a youth movement to strengthen the farm system, he hired a youthful director for the scouting department. Joe McIlvaine was 32 when he got the job last October.

title: Harold G. Roberts Dead; Devoted Career to Blind
description: Harold G. Roberts, executive director of Helen Keller International and a leader for 35 years of agencies that assist the blind, died Saturday at his home in Brookfield, Conn. He was 64 years old.

title: Marietta Priolo Is Bride
description: The marriage of Marietta Rose Marie Priolo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Priolo of Todt Hill, Staten Island, to Michael Philip Tempesta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Tempesta of New Dorp, Staten Island, took place yesterday at St. Teresa's Roman Catholic Church in Todt Hill. The Rev. Richard Carbo performed the ceremony.

title: Strike Talk
description: With the baseball strike in progress and major league teams only a week away from collecting strike insurance, the National Football League is keeping an eye on the proceedings. The N.F.L., according to Rusty Martin, a spokesman for the Management Council, has already purchased a $150 million line of credit from banks and is looking into an insurance package.

title: MORE HAITIANS ARRIVE IN FLORIDA
description: Some of the nearly 100 Haitians who arrived Saturday in Key Biscayne wait to be interviewed by immigration officials. Some area residents who were boating nearby offered them food from picnic lunchboxes; others shouted ''Go home!''

title: VILLAGE ZEROS IN ON SPACE INVADERS
description: A national fascination for warfare - the kind waged on computerized video screens against whizzing space rocks, electronic sharks and gun-toting outlaws - has captured the youth of this Westchester County village. Some parents think the children need less warfare and more class time.

title: Timerman Criticizes Reagan On Human Rights Policy
description: Jacobo Timerman, who credits the Carter Administration's human rights policy with saving his life, said tonight that the policy was being made irrelevant under the Reagan Administration.

title: A Losing Match for the Poor
description: The Senate Labor Committee, spurred by Edward Kennedy, may be doing its best to protect the poor against budget-cutting fever, but some other committees seem determined to outrun even the White House in the flight from responsibility. They are not just trying to save money but are abandoning America's commitment to share the burden of caring for the poor.

title: Two Star-Crossed Concerts Finally Find a Hero
description: The New York Philharmonic's ''Romantic Era'' series of spring concerts, which began on May 27, has had its share of bad luck, but the concerts scheduled for tomorrow and Wednesday seem to have been particularly jinxed.

title: THEATER: 'ISN'T IT ROMANTIC
description: IN her compulsively funny new comedy, ''Isn't It Romantic,'' Wendy Wasserstein sends two of her uncommon women into the jungle of New York to seek fulfillment, self-respect, romance and take-out food. One of the dozen morals in this overstuffed play is: you can't have everything, so make sure you know exactly what you want. As author, Miss Wasserstein seems a bit unsure what she wants. Her play, which opened Saturday at the Phoenix Theater, veers from character comedy to caricature, interspersed with throwaway jokes and routines, but there is no denying the playwright's comic virtuosity and her ear for contemporary jargon.

title: MAN, 22, HELD IN
description: BRONX HOLDUP AND SHOOTING OF 2 ARMORED-CAR GUARDS BY PETER KIHSS

title: Maidenform Account
description: No it's not a dream, Creamer has just won the $4 million Maidenform account. It will be taking over Aug. 1 from Daniel & Charles, the agency for nine years.

title:
RELATIONSHIPS;
THE CHILD VICTIM OF INCEST
description: I NCEST is not a topic for conversation. And what little is said is usually wrong, according to Dr. Alexander G. Zaphiris, a leading authority on the identification and treatment of incestuous families. Thousands of incestuous relationships go unnoticed and unreported, and their victims are neither rescued nor treated, he said.

title: Great Neck Is First
description: A strong ride by Angel Cordero Jr. brought Great Neck to a neck victory in the $140,750 Bowling Green Handicap on the inner grass course at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: Having warned Poland unequivocally to reverse its course toward democratization and having publicly demonstrated its loss of confidence in Warsaw's leaders, the Soviet

title: No Headline
description: KHOMEINI ASSERTS BANI-SADAR CAN CARRY OUT DUTIES

title: Birdie Gives Miss Caponi Title
description: Donna Caponi sank an 18-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to break a tie with Jerilyn Britz and Pat Meyers and win the 27th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association championship at the Jack Nicklaus Sports Center by a stroke.

title: IRAN'S GLUTTONOUS REVOLUTION
description: The revolution eats its children, goes the saying, and the greater the upheaval the greater the gluttony. Iran now, like the Soviets three generations ago and France in the 18th century, is descending into a dictatorship of blood and horror.

title: 4,000 SURVIVORS OF NAZI HORROR GATHER IN ISRAEL
description: For the first time since the Nazi concentration camps were captured by the allies, and the victims who survived were freed, many of those who lived through the Holocaust are gathering in Israel for a four-day remembrance and celebration of life. Just as it is the first such gathering, so it will be the last.

title: A BRIGHT SIDE RIDE ON THE L.I.R.R.
description: On the Long Island Rail Road, even some of the most faithful passengers use words like ''aggravating,'' ''annoying'' and ''infuriating'' when talking about the daily endurance contest that is the essence of their relationship with the railroad.

title: Reform Jews Back Israeli Raid
description: The leadership of Reform Judaism in America said today that Israel's raid on the Iraqi nuclear plant was ''fully justified'' and called on President Reagan to veto any effort at the United Nations to condemn the raid or impose sanctions against Israel. The board of trustees of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, holding its semiannual meetings here, also adopted a resolution that criticized Mr. Reagan for suspending the shipment of F-16 fighter-bombers to Israeli. The trustees represent the 750 Reform synagogues in this country.

title: Cox Appoints New Head
description: William A. Schwartz, 42 years old, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation. As president, he succeeds Clifford M. Kirtland Jr., who was named chairman and who previously held the additional title of chief executive officer.

title: Market Place; Burglar Alarms: A Growth Area
description: CRIME is a ''growth industry,'' and companies that provide burglary detection devices and those that offer monitoring services are beginning to grow with it. Although official statistics may understate the problem, 3.3 million burglaries were reported in 1979, an increase of 6.3 percent from the level of a year before.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
TV: THE REFINEMENT OF SUZHOU, CHINA
description: TOURING China is a tiring, if fascinating business, but reporting on China is even more so, and summing up China is yet more challenging than anything. But tonight at 10 o'clock on WNET-TV, you can sit back in your easy chair and spend what is one of the most restful half-hours in China, where you will visit the beautiful city of Suzhou, home of the fantastically tranquil garden whose copy is just making its debut in New York in a wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: OIL TAX IN NEW YORK AIDING MASS TRANSIT UPSET BY U.S. COURT
description: A Federal appeals court today struck down a key section of New York State's tax on oil company receipts. But it implied the statute might withstand Federal challenge after September, when Federal price controls on petroleum expire.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
Jets Waive Penrose
description: The Jets yesterday waived Craig Penrose, a quarterback who did not play a down during the 1980 season after being acquired in a trade with the Denver Broncos.

title: Notes On People; Composer Puts His Lectures to Good Use
description: ''I want to make it clear,'' Albert Hague said yesterday, ''that the performance is not instructional, it's all entertainment.'' Mr. Hague, a composer who has won the Tony Award and also played the music professor in the movie ''Fame,'' was referring to his appearance with his singer-wife, Renee Orin, at On Stage for three Tuesdays beginning tonight. The show is devoted to Mr. Hague's songs from such shows as ''Redhead'' and ''Plain and Fancy.''

title: Fred R. Conrad Youngsters Come to the Aid of the Marines
description: Matthew Volz, 6, and his sister, Charissa, 2, helping Chief Warrant Officer Wayne Devoe conduct the U.S. Marine Band during Flag Day ceremonies yesterday at the World Trade Center. The children, from Canton, Mich., are visiting New York with their parents.

title: Bonn Approves New U.S. Envoy
description: West Germany today formally approved the appointment of Arthur F. Burns, 77 years old, former chairman of the Federal Reserve, as the next American Ambassador to Bonn, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Constitution does not mandate comfortable prisons.'' - Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. (B9:1.)

title: Sharon Seeking 25% Of City Investing
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation will seek permission from the New Hampshire Insurance Department to acquire up to 25 percent of the stock of the City Investing Company.

title: Record Midwest Volume
description: Trading volume at the Midwest Stock Exchange reached a record 4.2 million shares yesterday, up from the previous high, set March 20, of 3.9 million, exchange officials said. Volume so far in 1981 totaled 307 million shares, they added, up 26 percent from the turnover of 244 million in the similar period last year.

title: GREAT BASINS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $1,190,000 extraordinary loss from the elimination of a tax credit...C-Including $4,648,000 extraordinary tax credit...D-Net loss after $352,000 loss from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting

title: Dr. Nathan Swerdlin, 73, Editor And Critic of Yiddish Newspaper
description: Dr. Nathan Swerdlin, former drama editor and film critic of the former Jewish Day-Journal, a Yiddish-language newspaper, died at his home in the Bronx last Tuesday.

title: Dunn Dancers in Premiere
description: Douglas Dunn and Dancers will present the world premiere of Mr. Dunn's ''Walking Back'' on Saturday and Sunday at the Midtown Y.M.- Y.W.H.A., at 344 East 14th Street. Mr. Dunn, a leading member of the experimentalist post-modern dance movement, performed with Yvonne Rainer, Merce Cunningham and the Grand Union improvisational dance company. ''Walking Back'' is set to an electronic score by John Driscoll and consists of 20 ''frames,'' or movement, tableaux. Performances will be at 8:30 P.M. Tickets are $5; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Reservations: 279-4200 (after 1 P.M.)

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $150,000 for the qr and $300,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $1,284,000 for the qr and $2,254,000 for the 6 mos

title: SANDERS ADAPTING TO A WAY OF LIFE WITHOUT FOOTBALL
description: It ended - or seemed to end - at halftime of the Detroit-Denver game in the Pontiac Silverdome on Thanksgiving Day, 1978. Charlie Sanders was honored by the Lions for his 10 years as one of the best players in the team's history. Sanders, a tight end, had recently retired, prematurely, at age 31. He received two oil paintings of himself in uniform, a football mounted on a trophy and proclamations from the Mayor of Detroit and the Governor of Michigan.

title: Italy's Handling of Aid From U.S. Wins Praise
description: Italy is making good use of the $50 million in United States aid sent to the country after the devastating earthquake last November, Maxwell M. Rabb, the Ambassador-designate to Italy, said today.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including gains of $223,407 for the qr and $1,615,313 for the 6 mos from the exchange of assets with a creditor bank... C-Including $752,638 gain from the exchange of assets with a creditor bank

title: INQUIRY INTO USE OF FUNDS PLANNED AT WEST VIRGINIA
description: The president of the West Virginia Senate, Warren McGraw, said today that subpoenas might be issued by the state's Commission on Special Investigations when it investigates athletic department spending at West Virginia University.

title: 20 Houses Burn on Coast
description: At least 20 houses burned today as winds carried brush fires across nearly 18,000 acres.

title: Syrian Official Says His Country Is Planning to Build Nuclear Plant
description: Syria is planning to build a nuclear power plant to generate electricity and reduce the cost of importing fuel, the Syrian Minister for Electric Power said today.

title: PRESSURE ON WORLD PRICE INTENSIFED
description: Britain agreed today to cut the price of oil from the North Sea by $4.25 a barrel, more than double its earlier intention and a further sign of the intense downward pressure on world oil prices.

title: STEPS ON THE ROAD TO IRISH UNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Aid Maneuver Laid to U. of Oregon
description: The University of Oregon's mounting athletic department deficit over three years was devised by school officials in hopes of obtaining financial aid for a Federally mandated women's program, The Portland Oregonian reported yesterday.

title: REPUBLICANS PUSH ATTACK ON BUDGET PLAN IN HOUSE
description: House Republican leaders went a step further today in their campaign against the budget cuts recommended by 15 Democratic-controlled House committees. The Republicans said that, unless the House Budget Committee took the unlikely action of eliminating cuts the Republicans considered illusory, counterproductive and unnecessarily severe, they would try to put their own package, which they began drafting last week, on the floor.

title: GROMYKO PRESSES U.S. ON STARTING ARMS CONTROL TALKS
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today pressed Soviet demands for American action toward negotiating arms controls with a speech declaring that it was ''necessary and possible'' to contain the arms race.

title: The City; Man Dies After Leap Despite Rescue Bid
description: A White Plains man died several hours after he jumped from the 19th floor of a housing project in East Harlem and landed on an inflated cushion placed there by the police.

title: SFN COS reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Net loss...C-Including $5.4 million or 46 cents a shr gain fr the sale of William Morrow & Co and $1.9 million writedown on investment income

title: Beethoven Society Offers Concert of His Folk Songs
description: It is not easy to shape a concert program around Beethoven's settings of Irish, Scottish and Welsh folk tunes. Both intimacy and energy are needed for revealing glimpses of their spirit.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $10,000 gain from the sale of rental property... C-Net income including $1.5 million gain from the sale of rental property

title: ISRAELI AIDES IN U.S. BEMOAN REAGAN LINE
description: In intense behind-the-scenes maneuvering to influence American policy, Israeli diplomats are telling their Congressional supporters and American Government officials that the Reagan Administration has put itself and Israel in a quandary over what steps may be necessary to restore suspended deliveries of military planes.

title: Dith Pran CITYSCAPE
description: In a pastoral oasis at Fifth Avenue and Central Park South where horse carriages wait between trips through the park, an artist captured a bit of the charm of the city in bold strokes and subtle tones.

title: Notes On People; Hank Aaron Discovers Admiration Only Goes So Far
description: Since Hank Aaron got his baseball career off the ground when he was with the former Milwaukee Braves, some of his admirers thought it would be a nice gesture to rename County Stadium in Milwaukee for him.

title: German Price Rise Slows
description: West Germany's wholesale price index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in May to 124.9, following an April advance of six-tenths of 1 percent, the Government reported today.

title: The Region; Convicted Killer In Suicide Attempt
description: Richard Cottingham, who was convicted Thursday of murdering a Manhattan prostitute and of kidnapping and sexually assaulting three other women, has attempted to commit suicide by drinking six ounces of a liquid antidepressant in his cell at the Bergen County jail, authorities said.

title: Cold-Stove League
description: ''On Friday,'' writes a man we know who likes his baseball, ''I would have gone home after work, had dinner and then settled down to watch the Yankees on TV. But since there was no game, I grabbed a sandwich at the deli and went to see 'Raiders of the Lost Ark.' Entertaining, but I went home in a sour mood nevertheless. On Saturday, when I might have watched part of the game before going to a party, I finished 'Gorky Park' and still got to the party too early.

title: Canadian Keeps Title
description: A devastating right hand and sweltering heat were the winning combination for Ralph Hollett last night, as the Canadian middleweight boxing champion retained his title by stopping Fernand Marcotte Jr. in the ninth round. Marcotte lost the title to Hollett in January 1980.

title: 'RAIDERS': TOO TERRIFYING TO BE PG?
description: With the beginning of hot weather, the movie industry's rating code - an admittedly imperfect instrument - is in its yearly hot water.

title: A TOP CBS OFFICER QUITS; COLUMBIA UNIT GETS CHIEF
description: John R. Purcell, the third-highest ranking executive at CBS Inc., resigned yesterday as executive vice president of the company. Mr. Purcell ''has plans but has not announced them yet,'' a company spokesman said.

title: AN EMIGRE POET GOES HOME, A PROPHET WITH HONOR
description: ''Language is the only homeland,'' wrote Czeslaw Milosz, the Nobel laureate. Poets, like politicians, can be wrong. Mr. Milosz returned to Poland on June 5 for a two-week visit, ending nearly 30 years of self-imposed exile. During that period his works, except for a few, scant verses from prewar times that turned up in an occasional anthology, were banned from official publications, and he was regarded by the Communist authorities as persona non grata and an enemy of a dangerous sort - of the pen.

title: Rockwell, Iveco Join To Produce Axles
description: The Rockwell International Corporation and Iveco, a truck manufacturer that is a member of the Fiat group, have established a joint venture to manufacture and market Rockwelldesigned heavy-duty truck axles in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, Rockwell announced.

title: Dr. Sylvain Weinberger Marries Naomi Williams
description: Naomi Joy Williams, an assistant professor of international relations at Yale University, was married yesterday to Dr. Sylvain Weinberger, who has been appointed an attending physician in neonatal medicine at Beth Israel Hospital. Rabbi Samuel A. Turk performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: WHITE MALE CHOICES
description: To the Editor:

title: I.M.F. Loans Set For Rumania
description: Rumania will get loans worth nearly $1.5 billion from the International Monetary Fund, it was announced today, and the Rumanian Government has promised to raise prices and hold down spending in an attempt to improve its international financial standing.

title: The U.N. Today; June 16, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaint by Iraq at 10:30 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: The Region; Bill to Ban Handguns Withdrawn in Jersey
description: TRENTON (UPI) - State Senator Joseph P. Merlino withdrew from consideration his bill to ban the sale and possession of handguns in New Jersey.

title: WINS BACKERS BUT FACES CHANGES
description: President Reagan, opening a personal lobbying campaign for his three-year program of tax cuts, won the endorsement of key Democrats in the Senate today, but he found that some of his allies were making plans for minor changes in his legislation.

title: 3 Dismissed, 14 Suspended After Michigan Prison Riots
description: A deputy warden and two guards were dismissed, 14 guards were suspended and two administrators were demoted today for their conduct in riots last month at the state prison in Jackson, the Department of Corrections announced.

title: The Cupidity Lobby
description: More than two years have passed since Federal and city officials began their investigations into the bus shelter mess and we are still waiting for the results. Meanwhile, the cloud of the potential scandal hangs heavily over the coming citywide elections -in particular over Harrison J. Goldin, running for a third term as city Comptroller.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including tax credits of $2,665,000 for the qr and $1.7 milli for the 40 weeks...C-Including $1.7 million or 38 cents a shr n gain for the qr and 40 weeks on the sale of property and $1,575 tax credit for the qr...D-Net income; sales figures include sal of leased departments; results do not reflect the expected sale the company's Margo's La Mode Inc subsidiary

title: Bills Sign Moore, Fullback, To 5 One-Year Contracts
description: Booker Moore, the Buffalo Bills' firstround draft choice, signed a series of five one-year contracts today, officials of the National Football League announced.

title: Stop and Shop's Net Loss
description: The Stop and Shop Companies, a diversified retailer, reported a $522,000 earnings loss in its first fiscal quarter compared with a restated loss of $2.8 million in the corresponding 1980 quarter. Sales for the 16 weeks ended May 23 rose 10.3 percent, to $622.7 million from $564.4 million, the company said.

title: Hoechst's Sales Rise
description: Hoechst A.G.'s sales rose 2.4 percent in the first five months of 1981 from levels a year ago, to 5.06 billion marks, or $2.07 billion at current exchange rates, Rolf Sammet, the managing board chairman, reported.

title: A KOCH BILL SEEKS TO GAIN MAJORITY ON SCHOOL BOARD
description: Mayor Koch has renewed efforts to gain a majority on the Board of Education by having a bill introduced in Albany that would increase the board's membership to 11, with six of the members to be chosen by the Mayor. The board now has seven members, five of them named by the borough presidents and two by the Mayor.

title: WINS FIRST RACE
description: Mincred Words, at right along the rail, leading the pack yesterday at Belmont. Steal A Story was second; Cabbar was third.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 16, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan won endorsements for his three-year tax cut program from key Senate Democrats as he began a personal lobbying effort. Yet some allies favored small changes in the plan, such as additional cuts in the tax on savings income to help the savings and loan industry. (Page A1.)

title: NIXON AND KOCH TURN UP AT
description: PRESIDENT'S SHOW By MAURICE CARROLL

title: ROYAL BALLET: 'SLEEPING BEAUTY' OPENS 50TH SEASON
description: BRITAIN'S Royal Ballet returned to New York last night at the Metropolitan Opera House for a three-week engagement for the first time since 1976. The fact that this is also the company's 50thanniversary season was also cause for celebration. There was, it would seem, no more appropriate opening ballet than ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the company's veritable signature piece.

title: Conoco Recovery Program
description: Conoco Inc. said it had begun a pilot program to recover heavy oil and tar from a 60-foot layer of sandstone and hydrocarbons.

title: DOW UP 5.71 ON DROP IN RATES AND STRONG INSTITUTIONAL BUYING
description: The stock market, buoyed by declining interest rates and heavy institutional buying, moved higher yesterday after late profit-taking erased some of the earlier sharp gains.

title: Singapore's Leader to Visit U.S.
description: President Reagan will confer with Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore on Friday, the White House announced today. Mr. Lee arrives for a largely private four-day visit tomorrow.

title: CABANAS IS EMERGING AS A COMPLETE PLAYER
description: Roberto Cabanas had always impressed his Cosmos teammates and Coach Hennes Weisweiler in practice, but his effectiveness as a complete soccer player had not come through in a game until recently.

title: No Headline
description: John G. Dinkeloo, a partner in one of the country's most distinguished architectural firms, Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates, died in his sleep yesterday morning while on a weekend trip to Fredericksburg, Va. He was 63 years old and lived in Mount Carmel, Conn.

title: 2 Americans Say Chile Brutalizes 3 Physicians
description: Two American doctors who were sent to Chile in an effort to investigate instances of terrorism while they were still under way said today that they had found that three physicians in Chile were being detained and brutalized for treating torture victims.

title: Pat Day Rides 5 Winners On Arlington Park Card
description: Pat Day rode five winners in seven mounts today at Arlington Park, including How Time Flies in the featured $21,300 Diamond Lil Purse.

title: NEW FARMERS NEED AID
description: Widespread ownership of farmland has been historically a key to economic and political democracy in America. Yet today, fewer and fewer people own farmland. Moreover, the growing inability of farmers to buy land has become a problem that transcends agriculture. New farmers - even qualified men and women with farm experience, background, and education - now find the astronomical land prices a nearly insuperable obstacle to land ownership. Instead of buying land, they rent it.

title: The Region; L.I.R.R. Plans Work On Babylon Branch
description: The Long Island Rail Road announced that there may be delays on the Babylon branch during midday for about three months while the track is improved in Nassau County between Valley Stream and Freeport.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 16, 1981
description: International A $3 billion aid program for Pakistan was announced by the State Department. It said that the economic and military assistance would bolster Pakistani defenses against a ''serious threat'' from Soviet troops in Afghanistan. The Carter Administration suspended aid to Pakistan in April 1979 because Pakistan refused to submit its nuclear development program to international inspection. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Israel was censured by France and Britain in the United Nations Security Council for the air attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor. But the two Western European countries, both permanent council members with veto power, declined to back an Arab demand for an arms embargo. (A1:3.)

title: U.S. Acts Against Floridian Cited For Wartime Persecution of Jews
description: The Justice Department moved today to revoke the citizenship of a St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., man on grounds that he allegedly participated in persecuting Jews while he was mayor of a Lithuanian town during World War II.

title: INVENTORIES UP BY 0.5% IN APRIL
description: United States business inventories grew by five-tenths of 1 percent in April as sales by the nation's manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers slipped slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Gulf & Western Has 7.15% Stevens Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had increased its stake in J.P. Stevens & Company, to 1.03 million shares, or 7.15 percent.

title: STANDARD NEWSPAPER UNIT SIZE
description: IN September, most major American newspapers, representing the country's biggest and one of its oldest advertising mediums, will begin an industrywide effort at standardization in an effort to regain advertising market share. The Standard Advertising Unit Program, devised by an industrywide committee, could be the beginning of the end of the traditional advertising pricing by agate line.

title: WHEN IN DOUBT, BLAME THE CLUB
description: Tom Watson glaring athis driver during a practice round yesterday for the United States Open, which begins Thursday at the Merlon Gulf Club in Ardmore, Pa.

title: Takeover of Danly
description: The Ogden Corporation is to take over the Danly Machine Corporation, the two companies announced.

title: SQUEEZING OUT THE OIL IN ALASKA
description: Next month, an armada of tugs and barges will leave Puget Sound for the two-and-a-half-week voyage north through the Gulf of Alaska, past the Aleutian chain, across the Bering Sea, around Point Barrow and to the docks at Prudhoe Bay.

title: A FASHION MARKET IN LUSTROUS METAL
description: ''All that glitters,'' ''gilt complex,'' ''gold standard'' - these are some of the catch phrases coursing through the fashion world. The gold rush is on, and not just gold. Bronze, copper, pewter and gunmetal are all contributing to the metallic luster.

title: ERNEST LEFEVER'S VIEWS ON HUMAN RIGHTS-- MINUS THE 'CARICATURE'
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: 'DON QUIXOTE'
description: MIKHAIL BARYSHNIKOV'S production of ''Don Quixote'' is both lavish spectacle and earthy comedy. It also gives its dancers a chance to do some fairly exciting dancing, and three casts of American Ballet Theater rose to the occasion at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: CORE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $646,000 gain from the sale of a division; yr-ago results have been restated

title: WEST CHARGES, VOTING IN EAST BERLIN MES CITY'S SPECIAL POSTWAR STATUS
description: When the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union signed the Berlin agreement 10 years ago, the Russians made it clear that they did not consider East Berlin part of the bargain, saying that only West Berlin remained under four-power rule.

title: KHOMEINI SUGGESTS BANI-SADR APOLOGY
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who said yesterday that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr could remain in office, appeared today to set a condition for allowing him to continue. The Ayatollah demanded that the President broadcast an apology to the Iranian people for calling on them last week to resist the clergy-dominated Government.

title: HIGH COURT RULES TWO MAY BE PUT IN A CELL FOR ONE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that two prisoners may be confined in a cell designed for only one as long as the overall prison conditions do not violate a ''contemporary standard of decency.''

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including equity in the earnings of 745 Associates of $200,000 minority interest in the earnings of Land Resources Corp of $301,000 and pretax gain on the sale of certain propert of $829,000...C-Including equity in the earnings of 745 Associa $246,000 and minority interest in the earnings of Land Resource Corp of $561,000; latest results are for periods ended Apr 30, 1981 and previous results are for periods ended May 31, 1980

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS ASSESSMENT OF VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: President Reagan asked the Attorney General today to determine whether the Voting Rights Act was ''the most appropriate means of guaranteeing'' the franchise across the nation.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of the LIFO method of accounting for vanilla in the fourth qr of fiscal 1980 for the correction of certain accounting practices and for the reclassification of certain customary allowances previously included in marketing costs as a reductio of net sales

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
BASEBALL'S OBJECT LESSONS
description: ''M Y boys can't fall asleep without a baseball game on,'' a father was saying the other day. ''What am I going to do if this strike continues?''

title: Gilbert & Sullivan Players In Weekend of 'Pinafore'
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players presented ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' at the Symphony Space over the weekend, and Sunday evening's performance had both the charms and the weaknesses that Gilbert and Sullivan productions usually seem to inspire.

title: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Including net losses from discontinued operations of $72,000 in the latest period and $72,000 in the previous period

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
Japanese to Cut Cars to Belgium
description: Japan's Prime Minister, Zenko Suzuki, promised today to restrict the flow of Japanese cars to Belgium amid European Economic Community criticism of Japan's rising trade surplus with the Common Market.

title: Q & A
description: Q. What effect does humidity have on arthritis?

title: Amoco Producing At Louisiana Wells
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said that its Amoco Production Company had begun oil and gas production from its field in an area known as the Tuscaloosa Trend in southern Louisiana.

title: KOCH TIES HIRING OF TRANSIT POLICE TO WORK DISPUTE
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would not agree to hire new police officers for the New York City transit system unless the officers' union agreed to changes that would give their commanders greater flexibility in assignments.

title: Chevron Prices Cut
description: Chevron U.S.A., a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of California, said that the company had reduced gasoline prices by 1.5 cents a gallon in the Middle West and cut home heating oil and diesel prices by 2 cents a gallon in the Southeast. The reduction in prices followed similar moves by Chevron's competitors last week.

title: British Trimaran Heading For Trans-Atlantic Record
description: The 65-foot British trimaran Brittany Ferries GB, sailed by Chay Blyth and Rob James, was reported heading for a record victory today in the Observer Trans-Atlantic Yacht Race.

title: LEE WRIGHT WINS DESIGN PRIZE
description: Lee Wright, a former actor who turned to designing in 1973, has been named the outstanding United States designer among the winners of the 1981 Cutty Sark Men's Fashion Awards.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE MONSTROUS RACES IN MEDIEVAL ART AND THOUGHT. By John Block Friedman. Illustrated. 268 pages. Har- vard. $20.

title: A WARY LAB SUPPLIER
description: Benjamin Fisher, the 65-year-old chairman of the Fisher Scientific Company, wants his corporation, a leader in the laboratory supply industry, to remain an independent entity. But recent events - such as the purchase of 8.9 percent of Fisher stock by Tyco Laboratories and the sale of 10 percent of the company's stock by Mr. Fisher's brother James - have caused Mr. Fisher to become somewhat concerned about his company's future.

title: A Drug Is Approved For Fungus Diseases
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today it had approved the first drug of its type to treat internal fungus diseases such as histoplasmosis and valley fever.

title: ARMS MAKERS SEEN GAINING POLITICALLY
description: The nation's largest defense contractors have enhanced their political power in recent years by investing heavily in campaign contributions and by billing the Government for major lobbying expenses in Washington, according to a report released today on the politics of defense contracting.

title: A.P. AND UNIONS CONTINUE TO TALK THROUGH DEADLINE
description: Negotiators for The Associated Press and two unions representing its employees throughout the nation continued to talk through a deadline last night in an effort to avert a strike.

title: Police Spread Thin
description: When people call the police, they want to believe they'll be taken seriously. When they are victims of upsetting crimes, they want to believe the police will do something. What's so unreasonable about that?

title: GOVERNMENT SCRUTINIZES LINK BETWEEN GENETICS INDUSTRY AND UNIVERSITIES
description: The headlong rush to commercialize genetic engineering is bringing close Government scrutiny into whether the trend is compromising the scholarly independence of university scientists and whether the taxpayers who for decades have paid for the basic research that forms the intellectual capital of the new ''biocommerce'' are getting a fair return on their investment.

title: 80% Dropout Rate Found For Pregnant Teen-Agers
description: By United Press International Pregnant teen-agers have an 80 percent dropout rate, as against less than 9 percent for other students, and schools ''neither seek nor want an active role'' in dealing with the problem, the National Institute of Education reported yesterday.

title: The City; Bronx Lawyer, 71, Killed in His Office
description: A 71-year-old Bronx lawyer was shot to death by two gunmen who invaded his law office in an apparent robbery attempt, the police reported.

title: KENYA ASKS AFRICANS FOR MORE AID TO NAMIBIA REBELS
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya issued a call today to African nations to step up their political, financial and military assistance to the guerrillas who are fighting to free South-West Africa from the control of South Africa.

title: HOSPITAL'S ANTITRUST SUIT BACKED
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that recent Federal health planning legislation, enacted to end the construction of excess hospital beds, did not leave private insurers free to refuse to deal with hospitals they regard as surplus or unnecessary.

title: McDermott To Lift Capacity
description: McDermott Inc. said today that it planned to spend some $80 million to raise capacity and reduce energy consumption at a steelmaking facility in southwestern Pennsylvania operated by its Babcock & Wilcox Company unit.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
City Housing Symphony Plays a Benefit Concert
description: Despite its name, the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra is not composed of superintendents and housing inspectors who enforce various chapters of the city's building code while playing musical instruments. But the Housing Authority has been the main regulator of the orchestra, whose players are ''rooted in the public housing community'' and give free concerts around the city.

title: Dianne McIntyre to Offer Dances Set to Jazz Scores
description: Dances set to commissioned jazz scores and a poem by Ntozake Shange will highlight performances by Dianne McIntyre's Sounds in Motion at Symphony Space, June 25-28.

title: EX-PROMOTER OF FIGHTS IS SENTENCED ON COAST FOR FALSIFYING PASSPORT
description: Ross Eugene Fields, the former boxing promoter, was ordered here today to serve 40 consecutive weekends in jail as part of his sentence on Federal charges of falsifying a passport application.

title: Unwelcome Personal Testimony
description: American critics of Jacobo Timerman, as well as Jews in Argentina, have accused him of exaggerating the degree of official anti-Semitism in that country, where he was imprisoned and tortured after his newspaper was seized by the Government.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $385,257 loss from discontinued operations and $5,153,2 provision for the phasing out of discontinued operations...C-Ne income after $110,232 loss from discontinued operations and $17 tax credit

title: Goldblatt Chain Files Chapter 11 Petition
description: Goldblatt Brothers, the Chicago-based operator of 39 retail stores, has filed a bankruptcy petition in Federal District Court.

title: RACE FOR UNION POST IS A CLASH OF STYLES
description: A highly charged and openly contentious struggle, rare in the labor movement, is being waged for the presidency of a relatively small but important union, the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers.

title: Youth Held Over in Incident Involving Queen in London
description: Marcus Simon Sarjeant, an unemployed British youth charged with firing six times from a blank pistol near Queen Elizabeth II over the weekend, appeared in court today and was ordered held in custody until June 24.

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
OUTLOOK PESSIMISTIC
description: Negotiators in baseball's labor dispute resume talks at 2 P.M. today, but there does not seem to be much chance of movement that could put an early end to the four-day-old player strike. Moreover, some knowledgeable observers yesterday saw deterioration in the dispute.

title: COMPUTER INVESTORS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including equity in loss from European operations that have been sold of $2,156,000 for the qr and $1,667,000 for the yr

title: 9 Records Set by Fabi In Capturing Can-Am
description: Teo Fabi, his red March racer making the opposition's machines look as if they had been rescued from a used-car lot, rewrote the record book at Mosport Park yesterday and gave the Paul Newman racing team early superiority in the 1981 Can-Am Challenge series.

title: MIDEAST ARMS EMBARGO URGED
description: Washington, June 15 (UPI) - The American Friends Service Committee, in letters to the heads of government in Washington, Moscow and Paris, called for an immediate embargo on shipments of arms and nuclear materials to the Middle East. The organization said that the Isreali bombing of Iraq's nuclear power plant "has set a most dangerous precedent" and that no time should be lost in planning steps away from further escalation of terror and war.

title: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS RETURN TO EAST GERMANY OF 2 DURERS STOLEN IN '45
description: Two 15th-century paintings by Albrecht Durer that were stolen from a German castle occupied by American troops in 1945 must be returned by a New York lawyer and art collector to an East German museum, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Chess: Karpov Outdistances Field In a Strong Moscow Event
description: Anatoly Karpov added another triumph to his brilliant record by winning the all-grandmaster Moscow international tournament with a 9-4 score.

title: 7 People Die, Iraq Says, As Iranians Shell Basra
description: Iranian gunners today shelled the southern Iraqi port of Basra, killing 7 people and wounding 38, all civilians, the Iraqi press agency reported.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS SALE OF SILVER
description: The House Armed Services Committee has approved the sale of about 75 percent of the country's stockpile of silver and about 1.5 million carats of diamonds as a budget-cutting measure.

title: ASKIN SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
No Headline
description: The Soviet Union has promised it will continue to give priority to Argentina as a supplier of grain, Argentine officials said here today.

title: Curbs Sought By Honeywell
description: An official of Honeywell Inc. called today for changes in the pending Telecommunications Competition and Deregulation bill to restrict the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and promote competition in the communications industry.

title:
Letter: ON Monitoring block grants;
WATCHING OVER COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT,E16
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Hearings Set in Atlanta In Case of Slayings Figure
description: A Federal judge ruled today that attorneys for a black man questioned about the slayings of 28 young blacks may argue privately tomorrow for an order barring city and lawenforcement officials from talking about their client.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL - NEW YORK METS (NL) - Signed fol- lowing selections from amateur draft: Ken Harris, shortstop from Laverne College; Richard Webster, pitcher from Memphis State; Larry McNutt, first baseman from Jackson State; Edward Garton, third base- man from University of Iowa; Steve Slaton, pitcher from Long Beach State; Russell Or- rick, outfielder from Vintage High School (Calif.); Mark Harlander, outfielder from University of Nebraska; Bruce Kastelic, shortstop from Oklahoma State; Larry Czeszewski, catcher from Midwestern State College; Scott Holid
description: BUFFALO (AFC)- Signed No. 7 draft pick, Steve D oolittle, linebacker from Colorado. DETROIT (NFC) - Signed No. 1 draft p ick, Mark Nichols, wide receiver of San J ose State, and No. 3 draft pick, Don Greco, g uard of Western Illinois.

title: G.E. AND NEBRASKA UTILITY SETTLE FUEL SUIT
description: The Nebraska Public Power District and the General Electric Company announced yesterday that they had agreed to an out-of-court settlement of the utility's three-year-old lawsuit in the United States District Court in Omaha that charged G.E. with reneging on an agreement to buy back spent nuclear fuel.

title: SPORTS NEWS BRIEFS
description: Anxious about a porous defense, the Hartford Whalers signed a free-agent goaltender, Greg Millen, to a longterm contract today.

title: BASEBALL STRIKE IS NO BOON TO SOCCER
description: It may be too early to determine if the North American Soccer League will reap benefits from the major league baseball strike, but an examination of the weekend's soccer games in cities that have baseball franchises indicates that the answer is no.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in SportsMonday yesterday incorrectly reported the winner and the score of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's championship baseball game. The winner was Nazareth Regional High School, which defeated Monsignor Scanlon, 6-2.

title: EDUCATION TRAINING MINORITY ENGINEERS
description: CITY COLLEGE yesterday received $2.7 million from the National Science Foundation, the largest Federal grant ever given to a unit of the City University of New York, to establish a center to promote the education of scientists and engineers who belong to minority groups.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Medalist In Women's Met Title Golf
description: Judy Cooperstein of North Shore won the medal today in the qualifying round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship after a four-hole playoff with Gail Flanagan of Westchester. The two were tied at 81 after 18 holes at the Huntington-Crescent Country Club.

title: WESTCHESTER ACCEPTS PLAN TO OPEN UP AIRPORT LAND
description: Westchester County announced today an agreement with the state for the Air National Guard to abandon Westchester County Airport in favor of Stewart Airport in Newburgh, opening up a large tract of land at the airport for possible commercial development.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carriage Carpet Mills appointed Jack W. Sloan executive vice president.

title: The Region; Irvington Board Acts On Video Machines
description: Trustees of this village voted unanimously last night to soften a proposed ordinance on the restriction of video games. They voted to permit a maximum of three of the machines, such as Space Invaders, instead of two, in any one commercial establishment.

title: TOWARD A LONG-RANGE CURE FOR NEW YORK TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Format Changed For Option Tables
description: The New York Times is beginning publication today of stock option tables with a new format.

title: Notes On People; No Fight on Qualifications
description: As a graduate of Cornell Law School, a former member of the Maine Legislature, a former Governor of Maine, a United States Senator for 22 years and a former Secretary of State, Edmund S. Muskie naturally seemed qualified to practice before the United States Supreme Court.

title: DOVER, DEL., PARKLANDS ARE LOVELY TO LOOK AT BUT COSTLY TO HOLD
description: This capital city set in the middle of Delaware farm country has an unusual commodity for sale: parks. At least, it would like to sell about a dozen of the 66 parcels of land that make Dover ''park-poor,'' as one city official put it, with too many parks and not enough money to maintain them.

title: Networks Seek to Avoid Players' Strike Losses
description: NBC and ABC, the TV networks that cover major league baseball weekly, as well as all of the stations that televise the home team games (and don't forget radio), are now trying to figure out a way of salvaging some of the ad revenues that are threatened by the players' strike.

title: FAIR-TEX MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Televising Reagan Conference
description: President Reagan's news conference, to be held today in Washington, will be televised live at 2 P.M. on the CBS, NBC, ABC and PBS networks - Channels 2, 4, 7 and 13 in New York. The conference will also be carried live on New York radio stations WCBS-AM and WINS.

title: SURVIVORS OF NAZI CAMPS MINGLE IN JOY AND SORROW
description: Many of the women are in stylish coiffures, the men in fashionable slacks and sport shirts. They would blend into a crowd on the streets of New York. But the blue numerals are still tatooed on their forearms, and now and then there is a man among them who may point to a scar where a German's pistol butt smashed his face.

title: IN NEW ASSEMBLY BILL, COURTS MUST CONSIDER JOINT CUSTODY
description: After eliminating provisions that had met with objections in the Senate, the New York State Assembly tonight approved a bill that would require judges to consider granting joint custody of children in divorce cases if one or both of the parents requested it. The vote was 94 to 43.

title: Protest Cancels Shift at Chrysler
description: ''Excessive absenteeism'' by Chrysler Corporation workers protesting the loss of a quarterly $800 cost-of-living payment forced the cancellation of production on today's first shift, company officials said.

title: PHILIPPINES EXPELLING U.S. PRIEST, APPARENTLY BECAUSE OF TEACHINGS
description: An American Roman Catholic priest on the southern island of Mindanao has been denied an extension of his stay and ordered to leave the Philippines by Saturday.

title: Reagan Daughter Hailed at Rally Of 18,000 Opposing Atom Power
description: A brief statement by President Reagan's daughter condemning atomic power brought more than 18,000 people to their feet at an antinuclear rally at the Hollywood Bowl yesterday afternoon.

title: FOR S.E.C. CHIEF, BIG DECISIONS
description: John S.R. Shad, after little more than a month as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, is facing two key decisions that Wall Street and businessmen feel could well set the tone for the future direction of the commission's crucial enforcement division.

title: Flying Typhus
description: Epidemic typhus, the scourge of many of the armies of World War I, has been a rarity in this country since the early 1920's. The last major outbreak in the eastern United States was in Philadelphia in 1836.

title: Don Hogan Charles Suspect Arrested in Wounding of Police Officer
description: Police officers carrying Mark Stephenson to a radio car after he was shot by Police Officer Elijah Frazier at 241 West 125th Street. The offduty officer was seriously wounded in the shoulder as he walked near a clothing store where, police said, Mr. Stephenson and two accomplices were attempting a robbery.

title: WORKERS AT JOB SITE ATTACK PROTESTER'S BUS
description: A school bus that had brought protesters seeking jobs for minorities to a midtown building site was attacked and heavily damaged yesterday by construction workers who were angered by the demonstrators, the police reported. There were no arrests.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Pact Sought
description: Efforts to reach a new long-term agreement to supply the Soviet Union with American grain has been given ''very high priority'' within the Reagan Administration, but no deadline has been set, a senior Agriculture Department official said today.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
E.E.C. Paraxylene Duty
description: In a new move against alleged dumping of petrochemicals from the United States, the European Economic Community's executive commission today announced a special duty on American paraxylene, a widely used basic material.

title: F.D.A. IS INVESTIGATING CHARGES OF ILLEGAL ORANGE JUICE DILUTION
description: In the next two months, the Food and Drug Administration expects to complete an investigation into whether some orange juice processors are diluting their products to increase profitability.

title: Mafia Leader Killed Near Naples
description: Vincenzo Genovese, the nephew of the late American crime figure Vito Genovese and the most powerful Mafia leader in the area south of Naples, was shot to death today as he was driving a sports car near this southern Italian city, the police reported. Mr. Genovese, 43, headed an extortion racket linked with the Raffaele Cutolo family of Naples, the police said.

title: Notes On Fashion
description: ''L IONS and tigers and bears, oh my!'' sang an astonished Dorothy as she skipped down the road toward Oz.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Dec 1980

title: CHEMICAL CUTS PRIME TO 19%
description: The Chemical Bank, the seventh largest in the nation, reduced its prime rate by a full percentage point, to 19 percent, yesterday from 20 percent, but no other major bank followed the move.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD STRIP MINING CURBS OPPOSED BY WATT
description: The Supreme Court today unanimously upheld the constitutionality of the Federal strip mining law, broadly endorsing the power of Congress to impose stringent environmental regulations on unwilling states and property owners.

title: POP: STEVE AND EDIE AT CARNEGIE
description: STEVE LAWRENCE and Eydie Gorme, who began their career as a husband-and-wife singing team 21 years ago, finally made their Carnegie Hall debut Friday evening in the first of a series of eight performances that will continue there tomorrow through Sunday.

title: The Region; Disciplinary Hearing For Sheriff Delayed
description: The start of a disciplinary hearing for Thomas J. Delaney, the suspended Sheriff and Commissioner of Public Safety Services in Westchester County, was postponed until June 29 by Bertram Harnett, a retired State Supreme Court Justice who is serving as the hearing officer.

title: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Rozelle Assailed by Davis Over Raiders' Bid to Move
description: Al Davis charged today that Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League, has tried to force the Raiders to remain in Oakland ''in perpetuity'' and has sometimes made the club a victim of difficult scheduling.

title: Loans Forecast For Oil Nations
description: Mexico, Venezuela and Nigeria together will need to borrow at least an extra $6 billion on world capital markets this year following cuts in their oil prices and production, international bankers said here today.

title: Inmates at Georgia Prison Start Fire in Dormitory
description: Two dormitories at the Georgia State Prison were evacuated tonight when inmates started a fire because prison officials had refused to let them use a gymnasium, the authorities said.

title: Staffs Sent to Farm Clubs
description: Cincinnati was one of several major league teams that found work for employees in the minor leagues yesterday, assigning its manager and coaching staff to observe and work with players in the farm system. The Cleveland Indians and Chicago White Sox made similar moves.

title: METS' BACKMAN EXPANDS STRIKE
description: While 650 major league baseball players were in the fourth day of their strike yesterday, Wally Backman of the Tidewater Tides went on a one-man minor league work stoppage.

title: ALEXANDER'S TO SELL SPECIALITY CHAIN
description: Alexander's Inc., the New York-based department store chain that has been plagued by earnings declines and, more recently, losses, moved yesterday to rid itself of what it considered an albatross.

title: FROM JUNGLE OUTPOST, EUROPE PREPARES SPACE AGE CHALLENGE
description: The Europeans who came here centuries ago in search of the fabled El Dorado only to find an unconquerable ''green hell'' have returned with a new dream of conquest, a dream they are pursuing vigorously in an incongruous setting on the Atlantic coast within sight of the infamous Devil's Island and downriver from jungle people barely out of the Stone Age.

title: URBANIZATION OF RURAL U.S. CALLED PERIL TO FARMLAND
description: Three million acres of American farmland are being converted each year to other uses, a trend that, the Agriculture Department has warned, poses ''some very serious longterm risks.'' But Lawrence Hertzke is not at all apologetic about the 500 acres he sold for housing tracts in this rapidly growing city.

title: EXCLUSIVITY UPHELD FOR JERSEY LEAGUES
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that membership in interscholastic sports leagues could be limited to public schools and that the exclusion of private schools was not necessarily a denial of equal protection under the Federal and state constitutions.

title: ANOTHER PRISONER JOINS ULSTER HUNGE STRIKE
description: Another member of the Irish Republican Army began a hunger strike in the Maze Prison near Belfast this morning. The decision by 29-year-old Patrick Quinn brought to six the number of prisoners going without food, and it increased the prospect of another series of starvation deaths in the prison beginning early next month.

title: Hecla's Bid for Day
description: The Hecla Mining Company announced that a bid by Day Mines Inc. for a temporary restraining order to halt Hecla's exchange offer for all outstanding Day shares had been denied by the Federal District Court in Spokane, Wash. The Hecla offer began June 9. Both companies are major silver producers based in Wallace, Idaho.

title: E.E.C. View On U.S. Rates
description: Finance ministers of the European Economic Community took a cautious step forward today in trying to formulate a common position toward high United States interest rates, although the rates have declined in recent days.

title: Well Owner Is Charged In Death of Italian Boy
description: Amedeo Pisegna, the owner of the property where a 6-year-old boy fell into an artesian well and died, was charged today with negligent homicide.

title: TASK FORCE ON ARTS IS TOLD TO DO MORE WITH LESS
description: Charlton Heston, co-chairman of the new President's Task Force on the Arts and Humanities, told the members of the group today that ''we have to find ways to do more, or even as much, with less.''

title: U.S. Said to Have Given Israelis Data on Reactor
description: American officials visited Israel in secret several times last year to keep the Israelis informed of Iraq's alleged progress toward producing atomic bombs, the daily newspaper Maariv reported today.

title: THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
