TALKS GOING WELL. HAIG AND DENG SAY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, said today that the first high-level talks between the Chinese authorities and the Reagan Administration had gone ''very well.'' American officials said that Taiwan had not been a major issue of contention.

title: PRETRIAL INVESTIGATIVE HEARING SET ON OFFICER'S CONTACT WITH SOVIET
description: The Air Force plans to begin tomorrow a formal pretrial investigative proceeding to determine whether a 25-year-old missile officer made unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy here in violation of Air Force regulations.

title: HOUSE ACTION NEAR IN FIGHT OVER LEGAL AID
description: The increasingly bitter ideological struggle over President Reagan's drive to abolish the Legal Services Corporation is slated to reach the House floor tomorrow, amid charges and countercharges that lobbying activities have been misleading.

title: Banks and Oldfield Excel In Helsinski Field Events
description: Willy Banks won the triple jump and Brian Oldfield the shot-put to highlightthe opening day of the 15th World Games at the Helsinki Olympic Stadium today.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Contract Talks Collapse in Strike By Coal Construction Employees
description: Efforts to end the 81-day strike by 11,500 mine construction workers collapsed today, with the top union negotiator exhorting management to negotiate seriously on issues that have been argued ''inside and out.''

title: ARMY ENGINEERS CRITICIZED IN PROJECT AUDITS
description: A series of audits of United States Army Corps of Engineers projects indicates that the agency overbuilt many water projects and has understated and been slow to recover the costs of both water and hydropower facilities.

title: Hundreds Flee as a Train Derails And Carloads of Cooking Oil Burn
description: A freight train carrying a load of cooking oil derailed and caught fire early today near here, and several hundred people were evacuated as a precaution, the authorities said.

title: After-Tax Profits For First Quarter
description: Manufacturers' after-tax profits averaged 4.7 cents for each dollar of sales revenue in the first quarter of 1981, down one-tenth of a cent from the preceeding quarter and down six-tenths of a cent from the first quarter of 1980, the Federal Trade Commission staff reported.

title: 'Piaf' Extended to July 5
description: ''Piaf,'' the play about the French singer starring Jane Lapotaire that was to have closed after Sunday's matinee at the Plymouth Theater, has extended its run through July 5, its producers have announced. Ticket sales had been lagging but rose to $35,000 for last week after Miss Lapotaire won the 1981 Tony Award for best actress in a play.

title: KHEEL VS. KOCH: TILTING AT WINDMILLS?
description: Maybe three minutes had passed after Edward I. Koch formally announced last week that he would seek re-election when someone asked about Theodore W. Kheel and his charges of election-law violations by the Mayor.

title: TREASURY RATES DECLINE AGAIN
description: Rates on new Treasury bills declined yesterday for the third consecutive week, with three- and six-month bills averaging 13.45 percent and 13.36 percent, respectively, at the weekly auction.

title: Mitsubishi Unit in U.S.
description: Mitsubishi Chemical Industries Ltd. said today that it had set up a wholly owned investment subsidiary in New York with capital of $3 million to expand investment in the chemical field, including takeovers and joint ventures.

title: What Kind of Defense?
description: The alacrity with which Congress is authorizing a whopping twoyear increase in the military budget -28 percent, after inflation - reflects a consensus that more defense is needed. But even if the nation can afford that much more, it is not yet clear that the Reagan Administration will spend it wisely. The costs and strategies of the country's biggest peacetime buildup are finally stirring public interest - assisted by CBS's commendable dedication of five prime hours to the subject this week.

title: GRAND RELATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: MEN OF BASEBALL, LEND AN EAR
description: Call this baseball strike an example of deny-side economics, which says you withhold from the consumer what he most desires so that you may substitute discipline for satisfaction; call it a symptom of the plague of distrust and divisiveness that afflicts our land; call it the triumph of greed over the spirit of the garden.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RETROSPECTIVE

title: MOTHS EVOLVE A JAMMING DEVICE TO THWART ENEMY BATS
description: ELECTRONIC detection and tracking devices played a pivotal part in the Battle of Britain, and since then, the rapid development of radar and anti-radar technology have come to dominate human warfare. But a new scientific study suggests that human achievements in electronic warfare are still incomparably cruder than analogous weapons used by bats and moths locked in struggle for survival.

title: Steel Output Off 1.2%
description: Steel production nationwide fell to 2.5 million tons in the week ended Saturday, down 1.2 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The production amounted to 82.1 percent of capacity in the week, compared with 83.1 percent the week before. Estimated figures for the year to date showed production at 59.6 million tons, up 8.3 percent from the 55 million tons in the similar 1980 period.

title: SUPREME COURT LETS STAND QUOTA ON HIRING OF MINORITIES BY POLICE
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to hear an appeal by New York City to overturn a lower court ruling that required that at least one-third of new police officers hired since August be black or of Hispanic origin.

title: New Janssen Drug
description: Janssen Pharmaceutica Inc., a Swiss subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson, has received permission from the Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing an oral antifungal drug, the company announced. The drug, to be sold under the trademark Nizoral, is used to treat lesions that develop under the skin.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings reflect 5 percent stock divd in Oct 1980 and Apr 1981

title: LEVELS STILL TERMED LOW
description: The nation's three largest domestic auto producers reported today that new-car sales rose 11.5 percent in the first 10 days of June compared with the depressed selling levels for the same period last year. Analysts said that, despite the rise, sales levels were still unsatisfactory.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Finish Strong For Grand National Victory
description: A strong finish by the New York representatives enabled them to snatch victory in the Grand National Team zonal playoffs in Washington Sunday night. Brian Glubok, Michael Rosenberg, John Lowenthal, Phillip Martin, Michael Becker and Ron Rubin ousted New England and Washington teams, and advanced to the national quarterfinals next month in Boston.

title: TENURED TEACHERS FACING LAYOFFS AT LEVELS OF 1930'S
description: Declining enrollment and budget difficulties have resulted this year in the layoffs of the largest number of tenured teachers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut since the Depression, school administrators in the three states say.

title: No Headline
description: The State Department announced today that the United States and Pakistan had agreed on a $3 billion military and economic aid program to strengthen Pakistani defenses against a ''serious threat'' from Soviet troops in Afghanistan.

title: The City; Police Break Up Bronx Bank Robbery
description: Detectives seized four men yesterday as they tried to hold up a teller at a Bronx bank that had been robbed at least six times in the last year, the police said.

title: CITY BALLET: 'PATHETIQUE' WITH BALANCHINE 'ADAGIO'
description: ALTHOUGH many ballets from the New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival will be repeated in the next two weeks, the festival proper closed Sunday night at the New York State Theater with a one-timeonly joint performance of George Balanchine's and Jerome Robbins's treatment of Tchaikovsky's ''Pathetique,'' or Sixth Symphony.

title: Canada Utility To Lift Exports
description: Ontario Hydro Ltd., a major Canadian electric utility, is expected to receive authorization from Canada's National Energy Board this week for a substantial increase of its electric power exports to the United States.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: Pope John Paul II is now at home in the Vatican where he has resumed some of his work and is gaining strength. He is awaiting a second operation - the next stage in his recovery from the gunshot wound he suffered on May 13. His convalescence has been steady but slow, according to one of his doctors, and the Pope, like any patient who suffered similar wounds, becomes easily fatigued.

title: Many Florida Animals Doing Well After Fires
description: Swamp wildlife in southern Florida suffered little harm from widespread fires earlier this year, according to environmentalists.

title: ESTIMATE BOARD, IN REVERSAL, VOTES FOSTER CARE AID
description: In a victory for Mayor Koch, the Board of Estimate yesterday ended five days of debate over foster care and voted to approve $185 million in contracts with 72 foster care agencies for the coming fiscal year.

title: U.S. Envoy Flies to Syria After New Israeli Threat
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, flew to Syria from Saudi Arabia today, officials here said.

title: New Australian Liqueur To Warriner Mandelbaum
description: Park Benziger & Company will be doing what it can to confuse the growing cream liqueur picture with an entry from Down Under. It is Conticream from Australia and instead of being based on Irish whisky like the original Bailey's from the Paddington Corporation, it has a heart of rum.

title: 3,000 Seeking 8 Jobs Tie Up St. Louis Traffic
description: At least three thousand job-seekers lined up today to apply for eight jobs on the production line of the Procter & Gamble Manufacturing Company, creating severe traffic jams, the police said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In the Advertising column in Business Day on June 8, the Republic Steel Corporation's advertising and public relations agencies were misidentified. They are Meldum & Fewsmith, the advertising agency, and Manning, Selvage & Lee, which handles public relations.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anglo Energy Ltd. acquired Duggan Machine Co. and Royle Duggan Equipment associated companies in Shreveport, La., for a total of about $6 million in cash and notes.

title: CONCERT OPERA: MERCADANTE'S 'ILL GIURAMENTO'
description: A NEGLECTED opera presented in concert form -shorn of daggers, potions, wartime battles, costumes and all the stage business that compensates for a mediocre score - might prove to deserve its neglect more than ever.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results reflect acquisition of the remaining 55 percent interest in Samuel Jacobs & Co

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
U.S. WARNS NATIONS ON USING STORED OIL
description: The United States warned today that it may not want to share oil with other members of the International Energy Agency during shortages, if they draw heavily on stockpiles now in order to save dollars by avoiding current purchases.

title: FOR SOCIALISTS IN FRANCE, A GREEN LIGHT
description: News Analysis

title: THE DIVERSE ART OF FORECASTING
description: EARNINGS forecasts, the most avidly watched indicators of corporate prospects, are wrong often enough to give investors pause. A new study by the Conference Board finds that, while 51 percent of forecasts prepared by 123 responding investment analysts were within 10 percent (plus or minus) of the actual income later reported by corporations, 37 percent of the forecasts were off by 15 percent or more.

title: No Headline
description: MISS AUSTIN SCORES IN FIRST MATCH ON GRASS

title: interview; TALKING BUSINESS; LIFO INVENTORY HELPS RETAILERS
description: Facing prospects of rising overhead, high interest rates and uncertain consumer buying, more retailers are adopting the LIFO method of inventory valuation that offers them an opportunity to save tax dollars and thereby in effect obtain an ''interest-free'' loan from the Federal Government. But there is a caveat. If inflation falls to a medium single-digit level or if the store's inventories are reduced, use of the LIFO method may require the store to repay the taxes it has saved.

title: REAGAN URGES MAYORS TO SUPPORT BLOCK-GRANT PLAN
description: President Reagan sent word to the United States Conference of Mayors today that ''our overall goal is the same,'' but he continued to insist that Congress approve his block grant proposals, which many mayors fear.

title: HARRY R. MARTIN
description: Harry R. Martin, former director of communications of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, died Sunday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Associates Corporation of North America, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $150 million of 6 percent 20-year senior debentures, underwritten by a Kidder, Peabody group.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Garcia, Cleveland Indians' manager, relaxing yesterday in the empty stands at Municipal Stadium.

title: A.A. Berie, head of Parks Council Inc.; SUIT CHALLENGES A MOVE BY NAVY INTO FORT ON S.I.
description: A suit seeking to stop the Navy from moving into Fort Wadsworth and seeking to reinstate the 220-acre Staten Island facility as part of the Gateway National Recreation Area was filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: APPEALS COURT UPSETS ORDER TO RAISE CENSUS TOTAL
description: In a setback for Detroit and some other major cities, a Federal appeals court in Cincinnati today reversed a ruling that had ordered the Census Bureau to add five million people to the nation's 1980 population total.

title: Transfer of Funds Averts Rail Shutdown in Chicago
description: Rail commuters in the region won a reprieve today with an infusion of funds that guaranteed continued service for the rest of June.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Wins A Seat in India's Parliament
description: Rajiv Gandhi, the 36-year-old son of the Prime Minister, was elected to Parliament today, capturing the seat that became vacant last June when his younger brother, Sanjay, was killed in the crash of a stunt airplane. Since the accident, it has widely been expected that Mr. Gandhi would succeed his brother as his mother's closest adviser.

title: Professor Opens Office in England
description: An English adman, who is fairly well known over here, has just opened a new agency over there. John P. Treasure, 56-year-old former vice chairman of the J. Walter Thompson Company and chairman of its British operation, yesterday opened John Treasure & Partners.

title: DUSTY SMOG NOW CLOUDS AIR IN PHOENIX
description: Motorists driving through the desert near here are often startled to see a huge clay-colored cloud on the horizon. As they get closer to Phoenix, it looms larger and larger.

title: Saab Earnings Dip
description: Saab-Scandia A.B. announced today that group profit before extraordinary items slipped to $63.7 million in the four months ended April 30 from $65.2 million in the similar period in 1980. Sales rose to $962 million, of which $456 million was posted abroad, from $866 million the year before, of which $408 million came from overseas.

title: SUPREME EQUIPMENT & SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
400 Anaconda Jobs Being Cut in Butte
description: The Anaconda Copper Company said it would eliminate 400 jobs here by closing an underground mine and trimming the work force at an open-pit copper mine and ore concentrator.

title: U.S. PANEL ON CRIME TO URGE F.B.I. TO INDEX STATES' DATA BY COMPUTER
description: An advisory committee studying the problem of violent crime plans to recommend that the Federal Bureau of Investigation establish a computerized index to ease the exchange of information among state police agencies.

title: STEVCOKNIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $251,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Notes On People; American Artist's Exhibition Is a Hit in Peking
description: He's the first American artist ever given a major one-man show in China and, according to Oakland-born Dong Kingman, the exhibition of 103 of his paintings has been packing them in in Peking.

title: FEDERATED CHOOSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE, 37
description: When Michael J. Boyle was appointed president of the Lazarus department store division of Federated Department Stores in Columbus, Ohio, about two years ago, a Wall Street retailing analyst said, ''At his age, in that job, you can look forward to hearing a lot more about him.''

title: FRANCE AND BRITAIN REBUKE THE ISRAELIS
description: France and Britain today joined the procession of nations in the Security Council censuring Israel for its assault on an Iraqi nuclear reactor. They declined, however, to support an Arab demand for an arms embargo.

title: LABOR PARTY LEADER SAYS LIKUD IS PROVOKING CAMPAIGN VIOLENCE
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party's candidate for Prime Minister, accused Menachem Begin's party today of organizing violent disruptions of his party's campaign rallies.

title: Bolivia Reopens Colleges Closed Since 1980 Coup
description: Bolivia's universities reopened today for the first time in 11 months.

title: Screenland Pays $17.60 In Victory at Belmont
description: Screenland, the 5-2 second choice who was making her 1981 debut, won the $52,900 Hyde Park Handicap for New York-bred fillies and mares yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: HAS FEMINISM AIDED MENTAL HEALTH?
description: IN little more than a decade the feminist movement, some recent research suggests, has already had a beneficial effect on the mental health of women.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE nation's schools are threatened by a steep decline in the quality of students entering the teacher training institutions. The academic aptitude of high school seniors choosing teacher training is at the bottom of entering college classes. A combination of low pay for teachers and low intellectual stimulation provided by many teachers' colleges is turning able young people away from teaching careers. Unless schools and departments of education raise their intellectual level, many of them may soon be shut down by the universities responsible for them.

title: Notes On People; Strout Recalls 60 Years and Many Presidents
description: He has spent 60 years with The Christian Science Monitor, and that seemed as good an excuse as any yesterday for a group of his colleagues to pry some reminiscences out of Richard L. Strout, 83, the Washington reporter who also writes the TRB column for the New Republic.

title: News Analysis
description: For the fourth time since 1975, the State Legislature decided today not to decide what it should do about New York's property tax system, which has been declared illegal by the state's highest court.

title: Around The Nation; Bible Society Translator Quits Over Religious Views
description: The American Bible Society said today that it had accepted the resignation of a noted Bible translator who publicly questioned literal interpretation of the Scriptures and criticized those who ''idolatrize'' it.

title: Rona Barrett and NBC Disagree on Her Return
description: Rona Barrett said yesterday that she intended to quit the ''Tomorrow Show,'' but an NBC official said he expected Miss Barrett to honor her contract and return to the show on July 6, after her vacation.

title: No Headline
description: John S. Knight, founder of the Knight publishing empire and editor emeritus of Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., died last night of a heart attack at the home of a friend in Akron, Ohio. He was 86 years old. Dale Allen, executive editor of The Akron Beacon Journal, the first Knight newspaper, said that Mr. Knight had been hospitalized for two or three days with a heart condition after attending the 150th anniversary celebration of another of his papers, The Detroit Free Press, about a month ago.

title: LOS ALAMITOS RACE COURSE reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
New College President
description: The Rev. Frank R. Haig, a Jesuit priest who is the brother of Alexander M. Haig Jr., the Secretary of State, has been appointed president of LeMoyne College in Syracuse.

title: 'I HAVE RECOVERED,' PRESIDENT DECLARES
description: Eleven weeks and one day after the attempt on his life, President Reagan declared at his news conference today that he had recovered from a gunshot wound in his chest and that, if anything, the shooting had proved the ineffectiveness of gun control laws.

title: MEXICO, IN SWITCH, WILL LIFT OIL PRICE
description: Mexico announced today that it would raise its oil prices early next month and warned that buyers unwilling to pay the new price might permanently forfeit Mexico as an energy source.

title: 50 TV SHOWS REJECTED BY PROCTER AND GAMBLE
description: In the clearest indication that pressure groups may be having an impact on advertisers, the new chairman of Procter & Gamble has acknowledged that his company - television's largest advertiser - was refusing to sponsor shows it regarded as containing excessive sex, violence and profanity.

title: OPERA: 'LEAR' BY ARIBERT REIMANN
description: Kurt Herbert Adler, who will retire at the end of this year after 28 seasons as general director of the San Francisco Opera, has always been a risk-taker. Last night, he undertook a double risk, in inaugurating a financially perilous summer season and presenting the American premiere of a difficult, highly chromatic new opera, Aribert Reimann's ''Lear.''

title: ASTREX INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including net losses from discontinued operations of $144,000 for the latest period and $88,000 for the previous period

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the World Bank in The Times Monday incorrectly identified Robert D. Muldoon. Mr. Muldoon is the Prime Minister of New Zealand.

title: FAMILY TIES STILL BINDING FOR BIRDSONG
description: May-Jo, Birdie and Katherine will come from Rochester, Marita from Cleveland, Eva from Washington, Charles, Nathaniel, Norris, Ava and Judy from Florida and Sgt. David Birdsong will fly in from in Phoenix.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 17, 1981
description: International The sale of American weapons to China has been approved in principle, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. announced at the end of a three-day visit to Peking. He told reporters that his talks with Chinese leaders had been ''unusually significant and successful'' and seemed to foreshadow ''a major expansion of Sino-American friendship and cooperation.'' (Page A1, Col. 6.) Israel apparently violated its accord with the United States on the use of American-made weapons when it bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor on June 6, President Reagan said. But he also told a news conference that Israel ''might have sincerely believed'' that the action was defensive. (A1:5.)

title: Space Pioneer, 24, Feted
description: The nation's pioneer in space, one of the first two survivors of a long-range rocket flight, turned 24 yesterday. And that was cause for celebration at the Alabama Space and Rocket Center in Huntsville.

title: Reagan's 'Fading' Russians
description: In the last few weeks the Reagan Administration has been emphasizing a theme that may very well be true but is highly dangerous. This is that the Soviet Union may seem to be the most formidable threat to freedom in the world, but actually is breaking up by its own failures and is now at the beginning of the end of its power.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: SINCE the term nouvelle cuisine was first created more than a dozen years ago, we have spent many hours in the company of many chefs from America, France, Switzerland and Germany, all of them practitioners of this so-called ''new'' form of cookery.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Associated Dry Goods, an operator of department stores, appointed John E. Toler president of its The Diamond division. Elmer Braun, current president, will become chairman and chief executive officer.

title: No Headline
description: IRANIANS SCHEDULE DEBATE TODAY OVER IMPEACHMENT OF BANI-SADR

title: News Analysis
description: A child-welfare advocate who followed the New York City Board of Estimate's bitter debate on foster care capsulized what some observers view as the issues underlying both the board's quarrel and the city's system of caring for neglected, abused, handicapped and orphaned children.

title: JONES AND PLUMMER SIGN FOR LEADS IN 'OTHELLO'
description: JAMES EARL JONES and Christopher Plummer will act in ''Othello'' at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., this summer, then tour in it for six months, and open on Broadway in March. Peter Coe will direct, and the Broadway producers will be Don Gregory and Barry and Fran Weissler. Mr. Coe, who is in his first season as artistic director of the Shakespeare Theater, says the casting - Mr. Jones as Othello and Mr. Plummer as Iago - not to mention the tour, is an ''astounding coup.''

title: WEICKER USES ORATORY IN BID TO STALL A BUSING CURB
description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. resorted to nonstop oratory today in an attempt to block the expected final approval of a Congressional curb on the Justice Department's participation in school busing cases.

title: Military Analysis
description: The Military Airlift Command has only about half the ability it needs to move the Rapid Deployment Force to Southwest Asia, according to its commander.

title: The City; 2d Suspect Arrested In Purolator Holdup
description: A 25-year-old maintenance man at Metropolitan Hospital was charged with robbery and attempted murder in connection with last week's $274,000 holdup of a Purolator armored car in the Bronx.

title: No Headline
description: MISS MANDLIKOVA IS TOPPLED BY KIM SANDS

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THERE are thousands of Metropolitan Diarists in the naked city, and Al B. Perlman of Forest Hills is one of them. Mr. Perlman witnessed one of Gotham's more improbable moments recently, an event made possible only by (1) the peculiar architecture of the West 4th Street station of the IND, (2) the Metropolitan Transit Authority's notion of efficient engineering and (3) by the intrepidity of the city's subway riders.

title: U.S. STILL FAVORS A BAN ON WHALING
description: The United States will continue to press for a moratorium on commercial whaling at a meeting of the International Whaling Commission in Britain next month, an Administration spokesman said today.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Margie Dyer, Wendy Lavitt and Meryl Weiss have been collecting Americana for years. Recently, when they found that they were becoming overwhelmed by their hobbies, they decided to pool their things and their talents and opened a shop called Made in America. The shop's wares are mainly antique quilts, furniture, toys and cooking utensils, but when the partners find a contemporary item made in the manner of the old crafts, they add it to the shop. One of the new things is a hen made of sprigged calico which has movable wings. The hen is weighted, so it can serve as a doorstop, but it would be equally cheerful nesting on the window sill or table of a country kitchen. The chicken, printed in blue on white or white on blue, is $25. Made in America is on the second floor of 1234 Madison Avenue (89th Street) and is open from 10:30 to 6:30 Monday through Friday, 11 to 5:30 on Saturday.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Net income includes equity in earnings of affiliates of $6,088, and $4,074,000 for the latest qr and 6 mos, respectively, and $6,574,000 and $11,619,000 for the previous quarter and 6 mos, respectively; shr earnings are per American Depositary Shrs eac of which equals one shr of common stock

title: Clurman Theater May Double Its Size
description: The Harold Clurman Theater is seeking to double its size from 125 seats to 250, which would make it the largest playhouse on Theater Row on West 42d Street. Jack Garfein, artistic director of the Clurman, and Byron Lasky, his business partner, have acquired the Black Theater Alliance next door and have hired the architect Paul Gugliotta to study the feasibility of combining the two.

title: HEAD OF DRUG ENFORCEMENT AGENCY PLANS TO LEAVE OFFICER NEXT MONTH
description: Peter B. Bensinger, head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, confirmed today that he would leave office July 10 because President Reagan wanted to appoint someone else to lead the Federal effort to control narcotics.

title: The City; Student Buys Copies Of 2 Regents Exams
description: Advance copies of two New York State Regents examinations were obtained by a freshman at Long Island City High School in Queens for $10, the police reported.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
2 BANKS CUT PRIME TO 19 1/2 PERCENT
description: Citibank and the Bankers Trust Company announced yesterday that they had lowered their prime rate to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent. On Monday the Chemical Bank reduced its prime rate a full percentage point, to 19 percent, and last week the Marine Midland Bank was the first to drop to the 19 1/2 percent level.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN ASSERTS ISRAEL HAD CAUSE TO MISTRUST IRAQ
description: President Reagan said today that Israel appeared to have violated its weapons agreement with the United States when it bombed an Iraqi nuclear reactor 10 days ago, but that the Israelis ''might have sincerely believed'' their action was defensive in nature.

title: Ousted Russians Depart Liberia
description: Nine Soviet diplomats who were expelled from Liberia left for Moscow today aboard a Soviet Aeroflot jetliner.

title: KRUPP SETS CUTBACKS IN STEEL
description: Fried. Krupp G.m.b.H., the West German steel-making and engineering concern, contradicting earlier statements by its Iranian shareholders, said today that it would sharply cut back steel output at three plants in the coming months and eliminate 4,000 jobs because of Europe's slumping steel market.

title: 'GAIJIN,' TRAVAIL OF JAPANESE SETTLERS IN BRAZIL
description: ''GAIJIN,'' a first feature by Tizuka Yamasaki, a young Brazilianborn Japanese woman, is a deeply felt tribute by Miss Yamasaki to her grandmother who, early in this century, migrated to Brazil with thousands of other Japanese to find fortune and found instead discrimination, poverty, loneliness and all of the other aspects of melancholy associated with exile.

title: RESTRICTION IS ACCEPTED BY A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in an apparent reversal of policy, told a Senate panel that it would accept restrictions on offering new information services.

title: Dow Off 8.66 in Slow Trading
description: The stock market ended broadly lower yesterday in slower trading with some of the energy-related, technology and blue-chip issues registering the biggest losses.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran and Iraq Exchange 42 Wounded Captives
description: Iran and Iraq exchanged a total of 42 wounded prisoners today in the first such exchange since war broke out between them last September, according to an announcment by the International Committee of the Red Cross.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Martin Tolchin JAVITS. The Autobiography of a Public Man, by former Senator Jacob K. Javits, with Rafael Steinberg. 528 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: Real Estate; Designing Manhattan Retail Sites
description: SEVERAL midtown office towers under construction in Manhattan offer a variety of approaches to urban retail space, one of the more controversial issues in the proposed revision of midtown zoning and the proposed designation of an Upper East Side Historic District.

title: Saudis Increase Stake In Donaldson, Lufkin
description: Two Saudi Arabian investors - a member of the Saudi royal family and a Mobil Corporation director - said yesterday that they had lifted their stake in Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. to 14.4 percent.

title: Davis Declares Charge Of Mansion Deal a Lie
description: Al Davis, the Oakland Raiders' owner, branded as a lie today an insinuation that he was to be given a mansion in Beverly Hills as part of the deal to move his team to Los Angeles.

title: Cuban Slain at Atlanta Prison
description: A Cuban detainee at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary was stabbed to death today. Victor Robaina-Valdivia, 34 years old, was the third Cuban refugee to die in a violent attack at the institution since the boatlift last year, said Jack Hanberry, the warden. Neither a prison spokesman nor the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is conducting an inquiry, would elaborate on the stabbing. Mr. Robaina-Valdivia, who had been imprisoned in Cuba, was being held here pending an Immigration and Naturalization Service hearing to determine whether he should be released.

title: Around The Nation; Oil Companies Allowed To Drill in Georges Bank
description: Massachusetts environmental officials today approved oil and natural gas exploration in the Georges Bank fishing area off Cape Cod and said that drilling could begin in late August.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP 0.3% IN MAY
description: The nation's industrial production rose a slight three-tenths of 1 percent in May, with most of the small gain a result of auto dealers' building up inventories, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: MARGERY BORG LOENGARD
description: Margery Borg Loengard, a former president and trustee of the Public Education Association in New York, died Monday at her home in Manhattan at the age of 81.

title: Eating Cashew Nuts at $3 Apiece
description: A follow-up: On April 4, Emma Harris, a registered nurse, was arrested on a St. Louis city bus and charged with eating four cashew nuts. She faced a maximum penalty of 60 days in jail and a $500 fine.

title: Index; International
description: Namibia council finds whites' grip remains strong A2 Police in Soweto break up me- morial meeting in church A3 Africans struggling to bring unity to O.A.U. A3 Reagan Administration favors a ban on whaling A4 Around the World A5 Saudis call mission ''futile,''but Habib presses on A9 New Polish party people emerg- ing in elections to congress A10 Marcos, virtually unopposed, wins by a huge majority A12 U.S. envoy stresses commitment to Salvadoran jnta A13 Italy to investigate civil servants in Masonic scandal A14 Census enlivens quest for inde- pendent Quebec A15 Government/Politics Head of drug enforcement agency to leave office next month A18 Weicker uses oratory in effort to block a ban on busing A22 Reagan favors California gun laws rated as mixed success A28 Agriculture aide expected to end Human Nutrition Center A29 Engineer on M.T.A. panel sees Flxible buses back in July B2 Carey and Koch agree to seek cut in taxes on commercial banks B3 Koch budget proposals are facing opposition B3 McCann victor in Jersey City mayoralty runoff B6 General Survey finds some black support for lower minimum wage A18 Mine owners and union announce a tentative agreement A18 Around the Nation A20 Michigander lands new job and plans move to Texas A20 Jersey Transit plans to buy 117 high capacity buses B2 Living Section Food When it's hot, eat cool: Food for summer nights C1

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-Net income...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $102,011 for the qr and $189,604 for the 9 mos; results include operations of Shirt Shed Inc since Apr 1, 1980; Shirt Shed was acquired on Apr 10, 1980 and accounted for as a purchase

title: A GLOBAL TEACHER, NOT A CULT LEADER
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN FAVORS A GUN LAW RATED AS MIXED SUCCESS
description: President Reagan suggested at his news conference in Washington today that instead of national gun control legislation, Congress should consider enacting laws like those in effect in California.

title: Greek Theater Offers 'Elektra'
description: The Greek Theater of New York will open its new production of ''Elektra'' on June 30. ''Elektra'' will be the first presentation at the Greek Theater's new home at 120 West 28th Street. The play, which will be staged in Greek, will run through July 19.

title: Too Big for Antitrust
description: It was in 1969 that the Justice Department began its prosecution of I.B.M. for violating the antitrust laws. Twelve years and hundreds of millions of dollars in legal costs later, the case is creeping toward resolution. William Baxter, the Justice Department's new antitrust chief, apparently has little zeal for the fight, and Judge David Edelstein is belatedly pushing both sides to settle.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THERE are good buys in summer fruits and vegetables and some meats this week. In the warm weather many items are useful for outdoor barbecuing, such as steak, spareribs, chicken and corn.

title: MARCOS IS VICTOR BY A HUGE MAJORITY
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, running virtually without opposition, was re-elected yesterday by an overwhelming majority. The voting was the first for the presidency since 1969.

title: C.I.A. Says Terrorism Is on Rise, With 760 Acts Counted Last Year
description: A new report by the Central Intelligence Agency says that the number of terrorist activities around the world have risen dramatically and that American businessmen and diplomats are the terrorists' favorite targets.

title: EASY BANANA ICE
description: One of the most incredible and incredibly easy ices to prepare is a banana ice made in a juicer with the trade name Champion, model G5-NG-853S. I first sampled the dish at the Golden Door Spa in Escondido, Calif.

title: Merger of 2 Coast Papers Approved by a U.S. Jury
description: The city's two major newspapers did not violate antitrust laws by merging their no@neditorial operations 16 years ago to survive, a Federal jury decided yesterday.

title: James H. Williams, 73; Sulfur Drugs Developer
description: Dr. James Horace Williams, a former director of the Lederle Laboratories who contributed to the development of sulfur drugs and other products, including aureomycin, died Thursday at his home in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 73 years old.

title: 2 KOCH BUDGET PROPOSALS RUNNING INTO DIFFICULTIES
description: Mayor Koch's plan to deny promotions to fourth- and seventh-grade students not proficient in reading and mathematics ran into trouble yesterday among members of the Board of Estimate who must approve his 1982 budget.

title: No Headline
description: RULE ON ATOM WASTE IS PROPOSED

title: Virgin Islands Constitution Gains
description: A constitution for the Virgin Islands cleared Congress today when the House of Representatives approved several minor Senate amendments. The self-government resolution now goes to the White House for President Reagan's signature.

title: Court's Cable Television Ruling Aids F.C.C. Deregulation Effort
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the Federal Communications Commission could take a significant step toward deregulating cable television by removing restrictions on the use of distant signals and syndicated programs.

title: Motions in European Parliament Condemn Israelis for Iraq Attack
description: Two resolutions condemning Israel for its bombing of an Iraqi nuclear power station were proposed today to the European Parliament.

title: The Region; Westchester Flights Approved for Airline
description: New York Air has received permission from the Civil Aeronautics Board to use Westchester County Airport for 36 flights a day, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello announced yesterday.

title: CHICAGO CUBS ARE SOLD BY WRIGLEY TO TRIBUNE CO. FOR $20.5MILLION
description: The Chicago Cubs, one of major league baseball's least successful franchises on the field in recent years, were sold yesterday for $20.5 million by William Wrigley to the Tribune Company, parent of The Chicago Tribune and The Daily News in New York.

title: Court Allows Bank to Ban Premature Withdrawals
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that a savings bank could refuse to let a depositor make a premature withdrawal of a time deposit even though the depositor was willing to pay the interest penalty and the bank was permitting such penalized withdrawals.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,418,000 for the latest yr and $775,000 for the previous yr

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: Yr-ago revs have been reclassified

title: The Region; Connecticut to Study Cameras in Court
description: Justice John A. Speziale of the State Supreme Court has announced the appointment of a seven-judge committee to study the issue of allowing cameras in the courtroom.

title: China Women Beat U.S.
description: China's national women's basketball team pulled away in the second half and beat an American all-star squad, 74-64, tonight before a capacity crowd of 18,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We didn't live on the wrong side of the railroad tracks, but we lived so close to them we could hear the whistle real loud.'' - President Reagan. (A27:2.)

title: No Headline
description: Around the Nation; Closed Hearing Held in Case Of Publicity on Atlanta Man

title: RULES CHAIRMAN SAYS REAGAN USES BUDGET AS A METHOD TO 'TYRANNIZE'
description: Representative Richard Bolling, the chairman of the House Rules Committee, accused President Reagan today of trying to use the budget process to impose a ''totalitarian'' rule over Congress.

title: MCCANN AN EASY VICTOR OVER SHEIL IN RUNBOFF FOR JERSEY CITY MAYORALTY
description: City Councilman Gerald McCann scored a lopsided runoff election victory over State Senator Walter N. Sheil today to become Mayor of this industrial city on the Hudson riverfront. Mr. McCann will be sworn in on July 1.

title: Chlorine Tank Breaks in Atlanta
description: A 150-pound chlorine gas tank ruptured today in downtown Atlanta, forcing the partial evacuation of the Hilton Hotel and hospitalizing 32 people, including six firefighters and four police officers.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I bought a bottle of minced garlic in oil and have been using it. I find it tastes bitter and should be used only in cooking. What is your experience?

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: For Mrs. Reagan and Prince Charles, a Busy Day
description: Nancy Reagan arrived in New York yesterday afternoon to keep a date today with Prince Charles of Britain.

title: New Unit Created For Executive
description: The Marketing Corporation of America, Westport, Conn., has created a new unit especially for the man it has to run it. The unit is called the MCA Marketing Group, and its managing director is Morgan V. Hunter, who resigned last November from the Scott Paper Company.

title: Advertising; Radio Ads Win Praise From Users
description: THE highlight of the 14th annual Association of National Advertisers/Radio Advertising Bureau Workshop yesterday - not counting Stan Freberg, the luncheon speaker -was the customary I Love Radio session, featuring six advertiser representatives or agency people citing their successes with the medium.

title: LEGISTALTORS FIND WHAT IT IS LIKE TO BE DISABLED Assemblyman Jose E. Serrano
description: A group of state legislators took part in a sensitivity project here today to experience the absence of sight, hearing and mobility in the hope that they might better understand the problems of New York's disabled.

title: TFI COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $54,000 for the latest first qr and $70,000 for the previous first qr

title: Economic Scene; Disengaging From OPEC
description: WASHINGTON FOR consumers, the widely heralded 1981 oil glut might not seem an event of much consequence. It's comforting, of course, not to have to worry about gas lines as vacation plans are made and its nice, too, to note that gasoline prices, instead of rising as the summer driving season approaches, are edging down.

title: COOKS FROM UPSTAIRS AT WORK DOWNSTAIRS
description: Susan Goodman is a freelance writer living in London. By SUSAN GOODMAN

title: President to Reshuffle Press Secretary's Office
description: President Reagan is planning to formally reshuffle the office of the White House press secretary pending the return of James S. Brady, the press secretary who was wounded in the head in the attempt on Mr. Reagan's life March 30.

title: Around the Nation; Evidence Found by Victim Of Theft Ruled Admissible
description: A burglary victim's right to recover his property through a private search supersedes the need for a search warrant in obtaining evidence, the California Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Market Place; Sunbeam's Dull Image
description: SUNBEAM, the world's largest maker of small household appliances, has had a static earnings record for the last four years. But that may change. Some analysts expect the company to report record earnings for its fiscal year ending next March 31.

title: Harlem Dancers to Appear At the Royal Opera House
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London, from July 27 through Aug. 8. The first black company to appear at the Royal Opera House, the 34-member troupe will present a repertory of 15 works. The Covent Garden engagement will end a tour that will take the company to the Festival of Two Worlds, in Spoleto, Italy, July 9-12, and to Jerusalem, July 15 to 21.

title: The U.N. Today; June 17, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaint by Iraq at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Around The nation; Member of Jamaican Cult Acquitted on Drug Charge
description: One of 11 members of a Jamaica-based cult being tried on drug conspiracy charges was acquitted and another had her case postponed by a Federal district judge late today.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $39,000 loss for the qr and $327,000 income for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $325,000 for the qr and $934,000 for the yr, $242,000 or 3 cents a shr nonrecurring gai for the yr from the sale of securities and $294,000 or 4 cents shr gain for the yr from the sale of real estate investments

title: FEW PLACES FOR VENTURES CAPITAL
description: The venture capital business is booming, but Paul M. Wythes, a partner in Sutter Hill Ventures of California, is not all that happy about it.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: 1980 results have been restated to reflect a change to LIFO accounting

title: The Economy
description: Housing starts dropped 14 percent in May, to a seasonally adjusted rate of 1.15 million units, the Commerce Department reported. The level was the lowest since the 938,000 units begun last May during the bottom of last year's recession. Analysts said the slump would last as long as interest rates remained high. (Page D1.)

title: COUNCIL IN NAMIBIA FINDS WHITES' GRIP STILL STRONG
description: West Africa, June 13 - It may seem a trivial sidelight on a subject of intense diplomatic interest, but when a high-level United States State Department mission arrived here to discuss the ever-receding prospect of this country's transformation into the independent nation of Namibia, it landed at an airport still named after the last unabashed white supremacist to serve as South Africa's Prime Minister.

title: ICE CREAM MAKERS
description: Ordinarily, even on the hottest, muggiest day, I would use one ice cream maker at a time. But as Craig Claiborne and I prepared the ice cream and sherbet recipes that appear on Page 6 of this issue the other day, the volume and variety of the work led us to call three into service. Two of these - the trusty White Mountain and the Champion juicer (a strange and superb machine that can produce ice cream as well as ices) - have been well known to me for some time and I have often described and praised them before.

title: PICK YOUR OWN BERRIES
description: This is the time of year when the farmers play Tom Sawyer. They persuade passers-by to help with the harvest - and pay for the privilege. But unlike whitewashing the fence, ''pick your own'' is mutually beneficial. The consumer who does his own picking pays less for the freshest produce and enjoys an outing, while a number of labor-intensive fruits and vegetables are gathered from the fields without adding to the farmer's payroll.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL 'EL BRAVO'
description: ''EL BRAVO,'' the new musical that opened at the Entermedia last night, has only one idea in its head: it wants to transplant the saga of Robin Hood to the Hispanic precincts of present-day New York. If that isn't an idea to make the heart sing, neither is it necessarily a prescription for disaster. As such current shows as ''Annie'' and ''The Pirates of Penzance'' attest, fairy-tale musicals can still thrive in the era of ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Evita.''

title: Michael Spinks Will Seek Mustafa Muhammad Title
description: Michael Spinks, who is undefeated, will challenge Eddie Mustafa Muhammad for the World Boxing Association light-heavyweight championship, Butch Lewis, a boxing promoter, announced yesterday.

title: WEBB CORP. TO SELL CASINO INTERESTS IN JERSEY BECAUSE OF LICENSE TO FIGHT
description: With a $150 million casino-hotel newly built and ready to open in Atlantic City, the Del E. Webb Corporation, the largest casino operator in the country, pulled out of New Jersey today under the cloud of a Federal indictment in Nevada charging criminal conspiracy.

title: NUTRITIONAL REQUIREMENTS OF THE ELDERLY
description: The nutritional needs of Americans who are over 65 years old - and there are more than 25 million of them, according to the Bureau of the Census -were the subject of a day-long conference last week at the New York Academy of Medicine. Some 150 authorities on geriatrics called for more research into the subject and better coordination of government and private programs.

title: WHEN IT'S HOT, EAT COOL
description: WHERE desserts are concerned, almost everyone I know is guilty of succumbing to one alluring vice or another. By ''vice'' I mean something sweet that is irresistible enough to offer sinful temptation, something that would arouse greed in an otherwise welltempered appetite; something to be indulged in without restraint, diets be damned.

title: Arbitration Hearing Opens On Riggins Pay Grievance
description: John Riggins, the Washington Redskins' fullback, presented his case today seeking a year's pay from the club, even though he sat out last season after walking out of training camp.

title: Driver Goes Off Ferry In Reverse and Drowns
description: The driver of the last vehicle in line on a Staten Island ferryboat drowned yesterday morning after accidentally putting his automobile in reverse at the St. George slip and sending it into the harbor.

title: 150,000 DEFY HEAT TO HEAR 'TOSCA' IN CENTRAL PARK
description: If the streets of Manhattan seemed a little empty last night, most of the missing were probably in the middle of Central Park listening to the Metropolitan Opera's concert performance of ''Tosca.'' Police estimates of last night's gathering on the Great Lawn ranged from 150,000 to 200,000; there were people as far as the eye could see, and then more people beyond that.

title: THE KREMLIN VS. LIZA AND ALEKSEY
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Good of The Game
description: Having lost intimate contact with baseball since the Giants and Dodgers were moved to California, I was baffled by the intricacies behind the baseball strike and sought out a scribe to clarify matters. I was referred to one Peregrine Pouter.

title: Kennedy Center Honorees Being Recorded on Tape
description: The Warner Communications Program for the Arts has awarded a three-year grant of $75,000 to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts to establish a videotape archive documenting the careers and achievements of artists who have been awarded the Kennedy Center Honors.

title: BRITISH PENSION FUND SEEKS U.S. REIT
description: The Connecticut General Mortgage and Realty Investment Trust, one of the nation's largest and most successful real estate investment trusts, was the object of a surprise takeover bid yesterday by the pension fund of the British coal miners' union.

title: TV: 'AMERICAN ODYSSEY,' A JOURNEY OF 3 RUNNERS
description: ''AMERICAN ODYSSEY,'' which goes on at 8 P.M. today on WNET-TV, Channel 13, is about three young West Coasters who traveled from this coast back to theirs taking every opportunity to flex their muscles. In this mind-wearying, body-building epoch, it is sure to evoke viewer admiration, at least from viewers who value physical fitness.

title: FURTHER DELAY ON TAX BILL SEEN WITH WRITE-OFFS UNDER ATTACK
description: Liberal Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee, who have already rejected President Reagan's proposal of tax relief for individuals, said today that they would also oppose the President on tax relief for business.

title: Turkey's Security Forces Report Capture of 61 Extreme Leftists
description: Turkish security forces today captured 61 members of the illegal Revolutionary Communist Party, an extremist group, and seized a coded list of fictitious names of 247 other members, the police said.

title: A CONTROVERSY IS STIRRED BY CAREY'S HIRING OF AIDE
description: Governor Carey has hired a new special assistant for $48,000 a year who approached the state for employment through Mr. Carey's wife, Evangeline Gouletas-Carey. The appointment has stirred resentment among several of the Governor's key aides and advisers.

title: The City; New Law Expands Rights of Disabled
description: A bill updating and expanding the rights of handicapped people was signed into law by Mayor Koch. Mr. Koch presented the pen he used to sign the law in the Blue Room at City Hall to a young deaf woman in the front row. She had told the Mayor earlier, through a sign-language interpreter, that she was ''shocked to learn I couldn't be considered disabled unless I had a hearing aid.''

title: LOUIS SOLOMON
description: Louis Solomon, a television producer and writer, died of cancer last Friday in Southold, L.I. He was 70 years old. Mr. Solomon was coordinating producer of ''The Great American Dream Machine'' and wrote for a number of programs, including ''Wide, Wide World.''

title: Gain Reported At Bonwit's
description: The new Bonwit Teller flagship store on 57th Street in Manhattan has received ''excellent'' customer acceptance since its opening on April 26 and its sales ''are running well ahead of plan,'' Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer of the Allied Stores Corporation, Bonwit's parent company, told the annual meeting yesterday.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF THE PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC
description: AFFAIRS Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in the Executive Office Building in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: ITALIANS TO WIDEN MASONIC INQUIRY
description: Acting Prime Minister Arnaldo Forlani has ordered an investigation of all civil servants suspected of links to the Masonic lodge that is at the center of Italy's latest government crisis.

title: WIMBELDON SEEDINGS PROTESTED
description: The Women's Tennis Association strongly protested today the decision to seed Hana Mandlikova No. 2 for the Wimbledon tennis championships starting next Monday.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed in Feb 1981

title: CENSUS ENLIVENS QUEST FOR AN INDEPENDENT QUEBEC
description: Census Day in Canada was June 3 and its expected results have given Premier Rene Levesque of Quebec a new reason for wanting his largely French-speaking province to be independent.

title: IN PRAISE OF DEPRESSION
description: Recent scientific research tells us that people tend to suffer from depression when they think that things are going badly for them. It should not surprise us that this insight into the workings of the psyche is slightly less than trenchant, given past generations of ''mice'' coughed out by the scientific ''mountain.'' But an important question obtrudes: Considering the state of the world, why does science still consider depression an aberration? Don't these people read the newspapers?

title: HOUSING STARTS FELL 14% IN MAY
description: Under the weight of high interest rates, new housing starts plummeted 14 percent in May from the April level, the Commerce Department reported today, hitting the lowest newhousing level since May of last year, in the midst of the 1980 recession.

title: RIGHT TO COUNSEL BRINGS REVERSAL IN MURDER CASE
description: New York's highest court reversed a murder conviction yesterday, ruling that the police must ask certain suspects if they already have a lawyer before seeking to question them in a criminal investigation.

title: Around The World; Bulgarian Prime Minister Is Reported Replaced
description: Stanko Todorov was replaced today as Prime Minister of this Soviet Bloc nation, the state press agency B.T.A. said.

title: CHINA AND FRAGILITY
description: Despite a claim by a member of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s entourage in Peking that the Chinese had been ''all hearts and flowers'' in the brief but important talks, Mr. Haig's visit should be understood as part an attempt at crisis containment.

title: FLXIBLE BUSES MAY BE BACK IN JULY, ENGINEER ON M.T.A. PANEL PREDICTS
description: An engineer hired by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that the Grumman Flxible bus fleet could begin returning to New York City in ''the latter part of July.''

title: AFRICANS STRUGGLING FOR UNITY IN O.A.U.  Unity.
description: The Organization of African Unity is facing major financial and political tests that could determine its future.

title: Girl Drowns in Whirlpool Bath
description: A young girl drowned in a whirlpool bath because officials say her long hair got caught in the drain and the current of the swirling waters pulled her under. Michelle Ardis, 10 years old, drowned Sunday at the home of a friend in nearby Vidor, Texas.

title: EQUITY GOLD INC reports earnings for Yr to Feb 28
description: B-There are no yr-ago comparable figures since this is the company's first yr of operation; results are for the period from Mar 17, 1980 when the company was incorporated to Feb 28,

title: MICHIGANDER LANDS JOB AND PLANS ON BEING A TEXAN
description: ''Well ma, I got the job,'' Robert Wahrenbrock said, sounding a little like a telephone commercial. ''Start the week after next.''

title: 37% OF BLACKS FOUND IN FAVOR OF LOWER WAGE FLOOR
description: Although black Americans generally continue to endorse liberal programs, more than a third of them support an idea advanced by political conservatives that a lower minimum wage would benefit the black community, according to a survey of black opinion released yesterday.

title: Darling, Yale Pitcher, Gets $100,000 Ranger Bonus
description: Ron Darling, who lost the last game he pitched for Yale, even though he had a no-hitter through 11 innings, signed a contract with the Texas Rangers of the American League today for an estimated $100,000 bonus.

title: Taking No Chances in Applying to Medical School
description: She earlier received her bachelor's degree in psychology summa cum laude and was a Phi Beta Kappa at Queens College. title: PHILARMONIC: WAGNER AND STRAUSS
description: KURT MAZUR, who made his New York Philharmonic debut last night leading an all - German program in the ''Romantic Era'' series at Avery Fisher Hall, is a superior example of the good Kapellmeister type that a generation or so ago was not hard to find in Central Europe. The Silesian musician does not go in for particularly fancy effects, either sonically or interpretatively, but on this occasion, at least, he had the Philharmonic playing with uncommon precision and fullness of tone. title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A young attorney had been suffering from recurrent headaches ever since graduating from law school. Most often, it seemed, the headaches occurred on Sunday when he should have been enjoying a day off and relaxing in advance of the work week to come. But what he was really doing on Sunday was worrying about his ability to perform well in court, where he had to appear nearly every Monday. His anxiety caused him to tense the muscles in the back of his neck and scalp, precipitating one of America's most common afflictions -a tension headache.

title: Baseball Notebook;          Foster Makes Big League Hits
description: Glenn Sample, the baseball coach at the University of Cincinnati, is also the official scorer for the National League at Reds games. During the baseball strike, he agreed to let the major leaguers use some of the equipment at the school to work out at Nippert Stadium. A lot of players declined for fear of getting hurt, but George Foster showed up for yesterday's workout along with Dan Driessen, Dave Concepcion, Ron Oester and Ken Griffey. Pete Rose of the Phillies, who lives in Cincinnati, was there on Monday but absent yesterday. ''Foster hit some that are still rolling out in the stadium,'' said Sample. ''It's 345 feet down the left-field line at the field and 365 feet down the right-field line. It's a bigger park than Riverfront Stadium.'' Foster, who was batting .297 and tied with Dave Kingman and Mike Schmidt for the league lead in home runs with 14 when the strike hit, said, ''It's important to be ready all the time. You're able to stay physically ready, but the mental part is more difficult.'' Sample doesn't mind chasing the balls and he also lets his players throw batting practice. ''It's a thrill for the college players,'' said Sample. ''It's like you are a scientist and Albert Einstein comes in and says hello.'' If the baseball strike is not over by Friday, Steven Freifeld, first grade teacher at the Marion Street School in Lynbrook, L.I., is in big trouble. ''Read 150 books by June and I'll treat you to a Yankee game,'' Mr. Freifeld told his 23 students last January in an effort to spur them to good reading habits. Eleven completed the assignment and 7-year-old Christine Miller plowed through 259. So Mr. Freifeld kept his part of the bargain by arranging a trip to Yankee Stadium for Friday, the last day of school, and he even arranged with the Yankees to flash a message on the scoreboard paying tribute to ''Lynbrook Marion Street First Graders, All-Star Readers.'' Yesterday, however, the teacher said he was finding it hard to explain to first graders the complexities of free-agent contracts. ''One child said he'd kill me or kill the Yankees,'' said Mr. Freifeld. ''I told them we'd go to a movie instead. I'm still hoping for a short strike.'' The strains of ''Take Me Out To the Ball Game,'' ''Orioles Magic'' and ''Wild Bill's Fight Song'' could still be heard on the jukebox at the Olympic Lounge in Memorial Stadium in Baltimore Monday night. That's because Wild Bill Hagy and other diehard Orioles fans were determined not to let the strike stand in the way of their postgame drinking and revelry. Hagy is the Birds' self-appointed cheerleader, who gained fame from his right-field seat in the 1979 World Series. As ''Wild Bill's Fight Song'' explains in its country music fashion: ''They had no one to lead their cheers until Wild Bill had too many beers.'' And Monday night he was leading an anti-strike party, originally scheduled to be held after the game the Orioles were supposed to play against the Texas Rangers. ''It's the fans who pay the bill,'' said Hagy. ''I think we should have a voice and that's why we're calling this anti-strike rally.'' The Mets announced yesterday that the weekend series between their Tidewater Class AAA affiliate in the International League and the Yankee-affiliated Columbus Clippers in Norfolk, Va., would be broadcast over WMCA in New York, Saturday night (7:30) Sunday (2 P.M.) and Monday night (7:30). The Mets regular broadcasters - Bob Murphy, Ralph Kiner, Steve Albert and Art Shamsky - will handle the play by play, but the club didn't say which ones would be making the trip. The Tides, currently in Toledo, are two games behind firstplace Columbus. ''We were preparing for the weekend, so I guess we have about 120,000 frankfurters in the refrigerator right now, plus beer and ice cream, which will hold for a couple of weeks at least,'' said Larry Kieran, manager of the Harry M. Stevens catering service at Shea Stadium. The Stevens people also handle the Astrodome in Houston, Fenway Park in Boston and Candlestick Park in San Francisco. They say they don't make enough in their other operations at the race tracks, Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands or Madison Square Garden to make up the slack. Then there is the problem of the scorecards that were printed up and delivered for the games over the weekend. They are not good anymore, but they will probably bring 10 times their face value at some baseball collectors' shows in the future. It's hard to tell how much the Mets are losing in revenue. Last year's attendance was 1,178,000, the second worst in the club's history. This year's attendance of 349,474 after 25 home games was slightly improved over last year's 225,569 at the same point. But at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, where crowds of 50,000 a game are not uncommon, it is estimated that the Dodgers are losing $225,000 per game.

title: To cool off hottest day.                 ON THE HOTTEST DAY OF '81, THE MERCURY RISES TO 93
description: If some like it hot, they were not saying so yesterday, the hottest day of the year, and many were downright uncomplimentary about the accompanying smog and humidity. The temperature in Manhattan rose to a high of 93 degrees at 2:40 P.M., and the temperature-humidity index of 86 at 2 P.M. matched the highest reading for all of last summer. ''Comfort is shot,'' one meteorologist said. From a distance, Manhattan seemed in the morning to be a city packed for shipping, engulfed in gray textured air. Weather experts said the condition was caused by a temperature inversion - a condition in which the air at higher altitudes is hotter than below, acting as a lid on pollution. Then the Sun Came Out Ozone and carbon monoxide levels were high throughout the city, and the State Department of Environmental Conservation issued a recommendation that those with respiratory problems reduce activity. Some of the smog cleared by midday, revealing the sun not to be a 15-watt light bulb, after all. But temperatures climbed to new high points for the year throughout the New York metropolitan area, including high readings of 97 in Newark and 89 in White Plains, the United States Weather Service reported. Cool ocean breezes gave some relief to shore communities and most of Long Island, but air movement on the streets of Manhattan proved as refreshing as a blast from a 1,400-watt hair blower. Even those profiting from the mugginess complained. ''What good is getting rich if you die of the heat?'' asked Paul Ramirez, a street vendor who was doing a land-office business in sodas and Italian ices on the Avenue of the Americas. Fans Are a Hot Item Sales of air-conditioners and fans were up predictably at stores throughout the metropolitan area. Sandals and perforated oxfords and slip-ons were ''selling like mad'' at the Bellmore Bootery in Bellmore, L.I. At the McDonald's in Tarrytown, N.Y., customers began what manager Andy Campbell said was a perennial seasonal change: ordering less to eat and more to drink. Mr. Campbell said another way he knew that summer had unofficially arrived was that he had to begin policing the ''No Shirt-No Shoes-No Service'' regulation. The Island Recreational store in Central Islip, L.I., was doing an extraordinary business in above-ground swimming pools and swimming pool supplies, according to the manager, Kevin Claeson. And those who own swimming pools went on the alert for attempts by slight acquaintances to invite themselves over. Municipal pools throughout the suburban area were unusually busy. Officials in New York City, where the pools have not yet opened, said they were worried that people would open fire hydrants despite a prohibition in the water-conservation program, submerging the program. Too Hot for Firemen The city had crews of maintenance workers on patrol, looking for open hydrants. ''Spray caps'' have been installed on about 1,000 city hydrants, to let some water come out, but only a fraction of the million gallons a day that would otherwise gush forth. In the Bronx, firemen suffering from heat exhaustion called in extra crews to help battle a blaze that engulfed 12 stores at Longwood and Westchester Avenues. In the evening, commuters -many with ties loosened and jackets over their arms - made their way to parking garages, subways, trains and buses with trepidation, facing a sultry trip home on the hottest day of the year.
