description: The temperature was in the 90's, the humidity was 89 percent, and the only concession Tom Watson made to the weather today was to wear a sun visor, for him as unusual a piece of headgear as the tasseled tam he sometimes wears in the British Open.

title: President of Texaco Unit
description: C. Robert Black, 45, has been named president of Texaco International Trader Inc., a major subsidiary of Texaco Inc. based in Harrison, N.Y. He succeeds Willis R. Buck, who died last month at the age of 53.

title: Yanks' Staff Sent to Minors
description: Manager Gene Michael of the Yankees and his entire coaching staff were assigned to minor league instructional duties yesterday until the players' strike is over. Michael will work with the club's Class AAA farm club in Columbus, Ohio, where he was manager two years ago.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick Rinehart, 78, Led Publishing Houses
description: Frederick Roberts Rinehart, a former book publisher who in recent years was president of the Mary Roberts Rinehart Foundation, died Monday at the age of 78.

title: Wometco Ends Joint Venture
description: Wometco Enterprises Inc., a diversified Miami-based company with operations including television broadcasting, cable TV, Coca-Cola bottling, automatic vending and entertainment, announced that it had terminated its joint venture with Universal Subscription Television Inc. of Burlingame, Calif., to operate the Wometco Home Theatre of New York, WWHT-TV in Newark and WSNL-TV in Smithtown, L.I.

title: SOUPS: SUMMER REFRESHER COURSES
description: AT one time, the way to impress dinner guests was to serve cold soup and a hot dessert. Now cold soups are no longer a novelty and frequently add their appeal to a hot-weather menu.

title: Hard Hat Outlaws
description: ''These are a bunch of wise guys who threaten our members,'' said a Manhattan construction worker after 100 of his colleagues had attacked 60 members of a group called Black Economic Survival and vandalized its bus. ''They can't get away with it here,'' the worker added.

title: Humana Net Rises 37.4%
description: Humana Inc., an operator of short-term acute-care community hospitals, reported yesterday that earnings for its third fiscal quarter, ended May 31, rose 37.4 percent, to $25.7 million, or 65 cents a share, from $18.7 million, or 45 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenues climbed 21.7 percent, to $446 million from $366.5 million. Last year's per-share figure was adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split that was distributed on Feb. 2.

title: Fleet Leader Drops Out Of Ocean Race to Newport
description: Kialoa, the leader of the fleet, dropped out of the Annapolis-Newport ocean race last night because, Jim Kilroy, the owner, said, ''We were going backwards and I like to go forwards.''

title: TIME TO ABANDON THE FLAT-FARE TRANSIT RIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Monetary Role Eludes P.L.O.
description: The Palestine Liberation Orgnization has been barred from the joint annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund next fall, but the I.M.F. left the door open for further talks.

title: CUBS ON THE FIELD: A LOSING PROPOSITION
description: ''Will the lady who lost her nine children at the Cubs' park please pick them up immediately. They are beating the Cubs, 10-0, in the seventh.''

title: I.B.M. Reduces Computer Prices
description: The International Business Machines Corporation cut its prices on a line of small business computers by 20 to 25 percent. The company said the price of the two least expensive models of its system 34 computers was being reduced by $5,000, from original prices of $20,310 and $22,090, respectively.

title: IF IRAQ HAD NUCLEAR WEAPONS
description: To the Editor:

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
F.D.A. CHECKS ORANGE JUICE
description: The Food and Drug Administration is expected to complete within 60 days an investigation of charges that some products sold as orange juice are really made from orange pulp, a spokesman said today.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Backs Houston Effort To Desegregate Its Schools
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Houston Independent School District had done its best to achieve racial balance and refused to order further desegregation efforts.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DOW CLOSES AT 1,0006.56, UP 3.23
description: Stock prices ended slightly higher in slower trading yesterday with some of the recently depressed energy-related and technology issues posting the best gains.

title: COSMOS 2-1 WINNERS ON CHINAGLIA'S GOAL
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who scored only once, from a penalty kick, in the previous three games, scored the winning goal tonight as the Cosmos beat the Washington Diplomats, 2-1.

title: Home Beat
description: IT'S a triple celebration for Thos. K. Woodard American Antiques & Quilts. It's owners, Thomas Woodard, near left, and Blanche Greenstein have moved the shop to 835 Madison Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets, where a show of small quilts coincides with the early copies of their book, ''Crib Quilts and Other Small Wonders'' (E.P. Dutton, $15.75 in paperback, $29.95 in hardcover).

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $198,000 of charges and legal expenses in excess of res in settlement of litigation...C-Net income

title: JUSTICES GIVE BROAD READING TO U.S. RACKETEERING LAW
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Justice Department's broad interpretation of the Federal antiracketeering law, ruling that the law is not limited to the prosecution of criminal organizations that take over or infiltrate legitimate businesses.

title: Business People; RATING CONCERN NAMES CHIEF OF OPERATIONS
description: Charles W. Moritz, 44, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, effective July 1. He will succeed Harrington Drake, 61, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: SIMPLER MARGIN RULES PROPOSED
description: The Federal Reserve Board agreed today to take a first step toward revising and simplifying rules that govern the buying of securities on margin.

title: WESTINGHOUSE SUIT SETTLEMENT
description: PITTSBURGH June 17 (AP) -The Westinghouse Electric Corportion said it had reached an out-of-court settlement with the last of 29 defendants in a five-year-old uranium antitrust suit.

title: Racing Inquiry Planned
description: The State Racing and Wagering Board plans to announce today that it will begin public hearings next Wednesday into ''allegations of corrupt practices at New York State thoroughbred race tracks in 1974 and 1975.''

title: WINTERTHUR: MORE MUSEUM THAN HOUSE
description: THE house-museum is a special breed of cultural artifact, not quite a house, and not quite a museum, either. It has neither the sense of domesticity of a true residence nor the air of a Great Institution that so many museums possess. It is something oddly in between.

title: Helpful Hardware; NEW BICYCLE ACCESSORIES
description: THERE are several new products that make bicycle riding easier and safer. The McNeill-Favia Company has manufactured the Pack & Pedal, a water-resistant bag that can be used as saddlebag, briefcase and shoulder tote.

title: Wilson D. McCarthy, Who Served Presidents Kennedy and Johnson
description: Wilson D. McCarthy, a former aide to President Kennedy, died Friday night of a heart attack in Guelph, Ontario. He was 50 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions of The Times yesterday incorrectly stated the number of doctors represented by the National Medical Association. The organization represents about 9,300 of the nation's black physicians.

title: A BREUER RETROSPECTIVE OF DESIGNS TO OPEN JULY 25
description: ''Marcel Breuer: Furniture and Interiors,'' a retrospective showing the range, scope and impact of that architect's interior designs and furniture, will open July 25 at the Museum of Modern Art. The exhibition, to remain on view through Sept. 15, is the third in the museum's series on important 20th-century designers.

title: AGAIN, WHY CONGRESS BARRED BRIBERY ABROAD
description: Judging from the debate over proposals to water down the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act of 1977, the Congress has forgotten just why it forbade the bribery of foreign government officials by United States corporations and required internal accounting controls adequate to ensure that such illegal payments would not be made.

title: U.S. AND PEKING JOIN IN TRACKING MISSILES IN SOVIET
description: The United States and China are jointly operating an electronic intelligence-gathering station in China to monitor Soviet missile tests, according to senior American officials.

title: ABROAD AT HOME
description: The security of Israel, in the most basic sense of survival, is the reason repeatedly given by Prime Minister Begin for the raid on Iraq's nuclear reactor. He argues that an enemy sworn to destroy Israel was about to acquire the means to make atomic bombs. And he says the usual deterrent, fear of retaliation, would not work in the case of Iraq because its leader, Saddam Hussein, is a ''meshuganah,'' a crazy man.

title: Around the Nation; Klan Chief Reportedly Bans Confrontations With Police
description: Legal expenses have caused the Ku Klux Klan such financial difficulties that Imperial Wizard Bill Wilkinson has issued a secret order banning confrontations with the police, a newspaper reported today.

title: RCA Releasing Show Albums
description: RCA Red Seal will release this month the first two albums in a planned series of hits from original Broadway cast performances that it has recorded. Under the title ''Opening Nights,'' the first two volumes will offer selections from shows of the 1960's and 70's, including ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' ''Carousel,'' ''Kismet,'' ''The King and I,'' ''Oklahoma!'' and ''Sweeney Todd.''

title: State Racing Told: Prove Need for Aid
description: A joint legislative task force studying the racing industry concluded today that the state should not provide financial assistance to the New York Racing Association for capital improvements at its tracks until the association proved that the improvements were needed and showed by how much handle and attendance would increase as a result.

title: PACIFIC COAST PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including $1,161,000 or 8 cents a shr net gain

title: STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $62,000 or 5 cents a shr for the qr and $250,000 or 20 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: Soviet Says Output Is Up
description: Soviet industrial output in this year's first five months was 3.2 percent above a year before, while meat production declined seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today. Productivity was reported 2.5 percent higher.

title: AMERICAN CRAFT MUSEUM SHOWS 5 ARTISTS AT WORK studio
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Roslyn Siegel is a freelance writer who writes frequently about crafts. By ROSLYN SIEGEL

title: Article 161425 -- No Title
description: A 155-year-old leatherbound book of John James Audubon's bird illustrations, valued at $250,000, has been stolen from a library here, the police said. Thieves broke into the Peabody Institute Library, a city facility, through a back window last night and escaped with ''Birds of America,'' a three-inch thick, 100-pound book of color lithographs by the naturalist-artist.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Congress itself defined the basic relationship between costs and benefits, by placing the 'benefit' of worker health above all other considerations save those making attainment of this 'benefit' unachievable.

title: Market Place; HOLLY SUGAR AND DISSIDENTS;  THE future direction of the Holly Sugar Corporation may be decided at the annual meeting a week from tomorrow at Colorado Springs, the company's headquarters.
description: For a year and a half, a dissident group led by Michael S. Buchsbaum has been critical of management. The group, Arcanum One, owns 80,000 Holly shares, or 5.05 percent of the total outstanding. It recently mounted a proxy contest whereby it hopes to seat its own board of directors.

title: Record $500,000 Is Paid For a Trotting Yearling
description: Boardwalk Chappie, whose sire and dam finished 1-2 in the 1972 Hambletonian, has been sold for $500,000, a record for a standardbred yearling.

title: FACTORY USE UP SLIGHTLY IN MAY
description: The nation's manufacturers operated at 80.1 percent of capacity in May, the highest level in 13 months but only one-tenth of a percentage point higher than April's factory use, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CBS-TV 'DEFENSE' SERIES GETS HIGH NIELSEN RATINGS
description: In its first two episodes, last Sunday and Monday nights, the CBS-TV five-part documentary ''The Defense of the United States'' won the networks' ratings battle in the 10-to-11 P.M. time period, scoring unusually high for a news program.

title: Technology; Treating PCB's With Chemicals
description: atom and a chlorine atom THESE days, there are frequently several ways in theory to solve a technical problem, but only a select few that have won approval from the relevant regulatory agency. Take, for example, the problem of how to handle PCB's, the hazardous chemical compounds that have shown up everywhere from river beds to chickens.

title: A.T.&T. RISES 10.8% IN QUARTER WITH RECORD NET OF $1.62 BILLION
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the world's largest corporation, reported yesterday that it had record quarterly net income of $1.62 billion in the three months ended May 31, up 10.8 percent from the same period a year ago.

title: NAZI HORROR HAUNTS SECOND GENERATION
description: ''It's like there's a rock inside of me.'' The young woman, Charlene Bradin, leaned forward intently as she spoke. And the other children of Holocaust survivors, sitting in a circle, were suspended on her words.

title: Topic; SCHOOL GATES NEW DIGS; Left Back
description: In a welcome break with the past, Schools Chancellor Macchiarola wants to stop social promotions - moving students from one grade to the next regardless of performance.

title: Notes On People; Changes in The Daily News's Afternoon Edition
description: Clay Felker will relinquish day-to-day editorial control of Daily News Tonight, and the editorial content of the 10-month-old afternoon edition of The Daily News will be reduced, according to an announcement by the paper.

title: Fans Will Be Fans at Park or Hotel Lobby
description: At the Doral Inn in Manhattan yesterday, Marian Quigley stood wide-eyed behind the check-in desk, grateful for the barrier that separated her from the throngs of photographers and celebrity-seekers waiting in the lobby for a glimpse of the negotiators in the baseball strike.

title: A FISTFIGHT ERUPTS AT AFRICAN PARLEY
description: Moroccan diplomats and representatives of the Polisario guerrilla group, which is fighting for independence for the Moroccan-held Western Sahara, exchanged blows this morning at a conference hall here.

title: Execution Date Passes; Judge Then Issues Stay
description: A convicted murderer, James William White, was supposed to die by lethal injection Monday but there was no execution. Late yesterday a judge issued a stay, saying that the problem had been partly caused by an error in the computer records.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JUNE 18, 1981; The Economy
description: The Supreme Court upheld standards limiting worker exposure to cotton dust, rejecting industry contentions that regulatory costs must be balanced against benefits and dealing a blow to the Reagan Administration's antiregulation agenda. (Page A1.) Textile executives expressed disappointment with the ruling. (D5.) The court also upheld a Federal law allowing safety inspectors to conduct surprise inspections of mines and quarries without warrants. (B9.)

title: Chinese Squad Dominates In U.S. Open Table Tennis
description: China dominated today on the first day of the United States Open table tennis tournament in Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: GUNMAN AND 3 KILLED IN ROCHESTER
description: A gunman firing at random killed three persons - including his mother - wounded seven and held several employees hostage in a bank for two hours today before the police shot him to death, authorities said.

title: BAKER ENDS EFFORT TO BAR SOCIAL ISSUES
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, conceded today that he could no longer hold off the intrusion of such social issues as abortion and school busing into the midst of debates on the budget.

title: Renault-Volvo Deal
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, the French state-owned auto maker, and a Volvo subsidiary signed an agreement today for Volvo dealers to distribute Renault cars in Denmark, Norway and Sweden, Renault said.

title: JEW ON TRIAL FOR ANTI-SOVIET 'FABRICATION'
description: Viktor Brailovsky, one of Moscow's leading Jewish activists until his arrest last November, went on trial in Moscow today charged with ''circulation of fabrications known to be false, which defame the Soviet state and social system.''

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
No Headline
description: Miss Navratilova Advances at Eastbourne

title: HAIG IN PHILIPPINES TO DISCUSS VIETNAMESE ACTIONS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. arrived here today from Peking saying that he had come to consult with Southeast Asian foreign ministers on ''the dangerous activities of Vietnam with the encouragement and with the support of the Soviet Union.''

title: A.&P. LOSS IN QUARTER IS $10.4 MILLION
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company reported yesterday that it had a $10.4 million net loss for the first fiscal quarter ended May 30 and cited price wars in major Eastern cities. But the loss was less severe than the $15 million net loss reported for the first quarter of 1980.

title: U.S. SAYS IT WASN'T SURE IRAQ SOUGHT ATOMIC ARMS
description: Under Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. said today that while the Reagan Administration had been ''concerned'' about Iraq's nuclear program, it had not concluded that Iraq was seeking to develop an atomic bomb.

title: Retail Beef Prices Unchanged
description: Retail beef prices nationwide were unchanged on average in early June as compared with May, the National Cattlemen's Association reported today.

title: Practice Over, the Pros Brace for the Open
description: Practice, as Jack Nicklaus said, ''is not the United States Open,'' and all the rounds that have been played the last few days on the Merion Golf Club have ''no resemblance to tomorrow.''

title: 2 Guards, 1 From Queens, Recruited by Willis Reed
description: Willis Reed, the new Creighton University basketball coach, has successfully recruited his first two players, both point guards.

title: DOMINICA COUP PLOT DESCRIBED TO COURT
description: A grandiose plan to invade the small island nation of Dominica, overthrow its Government and set up profitable industries, including a cocaine-processing plant, is unfolding in Federal District Court this week as a prosecutor questions Government witnesses.

title: PUERTO RICAN HANDICAP
description: To the Editor:

title: GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to May
SHUTTLE PLAQUE GIVEN TO SPANISH KING
description: John W. Young, at right, commander of the first orbital shuttle flight, presenting commemorative plaque to King Juan Carlos in Madrid.

title: DISCOUNT BROKERAGE FIRMS AGREE TO MERGE
description: Charles Schwab & Company, the country's largest discount brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Kingsley, Boye & Southwood, another discount broker. No price was disclosed for the merger of the two privately held firms.

title: JURY CHOICE TO BE DIFFICULT FOR LENNON TRIAL DEFENSE
description: When jury selection begins next Monday in the murder trial of Mark David Chapman, his lawyer will confront the same problem faced by attorneys for defendants in other widely publicized cases.

title: News Analysis
description: The announcement by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. that he had given up efforts to keep legislation on busing, abortion and other social issues off the Senate floor may imperil a prize Republicans hold dearer than President Reagan's economic program: attaining majority status in the nation.

title: There's No Ducking a Transit Tax Now
description: Thanks to the timely ruling of a Federal appellate court, New York has been given what should be an irresistible push to pass a legal and adequate transit subsidy tax. The court's decision has left metropolitan transit with an unambiguous deficit of at least $400 million, only $150 million of which will be covered by the expected fare increase on July 1. If the law struck down in court is not replaced by a new tax, subway and bus fares will have to go not to 75 cents but to at least $1 next month, with a comparable increase in commuter fares.

title: HOW A LONDON FIRM DESIGNED ITS SUCCESS team
description: When Tessa Kennedy and Michael Sumner set up shop as interior designers in 1968 they had no money, no customers and little experience. Today they are among London's most successful designers. Kennedy-Sumner projects include a new 450-foot yacht owned by the Greek shipowner Stavros Niarchos, the airport in the Persian Gulf sheikdom of Qatar and 14 small hospitals for the British United Provident Association.

title: TV SPONSOR'S GUIDELINES CALLED 'CONSERVATIVE'
description: Procter & Gamble, which this week revealed that it had withdrawn sponsorship from 50 television programs this season, did so on the basis of detailed standards that assess a show's socially redeeming value, whether it is likely to encourage antisocial behavior and whether depictions of sex and violence were gratuitous rather than clearly motivated.

title: Texaco Plans Tests To Lift Oil Output
description: Texaco Inc. said it would test a ''chemical-flood'' technique to increase production from an Illinois oilfield that began production in 1938.

title: YOUNG MILLIONAIRE'S NEW GOAL
description: One day in 1978, Jeff Carter's accountant called. ''You made it,'' he said. At the age of 26, Mr. Carter had become a millionaire - four years ahead of the schedule he had set for himself, and just 12 years after he vowed, as an eighth grader in Odessa, Tex., wearing other families' hand-me-downs, that he would never be poor again.

title: Reagan Accused of Overstating Social Security System's Woes
description: Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, accused the Reagan Administration yesterday of overstating the need for drastic action to save the Social Security System from bankruptcy and thus eroding public confidence in the retirement program.

title: GAIN FOR DENG SEEN IN TALKS WITH HAIG
description: Long-delayed meetings of the Communist Party leadership were reliably reported to be under way today, and Deng Xiaoping, the Chinese leader, is expected to tell them what Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said here yesterday: that Chinese-American relations are stronger than ever and continuing to improve.

title: HOW TO TAKE CARE OF FINE MAHOGANY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: TEXAS AIR BID FAILS TO HALT A STOCK PLAN
description: A Federal judge in Los Angeles yesterday rejected a second request by Texas International Airlines for an injunction to stop an employee stock-ownership plan at Continental Air Lines from proceeding.

title: CITY OPERA SERIES ON PUBLIC RADIO
description: In a series of 13 broadcasts, performances by the New York City Opera are being heard on public radio stations nationwide.

title: MAINE CENTRAL ACQUIRED
description: Timothy Mellon, a member of the Mellon banking family of Pittsburgh, has completed his acquisition of the Maine Central Railroad at an undisclosed price. Mr. Mellon, 38 years old, met today with railroad officials in Portland to confirm the purchase and his intention to retain current management, Bradley L. Peters, the railroad's vice president, said. Maine Central will be a subsidiary of Guilford Transportation Industries.

title: Advertising; Marathon Marketer
description: RICHARD E. CREMER, the newly named Direct Marketer of the Year, is a pioneer in the field of Multivariate Linear Regression Analysis. Don't let that turn you off.

title: BALLET: 'BEAUTY'S DESIGN
description: OVERALL design rather than individual detail is the strength of ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' as presented by the Royal Ballet this season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Westinghouse in Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. have reached an agreement to develop jointly an advanced pressurized water nuclear power reactor, Mitsubishi said today.

title: PRINCE CHARLES PAYS A QUICK VISIT TO CITY
description: Prince Charles, the heir to the British throne, visited New York for the first time yesterday and was welcomed with all of the panoply usually accorded a head of state.

title: AMERICAN ISRAELI PAPER MILLS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
The Region; High Court Rebuffs Prisoners on Parole
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Connecticut prison inmates serving life sentences do not have to be told why when their requests for parole eligibility are denied, the Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Business People; BALTIMORE CONTRACTORS APPOINTS TOP EXECUTIVE
description: William J. Pichon, 50, has joined Baltimore Contractors Inc. as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Victor Frenkil, 71, who founded the Baltimore general construction concern in 1932 and who was named chairman.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard MORNINGS ON HORSEBACK. By David McCullough. Illustrated. 445 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: REIT TO RESPOND TO TAKEOVER BID
description: Connecticut General Mortgage and Realty Investments said that it would respond by no later than June 26 to an unsolicited, $267 million takeover bid from the pension fund of the British coal miners' union.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT DECISION ON HEALTH STANDARDS
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court decision upholding the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's standards for worker exposure to cotton dust. Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the majority opinion; Associate Justices Potter Stewart and William H. Rehnquist, joined by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, dissented. title: HUDSON'S BAY UNIT REPORTS OIL FIND
description: The Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company said a test well in the Malacca Strait, which is in the offshore Sumatra area, flowed at a rate of 12,017 barrels of light gravity crude a day from depths of 3,894 to 4,498 feet.

title: U.S. MAY 'DISENGAGE' FROM NAMIBIA TALKS, AIDE SAYS
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, told a House hearing today that the United States would ''disengage'' from negotiations on independence for South-West Africa if South Africa continued to delay on an internationally acceptable settlement.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alaska Airlines named Kenneth F. Skidds vice president of services and John F. Kelly vice president of marketing.

title: Bomb Damages a NATO Depot
description: A bomb explosion at a halffinished North Atlantic Treaty Organization arms depot at Wahrendahl, 17 miles southwest of Hanover, caused damage estimated at $130,000 today. There were no injuries. The police said they suspected that antimilitary terrorists set the bomb.

title: 7 South African Miners Killed
description: Seven miners were killed last night by a rock fall deep within the Kloof gold mine at Westonaria, just west of Johannesburg, a mine spokesman said today.

title: A.T.&.T.' CABLE LINK
description: To the Editor:

title: IOWA BUSINESSMAN
description: Roy J. Carver, one of Iowa's leading philanthropists and wealthiest residents, died last night in Marbella, Spain, apparently of a heart attack, aides said today. He was 71 years old.

title: ORDER TO MERGE SCHOOL DISTRICTS IN PITTSBURGH AREA BRINGS BATTLE
description: A Federal judge has ordered four overwhelmingly white school districts and one predominantly black district just east of this city to merge into a single district. The response in the white districts has been anger, emotional outbursts and at least one student walkout.

title: BOOK PUBLISHER QUITS, ATTACKS NEW 'MENTALITY'
description: Declaring that he can no longer support either the ''publishing methods'' or the ''new administration'' of the company for which he served as president and publisher for 21 years, John J. Geoghegan resigned yesterday as chairman of Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. Mr. Geoghegan also sharply criticized ''the corporate business school mentality'' that he said increasingly dominates trade-book publishing. ''What's coming into publishing,'' he said, ''are finance and administration guys telling editors what kind of product and what kind of marketing will be done.''

title: OWNER STATEMENT SUPPORTS GREBEY
description: The sixth day of the major league baseball strike passed yesterday without the meeting of management and player negotiators that had been scheduled, even though both sides were on the same floor of the same midtown hotel.

title: Sanyo-Zimbabwe Deal
description: The Sanyo Electric Company Ltd. said today that its Japanese subsidiary, the Sanyo Electric Trading Company, and the Marubeni Corporation had established a joint venture company with Zimbabwe interests in Salisbury, to produce audio equipment. Sanyo said it expects the joint venture concern to make and sell about $9 million worth of radios, radio-cassette recorders and stereo systems in the first year.

title: Iran's Own Mess
description: A formidable witness has now asserted that Iran has not been liberated by the overthrow of the Shah. Iran's President Bani-Sadr could not have been more categorical: ''Of the three slogans of the Islamic revolution - independence, freedom and Islamic republic - nothing has been left.''

title: 7 Inmates Are Charged in Attack On 4 Guards in an Upstate Prison
description: Seven inmates who have been accused of ambushing and stabbing four guards at the Great Meadow Correctional Facility last month were arraigned today in Washington County Court. Three of the inmates were charged with attempted murder and the others were charged with assault.

title: ARGENTINA SEEKS WAY TO RESOLVE DEBT
description: Argentina's external debt continues to climb amid reports that the country will seek refinancing. The debt was $27.2 billion at the end of the year, according to the central bank, and it has since risen to $29 billion or $30 billion, according to economists and bankers.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: CONRAIL REPORTS A PROFIT FOR MAY
description: Conrail, the 17,000-mile, Federally subsidized railroad, achieved an operating profit of nearly $10 million in May after a loss of $13 million in the previous month, Congress was told today.

title: STAGE: O'NEILL'S 'WELDED'
description: JOSE QUINTERO'S unwarranted exhumation of Eugene O'Neill's 1924 ''Welded'' at the Horace Mann Theater at Columbia University succeeds in proving that this is one of O'Neill's most dreadful plays.

title: TEXT OF REPORT ON IRAQI REACTOR
description: Following is the text of a statement made June 12 by Sigvard Eklund of Sweden, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, to the agency's Board of Governors in Vienna:

title: WORLDWIDE LEADER IN METEOROLOGY
description: Dr. Jule G. Charney, an internationally recognized leader in weather research, died Tuesday night at the Sidney Farber Cancer Institute in Boston at the age of 64 after a 20-month battle with cancer.

title: 2 Polish Sailors Request Asylum After Leaving Ship in Oregon Port
description: Two Polish navigator trainees left the ship Kapitan Ledochowski today while it was in port for fuel and water and requested political asylum in the United States.

title: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.
description: AT this late date, it's no secret that our favorite hostile cartoonist, Jules Feiffer, is also a serious writer. No sooner do we laugh at the pop-art killings of his play ''Little Murders'' or the empty seductions of his film ''Carnal Knowledge'' than we are stung by the pricks of painful truth. But in ''Grownups,'' the Feiffer play now having its premiere at Harvard's American Repertory Theater, he has reversed his usual method and taken his seriousness a step further: now the pain comes first and then, somehow, the laughter. It's a big step - maybe a giant one. By forcing the audience to crawl through an emotional hell to get to his punch lines, Mr. Feiffer has written a drama of wrenching impact without sacrificing one note of his bracing comic voice.

title: HOUSE PANEL, IN A SHIFT, VOTES TO END CURB ON LOANS TO COLLEGE STUDENTS
description: In an abrupt reversal, the House Education and Labor Committee voted today to continue federally guaranteed student loans to college students from all family income levels.

title: Diamond Shamrock
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it had converted $200 million in short-term and variable-rate debt into a 10-year obligation with a group of banks led by First National Bank and Republic National Bank in Dallas. The corporate treasurer, Donald Mielke, said the package was part of a general restructuring to lay the groundwork for a public-debt issue when the market improved. Diamond Shamrock filed for a $200 million debenture offering last March, but it was never marketed.

title: High Iraqi Aide Flies to Moscow
description: An Iraqi delegation headed by First Deputy Prime Minister Taha Yassin Ramadan flew to Moscow today on an official visit, the official Tass press agency reported. Iraqi sources said the mission was mainly economic but that political questions might be discussed. The Soviet Union has strongly condemned Israel for its June 7 raid on the Iraqi nuclear reactor center outside Beghdad.

title: Anita O'Day Back to Marty's
description: Anita O'Day will return to Marty's, 1265 Third Avenue, for a return engagement June 29 through July 11. The singer, who began her career in 1941 with Gene Krupa and his band and then sang with Stan Kenton and Woody Herman before becoming a star on her own, will perform Mondays through Thursdays at 9 and 11 P.M., Fridays at 10 P.M. and midnight and Saturdays at 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.

description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Kudos to Frances Lear for her article ''Of Men and Women in the City of Angels'' (May 21).

title: Gardening; TRAPPING DESTRUCTIVE PESTS
description: ALTHOUGH caterpillars of the gypsy moth are on just about everyone's hit list this year, they are not the only insects around. When confronted with a six-legged creature, the gardener's proper response is to identify it. A too-hasty reaction could do a lot of harm because not all bugs are bad.

description: A House-Senate conference committee today forced a delay in President Reagan's nomination of Dr. C. Everett Koop to be Surgeon General.

title: Bridge: Sophisticated System Leads To Unsophisticated Errors
description: To what extent a sophisticated and complex bidding system confers an advantage on its users is a matter for argument. Those who favor such scientific methods contend that they gain in bidding accuracy, especially on slam hands. And there is good reason to think they are right.

description: The Labor Party elected a new leader today and was expected to give him approval for coalition talks with the Fine Gael Party, the main opposition in the last Parliament.

title: Offer for Treadway

Fair Lanes owns about 34 percent of Treadway and had made a tender offer for Fair Lanes early this year. Treadway, of Paterson, N.J., operates bowling centers and motor inns, primarily in the Northeast.

Long's otherwise excellent letter on survivor benefits under the Foreign Service Act of 1981 for divorced wives (May 28), he omitted the fact that only those divorced on or after Feb. 15, 1981, are covered. Those who were divorced earlier than that date will not get a survivor annuity unless their former husbands voluntarily wish to provide it and can meet certain other conditions.

title: Topic; The New (Sod) Frontier

description: A secret shipment of eight tons of Brazilian uranium headed for Iraq was intercepted and hijacked in January by United State-made fighter jets over the African coast, a respected newspaper reported today.

Rewards of $1,000 each have been offered by Mobile and a savings and loan association in the death of Michael A. Donald, 19 years old, who was beaten, stabbed and strangled before his body was hanged in a tree March 21.

description: Midtown Manhattan traffic has improved this summer, city officials say, largely because of the efforts of the city's 1,575 trafficenforcement agents. But the agents complain that all they have received in return is abuse.

title: PERSONAL INCOME UP 0.6% IN MAY
description: Americans' personal income rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Economists said that the modest increase indicated that the economy was slowing from this year's robust first quarter and that consumer paychecks were barely keeping pace with inflation.

title: U.S. CONSULTS IRAQIS ON ISRAELI RAID
description: The United States has met with Iraq to seek a compromise that would condemn Israel's June 7 raid on Iraq's nuclear reactor but not demand an arms embargo against the Israelis.

title: The Unseemly Regulatory Strip

The merits of the reorganization are debatable, but Mr. Watt's tactics are not. By developing the plan without wide consultation and rushing to stay ahead of Congressional doubters, he displays a deplorable arrogance.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 18, 1981
description: International French oversight of an Iraqi reactor was insured under a secret accord, the Government in Paris reported. It said that the pact would have made it impossible for Baghdad to make nuclear weapons without being detected at the reactor destroyed by Israeli jets on June 7. Under the agreement, France was to have kept scientists working at the reactor until 1989. They were authorized to watch all nuclear experiments and to check the reactor afterward. (Page A1, Column 1.) Iraq's nuclear objectives were discussed by Under Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. in House testimony. He said that the Administration was ''concerned'' about Iraq's nuclear program, but that it did not agree with Israel's assertion that the reactor bombed by Israel was designed to produce nuclear arms. (A18:5-6.)

title: BALTIMORE PROTEST HALTS DRAMA BY SOUTH AFRICANS

title: Burlington Awarded Judgment
description: Burlington Industries has been awarded about $21 million in settlement of a long dispute with Milliken & Company and several related companies over textile patents.

title: Hers
description: IT is a classic case of bad timing: Just as women begin to shed their economic dependence and to savor the luxuries of having their own money, the world makes independence too expensive. Take housing. Ten years ago, few women would have dared dream of having enough money to buy their own homes. But at almost the same moment that the income of a sizable number of women reached the point where owning a home was not unthinkable, housing prices and mortgage rates went through the roof. It now takes two good incomes to put even a modest roof overhead.

title: SUMMIT ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
The City; A Koch Nominee Forced to Withdraw
description: In the face of opposition from the Manhattan delegation on the City Council, Mayor Koch's nominee to fill a vacancy on the sevenmember Planning Commission withdrew her name from consideration.

title: Harris Settles With Argos, Drops Suit Against Them
description: Eric Harris, a Kansas City Chiefs cornerback, agreed yesterday to a $55,000 settlement with the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League, dropping the breach of contract suit he had planned to pursue against his former club.

title: AMERICANS PUZZLED ABOUT IRAQ'S GOAL
description: Despite Iraq's contention that the nuclear reactor that was destroyed by Israel was purely for research, American specialists remain baffled as to its real purpose, noting that its reported power rating of 40 megawatts is not typical of research installations.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision to supply arms to China and his comments on the situation in Eastern Europe have deepened the chill in Soviet-American relations and may have reduced the Administration's prospects for deterring Soviet military intervention in Poland.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: Harry Ortecho, a 27-year-old Bronx man who the police say is a drug dealer, was charged yesterday with the sniper killing on May 27 of Moe Hanif, 28, also of the Bronx. Mr. Ortecho was on a rooftop, Mr. Hanif on a park bench. The police said the two had been at odds over a drug deal. ... Stephen Napolitano, a 33-year-old transit police officer was stabbed on the platform of the Knickerbocker Avenue subway station of the Myrtle Avenue line in Brooklyn, but his bulletproof vest saved him from injury. He fired two shots but his assailant escaped. ... Henry Zallinger, 24, one of two men who escaped from Rikers Island in a bread truck on June 2, was recaptured outside a candy store in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn. Mr. Zallinger's companion in the escape, Felix Rojas, 22, was recaptured on June 5 on the street five blocks from his home in lower Manhattan.

title: Exacta Payoff Sets Record
description: A national harness racing record for a $2 exacta wager was set tonight at the Meadowlands when J.J.'s Biltmore won the second race and Farbro Mike finished second for a $2,855 return. The previous record was $2,845 at the Meadowlands on March 23, 1977.

title: 8 Veterans Plan Capital Protest
description: Eight Vietnam veterans on a hunger strike said today that they would pitch a tent in a park across from the White House and stay until President Reagan met with them. The White House said the President had no plans to see them. Twelve supporters, including the mother of a serviceman killed in Vietnam, sat down on the White House lawn in sympathy with the hunger strikers and were arrested by the Secret Service.

title: AN IDLE YASTRZEMSKI SEES AN ACTIVE ONE
description: The baseball strike has provided Carl Yastrzemski a rare opportunity to spend time with his son, Mike, a sophomore at Florida State and an excellent outfield prospect.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. BANKS SEEK A DELAY IN TALKS ON POLISH DEBTS
description: Because of the volatile political situation in Poland, American bankers are expected to ask European bankers tomorrow to postpone, at least until the end of the year, any efforts to renegotiate the terms for repayment of approximately $13 billion in debt that Poland owes to foreign banks.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 25 percent stock distribution payable July 1, 1981

title: The U.N. Today; June 18, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on complaint by Iraq at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Notes On People; A Solution for Those Not on the Prince's Invitation List
description: Robert Morley, who will serve as co-host with David Hartman on ''Good Morning, America'' on ABC-TV during the week of the royal wedding in London, has already demonstrated a shrewd sense of observation.

title: FRANCE SAYS IRAQIS COULDN'T HAVE BUILT A-BOMB UNDETECTED
description: The French Government has disclosed the existence of an agreement with Iraq that it said would have made it impossible for Baghdad to avoid detection if it had tried to make nuclear weapons at the reactor destroyed by Israel on June 7.

title: Shinnecock Hills 1986 Site of Open
description: Shinnecock Hills Golf Club in Southampton, L.I., will be the site of the 1986 United States Open. Will Nicholson Jr., president of the United States Golf Association, made the announcement today, along with the announcement that another course in the Northeast, Pine Valley Golf Club in Clementon, N.J., would be used for the 1985 Walker Cup matches between a United States team and a team from Britian and Ireland.

title: Dr. Anthony M. Primelo, Deputy Creedmoor Chief
description: Dr. Anthony M. Primelo, deputy director at Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens Village, died Tuesday of a heart attack in his hospital office. Dr. Primelo, who was a resident of Forest Hills, Queens, was 50 years old.

title: Canada Cement Sale
description: Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. said it intended to sell at least $105 million (Canadian) of stock to Lafarge Coppee, which already owns 54 percent of its shares.

title: INFANT FORMULA DRIVE IS ASSAILED
description: Representatives of a coalition of women, minority groups and health care professionals testified today before a House subcommittee that the promotion of infant formula in the United States had led to thousands of infant deaths each year, particularly among low-income families.

title: Home Improvement; BEST CURE FOR A LEAKY FAUCET CAN BE A NEW ONE
description: By BERNARD GLADSTONE Although an old, worn-out looking bathroom or kitchen faucet that leaks, drips or makes all kinds of weird noises when you turn it off or on can usually be repaired, in many cases replacement parts are hard to locate and disassembling the old faucet in order to work on it sometimes becomes quite difficult. Very often the easiest solution is to simply replace the entire faucet with a new washerless model that will minimize the maintenance problems usually associated with older faucets, and will also look a lot better than the old one did.

title: Critic's Notebook; ADVENTUROUS, OUTSPOKEN THEATER
description: WHEN David Mamet's ''American Buffalo'' first played Off Off Broadway and later on Broadway, there were many of us who admired the work and there were also some people who were offended by the author's candid language. Since then, the play has been staged with great success around the country at regional theaters and at London's National Theater. In revival at Circle in the Square downtown, ''American Buffalo'' is attracting a popular audience, drawn by Al Pacino but also enjoying the play because of its language.

title: PRESERVE BARRIER BEACHES
description: They face the ocean, cut off from the mainland by tidal estuaries and salt marshes. Narrow islands of sand, they are the barrier beaches of the Atlantic and Gulf coasts. To preserve them, the Government should buy them, but in a period of spending retrenchment it should at least try to slow down private development of them. A bill before Congress would make that possible.

title: The City; Abbie Hoffman Tells Of Drug Fight Plans
description: Abbie Hoffman, the former Yippie leader and 1960's activist, said he would use his ''celebrity status'' to encourage other people who have a ''cultural impact'' to join him in battling the heroin problem through an anti-heroin advertising campaign.

title: YUGOSLAV TV TO BE HONORED AT FISHER HALL GALA TONIGHT
description: Yugoslav television will be honored tonight in Avery Fisher Hall at an event sponsored by the International Council of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. The actor Karl Malden, who is of Yugoslav descent, will be the host.

title: The City; Fish Dealer Is Given 3 Years as Tax Cheat
description: A judge imposed a three-year prison sentence on Rosario Leanzo, the operator of a fish-unloading company at the Fulton Fish Market, in lower Manhattan.

title: COTTON INDUSTRY UPSET BY RULING
description: Textile industry executives expressed disappointment with the Supreme Court decision yesterday upholding the enforcement of Federal standards limiting workers' exposure to cotton dust.

title: The Region; Court Upholds State In School Takeovers
description: TRENTON (AP) - New Jersey officials may take over ineptly run school systems, the State Supreme Court ruled. In a unanimous decision, the court upheld the appointment of a state monitor general to oversee Trenton's troubled school system and turned back a challenge to the state's authority to run the system as it sees fit.

title: Robert F. Caille Is Dead in Paris; Published Vogue's French Edition
description: Robert F. Caille, publisher of the French edition of Vogue magazine, died in Paris on Monday after a short illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Chicago's Fans in a Whirl of Expectations
description: Chicago was swept by a kind of baseball fever yesterday as speculation increased over the personalities and even the stadiums in the city's future, following the sale of the Cubs five months after the sale of the White Sox.

title: Kissinger Out as Director Of Foreign Policy Group
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has lost his seat on the board of directors of the Council on Foreign Relations in a nine-way election for eight vacancies.

title: Union Underwear
description: The Woodward Manufacturing Company, a unit of the Union Underwear Company, said it would close its underwear plant here because it could attract only 250 workers to this northwestern Oklahoma area.

title: Price of Crude Slips in Europe
description: The spot price of Arab light crude oil fell 25 cents to the official Saudi Marker contract price of $32 a barrel during the past week, while prices of most oil products firmed slightly because of weakness of the dollar, market sources said today. Volume was sparse in both markets.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: 1981 results give effect to a 1.5 million common shr offering completed in Mar; the 1980 shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in Nov 1980

title: TWIN FOUND DEFECTIVE IN WOMB REPORTED DESTROYED IN OPERATION
description: Doctors at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine reported yesterday that they had punctured the heart of an abnormal fetus to destroy it in the womb while leaving its normal twin to survive and be born more than four months later as a healthy baby.

title: 2 Philadelphians Capture Newport Sailing Honors
description: Two Philadelphians with different approaches to yacht racing won the major prizes in the Annapolis-Newport race that ended today.

title: BUDGET AGREEMENT REACHED BY KOCH AND OTHER OFFICIALS
description: An election-year budget for New York City of more than $14.7 billion, including money to hire an extra 2,300 police officers over the next 12 months, was agreed to last night by Mayor Koch, the Board of Estimate and leaders of the City Council.

title: JUSTICES DECIDE U.S. MUST PROTECT WORKERS' SAFETY DESPITE HIGH COST
description: The United States Supreme Court dealt a major setback today to the Reagan Administration's anti-regulation agenda, ruling that the Occupational Safety and Health Administration must protect workers from exposure to toxic substances to the greatest extent feasible without regard to the balance between costs and benefits.

title: 13,807 SUMMER JOBS FOUND FOR CITY YOUTHS
description: A coalition of business and civic leaders headed by David Rockefeller announced yesterday that it had obtained almost 14,000 summer jobs in the private sector for economically disadvantaged youths, exceeding its goal of 10,000 to 12,000 jobs.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Digecon Inc. will sell 900,000 shares of common stock at $28.50 a share, underwritten by a Shearson Loeb Rhoades group.

title: IRAN'S PARLIAMENT DELAYS DEBATE ON OUSTING BANI-SADR
description: After several hours of wrangling, Parliament today postponed until Saturday the beginning of its debate on whether to impeach President Abholhassan Bani-Sadr.

title: NEW YORK CITY TO HONOR SEVEN FOR CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE ARTS
description: Seven persons will be honored for supporting and contributing to the artistic and cultural affairs of New York City in a ceremony at Gracie Mansion on Tuesday evening 6 o'clock.

title: FIRESTONE PLANS NEW HEADQUARTERS
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it will spend $25 million in the next six years to renovate its Plant 1 building into its world headquarters.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
POLAND AND U.S. BANKERS
description: Portes PARIS - American banks holding Polish debt meet today in New York City to decide whether to help Poland cope with its economic crisis or to stand aloof. Will they cooperate in postponing, or rescheduling, Polish debt repayments due from last April through December? The American banks seem set to say no, risking very dangerous consequences for no clear benefits.

title: BIRKENMEIER EXCELS IN FOILING DIPLOMATS
description: The ball had been bouncing off the hands and chest of Hubert Birkenmeier with so much frequency in recent games that he said he should be playing third base for the Mets.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Stephen Priest Marries
description: Stephen N. Priest, lead singer and bassist with the rock recording group Sweet, was married yesterday to Maureen L. O'Connor, director of publicity and artist relations at Capitol-EMI Records Inc. The civil ceremony was performed at the Municipal Building at City Hall by First Deputy City Clerk Herbert J. Rey. Mr. Priest, who lives in London, was previously married and divorced. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John V. O'Connor of North Plainfield, N.J.

title: Fujitsu Siemens Deal
description: Fujitsu Ltd. has reached basic agreement with Siemens of West Germany to supply large-scale computer systems to the German concern for sale under the Siemens brand name on the German market, informed sources said. The Japanese computer manufacturer declined to comment, but the sources said the computers they agreed to supply are the latest models of the Facom M-380 and M-382 developed by Fujitsu.

title: KNOWING JUSTICE WHEN YOU SEE IT
description: Potter Stewart, who will retire from the Supreme Court next month, wrote a classic line, though he may rue the day he did so, that says much about the man and the Justice. The occasion was a 1964 obscenity case that showed the Court divided many ways and vainly searching for clear guidelines. It took Justice Stewart to concede that some issues simply don't yield to lofty proclamations. He said he might never succeed in intelligibly defining hard-core obscenity, ''but I know it when I see it, and the motion picture involved in this case is not that.''

title: System; A SETBACK FOR NUCLEARPLANTS
description: When they were planned during the 1960's, the five nuclear power plants under construction in Washington State were considered the most efficient and economical way to provide electrical power for the Pacific Northwest.

title: STRAWBERRY FIELDS FOR THE PICKING
description: Now is the time for all good strawberry lovers to visit a nearby berry patch, combining a visit to the countryside not far from metropolitan New York with an opportunity to gather as many berries as needed for a strawberry feast at low prices.

title: GEORGE KATONA, 79, LEADING ECONOMIST
description: George Katona, a pioneer in the application of consumer psychology to economic forecasting who was often regarded as the dean of behavioral economists, died yesterday in West Berlin at the age of 79. Dr. Katona, who lived in Ann Arbor, Mich., had received an honorary doctorate from the Free University of Berlin on Wednesday.

title: CABINET AIDE GREETED BY REAGAN AS 'MAYOR'
description: President Reagan was making his way down a line of mayors visiting the White House, shaking hands, when he came to Samuel R. Pierce Jr., his Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: NEW STEPS IN BUDGET WALTZ HELP EASE THE GO-AROUND
description: For years, the final city budget negotiations among the City Council, the Board of Estimate and the Mayor have been conducted in the spirit of a 1930's dance marathon - the last people left on their feet would win. While this process had a sort of morbid charm, it has occurred to the various dancers over the years that it may not be the best way to produce a sensible budget.

title: Boys Choir to Sing Bach
description: For the last concert of its season, the Boys Choir of Harlem will perform a Bach program Sunday at 4 P.M. at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street.

title: U.S. AND IRAQ AGREE ON U.N. RESOLUTION TO 'CONDEMN' RAID
description: The United States and Iraq agreed today on a Security Council resolution that ''strongly condemns'' the Israeli attack on Iraq's nuclear reactor and urges Israel to open its nuclear plants to international inspection.

title: OPERA: 'SAMSON ET DALILA' ON S.I.
description: THE acoustic shell and speaker supports did not come crashing down on Wednesday night when the Metropolitan Opera gave its first outdoor concert presentation of Saint-Saens's ''Samson et Dalila'' in Staten Island's Snug Harbor. But at the score's climactic moment, Richard Cassilly's singing of Samson and Neeme Jarvi's compelling conducting made the destruction of the Philistine temple at least musically believable.

title: Around the World; MICHIGAN KILLER ACCEPTS HER SENTENCE: AVOID MEN
description: Judith E. Miller killed the man she had been living with, but instead of sending her to jail Circuit Court Judge Gary R. McDonald barred her for five years from marrying or living with a man without the court's approval.

title: Posner Units Raise Stake in 2 Concerns
description: The Sharon Steel Corporation, which is controlled by Victor Posner, the Miami Beach financier, said it had increased its stake in the Evans Products Company to 2,232,900 shares, or 18.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sharon Steel said that its holdings included purchases between May 19 and June 2 of 130,000 shares of Evans common for an aggregate purchase price of $4.1 million.

title: Angola Oil Output Off
description: Angolan oil production averaged 128,000 barrels daily in the last quarter of 1980, nearly 9 percent below the similar period in 1979, according to official Angolan sources. An oil ministry report said 67 percent of the oil came from the northern coastal enclave of Cabinda.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 8
description: B-Reflects a $1,343,000 reduction in financial and equity incom compared to the first qr of 1980 because of the merger in that of American Garden Products, previously 30 percent owned by Ini into Amfac and the consequent termination of equity accounting the company's interest in American Garden Products subsequent t first qr of 1980...C-Including $222,000 equity earnings from Am Garden Products; shr earnings have been adjusted for an 8 perce divd payable July 15; revs include capital gains of $479,000 fo latest period and $1,537,000 for the previous period

title: ASSEMBLY DEFEATS BILL ON REMOVAL OF CULT MEMBERS
description: The Assembly tonight defeated a bill that would have allowed courts to appoint temporary guardians to remove people from religious and other cults for a period of 45 to 75 days.

title: Letters; MISS HAYES ENDS A ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: A LOVE SONG FOR MARY LOU WILLIAMS
description: A CONCERT tomorrow evening at Town Hall called ''A Song of Love for Mary Lou Williams'' was planned as a tribute to the composer, arranger and jazz pianist. It will still be that, but now, following her death May 28, it will also be a memorial. The net proceeds will go to the Mary Lou Williams Foundation, which offers gifted children 6 to 12 years old training with professional jazz musicians.

title: OFFICER ACCUSED OF SHOOTING FLEEING MAN FATALLY IN BACK
description: A plainclothes police officer was indicted yesterday in the Bronx on a charge of fatally shooting an unarmed fleeing man in the back. After the incident, which occurred last March 31, the officer, Carol Esserman, contended that she had fired at the fleeing man, Robert L. Greene, because he had pointed a pistol at her and because he had earlier fired a gun at another police officer who was her partner in a special anticrime unit.

title: Baseball Notebook; LACHEMANN MISSING COMFORTS OF 'HOME'
description: While most players were returning to their homes during the baseball strike this week, Manager Rene Lachemann of the Seattle Mariners had to leave the place he was calling home. Since replacing Maury Wills as manager May 6, Lachemann has lived in the Mariner clubhouse in the Kingdome.

title: SUMMER SOLSTICE FESTIVAL TO OFFER INDIAN CLASSICS
description: THERE may be no colorful shamiana overhead, and no rugs or pillows for the audience, but there will be five leading performers of Indian classical music on stage at Town Hall on Sunday to bring to New York the atmosphere of a long, languid, hot-weather Indian musical evening.

title: Letters; WHOM THE GUARDIANSHIP LAW WOULD GUARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Thorpe Springs Latest Surprise
description: Jim Thorpe, the surprise leader after the opening round of the 81st United States Open, is accustomed to surprising people. ''A lot of people in the gallery think I'm an Indian and a lot think I'm dead,'' he said, '' and then they look up from their programs and see I'm black and alive.''

title: EXCEPTICON INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect the acquisition of Mutz Corp

title: Reagan Nominates Senate Aide As Assistant Defense Secretary
description: President Reagan today nominated Richard Perle, a staff member of the Senate Subcommittee on Arms Control for the last eight years, as Assistant Secretary of Defense for international security planning.

title: Business People; Nevada National Bank Names New President
description: John C. Deane, 34, has been appointed president of the Nevada National Bank, which operates 32 offices in its home state. He succeeds George E. Aker, 43, who was named chairman and continues as chief executive officer of the bank, which has its headquarters in Reno and is the principal subsidiary of the Nevada National Bancorporation.

title: BRING THE CONTROLLERS DOWN TO EARTH
description: The nation's air-traffic controllers threaten to strike unless the Government meets their demands for higher pay and shorter hours. A strike could ground most aircraft at a cost to the economy of hundreds of millions of dollars a day. Still, the Reagan Administration has little choice but to risk the walkout and seek help from the courts. For a settlement on the union's exorbitant terms would set an inflationary precedent for millions of Federal employees.

title: TREASURY REOPENING INQUIRY ON OFFICIAL
description: The Treasury Department is reopening an investigation into the role that Norman B. Ture, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Tax and Economic Affairs, played in arranging a Treasury contract for an economic forecasting model that Mr. Ture had developed and partly owned.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio air play. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record. title: ARTHUR COOPERMAN, LAWYER, 69, HEADED COMPENSATION PANEL
description: Arthur Cooperman, a lawyer who was chairman of the State Workers' Compensation Board, died of cancer yesterday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. Mr. Cooperman, who was a resident of Queens Village, was 69 years old.

title: Trains Are Stoned in Yugoslavia
description: Trains and railroad equipment are being stoned in the troubled southern province of Kosovo, it was reported today. The Belgrade newspaper Politika Ekspres did not blame anyone for the attacks. It said they had become frequent since the rioting by ethnic Albanians in Kosovo last March and April.

title: PUBLISHING: LOST PAPERS OF EUDORA WELTY FOUND
description: WHEN a 15-year-old classmate entrusted Ralph Hilton with several of her manuscripts in Jackson, Miss., in the 1920's, she wanted his critical opinion. ''Naturally, she came to me,'' Mr. Hilton recently joked, ''because I had a weekly byline about Central High sports in The Jackson Daily News, so I was already a professional.''

title: MISHAP AT LENA HORNE SHOW
description: Lena Horne's one-woman show was halted and canceled for the evening last night after a horizontal pole holding 20 lights separated in the middle and swung toward the stage as she began her opening number, ''From This Moment On.''

title: Chris-Craft TV Bid
description: Chris-Craft Industries, a diversified company that owns about 3.8 million shares, or nearly 32 percent, of United Television Inc., has asked the Federal Communications Commission to approve its plan to control the television company. Chris-Craft said that if it won the F.C.C. consent it would buy enough additional shares of the television company to elect a majority of the five directors. Currently Chris-Craft has two representatives on United Television's board.

title: Rossmoor Holders Approve Liquidation
description: Shareholders of the Rossmoor Corporation, the builder that pioneered the concept of the large retirement community and constructed seven Leisure World communities nationwide, have approved a motion to liquidate within 12 months, company officials said.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including gains from the sale of real estate of $1,773,000 fo latest 6 mos and $1,115,000 for the previous 6 mos

title: Litton-A.T.&T.  Case Up to Jury
description: A $600 million antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company went to the jury yesterday after a five-month trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Litton Systems Inc. accused A.T.&T. of forcing it out of the office telephone equipment business with monopolistic tactics.

title: HOUSE REPRIEVES LEGAL AID PLAN BUT CUTS FUNDS
description: The House of Representatives voted today to keep the Legal Services Corporation alive but to slash its funds drastically and impose stringent restrictions on the activities of lawyers financed by the corporation.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $432,000 for the qr an $837,000 for the yr...C-Including extraordinary tax credits of for the qr and $595,000 for the yr and gains of $70,000 for the $713,000 for the yr on the retirement of debt

title: SCOTT TAKES AIM AT TITLE IN NATIONAL 1,500 METERS
description: The USA/Mobil national track and field championship, beginning tomorrow at Hughes Stadium, is Steve Scott's kind of meet.

title: IRAQ COULD HAVE MADE 2 A-BOMBS, ISRAELI SAYS
description: Prof. Yuval Neeman, a physicist and a member of the Israeli Atomic Energy Commission, said today that Iraq could have produced enough uranium 235 for two Hiroshima-type bombs immediately after its French-supplied reactor was to have become operational in September.

title: Notes On people; Help for Children of Men Who Died in Iran Rescue Effort
description: Barry Rosen is not likely to forget the moment, months after the event, when he found out about the abortive helicopter attempt to rescue the American hostages in Iran.

title: REASONS NOT GIVEN
description: Associate Justice Potter Stewart announced today that he would retire July 3 after 23 years on the Supreme Court, and the Reagan Administration moved to fill the vacancy before the end of the summer.

title: Canada to Pay Grain Farmers
description: The Canadian Government will pay farmers up to $67 million (United States currency) in compensation for losses suffered because of the curtailment of grain shipments to the Soviet Union, federal officials announced today.

title: Pop Jazz; BANDS WITHOUT SINGERS GAINING
description: TODAY'S hit records have one common denominator - they all feature vocalists. Purely instrumental recordings rarely make it into the top 40, and they almost never crack the top 10. But it wasn't always so. In the late 1950's and early 60's, there were big all-instrumental rock-and-roll hits. Johnny and the Hurricanes, Link Wray, Duane Eddy, the Shadows and the most prolific instrumental group of them all, the Ventures, scored success after success, and so did the surf bands - the Champays, the Surfaris and the rest.

title: Article 162711 -- No Title
description: Soraya Khashoggi, the estranged wife of a Saudi Arabian billionaire, lost a two-year court fight today to have her $2.5 billion divorce suit tried in California.

title: THE LATEST IN FURS ON A DAY FOR BIKINIS
description: Nothing, apparently, stops the faithful from turning up at a Maximilian fur show. Even though the temperature was in the upper 80's and climbing, Chessy Rayner, Mica Ertegun, Estee Lauder, Ruth Ribicoff and Glady Solomon looked cool and collected in the front row and acted as though watching fur coats on a hot day was a perfectly normal thing to do. The audience also boasted Natalie Wood, wearing a white middy blouse and nautical pants, who was there with her husband, Robert Wagner.

title: BEGIN EXTENDS TIME ON MISSILES
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin met today with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, and said later that Israel had agreed to allow more time for diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis over Syrian antiaircraft missiles in Lebanon.

title: Japan-Soviet Talks Stalled
description: Talks between Japan's semiofficial Export-Import Bank and the visiting Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, Viktor Ivanov, over a $400 million Japanese bank loan have stalled on the issue of interest rates, the Japanese bank said today.

title: HEAVYWEIGHT PAGE: A BOXER WITH HEART
description: Greg Page had what he called a funny feeling as he headed toward the hospital. His father, Albert, had been there 30 days, but it was only a week earlier that his mother had told him why: cancer.

title: Olin May Sell U.S. Arms Unit
description: The Olin Corporation said today it had entered into serious negotiations with a group of private investors for the sale of its American sporting arms operations.

title: CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 26
SMALL ITALIAN PARTY NEAR COALITION
description: Senator Giovanni Spadolini, the head of the small, Republican Party, won tentative backing today from Italy's other political groups for the formation of a coalition government under his leadership.

title: OTHER POLICE FEUDS ACKNOWLEGED
description: The Police Commissioner acknowledged yesterday that there have been a number of other incidents, besides those at a Brooklyn precinct, involving suspected ''pranks or harassment'' by police officers against their precinct supervisors. But he asserted that there was no serious or widespread problem of discipline or morale in the Police Department.

title: Restaurants; Turtle Bay French and SoHo snuggery.
description: WHY does a chef who produces very good to excellent food at one restaurant suddenly descend to mediocrity at another? The relationship of owner to chef (when, of course, they are not one and the same) is among the more perplexing questions of restaurant life and one that presented itself again during recent visits to La Petite Marmite, the spacious and comfortable contemporary restaurant in the Beekman Tower Hotel on the corner of First Avenue and 49th Street.

title: VACCINE DEVELOPED BY GENETIC SPLICING
description: A safe, effective vaccine against foot and mouth disease, one of the world's most economically serious infections of livestock, has been developed using gene-splicing techniques, the United States Department of Agriculture announced yesterday.

title: MUSICAL: 'HEEBIE JEEBIES,' A BOSWELLS LIFE IN SONG
description: THE Boswell Sisters - Connie, Vet and Martha - a singing trio that was extremely popular in the early 1930's, had an influence on pop music and jazz singing that is still being felt today. Their vocal arrangements, backed by such jazz musicians as Bunny Berigan, Benny Goodman, Joe Venuti and the Dorsey Brothers, paved the way for the marriage of pop and jazz that came about in the Swing Era. Their inventive use of scat singing was a source for Ella Fitzgerald and all the other jazz singers who vocalize without words. They were the direct inspiration for the Andrews Sisters. And there is a lurking suspicion in some quarters that the habit of jazz musicians and singers from Chicago, New York and other northern cities of affecting a slightly Southern accent is a reflection of the legitimate Southern accent of the New Orleans-born Boswell Sisters.

title: RULING ON FAN'S RISK REVERSED
description: If a spectator at a baseball game chooses not to sit behind the backstop and is later hit with a foul ball, the proprietor of the ball park cannot be held liable, the state's highest court ruled today.
