Gramm A16 White House scales down goals as another budget battle looms A17 City budget process proves a little less painful than usual B3 Assembly defeats an anti-cult bill B3 Recruiting stepped up for Correc- tion Dept. personnel B3 Vandalism by resentful officers acknowledged by McGuire B3 General Around the Nation A12 2 distinct kinds of riders clash on the L.I.R.R. in summer B1 Salmon returning to Connecticut River in record numbers B1 The Region B2 Officer indicted in fatal shooting of fleeing man B3 Health/Science European Space Agency rocket poised for liftoff A13 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 A walk in Poe's Manhattan C13 Where to pick your own strawber- ries C14 Crosstown fair Sunday on 52d Street C14 Theater: Broadway C2

title: Letters; FRAGMENTING THE CARE SYSTEM FOR THE MENTALLY ILL
description: To the Editor:

title: FLAT RESULT EXPECTED FOR APRIL-JUNE G.N.P.
description: The gross national product will show no growth at all in the current April-June quarter, the Government projected today, after reporting that first-quarter G.N.P. had grown at a vigorous 8.6 percent annual rate.

title: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-After $3.2 million loss from the sale of Delmar Chemicals and provision for an anticipated loss on the sale of a Zambian brew interest; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal sto exchanges

title: 'NUMERO DEUX,' A GODARD EXPERIMENT
description: FOR most filmgoers, even those who struggled to keep up with Jean-Luc Godard during his so-called Maoist-Dziga-Vertov Group period, the release last year of his funny, probing, original ''Every Man for Himself'' (''Sauve Qui Peut/ La Vie'') in commercial theaters was something of a revelation. This most committed, innovative director of his generation had - quite obviously - not been sitting around, dozing, since he abandoned commercial movies after the production of ''Weekend'' in 1967 to devote himself to political cinema.

title: AFRICANS SAY REAGAN IS SEEKING TO TURN BACK CLOCK ON NAMIBIA
description: The Reagan Administration is coming under increasingly sharp criticism from a growing number of African countries that say the United States is stepping up its support for the white minority Government in South Africa at the expense of black Africa, particularly the region's guerrilla movements.

title: BALLET: A 'SLEEPING BEAUTY' ROYAL GALA
description: THE Royal Ballet became its recognizable self when Jennifer Penney and David Wall stepped into the leading roles of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' for a superlative performance Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: MISSILE OFFICER IS ACCUSED OF GIVING ARMS DATA TO UNAUTHORIZED PEOPLE
description: The Air Force broadened its case against Second Lieut. Christopher Cooke today, accusing the 25-yearold missile-launching officer of passing military information to unauthorized persons on five occasions and of making contact with Soviet officials 13 times in the last year.

title: Letters; NON-INFLATIONARY WAY TO EASE TAX BURDENS
description: To the Editor:

title: EUROPEAN SPACE AGENCY ROCKET POISED FOR LIFTOFF IN TEST TODAY
description: A European-built Ariane rocket stood ready today on its launching pad here, where the equatorial jungle of South America gives way to the Atlantic Coast, as the countdown began for a liftoff scheduled tomorrow morning.

title: China Graphite Order
description: China has awarded an order to a Japanese consortium led by Mitsui & Company to build a plant to produce coloid graphite for color picture tubes, Mitsui said today. The order, placed by the National Technical Import Corporation, called for completion of the plant by mid-1983.

title: 3 GOLFERS TIED FOR LEAD IN NEW JERSEY AMATEUR
description: The competition in the 80th New Jersey amateur golf championship tightened today at the Canoe Brook Country Club's north course.

title: CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
WATT ORDERS CHANGES ON PARK CONCESSIONS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced today a series of actions designed to give private concessionaires a larger role in the national parks.

title: SALMON RETURN TO CONNECTICUT RIVER
description: The Atlantic salmon, cut off from spawning grounds here before the American Revolution by encroaching development, is returning to the Connecticut River system in record numbers.

title: WHITE HOUSE REVIEWS BUDGET, GIRDING FOR NEW BATTLE
description: White House officials were scaling down their proposed changes in Federal budget priorities today in the face of growing opposition from both parties. But another major confrontation over budget policies continued to loom in Congress.

title: MRS. COOPERSTEIN OUSTED IN SEMIFINAL OF MET. GOLF
description: Judy Cooperstein of North Shore, seeking her fourth title in the event, was eliminated today in the semifinals of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association match-play championship at the Huntington-Crescent Country Club. She lost to Barbara Jones of the Ridgewood (N.J.) Country Club, 2 up.

title: The Region; Detective Is Guilty In Test-Rigging Case
description: HARTFORD (AP) - A New Britain police detective was convicted of lying twice to a grand juror investigating his city's scandal over the alleged rigging of Civil Service tests, in which more than two dozen people have been charged.

title: Jack Manning
description: WORLD'S LARGEST FLAG UNFURLED: The stars and stripes of what is said to be the largest flag in the world stretching across a softball field in Central Park yesterday. The 411-by-211-foot flag was put on display by the Great American Flag Fund to help raise $650,000 to build special rigging that would allow it to be raised and lowered on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. Stars of the two-acre, seven-ton, nylon-tafetta banner are 13 feet wide.

title: energywatch
description: JUNE 12, 1981 Crude oil stocks held steady at 404 million barrels.

title: GLENDA JACKSON FROM LONDON IN 'STEVIE'
description: YOU'D better put on your running shoes if you don't want to miss the best performance by an actress to be seen in any film released so far this year. It's Glenda Jackson in ''Stevie,'' Hugh Whitemore's very good film adaptation of his play about the late Stevie Smith, the gallant, original, profoundly witty English poet who died in 1971 at the age of 69. Stevie, in Miss Jackson's splendid performance, is funny, fragile, demanding, suicidal, brave and never at a loss for the kind of words that light up the conventional world she clung to, even as those words turn the world upside down.

title: Sports of the Times; NICKLAUS & SON SHOOT 69
description: yard fifth hole at Merion yesterday, Jack Nicklaus had driven into the left rough and now he was surveying his next shot when he heard his caddie talking.

title: REDRAWING WILL FORM DISTRICTS WITH NEW PRIORITIES districts
description: If one colored a map of the United States and used the brightest hues for those areas that were growing the fastest, Florida would light up like the nose of a circus clown.

title: TV Weekend; 'CRONKITE'S UNIVERSE'
description: WALTER CRONKITE is a man who is at home in a half-hour, although Heaven only knows that he has proved that he can go the full count when the situation warrants. ''Walter Cronkite's Universe,'' which starts its new season at 8 P.M. Sunday on CBS-TV, is an exception to the often onerous rule that only situation comedies and national news can fit into 30 minutes and that the way everything else proves its mettle is by running one hour or longer. After this program, the series of 13 shows will appear at 8 on Tuesdays.

title: OPEC Extends Oil Price Study
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that the Long-Term Strategy Committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would meet again in August to study new forecasts of energy production and consumption on which to base a pricing formula.

title: Venezuela Oil Find
description: Corpoven, a subsidiary of Venezuela's state oil corporation, said today that a test well in the northeastern state of Monagas flowed 3,000 barrels daily of relatively light crude oil from a depth of 12,000 feet. The well is near the site of oil camps operated since the 1930's, but is deeper than most wells in the area. Corpoven said it would continue exploration in the area and would reactivate old wells.

title: NOBLE NASHUA A WINNER
description: Eddie Maple riding Noble Nashua, right, to victory over Five Star Flight in the seventh race yesterday at Belmont. West on Broad and Banker's Sun finished in a dead heat for third.

title: Ulster Arts Day Tomorrow in High Falls
description: The streets and parks of High Falls, N.Y., in Ulster County, will be filled with music, crafts and other activities tomorrow during a free arts celebration sponsored by the Ulster County Council for the Arts. It begins at 9:30 A.M. with races of 5 and 10 kilometers, open to all.

title: In the Nation; AMTRAK TURNS THE CORNER
description: The average airline trip is now about 1,000 miles long - and the average is rising. The average bus trip is only 100 miles - and the average is falling.

title: AT THE WAILING WALL, A REMEMBRANCE AND A WARNING
description: In a somber mood of warning for the future, 5,000 survivors of the ghettos and the concentration camps of Hitler's Europe ended four days of remembrance and reunion tonight at Jerusalem's Wailing Wall, the holiest place in Judaism, where they passed the legacy of the Holocaust symbolically to their children.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; WORKSHOP ON 53D ST.
description: With appropriate dexterity, the American Craft Museum, at 44 West 53d Street, is turning itself into a studio to celebrate its 25th anniversary. Starting today and continuing through Sept. 6, five artisans can be seen at work: Elsbeth Woody will construct a series of nine-foot-tall columns of clay, using a kiln in the museum's rear courtyard; Tommy Simpson will build a wooden room with wooden furniture and toys; Deborah Aguado will make objects, mostly jewelry, of metal and other materials; Richard Yelle will paint on glass and piece glass fragments together, and Leora Stewart will work at two massive frame looms. Admission is $1 (50 cents for children, students and the elderly). Information: 397-0630. SINGING IN THE PARKS

title: No Headline
description: MISS AUSTIN REACHES SEMIFINALS IN BRITAIN

title: News Analysis
description: Of all decisions that human beings must make, none is more agonizing than terminating the life of a defective newborn child. Yet daily and in increasing numbers such decisions are being made across the country.

title: Data General Has Simpler Computer
description: The Data General Corporation, continuing an industry trend toward making computers easier to use and understand, said it would introduce today a very small business computer that will use a videodisk to instruct its buyer on how to use it.

title: W.B.A. WARNS WEAVER TO FACE TILLIS PROMPTLY
description: Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, has until Saturday to sign to defend his title against Mike Tillis or be stripped of his title, a top W.B.A. official has warned.

title: INCONCLUSIVE
description: Since Israel's air strike that destroyed Iraq's nuclear reactor on June 7, Government officials and private nuclear experts have been debating a critical issue: Was Iraq planning to develop an atomic bomb and, if it was, could it have done so?

title: Suzuki Starts Talks With Dutch
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki of Japan arrived in the Netherlands today and immediately began talks with Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt. Mr. Suzuki arrived from London after a tour of six Western European countries aimed at easing trade tensions. He is expected to face criticism of a growing trade imbalance between the Netherlands and Japan.

title: Budget Unit Role at Issue
description: A study by the American Law Division of the Library of Congress said today that President Reagan had exceeded his authority in making the Office of Management and Budget the gatekeeper in the Federal process intended to reduce the regulatory burden on the economy.

title: GREECE DENYING REPORTS OF SOVIET NAVAL ACCORD
description: The Greek Government today denied reports in the British press that new access to repair facilities was being given to auxiliary vessels of the Soviet combat fleet in the Mediterranean.

title: JERSEY SPENT $6.3 MILLION ON THE PRIMARY
description: New Jersey taxpayers spent $6.3 million to help most of the record field of 21 candidates in the June 2 gubernatorial primaries conduct their campaigns, according to reports filed yesterday by the candidates. Officials said the cost would go even higher when final reports are filed next month.

title: Around the Nation; SAN DIEGO REALTY AGENTS ASSAILED IN COURT RULING
description: A California appeals court has ruled that it is illegal to charge a fixed fee such as 6 percent to sell a house and for a realty agent's association to maintain that fee.

title: ANDERSEN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SOUTH AFRICAN BANNED FOR BID TO JANE FONDA
description: A white student who invited Jane Fonda and her husband, Tom Hayden, to South Africa was put under a five-year ban by the Government today. The actress, saying she was ''outraged,'' vowed to campaign on the student's behalf.

title: Broadway; Musical about life of Jean Seberg tentative for spring
description: TENTATIVELY, there is a musical about Jean Seberg scheduled for next spring. Reluctantly the people involved will talk, or else they will talk about it not at all. ''I have nothing to say about it, absolutely nothing,'' said Marvin Hamlisch, who has written the music. In fact, the musical, called ''Jean,'' may be thought of as a kind of work in progress, and Mr. Hamlisch and his collaborators Richard Adler, the lyricist, and Julian Barry, the book writer - are waiting to see if Michael Bennett will collaborate, too. Mr. Bennett is already director and co-choreographer of ''Dream Girls,'' which is now scheduled to open at the Winter Garden in December, and the question is whether he wants to direct and choreograph ''Jean'' as well. Meanwhile, Mr. Hamlisch, Mr. Adler and Mr. Barry are waiting, and while they wait they are rewriting.

title: TEXT OF THE U.N. DRAFT RESOLUTION
description: Following is the text of a draft resolution that is to be submitted to the Security Council on Israel's raid on the Iraqi nuclear reactor:

title: Bridge: It May Take Long Thought To See Error in Some Plays
description: Playing second-hand-low is so deeply ingrained in the consciousness of all experienced players that even experts sometimes miss the occasions that call for second-hand-high. It was certainly very difficult for West to see that the normal play was fatal on the diagramed deal, played last weekend in the Grand National Team zonal playoffs in Washington.

title: Athletes to Join Youngsters in Street Games
description: About 100 youngsters who belong to the Police Athletic League will be joined by professional athletes and sports announcers in a competition of street games tomorrow from 1 to 4 P.M. on West 60th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues.

title: REQUEST CALLED ROUTINE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that, acting on a request by the Israeli Government, it had advised Israeli scientists last Oct. 9 about the amount of damage that would be inflicted on a nuclear reactor by 1,000-kilogram (2,200-pound) bombs.

title: MUSEUMS ARE HIGHLIGHTING SHAKESPEARE AND CHINA COLLECTION FROM FOLGER
description: AT NATURAL HISTORY By JOHN RUSSELL

title: 'COUP DE SIROCCO'
description: ''COUP DE SIROCCO'' bears a certain resemblance to ''Bread and Chocolate,'' being the self-consciously heart-rending story of people living as outsiders in a foreign land. It's told in a graceless and self-serving way. But the story is sad and moving, and it has enough sentimental energy to make it involving.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 7
Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-20.00** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOLLOWING POE'S FOOTSTEPS ON MANHATTAN'S OLD PUBLISHERS ROW
description: Edgar Allan Poe belonged to a world other than our own, a world of haunted palaces, sealed cellars and ''Night's Plutonian Shore.'' But he walked the streets of New York, a young literary critic and newspaperman, most often a little drunk and always belligerent in his dark-eyed, feverish way. The Academy of American Poets will track Edgar Allan Poe, New York journalist, in ''A Walk Through Publishers Row: 1844-45,'' a free walking tour, tomorrow at 2:30 P.M.

title: BIG CROSSTOWN BROWSE ON 52D STREET RETURNS
description: Jazz bands will play, pottery wheels will whir, and waiters and waitresses will run an obstacle course during the sixth annual 52d Street Fair, one of the city's largest street festivals, which will occupy 52d Street between Third and Ninth Avenues on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: Notes On people; For Larry Kert, a Happy Ending Four Years Late
description: He made his Broadway debut as the leading man in ''West Side Story'' in 1957. He's appeared in nightclubs, on television and on tour, and he received a Tony nomination when he starred in Stephen Sondheim's ''Company'' in New York in 1970.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES TO CUT TAX RATES
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved, 15 to 4, President Reagan's proposal to cut individual tax rates across-the-board by 25 percent over 33 months, starting next Oct. 1, while the House Ways and Means Committee approved $3.3 billion of special tax relief to six basic industries in the next four years.

title: TOSCO TAKEOVER BATTLE IS HEATING UP
description: The Tosco Corporation, trying to block acquisition of its shares by an outsider, again finds itself in a mudslinging court fight. This time the nation's second-largest independent oil refiner is battling Kenneth M. Good, a Denver developer.

title: Free Eastern Dance
description: Fifteen Middle Eastern dances, some from Turkey and Egypt, will be performed by Serena Wilson and her ensemble tomorrow at 8 P.M. in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Avery International, a manufacturer of self-adhesive labels and labeling systems, appointed Richard J. Hartl group vice president of technology.

title: WESTCHESTER SIGNS CONTRACT FOR A GARBAGE-TO-FUEL PLANT
description: Westchester County ended an eight-year search for a solution to its garbage disposal problem today by signing an agreement with Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. of Hampton, N.H., to convert the refuse of 34 municipalities into low-cost electricity.

title: SENATORS OPEN HEARING TO EXAMINE WHETHER IRAQ RAID BROKE U.S. LAW
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee began a series of hearings today into Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor on June 7 to determine whether, among other things, the raid violated a 1952 agreement governing the use of American-supplied arms.

title: Auctions; When time really is money.
description: THE time to buy watches and jewelry may be next week, when there will be four sales in three of New York's top auction houses. The action opens with the auction of watches, silver wares and Russian works of art next Monday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street. The watches, which will be up for bidding in the afternoon session, include some of the most expensive wares in the auction.

title: SETTLEMENT SOUGHT IN I.B.M. CASE
description: Moving to explore what the lead attorney of the International Business Machines Corporation called the ''last clear chance'' to settle or narrow the Government's monumental antitrust case against the computer giant, the two sides agreed yesterday on procedures for settlement discussions in the United States District Court here.

title: Money Funds Post $2.1 Billion Gain
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds jumped nearly $2.1 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: WEEKENDERS AND COMMUTERS SHARE FRIDAY HEAT ON L.I.R.R.
description: It is Friday night at the Long Island Rail Road gates in Penn Station, and pandemonium reigns. The temperature would be excessive in a malfunctioning steam bath; unintelligible squawks blare from the public-address system, and passengers dash at top speed in all directions, frequently colliding.

title: AN ERROR-CONDITIONED BILL
description: Who should bear the higher cost of generating electricity in the summer? Economics - and common sense - suggest that it should be those who use the power. But the New York Legislature apparently disagrees. Both houses have passed a bill exempting the first 500 kilowatt-hours used each month by residential customers from higher seasonal rates. Only a veto by Governor Carey can stop it.

title: Chief of Operations Quits Vornado Posts
description: Seymour Karch, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Vornado Inc., the troubled discount store chain that operates the Two Guys stores, resigned yesterday. The company said that Mr. Karch, who will remain until a successor is named, is leaving ''to pursue other personal business interests.''

title: PLAY: JOHN SPEICHER'S 'FASNACHT DAY'
description: IN his first two novels, John Speicher took an unsparing, interior view of men at war with themselves on an urban battlefield. His third book, ''Lower and Lower,'' brought a characteristically tormented character home to his childhood in an attempt to penetrate his primal nature. ''Fasnacht Day,'' Mr. Speicher's first play, covers some of the same emotional territory of ''Lower and Lower,'' with the welcome addition of humor and theatricality. The play, now running at the Meat and Potatoes Company in a production directed by James E. Dwyer, is sprawling and somewhat repetitive, but it offers definite signs that the author is a talented dramatist as well as novelist.

title: Turner Inc. Seeking $50 Million in Loans
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc., parent of the all-news Cable News Network and the Atlanta Braves, said it was working to obtain $50 million in financing before its annual stockholders meeting next week without selling additional stock.

title: Indefinite Auto Layoffs Drop
description: The number of indefinite layoffs in the American auto industry dipped again this week and scheduled car production was running 28 percent ahead of the comparable 1980 week, according to industry reports today.

title: Alfonso Bressan, Leader In TV Sound Technology
description: Alfonso Bressan, supervisor of audio operations for the CBS televison network, died Wednesday of lung cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in Wantagh, L.I.

title: ALBANY COURT CUTS LIABILITY OF CHECKROOMS ON LOSSES
description: The state's highest court gave new meaning today to the old restaurant warning, ''Watch Your Coat.'' The Court of Appeals narrowly defined the circumstances under which a restaurant patron can recover the full cost of a garment that disappears from a checkroom.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
STUDIES BY 2 NETWORKS DISPUTE MORAL MAJORITY
description: TV and NBC-TV yesterday released separate studies indicating that most television viewers, including members of the fundamentalist Moral Majority, oppose efforts to have their viewing choices restricted, and do not believe that any specific prime-time shows include excessive levels of sex or violence.

title: B.P. RAISES $1.2 BILLION IN A STOCK ISSUE
description: The British Petroleum Company went to its shareholders today to raise $1.2 billion of new capital, setting a record for a new stock offering by a British or American company.

title: SPINKS SEIZED ON GUN CHARGE Thursday morning
description: Less than a week after Larry Holmes knocked him out, Leon Spinks was arrested and charged today with carrying a concealed unregistered weapon.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: EXPLOSIVELY HOT
description: A furniture truck burning on a street in Los Angeles after its propane fuel tank ignited.

title: CITY BUDGET PASSES AS HURDLE ON TRANSIT HIRINGS IS CLEARED
description: A compromise was reached yesterday on legislation to change work rules for the Transit Authority police, clearing the way for New York City to add 500 officers to subway and bus patrols in the next year.

title: MUSEUMS ARE HIGHLIGHTING SHAKESPEARE AND CHINA PAINTING ROOMS AND A
description: GARDEN OPEN AT MET By HILTON KRAMER

title: At the Movies; A DANCER INTENT ON MAKING IT AS AN ACTRESS
description: ANN REINKING has blue eyes, long legs, a husky voice and a determination to make it as an actress, since dancers (always excepting Fred Astaire) can't go on forever. ''Can you imagine being 40 years old?'' she says, ''and having to worry because you don't jump so high anymore?''

title: A FIGHT FOR AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: A national organization of women who work in offices began a drive today to counter efforts by the Reagan Administration, businesses and some Republicans in Congress to dilute the Government's affirmative-action activities.

title: About Real Estate; PIANO FACTORY TURNED INTO A CO-OP AT 10TH AVE. AND 45TH
description: There was a time when Wessell Nickel & Gross built piano actions for most of the American piano manufacturers. All three gentlemen were Steinway craftsmen who in due time set up their own establishment on West 45th Street in Manhattan, on the northeast corner of 10th Avenue. That was in the 1870's.

title: LABOR GIVES DEMOCRATS $200,000 AS MANATT ASSAILS REP. GRAMM
description: The Democratic Party is groping toward ways of achieving greater party discipline and is impressing organized labor in the process.

title: Canadian Wheat for China
description: The Canadian Wheat Board said today that it had sold 1.4 million tons of wheat to China on a cash basis in Canadian dollars. Delivery is to be made between Aug.1 and Jan.31, 1982.

title: Around the Nation; COAST FIRE FATAL TO BOY BELIEVED WORK OF ARSONIST
description: The fire that killed a child and critically burned three members of the child's family was set deliberately, the authorities said today.

title: THE OUTLOOK OF FEMMINISM DEBATED BY VASAR PANELS
description: Feminism, the cultural patterns that perpetuated male dominance, the irrelevance of much of the current women's movement to women in minority groups and the dangers of a return to the antifeminism of the 1920's and 30's were among the themes dominating the Fifth Berkshire Conference on the History of Women, which ended here today.

title: 'MR. FORBUSH' STUDIES PENGUIN MATING
description: FOR those who like penguins -and, really, who wouldn't? -the Thalia has a nice surprise. ''Mr. Forbush and the Penguins,'' which will be shown there today and tomorrow, is a film that's for the birds in the best sense of that phrase. The actual title of this previously unreleased 1971 film is ''Cry of the Penguins,'' and perhaps that has a melodramatic ring. But many of these birds' best scenes have a passion and poignancy that human players don't often match.

title: Business People; 14 Real Estate Brokers Going to Pearce, Urstadt
description: On July 1, Robert J. Mehlman, 47, will lead 13 other real estate brokers, his entire department, from Herbert Charles & Company to Pearce, Urstadt, Mayer & Greer, when he becomes president of its new commercial leasing division. The reason for the move from one New York real estate firm to the other: the Charles concern is leaving the field of commercial leasing and the Pearce company is going into it full steam.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1981
description: International The United States and Iraq agreed on a Security Council resolution that ''strongly condemns'' the Israeli attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor and urges Israel to open its nuclear plants to international inspection. Western diplomats at the United Nations said that the resolution was expected to win unanimous approval at an open meeting today. (Page A1, Column 1.) Israel sought and received advice from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission last October about how much damage would be inflicted on a nuclear reactor with 1,000-kilogram (2,200-pound) obmbs. Bombs of that size apparently were used by Israeli airplaned last June 7 to destroy the Iraqi nuclear reactor at Baghdad. (A1:1.)

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,807,990 for t qr and $3,011,268 for the 9 mos...C-After $69,224 loss from dis operations...D-Net income after $172,163 loss from discontinued shr earns reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Jan 30, 1981

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard HOW IT FEELS WHEN A PARENT DIES. By Jill Krementz. Illustrated. 110 pages. Knopf. $9.95.

title: 2 FORMER RIDERS BACKED IN RULING AGAINST BOARD
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan yesterday refused a motion by the State Racing and Wagering Board to cite Jose Amy and Con Errico for contempt because they would not answer questions in its race-fixing investigation.

title: The U.N. Today; June 19, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on complaint by Iraq and at 3 P.M. on Interim Force in Lebanon. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: HAIG ARRIVES IN MANILA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. yesterday as he reviewed honor guard. Later, he laid a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Sol-dier at the U.S. and Philippine cemeteries. Mr. Haig is in Manila for talks on regional security with foreign ministers of Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Sales figures include other income of $6,038,000 and $13,207,00 for the latest qr and 6 mos, respectively, and $4,641,000 and $9,685,000 for the previous qr and 6 mos respectively

title: Paul Albano Despite Rescue Efforts, Beached Whale Dies on Long Island
description: A front-loader tractor and several volunteers trying to tow a sperm whale back to sea yesterday after the 24-foot-long mammal beached itself near Point Lookout, L.I. Ef-forts to save the five-year-old animal were in vain and it died about three hours after it was found in shallow water. An autopsy failed to reveal the cause of death.

title: Pan Am Rating Cut
description: Moody's Investors Service said that it cut to B from Ba its ratings on guaranteed loan certificates and secured equipment certificates of Pan American World Airways Inc. The lower rating reflected Pan Am's recent large losses.

title: SATIRE FROM AESOP TO PERELMAN SHOWN
description: ''Satire is what closes Saturday night,'' George S. Kaufman said about the theater in the 1930's, a wisecrack that hasn't quite held up. But the line is amusing, and it makes you think twice about the aims of that most useful weapon of words, satire.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The debate is on in British financial circles: Will Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher reverse her field and stimulate the economy, or will she be able to resist the growing pressure to do so from business leaders and politicians?

title: ROOSEVELT STRUGGLES TO REVERSE DECLINE
description: Roosevelt Raceway began a 49-night summer meeting tonight that will be watched closely by legislators and the harness racing industry.

title: U.S. TRADE IS IN SURPLUS BY $3.1 BILLION IN QUARTER
description: The nation showed a $3.1 billion firstquarter surplus in its foreign trade balance as measured by the broad current account of goods, services and other financial transactions, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Around the World; SOVIET JEWISH ACTIVIST GETS FIVE YEARS OF INTERNAL EXILE
description: After a trial that lasted a day and a half, a Soviet judge today sentenced Viktor Brailovsky, a Jewish activist, to five years of internal exile on charges of defaming the Soviet state.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JUNE 19, 1981
description: The Economy

title: Trusthouse Forte-Savoy
description: S.G. Warburg Ltd. said today that it had purchased on behalf of Trusthouse Forte Ltd. 9.59 million 'A' ordinary shares of Savoy Hotel Ltd. at 190 pence and 95,584 'B' ordinary shares at 1,122.5 pence from the Kuwait Investment Office, indicating a value on the transaction of about $18.76 million. The purchases raise Trusthouse Forte's stake in the Savoy to 60.16 percent of total equity and 37.47 percent of total votes. The Trusthouse offer for the Savoy closes tomorrow.

title: Dutch Break Up Nuclear Protest
description: Riot policemen cleared 500 antinuclear demonstrators from the main gate of the uranium enrichment plant in this eastern Dutch city today, permitting nine busloads of employees to get to work, the authorities said.

title: Letters
description: FRAGMENTING THE CARE SYSTEM FOR THE MENTALLY ILL

title: U.S. DEFENDS REPORT ON SALVADOR ARMS
description: The State Department today issued a detailed rebuttal of criticisms of an official report on Communist arms shipments through Cuba and Nicaragua to El Salvador's guerrillas.

title: Landlords Urge Tenant Tax Cut
description: An association of apartment building owners, hoping to revive investor interest in rental properties, urged Congress today to grant tenants the same interest and propertytax deductions that homeowners get.

title: WEAVERS TO BE REUNITED AT HUDSON RIVER REVIVAL
description: It did not take much to spread the word. A single newspaper advertisement last December announcing the reunion of the Weavers immediately sold out both of their performances at Carnegie Hall. With recordings of such songs as ''Goodnight, Irene,'' ''Tzena Tzena'' and ''So Long, It's Been Good to Know You,'' the four singers sparked the folk-music boom of the 1950's, even though they had been blacklisted for most of that decade. They had last sung together in 1962, but nostalgia for the group - Pete Seeger, Ronnie Gilbert, Fred Hellerman and Lee Hays - remains high.

title: ORIGINATED 'DICK AND JANE' TEXTS
description: Zerna A. Sharp, who created the concept for the Dick and Jane reading textbooks that were widely used in American classrooms for four decades, died on Wednesday at the Wesley Manor nursing home in Frankfort, Ind. She was 91 years old.

title: RUSSELL STOVER CANDIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
No Headline
description: IRANIAN OFFICIAL ASSERTS BANI-SADR HAS VANISHED AND MAY HAVE FLED

title: ART: ZORACH AND TRAJAN, 2 SCULPTORS WHO PAINTED
description: THE juxtaposition of shows by William Zorach (1889-1966) and Turku Trajan (1887-1956) at the Zabriskie Gallery (29 West 57th Street) is apt in many ways. Both men were immigrants - Zorach from Lithuania and Trajan from Hungary - and both were sculptors who also painted. But while the one achieved considerable success in his lifetime, the other died in poverty, having failed to sell one work.

title: PIRATING PERSONNEL IN MEXICO
description: They wear neither black eye patches nor three-cornered hats, but they are nevertheless known here as pirates. And, armed with a secret list of names and telephone numbers, they swoop down at a moment's notice on unsuspecting companies and steal away top managers.

title: Around the World; U.S. CLEARS MILITARY VEHICLES FOR EXPORT TO GUATEMALA
description: The Reagan Administration, easing human rights restrictions on military aid to Guatemala, has issued an export license for jeeps and trucks valued at $3.1 million for the Guatemalan army.

title: Sale of The Real Paper Final
description: The sale of The Real Paper, a nine-year-old alternative weekly, to its rival, The Boston Pheonix, has been made final. The sale Tuesday left The Phoenix with a subscription list ''somewhere around 10,000,'' according to Stephen M. Mindich, owner of The Phoenix. Neither William D. Scott 2d, publisher of The Real Paper, nor Mr. Mindich would give the price of the paper, which ceased publication last week.

title: Curb Urged on Commodity Pool
description: The Government asked a Federal judge today to take charge of a Colorado commodity investment pool accused of defrauding customers of millions of dollars.

title: The Evening Hours
description: P ERRY RATHBONE said all the right things. ''I don't believe it. Oh, my God. I've never seen anything like it. David, you liar. What a deceiver you are. I'll never trust you again.'' The occasion was, of course, a surprise party for Mr. Rathbone. It was his 70th birthday, and his comments convinced the 100 friends present that he really was suprised. Otherwise he would have said something more original, right?

title: THORPE LEADS U.S. OPEN BY 1 ON A 66 hole at the U.S. Open
description: As sometimes happens in the first round of the United States Open, a relatively unknown player led the field today. This time it was Jim Thorpe, one of the few black players on the professional golf tour.

title: Letters; ARGENTINE NIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: One Killed, 5 Hurt in Plane Crash
description: A light plane crashed into a house and garage in this Minneapolis suburb today, killing one person and injuring five, including Jeff Siemon, a football player with the Minnesota Vikings, the authorities said.

title: 11.41 DROP PUTS DOW AT 995.15
description: Wall Street's apprehension over the current uncertain trend of interest rates sent the stock market down sharply yesterday in much slower trading. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 11.41 points, to 995.15, closing below the 1,000 level for the first time in the last five sessions.

title: Father's Day Races
description: The New York Road Runners Club and Citibank plan a Father's Day of racing Sunday in Central Park, with two races.

title: Advertising; Music Channel on Cable TV
description: OVER at Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment, the word for the day is, ''Youth will be served.'' Now, that's not the little preteens; the company's already taking care of them with its Nickelodeon, which is cable network programming for wee ones. This is the big kids, the kind that get turned on by the big rock sound and the weird assemblages that make it. This is the kind of youth that has enough discretionary income from some source or other to make it of interest to advertisers.

title: News Analysis
description: In his 23 years on the Supreme Court, Potter Stewart has been a lawyer rather than a philosopher. Throughout the Court's history, some Justices have used the Court as a platform from which to shape doctrine and take American law in new directions. Potter Stewart has not been such a Justice. Intelligent, somewhat patrician, instinctively conservative, he has taken his job to be that of deciding cases rather than pronouncing theory.

title: Andrea Shapiro Is Bride Of Michael Goldschlager
description: Andrea Gene Shapiro, daughter of Beverly Myers Shapiro of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Jay A. Shapiro of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Goldschlager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Goldschlager of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Judah Nadich performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Letters; THE HUNGER STRIKE IN ANCIENT IRISH LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters; AN A.M.A. INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Docutel Corp. announced the public offering of 600,000 shares of common stock at $31.50 a share, underwritten by a Rauscher Pierce Refnes Inc. group.

title: Around the World; GREECE HALTS NEGOTIATIONS ON AMERICAN MILITARY BASES
description: The Greek Government today suspended negotiations with the United States on a new defense and economic cooperation agreement covering the operation of American military bases here.

title: ASIAN PARLEY URGES CAMBODIAN SOLUTION
description: The five non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia ended a conference tonight at which they laid the groundwork for their approach to next month's meeting at the United Nations on Vietnam's continuing occupation of Cambodia.

title: The Region; Labor Chief Indicted On Extortion Count
description: The president of a labor union based on Long Island has been arrested on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands on Federal charges of having extorted more than $40,000 from a Long Island businessman in 1975 and 1976, Federal officials said.

title: Dance at Japan House
description: New dance and ballet works will be presented by Dancers in Repertory this weekend at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street. Tickets are $5. Information: 832-1155, extension 33.

title: Harvard Lampoon To Parody People
description: The droll, witty Harvard Lampoon staff, the prime joshers of the Ivy League, have selected People magazine for their next parody effort. And now that they've discovered that you can make money selling ad space in them, it's oh so much more fun.

title: STAGE: 'HOW IT ALL BEGAN,' 60'S TERRORISTS STORY
description: ''HOW IT ALL BEGAN'' began as an improvisational exercise for third-year acting students at Juilliard. Its classroom origins, I'm afraid, remain all too clearly apparent in the polished version, directed by Des McAnuff, that opened at the Public last night. This documentary theater piece tries hard to deal with a volatile topic - contemporary urban terrorism - in a factual, objective manner. While the evening's studious approach is to be applauded, ''How It All Began'' could do with fewer facts and a lot more political and theatrical sophistication.

title: NEW YORK NEEDS TRUE CRISIS
description: The New York City transit system badly needs a crisis - not the kind of slow strangulation that the newspapers have been calling a ''crisis'' for the last 10 years or so, but a wheels-grinding-to-ahalt, tunnel-clogging, gridlocking crisis.

title: Letters; MERCHANTS OF DOOM
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes On People; Prince's Heckling Celebrated
description: Kevin Martin, one of four Irish nationalists charged with disorderly conduct for shouting political invective at Prince Charles at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night, was at Liffey's bar in Elmhurst, Queens, last night celebrating what he called ''our victory.''

title: DRIVE TO FILL CITY JAIL JOBS STEPPED UP
description: The Correction Department went out into the streets of New York to seek recruits yesterday because so few had responded to its earlier less-visible hiring campaign despite a high unemployment rate in the city.

title: Mack Trucks Lists Loss for Quarter
description: Mack Trucks today reported a loss of $2 million on sales of $364.6 million in the first quarter of 1981 ended March 31, a sharp reversal from its record earnings in the same period last year.

title: Around the Nation; CLEANUP SYSTEM APPROVED FOR THREE MILE ISLAND
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a decontamination system at Three Mile Island to clean up nearly a million gallons of radioactive water trapped in the plant for 27 months.

title: TWO SAY PLAN TO SEIZE DOMINICA WAS TO THWART A COMMUNIST PLOT
description: Michael Norris and Joe Daniel Hawkins, two of three men on trial for plotting to overthrow the government of Dominica, testified in Federal District Court here today that they thought they were part of a legitimate effort to save the tiny Caribbean island from Communism.

title: 'SUPERMAN II' IS FULL OF TRICKS
description: ''SUPERMAN II'' is a marvelous toy. It's funny, it's full of tricks and it manages to be royally entertaining, which is really all it aims for. This hasn't been a good year for real people or recognizable situations on the screen. But it's a fine time for cardboard heroes, and none of these are as enjoyably two-dimensional as the omnipotent Man of Steel. ''Superman II'' doesn't break new ground in the thrills-and-chills realm, the way ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' does. But the makers of the 1978 ''Superman'' have set out to build a better mousetrap, and they've succeeded.

title: AN ABSCAM JURY INDICTS 2 IN LINK TO CASINO BRIBE
description: The Mayor of Camden, N.J., and a former vice chairman of New Jersey's Casino Control Commission were indicted yesterday on Federal extortion and conspiracy charges of taking $125,000 in illegal payments from undercover agents.

title: Around the World; MOSLEM-CHRISTIAN DISPUTE TOUCHES OFF RIOTING IN CAIRO
description: Rioting broke out in a poor quarter of Cairo yesterday and continued today, killing at least two people and injuring 31, according to the Interior Ministry.

title: Woolworth to Close More Woolco Stores
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company, which lost $6 million on its worldwide network of retail stores in the first quarter, will close more discount stores this year and accelerate its expansion into specialty stores, the company's top executives told stockholders yesterday.

title: WEAPONS ARE NOT A POLICY
description: In one sense, the President is right. He needs no foreign affairs speech to prove that his Administration has a distinctive tendency abroad. It is plainly buying friends with weaponry, wherever it seems even loosely to help contain the Soviet Union.

title: Market Place; Cement Shares Arouse Interest
description: FANS of General Portland Inc. have been praising this major cement producer for years, but nobody seemed to be listening. However, the company's stock began to show surprising vigor last week. After closing at 24 1/4, off 3/8, on Tuesday, the shares shot upward to finish Friday at 33 5/8.

title: Time Inc. Stock Split
description: Directors of Time Inc. have proposed a 2-for-1 split in the company's stock and increased the quarterly dividend 11 percent. J. Richard Munro, president of the diversified communications and forest products company, said shareholders would be asked on Aug. 20 to approve an increase in Time's authorized shares. If approved, the additional shares would be distributed on or about Oct. 1 to shareholders of record Sept. 1. The quarterly dividend, discounting the split, was raised to 50 cents from 45 cents, payable Sept. 15 to shareholders of record Sept. 1.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
description: B-After $2,748,396 loss from discontinued operations

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alcan Aluminum Corp,, the United States unit of Alcan Aluminum Ltd., said it will wait until 1984 to build a planned $32 million heat-treatment line at its Oswego, N.Y., plant.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
L.I. Couple Die in Fire
description: A Long Island couple died in a fire that swept their small frame home today, the Nassau County police said. The victims were identified as 51-year-old John Graham and his wife, Adele, 71, of 6 Morgan Place in Port Washington. Detectives said that the fire apparently started in a rear bedroom occupied by Mrs. Graham, who was an invalid. Mr. Graham's body was found in a front bedroom. Detectives said an alarm had been called in at 3:33 A.M.

title: Koch Seeks Crackdown On Fire Code Violations
description: Mayor Koch, asserting that builders and building owners were violating zoning and building laws and accepting fines as ''the price of doing business,'' yesterday proposed stiffer fines and jail sentences for violators.

title: INTEREST RATES INCREASE AGAIN
description: A six-week-old pattern of declining bond yields was interrupted for the second straight day yesterday by a sharp increase in shortterm interest rates that has surprised bankers and securities dealers.

title: SENATE HEARINGS ON ABORTION CLOSE ON EMOTIONAL NOTE
description: Senate hearings on a bill designed to ban abortion ended today on an emotional pitch, with a wide range of medical and religious groups calling the measure unconstitutional, scientifically unsound and potentially damaging to the health of American women.

title: IRAQ REPORTED A BUILDUP
description: Officials and diplomats at the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna said today that Iraq had been stockpiling uranium for at least a year before Israeli planes destroyed its French-built reactor on June 7.

title: Armstrong Purchase
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company has purchased 70 percent of its outstanding 8.25 percent cumulative preferred stock from its holders, the company said today. Financial details of the transaction were not disclosed, but James A. Walsh, chairman, said the principal value of the stock was $6.7 million. Armstrong, with headquarters in New Haven, is the sixth-largest domestic tire manufacturer in the United States.

title: BASEBALL TALKS TO RESUME
description: As the baseball strike became one week and a record 87 games old yesterday, a meeting of the owners' player relations committee seemed to provide the only hope that today's bargaining session could produce some movement in the dispute between the players and the club owners. At best, though, that hope was only a glimmer.

title: Economic Scene; The Challenge Facing Reagan
description: THE biggest mistake President Reagan made at his news conference this week appears to have been his attack on House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., whom he accused of ''sheer demogoguery'' for criticizing his economic program as too generous to the wealthy and too hard on working people and the poor. ''I'm trying to find out something about his boyhood,'' the President said, ''because we didn't live on the wrong side of the railroad tracks, but we lived so close to them we could hear the whistle real loud.''

title: Foreign Affairs; CONTINUITY OF STATE
description: The new French Government has proclaimed continuity and fulfillment of all state agreements as a cardinal principle of its foreign policy.

title: PEKING SAYS ARMS FOR TAIWAN PERIL U.S.-CHINA TIE
description: The New China News Agency, in an assessment of the visit by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., said today that China and the United States had ''identical or similar views'' on global strategic matters and had made progress in improving their realtions. But it said the issue of arms sales to Taiwan remained a stumbling block.

title: F.D.A. HEAD URGES LESS SALT IN FOOD
description: The Commissioner of Food and Drugs said today that his agency would press for the labeling of the salt content in foods and the lowering of the amount of salt in foods in general.

title: Calderon at St. Patrick's
description: ''The Purgatory of St. Patrick,'' a play by the 16th-century Spanish writer Pedro Calderon de la Barca, will be presented by the Royal Theater of Spain on Sunday at 7 P.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and 50th Street. The free performance, a world premiere, will be in Spanish; a version in English will be done next Thursday at 7 P.M. Information: 753-2261.

title: The Region; L.I.R.R. Dismisses Suspended Engineer
description: The Long Island Rail Road dismissed an engineer who had been suspended and charged with intoxication after he drove a train at excessive speeds past three scheduled stops on May 2, a railroad spokesman said.

title: Around the World; SENATE ASKS ADMINISTRATION TO BACK BABY FORMULA CODE
description: The Senate voted 89 to 2 today to urge the Reagan Administration and the infant formula industry ''to support the basic aim'' of a World Health Organization code restricting the promotion of formula.

title: RUSSIAN SCORNS CHINESE AS 'AGENTS' OF U.S.
description: A Soviet commentator today cited news reports that the United States had an electronic intelligence station in China as evidence that the Chinese were becoming ''voluntary agents of the imperialist intelligence services,'' which he described as a ''disgraceful role.''

title: WHITE HOUSE WARNS FLIGHT CONTROLLERS
description: Saying ''we will not tolerate an illegal strike,'' the White House yesterday reinforced warnings of stern legal action against air traffic controllers who are threatening a nationwide walkout starting Monday.

title: NAVY REPORTS 6 OF 14 KILLED ABOARD NIMITZ HAD USED MARIJUANA
description: The Navy acknowledged today that six of the 14 men killed in a crash aboard the aircraft carrier Nimitz had smoked marijuana but said that drug use had not caused the accident.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have entrusted him to God. May God keep him.'' - Robabeh Sakineh, sister of President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran.

title: SOVIET PLANS BIG ORBITING STATION
description: A Soviet research satellite docked with the orbiting Salyut 6 space laboratory today in the first step toward building a permanent station in space, the Tass press agency announced.

title: STRIKE FINDS STAUB BUSY ON THREE JOBS
description: Rushing from one part of Manhattan to another this week, Rusty Staub certainly did not seem like a ballplayer whiling away the lazy afternoons of the baseball strike. Instead, Staub was attending to the frenzied demands of three jobs - striking athlete, restaurateur and labor negotiator.

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Miss Lotz Dies of Injuries Suffered in Diving Mishap
description: Jenny Lotz, an American diver who suffered brain and spinal cord injuries in a training accident a week ago, died yesterday, a spokesman at Veterans Hospital here announced today.

title: L.I. MAN ACCUSED AT TRIAL OF NAZI PAST
description: The United States Government is seeking to deport a 62-year-old Long Island man who is said to have been an officer at a Nazi prison camp in Estonia. Some 12,000 Eastern Europeans, including 2,000 Jews, were executed at the camp in World War II.

title: THE COMMITTEE SYSTEM: ALBANY'S FUNNELL FOR BILLS
description: They call it ''the Boulevard of Broken Dreams,'' a gleaming mahogany table littered with dead and dying pieces of legislation.

title: Patents; Quick Way To Destroy Mine Fields
description: A METHOD of destroying mine fields by wide overhead explosions has been invented by Navy researchers. A number of rounds can be fired from a launch vehicle, creating explosive clouds that are detonated.

title: LENA HORNE SHOW IS RESUMED
description: The curtain went up as usual last night for ''Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music,'' following an accident that halted and forced the cancellation of Thursday night's performance.

title: Marathon Test Well
description: Marathon Petroleum Indonesia Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Marathon Oil Company, said a delineation well on the Kakap Block in the Natuna Sea off Indonesia had flowed 6,594 barrels of oil and 4.4 million cubic feet of natural gas a day in a series of tests. The well was drilled to a total depth of 8,100 feet in association with three companies, including Hudbay Oil Indonesia Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of Hudson's Bay Oil and Gas Company of Calgary, Alberta, and Coastal Indonesia Inc., a wholly owned unit of the Coastal Corporation of Houston. Additional drilling will be conducted to define the reserves, the company said.

title: 2 Businessmen Join Lincoln Center Board
description: Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and Thomas H. Wyman, president of CBS, have been elected to the board of Lincoln Center. Mr. Butcher will also become chairman of the center's Consolidated Corporate Fund.

title: Elizabeth White and David Herter Wed
description: Elizabeth Virden White and David Bigelow Herter were married yesterday on Fishers Island, N.Y. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. and the Rev. Peter Sturtevant.

title: CANADIAN COURT DASHES TRUDEAU'S HOPE FOR NEW CONSTITUTION JULY 1
description: July 1 was to have been a climactic day in the political career of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau. Canada's national holiday, commemorating the establishment of the Canadian federation in 1867, would have been marked this year by the completion of its independence from Britain with the proclamation of a new constitution.

title: AM INTERNATIONAL'S STRUGGLE
description: It was only on April 8 that Richard B. Black moved into AM International, the maker of Addressograph machines and a slew of other office products, to try to turn the company around. For four years, Roy L. Ash, once the No.2 man at Litton Industries and then former President Nixon's budget director, had tried to do the same, before he collided with the AM board and resigned.

title: A RETIRED DISTRICT HEALTH OFFICER
description: Dr. Oma Henry Price, a retired district health officer of the New York City Department of Health, died Monday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock divd paid in May 1981

title: EXCERPTS FROM STEWART'S SESSION WITH REPORTERS
description: Following are excerpts from Associate Justice Potter Stewart's news conference today. In the transcript, Justice Stewart's answers are verbatim but the questions are paraphrased for brevity.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK'S SPEECH BEFORE VOTE
description: Following is the text of the speech to the Security Council today by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American representative at the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Man in Stolen Car Dies in Chase Crash
description: One man was killed and another injured yesterday when the stolen car they were in crashed into a railing at the Manhattan exit of the Brooklyn Bridge while being chased by the police.

title: BIPARTISAN CANDIDATE KOCH
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMAICAN LEADER URGES A DOUBLING OF CARIBBEAN AID
description: Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga of Jamaica said today that the goal of a proposed Caribbean and Central American development program should be to double the region's per capita income in 15 years.

title: JUSTICE STEWART ON HIS RETIREMENT: 'BETTER TO GO TOO SOON'
description: Citing his belief in ''the principle that it's better to go too soon than to stay too long,'' Associate Justice Potter Stewart talked today about his decision to retire from the Supreme Court next month and his view of the job he has held for 23 years.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: University of California Regents, casting votes as 200 protesters chanted and clapped, agreed today to continue managing nuclear weapons laboratories for the Federal Government.

title: Amy Finkelstein and Jeffrey Diamond Wed
description: Amy Susan Finkelstein and Jeffrey Lewis Diamond were married yesterday. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson of Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathan G. Finkelstein at the Lombardy Hotel. Mr. Diamond is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon D. Diamond of Great Neck.

title: 43 PERSONS ARE FELLED BY CARBON MONOXIDE IN A JERSEY HAIR SALON
description: Carbon monoxide fumes circulating through the cooling system of a hairdressing salon and boutique in Millburn, N.J., sent 43 persons to hospitals yesterday.

title: GETTING OFF, AND ON, MAIL LISTS
description: ''A s an art collector, you are a choice candidate for a burglary,'' began the form letter received by a Washington Heights resident this week. ''I have learned there is a good chance you have a valuable art collection and there is nothing to prevent a burglar from getting the same information,'' continued the letter, sent by American District Telegraph to promote its antiburglary services and equipment.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; 7 Nicaraguans Say Cubans Are Running Their Nation

title: AMERICAN AGRONOMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for the Apr sale of $1 million common shrs

title: No Headline
description: Canada Energy Policies Assailed at U.S. Hearing

title: CORAL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
WASHINGTON'S TEETH VANISH
description: George Washington's false teeth were reported missing today from the National Museum of American History. The teeth, made of gold and ivory and not wood, as rumor would have it, were fashioned in 1795 by his dentist, John Greenwood, according to Ellen McCalester, librarian at Mount Vernon.

title: ARAB NATIONS SET UP GROUP TO PROMOTE NUCLEAR POWER
description: The first Arab nuclear conference ended here today with the establishment of a committee to coordinate efforts toward setting up nuclear power stations in Arab countries.

title: Emergency Power For Seagoing Craft
description: A ''get home'' propulsion system for emergency use on yachts and other craft in case of engine failure was patented this week by James D. McCusker.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.H. Robins Co. said it had sold substantially all of the assets of Babcock Poultry Farm Inc., an Ithaca, N.Y., operating unit of its Babcock Industries subsidiary, to Institut de Selection Animale of Lyon, France, for an undisclosed amount.

title: No Headline
description: Two Fijian soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon were shot in the back and killed after being taken prisoner by Palestinian guerrillas, according to a United Nations spokesman here. In Beirut, the authorities said two people were killed and at least 26 wounded tonight in heavy artillery battles around the besieged eastern Lebanese town of Zahle.

title: DEMOCRAT DISCLOSES REAGAN DRAFT DOCUMENT EASING CLEAN AIR STANDARDS
description: A document prepared by the Reagan Administration proposes sweeping changes in the Clean Air Act, including the elimination of specific goals and deadlines for reducing pollution in areas of the country with dirty air.

title: 12 PROFESSORS BACK ANTI-ABORTION BILL
description: Twelve law professors have signed a letter supporting the constitutionality of a bill, being debated in the Senate, that would ban abortion by overruling the Supreme Court's interpretation of the 14th Amendment.

title: FRANCE'S BSN POISED TO GROW
description: Many Frenchmen expect at least one big businessman -Antoine Riboud - to be happy with the recent Socialist victory. Mr. Riboud is chairman and president of BSN-Gervais Danone, France's No.1 food company.

title: McDonnell Douglas
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had acquired a northern California company that is developing videodisk technology based on the use of photographic film.

title: BRITISH NOVELIST AND PLAYWRIGHT
description: Pamela Hansford Johnson, one of England's best-known novelists, who also wrote plays, biographies and criticism, died Thursday in London at the age of 69. Her death came almost a year after that of C.P. Snow, the novelist, playwright and scientist to whom she was married for 21 years. Lord Snow was 74 and died July 1, 1980.

title: Getty Plans Outlay
description: The Getty Oil Company said it would spend $160 million on a reforming unit to improve yields and octanes at its Delaware City, Del., refinery. The unit's capacity will remain at 140,000 barrels a day, Getty said. The company said the new unit should be operational by mid-1983.

title: VENEZUELA SUPORTS FREEZE IN OIL PRICE
description: Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's oil minister, is calling for a freeze in OPEC oil prices until 1983. The statement, reported yesterday by The Associated Press from Geneva after a meeting of OPEC's Long-Term Strategy Committee, appeared to mark a major attempt within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to restructure oil prices in the face of weakening worldwide oil demand.

title: No Headline
description: Newt Lobell paced the third fastest mile in the 41-year-history of Roosevelt Raceway tonight when he won the $154,000 George Morton Levy Memorial Pacing Series final.

title: Nazareth Captures City Baseball Title
description: A balk by Abraham Lincoln's star pitcher, Carmine Sperto, with two out and the bases filled in the bottom of the last inning gave Nazareth a 4-3 victory yesterday at Yankee Stadium in the first game ever to match the city's public and Catholic high school champions.

title: GUSTATORY SNOBBERY: THE GEOGRAPHY OF STATUS
description: With apologies to Horace Greeley, the better advice today seems to be, ''Go north, young man,'' especially if that young man happens to be in the restaurant business and would like to charge high prices. In fact, such an aspiring young man need not actually ''go'' north; he can merely look in that direction for the items on his menu, for up north lies status, in food as in so many other matters.

title: A Tribute for Lombardo
description: ''When my Guy died in 1979, so did my own life, and it has seemed that in three short years, the world has fogotten him,'' Lilliebell Lombardo said yesterday. ''But now Governor Carey has done this wonderful thing and made me the happiest person you can imagine.''

title: G.P.U. Unit's Credit Reduced
description: The parent company of the Metropolitan Edison Company, former operator of the idle Three Mile Island nuclear generating plant, announced today that banks would reduce the credit limit of the financially troubled unit.

title: BANKS IN SWITZERLAND
description: Combined net profit of foreign banks operating in Switzerland rose 30 percent last year, with cash flow rising 44 percent and taxes 53 percent, the Association of Foreign Banks in Switzerland said today. The group gave no absolute figures, but specified that as a percentage of combined balance-sheet total, cash flow averaged 1.4 percent, and net profit averaged 0.85 percent. The combined balance-sheet total of the 99 member banks of the association was about $26.3 billion, it said.

The Tidewater Tides will be the hosts to the Columbus Clippers in Norfolk, Va. The Clippers lead the Class AAA International League, and the Tides are in second place.

description: Though their pieties could be irritating, the old-style environmentalists who wanted to save people from poisonous air and water had a point. Now we have a new breed of environmentalist who wants to save people from themselves, despite 4,000 years of history suggesting that people don't want to be saved from themselves.

description: At his best, Benn Fields is a skilled and elegant high jumper. He shares the American record of 7 feet 6 1/2 inches, and last June he won the United States Olympic trials at 7-5.

description: Sir Frederick Ashton, New York's favorite Englishman, received a roaring ovation after the Royal Ballet's local premiere of his Rachmaninoff ballet ''Rhapsody'' at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday night.

description: Conoco Inc., the nation's ninth-largest oil company, announced yesterday that it had rejected a proposal by an unnamed ''major foreign corporation'' to buy about 25 percent of its stock for as much as $2 billion.

title: YITZHAK ZUCKERMAN, COMMANDED FIGHTERS IN THE WARSAW GHETTO
description: Yitzhak Zuckerman, the last commander of the Warsaw ghetto uprising in World War II, died here Wednesday after suffering a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1981
description: INTERNATIONAL A unanimous Security Council vote approved a resolution that "strongly condemned" Israel for its destruction of an Iraqi nuclear reactor and urged Israel to open its nuclear plants to international inspection. The resolution was agreed to on Thursday by the United States and Iraq. Jeane K. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, said Israel deserved condemnation for not using all diplomatic means to deal with its concern that Iraq would build a nuclear bomb. She said, however, that "nothing in the resolution will affect my Government's commitment to Israel's security." (Page 1, Column 6.) Iraq intended to build a nuclear bomb, according to a former inspector for the International Atomic Energy Agency. The former inspector, Roger Richter, told a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that international safeguards would not have detected Iraq's secret production of plutonium, which is needed for a bomb. He also said that his concern over the agency's constraints on inspection of the Iraqi nuclear reactor led him to report to the State Department last year. He said that on the basis of available information, Iraq had an "aggressive, coordinated program" to develop the ability to make nuclear weapons in the next five years. (1:4-5.)

title: IRANIAN FORCES HUNT FOR BANI-SADR AS HE IS BLAMED FOR COUNTRY'S ILLS
description: Iranian security forces hunted for President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today as an aide to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini accused him of being responsible for whatever shortcomings Iran had.

title: No Books For 'We The Kids'
description: During the Great Depression, the branch libraries in this city were regularly open six days and four nights a week. We must be in terrible shape now, because the average city library in 1981 is open at best only three or four days a week and one night - and even on the open days the hours have been shriveled.

title: TALKS BREAK OFF, NONE SCHEDULED IN BASEBALL STRIKE
description: Talks aimed at ending the baseball strike broke off yesterday, and relations between the two sides deteriorated sharply. The owners' chief negotiator had only sparse comment at a news briefing after the breakdown, but the players' representatives were blunt and angry. Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, said he would not call another meeting until he heard ''something positive'' from both sides.

title: 'Edgar' Awards Presented By Mystery Writers Group
description: The Mystery Writers of America have presented their 1981 Edgars (named after Edgar Allan Poe) honoring books, plays and scripts. Special Edgars were given to Paul Nathan for ''Richochet,'' best mystery-suspense play; Joan Wilson, producer of the television program ''Mystery,'' and Nick Nicholson for dramatic episodes on the television program ''Edge of Night.''

title: Suit Over Deprogramming From Religious Sect Settled
description: Shortly after she took the stand today, a Colorado woman settled her $1 million lawsuit against her parents and others who, she had asserted, had abducted her for religious deprogramming.

title: BURNS TAKE 1-STROKE LEAD IN OPEN
description: Long after his competitors had changed into street shoes and gone back to their motels, George Burns came out of the gathering darkness today with a 66, four under par for the Merion Golf Club, to lead the second round of the 81st United States Open.

title: U.S. TELLS ALLIES IT WANTS TALKS WITH SOVIET
description: A high-ranking State Department official, seeking to allay European concerns about the Reagan Administration's foreign policy, said today that the United States wanted to achieve a dialogue with the Soviet Union rather than its isolation.

title: California Firefighters Encircle Vast Blaze
description: Firefighters today encircled the last of a score of southern California brushfires that blackened 60,000 acres, damaged or destroyed 80 homes, killed a 6-year-old boy and injured 25 other people.

title: AIR CONTROL UNION EASES STRIKE THREAT
description: The Monday deadline for a threatened strike by air traffic controllers that would seriously disrupt air travel nationwide was eased conditionally today when the president of the controllers' union said he would delay a walkout if an agreement seemed near and talks were continuing.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
News Group Corrects Omission In Statement on Press Freedom
description: A May 17 statement on press freedom by leaders of news organizations meeting in Talloires, France, was made public with a sentence inadvertently dropped, according to a spokesman for the World Press Freedom Committee, one of the co-sponsors of the conference. The text of the statement was published in the May 18 editions of The New York Times.

title: AUTHORITIES TIE HEPATITIS CASES TO A FOOD PLACE
description: Fifty-two persons, most of them in their late teens and early 20's, have come down with infectious hepatitis that health officials have traced to a small Mexican restaurant in Middletown Township, N.J. Fifteen persons have been hospitalized.

title: TEEN-AGE SEXUALITY AND INVOLVEMENT OF THE FAMILY
description: Professionals concerned about changing Federal directions in the area of teen-age pregnancies and the possible mandating of family involvement and consent in sex education, contraception and abortion were told yesterday by a Reagan Administration official that the Administration would carry out its stated policy decisions in a consistent manner.

title: Yacht Sought for Reagan
description: Trisha Wilson & Associates, a design firm, has been commissioned to restore the interior of the Presidential yacht Sequoia for possible use by President Reagan. The yacht was recently bought by a group calling itself the Presidential Yacht Trust, which said it would offer the boat to Mr. Reagan for his use. The trust commissioned the design firm.

title: Companies
description: Conoco rejected a proposal by ''a major foreign corporation'' to buy about a quarter of its stock for as much as $2 billion. Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company, also said it was engaged in preliminary discussions with an unidentified ''major corporation looking toward a merger with Conoco.'' (Page 29.)

title: Assemblyman Emery Wants to Get Out of the Picture
description: The minority leader of the New York State Assembly, James L. Emery, had to have his arm twisted in the first place to appear in an advertisement with Governor Carey that says ''New York State Votes 'Yes' for Business,'' and now he wants to get out of it.

title: U.S. INDUSTRIES TO SELL 14 DIVISIONS
description: U.S. Industries, which was one of the models of the conglomerate movement in the late 1960's, announced yesterday that it planned to dispose of 14 of its divisions and subsidiaries, employing about 5,000 people, in a move to trim some of its less profitable operations.

title: A PRIVATELY FINANCED SAFETY DRIVE IS PLANNED BY FIRE OFFICIALS ON TV
description: The New York City Fire Department will seek $3 million to $4 million from private sources for a yearlong advertising campaign on prime-time television to make the public more concerned about fire safety.

title: CITY APARTMENT HUNT: TALE OF SORE FEET AND SAD LUCK
description: Eighteen months into his search for an apartment, Vaughn Dobson, a Columbia University student, has placed his name on the waiting list of every apartment house between 86th and 96th Streets on Manhattan's West Side. Meanwhile, he is staying with a friend.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31

description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: PEARL LANG, EARTHY TO AIRY
description: Pearl Lang's dances ranged from the earthy to the airy at Wednesday night's program by the Pearl Lang Dance Company at the Public Theater. On the whole, earthiness fared better than airiness.

title: SANTUCCI ASSAILS PROBATION STATUS FOR A KILLER, 16
description: District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens rebuked a state judge yesterday for declining to give a prison sentence to a 16-year-old youth convicted of manslaugther.

title: TRUCE, OF SORTS, ON WHITE HOUSE TOURS
description: They may not have achieved peace and harmony, but Representative Thomas J. Downey and the office of the First Lady, Nancy Reagan, have agreed to glower and make up. As a result, Mr. Downey's Long Island constituents will be able to go on tours of the White House again.

title: by James S. Coleman
description: Should social research directly address divisive issues of social policy? A report comparing public and private schools that I and two co-authors wrote has provoked the question: Why didn't we instead examine the constructive issue of what makes a good school?

title: 1Surgical Instrument With a Laser Beam
description: Laser beams can be used in surgery to make incisions and coagulate blood. A surgical instrument was patented this week by David C. Auth and Robert F. Rushmer, faculty members at the University of Washington, Seattle.

title: East German-Citroen Deal
description: East Germany has ordered 5,000 Citroen GSA-model cars for delivery between June and December this year, Peugeot S.A., a unit of Automobiles Citroen S.A., said today. Financial details were not disclosed.

title: Reagan Names a Chief For Strategic Air Unit
description: President Reagan has named Gen. Bennie L. Davis as commander in chief of the Strategic Air Command, effective Aug. 1, the Pentagon announced today.

title: Japan, Mexico Hold Oil Talks
description: Japanese oil importers are meeting in Mexico with officials of Pemex, the Mexican national oil company, in an attempt to resolve a pricing dispute that has delayed shipment of 3 million barrels of crude to Japan, a spokesman for the Mexican Petroleum Import Company, the Japanese company set up to import Mexican oil, said today.

title: NEW CLASHES ERUPT IN CAIRO SLUM
description: Disturbances broke out in a slum district of Cairo today for the third successive day, and Egyptian religious leaders pleaded for an end to sectarian clashes.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It began, as such things always do, with a small white florist's box lined with leaf-green tissue paper. Inside were the flowers. The flowers were beautiful. The flowers are always beautiful for the prom. So are the girls, their dresses, the table favors, the photographs and the memories.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY THE PRESIDENT ON U.S. BUDGET
description: Following is the text of the statement by President Reagan today on the budget: Forty-three days ago, the House of Representatives joined in a bipartisan commitment to bring runaway Federal spending under control. That was an essential step toward national economic recovery - toward reducing inflation, creating more jobs and lowering interest rates. But that was only a step. It required faithful implementation by the committees of the Congress.

title: A Second Look at Love Canal
description: A new study of Love Canal's health hazards - the first to win the approval of serious scientists - is surprisingly reassuring: People who lived near that leaky chemical-waste disposal site show no higher rates of cancer than other residents of New York State.

title: Nancy Littlefield Honored
description: Nancy Littlefield, director of the Mayor's Office for Motion Pictures and Television, will receive the sixth Big Apple Award of the National Home Fashions League on Wednesday. In a ceremony at the Pinnacle Club, 150 East 42d Street, she will be honored for ''putting New York City, New York buildings and New York interiors on the map via motion pictures.''

title: CANADIAN G.N.P. UP 1% IN PERIOD
description: A harassed Canadian Government, under daily attack for high interest rates that it can do little to check because of their close link to United States developments, got the welcome news today that the nation's economy grew by 1 percent in the first quarter.

title: 'THE PATRIOT GAME'
description: Sometimes the most rational analysis of a catastrophe can be the most chilling. ''The Patriot Game,'' a forceful and revealing documentary opening today at the Public Theater, examines the warfare in Northern Ireland in a reflective manner that only intensifies the horror of the situation. The American director, Arthur MacCaig, makes no secret of his sympathies, which lie with the Irish Republican Army. But he has not made a film that is pure propaganda. ''The Patriot Game'' is too thorough and thoughtful to be categorized simply.
