title: Ontario Hydro Adding to Exports
description: Ontario Hydro, Ontario's big provincially owned electric utility, said yesterday that it had received permission from the Canadian Government to sharply increase its electric power exports to utilities in the United States over the next decade.

title: PRIME BACK TO 20% AT 2 BIG BANKS
description: The recent movement toward a lower prime rate was aborted yesterday as two large New York banks reversed actions taken barely a week ago and raised their basic lending rate to 20 percent from 19 1/2 percent.

title: Koch and Britain Continue Their War of Words
description: Mayor Koch lobbed another volley across the Atlantic yesterday at the British Government and press. The British press has been castigating the Mayor for having quoted his conversation in New York City Wednesday with Prince Charles about Northern Ireland.

title: Ex-Editor's Slayers Given Long Terms
description: WHITE PLAINS (AP) - Two 17-year-old youths were given long prison sentences in the robbery and murder of Eleanor Prouty, a retired Reader's Digest editor, in May 1980.

title: Mount St. Helens Erupting
description: Scientists reported today that a nonexplosive eruption was taking place in Mount St. Helens, causing the giant lava dome in the volcano's crater to grow. It was the ninth eruption since the mountain's severe blast on May 18, 1980, and the fourth nonviolent dome-building eruption.

title: NORMAN ALPERT, THE FOUNDER OF ALPEX COMPUTER CORPORATION
description: Norman Alpert, founder and president of the Alpex Computer Corporation of Danbury, Conn., died Tuesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 56 years old.

title: The Court Gives Prisons an Easy Out
description: Hot and cold running water. A 36-by-80-inch bed. Heating and ventilation. A shelf, a flush toilet, a cabinet / nightstand and a built-in radio.

title: Oklahoma Aide Convicted Of Extortion and Fraud
description: A Federal jury today convicted Orville Pratt, the Blaine County Commissioner, on two counts of extortion and mail fraud for accepting kickbacks totaling $1,870.

title: 4 TERRORIST ATTACKS IN ROME LEAVE 1 DEAD AND 3 WOUNDED
description: Terrorists struck four times in different sections of Rome today, killing a deputy police superintendent and wounding his driver, wounding a lawyer, shooting a publishing executive in the legs and firing on a police patrol. In Pescara, on the Adriatic coast, terrorists reportedly killed the brother of a former member of the Red Brigades terrorist organization who had cooperated with the police.

Sales in the quarter, which ended May 31, rose 18.8 percent, to $279.4 million from $235.1 million.

An article on the successful launching of Ariane yes- terday appears on page 1.

description: Dr. Rosario Terranova, an associate professor emeritus of pharmacology and medicine at the New York Medical College in Valhalla and Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital in Manhattan, died Thursday at Pelham Bay General Hospital in the Bronx.

title: HOUSING GETTING SCARCER FOR CITY, SAYS A U.S. AIDE
description: New York City's critical housing shortage is virtually certain to get worse in the next several years, according to the outgoing manager of the New York area office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: GAS VALVE BREAK FORCES THOUSANDS TO LEAVE OFFICES
description: A thousand office workers in a commercial park were led to safety today after a valve atop a natural-gas transmission line had been broken by an earth mover at a construction site. No injuries were reported.

title: DECREE ALLOWS CBS TO RETAIN FAWCETT
description: Although three years ago the Federal Government filed suit to force CBS Inc. to divest itself of Fawcett Publications, the mass-market paperback publisher, the broadcast company will be allowed to keep Fawcett under the terms of a consent decree that CBS has reached with the antitrust division of the Department of Justice. The terms were announced yesterday by CBS.

title: Your Money; Estate Planning And Tax Cuts
description: THERE is good news in the Reagan Administration's tax program for prosperous and/or generous taxpayers: the reductions envisaged in Federal estate and gift taxes.

title: TRANSIT CONCERNS GET READY FOR EFFECTS OF POSSIBLE STRIKE
description: In the event of a strike by air traffic controllers, the Federal Aviation Administration will permit airlines to operate as many flights as can be handled by 2,000 supervisory employees. The supervisors would operate the network of control stations that normally employs 17,000 people.

title: DURSBLES ORDERS OFF 0.4% IN MAY
description: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods declined four-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the latest in a lengthening list of indications that the national economy has been weakening since the first quarter's big expansion.

title: BUTZ SENTENCED TO 30 DAYS, FINED $10,000 IN TAX CASE
description: Earl L. Butz, the 71-year-old former Secretary of Agriculture, was sentenced today to serve 30 days in jail and pay a $10,000 fine for filing a false Federal income tax return.

title: BASEBALL STRIKE DISRUPTS THE RANKS OF DEDICATED IDLERS
description: Stanley Reich of New Milford, N.J., was spotted last weekend trimming a plum tree in his backyard, something he had steadfastly refused to do for three years. A concerned neighbor went out to see what was wrong. Mr. Reich explained that there was no baseball on television.

title: REAGAN PUSHES PLAN BY G.O.P. TO CHANGE SPENDING PRIORITIES
description: President Reagan joined a new budget battle with Democrats on Capitol Hill today by strongly endorsing a Republican proposal to change the basic spending priorities established by House committees over the last month.

title: Contract Awarded On Bus Shelter Ads
description: The Miller Sign Company of 321 11th Avenue was apparently the high bidder on a contract to maintain and sell advertising space for the city's 499 bus-stop shelters in Manhattan and the Bronx, the Department of General Services announced.

title: Dr. Sidney Rothbard, Researcher And Medical Professor Emeritus
description: Dr. Sidney Rothbard, professor emeritus of the department of medicine at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died Wednesday at the hospital. He lived in Suffern, N.Y., and was 73 years old.

title: HEAD OF NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH RESIGNS FOR PERSONAL REASONS
description: Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson announced today his resignation as director of the National Institutes of Health, the Federal agency that has given the United States a dominant position in biomedical research.

title: Stimulating Growth Of Blood Vessels
description: Three researchers for the Monsanto Company in St. Louis were granted a patent this week for a method of stimulating the growth of human blood vessels. The results are expected to have eventual value in healing wounds and burns.

title: INDIA'S PROPER MOVE TO LIMIT BIRTHS
description: To the Editor:

title: HEAD OF NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF HEALTH RESIGNS FOR PERSONAL REASONS
description: His resignation for "personal reasons" was initially disclosed to about 550 employees at the end of a morning meeting on the agency's compound in Bethesda, Md. The 56-year-old expert on blood fats said the agency seemed "as exhilarting and worthwhile as in the summer of 1953 when I arrived."

title: WITHOUT FATHER
description: I'm not looking forward to Father's Day tomorrow - the first without my father. He would probably find my reactions amusing - and the day an inappropriate occasion to mourn him.

title: F.C.C. Opposes A.T.& T. Rate
description: The Federal Communications Commission's staff disclosed today it had tentatively decided that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has failed to justify a 16 percent increase in interstate long-distance telephone rates.

title: Nissan Introduces 3 New Models
description: Japan's Nissan Motor Company, the maker of Datsun cars, introduced three new models of front-engine, frontwheel-drive economy models for overseas markets.

title: By Sports of The Times
description: SUDDENLY, he has swooped onto the scene as golf's ''Great White Shark,'' a 26

title: HOSPITALS' NON-SURPLUS
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'CANNONBALL RUN' WITH BURT REYNOLDS
description: ''The Cannonball Run'' is the latest screaming-wheels movie by Hal Needham, the former stunt man and second-unit director who broke into the big time as the director of ''Smokey and the Bandit'' and ''Smokey and the Bandit II,'' both of which starred his good friend Burt Reynolds, who also stars in this film with a lot of his friends, old and new.

title: Kabul Promises Amnesty To Rebels Who Surrender
description: The Soviet-installed regime in Afghanistan will grant amnesty to all rebels who voluntarily surrender, the Kabul radio reported today.

title: Australia Bauxite
description: The Tipperary Corporation said it had received final approval from the Australian Government for the sale of its interest in the Aurukun bauxite project in Queensland to the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann S.A. for $27 million in cash. Tipperary said it would also receive a deferred payment of 50 cents a ton on an estimated 252 million tons of Bauxite as it is mined.

title: Failure in Communications Cited in Shuttle Pad Deaths
description: An investigative board said today that inadequate explanation of a last-minute change in testing procedures was partly to blame for an accident on the launching pad of the space shuttle Columbia that killed two workers March 19.

title: Full-Time Civilian Becomes Part-Time Officer
description: ''Lou Who?'' That's the way the handbills read back in 1977 when Louis P. Wein, a former mayoral aide, ran for Mayor of New York as an independent candidate.

title: HOME KNITTERS' VICTORY REPORTED
description: The Labor Department will lift restrictions on home work in rural parts of the country, a victory for some Vermont knitters who opposed the Federal Goverment in their fight to keep working at home, a Vermont newspaper reported today.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: Dr. Barbara Spector Married to Student
description: Dr. Barbara Spector and Michael Andrew Hertzberg were married yesterday at the Villa Teo in Chapel Hill, N.C. Rabbi Steven Sage performed the ceremony.

title: ARNIE'S AIM CAPTURES TROT AT MEADOWLANDS
description: Arnie's Aim, a 20-to-1 shot, won by three-quarters of a length tonight in the $131,000 Historic Cup for 3-year-old trotters at The Meadowlands.

title: 84 Rikers Inmates Are Released Early
description: Eight-four inmates whose terms were ending were released from Rikers Island in the early morning hours yesterday under a new program to ease overcrowding at the jail complex.

title: Byrne Is Leaving For Soviet Tonight
description: TRENTON (UPI) - Governor Byrne, accompanied by his Environmental Protection Commissioner, Jerry English, and a host of New York and New Jersey businessmen, is scheduled to leave tonight for a visit to the Soviet Union.

title: SANGSTER BUILDS AN EMPIRE
description: When Robert Sangster turned to the racing and breeding of thoroughbreds five years ago, British pre-eminence in the sport had long since shifted to the United States and France. Now, with his horses competing and breeding from Kentucky to Australia, the sun never sets on the Sangster stables.

title: ORDERING BULBS FOR SPRING
description: While some may want to go to the beach to cool off, gardeners can page through their bulb catalogues and think cool thoughts about spring - snowdrops, crocus, daffodils and tulips. Wise shoppers know that if they make selections and order hardy bulbs now, they will get better prices. Discounts of at least 10 percent and sometimes even 50 percent are offered.

title: LLOYD'S HAS SECOND THOUGHTS
description: Lloyd's of London seemed to be on the verge of acceding to fundamental changes in how it regulates itself and how insurance is bought and sold on the Lloyd's exchange. But as the changes wend their way through Parliament, the 300-year-old giant of insurance exchanges appears to be having second thoughts.

title: British Yacht Is Slowed In Trans-Atlantic Race
description: The British trimaran Brittany Ferries, holding a virtually unbeatable margin in the double-handed trans-Atlantic race, ran into calm seas today that slowed its record pace.

title: MACK TRUCKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Reynolds Still Unsigned
description: Despite previous reports that he had signed with the Buffalo Bills, Jack Reynolds left town yesterday without a contract, the team said. Reynolds, a linebacker, was cut by Los Angeles recently after a salary dispute.

title: THE PRESS CLUB READMITS AN ANGRY YOUNG MAN, 73
description: I.F. Stone has rejoined the pack. Mr. Stone, the premier loner and dedicated maverick of American journalism, was welcomed back into the National Press Club yesterday after having been ostracized by that section of the journalistic Establishment for trying to take a black friend to lunch at the club 40 years ago.

title: EAGLE EXPLORATIONS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-The company was formed Oct 2, 1979 and did not report revs for the previous yr...C-Net loss

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. SHARPLY INCREASES FARM EXPORTS TO CHINA
description: China has quietly become the United States' fourth-largest customer of food and other agricultural commodities, with an estimated 12 million acres of American farmland now planted annually to grow crops bound for China, according to American agriculture officials.

title: Sewage Entering Niagara River
description: Canadian officials say they hope they will be able to discontinue a daily discharge of more than 500,000 gallons of chlorinated raw sewage into the Niagara River within a few days. The discharge began Monday when an explosion disabled a Fort Erie pumping station. It will continue until officials are sure that suspected leaks from gasoline tanks, which they believe caused the explosion, have been fixed.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Three teen-agers were charged with the rape and robbery of a 37-year-old woman in her apartment on East 77th Street, the police said. The suspects were Andre Williams, 16 years old, of 1385 Washington Avenue, the Bronx; Swain Chappelle, 16, of 1839 Lexington Avenue and Kerry Brown, 18, of 2095 Third Avenue. ... A third suspect in last week's shooting of two armored-car guards at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx was arrested Thursday night, the police said. The suspect, Dwayne Thomas, 19, of the Bronx, was charged with robbery and attempted murder. ... An 80-year-old Brooklyn woman, whom the police could not immediately identify, was shot in the face and critically wounded by a security guard chasing a man who had allegedly held up a bingo parlor in the borough's Sheepshead Bay section.

title: Cleared California Prisoner Free
description: Russell Little, whose murder conviction was recently overturned in the 1973 cyanide-bullet slaying of a Superintendent of Schools, was given his freedom today after nearly eight years in prison. Mr. Little, 31 years old, had been convicted of killing Marcus Foster, the Oakland official, while Mr. Little was a member of a now-defunct organization that called itself the Symbionese Liberation Army.

title: FIGURE IN ATLANTA INQUIRY ASKS CURB ON NEWS MEDIA
description: A lawyer for a 23-year-old man questioned by the authorities in the series of 28 murders here pleaded with a Federal judge today to restrain the news media from publishing or broadcasting virtually anything about her client.

title: Space Sharks
description: In a time when there is doubt whether the pistol that a 10-year-old uses to try holding up a bank is a toy or a .38, and when the word juvenile is often used to precede ''court,'' it is refreshing to read about the trouble in - not River City - but Irvington, N.Y. There, in locations ranging from a delicatessen to a pizza parlor, legions of children are lining up to play video games.

title: Saxon Oil's Gas Find
description: The Saxon Oil Company said a test well in Comanche County in Oklahoma's Anadarko basin had flowed at more than 150 million cubic feet of gas a day, indicating what the company called the biggest gas well in the state.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $500 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a modest $500 million increase in the nation's basic money supply, a change that left intact the trend to slower monetary growth, which many credit market analysts expect to result in lower interest rates soon.

title: 'I DON'T WANT TIMES SQUARE CLEANED UP'
description: To the Editor:

title: Commonwealth Oil's Settlement Backed
description: The Commonwealth Oil Company said that Judge Joseph Elliott of the United States Bankruptcy Court in San Antonio had confirmed an earlier creditors' vote approving the company's plan to settle the claims against it.

title: McCrory Gets Loan
description: The Rapid-American Corporation said that the McCrory Corporation, its retailing subsidiary, had completed its bank refinancing through a $175 million agreement with a 10-member bank group, led by Chemical Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company. It provides McCrory with $75 million payable over three years ended July 31, 1984, at prime plus 1/2 percent and $100 million revolving credit at prime. The McCrory borrowings are guaranteed by Rapid and collateralized by the capital stock of Rapid's and McCrory's principal operating subsidiaries.

title: 45 YEARS IN BROADCASTING
description: Donald L. Kearney, who was in the broadcasting field for 45 years and a former chairman of the Television Bureau of Advertising, collapsed and died Thursday on Fire Island, N.Y. He had been under treatment for a heart problem. He was 63 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: WALTER, JIM, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $4.3 million extraordinary credit reflecting gain on the sale of securities...C-Including $9.5 million extraordin credit reflecting gain on the sale of sugar business

title: Art; DISCOVERIES ABOUND IN SHOW AT POST
description: BROOKVILLE ANYONE who has been making the rounds of museums and galleries in recent years on the Island or in New York City will certainly recognize some of the 18 artists featured in the current exhibition at Long Island University's C.W. Post Gallery. While they are by no means international figures, Shirley Gorelick, Janet Schneider, Susan Zises, Rhoda Sherbell, Caroline Kaplowitz and Helen Meyrowitz are among those who have exhibited their works on the Island almost enough to qualify as names in the Long Island artistic household. They are artists of a certain accomplishment and it is rewarding to see them in any exhibition, either alone or as a group.

title: ANTICRIME TEAM FACES LOSS OF FUNDS
description: NEWARK ONE of this city's most successful anticrime efforts, the Police Department's Rapid Response to Robbery Team, will run out of funds at the end of June.

title: LABOR'S LOSS
description: To the Business Editor: While hinting broadly at the root cause of current labor timidity, the article ''Where Are the Pickets of YesterYesteryear?'' (May 31) avoids identifying the underlying reason that unions are ''groping for direction'' and that there are fewer workers on picket lines.

title: U.S. Recalls 70,000 Power Saws That May Have Faulty Switches
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced a recall of 70,000 power saws that it said might have defective switches that could cause them to start up suddenly.

title: Business Conditions; BOOM IN BUSINESS ADS
description: While most corporate advertising expenditures are directed at mass market media like radio, television and newspapers, companies are beginning to spend more money on reaching a smaller, more selective audience -those who read business publications. Although individual companies keep track of how much they spend for advertisements in magazines like Business Week, Forbes as well as industry-specific trade publications, until recently no accurate indicator of the size of this particular market was readily available.

title: ART BY INMATES FROM NEW YORK SHOWN IN SOUTH
description: Rikers Island is not exactly the kind of place where men's creative souls soar. Yet inmates there and at other New York City prisons have produced an impressive array of paintings, drawings and collages that will be shown at the Firebird Gallery on the Potomac waterfront here beginning Sunday.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Paul Lawrence, a Cellist, In Wide-Ranging Program
description: Paul Lawrence's debut cello recital Thursday night in Carnegie Recital Hall was a pleasing, well-schooled affair. Mr. Lawrence was trained at Indiana University, where he received bachelor's and master's degrees. If he sometimes seemed to relinquish leadership of the proceedings to his rather more dynamic pianist, Kenneth Huber, and if he sometimes grew a little tentative in the upper positions, he still played very well.

title: TRACY AUSTIN BEATS MISS JAEGER
description: Two weeks ago, Tracy Austin sat in a locker room in West Berlin and cried, her body encased in eight icebags and her hopes of playing at Wimbledon diminished by persistent back pains and limited mobility.

title: A POET OF EVERYDAY PATHOLOGY
description: ONLY THE DREAMER CAN CHANGE THE DREAM Selected Poems. By John Logan. 209 pp. New York: The Ecco Press. $14.95. THE BRIDGE OF CHANGE Poems 1974-1980. By John Logan. 75 pp. Brockport, N.Y.: BOA Editions. Cloth, $8.95. Paper, $4.50.

title: Letters to the Long Island Editor; The Commercialization Of Route 347
description: In preparing for the next Town Council hearing on the proposed further development of Route 347 in Brookhaven, I came upon the article ''Commercialization Stirs Town's Ire'' (Feb. 1), in which John Luchsinger, chairman of the Brookhaven Town Planning Board, is quoted as saying, ''We do not want another Jericho Turnpike.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Pope smiled a little, but it was not a smile of somebody who was very happy to come back to the hospital.'' -Dr. Emilio Tresalti, chief of staff of Gemelli Hospital in Rome. (1:2.)

title: Long Islanders; DISPELLING CLICHES ABOUT AGE AND LOVE
description: ''I'VE ALWAYS liked older people,'' said Joseph Cowley of Huntington. ''My mother says I was born old. I empathize with older people. I get annoyed -everybody thinks old age is a time of senility and rocking chairs. Nonsense. Old people are human beings. They can make love. They feel. I hope this book dispels a little bit of this cliched stuff about old people.''

title: New Jersey Housing Springfield; HOMES AND THE SINGLE WOMAN
description: EIGHTEEN months ago, an information systems manager for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company who was being transferred from Washington to New Jersey joined what the National Association of Realtors calls the fastest-growing segment of the market: Single women as home buyers.

title: Headliners; THE EXECUTIONER'S SNAG
description: The philosophically inclined might say there's no real difference between a prison sentence of 999 years and one of death. James William White knows better.

title: AUXILIARY POLICE ROLE IN DISPUTE
description: LAST fall, with little fanfare and almost no publicity, state laws governing the categories and powers of ''peace officers'' were amended. Concluding that the new law has eliminated both their authority and their liability protection, in the past month or so auxiliary police units in most Westchester communities have suspended operations.

title: 10,000 in Boston March For Homosexual Rights
description: More than 10,000 supporters of rights for homosexuals marched through Beacon Hill and rallied on The Common today in the annual Gay and Lesbian Pride parade.

title: Art; TAKING THE PARAMOUNT PATH
description: SAG HARBOR AS the 1970's drew to an unlamented end, an exhibition at the Whitney Museum optimistically offered a crystal ball in which the art world might find its new direction for the 1980's. Many a snicker greeted this blatant attempt to prefigure and even direct the course of artistic expression. Trends, we believe, should emerge naturally, as a result of some common sensibility that unifies artists and places them in their cultural context. Yet, perhaps partly in reaction to the show and its pretentions, commentators now seem to be accelerating the process of identification, the search for the fresh and the discovery of the new.

title: Design
description: A KNACK FOR STYLISH SURVIVAL Though it seems the very epitome of the luxurious second home, this East Hampton house is made of sterner stuff. It is elegant, true, but it is also efficient, economical and deeply bound to nature. A sprawling deck, which unites the house with the garage (below), is interrupted by a vegetable garden where one might expect to see a pool. The garden (above, as seen from the house's rooftop deck) is elegantly arranged in right-angled rows, an appropriate conceit since the owner places great importance on gardening.

title: KINGS PARK DUMP DISPUTED BY STATE
description: KINGS PARK OFFICIALS of Smithtown and the State Environmental Protection Department will meet Thursday to try to resolve differences that have kept a garbage dump here looking like an ugly moonscape even though it has been closed for a year and a half.

title: CHINA'S SCHOOLS TO BEGIN GIVING ADVANCED DEGREES
description: The Chinese Government, which has punished intellectual achievement off and on for decades, has authorized universities to begin awarding advanced academic degrees this year.

title: Bridge; WHEN THE CLOCK TAKES ITS TOLL
description: Controlling slow play has been a simple matter for chess organizers since the chess clock was introduced more than a century ago. But it has been a headache for bridge organizers who ignored the problem for many years and then tried a variety of remedies.

title: SPRINTER EXCELS AT PREP MEET
description: Mike Morris of Ayer, Mass., won the 100-meter dash todayin 10.34 seconds and narrowly missed winning the 200 meters at the 10th annual International Pre INvitational track and field meet for the nation's top seniors.

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN CUISINE IN CHEERFUL SETTING
description: STAMFORD THE proliferation of quality restaurants that some thought would accompany the arrival of all the corporate headquarters in Stamford has not materialized. But relatively new and interesting restaurant choices can nevertheless be found.

title: The World in Summary; PRODDING, HOPING ON PEACE PLAN FOR SOUTH-WEST AFRICA
description: Where the Carter Administration preferred sticks to get South Africa to grant Namibia independence, the Reagan Administration is offering carrots, and in advance.

title: POLE VAULTER EXCEEDS 19- 1/4
description: Thierry Vigneron of France became the first to break the 19-foot barrier in the pole vault today, clearing 19 feet 1/4 inches for a world record in an international meet.

title: Headliners; WRIGLEY TAKES A WALK
description: William Wrigley, heir to a family fortune built on chewing gum, last week sold a badly tarnished family jewel.

title: Recordings; POP ECCENTRICS REVISITED
description: The 60's produced a bumper crop of pop music eccentrics. War thundered in the East, traditional values seemed to be crumbling, the use of psychedelic drugs was proliferating, and an entire generation of young people looked to popular music for political and behavioral cues as well as for entertainment. Some of the period's most successful pop performers indulged in musical eccentricities that would have seemed equally out of place in the 50's or the 70's - the Beatles on ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band,'' the Rolling Stones on ''Their Satanic Majesties Request.'' Anyone unfamiliar with the 60's would have to conclude, after listening to these albums, that if this was the sort of thing the millions were buying, the commercial fringes of popular music must have been fairly seething with crackbrained visionaries (and outright charlatans) of every conceivable stripe.

title: AIR CONTROL UNION AND U.S. FAR APART AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: The Reagan Administration and the air traffic controllers' union intensified talks today with only slightly increased hopes of averting a threatened Monday strike that would severely curtail air travel and have serious economic effects.

title: Bradley Chapman Irwin Weds Catharine M. Kane
description: Catharine Mary Kane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Kane of Wilmington, Del., was married there yesterday to Bradley Chapman Irwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Irwin of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Ralph Silverio performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph's on the Brandywine.

title: WHERE ARE ALL THE WOMEN WHO FELL FOR 007?
description: They always seem to wear the skimpiest of bikinis, and they often carry weapons - a gun, a knife, a spear, perhaps even a miniature Abomb. Their hair is always long, their smiles are always pouty and their names are always memorable. First there was Honeychile Rider (played by Ursula Andress), and later came Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman) and Kissy Suzuki (Mie Hama) and Tiffany Case (Jill St. John) and Holly Goodhead (Lois Chiles).

title: Art; 30 YEARS OF AMERICAN DRAWING
description: RIDGEFIELD THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art's summer blockbuster is ''New Dimensions in Drawing,'' a show of more than 200 works by some 125 artists that remains open through Sept. 6. Despite the bravado of its title, the exhibition is a quite conventional reprise of mainly American drawings from the last 30 years, and it has been chosen with some discrimination by Dorothy Mayhall, the museum's director.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Civil War Debt
description: As Oregon remembered it, the state had run up a $1.3 million bill protecting the Oregon Trail and settlers against Indian attacks after Federal troops pulled out to fight in the Civil War. Last April the State Senate unanimously called on Congress to repay the debt.

title: Other Business; A MOTH-EATEN TALE OF MONEY, SEX AND NATURE'S WAY
description: The gypsy moth, plague of the Northeast, doesn't daunt the spirits of the Health-Chem Corporation of New York. In fact, the insect is a plus.

title: THE FATHER AND THE GHOSTWRITER
description: ''To understand the Father's Day I remember best,'' a friend was recalling the other day, ''I have to tell you a little about my father, who died a few years ago. He was a judge of some rank in Germany - until Hitler. He could not use his German law knowledge when he came to this country, and the Depression was no time to study American law, not with a family to support. So he became an accountant, eventually a fairly successful one.

title: A REAGAN CHARGE ROUSES DEMOCRATS
description: It will probably be remembered as just another of Ronald Reagan's impetuous shots from the hip. But the President's attack on House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill last week - he accused him of ''sheer demagoguery'' in a postscript to a news conference -helped Congressional Democrats appear, however briefly, very much like a unified opposition.

title: LITTLE TOUCHES THAT SAY SHE'S BACK
description: IT happens around this time every year. You can't open the medicine cabinet without having a strange object falling into the sink, usually a mangled tube of toothpaste or an unknown brand of cold tablets.

title: RENEWAL IN FLATBUSH TAKES TEAMWORK
description: To 45 architecture students from Delft University who are touring American cities to study low-income housing and neighborhood revitalization, the Flatbush section of Brooklyn was a required stop -and not just because of the heritage of the Dutch who first settled it in the 17th century.

title: WHEN THE BUBBLE BURST
description: THE first step, I've been told, is to place the paper in the typewriter - no excuses, no stalling. I will not run across the street to see how my sister feels, since I know her nonfunctioning gall bladder will never function again.

title: Westchester Guide; COUNTY TENNIS COURTS
description: The first tennis courts owned and operated by the county are to be dedicated at 11 A.M. Tuesday in Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers. A spokesman for the Parks Department said that the complex would be open for play immediately after the dedication.

title: Mailbox; VOID LEFT BY END OF RESERVE CLAUSE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; GENE-SPLICING PAYS A HEALTHY DIVIDEND
description: Researchers in recombinant DNA techniques - gene-splicing - seem to have succeeded so far in realizing some of its best promise while avoiding its direst perils. Last week came word of one of the most significant successes to date.

title: MRS. CARNER LEADS BY 2 STROKES AT 137
description: Joanne Carner turned in a steady round of 69 today for a 36-hole total of 137 and a two-stroke lead in the $125,000 Lady Keystone Open at the Hershey Country Club West Course.

title: Alice L. Ober Has Wedding
description: Alice Lawrence Ober and Harry L. Curtis 3d were married yesterday by the Rev. Huntington Williams Jr. at St. James Episcopal Church in Monkton, Md.

title: U.N. Envoy Will Discuss Gulf War With Iranians
description: Olof Palme, the special United Nations envoy trying to bring an end to the Persian Gulf war, is to meet with Prime Minister Mohammad Ali Rajai and members of the Supreme Defense Council, Iran's official Pars news agency said today.

title: PLAYERS EYE DRAW, MOLD WIMBLEDON PLANS
description: Chris Evert Lloyd studied the draw for the women's singles at this years Wimbleton tennis championships and saw Andrea Jaeger and Tracy Austin as potential opponents in successive rounds. Miss Jaeger and Miss Austin have similar syles, and it was suggested that Lloyd's advantage. Each of the younger players has a two-handed baseline game. "That thought entered my mind," said Mrs. Lloyd, a two-time Wimbledon champion who is top seeded this year and who lost last year's singles final to Evonne Goolagong Cawley

title: 9 Members of Church Convicted of Drug Charges
description: Nine members of the Ethiopian Zion Coptic Church were convicted yesterday of Federal drug charges in what the Government called a mammoth conspiracy to smuggle marijuana.

title: Karen Wehmann Is Bride
description: Karen Elizabeth Wehmann, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy C. Wehmann of Camillus. N.Y., and Mr. G. Donald Wehmann of Ghent, N.Y., was married yesterday to Lieut.

title: Lisa Adams Married to James H. Rowe 3d
description: The marriage of Lucy Smith Adams to James Henry Rowe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rowe Jr. of Washington, took place in Old Field, L.I., yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Lawrence J. Bracken performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George B. Adams Jr. of New York and Old Field.

title: Politics; DELBELLO WEIGHS JURY REPORT
description: COUNTY Executive Alfred B. DelBello took a few moments to consider his answer last week, during a news conference, when he was asked if he thought his re-election bid had been damaged by a recent grand jury report critical of the law that Mr. DelBello helped design that created the Department of Public Safety Services.

title: Miss Douglas Has Wedding
description: Robyn Ann Douglas was married yesterday to Robert Edward List 2d at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. The Rev. Ronald J. Lafferty performed the ceremony.

title: DOES JAZZ QUALIFY AS 'CLASSICAL'
description: The Kool Jazz Festival, which starts Friday and continues through July 5, is a successor of the Newport Jazz Festival, and despite the occasional idiosyncrasies of its director, George Wein, it remains about the most prestigious annual forum for jazz.

title: Officer Weds Susan Schoff
description: Susan Joanna Schoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Schoff Jr. of Pelham, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Robert Gordon Bonn, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bonn, also of Pelham.

title: Connecticut Guide; MERIDEN MARKS 175 YEARS
description: Meriden's 175th birthday gift to itself will be a two-day encampment and re-enactment of military maneuvers that took place throughout the Colonies a few years before the city was born.

title: RULES BAR LOW BIDDER ON S.I. MILK PACT
description: For three years, Nathan Abramson, a milk dealer, has wanted to sell milk to schools on Staten Island. He was low bidder on a 1978-79 school-year contract, but was rejected because he lacked a state license to supply milk on Staten Island, even though he was then and remains licensed to serve schools in Queens.

title: The Week in Business
description: Interest rates presented a puzzling picture last week. They seemed to be declining as the week started. I.B.M. announced a $250 million issue of two-year debentures. Chemical Bank trimmed its prime lending rate to 19 percent. Then short-term rates unexpectedly rose sharply. I.B.M canceled its issue. On Friday, Bankers Trust and Marine Midland raised their prime rate to 20 percent from 19.5 percent. But when money supply figures were issued Friday afternoon, they showed only a slight $500 million rise in the week ended June 10, which would normally be an outlook for lower rates.

title: JERSEY HEALTH OFFICIALS GIVE SHOTS TO COMBAT OUTBREAK OF HEPATITIS
description: New Jersey health officials continued a mass inoculation program today to stem an outbreak of hepatitis traced to a Mexican restaurant in this Monmouth County community.

title: THE BUMBERSHOOT BOORS
description: THE recent rains have been most welcome. Who can argue with that? Why, one can even tolerate station platform banalities like ''We sure can use it' and ''Good for the reservoirs,'' knowing that, this time, those awful cliches are ''right on.''

title: Blasphemy
description: To the Editor:

title: Leisure; GROUND RULES FOR TENDING THE STRAWBERRY PATCH
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Walter Chandoha, an amateur gardener, is a professional photographer of animals and nature. By WALTER CHANDOHA

title: Shelling by Syrians Kills 2 And Wounds 11 in Lebanon
description: Syrian shelling of Christian strongholds in Beirut and the eastern city of Zahle killed two persons today and wounded nearly a dozen, the police said.

title: Pamela C. Thomas Is Married on L.I.
description: Pamela Cook Thomas, daughter of John C. Thomas Jr. of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Eula M. Thomas, was married yesterday to John Taylor Strohmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Strohmeyer of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Charles Newbery performed by ceremony in St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: THE BREED OF MEN CALLED OWNERS
description: ONCE dynasties roamed the earth in baseball.

title: THE PICTURES IN THE PAINTINGS
description: ARSHILE GORKY The Implications of Symbols. By Harry Rand. Illustrated. 246 pp. Montclair, N.J.: Allanheld & Schram. $40. ARSHILE GORKY 1904-1948 A Retrospective. By Diane Waldman. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams/in collaboration With the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. $45. THE MANY WORLDS OF ARSHILE GORKY By Karen Mooradian. Illustrated. 327 pp. Chicago: Gilgamesh Press Limited. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: Miss Peloubet, Stephen Potter Are Married
description: The marriage of Anne Lynn Peloubet, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Peloubet 2d of Ridgefield, Conn., to Stephen Welch Potter took place in Riverside Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Philip E. Perkins performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Bus Hijacked in Texas; Man Gives Up in Oklahoma
description: A Greyhound bus loaded with passengers was hijacked on Interstate 40 in Texas early today and the suspect held a gun to the driver's head until surrendering two hours later in Oklahoma, the authorities reported. No one was injured.

title: LABOR LOST
description: To the Business Editor: ''Much to the irritation of many young, activist-minded men and women within the movement,'' the article said, ''there is a dearth of aggressive, imaginative leadership.'' But that is no accident. Decades of ignoring, and in many unions, suppressing activists from the ranks who criticized or opposed the established leaders have posed the established leaders have de Dkstratum of leadership.

title: GOMEZ KNOCKS OUT SILVA IN THIRD OF NONTITLE BOUT
description: Wifredo Gomez of Puerto Rico sent Raul (Hurricane) Silva of Costa Rica to the canvas twice tonight and knocked him out at 51 seconds of the third round in a nontitle fight.

title: WHEN MA BELL'S LADY SPEAKS, WALL STREET LISTENS
description: I F Virginia Dwyer could have it her way, she probably would prefer not to be written about. But as treasurer of American Telephone & Telegraph Company, which raises more money every year than any entity except the United States Government, there is little she can do to escape the spotlight.

title: LOUIS E. RAU
description: Louis E. Rau, Eastern regional manager of the Fairbanks Morse Engine Division of Colt Industries, died Friday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Newark. Mr. Rau, who was a resident of Scotch Plains, N.J., was 60 years old.

title: BORJA OF COSMOS MAKING GOOD ON THE WING
description: It was the Cosmos' search for wingers that awakened Chico Borja, the rookie who has started the last 11 games for the North American Soccer Leaguechampions.

title: Julie Jetton Is Bride Of Paul Lee, Banker
description: The marriage of Julie Jetton, a student at the Rutgers University Law School in Newark, to Paul L. Lee, deputy superintendent and general counsel of the New York State Banking Department, took place at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York yesterday. The Rev. Eugene Y. Lowe Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: IN A LAND OF PLENTY, POLITICIANS CAN AFFORD TO BE NICE--USUALLY
description: This is a town where the Governor walks home to lunch, alone. He is just a middle-aged former commercial guide, trapper and fisherman, trudging along bareheaded in the light rain. A man who passed him along the way nodded but didn't speak.

title: No Headline
description: If anyone deserves credit for recasting Alexander Haig's image, it's Neil Selkirk. His photograph of Mr. Haig continues to support the adage that ''one picture is worth a thousand words'' - the general appears convincingly loving and demure to me. PAUL PETRICONE, Boston

title: Glenn Davis, Martha Russell Are Married
description: Martha Leslie Russell and Glenn Edward Davis were married yesterday in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn. The Rev. Frederick Tuttle Bender, assisted by the Rev. Howard Ronald Whitebred, performed the ceremony.

title: Connecticut Housing; NEW OPTIONS FOR OLD SITES
description: FOR the last four years, Andrew and Mary Barabas have been manufacturing convertible couches and upholstered armchairs in a 100-year-old hat factory that spans the banks of the Oil Mill Stream in a residential section of Danbury.

title: HOW THE OIL GLUT IS CHANGING BUSINESS
description: Oil glut! What once seemed as unlikely as $850 gold or an 18 percent Treasury bill is here. Suddenly, oil is so plentiful that prices are falling by amounts that impress even big-time corporate decisionmakers.

title: Michel Tournier
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Housing; MOBILE HOMES: A VESTIGE OF THE PAST
description: ''I WOULDN'T trade this place for a castle,'' Frederick Kraft said, swinging his arms wide to frame his view of the Hudson and five mountain ridges on the other side, his little fishing dock and an eye-filling rose garden.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Doomed Sparrows
description: The dusky sparrows of Florida were down to six known survivors last January - all males. Five were in the Sante Fe Community College Teaching Zoo in Gainesville, each living on what amounted to a $9,200 Federal pension.

title: Collaborators
description: To the Editor:

title: Recasting Haig's Image
description: It will be unfortunate for the American people if Alexander Haig is successful in ''recasting his image'' (''How Haig Is Recasting His Image,'' by Leslie H. Gelb, May 31). People will be talking about the ''new Haig'' as they did about the ''new Nixon,'' as if a person's character changes along with his demeanor.

title: Headliners; A SOMEWHAT LESSER EVIL
description: In the Soviet Union, dissidents of all kinds, but especially Jewish dissidents, learn to be grateful for small things. Thus it was that the wife of Viktor Brailovsky expressed relief last week after her husband was sentenced to five years of internal exile. Mr. Brailovsky, a computer specialist who had edited an underground journal called ''Jews in the U.S.S.R.,'' was convicted of circulating ''fabrications known to be false, which defame the Soviet state and social system.'' He could have gotten three years in a labor camp.

title: Prospects
description: The 'No Tax Cut' Scenario

title: Editor's Choice
description: 50. SAND RIVERS, by Peter Matthiessen. (Viking, $19.95.) An account of a safari into a wild southern Tanzanian game preserve that becomes a strange, bittersweet journey back into time.

title: GRACE, MAGIC AND LOVE
description: CUSTOMS By Lisa Zeidner. 272 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Food; COOKING WHAT'S LIGHT FOR SUMMER
description: CHARCOAL ignited for barbecues and tablecloths laid for picnics befit the season - summer arrives at 11:45 A.M. today. Warm-weather dining on the Island lends itself to backyards and beaches, but most of the preparatory work still occurs behind the scene in the kitchen. Meats must marinate, homegrown vegetables and tree-ripened fruit require slicing and thirst-quenching lemonade tastes better when the citrus is squeezed by hand.

title: 14 on Panel to Consult On a Park for Westway
description: Governor Carey announced today the formation of a 14-member panel that will consult with the state on designing the 93-acre, four-mile-long state park that is planned as part of the Westway highway project in Manhattan. The project itself is still embroiled in political and environmental fights.

title: NEW DELAYS FOR $200 MILLION HOSPITAL, EMPTY 3 YEARS
description: Woodhull Hospital, designed as one of the world's most innovative and visually striking hospitals and completed three years ago, is now unlikely to open before 1983, according to New York City officials. That would be nearly a decade after it was originally scheduled to open as a municipal hospital in Brooklyn.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO CARE FOR MARBLE-TOPPED SURFACES
description: REAL marble is a luxurious-looking decorative material that looks as though it should be very easy to maintain -but as owners of marble-topped tables and similar pieces of furniture soon discover, it is easily discolored or stained when spilled food or liquids are not promptly mopped up.

title: No Headline
description: Tomi Ungerer is quoted as observing, ''I don't like women.'' His art is described as ''unremittingly negative'' with regard to women and ''consistently brutal.'' Would the sentiments be so bold if they were describing blacks or Jews?

title: Headliners; HENRY WHO?
description: It was no earthquake that shook the foreign policy establishment last week, but rather the democratic process.

title: 2 ARRESTED AT FESTIVAL IN TEXAS DROWN AS BOAT SINKS
description: A small motor boat carrying three sheriff's deputies and three young men arrested at a festival capsized today on Lake Mexia, and at least two of the prisoners drowned, the authorities said. Witnesses said the suspects were manacled and were not wearing life jackets.

title: THE PITFALLS OF MEDIA CRITICISM
description: Late last month, ''Inside Story,'' public television's new program about journalism, was complimenting Bob Pisor, who analyzes newspaper performance for a Detroit television station, WDIV. ''Inside Story'' used as an example of Mr. Pisor's good work a film clip in which he said The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press had underreported the causes of the city's financial problems.

title: CAMPERS LEARN TO TREAT THE MAINE WOODS WITH RESPECT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- DAVID PETERSON is a guidance counselor in a New Jersey high school. By DAVID PETERSON

title: The World in Summary; GUATEMALA GETS HELP ON 4 WHEELS
description: The human rights situation in El Salvador ''continues to be bad but it's better than it was,'' the new United States Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton, asserted diplomatically last week in his first interview since assuming the post in May.

title: DAVIS DOMINATES N.F.L. TRIAL
description: Al Davis, managing general partner of the Oakland Raiders, ended more than six days as a witness in his antitrust suit against the National Football League this week, and as he did, Federal District Judge Harry Pregerson, who is hearing the case, waved a friendly goodbye to him and said:

title: Sarah Latham Married to Richard Kearns
description: Sarah Thornton Latham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Latham of Arlington and Kilmarnock, Va., and Richard Kenneth Kearns, son of Mrs. John McCullough Hodgson of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Richard Kenneth Kearns, were married yesterday.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Dianne McIntyre has always been an adventurous modern-dance choreographer and performer, but she may outdo herself this time. Just back from its first European tour, her Sounds in Motion company will perform new dances set to commissioned jazz scores and a poem in programs at Symphony Space from Thursday through next Sunday.

title: Critics' Choices
description: FILM ''Shake, Rattle and Roll'' is the name of the new series currently under way at the Harold Clurman Theater. The subject, of course, is rock and roll.

title: GUARDIAN ANGELS GET A MIXED RECEPTION
description: FOR a group spawned in New York City's subways, crossing the Hudson via PATH to emerge above ground in New Jersey seemed a logical way to go.And the Guardian Angels, the youthful - and controversial - civilian safety patrol, did just that, setting up their first New Jersey branch just one year ago.

title: FLIGHT CONTROLLERS' WORK CAN BE HECTIC
description: The nation's 17,000 air traffic controllers work eight-hour shifts and 40-hour weeks. They work with other people, yet depend heavily on their machines. Their employer is the Federal Aviation Administration, which pays them $20,500 to $50,000 a year, plus overtime. After 15 years on the job they are entitled to 26 vacation days a year. In many ways, their jobs are similar to millions of other office jobs throughout the country.

title: 'BUY AMERICAN' RULE DIVIDES MIDDLETOWN
description: MIDDLETOWN ''WE have to start somewhere to buy goods made in this country; it's time to instill the pride we once had in American-made products,'' a Middletown Councilman says of his effort to restrict municipal purchases to equipment and supplies manufactured in the United States.

title: Scotland by Puffer
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review; FARCE HOLDS NO RESERVATIONS
description: HERRICKS WHEN Lynne Fontanne was asked whether she had ever wanted to divorce Alfred Lunt, she answered: ''Divorce, no; murder - yes!'' The farce ''Murder at the Howard Johnson's'' (at the Nassau Repertory Theater through next Sunday) starts out as a variation of that well-known riposte. In the first act, a husband, given the choice between divorce and death, opts for the latter as his wife and her lover tie him up and prepare to drown him in the motel bathtub.

title: Sound; NEW EARPHONES- FIDELITY AND COMFORT
description: More and more listeners are turning to earphones as ther key to instant privacy. Take my own case for instance. Our hilltop house in the Berkshires was intended as a sort of retreat. It doesn't always work out that way. On summer weekends the premises swarm with noisily vital visitors of all ages who sometimes bring their dogs, cats and hamsters. There is - as the saying goes - never a dull moment. And while I am generally sociable, I am also addicted to my daily dose of quiet music. Under the circumstances, earphones are an unfailing means of escape. Slip them on, and the scampering and clatter fall away. I am left serene in the exclusive company of Joseph Haydn.

title: A SMALL AD AGENCY THAT'S NO SMALL BEER
description: Just when Madison Avenue had settled comfortably into the age of the superagency, something happened. Carl Spielvogel, vice chairman of one of the world's largest advertising conglomerates, the Interpublic Group of Companies, was passed over for chairman in May 1979, and he left.

title: DUTCH YACHT OVERCOMES TRIALS
description: For Flyer, the race started with light gasps of hot, humid air in the Chesapeake Bay. It ended with the 76-foot ocean racer crunching across a patch of rocks in Narragansett Bay, narrowly escaping a devastating impact with the shore.

title: Italy Indicts Top Masons On Charges of Conspiracy
description: Leaders of the Masonic lodge whose alleged associations with political figures brought down the Italian Government last month were indicted today on charges of political conspiracy and acts against the state.

title: WHOLE EARTH CONTROVERSY
description: JOHN MUIR AND HIS LEGACY The American Conservation Movement. By Stephen Fox. Illustrated. 436 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $17.50.

title: BLACKS SEEN RETAINING 17 SEATS IN THE HOUSE DESPITE CENSUS LOSSES
description: The cold numbers from the 1980 census show that all 17 black members of the House represent districts that have become too small, mostly much too small, to meet the one-man, onevote standard. But almost all 17 seem likely to survive the redistricting process anyhow.

title: John Heithaus, Susan Gaynor Have Nuptials
description: In the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity in Mamaroneck, N.Y., Susan Lydia Gaynor, daughter of Col. Peter F. Gaynor, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gaynor, was married yesterday to John Louis Heithaus, son of Louis Heithaus of Purchase, N.Y. and Mrs. Marcia Krikorian of Mamaroneck. Msgr John J. Mulroy performed the ceremony.

title: THE ART OF LETTER-WRITING: GOING, GOING...
description: ON ARRIVING home from work each evening, my daughter looks through the mail to see if there is anything for her. Except for an occasional circular or advertisement, there is never anything.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: COUPS AND EARTHQUAKES, by Mort Rosenblum. (Harper/Colophon, $4.95.) The former editor of the International Herald Tribune, who has also served as an A.P. correspondent in Asia and Africa, discusses the ways in which events abroad are currently being covered by star reporters, stringers and photographers for the print and broadcast media. Our reviewer, Caroline Seebohm, called this ''both a good read and a salutary warning'' about the increasingly limited foreign news coverage provided by the media.

title: A STRONG DOLLAR BRINGS THOUGHTS OF EUROPE
description: As the Reagan dollar has soared in value against other currencies, an increasing number of Americans are finding that their vacation budgets can stretch to buy a European holiday this summer. The situation can change on short notice, but right now, despite recent fluctuations, the tourist's dollar is stronger than it has been in years, and the gain is even outpacing European inflation.

title: RIDING THE CONGRESSIONAL HORSE
description: In 1974, reformers in Congress won a stunning triumph over a hundred years of haphazard Government spending. A new budget process was instituted to give Congress more say over economic policy and more discipline over its own fragmented spending. But the reform was born a colt with shaky legs. Inflation continued to push the budget above the levels that Congress set for itself, and old spending habits were hard to change.

title: Letters to the Long Island Editor; GASOLINE PRICES AND LACK OF SERVICE
description: Concerning the recent article ''L.I. Gasoline Prices Dropping Slowly,'' the emphasis should decidedly be on the final word. Reductions to drivers in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens lag well behind what I've encountered in New England.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL OUTLOOK LIES IN TV TALKS
description: Executives of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and ABC Sports met last Thursday in the first contract negotiating session that the N.C.A.A. hopes will lead to a revolutionary two-network television showing of Saturday afternooncollege football in the 1982 and 1983 seasons. Some time after July 16, the N.C.A.A. will begin talks with NBC and CBS before deciding which of the other two major networks will get the right to pay millions of dollars to show college football.

title: The Nation in Summary; NEW NUCLEAR SUB MAKES ONE LONGER LEG IN THE TRIAD
description: Thirty months late, $280 million over budget and with Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, the godfather of the nuclear Navy on the bridge, the USS Ohio, the nation's first Trident submarine, slid from its slip in Groton, Conn., last week and into Long Island Sound for its first sea trials.

title: Noelle King Wed To R.J. O'Connor
description: Noelle Warden King, daughter of Dorothy Warden King of Southport, Conn., and Charles King Jr. of Wilton, Conn., was married at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport yesterday to Robert J. O'Connor, son of Mrs. Joseph R. O'Connor of Brooklyn and the late Mr. O'Connor. The Rev. Robert Tate and the Rev. Michael Flannery, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: VISITING CHINA'S ARCHEOLOGICAL TREASURES AT XIAN
description: CHINA is justly famous for its inventions. Gunpowder, paper and one of the world's great cuisines are but a few testaments to Chinese innovation. But the city of Xian, in the prov-ince of Shaanxi, can put forward a special claim to ingenuity: It invented China.

title: Andrea di Bonaventura Bride in Lenox Of John A. Re, Buyer for Clothing Firms
description: The marriage of Andrea di Bonaventura to John Alfred Re took place yesterday at St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Lawrence Costello performed the ceremony.

title: ISRAELIS CITE QUOTATIONS BY IRAQI AIDES TO STRESS PERILS OF A BAGHDAD
description: Israel's Foreign Ministry has made public a selection of quotations from Iraqi officials and newspapers on the subject of Iraq's alleged potential as a nuclear power and its intentions toward Israel.

title: Pilot Rescued From Small Plane Dangling Over Canyon in Arizona
description: Ralph Neal was as ''cool as a cucumber'' for five hours, officials said, but he collapsed when rescuers finally took him out of his small plane, which was tangled in 230,000-volt electric transmission lines 95 feet over a small canyon.

title: Dance View; SURPRISES FROM CITY BALLET
description: The New York City Ballet's Tchaikovsky Festival was a low-key affair if one remembers the company's 1972 Stravinsky Festival and 1975 Ravel Festival. And yet it was a creative event only this company could produce - not without its surprises, some planned and some a consequence of unexpected circumstances.

title: Mailbox; MOTION SECONDED ON DOUBLES EVENT
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Region in Summary; MACDONALD IS INDICTED
description: When his name first cropped up in reports about Abscam, former New Jersey casino commissioner Kenneth N. MacDonald insisted he had ''violated no rule of law or morality.'' Last week, a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn told him to tell it to the judge.

title: THE HARDWARE STORE IS OPEN AND CUSTOMERS COME RUNNING
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration has still not announced a policy on weapons sales, but last week it demonstrated that deeds can speak louder than words. Laying aside the policy of restraint preached by President Carter, within 24 hours it announced new arms-supply arrangements with China and Pakistan. A week before, plans were disclosed to sell F-16 jet fighters to Venezuela.

title: Antiques Johann Joachim Kaendler, Meissen model-meister; TREASURED COLLECTION ON VIEW IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON ONE of the antiques treasures of New Jersey has returned from a tour of the southern United States and Canada. It is a collection of soup tureens, ladles, spoons, plates and ecuelles from the Campbell Museum in Camden, and it will be on view at the State Museum here through Aug. 23.

title: NEW ENVIRONMENTAL CHIEF VOWS TO LIFT REGULATORY 'OVERBURDEN'
description: The new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne M. Gorsuch, says that her agency will help advance the Reagan Administration's goal of ''industrial revitalization'' while continuing to protect public health and welfare.

title: Business Forum; IT AIN'T NECESSARILY SO ABOUT HIGH RATES
description: THE Reagan Administration, in conjunction with the Congress, has a mandate to increase productivity, improve the nation's standard of living, reduce wasteful Government spending and interference with the free enterprise system and stabilize monetary values. These objectives cannot be achieved unless there is a re-education of the Federal Reserve Board and the American public in the true causes of inflation and the effective control of money and credit.

title: CITY MAYORS YEARN FOR THE OLD FEDERALISM GA, and Lee Alexander of Syracuse, NY
description: After more than two decades of a steady flow of financial aid and attention from Washington, the nation's cities now find their relationship with the Federal Government threatened by radical change.

title: Economic Affairs; TO AID SAVINGS, KEEP THE TAX LAW SIMPLE
description: HERBERT HOOVER allegedly promised ''a chicken in every pot.'' According to William Safire of The New York Times, the promise came from King Henry IV of France. In that it was the 16th century, the chicken was promised only on Sundays.

title: PLAN TO REINTRODUCE BEARS STIRS UP A HONEY OF A FIGHT
description: TRENTON THE black bear - Ursus americanus americanus to some and 200 pounds of garbage-picking, honey-stealing nuisance to others - may roam again through parts of its native habitat in the southern pinelands, an area from which it vanished more than 70 years ago.

title: BOAT INDUSTRY BUFFETED BY ECONOMY
description: ESSEX THE boating season is at hand, and Connecticut sailors are heading for the water, leaving behind thoughts of gypsy moths and crabgrass, but generating sales for a variety of boatyards and supply stores that make up a significant part of the economy in many of the state's shoreline communities.

title: Letters to the Long Island Editor; MALPRACTICE INSURANCE RISE: A DOCTOR'S VIEW
description: THE article ''L.I. to Feel Impact of Insurance Rise for Malpractice'' (June 7) was timely and important. The problem faced by physicians was exemplified in the quotations of the attorneys.

title: No Headline
description: The two divorced women who merely ''decided to pool their resources and build a home at Dolphin Cove in Stamford'' could not have been representative of the majority of singles.

title: BILL SEEKS HIGHER SUMS FOR SURVIVORS OF U.S. JUDGES
description: Legislation to improve survivor benefits for the families of Federal judges has been introduced in Congress as part of an effort to recruit and retain judges.

title: Kauai
description: To the Editor:

title: Helicopters
description: To the Editor:

title: EMERGENCY PLANS AT SALEM ASSAILED
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TWP. IF ANYTHING ever seriously goes wrong at the Salem I or Salem II nuclear plants here, the evacuation plans, some residents of the area say, will not work because they are incomplete, inadequate and not understood.

title: INTERESTING TIMES
description: 1587 A Year of No Significance: The Ming Dynasty in Decline. By Ray Huang. Illustrated. 278 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: PIANO: WILLIAM WESTNEY
description: William Westney's piano recital Friday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall seemed intent on showing all the different faces of the Romantic era. Weber's C major Sonata (Op. 24) offered Romanticism's first flushes, and Prokofiev's Four Pieces (Op. 4) its Expressionistic last gasps.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; TRAINIING MANAGERS TO MANAGE TECHNOLOGY
description: If the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has its way, by this time next year 10 businessmen will be the first executives anywhere with masters degrees in the management of technology.

title: Alexandra Murnane Is Married
description: At St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday, Alexandra Murnane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Murnane Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married to Christopher Dehli Hillyer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Norman Hillyer of Devon, Pa. The Rev. Stephen Babos performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Long Island Editor; Advice on Spraying Against Gypsy Moths
description: A comment in the article ''Gypsy Moths Shocks Forecasters'' (June 7) gave me quite a shock. It was a quote from Thomas Kowalsick of the Suffolk County Extension Service in which he had been telling the homeowners that ''there is no sense in spraying now.''

title: ELIZABETH JOEL SHIFTS TO L.I. CHARITY ROLE
description: OYSTER BAY THERE is a strong feeling of familiarity to Elizabeth Joel's elegantly appointed home in Oyster Bay. In the sunken living room, a grand piano stands near the ornately carved harpsichord she recently purchased as a birthday gift for her husband, Billy Joel, the rock musician. The familiarity, however, arises from the recognition that a photograph of the home is featured on the cover of Mr. Joel's latest album, ''Glass Houses,'' which has sold seven million copies.

title: Richard H. Mansfield 3d Weds Jacqueline Snelling
description: Jacqueline Taylor Snelling and Richard H. Mansfield 3d were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Shelburne, Vt.

title: STRUGGLING TO MAKE CONNECTICUT FIT FOR FISH
description: On the back of the official Connecticut highway map is a cartoon crammed with happy vacationers, perhaps the happiest being an angler with a large fish fairly jumping onto his hook. Connecticut is doing its best to live up to this image, and although the state recorded several notable gains last week, it has been a difficult, expensive and controversial undertaking.

title: Topics; RELATIVE CRIME
description: Police departments in California are in a bind: Crime is increasing, but after Proposition 13 took its toll of local property taxes, they are running out of money. So some communities are turning to the ''police tax.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT GOES ITS OWN WAY ON KEY REGULATORY CASES demonstration in Washington
description: The Supreme Court last week gave President Reagan an opportunity and a lesson. The opportunity came with the unexpected retirement of Associate Justice Potter Stewart, a moderate, essentially nonideological jurist. His departure will let Mr. Reagan put his stamp on the Court sooner than anticipated. The lesson was in the separation of powers; it will retain its validity no matter whom Mr. Reagan names to Justice Stewart's seat.

title: DESIGNERS PREPARE FOR RHINEBECK FAIR
description: LAZY Sundays are usually reserved for mugs of savory coffee and a leisurely reading of the newspaper. But at this very moment, in about 500 households nationwide, a frenzy of activity has begun. Styrofoam ''worms'' dart out of packages, cloaks of corrugated cardboard spring in tight spirals around mysterious objects and boxes, cartons and crates bulge with unknown bounty.

title: U.S. Population Reported Up 1%
description: The nation's total population on April 1, a year after the 1980 census was taken, was up about 1 percent to 229,283,000, from 227 million, according to the Census Bureau. The total included armed forces overseas.

title: Elizabeth McHaney Bride of William Cook
description: Elizabeth Banta McHaney, daughter of Banta McHaney of Jefferson City, Mo., and James Robert McHaney of Cape Girardeau, Mo., was married yesterday to William Hubbard Cook, son of Mrs. George Cook 3d of Darien, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and the late Mr. Cook. The Rev. Silas George Kessler performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Jefferson City.

title: John Boswell replies
description: My comments about Mr. Levy's book speak for themselves; I do not wish to add to them or defend them. For the sake of clarity alone I will note that the ''grand error'' to which I refer was Mr. Levy's failure to recognize the semantic equivalence of the Greek word eulogetos (''blessed,'' from eulogesai, ''to bless'') and the Hebrew baruch (also ''blessed,'' and also from the verb ''to bless,'' barach).

title: EXPOSING THE LIBYAN LINK
description: Five years ago, two former operatives of the Central Intelligence Agency made a deal with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to supply the Libyan strongman with explosives for huge sums of cash. They also hired former Green Berets to set up a secret training school to teach the Libyans the latest techniques in assassination and international terrorism. As a cover for these operations, the two men, Edwin P. Wilson and Frank E. Terpil, operated several seemingly legitimate export companies. To head one such company, they hired another former C.I.A. employee, Kevin P. Mulcahy. For a long time, Mulcahy let himself believe that the entire operation was really part of an unofficial but approved American intelligence operation being carried out by an ''old-boy'' network of former Government workers, intelligence agents and Green Berets with strong and lasting connections to Washington officialdom. In this, the second of a two-part series, Mulcahy discovers that the Qaddafi connection is illegal and not an intelligence operation, and, at considerable personal risk, goes first to the C.I.A. and then to the F.B.I. Seymour M. Hersh, a former reporter for The New York Times, is at work on a book about Henry Kissinger to be published by Summit Books. By Seymour M. Hersh hortly before midnight on a muggy Washington Sunday in September 1976, Kevin P. Mulcahy, a former C.I.A. analyst who was then in the export business, telephoned the duty officer at agency headquarters in McLean, Va. ''There are problems overseas,'' Mulcahy said without elaboration, and he had to talk immediately to the agency's assistant to the deputy director of clandestine operations.

title: Gallup Reports Reagan Slipping Sharply in Poll
description: President Reagan's standing in the Gallup Poll has slipped markedly in the last month, to levels comparable to those of Presidents Carter and Nixon after four months in office. The researchers also reported that four months after his election Mr. Reagan had a higher level of disapproval than any recent President.

title: BUDGET AS BECOMES A TOOL OF SOCIAL CHANGE
description: In recent months, the White House has inundated Congress with numbers - budget cuts, tax rates, spending ceilings. But while the battle cry has been ''Control the Federal budget,'' a growing number of lawmakers in both parties now believe the real purpose of the Administration's campaign is to enact a ''second agenda'' that goes far beyond mere figures.

title: THE MOST BRITISH OF SPORTS MOVES QUIETLY INTO SALISBURY
description: SALISBURY A FLICK of the bat, and the Salisbury Village Team claimed victory with a score of 95 runs over the visitors' 94. ''We could quit while we're ahead,'' declared Salisbury's captain, John Woods Conlin. ''But that wouldn't be cricket.''

title: Horse Kills Blacksmith On a Farm in Newfane
description: A 61-year-old blacksmith died this morning when the horse he was shoeing kicked him in the head, the Niagara County Sheriff's Department said.

title: A Widow's Pique
description: In ''The English Mafia,'' Russell Baker created an offensive stereotype in the context in which he twice used the word ''widow.'' (Sunday Observer, April 26).

title: No Headline
description: I so enjoyed reading about the success of Tomi Ungerer since it has been my pleasure to share his very funny books with my students in library reads. However, I was disturbed to hear of his plans to write a new children's ''classic.'' One cannot plan to write a ''classic''; like falling in love, it just happens. ANITA C. GOLDWAG, Oceanport, N.J.

title: PEE WEE ERVIN, 68, JAZZ TRUMPET PLAYER WITH GOODMAN BAND
description: Pee Wee Erwin, a jazz trumpeter who played with the Benny Goodman and Tommy Dorsey bands, died today in Holy Name Hospital here after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: KOCH MANNER TONED DOWN, OBSERVERS SAY
description: Notwithstanding his comment on Friday about the British Government being ''a little crazy,'' people who both watch and work with Mayor Koch believe he has toned down his style in recent weeks and months.

title: Sports of the Times; THE CROWD DEFECTS
description: The most noteworthy difference between the present strike of major league baseball players and previous employer-employee confrontations in baseball and professional football is the attitude of the public and the press. Generally solidly on the side of management in past disputes and shown irrable impatience with the players.

title: Letters; POVERTY, AFFLUENCE AND THE CAUSES OF CRIME
description: To the Editor Having just read of Gerald Caplan's pessimism about the establishment of another crime commission, I can only register surprise at the sad picture Caplan paints of the criminal justice system in particular and society in general. It is even sadder that Mr. Caplan feels the way he does after having spent four years in a position to do something about it.

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 21, 1981
description: International Iran began impeachment proceedings against President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr. As Parliament met in Teheran to debate Mr. Bani-Sadr's fitness to remain in office, 19 people were reported killed in street fighting between rival political factions in the capital. (Page 1, Column 4.) The Pope returned to the hospital in Rome where he was taken after being shot in St. Peter's Square on May 13. A persistent mild fever caused his readmission to Gemelli Hospital, which he left on June 3 to continue recuperation at the Vatican. (1:2-3.)

title: THE QUEST FOR A SPANISH BEACH RESORT MAY END AT MOJACAR
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- JAMES M. MARKHAM is The New York Times correspondent in Madrid. By JAMES M.MARKHAM

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Romantic business. This coming Saturday and Sunday are likely to be a red-letter weekend for those Americans who together spend $100 million a year -more than one-quarter of all paperback sales - to buy novels about romantic encounters between men and women, books that, in the words of one devotee, ''you can curl up with for an hour or two.'' Nearly 500 writers, editors, agents and fans will be getting together at a posh inn in the rolling woodland country northwest of Houston for the first annual conference of the Romance Writers of America.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Washington; THE ART OF RESIGNING
description: Associate Justice Potter Stewart is leaving the Supreme Court of the United States at age 66, younger than most of its members.

title: Frederick King 3d Weds Elaine Behr
description: Elaine Lee Behr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Karl H. Behr of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday in the garden of her parents' home to Frederick Paul King 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. King Jr. of Princeton and Tubac, Ariz. The Rev. Donald MacLeod of the Princeton Theological Seminary performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: TRINITY'S NEW HAND AT THE HELM
description: HARTFORD TRINITY College named a new president last week to lead it through the financial and academic challenges of the years ahead. Like most institutions of higher learning, Trinity faces potential shortages of both students and money - and to handle the problem, the college stepped outside the world of scholars and picked James F. English Jr., the former president and board chairman of the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company, to take over the presidency on July 1.

title: Business Conditions; STEEL IMPORTS SURGE 60%
description: Buoyed by a strong dollar, which has given foreigners a competitive price advantage over American producers, and weak demand in Europe, steel imports rose more than 60 percent in April from March levels, to 1.8 million tons. The increase caught many analysts by surprise, and, if the pattern persists, it could lead to complaints from domestic producers about the trigger pricing system for imports.

title: Strike Halts Production Of Nuclear Components
description: Only security guards and supervisors were on duty today after 4,400 workers walked off their jobs yesterday, halting the making of components for nuclear weapons at the Y-12 plant and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.

title: Topics
description: The New Jersey Sports Authority has made sure that Governor Brendan Byrne will not fade into oblivion by affixing his name to the new sports arena in East Rutherford, soon to be the home of the New Jersey Nets.

title: Food; MASTERING THE MINI DUMPLING
description: FOOD adv21/ By CRAIG CLAIBORNE AND PIERRE FRANEY/ c. 1981 N.Y. Times News Service/

title: The World in Summary; WHERE WILL THE BARREL BOTTOM OUT?
description: Not that long ago, members of the oil producers cartel argued mostly about price ceilings, but last week in Geneva the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was groping for the floor.

title: No Headline
description: France is to hand over a 1,170-ton frigate to Argentina, thus honoring a contract signed by the defeated Government of President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, officials reported today. The frigate, the Granville, will be given to an Argentine Navy crew Monday at Lorient, Brittany, where it was built.

title: THE ODYSSEY OF A YOUNG CHOREOGRAPHER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine writes frequently about dance. By BARRY LAINE

title: ARTIST'S INSPIRATION BEGAN WITH THE FRESH AIR FUND
description: Muriel Castanis, a native New Yorker who grew up in Manhattan, spent so many of her childhood summers in Waynesboro, Va., with a Fresh Air Fund family that she qualified last year as a ''Virginia Artist'' in an exhibit at the state capital. The sculpture she sent won an ''Award of Distinction'' from the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts.

title: LUCKY BOUNCE HELPS HATALSKY MAKE PAR
description: Morris Hatalsky hit his approach shot at the 11th hole on the Merion course into Cobbs Creek today and ended up hardly believing his good fortune. The ball bounced off a rock in the creek, and came flying out and onto the green 10 yards in front of the little stream. Hatalsky threw his wedge high into the air in disbelief and then went on to get a par 4 on the hole.

title: Suzanne Koblentz Bride of Reporter
description: Suzanne Kay Koblentz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Koblentz of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Jordan Elliot Goodman, son of Prof. and Mrs. Elliot Raymond Goodman of Cranston, R.I., and Hyannis, Mass. Rabbis Barry H. Greene and Bennett F. Miller performed the ceremony at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J.

description: SOUTHAMPTON THE setting of Lake Agawam is postcard-perfect as children in their canoes and ducks with their offspring paddle across the 60 acres of fresh water.
