description: Andree Brooks suggests a common-sense solution to both the problems of the single-parent family and of our troubled school systems.

description: IF you are a Connecticut motorist with a van or a pickup truck with either passenger or ''combination'' license plates, stay off the New York parkway system. It could mean a $15 ticket. That was the recent warning to Connecticut drivers by Benjamin A. Muzio, the state Motor Vehicles Commissioner, who has gotten some recent complaints from Connecticut drivers.

description: For a 19-year-old, Carl Lewis already has a habit of making history repeat.

description: ASKED about Poland last week at his news conference, President Reagan was more blunt than diplomatic. ''The Poland situation is going to be very tense for quite some time now,'' he said. ''The Soviet Union is faced with the problem of this crack in their once Iron Curtain, and what happens if they let it go.''

title: Susan D. Conway And Joseph Petrelli, A Banker, Are Wed
description: Susan Dolores Conway and Joseph James Petrelli were married yesterday in the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. Paul Duff performed the ceremony.

title: Joy Landreth Slater Wed
description: The marriage of Joy Landreth Slater to Russell Neff Carrier Jr. took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Kennett Square, Pa.

description: ''Ester Fiszgap is looking for any survivor from Brezsc, Poland.'' ''Anna Tuch, daughter of Isidor and Sabina from Lvov, is looking for relatives.'' ''Anyone who was at @Mauthausen in the year 1942 and knew my brother Alexander Kopelmann, please, please contact me!''

title: VOTE DUE TOMORROW ON RIPARIAN RIGHTS
description: TRENTON APROPOSED amendment to the State Constitution that would limit state claims to former tidal lands is scheduled for a vote in the Assembly tomorrow.

title: DISPUTE OVER MINER BREATHING DEVICES UNRESOLVED
description: More than two years ago the Labor Department said that it would have an improved rescue breathing device for coal miners by Dec. 21, 1980. But when December came, it extended the date until tomorrow.

title: Personal Finance; A CHECKING ACCOUNT WITH PIZZAZZ
description: QUESTION: What do you get when you cross a checking account with a bank repurchase agreement? Answer: A high-yielding checking account - the effective June rate at the one bank that offers such a hybrid is almost 14 percent.

title: Molly Boylan Is Married To Christian D. Garnett
description: Molly Boylan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Boylan of Newington, Conn., and Bar Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Christian Deyo Garnett, son of Dr. and Mrs. James H.P. Garnett of Washington and Easton, Md. The Rev. Seymour St. John of Westerly, R.I., performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Union Chapel on Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: ONE-DAY TOURS OF NEWFOUNDLAND
description: Did you hear the one about the travel agency that wanted to organize a tour to an exotic place for just one day? It sounds like a bad joke, but Goliger's Travel Ltd. of Toronto has been doing just that with considerable success.

title: HOME IS WHERE THE MEMORIES LINGER
description: TWENTY years ago, we bought a house in suburbia and made it into a home. We filled it with love, sweat and tears. We stamped upon it our own character. A stranger's house soon became our family sanctuary, cemented with a commitment to growing together and sharing all that life has to offer.

title: NEW HAVEN GIVING THE BICYCLE A TRY
description: NEW HAVEN ''NO city seems better suited for bicycles than New Haven. Its 24 square miles, flat, picturesque and quaint, buffeted by coastal breezes in the summer and its winter chill softened by the same seaside air, provide first-rate conditions for the cyclist.''

title: CONCERT: LEVINE'S BERLIOZ
description: James Levine has not always matched his accomplishments in the opera house with his symphonic appearances. But Friday night in Avery Fisher Hall, leading the final program of the New York Philharmonic's Romantic Era series, he did a resplendent job.

title: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHY Anyone who expects socialist realism from Jan Saudek, the 46-year-old Czech photographer currently showing at Marcuse Pfeifer Gallery, is in for a surprise. Nothing could be more private and intimate than Saudek's pictures of infants with their fathers or little girls dressed up in adult clothes.

title: NATIONAL PHOTOGRAPHIC CENTER OPENS IN BRITAIN
description: Britain's Royal Photographic Society, founded in 1853, has established a National Center of Photography in Bath, 116 miles west of London. The center was officially inaugurated with the formal opening in April of the Octagon, a neo-classical building that was erected in 1764 as a private chapel and now incorporates two exhibition areas. In addition, the center includes two new galleries, a lecture and film center, a library and a bookshop.

title: ALBANY SENATE BACKS LIFTING OF 8% INTEREST LIMIT ON INSURANCE LOANS
description: The Senate approved a bill this week that would remove the 8 percent interest limit on loans borrowed against lifeinsurance policies purchased after this year, allowing the rate to vary with the market.

title: SHUT-INS GET CHANCE TO GO TO THE OPERA
description: It had been more than a decade since 90-year-old Eugene Birlenbach had been near the familiar sights and sounds of a live opera performance.

title: DEMOCRATS AWAIT WORD BUT O'NEILL STAYS SILENT
description: HARTFORD POLITICAL campaigns are usually blunt and aggressive, and before it ends next summer the contest to pick a Democratic nominee for Governor will probably be no exception. But in its early stages - 17 months before the election - the political maneuvering has been marked by a cautiousness bordering on coyness.

title: Architechure View; SOME GOOD NEWS, AND BAD, FOR WEST 54TH STREET
description: This is another side-street story. New Yorkers will recognize some familiar themes - the battle to save a row of historic town houses of particular architectural richness from demolition for high-rise development, the dedicated attempts of a local group to save the houses, the rumors of air rights transfer and clandestine development studies, and an ending with mixed elements of celebration and uncertainty.

title: LACK OF LIFEGUARDS UPSETS FIRE ISLAND
description: A RECENT drowning in unprotected Atlantic Ocean waters off Kismet, a small Fire Island community where ocean swimming areas had been staffed by Islip Town lifeguards, has raised fresh criticism of the town's responsibility to the largely summertime populations on the barrier beach.

title: FRANCE'S SOCIALISTS ARE FAVORED TO WIN RUNOFF VOTE TODAY
description: France will wind up its long and complicated electoral process tomorrow in a final vote that is expected to confirm the solid control of the Government by President Francois Mitterrand and his Socialist Party.

title: Speaking Personally; LEARNING TO WALK IN FATHER'S LARGE FOOTSTEPS
description: ON A late-summer afternoon in 1936, you could see three little girls fidgeting on the steps of their house, anxiously looking up the street. They were freshly scrubbed and wore identical dresses; however, their assorted sizes told you that they were not triplets.

title: FATHERHOOD AND CHANGE
description: NORWALK MORE than many other successful male novelists, more than many other surburban fathers, Evan Hunter has been thinking long and hard about fatherhood and the young.

title: No Headline
description: The jazz festival that George Wein started in Newport, R.I., in 1954 and that became a symbol for jazz around the world will celebrate its 28th year starting Friday with a 10-day stand in New York. It moved from Newport to New York in 1972, where it continued to be known as the Newport Jazz Festival, as it was when it was founded in Newport.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; DCOTORS ABORT ONE OF TWIN FETUSES
description: Medical techniques that detect a genetic defect of a fetus in the womb sometimes present parents with a difficult decision: abort or carry the abnormal fetus to term. But if such a choice is the stuff of which moral philosophy is made, it can also be the stuff of which medical feats are fashioned.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE odds on landing a job in an Atlantic City gambling casino are probably as tough as they are on winning at one of the tables, according to a report last week by the state's Casino Control Commission.

title: Headliners; FORIEGN ENTANGLEMENTS
description: If Soraya Khashoggi wants to take her husband to the cleaners, she'll have to do it somewhere other than California. So said a judge in Los Angeles last week as he tossed out Mrs. Khashoggi's $2.5 billion divorce suit against Adnan Khashoggi, a Saudi Arabian billionaire and one of the world's wealthiest arms dealers. Mrs. Khashoggi, a Briton, moved to California three years ago and engaged Marvin Mitchelson, the lawyer of Marvin v. Marvin ''palimony'' fame, to represent her.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Sheila Akin Pearl Sings Art Songs
description: Sheila Akin Pearl, a soprano with empathy for art songs and the ability to project them affectingly, made her debut Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall. With Linda Hall at the piano, Miss Pearl offered groups by Mendelssohn, Griffes, Barber, Rangstrom and Sibelius, plus other songs and two arias - ''O patria mia'' from Verdi's ''Aida'' and ''O Lovely Moon'' from Dvorak's ''Rusalka.''

title: Jean N. Hayden Wed to Physician
description: Jean Nikander Hayden, daughter of Mrs. William J. McCart of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Eugenio DeMarchis, son of Mrs. Luigi DeMarchis of Rome and the late Mr. DeMarchis. The Rev. Charles Miller performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

title: Elizabeth Robbins Bride of John R. Cissel
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Brown Robbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Spalding Robbins of Fairfield, Conn., and New York, to John Rittenhouse Cissel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wood Cissel of St. Louis and Little Compton, R.I., took place in Fairfield yesterday.

title: CO-ED ATHLETICS GAINING
description: ONE New Jersey school districts are apparently ready to comply with a Federal order to correct discriminatory practices and increase athletic opportunities for their female students, when the new term starts in September.

title: 18 Burned in Refinery Flash Fire
description: A flash fire apparently caused by chemical vapors burned 18 workers, one critically, at a refinery here yesterday, officials said. There was no damage to the plant of the GHR Energy Corporation.

title: 22,700 TAKE POLICE EXAMINATION, FIRST TO BE GIVEN BY CITY SINCE '79
description: More than 22,700 men and women crowded high school classrooms around the city yesterday to take the first Police Department Civil Service examination offered since 1979.

title: 2 GUILTY IN NEW ORLEANS FOR PLOT ON DOMINICA INVASION
description: Two of three mercenaries accused of plotting to overthrow the tiny republic of Dominica in the Caribbean were found guilty today of conspiracy and violation of the Neutrality Act.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; SECRETS OF WRITING, PART 1: GET A JOB
description: Man - or woman - may not live by bread alone; neither, apparently, can they do so by just writing, whatever its spiritual satisfactions. This not entirely surprising conclusion finds unusually strong documentation in ''The Columbia University Survey of American Authors,'' released by the university's Center for the Social Sciences last week.

title: BANI-SADR TRIES A VANISHING ACT
description: Knowing better than most the character of Iranian revolutionary justice, President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr went into hiding last week. ''We don't know where he is,'' Teheran's revolutionary prosecutor said, admitting it was possible he had fled the country.

title: HITLER'S RUSSIAN BLUNDER
description: The first light touched the Kremlin's towers and the bulbous steeple of St. Basil's on Red Square. The rising sun cast long shadows across the sleeping cities and villages that lay between Moscow and the frontier that Stalin and Hitler had drawn across a conquered Poland.

title: LACKING THE EVIDENCE
description: Prime Minister Begin explained the attack on Iraq's nuclear reactor at a press conference June 9, two days after the raid. title: JUST A PUCKISH COUNTRY COMMUTER FROM BERGEN COUNTY
description: LIKE thousands of other Bergen County residents, Mickey Rooney commutes to a job in Manhattan, in his case to the Mark Hellinger Theater on West 5lst Street.

title: Yuki A. Moore, Banker, Bride of Jeffrey Laurenti
description: Yuki Ann Moore, daughter of Ai Constance Handa Moore and James W. Moore, both of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Laurenti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario J. Laurenti of Trenton. Msgr. Leonard R. Toomey performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart in Trenton.

title: SIMPLICITY IS THE KEY TO HER ART
description: Maureen Stapleton, a small, plump woman with big hazel eyes and a thick crop of white hair, apologizes profusely for being five minutes late, leads her visitor across the darkened set and enters her dressing room. ''My feet!,'' she growls, and slips off her shoes. Then she removes her dress, wiggles into a zip-up smock suitable for housework, bats a few flies, gets out her cigarettes, wonders why the carbonated water has lost its bubbles, fiddles with the airconditioner and, finally, barefoot and organized, sits down.

title: Pamela Hart Wed To M. T. Mallory
description: Pamela Warfield Hart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Ridgefield, Conn., was married at home yesterday to Matthew Thomas Mallory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Mallory of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Marshall Rice, an Episcopal priest of Weston, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: HAIG CONDEMNS VIETNAM FOR OCCUPATION OF CAMBODIA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. joined five of the non-Communist nations of Southeast Asia today in condemning Vietnam over its occupation of Cambodia and did so in terms far stronger than Vietnam's neighbors.

title: POPE RETURNS TO HOSPITAL FOR TESTS TO FIND CAUSE OF CONTINUING FEVER
description: A persistent mild fever forced Pope John Paul II to return to Gemelli Hospital in Rome yesterday for tests to determine its cause, according to the hospital's chief of staff, Dr. Emilio Tresalti.

title: A Look Back At the Souffle
description: Concerning the souffle, the Swiss chef and his passion fruit had nothing that ''The Joy of Cooking'' hasn't known for generations (''The Fluff Without Flour,'' by Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey, May 10).

title: CONSUMER RATES
MITTERRAND'S MANDATE SEEMS CLEARER THAN HIS INTENTIONS
description: President Francois Mitterrand has been relatively silent and all but invisible since he took office a month ago. Nevertheless he and his Government have been running just as hard as they can to achieve a Socialist majority in the two-round elections for the National Assembly.

title: Television Week
description: Travels With Walter Remember the hoopla that surrounded Walter Cronkite's retirement? Well, he remained ''retired'' for all of 36 hours after turning over his anchorman's chair to Dan Rather on the CBS Evening News. Ever since, Mr. Cronkite has been on a globe-hopping adventure in preparation of ''Walter Cronkite's Universe,'' his new science ''magazine'' for CBS. The program, an outgrowth of a pilot miniseries last summer, has its season premiere Sunday evening at 8. His friends at CBS picked that particular time because it's an advantageous one, following the widely-watched ''60 Minutes.''

title: South Africans Arrest Black Student Leader And Black Journalist
description: Zwelakhe Sisulu, a ''banned'' black journalist, was arrested at his home early today in a continuing crackdown on opponents of the Government. No reason was given.

title: THE ARABS SHOULD FACE THEIR REAL PRIORITIES
description: Perhaps the time has come for words to approximate reality a bit more. On June 11, President Reagan met with five Arab ambassadors and assured them that he ''appreciated'' their concern about what had just occurred. Israel, using American-supplied planes, had flown over the territories of two friends of the United States (Saudi Arabia, ''protected'' by American Awacs aircraft, and Jordan), bombed Iraq's nuclear installation, and returned uneventfully. Israel, whose Prime Minister boasts that he operates outside any known framework of international conduct, claimed the right of pre-emptive selfdefense even though it is the only Middle Eastern country both to have a nuclear arsenal and not to have signed the nuclearnonproliferation treaty. Having devastated southern Lebanon, waged openly declared war with American weapons on the Palestinian people, overtly threatened and intervened in the lives of millions of Arabs, Israel has become an outlaw state. Yet it continues to be America's major strategic regional asset, receiving no less than 43 percent of the current foreign aid budget. Is ''appreciation'' the right word for all this?

title: A HERO, SOVIET-STYLE
description: BORODIN Stalin's Man in China. By Dan N. Jacobs. Illustrated. 369 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Police Still Seek Abducted Infant
description: The police in Jamaica, Queens, will hold a neighborhood canvass at 6 P.M. Tuesday to seek information on the abduction of an 8-day-old girl from Jamaica Hospital on June 16. The baby, Kawana Williams, was discovered missing when her mother, Cynthia Johnson, 24, visited the hospital's nursery at Jamaica Avenue and the Van Wyck Expressway. The police asked that anyone with information call 520-9200 or 846-1611.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: QUIMBLE WOOD By N.M. Bodecker. Illustrated by Branka Starr. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $8.95. (Ages 6 to 9) By GEORGE A.WOODS

title: FLORIDA STATE TAKES TITLE
description: Barbara Bunkowsky shot a par-74 that helped Florida State capture the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women national golf championship today.

title: Miss DeHaas Wed To Robert D. Joffe
description: The marriage of Virginia Ryan DeHaas to Robert David Joffe, a partner in the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, took place yesterday in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the ceremony.

title: BLYTH IS VICTORIOUS IN TRANS-ATLANTIC
description: Chay Blyth of Britain and his Brittany Ferries coasted through the fog to an easy victory today in the first Observer double-handed trans-Atlantic race.

title: MEETING IS CALLED OFF BY BASEBALL OWNERS
description: A meeting of major league club owners, at which wome owners were expected to express their displeasure over the pace of negotiations in the baseball strike, was canceled yesterday.

title: Thomas Sommers Weds Norma Mills
description: Norma Fleury Mills, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Steward Mills of Trenton, was married there yesterday to Thomas George Sommers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Arnold Sommers of Villa Park, Ill. Msgr. William F. Fitzgerald performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Good Counsel Roman Catholic Church.

title: ANNE M. SMITH
description: Funeral services were held today for Anne M. Smith, the first woman to receive a doctorate in anthropology from Yale University.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Isle; WHALE WATCH
description: Whales once played an important part in the economic life of the Island, what with the big business of whaling through the 19th century. These days, although blubber isn't what it used to be, the whale has returned to take its rightful place - but, this time out, in the tourist industry. Discovered by environmentalists as a handsome fund-raiser, the leviathan is being pursued all summer long - visually, of course, with scientists aboard to make the pursuit meaningful.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; AGENT ORANGE VETS MOVE UP THE LINE
description: If good things come to those who wait, then two beleaguered groups of veterans may have waited long enough. Following quickly in the footsteps of the House, the Senate last week overwhelmingly approved Federally financed medical treatment for veterans exposed to the defoliant Agent Orange in Vietnam.

title: DETROIT VOTERS' CHOICE: TAX OR POSSIBLE INSOLVENCY
description: Voters here will decide Tuesday whether to increase the local income tax on residents and nonresidents working in the city or face what officials say is almost certain insolvency.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Pledge to Bikinians
description: When American nuclear testing in 1946 made Bikini atoll in the Pacific unhabitable for 100 years, the Government promised the 167 ousted Bikinians equitable resettlement one day near their ancestral island. The natives were placed temporarily on Kili, an isolated island 400 miles to the south, and they suffered periodic food shortages.

title: The Region in Summary; APPEALS COURT PULLS THE PLUG ON N.Y. OIL COMPANY TAX
description: In its perpetual search for new money for the state's mass transit systems, Albany apparently turned one stone too many last year. Ruling last week on New York's tax on the gross receipts of oil companies, a Federal appeals court threw out a provision prohibiting the companies from passing along the tax to their customers. Under a clause written into the tax bill, the ruling - if upheld on appeal - would abolish the tax, which had been counted on to produce $235 million a year, most of it earmarked for the cash-starved Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: About Westchester
description: YONKERS THEY were gathered about the piano, singing the theme from the movie ''The Rose.'' Their voices were less than professional, their stage presence almost nonexistent, but from the shaky sopranos and rusty baritones came a certain strength and sweetness.

title: MEET THE MAN WHO TALKS BACK FOR THE OWNERS
description: To the multitudes of landless New Yorkers who believe they are at the mercy of it, the city's real-estate industry needs no help. But to Richard M. Rosan, the industry has suffered too quietly for too long in a city that loves to hate landlords.

title: NEW YORK IS SET TO BEGIN 10-YEAR PHYSICAL THERAPY projected 1985
description: When he proposed his $2 billion capital budget last month, Mayor Koch declared that ''rebuilding the city's infrastructure'' was crucial to its ''economic revitalization.'' The money, Mr. Koch pledged, would be just the beginning of an ambitious 10-year program to restore New York's deteriorating roadways, bridges, sewers, water mains and mass transit system to health.

title: Notes; A DAY'S CRUISE TO SACRAMENTO
description: Visitors to San Francisco are being offered a seven-hour cruise to the state capital through the Bay Area and up the Sacramento River, a stream so mighty it is called ''the Nile of the American Far West.''

title: No Headline
description: Political activists today called for a nationwide protest to carry on the cause of three hunger strikers who ended their fast today. The Committee for the Defense of Prisoners of Conscience said it would protest ''incessantly'' on an ''all-Poland scale'' until two convicted bombers are released from prison.

title: Dr. Miloslava Machac, an Obstetrician, Wed
description: Dr. Miloslava Ann Machac was married yesterday to Dr. J. Michael Mervart at the First Presbyterian Church in Babylon, L.I. The Rev. Frank D. Svoboda of East Islip, L.I. performed the ceremony.

title: Letters; POVERTY, AFFLUENCE AND THE CAUSES OF CRIME
description: To the Editor:

title: Polly Bartlett Married to Charles Lawrence Bryson Jr.
description: Mary Andrews Bartlett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Bartlett of South Kent, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Lawrence Bryson Jr., son of Mrs. Bryson of Dedham, Mass., and the late Mr. Bryson. The Rev. Edward S. Gleason, headmaster of Noble and Greenough School in Dedham, performed the Episcopal ceremony in St. Michael's Chapel at the South Kent School, of which the bride's father is headmaster.

title: Correction
description: An article in last week's Real Estate Section gave an incorrect explanation of the tax consequences of a two-way exchange of fully depreciated properties.

title: Beauty Fashion
description: R RAILS: Beauty/Fashion LOOKING AHEAD TO FALL Today, fashion is not just clothes. Rather, it is a total look comprising makeup and hairstyles as well as clothes and accessories. One of the best places to see what's coming in hairstyles and makeup looks is at fashion shows, where designers combine their new clothes with the beauty looks that complement them. Here are glimpses backstage at several major American collections for the coming fall.

title: McKay Payne White Is a Bride
description: McKay Payne White, senior vice president of the Compliance Data Center Inc., a New York consulting concern, was married yesterday in the Universalist Unitarian Church to William L. Sheppard, a publicrelations consultant.

title: CAMPERS' BATTLE LANDS IN COURT
description: MINEOLA WHEN Ralph G. Caso was Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead and later Nassau County Executive, he prided himself on the fact that he was the prime architect of an expanded park system to serve all the recreational enthusiasts in the county. The last group he took care of were campers, but now the campers have no camping site, and they have gone to court to force Nassau County to give them their place in the sun. Their lawyer is Ralph G. Caso.

title: FRENCH CHEF IS DEFEATED
description: Seahawk Hanover, driven by Ben Webster, gained the lead tonight in the last sixteenth of a mile and went on to win the $130,000 Jersey cup.

title: On Language By William Safire Caste Party Kimble Mead
description: Only fuddy-buddies go to the gym, or to the drugstore, or to Europe; the upscale (formerly hoity-toity) crowd goes to the spa, or to the pharmacy, or to the Continent. The truly avant garde know that nobody who is avant garde uses avant garde anymore: They are the trendies, or the cutting edge.

title: The Nation in Summary; COURT COUNTS OUT A CENSUS CHALLENGER
description: With $500 billion in Federal aid and any number of Congressional seats riding on the outcome, the Census Bureau's count of the population of the United States in 1980 has been in the courts even before it was issued. Last week, another blow was dealt declining cities that, like New York City, are trying to win back some of those dollars and those seats.

title: William Sprague Weds Anne Jones
description: Anne P. Jones was married yesterday in the Holy Trinity Chapel at Boston College to William Sprague. The Rev. J. Donald Monan, president of the college, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: UPSTATE GROWERS 'GAMBLE' ON LETTUCE
description: The lettuce harvest has started in the mucklands of southwestern Orange County, the richest soil in New York State, only 60 miles from Times Square.

title: Gardening; JUNE IS NO TIME FOR SPARING THE TROWEL
description: GARDEN work usually slows down a bit during June, if only because most planting has been done. Yet, a variety of tasks must be carried out if we are to reap the fruits of early spring efforts.

title: ALICE R. VANDYNE PLANNING WEDDING TO ROBERT HOFFMAN
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Roger Van Dyne of Old Westbury, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Risa Van Dyne, to Robert S. Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Hoffman of New York.

title: FOR WESTPORT SELECTMAN, POLITICS HAS RUN ITS COURSE
description: WESTPORT A LOT of folks here were surprised last month when Jacqueline P. Heneage announced that she would not seek re-election as First Selectman.

title: Elizabeth Ide Downing, Ad Agency Aide, Wed to Scott Sartorius, Business Student
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., yesterday, Elizabeth Ide Downing, daughter of Mrs. Edmund R. Beckwith Jr. of Skillman, N.J., and James B. Downing Jr. of Trappe, Md., was married to Scott Cauchois Sartorius, son of John M. Sartorius of Quogue, L.I., and the late Frances Cauchois Sartorius. The Rev. John Crocker performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: Two gunmen shot an offduty policeman to death today six miles from the border with the Irish Republic, the police said.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Elan Sicroff, Violinist, Performs de Hartmann
description: Thomas de Hartmann (1886-1956) was a Russian-born and trained composer who lived and worked first in France and then in the United States and came under the influence of G.I. Gurdjieff, a mysticphilosopher. For one reason or another, de Hartmann's works have never been widely performed, but Wednesday night Elan Sicroff went to Carnegie Recital Hall to play some of the piano pieces along with Beethoven's Sonata in A flat (Op. 110).

title: About Long Island
description: WHILE others are out watching the grass grow and trying to figure out how the weeds can grow so high, my thoughts are still in a turmoil over the case of the missing pencil. It is a case that I have never been able to crack, even after decades of vigilance, education and shouting.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Jobs in New York
description: Using 900 equations and 1,450 variables, a new computer program analyzed New York City's economy and predicted in January 1980 that 97,000 jobs would be wiped out in a recession before the year was out. That would be about 3.5 percent of all the city's jobs.

title: Dining Out; THE HEART OF THE MATTER IS A BEAT OFF
description: WE know of no other restaurant in Westchester quite like Sergio's in Hartsdale for drama. It's attractive mock-Tudor dining room is whimsically and prettily crammed with old weaponry, dried flowers, antique clocks, a spinning wheel, decoys and such; stained-glass windows insulate the diner from the rattling world of Central Avenue just outside the walls. During the week unobtrusive piano music accompanies dinner, and later in the evening, there is dancing. On Sunday evenings an operatic quartet informally sings popular arias from Puccini, Verdi, Bizet. It is not surprising, then, with all these attractions Sergio's enjoys a happy and faithful clientele. Yet, while all our visits here were enjoyable, we would have wished that more attention had been given to the heart of restaurant operation - the food.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times last Sunday incorrectly identified the location of the wedding of Karen Astrid Larson to Larry Alan Wentz. The civil ceremony was held in the couple's home in Southampton, L.I.

title: Susan Moch, Lawyer, Bride Of Roland Poirier, Engineer
description: Susan Alison Moch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald M. Moch of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Roland Paul Poirier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alban Poirier of Patchogue, L.I. The ceremony was performed at the Tarrytown Hilton by Rabbi Maurice Davis of the Jewish Community Center in White Plains.

title: HOW TENNIS BEGAN: THE FISH STORY
description: SOMETHING about me - I like to think it's the leam, athletic look of a 5-foot-10-inch, 180 pounder - seems to inspire those who meet me for the first time to talk about tennis. In conversational self-defense, I have acquired bits of knowledge about the serve and the drop-shot, the lob and the overhead smash. In the process I have learned enough about the history of the game to qualify as an expert.

title: JENNY LOTZ, U.S. DIVER, DIES AFTER SWIM MISHAP
description: Jenny Lotz, a 23-year-old American diver, died yesterday, five days after suffering brain damage and spinal cord injuries in a diving accident.

title: INDIA'S FERTILE CINEMA SPROUTS A FRESH BRANCH
description: Name five Indian film directors. Well, there is Satyajit Ray, and... Indian cinema is a bit like the blind man's elephant: how you describe it depends on where you touch it first. To film audiences in Western capitals, Indian cinema often is Satyajit Ray, with his incisive studies of Bengali life.

title: Realty News; Third Avenue
description: Two leases have been signed in the Chrysler East Building at 666 Third Avenue at 42d Street. The Permanent Mission of the Republic of Indonesia to the United Nations has leased the entire 12th floor, which contains about 18,000 square feet of office space for 10 years at an aggregate rent of $6.5 million.

title: OHIO RACE DRAWS TOP DRIVERS
description: A week ago, Hurley Haywood was dirving a half-million dollar Porsche around the historic circuit of Le Mans, searching for another victory in the classic French 24-hour race. Haywook is at it again today, but this time he's racing twice around the clock near Warren, Ohio.

title: LAFFITE GETS POLE POSITION FOR SPANISH GRAND PRIX
description: Jacques Laffite of France, driving a V-12 Talbot-Ligier, won the pole position today for the Spanish Grand Prix for the third straight year.

title: A NIGHT ON PATROL WITH THE 'ANGELS'
description: NEWARK A FRIDAY night in May. Two of them have no trouble finding me in Penn Station. They're smiling, businesslike and young - 17, 18. They wear white T-shirts with ''Guardian Angel Safety Patrol'' and a winged all-seeing eye stamped in red. Red berets, covered with studs, medals and favorite buttons, are attached to long strands of colored beads that dangle down their backs.

title: THE MARKETING OF SUPERMAN AND HIS PARAPHERNALIA
description: To the Warner Communications empire, ''Superman'' is not merely a movie or even a series of movies. It is a separate industry.

Hersh 32 The Qaddafi Connection / Part 2: Exposing the Libyan Link 56 Beauty/Fashion Looking Ahead to Fall Terry Robards 58 Wine The Beaujolais Season Marilyn Bethany 60 Design A Knack for Stylish Survival Craig Claiborne 62 Food with Pierre Franey Mastering the Mini Dumpling 67 Puzzles Answers, Page 70 78 Letters Cover: Photograph of Frank Sinatra by John Barr/Gamma-Liaison; photograph of Ella Fitzgerald from Culver Pictures. title: Letters to the New Jersey Editor; THIRD WORLD CENTER IS HELD MISDIRECTED
description: Gertrude Dubrovsky's articles on Princeton University (June 7 and 14) mentions a Third World Center that is the focus of black student life, providing social, cultural and educational activities for its members and responsive to a student-elected governance board.

title: New Jersey Guide; MUSIC IN PRINCETON
description: As part of its summer session, Westminster Choir College, a small, 56-year-old private music school in Princeton, holds workshops that attract participants from all over the United States and some foreign countries. Noted singers and musicians give master classes, and the public is the beneficiary of a constant variety of concerts and recitals until early August.

title: The Lively Arts; BACH AFICIONADOS TUNE UP FOR FESTIVAL
description: STONY BROOK IF Carol and Samuel Baron - and Johann Sebastian Bach, by proxy, at least - have their way, the State University campus here will become the home of an annual summer music festival that will draw people from all over the world.

title: FREDERICK TAUBES, ARTIST AND AUTHOR OF 40 BOOKS
description: Frederic Taubes, a New York artist who was also known for his writing and teaching, died yesterday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital after a long illness. Mr. Taubes, who lived in Haverstraw, N.Y., was 81 years old.

title: OUTLASTING ROCK
description: Sidney Zion, whose book, ''Read All About It!'' will be published this winter, has been a music fan all his life. By Sidney Zion etween the rock and the hard disco, the melody began to slip back in. A piano bar here, a big band there, a touch of Gershwin, a spot of Kern. In gay places and out-of-the-way places. Exuberant, but a little wary, like a gambler with a short bankroll. When was it, two years ago, three?

title: CANADA URGED TO LIFT CONTROLS FOR SOME INDUSTRIES
description: The Reagan Administration's drive for less government in the United States has just spilled over into Canada in a powerful way. After a three-year study, the Economic Council for Canada, the principal advisory body to the Cabinet, has concluded that Canadians can also benefit by taking the government off their backs.

title: Pro Football Notebook; SONS OF SHULA, KEMP TRY TRAINING CAMP
description: Two sons of famous fathers are going to have their opportunity to become pro football players next month when the training camps open.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CABARET In the two years since Karen Akers first appeared in New York at Reno Sweeney, she has developed from a promising performer to one of the most polished and arresting singers in the current Cabaret field.

title: MUSIC IN FRANCE AND JEAN FRANCAIX
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judith Karp writes frequently about music. By JUDITH KARP

title: Madeline T. Bayliss Bride of Jeffrey T. Allen
description: Madeline Therese Bayliss of Bronxville, N.Y., manager of corporate marketing at the Manufacturers Hanover Leasing Corporation, was married at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Westport, Conn., yesterday to Jeffrey Thomas Allen of New Canaan, Conn. He is a certified public accountant and supervisor in the audit department of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. in New York.

title: Dining Out; THE PLACE LOOKS FAMILIAR, BUT...
description: WHEN a new restaurant opens in the same place formerly occupied by a highly rated one, there are both negative and positive aspects. On the plus side is the built-in clientele. A customer, no matter how faithful he remains to the former owner, will at least sample a meal at the new establishment. If it is good, he not only will return, but also will spread the word.

title: 3-1 MAIRZY DOATES TAKES TURF HANDICAP AT BELMONT
description: Mairzy Doates, a 5-year-old mare who competed in Florida and California earlier tis year, made her 1981 Belmont Park debut a winning one yesterday by capturing the $56,600 New York Handicap before a crowd of 23,424.

title: BURNS LEADING OPEN BY 3 ON THIRD-ROUND 68 FOR 203
description: George Burns 3d knows that his golf game goes hot and cold, and he is just as surprised as anyone else to be leading the United States Open after three rounds.

title: Maginot Thinking, Nuclear Style Adm. Stansfield
description: Turner's article, ''Toward a New Defense Strategy,'' was one of vision and clarity (May 10). In my own career as a psychiatrist, a professor and a military officer in World War II and the Korean conflict, I find myself thoroughly in agreement with his presentation. I, too, fear that we are so committed to perpetuating strategies, weaponry and tactics of proven obsolescence that we have blinded ourselves with a rusty Maginot-line confidence. AVROHM JACOBSON, M.D., Ocean, N.J.

title: Susan Savage Wed to Gregory Fusco, Columbia Officer
description: Susan Ellen Savage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Savage Jr. of Windsor, Conn., was married yesterday to Gregory Fusco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Fusco of Spring Lake Heights, N.J., and Boynton Beach, Fla.

title: WOMEN'S HISTORY MEETING ANALYZES TRENDS
description: An electric fan did losing battle with the humidity as Prof. Barbara A. Hanawalt said, ''On Tuesday the 14th of April, 1322 -.'' She was discussing the role of women in the domestic economy of late medieval England.

title: TREASURY SAYS OFFICIAL ASKED 2D CONTRACT INQUIRY
description: The Treasury Department said today that Under Secretary Norman B. Ture late yesterday requested that a new report be prepared by an inspector general on a $223,000 noncompetitive Government contract for use of an economic forecasting model that Mr. Ture had developed and partly owned.

title: PENTAGON CHIEF SEES SOVIET HOLDING LEAD
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger acknow ledged in an interview today that the Reagan's Administration's accelerated military effort was unlikely to ''close the gap'' between the United States and the Soviet Union in conventional weapons in the immediate future.

title: WHY DO THE GEESE, DEER AND RACCOONS CROSS THE ROAD?
description: THEY'VE been seen at all the right places so far this season. They have attended exclusive lawn parties, appeared at private golf courses and made the rounds of many members-only yacht clubs. But lest people think they are snobs, they have also been known to appear at more mundane locations such as supermarket parking lots, athletic playing fields, public tennis courts and backyard swimming pools, and they have even been seen engaging in amorous activities in the middle of a busy highway.

title: SUMMERFARE EXPANDS FESTIVAL PROGRAM
description: THE Abbey Theater of Dublin, the Joffrey Ballet, the Erick Hawkins Dance Company and jazz and family fun, including the opera ''Noah's Flood,'' with a cast of 1,000, will be among more than 135 peformances offered up at Pepsico Summerfare '81 at the State University of New York's College at Purchase from July 4 through Aug. 9.

title: A DAUGHTER REFLECTS ON A FATHER'S GIFTS
description: HE came down the steep flight of inside steps at his apartment house, sitting down very slowly and not without great effort and pain. His wife of 60 years stood at the bottom of the stairs, next to his walker, watching. He had started the long descent early so that they would be outside in plenty of time when the taxicab came.

title: Andrea Some Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Andrea Phyllis Some, daughter of Jerome S. Some of Paramus, N.J. and of Louise Some of Oradell, N.J., to Lloyd Jon Goldstein took place yesterday at the Tammybrook Country Club in Cresskill, N.J. Rabbi Cyril Cohen performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Goldstein of Seaford, L.I.

title: Miss Heyn, Editor, Wed To Jeffrey Jones, Writer
description: Dalma Victoria Heyn and Jeffrey Owen Jones were married yesterday in Westport, Conn., at the home of Ruth Cohen, a friend of the couple. The Rev. Steve Emmett, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: AN EXPERIMENT WITH LIVES
description: BAD BLOOD The Tuskegee Syphilis Experiment. By James H. Jones. Illustrated. 272 pp. New York: The Free Press. $14.95.

title: Antiques; QUILTS STAR IN NEW EXHIBITS
description: Amish and crib quilts are the two most admired types of coverlets collected today. Understandably, therefore, prime examples are becoming extremely scarce. For that reason, quilt collectors will view as a bonanza the two gallery shows that opened last week on Madison Avenue and will continue through July 17. Forty-five color-pulsing, graphically arresting Amish and Mennonite quilts dramatize the interiors of George E. Schoellkopf's gallery, 1065 Madison Avenue (at 81st Street), and 24 ingenious, meticulously stitched crib quilts transform the spaces at Thomas K. Woodward, 1065 Madison Avenue (at 70th Street).

title: SCHOOL BUDGET WOES STALK EAST HAMPTON
description: WHEN the school year started in September, Dr. Robert E. Terrill, Superintendent of Schools in East Hampton, could not have been more confident about the school system's ability to live within its $3.7 million budget.

title: CABARET: TAMMY GRIMES
description: Tammy Grimes's singing voice is a low, throaty quiver, a hum that takes wings. She is, one might say, a lyric baritone - slightly above the basso of Tallulah Bankhead, whose voice had some of the same texture as Miss Grimes's, but below the firmly cadenced lilt of Katharine Hepburn's.

title: The Region in Summary; CULTS WIN TEST, BUT NOT BY MUCH
description: It was hardly an overwhelming affirmation of freedom of religion, but the New York State Assembly last week defeated a bill that would have legalized the involuntary removal of people from ''cults'' and regulated their ''deprogramming.''

title: THE BIG YELLOW CAT POUNCES ON ENGINES
description: PEORIA, Ill.

title: MAYORS CALL CONVENTION GLOOMIEST YET
description: When the United States Conference of Mayors recently asked 100 major American cities to report on their fiscal plans for 1982, the replies seemed to many urban officials to suggest an economic calamity of the magnitude that led to the founding of the conference in the depths of the Great Depression.

title: EGYPT NOW SAYS 10 DIED IN MOSLEM-CHRISTIAN CLASHES
description: The Egyptian Minister of the Interior reported to Parliament today that 10 people were killed and 55 injured in rioting between Moslems and Christian Copts in Cairo this week.

title: AIRLINE FINED FOR BLOCKING REPORT
description: A Federal district judge has ordered American Airlines to pay more than $200,000 in penalties for concealing the whereabouts of a maintenance report prepared after the 1979 crash of a DC-10 that killed 273 persons.

title: Letters; QUESTIONABLE ADVICE FOR ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: JERSEY SAYS CONGRESS HAS WORSENED EFFECT OF PROPOSED AID CUTS
description: The New Jersey State office here has concluded that the Congressional budget process has worsened the likely effect of the Administration's proposed budget cuts on the state, particularly in housing, transportation, Medicaid, child nutrition and care for the elderly.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: Practical Traveler; USEFUL READING FOR TRAVELERS: THE FINE PRINT ON TICKETS
description: Few travelers read the fine print on an air, rail or bus ticket, even though the ticket is a contract between a carrier and a passenger. Most of us seem to care little about the fine print and once we have used a ticket for the purpose we bought it - to get from Point A to Point B - we usually discard it.

title: Ocean City's 'Blue Law' Upheld
description: A Federal judge yesterday upheld Ocean City's ''blue law,'' which controls commercial activities on Sundays.

title: Tax Refunds to Go to Wildlife
description: Governor Byrne signed legislation today authorizing a state income-tax form checkoff of up to $10 for a wildlife protection program. The law authorizes taxpayers who are to receive a tax refund to have $2, $5 or $10 of the refund deducted as a contribution to the wildlife program.

title: PARIS
description: Paris is dead, people say. If this were true, it would be very bad news. Of what other city in the world can we say that it has produced great art, great literature, great architecture and very good music uninterruptedly for 300 and some years? A mere 60 years ago James Joyce said of Paris that ''There is an atmosphere of spiritual effort here. No other city is quite like it. It is a racecourse tension. I wake early, often at five o'clock, and start writing at once.'' We cannot afford to lose a city of that kind.

title: ECONOMIC ASPECT OF BASEBALL STRIKE
description: BENEATH all of the rhetoric, the issue of the major league baseball strike can be clearly stated in terms of the economics of industrial organizations.

title: UNION LEADERS DISCUSS HARMON SHOP
description: ON-HUDSON UNION leaders at the Conrail maintenance shop here say that any problems of low productivity at the Harmon shop, the major maintenance center for rolling equipment on the Hudson and Harlem Divisions, can be traced to problems that are the responsibility of management.

title: PUERTO RICO CHECKING POSSIBLE INSURANCE POLICY FRAUD
description: The government of Puerto Rico is investigating what it calls an apparent fraud involving hundreds of millions of dollars in insurance and millions of dollars in premiums paid on supposed Lloyd's of London policies.

title: E.P.A. RESTRICTS REGIONAL ORDERS ON TOXIC WASTES
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has told its regional offices to stop ordering cleanups of alleged hazardous-waste sites without prior approval from Washington. So far, approval has been denied for about half the requests.

title: Paparbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: Cubitis. The sketches to the right depict an innocent-looking toy that is currently causing millions of Americans to go quietly crazy. ''Rubik's Cube,'' as it's called, is a 2 1/8-inch-by-2 1/8-inch plastic cube composed of 26 small blocks that can be moved about or rotated on a spindle inside. When you first get your hands on a Cube, it looks like the first sketch, with each of its sides a different color - blue, white, yellow, green, red and orange. Once you start moving its parts, it will assume quite different looks, one of which is shown in the second sketch. By twisting and moving them about, the parts of a Rubik's Cube may be made to assume as many as 43,252,003,274,489,856,000 positions. That's right -more than 43 quintillion positions. No wonder that, once you start playing with a Cube, it may take months to restore it to its original appearance.

title: Gertrude S. Moffat, a Medical Student, Married to Dr. Paul E. Neumann on L. I.
description: Gertrude S. Moffat, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Keith M. Moffat of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Dr. Paul E. Neumann, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Norman E. Neumann of New York and Minneapolis, were married yesterday in Cold Spring Harbor. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee, assisted by the bridegroom's father.

title: Stage View; THIS MAY BE 'A TALE TOLD' ONCE TOO OFTEN
description: The problem is: if you have a character who is dead and you want to let us know that he is dead by constantly bathing him in blue light, how do you do it when there are three or four or six or eight other characters onstage bathed in such bright white light that blue won't show up against the white at all? Or, to put the problem in reverse, if you want to lower the stage lights to the point where a dull blue dominates the semi-darkness, how do you keep the other characters from tripping over the furniture?

title: STEPPING INTO HER NEW SHOES
description: The coach stands in the first row of the darkened Ambassador Theater as three young dancers on stage practice a number from the show ''Dancin'.'' She stops them after a few steps. ''Do that like you're in the army,'' she calls out. They start over. But soon she interrupts again.

title: Music View; BUILDING TIME MACHINES FOR BACH, ET AL
description: What if some adventurous pilot were to take off tomorrow in an exact reproduction of the Spirit of St. Louis, trying to duplicate Lindberg's solo flight across the Atlantic. What if, furthermore, every conceivable effort had been made to replay that historic event, right down to such details as an authentic leather helmet and the Ryan monoplane's original compass or a faithful reconstruction of that instrument. Assuming the trip were made with total success, what would be the world's reaction? Admiration, certainly. But would the response duplicate the wild euphoria that swept the globe when the feat was accomplished for the first time? Hardly, unless we all had wandered into a Wellsian time machine. You might imagine how the crowds of 1927 felt, but only a psychotic or a person who had been asleep half a century would ever be able to feel what they felt. Everything has changed since Lindberg's flight, even the ocean itself.

title: Susan B. Wise Is Bride Of Scott Nelson, Teacher
description: Susan Brayton Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Wise Jr. of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Hilton Head, S. C., was married yesterday to Scott Alan Nelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Scarff Nelson of Yonkers. The Rev. Dr. Scottie Griffin performed the ceremony in the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Gretchen Heller Is Bride Of Philip Morgan Farmer
description: Gretchen Heller and Philip Morgan Farmer were married yesterday in St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Milwaukee. The Rev. Donald Hayes performed the ceremony.

title: Back Your Foremen
description: To the Business Editor: The view expressed in ''New Twists in the Foreman's World'' (May 17) that many first-line supervisors fail to feel part of the management team is disconcerting and should be a warning to operating managers to look for similar feelings among their forepersons. firstline supervisor, regardless of training or level of staff support, can be fully effective if he (she) does not believe they have both the ear of and support from senior management.

title: CRIME INQUIRY DELAYS LOS ANGELES CONTRACT ON REFUSE COLLECTIONS
description: City officials have held up plans to award a contract to a Boston refuse collection company that has figured prominently in investigations of organized crime in New Jersey.

title: Black Youths Loot Shops In Southeastern London
description: About 500 black youths smashed shop windows in southeastern London tonight, looting stores and hurling debris at motorists.

title: AUDIT UNCOVERS WASTE IN AID TO SUB-SAHARAN AREA
description: An audit of United States aid programs in sub-Saharan Africa that reported the waste or misuse ''potentially in the millions of dollars'' has raised concern in Congressional committees considering the Administration's $6 billion foreign aid request.

title: AND WHAT IF LANDIS WERE AROUND?
description: BASEBALL'S labor history has been a recurring tale of domineering management tactics and episodic player rebellions. With the current strike in its second week and with no end in sight, it is worth remembering that it is not the first midseason strike in baseball history. In May 1912, the Detroit Tigers refused to play a game against the Philadelphia Athletics in sympathy with the suspended Tiger star, Ty Cobb. Cobb had become so enraged at a heckler in New York's Highlander Park that he barged into the stands to throttle the fan. When Cobb later learned that the fan was missing fingers lost in an industrial accident, he snorted, "I don't care if he has no feet."

title: A STORYTELLER'S STORY
description: LOST IN AMERICA By Isaac Bashevis Singer. Illustrated by Raphael Soyer. 259 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95 By MARK HARRIS

title: Let Housing Industry Attack Economic Factors
description: The article on the Opinion Page by Frank T. Johnson (''Affordable Housing: How It Can Be Built,'' May 24) must certainly have been based on the writer's experiences in the field of housing. Yet, so many of his statements or implications are contradicted by my own experience that I can not leave them unchallenged.

title: BLACK AFRICANS ASK PARLEY WITH ARABS
description: Foreign ministers from the 50 members of the Organization of African Unity overwhelmingly approved a resolution today calling for a summit meeting of Arabs and black Africans to sort out their grievances.

title: The Region in Summary; WEBB DEALS ITSELF OUT OF NEW JERSEY
description: As the nation's largest casino operator, the Del E. Webb Corporation makes a lot of its money dealing out losing hands. Last week, the company concluded that that's exactly what it was holding in Atlantic City and decided to quit while it was ahead.

title: NATIONAL N.A.A.C.P. WINS TAX RULING ON DONATIONS
description: Contributions to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are, for the first time, tax-deductible. The change was approved by the Internal Revenue Service earlier this year without public announcement. The tax-exempt status could have wide implications on the financial position of the association, the largest and oldest civil rights organization, which has been perennially plagued by money problems.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Akalaitis 'Request Concert' Is Extended to July 12
description: ''Request Concert,'' featuring Joan McIntosh in its sole and silent role, has had its run extended again - through July 12 at the Interart Theater, 549 West 52d Street. JoAnne Akalaitis staged the Franz Xaver Kroetz drama, which has a setting designed by Manuel Lutgenhorst.

title: FEDERAL BUDGET SCORECARD--SELECTED PROGRAMS
description: THE White House reserved its heavy artillery for the tax battle last week. But it was more than mindful of the need to protect its second front - the budget cuts that are the other half of the Reagan program to revive the economy.

title: WOMEN EXCEL IN SHOW OF MUSCLE
description: IN high-school auditoriums, convention centers and sport arenas across the country women of various ages are working out, ''pumping up'' and ''oiling down'' in preparation for body-building contests.

title: MCNAMARA WARNS U.S. OF PERILS IN REDUCING AID TO WORLD'S POOR Washington
description: Robert S. McNamara, who will retire at the end of this month after 13 years as president of the World Bank, believes that United States economic and political interests will be seriously injured if this country retreats further from its earlier commitments to aid the poor people of the third world.

title: SCHOLASTIC ALCOHOL USE CALLED WIDESPEAD
description: Amateur athletes are encouraged to drink by parents and school officials who are unwilling to discipline them because it would hurt the athletes, their team and the self-esteem of the community.

title: CALF-ROPING COLLEGIANS MAKE RODEO A STUDENT ACTIVITY
description: They started filtering in last weekend, bringing to this town nestled in the fertrile Gallatin Valley a wealth of 10-gallon hats, trailers carrying horses and bearing out-of-state license plates and accents ranging from deep Southern drawls to Cajun patois. Over the week, a pattern developed; cowboys were spending days with their animals, the early evenings in front of an audience, the late nights drinking beer or whisky and the last hours before daylight in crowded motel rooms, cramped campers or $5-a-night dormitory rooms.

title: Hearing for Missile Officer Is Recessed Until June 30
description: An Air Force hearing to determine whether enough evidence exists to court-martial a missile officer for meeting with Soviet officials was recessed today until June 30.

title: MORE IRKED BUYERS SUING BROKERS against a broker
description: Eighteen months ago a ranch-style home in Contra Costa County in California was listed for $300,000. The property was described as being on one acre with a regulation tennis court, hardwood floors throughout, slate entryway, floor safe and electric garage door opener. After the buyer took possession it was determined that the lot was only eight-tenths of an acre, the tennis court was 4 feet two narrow, there were no hardwood floors in the dining room, the slate turned out to be Arizona flagstone, nobody had a combination to the floor safe and the garage door opener did not work. The buyer sued the broker for misrepresentation, charging that the defects reduced the property's value. Final settlement is pending.

title: Numismatics; PAPER MONEY IS MAKING SOME IMPRESSIVE GAINS
description: Not all dollar bills are shrinking in value these days. Older, scarcer specimens have made impressive gains in recent years, far outstripping inflation as a rule. Paper money, like coins, has proven to be a very sound investment.

title: Looking at Tomi Ungerer
description: Thank you for the wonderfully illustrated article on Tomi Ungerer (''Peck's Bad Boy of Art,'' by Selma G. Lanes, May 24). Ever since chuckling with my toddlers over ''The Mellops Go Flying'' and others in the calm corner of our local library in 1959, I've been a closet fan. Tomi Ungerer, I love you! JOCELYN MCKENZIE, Riverside, Conn.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS BAN: A TOWN AND A CITIZEN SPEAK OUT
description: AFTER brooding about the idiocy rampant in the world, I've decided to send my regrets to Stockbridge, Mass., for its kind invitation to come up for a visit in case of nuclear war. At that, it was a better offer than the first plan -to put me in a railroad tunnel in North Adams, Mass.

title: A BEACON BECKONS WITH LORE
description: I stand as on some mighty eagle's beak, Eastward the sea absorbing, viewing, (nothing but sea and sky) The tossing waves, the foam, the ships in the distance, The wild unrest, the snowy, curling caps - that inbound urge and urge of waves, Seeking the shores forever.

title: Letters to the New Jersey Editor; ENVIRONMENTALIST SAYS GROUPS DO COALESCE
description: Leo H. Carney, in his article on environmentalism (June 7), says that New Jersey environmentalists seldom speak with one voice. While it is true that different groups focus on different interests, there are many times when they coalesce around a major issue.

title: Lynn A. Pollock Married To Gerald J. Van Dorn
description: Lynne Augusta Pollock was married yesterday to Gerald Jerome Van Dorn in the Chapel of the Sisters of the Good Shepard at the Collier School in Wickatunk, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Scheg of Holmdel, N.J., performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: Suburban Singles
description: Andree Brooks's article, ''Divorce Suburban Style: Single at Midlife'' (May 24), is very much in touch with all of the changing sociological factors of being single in the suburbs, although I would question the arbitrary cutoff ages of 25 to 44. Is 46, 50 or 55 ''over the hill,'' as many singles groups would have us believe? This overlooks a vast number of older men and women whose spouses and children have long since left the family home and who have many of the same problems but do not have all the social or job options that are available to the younger group mentioned. They also have to cope with the loneliness and exclusion. NATALIE SINGER CLUXTON, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: THE L.I.R.R. FARE: HOW HIGH THE RIDE
description: ONLY a year ago, Long Island Rail Road riders were jolted by a 20 percent fare increase invoked to help cover a projected operating budget deficit of $194.9 million.

title: Robert Barlow, 66, Dies; Jersey Bank's Chairman
description: Robert B. Barlow, chairman and chief executive officer of the Central Jersey Bank and Trust Company in Freehold, N.J., died Friday at his home in Brielle, N.J. He was 66 years old.

title: Business Conditions; GASOLINE USE CREEPS UP
description: A lot of things affect how much gasoline motorists use, but they all get back to the price of gas. That's the main implication of a new study of Americans' driving habits.

description: Three New York men who reportedly told undercover agents they were interested in ''social justice'' in Northern Ireland were arrested by Federal authorities Friday night and yesterday morning on charges of supplying weapons to the Irish Republican Army.

title: The Nation in Summary; ECONOMIC MODEL TURNS A PROFIT
description: Strict construction of conflict of interest may or may not inhibit recruitment of qualified public servants, as the Reagan Administration sometimes asserts. It can, however, cause other things, including political embarrassment.

description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. FOOTNOTES If you look at the lower right hand corner on the back of any recent book jacket you will see the letters ISBN followed by digits and hyphens.

title: HARTFORD FAMILY GATHERS FOR REUNION
description: VALHALLA THEY came from as far as Palm Beach and as near as Manhattan, to gather at a mansion that once belonged to one of their clan. Sporting suntans and smiles, uttering jovial greetings and wistful recollections, they wandered through this great house, which had changed, like so many of its kind, from private to public ownership.

title: BURNS IS REVERSING A 'BAD' YEAR AT OPEN
description: George Burns 3d can still hit a golf ball a long way, as he indicated yesterday with a 175-yard 9-iron shot out of the deep rough at the Merion Golf Club's 14th hole, and today's 220-yard, 4-iron shot at the fifth hole that helped him save par.

title: FAMILY LIFE: WHY ALL THE CONTROVERSY?
description: ALARMED by trends showing the serious consequences of early-age sexual activity, including adolescent pregnancy and venereal disease, officials of the state's Department of Health asked the State Board of Education to find ways in which schools could help in reversing them.

title: Wine; THE BEAUJOLAIS SEASON
description: eaujolais Nouveau, the young wine of the new vintage that is released amid great hoopla each autumn, is probably the most heavily promoted alcoholic beverage in the world during that brief period when it goes on the market. It is the first wine of the harvest, made from grapes still hanging on the vines only a month or so earlier. It is supposed to be fresh and young and capable of providing consumers with their first indication of the quality and style of the vintage.

title: NEW E.P.A. OFFICIAL SEES NO ROLLBACKS
description: JOHN P. HORTON, the millionaire Bernardsville businessman who last week became the second-highest official of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, says that changes being made in the agency need not signal a collapse of environmental protection, as some environmental groups have suggested.

title: Politics; AN UNUSUAL ELECTION
description: MAYOR Thomas F.X. Smith of Jersey City was an almost disinterested spectator at last Tuesday's runoff election to decide who will take over his office on July l.

title: City Council Meetings Scheduled This Week
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on Environmental Protection, to consider recommendations on transport of hazardous materials through the city, City Hall, 10 A.M.

title: EXPLORING THE PIANO-TRIO REPERTORY
description: The duplication of repertory has long been a way of life in the classical record business - every major artist understandably wants to inscribe his or her thoughts on a repertory cornerstone. Sometimes this results in the simultaneous release of a work in multiple versions, but rarely has one score received so much attention of late than the Tchaikovsky Piano Trio, which has recently been favored by no less than five new recorded performances.

title: 8 JAZZ FILMS JOIN FESTIVAL
description: Eight jazz films, half of them to be seen in New York for the first time, will be screened during 10 days beginning June 26, at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street. The showings will coincide with the Kool Jazz Festival, although they are not part of it.

title: Duffin's 'Behan' to Close
description: Shay Duffin, who has been offering his one-man show, ''Shay Duffin as Brendan Behan,'' at the Astor Place Theater, 434 Lafayette Street, will end his engagement tonight. He will have given 14 performances and 1 preview.

title: DANCE: BY MILTON MYERS
description: The Joyce Trisler Danscompany celebrated Igor Stravinsky on Thursday at Alice Tully Hall with a program of dances set to Stravinsky scores. The show was stolen, however, by a gentleman named Milton Myers and a charming new dance of his called ''Four Etudes.'' In her telling ''Four Against the Gods'' and, particularly, her ''Sacre du Printemps,'' Miss Trisler choreographed to the composer's prescription for ''clear-cut and positive lines'' ''flowing simply and naturally from what the music demands, steps danced in the tempo prescribed which flow out of the music.'' Mr. Myers - a former Ailey dancer who took over the directorship of Danscompany after Miss Trisler's death in 1979 - plays against the music, teasing it and letting it tease out his patterns and images in ''Four Etudes.''

title: LOOK WHO'S TALKING TO WHOM AT THE U.N.
description: An unlikely diplomatic couple, Saadun Hamadi, Iraq's stolid Foreign Minister, and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the brisk United States delegate, last week engaged in a collaboration that could transform politics in the Middle East. Over three days of intensive negotiating, they worked out a compromise resolution that enabled a unanimous Security Council to condemn Israel's destruction of an Iraqi reactor but spared Israel from any more tangible penalty.

title: The World in Summary; IRISH TROUBLES, NORTH AND SOUTH
description: Ireland's muddied election results make an Ulster settlement more distant, and for two reasons: First, no new government that emerges in the Republic - and none was forthcoming last week - will be strong enough to make the kind of concessions Britain will need in return for acceding to Irish unity. Second, the election of two Irish Republican Army prisoners, one of them a hunger striker, demonstrated that the terrorist group has more support among the Irish population than even its partisans believed.

title: Topics; NO SOAP
description: Ignaz Semmelweiss must be turning in his grave. More than a century ago the Hungarian physician demonstrated that medical students were infecting young mothers with deadly fever by failing to scrub their hands before entering the maternity ward.

title: Music; 3 BIG FESTIVALS OPENING
description: THERE may have been a time when warm weather signaled a recess in musical activity in Westchester, but no longer - summertime is concert time all over the county, and this week alone marks the start of three major festivals.

title: Sunday Observer by Russell Baker A Square Meal Patrick McDonnell
description: After hearing that a Japanese scientist had bred a square watermelon, Prof. Walton C. Galinat, an agricultural geneticist, rolled up his sleeves and bred a square ear of corn. The press, of course, found it highly entertaining. Galinat received the ultimate in publicity, an entire page in People magazine. It was very, very sad.

title: TRAVELERS' ALTERNATIVES IF STRIKE OCCURS
description: Airlines, bus lines, railroads, car-rental companies and cruise lines have made special arrangements for handling passengers in the event of a strike tomorrow by air traffic controllers.

description: If you live in a poor country and want somebody to give you money for new schools, never tell them: ''We're poor. We need money for schools.'' You'll have much better luck if you say you want to expedite host country pedagogical data bases.

title: AMBUSH AT MERION ON THE FINAL HOLES
description: Tricky and treacherous, they lurk as if in ambush for a golfer with a lead to blow. They are the three finishing holes at Merion in the United States Open

title: CAROLINA SETTLES INTEGRATION SUIT ON UNIVERSITIES
description: The Reagan Administration said today that it had agreed with the State of North Carolina to end an 11-year-old civil rights battle in an arrangement that helps black colleges but does not penalize white schools.

title: VISITING ITALO CALVINO
description: ITALO CALVINO returned last fall to his native Italy after an absence of 15 years in France. He now occupies a spacious duplex in a 17th-century palazzo two blocks away from the Pantheon, in the center of Rome's prestigious Centro historico. Its decor is of distilled and signorial elegance: stark white walls alternating with walls filled floor-to-ceiling with books, ultramodern seating arrangements upholstered in lush suedes and leathers, doorways of travertine, vitrines filled with art nouveau glass, an extensive collection of primitive African sculpture assembled dramatically among large tropical plants.

title: Film View; MIXED ADVENTURES
description: If, as now seems apparent, movie makers are going to pursue profits by making films with built-in appeal for the family trade (a trade, I suspect, that doesn't go to movies as family units as often as it goes in clusters of adolescents, clusters of teen-agers and clusters of adults), we could do a lot worse than two of the summer's major offerings. They are ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' the Steven Spielberg-George Lucas instant classic adventure-film, and ''Superman II,'' a sequel that is that rare film phenomenon - a movie far better than the one that prompted it.

title: Stephanie A. T. Barry Is Bride of Mark William Agnew
description: Stephanie Anne Thankful Barry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip S. Barry of West Los Angeles, was married at home yesterday to Mark William Agnew, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Agnew 3rd of West Boxford, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Canon K. Castellanos, rector emeritus of All Saints' Episcopal Church in Beverly Hills, Calif.

description: EXTINCTION The Causes and Consequences of the Disappearance of Species. By Paul and Anne Ehrlich. 305 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95. By BAYARD WEBSTER

title: Crime
description: MIND OVER MURDER (Andrews & McMeel, $9.95), by William X. Kienzle, is the third of the Father Robert Koesler books - a series, set in Detroit, that mixes Catholic theology and crime. (Mr. Kienzle was a parish priest in Detroit for 20 years.)

title: SPOTLIGHT GRABBED BY MINOR LEAGUERS
description: When Gary Rajsich hit a home run the other night in Columbus, Ohio, it was seen at a cocktail lounge in Phoenix, Ariz., thanks to the wonders of cable television and the change in public priorities prompted by the strike of major league ballplayers.

title: Art View; ARTHUR DOVE AND HIS CONSTANT PATRON
description: WASHINGTON The relationship that obtains between artists and their patrons is, by its very nature, not one that is likely to remain either untroubled or disinterested once the first flush of enthusiasm has settled into a pattern of expectation and obligation. Even where both parties to the transaction may be presumed to be governed - in one degree or another - by their devotion to the art in question, the interests they bring to it are very different, and the stakes they have in the results are therefore bound to be markedly unequal.

title: Theater; ONE-MAN SHOW ON WHISTLER
description: THE play was announced as ''The Gentle Art of Making Enemies,'' which was the title of a work published by James McNeill Whistler in 1890. Since then, the title has reverted to that of the novel written by Lawrence Williams, which Mr. Williams and his wife, Maggie, have turned into a play. It is a one-character play in which John Cullum takes the stage as Whistler and tells his life story.

title: HENRI G. BUSIGNIES, INVENTOR-EXECUTIVE
description: Henri Gaston Busignies, an electronics and communications expert whose more than 140 inventions in aerial navigation and directionfinding helped guide aircraft the world over, died yesterday in Antibes on the French Riviera. He was 76 years old.

title: Dining Out; JAPANESE FOOD SERVED WITH GRACE
description: JAPANESE restaurants serving authentic dishes, a novelty on the Island just a year or so ago, are now becoming fairly commonplace. The latest addition to the growing list is Kurofune in Commack.

title: The World in Summary; GOING THROUGH THE MOTIONS FOR MARCOS
description: The main interest, after Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos predictably won overwhelming re-election last week, centered on how many voters had stayed home. The Government announced that Mr. Marcos's winning margin was 86 percent.

title: A REBUKE FOR ISRAEL, A QUESTION FOR IRAQ
description: Doomsaying is a Middle East pastime and early predictions of United States political reversals in the region, after Israeli jets destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor June 7, were dire. Last week, however, Washington seemed to be holding its own, offering moral support to the Arabs without doing real damage to Israel.

title: UPROOTED MICHIGANDERS OFF FOR TEXAS
description: (This is the fourth in a series of occasional articles following one Middle Western family on their search for a new life in the Sun Belt.)

title: Lee Springmeyer Weds Sara Dugan
description: Sara Ellen Dugan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Dugan Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday to Lee A. Springmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Springmeyer, also of Short Hills. The Rev. David Earnest, assisted by the Rev. Richard Anderson of Ridgewood, N.J., performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Lo-anne Quinn Is Married
description: The marriage of Lo-anne Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Quinn of Rochester, to Charles J. Cellar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cellar of Stratford, Conn., took place yesterday in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Carolina, R.I. The Rev. John F. Heaney performed the ceremony. The bride's father is senior vice president and chief news executive for the Gannett Company Inc. and president of the Washington-based Gannett News Service.

title: Indian Officials Send Out a Plane To Hunt for 401 Lost Fishermen
description: A Government aircraft took off today from the South Indian coast to search for 401 fishermen missing for three days, a Fisheries Department official said.

title: A ROMANCE OF THE READER
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER By Italo Calvino. Translated by William Weaver. 260 pp. New York: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95.

title: The Region in Summary; CITY DISCOVERS THE JOY OF SPENDING
description: If Mayor Koch had not smiled when he suggested using New York's 1981 budget surplus to buy four jets for Israel, the City Council and Board of Estimate just might have said ''Why not make it eight?'' and approved the appropriation on the spot. That was largely the way things went last week in the negotiations preceding passage of a $14.7 billion spending plan for the 1982 fiscal year.
