description: NEWARK LAST summer, when NJ Transit started putting together its budget for fiscal 1982, it made a number of assumptions, among them:

title: ARGENTINA SAID TO BUY 57 TANKS FROM AN AUSTRIAN ARMS CONCERN
description: Argentina has signed a $180 million contract in Paris with an Austrian arms company to buy 57 tanks, according to sources close to the agreement.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; CROWDED IS NOT NECESSARILY CRUEL, COURT DECIDES
description: Prisons are not generally designed for three-star living; but at what point does discomfort exceed tolerable bounds? Last week, in its first attempt to answer that question, the Supreme Court ruled that two inmates may be confined in a cell meant for one as long as the overall prison conditions do not violate a ''contemporary standard of decency.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN CHATTANOOGA
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- CAROLYN MITCHELL is a reporter for The Chattanooga Times. By CAROLYN MITCHELL

title: Andrew N. Dewing Marries Sarah Ann Webb in England
description: Sarah Ann Webb, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank E. Webb of Edgebaston, England, was married there yesterday to Andrew Nathan Dewing of Miami, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan H. Dewing of Short Hills, N.J. The Anglican ceremony was performed in St. Augustin Church by the Rev. Maxwell Lucas.

title: Miss Buchanan, Teacher, Is Wed to Peter J. Vesey
description: Daryl Henderson Buchanan was married yesterday to Peter John Vesey in the Christopher Wren Church in Sandwich, Mass. The Congregational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ross Cannon.

title: I.R.A.'s at Home
description: To the Business Editor ''An I.R.A. in Every Portfolio'' (June 14) was interesting reading as far as it went. While it mentioned legislation on Capitol Hill, it omitted one very important bill sponsored by three Republican Senators - David F. Durenberger of Minnesota and Mark O. Hatfield and Bob Packwood of Oregon.

title: Megan Elizabeth Maguire Wed
description: Megan Elizabeth Maguire, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Laurence Maguire of Madison, Conn., was married in the First Congregational Church there yesterday to Daniel Carroll de Roulet. He is the son of Mrs. Vincent de Roulet of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. de Roulet, former Ambassador to Jamaica.

title: MARYKNOLLERS PURSUE RISKY PATHS IN THE THIRD WORLD
description: The mandate of Christian missionaries has always been primarily religious: to bring the Gospel message to all, including the most downtrodden and oppressed. But that mandate has egalitarian implications which the established powers have often found highly annoying and deeply threatening. Such displeasure is well known to the Maryknoll missionaries, a society of Roman Catholic priests and an order of nuns whose commitment to the poor and to social justice as integral to Gospel teachings has had unpredictable and, sometimes, grave political consequences.

title: CHINESE DEFEAT U.S., 3-0, TO WIN TABLE TENNIS TITLE
description: China's mens' table tennis team won the 1981 United States Open team title tonight with a 3-0 victory over the United States at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: A Correction
description: The teams described in the article ''Little League Ouster Linked to Sex Bias'' in the Long Island Weekly section on June 7 are not affiliated with Little League Baseball Inc. The teams belong to the International League of the Glenwood Landing-Glen Head Junior Baseball League.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A FATHER REFLECTS ON THE GIFT OF CHILDREN
description: TWENTY years ago, we bought a house in suburbia and made it into a home. We filled it with love, sweat and tears. We stamped upon it our own character. A stranger's house soon became our family sanctuary, cemented with a commitment to growing together and sharing all that life has to offer.

title: SOVIET AFFIRMS RISE IN INFANT MORTALITY
description: A Soviet statistician has acknowledged that infant mortality rates, last published here in 1974 and considered one of the barometers of a society's well-being, have remained high since an upward turn 10 years ago.

title: MRS. GOODHUE'S ROLE IN JOINT-CUSTODY BILL
description: ALBANY FOR two weeks, the Democratic-led Assembly withheld bringing to the floor of the house a controversial bill that would require judges to consider joint custody of children if either party requested such an arrangement - waiting until certain revisions were included in the bill to satisfy the objections of the Republican-controlled Senate. Last week, the bill obtained final passage in the Legislature, although it is uncertain how Governor Carey will respond when the measure reaches his desk.

title: Westchester Journal
description: MAYOR Gerald E. Loehr of Yonkers last week formally opened his reelection campaign, and a possible re-run of the 1979 race, by attacking his opponent, former Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli, as ''a man of proven incompetence'' who had damaged the city in his six years in office.

title: Amy M. Waldinger, Buyer, Wed to Alan Emanuel Lax
description: Amy Marie Waldinger, daughter of Rebecca Powell Waldinger of Flushing, Queens, and Richard A. Waldinger of Searingtown, L.I., was married yesterday to Alan Emanuel Lax, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Lax of New York. The ceremony was performed at the St. Regis Roof by Rabbi Edward Klein.

title: SEX EDUCATION CURRICULUM GUIDE DEBATED
description: HARTFORD FOUR of every 10 girls across the United States will become pregnant before reaching age 20, according to educators and family planners. That kind of statistic and the recent release of a state report on ''family life education'' has reopened debate among Connecticut officials on sex education in public schools.

title: COURTS ARE NAMING ADMINISTRATORS NOW TO BETTER BUILDINGS
description: After a year and a half of a rent strike, the tenants of 19-21 West 68 Street off Central Park West had learned to make do with intermittent heat and hot water, dirty hallways, a leaky roof, no super, and even, at times, with no electricity. Then the gas went too. May faded into June, and June into summer. The gas still did not come back on.

title: SECRETARY HAID PLAYS THE CHINA CARD IN SPADES
description: In foreign affairs, the compass of the Reagan Administration is fixed almost exclusively along one axis: East-West. The spires of the Kremlin are what make the needle in Washington flutter. The same is true in Peking. There, more closely attuning the policies of both nations, Alexander M. Haig Jr. last week pronounced China a ''friendly nation with which the United States is not allied but with which it shares many interests.''

title: THE 'CHUNNELERS' ARE PUSHING A EUROPE LINK- AGAIN
description: LONDON EVER since Napoleon in 1802 proposed a tunnel under the English Channel for military reasons, politicians and engineers on both sides of the water have refused to let the idea die. This year the planners are dreaming again.

title: The Nation in Summary; TAKING STOCK OF THE ARMY DAM-BUILDERS
description: Find any trickle of water and chances are the United States Army Corps of Engineers can throw a dam across it in no time at all. But in many instances, according to Federally commissioned audits released last week, the projects are either prime pork barrel or poorly administered.

title: Letters; BUREAUCRATIC LARGESS
description: To the Editor:

title: 27 Food Establishments Named Health Violators
description: The New York City Department of Health last week cited 27 food establishments for violations of the Health Code. It also named six establishments that had corrected earlier violations and six that it had closed for failing to do so.

title: SOVIET SPOKESMAN SEES CONSPIRACY IN WEST TO USE POLAND TO SPLIT BLOC
description: A leading spokesman for the Soviet Communist Party today linked developments in Poland and plans by the West to deploy new medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe as attempts to undermine the Warsaw Pact.

title: Long Island Journal
description: TWO and a half years ago, Nassau County spent $347,672 to purchase 3,600 bulletproof vests for its police officers. A year ago, the State Legislature appropriated $1 million to reimburse police departments throughout the state for bulletproof vests purchased after May 15, 1980. So far none of the money goes to counties that took action earlier to protect their own police officers, and the Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, doesn't think that's fair.

title: The Careful Shopper; Norwalk Complex Is Expanding
description: The expansion of offerings continues on two floors at the Norwalk Factory Outlet Center: casual and dressy separates for junior and contemporary sizes; national brands of women's shoes, with men's shoes to come; active sportswear and accessories; and, to sustain hungry shoppers at the 15 discount stores, a candy shop, B&B Sweets - the only full-price shop. The new shops, when completed, will probably carry books on the main floor and handbags and food on the third floor.

title: ON AUTONOMY, CATALANS FOLLOW THE QUITE PATH
description: For five years, the Catalans have been the well-behaved pupils in the sometimes unruly classroom of Spanish democracy.

title: Spain Pardons Eleuterio Sanchez, The Murderer Known as El Lute
description: The Government granted a pardon yesterday to Eleuterio Sanchez, known as El Lute, who had been sentenced to death for robbery and murder, and given sentences totaling 1,000 years for other crimes.

title: Art; AT HUDSON, A LIASON AND PUNS
description: YONKERS COMPLAINTS of there being ''nothing to look at'' in the Hudson River Museum have surely been put to rest by two of the shows now playing there through July 5. The pattern painter, Cynthia Carlson, has transformed the museum's upper floor with nine canvases and floral motifs applied directly to the walls.

title: YANKEES REVISE TICKET POLICY
description: The Yankees have announced their policy for dealing with tickets to games affected by the strike.

title: Investing; A STIR IN RATE- SENSITIVE STOCKS
description: THE slow, on-and-off decline in interest rates of late has brought rate-responsive stocks into sharp focus for investors. Utility and banking issues, which along with insurance are two of the most interest-sensitive, led the market ground and helped generate renewed enthusiasm for equities before giving up some of their gains. Though most economists seem to hedge their bets on how far interest rates will slide, a broad swath of stocks, including many blue chip, defense, and some high-technology issues, have fared well, at least in part on a more optimistic outlook for interest rates.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Foundation to Get Knight Estate
description: The bulk of the estate of John S. Knight, editor emeritus of the Knight-Ridder newspaper group, will go to a charitable foundation he established 31 years ago. Alvah H. Chapman, president and chief executive of Knight-Ridder, said the majority of Mr. Knight's 6,356,504 shares of stock in Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc. would go to the Knight Foundation of Akron. Mr. Knight died Tuesday at the age of 86.

title: Camera; TECHNIQUES FOR TAKING OUTDOOR PORTRAITS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lou Jacobs Jr. is the author of several books on photography and a frequent contributor to this column.

title: Chess; POSITIONAL SACRIFICES
description: The positional exchange sacrifice is not a new idea. Siegbert Tarrasch, the great German theoretician, pointed out 60 years ago that a strong outpost knight could easily outweigh a rook. And long before that, Paul Morphy, the American genius, used it in several 1857 games.

title: GROUND-LEVEL TROUBLE FOR THE F.A.A.
description: By one measure - air safety statistics - the Federal Aviation Administration is doing a bangup job. As of this month, two years had passed since a life was lost in a commercial airline accident. But there are plenty of other concerns these days for the agency and its new administrator, J.Lynn Helms.

title: SOME COFFINS WENT UNBURIED IN CITY'S POTTER'S FIELD
description: Coffins containing unclaimed corpses have sometimes been left exposed in burial trenches recently in the New York City potter's field on Hart Island, the City Correction Department said yesterday. However, the department said the practice had now been halted.

title: PARISTO PICK IN OHIO DERBY
description: The defection of two potential favorites from the Ohio Dergy field has left Paristo a 2-1 choice for the 47th running of the event at Thistledown tomorrow.

title: Reading and Writing through them; IS FICTION A PAIN?
description: Reading reviews of novels and especially those parts of reviews that publishers choose to quote, one might suppose that fiction is an intrinsically painful business and that fiction readers are seeking some form of expiation. Novels are regularly praised for being searing, scouring, excoriating, cruel, alarming, devastating, merciless, remorseless, unrelenting, chilling, bleak, lacerating and unflinching.

title: Miss Frothingham New Canaan Bride Of S.R. Wendin Jr.
description: Caesara Sperry Frothingham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Langdon Frothingham of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Sigurd Robert Wendin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wendin of Grosse Pointe, Mich. The Rev. Alfred Whisler performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: No Headline
description: While making a plea for new thinking about traditional weapons systems, the admiral is still thinking in terms of conventional warfare. The word ''nuclear'' never appears. Today, this omission is the equivalent of Maginot-line thinking. KAY ARTHUR, Rowayton, Conn.

title: MATERNITY REBATES
description: Sally and Robert Gallant got a $100 rebate on their first delivery March 4. But it wasn't for a car - it was for their second-born son, Daniel Patrick.

title: Antiques; FLEA MARKET IN LITCHFIELD OFFERS VARIETY
description: LITCHFIELD ONE of the more posh of the summer outdoor antiques shows for which Connecticut is noted, the Litchfield Flea Market, will be held here next Saturday on the grounds of White Memorial, Route 202, with 150 exhibitors taking part. The show, a benefit for the Little Guild of St. Francis for the Welfare of Animals, will run from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and will feature a wide variety of antiques - everything from eons-old sharks' teeth to Queen Anne furniture to redware pottery turned and glazed in the 19th century.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: The Lively Arts The V.I.P.'s; 'V.I.P.'S' MARKS FIRSTS FOR ROBERTSON
description: EAST HAMPTON ALTHOUGH it is a line they have apparently used before, it still continues to amuse them. ''Now, Nedinia,'' he said, ''in the interests of complete candor, admit it. You got the part because you're sleeping with the director.''

title: Stamps; FOR THE MAN WHO STARTED BUSINESS EDUCATION
description: Up until about 100 years ago, business education consisted primarily of on-the-job training in the school of experience, but Joseph Wharton changed all that when he established the first school of business in the world. Today the graduates of management education, as it is currently known, are outstanding figures in the nation's economy and among the leaders of America.

title: 6 Independents in Ireland Are Asked to Back Premier
description: Prime Minister Charles Haughey has asked six independent legislators to back his Fianna Fail Party to end a parliamentary deadlock and keep him in power.

title: Behind The Best Sellers; LEN DEIGHTON
description: Len Deighton is one of a number of British writers who, because their books do well on both sides of the Atlantic, make one wonder if Shaw was right in saying that Britain and the United States are separated by the same language. He has had a number of big sellers in both countries, including ''Funeral in Berlin,'' ''The Ipcress File'' and ''Billion-Dollar Brain,'' and now his ''XPD'' is also a trans-Atlantic best-seller.

title: ARGUELLO CAPTURES TITLE
description: Alexis Arguello of Nicaragua won the world Boxing Council lightweight title by taking a unanimous decision over Jim Watt of Scotland, the defending champion, in 15 rounds at Wembly arena tonight.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: HAND-ME-DOWN DREAMS By Carol Antoinette Peacock. 167 pp. New York: Schocken Books. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Other Business; DAD'S DAY GETTING AHEAD, AS RETAILERS CHEER
description: The liquor will flow, the steaks will sizzle, the neckties are already out of the box. Father's Day, that early summer homage to the gods of retailing, has by and large caught up with Mother's Day, despite the latter's long headstart. (Mother's Day was authorized by law in 1914, a status Father's Day only acquired in 1971.)

title: Outdoors; LURES TELL FISHING'S HISTORY
description: If the pursuit of fish no longer tugs as it did when you were young but you wish to maintain at least a peripheral contact with the sport, might turn to the collection of old lures.

title: DISQUIETING LESSONS OF THE COAL STRIKE ARE SINKING IN
description: I am Appalachia! In my veins runs fierce mountain pride: the hill-fed streams of passion; and stranger, you don't know me! You've analyzed my every move - you still go away shaking your head. I remain enigmatic - I am Appalachia: and, stranger, Though you've studied me, you still don't know. from ''My Appalachia,'' by Muriel Miller Dressler

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: TV View; AN EXPLOITATION OF THE FANCIFUL
description: Daytime television, as most of us know, is an especially profitable exercise for the networks. All of those soap operas and game shows are relatively cheap to produce, making all of those commercials for cake mixes and floor waxes the equivalent of rich gravy in the financial ledgers. NBC, which has been having widely publicized ratings problems with its evening prime-time schedules, is therefore understandably concerned about its sagging daytime numbers. According to industry analysts, the NBC situation in this area wavers between serious and desperate. The inevitable panic in executive quarters probably accounts for the recent week-long trial run of a most curious production called ''Wedding Day.''

title: THE EMBELLISHMENT OF HISTORY
description: I HAVE no problem with the accuracy of historians in general, or Josephus in particular. They are all inaccurate. The historian, the chronicler and the newspaperman all embellish.

title: Art; PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST: SASS AND SENSIBILITY
description: MORRISTOWN TO JUDGE from a self-portrait taken in 1913, when she was 30 years old, Imogen Cunningham was a very fair woman with translucent milky skin. Her hair appears to be short, and her simple dark dress is made more demure by a wide lace collar. She is, nevertheless, the embodiment of ethereal Celtic beauty, which had been so popular with artists around the turn of the century.

title: FOYT DRAWS POLE POSITION FOR RENAMED POCONO 500
description: A.J. Foyt drew the pole position from a hat today for the United States Auto Club's Van Scoy Diamond Mine 500-mile race tomorrow at Pocono International Speedway.

title: EUROPEANS PREPARE FOR NEW LAUNCHINGS
description: With the successful test of their Ariane rocket yesterday, Western Europeans looked with new confidence toward the expansion of their launching base here and the development of even more powerful rockets to deliver satellites into orbit.

title: Essay; THE REAL TIMERMAN ISSUE
description: By William Safire WASHINGTON - Is Jacob Timerman the courageous accuser of anti-Semitism in Argentina, whose personal witness of torture and repression shames the don't-make-waves Jews of that country and demonstrates the need for the U.S. to put pressure on dictatorships of the right?

title: Around The Nation; 3d Victim Who Was Aboard Texas Sheriff's Boat Found
description: The body of a third teen-age drug suspect who drowned in Lake Mexia was recovered from the lake today, the authorities said. The youths drowned when a sheriff's boat capsized.

title: SITARIST: YODH PLAYS WITH LYRIC SPIRIT
description: Shyam Yodh and his sitar welcomed a warm summer Saturday evening in New York last weekend with two extended ragas and two briefer songlike episodes. The music was played at the Alternative Museum in lower Manhattan.

title: The City; Trial Starts Today In Lennon Murder
description: The selection of a jury in the trial of Mark David Chapman, who has been charged with the murder of John Lennon, is scheduled to start this morning in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Pass the Tab Wins
description: Pass the Tab took the lead from Wartime Admiral heading into the final turn and went on to an easy victory in the $150,000 Ohio Derby today at Thistledown.

title: Around The Nation; U.S. Jury to Consider Action On More in Dominica Case
description: A Federal grand jury will consider whether to indict businessmen who are accused of backing a scheme to overthrow the Government of Dominica now that two men have been convicted of planning to invade the island, Federal prosecutors say.

title: Cynthia S.Kass Married To Dr. Robert S. April
description: Cynthia Sue Kass, program officer of the French-American Foundation in New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Samuel April, an attending neurologist at Lenox Hill Hospital. Rabbi Alan W. Miller and Cantor Eliezer Kornreich performed the ceremony at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism.

title: Sports World Specials; Foul Play
description: When Ty Cobb rampaged through major league baseball earlier this century, he used to get his groundskeepers to construct a puddle-like water hole along the third-base line. Then he would plop bunts into the area, appropriately nicknamed Cobb's Lake. But with so many stadiums being built or converted to artificial turf, there is little room left for innovation.

title: Carbo Will Play For Tigers' Farm
description: The veteran Bernie Carbo will return to baseball this week when he joins the Detroit Tigers' top farm club in Evansville, Ind.

title: ; The Specter Of Margin Calls
description: THERE is concern these days that a moderate stock market setback could lead to mass liquidation and a serious bear market. The high levels of three key statistics are contributing to this concern. They are broker loans, the cost of broker loans and stock prices themselves.

title: CHINESE GIVE TABLE TENNIS LESSON TO U.S.
description: The game of table tennis in the Western world, according to the most prevalent theory, began at an English officers' club in 1881, when two besotted army men carved balls from champagne corks, stacked books for a net and used cigar-box lids as paddles.

title: PORT AUTHORITY AGREES WITH CITY TO EXPAND TWO MAJOR AIRPORTS
description: The Koch administration has reached agreement with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on a $500 million package of investment and development at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports over the next 15 years.

title: Lakeland Terrier Is Best in Show
description: A Lakeland Terrier, Ch. Red Ruler Gadabout of Dor-Ru, who was bought as a pet for $250 by Ruth and Dorothy Anderson of Bloomington, Calif., was named best in a field of 1,401 at the 43d annual fixture of the Staten Island Kennel Club at Fort Wadsworth yesterday.

title: UNFAIR APPROACH TO SETTING DISABILITY BENEFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: NO SIGN OF STRIKE MOVES
description: Less than 12 hours after baseball's club owners and players reached the agreement that averted a strike last year, Ray Grebey, the owners' labor negotiator and spokesman, issued a news release in which he outlined details of the settlement.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL CHIEF DOUBTS GAS NEED
description: The chairman of the Synthetic Fuels Corporation has expressed strong doubts about the need for plants that produce natural gas, raising new fears that the Government may reduce its support for the fledgling industry.

title: CAPE COD PROVIDES SHOWCASE FOR COLLEGE BASEBALL PLAYERS
description: base coaching line, the visiting team's manager cups his hands and shouts a jubilant warning.

title: GRAHAM OVERTAKES BURNS, WINS OPEN BY 3 SHOTS
description: This, for a change, was not a tournament that somebody lost. It was a championship that David Graham won. He made up a three-stroke deficit today to capture the 81st United States Open by three strokes.

title: JETS TO TAIWAN: FROM HAIG'S VIEWPOINT, NO URGENCY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported today to see ''no urgency'' in dealing with the possible sale of advanced jet fighters to Taiwan.

title: Advertising; Many New Accounts Landed by Agencies
description: In account action, Tilley, Marlieb & Alan, New York; Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles; Marsteller, all over, and Mingo-Jones Advertising, also New York, all landed new business.

title: ANCHORED HOSTAGES
description: Wars produce strange circumstances, and one of the ongoing oddities of the Iran-Iraq war is still being played out. Since the fighting broke out in September 1980, the world has virtually forgotten a fleet of 63 merchant ships from 23 countries caught in Shatt al-Arab, a waterway that divides the two nations.

title: Article 198406 -- No Title
description: The appetite of investors for corporate bonds will be thoroughly tested this week as investment bankers try to sell more than $2 billion of new issues - the largest weekly volume of the year.

title: JERSEY ORDERS CONCERN TO PLAN FOR A CLEANUP OF 26 POLLUTED PONDS
description: The American Cyanamid Company has been ordered to develop a plan to clean up 26 lagoons containing 800,000 tons of chemical wastes at its plant near Bound Brook, N.J., state officials said yesterday.

title: DECISION FOR ISRAELIS
description: Arguments about the Israeli raid on Iraq's nuclear reactor and the international fallout are obscuring more decisive issues.

title: Ms. Magazine Editor To Head Ad Council
description: Patricia Carbine, the editor in chief and publisher of Ms. magazine, has added another feather to her cap. Last Wednesday she was chosen as chairman of the Advertising Council, and as such, is the first women to hold that post.

title: LEWIS TAKES TITLES IN JUMP, 100 METERS
description: For a 19-year-old, Carl Lewis already has a habit of making history repeat. Two weeks ago, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's outdoor tack and field championships, Lewis became the first athlete since Jesse Owens in 1936 to win a track event and a field event in the same championships. Tonight, in the USA/Mobil outdoor championships, he became the first athlete since Jesse Owens in 1936 to achieve the same feat in this meet.

title: Jacklin, on 68-279, Takes British Golf
description: Tony Jacklin, the 36-year-old former British and United States Open champion, won the Jersey Open by one stroke today for his first British victory in eight years.

title: Sanders Captures Central Park Run
description: Odis Sanders of the Millrose Athletic Association, winner of the Madrid Marathon two weeks ago, captured the Citibank four-mile run yesterday at Central Park in 19 minutes 28.6 seconds.

title: Different Role for the Governor of New Hampshire
description: Taking a leaf from President Reagan's book, Gov. Hugh Gallen of New Hampshire is switching careers, at least temporarily. Mr. Reagan gave up acting to go into politics. Mr. Gallen is forsaking politics, for a time, to go into acting. Mr. Gallen has been given a part in a five-hour movie about the 1905 Japanese and Russian peace treaty, which was signed in Portsmouth, N.H. The film is being made in Portsmouth by the Japanese Public Broadcasting System.

title: OIL REFINERS ARE HURT BY OVERSUPPLY
description: The precipitous decline in American crude oil imports has significantly improved the nation's balance of payments, but the oil companies stuck with millions of barrels of unsold crude are having trouble dealing with the excess supply.

title: The City; Mayor Declines To Endorse Goldin
description: Mayor Koch, whose support for City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's re-election campaign has been in some doubt, said that he expected to vote for the Comptroller, but declined to endorse him.

title: WINNERS MAKE ATLANTIC SAIL SOUND SIMPLE
description: Chay Blyth and Rob James, two effervescent Britons who have been sailing the oceans for many years, completed a record passage across the Atlantic last night, finishing their 3,000-mile voyage from Plymouth, England, in 14 days 13 hours 58 minutes.

title: CLARK WINS HARLEM BIKE RACE AGAIN
description: When Danny Clark of Australia and Claude Langlois of Montreal staged their duel over the last 20 miles of the 35-mile circuit around Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem yesterday, the race won by Barbara Trent of Brooklyn had long been over. But the satisfaction of victory lingered for Miss Trent.

title: BARGAINING POWER ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: Iron Supplies Questioned
description: Iron ore prices are now so low that the stability of future supplies is in jeopardy, Deputy Australian Prime Minister Doug Anthony said on Friday at the end of an eight-day visit to Brazil. After a visit to the Carajas project, site of one of the world's biggest iron ore projects, he said no new iron ore projects could be economically developed at today's prices and many small mines around the world were going bankrupt. He said he had discussed the problem with Brazilian officials, adding: ''I think both of us recognize we have to persuade our customers to pay more.''

title: A NUCLEAR-ARMS-FREE MIDEAST, WITHOUT DELAY
description: The legal, political, and moral fallout of the Israeli raid on Iraq's reactor aside, the crucial issues in the Middle East remain: how to save the region from escalation and explosion, and how to bring about a just and comprehensive peace to all the parties in the area.

title: Surgery Scheduled For Brewers' Hisle
description: Larry Hisle, who appeared in only three games for the Milwaukee Brewers this season after hurting his left arm May 8, will undergo surgery Tuesday in Los Angeles to remove a bone spur from his shoulder.

title: Goalie Kicks Referee
description: Roy Amundsen, Norway's international soccer goalkeeper, faces punishment by the Norwegian Soccer Federation after knocking down and kicking a referee unconscious during a match, Norwegian Radio said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE GLITTER DOME. By Joseph Wam- baugh. 299 pages. Perigord Press/Mor- row. $12.95.

title: 'Surprise! Surprise!' Producer Keeps It Hush-Hush
description: For a producer with a musical in the works, Robert Lissauer has been unusually tight-lipped about his new project, but only, he says, out of fear that an unscrupulous competitor might beat him to the stage with his own show. It is called ''Surprise! Surprise!'' and Mr. Lissauer clearly wants to keep it that way.

title: MRS. CARNER ROMPS TO 8-SHOT VICTORY
description: JoAnne Carner displayed brilliant iron play today in capturing the Lady Keystone Open golf tournament for the second straight year. She set a tournament record of 13-under-par 203 and won by eight shots.

title: The Region; Battle on Hepatitis Winds Up in Jersey
description: The immunization of 75 eighth-graders against hepatitis concludes a fight against an outbreak of the disease believed to have stemmed from Taco Town, a popular Mexican restaurant here, health officials said.

title: POP: ASTRUD GILBERTO, SINGER
description: WHEN Astrud Gilberto sang ''The Girl From Ipanema'' at a recording session featuring her husband, Joao Gilberto, the guitarist, and the saxophonist Stan Getz in 1963, she had never performed in public. The success of the recording - it has sold 27 million copies - led her to undertake a singing career.

title: COUNTRY-POP: JUICE NEWTON
description: ALTHOUGH Juice Newton, the silvery-voiced country-pop singer who made her New York debut Thursday at the Savoy, has made six albums in six years, she only recently scored her first major success with a remake of Merilee Rush's 1968 hit, ''Angel of the Morning.'' On record, Miss Newton shows a marked vocal resemblance to Linda Ronstadt during her country period in the early 1970's.

title: U.S. OFICIALS INVESTIGATING POSSIBLITY OF FRAUD IN IMMIGRATION OF KHOMEIMI IRANIANS
description: Federal officials are reviewing immigration records for hundreds of Iranians on the suspicion that many got immigration benefits, including status as permanent residents of the United States, through fraud or bribery.

title: LIFE IN HOUSTION: THE FLEAS AND THE EXTERMINATORS HAVE FOUND PARADISE
description: It seemed as if the flea socks had barely been put away when he sat down to relax after dinner and felt the telltale itch on his calf.

title: The U.N. Today; June 22, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Development Program Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CITY BALLET: 'SQUARE DANCE' AND 'FOUR TEMPERAMENTS'
description: The New York City Ballet returned to its regular repertory on Wednesday and Friday at the New York State Theater - with a slight difference, for the hanging plastic tubes that formed Philip Johnson's set for the just-ended Tchaikovsky Festival will remain up until the end of the season. Seeing George Balanchine's ''Four Temperaments'' in that setting was a little like having one's caviar served up on a bed of Saran wrap. But neither Mr. Balanchine's ''Square Dance,'' also on Wednesday's program, nor his ''Ballo della Regina,'' danced on Friday, were much affected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A new political generation has been raised to responsibility.'' - Lionel Jospin, French Socialist Party leader. (A1:6.)

title: POP: SOUTHSIDE JOHNNY AT SAVOY
description: Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes, the 10-man band that played four performances at the Savoy over the weekend, are passionate exponents of the early 1960's rock-and-roll tradition that also nurtured Bruce Springsteen, their friend and fellow native of New Jersey. But unlike Mr. Springsteen, they have never transcended their provincial band image.

title: cc12.6Magazine-Cable Joint Advertising
description: With hopes of attracting advertisers who can't really afford a stong spot TV campaign and certainly can't manage a decent network TV showing, Sports Illustrated and E.S.P.N., a sports cable network, have devised what they consider a cheaper alternative.

title: 'LOVE NEW YORK' DRIVE WOOING MILLIONS AND BRINGING IN BILLIONS
description: Crowds of tourists from 14 states and three Canadian provinces came here this weekend for the opening of a $60 million amusement park and campground, and they served as living proof that tourists are pouring into New York State and spending money as never before.

title: MOSES GETS A SCARE, BUT TRIUMPHS AGAIN
description: Some day, Edwin Moses may lose a 400-meter hurdles race. Today, he won his 63d consecutive final at that distance and his 69th straight race, including trials. But for a moment, it looked as if that 4-year-old streak would go down the drain.

title: Threat Cited to Reagan Plan
description: President Reagan's economic recovery package could be jeopardized by changes the House of Representatives is making in the spending cuts it adopted last month, Senate Budget Committee chairman Pete Domenici said today.

title: Lisa J. Avery Bride of Dr. Alan Jeffery Peck
description: Lisa Joy Avery, daughter of Cantor and Mrs. Lawrence Avery of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married at Temple Beth El there yesterday to Dr. Alan Jeffery Peck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Peck of Chicago. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner and Cantor Avery officiated at the ceremony.

title: 400 RIGHTIST GROUPS IN NATIONAL COALITION TO START BOYCOTT OF TV WILDMON SPONSORS THIS WEEK
description: No one in the bustling barber shop off Main Street had ever heard of the Coalition for Better Television or its chairman, the Rev. Donald Wildmon. The coalition has its national headquarters just two blocks up the street, but the offices are unmarked and unimpressive: three sparsely furnished rooms that rent for $125 a month.

title: MAJOR ISSUES CLEAR TO S.E.C. NOMINEE
description: Bevis Longstreth, the 47-year-old New York lawyer who was nominated by President Reagan last week for a seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a clear view of what he considers to be the major issues facing the Federal agency.

title: BURNS FLARES AT U.S.G.A.
description: yard third hole at Merion yesterday, George Burns tapped a 40-foot putt, trying for a birdie, that slid about 8 feet past the cup. But he saved his par and now he was walking toward the fourth tee when he overheard Harry Easterly, the senior executive director of the United States Golf Association, talking to another U.S.G.A. official.

title: Drug Concern Cited by F.D.A.
description: The Food and Drug Administration has recommended that criminal charges be filed against the SmithKline Corporation because the company allegedly waited too long to notify the Government of adverse reactions to its blood pressure medication Selacryn, an F.D.A. spokesman said late last week.

title: Two Royal Birthdays and the Turns of Fate
description: Prince Andrew, the second in line to the British throne, and the woman his great-uncle loved enough to renounce it marked birthdays Friday.

title: COUP BID HASN'T DETERRED SPAIN'S FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: The mood of political uncertainty that has enveloped Spain since February's attempted military coup d'etat so far seems to have had relatively little impact on the flow of foreign investment into the country.

title: Iranian Guerrilla Leader Is Killed in the War Zone
description: The head of Iran's guerrilla warfare units in the war with Iraq was killed today, the official Pars press agency reported.

title: Bridge: Title Tournament Bulletins Popular With Enthusiasts
description: Virtually all major tournaments throughout the world, and some that are not so major, publish a daily bulletin giving results, news and a selection of the most interesting deals. This concept was introduced by the great Dutch player-writer, Herman Filaski, at the 1955 European championships in Amsterdam.

title: INFECTION WILL KEEP POPE IN HOSPITAL FOR TWO WEEKS
description: Pope John Paul II will have to spend at least two weeks in the hospital as his doctors seek to locate and cure a virus infection that has weakened him and caused a persistent fever, physicians at Gemelli Hospital said today.

title: Stacy L. Kaufman Is Married To Steven Hoffman, Lawyer
description: Stacy Lynn Kaufman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul S. Kaufman of Roslyn, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Roy Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley D. Hoffman of Kings Point, L.I. and New York. The ceremony was performed jointly by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman and Rabbi Norman Kahan at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: STATE PRISONS, FILLED OVER CAPACITY, CUT BACK SHARPLY ON RIKERS INTAKE
description: State prison officials said yesterday that New York's prisons were jammed beyond capacity and that for the last two weeks the state had taken far less than its normal allotment of prisoners from Rikers Island.

title: POP: MISS LOCKHEART CONJURES LADY DAY
description: Paula Lockheart, who appeared with her trio at Folk City on Saturday, is a blues singer of considerable promise who models herself closely after the late Billie Holiday. Dressed in a period cocktail dress, she even goes so far as to wear a flower behind one ear.

title: A BALLOONING BUSINESS
description: A newcomer to the offbeat shops of SoHo is Balooms, whose main business is balloons. The baby talk doesn't mean it appeals just to children.

title: Family Over News
description: Working side by side seven days a week assures maximum togetherness for a married couple, and for Josh Friedman and Carol Ash, the editor and publisher of The SoHo Weekly News, the two-year-old arrangement might have been perfect except for their concern about one thing - their 4-year-old daughter, Susannah.

title: ; Curbing Write-Offs On Taxes
description: THE commodity futures industry is bracing this week for what could be the most damaging attack on its markets since the early days of the New Deal, when popularist reformers sought to abolish futures trading entirely.

title: Rex Harrison's 5 Goals
description: At the age of 73, he's thinking of the day when he will take the ''final curtain call,'' says Rex Harrison. But before that happens, there are five more plays he'd like to appear in.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: I was playing the net in a tennis match and my opponent, racing in for a low ball, hit me with the ball on his return. However, his momentum carried him into the net and he nearly fell over it. Whose point is it?

title: Chinese Defeat U.S., 3-0, To Win Table Tennis Title
description: China's men's table tennis team won the 1981 United States Open team title tonight with a 3-0 victory over the United States at Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: How Much Should Health Cost?
description: The Supreme Court's ruling on cotton dust settles a narrow legal dispute over the powers of a particular regulatory agency. But it leaves unanswered a far more important question: should regulatory standards strive to protect health at almost any cost - or only at some ''reasonable'' cost?

title: News Summary; NEWS SUMMARY; MONDAY, JUNE 22, 1981
description: International Control of France's National Assembly was won by the Socialist Party, led by the new President, Francois Mitterrand. In a sweeping victory, the Socialists and their centrist electoral allies, the small Radical Left Movement, will control between 280 and 293 of the 491 Assembly seats. The Communist Party will control 43 seats, fewer than half its previous total. The seats held by the allied parties of the right will be reduced from 274 to between 150 and 160. (Page A1, Column 6.) Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was impeached by the Iranian Parliament, which declared him politically incompetent. The action paved the way for his dismissal as President of Iran by the country's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The impeachment vote was 177 to 1, with 11 members not voting. The President was ordered arrested on sight. (A1:5.)

title: The City; Testing of City Buses Faulted in U.S. Study
description: More rigorous testing might have avoided the problems that sidelined new Grumman Flxble buses in New York and 26 other cities, according to a General Accounting Office study.

title: THE FRIDAY AFTERNOON MONEY-SUPPLY LOTTERY
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAN-IRAQ WAR: LIFE IN BAGHDAD GETS BETTER
description: I-SHIRIN, Iraqi-Occupied Iran, June 17 - Nine months ago this place was a thriving Iranian town of about 50,000 people, an unassuming spot dominated by a huge, handsome mosque. For many months now it has been a place of blasted buildings, crushed metal, toppled monuments, gutted stores and no civilians.

title: Artist Portfolio at Library Of Medgar Evers College
description: The Medgar Evers College Library in Brooklyn is showing the ''Black and Beautiful'' portfolio collection of Elton Fax, artist and author. The exhibition is open during library hours in the second-floor lounge through August. The library is at 402 Eastern Parkway.

title: SUMMER USHERED IN WITH MUSIC AND GAMES OUTDOORS
description: The first day of summer settled on New York yesterday like a warm gray blanket on a fevered body. And recalling bits of the history of this day was Peter Shaw, a professor of English, who sat on a folding chair amidst the ebb and flow of the annual block party on 69th Street between Columbus Avenue and Central Park West.

title: Joseph Frederico Seiler Weds Mary Stuart Steel
description: Mary Stuart Steel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Brevard Steel Jr. of New York, was married in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday to Joseph Frederico Seiler, son of Theodore E. Seiler of Zurich and Porto Alegre, Brazil, and the late Mrs. Seiler. The Rev. Frederick Bowen Northup performed the ceremony.

title: 11 CLIMBERS MISSING ON MT. RAINIER IN FALL OF ICE WALL
description: Eleven mountain climbers were believed dead after being swept off the face of Mount Rainier early today and buried by up to 70 feet of boulder-sized chunks of ice.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BACK

title: U.S. AND UNION MEET IN EFFORT TO AVERT AIR CONTROL STRIKE
description: Working against a strike deadline set for later this morning, the Government and representatives of its air traffic controllers continued negotiating early today on a new contract.

title: SUPPLYING DATA ON CONSUMERS
description: IN the advertising business, personal judgement may be an endangered species - if you can't back it up with numbers, don't bring it up. The higher the stakes, the more burning the desire for data on the consumer.

title: ALBANY RENEWAL PRODUCES PRIDE AND A REBELLION
description: Inside the once-gracious town houses and brownstones surrounding the State Capitol, middle-class urban pioneers are painstakingly restoring to nobility the staircases and oak beams that have suffered under generations of paint and neglect. Dumpsters - the surest sign that rehabilitation is in progress -are everywhere.

title: NO MAGIC AT THE GATE FOR ASTRODOME CARD
description: The witch doctor was imported from Uganda to help the champion. The witch doctor, it was discovered, is a Catholic with six children. On the surface, it would seem that any boxing card with Sugar Ray Leonard, Thomas Hearns, Pipino Cuevas and Tony Ayala Jr. would do well. But like the witch doctor, the Thursday night closed-circuit show from the Houston Astrodome - dubbed ''The Welterweight Astrowars'' - is perceived as a mere publicity stunt, not the movie, but the coming attractions. The public does not buy tickets to coming attractions.

title: Around the Nation; Tulsa Hilton Is Evacuated As 3d-Floor Room Burns
description: Guests and staff of the 400-room Tulsa Hilton were evacuated today when a fire burned out a room on the third floor.

title: FOYT GETS 4TH VICTORY IN RAIN-SHORTENED POCONO RACE
description: A.J. Foyt, four-time winner of the Indianapolis 500 auto race, matched that number of victories in the Pocono championship car 500-miler today by capturing a rain-shortened contest under a yellow flag.

title: GALA $300,000 SPORTS EXHIBIT DRAWS TEPID REACTION
description: Is Bobby Hull's hockey stick a work of art? Is Rocky Marciano's boxing glove a masterpiece? Can Wilma Rudolph's track shoes compete with Van Gogh?

title: THE MATCH THAT'S CAPTIVATED CHICAGO
description: Mayor Jane M. Byrne grasped immediately the historic propriety of William Wrigley's decision last week to sell his bedraggled but beloved Chicago Cubs to the Tribune Company.

title: The Region; Job Actions Planned At 2 Jersey Hospitals
description: TRENTON (AP) - About 1,600 members of the state's largest union of nonprofessional hospital employees planned a one-day job action today at two state psychiatric institutions.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 22, 1981. MONDAY Borman's Mayer (Geo A) & Co Esterline Corp Proler Intl General Mills Sterchi Bros Stores TUESDAY Borg-Warner Corp Natl Gypsum Chase Co Fund Boston rthern Ind Pub Serv Cleveland Elec Illum Ranco Inc Federated Dept Stores Rubbermaid Inc Fleming Cos Sanders Associates General Dynamics Corp Scott & Fetzer Co Income & Capital Shs Toledo Edison Knight-Ridder Union Oil Calif Montana Power WEDNESDAY Brooklyn Union Gas Medtronic Inc City Investing h'n States Pwr Minn INA Corp Raytheon Co Iowa Resources SFN Companies Lear Petroleum Wash DC Gas Lt Long Island Lighting THURSDAY Boston Edison Keller Indus Campbell Soup New Engld Gas & Elec Consol Foods Corp Orange & Rockland UtilsGeneral Signal Corp Quanex Corp Handy & Harman Sperry & Hutchinson Ames Dept Stores Outlet Co Avco Corp Rexham Corp Central Hudson G & E Snap-On Tools Church's Fried Chicken Trane Co Omark Indus Vulcan Materials

title: WIMBLEDON: A NEW LOOK FOR THE OLD CHAMPIONSHIPS
description: Dan Denny gently placed the pot of red, blue and pink hydrangeas in a freshly dug bed under a rosebush in front of court 3 at the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club yesterday.

title: Two Jets Narrowly Miss Colliding Over Airport at Brownsville, Tex.
description: A Bolivian Air Force jet came within 200 feet of colliding with a Braniff Airlines flight carrying 87 passengers today, an airport control tower spokesman said.

title: Gomez Knocks Out Silva In Third of Nontitle Bout
description: Wilfredo Gomez of Puerto Rico sent Raul (Hurricane) Silva of Costa Rica to the canvas twice tonight and knocked him out at 51 seconds of the third round in a nontitle fight.

title: YOU'RE SAFER RIDEING THE F TRAIN TO QUEENS THAN DRIVING A CAR
description: THERE To the Editor:

title: Miss Caulkins Wins Two Finals at Meet
description: Tracy Caulkins of the Nashville Aquatic Club won two events today to give her six victories in the three-day Swim Meet of Champions.

title: 'SUPERMAN II,' IN FIRST WEEKEND, SETS RECORDS
description: ''Superman II,'' which opened in 1,395 theaters on Friday, has broken several box-office records during its first few days. It had the best single day in the history of the industry yesterday, when it sold $5,603,000 in tickets.

title: Tides Beat Clippers by 8-7
description: Ronald MacDonald's infield single drove in the deciding run today as the Mets' top farm club, the Tidewater Tides, beat the Yankees' top farm team, the Columbus Clippers, 8-7, in 10 innings in International League baseball.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT AZTECS, 3-0
description: An early goal by Chico Borja and two second-half goals, one on a penalty kick, by Giorgio Chinaglia gave the Cosmos a 3-0 victory over the Los Angeles Aztecs this afternoon at Giants Stadium.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A Company News article in Business Day on June 11 incorrectly stated the amount of Zale Corporation stock held by Peoples Jewellers. Peoples holds 10 percent of the voting stock of Zale.

title: ALARMING POSSIBILITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Utility Credit Needs
description: Electric utility companies in the private sector in the United States will need to borrow about $95 billion from outside sources to finance construction programs in the next five years, William McCollam, president of the Edison Electric Institute, said here Friday. He told a seminar that the figure represented about 60 percent of a total $155 billion construction program in that period.

title: AMERICAN AIR IMPROVES PERFORMANCE
description: Just about six months ago, the boyish face of Robert L. Crandall, president of American Airlines, was lined with fatigue. He had been getting to work at corporate headquarters in Grand Prairie, Tex., before sunup some mornings, and he said ruefully that if his days didn't start even earlier it was ''because I don't think I can make them any longer and survive.''

title: MENSTRUATION: SURVEY FINDS IT'S STILL UNEASY SUBJECT
description: Despite the increasing frankness with which Americans discuss sexuality, many people are still uncomfortable about the topic of menstruation. According to the findings in a new report, a significant number believe that it should not be discussed at the workplace or in social situations, with a quarter of them considering it unacceptable even with other family members at home.

title: Mayor Steps Up Personal Belt-Tightening Campaign
description: Mayor Koch, who has been jogging and exercising in a gym near City Hall for nearly four years in an unavailing effort to lose weight, said yesterday that he was trying something new: diet pills.

title: ARRANGEMENTS FOR PASSENGERS
description: In the event of a strike today by air traffic controllers, New York City airports expect to accommodate about 30 percent of their regular flights.

title: Surgeon-Become-Artist Recalls a Patient's Timely Tip
description: If Zero Mostel hadn't been hit by a bus in 1959, Dr. Joseph R. Wilder wouldn't be making plans to go to the White House this afternoon.

title: Gentlemen's Quarterly Still Pursuing Playboy
description: Gentlemen's Quarterly, a property of Conde Nast for 18 months, will continue going after Playboy in new advertising breaking this week, courtesy of Wyse Advertising.

title: Catherine Bobrinskoy Wed to Thomas Casti, a Chemist
description: Catherine Bobrinskoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas A. Bobrinskoy of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward Casti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Robert Casti of Yonkers. The Very Rev. Alexander Schmemman, dean of St. Vladimir's Seminary in Scarsdale, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Russian Orthodox Church in Yonkers.

title: Seewagen Takes State Net Title
description: Butch Seewagen, who has played at Wimbledon, Forest Hills and Flushing Meadows, made a sentimental return to his old home club and won the New York State men's tennis championship yesterday for the seventh time.

title: Nancy Koppelman Wed to Todd Siegal
description: Nancy Faye Koppelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Koppelman of Princeton, N.J., was married at home yesterday to Todd Loring Siegal, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Siegal of Springfield, N.J. Rabbi Selig Salkowitz of Temple Avodah in Fair Lawn, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: JOHN SHELDON
description: John Sheldon, publisher of The Alamosa Valley Courier and chairman of the board of the Colorado Press Association, died at home of a heart attack yesterday.

title: An Insurance Premium for New York
description: Last year, New York State was smart enough to establish a special insurance exchange, designed to lure new commercial insurance business - and jobs - to New York City. But it was not quite smart enough to finish the job. The law inadvertently prohibits the exchange from insuring out-of-state clients. The error ought to be promptly corrected.

title: Around The World; Warsaw Pact Commander Vows Defense of Poland
description: Marshal Viktor G. Kulikov, commander in chief of the Warsaw Pact forces, said today that the armies under his command would defend Communist rule in Poland.

title: PROTECTING TENANTS CURING CO-OP CONVERSIONS
description: Tothe Editor: Your editorial assertion (June 10) that the State Assembly's true purpose in amending the co-op law is to discourage owners from trying to convert is inaccurate and misinformed.

title: SURVIVORS OF HITLER'S CAMPS TELL OF THEIR RESISTANCE
description: Edith Singer simply decided that she was not going to die. Joseph Sandala stole potatoes to stay alive. Irene Eber dug under the fence of a labor camp and fled. Samuel Zabner hid and let a death march go on without him. David Tenenbaum sucked the ink out of his concentration-camp tattoo.

title: Mt. St. Helens Quakes Decline
description: Mount St. Helens shuddered with low-level seismic activity today, but scientists monitoring the volcano's latest eruptive phase said the number of earthquakes had declined. Lava began oozing out in a ''nonexplosive'' eruption Friday, accompanied by a number of shallow quakes.

title: Habib Meets With Saudi Prince
description: Prince Saud al-Faisal, the Foreign Minister of Saudi Arabia, met with Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, in Jidda today to discuss the Lebanese situation, the official Saudi press agency reported. The Prince was the first official Mr. Habib had met since his arrival here from Israel three days ago.

title: Baseball Notebook; The Waiting Game Is the Strike Puzzle
description: At the Doral Inn last Friday, after 10 minutes of face-to-face conversation, Kenneth E. Moffett, the Federal mediator, recessed the talks indefinitely. ''What I see is a waiting game,'' he said. ''A long waiting game.''

title: LUCKY BOUNCE HELPS HATALSKY MAKE PAR
description: Morris Hatalsky hit his approach shot at the 11th hole on the Merion course into Cobbs Creek today and ended up hardly believing his good fortune. The ball bounced off a rock in the creek, and came flying out and onto the green 10 yards in front of the little stream. Hatalsky threw his wedge high into the air in disbelief and then went on to get a par 4 on the hole.

title: SUSPECT IS ARRESTED AND CHARGED WITH THE LATEST ATLANTA SLAYING conference (page A14)
description: Wayne B. Williams, a 23-year-old music promoter and talent scout, was arrested today and charged in the most recent of 28 murders of black children and young adults. He was held without bond in the Fulton County Jail.

title: Bridge Reconstruction Pact Let
description: A $1,035,000 contract has been awarded by the city's Department of Transportaton for the reconstruction of the Bedford Avenue Bridge over the Long Island Rail Road tracks in Brooklyn. The bridge in the Flatbush section is being rebuilt with an 18-foot clearance to accommodate ''piggyback'' flatbed cars that carry freight containers. The department says the bridge reconstruction is a follow-up to the $6.7 million street and railbed reconstruction project at Brooklyn's Bush Terminal.

title: OUTDOORS: SKIN DIVING AS A ROUTE TO DISCOVERY
description: THERE was a time when my idea of the ultimate in swimming pleasure was to cavort in the surf with friends at the end of a long day of pitching hay or to visit Jerry's Pond after dark with a bar of soap, a towel and a bottle of wine, but that ended when skin-diving equipment became generally available after World War II.

title: Lisa Yudenfriend Bride Of Douglas David Aronin
description: Lisa Yudenfriend, a recent graduate of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work of Yeshiva University, was married yesterday to Douglas David Aronin, a third-year student at the Columbia University Law School. Rabbis David Shudrick and Michael Monson performed the ceremony at the Marriott Motor Inn in Philadelphia.

title: 4 CLIMBERS DIE IN FALL ON MT. HOOD
description: Four members of a climbing party died today in a fall while scaling Mount Hood, the Hood River County Sheriff's office reported.

title: ADAPTING SHAKESPEARE AND TURGENEV
description: The Royal Ballet's Friday night program at the Metropolitan Opera House featured cast changes in two dramatic works. And it also exemplified two different choreographic solutions to the problem of adapting plays into ballets.

title: Delinquent Mortgages Up
description: Mortgage loan delinquencies at the nation's savings and loan associations rose slightly last month but remained below 1 percent, according to the United States League of Savings Associations.

title: PROGRESS OF TAX BILL DISPUTED
description: Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, asserted today that House Democrats ''may not want a tax cut in 1981.''

title: 2-HOUR 'NICKLEBY' DUE AT WINTER GARDEN IN FALL
description: In what promises to be one of the theatrical events of the fall season, the Royal Shakespeare Company's hit production ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby'' will be imported from London and open on Broadway at the Winter Garden Theater in mid-September. The production, which will be here for a limited run, will be performed in two parts, totaling eight and a half hours, by the original cast of 43 actors, playing 150 characters.

title: NEW YORK AIRPORTS NEARLY NORMAL DESPITE THREAT OF STRIKE
description: The three major airports in the New York area reported the number of travelers a bit above normal yesterday as negotiators in Washington pressed to head off a strike by air traffic controllers that could cripple airport operations this morning. The airports were slightly busier than usual, officials said, largely because of its being both Father's Day and the first day of summer.

title: Thefts of U.S. Weapons Said to Benefit Terrorists
description: The United States is the world's largest supplier of arms to terrorists through thefts from its armories, according to a report published here today.

title: Vermont Lodge to Be Rebuilt
description: The Trapp Family Lodge, a landmark Vermont inn destroyed by fire last winter, will be replaced with a lodge twice the size of the original building. Johannes von Trapp, business manager for the Trapp family, which fled Nazi-occupied Austria 40 years ago, said today that construction would begin in August.

title: MUSIC: CLEO LAINE AND JAMES GALWAY? YES
description: TWO musicians who have not followed the customary career paths - Cleo Laine, the jazz singer who has stretched toward classical singing and has also become an actress, and James Galway, the classical flutist who is becoming a popular entertainer - joined forces in three concerts at Avery Fisher Hall over the weekend that evolved into the kind of friendly challenges that might occur at a house party.

title: SIMONSON OF DAWSON WINS COLLEGE RODEO
description: Chuck Simonson of Montana's Dawson Community College won the College National Finals Rodeo all-round title today to lead his school to the 1981 National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association championship.

title: News Analysis
description: Barely seventeen months ago, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, was elected Iran's first President with a stunning 75 per cent landslide. Today, he is in hiding, his enemies in the Parliament having voted him incompetent, his remaining supporters fighting last-ditch street battles, mobs crying for his death and a warrant out for his arrest.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * AVCO announced a $150 million credit agreement with Bankers Trust Company and 15 other banks.

title: Waterskier Drowns in L.I. Bay
description: A 23-year-old waterskier drowned after falling off his skis in Quantuck Bay today, the police said. He was Lawrence Swanson, of Quiogue, L.I.

title: EXPERTS DIVIDED ON RATE TREND
description: Although long-term interest rates have dropped significantly from their peaks of early May, opinion in the credit markets remains sharply divided about whether the declining trend will continue.

title: Joan Rachel Malman Wed To Steven Arthur Carples
description: Joan Rachel Malman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Malman of Great Neck, L.I., was married at Temple Israel there yesterday to Steven Arthur Carples, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carples of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: Around The World; London Police Charge 2 And Hold 28 Over Rioting

title: DIVERSIFICATION OF STATUS JEANS
description: Since their appearance a few years ago, the status jeans companies have vied with each other in touting their blue-denim, straight-leg, stitched-pocket jeans as the only pants to wear.

title: The Region; Beer Truck Drivers Agree to Contract
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Truck drivers represented by Teamsters Local 1035 agreed to a new three-year contract yesterday, ending a 12-day strike that had threatened to dry up beer supplies at supermarkets and liquor stores.

title: CHILDREN EXPLORE EMOTIONS
description: T HE subject was anger and Carrie Cantor, age 10, said that what made her most mad was ''one time when I was going to a party and my mother bought the present for my friend and it was something I really wanted for myself.''

title: OFF TO A BUMPY START
description: As young racers burst from the starting line in Central Park, one of them lost her footing, her composure and her place.

title: British Orders Rise Slightly
description: The latest survey of British industry suggests that orders have improved slightly since last autumn, the Confederation of British Industry said.

title: WINNER REMEMBERS LONELY TOUR YEARS
description: Anthony David Graham, copying the victory style of the late Champagne Tony Lema, bought 25 cases of champagne today for about 900 reporters covering the United States Open golf championship. It was the second time in 13 months that the Australian had celebrated that way. He bought for everyone after winning the Memorial tournament in May 1980.

title: NEW WAYS TO CURB ILLEGAL ALIENS ARE ADVANCED BY 2 CONGRESSMEN
description: Senior Congressional leaders on immigration policy said here this weekend that a consensus was emerging in both houses on the legislation needed to restrict the flow of illegal immigrants into the United States.

title: MORE COMPANIES ISSUING STOCK
description: It has been a long time - 45 years to be exact - since the United Technologies Corporation issued common stock. To be sure, the number of its common shares has increased over the years, thanks to stock splits and debt conversions. But not since the midst of the Depression has United Technologies decided to create new pieces of the corporation and sell them to the public.

title: Around the World; African Aides Fail to Agree On Human Rights Charter
description: Foreign Ministers from the 50 member countries of the Organization of African Unity were unable to agree tonight on a proposed human rights charter.

title: The Myth Of Louis-Conn
description: ONE of the indestructible myths of sports tells us that Billy Conn would have won the heavyweight championship of the world in his first bout with Joe Louis if he had not recklessly abandoned his hit-andrun tactics, tried to slug it out with Joe, and been knocked kicking. Like the ones about Abner Doubleday inventing baseball and Babe Ruth calling his home run in the 1932 World Series, this is a dandy myth, lacking nothing but truth.

title: FED OFFICIALS BOOED IN CHICAGO ON RATES
description: Officials of the Federal Reserve Board got a hostile reception yesterday when they made an extraordinary appearance here before 100 local citizens. The five bankers, three from the local office and two from Washington, were booed repeatedly and criticized about the high level of interest rates.

title: GRAY PANTHER FOUNDER AND A FAMILY OF CHOICE Robert Jaffe and Harold Bair
description: It was almost dusk, and the members of Maggie Kuhn's ''family of choice'' began gathering for a potluck dinner on the back porch.

title: SUSPECT IN ATLANTA: YOUNG, BIG IDEAS, BUT A CAREER OF LIMITED ACHIEVEMENTS
description: Hearing Wayne B. Williams talk about the big plans that are on the verge of taking shape and reading his impressive resume, one can be persuaded that this 23-year-old black man was born with the key to upward mobility in his hand. The record of his recent life as it emerges in interviews with people who know him seems to offer little solid accomplishment, however, and more and more questions about his activities have arisen since he was first questioned about the series of abductions and murders of young black people here.

title: 'NO-BAY'PLEDGES BY TENANTS
description: ARE BINDING,JUDGE DECIDES By MICHAEL GOODWIN

title: A SMALL-TOWN SAVINGS ASSOCIATION USES LOCAL APPROACH TO NATIONAL PROBLEMS
description: ''I'm not saying we will never merge,'' said Charles C. Weyant, president of the Highland Falls Federal Savings and Loan Association, ''but there's going to be an awful lot of my blood around this office before that happens.''

title: Two Nations Join Fair
description: Promoters of the 1982 World's Fair said Canada and South Korea promised to participate in the exposition. Nine other nations and the European Economic Community also plan to have exhibits. The fair, to be held near Knoxville, is to open next May and run through October.

title: Salvador Gets U.S. Loan
description: The United States is lending El Salvador $12.7 million to import wheat and cooking oil, the American Embassy announced yesterday. The announcement said Ambassador Deane R. Hinton and Foreign Minister Fidel Chavez Mena had signed an agreement for a 25-year loan on Friday, bringing the amount allocated for special food aid this year to $26.2 million. This sum is not included in the $125 million in economic aid and $35 million in military aid Washington is providing El Salvador in the 1981 fiscal year. Mr. Hinton said in an interview Friday that El Salvador's economy was ''tending to worsen.''

title: Business People; SHIFT AT DATA RESOURCES
description: Joseph E. Kasputys, 45, has been named president and chief executive officer of Data Resources Inc., the economic forecasting company that handles an estimated 50 percent of all such activities in the country. He succeeds Otto Eckstein, 54, the economist who headed the Lexington, Mass., corporation since its inception, sold it to McGraw-Hill Inc. about two years ago for about $103 million and who will become chairman.

title: Shelley Ann Pevner Married In Norwich to Stuart Zakim
description: At Temple Beth Jacob in Norwich, Conn., yesterday, Shelley Ann Pevner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pevner of Putnam and New London, Conn., became the bride of Stuart Ira Zakim, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Zakim of Wayne, N.J. Rabbi Aaron Pearlstein officiated.

title: ROYAL BALLET: SIBLEY-DOWELL DUO GRACES 'HAMLET'
description: It was a Royal Ballet in full stride that finally emerged in Saturday's two performances at the Metropolitan Opera House. Major debuts, including those by Anthony Dowell and Stephen Jefferies, showed off the great company the Royal still is - even some of the repeat casts in the season's initial mixed bill displayed the kind of dancing absent in last week's first round.

title: TITANIC PUBLICITY EFFORT FOR 'CLASH OF THE TITANS' TITANS''
description: To the surprise of nearly everyone except Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, ''Clash of the Titans'' sold more than $9 million worth of tickets during its opening week.

title: MALPRACTICE INSURANCE RATE FIGHT NEARING A CLIMAX
description: Within the next few days, the New York State Superintendent of Insurance, Albert B. Lewis, is expected to decide whether to grant a 71 percent increase to the insurance company that underwrites most of the malpractice coverage for New York physicians and a 369 percent increase to the company that provides the rest of the coverage.

title: Elizabeth field Is Bride of Bruce Shenker
description: Elizabeth Jane Field, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold C. Field of Harrison, N.Y., and Truro, Mass., was married at the home of her parents yesterday to Bruce Alan Shenker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Shenker of Pomona, N.Y. Rabbi Hillel Friedman performed the ceremony.

title: Blyth Is Victorious In Trans-Atlantic
description: Chay Blyth of Britain and his Brittany Ferries GB coasted through the fog to an easy victory today in the first Observer double-handed trans-Atlantic race.

title: A Breuer Retrospective Of Designs to Open July 25
description: ''Marcel Breuer: Furniture and Interiors,'' a retrospective showing the range, scope and impact of that architect's interior designs and furniture, will open July 25 at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Toward Sensible College Loans
description: Cutting back the college student loan program is a chore not relished by any Congressman who can count constituents. Two committees marched bravely up the hill in recent weeks, but now the House is running for cover. Hope for a sensible retrenchment therefore rests with the work of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee.

THE beleaguered thrift industry has a lot riding on a meeting this Thursday between bank regulators and Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan. It's still an open question what will be decided, with chances only 50-50 that the savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks will be allowed to pay a quarter of a percentage point more interest than commercial banks do on six-month money market certificates.

title: CITY UNIVERSITY TAKING NEW LOOK AT STUDENT ACTIVITY FEES POLICY
description: Amid controversy over the use and control of student activity fees, the board of trustees of the City University of New York is reconsidering its policy.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A young Bronx man was found shot to death on King and Varick Streets in Manhattan. The police identified him as Gerard Arachell, 23 years old, and said that he had been shot in the chest by one of three men with whom he apparently had been arguing. There were no immediate arrests. . . . Another man, Arguinides Hidalgo, 37, of 504 West 162d Street, was found shot to death on Audubon Avenue in Manhattan.

title: ISRAELIS REJECT U.N.'S ON RAID, CHIDE U.S. 'UNJUST RESOLUTION'
description: Israel today rejected the Security Council's condemnation of the bombing attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor two weeks ago, and chided the United States for approving ''this unjust resolution.''

title: FRENCH VOTE GIVES SOCIALISTS CONTROL OF THE PARLIAMENT
description: In a sweeping victory, somewhat exceeding predictions, the Socialist Party was given a majority in the National Assembly by French voters today, thus assuring President Francois Mitterrand of full government power.

title: MUSICAL REVUE: 'CLOSE ENOUGH FOR JAZZ'
description: It is a bit ominous when the revue called ''Close Enough for Jazz'' at the Wonderhorse Theater, whose author and lyricist, Joseph Keenan, is a 22-year-old former Columia University student, opens with a skit about a group of college students struggling with ''The Mill on the Floss.'' Are we in for an evening of sophomoria revisted?

title: The Rent Control Fairyland
description: Some New York legislators apparently believe there's a fairy godmother protecting the city's housing stock. An Assembly housing committee proposes to renew the expiring Emergency Tenant Protection Act, barring rent increases when an apartment becomes vacant, prohibiting them to cover unforeseen cost increases in major items like fuel and labor and turning rent administration over to the state. There may be legislators who do not believe in fairy godmothers; they should redraft the bill.

title: U.S. POLITICS LURE BRITON
description: A most unusual Minister of Agriculture is scheduled to begin a three-day visit to the United States today. Peter Walker of Britain may have the responsibility these days of worrying about fisheries and food, but his other interests lie elsewhere.

title: Two Postal Unions Plan to Picket On Thursday to Back Negotiators
description: Two major postal unions announced plans today to picket post offices on an information basis throughout the nation while negotiations resume on a new contract.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 22, 1981; The Economy
description: U.S. oil imports have fallen sharply, contributing to the current oversupply of crude on world markets. This has helped the nation's balance of payments, but refiners are having trouble coping with the oversupply and many are expecting a major confrontation with oilproducing countries over prices, which remain high. (Page D1.)

title: Manufacturer Says Navy Will Get Its First Trident Sub in October
description: The builders of the nation's first Trident nuclear submarine, buoyed by its successful debut at sea, plan to deliver the $1.2 billion undersea warship to the Navy in October.

title: Katherine Maurer, Teacher, Bride of Mitchell Brian Fox
description: At Temple Sinai in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday, Katherine Angela Maurer, daughter of Dr. Anne Estrin Maurer of East Hills, L.I., and the late Dr. Murray Lawrence Maurer, was married to Mitchell Brian Fox, son of Millicent Fox of Great Neck, L.I., and Myron C. Fox of Fort Salonga, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan officiated.

title: Victoria Lincoln, Wrote Novels and Biographies
description: Victoria Lincoln, author of a dozen books of fiction and biography, died June 13 at her home in Baltimore. She was 76 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Security Bank elected Anthony J. D'Ermes executive vice president.

title: PUBLIC CAMPAIGN-FINANCING PLAN IS AGREED ON BY CAREY AND FINK
description: Governor Carey and Stanley Fink, Democrat of Brooklyn, the Assembly Speaker, have reached agreement on a public campaign-financing plan, according to a statement issued by the Governor's press office today.

title: Yolette Leconte Magloire, 62, Wife of Ex-President of Haiti
description: Yolette Leconte Magloire, the wife of Paul E. Magloire, the former President of Haiti, died in Mount Sinai Hospital on June 13 after a long illness.

title: 2d Grand Prix for Villeneuve
description: Gilles Villeneuve of Canada drove his Ferrari to his second straight Formula One victory today, holding onto an early lead and defeating Jacques Laffite by less than half a second in the Spanish Grand Prix.

title: Riggins's Arbitration Case Is Recessed Indefinitely
description: The arbitration hearing on John Riggins's grievances against the Washington Redskins recessed yesterday with lawyers for both sides unsure when it would resume.

title: The City; Off-Duty Officer Shot in Robbery
description: An off-duty police officer was wounded in attack by two men who had followed him into his apartment building in Washington Heights. Two neighborhood youths were arrested hours later on charges of attempted murder and robbery.

title: Polio Virus Deciphered
description: Polio has maimed and killed millions from at least the time of ancient Egypt to the present. Polio was shown to be caused by a virus in 1908, although the virus could not actually be seen until the invention of the electron microscope more than 20 years later. Conquest of the disease in the United States and other developed countries came in the 1950's with the advent of vaccines.
