description: * New on list Source: First Boston Corp.

title: EDUCATION
description: DONALD NEVINS, who majored in history at the College of Staten Island, has left behind Caesar and Charlemagne and gone on to work as a broker on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, where an understanding of the causes of the Peloponnesian War probably never earned anyone an extra buck.

title: Signing of Czech Players Brings Tampering Charge
description: The Winnipeg Jets and Colorado Rockies filed charges of tampering against the Vancouver Canucks today in connection with the signing of two Czechoslovak players.

title: Keeping Books
description: As people who write books are fond of telling their friends, it's no way to make a living. And according to a study released by Columbia's Center for the Social Sciences, they're right: the average book author's income from writing is $4,775 a year.

title: S.E.C. CENSURES ANDERSON ON 2 AUDITS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had censured one of the nation's largest accounting firms, Arthur Andersen & Company, in an administrative proceeding for numerous alleged deficiencies in the firm's audits of two public corporations, Mattel Inc. and Geon Industries.

title: MGM Grand's Net Falls
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc., owner of a Las Vegas hotel that was seriously damaged by a huge fire last November, said today that net income for the third quarter ended May 31 fell 2.6 percent from the same quarter a year ago, to $7.5 million, or 23 cents a share, on revenues of $49.6 million, including $24.8 million in business interruption insurance. The company had earnings in the comparable 1980 quarter of $7.7 million, or 24 cents a share, on revenues of $76.8 million. The company said the ultimate financial impact of the hotel fire had not yet been determined.

title: Around the World; Bangladesh's Acting Chief Enters Presidential Contest
description: The ruling Bangladesh Nationalist Party has unanimously nominated acting President Abdus Sattar as its candidate in the Sept. 21 presidential election, Prime Minister Shah Azizur Rahman announced today.

title: Corn, Soybean Supply Is Down
description: The nation's supply of corn and soybeans is down sharply from the record levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: RULING BANNING L.I.R.R.  STRIKES TO BE REVIEWED
description: The United States Supreme Court agreed yesterday to review a lowercourt ruling that employees of the state-owned Long Island Rail Road were subject to New York State's Taylor Law, which bans strikes by public employees.

title: Arco Joint Venture
description: Gordon S. Knox, chairman of Mid-America Petroleum Inc., said that his company had agreed with the Arco Oil and Gas Company, a division of the Atlantic Richfield Company, to form a joint venture company, Mid-America-Arco, to drill for oil and gas in an area of Mississippi.

title: Fromm, a Long Islander, Casual Over His Victory
description: Eric Fromm walked into his first Wimbledon news conference, saw a crowd of reporters, smiled sheepishly and said, ''I thought there'd be like two people here.''

title: HEARING SET TODAY ON ATLANTA SUSPECT
description: A preliminary hearing is scheduled tomorrow to decide whether evidence against the young black man arrested yesterday in the murder of Nathaniel Cater, whose nude body was pulled from the Chattahoochee River on May 24, is sufficient to warrant the case's being submitted to a grand jury.

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
The City; Queens Parents Plan To Withdraw Pupils
description: Many parents of white children who were transferred to a Queens school with a predominantly black enrollment are planning to take their children out of the city school system, a local school board leader said yesterday.

title: ROSTOW PREDICTS A DELAY IN TALKS ON ARMS LIMITS
description: Eugene V. Rostow, President Reagan's nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that the Reagan Administration would probably not be able to begin formal negotiations with the Soviet Union to limit strategic weapons until March 1982.

title: Summer Solstice Festival Offers the Music of India
description: The music of north and south India were united at Town Hall Sunday evening for a five-hour, three-part Summer Solstice Festival. This listener was able to look only in passing at this Indian music extravaganza; but judging from the first segment - the singing duo of Parween Sultana and Mohammad Dilshad Khan - summer was welcomed in sultry and evocative style.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: American Business Press President Plans to Retire
description: Charles S. Mill, president of the American Business Press for 11 years and part of the business press scene for 36 years, says he plans to retire Sept. 1.

title: 9,700 GRANTED U.S. CITIZENSHIP IN LOS ANGELES naturalization ceremony in nation
description: Almost 10,000 immigrants, more than half of them from Asia and the Pacific, became American citizens today in the largest naturalization ceremony in the nation's history.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Britain Moves to Bar Prisoners From Parliament

title: UMPIRES, TOO, ARE FRETTING TO GET BACK
description: When he is not umpiring baseball games, which is now, Dick Stello runs a flea market in Florida. Billy Williams tends to his chickenand-seafood carry-out restaurant near West Palm Beach. Satch Davidson serves as deputy sheriff of Madison County, Ohio. John Kibler sells real estate in California. Jerry Crawford drives an oil truck in Pennsylvania. And Fred Brocklander officiates basketball and soccer games, and once even worked the World Cup.

title: Four Children Rescued By Lifeguard at Beach
description: A 20-year-old lifeguard saved four children from drowning on a Father's Day outing at a county park yesterday, witnesses said.

title: JUSTICES DECIDE STATES CAN LIMIT RELIGIOUS SOLICITING
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a state may limit the opportunity for the Hare Krishna sect to sell merchandise and solicit money at a state fair, despite the assertion of the sect's members that fund-raising is a mandatory religious ritual.

title: NCNBProposes Merger
description: The NCNB Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., a bank holding company whose principal subsidiary is the North Carolina National Bank, said that it had proposed a merger with Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., Florida's fourth-largest bank holding company, in a stock transaction worth $210 million.

title: Combat Crime With Industrial Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: DICK PLASMAN
description: Dick Plasman, a former receiver and linebacker for the Chicago Bears, died Saturday at the age of 67. Mr. Plasman, after starring in football and basketball at Vanderbilt University, played for the Bears from 1937 through 1942. Later, he coached the Chicago Cardinals for two seasons, and served as an assistant coach for the Green Bay Packers and Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: RIGHTS AWARDS MARK 10TH YEAR OF THE ROTHKO CHAPEL IN HOUSTON
description: The Rothko Chapel, opened here in 1971 as an ecumenical center for religious, intercultural and human rights activities, observed its 10th anniversary this weekend with the presentation of gifts of $10,000 each to 12 recipients, including two Soviet prisoners.

title: CITY TO DELAY AIRPORT PACT OVER $5 MILLION PAYMENT
description: The Koch administration will delay approving changes in the lease agreement between the city and the Port Authority on Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports until the authority ''satisfactorily resolves'' a $5 million overcharge to the city, an aide to the Mayor said yesterday.

title: Seize the Time for Times Square
description: After trying for more than a decade to refurbish Times Square in various ways, New York may finally be on the verge of success. The viability of a 42d Street plan by the city and Urban Development Corporation now depends on the requested proposals of developers. If demand for commercial space remains strong and if signs of regeneration around Times Square continue, the rebuilding of the midtown West Side looks like an inviting target for investors.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 28
description: B-Including $1.4 million extraordinary gain from the repurchase of the company's $4 million convertible debenture from Madison Fund Inc for $2.6 million and a $1.1 million extraordinary gain from the consolidation of two company pension plans

title: STUDENT ACTIVITY FEES AT CITY U. ARE SUBJECT TO NEW TRUSTEE CURBS
description: A new policy giving the administration greater control over the use of student activity fees was passed last night by the trustees of City University.

title: Bridge: A Refusal to Cash Winners Requires Difficult Decision
description: One of the most difficult decisions in defensive play concerns the refusal to cash winning tricks to avert an eventual squeeze. An example is the diagramed deal from a Swiss team match played in Lancaster, Pa. The South hand was well below the normal standard for a two no-trumpo pening, but as Hamlet said, the paly's the thing. After West's s pade lead, East might have reasoned that South was virtually sure toh ave a doubleton king or a doubleton queen, in which case the play oft he ace could wait: West would not have a suit headed by K-Q, for t hat would leave South with only 18 high-card points.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that it had purchased a total of 1,393,756 shares of Bunker Ramo Corp. common stock under its $55-a-share cash tender offer that expired June 11.

title: News Analysis
description: Despite the unexpected agreement by President Reagan and Mexico's President Jose Lopez Portillo in their talks earlier this month to work out a joint economic aid package for the Caribbean basin, the initiative faces formidable political difficulties.

title: Rosario, 18, Seems Headed for a Title
description: ''Just a minute, dear,'' said Jimmy Jacobs, never expecting that the minute would wind up costing $80,000. The fight film collector and boxing manager had been watching television that hot August night last year and the main event ended quickly, thanks to another Wilfredo Gomez knockout. But Jacobs's attention was still on the television set and not on his wife. ABC was going to show a tape of a preliminary contest and Jacobs couldn't turn away.

title: Winfields Denied Access To the N.Y.R.A.'s Tracks
description: The New York Racing Association yesterday barred Malcolm and Nigel Winfield from access to Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga and ordered their horses off the grounds no later than next Monday.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PACESETTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Jan 3
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,375,525 for the latest yr and $246,100 for the previous yr

title: EXPERT SAYS BASING MISSILE ON SUBS COULD BE AS EFFECTIVE AS ON LAND
description: A Congressional specialist in technology testified today that basing the controversial MX nuclear missile ''on relatively small submarines could provide military effectiveness comparable to land basing.''

title: General Tire Net Climbs in Quarter
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 ended May 31 more than tripled to $22.7 million, or 93 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 28 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: CAMPUS COUPLES AND VIOLENCE
description: He would find excuses to come home later every night and leave at dawn to work out at the gym. It was, Steve thought, the gentlemanly way to cool his relationship with his 22-year-old live-in college girlfriend.

title: Alouettes Get Overstreet, Dolphins' No. 1 Selection
description: After several unsuccessful attempts to land a good running back, the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League signed the former University of Oklahoma standout David Overstreet to a two-year guaranteed contract today.

title: 8 PLAYWRIGHTS GET FELLOWSHIPS
description: Eight playwrights will receive grants under the 11th Rockefeller Foundation fellowship program designed to develop plays by writers who have had at least one major production. The playwrights will each receive $9,000 for a residency of six weeks at a theater of their choice. The theaters will get $4,000.

title: THE HUTTON MOVE INTO LENDING
description: The people who listen to E.F. Hutton talk may soon be hearing some new sounds, as the Wall Street firm jumps from the brokerage business into lending.

title: CHAPMAN, IN A CLOSED COURTROOM, PLEADS GUILTY TO KILLING OF LENNON
description: Mark David Chapman pleaded guilty yesterday to killing John Lennon last December outside the apartment building in which the 40-year-old former Beatle lived.

title: A Libyan Is Charged in England With Trying to Kill an Expatriate
description: A Libyan airline worker left a package of poisoned peanuts at the home of a Libyan expatriate, prosecutors told a court today.

title: John Palm, Imprisoned 44 Years in Connecticut
description: John Palm, who spent more time in Connecticut prisons than anyone else in the state's history, died today in a maximum security facility here. For 44 years, he had maintained that he had been unjustly convicted of murder.

title: Advisers Said to Narrow Choice for Seat on Court
description: President Reagan's advisers have narrowed their choices for possible nominees to the Supreme Court to fill a vacancy being left by Associate Justice Potter Stewart, White House officials said today. But the officials said that Mr. Reagan was not likely to make up his mind for another week or so.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Mankind has been looking at outer space, and taking pictures of it, since long before it actually got there. The fruits of photographic exploration of space are adorning the walls of New York University's Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 33 Washington Place, near Washington Square, starting today and running through July 31. In this roomy space, more than 180 pictures illumine for us what the exhibitors call ''this last frontier.'' Most of the pictures were not taken for esthetic pleasure but for scientific purposes, and most have never before been presented to the public.

title: European Unemployment
description: The number of jobless in the European Economic Community stood at 8.3 million in May, 35 percent higher than a year ago, the Common Market's statistics office said today. The figure is little changed from April, but seasonally adjusted unemployment increased by 2.5 percent in May over April, the office said. The number of jobless represented 7.3 percent of the work force in the Common Market's 10 member countries, against 5.4 percent in May 1980, in the nine-member Community before Greece joined.

title: CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Fiscal 1981 results include a net gain from the sale of river barges; fiscal 1980 results reflect an estimated loss resulting from the discontinuance of the Soy Isolate product line; sales figures reflect a change from the gross revs to the gross margi method of reporting grain sales

title: SADAT BLAMES OPPONENTS FOR RIOTS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat today blamed the opposition Socialist Labor Party and the Communists for last week's sectarian clashes in a Cairo slum.

title: NEW ZEALAND QUESTIONS THE U.S. GOAL OF ISOLATING AND PUNISHING VIETNAM the Foreign Minister of New Zealand
description: One of America's closest allies in the Pacific questioned at a two-day conference that ended today whether the Reagan Administration's policy of seeking to isolate and punish Vietnam for its ties to the Soviet Union might be too harsh and result in pushing Hanoi even closer to Moscow.

title: Larry St. Peter with his family after return from Mount Rainier
description: Taking advantage of a brief break in a pall of obstinate weather, a team of searchers made their way tonight to the glacial mass on Mount Rainier that buried 11 climbers in an icy crevasse yesterday. They found no sign of life.

title: WILLIAM L. EDWARDS Jr.
description: William L. Edwards Jr., chairman and chief executive officer of Interco, the diversified apparel, footwear and home furnishings company, died Sunday evening in a hospital in St. Louis after a brief illness.

title: Polish Debt Repayment
description: Poland's Bank Handlowy has repaid the principal on a $30 million floating-rate note issue due today through the Banque Nationale de Paris, banking sources said here today.

title: Accounts
description: * The American University, Washington, to Trout & Ries Advertising for a special positioning project. People

title: PROSECUTOR S HIRE 3 PSYCHIATRISTS TO STUDY HINCKLEY
description: Federal prosecutors have retained three eminent psychiatrists to evaluate the mental state of John W. Hinckley Jr., the man accused of shooting President Reagan on March 30.

title: LOSSES BLUNT HOPE OF BIG PAYOFF FOR ATLANTIC CITY CASINO OWNERS
description: The plight of the casino gambling industry here is on display almost every night. Midnight should be a time of bustling activity at casinos like the Sands. But even some of the popular blackjack tables are vacant, except for dealers idly fingering cards, and several of the dice tables are roped off, unattended.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Short-Term Interest Rates Drop By MICHAEL QUINT

title: ADOLFO'S FAN CLUB GATHERS
description: ''There are 15 of these dresses here - we've counted,'' said Susan Fine. ''Not just in black - they're in red and green too.'' Mrs. Fine, who was wearing the four-leaf-clover-printed silk dress in black and white, added that ''Mrs. Reagan has it in red.'' Her companion, Isabelle Leeds, who helped with the counting, seemed disappointed she didn't spot anyone else wearing her pleated dress with white cotton knitted top.''It's the only thing I own with short sleeves,'' she explained.

title: Around The Nation; Alleged Backer of 'Invasion' Of Dominica Kills Himself
description: A 61-year-old lawyer, identified in a Federal trial as a financier for a plot to overthrow the Government of the Caribbean island of Dominica, has been found shot to death, sheriff's deputies here said.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES $5.6 BILLION PLAN FOR M.T.A. AID
description: The Assembly tonight approved a measure creating $5.6 billion in bonding authority to improve the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's facilities over the next five years. The vote was 95 to 49.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid in Nov

title: Rome Police Capture Gunman
description: The police captured a man who fired at them with a shotgun in front of the international terminal at Rome's airport today, the police reported.

title: SALVAGER SEEKS DOLPHINS' AID IN SEARCH FOR TREASURE>KEY WEST, Fla., June
description: 22 (AP) -Dolphins are in training here for a new mission for man: helping to locate sunken treasure.

title: CHANGES AT THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE, BALL TEAM AND ALL, MAKING THE STAFF ANXIOUS
description: For decades, the conservative Chicago Tribune boasted on its front page that it was ''The World's Greatest Newspaper,'' proclaiming a vision of itself that even some of its friends found inaccurate.

title: RENT STABILIZATION ATTACKED BY 2 SIDES AS STATE LEGISLATION NEARS proposed rent increases
description: EXPIRATION By LEE A. DANIELS

title: The Economy
description: A nationwide strike of air traffic controllers was averted when the Government and the union agreed on a tentative contract less than three hours before the walkout was set to begin. (Page A1.) Airlines lost passenger traffic as a result of the strike threat. Many reservations were canceled. (A19.)

title: Market Place; Borrowing For Dividends
description: THE method of treating patients through bleeding is regarded as quackery today. But corporations continue to bleed themselves - borrowing money to pay dividends - and the practice could be as unhealthy for corporations as it is for individuals, one management consultant argues. And the bleeding metaphor is apt, according to the consultant, Donald W. Mitchell, ''especially today when the cost of borrowed money is high.''

title: Around the World; Spanish Parliament Votes To Legalize Divorce
description: After several years of heated public debate and opposition from the Roman Catholic Church hierarchy, the Spanish Parliament approved a bill tonight that will permit civil divorce in Spain for the first time since Gen. Francisco Franco overthrew the republic in 1939.

title: OFFICIAL DESCRIBES BURNS INSULT AT OPEN
description: Harry Easterly, senior executive director of the United States Golf Association, said yesterday that he did not intend to ''escalate'' the incident in which he was insulted by George Burns during the final round of the United States Open championship Sunday at the Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa.

title: Maritime Unit Switch Backed
description: The Reagan Administration and the shipping industry's labor and management joined today in supporting the transfer of the Maritime Administration from the Commerce Department to the Transportation Department.

title: HOW MARTHA'S VINEYARD INFLUENCED BENTON'S ART
description: THOMAS HART BENTON, the American regionalist painter who was Jackson Pollock's teacher and Harry S. Truman's favorite artist, has long been associated in the public ken with the earthy art and people of his native Missouri and Middle West. The muralist depicted farmers' scything hay, gaunt Ozark hillbillies, black sharecroppers, soldiers in honkytonks, miners hunched over from years in the pits and riverboats on the Mississippi.

title: Harvester Trucks
description: The International Harvester Company said that its combined national market share for medium truck categories rose to a record 35.7 percent in April, or 2,986 units, from 13 percent a year ago. The categories include trucks of 19,501-26,000 pounds gross vehicle weight and trucks of 26,100 pounds and over. For the six months ended in April, Harvester, which manufactures trucks under 10 nameplates, said that its combined market share for the medium truck categories rose to 31 percent from 17.9 percent in the strike-affected period a year earlier.

title: FROM FERTILITY TO MOOD, SUNLIGHT FOUND TO AFFECT HUMAN BIOLOGY
description: AS the sun shone from its northernmost point Sunday, bringing the summer solstice - and the longest day of the year - to the Northern Hemisphere, a mysterious hormone that may influence fertility, mood and many other body functions should have reached its annual low point in the blood of those who spent the day outdoors, according to a new finding that may ultimately revolutionize studies of the effects of light on people.

title: BALLET JUDGES ARE CRITICIZED
description: The chief of the United States ballet team said today that the Soviet-bloc dominated jury of the Moscow International Ballet Competition gave too much emphasis to classical techniques, to the detriment of the American entrants.

title: ISRAELI PREDICTS EARLY RESUMPTION OF AMERICAN SHIPMENTS OF F-16'S
description: An Israeli diplomat said today that the Administration's suspension of the delivery of four F-16 aircraft, pending a review of Israel's destruction of Iraq's nuclear reactor, would not remain a problem ''for a long time.''

title: ADMINISTRATION'S VIEW ON AGED AROUSES CRITICISM AT CONFERENCE
description: The Reagan Administration's ''new outlook on aging,'' calling for less Government spending and ''intrusion'' and more emphasis on self-reliance among the elderly, has stirred controversy among professionals in the field.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I was a kid, growing up in New York in the 40's, we would never go through a red light because we believed there was a cop behind every bush.

description: To the Editor:$

description: While other scientific researchers concern themselves with such mundane matters as weather patterns, population trends, occupational hazards and disease control, Rosemary Wells tackles the tough stuff.

title: FOR BRAZIL, ON EMBARRASSING TALE OF INTRIGUE
description: The Brazilian Government has been dragged into the controversy over Israel's bombing of an Iraqi nuclear reactor through a tale of intrigue involving the Israeli secret service, alleged clandestine shipments of uranium to Baghdad and an air chase over the African coast.

title: POPE SUFFERS FROM INFLAMMATION OF LUNG BUT IS REPORTED BETTER
description: The doctors attending Pope John Paul II have identified the ailment that slowed down his recovery as a pleuropulmonary inflammation of the right lung, a Vatican spokesman said today.

title: BATTING .500
description: After 20 years backstage at lesser labor dramas, Kenneth E. Moffett is in the national limelight as a man trying to save the baseball season for the fans after helping to spare the passengers of 14,200 daily airline flights and all other travelers the coast-to-coast chaos of an air controllers' strike.

title: MORE PEDESTRIANS DYING AS DRIVERS DISREGARD LIGHTS
description: Alarmed by a recent increase in the number of pedestrians killed by automobiles on New York City streets, officials are trying to devise ways to combat what they say is a major contributing factor - motorists who ignore traffic signals.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Reagan Names Gold-Role Unit
description: The Reagan Administration has named a ''gold commission'' made up of 17 men - most of them Government officials - who are to begin meeting soon ''to assess the role of gold in the domestic and international monetary systems,'' Treasury Department officials said today.

title: Peugeot Posted Loss for 1980
description: Peugeot, Europe's forth-largest automobile company, today reported a $263 million loss for last year compared with a $316 million profit in 1979.

title: IRAN AFTER BANI-SADR
description: WASHINGTON The fall of Presiden Abolhassan Bani-Sadr of Iran strengthens a regime that already has survived many premature obituaries. Contrary to expectations, this development may produce a less adventurous Government in Teheran.

title: BEGIN REPORTEDLY SAYS U.S. TOLD ISRAEL OF CONCERN ON IRAQ'S GOALS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin was reported today to have told a parliamentary committee that the United States had provided him with a document expressing American concern that Iraq was planning to use its French-built reactor to manufacture nuclear weapons.

title: HUGO LORANT
description: Hugo Lorant, retired executive vice president with the former Hydropress Inc. of New York City, designers and builders of extrusion presses and rolling mills, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a clerical error, the items in Finance Briefs in Business Day yesterday were outdated.

title: the City; Fumes Overcome 12
description: Twelve persons were overcome by toxic fumes from a 55-gallon drum containing a highly flammable acid that ruptured at a warehouse in Elmhurst, Queens, fire officials said.

title: Brooks Thomas Succeeds Knowlton as Harper Head
description: Brooks Thomas was named president and chief executive officer of Harper & Row yesterday, succeeding Winthrop Knowlton as chief executive. Mr. Thomas, who has been president and chief operating officer of the company since April 1979, joined Harper's as its general counsel in 1968 and later served as executive vice president.

title: JUNE WILL LAST A SECOND LONGER THAN COMMONLY THOUGHT
description: NEXT Tuesday those who pride themselves on accuracy should set their clocks back exactly one second, for a ''leap second'' has been declared by the International Time Bureau in Paris, officially known as the Bureau Internationale de l'Heure.

title: 'Hypocritical Action' by Procter & Gamble
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPREME COURT WIDENS POLICE POWER ON WARRANTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a warrant to search a home for contraband automatically gives the police the power to detain temporarily anyone found on the premises.

title: SAUDI OIL OUTPUT CUT IS RUMORED
description: Fresh reports that Saudi Arabian crude oil is selling in the spot market for less than the long-term contract price of $32 a barrel were cited yesterday as suggesting that the world's largest oil exporter is poised to cut back production.

title: A GALLIC SHRUG OF RESIGNATION
description: The French business community welcomed last night's sweeping Socialist victory in the parliamentary elections with an immense Gallic shrug of resignation.

title: R.S. Rozman, Expert on Malaria And a Walter Reed Institute Aide
description: Robert S. Rozman, chief of the drug metabolism section of the Walter Reed Army Institute and an authority on drugs to prevent malaria, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Kensington, a Washington suburb. He was 49 years old.

title: STUDY CITES SOARING MEDICAID COSTS AND UNEVEN ELIGIBILITY STANDARDS
description: The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that the cost of the Medicaid program, which totaled $1.5 billion in 1967, might be expected to reach $24 billion by 1986.

title: Boys Choir of Harlem Presents Bach Cantatas
description: The concert of Bach cantatas presented by the Boys Choir of Harlem at Abraham Goodman House Sunday aternoon centered on the arresting music-making by two of its performers - Warren George Wilson, who conducted the St.Luke's Chamber Ensemble, and Charlae Olaker, the soprano soloist in ''Liebster Jesu, mein Verlangen'' and ''Wachet auf, ruft uns die Stimme.''

title: ARILINES REPORT RASH OF 'NO-SHOWS'
description: Although the nation's flight controllers did not go out on strike, their walkout threat prompted thousands of airline passengers to cancel reservations for flights yesterday or to simply not show up to take their seats, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association reported.

title: Iraqi Order to Japan
description: Two Japanese companies have been awarded an order from Iraq to equip a hydro-electric power station to be installed by July 1986, one of the concerns, Mitsui & Company, said today. Four sets of 193,000-kilowatt turbines and generators will be supplied by the Toshiba Corporation through Mitsui, with related equipment such as transformers coming from European companies, Mitsui said.

title: ROCHELLE N. SHARFMAN WED TO DR. ROBERT BRUCE JETTER
description: Rochelle N. Sharfman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Solomon J. Sharfman of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Bruce Jetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Jetter of Oceanside, L.I. and New York, at the Sands on Atlantic Beach, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Benjamin Blech of Oceanside.

title: British Bid for Crocker Protested
description: Church, community and civil rights groups protested today before the Federal Reserve Board a Britishowned bank's proposed purchase of a majority interest in the Crocker National Bank, the nation's 12th largest.

title: Italian Socialists Make Gains in Local Elections
description: Italian Socialists posted significant gains in partial local, provincial and regional elections today. In the city of Bari, the Socialists nearly doubled their vote to 23 percent from 12 percent in the last local elections there in 1976.

title: LARRY J. CLAFLIN
description: Larry J. Claflin, a Boston sportswriter and columnist for 30 years and the sports director for WITS radio, suffered a heart attack yesterday morning and died at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 53 years old. Mr. Claflin, who was divorced, is survived by his mother, a sister and three children.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
HEINZ NET RISES 39.9%; BEATRICE FOODS UP 10.2%
description: The H.J. Heinz Company, producer of an extensive line of convenience foods in the United States and abroad, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of the company's 1981 fiscal year rose 39.9 percent on a sales increase of 18.2 percent.

title: Films of Satire Sought
description: Films of social and political satire are being sought by the Film Society of Lincoln Center for a special series next Sept. 18 to 24.

title: Gulf Canada Plans Beaufort Drilling
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said today that it would spend $674 million (Canadian) to build and operate a yearround drilling system for the frigid Beaufort Sea, estimated to hold reserves of some six billion barrels of oil.

title: Innocents Abroad
description: In one extraordinary half-hour last week, President Reagan pronounced the tensions in Poland to be ''the first beginning cracks, the beginning of the end'' of Communism everywhere; called his decision to sell arms to Communist China a ''normal part'' of improving relations; and then said he saw no connection between the two situations. The President thus revealed a powerful failure of imagination - and a critical flaw in his approach to the world.

title: MCENROE, BORG WIN
description: John McEnroe lost his temper and survived, but Ivan Lendl, Victor Pecci and Yannick Noah were stunned by unheralded players today in a rousing start to the 95th Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: Steel Production Drops
description: Steel production fell to 2.4 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, down from the previous week's 2.5 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Citicorp Acquisition Of Diners Club Unit
description: Citicorp, which already offers the Carte Blanche credit card, said that it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to complete its previously announced acquisition of the Continental Corporation's Diners Club credit card operations.

title: Panel Approves Saccharin Bill
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today approved legislation allowing the artificial sweetener saccharin to remain on the market for another two years while scientists study its possible cancer-causing effect. The bill is expected to be passed by the full Senate, and a similar bill is expected to clear the House.

title: COURT OVERULES N.L.R.B. ON PARTIAL WORK CLOSING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer had no legal obligation to negotiate with employees over a decision to close part of the company's operations.

description: As a historian, Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. has studied a lot of American trends over the years, but nothing, it seems, has quite prepared him for one current trend.

description: The leader of the South-West Africa People's Organization accused the Reagan Administration today of undermining efforts by the United Nations to bring about a settlement for the territory that would lead to its independence under the name of Namibia.

description: TRENTON (UPI) - About 900 workers at two state hospitals walked off the job yesterday in the first of a series of one-day strikes threatened by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees at all of New Jersey's 16 hospitals for the retarded, the mentally ill and for disabled soldiers.

description: Negotiators in baseball's 11-day-old strike were nearly brought together yesterday, but now it seems more likely that they will resume their stalled talks in the next day or two.

description: Federal Bureau of Investigation officials were sent here today to investigate the deaths of three black teen-agers, arrested on suspicion of drug possession, who drowned when a small boat capsized while deputies were ferrying them across a lake. The deputies swam to shore.

description: Vietnam veterans resting yesterday by their symbolic pup tent, which they pitched across from the White House in a campaign to win attention for their demands from President Reagan. The veterans are protesting what they say is inadequate care by the Veterans Administration.

description: Conoco's stock rose sharply yesterday as industry analysts tried to determine the mystery company with which Conoco said it is holding merger talks. Names ranged from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to the Nova Corporation, a Canadian oil and gas concern.

description: Two years ago, Warner Cosmetics, a division of Warner Communications, assigned a new line of men's fragrances to Kurtz & Tarlow. It is what is now known under the brand name Chaps.

description: A $5.7 billion state budget won approval in the State Senate today, despite Republican complaints that the Democrats had written the budget with a ''parochial'' attitude and without regard to fiscal safeguards. After being approved, 26 to 11, the budget, for the fiscal year starting July 1, was sent to the Assembly. A final vote could take place on Thursday.

description: The Bank of New York yesterday announced a cash management account plan enabling small and medium-sized businesses to invest their checking account balances in high-yielding money market funds.

title: Notes On People; Battle Erupts Over Delay in Karpov-Korchnoi Match
description: The match for the world chess championship is not set to begin in the northern Italian resort of Merano until Oct. 19, but the impending battle between the titleholder, Anatoly Karpov of the Soviet Union, and the challenger, Viktor Korchnoi, a Soviet defector, has already turned into a test of wills with international political implications.

title: z; Extending Voting Rights, or Stalling?
description: President Reagan's open call to Attorney General Smith for a study of the Voting Rights Act was strange yet understandable. Mr. Reagan need hardly remind Mr. Smith, his old friend and counselor, that the Justice Department has heavy responsibility under that law and a big stake in whether Congress renews it next year. And given the department's 16 years of experience in enforcing it, Justice doesn't need to start an investigation from scratch.

description: When Lionel H. Olmer stood up to address last week's meeting of the Japan-United States Businessmen's Conference, the Japanese executives in the audience seemed to adjust their translation headsets a little tighter, while the American businessmen leaned forward that extra inch. Mr. Olmer is the Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, and his comments were of more than passing interest to these high-level industrialists.

title: Guggenheim Band Opens Season With Premieres
description: The Guggenheim Concert Band greeted a new summer with new music Sunday evening at Damrosch Park. Rain managed first to thin the crowd and then finally to send the band home early, but most of the premieres had their airings.

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS RIGHTS OF NEW YORK TO BAN TOPLESS BARS
description: The United States Supreme Court ruled today that New York State had the constitutional right to ban topless entertainment in bars licensed by the State Liquor Authority.

description: Leaders of France's victorious Socialist Party said early this morning that they had reached an agreement with the Communists that could lead to their participation in the new French Government, expected to be announced later today.

description: The Senate tonight stripped dozens of measures assailed as extraneous from the package of $39.6 billion in budget cuts, responding to criticism that the bill had been overburdened and the traditional processes circumvented.

title: Japan Shipbuilding Plans
description: Applications by Japanese shipowners for low-interest Government loans to finance shipbuilding plans in the 1982 fiscal year, which began last April,have totaled 2.43 million gross tons so far against 1.24 million inthe 1981 fiscal year, the Transport Ministry said today. The ministry gauges loan allocations by tonnage to give a picture of the trend in domestic shipbuilding demand. The loans are granted at a rate of 7.5 percent by the semiofficial Japan Development Bank.

title: ZAMBIA EXPELS 2 U.S. DIPLOMATS
description: The Zambian Government citing alleged activities of the Central Intelligence Agency here, tonight ordered two American diplomats to leave the country within 48 hours and announced the arrest of a Zambian Foregn Ministry official.

title: POSTAL SERVICE, CITING LARGE LOSSES, MAKES A 3D BID FOR 20-CENT STAMP

title: 2 Soccer Leagues In Byrne Arena
description: Both soccer leagues will have indoor teams next winter in the Brendan Byrne Arena, the new 20,000-seat center at the Meadowlands.

title: Argentine Peso Float And Trade Rate Set
description: The Argentine Government permitted the peso to float freely today for all exchange transactions not involving payments for exports and imports, and the peso quickly dropped more than 25 percent in value against the dollar.

title: Joseph J. Morrow, Former Official At Pitney Bowes and Civic Leader
description: Joseph J. Morrow, retired vice president for administration of Pitney Bowes Inc. of Stamford, Conn., died Sunday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Atlanta. He was 78 years old and had lived in Atlanta since 1976.

title: New Viewdata Test
description: Viewdata Corporation of America, a unit of Knight-Ridder Newspapers Inc., said that it would begin testing its expanded Viewtron at-home information service in mid-1983 in cooperation with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The test will involve some 5,000 participants in an area of south Florida still to be chosen, said Viewdata's president, Albert J. Gillen. V.C.A. and A.T.&T. currently operate a smaller trial system in Coral Gables, Fla., that allows about 200 participants to receive continually updated news, weather, sports, stock market, travel and entertainment information, consumer advice, educational aids, games and quizzes and advertising on their televisions.

description: The director of the Energy Department's Solar Energy Research Institute, Dennis Hayes, said today that he had been told he would be dismissed tomorrow.

Massey-Ferguson Refinancing Delay
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. hopes to have its $712 million (Canadian) refinancing program ready for signing by the middle of July, a company official said. That will be about three weeks later than the target date set April 28.

Mr. Riedy, who was elected at a directors' meeting following the annual meeting yesterday, will succeed William L. Edwards Jr., who died Sunday night at the age of 62. Harvey Saligman, 42, who became president and chief operating officer last March, continues in those positions.

title: CRACKDOWN UNDER WAY IN SOUTH AFRICA Mol of kenya
description: In what amounts to the most severe crackdown by the security police since Prime Minister P.W. Botha took office nearly three years ago, about 30 black trade-union leaders and student activists have been arrested in the last three weeks under security laws permitting detention without trial.

title: Chemical, Citibank Raise Prime to 20%
description: The prime lending rate charged by the nation's major banks was unified yesterday at 20 percent as two large New York banks, Chemical Bank and Citibank, raised their rates.

title: Japanese Cassette Plants
description: BASF Japan Ltd. said today that its parent firm, BASF A.G. of West Germany, planned to build two plants in northern Japan to assemble magnetic tape cassettes at a monthly rate of about two million.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS 3-TAX RELIEF MOVES
description: Without a single dissenting vote, the Senate Finance Committee today approved three major provisions of a taxrelief bill, including a cut to 50 percent from 70 percent in the maximum tax rate individuals pay on investment income.

title: AUTHORS AGREEING TO SMALLER ROYALTIES
description: WHEN it appeared that Joyce Carol Oates's ''Bellefleur'' would carry a $16.95 price tag, John Macrae, publisher of Elsevier-Dutton, suggested that if Miss Oates were willing to accept a lower royalty on the first printing, the 600-page novel could be priced at $12.95, more copies could be printed and more could be spent on promotion and advertising. The author agreed, and the book, published last summer, became a best seller.

title: NIXON LOSES RULING IN WIRETAPPING CASE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that former President Richard M. Nixon and three top aides may be required to pay monetary damages for the unconstitutional wiretap of the home telephone of Morton Halperin, a former national security aide.

title: CANADA SOUTHERN PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $112,000 for the qr and $200,000 for 9 mos...C-Net income; the company is listed on the Pacific, Tor and Boston stock exchanges

title: Baghdad Official Favors Sanctions Against U.S.
description: An Iraqi leader asked the Arab world today to use the ''oil weapon'' against the United States for its support of Israel, the official Iraqi press agency reported from Baghdad.

title: MEASURE TO LIFT A CAP ON BENEFITS TO JOBLESS VETOED IN CONNECTICUT
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today vetoed a bill that would have raised the maximum unemployment benefit from $140 to $210 over five years. He also vetoed a bill to institute one-way tolls on the Connecticut Turnpike and the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways.

title: The Region; Rockland Reverses Fluoridation Order
description: The Rockland County Board of Health, reversing a 1978 order, voted not to require the mandatory fluoridation of the county's water supplies.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 23, 1981
description: International A delay in arms negotiations was indicated by Eugene V. Rostow, President Reagan's nominee to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. Mr. Rostow told a Senate hearing that the Administration would probably not be ready to begin formal talks with Moscow on limiting strategic arms until March 1982. (Page A1, Column 1.) American concern over Iraqi plans to manufacture nuclear weapons was expressed in a document given to Prime Minister Menachem Begin in January by the United States Ambassdor to Israel, according to a knowledgeable Israeli official. Mr. Begin was reported to have informed a parliamentary committee about the document, which was said to have been based on American intelligence reports. (A1:1-2.)

title: SOVIET MARKS'41 GERMAN ATTACK BY SAYING BONN SHOWS HOSTILITY
description: The Soviet Union marked today's 40th anniversary of the German invasion with ceremonies honoring its war dead and an intensification of a press campaign implying a similarity between West Germany's current policies and the anti-Communism that inspired Hitler's attack.

title: Shift at St. Jude Medical
description: Manuel A. Villafana, the 40-year-old founder, chairman and chief executive officer of St. Jude Medical Inc., a St. Paul manufacturer of prosthetic heart valves, drug delivery systems and other medical devices, will resign his posts, effective Oct. 1. The announcement came after a panel of the Food and Drug Administration accepted the corporation's data on a new heart valve, but requested additional information.

title: 'Bravo' to Continue; 2 Other Shows Close
description: ''El Bravo,'' the musical at the Entermedia Theater on Second Avenue that was to have closed Sunday after seven performances and 24 previews, will continue for an indefinite run because of enthusiastic audience response and increased box-office sales over the weekend, a spokesman said.

title: Strip-Searches Are Suspended
description: In a suit brought by Mary Morgan, the wife of Dr. Benjamin Spock, the pediatrician, city jail officials agreed today to halt for 10 days a policy of strip-searches of women being held overnight. Miss Morgan filed suit after being held in the jail after a protest at the White House.

title: CLARK OIL SHARES
description: Members of the family of Emory T. Clark, chairman of the executive committee of the Clark Oil and Refining Corporation, who together beneficially own about 6 million, or 41.8 percent, of the company's stock, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that they would "seriously consider" the sale of their shares. Clark, a Milwaukee refiner and retailer with outlets in several Middle Western states, closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 31 3/8, up 5/8, after a trading halt.

title: KENNEDY CALLS U.S. VOTE ON ISRAELI RAID 'DISASTROUS'
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy said last night that the Reagan's Administration vote in the United Nations to condemn the Israeli raid on an Iraqi nuclear reactor reflected a ''disastrous'' anti-Israel policy.

title: ' GIN GAME': HAPPY TRIP TO MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW A PLAY about an aging American couple playing gin in a shabby Dallas nursing home may seem a curious choice for a Moscow repertory theater.

title: Invisible Flying Cats TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: With regard to Malcolm Browne's article, ''The Invisible Flying Cat'' (June 9), how did you become privy to the extremely wellguarded secret that the cats do exist? Of course, both your facts and your logic are faulty - sparrows still exist because these cats, which I have studied for years, have sweat glands which exude a distinctive odor, terrifying all flying creatures. Also, although they do not eat birds, they do occasionally play with them, as can be attested to by anyone who has seen a flock of starlings suddenly and for no apparent (visible) reason simultaneously ''spook themselves'' into flight.

title: Oscar Brand in Exxon Park
description: Oscar Brand, the folk singer, will appear July 1 in Rockefeller Center's ''Music for a City Evening'' concert series. He will perform in Exxon Park, just west of the Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets, from 4:30 to 6 P.M.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. announced that its proposed exchange offering to acquire its common shares for units of debentures had been made effective by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: The Region; Conviction Upheld In Killing of Student
description: A New York State appeals court unanimously upheld the manslaughter conviction of Richard Herrin, a former Yale University student, in the 1977 hammer slaying of his college sweetheart from Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: DEBORAH NEWFIELD BRIDE OF HOWARD GOLDSCHMIDT
description: Deborah Newfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Newfield, was married yesterday in Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I. to Howard Zvi Goldschmidt, son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Goldschmidt. Both families are of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens.

title: Let the Unknowns Be Heard
description: All of the candidates running against Mayor Koch have been described as unknowns or relative unknowns or minor politicians lacking citywide identification. The knowns and the big guys are sitting this one out.

title: Kuhn's Big K Stores Plans Wal-Mart Tie
description: The financially struggling Kuhn's Big K Stores Corporation has agreed to merge with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. of Bentonville, Ark., in a stock transaction worth about $13 million.

title: VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
CORRECTION
description: As the result of an editing error, an article Thursday on fetal twins incorrectly described the means used in the final diagnosis of a defect in one of the twins. The abnormality was confirmed by blood test.

title: PREHISTORIC MAN'S KILLINGS OF 90 GIANT BABOONS SUGGESTS EARLY RITUAL
description: WAS it a strange ritual slaying by prehistoric man? Was it a mass slaughter of animals for food? Or were the killings for purposes so arcane that modern man will never fathom them?

title: Around The Nation; Government Sues to Get Asbestos Dumps Covered
description: The Justice Department filed a civil suit today to force the Johns-Manville Sales Corporation and six other defendants to cover six asbestos waste dumps in Hudson, N.H., with soil and vegetation and to block off public access to them.

title: Corning Glass Net Drops
description: Corning Glass Works said yesterday that net income for the second fiscal quarter of 1981, which ended June 14, plunged 32.8 percent, to $24 million, or $1.31 a share, from $35.7 million, or $1.94 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Sales increased 4.3 percent, to $369.5 million, from $354.1 million. Corning said that, excluding the impact of asset sales in the quarter a year ago, earnings were down by 7 percent.

title: Soviet Replaces a Chief of Staff
description: The chief of staff of Soviet forces in East Germany, Col. Gen. Dmitri Grinkevich, was replaced today by Lieut. Gen. Ivan Sviridov, the official East German press agency reported. It was the second change in the Soviet military leadership in East Germany in six months.

title: Colombia Reopens a University Shut Because of Student Unrest
description: The National University of Bogota, Colombia's largest university, was reopened today after a two-week shutdown ordered by the Government after a wave of student unrest, its rector said.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: YOUNG people in America may be the most analyzed commodity of society. And at no time are they subject to more critical review than at the end of the academic year, when a new vintage of graduates is bottled by some 3,000 colleges and labeled with its virtues and vices, primarily the latter.

title: CHARLES A. GRUMICH
description: Charles A. Grumich, a reporter and editor at The Associated Press for 43 years, died of a heart attack Sunday in his Greenwich Village home.

title: PACIFIC TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated; the company is a unit of American Telephone & Telegraph Co

title: SCA Services Names 2
description: Henry E. Russell, 64, has joined SCA Services Inc., the nation's third-largest waste disposal concern, as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Thomas C. Viola, 53, who left the company, which is based in Boston. In addition, James J. Needham, former chairman and chief executive officer of the New York Stock Exchange and an SCA director since 1977, was elected vice chairman.

title: Notes On People; Juan Carlos Leaves Madrid Hospital After Accident
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain checked out of a Madrid hospital yesterday, 13 hours after being admitted for treatment of cuts and bruises in an accident at his Zarzuela Palace outside the capital.

title: 4 CHARGED WITH FALSIFYING REPORTS OF DRUG AND PESTICIDE HEALTH TESTS
description: The former president of a research laboratory and three former subordinates were indicted today for allegedly falsifying health tests on pesticides and drugs to save money, the authorities said.

title: PROGRESS ON INFLATION DETECTED
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, declared today that inflation had fallen below 10 percent, but he said it was unlikely that the increases in the Consumer Price Index would continue to be as small as those in March and April.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 29
California V. Watt And Oil
description: Secretary of the Interior James G. Watt is about to issue a ''final'' determination - probably before July 1 -on whether to make four disputed areas off the northern California coast available for oil drilling. Even before that decision is made, it's entangled in a legal battle of great importance to all the coastal states.

title: THE DANCE: BARBARA DILLY GIVES HER VERSION OF MYTHS
description: THE dances on Barbara Dilley's Saturday night program at the Performing Garage bore such titles as ''Opening,'' ''The Way It Is,'' ''Navajo Homage,'' ''Invoking'' and ''Open Structures.'' In addition, ''Open Structures'' contained 10 parts, each with its own title. Yet all these works were compositionally similar.

title: AIR CONTROL STRIKE CANCELED AS UNION AND U.S. REACH PACT
description: Air traffic controllers called off their threatened nationwide strike early today when the Government and the union agreed on a tentative new contract in which the Government held firm to its initial $40 million total of wages and benefits.

title: By Sports of The Times; Another Ailing Golfer Wins
description: BEWARE the ailing golfer -that phrase is as much a part of the game as keep your head down. Four weeks ago, David Graham had no pep. When he missed the 36-hole cut in the Memorial tournament after having shot 81 and 75, the transplanted Australian returned to his Dallas home for a medical checkup. Told that he lacked potassium, he began eating more fruit, especially bananas. To build his strength for the United States Open, he skipped the next three PGA Tour events but he practiced daily.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for an accounting change and also for a 10 percent stock divd in Dec 1980

title: Retired Colonel Is Shot in Spain
description: A retired colonel was badly wounded by gunmen today in the Basque frontier town of Irun. The shooting appeared to be the work of the Basque terrorist organization E.T.A. Luis de la Parra Urbaneja, a 63-year-old former infantry officer, was shot outside a movie theater where he works in Irun.

title: CANADA ENERGY BILL INTRODUCED
description: The Canadian Government took another major step today to carry out its controversial national energy program by introducing what it called an Energy Security Act into the House of Commons.

title: DANCE: DOUGLAS DUNN PRESENTS 'WALKING BACK'
description: THE dancing was good in Douglas Dunn's new ''Walking Back,'' performed Sunday at the Midtown Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Associaton auditorium. The accompaniment was even better. John Driscoll's acoustical and electronic score was a sympathetic suite of whale songs and muted clanks and drones. It also included two very funny spoken excerpts. ''Genetic death may or may not produce cadavers,'' a biology lecturer with a high-pitched voice and a heavy Middle European accent cried. And a child wandered through a vivid improvised fairy tale with dinosaurs, a pacifist named Stanley, a prince and princess and an amorous policeman. ''Is that the end?'' an adult voice asked on the tape, after about 20 minutes. ''Um, I think I can think of something else,'' the child replied.

title: Textile Sellers Hold Meeting
description: The fight by textile exporters of the third world to gain better access to Western markets was renewed here today at the opening of a meeting of delegates from 20 developing textile exporting countries.

title: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BICYCLIST DIES IN FALL UNDER TRUCK
description: A 24-year-old Columbia University graduate student who was riding her bicycle to work in heavy traffic yesterday morning on the Upper West Side was killed when she lost her balance and swerved under the rear wheels of a moving truck, the police said.

title: STUCK SOLAR PANEL IMPERILS INDIAN SATELLITE
description: One of the two satellites put into orbit Friday by the European Space Agency's Ariane rocket ran into trouble today when an American-made solar panel failed to open, threatening the satellite with a power cutoff.

description: To the Editor:$

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Around the Nation; Hundreds Flee Brush Fires In California's Napa Valley
description: Hundreds of people fled their homes today as brush fires erupted in the heart of northern California's wine country, destroying about three dozen houses and charring 14,000 acres.

title: RATE RISES WEAKEN MARKET
description: Renewed concerns over interest rates sent stock prices slightly lower yesterday after two major New York banks raised their prime rates to 20 percent, the prevailing level for the industry. Airline issues, however, posted gains following the Government's tentative agreement with air traffic controllers to avert a nationwide strike.

title: Portland Gets Cup Semifinal
description: If the Uniter Dtates beats Czechoslovakia in the Davis Cup quarterfinals in New York next month, the semifinal series will be held in Portland in October, the United States Tennis Association said today. Gordon Jorgensen, second vice president of the association, said the association, said the matches would be held Oct. 2, 3 and 4 at Memorial Coliseum.

title: Around the nation; Nuclear Plant Awaits Approval to Retrieve Fuel
description: Workers at the Donald C. Cook nuclear power plant today awaited approval from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of plans to extricate a spent fuel rod that slipped to the bottom of a water-filled tank Friday during routine refueling.

title: The company's laboratory; TAKING A STEP FROM THE MOON TO TROY, N.Y.  and former acting head of NASA
description: The technocrat who directed the manned moon landings is now attempting to apply high-technology ideas from his alma mater to build new companies and revitalize this depressed region of the Upper Hudson Valley.

title: BALLET: A 'SWAN LAKE' WITH ROYAL CHANGES
description: AREAL ''Swan Lake'' is hard to find nowadays but this is exactly what the Royal Ballet -thankfully - offers, and its first performance this season of the 19th-century classic on Monday night was totally true to form.

title: The Region; Prosecutor Quizzed In Abscam Hearing
description: A lawyer for Senator Harrison J. Williams of New Jersey sought to pinpoint when the Federal Government decided to seek an indictment against his client in the Abscam investigation.

title: U.S. Pilot Killed in Germany
description: A United States Air Force F-15 jet crashed on a training mission 15 miles northeast of Bremen today, killing the pilot, officials announced. A United States Air Force spokesman identified the pilot as Capt. George T. Hall of Goodlettsville, Tenn.

title: WISE EATING ON VACATION
description: VACATIONS often spell disaster even for the most disciplined of diners. Confronted three times a day with calorie-laden restaurant menus, many throw caution to the winds and come home five or more pounds heavier and sometimes with raised serum cholesterol and blood pressure to boot.

title: Eleven Harness Horses Killed in Delaware Fire
description: Eleven harness racing horses died early today in a fire at the Harrington Raceway on the grounds of the Delaware State Fair here.

title: Notes on People; Javits Donates Papers
description: After 34 years in public life, Jacob K. Javits donated his papers to the State University of New York, and it took more than 1,300 cartons to hold them all.

title: A LEFTOVER PRIMER: MEALS THAT COME IN FROM THE COLD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon, an Episcopal priest and food writer, is the author of ''Supper of the Lamb'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
BLACK IRON DUTCH OVEN
description: AS I prepared a boeuf en daube -a French beef stew - the other day, I remembered how my mother used to labor diligently over her big black iron Dutch oven in Burgundy and how that was the first pot I bought when I came to this country.

title: ANOTHER STEWART, PLEASE
description: The phone rang in San Francisco, where I was working in 1965, my first year out of Yale Law School. ''Hello, Steve. This is Potter Stewart. I am calling to see whether you'd like to come to Washington for a year to be my law clerk.'' Would I like to come? I would have crawled over miles of broken glass to get there. That invitation made me one of the luckiest young lawyers in America: I was welcomed into that small company of recent graduates who each year get to serve one term as a Supreme Court law clerk.

title: NONPROFIT FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS ARE A DISPENSABLE ECONOMIC BURDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: France Ends Its Embargo On Armaments for Iran
description: France has lifted a provisional arms embargo against Iran and will deliver three missile boats ordered by the Iranian Navy, a spokesman for Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today.

title: A PILOT PUBLIC-HOUSING COMPLEX IN EAST HARLEM STILL UNFINISHED AFTER
description: 10 YEARS By LAURIE JOHNSTON

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Broadway column in the Weekend section last Friday, the lyricist for ''Jean,'' a new musical that Michael Bennett may direct next spring, was reported incorrectly. The lyricist is Christopher Adler.

title: PRICES IN NEW YORK ROSE BY 0.5 PERCENT
description: A decline in the cost of energy helped hold last month's rise in consumer prices to five-tenths of 1 percent for the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: RECALLING WHAT THE FAMILY NEVER KNEW
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alma Denny is a former syndicated columnist. By ALMA DENNY

title: Witness in Wood Case Jailed
description: A key witness in the two-year-old investigation of the shooting death of Federal District Judge John Wood Jr. surrendered today to a United States marshal and was jailed for refusing to testify. George Edward Kay, 39 years old, a lifelong friend of Charles Harrelson, who is a suspect in the Federal investigation of the 1979 killing, was cited for contempt by Federal District Judge William Sessions.

title: House Approves Emergency Bill To Keep Food Stamp Aid Flowing
description: The House approved an emergency bill today to keep full food stamp benefits flowing to 23 million Americans through Sept. 30.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'YOU'D BE DEAD'; 'You'd Be Dead'
description: The handy household handgun: In 20 years, the proportion of American families who keep them has gone from 12 percent to 24. Nancy Reagan, it is said, keeps a ''little gun.'' The man designated as the new police chief of Washington criticizes the city's gun law; it doesn't stop criminals from getting guns, yet makes it harder for the law-abiding. Why do all those people want guns at home?

title: Teaching Kit Explores Techniques of K.K.K.
description: The ''hate'' techniques of the Ku Klux Klan and how to combat them are the subject of a classroom kit being prepared by a teachers' union for fall distribution to schools in Connecticut and elsewhere.

title: VANCE ASSAILS POLICY ON CHINA ARMS SALES
description: Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, has sharply criticized the Reagan Administration's decision to sell arms to China as ''needlessly provocative.''

title: IMAGE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $95,307 gain

title: Architect Of the ABC Building in Manhattan
description: Marvin Fine, the chief designer of the ABC Building on the Avenue of the Americas and other structures in New York City and Westchester County, died Sunday while attending a party at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, where he had been an active member of 40 years. A resident of New Rochelle, he was 77 years old.

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
Western Union Legislation
description: A bill that would let the Western Union Telegraph Company offer service to overseas points has been approved by the Senate and sent to the House, where it is believed to face an uncertain fate.

title: About New York
description: People are not always kind to the beluga whales at the New York Aquarium. Sometimes they throw pennies into their pool, as though Amy Lou and Blanchon were marble fish on the Trevi Fountain, not mammals that some scientists posit may have intelligence greater than that of the average tourist.

title: SALMON, A SUMMER LUXURY
description: SALMON was once a cheap fish, as prevalent as chicken today. It was so plentiful that servants in Colonial America had clauses in their contracts stipulating that they could not be served salmon more than a certain number of times a week. Two centuries before, Elizabethan servants had objected to too many oysters. No wonder you can't get help these days.

title: PARIS REVIEW MARKS ITS 25TH, 3 YEARS LATE
description: IT was 1953, and Paris was inexpensive and romantic, and it was possible then, as it had been possible in Hemingway's time, to make writing not only a vocation but an entire way of life. And so a group of young Americans went to Paris, where they wrote and drank and played tennis and sat up all night at cafes, and where they started a little magazine that ran on talent and enthusiasm and a youthful joie de vivre.

title: ATLANTA MURDER CASE IS SENT TO GRAND JURY
description: The murder case against Wayne B. Williams was forwarded to a grand jury today after a heavily guarded three-hour preliminary hearing, and the District Attorney said he would seek an indictment within 30 days.

title: Article 174493 -- No Title
description: The New York State Senate today gave final approval by a wide margin to a $5.6 billion statewide transportation package aimed primarily at improving the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's subway, bus and commuter rail lines.

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
'60 MINUTES' NEWSMEN TO ADD A DAILY PROGRAM
description: The four correspondents on ''60 Minutes'' - Ed Bradley, Harry Reasoner, Morley Safer and Mike Wallace - will take on added duties in the fall as rotating anchors for a new CBS News afternoon program, ''Up to the Minute.''

title: U.S. DENIES ZAMBIA'S CHARGES AGAINST DIPLOMATS
description: A State Department spokesman denied today that two American diplomats, expelled yesterday by Zambia for alleged Central Intelligence Agency activity, had ''engged in any inappropriate activity.''

title: The City; Transit Report
description: A Manhattan-bound IRT No. 3 train from Brooklyn was stopped at 9:20 A.M. for 50 minutes between the Newkirk and Flatbush Avenue stations because of a mechanical failure.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 24, 1981
description: International An accord among French leftists led to the appointment of four Communists to the 44-member Cabinet of President Francois Mitterrand in the wake of the Socialist Party's sweeping legislative election triumphs. The four posts are not politically sensitive. In return, the Communist Party has agreed to support some Socialist policies in foreign and domestic areas that it had opposed. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) The offer to sell U.S. arms to China was denounced by Cyrus R. Vance, a Secretary of State in the Carter Administration, as ''needlessly provocative.'' In an interview, Mr. Vance said that the new policy of the Reagan Administration ''has substantially diminished'' any influence the United States had over the Soviet Union. (A1:1.)

title: JAZZ-FUSION: MOREIRA
description: AIRTO MOREIRA, the influential Brazilian percussionist who has lived in the United States for 13 years, brought his newest ensemble, a jazz fusion septet that has been together for more than a year, to the Bottom Line on Monday.

title: Co-ed Magazine Adds Guide to Getting Married
description: Co-ed magazine is creating a new advertising medium called Co-ed's Guide to Getting Married, planned as an annual, that will be distributed free to 300,000 youngsters in their last two years of high school and taking special marriage and family and living classes.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MCENROE IS FINED $1,500 AND WARNED OF BEING SUSPENDED
description: John McEnroe was fined $1,500 today, the maximum, and threatened with suspension and an additional $10,000 fine for further misconduct during the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: DETROITERS SUPPORT $96 MILLION IN TAXES
description: Detroit voters apparently granted Mayor Coleman A. Young's request for a $96 million increase in income taxes in yesterday's special election, the first part of his plan to prevent the city's fiscal collapse.

title: INDONESIAN COMMANDOS RECEIVED U.S. HELP IN FREEING A HIJACKED PLANE
description: A United States military team trained in antiterrorist tactics assisted an Indonesian commando unit that overpowered the hijackers of an Indonesian airliner held in Thailand in March, American officials said today.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Howard Henri Quint, Professor At University of Massachusetts
description: Howard Henri Quint, professor of American history at the University of Massachusetts, died yesterday at the Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

Giuliani held with the general counsel of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation while the Government is preparing a criminal case against the company and four of its officers involving alleged foreign payments.

Millen Compensation Issue Is Presented to Arbitrator
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins said today they had asked a National Hockey League arbitrator to award them two players from Hartford to compensate for the Whalers' recent signing of their goalie, Greg Millen.
