description: To the Editor:

title: Sunshine Silver To Pursue Merger
description: The Sunshine Mining Company, one of the nation's largest silver producers, said that it had received court approval to pursue its acquisition of three small, related Wallace, Idaho, mining companies -Silver Dollar Mining, Silver Syndicate Inc. and Sunshine Consolidated.

title: 2 Banks Reduce Broker Loan Rate
description: Two large banks lowered their broker loan rate yesterday to 20 percent from 21 percent, reflecting lower costs of funds and competition for loans that have led to widespread discounting of the prime rate from the posted 20 percent level.

title: Thunder On the Potomac
description: There are times in this city when you can feel the temperature rising and cannot avoid hearing the thunder over the Potomac, and this is one of them. The Administration's misconduct of foreign policy is clearly blowing up a storm.

title: RED SMITH
description: THE Wimbledon championships are under way, that courtly gathering of knights and ladies, the beauty and chivalry of the All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club with its strawberries and cream, its white gloves and flowery hats, meticulously manicured lawns and impeccable manners. It is also the stage on which a spoiled brat like John McEnroe can demonstrate just how ugly an ugly American can get.

title: FOR A FADING COMMUNIST PARTY, MEAGER PICKINGS
description: The French Communist Party has entered the Government for the first time in 34 years. Paradoxically, instead of celebrating a victory it is getting a meager consolation prize for a defeat.

title: The Region; Bowling Balls Out, A Waste Line Flows
description: Five bowling balls have been removed from a pipeline, allowing SCA Chemical Waste Services to resume pumping treated chemical waste from a treatment plant into the Niagara River.

title: Potential Phils' Buyers Turned Off by Strike
description: A group of potential buyers of the Philadelphia Phillies has withdrawn from the bidding because of the baseball strike.

title: M.A.C. BACKS CITY BUDGET, BUT FEARS THREATS TO LOANS
description: Even as the Municipal Assistance Corporation was endorsing New York City's $14.7 billion budget for 1982, its chairman warned yesterday that the city faced new threats in attempts to meet borrowing needs over the next few years.

title: Con Artists Rent Home To 7 Families in Texas
description: Things are a little crowded at 6026 Knotty Post Lane. Seven families have tried to move in since Saturday after paying a total of more than $4,700 to a pair of confidence artists who rented the three-bedroom house to all the families, officials said.

title: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Banks Seek Plan on Polish Debt
description: International banks will try to reach a compromise here tomorrow to ease Poland's crushing burden of foreign debt, on which repayments are becoming increasingly difficult for Warsaw.

title: KALULE AND BAEZ KNOWN ONLY AS THE 'OPPONENTS'
description: Five years ago, Ayub Kalule, a world amateur champion from Uganda, didn't even know they paid fighters in other parts of the world. In Pablo Baez's world, they often forgot to pay. Baez, the son of a sugar factory worker in the Dominican Republic, once got paid $3 for two 10-round fights in Los Angeles.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK FAULTED ON IRAQ BY HAIG'S AIDES
description: Aides of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today criticized the way Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, handled the behind-the-scenes negotiations last week leading up to the Security Council vote condemning Israel for its attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: Around the World; Unemployment Rate Rises To 11.1% in Britain
description: British unemployment rose to a 50-year high of 2,680,977 in June, or 11.1 percent of the work force, the government announced today. The figure was double the jobless total when Conservative Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher took office in May 1979.

title: Review; RECITAL: KEIKO NOSKA ON KOTO
description: MOST practitioners of non-Western classical traditions have had to come to terms with the new international - meaning Western, mostly - musical world. Keiko Nosaka, who gave a koto recital Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, seems to be one of the more imaginative musicians to have confronted this problem.

title: South Africa Bank Rate
description: The South African Reserve Bank said today that it would raise its discount rate, known as the bank rate, to 10.5 percent tomorrow from 9.5 percent. As a result, commercial banks are expected to raise their prime lending, or overdraft, rate to a record 14 percent from the current 13 percent. Under terms of an agreement between the authorities and the banks, the prime rate may not rise more than 3.5 percentage points above the bank rate.

title: Around The World .; Senate Panel Backs Burns As Envoy to West Germany
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today unanimously approved the nomination of Arthur F. Burns, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve under three presidents, to be Ambassador to West Germany.

title: Around The Nation; 26 Aboard Freighter Jailed After Chase in Florida Strait
description: The master and 25 crewmen of a freighter were jailed today after their ship led two Coast Guard cutters on a twoday chase through the Florida Straits to the Yucatan Peninsula, surrendering only after Coast Guardsmen riddled it with machine-gun fire.

title: Still Inflated
description: The Administration has tried for months to refrain from cheering at the price news. Others have declared that inflation is on the wane, but the insistent word from the White House has been that there can be no victory over inflation until Congress passes the President's economic program.

title: Gen. Edwin B. Owen, 60, Ex-Chief Of Eastern Area Terminal Service
description: Brig. Gen. Edwin B. Owen, former commanding general of the Eastern Area Military Traffic Management and Terminal Service at the Brooklyn Army Terminal, died of a heart attack June 15 at his home in Carlisle, Pa. He was 60 years old.

title: NEWCOMER FROM RETAIL FIELD IS PRESIDENT OF SELIGMAN & LATZ
description: Richard Hart, 39, has joined Seligman & Latz, an operator of about 1,000 leased beauty salons and jewelry and cosmetic departments in department and specialty stores, as president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Malcolm A. Seligman, 56, who was appointed vice chairman of the company, based in New York.

title: Careers; Molecular Biology and Business
description: SCIENTISTS with training in molecular biology are apparently moving at a fast pace out of college classrooms and laboratories and are taking jobs in the business community that were unavailable a few years ago.

title: Market Place; Lexicon Gets Second Wind
description: IN the beginning the Lexicon Corporation manufactured a hand-held language translator. Although this product was the first in the field when it was introduced in November 1978, the company lacked the financial strength to compete after the translator market grew hot.

title: TOP OFFICER FOR HARTE
description: Axel L. Grabowsky, 43, has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Harte & Company, a major manufacturer of flexible vinyl sheeting for decorative and industrial applications. He succeeds Robert C. Lewis, 64, who became vice chairman of the New York corporation, a unit of the Dynamit Nobel organization of West Germany since 1979.

title: Q & A
description: Q. You recently printed a recipe for an angel food cake with an illustration showing it in tandem with a sharp knife. Hasn't angel food cake always been pulled apart with two silver forks to make nice rough edges for each serving?

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: SOME wives are quite blunt about it: ''When are you going on a trip?'' they ask their husbands. Others get the same information more subtly. Their opener usually goes something like this: ''I hope you don't have any trips scheduled in the next few months.'' They sound properly unhappy when they are told that, indeed, there is a trip in the offing.

title: EMISSION CURBS TERMED FEASIBLE
description: Witnesses before a Senate committee reviewing the Clean Air Act testified today that current regulations and timetables for removing pollutants from automobile tailpipe emissions could be met without excessive cost or loss of fuel efficiency.

title: Nissan Denies Report
description: The Nissan Motor Company, which produces the Datsun automobile, today denied published reports that it was reconsidering its plans to build a car assembly plant in Britain. A spokesman for Japan's No.2 auto producer said he had no knowledge of a report published in The London Daily Mail that Nissan was now considering building the plant in Belgium.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City fell 4 cents to $103.83 during the period June 8 to 19, according to the market basket survey of the Department of Consumer Affairs. Shoppers paid $9.24 more than during the same period last year.

title: 3 G.E. Executives Sentenced in Bribery
description: Three executives were sentenced to prison terms today in a $1.25 million bribery scheme intended to enhance the General Electric Company's bid for a contract to build a Puerto Rican electric-generating plant.

title: CITY COMPTROLLER STARTS CAMPAIGN FOR A THIRD TERM
description: Describing himself as ''the target of one of the most vicious smear campaigns in the city's political history,'' Harrison J. Goldin formally opened his campaign yesterday for a third term as New York City Comptroller.

title: Chris-Craft's Net Down by 23.4%
description: Chris-Craft Industries, a diversified television broadcaster and a producer of plastics, chemicals and pleasure boats, reported yesterday that its net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 ended May 31 fell 23.4 percent, to $3.6 million, or $1.05 a share, from $4.7 million, or $1.49 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year ago.

title: U.S. Deficit in May At $16.1 Billion
description: The Government's finances showed a $16.1 billion deficit last month, pushing the shortfall for the first eight months of the 1981 fiscal year well past the Reagan Administration's projected deficit for the entire year, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: BASEBALL TALKS RESUME TODAY
description: After four days without a meeting, negotiators for baseball's club owners and players will try again today to initiate the beginning of the end of the strike that has lasted 12 days. But no one seemed likely to head into the 2 P.M. meeting at the Doral Inn with optimism.

title: Limited Prayer Allowed By School Board in Ohio
description: After a six-month dispute, Akron public school students will be allowed to conduct prayers in schools under strict guidelines laid down by the school board.

title: SENATE'S TAX PANEL BACKS ADDED RELIEF
description: The Senate Finance Committee, driving to finish by tomorrow its drafting of a tax-relief bill, today approved eight types of special tax breaks for individuals and businesses, including an easing of the ''marriage penalty'' paid by some two-earner couples.

title: TV: TREVOR HOWARD AS A BAND LEADER
description: ''AND THE BAND Played On,'' a 90-minute film on WNET-TV at 8:30 this evening, is the kind of British production that almost casually sneaks up on the unsuspecting, the better to charm and disarm them. On the surface, the plot is about a village band, a ''stubborn bunch of geriatrics,'' resentful over their longtime conductor's being replaced by a pop musician newly arrived from the big city. Before it's over, however, this gentle drama touches on the crucial need for understanding people, indeed on the peculiar and unique style that constitutes England itself.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
PRESIDENT MEETS A SNAG IN DRIVE FOR ECONOMIC PROGRAM
description: President Reagan ran into a major obstacle in pursuit of his economic program today when the chairman of the National Governors Association withheld his support for the program because of dissatisfaction over cutbacks in Medicaid.

title: Around The World; U.S. and Mexico Establish Joint Commission on Trade
description: The United States and Mexico signed an agreement today creating a joint commission on commerce and trade to expand the ties between the two nations.

title: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
description: B-After losses on the sale of subsidiaries of $3.2 illion for t latest yr and $1.5 million for the previous yr; the company is on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: New Bond Issues TUESDAY, JUNE 23, 1981 UTILITY BONDS Moo dy's urrent IssuesRat ing d&Asked Chng Yield New Engl Tel 15 1/4s18 Aaa -99 5/8 7/8 15.30 Pac Gas & Elec 16 1/4s14 Aa 102 1/2 ...  15.84; CORPORATE BONDS Tenneco 15s06 A 100 1/4 1/4 14.96 Shell 14 1/4s11 Aaa 5/8-100 3/8 14.25; INTERMEDIATE NOTES Upjohn 14s91 Aa 1/2-99 1/2 14.19 Pembroke 14s91 Aaa 1/2-99 3/8 14.19; INTERNATIONAL ISSUES Ontario 14 5/8s91 Aaa 100 1/4 7/8 14.57 Ontario 15 1/8s11 Aaa 101 1/2 5/8
description: Source: First Boston Corp.

title: State Savings Association Near Agency Selection
description: It's not official yet, but it is understood that the agency selection committee of the Savings Banks Association of New York State will recommend to the organization today that it retain Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein for the estimated $2 million account.

title: notes On People; The King of the Cowboys Visits the Big City
description: There was nary a tumbleweed a-tumblin' in Central Park yesterday morning, but that didn't stop Roy Rogers. When the King of the Cowboys wants to go riding, someone else can worry about the props.

title: The Economy
description: The Consumer Price Index rose 0.7 percent last month, indicating that inflation is continuing to ease. Most of the rise was a result of the housing component, reflecting high mortgage and housing prices. The C.P.I. has registered an annual inflation rate of less than 10 percent for three straight months, the first time this happened since spring 1978. (Page A1.) Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area. (A16.) The Senate Finance Committee approved tax breaks for individuals and businesses in eight categories. The ''marriage penalty'' paid by some working couples was targeted for relief. The panel also voted to extend special tax treatment of individual retirement accounts to employees covered by a company pension plan. (A1.)

title: Former Dakota Madam Indicted On Income Tax Evasion Charges
description: Pam Holliday, formerly madam of a brothel, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on three counts of income tax evasion, United States Attorney Terry Pechota has announced.

title: 12.46 SURGE SENDS DOW TO 1,006.66
description: A late buying surge yesterday sent the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 12.46 points, to 1,006.66, its first finish above the 1,000 hurdle since last Wednesday.

title: Southwest Airlines To Buy 10 737-300's
description: The Southwest Airlines Company of Dallas said that it had agreed to buy 10 Boeing 737-300 aircraft, the stretch version of the Boeing Company's basic twin-engine 737-200 series jetliner, at a base price of $16.2 million each, or a total of $162 million.

title: RARE GLIMPSE OF THE IRANIAN MALIGNANCY
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE RULES AUTOWORKER MUST LOSE U.S. CITIZENSHIP FOR FALSIFYING PAST
description: A Federal district judge today ruled that John Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian-born autoworker accused of covering up Nazi war atrocities, must be stripped of his United States citizenship because he concealed his past from immigration officials.

title: LONG-TERM BONDS FIND BUYERS
description: New long-term bonds continued to find buyers yesterday even though the market was disrupted by rapid changes in overnight interest rates that made it difficult for securities firms and investors to agree on yields for long-term issues.

title: VEITCH PLANNING 2d COMEBACK; Veitch Planning 2d Comeback
description: It was a nervous moment. Nine fractious 2-year-old colts were circling the walking ring in Belmont Park's paddock. Hundreds of undecided bettors crowded the rail of the ring, looking for some portent of how to wager on a race full of first-time starters. Several edgy trainers carefully watched each step taken by their young horses.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY IRAQI PRESIDENT TO CABINET
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to his Cabinet today as broadcast by Baghdad Radio and monitored and translated from the Arabic by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service:

title: SENATE TURNS DOWN FLOOR FOR PENSIONS
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today rejected, 53 to 45, a Democratic proposal to rescind $925 million in proposed cuts in the Social Security program by continuing the $122-a-month minimum benefit.

title: Budd Unit to Make Pollution Equipment
description: The Budd Company of Troy, Mich., a unit of Thyssen A.G., the West German heavy-industry concern, announced its entry into the air pollution control business with establishment in New York of Thyssen-CEA Environmental Systems Inc. in partnership with Thyssen Engineering, another Thyssen A.G. unit.

title: Hearing Held on Sonics' Offer of Stock to English
description: George Nicholau, the arbitrator in disputes arising from the right of first refusal involving basketball free agents, held a hearing yesterday to place a money value on the stock option the Seattle SuperSonics have offered Alex English, the Denver Nuggets' free agent.

title: ARCHITECTURE: REVELATION OF PALLADIO'S DRAWINGS
description: WASHINGTON THE buildings of Andrea Palladio may well be among the most beloved in all of Italy: they are at once disciplined and spirited, formal and relaxed. In the 16th century, Palladio took the forms of Roman classicism and reshaped them into something graceful and almost lyrical in its inventiveness. ''He combines the gravity of Rome with the sunny breadth of Northern Italy,'' wrote Sir Nikolaus Pevsner, the architectural historian.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corporation, Milwaukee, has elected Richard A. Buese a vice president.

title: British Unemployment Up
description: Unemployment in Britain reached a postwar record in June, a total of 2.7 million, or 11.1 percent of the work force, compared with 2.6 million in May, the Department of Employment said today. The number of recent graduates without a job rose to 217,000, an increase of 117,000, the report said.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: An 18-year-old woman was chased for at least half a block and stabbed to death on a residential street in Laurelton, Queens, around 4 A.M. Neighbors who heard the victim, Karen Brown, of 131-48 231st Street, yelling, ''Help, help, rape,'' called the police and rushed out as her attacker fled. ... A postman, Feliciano Guadalupe, 45, was found stabbed to death in the hallway of his apartment building at 920 East 174th Street in the Bronx. ... A psychiatric patient at Bronx State Hospital apparently committed suicide by wrapping a strip of cloth around her neck. The patient was identified as Gloria Rodriquez, 34.

title: LESLIE FAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $284,000 for the qr and $3,138,000 for the yr

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Abbott Laboratories said a previously announced secondary offering of 733,000 common shares, underwritten by a Goldman, Sachs & Co. group, had been completed.

title: BURROUGHS EXPANDS PRODUCT LINE FOR USE IN AUTOMATED OFFICES
description: The Burroughs Corporation moved more aggressively into the market for the automated office yesterday with the introduction of an information processing system that can be used by managers and other professionals with no computer training.

title: ALFRED FRANKENSTEIN, LONGTIME MUSIC CRITIC AND AUTHORITY ON ART
description: Alfred Frankenstein, the author, teacher and former music and art critic of The San Francisco Chronicle, died of a heart attack at Kaiser Medical Center in San Francisco on Monday. He was 74 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We played the China card in no-trump, and there is not much left.'' -Former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance. (A1:1.)

title: A PALESTINIAN OVERTURE TO PEACE WITH ISRAEL?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reunion Toasts Bell, Paige
description: James (Cool Papa) Bell and Leroy (Satchel) Paige, both members of the Baseball Hall of Fame, were honored last night at the third annual reunion of Negro League players. The reunion started Monday with a private gathering for the players, and ended with 63 old-timers at last night's banquet.

title: RAN BANKING AGENCY
description: Harold F. Linder, a former president and chairman of the United States Export-Import Bank and a former Ambassador to Canada, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan at the age of 80. He lived in Manhattan.

title: F.T.C. Urged To End Oil Suit
description: Federal Trade Commission lawyers asked today that a huge eight-year-old antitrust case against the nation's eight largest oil companies be dismissed.

title: TAX PROPOSAL WOULD AID THRIFT UNITS
description: The creation of a tax-exempt savings certificate, a proposal that has gained wide support in Congress, could significantly alleviate the problems of the savings and loan industry, industry experts said yesterday.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 sto split in Nov 1980

title: ALL-AMERICAN LAND
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Search Called Off For Missing L.I. Men
description: The Coast Guard abandoned its search last night for two young men who had been missing since their boat overturned in Long Island Sound on Monday.

title: 9 ARE HONORED FOR PUBLIC SERVICE
description: Four men and a woman who devote their time to helping others were honored today by the American Institute for Public Service for contributions to people in need at home and abroad.

title: Dannon to Be Sold To BSN of France
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said today that it would sell its yogurt-producing Dannon Company for $84.3 million cash to BSN-Gervais Danone, a food concern with headquarters in Paris.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOVING PICTURES

title: Jockey Injured At Monmouth
description: David Donahue, a 19-year-old apprentice who is the leading jockey at the Monmouth Park meeting, fractured a collarbone in a spill today, an injury that will keep him from riding for several weeks.

title: MISS BELLAMY FAULTS PLANS TO BUY NEW SUBWAY CARS
description: Carol Bellamy charged yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was going to waste as much as $154 million buying new subway cars that were not needed.

title: MANHATTAN COLLEGE: GRADES OVER GAMES
description: For decades, Manhattan College athletes were among the best in the East and the nation. Before World War II, Manhattan was a football power, and in 1933 it played in the first Orange Bowl game. Manhattan basketball teams were consistent winners from the 1930's through the 1950's, and since 1943 they have played in 13 National Invitation Tournaments and two National Collegiate Athletic Association championships. Manhattan track teams have won many Eastern and Metropolitan honors and one national team title.

title: Around The World; 66 Are Killed and 110 Hurt In Rioting in Casablanca
description: The Government said today that 66 people were killed and 110 others were injured in weekend rioting in Casablanca over price increases.

title: ARGONAUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
Crowded Jersey Prisons to Move Some Inmates to Jails for 90 Days
description: County jails will soon begin picking up the overflow from crowded state prisons under an executive order by Governor Byrne made public today.

title: New American Library Switches to Marsteller
description: In another account switch, Marsteller, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, has been named to do advertising for the New American Library, a subsidiary of the Times-Mirror Corporation.

title: LAND BASING OF MX MISSILE ASSAILED BY NEW REPORT
description: A Congressional staff report circulated on Capitol Hill today asserted that the strategic defects of the current land-basing plan to deploy the MX nuclear missile were so great that the plan should be rejected.

title: SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
AVIATION CHIEF SEES ANTICOLLISION SYSTEM IN OPERATION BY 1984
description: The head of the Federal Aviation Administration announced today that a new anticollision system had been developed for air traffic and said that he ''absolutely and firmly'' intended to have it in regular operation by the end of 1984.

title: Corporal in Marines Is Sentenced To Death in Shooting of a Private
description: A six-member military panel sentenced Lance Cpl. Leman Hutchinson Jr. to death yesterday in the shotgun-slaying of a fellow marine in February.

title: CHICAGOAN, JOGGING NATION'S MEMORY, SPEEDS PLANS FOR ROOSEVELT'S CENTENNIAL
description: The centennial of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth is Jan. 30, 1982, but few people seemed to be aware of it until a young Chicagoan began checking six months ago to see what was being done about it.

title: Carpenters in Northern California End Strike Against Homebuilders
description: About 10,000 carpenters in northern California ended their weeklong strike against homebuilders today with a tentative contract.

title: G.O.P. SEEKING ACCORD WITH CONSERVATIVE GROUPS
description: Richard Richards, chairman of the Republican National Committee, is trying to get conservative political action committees to promise not to campaign against Democrats where local Republicans tell them they are not wanted.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CAREY SIGNS BILL TO ALLOW MALPRACTICE AWARD CUTS
description: Governor Carey today reversed an earlier position and signed a bill that would allow courts to reduce medical malpractice awards to persons who have already been compensated by other insurance benefits. Only life insurance would not be affected by other awards.

title: CHAPTER 11 ENDED FOR CITY STORES
description: The City Stores Company, which operates the W.&.J. Sloane furniture chain and other stores, said yesterday that it had emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings with a sharply lower loss in the fiscal year that ended on Jan. 31.

title: Saudis Warn Toyota on Ford
description: Saudi Arabia warned today that the Toyota Motor Company would face retaliatory action from Arab nations should it form a business tie with the Ford Motor Company, Japanese officials said.

title: FOR BERLIN, A WORLD OF FOOD
description: WEST BERLIN More than 1,000 kinds of sausages. Eighty varieties of bread, flown in daily from bakeries all over West Germany. Some 1,500 kinds of cheese, from France and Italy, West Germany and Denmark. One almost believes that if it exists and is edible it can be found in the mammoth sixth-floor food hall of KaDeWe.

title: Profits Down 9.4% At Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter ended May 31 slipped 9.4 percent, to $12.6 million, or 56 cents a share, from $13.9 million, or 68 cents a share, in the preceding fiscal year's fourth quarter.

title: THEATER: 'OSCAR REMEMBERED'
description: MANY of the plays and stories of that celebrated esthete Oscar Wilde shared a dominant motif - the exposure of a secret sin, followed by humiliation and disgrace. And in what seemed like a sad, self-fulfilling prophecy of his favorite argument that life had a way of imitating art, Wilde himself lived out that story line: his willful pursuit of pleasure ended in Reading Gaol, when the Marquess of Queensberry - the father of his close friend the young Lord Alfred Douglas - accused him of being a sodomite and triumphed in a libel suit brought by Wilde. It is presumably the aim of ''Oscar Remembered,'' an uneven one-man play written and acted by Maxim Mazumdar, to examine the friendship between Wilde and Douglas.

title: 7 HONORED FOR AID TO THE ARTS
description: Mayor Koch honored seven persons last night at Gracie Mansion for their ''extraordinary contributions to the cultural life of New York City,'' and asked other notables in the arts to explain what those contributions had been.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: B-After $225,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: British Soccer Team Tour Of South Africa Dropped
description: A tour of South Africa by 14 British soccer players was called off today because of international pressure. The cancellation was announced shortly before the first game was scheduled to begin in Johannesburg's black township of Soweto.

title: FOOD FAIR INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to May 9
description: B-Including tax credits of $3,644,000 for the 12 weeks and $8,0 for the 40 weeks...C-Including tax credits of $1,451,000 for th weeks and $2,319,000 for the 40 weeks; the company is listed on Pacific, Boston and Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: A FOOD SYMPOSIUM LABELS THE AMERICAN DIET UNSATISFACTORY
description: The way Americans eat has again come under attack, this time by a panel of food experts gathered for a symposium yesterday morning at Christie's, the auction house on Park Avenue. The American diet was clearly on the block, and no one wanted it.

title: Around The World; New Leader Assumes Office On British West Indies Isle
description: Ronald Webster was sworn in today as Chief Minister after his Anguilla Peoples' Party won five of the seven seats in the Legislative Assembly of the British dependency.

title: Socialist France
description: The democratic left in France has been paralyzed since World War II by the voters' belief that it could not achieve power without the Communists or govern well with them. That spell has now been dramatically broken by Francois Mitterrand. His Socialist Party gained power with the Communists' help yet won a parliamentary majority that is secure for five years without their votes.

title: Advertising; New Chief For Bozell Division
description: AFTER a two-year search, Charles D. Peebler Jr., president and chief executive of Bozell & Jacobs, thinks he has the right person to run his three-office Atlantic division. He is G. Bruce McLaren, a 37-year-old Fordham graduate from New Jersey, who has been charged with doubling the billings of the division to $250 million in four years.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
MOSCOW IS STRESSING PERIL FROM POLAND
description: Invoking the bitter memories of the German invasion of the Soviet Union 40 years ago, a series of commentaries culminating in a tough article in Pravda today have declared that events in Poland pose a fundamental threat to postwar European borders and to Soviet strategic interests.

title: S.A.S. ANNOUNCES ITS NEXT PRESIDENT
description: Jan Carlzon, 40 years old, has been named president of the Scandinavian Airlines System, the aviation, hotel and travel-related consortium operated by Sweden, Norway and Denmark. On Aug. 1 Mr. Carlzon, who has been head of the S.A.S. airline division since last November, will succeed Carl-Olav Munkberg, 55, who has resigned from the Stockholm-based corporation.

title: Iowa Beef Merger
description: The proposed $795 million merger of Iowa Beef Processors into the Occidental Petroleum Corporation moved a step closer following announcement by the two companies that the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice had granted early termination of the minimum waiting period required by Federal law, which generally is an indication that the two Government agencies did not plan to oppose the merger. The companies announced merger intentions on June 1 and signed an agreement last Friday. Special shareholder meetings to vote on the merger will be scheduled in August.

title: The City; Woman, 18, Is Slain On Laurelton Street
description: An 18-year-old woman was stabbed to death in Laurelton, Queens, apparently as she tried to evade a rapist, the police said. The murder occurred around 4 A.M. ''I was sleeping, the whole family was sleeping'' Mrs. George Joseph, a resident of the neighborhood, told The Associated Press.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard JOAN OF ARC. The Image of Female Hero- ism. By Marina Warner. Illustrated. 349 pages. Knopf.

title: SOUTH AFRICA STRUGGLES TO BUILD A NUCLEAR INDUSTRY
description: If a clue were needed as to the sensitivity of the costly industrial enterprise that South Africa is rushing to completion at this site in lovely hill country west of Pretoria, it could be found in the name of the place. Derived from the African language Sotho, Valindaba means, ''About this we do not talk.''

title: NEW INDOOR COSMOS LACK FOREIGN STARS
description: The Cosmos' new indoor team, whose creation was announced at a midtown press briefing yesterday, will apparently play without the foreign stars who have helped the club dominate the North American Soccer League's outdoor season in recent years.

title: Winnebago Apparel
description: Winnebago Industries Inc., the producer of motor homes, said that it had signed a contract with National Brand Licensing Inc. of New York to develop the licensing of the Winnebago name in the apparel and camping equipment industries. A company spokesman said that the agreement was part of Winnebago's long-range program to diversify into business not related directly to motor homes.

description: Quick & Reilly Inc., the second-largest firm in the discount brokerage business, said it had acquired Kelly Associates, a discount broker in Texas, for about $3 million.

title: Around The Nation; Vanishing of Vessel Brings U.S. Safety Board Criticism
description: A Federal safety board said today it could not determine why the freighter Poet, with 34 sailors aboard, disappeared in the Atlantic last October.

title: SPECIAL COURT SAYS IT LACKS POWER TO APPROVE SEARCHES IN SECURITY CASES
description: A special court established to regulate the use of electronic surveillance in foreign intelligence cases has concluded that it has no power to issue search warrants authorizing Federal agents to search private property.

description: The only reference Maureen Reagan made to her father in a commercial she filmed for a mail-order acne lotion was oblique. ''Let me tell you,'' she said, ''it certainly made my life easier during that frantic election campaign.''

title: BREZHNEW SAYS U.S. IS EVADING ARMS TALKS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, saying that nations encouraging an arms race ''are in fact pushing mankind toward the abyss,'' today renewed his call for an early resumption of arms limitation talks with the United States and its NATO allies.

title: N.F.L. Opens Defense, Disputes Davis Contention
description: The National Football League began its defense today in the antitrust trial in which the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission have sued the league over its refusal to allow the Raiders to move to Los Angeles.

title: Bridge: Touch of Caution Is Urged In Bids After Weak Opener
description: Explaining how to bid against a weak-two opening is one of the easiest tasks for a bridge teacher. ''Bid as you would against a onebid,'' he can say, ''but with a small pinch of caution since you are a level higher than usual.''

title: Japan Orders Cut in Oil Output
description: The Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has told oil refineries to cut production of oil products in July by 15 percent from a year ago, to 100.45 million barrels, ministry officials said today.

title: FURTHER EASING OF INFLATION IS SEEN
description: The Consumer Price Index rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department reported today, a result that economists took as further confirmation that inflationary pressures continue to ease.

title: Thin Ice in Central Park
description: The never-ending fight over New York's Central Park always heats up with warm weather. Preservationists concerned with landscape and tranquillity are battling those who want the park for active pleasures and entertainment. Underuse means curtailing the park's social value; overuse means its destruction. Policy has to land somewhere in between.

title: Dith Pran 5th Precinct House Marks Centennial
description: Wearing the police uniform of a century ago, Detective Alfred Young took part in yesterday's observance of the 100th anniversary of the Fifth Precinct station house on Elizabeth Street. A parade through the streets of Chinatown opened a three-day celebration in honor of the city's oldest police station.; The New York Times/Dith Pran 5th Precinct House Marks Centennial Wearing the police uniform of a century ago, Detective Alfred Young took part in yesterday's observance of the 100th anniversary of the Fifth Precinct station house on Elizabeth Street. title: AFRICAN OPEC MEMBERS REJECT OIL PRICE CUTS
description: The four African members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, which charge the world's highest prices for their crude, said yesterday that they would not bow to pressure from Saudi Arabia and the international oil companies to lower their oil prices.

title: PAWTUCKET PREVAILS IN 33D, COMPLETING LONGEST GAME
description: Two months and 33 innings after it started, the longest baseball game in history was completed tonight when the Pawtucket Red Sox defeated the Rochester Red Wings in their first time at bat, 3-2.

title: Zaire Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: Zaire, source of much of the Western world's cobalt and copper, will be allowed to draw the equivalent of more than $1 billion from the International Monetary Fund over the next three years, it was announced today.

title: Saudi Output By Aramco Up
description: The Arabian American Oil Company's oil production in Saudi Arabia rose about 3 percent and output of natural gas liquids rose about 22 percent last year, according to the company's annual report released today.

title: Excerpts from statement, page A10.
description: President Francois Mitterrand reached an agreement on policy with the Communist Party today and appointed four Communists to a 44-member Cabinet.

title: VILAS IS OUSTED
description: Wimbledon toasted Kathy Rinaldi today as the youngest player ever to win a match in the historic tennis championships. And Miss Rinaldi, a 14-year-old American, achieved the distinction by recovering from match point for a three-set victory over Sue Rollinson of South Africa.

title: Japan Lifts Output Of Recorders
description: Japan's production target for home-use video cassette recorders this year has been revised upward to 8.4 million sets from an earlier estimate of 6.2 million, the Japanese Electronics Industries Association said today.

title: 2 U.S.-Born Dancers Enter Finals of Moscow Contest
description: Two United States-born dancers representing Canada have reached the finals of the Moscow International Ballet Competition.

title: The City; 150 Students to Make Learning Devices
description: The United Federation of Teachers said that 150 economically disadvantaged students from the city's schools, including 30 who are handicapped, had been hired this summer to make learning tools for the public school system.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Motivation Questioned On P.& G. Withdrawls Among top advertising people, the reaction to the furor created by last week's Moral Majority speech by Owen Butler, Procter & Gamble chairman, was pretty much summed up by David B. McCall, chairman of McCaffrey & McCall, who remarked, ''Much ado about nothing.''

title: WEAK PALNE MARKET SHUTTING PIPER PLANT
description: The Piper Aircraft Corporation, a major manufacturer of airplanes operated by corporations and private aviators, said yesterday that it was closing its Santa Maria, Calif., plant permanently, with the loss of more than 600 jobs, and temporarily cutting production at its Vero Beach, Fla., plant.

title: Purina to Relocate Van Camp Division
description: The Ralston Purina Company said that it would reorganize its Van Camp sea food division for greater efficiency by moving several departments to St. Louis from San Diego and making Van Camp a part of its grocery products division.

title: Observer; CHESHIRE CAT GEOGRAPHY
description: Have you been under the impression, neighbor, that Iran went away a long time ago? Surprising, isn't it, to hear that they're still there and still at it, still shouting ''Death''?

title: TEACHER, STUDENT, AND BOOK
description: So far I've outlasted them all. Over the last two decades, education fads have come and gone and I'm still in the classroom with the student, with only the textbook between us.

title: the Region; Radioactive Water Leaking at Millstone
description: About 80 gallons of radioactive water leaked into Long Island Sound from the Millstone nuclear plant Sunday and Monday and the leak was still continuing, according to officials.

title: PANEL ON FEDERALISM FOCUSES ON MONEY
description: The Presidential Advisory Committee on Federalism convened here today to explore ways that President Reagan might use to achieve his ''dream'' of shifting Federal power from Washington to the states.

title: IRAN STEPS UP HUNT FOR BANI-SADR AND ARRESTS SOME OF HIS AIDES
description: Iranian authorities, asserting that former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was still in the country as recently as last night, stepped up their hunt for him today, arresting and questioning some of his closest friends and aides.

title: A YOUTH DROWNS IN THE RESERVOIR IN CENTRAL PARK
description: An 18-year-old youth drowned yesterday in the reservoir in Central Park, where he had gone swimming at about midnight with friends who had just graduated from Stuyvesant High School.

title: The City; Nursing Home's Sale Approved by Judge
description: The Park Crescent Nursing Home in Manhattan, which has been operated by a court-appointed trustee since 1977, will be sold for $6.3 million to Kateri Residence, an arm of Catholic Charities.

title: News Analysis
description: While Wayne B. Williams remained locked in solitary at the Fulton County jail last night, and while the public wondered whether his arrest would bring an end to the series of murders of young blacks here, the police were back at Mr. Williams's home, removing carpets, going through garbage cans, scouring shrubbery.

title: Canadian Grain Prediction
description: United Grain Growers, a farmerowned grain company, forecast today that prairie farmers in Canada's western provinces will produce a bumper 1981 crop of 41.8 million tons of grain, significantly above the 34.1 million tons in 1980.

title: SEAGRAM TELLS OF BID FOR CONOCO
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons dislosed yesterday that it was the mystery suitor whose $2 billion bid for 25 percent of Conoco was rejected last week by the oil company. Despite the rebuke, Seagram said that it might proceed anyway, and notified the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission that it may purchase shares of Conoco on the open market.

title: SOLD-OUT SPRINGSTEEN CONCERT WILL OPEN JERSEY ARENA JULY 2
description: Although the lockers and dressing rooms will not be finished, the building's sound system will not be functional and painters and technicians will still have hundreds of jobs left, the 20,000-seat Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands Sports Complex will be packed with rock-music fans in less than two weeks.

title: Asian Development Loans
description: The Asian Development Bank has approved loans totaling $185.7 million to Indonesia, Pakistan and Burma, the bank announced today. The loans include $87.7 million to Indonesia for an irrigation, drainage and flood control project in southcentral Java; $23 million to Indonesia for a cotton production project in southern Sulawesi; $55 million for a thermal generation project in Pakistan, and $20 million for a pump irrigation and infrastructure development project in Burma.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK TACKLES HER U.N. JOB WITH ZEST
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the professor turned diplomat, is coming to terms with her new and unfamiliar role in public life.

title: Canada-Egypt Deal
description: Canada has sold 92 railway locomotives worth $100 million ($83 million United States) to Egypt, the Government announced today. The Government expects loan agreements for the sale, backed by a Canadian Government financial package, to be signed soon, the Department of Industry, Trade and Commerce said in a statement. Delivery of the engines, manufactured by General Motors of London, Ontario, is due to begin in the last quarter of this year.

title: JAPANESE PUT DAZZLE IN CAR ADS
description: The voice-over announcer growls ''we are driven'' as a sleek Datsun car whips down a twisting highway in a recent television commercial. An exultant Toyota owner leaps skyward as a chorus trills ''Oh, what a feeling!'' A throaty singer implores viewers to take ''just one look'' at Mazda's offerings.

title: The Region; Jersey Fairgrounds Sold to Investor
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The 130-acre site that has served as New Jersey's state fairgrounds since the 19th century has been sold to a realestate investor.

title: 5 Hurt in Texas Refinery Blast
description: An explosion rocked a petroleum refinery on the Houston Ship Channel early today, injuring five workers and setting off a series of fires, the authorities said. About 30 fire units from neighboring communities and industrial plants stood by before firefighters from Pasadena and the Crown Central Petroleum Corporation doused the flames. Crown Central officials had no comment on the incident.

title: BOARD IMPELS JOCKEYS TO TESTIFY
description: Sources close to the State Racing and Wagering Board said yesterday that the board would suspend any jockey who invoked the Fifth Amendment at wide-ranging public hearings that start today into the fixing of thoroughbred races at Aqueduct and Saratoga in the mid-1970's.

title: Peugeot-Honda Pact Expected
description: Cycles Peugeot, part of the Peugeot Auto Group, is expected to announce tomorrow an accord with Japan's Honda Motor Company to produce motorcycle engines in France under license, industry sources said today.

title: STAGE: ANN CORIO RECALLS 'THIS WAS BURLESQUE'
description: IT seems only yesterday that Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, cleaning up Times Square, ran burlesque out of 42d Street, clear to Union City, N.J. Actually that happened more than 40 years ago. It is something of a commentary too that Ann Corio, once a supreme practitioner of the torrid striptease art, has brought her stage memoir, ''This Was Burlesque,'' back to Times Square, to the Princess Theater, and it has an almost uplifting effect on the neighborhood.

description: * Allied Bancshares Inc. of Houston said it and the First National Bank of Giddings, Tex., had agreed in principle to the merger of the bank into Allied.

title: Around the Nation; Searchers Leave Mt. Rainier As Weather Brings Danger
description: Searchers worn by fatigue and frustration today gave up their effort to recover the bodies of 11 mountain climbers buried beneath ice, snow and rubble on Mount Rainier.

title: G.T.E. Yellow Pages For Chinese Cities
description: If your fingers are really up to it, how about a little walk through some Chinese phone books? That's right, they do have advertising in their telephone books, local advertising interspersed with the regular name listings, and if the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation has its way it will soon have some ads from the rest of the world. The G.T.E. Directories Corporation has signed an agreement with the Sino-International Trade Promotion Company, a Hong Kong ad agency, to sell ads outside China for telephone directories in six Chinese cities.

title: Economic Scene; Third World Instability
description: AT the Ottawa conference of the leaders of the major Western industrial nations next month, President Reagan is likely to face heavy criticism for the impact of high United States interest rates on other countries. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, President Francois Mitterrand of France and other leaders have already voiced their fears that the Reagan Administration's stringent monetarist strategy could worsen unemployment and cause a breakdown of economic cooperation in the West.

title: STATES IS DECLARED A CO-DEFENDANT IN PRISONS SUITS
description: New York State was ordered to be a co-defendant with the city yesterday in continuing suits against jail conditions here. Federal Judge Morris E. Lasker called overcrowding ''desperate'' in both state and city prisons.

title: 1. Initial Crest
description: A nifty way to brighten up a plain, tailored blazer is to add a gold-embroidered crest to its pocket. The crest won't give you entry to an exclusive British club, since its legend is merely your initial, but the red and gold crown and laurel leaves it bears can be very impressive. The crests, available in all the letters of the alphabet and ready to sew on, are $13.50 each at Goldberg's Marine, 12 West 46th Street.

title: CANADIAN OFFER FOR GENERAL PORTLAND
description: Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd., the largest maker of concrete in Canada, yesterday offered to acquire General Portland Inc., the third-largest concrete producer in the United States, for $315 million (United States) in cash. The proposal calls for each shareholder of General Portland to receive $45 a share.

description: Allyn Delano Urbahn was married yesterday in Paris to James Lambert Simmons.

title: Notes On People; Landrieu Joins Law Firm in Washington
description: Moon Landrieu has become the latest official from the Jimmy Carter Administration to land a place with a major law firm in Washington. Beginning next week, the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will be of counsel to Rogers & Wells, a New York-based firm that maintains a Washington office, where Mr. Landrieu plans to work.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IHAVE long since lost the parochial feeling that there is no other worthwhile cuisine in the world except that of my native France. I have learned to cook with some degree of adeptness, or been exposed to, many kinds of cooking in this country.

title: On Weaver's Title Status
description: The World Boxing Association executive committee will vote tomorrow on whether to strip Mike Weaver of the heavyweight championship for not fighting James (Quick) Tillis, the No. 3-rated contender.

title: Around The Nation; Judge in Miami Authorizes Surgery on Deformed Infant
description: A judge ruled today that a 10-day-old deformed baby should be given a chance to fight a crippling spinal defect and told the infant's parents, who opposed surgery, to allow a hospital to operate.

title: REGAN'S POLITICAL EDUCATION
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, the former chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company now in his first government post, recently called in some political aides for advice on handling Congress.

title: Food Fair's Net Up
description: Food Fair Inc., operating under Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Act, reported today that it earned $7.4 million, or $1.01 a share, in its fiscal third quarter, compared with a profit of $2.9 million, or 39 cents a share, for the same period a year ago, which included an extraordinary tax credit of $1.5 million, or 19 cents a share. The supermarket chain said that income in the quarter, which ended on May 9, included an extraordinary credit for utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $3.6 million, or 50 cents a share.

title: FUTURE OF EXPORT-IMPORT BANK IS DEBATED AS IT FACES FIRST LOSS
description: An intense debate - partly philosophical, partly practical, entirely political - is under way in Washington about the role and future of the Export-Import Bank, the 47-year-old institution that provides low-interest loans to finance the sale of American products abroad.

title: General Instrument Gains
description: The General Instrument Corporation, a national leader in cable television electronics, wagering systems and programmable microelectronic systems and circuits, announced yesterday that its net income in its first fiscal quarter ended May 31 rose 25.3 percent, to $18.8 million, or $1.96 a share, from $15 million, or $1.69 a share, in the first quarter of the preceding fiscal year. Revenues rose 7.4 percent, to $220.1 million, from $205 million.

title: Levi Strauss Net Plunges 33.8%
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday that net income in the second fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Jan. 31 plunged 33.8 percent, to $34.6 million, or 83 cents a share, from $52.3 million, or $1.25 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: U.S. URGED TO BAR COUNCIL REDISTRICTING
description: The Citizens Union said yesterday that it was urging the Justice Department to disapprove the new City Council redistricting plan on the ground that it discriminated against minority residents.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE CUTS SERVICES AS THOUSANDS OF WORKERS CALL IN ILL
description: More than 80 percent of New Hampshire's 9,200 state workers called in sick today to press demands for higher pay, forcing officials to close most state liquor stores and suspend the state lottery.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN the alto saxophonist and composer Ornette Coleman first played in New York City in 1959, he stirred up a controversy that quickly spread beyond the insular world of jazz. Many jazz musicians and critics attacked him for playing formless, out-of-tune music, and classical composers and educators such as Leonard Bernstein and Gunther Schuller leaped to his defense.

title: REAGAN AIDE BACKS BIRTH-AID EDUCATION
description: The Reagan Administration said today that family planning education for poor women and teen-agers was a ''necessity,'' and urged the use of Federal funds for the program.

VIOLENCE FOLLOWS EVICTION OF WEST BERLIN SQUATTERS
description: Policemen carrying away a demonstrator after a street battle yesterday in the Zehlendorf district of West Berlin. The police arrested 203 people who were reportedly protesting the ouster of squatters from the empty buildings they had occupied. Demonstrations deploring the shortage of housing in West Germany have been frequent in recent months.

title: Boxing Promoter's Bail Revoked
description: The judge who ordered the boxing promoter Ross Fields freed on $10,000 bail two weeks ago has ordered Mr. Fields back to jail. Mr. Fields, also known as Harold J. Smith, was in Municipal Court yesterday to fight extradition to North Carolina when Judge Julius Leetham of Superior Court entered the courtroom and revoked bail. He had granted bail on June 10 so that the defendant could surrender himself in North Carolina. Because Mr. Fields did not go, Judge Leetham said he had broken ''faith with me.''

description: Pakistan has given the Reagan Administration ''absolute assurances'' that it is neither developing nor planning to develop nuclear weapons, Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley said today.

title: A MANSION FOR DADDY WARBUCKS
description: THE set designers needed a mansion for shooting ''Annie,'' Columbia Pictures' film version of the long-running Broadway musical. But not just any mansion. The director, John Huston, wanted one that could easily house the film's eccentric billionaire, Daddy Warbucks, and copies of such colossal status symbols as Rembrandt's ''Night Watch,'' the ''Winged Victory'' and, of course, the Venus de Milo.

title: BLAKE EDWARDS IN TIFF OVER 'S.O.B.'
description: A few pages that might have been torn from the script of ''S.O.B.,'' Blake Edwards's new black comedy that chops Hollywood into little pieces, are being played out between Mr. Edwards and Paramount Pictures this week.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL TO SELL ROTHESAY
description: MacMillan Bloedel Ltd., Canada's largest forest-products company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its subsidiary, Mac-Millan Rothesay Ltd., to the Irving Interests, a diversified company with interests in energy and pulp and paper. The company said that the total price is $145 million (Canadian).

title: Around the nation; Baby With Deformed Spine Has Court-Ordered Surgery

description: Unlike prime agricultural counties in such places as New York, California, Florida and Texas, which are rapidly yielding some of the nation's most fertile farmland to relentless urban growth, Finney County sits amid the prairies of southwestern Kansas, far removed from metropolitan pressures.

description: China is working out a detailed development plan for the next decade that requires lower investment, aims at improving living standards and does not attempt ''a growth rate that cannot last,'' a leading planner said today.

title: The City; 45 Citizens Honored
description: Forty-five private citizens who performed signficant acts to combat crime, including a Brooklyn man who gave his life while pursuing an assault suspect, received civilian commendation awards from the Police Department yesterday.

title: Angola Urges a New Conference To Seek a Solution on Namibia
description: Angola has called for a new conference to seek a peaceful solution to the problem of South-West Africa, or Namibia, the Angolan press agency Angop said today.

description: Exhaustive clinical tests have shown that Pope John Paul II is suffering from a mild viral infection that has no direct connection with the wounds he suffered in an assassination attempt in May, his doctors announced today.

title: ALASKA PAPER SEEKS TO REGAIN INFLUENCE
description: While The Anchorage Times and The Anchorage Daily News are engaged in the most bitter newspaper competition this state has ever seen, the moribund Tundra Times, the paper of Alaska's natives, is being rejuvenated in the hope that it may eventually reach more readers than either of the Anchorage dailies.

title: TV: WORKING AND NOT WORKING IN AMERICA
description: ''AMERICA Works When America Works,'' the NBC News White Paper broadcast tonight at 9:30, looks at this country's labor picture and finds a manpower system that has failed to keep up with industrial change. It is an important, if not crucial, subject, and this documentary manages to touch on most of the key points. But the overall treatment falls into the common television trap of trying to cover too much, meandering off into tangential essays and substituting pointless repetition for needed depth.

title: S.&P. CUTS RATINGS ON NORTON SIMON
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its ratings of Norton Simon Inc. debt yesterday, citing continued weakness in the company's consumer products business and the impact of sluggishness in the airline industry on its automobile rental operations.

title: Home Improvement; AUTOMATIC OPENERS FOR GARAGE DOORS
description: AN automatic garage door opener, operated from inside the car, not only eliminates the need to get out on a rainy or windy night but also is widely regarded as an important safety feature, especially for people who arrive home alone at night.

title: NORWAY CUTS OIL PRICE BY 10% ADDING TO PRESSURE ON AFRICANS
description: Norway's state-owned oil company announced yesterday that it was reducing the price of its North Sea crude oil by 10 percent, another indication of the intense downward pressure on world oil prices.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alpine International Corp. said its subsidiary, Alpine Veneers Inc., had negotiated the sale of the rights to harvest and dispose of about 90 million board feet of timber in Oregon and Washington to Rimrock Lake Timber Co. of Beaverton, Ore.

title: Business People; PRESIDENT OF CASIO INC. GETS BEHIND THE COUNTER
description: John J. McDonald, the 51-year-old president of Casio Inc., the American subsidiary of the Casio Computer Company of Japan, is a person who likes to meet the people who buy his products. And so, for about 15 days a year, he does his own personal market research by working as a salesman at electronic product counters of department stores, such as Macy's in New York and Meier & Frank in Portland, Ore.

title: S.E.C. SEEKS SHIFT IN SECURITIES RULE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is proposing to do away with a seven-day waiting period that several international lending agencies must undergo before offering securities to United States investors, S.E.C. officials said today.

description: A Reagan Administration proposal that Congress forbid public schools to charge tuition for children of military personnel got a cold reception today in the Senate Armed Services Committee.

description: Spokesmen for the auto industry urged Congress today to repeal parts of the Clean Air Act immediately so they could hold down costs of 1983 model cars.

title: Critic's Notebook; THE CASE OF THE PURLOINED IMAGE
description: Revelations of plagiarism are always disconcerting, but they induce a special feeling of horror when the plagiarist is a person of notable gifts and high accomplishment. For such a person to appropriate the work of someone else and present it as his own suggests something more than routine dishonesty - something closer to desperation. Even where the motive for plagiarism is neither cynical nor mercenary, it signifies a sense of inadequacy and an inordinate fear of failure. Even when the plagiarism goes undetected, it must therefore result in damaged pride and a diminished sense of self. Concealment may allay embarrassment, but it cannot relieve the feelings of impotence and anguish that are likely to lie at the heart of the plagiaristic deed.

title: U.S., BONN AND JAPAN END SYNTHETIC FUEL PLAN
description: The United States, West Germany and Japan agreed yesterday to abandon a cooperative $1.55 billion coal liquefaction project that less than a year ago was hailed by Department of Energy officials as a centerpiece of the nation's drive to reduce dependence on imported oil.

description: Gov. James R. Thompson of Illinois appealed today for a penny increase in sales taxes and for higher liquor taxes, saying that was the only ''responsible'' way to return financial stability to the Chicago area's mass transit system.

title: HAIG DISAVOWING AIDES' CRITICISM OF U.N. DELEGATE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today disavowed criticism attributed to his aides of the way Jeane J. Kirk) - "I am shocked and disappointed that such a story should be written and, more importantly, that it should be attributed to one of my aides or more," Mr. Haig said of an article in today's issue of The New York Times. "Any such statements by my aides are misinformed or they have been misinterpreted."

title: A Faster Than Usual Pace for the Business Community Draws 6,000 Runners
description: The field at the start of the women's division competition in the opening round last evening of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporate Challenge series in Central Park. More than 600 corporations, trade associations and government agencies fielded teams of runners for 3.5-mile event. Other races are scheduled for July 15 and Aug. 4.

title: Business Peoplej; MILLIONAIRE THANKED FOR BUYING UNITS
description: Early this month, less than half a year after Bernard P. McDonough, a 77-year-old multimillionaire industrialist, completed the sale of his McDonough Company to a British organization for $180 million, he bought back two of its units for some $50 million.

title: A Connecticut Woman Wins $2 Million Prize
description: A Connecticut woman won $2 million today in the New Jersey State Lottery's largest grand prize drawing in its 10-year history.

title: U.S. GRAIN EXPORTERS LISTS SALES
description: United States grain exporters said yesterday that several countries, including Japan, Venezuela and the Philippines, had purchased 275,000 tons of United States wheat and had tendered for 400,000 tons of corn and sorghum.

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
SALE OF CARDINALS IS CONSIDERED
description: Anheuser-Busch will consider selling the St. Louis Cardinals if they continues to show financial losses, August A. Busch 3d, the corporation's chairman, said.

title: Lear TV Ads to Oppose The Moral Majority
description: People for the American Way, a nonprofit organization, began a national campaign today to counter what the television producer Norman Lear called ''the intolerant messages and antidemocratic actions of moral majoritarians.''

title: The U.N. Today; June 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Development Program Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Around the Nation; Mine Construction Workers End Strike by Ratifying Pact
description: Mine construction workers ratified a new contract today, ending their 90-day strike and bringing labor peace to the soft coal industry.

title: MERGER BID BY CONOCO IS EXPECTED
description: Conoco and Cities Service are apparently engaged in preliminary merger discussions that, if successful, would create the nation's seventh-largest oil company.

title: Key Civil Service Aide Selected
description: President Reagan will nominate Gloria Toote, a New York lawyer, to be head of the Merit Systems Protection Board, one of the key jobs in managing the civil service, Administration officials said last night. Miss Toote, a Republican, would have the second highest rank for a black person in the Administration.

title: 3 OFFICERS AND 5 OTHERS HELD IN SPAIN IN POSSIBLE PLOT
description: Three military officers and five civilians have been arrested in what might have been another attempt to overthrow the Spanish Government.

title: HAIG STATEMENT
description: Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. disavowing his aides' reported criticism of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations:

title: NU-WEST INCREASING TRANSALTA STAKE
description: Nu-West Group Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, announced plans to buy 4.6 million shares of the Transalta Utilities Corporation, one of Canada's largest investor-owned utilities, following expiration of a tender offer.

title: Around the nation; State Employees Return To Jobs in New Hampshire
description: State workers began returning to their jobs today after legislative leaders agreed to support higher pay increases in the new budget.

title: News Analysis
description: Congress is now wrestling with the spending priorities that will govern the country's budget over the next year. But a second front in the budget battle is the struggle between the executive and legislative branches over which shall shape Federal budgets.

title: AMERICAN AIR ROUTE
description: An administrative law judge has selected American Airlines for a new air route from the United States to Brazil, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced. The decision must still be approved by the C.A.B. and then President Reagan. If American decides not to fly the route from Dallas-Forth Worth to Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo within one year, the route would be awarded to Eastern Airlines, which would fly out of Atlanta to the two Brazilian cities, the C.A.B. said.

title: HOWARD PIPER, A FORMER OFFICIAL OF THE PIPER AIRCRAFT CORPORATION
description: Howard Piper, who worked for 28 years for the Piper Aircraft Corporation, died Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital in Wichita, Kan., where he lived. He was 63 years old.

title: Raise a Cheer for the Fourth Platoon
description: A bill in the New York Legislature would give the New York City Transit Authority power to assign police officers to a special shift during peak hours of subway crime. The measure is long overdue; along with 500 additional transit police officers the city has agreed to hire for subway and bus patrol, it promises a new crackdown on subway crime.

title: JOHNNY GRIFFIN ON SAXOPHONE
description: JOHNNY GRIFFIN plays the tenor saxophone with long, light, flowing lines that build to tremendously forceful passages which, despite their fierce energy and the power of his attack, always remain completely controlled and smoothly executed. Mr. Griffin, who has been living in Europe for the last 20 years, is making one of his occasional visits to New York at the Village Vanguard, through Sunday, where he is leading a quartet that reflects the dashing flair that he brings to his playing.

title: LOLA LANE, ACTED IN 30's AND 40's
description: Lola Lane, one of the Lane Sisters who were among Hollywood's top leading ladies during the 1930's and 40's, died at her home on Monday. She was 75 years old.

title: CONSUMER NEEDS OF 1980'S ARE CITED TO SENATE PANEL
description: Consumer advocates, representatives of business and Government officials told a Senate subcommittee today that education and reliable information were among the most critical consumer needs in the 1980's.

title: U.S. EXPERT DISPUTES ISRAELIS ON REACTOR
description: A leading American specialist in nuclear reactor safety has challenged the Israeli contention that the Iraqi reactor that was bombed on June 7 would have spread ''a huge wave of radioactivity over the city of Baghdad and its innocent citizens'' if it had been attacked after it went into operation.

title: SENATE PANEL APPROVES BILL ON ADOLESCENT SEX
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved a bill today designed to encourage teen-agers to practice ''self-discipline and responsibility in matters of human sexuality'' and to promote adoption as an alternative to adolescent parenthood.

title: ALBANY AGREEMENT CLOSE ON A RENT RISE PACKAGE
description: The outlines of a possible agreement to revise rent and other housing laws for New York City and its suburbs - including a more generous increase for landlords renting vacant apartments and an end to rent increases offsetting higher fuel costs - began to circulate here today.
