title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Notes On People; Brooke Shields and the Fight on Smoking
description: A Federal official denied yesterday that the Government had canceled an antismoking advertising campaign featuring the 16-yearold actress, Brooke Shields, because of pressure from the tobacco industry.

title: THE STATES OF THE ARTS
description: The cries of desperation from the arts community in the face of the threatened withdrawal of Federal art funds have set the tone for the President's Task Force on the Arts and Humanities. Since the body is composed of some of our most capable and experienced cultural doctors, it is premature to write the patient off as a lost cause, even if the patient's reaction to withdrawal appears alarming.

title: Notes On People; A New Marquis
description: On Sunday he received an honorary doctorate in his hometown of Granada. Yesterday, in Madrid, it was announced that King Juan Carlos had awarded him the title of Marquis of Salbrena.

title: BLOCK, H & R, INC reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
CHOOSING A MORTGAGE THAT SUITS YOUR NEEDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elliot Raphaelson is a banker and a faculty member of the New School, where he teaches personal finance. By ELLIOT RAPHAELSON

title: Head of State U. College Named
description: The trustees of the State University of New York today approved the appointment of Dr. John F. Walter as president of Sullivan County Community College in South Fallsburg. Dr. Walter is vice president of Lake Michigan College in Benton Harbor, Mich.

title: BUSH VOICES UNEASE ON FRENCH CABINET
description: Vice President Bush expressed some concern today over the inclusion of four Communists in France's new Government. As he left Elysee Palace this afternoon after a two-hour lunch and an hour of talks with President Francois Mitterrand, Mr. Bush told reporters, "Our European allies are sovereign nations and the decision on how they are governed rests with their citizens and with their elected representatives."

title: F.B.I. STARTS TO WITHDRAW AGENTS ASSIGNED IN ATLANTA
description: Partly because of the arrest of a suspect in one case, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun to withdraw the dozens of special agents it sent to Atlanta to help investigate the killings of 28 young blacks, a Justice Department official said today.

title: Advertising; COLGATE INSERTS
description: Colgate-Palmolive will distribute 33 million free-standing inserts through 120 newspapers on July 19. Each insert will contain five 12-cents-off coupons for four different dental hygiene products: Colgate toothpaste; Fluorigard dental rinse; Ultra Brite toothpaste, and Curad Adhesive Bandages (''Helps Boo-boos Heal Fast!'').

title: Troublemaker
description: The American critics of Jacobo Timerman have this much of a point: this outspoken survivor of Argentina's clandestine prisons is indeed a troublemaker. But the polemical storm he has provoked was not ignited by his account of his 30-month prison ordeal and eloquent indictment of his sadistic captors. His suffering was real, as his detractors concede. What they don't like is Mr. Timerman's troublemaking insistence that Argentina demonstrates the speciousness of the Reagan Administration's split-level approach to human rights outrages abroad.

title: DRAVO AUSTRALIA CONTRACT
description: The Dravo Corporation said today that its Dravo Australia unit had been awarded a ''multimillion-dollar'' contract by Curragh Queensland Mining Ltd. to design and manage coalhandling and mine-support facilities for the Curragh coal mine project near Blackwater in Queensland, Australia.

title: NOFZIGER THRIVES ON TOUGH REPUTATION
description: As Administration strategists quietly planned an intensive Fourth of July campaign in the home districts of Congressmen who are not pledged to President Reagan's tax-cutting plan, five abrupt promises of support came into the White House political office from members of Congress. According to a worker there, they arrived with statements such as: ''Look, we don't want Nofziger in our district.''

title: WEALTHY GREENWICH SCHOOLS OFFERING STUDENTS MANY ADVANCED COURSES
description: Because of its high tax base, the Greenwich public school system has more money than most other systems in the New York metropolitan area to spend on its students. And the students come from homes that do not suffer from the problems of poverty.

title: JAPANESE CAR MAKERS NOTIFIED OF QUOTAS ON U.S. SHIPMENTS
description: The Ministry of International Trade and Industry notified the nation's seven major car makers today of their quotas for car shipments to the United States for the current fiscal year that ends March 31, 1982.

title: LEONARD VS. HEARNS OVERSHADOWS CARD
description: With less than three months to go until their showdown bout, Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns are getting closer to each other. They even sound alike.

title: ROYAL BALLET: 'SWAN LAKE'
description: LESLEY COLLIER and Stephen Jefferies, a model cast of principals, stepped into the Royal Ballet's ''Swan Lake'' Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for an exemplary performance.

title: Going Out Guide
description: SUBCONTINENTAL

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1981
description: International Israel can produce nuclear weapons, Moshe Dayan acknowledged in an interview. The former Defense Minister and Foreign Minister said that Israel had not produced any nuclear bombs, but had developed the ability to do so and could manufacture them ''in a short time'' if the Arab countries produced them. (Page A1, Column 4.) The future of democracy in Israel is a subject of deep concern to many Israelis amid an emotional political campaign marked by violence and vituperation. Many leaders are sounding urgent alarms about antidemocratic trends, such as insensitivity to individual rights. (A8:1-6.)

title: FIREFIGHTERS STEM NAPA VALLEY BLAZE
description: Fire officials today began taking weary firefighters and equipment out of the Napa Valley foothills, scorched by an arsonist's blaze that raged through 23,000 acres, burned $500,000 homes and injured 11 persons.

title: Around the World; 55 at Uganda Mission Slain In Continuing Civil Conflict
description: Ugandan soldiers killed 55 people and wounded 100 today when they attacked a mission station in the West Nile region, a Red Cross worker said.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 13
U.S. AIDS WORKERS
description: Because of the impact of imports, some 1,600 workers making men's shirts at six plants owned by the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation in Alabama and Arkansas have received Labor Department approval for financial assistance.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS TAX-FREE CERTIFICATE
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved today a new but temporary tax-exempt savings certificate that is being promoted by the thrift industry as a way to rescue savings and loan associations now operating at a deficit.

title: SAV-A-STOP INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
WEAVER APPEARS ABOUT TO LOSE TITLE
description: The World Boxing Association, by a 16-0 vote of its executive committee today, in effect stripped Mike Weaver of his heavyweight title for not fighting the third-ranked contender, James (Quick) Tillis, but instead signing to meet the top-ranked challenger, Gerry Cooney.

title: CITY DETAILS PLAN TO SHIFT DEVELOPMENT TO THE WEST SIDE
description: In an effort to shift development from the congested East Side of midtown Manhattan to the less developed West Side, the City Planning Commission yesterday proposed a set of zoning and tax incentives to encourage the construction of office and residential buildings west of the Avenue of the Americas.

title: MANY FLIGHT CONTROLLERS WANT TO REJECT NEW CONTRACT
description: The air traffic controllers' union has been beseiged by members critical of a tentative contract reached earlier this week and many want to reject it, a spokesman for the union said today.

title: Notes On People
description: McG. Thomas Jr. A Home Away From Home for the Royal Couple

title: Around the World; Judge Clears Mrs. Peron Of Misuse of Funds
description: A federal judge acquitted former President Isabel Martinez de Peron today of charges that she had misused executive funds, increasing the possibility that she might be freed next month.

title: DIFFERENCE DENIED BY MRS. KIRKPATRICK
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick today rejected assertions that she had differed with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and supported a Security Council draft resolution that would have imposed sanctions against Israel for bombing an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: PLAYERS KEEP BUSY IN VARIED WAYS
description: Hi! This is Rick. How you doing? I'm out on strike. I'm going down to the unemployment line. I need a job. I can sing a little bit, dance, tell jokes, anything. I can even play baseball once in a while. Why don't you let me know. Leave your number.

title: DETROIT'S MAYOR RINGS IN VICTORY ON CITY TAX RISE and Council President Erma Henderson
description: With a resounding victory in his drive to increase the city's income tax behind him, Mayor Coleman A. Young now faces the tasks of obtaining wage concessions from several municipal unions and convincing lenders there is hope for the city's shaky finances.

title: MINNESOTA MAN, 23, KILLS HIMSELF TRYING RUSSIAN ROULETTE AT PARTY
description: A 23-year-old man shot himself in the head in a game of Russian roulette apparently inspired by watching the movie ''The Deer Hunter'' on television, the Anoka County Sheriff's Department said today.

title: BENTLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 100 percent stock divd paid in May 1981

title: DALLAS BANK TAKEOVER
description: The Republic of Texas Corporation said today that it had agreed in principle to acquire the First National Bank of Sherman, Tex., for about $3.8 million, based on the $45.625 price of Republic stock on the New York Stock Exchange today.

title: FABRI-CENTERS IN BID
description: Fabri-Centers of America Inc., a Cleveland-based specialty fabric stores chain operator, said it had signed a definitive agreement with Discount Fabrics Inc. of Portland, Ore., to acquire its chain of about 50 specialty fabric stores operating in the Northwest and the province of British Columbia. The purchase price is expected to be about $3.3 million. Fabri-Centers operates more than 525 stores in 26 states and the District of Columbia.

title: N.&W. ACQUISITION
description: The Norfolk and Western Railway, one of the nation's largest bituminous coal carriers, said it had received Interstate Commerce Commission approval to acquire the Illinois Terminal Railroad, a 420-mile-long bridge line in Illinois and Missouri. N.& W., which currently owns about 18 percent of the stock in Illinois Terminal, will pay $25,000 each to seven railroads also owning stock, assume $5.3 million of first mortgage bonds, and pay the $250,000 annual rent for the McKinley toll bridge over the Mississippi River.

title: DAYAN SAYS ISRAELIS HAVE THE CAPACITY TO PRODUCE A-BOMBS
description: Moshe Dayan, the former Defense Minister and Foreign Minister, said today that Israel had developed the capacity to produce nuclear weapons, and could manufacture bombs ''in a short time'' should the Arabs do so.

title: WORLD BANK LENDS TO CHINA
description: The World Bank today announced the approval of a $200 million loan to China -its first to that country. China's effort to develop higher education in science and engineering will be helped by two moves, the World Bank said.

title: PLAN WITHDRAWN TO MOVE BRUINS TO NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Delaware North Companies has given up plans to move the Boston Bruins to New Hampshire. Donald Carmichael, head of Delaware North, a Buffalo-based sports conglomerate, said today that New Hampshire had made it impossible for the company to rebuild the burned-out Rockingham Park race track in Salem, its proposed new home for the Bruins.

title: MAJORITY IN CONGRESS URGE REAGAN NOT TO SELL AWACS TO SAUDI ARABIA
description: A majority in the Senate and the House urged President Reagan today to cancel the proposed sale to Saudi Arabia of highly sophisticated electronic surveillance planes known as Awacs. However, a White House spokesman said the sale would be pushed.

title: STATE MAY TELL GALLERIES TO GIVE FACTS ON PRINTS
description: To protect the growing number of people who buy prints - affordable Rauschenbergs, for instance, rather than Rembrandt oils - the State Legislature is considering a measure that would require dealers, auctioneers and other sellers to disclose basic information about artistic ''multiples,'' including photographs, so that the public can have legal recourse in case of deception.

title: MORGENTHAU AND STUDY PANEL HEAD OPPOSE LEGAL CASINO GAMBLING BILL
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan and Dr. Gerald W. Lynch, who headed the state panel that studied casino gambling, said yesterday that legalized gambling casinos would promote crime and corruption.

title: Andrew Savulich FIRE HALTS SERVICE ON IRT
description: Firemen and medical aide assist passenger last night after fire broke out on an IRT express train at Grand Central.

title: Advertising; TIME TEAM PLANS CABLE MAGAZINE;
description: TIME INC., which is both the country's largest magazine publisher and cable systems operator, is apparently planning a new magazine to serve the nation's growing number of cable subscribers.

title: SAUDI WARNING TO TOYOTA
description: Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, Rokusuke Tanaka, confirmed today that Saudi Arabia had warned the Toyota Motor Company of possible retaliatory action by the Arab League if it concluded a joint production agreement with the Ford Motor Company.

title: POTTERY EXHIBIT FEATURES CURRENT AMERICAN ARTISTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Roslyn Siegel is a freelance who writes frequently about the arts. By ROSLYN SIEGEL

title: A NEW BREED OF NURSES NEEDS TO BRING NURSING BACK TO THE BEDSIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JUNE 25, 1981; The Economy
description: Prospects dimmed for House adoption of the budget cuts sought by the White House. House Democratic leaders thwarted President Reagan by agreeing upon separate votes on the package's six parts. Outraged Republican leaders vowed a floor fight to enable the President's proposal to be voted upon as a single package. (Page A1.) The House Ways and Means Committee, as the Senate Finance Committee had done earlier, approved a tax-exempt savings certificate as a way to help savings and loan associations. (D14.)

title: Technology; LUBRICATION IN SPACE AGE;
description: WHEN a door in your home starts to squeak, you squirt a bit of oil on the hinge. When the carefully packaged antenna on a space capsule sticks together instead of unfolding on command, the problem is the same - poor lubrication -but oil is not the answer.

title: Letters; WHILE WE WAIT FOR 'BATTER UP!'; * To the Editor:     Oh, somewhere in this favored land the sun is shining bright; The band is playing somewhere, and somewhere hearts are light, And somewhere men are laughing, and somewhere shouts a tyke; But there is no joy in Mudville - mighty Casey is out on strike.  (With apologies to the late Ernest Lawrence Thayer.) RON ROSS
description: Arlington, Va., June 17, 1981

title: Lewis Says Controllers' Accord Is Government's Top Money Offer
description: Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis warned today that there would be no more money for air traffic controllers if they rejected the tentative contract agreement that their union reached with the Government.

title: MCENROE, CONNORS ADVANCE, KATHY RINALDI LOSES AT WIMBLEDON
description: John McEnroe quietly made his way into the third round at Wimbledon today, and Jimmy Connors grunted his way there. But Roscoe Tanner, Brian Gottfried, Brian Teacher, Peter Fleming and Kathy Rinaldi were surprising second-round losers.

title: ART: GROUP SHOW BY SEVEN AT BORGENICHT GALLERY
description: THE character of ''Episodes,'' a group show by seven relatively unknown artists at Grace Borgenicht (724 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street) is uncommon, to say the least. The paintings, all figurative, are visually quite plain - none of the rococo paint effects now in vogue -and they are often spiked with tart humor. There are some mysteries but, on the whole, the feeling is of sensibilities trying very hard to communicate.

title: Advertising; K.&E. GETS HELPING HAND ON CHRYSLER ACCOUNT
description: John J. Morrissey, chairman of Kenyon & Eckhardt, has gotten a real heavyweight to join him in the Detroit office as No.2 man on the big, big Chrysler account. He is R. William McNealy Jr., 53, who before a brief tour as president and chief operating officer of AMF, was vice chairman of American Motors.

title: 3,000 APPLY FOR 236 GOVERNMENT-SUBSIDIZED APARTMENTS I SOUTH BRONX
description: The chance to apply for 236 new Government-subsidized apartments drew a crowd of 3,000 to 4,000 people to the South Bronx yesterday morning. The size of the turnout for the relatively few apartments led the head of the community group that had built the project to criticize the Reagan Administration's plan to reduce housing subsidies.

title: Dolphins' Griese Ends 14-Year Career
description: Bob Griese, the onetime star whose latest comeback was thwarted by a shoulder injury, announced his retirement today after 14 years as a pro quarterback, all with the Miami Dolphins.

title: 10TH JAZZ FESTIVAL GOES SINGING AND DRUMMING IN
description: THE first weekend of New York's 10th consecutive summer jazz festival, which opens this afternoon, will highlight jazz drumming, jazz singing and jazz tradition, indoors and outdoors, live and on film.

title: No Headline
description: Tuition Plan Dropped in St. Louis

title: No Headline
description: Mayor Koch and Luesther T. Mertz receiving flowers yesterday from neighborhood children before Mr. Koch spoke at ground-breaking for reconstruction of the Elgin Theater, at Eighth Avenue and 19th Street, as a dance theater.

title: CORRECTION
description: A sports article yesterday about hearings by the State Racing and Wagering Board incorrectly identified the president of the Jockeys Guild. The organization's president is Bill Shoemaker.

title: HOLLY SUGAR DISSIDENTS
description: The head of a New York investment group said today that the group ''will continue its campaign to oust the present board'' of the Holly Sugar Company, despite a setback from a Federal judge.

title: ALCAN CHALLENGES CALIFORNIA TAX POLICY
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. filed suit challenging a policy it claims unlawfully requires its United States unit, the Alcan Aluminum Corporation, based in Cleveland, to pay California state franchise taxes based on the parent company's worldwide income.

title: PHONE RATE CHANGES APPROVED
description: The Federal Communications Commission authorized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today to begin applying a series of telephone rate increases, including a 16 percent increase for interstate long-distance calls.

title: BRUNO 'FAMILY' GETS NEW BOSS, AGENT TESTIFIES
description: An organized-crime specialist for the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Nicodemo Scarfo of Atlantic City was the new boss of the Bruno crime ''family'' in Philadelphia, Atlantic City and southern New Jersey.

title: 'STRIPES' AND THE BIGGEST WISE GUY IN THE ARMY
description: ''STRIPES'' is a lazy but amiable comedy presenting Bill Murray as the biggest wise guy ever to wind up in the Army. Like ''Cheech and Chong's Nice Dreams,'' with which it will doubtless compete for the audience that is young, cheerful and none too particular, ''Stripes'' takes a lot for granted. The chief thing it counts on is a built-in appreciation of the Murray sense of humor, which is growing ever more refined as Mr. Murray proceeds with his movie career. Mr. Murray hasn't yet reached the point at which his routines can be sustained for more than 10 minutes at a time. But he has achieved a sardonically exaggerated calm that can be very entertaining.

title: ASARCO TO SELL SHARES TO M.I.M. HOLDINGS
description: The Asarco Corporation, one of the world's leading producers of silver, copper, lead and zinc, said it had agreed to sell 2.5 million of its treasury shares to M.I.M. Holdings Ltd., an Australian metals producer, for $56.50 a share, or a total of $141.25 million.

title: REAGAN'S PLAN WINS AS DEMOCRATS SPLIT IN HOUSE ON BUDGET
description: A coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats in the House of Representatives, spurred by President Reagan's personal lobbying, today overturned the Democratic leadership and laid the parliamentary groundwork for adoption of the White House budget cuts in a single package.

title: FARM CO-OP PLANS SALE OF DEBENTURES
description: The first public issue of long-term debt ever offered by an agricultural cooperative was announced this week by Farmland Industries. It plans to sell $100 million of 25-year debentures through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio air play. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.
