title: LILLY IN ANOTHER PACT ON GENETIC RESEARCH
description: Eli Lilly & Company, the large pharmaceutical concern, and the International Plant Research Institute, a private California company, announced a joint effort at genetic research intended to improve crop yields. The agreement grants Lilly marketing rights to any new products resulting from International's research into plant breeding in exchange for research funding.

title: TRADE SECRETS BILL APPROVED
description: The State Senate and Assembly gave unanimous approval today to legislation that would prohibit state agencies from divulging sensitive trade secrets, submitted by businesses and industries in their dealings with the government, to outside sources.

title: THE STAGE: 'SCENES AND REVELATIONS'
description: THERE are no meaty scenes and no exciting revelations in Elan Garonzik's ''Scenes and Revelations,'' the play that opened at the Circle in the Square last night. This is an evening of splintery, arty tableaux vivants that delineate the broad outlines of a family drama without ever coalescing to become the drama itself. Because most of the tableaux are derivative of far superior plays, it comes as no great surprise to learn, courtesy of the Playbill, that Mr. Garonzik first created this work as a university master's project. ''Scenes and Revelations'' sums up a theatrical education without transcending it.

title: Around the world; Fourth Spanish Officer Arrested in Alleged Plot
description: The police have arrested a fourth Spanish Army officer for alleged involvement in a new anti-Government plot that reportedly included tapping of the telephones of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo and other officials, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: PENN CENTRAL CREDIT
description: The Penn Central Corporation said it had established a new $600 million, eight-year revolving credit agreement with a group of 14 domestic banks. The new accord replaces a $400 million revolving credit agreement established in November 1979 with the same banks. Richard Dicker, chairman and chief executive, said the expanded credit line might be used for ''existing operations or potential acquisitions, or both.''

title: AT CARAMOOR, THE MUSIC IS DOMINATED BY A HOUSE
description: The spirit of Tanglewood emanates from the Boston Symphony. Marlboro has its Serkin family. But the personality of Westchester's Caramoor Festival, whose summer of music begins tomorrow evening, is dominated by a house.

title: The Region; Del Tufo Tells Court Of Abscam Concern
description: Robert J. Del Tufo, who was United States Attorney for New Jersey at the time of the Abscam investigation, testified that he was ''deeply concerned about some of the investigative techniques'' used against Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey in the undercover Federal inquiry.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A fourth suspect was arrested in the wounding of two armored-car guards during a robbery at the Hunts Point Terminal Market in which $250,000 in checks and cash were taken two weeks ago. The suspect, Terence Maxwell, 26 years old, of 820 Colgate Avenue, the Bronx, was charged with attempted murder. ... A resident of the Palace Hotel at 315 Bowery was stabbed in front of a men's shelter two blocks away at 8 East Third Street.

title: SEARCHING FOR SURVIVORS ON MOUNT RAINIER
description: In a photograph made moments after 11 members of a climbing party in Washington State were buried under an avalanche of ice, five mountaineers search in the snow for survivors. None of the 11 were found. Cordell Berge of Eugene, Ore., a member of the party, took the picture.

title: NO PROGRESS IS SEEN
description: As legal maneuvering in baseball's two-week-old strike intensified, negotiators for the players and the club owners spent more time in talks at the Doral Inn yesterday than they had at any other time since the strike began. But they made no progress toward settling the dispute that has forced cancellation of 169 games and has become the longest strike in baseball history.

title: A Windjammer Weekend At Mystic Seaport
description: Schooners from Maine, Massachusetts, Long Island, upstate New York, New Jersey and other Eastern ports will set sail this weekend for a windjammer weekend at the Mystic Seaport Museum in Connecticut. About 30 vessels will be docked and open for viewing tomorrow and Sunday at the museum and at a pier in downtown Mystic.

title: JERSEY APPROVES BROAD REVISIONS N WATER POLICY
description: After three days of intensive lobbying by the Byrne administration, New Jersey's Legislature today approved a $350 million water-supply bond issue and two bills that would give the state broad powers to deal with allocation of water and to prevent future water shortages.

title: AS ROYAL WEDDING NEARS, SOCIAL WHIRL INTENSIFIES
description: As the London social season races toward the crescendo of The Wedding, it has acquired in this special year a glamour not seen in decades.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Times yesterday on opposition to the sale of Awacs aircraft to Saudi Arabia incorrectly reported the party affiliation of Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon. Mr. Packwood is a Republican.

title: INLAND EXPANSION
description: The Inland Steel Company said that it would build a continuous anneal line at its plant near Chicago that would be capable of processing up to 400,000 tons a year of high-strength, light-weight sheet steel. That steel is used in large amounts by the auto industry. Inland, which ranks seventh in terms of raw steel production, did not disclose the cost of the project which was due to completed in 1983.

title: Broadway; Orson Bean to make directing debut with play by Casey Kelly.
description: SOME years ago Orson Bean quit working -except for frequent guest appearances on ''The Tonight Show'' to keep his name alive - and for the next decade went globe hopping in search of new adventures. The entertainer returned to work a year and a half ago, but his quest for new adventures is far from over. Mr. Bean plans to make his debut as a Broadway director next season with ''Grand's Finale,'' a new comedy by Casey Kelly, making her debut as a Broadway playwright. The producer is Karen Wald, also making her Broadway debut. Miss Wald hopes to open ''Grand's Finale'' in October.

title: PEARCE URSTADT MAYER & GREER reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $61,000 for the qr and $93,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including $266,000 gain on the sale of a foreclosed property

title: YET ANOTHER CASINO CAPER
description: Casino gambling has been declared dead often enough in New York to convince the most skeptical coroner. Nevertheless, Governor Carey's recent remarks on the economic potential of casinos may have given them breath enough to put a little mist on the legislative mirror. That is bad news for those who don't like roulette wheels and are tired of political deals.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including $98,000 income from discontinued operations; yr-ago results have been restated to include a 50 percent equity investment in Brown Camera Inc and to reflect discontinu operations

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The reason women are exempt from registration is not because military needs can be met by drafting men.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
GERMAN AUTO OUTPUT
description: Motor vehicle production in West Germany was generally steady in May at 16,994 vehicles a day, a trade association said today. This was slightly up from daily production of 16,799 in April, but below average daily production of 17,407 in May 1980. Car output in May was down 2 percent, at 296,300, from 301,340 a year ago, and below the 309,800 in April, when there were more working days, the group added.

title: Brazilian Envoy in Israel Leaves for Consultation
description: Ambassador Vasco Mariz of Brazil flew home yesterday for consultations in connection with a report that an Israeli secret agent had tried to ''plant'' an account alleging that Brazil had supplied uranium for the Iraqi nuclear reactor destroyed on June 7.

title: DEPOSITION CONNECTS VASQUEZ TO BRIBE OFFER
description: A former New York-based trainer has identified Jacinto Vasquez, a leading rider who has twice won the Kentucky Derby, as the man who offered the jockey Mike Hole a $5,000 bribe to hold back a horse at Saratoga in 1974, according to a deposition given to the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: The U.N. Today; June 26, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Development Pro- gram Governing Council - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Letters; A NUCLEAR ARMS BAN PROMOTED BY ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; Roger Moore is anybody's replacement.
description: THE latest James Bond thriller, ''For Your Eyes Only,'' opens today in 1,100 American and Canadian theaters, as Roger Moore charges once more unto the breach. (For a review, see page C8.) He doesn't exactly scale the wall at Harflew, but he does appear to hang off a virtually perpendicular mountain in Greece. When he isn't flying a helicopter, he is bobsledding (actually, the other guys are on bobsleds; Mr. Moore is on his backside), fighting underwater or chasing cars, girls and the plot, which moves very fast.

title: Executive Changes
description: * Bank of New York Company and Bank of New York have elected Robert J. Goebert secretary.

title: PLAYING AT THE WHITNEY: WHAT MAKES MICKEY RUN
description: Such goings on at the Whitney Museum! Mickey and Minnie Mouse careening in a plane, Pluto falling down in a complicated way, Goofy doing a double-take, a skeleton dancing and Rat apologizing haughtily to Toad. That is only a tiny sample of the motion - on paper and film - in a large exhibition on view through Sept. 6 that examines the animation techniques of the Walt Disney studio.

title: A $5.7 BILLION BUDGET IS APPROVED IN JERSEY
description: The State Assembly gave final legislative approval today to a $5.7 billion budget for the 1982 fiscal year beginning July 1. The vote was 42 to 31.

title: CARVEL TRADEMARK CASE DISMISSED
description: A Federal judge dismissed a contention by the Carvel ice cream chain that a Long Island catering organization that manufactures and sells a frozen dessert called Parvelle was infringing on its trademark.

title: CAR-RENTAL AGENCIES GIRD FOR HOLIDAY
description: The car-rental industry's booming summer business in New York City is divided into three peaks: the Memorial Day, Fourth of July and Labor Day weekends.

title: BANKS IN COMPROMISE TO DEFER POLISH DEBT
description: A group of international banks agreed today to general terms of a compromise plan for deferring repayment of about $2.37 billion in bank debt that Poland is scheduled to pay this year.

title: The Region; Transit Report
description: The 4:23 P.M. train bound for North White Plains ran 10 minutes late when a man riding outside of the train had to be removed.

title: Belgium Says East Is Obsessed With Secrecy in Troop-Cut Talks
description: Belgium accused the Warsaw Pact countries today of an outmoded preoccupation with secrecy in opposing measures to monitor troop levels in Europe.

title: Around the Nation; 14 Persons Are Injured In Puerto Rico Prison Riot
description: Inmates rioted for three hours today in Puerto Rico's largest prison, the police said. Eleven prisoners and three guards were reported injured.

title: Outdoor Folk Dancing
description: Free international folk dancing sessions will be held every weekend through the summer and into the fall at three sites around the city.

title: ART: AMERICAN FINDS OF A GRAND COLLECTOR
description: IF ''American Artists in the A.E. Gallatin Collection'' does not grab you as a title, please be assured that the exhibition commemorates one of the great moments in the cultural history of our city. (The show can be seen at the Washburn Gallery, 42 East 57th Street, through July 31.)

title: CONSERVATIVES ARE GENERALLY PLEASED, FEMINISTS DISMAYED BY COURT'S
description: RULING By COLIN CAMPBELL

title: Around the Nation; Boy Disputes Testimony Of Kidnapping Suspect
description: Young Timmy White took the witness stand today to testify against Kenneth Parnell, the man charged with kidnapping him, and said he had never seen the man that Mr. Parnell maintains was the abductor.

title: PERES AND BEGIN DO BATTLE ON TV AS ELECTION NEARS Prime Minister Menachem
description: Shimon Peres, chairman of the opposition Labor Party, launched a strong attack today on the record of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government as the two major candidates in next Tuesday's election faced each other for their only televised debate of the campaign.

title: CARIBBEAN ASSETS SALE
description: The Exxon Corporation said today that it is selling its assets in the British Virgin Islands, Anguilla, Grenada, St. Barthelemy, St. Kitts-Nevis, Saint Lucia, St. Maarten, St. Vincent and a few adjoining dependencies to the Shell Antillas and Guianas Company. Exxon said that the transfer of its assets and inventories in Esso Standard Oil S.A. should be completed by Aug. 1 and necessary arrangements had been made to insure normal supplies to consumers.

title: F.A.A. TO REVIEW PLANS TO MOVE OFFICE TO BOSTON AREA
description: After hearing protests from New York officials, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it was reviewing plans to close its regional office at Kennedy International Airport and transfer many of the 441 employees there to the Boston area.

title: Jersey to Study 2 Mishaps In One Race at Monmouth
description: The New Jersey Racing Commission plans to investigate two accidents at Monmouth Park that resulted in injuries to one jockey and the killing of three horses.

title: Energy Watch
description: JUNE 19, 1981 Crude oil inventories surged to 410.9 million barrels, up 6.9 million.

title: The Evening Hours
description: M ORTON Gottlieb is better known as a Broadway producer than as ''a nose,'' but a nose he was at a fragrance testing held at the Vanessa restaurant on Bleecker Street on Wednesday. The restaurant has decided that, like the old Stork Club, it will have its own unisex perfume to give to good customers, and perhaps sell in limited quantities, and the noses were on hand to sniff four scents, inspect four bottles and choose their favorite.

title: 3 REAGAN AIDES AFFIRM FEDERAL SUPPORT FOR BASIC SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH
description: Three high-ranking members of the Reagan Administration said today that the Federal Government should be the main backer of fundamental scientific research in the United States and suggested that such basic research, while subject to significant shifts in emphasis, would probably be spared for the most part in future budget cutting.

title: CHANGES PROPOSES IN FOOD SAFETY LAW
description: Legislation that would make sweeping changes in the nation's food safety laws was introduced in Congress today. It is expected to find considerable sympathy in the Senate but to face a tougher audience in the House.

title: TV Weekend; FLYING WOMEN IN WAR AND 'CINDERELLA'
description: ''SILVER WINGS and Santiago Blue,'' an hourlong documentary on WNET-TV tomorrow at 10:20 P.M., recounts the story of 1,000 women who served as pilots for the military during World War II. It begins at a Congressional hearing where, 35 years later, many of these women were finally awarded the official military status they had been promised in the beginning.

title: BOND IN 'FOR YOUR EYES ONLY'
description: FORGET about the relationship of this planet to the sun. Whenever possible, summer officially begins with the release of a new James Bond film - that is, today, with the opening at Loews State 1 and other theaters of ''For Your Eyes Only,'' the 12th in the phenomenally successful series of movies that was initiated almost 20 years ago with ''Dr. No.''

title: Letters; ZOOS ARE NO PLACE TO RESCUE PERILED SPECIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Driving Rain and Gusting Winds Buffet the Metropolitan Area
description: Theatergoers carried their folding umbrellas at half-staff to keep them from being turned inside out last night as 50-mile-an-hour winds drove horizontal sheets of rain across the city. Shubert Alley was temporarily closed and police officers diverted pedestrians away from tall buildings after pieces of glass reportedly fell into West 44th Street. Heavy thunderstorms knocked out power to 50,000 homes, with the most severe storms hitting the South Shore of central Long Island and parts the Jersey Coast.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
The city; Contract Approved For Wards I. Shelter
description: Over the objections of community residents, the Board of Estimate unanimously approved a $2.1 million contract with the Volunteers of America to run a shelter for homeless men on Wards Island. The shelter has drawn complaints from area residents for exposing neighborhood children to homeless and - the residents contend - dangerous men.

title: SEAGRAM RAISES BID FOR CONOCO
description: Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, the United States subsidiary of the huge Canadian liquor company, offered $2.5 billion yesterday for 40.7 percent of the outstanding shares of Conoco, the nation's ninthlargest oil company. Hours after the announcement by Seagram, the foreign suitor that Conoco had turned away last week, Cities Service called off its merger discussions with Conoco.

title: ALL THE FILMS OF SATYAJIT RAY AT THE MODERN
description: IN the world of cinema there have been two Satyajit Rays. To those who sought his work in the art houses and universities of the West, Mr. Ray has been the director who struggled against great odds to produce spare and sensitive films on the lives of unknown Indians - a poor Bengali making films about poor Bengalis. Closer to his Calcutta home, however, Mr. Ray has been a box-office success, attracting audiences of all ages by ranging over country and city, reality and fantasy, sadness and humor.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1981
description: International An accord on a new Sinai peace force to patrol the vast desert after the scheduled final withdrawal of Israel from the Egyptian territory next April 25 was announced by Egypt, Israel and the United States. The agreement must be ratified by the Egyptian and Israeli parliaments, but the senior American negotiator seemed confident of their approval. The multinational force of 2,000 to 3,000 members may include 800 Americans. (Page A1, Column 6.) A sharp cut in Britain's naval forces to permit development of the Trident nuclear missile system was set in a major restructuring of defenses. Despite the cuts, the British Government insisted it was holding to its commitment to NATO to increase military spending by 3 percent a year after adjustment for inflation. (A8:3-6.)

title: The Editorial Notebook; THE VENEZUELA STRATEGY
description: Energy independence: four years ago economists dismissed the idea as an impossible dream. It would be difficult enough, they argued, to hold oil imports to current levels.

title: 2 KEY SENATORS OPPOSE MISSILES FOR THEIR STATES
description: Two influential Republican Senators, Paul Laxalt of Nevada and Jake Garn of Utah, announced today that they would oppose the deployment of MX mobile missiles in their home states.

title: Business People; FIRST PRESIDENT CHOSEN AT GULF AND WESTERN UNIT
description: James I. Spiegel, 52, has been named the first president of the apparel and home furnishings group of Gulf and Western Industries, the New York-based conglomerate. The group -which encompasses the Kayser-Roth Corporation, the Simmons Company and Simmons Universal - had sales in the fiscal year ended last July 31 of about $1.4 billion and operating earnings of $83.3 million.

title: 'Tosca' in East Meadow
description: A free performance of Puccini's ''Tosca'' will be presented by the Metropolitan Opera tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at Eisenhower Park on Hempstead Turnpike in East Meadow, L.I. Directed by Angelo Campori, the cast features Galina Savova, Carlo Bini, Peter Glossop and William Fleck. If it rains, the performance will be held Sunday. Information: 580-9830.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1981; The Economy
description: The way was paved for passage of the President's budget cuts. Handing President Reagan a stunning victory, a coalition of Republicans and conservative Democrats foiled the attempt by the House Democratic leadership to split into six separate votes the President's request for $5.2 billion in additional budget cuts. Instead, the House will vote on the cuts as a package, thus increasing the likelihood they will not be changed. (Page A1.)

title: Dr. Ralph F. Schneider, 71, Dies; Medical Director of Exxon Corp.
description: Dr. Ralph F. Schneider, retired medical director of the Exxon Corporation, died Sunday at Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I., and Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: LEONARD AND HEARNS VICTORS BY KNOCKOUTS
description: For several moments, it all trembled precariously on Sugar Ray Leonard's shaky legs. His second world championship, the $13 million fight with Thomas Hearns, it was all very shaky.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Advertising; OLD TYME GINGER BEER PROMOTION
description: ' 'What nut would come into the New York market and try to sell another soft drink?'' asked Alice O'Leary, president of Fearon/ O'Leary, as she began her lively tale about a new client who is about to try just that.

title: CALNY FOOD SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to May 23
News Analysis
description: A proposal by Mayor Koch to expand the New York City Board of Education to 11 members from seven has reopened a debate over what sort of board would best serve the city's 945,000-pupil public school system.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; IT'S TANGLEWOOD TIME AGAIN
description: Alfresco music lovers come into their own this weekend with the start of various summer festivals. The best known of them all, Tanglewood, in Lenox, Mass., gets under way tonight at 8:30, when the Boston Symphony Chamber Players, members of the Guarneri String Quartet and Gilbert Kalish, the pianist, play string quintets by Beethoven and Mozart and Bartok's ''Contrasts'' for clarinet, violin and piano. Lawn tickets are $4; tickets to the Theater-Concert Hall are $7 and $10. They may be obtained at Ticketron outlets or the Tanglewood box office. To charge, call (617) 426-8383. The site is three and a half hours from New York City. There are four daily buses from the Port Authority. By car, take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway or the Taconic State Parkway to Route 90 and get off at Exit 1 or 2. Information: (413) 637-1940.

title: 7 Drivers Are Suing CART Over Ban on USAC Races
description: Seven Indy car drivers have filed suit in Federal court against the Championship Auto Racing Teams, seeking to run in Sunday's twin 125-mile races at Atlanta International Raceway.

title: THE MAN BEHIND BALLET'S ASHTON TOUCK
description: The impulse for one of his ballets came to Sir Frederick Ashton in the bath. For another, it was the desire to sweep out a cluttered corner of English ballet. A third dance grew out of regret that a ravishing piece of ballet music lay untouched. In such homely fashion were ''Scenes de Ballet,'' ''Symphonic Variations'' and ''Daphnis and Chloe'' conceived, three signatures works to be danced by the Royal Ballet tonight and next week at the Metropolitan Opera House. But then it is important to remember that the shyly rumbustious stepsister in his ''Cinderella,'' a role in which he was much admired, is as much a part of the choreographer's personality as his lucid inventions, which have shaped English ballet for the last 55 years.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Habib Returning to U.S.  To Consult on Mideast
description: Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, departed for Washington today for new consultations scheduled to take him out of the Middle East during the Israeli elections next Tuesday.

title: Letters; WHILE WE WAIT FOR 'BATTER UP'
description: To the Editor:

title: MCI IN PACT WITH IOWA PHONE CONCERN
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, a competitor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said it had signed its first contract with an independent local phone company that provides it the same access to customers enjoyed by A.T.&T.

title: Market Place; RUSSELL RIDES ATHLETICS BOOM
description: THE American passion for athletics is helping a rejuvenated Russell Corporation earn higher profits. Russell makes uniforms for all sports and enjoys a dominant position in uniforms manufactured for professionals. But that is a minor aspect of the sports clothing market. Some 99 percent of the uniforms sold in the nation go to schools, amateur athletic associations and individuals. Russell has an estimated 35 percent of the total market.

title: WITTER, DEAN, REYNOLDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ART: NEARLY 400 PIECES AT 'RODIN REDISCOVERED'
description: WASHINGTON EXCEPT for Picasso in the later years of his life, when his art declined and his reputation soared, no artist in the last 100 years has achieved an international renown equal to that enjoyed by the French sculptor Auguste Rodin (1840-1917). In the legendary belle epoque that preceded World War I, Rodin was universally looked on as an artistic colossus - at once the heir and equal of the great masters of the past and a giant among the artists of the modern age. Virtually every sculptor who came to maturity in the heyday of Rodin's fame felt the force of his influence, and either openly rebelled against it or succumbed to its overwhelming power.

title: FACELIFT BEGINS AT RENAMED ELGIN
description: A ground-breaking and renaming ceremony for the Elgin Theater took place yesterday morning, with Mayor Koch and dancers, choreographers and members of the New York State Council on the Arts and the National Endowment for the Arts in attendance.

title: AMERICAN PAD AND PAPER (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
DOUBT GREETS CURBS BY JAPAN
description: Japan's decision to reduce auto exports to the United States by 7.7 percent in 1981 will not help Detroit this year, a Ford Motor Company senior executive said here today.

title: Around the Nation; Republican Wins Narrowly In Ohio Congressional Vote
description: A Republican state legislator won a narrow victory over a Democratic lawmaker tonight in a special election to fill the Congressional seat of Representative Tennyson Guyer, who died in April.

title: The City
description: Pending an expected appeal, a Federal judge has stayed his recent ruling that two stolen 15th-century paintings by Albrecht Durer must be returned to an East German museum by a New York lawyer and art collector.

title: Advertising; KELLOGG MAPS CAMPAIGN FOR ITS NUTRI-GRAIN CEREAL
description: Suddenly the Kellogg Company, the dominant force in the country's dry cereal business, has four new products, but that doesn't come as much of a surprise to the industry, which has been getting bits and pieces from the trade press since William E. LaMothe, chairman, slipped out a teaser line at the annual meeting six weeks ago.

title: FEDERAL BOARD MODIFIES THE RULES FOR SMOKING ON AIRLINER FLIGHTS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board decided today that airline passengers who arrive late for flights no longer will have an absolute right to a seat in a no-smoking section, probably beginning this summer.

title: HAIG MEETS REAGAN, VOICES REGRET ON U. N. DISPUTE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., returning from a two-week trip to the Far East, met with President Reagan today and said afterward that he was ''sorry and disappointed'' about news reports that he and his staff had criticized the performance of Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, and White House officials.

title: 3-D Festival at 8th St.
description: ''House of Wax,'' the horror classic starring Vincent Price, will be shown in 3-D this weekend at the Eighth Street Playhouse, 52 West Eighth Street.

title: David Grossblatt, 61, a Painter And Operator of the Cafe Rienzi
description: David Grossblatt, a painter who operated coffee houses in Greenwich Village, died in his sleep Wednesday morning at his studio on Great Jones Street. He was 61 years old.

title: z; AWACS FOR SAUDIS: CURB ON SOVIET OR PERIL TO ISRAEL?
description: The proposed United States sale to Saudi Arabia of electronic surveillance planes, aerial tankers, and extra fuel tanks, advanced air-to-air missiles and possibly bomb racks for F-15 fighters has provoked controversy about a perceived military threat to Israel.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
Las Vegas Named as Site For Oct. 17 Grand Prix
description: A Grand Prix, only the second Formula One race in the United States this year, will be held Oct. 17 in Las Vegas, organizers announced today.

title: Business People; NEW PRESIDENT OF SIKES WILL SUCCEED FOUNDER
description: Kelly Norton, 42, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of the Sikes Corporation, a leading manufacturer of ceramic floor and wall tile. As president, he will succeed James W. Sikes, 51, who was elected to the vacant post of chairman while continuing as chief executive officer of the company, which has its headquarters in Lakeland, Fla.

title: CHABROL'S 'HIGH HEELS' AND SCHATZBERG'S 'DANDY'
description: CLAUDE CHABROL'S ''High Heels,'' made in 1972 under the title of ''Dr. Popaul,'' and Jerry Schatzberg's ''Dandy, the All-American Girl,'' which received a limited release in 1976 as ''Sweet Revenge,'' is the new double bill in the Thalia Theater's summer series devoted to movies that (sometimes for obvious reasons) haven't previously received commercial engagements here. They will be at the Thalia today and tomorrow.

title: HOLLYWOOD STRATEGY FOR SUMMER FILMS
description: Last December, Warner Brothers decided that instead of releasing its new movie ''Superman II'' during the Christmas season, it would wait until summer. That strategy now seems to be paying off.

title: Notes On People; From the Halls of Congress to an Oil Refinery
description: A follow-up: Before he became a member of the Pennsylvania Legislature and later a United States Representative, Raymond F. Lederer worked in blue-collar jobs such as bartender, doorman, carpet cutter and warehouseman.

title: Foreign Affairs; FRANCO-AMERICAN BLINKERS
description: Within half a year the U.S. and France have had sweeping political upheavals, similar in the sense that incumbents were massively rejected, dissimilar in the direction promised by the new teams.

title: THE PARITY PRINCIPLE IN U.S.-SOVIET RELATIONS lanterns that illuminate missiles in the background
description: The question is fateful and urgent: Why is detente, the only sane alternative in the nuclear age, in deep crisis, or even, as hardline critics rejoice, dead? More generally, why has every attempt to normalize American-Soviet relations, a process begun by Dwight D. Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev in the mid-1950's, collapsed in political disrepute, with diplomacy giving way to militarization of foreign policy, weapons control to the pursuit of strategic superiority, trade to embargoes, cultural exchanges to ostracism?

title: Westchester Run
description: The sixth Westchester half-marathon, the largest run of its kind in the United States, will be held Sunday through the towns of White Plains, Scarsdale and New Rochelle. About 4,500 runners, a record number for Westchester County, is expected for the 13.1-mile run, which begins at 10 A.M. at the intersection of Paulding Street and Maple Avenue in White Plains.

title: INTERNATIONAL MOGUL MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
COLLINS FOOD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Around the Nation; Kansas City Unit Cuts Ties With 'Stop Child Murders'
description: A Missouri group offering summer vacations to poor children from Atlanta has cut its ties with the Committee to Stop Children's Murders because of what it describes as a ''demoralizing, exploitive stench'' around the deaths of 28 young blacks.

title: ROCK-AND-REEL FESTIVAL AT THE CLURMAN
description: The rock film, which is being celebrated at the Harold Clurman Theater on West 42d Street in daily screenings through July 14, has many meanings. On its simplest level, the term can mean a film of a rock concert. On a slightly more elevated level, it can be a documentary that concentrates on performance footage, but which also includes backstage glimpses, depictions of life on the road and insights into the character of the musicians involved.

title: DEAN WITTER INCOME GAINS
description: Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. announced yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter ended May 31 increased 14.4 percent, to $12.7 million, or $1.15 a share, from $11.1 million, or $1.10 a share, in the corresponding fiscal quarter a year earlier. Revenues increased 23.8 percent, to $225.5 million, from $182.2 million.

title: Oarswomen Make Waves In Lifeboat Races
description: Correction: June 27, 1981, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

title: BRITAIN ANNOUNCES DEEP CUTS IN THE NAVY TO PAY FOR NEW TRIDENT SYSTEM
description: Britain unveiled a major defense restructuring today that would significantly reduce conventional naval forces to permit the money to be spent on development of the Trident missile system.

title: RICKOVER LOSING FIGHT TO STOP A BIOGRAPHY
description: Despite strenuous opposition from Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, Simon and Schuster plans to publish a biography of the controversial four-star admiral who founded and led the development of the nation's nuclear navy.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard RIDDLEY WALKER. By Russell Hoban. 220 pages. Summit Books. $12.95.

title: Martha Albrand, 66, Novelist Who Worked in Suspense Genre
description: Martha Albrand, author of more than 40 novels, many in the genre of mystery and suspense, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 66 years old.

title: DIRECTORS SEEK TO AVERT STRIKE
description: Movie and television directors, hoping to avoid a strike, attacked the main obstacle in negotiations with producers and proposed a new way of dividing pay-television earnings.

title: SUN MYUNG MOON FOCUS OF MOON IMMIGRATION INQUIRY
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has been conducting an investigation to determine whether the Rev. Sun Myung Moon and hundreds of his followers in the Unification Church acted improperly when they entered the United States, an official said today.

title: CP TO IMPROVE TRACK
description: CP Rail, the railway unit of Canadian Pacific Ltd., said today that it would spend $500 million (Canadian funds) improving its track through Rogers Pass in British Columbia. The mountain project will include building two tunnels totaling 10 miles, constructing 11 bridges and laying 21 miles of additional track.

title: No Headline
description: BREAKDOWN OF VOTERS ON BUDGET MEASURE

title: COMPUTER AND WEATHER DELAY NEW YORK AIR TRAVELERS
description: A computer breakdown and weather troubles caused delays of up to two hours and many flight cancellations at the three major metropolitan New York airports yesterday. Thousands of passengers were affected.

title: Notes On People; There Is a Nurse in the House
description: Since there are seven children in of the Broadway musical ''Annie,'' there are several stage mothers behind the scenes who are worrying about the health and well-being of their offspring.

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-After $106,800 loss from discontinued operations...C-Includin $225,800 or 11 cents a shr extraordinary credit

title: JUSTICE ON THE RUN
description: Not content with the House's move to prohibit the Justice Department from advocating busing in school desegregation cases, Senator Bennett Johnston of Louisiana wants to forbid such Federal court orders altogether.

title: M.T.A. CHIEF PREDICTS RISE IN FARES TO 95
description: WITHOUT TAX ACTION By JUDITH CUMMINGS

title: JAPANESE PRICE INDEX UP
description: Japan's consumer price index rose 1 percent in May, as compared to an eight-tenths of 1 percent April rise, the Prime Minister's office said. The year-to-year rise was 5.4 percent, up from a 5.2 percent April increase.

title: Paul Butler Dead at 89; Top Aviation Executive
description: Paul Butler, founder of Butler Aviation, the nation's biggest general aviation company, was struck and killed last night as he crossed a street near his home here. He was 89 years old.

title: HOW TO BRING INTEREST RATES DOWN
description: There is bipartisan agreement, a national consensus, and a loud international outcry that interest rates in the United States must come down. Double-digit rates are threatening to wreck investment, small business, farmers, housing, construction, the automobile industry, financial markets and institutions, and to hurt some of our staunchest allies.

title: CONWEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $1.1 million gain from discontinued operations... C-After $28,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Around the World; Koreans Mark Anniversary Of War's Outbreak in 1950
description: North Korea observed the 31st anniversary today of the outbreak of the Korean War with anti-American rallies and a warning that dangers of an imminent new conflict has been increased by the Reagan Administration.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results reflect foreign currency translation losses equal to 32 cents a shr and 47 cents a shr for the latest qr and 6 mos, respectively, and 14 cents and 5 cents a shr for the previous qr and 6 mos

title: EXODUS OF VIETNAM 'BOAT PEOPLE' CLIMBING BACK TO THE 1979 LEVELS
description: The number of refugees leaving Vietnam on small boats rose in April and May to the highest level in two years, and partial statistics obtained from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees indicate that the rate of departure remains high this month despite heavy monsoon weather in the South China Sea.

title: HEAVY USE OF COCAINE IS LINKED TO SURGE IN DEATHS AND ILLNESSES
description: Cocaine, the drug of choice for dealers, entertainers and the well-to-do seeking a powerful recreational drug with comparatively few dangers, is sending more and more users to the emergency room or the morgue, according to statistics that are emerging around the country.

title: Notes On People; How Do You Use That Lasso, Mr. Secretary?
description: Since he's also a champion-caliber rodeo performer, Malcolm Baldrige is not your ordinary, run-of-the-mill Presidential Cabinet member.

title: Notes On People; Right for the Job
description: After a succession of James Bond movies, Roger Moore may be planning to hang up his license to kill.

title: Credit Markets; NEW 20-YEAR BOND SETS RECORD
description: The Treasury sold 20-year bonds yesterday at an average yield of 13.45 percent, a record for a new issue of that maturity, and one that demonstrated the reluctance of many investors to buy additional long-term bonds.

title: About Real Estate; A PLAN FOR AIDING MITCHELL-LAMA PROGRAM
description: The Carey administration is publicizing a deftly fashioned plan to bring money into the publicly aided housing system while giving the owners of Mitchell-Lama cooperatives the right to realize some of the gain in value of their apartments.

title: Ralph McWilliams, 55, Former Dancer, Is Dead
description: Ralph McWilliams, a former dancer and stage manager with the American Ballet Theater who also appeared on Broadway, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 55 years old.

title: In The Nation; BUSING AFTER A DECADE
description: The irony was not lost upon the sponsors of a dinner honoring attorney Julius L. Chambers and Federal Judge James B. McMillan.

title: NELLISE CHILD
description: Nellise Child Rosenfeld, a novelist and playwright who wrote as Nellise Child, died June 11 in Chicago.

title: JUSTICES, 6-3, RULE DRAFT REGISTRATION MAY EXCLUDE WOMEN
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits Congress to limit draft registration, and presumably the military draft itself, to men.

title: WHEELING STEEL TO ADD NEW CASTERS
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that it would spend $140 million to install continuous casters at its plants in Monessen, Pa., and Steubenville, Ohio.

title: 46 COMMUTERS START THEIR OWN 'LINE'
description: The Toms River rebellion was long in the making. The people who commuted by bus between Toms River, N.J., and New York City had complained for years about rundown vehicles and rude drivers. In the winter they grumbled about the lack of heat; in the summer they cursed the sweltering rides that made corporate men feel as if they were wrapped in wet, pin-striped sponges.

title: Transactions; FOOTBALL MIAMI (AFC) - Announced retirement of Bob Griese, quarterback.
description: NEW ENGLAND (AFC) - Signed Ken T oler, wide receiver from Mississippi who w as seventh-round draft choice, to multi- y ear contract. SOCCER SAN JOSE (NASL) Traded Alan Merrick, midfielder, to Minnesota for future draft choices.

title: The City; Parole Officer Stabbed in Queens
description: A New York State parole officer was stabbed and seriously wounded as he tried to arrest a man in Queens for a parole violation, the police said.

title: HIGH PEKING AIDE IS DUE IN INDIA
description: The Chinese Foreign Minister arrives here tomorrow on a fence-mending mission that could pave the way for a new phase of friendship between India and China.

title: Letters; PROHIBITION REVISITED
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters; KOCH VS. THE WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD BANK PLANS BORROWING IN U.S.
description: The World Bank, which specializes in loans to developing nations, said yesterday that it had completed arrangements for its first borrowing in United States financial markets since July 1977.

title: DOW CHEMICAL YEN BOND
description: The Dow Chemical Company is planning to raise 20 billion yen, or about $90 million at current exchange rates, on the Japanese capital market by offering an unsecured yendenominated bond later this year, securities sources said here today.

title: ORANGE-CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $442,000 loss from the disposition of Arthur Treacher's Chips...C-Net loss after $6,639,000 loss from discontinued oper which included a $5.9 million loss on the disposition of the co Arthur Treacher's unit

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: 1981 net income includes a $12.2 million net gain from the sale of technology for overseas development, proceeds from the settlement of antitrust claims against carton manufacturers and provision for loss on closing of certain vegetable processi facilities and also a $6.6 million gain from sale of the compan ownership an insurance recovery related to an involuntary conve and ownership in an affiliate

title: IRAN CONDUCTING NATIONWIDE
description: HUNT FOR FORMER PERSIDENT AND HIS AIDES

title: Kite Leads Memphis Golf By Shot With 5-Under 67
description: Tom Kite struggled through humid, strengthsapping heat and posted a five-under-par 67 as he took the firstround lead today in the $300,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis Golf Classic.

title: SORCERY AND IMMORTALITY IN 'DRAGONSLAYER'
description: ''DRAGONSLAYER,'' which opens today at the Baronet and other theaters, is a movie that makes you believe what you're seeing is real. Because what you're seeing are fire-breathing dragons and various acts of sorcery, this plausibility is no mean accomplishment. ''Dragonslayer'' has pacing problems, and its special effects tend to be more overpowering than helpful. But it also has a sweetness and conviction that amount to a kind of magic.

title: OCCIDENTAL AND SOVIET IN ACCORD
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, completed arrangements today for resuming the exchange of American phosphates for Soviet ammonia, both fertilizer materials, and left Moscow.

title: The Boxing Jungle, Houston Version
description: HOUSTON THERE were fist fights in the Astrodome, a lot of them, and some were lively but not necessarily more entertaining than the fighting outside the ring. In one corner, wearing red trunks out of respect for the financial bath he expected as promoter of the fisticuffs, was Bob Arum, head of the promotional firm of Top Rank Inc.; in the other was Mike Trainer, the lawyer who handles the affairs of Sugar Ray Leonard. He wore the expression of a man sorely put upon.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 28
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $68,789 for the qr and $615,204 for the yr...C-Net income including $29,712 inc for the qr and $12,148 loss fro the yr from discontinued operat

title: Letters; THE FEDERAL PENSIONER WHO NEVER WAS
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIAM BLISS HARRIS, EX-EDITOR AND WRITER ON GARDENING TOPICS
description: William Bliss Harris, a retired senior editor of Fortune magazine who was also known as ''Amos Pettingill'' to a wide readership of gardening enthusiasts, died Monday in Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. He was 80 years old.

title: THE JAZZ OF SUN RA
description: SUN RA, the composer, bandleader and pianist, has been an enigmatic figure in jazz history. He has led a big band with a stable core of personnel since the late 50's, and his groups were among the first to attempt free form ensemble improvisations. He was also a pioneer of electronics in jazz, first as the owner of one of the earliest electric pianos and later as a champion of the synthesizer. But he has issued his own records, how many nobody seems to know for sure, and mostly kept his own counsel. Attempts to interview him and document the various stages of his career are usually met with ruminations on ancient Egypt, outer space, and Sun Ra's own personal mythology.

title: STATE MUTUAL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $2 million for the latest period and $635,000 for the previous period

title: YANKEE BALLERINA, 17, TOAST OF MOSCOW
description: When Amanda McKerrow danced tonight at the Bolshoi Theater, the audience summoned her back for bows at center stage five times. Only the better Russians get that kind of reception from discriminating Bolshoi regulars, and Miss McKerrow, a 17-year-old from Washington, clearly had made her mark.

title: MISS PIGGY STARS IN 'GREAT MUPPET CAPER'
description: AFTER decades of doing without, moviegoers have a team of stars on which to heap the adoration they once dumped on Nelson Eddy and Jeanette MacDonald. All hail Kermit the Frog and Miss Piggy! They've been around for a while, but their romantic possibilities are the revelation of ''The Great Muppet Caper,'' the new, sometimes riotously unruly Muppet movie that opens today at the Ziegfeld Theater.

title: ANTITRUST ISSUE SNAGS VELSICOL SALE
description: The Federal Trade Commission, in another move to block sale of some assets of the Velsicol Chemical Corporation, has charged that the Great Lakes Chemical Corporation's proposal to purchase the assets for some $29.7 million may violate Federal antitrust law.

title: SHAEFFER BEGINS BREWERY EXPANSION
description: The F.&M. Schaeffer Brewing Company said it had begun a $30 million expansion of its Fogelsville, Pa. brewery to produce Stroh's and Schaeffer beer for the Pennsylvania market.

title: STOCKS CONTINUE TO WEAKEN
description: Merger developments held center stage in Wall Street yesterday as stock prices generally showed slight losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, after dropping 7.33 points Wednesday, eased 2.56 points, finishing at 996.77. The volume of 43.9 million shares compared with Wednesday's 46.7 million.

title: Business People; J. ROTHSCHILD OFFICE SET UP IN NEW YORK
description: When the squabble between Jacob Rothschild and his cousin Evelyn de Rothschild, two prominent members of the British Rothschild banking family, ended last September, the Rothschild Investment Trust was renamed RIT, Ltd. Now this organization, a fast-growing investment company, with Jacob Rothschild as its chairman, has established an American entity - the J. Rothschild Management Corporation - and named Francois Mayer as its president.

title: FANNIE MAE LOAN GUIDELINE
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest purchaser of home loans, said today that it would accept a wide variety of new adjustable-rate mortgages, including some with rising loan principals as well as monthly payments.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of May 31
Around the World; Turks Execute 2 Terrorists Who Killed U.S. Sailor
description: Two leftist terrorists were executed early today in Istanbul for killing an American sailor and his driver in April 1980.

title: TV ADVERTISERS MEET COALITION IN EFFORT TO AVERT BOYCOTT
description: Several major television advertisers have been discussing with the Coalition for Better Television a possible compromise that would avert a threatened call for a consumer boycott of companies that sponsor prime-time shows that the coalition deems offensive.

title: The City; Boy, 7, Kills Himself Playing With a Gun
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn boy accidentally shot himself to death with an unlicensed .22-caliber revolver that his mother said she kept for her protection, the police reported.

title: The Region; Man Wins $28,000 In Dispute Over Sign
description: A Long Island man who posted a ''For Sale'' sign in front of his Freeport home three years ago has won more than $28,000 in an outof-court settlement with the village, which had jailed him when he did not pay a fine for posting the sign.

title: ANTIQUE FIRE ENGINES GATHERING FOR SHOW
description: The fire buffs will be there, and so will the nostalgia buffs, perhaps 10,000 in all, when the 12th annual Great American Antique Fire Apparatus Show and Muster fills the Kensico Dam Plaza tomorrow at Valhalla in Westchester County.

title: PLESSEY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 2
description: B-After extraordinary losses of $3.5 million for the latest yr and $10.4 million for the previous yr; shr earnings are per American Depositary Receipts

title: AFTERMATH OF MIDAIR COLLISION
description: Fireman spraying foam on wreckage of a Piper Archer 2 in a Los Angeles department store after it collided with a Cessna 152 and plunged through the store's roof, killing all three persons aboard. Cessna managed to land safely at an airport three miles away, despite a crumpled left wing.

title: Baseball in Art
description: Baseball fans dismayed by the players' strike may take solace in an exhibition of paintings, drawings and sculpture with a baseball theme on view through Sept. 24 at Spectrum Fine Art Ltd, 30 West 57th Street.

title: FUTURE OF DU PONT TRUST STUDIED FOLLOWING DEATH OF ITS HEAD
description: The death Wednesday of Edward Ball, the 93-year-old chairman of the billion-dollar Alfred I. du Pont Testamentary Trust, has set off a whirlwind of speculation about the future of the trust's myriad paper, oil and railroad properties. According to Mr. Ball's friends, the hard-nosed financier would have found the confusion following his death worthy of a toast.

title: VOLCKER PROPOSES MONEY FUNDS BE SUBJECT TO RULES ON RESERVES
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testifying before a Congressional subcommittee, proposed yesterday that money market funds be subject to regulations that would make them more competitive with banking institutions and less attractive to investors.

title: ASSETS INCREASE AT MONEY FUNDS
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds grew by $2.67 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: CHASE LOAN POLICIES DRAW FIRE
description: Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, accused the Chase Manhattan Bank today of ''paying lip service only'' to Federal regulations requiring lending institutions to answer credit needs of their communities.

title: EXCERPS FROM SUPREME COURT OPININS ON LIMITING THE MILITARY DRAFT TO MEN
description: Following are exerpts from the opinions in today's Supreme Court decision upholding, by a vote of 6 to 3, the constitutionality of male-only draft registration. The majority opinion was delivered by Justice William H. Rehnquist. The minority opinions were by Justice Thurgood Marshall, with whom Justice William J. Brennan Jr. joined, and by Justice Byron R. White, with whom Justice Brennan also joined. From Majority Opinion By Justice Rehnquist

title: EXCHANGE BLOCKS CONTINENTAL PLAN
description: The purchase of Continental Airlines by its employees has been blocked, at least temporarily, by the New York Stock Exchange, which indicated that it would delist Continental stock if the workers buy control of the company without shareholder ratification.

title: E.E.C. IN PACT ON STEEL AID
description: The European Economic Community reached agreement today on a steel industry revitalization plan that will phase out national subsidies to ailing steel companies and help fund unemployment benefits for steel workers.

title: BUDGET DIFFRENCES CENTER ON SOCIAL SERVICE
description: The key difference between the Republican and Democratic budget proposals now before the House is in the extent that they would make long-range reductions in major social service programs, including Social Security, Medicaid and welfare.

title: JERSEY BUSES STILL A CAUSE OF DISTRESS
description: Nearly two years ago, the state created the New Jersey Transit Corporation with the promise that better days were ahead for bus and train commuters. But as its July 17 anniversary nears, its patrons are grumbling that the only evidence of its existence has been fare increases.

title: C.D.C.'S AQUITAINE BID EXPECTED
description: C.D.C. Oil and Gas Ltd., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Canadian Development Corporation, is expected to announce plans to acquire the Aquitaine Company of Canada Ltd., for between $1.8 billion and $2 billion (Canadian), sources close to the negotiations said today.

title: PRESIDENT IS BUOYED BY VOTE ON BUDGET , talking to reporters
description: President Reagan, exulting in his budget victory in the House of Representatives, proclaimed here today that his success in winning Democratic support in the vote meant that ''a new coalition'' had emerged in Congress and that it would pass his entire economic program.

title: CUT SEEN IN SAUDI OIL OUTPUT
description: Saudi Arabia's oil production ceiling will drop by 450,000 barrels a day, to 9.85 million barrels, beginning July 1, oil industry sources said today. No official Saudi statement has been made.

title: Pop Jazz; MESSENGERS REUNION HONORS ART BLAKEY
description: ''IF you're going to play jazz, you've got to keep at it,'' the masterly drummer and bandleader Art Blakey was saying the other day. ''If you sit around and don't play, you've had it. Everybody asks me when I'm going to retire, and I tell them, when they pat me in the face with the shovel I'll retire. I don't have time to retire.''

title: SAVINGS LOSS AT THRIFT UNITS
description: The nation's savings and loan associations, battered by record withdrawals in March and April, suffered a third straight savings loss in May, Federal regulators said today.

title: POLISH OFFICIALS ARE REORTED WORRIED ABOUT HUNGARIANS ' ACTIVATING A KULIKOV, COMMANDER OF WARSAW BRGADE SIZE FORCE
description: High Polish officials are reportedly concerned about information they have received that part of the Hungarian armed forces has been placed in readiness.

title: ACCORD SET IN CAIRO ON SINAI PEACE UNIT
description: Representatives of Egypt, Israel and the United States announced agreement today on a peacekeeping force to patrol Sinai after the scheduled final withdrawal by Israel from the Egyptian territory next April 25.

title: Restaurants; Viennese style, restful and plush.
description: IN the strict sense, double jeopardy refers to the possibility of a person being tried twice for the same crime. But that is the term that always comes to mind when we hear of a restaurant owner who opens a second establishment. ''Double jeopardy'' hardly seems adequate to describe the compounding of difficulties facing the owner of an already successful restaurant who must find a second competent staff and who tries to divide his attention between restaurants at two locations. Fearless on that score, and apparently for the best of reasons, Peter Grunauer, originator and owner of the four-star Vienna '79 restaurant at 320 East 79th Street, has opened Vienna Park on East 60th Street between Madison and Park Avenues on the site of the short-lived Claret's.

title: SENATE PANEL VOTES TAX-CUT BILL
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved a sweeping tax-relief bill for individuals and business today that is faithful to the Administration's proposals and is likely to win on the Republican-controlled Senate floor without major changes.

title: Auctions; Moderate-price sales of art.
description: THE final sales of the season at two of New York's leading artauction galleries next week will focus primarily on moderate-price examples of 19th-century and early-20th-century art. The auctions begin Tuesday at Sotheby Parke Bernet's Madison Avenue galleries, with sessions at 10:15 A.M. and 2:30 P.M., at which more than 330 paintings will be for sale, ranging in estimates from $500, for a turn-of-the-century portrait, ''The Young Scholar'' by Simeon Buchbinder, a Polish painter, to as much as $8,000 for ''A Pinch of Snuff,'' an early-20th-century genre painting by the Frenchman Victor Marais-Milton. Three other paintings are estimated to bring up to $7,000 - Peter Josef Wilms's ''Still Life With Wine Glass,'' a 19thcentury German study; Louis Beroud's ''In the Gallery'' (1909), which shows two women visiting an art gallery, and Edmund Adler's ''The Lesson,'' which depicts German children studying together.

title: CANADA PERMANENT ACCEPTS A FRIENDLY GENSTAR BID
description: The Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation of Toronto announced today that it had agreed to a $250 million (Canadian) cash takeover offer by the Genstar Corporation of Vancouver. The offer counters an unwelcome $300 million share exchange bid by the Belzberg interests of Vancouver.

title: Economic Scene; TAX WRITERS' 'CHRISTMAS TREE'
description: WHAT started out as a simple, clean tax cut is becoming, with the Reagan Administration's collaboration, a ''Christmas tree'' bill that outglitters any of the past. With Republicans and Democrats vying for the privilege of providing tax breaks to assorted special groups, the bill is becoming a masterpiece of fiscal graffiti - a bonanza perhaps most of all for tax lawyers, tax accountants and investment advisers.

title: Briefs
description: * Conna Corp. bought 20 Majik Market convenience-type food stores in the Indianapolis area for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: 8 INDICTED AS THE LEADERS OF CROATIAN TERROR GROUP
description: Eight men described by the Federal authorities as the hierarchy of a Croatian nationalist organization were arrested separately around the nation yesterday on racketeering and conspiracy charges involving extortion, arson and murder.

title: Kuhn's Viewpoint: Compensation Vital
description: Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that the issue of free agent compensation was too important to surrender in the baseball negotiations, and added: ''We won't abandon it just to shorten the strike.''

title: COURT LIMITS CITIZEN SUITS BASED ON 2 POLLUTION LAWS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the enforcement provisions of two key water-pollution laws could be invoked only by those individuals who adhered to the laws' precise procedural requirements.

title: Magic Johnson Signs $25 Million Contract
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson has signed a 25-year contract for $1 million a year, starting in 1984, Jerry Buss, the Los Angles Lakers' owner, said tonight.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Dean Witter Reynolds Organization is calling for redemption on July 31, at $50 a share, of all the 114,394 shares of $2.50 Series A cumulative convertible preferred stock that were outstanding on May 31.

title: Plessey's Profit Down in Quarter
description: The Plessey Company, a London-based high technology company, announced yesterday that its net income in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended April 13, fell 17.9 percent, to $30.7 million, or $1.28 for each American depository receipt, from $37.4 million, or $1.57 per A.D.R., a year earlier. Sales increased 11.2 percent, to $553.7 million, from $498.1 million.

title: ROYAL BALLET: JENNIFER PENNEY DANCES LEAD IN 'SWAN LAKE'
description: ON previous visits of the Royal Ballet, Jennifer Penney has been both pleasing and vexing. She has pleased balletomanes by her ability to make an almost moral virtue out of classical correctness.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Rules Against Barring Homosexuals From U.S.
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that the Government could not exclude people from entering the United States just because they were homosexuals.

title: THE TIME FOR A TRANSIT TAX IS NOW
description: New York's Financial Control Board has sent up a timely danger signal. In effect, it told the Legislature that the promise in the city's fiscal plan for 1982 wilted when a Federal Appeals Court invalidated the transit tax on oil companies. Without a substitute, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's income will fall $250 million short of expenses in the year starting Wednesday. If the city is left alone to bear the deficit, its precarious financial structure will start tottering. The time to shore it up is now.

title: RENT RISES OF UP TO 16% APPROVED AT ROWDY RENT GUIDELINES SESSION
description: Basic rent increases for 300,000 rent-stabilized apartments where leases expire in the year beginning Oct. 1 were voted yesterday at a raucous meeting of New York City's Rent Guidelines Board. The ninemember board set the basic increases at 10 percent for one-year leases, 13 percent for two years and 16 percent for three years.

title: Sadat Asserts He Is 'Optimistic' On Accord on Palestinians in '81
description: President Anwar el-Sadat said in an interview published today that he was ''optimistic'' that an agreement would be reached by the end of this year on granting autonomy to Palestinians in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Rosario, Starling Score Knockouts
description: Edwin Rosario, an undefeated 18-year-old featherweight boxer from San Juan, P.R., and Marlon Starling, an undefeated middlewight from Hartford, scored knockout victories at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: PILLSBURY NET UP 19.7% IN QUARTER
description: The Pillsbury Company, a diversified food concern, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended May 31 increased 19.7 percent, to $30.4 million, or $1.51 a share, from $25.4 million, or $1.26 a share, in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1980. Sales increased 6.3 percent, to $861.9 million, from $810.6 million.

title: Letters; FOR A TWO-BRACKET TAX SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: VIETNAM WAR BOOK BANNED IN MAINE
description: The latest book to be banned by a school board - this one in a high school in eastern Maine - is ''365 Days'' by Ronald J. Glasser, a graphic report written by a physician who worked in a burn ward treating wounded soldiers and in a pediatrics ward treating children for a year in Vietnam. (The title's 365 days refer to a single tour of duty.)

title: News Analysis
description: With some deft and intensive personal politicking and some clever bargaining, President Reagan outplayed the Democrats on a crucial test vote today and demonstrated that he can hold a working conservative majority for the heart of his economic program in the House of Representatives.

title: Letters; HOW EUGENE GOLD PICKS HIS ASSISTANT D.A.'S
description: To the Editor:

title: The City; Body of Missing Girl Found in Freezer
description: The burned and battered body of a teen-age girl who had been missing since Friday was found yesterday afternoon in the basement freezer of a closed nursing home only a block away from her midtown Manhattan home, the police said.

title: Senate Passes Boxer Safeguards
description: One day after passage by the Assembly, the Senate today approved regulations that would enhance safeguards for boxers. Among the rules is one that would grant the State Athletic Commission the power to require ambulances and medical equipment at all matches and exhibitions.

title: PARIS AIDE BELITTLES U.S. CONCERN
description: The French Foreign Minister said today that an American expression of displeasure at the inclusion of four Communists in the French Government showed that the United States did not understand what was going on in France, and appeared designed to placate right-wing opinion at home.

title: BOOK PUBLISHERS ELECT CHIEF
description: Martin P. Levin, president of the Times Mirror Company book group, has been elected chairman of the Association of American Publishers, the leading trade association of book publishers in the United States. He succeeds Leo N. Albert, vice president of Prentice-Hall.

title: CEILING ON 2 1 2-YEAR C.D. TO END
description: Federal bank regulators decided today to lift by Aug. 1 the interest rate ceiling on 30-month ''small-saver'' certificates of deposit offered by banks and savings and loan associations and to study a proposal to double interest rates on passbook savings, now a maximum 5 1/2 percent.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLDS LAW PROHIBITING UNSTAMPED MATTER IN MAILBOXES
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law that prohibits placing unstamped material in private mailboxes. The Court, voting 7 to 2, reversed a ruling by a Federal district judge in New York who said that the law violated the free speech rights of a Westchester County civic group. The group, the Saw Mill Valley Civic Association, used homeowners' mailboxes as the chief means of distributing its leaflets.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Three Dodgers Reported To Have Played in Mexico
description: Fernando Valenzuela and two other Dodger players may have violated their major league contracts by playing in a two-game exhibition series last weekend in Mexico, a newspaper reported yesterday.

title: RENT PANEL MEMBERS AND THEIR VOTES
description: The members of New York City's Rent Guidelines Board are appointed by the Mayor and are barred from holding office in any tenant or owner organization or owning or managing property covered by the rent-stabilization law. Two members are designated to represent tenant interests, two to represent owners and four to represent the public. The chairman is paid $125 for each meeting; other members receive $100.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK : ON HAIG TRIP A SENSITIVE DISCLOSURE LIGHTS A FUSE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s 27,643-mile Asian mission is drawing to a close today with the satisfaction that he had felt over the trip somewhat dampened.

title: NIELSEN, A C, CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an acquisition

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $3 million for the qr and $5 million for the yr
