title: Desegregation Tuition Proposal To Be Studied by Johns Hopkins
description: The Justice Department will tell a Federal judge that it has no objection to his order to put into effect a limited plan for voluntary school desegregation in the St. Louis area.

title: Two Drivers Win Order Restoring Them to Circuit
description: Two racers on the Championship Auto Racing Teams circuit achieved a partial victory today in their fight against a 60-day suspension, but they cannot race in Sunday's Kraco Twin 125-mile championship car races at Atlanta International Raceway.

title: The Region; LEGISLATOR INDICTED ON BRIBERY CHARGES
description: Assemblyman Michael Bragman, Democrat of Cicero, was indicted on a charge of requesting $1.6 million in bribes from United States Environmental Systems Inc., which hoped to sell a garbageburning steam plant to Onondaga County in 1978. Mr. Bragman was then chairman of the County Legislature.

title: No Headline
description: AIDE TO KHOMEINI PRAISES FIRING SQUAD EXECUTIONS

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1981; The Economy
description: The House approved President Reagan's proposed budget cuts that would trim $36 billion in fiscal 1982. By a vote of 217 to 211, the Republicans and 29 Democrats gave the President most of what he sought. The House-approved budget legislation included authorization for the President to sell 105.1 million troy ounces of silver from the nation's strategic stockpile. (Page 1.)

title: No Headline
description: CHICAGO TRANSIT TALKS BROKEN OFF

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 38.

title: Bulk of Knight Estate Entrusted
description: John S. Knight, late founder of a group of newspapers that became part of the Knight-Ridder newspaper chain, left the bulk of his estate to a trust controlled by his brother, James L. Knight of Miami, according to court records. The late Mr. Knight, who died of a heart attack June 16 at the age of 86, left his personal papers to the University of Akron and his personal property to his only surviving son, C. Landon Knight.

title: POLES SEEK REFUGE IN AUSTRIA:
description: Polish citizens gather near the Traiskirchen refugee camp, 12 miles south of Vienna, waiting to be processed as refugees. Each day, about 150 Poles arrive in Austria, their first step in seeking asylum in a Western country. At present, the camp is overcrowded, with more than 1,500 refugees.

title: TRUSTCO TERMINATES BANK MERGER TALKS
description: Royal Trustco Ltd., parent of Canada's largest trust company group, said today that it had concluded talks with Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami about a possible acquisition of the Florida bank holding company.

title: De Gustibus; ON A MENU, INFORMATION CAN BE OVERDONE
description: Too much of a good thing can be almost as bad as not enough, and even the desirable virtue of clarity can be overdone. That is the thought that occurred last week after reading through a menu sent by a Los Angeles restaurant owner in response to a recent column advocating clarity in menus.

title: Consumer Saturday; 2 LOSSES IS LIMIT FOR BANK CARDS
description: S USAN HANNAH's wallet, with several credit cards inside, was stolen for the second time in two years during her recent vacation. When she returned to Manhattan, the Chemical Bank refused to reissue her Visa and MasterCard cards because ''such instances create a high risk of fraudulent misuse of the cards and subsequent losses to the bank,'' a form letter from the bank stated.

title: The Region; JERSEY TRANSIT GETS 2 FEDERAL GRANTS
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - The New Jersey Transit Corporation has been awarded two Federal grants totaling more than $22 million, Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of Old Bridge, announced yesterday.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $200 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that the nation's basic money supply had dropped by a modest $200 million in the latest reporting week. But it also added new data to the money supply figures that resulted in a sharp upward revision of $3.8 billion.

title: DOW SLIPS BY 3.90 IN WEAK TURNOVER
description: Takeover fever, touched off by acquisition bids from Canada, gripped Wall Street yesterday and sent a handful of stocks briskly higher in a rumor-filled session. Elsewhere, lingering worries over interest rates produced a modest setback for the overall market.

title: RUSSIAN BREAKS VAULT MARK
description: Vladimir Polyakov of Soviet Union clearing 19 feet 3/4 inch in the pole vault yesterday in Tbilisi, U.S.S.R. The vault broke by a half-inch the world record set last Saturday by Thierry Vigneron of France.

title: New Food Stamp Funds Approved by the Senate
description: The Senate, avoiding a possible deadlock over food stamps, voted $1.7 billion in additional appropriations today, raising the total in this fiscal year to $11.4 billion.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago results include operations of Rhinelander Paper Co purch on Jan 1, 1980

title: The City; MISSING MAN, 86, FOUND AT BUS STATION
description: An 86-year-old man who had been missing from his daughter's home since Monday turned up at the Port Authority Bus Terminal looking for a bus to Chicago, according to United Press International.

title: THE LIVELY ARTS THE HOUSE THAT 'VANITIES' BUILT
description: SAGAPONACK SURROUNDED by overflowing baskets of white wildflowers that filled the vast expanse of a sparsely furnished living room, Jack Heifner, the playwright, and Milton Justice, the producer, two of the men who gave us ''Vanities,'' talked about how the play had changed their lives.

title: Patents; MACHINE OBEYS A SINGER'S VOICE
description: A device for controlling machines by voice and musical sounds has been invented by Theodore Lasar, a New York electronics engineer.

title: Notes on People
description: Canada Finds Way to Honor Terry Fox With a Stamp

title: No Headline
description: The first question is this: Has George Bush, Ronald Reagan's Vice Presidential running mate, violated an important regulation of the Central Intelligence Agency, the spy organization he once headed?

title: DEFECTIVE CASUALTY LIST OF ISRAEL'S STRIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: GOURDINE REFLECTS ON N.B.A.
description: In more than a decade as an official in the National Basketball Association, Simon Gourdine has watched the sport change and grow, participated in the league's complicated legal and financial affairs, and has been something of a pioneer as the highest-ranking black executive in professional sports.

title: GARDENING BENEFITS FROM USE OF GROUND COVERS
description: WHAT will control weeds, reduce the need for mowing, prevent erosion, prevent lawnmower damage to trees, grow where it is too shady for grass, provide a transition between lawn and shrubs and add variety to the landscape? The answer is ground covers. Not every ground cover will do all these things, but most will do all except one or two and, perhaps, even some that are not listed.

title: F.D.R. Drive Gets Additional Repairs
description: Workmen filling collapsed section of northbound roadway near 42d Street. The Transportation Department said inspections in the area had found ''additional undermined areas'' in the left northbound lane, and repair crews could be working around the clock through the weekend to correct those conditions.

title: Davis Wins In Comeback
description: Howard Davis Jr. made a successful comeback tonight by stopping Larry Stanton tonight in eight rounds of a scheduled 10-rounds lightweight bout.

title: The U.N. Today; June 27, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: United Nations Development Pro- gram, Governing Council - 10 A.M.

title: 18 1 2% PRIME RATE PLANNED
description: Commerce Bancshares, a holding company of 38 Missouri banks, announced today that it would lower its prime interest rate to 18 1/2 percent from 20 percent, effective Monday. The prime rate at the nation's major banks remains at 20 percent. United Missouri Bancshares, a network of 21 United Missouri banks, has promoted a prime rate of 18 3/4 percent since June 12.

title: GARDENING KEEPING LAWNS GREEN ALL SUMMER
description: THE commonly planted turf grasses of the Northeast are cool season grasses. This means that they do best in spring and fall. When exposed to high temperatures, such as those experienced this summer, it is normal for them to turn brown and become dormant. Autumn rains and cool weather end their dormancy and they turn green again. No one is particularly fond of a brown lawn, however, so we attempt to keep them green throughout the summer.

title: FORD FOUNDATION MOVING ON PLANS TO FIGHT POVERTY
description: Ford Foundation trustees this week approved a new program to combat urban and rural poverty and also looked at a problem closer to home - low staff morale at the foundation itself.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOUSE BUDGET CUTS DIFFER FROM COMMITTEE VERSION
description: The budget package endorsed by the Reagan Administration and approved by the House today cuts spending in some areas by $5.2 billion more than 15 Democratic-controlled committees had proposed and restores $3 billion in spending that was cut by those committees in other areas. The net increase in spending cuts for the fiscal year 1982 is therefore $2.2 billion.

title: Around the World; U.S. Judge Jails Cuban Exile For Perjury in Letelier Case
description: An anti-Castro Cuban was sentenced today to four and a half years in jail for perjury in connection with the car-bomb assassination of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: TRAVELING TO BABYLON VIA STAGE
description: GARDEN CITY WILL the Actors Conservatory Theater at Adelphi University develop into a major regional theater on the Island? At this early stage, nearing the end of a three-play all-Equity summer season, it is presenting a new work with professional actors.

title: CHINA PLANS TO POSTPONE OIL SEARCH
description: China has postponed until next year plans to solicit bids from foreign oil companies to search for oil in the South China Sea, Willard C. Butcher, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, disclosed here today.

title: 2 BELGIUM STEEL CONCERNS IN MERGER
description: Shareholders of Belgium's two main steel concerns approved a merger involving large-scale Government aid in an attempt to stem crippling financial losses.

title: British Airways Cancels Flights In New Strike by Air Controllers
description: British Airways canceled 117 European and domestic flights today because of an air traffic controllers' strike at Heathrow Airport.

title: DIRECTORS' TALKS PROGRESS A BIT
description: The biggest hurdle in the talks between movie and television directors and the major producers has been cleared, but there are still issues to be resolved if a crippling strike is to be avoided, industry spokesmen said yesterday.

title: THOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-After $86,000 loss from discontinued operations...C-Net income including $20,000 income from discontinued operations

title: Around the World; Chinese Foreign Minister Holding Talks in India
description: The Foreign Ministers of India and China spent over two hours today discussing mutual problems as well as the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

title: DELAWARE COURTING COMPANIES FOR JOBS
description: Among the loneliest people in this diminutive coastal state are its consumer activists, people like Ted Keller, who seems to feel at times as if he were trying to hold back a tidal wave.

title: Chairman Reagan's Sayings
description: The Presidential campaign is picking up speed and losing altitude. Both sides promise to debate the issues of the future, but the outlook is for a vicious personal conflict between Carter and Reagan about the past.

title: CLOSE CALLS IN CROWDED PORT WORRY NEW LONDON OFFICIAL
description: Two near-accidents and one minor collision involving huge vessels and tiny fiberglass fishing boats in the crowded waters off New London have prompted the Coast Guard port captain there to consider stricter traffic-control measures.

title: Police Academy Graduates 928 New Officers
description: Probationary police officers applauding Mayor Koch yesterday in Alumni Hall at St. John's University in Queens as their five months of training came to an end. The Mayor advised the new officers to wear their bulletproof vests.

title: DESIGNER MOTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Mondale Is Received in Bonn
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher received former Vice President Walter F. Mondale for lunch today, the Foreign Ministry said. Mr. Mondale is on a private visit.

title: NOMINEE AS F.T.C. HEAD
description: James Clifford Miller 3d, who was named by President Reagan today to be the chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, brings to the post a strong commitment to the free-market system, energy and a dash of humor.

title: Finance Briefs
description: * Ackerly Inc. expects to file in early July with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 500,000 shares of common stock, following a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: Senator Tower Assails Proposals Of Garn and Laxalt on MX Basing
description: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee took issue today with two Republican Senators who are urging that MX missiles be based in Minuteman silos instead of new shelters.

title: GOODS AND SERVICES FOR SUBURBAN HOME
description: STAMFORD DID you ever chance upon a hideaway stall, shop or store with treasures galore, but prudently keep the wares and whereabouts to yourself? Did you ever discover a service or sideline virtually unknown, and guard the knowledge as your very own?

title: Patents; A TALKING SIGN GIVES ADVICE IN AN EMERGENCY
description: Signs that can talk and tell people how to get out of buildings in case of fire and other emergencies are being manufactured by Exit-Us Inc., Easton, Conn. Tim G. English, president, was granted patent 4,275,274 this week for the monitoring system.

title: REAGAN, IN BID FOR BUDGET VOTES, REPORTED TO YIELD ON SUGAR PRICES
description: The White House, in return for the support of Southern Democrats from sugar-producing states, reportedly promised that the Administration would no longer oppose a new pricesupport program that would put the Government back into the business of buying and storing sugar.

title: BASEBALL STRIKE FORCES TV TO IMPROVISE
description: When Tucker Ashford, third baseman for the Columbus Clippers, heard that cable television would be carrying Clippers' games two weekends ago, he phoned his parents in Covington, Tenn., to tell them to look for a town where ESPN, the all-sports cable network, was available. They found one - Dyresburg, 35 miles north of Covington - and they spent the next three days checking in and out of a motel room there.

title: STATE REFINING PLAN TO PROTECT THE COAST
description: ASBURY PARK THE state hopes to take another step toward saving rapidly eroding beaches along its 127-mile coastline when it unveils its shore protection master plan in the next few weeks.

title: AGREEMENT AVERTS STRIKE AGAINST BELL
description: The Bell System and its largest union reached a tentative contract settlement tonight, averting a threatened coast-to-coast strike that was scheduled to begin at midnight.

title: So This Is Nature
description: Yes, we are in the country. Deep in the country. We are in a stone house of antique vintage, very small, up a hollow, perched on the side of a hill, a creek down in the basin, jungle all around us. Out there it is kill and be killed, eat and be eaten. I am being eaten at this very instant by a monstrous fly of incredible stupidity.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Continued stories. This week, like many weeks, the interesting news from Publishers Row consists of sequels to tales told in the past. To wit:

title: Future Events Tippling For Tennis
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: A Winner For Vitas Aug. 19 - Other who's who folk in tennis join Vitas Gerulaitis tonight at 6:30 on Bloomingdale's underground level to open the department store's Athletic Club, the name of the new place where clothing for all sports will be sold. The ''club'' includes an indoor track, lockers and audio-visual devices flashing great moments in sporting events. The party will raise funds for the Vitas Gerulaitis Youth Foundation through which New York City youngsters aged 4 and up receive free tennis racquets and lessons from Vitas and his friends in summer programs in city parks encouraging them toward tennis fame. Mr. Gerulaitis, himself a city boy, was started toward his tennis career at 8, when his father would come home from work when the family lived in Brooklyn, and take him to practise in that borough's Highland Park. This morning's friend of Mr. Gerulaitis, who turns teacher for the foundation on Central Park's tennis courts, is Bjorn Borg, who also will be a guest at the party. Take the escalator down with him to the open bar, hors d'oeuvres and edibles from Bloomingdale's 40 Carrots eatery. John McEnroe and Ilie Nastase also said they'd be there to help Mr. Gerulaitis reach the foundation's eventual goal of a year-round tennis center for the children of New York. The address of the Vitas Gerulaitis Youth Foundation is P.O. Box 1165 Old Village Station, Great Neck, L. I. 11023.

title: BETTING SYSTEM SET UP ON A MUNICIPAL COMPUTER
description: A Board of Education computer programmer has been arrested and charged with using school computers to create a race-track betting system and to trace the genealogy of horses that he owns.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago figures since the company changed from a calendar yr to the fiscal yr; a change to the LIFO accounting method reduced net income for the latest period by $260,000 or 14 cents a shr for the qr $1,097,000 or 57 cents a shr for the yr

title: NEW YORK JOBLESS RATE SLIPPED TO 7.3% IN MAY
description: For the first time this year, the unemployment level in New York State has slipped below that of a year earlier, the State Labor Department announced today.

title: DILLINGHAM CORP.
description: Three British Virgin Island entities controlled by Hong Kong investors said they had increased their collective stake in the Dillingham Corporation to 1.2 million shares, or 7.1 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission the three - Rosslyn Park Ltd., Saracens Ltd. and Twickenham Ltd. - said that recently 271,500 shares of Dillingham stock had been acquired between May 28 and June 22 for an aggregate purchase price of $9.2 million.

title: BREAKDOWN OF VOTE ON REAGAN'S BUDGET
description: Following is a breakdown of the 217-to-211 roll-call by which the House today approved President Reagan's budget package.

description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER OPINION AFTER 30 YEARS, TRUE CONFESSIONS
description: IHAVE always been partial to True Confessions magazine. As a matter of fact, I must confess that if it weren't for True Confessions, I might not know how to read. For the last 30 years, I have been saving some true confessions of my own. In deference to Wellesley, where I learned to make a certain amount of order out of chaos, I will present my true confessions in outline form. True Confession I

title: BEAUTY KEEPING A FRESH FACE AT THE OFFICE
description: top-flight executive woman has to be capable, efficient and, if she has any healthy vanity at all, radiant. Her day is long, starting at or before 8 A.M. and often ending at midnight. All those hours in between are devoted to work; even a dinner or cocktail party may be a guise for more work. In order to stay crisp and fresh throughout it all, the executive woman has to have an arsenal of beauty tricks, from steam-heated rollers to astringents, makeup kits in quadruplicate to hairdressers who begin work shortly after dawn. Here are the office beauty secrets of six women executives who are decision makers in businesses ranging from fashion to news broadcasting. BARBARA WALTERS, ABC News correspondent, New York: I try to keep my on-camera and off-camera look the same. I keep four sets of makeup: one in my office, one at home, another set in the makeup room at ABC, and I travel with the fourth set.

title: Thomas J. Lynn, Artist, Marries Alisa B. Boyle
description: The marriage of Alisa B. Boyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Boyle of East Islip, L.I., to Thomas J. Lynn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lynn of Kings Park, L.I., took place yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in East Islip.

title: Around the World; Italian Reports Completing Formation of New Cabinet
description: Prime Minister-designate Giovanni Spadolini said today that he had completed formation of his new government and would act promptly on Italy's economic problems.

title: JAMES V. MARTINDALE
description: James V. Martindale, chairman of the board of Martindale-Hubbell Inc. of New Providence, N.J., which annually publishes the Martindale-Hubbell Law Directory, died Thursday at Memorial Hospital in Ormond Beach, Fla.

title: Frank C. Dougherty
description: PRAYING FOR PEACE IN LEBANON: Some of the Christian demonstrators who are staging a sit-in outside the Presidential Palace in Beirut.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW THE MASTERLY STYLE OF MEYEROWITZ
description: Try to imagine Joel Meyerowitz as a magazine photographer working for the National Geographic Magazine or the old large-format Holiday. Then look at his latest (and best) book, ''St. Louis & the Arch'' (New York Graphic Society, $29.95), and see what museum exhibitions and Government and foundation funding have wrought.

title: IT'S TOUGH TO CUT THE MUSTARD
description: WHEN Eddie Glynn sold hot dogs in Shea Stadium, he would ignore his customers when possible in order to watch the players on the field. ''I was a big fan,'' he said the other day. ''I'd ask for their autograph, try to talk to them after the game. I thought a lot of them were hard-noses because they didn't have the time. Now I realize how tough it is to be a ballplayer.''

title: ANTIQUES PAINTED CHINESE ENAMALS IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK ASMALL but informative show called ''Chinese Painted Enamels From the Museum Collection'' is on view at the Newark Museum until Sept. 30. Almost four dozen pieces of these finely decorated pieces made by the Chinese in the 18th and 19th centuries are on view in the small gallery of the music room in the museum's Ballantine House.

title: ACTION TO DEPORT SUN MYUNG MOON CALLED LIKELY BY JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE
description: A Justice Department official said today that the Government would probably begin deportation proceedings this summer against the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, the founder of the Unification Church, on the basis of an investigation suggesting that he and his wife, Hak Ja Han, had violated Federal immigration rules.

title: Notes on People; A Word From Buckley
description: When the instigators of a tongue-in-cheek sailor's award decided on a name for it, they thought they would be having the last word on the subject. But because they chose William F. Buckley Jr. to receive the award, they were wrong about having the last word.

title: Going Out Guide
description: EARLY ROCKER

title: Pollution and Striped Bass
description: THOSE involved in the recently-launched study to determine the reasons for the decline in East Coast striped bass populations have already come up with one possible cause: the backbones of the fish may have been weakened by toxic chemicals.

title: Your Money; REAGAN'S PLAN FOR BOAT FEES;
description: IF the Reagan Administration has its way, owners of yachts and lesser recreational boats will soon have to reach down into their oilskins and come up with annual fees set forth in a complicated schedule that could bring the Government hundreds of millions of dollars in years to come.

title: U.S. TEAMS GAINS IN WORLD YOUTH SOCCER
description: Although the champagne was flowing freely in the locker room at R.F.K. Stadium early this morning, no one in the group of soccer players under 19 years of age was drinking it. Some used it to douse the coach, some to douse teammates and others to douse themselves. They all wiped their faces with red jerseys that had the letters ''USA'' over the heart.

title: GROUP 'LEANING' TO POSTPONING BOYCOTT OF TV ADVERTISERS
description: The Coalition for Better Television is ''leaning toward'' postponing a boycott against the sponsors of shows that it deems objectionable, a spokesman for one of the coalition's members said yesterday. The coalition had planned to announce Monday the names of the sponsors it would boycott.

title: DIANES BEAU, CARAMORE LEAD QUALIFIERS FOR CLASSIC
description: Dianes Beau and Caramore won their divisions tonight to lead the qualifiers for the $265,000 New Jersey Classic for 3-year-olds at The Meadowlands next Friday. Five horses qualified for the race in each division.

title: GOSPEL: THE CLOUDS OF JOY
description: The Mighty Clouds of Joy, the Los Angeles-based gospel quartet that appeared at the Ritz on Tuesday, have been performing together for 21 years. In that time the group has developed an impressive array of styles that range from traditional church-oriented calland-response vocals shouted over rolling organ chords, to gospel adaptations of rhythm-and-blues hits.

title: Jersey State Dance Week Culminates Tonight
description: The New Jersey State Dance Festival will culminate tonight at 8 o'clock with a performance by five dance companies at the State Theater, Livingston Street, New Brunswick.

title: REAGAN CALLS HOUSE BUDGET ACTION 'A MAJOR VICTORY' IN INFLATION WAR
description: President Reagan, who made seven more telephone calls to Democratic Congressmen last night and this morning in behalf of his proposed budget cuts, learned that his budget program had won approval in the House of Representatives after he arrived at his ranch in the mountains near Santa Barbara this afternoon. He termed the vote ''a major victory in the war against inflation.''

title: The City; TRANSIT REPORT
description: The 6:27 A.M. out of Massapequa Park on the Babylon branch was 20 minutes late because of equipment problems, and 12 trains were delayed an average of 11 minutes by the congestion of Amtrak trains that have priority in entering the tunnels into Pennsylvania Station. The 5:43 P.M. train to Port Washington and the 5:5l P.M. to Hempstead were delayed by equipment problems, and the 4:11 and 4:29 P.M. to Montauk were late because of debris on the tracks.

title: BASEBALL STRIKE PAYMENTS RESUME
description: Judges Stanley Greenberg, left, and Bernard Goodheart of a state court in Philadelphia being addressed by lawyers for Lloyd's of London.

title: WITH FIDGETING AND LOVE, SCHOOL YEAR ENDS FOR A FOURTH-GRADE CLASS
description: With a sunny June day waiting outside, it was difficult to tell whether the fidgeting in Classroom 201 at Public School 119 was seasonal or simply a manifestation of the inalienable right of fourth graders never to sit still.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 27, 1981
description: International U.S. foreign policy on Angola and Libya is of deep concern to American corporations that have highly profitable operations in the two oil-producing and strategically important nations. In both countries, the Reagan Administration is moving to isolate regimes it considers disruptive. The companies are resisting Administration policy to protect their considerable investments in both countries. (Page 1, Column 5.) A relentless drive against dissidents in Iran was urged by a close aid of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. Hojatolislam Ali Khameini, Teheran's spiritual leader, called on Iran's courts to continue making the ''resolute decisions'' that resulted in the execution of about 50 people this week. Shortly after he spoke at an open-air prayer ceremony, eight more Iranians were executed in northwestern Iran. (3:-5-6.)

title: Around the World; Pope, Still Running Fever, To Stay in Hospital 2 Weeks
description: Pope John Paul II is still running a sporadic fever and will have to remain at least two weeks at the hospital where he is being treated for a cystomegalovirus infection, his doctors said today. They termed his recovery satisfactory.

title: WESTWAY OFFERS NEW YORKERS A FEDERALLY FUNDED BONUS
description: To the Editor:

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,160 for the q and $776,446 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued oper of $5,946 for the qr and $15,603 for the yr; results are for 38 and 160 days for the latest qr and yr and 40 and 155 days for t qr and yr

title: G.M. REORGANIZATION
description: The General Motors Corporation said it had reorganized its worldwide truck and bus operations to improve efficiency. F. James McDonald, G.M. president, said the realignment would bring together in one group all of G.M.'s truck and bus operations, starting with the GMC Truck and Coach division in Pontiac and the Worldwide Truck and Transportation Systems Center in Warren, effective July 1.

title: PARTIES IN ISRAEL FOCUS APPEALS ON SEPHARDIM
description: Israel has never been much of a melting pot, nor has it tried to be. Its population has been gathered over the decades from the scattered shtetls of eastern Europe and the villages of North Africa, the urban centers of the United States and the Arab countries of the Middle East.

title: SADAT HOPING TALKS IN U.S. WILL BRING A TURNING POINT
description: President Anwar el-Sadat said today that his meeting with President Reagan in Washington in August would mark a new phase in the Middle East peace effort, and that he wanted an agreement on autonomy for the Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to be signed by the end of the year.

title: ANTIQUES ON THE PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: The more things change the more they remain the same - especially in political campaigns. That, in any case, appears to be the message of ''A Panorama of Presidential Elections,'' an exhibition on view at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, through Aug. 31. On view, for example, is a broadside questioning the public morality of General William Henry Harrison, ''Institutions cannot long survive the corruption of public morals''; an 1872 lithograph announcing the candidacy on the Equal Rights party of Victoria Claflin Woodhull, the first woman to ever run for President; and numerous anti-war attacks on military heroes who campaigned for - and frequently won - the highest office in the land. ''History just walks in her own footsteps,'' said Richard Koke, curator.

title: A WAR ON CRIME GETS PERSONAL
description: The vice president of a group called Citizens Against Crime drove to City Hall to hear a City Council proclamation marking Citizens Against Crime Week.

title: MAURICE ROSENFELD, CIVIC LEADER AND PRESIDENT OF BAG COMPANY
description: Maurice Rosenfeld, a civic leader, philanthropist and founder of the Equitable Bag Company, died Thursday night at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 90 years old and had homes in Manhattan, Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: RENNER SEEKING A RETURN TO GOLFING FORM
description: Jack Renner, a reedy, young professional golfer, can look back on 1979 with some satisfaction. He won the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, the first victory of his career, and did well enough to earn $182,808. That gave him more than a quarter of a million dollars in his first three seasons on the PGA Tour.

title: BY Martin Waldron
description: THERE is, relatively speaking, very little wildlife in New Jersey. You hear of copperheads and rattlesnakes in the northwest, rattlers and pine snakes in the pinelands, some deer here and there, chipmunks, skunks, raccoons and groundhogs.

title: Hinckley Examination Extended
description: The judge who ordered mental tests for John W. Hinckley Jr., accused of attempting to kill President Reagan, extended his commitment period today to Aug. 2 at the request of the warden of the Federal Correctional Instution in Butler, N.C., where Mr. Hinckley is undergoing the tests. Federal District Judge William B. Bryant Jr. said the warden indicated that the Butler medical staff would be able to complete its examination by Aug. 1.

title: Patents; ELECTRONIC SWITCH: IT'S TINY AND FAST
description: A tiny electronic switch, only a millionth of a square inch in area, was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories by a researcher at its plant in Murray Hill, N.J. Patent 4,275,314 was obtained by Theodore A. Fulton.

title: BUS CRASH, POSSIBLY CAUSED BY STOVE, KILLS 10 ON COAST
description: A converted bus carrying seven related families to a reunion in Alabama burst into flames today on a mountain freeway. Ten persons were killed, five of them children. All 10 were from Los Angeles.

title: HOUSE GIVES REAGAN VICTORY ON BUDGET BY APPROVING CUTS
description: The House of Representatives, after a tumultuous debate, today gave President Reagan his second successive victory by adopting a Republican package of $38.2 billion in budget cuts opposed by the Democratic leadership.

title: CONCERT: GAY MEN'S CHORUS DIRECTED BY GARY MILLER
description: The New York City Gay Men's Chorus of some 140 voices made an impressive debut under the direction of Gary Miller at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night. Choral singing of quality was heard in two of Copland's American folk-song arrangements, four of Brahms's ''Liebeslieder Waltzes,'' Randall Thompson's ''The Testament of Freedom'' and new or newly arranged works by Calvin Hampton, John Mueter, Jack Gottlieb, Leonard Bernstein, Stephen Sondheim and Glen Vecchione.

title: Future Events Hot Stuff
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Cayenne Aug. 12 - Tonight's gig for Cayenne, the five-man band that plays New Orleans-style jazz at the southeast corner of Central Park, is on the terrace of the Jewish Guild for the Blind at 15 West 65th Street. There the singles and young married couples who belong to the associates division of the guild will be joined by other members of Cayenne's fan club for a peppery concert with cocktails and a cold buffet. Gary Brocks heads Cayenne, whose instruments are clarinet, drum, tuba, trombone and trumpet. Proceeds will support the guild's services for blind and visually impaired men, women and children of all races and religions. Tickets: $25 from 595-2000, ext. 233, or at the door.

title: GIANTS BEATEN BY 13-0
description: The numbers on the scoreboard, 13 and 0, were not the most significant ones. The Giants had lost to the Steelers, but there was more to it than that.

title: FLORIDA BANKS TO ADD SERVICE
description: Gov. Bob Graham of Florida signed a bill today that allows banks in the state to offer International Banking Facilities, or I.B.F.'s.

title: STILL TIED TO SEAL HUNT, 750 ALEUTS PONDER CHANGE
description: On St. Paul and its companion island, St. George, small dots in the Bering Sea, the lemon-yellow Arctic poppies are blooming and the 700-pound seals the Aleuts call beachmasters are bellowing at other males challenging them for control of harem sites. These are signals that it is time for the annual fur seal hunt, but this year the hunt is taking shape as a new social order arises because of decisions made in the world beyond the Bering Sea.

title: 'GOIN' TO CHICAGO,' HOW WORLD WAR I AND WEEVIL MADE IT SECOND CITY OF
description: JAZZ By JOHN S. WILSON

title: Conspiracy Charge Killed At N.F.L. Antitrust Trial
description: A charge of conspiracy against Commissioner Pete Rozelle; Georgia Frontiere, the Los Angeles Rams' owner, and Gene Klein, the San Diego Chargers' owner, was thrown out of the antitrust case against the National Football League today.

title: Dodgers Say Valenzuela, Two Others Violated Pacts
description: Al Campanis, the Los Angeles Dodgers' vice president in charge of player personnel, said in a statement today that Fernando Valenzuela and two other Dodger players, Pedro Guerrero and Pepe Frias, had violated their contracts by playing in exhibition games in Mexico last weekend.

title: No Headline
description: Around the Nation; Fires Rage in Several States; Plane Crash Kills 3 in Idaho

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 19. 1. False. They are made of gold and ivory and perhaps a few human teeth. 2. The sale of highly sophisticated electronic surveillance planes known as Awacs to Saudi Arabia. The White House said the sale would be pushed.

title: SALVADOR SAYS 30,000 REFUGEES MAY BE MOVED FARTHER INTO HONDURAS
description: Some 30,000 Salvadoran refugees living in camps just over the Honduran border may be removed ''in the near future,'' according to the Salvadoran Minister of Defense.

title: Dr. Samuel G. Feuer, 77, Is Dead; A Rehabilitative Medicine Expert
description: Dr. Samuel G. Feuer, director emeritus of physical medicine and rehabilitation at Long Island College Hospital and retired associate professor of rehabilitative medicine at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I., where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: Partial Verdict Reached in Case Of Wrong Engines in Oldsmobiles
description: A partial verdict was reached today by jurors in a $131 million lawsuit brought by consumers who purchased Oldsmobiles equipped with Chevrolet engines.

title: JUNED IN AND GAYED OUT
description: June is a hectic month for brides and homosexuals. Take my own schedule, for instance. So far this month, I have read from my books at the Gay American Arts Festival in New York City and at the Walt Whitman Bookshop in San Francisco, attended the New York premiere of the San Francisco Gay Men's Chorus, addressed a rally at the San Jose Gay Pride Celebration, and rooted for the contestants in a gay tricycle race benefitting the S.P.C.A. and a gay dog show sponsored by the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence, an ''order of gay male nuns dedicated to the expiation of guilt,'' as it describes itself.

title: GOVERNOR PROPOSES 3-PART TAX PROGRAM TO CLOSE M.T.A. GAP
description: Governor Carey today proposed new taxes and higher contributions by New York City to balance the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's budget over the next two years. But his plan was immediately denounced by Mayor Koch as ''devastating'' and ''a sellout,'' and it drew a mixed response from the legislative leaders.

title: Books of The Times
description: What Do Conductors Do? By DONAL HENAHAN THE COMPOSER'S ADVOCATE: A Radi- cal Orthodoxy for Musicians. By Erich Leinsdorf. 216 pages. Yale University Press. $14.95. NOTES OF SEVEN DECADES. By Antal Dorati. Illustrated. 371 pages. Wayne State University Press. $22.50. THE GRAMMAR OF CONDUCTING: A Practical Guide to Baton Technique and Orchestral Interpretation. By Max Ru- dolf. Illustrated. 471 pages. Schirmer Books. $16.

title: Taiwanese Donate to Buy Tanks
description: Taiwan will buy 14 tanks abroad with public donations, the Defense Ministry said today. A spokesman, Col. Wang Miao, said donations for the ''tank squadron'' from the public in the past six months amounted to $2.6 million.

title: FOOD DINING RIGHT THERE AT THE FISH STORE
description: TABLES and chairs have been crowding the lobster tanks in the Island's fish markets as restaurant service is added. Fish-market dining can be anything from clams on the half shell or fish and chips to a full-course dinner with cocktails and wine. Its appeal lies in the fact that the fish and seafood are likely to be very fresh.

title: NAILING THE COFFIN OF HOUSING HERE
description: For the last 40 years, my talent, energy, and money has gone into providing housing for the average New Yorker. I now find myself frustrated, disillusioned, and angry. There's a concerted effort by the politicians directed against the professional owner and builder of apartment houses. Vote-getting at any cost means that an average person has little chance of living in a decent New York apartment. Let me give you some examples:

title: U.S. IS INVESTIGATING STEEL IMPORTS
description: The Government today announced a series of actions to enforce the trigger price mechanism, which regulates the flow of steel imports into this country, and said that in one such case a grand jury was considering fraud allegations against the Mitsui Company, one of the largest of Japan's trading companies.

title: FOES IN BEIRUT EXCHANGE CHARGES OF NEO-NAZI TIES
description: The Lebanese Christian Phalangists and the Palestine Liberation Organization have accused each other of secretly training neo-Nazis, each producing a pair of would-be German terrorists with tales of a shadowy underground that seemed as inept as it was sinister.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Re- port yesterday incorrectly named the winner of the Harbor Festival's women's lifeboat races.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accoun

title: M.T.A. DECLARES IT MAY WITHHOLD UNION PAY RAISE
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has warned the transit union that it will withhold $24 million in scheduled cost-of-living wage increases in October unless bus and subway workers produce ''hard money'' productivity savings.

title: Albert Manzi, 69, Dies; Massachusetts Politician
description: raiser for four Republican Governors of Massachusetts and the subject of charges involving alleged payoffs on state contracts, died of cancer today at Memorial Hospital here. He was 69 years old.

title: HAIG REMARK ON CHINA PUZZLES WHITE HOUSE AIDES
description: Two White House spokesmen traveling with President Reagan said today that they had no explanation for what Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. meant yesterday when he said that American relations with China had been ''on the decline steadily'' for the last three years.

title: PUTTING VIDEO ADS AT THE SUPERMARKET CHECKOUT
description: Commercial-haters beware. On-Line Media Inc. wants to flash ads at you while you stand in the mindless peace of the checkout line at the supermarket.

title: No Headline
description: Mitchell Posts 68-139, Shares 3-Way Lead

title: WESTPORT
description: WHEN compared to Europe, America was late in recognizing the appeal of gymnastics. It wasn't until the 1950's that dedicated fitness buffs discovered Nicholas Kounovsky, a White Russian whose training methods enabled enthusiastic amateurs to enjoy gymnastics, which had been the province of the very young and of professional athletes. Eventually, a number of well-known people joined Mr. Kounovsky's classes, and his reputation grew from there.

title: Earnings; VW'S NET DROPS 66.4% IN QUARTER
description: Volkswagenwerk A.G., West Germany's leading car manufacturer, reported yesterday from its headquarters in Wolfsburg that depressed economic conditions in the European automobile industry caused its net income in the first quarter to plunge 66.4 percent, to $18 million, from $53.5 million in the same period last year.

title: SOVIET SAID TO HOLD 10% OF AFGHANISTAN
description: Soviet occupation troops in Afghanistan control no more than 10 percent of the country and are limited mainly to search-and-destroy operations from isolated strongholds and outposts, according to a West European physician who has traveled widely through insurgent areas as part of a medical mission.

title: MICHELS MAY RETURN TO EUROPEAN SOCCER
description: Another world-class soccer personality besides Franz Beckenbauer may be lost to the North American Soccer League after this year. Rinus Michels, the coaching expert from the Netherlands, said during a visit to New York last week that he was contemplating a return to Europe at the conclusion of the N.A.S.L. season.

title: The City; CURBS ON PEDDLERS IN BROOKLYN URGED
description: Brooklyn officials and business and community figures called yesterday for restrictions on street vendors, United Press International reported.

title: QADDAFI TERMS THE $220,000 GIVEN BILLY CARTER A LOAN TIED TO BUSINESS
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, defended his nation's relationship with Billy Carter today and said the $220,000 given to the President's brother was a loan related to business transactions carried out during two visits, in 1978 and 1979.

title: The City; THE POLICE BLOTTER
description: A gunman was arrested in front of 1196 Park Place in Brooklyn, and a block away Officer Peter Heron fired three times at a second armed man when the man did not drop his weapon. The suspect, identified as Keith Branie, 22 years old, address unknown, was reported in serious condition at St. Mary's Hospital.

title: Notes on People; Carter Going to China
description: Although he was the President who restored full diplomatic relations with China in 1978, Jimmy Carter has never visited that country, but he now intends to change that.

title: Ulster School Bus Attacked
description: Gunmen in a speeding car sprayed automatic weapons fire on a school bus today, wounding the part-time soldier-driver, the police said. No children were aboard.

title: STARS ARE UPSTAGED IN WIMBLEDON PLAY
description: Who are Paul Kronk, John Fitzgerald, Tim Mayotte and Francisco Gonzalez, and what are they doing in the last 16 of men's singles at Wimbledon?

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
The Talk of Seabrook
description: ''Funny how things change,'' Jim Craig was saying. Mr. Craig operates the docks of ''Saigon Harbor,'' the main base of operations for the Vietnamese shrimp fishermen whose competitive presence not long ago invited the wrath of native white fishermen and the Ku Klux Klan. Burning crosses, holding rallies and brandishing automatic weapons, the Klan and the white shrimpers threatened to drive the newcomers out by violence. Most of the Vietnamese said they were ready to go.

title: NORTH CAROLINA GOVERNOR WINS GAS TAX FIGHT WITH HELMS BACKERS
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr. won final approval yesterday from the North Carolina General Assembly for a 3-cent-agallon increase in the state gasoline tax, overcoming a fierce antitax campaign financed by the political organization of United States Senator Jesse Helms.

title: Conjugal Smoke
description: Just a few months ago, those of us who believe that cigarette smoking is a major public health problem clutched gleefully at the results of a study from Japan. It contended that nonsmoking wives of heavy smokers develop lung cancer at an astonishing rate; simply breathing the smoky air of the marital domicile could be half as dangerous as actually smoking.

title: THE BRIGHTLY REALISTIC PERSPECTIVE OF JACK BEAL
description: KATONAH ''FOR Real with Jack Beal'' is the effective, if ungainly, title of a show now almost filling the Katonah Gallery to capacity. It means that the work - more than 130 paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures and photographs submitted by artists from all over - is figurative and that the noted realist, Jack Beal, chose it.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Dec 1980

title: ATLANTA INQUIRY INTO SUSPECT'S WORK
description: Investigators are studying the talent scout work of Wayne B. Williams, who has been charged with the murder of a black man here, for a possible link to other killings, sources close to the investigation said today.

title: ARGENTINA CALLED ESPECIALLY CRUEL TO ARRESTED JEWS
description: The leaders of an Argentine human rights group, Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, say the Argentine Government singles out Jewish political dissidents for especially cruel forms of torture and abuse.

title: News Analysis
description: With the approach of the crucial Communist Party congress in Poland, accusations and warnings come almost daily in Soviet commentaries, editorials and dispatches - Poland is in the grip of a counterrevolution, threatening not only its own security, not even just the Soviet bloc, but the balance of all postwar Europe.

title: No Headline
description: Hemphin and Linda Roberts of North Carolina/photo of Sue Pate and NEW YORK GIVES DELEGATES DOWN HOME WELCOME James Forte, delegates from Texas By BARBARA BASLER

title: Continued 10-Cent Rate In Pay Phones Urged
description: I would like to compliment Mr. Van Sinderen for sharing his humanistic feeling in the article ''A Strategy for Human Relations'' (Opinion Page, July 20). It is hard for me to realize that corporate executives are so far removed from the real world that the suggestion ''to communicate with others as people'' needs to be mentioned. But talking with one another is important in bridging the gap between persons.

title: JAZZ EVENTS
description: Following is a schedule of today's Jazz Festival events. For information, call 787-2020. 10:30 A.M, 1 and 3:30 P.M.: South Ferry.

title: Boycott Screens, Not Sponsors
description: What is the best way to object to a television program? Turn the dial. What then is the best way for organized critics of television to make their views felt? Persuade enough people not to watch what they don't like.

title: EXTREME AND PURE
description: THUNDER ON THE RIGHT The ''New Right'' and the Politics of Resentment. By Alan Crawford. 381 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $13.95.

title: CITY REPUBLICANS' IMAGE HAS SHIFTED CONSIDERABLY
description: As he prepares for an unfamiliar battleground - a G.O.P. primary - Mayor Koch, whose own image has changed considerably since he entered City Hall, will confront a Republican Party whose image has also been altered.

title: U.S. SHOE INDUSTRY VS. IMPORTS
description: In the protectionism vs. free trade dispute, the American shoe industry has a foot planted firmly in each camp. Since 1977, United States shoe manufacturers have been protected by quotas on imports of ''nonrubber footwear'' - the term used to describe most shoes other than traditional sneakers and galoshes, which have separate tariff protection - from Taiwan and South Korea. Those quotas expire next Tuesday, and it is widely expected that the Reagan Administration, intent on refurbishing its free-trade image, will let them lapse.

title: BRAZIL'S LIBERALIZATION PROGRAM SURVIVES NEW SCARE
description: In what is taking on the narrative continuity of the tormenting episodes of the soap operas that Brazilian television viewers love, the political liberalization program of President Joao Baptista Figueiredo has just passed through another apparent life or death crisis.

title: SPOTLIGHT REMAKING THE GIBBS MYSTIQUE
description: When Lynn D. Salvage became president of the Katharine Gibbs School last January, many speculated that she had taken the post at the tradition-steeped secretarial school merely as a haven from the challenges of feminism and high finance that beset her during her tumultuous stewardship as president of the First Women's Bank.

title: DIVORCED WIFE MAY NOT SHARE ARMY PENSION
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that military pension benefits may not become part of a property settlement in a divorce.

title: Hang-Glider Pilot Killed in Crash
description: An Albuquerque hang-glider pilot who took off from 10,678-foot Sandia Crest in a thunderstorm was killed yesterday in a crash in Corrales, about 10 miles west of the mountain. The police said that Bob Abbott, 26 years old, crashed about 45 minutes after he left the crest and was carried into a mass of storm clouds.

title: FALSE BURGLAR ALARMS SET OFF CONTROVERSY
description: NO one knows how many burglar alarms there are in Suffolk County, but there are days when every other entry on the police blotter is an alarm call. Last year 45,000 of them were false alarms, costing the police 22,500 man-hours and jamming 911, the central number for emergency calls.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Liberals And Anderson
description: Carter/Mondale Campaign Manager Tim Kraft has conceded that, without New York's 41 electoral votes, a Democratic victory in the 1980 Presidential election would be ''almost impossible'' - an opinion bolstered by the fact that had Jimmy Carter lost New York in 1976, he would have lost the race to Gerald Ford, 281 electoral votes to 256.

title: FAST-PHOTO STORE CHAIN PLANNED BY TECHNICOLOR TYPIFIES DIVERSIFICATION
description: When the Technicolor Corporation, the largest independent movie film processor, announced that it was beginning a $150 million expansion into the one-hour consumer photo processing business, Wall Street shook its head. ''Several analysts took the company off their recommended list,'' said David J. Londoner, a vice president at Wertheim & Company. ''It's very controversial.''

title: Long Contract Gives Johnson an Option
description: The 25-year contract, reportedly worth $25 million, that Earvin (Magic) Johnson signed with the Los Angeles Lakers is not binding on Johnson after seven years, according to California labor laws.

title: Briefs
description: * Allied Bancshares Inc. received approval from the Federal Reserve Board for the acquisition of Jetero Bank of Houston.

title: 'A FEW GOOD MEN' FOR THE UNITED STATES MARINES
description: To the Editor:

title: Decision on Arbour Is Due
description: Bill Torrey, the New York Islanders' general manager, and Al Arbour, the National Hockey League champions' coach, discussed Arbour's future yesterday, and a decision was expected today.

title: SCHOOLS THAT POLLUTE INNOCENT COMMUNITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: TRIAL IN BOY'S KIDNAPPING NEARING END IN CALIFORNIA
description: Closing arguments are expected to begin Monday in the trial of 49-year-old Kenneth Parnell, who is accused of kidnapping a 5-year-old boy on Valentine's Day in 1980.

title: I.B.M. ANNOUNCES PRICE INCREASES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it was raising by as much as 15 percent the prices it charges for some equipment services and program products.

title: LABOR DUBIOUS OF DELIVERING FOR CARTER
description: Jim Morgo, a member of the American Federation of Teachers, came to the Democratic National Convention as a Kennedy delegate, and he dreaded the thought of going back to Bayport, L.I., to drum up support for Jimmy Carter.

title: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS GAIN DAMAGE SUIT PROTECTION
description: The Supreme Court today limited the type of damages that may be recovered from local governments that violate an individual's constitutional rights.

title: ULLMAN SCRAMBLING AFTER A 13TH TERM
description: Here's Al Ullman - 12 terms in the United States House of Representatives, chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee, and campaigning for Congress like some aspiring challenger.

title: HOME CLINIC WAYS TO REMOVE NAILS AND STAPLES
description: PULLING long nails and staples out of wood when taking structures apart and when cleaning up old lumber for eventual reuse is often a frustrating job - especially if the lumber is good quality wood that you want to save for other projects. The ordinary carpenter's claw hammer not only tends to bend long nails before they can be pulled all the way out but also can dent or scratch the wood.

title: Eugene A. Doherty 2d Weds Ann G. Lammers
description: Ann Gerard Lammers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Lammers Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday to Eugene Aloysius Doherty 2d, son of Mrs. Sidney Doherty of Larchmont and the late Mr. Doherty. The Rev. John Scully performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Augustine.

title: MAY DEFICIT IN TRADE STEADY
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit was little changed in May at $3.44 billion, the Commerce Department reported today, even though oil imports fell to their lowest volume since June 1975. April's deficit was $3.46 billion.

title: ICE CLIMBING ON THE EQUATOR
description: The first pitch was unbelievably hard,'' recounted Phillip Snyder, a veteran mountaineer whose specialty is ice climbing. ''Just getting up to it, first of all; then this steep wall of water ice which reluctantly yields a single chip to a swing of the hammer. Beautiful, clear, hard ice it is: clean enough to cool the palate of a diplomat or queen. One must not look ahead. A glance at the steep expanse ... is unnerving to the rational mind, which needs a plan or at least a hope. Instead, one must adopt the plodding optimism of the dung beetle who moves his load unmindful of and undaunted by the obstacles that would confound a greater mind.''

title: LOVE SIGN, AT $15.60, SETS ALABAMA STAKE MARK
description: Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Love Sign, racing more than a mile for the first time in her career, handled the assignment impressively today and captured the $109,800 Alabama Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: FINDING THE ARCHITECTURAL ROOTS OF OLD HOUSES
description: Finding the architectural roots of an old house, for curiosity's sake or for a restoration project, can mean a lot of detective work. Homeowners usually consult newly published architectural books as well as antique books and records at libraries, historical societies, museums, local building departments and at other public and private preservation agencies.

title: Around the Nation;
description: A 34-year-old man pleaded guilty today to charges stemming from the nation's largest cash theft from a bank, but the authorities said the case was still not solved.

title: MOROCCO, IN REVERSAL, PROPOSES CEASE-FIRE AND VOTE FOR WESTERN SAHARA
description: King Hassan II of Morocco announced today that he was prepared to agree to a cease-fire in the guerrilla war in the Western Sahara and a referendum under international supervision on continued Moroccan rule there.

title: Man Held in 2 New York Holdups
description: An Alabama man was arrested today on charges of robbing two banks in Manhattan, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced. The suspect - Wayne McClannahan, 28 years old, of Adamsville - was charged with robberies on Oct. 19, 1978 and Jan. 24, 1979.

title: DINING OUT MEXICAN FARE IN A SURPRISING SETTING
description: MARIA Bonita, a Mexican restaurant in New Rochelle, is one of those out-of-the-way, somewhat off-putting places where you are surprised to find good food. A bold sign at the entrance advertises live entertainment on Friday and Saturday nights; most of the customers inside are at the bar; the dimly lighted interior and the stucco and wrought-iron furnishings look obscurely theatrical. On our introductory visit, our first glance judged this a low-rent nightclub.

title: PLANS THAT COULD CHANGE FIFTH AVENUE...WHILE RENEWAL PROCEEDS
description: A little more than a year ago, Jiro Shinohara, manager of Takashimaya Fifth Avenue, had this to say about his store's location at one of New York City's best known intersections: ''The area on Fifth Avenue near 42d Street has deteriorated and many stores, such as Arnold Constable, have closed.''

title: Dr. John Nagurney, Miss Mariner Wed
description: Wendy Kathleen Mariner and Dr. John Tobias Nagurney, both of Cambridge, Mass., were married yesterday in the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College in Massachusetts. The Rev. Michael R. Stotts, minister of the United Methodist Church in Bourne, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: BRITAIN TO SELL OIL HOLDING
description: In a move to return some nationalized business to private hands, the British Government yesterday ordered the sale of its 50 percent holding in the Wytch Farm oilfield in Dorset, England.

title: DOES 'MOSTLY MOZART' MAKE THE MOST OF IT
description: Fifteen years ago, when the summer concerts at Lincoln Center now known as the Mostly Mozart Festival first broke into view, its promoters put out a button that read: ''Mozart Forever.'' There was a tinge of defiance to the slogan because classical music in New York and elsewhere in the nation was undergoing a crisis of confidence. Concert managers gathered in second-rate restaurants to wring their hands over the declining public interest in recitals and other serious events. The Metropolitan Opera was floundering toward financial disaster and possible extinction. In that first Mozart season of 1966, the younger audience had virtually dried up, partly owing to a widespread perception that all music antedating that of the Beatles and Bob Dylan was pointless, not only socially and politically but even, according to the hipper academics, esthetically. In such an atmosphere, a month-long series of 26 concerts entirely devoted to the music of Mozart struck some of us at the time as borderline quixotism.

title: Off Off Broadway Alliance Names Jane Moss Director
description: Jane Moss, former managing director of Playwrights Horizons and a member and past president of the Off Off Broadway Alliance, has been appointed executive director of the alliance, effective July 20.

title: CONOCO RISES $3 ON SEAGRAM BID
description: As shareholders positioned themselves to respond to Joseph E. Seagram & Son's $73-a-share tender offer for 35 million shares of Conoco, the stock of the nation's ninth-largest oil company rose $3, to $65, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Conoco was the volume leader, with 1.54 million shares traded.

title: Bridge: Upsets Marred Fine Record Of New Yorkers at Detroit
description: Experts from the New York area did well in the Spring Nationals in Detroit. Eight were among the 13 winners in the first four major events, and one of them, Allan Stauber of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., won twice.

title: Kathleen O'Brien Bride Of Joseph McGoldrick Jr.
description: The marriage of Kathleen L. O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. O'Brien of New Canaan, Conn., to Joseph F. McGoldrick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McGoldrick of Garden City, L.I., took place in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. Msgr. John J. Barry performed the ceremony.

title: MOTHER THERESA OPENS NEWARK MISSION
description: The neighborhood around St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in the Central Ward is pocked with the hulks of burned-out buildings, garbage-strewn lots and knots of people who have given up hope.

title: COMPANIES RESISTING U.S. FOREIGN POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration and some of America's largest corporations are engaged in quiet but intense struggles over the nation's policy toward two oil-producing and strategically important nations: Angola and Libya.

title: A JFK EXPRESS TRAIN KILLS BROOKLYN MOTHER AFTER SHE SAVES SON, 4
description: A Brooklyn woman was killed by a Manhattan-bound JFK Express subway train on the IND line yesterday after pushing her 4-year-old son to safety.

title: Notes On People; It's a Quieter Career Now for Mark Rudd
description: Who should turn up in Albuquerque, N.M., as a teacher at the Technical-Vocational Institute but Mark Rudd, a leader of the student revolt at Columbia University in the late 1960's.

title: BELGIAN WINS FIRST STAGE OF BIKE RACE

title: The Region; NO STATE OBJECTIONS TO A CASINO IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON (UPI) - State gaming officials said they did not plan to file any objections against the operators of the Golden Nugget Hotel-Casino in Atlantic City when the company applies for a permanent casino license later this year.

description: A former Republican President and the widow of a former Democratic President will be co-chairmen of a committee to raise funds for a building to be named for the late Nelson A. Rockefeller.

title: A Storm Signal for New York Prisons
description: It has become a familiar pattern: the easing of traditional ironfisted prison management coincides with the entry of prisoners who are young, violent and invested with new legal rights. Prison guards, overwhelmed and resentful, make a cynical deal with the inmates: to keep the place quiet, they overlook lesser rules, peddle special treatment, ignore traffic in contraband and even participate in it themselves. Before long, the prison slides out of control.

title: STOCKMAN SAYS NO DEALS WERE MADE FOR KEY VOTES
description: The Reagan Administration's budget director, David A. Stockman, inisted today that there were no ''deals made,'' but only ''adjustments and considerations,'' as a result of President Reagan's personal lobbying for votes in his budget victory Thursday over House Democrats.

title: TALKS FALTER ON CONTRACTS FOR 65,000 JERSEY WORKERS
description: Labor contracts for 65,000 state employees will expire at midnight on Tuesday. No new talks have been scheduled between the state and its largest union, the Communications Workers of America, which represents 33,500 white-collar workers.

title: CAPITOL REPORT
description: SOME sense of order is beginning to develop regarding state officials and casinos. Legislators have brought themselves more firmly under regulations limiting their connections to the gambling industry. The new state law forbids accepting a casino job while holding public office and for two years after that.

title: BOAT ACCIDENTS RISE AS A TREND IS REVERSED
description: TIMBER POINT BOATING accidents on the Island's waterways, which by midseason have accounted for 10 deaths and scores of collisions, groundings and other mishaps, are on the increase, reversing nearly a decade of gradual decline. And while marine police and Coast Guard officials feel that this season's accident and fatality increase may be ''a matter of odds,'' they also fear that Federal cutbacks in boating safety funds in 1979 may propel the number of accidents upward in the 1980's.

title: INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
HOW PAMELS MASON IS RATTLING BRITISH WOOL
description: A STRONG-WILLED heiress, an ailing company, a tradition-bound milltown: It's a setting that is supposed to happen only in the movies. But lately, real-life Hollywood has been intruding on the largest manufacturer of wool textiles in Britain.

title: Senators Confirm Six, Among Them Rostow
description: The Senate approved the nominations early today of Eugene V. Rostow as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency and Arthur F. Burns as Ambassador to West Germany.

title: FRANCANA OIL TOPS BID FOR ADOBE STAKE
description: A Canadian oil and gas concern yesterday topped a bid made by an Oklahoma company for Amax Inc.'s 30 percent interest in the Adobe Oil and Gas Corporation and said that it was ''considering'' increasing its Adobe stake if the offer was successful.

description: ''This isn't a bill to alleviate corruption,'' thundered Assemblyman Dominick L. DiCarlo, to the applause of his Republican colleagues. ''This is a bill to centralize it!''

description: Those accustomed to the competitiveness of tournament play, to the orderly progress of a club game, or to leisurely and sociable home bridge find themselves in a different world if they venture into a railroad commuter game.

title: Patents; A FUNGUS HELPS FOOD PRODUCTION
description: WASHINGTON A MICROORGANISM patented for the Army this week is expected to have wide use in food and fuel production. The Commerce Department's National Technical Information Service has applied for patents on it in a dozen foreign countries and is offering licenses under them.

title: Taxes For Prison Trains
description: Summer is supposed to be a quiet news time for cities, a respite from other seasons' headlines of doom and gloom and foreboding. Paris empties, a large part of London migrates to Majorca and New York moves into humid slow-motion, undulating in rhythm with the melting street tar. Killer gypsy moths may intrude, but not Armageddon.

title: Mary Anne White Becomes the Bride of Marvin Zim
description: The marriage of Mary Anne White, a marketing analyst with SAMI, a Time Inc. subsidiary, to Marvin Zim, director of corporate communications for the Union Pacific Corporation, took place yesterday. The Rev. Ronald J. Cioffi, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite.

description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police called it ''a systematic approach to penetration.'' The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent agents to seize computer printouts and a terminal log sheet. So began an international computer mystery in April.

title: PANEL SETS HEARINGS ON TEACHER LICENSES
description: TRENTON FOR more than a dozen years, New Jersey has been wrestling with its teacher-licensing system without tangible results. Advocates of change say it is too easy to get and keep a license, making it possible for teachers whom they describe as incompetent and inadequate to remain in the classroom indefinitely.

title: ARGENTINA'S RULERS ARE THERE TO HELP
description: BUENOS AIRES ARGENTINA'S military regime is exporting its ''national security'' doctrine, supporting right-wing political conspiracies in Bolivia and other neighboring countries and sending intelligence agents abroad to kidnap and murder Argentine dissidents.

title: Randell Kay Peyser Is Married
description: Randell Kay Peyser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Peyser of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph C.A. Mercurio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fortunato Mercurio of Richmond Hill, Queens. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York. The bride, a jewelry designer, is a former professor of art at Meredith College in Raleigh, N.C. Mr. Mercurio is president of Dresner Mercurio Inc., a New York advertising agency specializing in political campaigns.

title: TWO-CAREER COUPLES: EMPLOYERS LISTENING
description: American corporations are becoming more responsive to the problems of two-career couples, according to a report made public here this week in which 374 corporations and 815 couples were surveyed.

title: A FAST-FOOD CHAIN; Hampstead, a Literary Community, Is Upset by McDonald's Plan to Open Hamburger Spot
description: Residents of Hampstead, one of London's most fashionable neighborhoods, have banded together to combat what they see as a dangerous threat to the character of their pleasant little main street - a plan to open a McDonald's hamburger restaurant.

title: Notes on People; Dressing Up for a Part Brings Wrong Kind of Attention
description: She usually goes around New York ''looking like a bag lady,'' says Melody Anderson. But when the actress had a call Monday to read for the part of Marilyn Monroe in a play based on Norman Mailer's book ''Marilyn,'' she decided to go dressed as Miss Monroe, and put on a slinky black dress and high spike heels.

title: ROYAL BALLET: PRIMIERE OF MACMILLAN'S 'GLORIA'
description: The future of Britain's Royal Ballet clearly lies with its creative side, and the wonderful aspect of its current season at the Metropolitan Opera House has been the quality - and success -of the new works and revivals on its mixed bills.

title: IRANIAN AID DENIED BY STUDENT LEADER; He Says Group in U.S. Has No Ties With Teheran Government but Is Linked to the Militants
description: Spokesmen for a major Iranian student organization say they are receiving no financing or direction from the Iranian Government, but they acknowledge that they have informal connections with the militants holding the American hostages.

title: 'Atomic Man'
description: Harold McCluskey was working near a vat containing americium, a radioactive metallic element being extracted from reactor waste at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation, when the vat blew up. The explosion tore off a mask that he was wearing. Americium, acid and glass and metal shards from the containment vessel slammed into his face, eyes, neck and right shoulder.

title: AQUITAINE TO ACQUIRE TEXASGULF
description: Through a series of transactions with a total value approaching $5 billion, France's Elf Aquitaine group plans to take over Texasgulf Inc., a chemicals and natural resources company based in Stamford, Conn., and then to sell Texasgulf's Canadian mining interests to the Canada Development Corporation.

description: Question: The issue in Madison Square Garden is whether the votes of the people or their representatives should be decisive. Let's start with you, Mr. de Tocqueville.

title: Around the Nation; State's Nuclear Waste Ban Is Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A Federal District judge ruled today that Washington State's ban on out-of-state shipments of nuclear waste was unconstitutional.

title: JOIN THE GOVERNMENT AND SEE THE WORLD
description: WASHINGTON NEW JERSEY'S two Senators and 10 of its 15 Representatives took a total of 18 overseas trips at Government expense in 1979, visiting 25 countries, including China, Cuba, Mexico and the Soviet Union.

title: RAIL FREIGHT RATES UP 2.8%
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had approved a 2.8 percent increase in rail freight rates to allow railroads to recoup cost increases. The higher rates will go into effect next Wednesday. An I.C.C. statement said the rate increase had been calculated to cover additional costs incurred by the railroads since mid-May and anticipated costs through mid-August.

title: RALLIES AGAINST ARTS CUTS JULY 18
description: Rallies coordinated by the new American Coalition to Support the Arts will be held July 18 in six cities to protest proposed cuts in the Government's arts budgets. The coalition represents 100 service organizations, museums, visual and performing artists and individuals.

description: In Bronx Courthouse Held Proper By United Press International

description: President Reagan has nominated Maj. Gen. Robert Kingston of the Army to take over the Rapid Deployment Force, which is designed to send American troops to world trouble spots in the event of an emergency.

title: AMERICAN GROTESQUES
description: FORGOTTEN IMPULSES By Todd Walton. 253 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $10.95.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE planning board has been giving me problems. I have been needing some new construction, but the planning board has turned me down. The board has ruled that the new work would aggravate an already ungovernable pollution that threatens to engulf us all. Not only that, the board has found that the proposed work is unesthetic in concept, location and function.

title: NEW ROUND IN SCHOOL FUNDS DEBATE
description: THE debate over school financing will be back in court and in committee this fall in a confrontation that has started to divide cities and towns along economic lines as the wealthier seek to keep the education funds they are getting while the poorer municipalities seek more.

title: Byers Beats Ovett in 1,500
description: Tom Byers of Eugene, Ore., outran Steve Ovett of Britain, the 1,500-meter world record-holder, and won that event today in the Bislett Games track and field meet. It was only the third loss of Ovett's career at 1,500 meters.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Today's vote was a profile in political courage and should inspire the gratitude of us all.''

title: Article 176318 -- No Title
description: Caribbean countries received assurances today of $700 million in development aid from other countries at a meeting sponsored by the World Bank.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY ISN'T S.J. PEARLMAN WORTH A STAMP
description: THIS coming Saturday, the United States Postal Service will issue a stamp commemorating the life and career of George Meany, the late labor leader and president of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations, who died in January.

title: News Analysis
description: The risks created by modern science and technology, Judge David L. Bazelon noted in a recent speech, present choices that sometimes require placing values on human life and health. And the problem of controlling the risks in those decisions, he said, has ''thrown the Federal regulatory agencies into a political and scientific maelstrom.''

title: Football Takes Weird Bounces
description: There's trouble in the nation's professional summer football organization, the American Football Association. One of its 10 teams, the Orlando Americans, has dismissed one of its linemen after discovering he was an impostor. And another of the teams, the Carolina Chargers of Charlotte, has virtually disintegrated in a fit of tempers over low pay and a lack of fans.

title: Derailment Delays Amtrak Runs
description: Nineteen cars of a Conrail freight train derailed here today, curtailing all Amtrak service between Washington and Baltimore, an Amtrak spokesman said. No injuries were reported in the noontime wreck. Delays of two to four hour were experienced between Baltimore and Washington and rail officials arranged bus transportation for passengers.

title: Leonard Is Eager for Hearns Showdown
description: The fight will go on despite his injured left hand, but Ray Leonard, more Spice than Sugar when it comes to Thomas Hearns, was acting as if he wanted the showdown earlier than scheduled.

title: CAR THEFTS MOUNT IN PARKING GARAGES Manhattan's theater district
description: ''I've heard of situations especially where there are long lines of cars waiting to get into a garage,'' said Donald Karp, president of a New York City parking-garage concern. ''A guy comes along the line wearing something that vaguely resembles an attendant's uniform and he's holding a bunch of tickets - used tickets he's picked up from the ground.

title: Sports of the Times; STRIKE INTERRUPTS GROTE'S COMEBACK
description: WHEN his wife told him last November that their 17-year marriage was over, Jerry Grote says he felt stunned, paralyzed. ''My entire life was changed,'' he recalls. ''I had to find something to do where I wouldn't have to think, where I could just go to work and turn on the switch and forget about everything.''

title: G.O.P. CONSERVATIONISM
description: During the first few months of the new Administration, the Grand Old Party of the conservation movement seems to have lost its way. Judging by the Interior Department's performance, I think that Republicans have abandoned their long, distinguished tradition of conserving and wisely managing our natural resources.

title: A Musicless Day Proposed By Musicians' Union Head
description: SALT LAKE CITY (UPI) - Victor Fuentealba would like to put a tax on blank recording tapes and turn off all the music in the world for a day.

title: Terese Souther Married To Christopher Cronauer
description: At. St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., yesterday Terese Marie Souther, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Patrick Souther of Muttontown, L.I., was married to Christopher David Cronauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Anthony Cronauer of Massapequa, L.I. The Rev. Robert S. Hewes performed the ceremony.

title: Around the Nation; Oregon Jury Convicts Man Of Murder and Sodomy
description: A 30-year-old former college football star was convicted today on one count each of murder and attempted murder and two counts of sodomy.

title: Court in Israel Orders Parliament To Reinstate an Ousted Member
description: The Israeli High Court today ordered the reinstatement of a member of Parliament suspended after being convicted on election bribery charges.

description: raiders By HENRY KAMM

title: ORIOLE OWNER IN MIDST OF FUROR
