description: Two weeks ago, before the Baltimore Orioles began their eight-game stretch against the New York Yankees, Edward Bennett Williams celebrated his first anniversary as the owner of the Baltimore club, for which he had paid $12 million.

title: REVUE: 'HARRY RUBY'S SONGS MY MOTHER NEVER SANG'
description: If a three-person musical revue boasts three stylish, gifted performers, can anything go wrong? On the basis of ''Harry Ruby's Songs My Mother Never Sang,'' the answer is a qualified yes. Not disastrously wrong, of course, but at least partly so. Given its cast and some of its material, this jolly hourlong show at the Manhattan Theater Club should fly higher than it does.

title: SUNY'S MUSIC TENT: A BRIGHT YELLOW BIRD SOARS OVER CAMPUS
description: PURCHASE WHEN the curtain fell at Pepsico-Summerfare last Sunday night after five weeks of dance, theater, music and circus arts on the SUNY Purchase campus, it seemed fitting that the one permanent structure built for the festival, a bright yellow, birdlike music tent, would remain as part of the Purchase landscape.

title: MISSING U.N. OUTRAGE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE GOVERNOR VETOES $1.6 BILLION BUDGET
description: Gov. Hugh J. Gallen angrily vetoed a $1.6 billion state operating budget today because it did not provide enough money for pay increases for state employees, who had staged a two-day work stoppage for higher pay.

title: Boxer's Widow Files Suit
description: The widow of Cleveland Denny has filed a lawsuit seeking $509,682 for the loss of her husband, who died almost a year ago from head injuries sustained in a fight with Gaetan Hart. The suit, filed in Quebec Superior Court yesterday, names Hart, the Montreal Athletic Commission and the Olympic Installations Board - the Government agency that manages the Olympic Stadium -as defendants along with Hart's trainer, Ralph Citro, and Pierre Gobeil, a sportswriter who acted as Denny's co-manager.

title: NEW TENURE RULING SOUGHT
description: THE State Board of Education wants the New Jersey Supreme Court to reconsider its decision denying tenure rights for teachers transferred under state-ordered school closings.

title: RESTRAINT ON STRIKE INSURANCE LIFTED CASE IS SHIFTED INTO U.S. COURTS
description: A Federal judge today dissolved a temporary restraining order, permitting Lloyd's of London to resume paying benefits on its part of a $50 million strike insurance policy held by the owners of the 26 major league baseball teams.

title: GATT TRADE PARLEY
description: The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the 85-nation agency that seeks to keep international commerce flowing, proposed today that a ministerial session be held next year to examine the overall situation of the global trading system. The GATT consultative group, a steering committee of 18 members representing all types of trading nations, agreed that such a meeting was needed after expressing concern because trade relations were ''beset by a number of complex and potentially disruptive problems.''

title: RESTRAINT ON STRIKE INSURANCE LIFTED NEGOTIATIONS BREAK OFF AGAIN
description: On the 15th day of a strike that has now caused the loss of 185 games, major league baseball's club owners and players remained far apart yesterday in their dispute over compensation to teams that lose premium free agents.

title: MEXICAN STEEL ISSUE
description: The private Mexican steel pipe company Tubos de Acero de Mexico S.A. is raising $80 million through an eight-year floating rate note on the Eurobond market, the lead manager, Merrill Lynch International & Company, said today.

title: NEC PLANS $100 MILLION U.S. PLANT
description: In what industry analysts are calling a bold move into the United States semiconductor market, a Japanese company, NEC Electronic U.S.A. Inc., announced today in Tokyo that it would build a huge semiconductor manufacturing plant in California.

title: Caring for Fish After Landing Them
description: MANY accomplished sport fishermen who hold their living prey in high esteem display an appalling lack of concern for its treatment after capture.

title: Reading and Writing; LENDING BOOKS
description: Summer vacation is a time for reading, and my friends come to me to borrow books because I have more than most people. In their innocence, they have no idea what I go through in lending a book. They don't understand that I think of myself as offering them love, truth, beauty, wisdom and consolation against death. Nor do they suspect that I feel about lending a book the way most fathers feel about their daughters living with a man out of wedlock.

title: Carter McShane Is Bride in New Vernon Of Bruce C. Conway, Shipping Executive
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., yesterday, Elizabeth Carter McShane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon McShane of New Vernon and Delray Beach, Fla., was married to Bruce Cameron Conway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Conway, also of New Vernon. The Rev. John Corr performed the ceremony.

title: STATE'S DIVERSE SANCTUARIES OFFER TRANQUIL FARE
description: ORCHIDS, carnivorous plants and panoramic views are just a few of the delights to be found in New Jersey's parks and wildlife sanctuaries, where thousands of acres and miles of trails are available for quiet summertime activities ranging from birdwatching, hiking and picnicking to simply sitting.

title: ARBOUR TO STAY
description: Nothing will change behind the Islanders' bench next season. Coach Al Arbour will stand there again, rarely smiling, seldom showing emotion and peering through his thick glasses.

title: Letters to the New Jersey Editor; KOSHER DINING BUT A PART OF STEVENSON HALL
description: In Gertrude Dubrovsky's otherwise informative second article on Princeton minorities (June 14), there were a few errors in the discussion of Stevenson Hall.

title: MILAN'S FASHIONS FOR FEET
description: On any given day in Milan, one can spot all of the latest trends in shoe design simply by strolling down the sundrenched pavements of Via della Spiga or Monte Napoleone, the two streets with the highest concentration of designer boutiques casually visited every day by the fashion conscious while they walk their dogs.

title: Alexander Kulch Weds Margot Horn
description: Margot Ann Horn, daughter of Mrs. John J. Rowan of Southampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to Alexander J. Kulch, son of Mrs. Anna Kulch Williams of Southampton and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Alexander Kulch. The Rev. Malcolm Foster performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's in the Dunes Episcopal Church.

title: Amy Rowen Wed To Thomas Bishop
description: Amy Rowen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Rowen of Rocky Hill, N.J., was married yesterday at the home of her parents to Thomas Harbison Bishop, son of Katharine T. Bishop of Haverford, Pa., and Dr. Harry C. Bishop of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Judge Russell Annich of the Princeton (N.J.) Borough Municipal Court.

title: L.I. 'TOWN MEETING' TO GET PRIME TIME
description: LONG ISLAND is going ''live'' on prime-time television Tuesday night, much to the delight of community groups that have been working over the last several years to get more television coverage of the Island by New York City stations.

title: Gary Madeira, Miss Goss Wed In Waterbury
description: Harriet Wheeler Goss 2d, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Middlebrook Goss Jr. of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Harry Rosengarten Madeira Jr., son of Mrs. Rufus C. Finch Jr. of New York and Harry Rosengarten Madeira of Haverford, Pa. The ceremony was performed in St. John's Episcopal Church in Waterbury, Conn., by the rector, the Rev. James G. Wilson.

title: Bridge; SOME LEARNING AIDES
description: For the player who has learned the rudiments, there are five ways to attempt to improve. The obvious one is to keep playing, on the theory that experience is a great teacher. This can work if the other players in the game are slightly better; many great players followed this route. But for the majority, something more is needed, and some combination of the following must be considered.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART In any great museum the department of prints and drawings is the secret garden to which everyone has the key, in principle. But not everyone knows how to turn it in the lock.

title: Chess; FOREGOING FAST GAIN CAN YIELD LONG-TERM RESULTS
description: The temptation is always there to grab the first thing available rather than to look deeper to discover a more potent way to get the upper hand. Especially when there is material for the taking, the chances are that it will be seized without even a serious glance at alternatives.

title: WEINBERGER URGING RETALIATORY ABILITY
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has instructed the armed forces to acquire the capacity to launch a conventional retaliatory strike against the Soviet Union wherever it would be to the United States' advantage, according to senior Pentagon officials.

title: CBS WANTS TO STAR IN THE MOVIES--AS ONE OF THE MAJOR FILM PRODUCERS
description: W hile movies have been booming at the box office the past few weeks, all is not well in the movie business. The majors are said to be retrenching and the independents falling by the wayside. And the reasons are legion: the skyrocketing costs of talent, production, promotion and distribution; the percentage of profits consumed by the rising prime rate; the impending directors' strike; the attrition rate of quality motion pictures; and the difficulty of closing favorable distribution deals and of collecting the agreed-upon share of box office receipts.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: DOCTOR FISCHER OF GENEVA: Or the Bomb Party, by Graham Greene. (Avon, $2.50.) It is the pleasure of Dr. Fischer, a self-made Swiss millionaire, to give dinner parties at which he first humiliates guests, then rewards them for being toadies. Finally, he stages a ''bomb party,'' his version of Russian roulette. Our reviewer Julian Symons found that Graham Greene's symbolism doesn't quite cohere in this novella, but that nevertheless it is the sort of tantalizing, smoothly told tale we expect of a master writer.

title: Long Islanders; IT'S OVER-THE-COUNTER FOR A STOCK IN TRADE
description: ''IN 1971,'' recalled Morton Weiss of East Hills, ''NASDAQ was created. That was probably one of the most significant things that ever happened to the over-the-counter market. For the first time, it gave us visibility that we had never had before. At the press of the button, you could see the market in any one of these securities.''

title: ECONOMICS IS STILL BASIC TO REAGAN'S POLITICAL STRATEGY
description: From President Reagan's perspective, the stakes in last week's budget battle were far larger than the few billion dollar difference between his proposal and the Democrats'. Less than 1 percent of total Federal spending is hardly the material for titanic legislative struggles.

title: Letters; NEIGHBORHOOD TRANSITION
description: To the Editor:

title: Baluchis Said to Plan Drive for Independence
description: Baluchi emigre leaders have decided to press for independence, possibly through guerrilla war in western Pakistan and eastern Iran, according to a study made public tonight by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a nonprofit foundation.

title: Grand Canyon
description: To the Editor: Our first visit to the Grand Canyon sustained all the superlatives ever showered on this wonder of wonders. The Canyon speaks volumes to the human spirit.

title: R. L. Roth Fiance Of Perri Parmett
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Parmett of Massapequa Park, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Perri Parmett, to Richard Lee Roth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Roth Jr. of New York.

title: Design; THE REGIONAL- STYLE FARMHOUSE
description: raditional American farmhouse styles are as peculiar to their regions as the speaking styles of the farmers who, over many generations, originated them. These nonarchitects created houses that were practical and as pretty as pragmatism, limited means and middling craftsmanship allowed. Shifts in style from region to region were born of variations in climate, materials available, degrees of prosperity and the builders' heritage.

title: Behind the Best Sellers; D.M. THOMAS
description: When the Hereford College of Education in western England closed down in a Government economy move three years ago, the former head of the English department decided to become a full time writer. So it was that D.M. Thomas proceeded to finish ''The White Hotel,'' the best-selling story of Lisa, the tormented opera singer whose life embraces Sigmund Freud and ends in the Holocaust at Babi Yar.

title: HELMS TAKES AIM AT 'SECULAR HUMANISM'
description: The time-honored image of the United States Senate as a club where members preen one another with baritoned rhetoric and genteel agreements may be fading, if the things being said lately about Senator Jesse Helms are any indication. Under pressure of the North Carolina Republican, who has made a career of pursuing relentlessly his own conservative agenda, the club may be evolving into a jungle where some of the Senate lions watch in beady-eyed anxiety for the stalker among them.

title: AUTO INSURANCE PLAN RAISES THORNY ISSUES
description: THE issue seems clear enough. The Commissioner of the state's Department of Insurance wants to change the way in which companies determine automobile insurance rates, and the insurers are opposing the change in court.

title: Sutton Hays, Artist, Is Wed To Dr. Walter Forwood Jr.
description: Priscilla Barton Hays, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Lansing Hays Jr. of Riverside, Conn., and Point O'Woods, L.I., was married at the Connecticut home of her parents yesterday to Dr. Walter Albert Forwood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Forwood of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. Gabe L. Campbell, rector of the First Congregational Church of Akron, Ohio, performed the ceremony.

title: Aronow Introducing Unlimited Catamaran
description: For 17 years, Don Aronow has been the biggest kid on the block. And why not? It's his block, after all, the swampy stretch of 188th Street in Florida's North Miami Beach. With his fortune made in real estate, Aronow returned to the first love of his youth -fast boats. And he started on 188th Street by creating a Formula boat company.

title: The Nation in summary; WEINBERGER FACING THE $100 BILLION DEFENSE QUESTIONS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has had more to contemplate than Maine sunrises on his coastal holiday. When he returns to Washington this week, a blue-ribbon panel is scheduled to give him its recommendations on where and how - in Western burrows, Minuteman silos, on yet-to-be-designed small submarines - to deploy the MX missile. And then there is the little matter of whether to revive the B-1 to fill in for the aging B-52 before the next, so-called Stealth (or less detectable) generation of bombers is airborne.

title: STATE BAR GROUP VOTES FOR REPEAL OF NEW LAW TO REGISTER LAWYERS
description: Calling a newly enacted lawyerregistration law ''inequitable and of questionable legal validity,'' the New York State Bar Association today urged that the law be repealed before the end of the current session of the Legislature.

title: Susan Black Is Married To Leigh Allen in Rye
description: Susan Ellen Black, daughter of Mrs. Christiane C. Lasker of Rye, N.Y., and Eugene R. Black Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Leigh Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Allen of Linwood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.

title: Major News in summary; NO WOMEN ALLOWED IN DRAFT SIGNUP
description: Congress's wish was the Supreme Court's command last week, insofar as coequal branches of Government can defer to one another. Ruling in what it considered more a matter of national defense than equal protection under law, the Court held 6-3 that Congress is within its constitutional rights in limiting draft registration, and presumably the draft itself, to men.

title: Mary C. Petersen Is Married To Frederick Fairchild Frost
description: The marriage of Mary Christina Petersen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Petersen of Greenwich, Conn., to Frederick Fairchild Frost took place yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: No Headline
description: John Kifner writes, ''For it was America, in the Iranian view, that supported and propped up the Shah, that took the oil, that profited from the enormous sales of arms and that helped train the Savak. The Shah, in the Iranian view, was a creature of the United States'' (''How a Sit-In Turned Into a Siege'').

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Soviet Union cannot remain indifferent to the new dangerous turn in the Chinese-American relations, especially to the plans of supplying China with modern American weapons, military equipment and technology.'' - A commentary in the Soviet newspaper Pravda. (1:2.)

title: EMPLOYEE HOUSING AID INCREASES
description: Claudia Ryan, a psychiatric nurse practitioner at Hartford Hospital in Connecticut, is purchasing a $40,000 condominium with the aid of a mortgage program begun this spring by her employers.

title: A Correction
description: An article last week about the nuclear-power plants in Lower Alloways Creek Township contained incomplete information about an alert that began shortly after midnight on March 11. Public Service Electric & Gas, owner of the utility, advised the township of the alert at 8:54 A.M. It also allowed a small group of local schoolchildren to make a scheduled tour of the facility while engineers looked for possible radiation leaks.

title: Crafts
description: TWO groups of veterans in the crafts field met recently to screen applicants for the fifth annual Morristown CraftMarket and a new event, Craft America, both scheduled to be held in the fall.

title: ONE MAN'S WATCH OVER COLT INDUSTRIES' STOCK
description: W HEN Colt Industries reported a 14 percent drop in 1980 earnings last January, a sharp drop in its stock might have been expected. Colt shares did lose 1 1/2 points the following week, but bounced right back and began to move up. The recovery was in part a result of 1980 being Colt's second most profitable year. But another important, albeit less quantifiable, factor was the company's aggressive investor relations program.

title: 3 NATIONS WIDENING NUCLEAR CONTACTS
description: An expanding pattern of nuclear contacts between Israel, Taiwan and South Africa has opened a debate within the Administration over whether the three nations are assisting each other in the development of atomic weaponry.

title: POP: CHUCK BERRY ROCKS THEM AT THE RITZ
description: As the great rock pioneer Chuck Berry demonstrated to a packed house at the Ritz on Thursday, youth and rock-and-roll are not necessarily synonymous. The graying Mr. Berry proudly pointed out that ''Maybelline,'' his first hit, was older than most of the jitterbuggers on the floor. Mr. Berry is not the only rock founder who has performed impressively in recent months.

title: At Home
description: THE Memorial Day parade was just a dress rehearsal for the orgy of national self-congratulation that will flash through thousands of towns next weekend, and I wouldn't eliminate so much as a single baton. The Fourth of July home-grown bash has very nearly everything: hot soldiers savagely poking at mosquitoes buzzing under their helmets as they try to stay in step; fife and drum corps rigged out in Revolutionary tricorns and Adidas sneakers; tuba players whose fiery, swollen faces suggest imminent cardiac arrest; ancient autos backfiring explosively at sleeping babies.

title: At Home
description: THE Memorial Day parade was just a dress rehearsal for the orgy of national self-congratulation that will flash through thousands of towns next weekend, and I wouldn't eliminate so much as a single baton. The Fourth of July home-grown bash has very nearly everything: hot soldiers savagely poking at mosquitoes buzzing under their helmets as they try to stay in step; fife and drum corps rigged out in Revolutionary tricorns and Adidas sneakers; tuba players whose fiery, swollen faces suggest imminent cardiac arrest; ancient autos backfiring explosively at sleeping babies.

title: No Headline
description: ''America in Captivity'' illuminated the events that precipitated the seizure, the reason for the extreme hatred of the militant students for the United States and the ramifications of this event for the world and for history.

title: Going Incognito
description: Patrick McDonnell

title: Realty News; DURST, IN WARNING, POINTS TO FORECLOSURES
description: Here is Seymour Durst, president of the Durst Organization, with real-estate assets in New York City of half a billion dollars, draping himself with a scroll of housing foreclosures.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Strangely Secret All-Star Vote
description: OF all the all-star games, baseball's is the only one with traditional values. Pro football's all-star game, the Pro Bowl, is an afterthought that resembles touch tackle; pro basketball's dissolves into a one-on-one pageant; hockey's should be scored by figureskating judges. But for nearly 50 years, the baseball All-Star Game has had a sense of meaningful theater - Carl Hubbell's five consecutive strike-outs, Ted Williams's game-winning homer, Willie Mays's perennial presence.

title: VICTORY IN EUROPE
description: EISENHOWER'S LIEUTENANTS The Campaign of France and Germany 1944-1945. By Russell F. Weigley. Illustrated. 800 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $22.50. By DREW MIDDLETON

title: THIS FAMILY'S FIREWORKS ARE NOT A METAPHOR
description: The following article is based on reporting by Harvey L. Bilker and Robert M. LaTorre and was written by Mr. Bilker. MILLINGTON ''YOU won't find anything like these made anywhere else,'' August N. Santore said, holding a 40-pound exhibition aerial shell containing 150 components.

title: HOW TO HANDLE HEALTH PROBLEMS AT THE SEASHORE
description: Summertime: At seashore resorts, the living is, as the song says, easy. Salt air. Soothing sunshine. Ocean swimming. Warm sands. What could be more benign? Millions of Americans seek these pleasures each summer, yet thousands of them have unhappy vacations because they fail to take the simple precautions needed to keep themselves healthy, even in such healthful environments as the Hamptons, Cape Cod, the Jersey Shore and the Eastern Shore of Maryland.

title: ONCE UPON A TIME THERE WAS ONE KOREA
description: It was flattering, the other day, to have one of my sons ask me to play tennis with him. It was sobering to have another say: ''You were in Korea during the war there, weren't you? What was that all about, anyway?''

title: Sound; LISTENING TO THE DIGITAL FUTURE
description: Giant steps are usually taken by giants, nobody else having the requisite stride. Last month the world of audio was treated to the rare spectacle of two giants stepping in tandem, departing boldly for the future. Before a gathering of technical experts and reporters at New York's Plaza Hotel, two of the largest and most innovative electronics firms - Sony of Japan and Philips of the Netherlands - showed and played prototypes of what they confidently propose as the digital phonograph of tomorrow.

title: Susan Eileen Shaw Is Wed
description: Susan Eileen Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Shaw of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Carl Mendenhall Webster, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul F. Webster of Altoona, Pa. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church. The couple are with Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co. in New York, she as a senior accountant and he as a senior tax specialist.

title: Food; DISCOVERING ROSEMARY
description: Most Americans aren't very familiar with the herb called rosemary. This probably has nothing to do with the once-popular belief that rosemary flourishes in the gardens of the righteous. More likely, it has been ignored by American cooks simply because they have been nonadventurous with seasonings in general, and rosemary is one of the most pungently scented of all herbs.

title: Normal Service Resumes At Burlington Northern
description: The Burlington Northern, the nation's longest railroad, resumed normal service today after a Federal judge ordered striking carmen to return to work.

title: Stamps; SAVING WILDLIFE HABITATS
description: The wetlands, the grasslands and even the mountains are all habitats of American wildlife that have been and continue to be diminished under the steady encroachment of man - just as the nation's farmlands have been rapidly disappearing as a result of the advance of suburbia and exurbia.

title: RACING-FIX INQUIRY: BOARD LACKS CLOUT TO HALT CORRUPTION
description: When the State Racing and Wagering Board opened hearings last week into alleged race-fixing at New York's throughbred tracks in the mid-1970's, it said that it was time to ventilate the charges and clear the air.

title: 'HIGH RISK,' 4-MAN ADVENTURE
description: There is a fluffy little white dog in ''High Risk,'' and this dog shares all the escapades of the film's four heroes, who travel to Colombia to carry out a heist. So what kind of adventure movie can this be? An unusual one, that's for sure. ''High Risk,'' which opened Friday at the Rivoli, is about four nice guys who don't really mean to hurt anyone. They just happen to be out of work and plot to steal $5 million, that's all.

title: Patricia McKiernan Is Wed
description: Patricia McKiernan and John Ciarleglio 3d were married yesterday in Calvary Episcopal Church. The Rev. Thomas Pike performed the ceremony. The bride, director of nursing services at H.I.P.-Manhattan Health Center, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John McKiernan of Daytona Beach, Fla. Mr. Ciarleglio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ciarleglio Jr. of West Haven, Conn., is a senior financial analyst with the General Motors Corporation.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC The 92d Street Y, with Omus Hirshbein as director of its performing arts program, has established itself as the East Side's leading home for classical music in recent years. But it has not heretofore ventured into the realm of off-season programming.

title: FIRE I. TAKEOVERS STIR NEW CRITICISM
description: by-100-foot plot of land he owned in the quiet Fire Island community of Ocean Bay Park.

title: Cornelia Ann Wagstaff Married to Lieut. Gifford Slater
description: Cornelia Ann Wagstaff, daughter of Col. David Wagstaff Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Wagstaff of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lieut. Gifford Wiggin Slater, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Grenville McVickar of Old Lyme, Conn., and John E. Slater of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Edwin Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church.

title: EVERYONE MAY BE GONE FISHIN'
description: FISHING off the New Jersey coast this year is the way it has been in recent years: Good. Although fishermen say the season got off to a slow start, there has been no dearth of the more popular species.

title: TRAINING PLAN MATCHES SKILLS AND JOBS
description: Dolores Hampton, wearing dungarees, a protective apron and heavy protective shoes, pushed the welder's shield back on her head and began to explain how she happened to be doing mig and arc welding in a huge structural shop in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Back From 'Dead'
description: Her car off the road and stalled in windy, 22-below-zero weather in northwestern Minnesota, 19-year-old Jean Hilliard set out on foot last Dec. 20 for a neighbor's house two miles away. Clad in leather boots, a coat and mittens, she collapsed 15 feet from the neighbor's door.

title: ISRAEL PREPARES TO RENDER ITS VERDICT--ON BEGIN AND ITSELF
description: year dynasty of Israel's Labor Party in 1977, is fighting again to foil the pollsters and politicians and foreign leaders who had settled into the complacent assumption, just months ago, that he was on his way out.

title: BELEAGURED TEACHER MAY GET JOB BACK
description: LAST October, following a decision by Dr. Fred G. Burke, the state's Commissioner of Education, John Gish lost what might be his last chance to become a teacher again. After seven years as an English teacher at Paramus High School and eight as an administrator there, he found himself standing on an unemployment line.

title: Soviet Bike Racers Fulfill Expectations in U.S. Debut
description: Battling temperatures in the 90's and altitudes of more than 9,400 feet, 70 of the world's top bicycle racers today launched the first leg of the nine-day Coor's International Bicycle Classic.

title: On the Isle; VANDERBILT CUP
description: William K. Vanderbilt 2d was not the ordinary kind of Long Island millionaire. He was a devotee of automobile racing, and back at the turn of the century this was pretty rarefied stuff. So devoted to the sport was he that he built himself a little highway, the Vanderbilt Motor Parkway, which from 1904 to 1910 was the site of the world's most prestigious and dangerous auto race, called - you guessed it - the Vanderbilt Motor Cup Race. Using Vanderbilt's extensive collections of photos, news articles and souvenirs, the Vanderbilt Museum has put together an exhibition, ''Vanderbilt Cup Race,'' which can be seen from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and noon to 5 P.M. Sundays through Oct. 31. Admission to the museum is $2.50; children and the elderly, $2.

title: Cornell Crew Is Defeated, But Gains Berth in Finals
description: Cornell University's eight qualified for the finals of the Holland Cup international rowing regatta despite losing by a length toda to the French national team at the Bosbaan course.

title: COMEDY FROM SWEEDEN TO OPEN
description: Sweden's longest-running comedy hit, ''Behavior Game,'' written and directed by Jan Bergquist, will be performed in English by its original cast at the Symphony Space, Broadway at West 95th Street, tomorrow through Thursday.

title: Joel H. Cook Weds Kate Page Biddle
description: Kate Page Biddle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Livingston L. Biddle 3d of Ligonier, Pa., was married yesterday to Joel Hammond Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Cook of Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Max E. Smith performed the ceremony at St. Michael's of the Valley Episcopal Church in Rector, Pa.

title: The Connaught
description: To the Editor: We, too, feel as Rona Jaffe did in writing ''The Connaught Is Like the Home of a Rich Friend'' (Travel Section, June 7). The hotel is everything she says it is.

title: SO WHERE'S THE GREAT BOND RALLY OF '81?
description: B Y rights, the bond market should be enjoying a headlong, thrill-aminute rally. The bond market, after all, is supposed to be the running register of investors' information, predictions and beliefs about the coming trajectory of inflation. As inflation slows down, long-term interest rates, in theory, decline as well. And lower rates mean higher bond prices, which, in turn, define a rally.

title: Youth Group Seeks Vote in U.S. Soccer
description: The United States Soccer Federation will hold its annual convention in Seattle this week with the key topic being a proposal to alter the structure of the governing body of soccer in this country.

title: OFFICIALS KEEP EYES ON OFFSHORE WATERS
description: BATHERS along the state's Atlantic coastline will find the waters generally clean and safe for swimming this summer. However, Federal and state environmental officials last week reported no discernible improvements in the long-standing pollution that lies just offshore and in some inland waters.

title: Julia K. Held Bride Of Randall White
description: Julia Karoline Held was married yesterday to Randall White in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Jamestown, R.I. The Rev. Charles Cloughen Jr. performed the ceremony.

title: CLOSED COURT IN LENNON CASE PLEA TERMED UNUSUAL
description: The decision to exclude the public and the press from the courtroom when Mark David Chapman pleaded guilty to the muder of John Lennon was proper but "very unusual," according to the deputy administrative judge in charge of New York City's courts.

title: A TOUCH OF THE 1900'S FOR CENTER MORICHES
description: CENTER MORICHES UNDER a Federal revitalization program, Center Moriches will receive approximately $2 million to restore the town to a turn-ofthe-century style. And local merchants, who view Center Moriches as ''nondescript'' and lacking in identity, are delighted.

title: Letters; MEMO TO THE FED: DISREGARD PREVIOUS MEMO
description: To the Business Editor: There are a number of serious flaws in John Winthrop Wright's ''Memo to the Fed: It Ain't Necessarily So About High Rates'' (June 21), two of which deserve at least a brief comment.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; LABORATORY OFFICIAL ACCUSED OF FUDGING
description: There are many ways to learn that honesty is the best policy, but former executives at Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories Inc., of Northbrook, Ill., chose the hard way. Four men, including former company president Boynton Calandra, were indicted last week on charges of falsifying test data for two widely used pesticides, Sencor and Nemacur, the arthritis drug Naprosyn and TCC, an antibacterial agent used in deodorant soap.

title: SIX VOCALISTS DISPLAY THE ART OF SINGING
description: Jazz singing is a term that cannot be pinned down with any exactness, particularly when the material being sung is a pop ballad. Most pop singers have enough jazz influence in them these days, and jazz singers have enough pop instincts to make it difficult to draw distinctions between the approaches that each might take to a ballad. Is one jazz and the other not?

title: Manila Cleric Says Marcos Stifles Religious Freedom
description: Cardinal Jaime Sin, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Manila, accused the Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today of stifling religious freedom in the Philippines.

title: 13 Fans Pay the Price For Watkins Glen
description: To the Sports Editor: I feel it disgraceful that Watkins Glen could not meet its financial obligations relative to last year's Formula One Grand Prix event. The most unfortunate result is, of course, that thousands of dedicated race fans will now be deprived of this heretofore premier East Coast event.

title: Canadians Withdraw From Whaling Commission
description: Canada announced last night that it was withdrawing from the International Whaling Commission because of a lack of ''any direct interest in the whaling industry or in the related activities of the commission.'' Canada outlawed commercial whaling in 1972.

title: U.S. OPEN: WHEN CLUB PROS PLAY GOLF WITH THE STARS
description: THE United States Open is the biggest, most important, most glamorous event on the PGA Tour - not only for top touring pros likely to win but also for non-touring club pros and amateurs. The special attraction about it to me is that it always is open to all who can play well enough to qualify against the best in the world - a real challenge for a golfer.

title: SOVIET DIPLOMACY: BLUFFING
description: DIPLOMACY OF POWER Soviet Armed Forces as a Political Instrument. By Stephen S. Kaplan with Michel Tatu, Thomas W. Robinson, William Zimmerman, Donald S. Zagoria and Janet D. Zagoria, Paul Jabber and Roman Kolkowicz, Alvin Z. Rubinstein, David K. Hall, Colin Legum. 733 pp. Washington: The Brookings Institution. Cloth, $29.95. Paper, $14.95.

title: GAINS EXPECTED IN SKILLS TESTS
description: TRENTON STATE education officials said last week that they expected the results of this year's Minimum Basic Skills tests - they are scheduled to be announced Wednesday at the State Board of Education meeting - to match the dramatic gains made last year.

title: New York Political Notes
description: In one of his first actions as the new Republican chairman of Manhattan, State Senator Roy M. Goodman has endorsed a Liberal for re-election as one of the two Councilmen at Large from the borough.

title: The Region in summary; AND FOR DESERT, BREAD AND WATER
description: There were bullets on the menu when Gov. William A. O'Neill of Connecticut summoned his commissioners to the Executive Residence for lunch last week. He ordered them to reduce spending by five percent, a move he said would cut the state's $2.98 billion budget by about $50 million, or roughly the amount Mr. O'Neill expects to lose in Federal aid.

title: The Region in summary; GO WEST, YOUNG BUILDERS URGED
description: The current zoning rules for midtown Manhattan, passed 20 years ago, are so riddled with amendments and special provisions that some planners question whether meaningful zoning codes any longer exist. Which is just as well, for last week, after two years of study, the City Planning Commission proposed new ones.

title: A WARM WELCOME FOR 'KISS ME, KATE'
description: WESTBURY WHAT a treat to see ''Kiss Me, Kate'' again. The Lee Guber and Shelly Gross touring production of Cole Porter's musical (at the Westbury Music Fair through July 5) couldn't be more felicitously timed. It caps the celebration of the late composer's birth month - he would have turned 90 three weeks ago; all June long, there have been Cole Porter soirees, tributes and revues. No, the show isn't being done just right, but it's only right - and high time - that it's being done.

title: World on Ice Show Opens July 14 in Meadowlands
description: Disney's World on Ice will have its world premiere July 14 at the Brendan Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. The show will be at the arena through July 28.

title: No Headline
description: George S. Clinton's Letter to the Editor about the Village of Hempstead as the center for the Long Island arts complex was both disturbing and insulting. His thoughts reflected the far too typical, twisted and elitist views of so-called ''knowledgeable'' people.

title: ATLANTIC MACKEREL; Scomber scombrus
description: Size: Length to 2 feet, weight to 4 1/2 pounds.

title: JURY ORDERS G.M. TO PAY 10,000 IN SWITCH OF ENGINES
description: A Federal jury ruled today that the General Motors Corporation must pay $550 to each of more than 10,000 purchasers of 1977 Oldsmobiles that contained Chevrolet engines.

title: Seeds of Settlement For Baseball Strike Exist With a Big If
description: It is as if the players' negotiators are seated at a table in Yankee Stadium and the owners' negotiators at a table in Shea Stadium. The two sides are, seemingly, so far apart in their effort to settle the baseball strike that they don't appear to be in the same ball park.

title: Barbara R. Smith and Richard Bryce Jones Are Married
description: Barbara Reynolds Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elting H. Smith of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Bryce Jones, son of Dr. and Mrs. John M. Jones of Exmouth, England. The Presbyterian ceremony was performed in the Huguenot Memorial Church in Pelham by the Rev. Donald R. Kocher.

title: AMERICAN DEFENSE: SPENDING
description: NATIONAL DEFENSE By James Fallows. 204 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95.

title: WHY BROOKLYN WANTS A MOVE UP
description: AFTER many months of evaluation of Division I status for Brooklyn College's athletic program, we are trying to bring our dream to reality. It would seem that a college's attempt to reclassify its athletic program to Division I would be a relatively simple process. Just obtain support from the college administration and secure funds to support the program. But this is definitely not the case.

title: PLAINS PROPERTY OF BILLY CARTER SOLD IN AUCTION
description: It required less than 45 minutes to end an era here today when an auction company that says it ''sells the world'' sold Billy Carter out of his hometown to satisfy Internal Revenue Service tax liens against him.

title: Hutchinson-Baker Team Wins
description: Joe Hutchinson and Tom Baker put together four consecutive strikes to rally and defeat Earl Anthony and Nelson Burton Jr. today in a $110,000 Professional Bowlers Association doubles tournament.

title: Mary B. Quaranta Wed to Accountant
description: Mary Beth Quaranta, daughter of Dr. Mary Ann Quaranta of Blauvelt, N.Y., and the late Dr. John V. Quaranta, was married yesterday in Manhattan to Edward R. Morrissey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward R. Morrissey of Brookfield, Conn. The Rev. Robert O'Connor, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: Fabi Wins Pole Position For CanAm Race in Ohio
description: With Paul Newman, owner of the car, watching, Teo Fabi of Italy won the pole position today for the $80,000 CanAm race tomorrow. In doing so, he set a speed record for the Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course with an average of 107.9 miles an hour around the 2.4 racing circuit.

title: DANCE: BALINESE FORMS BY ISLENE PINDER TROUPE
description: Islene Pinder, a faculty member in Lehman College's dance department, traveled to Bali in 1973 to study dance and became fascinated by Balinese dance and gamelan music. Four years later, she founded the Balinese-American Dance Theater, with the idea of providing American dancers with training in the Balinese dance forms.

title: ARTHUR DEUTSCH
description: Arthur Deutsch, retired administrative assistant at Bryant High School in Queens, died yesterday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. Mr. Deutsch, who was a longtime resident of Manhattan, was 79 years old.

title: A 'BLITHE SPIRIT' WITH LITTLE SPARKLE
description: HARTFORD WATCHING this ''Blithe Spirit,'' which I saw at the final preview before its official opening, I kept thinking of a television commercial I had seen recently. The commercial concerned fine crystal goblets that needed to be rewashed because they were spotted and dull looking. Well, ''Blithe Spirit'' is one of Noel Coward's finest comedies, a 1941 hit on both sides of the Atlantic. It is as bright today as it was then. Sir Noel brought total sanity to a highly improbable situation and created a witty and urbane comedy. However, like that spotted crystal, it is not being shown to best advantage at Summerstage here.

title: Letters; MEMTO TO THE FED: DISREGARD PREVIOUS MEMO
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Wright expresses the wish that the Federal Reserve Board be re-educated, assuming that a re-educated Fed would lower interest rates. In that, he is typical of many sensible men who have listened too much to economists.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Summer in the dance world begins on Tuesday with the opening of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival at Lee, Mass. This is the Pillow's 49th season since its founding by Ted Shawn, but there's nothing doughty about the season's concerts, which includes the newest avantgarde, modern and ethnic dance and even a little ballet.

title: CHARITY ON MISSION OF PEACE FOR CHILDREN OF ULSTER
description: When the winds and rainstorm hit Manhattan Thursday night, about 300 people were aboard a chartered Circle Line boat, drinking Irish coffee while a band of pipers played on. By the time the craft nudged into the East River, a rainbow had stretched across the sky.

title: Letters; BIASED ABOUT FITNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gallery View; PHILIP KING: IN A CHALLENGING PHASE OF DEVELOPMENT
description: It is now going on 20 years since English sculpture got up and danced, put on fancy dress and did impersonations. No one who was there at the time will forget the impact of the ''New Generation'' exhibition that was held at the Whitechapel Art Gallery in London in 1965 under Bryan Robertson's directorship. English sculpture at that time had been dominated by Henry Moore for three decades. Moore's way with the classic materials of sculpture - bronze, stone, wood - had come to seem almost mandatory. For the public he was Mr. Modern Art, as far as England was concerned, and as the English prefer to take their heroes one at a time there seemed every likelihood that he would hold that position in perpetuity.

title: A FAREWELL TO AFRICA
description: Gregory Jaynes has just completed 22 months as a correspondent for The Times based in Nairobi. By Gregory Jaynes We were burying three scrawny boys on a plain where dust devils danced. The Roman Catholic priest had closed the boys' eyes, but nothing could be done about the hideous set of their jaws. Their jaws were set so that the boys looked as though they had died laughing. In fact, they had starved. The wind got up, and with it the dust. The priest sneezed, used a rag to tend his nose and went back to work.

title: The Careful Shopper; Children's Clothes At Bargain Prices
description: Little Rascals is a retail store in Mamaroneck that became a discount establishment last February and found a quadrupling of its sales of children's clothes in sizes from infant to 14. Now each label shows the manufacturer's suggested retail price and the shop's 20 percent discount, or 10 percent on Carter's underwear, all firstquality name brands in clothing and accessories, with spring and summer fashions on extra markdowns now. The way the world of merchandising works, according to the owner, Charlie Nardi, fall snowsuits slumber in storage areas while new bathing suits have yet to visit the waterfront.

title: Theresa L. Mara Is Bride of Lawyer
description: Theresa Louise Mara, an assistant manager and a corporate credit analyst with the Chemical Bank in New York, and William Henderson Woolverton 3d, a lawyer with the New York firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn, were married yesterday in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. Raymond Flautt performed the ceremony.

title: Film View; WHERE ARE THE 'NEW WOMEN'?
description: Much in the manner of someone of wit and spirit who finds herself at a dull party and, refusing to tolerate the company of boobs, leaves forthwith, trailing a few well-elocuted rude words, Glenda Jackson swept in and out of New York last week in a two-day run of her heretofore-unseen-here 1978 film, ''Stevie.'' ''Stevie'' is certainly not a rude word, but the film, which is devoted exclusively to Miss Jackson's extraordinary performance, was a sudden, surprising reminder of how ineffectively have most of this year's movies made use of a lot of talented women.

title: STRAINS OF JAZZ FILL S.I.  FERRY FOR A FESTIVAL
description: They filed up the gangplank of the Staten Island Ferry yesterday morning with the purposeful trudge of the true aficionado, cameras, picnic baskets and tape recorders dangling from their arms. A clarinetist ran through a few scales as the fans watched from a respectful distance.

title: A CONCERTO FOR ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
description: If Marvin L. Minsky is correct, then one day, when a computer is programmed to exhibit human-style intelligence, it will also express a desire to listen to music. As one of the founding fathers of artificial intelligence, Mr. Minsky firmly believes in the possibility of machine intelligence. He also believes that music is intimately connected with intelligence, that studying one will shed light on the other.

title: NEW YORK GROUP OPPOSING BOND ISSUE FOR PRISONS
description: A statewide coalition of church and criminal-justice organizations has organized to combat Governor Carey's proposed $475 million bond issue for expanding and improving state and local prisons. The group argues that alternatives could overcome current prison overcrowding.

title: James Schwartz Jr., A Banker, Marries Miss Van Nostrand
description: Abbie Eaton Van Nostrand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. Abbott Van Nostrand of New York was married yesterday to James J. Schwartz Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs Schwartz of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony in St. James' Episcopal Church.

title: The New York Times Magazine; June 28, 1981
description: William Safire 7 On Language Out of Left Field Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Going Incgnito Willaim Stockton 14 The Technology Race Gregory Jaynes 23 A Farewell to Africa A correspondent seeks to come to terms with a turbulent, 22-month tour of duty on a continent he foun distressing, perplexing and compelling. Andrei Voznesensky 26 A Russian Poet's Homage to Pasternak Andrei Voznesensky, one of the Soviet Union's leading poets, acknowledges his debt to Boris Pasternak in a memoir that reflects on the genius of the author of "Dr. Zhivago." Craig Claiborne 36 Food with Pierre Franey Discovering Rosemary Jani Wooldridge 42 Fashion Wearing Insides Out Marilyn Bethany 44 Design The Regional-Style Farmhouse 61 Puzzles Answers. page 54 62 Letters Cover: Photograpy by Dan McCoy/Rainbow

title: HOW I SPENT MY BASEBALL VACATION
description: Make the best of it, I exhorted myself. Life without baseball doesn't have to be wretched. Regrettable as it is, the strike could be a marvelous opportunity. In the halcyon days befor June 12, after all, a typicla week included 15 ours watching games, another hour watching highlights of the games I'd watched, four hours reading the accounts and studying the box scores of the games I'd watched and four more hours - minimum - talking shop with the diamond junkies I've surrounded myself with. By my reckoning, life baseball would present me with the equivalent of an extra day every week. The siren of self-improvement beckoned.

title: Major News in summary; DEMOCRATS SET TRAP ON BUDGET CUTS AND WALK INTO IT
description: Just when Tip O'Neill thought it was safe to go back in the water.... The Speaker of the House and his loyal legions were victimized last week not so much by a Republican man-eater as by Democratic boll weevils. On a key procedural vote that party leaders hoped would regain for them the initiative that has steadily been slipping away to the White House, 29 conservative Democrats deserted to give Ronald Reagan the margin for his most impressive victory yet.

title: NEW YORK AREA EXPECTS TO LOSE MILLIONS IN AID
description: The package of budget cuts passed by the House of Representatives on Friday represents a serious and unexpected setback for the region's fiscal health, officials of New York and New Jersey said yesterday.

title: The World in summary; WISELY, BANI-SADR RUNS FOR HIS LIFE
description: President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr was impeached and vilified by the clerics last week, and if words could kill he would surely be as dead as the dozens of Iranians who were summarily executed for protesting his ouster. As it was, Mr. Bani-Sadr's fate could not be learned; reports had him variously holed up in Egypt, or Turkey, or his home city of Hamadan, or with Kurdish rebels.

title: POLLUTION OVER ATHENS HAS BECOME A POLITICAL ISSUE
description: A dark gray cloud of pollution, described by experts as worse than those of Los Angeles and Tokyo, has become an almost permanent feature of the sky over Athens, provoking politicians into disputes with an eye to the elections due in November.

title: HOW A COMPOSER AND CHOREOGRAPHER CREATE A NEW BALLET
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: No Headline
description: As one who lived in Iran and witnessed the Islamic revolution, I read the special issue on the hostage crisis with avid interest. I would like to contest one point - that we did not learn of the Shah's cancer ''despite a vast United States intelligence network in Iran.''

title: Leisure; IT'S TIME TO TAKE CUTTINGS OF GARDEN SHRUBS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kathy Freeland is a professional plant propagator. By KATHY FREELAND

title: IONA: SCOTLAND'S ISLE OF SAINTS
description: On Oct. 19, 1773, Dr. Samuel Johnson and his devoted biographer, James Boswell, reached the shores of the Scottish island of Iona in the Inner Hebrides. After what Dr. Johnson records as a tedious sail, the two men embraced on reaching the place ''whence savage clans and roving barbarians derived the benefits of knowledge, and the blessings of religion.''

title: Robert Murphy, Lawyer, Weds Mary Beth Piasio
description: Mary Beth Piasio, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Piasio of Old Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert S. Murphy, son of Mrs. Arthur M. Shelton Jr. of Kensington, Calif., and Robert B. Murphy of Petaluma, Calif. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I.

title: Washington; WHAT'S GOING ON?
description: This is probably the most talkative capital in the world, but it still hasn't had the semblance of a coherent debate about President Reagan's foreign policy.

title: Connecticut Housing; BLOCK PARTY: A TRADITION RENEWED
description: I am having a block party for the residents of our street this Fourth of July. The invitations have been circulated. The replies are in. There will be traditional cookout fare and games for the children.

title: ALL BUT COMPUTERS HAD CLEAR SAILING
description: The largest sailing regatta on the East Coast, the Storm Trysail Club's Block Island Race Week, came to a close today as the 1,700 participants, most of them Long Island Sound sailors, abandoned the pastoral island for a return to the real world.

title: The World in summary; HASSAN MAKES A CONDITIONAL OFFER
description: With a royal flourish, Morocco's King Hassan offered last week to accept an internationally supervised referendum to decide the future of the Western Sahara. He thereby thwarted the hopes of his enemies, the Polisario guerrillas, to gain new legitimacy.

title: Illinois Governor Favors Rise in Mass Transit Funds
description: Gov. James R. Thompson said today that he would be willing to provide more money for mass transit if Republican leaders can assure him that the proposal will be approved by the Legislature.

title: Prospects; HERE COMES CLAUSEN
description: An important changing of the guard occurs this week. Robert S. McNamara retires as president of the World Bank, turning over the reins to A.W. Clausen, former head of the Bank of America.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: LOVE AMONG THE BUTTERFLIES The Travels and Adventures of a Victorian Lady. By Margaret Fountaine. Edited by W. F. Cater. Illustrated. 223 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $16.95.

title: U.S. Collegiate All-Stars Defeat Japanese Squad, 4-3
description: Augie Schmidt of the University of New Orleans smashed a two-run homer in the top of the fourth inning to lead the United States collegiate all-stars to a 4-3 victory over Japan's college all-stars today before 15,000 spectators.

title: ARMY OVERSEAS CITES PROBLEMS OF FEMALE G.I.'S
description: ''The personnel policy of the Army for several years regarding the assignment of women has made their presence throughout the battlefield, with attendant risks, a reality.''

title: New Jerseyans
description: ''THE epic story of one of America's most severely maligned ethnic groups, the Italian-Americans,'' is the publisher's description of a new book by Patrick J. Gallo of Glen Rock.

title: Amelia Newcomb, Paul Trevithnick Marry in Weston
description: Amelia Ames Newcomb, daughter of Mrs. Frank Dillingham of West Redding, Conn., and Wellington Ames Newcomb of New York, was married yesterday to Paul Byers Trevithick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Trevithick of Belmont, Mass. The Rev. John Macort, chaplain of the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., performed the ceremony in the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn.

title: Haughton Stable Suspended
description: The judges at the Meadowlands race track have suspended the Billy Haughton Stable and one of its trainer for 30 days each for a drug violation in a stakes race.

title: Howitzers in '1812' Finale Too Realistic for Texans
description: The Dallas Symphony Orchestra teamed up with four Marine Corps howitzers for a bang-up rendition of Tchaikovsky's ''1812'' Overture this week.

title: THE GENE MACHINE HITS THE FARM of their new usage
description: By ANN CRITTENDEN

title: Business Conditions; SOME GIVE IN COLLECTIBLES
description: According to the fifth annual survey of 15 different types of tangible and financial assets, a very odd couple -Chinese ceramics and American equities - appreciated the most in value last year. However, for the first time since Robert S. Salomon, general partner and director of stock research at Salomon Brothers, investment bankers, started to track the performance of these items, certain commodities and collectibles actually declined in value from a year earlier.

title: Dr. Brooke Millon Barton Wed
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Dr. Brooke Millon Barton and Newton Lee Ormasa, 1975 graduates of Princeton University, were married by Msgr. James G. Wilders.

title: Jeanne Bussiere Is Wed To James W. Stephens
description: Jeanne Elaine Bussiere, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Bussiere of East Setauket, L.I., was married yesterday to James Walter Stephens, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Stephens of Allentown, Pa. The Rev. Philip Zaeder performed the ceremony at the nondenonimational Sylvia Platt Kemper Chapel of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., where he is the Protestant chaplain.

title: Art; VIRTUOSITY AS A STIMULUS TO CREATIVITY
description: LONG BEACH THE most creative and expressive of artists are often not the best craftsmen; the opposite is also true. It is indeed possible to master one's craft so completely that technical proficiency becomes the overriding concern, reducing the work to immaculate but empty exercises.

title: City Council Schedules 3 Committee Meetings
description: The following City Council meetings have been scheduled for this week: TUESDAY - Committee on State Legislation, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Health, to consider licensing and protection of horses and amending rates for horse-drawn cabs, City Hall, 11 A.M.

title: Letters; THE USE OF 'AFFECTIVE VALUE CLARIFIERS' TO GET KIDS TO 'SELF-ACTUALIZE'
description: To the Editor:

title: A TRIP ABOVE THE CLOUDS ON A VENEZUELAN CABLE CAR
description: The cable car swept silently up the mountainside, a hundred feet above the steep slopes. Above, at 16,429 feet, the rocky summit of Pico Bolivar, Venezuela's highest peak, stood silhouetted against the sky. Below, the city of Merida lay dwindling in the haze.

title: Woman Kills Husband, Thinking He Is a Burglar
description: A Bronx woman shot her husband to death yesterday afternoon, in the mistaken belief that he was a criminal trying to break into their apartment, the police said.

title: The Energy Outlook; LULLED TO SLEEP BY THE OIL GLUT MIRAGE
description: T HE oil crisis has given way to the oil glut. This perception is reinforced by an almost daily litany of price reductions on the world market. Yet, the word ''glut'' is misleading, for it suggests that the days of easy availability have returned. This is a dangerous and potentially costly illusion, based on a misinterpretation of what is going on. What we have is a breathing space, not deliverance.

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Squeeze, who are at the Ritz Sunday and Monday night, have written and recorded some of the most infectious pop-rock of the past few years. Like the Beatles and the Kinks, their principal influences, they think pop music should be melodically memorable as well as danceable; their songs, co-written by the guitarists Glenn Tilbrook and Chris Difford, are songs you can sing in the shower.

title: HAITIANS' PLIGHT FRUSTRATING TO ALL SIDES
description: As the boatloads of Haitian refugees stream across the summer calm of the Florida Straits and the crowding increases in the Federal holding camp near the Florida Everglades, immigration officials, resettlement workers and community activists share a common sense of futility, of trying to trap water in sand.

title: Business Conditions; NO SPRING YET FOR COPPER
description: In terms of important market fundamentals, copper producers should be pleased right now. After a bad year in 1980, when the industry suffered through a long strike and a precipitous drop in demand, the elements of a turnaround seem to be falling in place.

title: ROYAL WEDDING IS FOCUSING ATTENTION ON THE INCREASINGLY COMMON PROBLEM OF DIVORCE
description: Next month, when Lady Diana Spencer's mother and father go to St. Paul's Cathedral for their daughter's marriage to Prince Charles, they will sit together in the front pew, with their present spouses sitting somewhere behind.

title: Letters to the New Jersey Editor; SOLAR POWER IS SAID NOT TO BE COST EFFICIENT
description: In the June 7 issue of the New Jersey Weekly, Fletcher Knebel wrote an article about a solar-heated, solar-cooled home (''Using the Sun to Cut the Cost of Living''). Unfortunately, the cost and savings data in the article do not support the conclusion implied by the headline.

title: Propects; MEDICARE COSTS GET CUT
description: Washington's largest single benefit program - Medicare - celebrates its 15th birthday this week. It's likely to be an unhappy one. Inflation, a rapidly aging population and the need to cut costs in entitlement programs are likely to force sharp reductions in what has been viewed as a sacrosanct area of government spending.

title: Letters; TO BE PRINCIPLED IN A CYNICAL WORLD, WITHIN LIMITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; HIGHWAY ADVICE: LIVE AND LET LIVE
description: THE people who really should read this article probably have discarded the newspaper already. That's a shame, for it deals with a rather important topic: Life.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage View; DOES THIS PLAY NEED A STAGE?
description: I'm going to have to explain my favorite dialogue exchange in Wendy Wasserstein's ''Isn't It Romantic'' and explaining it is naturally going to spoil it, but we'll just have to chance the damage. How else am I going to tell you what it is I like, and what it is I doubt, about the new ''feminine sensibility'' piece that's been commissioned by the Phoenix Theater for workshop production and that will be giving its final performance tonight?

title: Letters; MEMO TO THE FED: DISREGARD PREVIOUS MEMO
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Wright's article is a pro-inflation hustle.

title: DANCE: DIANNE MCINTYRE'S SOUNDS IN MOTION
description: Dianne McIntyre has been making dances for her Sounds in Motion company for just under 10 years. If the messages and their delivery sometimes seem a little simplistic, hers is dance that goes its own way, throbbing with an affecting sweetness and rebellion. And she herself is a very fine performer. So it was good to have the company back Thursday at the Symphony Space, augmented by a topnotch jazz ensemble that is alone worth a trip to the theater.

title: Barner Wins Six-Day Race On 430 Miles
description: The six-day Go-As-You-Please race ended this afternoon at Cooper River Park and all 13 starters finished with an assortment of gaits that ranged from all-out sprints to limping walks.

title: THE TECHNOLOGY RACE
description: Andrew Carnegie sold his Carnegie Steel Corporation in 1901 to the J.P. Morgan syndicate for $480 million, believed to be one of the largest financial transactions the world had then known. Carnegie was the epitome of the self-made man, a daring and creative entrepreneur whose example beckoned to legions of immigrants and promised that hard work would lead to success. Carnegie's steel corporation was a symbol of a young nation that stood at the brink of an era of world economic and political dominance. Everything seemed to be in America's favor then: abundant natural resources, throngs of eager new citizens ready to work hard and a national spirit marked by frontier brashness, inventiveness and supreme self-confidence.

title: Virginia Joan Carroll Is Wed To Thomas Francis Daly 3d
description: Virginia Joan Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Roberts Carroll of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Francis Daly 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daly of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman performed the ceremony at the Carroll home.

title: COOKING FOR THE HEARTY PALATE OF THE MAYOR
description: Well-known for his strong opinions and the candor with which they are often expressed, Mayor Koch apparently has an equally strong palate and definite preferences in food.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN ENERGY? THE CLOTHESLINE
description: WHEN the Long Island Lighting Company raises its rates, we all look for ways to save energy. Lilco suggests that if we all use our appliances at off-peak hours - that is, say, 3 in the morning - it might help. But I like better a suggestion from Palo Alto Public Utilities in California, which announced proudly that it had an innovative solution to the high cost of energy.

title: NJ TRANSIT HOPING IT PAYS TO ADVERTISE
description: NEWARK ANYONE who has ridden a bus this weekend already knows: NJ Transit has been threatening massive fare increases and alterations in service since April, and yesterday fares averaging 20 percent higher became reality for some 255,000 bus riders.

title: KREMER HOLDS KEY ROLE IN RUSH TO ADJOURN
description: ALBANY THERE is no escape these days for Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer of Long Beach. His colleagues parade into his office, accost him in the hallways, corner him in restaurants, block the path to his car. If he leaves his office early, they have been known to berate his secretary. ''The poor girl,'' Mr. Kremer said. ''She told me, 'Even my mother never talked to me that way.' ''

title: Susan Alicia Mann Wed
description: The Abbey Chapel of Mount Holyoke College was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Alicia Mann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard O. Mann of Chappaqua, N.Y., to Francis Whitten 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Whitten Jr. of Stoneham, Mass. The Rev. J. Earl Naegele, pastor of the Faith Presbyterian Church in Emmaus, Pa., officiated. He was assisted by the Rev. John Seidenschwang, the bride's maternal uncle, who is principal of the Holy Trinity Diocesan High School in Hicksville, L.I.

title: Patrice Sachs Is Married To Dennis Jon Anderson
description: The marriage of Patrice Sachs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Brice A. Sachs of Convent Station, N.J., and Walton-on-Thames, England, to Dennis Jon Anderson took place yesterday in the chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station. The Rev. Stephen W. Findlay performed the Roman Catholic ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. John Alexander.

title: Prospects; BAND-AIDS FOR THE THRIFTS
description: Given the clout of the savings and loan lobby, Congressional steps to rescue the beleaguered business from the ravages of inflation were probably inevitable. However, financial analysts contend the array of proposals currently circulating in Washington is unlikely to provide more than limited relief.

title: TRAFFIC 'DANCE' ENDS, BUT DEBATE GOES ON
description: HUNTINGTON AFTER a second go-around, the ''Barnes Dance'' traffic signal here has been retired, taking with it a cacophony of car horns and a troop of jaywalking pedestrians, but leaving behind an unresolved traffic problem.

title: Mary Ann Scheideler Wed
description: Mary Ann Scheideler, daughter of Elisabeth Scheideler of Yonkers and the late Joseph Scheideler, was married yesterday in St. Eugene's Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers to Philip Murray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Murray.

title: Practical Traveler; CUTTING THE COST OF PHONING FROM ABROAD
description: During a recent stay at the Sheraton-Stockholm Hotel in Sweden, William T. Hazard, a business executive from New York, had to telephone the United States. He later recounted his experience in a letter to Howard P. James, chairman and president of the Sheraton Corporation at its headquarters in Boston:

title: Miss Supplee, Don Chesser Plan Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cochran B. Supplee of New York and Wassaic, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Angela Turner Supplee, to Don Francis Chesser, son of Mrs. Ermel F. Chesser of Athens, Ohio, and the late Mr. Chesser. A September wedding is planned.

title: Connecticut Guide; NO HOLDS BARRED
description: Professional wrestling makes it debut at the Hartford Civic Center at 8 tonight with a card said by the promoter to be ''the greatest ever lined up in Connecticut.''

title: No Headline
description: A group of limited partners of the Islanders has filed suit against the pending sale of its share in the team to Long Island Cablevision. The group is taking the case to State Supreme Court in Mineola Tuesday to seek an injunction against the transaction.

title: Dalai Lama to Visit the West
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan religious leader, will leave here on Monday for a six-week lecture tour of Britain and the United States, his spokesman said today.

title: TOXIC WASTE BILLS ADOPTED IN ALBANY
description: The Legislature gave final passage last night to parts of a 13-bill package aimed at improving the shipment, disposal and treatment of hazardous wastes, including a measure that would - for the first time - allow felony prosecution of people responsible for the illegal dumping of hazardous materials.

title: DOUBTS UNRESOLVED ON TEXAS DROWNINGS
description: The party would go on all night. But at 11 P.M., as the festivities were just gathering steam, the drownings that would mar memories of the day and create a furor whose tremors would reach Washington, were about to happen.

title: Topics; PASSAGES-AN EXTRA MOMENT
description: It has been a lovely month, the best June we remember in a long time. There have been more of those warm, bright blue mornings that have not yet sunk into languor, and fewer chill, damp reminders of April's false hopes or May's cautious flowering.

title: SOLDIERS AREN'T COPS
description: Drug-law enforcement agencies, losing their battles against marijuana smugglers and the President's budgetcutters, are seeking military assistance. They want the Navy to track yachts and shrimp boats, the Air Force to chase planes, and the Army to flush suspected smugglers from Florida swamps.

title: COUP ATTEMPT FAILS IN BOLIVIA AND PLOTTERS ARE SEIZED
description: Bolivia announced today that an effort to topple its President, Gen. Luis Garcia Meza, had been thwarted without bloodshed and that the Bolivian Army commander and Chief of Staff had been arrested as plotters.

title: Food; SPECIAL CAKES TO TOP A PARTY
description: PORT WASHINGTON SUMMER is a great time for entertaining, but not for cooking - and especially not for baking elaborate desserts. That's where La Mise en Place, a catering company that recently moved here, comes in.

title: Headliners; THE TOAST OF MOSCOW
description: Amanda McKerrow, an American visitor to Moscow, created an international incident last week.

title: R. K. Emerson Jr.  And Ellen O'Meara Are Wed in Maine
description: Ellen Ketchum O'Meara, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. O'Meara of Waterville and Hancock Point, Me., was married yesterday to Robert Kennerly Emerson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson of Huntington, W. Va., and Hancock Point. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Clague-Davies at the Hancock Point Chapel.

title: PLANE CRASH KILLS 2 AIDING IN SEARCH
description: Two men died today when their light plane crashed as they returned from a search for a woman whose plane went down in Colorado five days ago.

title: IS THE U.S. IN TOO DEEP TO 'DISENGAGE' ON NAMIBIA?  army
description: When a high-powered State Department delegation flew to South-West Africa this month to try to breath some life back into a plan for the disputed territory's independence, the commentator on the state-owned radio station here professed to see the visit as the expression of ''an entirely changed international political scenario'' in which the United States was finally standing up to Soviet expansionism. The Reagan Adminstration, a subsequent bulletin proclaimed, was negotiating with South Africa on ''closer military ties.''

title: New Jersey Housing; PLANNING HOUSING FOR THE ELDERLY
description: BURTON BERGER was frustrated. An architect, he hates to see blinds and draperies closed, as many were during a recent visit to Baldwin Oaks, a 250-unit apartment project for the elderly in Parsippany.

title: Headliners; HOW RESPONSIBLE?
description: That Mark David Chapman had killed John Lennon no one disputed.

title: No Headline
description: Your special issue is a remarkable piece of journalism that fills in many gaps and provides a more understandable picture.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; REFINING THE LAW ON SEARCH AND ARREST
description: A search warrant is not an arrest warrant, but it can be nearly as good. In a 6-3 vote, the Supreme Court ruled last week that a warrant to search a home for contraband gives the police the power to temporarily detain individuals on the premises. The decision reversed a Michigan Supreme Court ruling in the case of a Detroit man detained while his home was searched for narcotics.

title: CEDAR WALTON, FIRST IN SOLO PIANO SERIES
description: Cedar Walton opened the 10-day Kool Jazz Festival, formerly the Newport Jazz Festival, with a solo piano recital late Friday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Walton, the first of a series of pianists who will perform as soloists in Carnegie every afternoon at 5 o'clock throughout the festival, except Sunday, played four neatly organized sets in a neatly organized program that was a summation of his basic characteristics.

title: Letters inflation; HOW DOES YOUR DOLLAR GROM?; IN DEFENSE OF HOUSING'S APPEAL
description: To the Business Editor: I was concerned to read ''Homes Losing Appeal'' (June 7), which stated that housing appears to be losing its appeal as a hedge against inflation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on the marriage of Andrea Phyllis Some and Lloyd Jon Goldstein gave an incorrect date because misinformation was supplied to The Times. The couple plan to marry in June, 1982

title: Magic Number's New Definition
description: To the Sports Editor: The ''magic number'' for the New York Yankees is 181 (as of June 28, 1981). Any combination of games will result in the clinching of the American League East title for the Yankees. DAVID I. KASS Washington

title: New Jersey Journal; by Daniel Akst
description: QUICKER divorces, tougher alimony enforcement and fairer custody arrangements were recommended to the State Supreme Court last week by a 23-member, court-appointed panel that spent two years on the problems of tearing asunder what hasn't quite held up for better or for worse. The court promptly agreed, vowing to adopt the committee's specific recommendations.

title: SEASHORE OPTIMISTIC ON SEASON
description: POINT PLEASANT BEACH EACH June, as it has for decades, this Ocean County community undergoes a rapid transformation from a sleepy seaside retreat to a full-fledged summer resort.

title: CAMPS TO OPEN TOMORROW FOR FRESH AIR FUND YOUNGSTERS
description: Today, as she has for the last several days, Shelley Stoughton will walk into a quiet corner of the Model Farms building on the Sharpe Reservation in Fishkill, N.Y., and look expectantly at three dozen eggs warming in an incubator. And if everything goes well, sometime today tiny beaks will poke through shells and the miracle of life will be celebrated again.

title: TEXT HJ'S AT 39 INCHES
description: On LanguageBy William Safire Out of Left Field Kimble Mead

title: Dining Out; BY LAND OR LAKE, A NAUTICAL MOTIF
description: LA BONNE VIE on Lake Mahopac has long been discovered by those who approach its dockside from waterskis or boat. Entering the restaurant from the other direction, landmen, too, will find that the dock, suspended over the water, makes an unusual and pleasant place to have a drink or a meal while one watches swift, silent sailboats cut across the vast lake, busy gaggles of geese, and willow trees cascading into the water that gently laps the shore. Much of this panorama can be appreciated through the large window of the dining room as well, but we would save that view for other seasons and chilly evenings. Right now, outside is where the action is.

title: THE FARMERS GO TO MARKET
description: STONINGTON ''SUPPORT your local crops,'' the new battle-cry of Connecticut's agricultural community, symbolizes a grassroots movement born of the need to protect small farms in the state and to give consumers freer access to better quality food at lower cost.

title: FOR LIMITING A TEACHER'S USE OF PUNISHMENT
description: THE New Haven Board of Education's recent decision to ban corporal punishment in New Haven schools demonstrates that in a world full of violence there are determined citizens in leadership roles who assume the total responsibility of maintaining an educational system that nurtures and protects children in every way possible.

title: EXPORTS OF WASTE CAUSE CONCERN
description: American corporations are increasingly looking overseas for places to dispose of unwanted hazardous wastes, a situation that is causing growing concern among Federal officials and environmentalists, who fear that there will be disasters in health and foreign affairs unless stricter rules are enacted.

title: Television Week
description: The Arts in Preview Are the performing arts in this area about to wilt under the summertime onslaught of heat and humidity? Not a chance. And Channel 13 has evidence. Starting Sunday night at 11, Channel 13 is broadcasting ''Summercast Live,!'' a four-part series telling viewers all about the abundance of things to see and hear in theaters and concert halls around town in the weeks ahead.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE state's overcrowded psychiatric hospitals came up for intensive review last week after there had been charges of violence against staff members at some of the institutions. The review could lead to smaller patient loads at the largest institutions.

title: Dance View; THE ROYAL'S LATEST WORKS
description: If it is too soon to sum up the Royal Ballet's present season in New York, its first since 1976, the initial week of premieres and new productions did tell us something about the great British company's current creative side. In view of its emphasis on the full-length 19th-century Russian classics, it is easy to forget that the company's artistic profile has always been molded as much by its contemporary repertory, as by its living museum pieces.

title: Church in Spain Forbids Divorces Under a New Law
description: Roman Catholics in Spain were forbidden today by the Bishops Conference to obtain divorces under the relaxed terms of a new law.

title: A PLEA FOR SELF-SERVICE GAS STATIONS
description: FOR more than 30 years, New Jerseyans have been prohibited by law from pumping their own gasoline. New Jersey is one of two states (Oregon is the other) where self-service filling stations are banned.

title: Home Clinic; ROOF GUTTERS GET CLOGGED? PROBLEM IS EASY TO OVERCOME
