description: GUTTERS are installed along the eaves of most houses to carry away rainfall. The gutters empty into the downspouts, or leaders, which channel the water to ground level. At that point, the water is safely carried away from the house foundation by means of drainage pipes or splash pans.

title: America In Captivity
description: My congratulations to every contributor to the special issue, ''America in Captivity: Points of Decision in the Hostage Crisis'' (May 17). It is the finest piece of journalism I have read in some time, and is totally in keeping with the tradition of The New York Times. SISTER GRACE DEVOTA, Brentwood, N.J.

title: Letters to the New Jersey Editor; THE STATE HAS A RIGHT TO ITS OWN CULTURE
description: Marsha Gwynne Sloat, the writer of an Opinion Page article on June 14, is obviously unaware that business, ''industrial and private,'' has not failed the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. It seems equally obvious that she does not realize that only by government support, whether state or national, can any symphony, including the New York and Philadelphia Philharmonics, exist.

title: Karen Louise Alderfer Wed to Peter Whelan 2d
description: Karen Louise Alderfer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Harr Alderfer of West Chester, Pa., was married there yesterday to Peter A. Whelan 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Joseph Whelan of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Robert D. Young performed the ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church.

title: MOSCOW CALLS U.S. DECISION TO SELL ARMS TO CHINA 'HIGHLY DANGEROUS'
description: In its most authoritative comment yet on the United States decision to sell arms to China, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda described the move today as ''an escalation of reckless policy'' that was ''highly dangerous for the cause of peace.''

title: A. M. Donaldson And Georgia Cobb Married in Capital
description: Georgia Harkness Cobb and Alexander Macfarland Donaldson were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church in Georgetown, Washington. The Rev. Peter Gerrard Winterble and the Rev. William M. Sharp performed the ceremony.

title: MUSIC: BAROQUE SOLOISTS PLAY MODERN WOODWINDS
description: The New Baroque Soloists, who made their formal debut Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House, believe they are following a ''third course'' between anachronism and fanatical purism in the performance of 17th- and 18th-century music. The group rather defiantly performs on modern woodwind instruments - although one member does alternate between oboe and oboe d'amore, and the keyboard instrument is a harpsichord, not a piano.

title: Headliners; UNMITIGATED LIES
description: The charge against John Demjanjuk - that he lied to get into the United States after World War II - was proven at the start, because he admitted it to the judge. His five-week trial in Cleveland was actually about mitigating circumstances. Mr. Demjanjuk, a Ukrainian by birth and a former soldier in the Red Army, said he had lied to avoid being sent back to the Soviet Union.

title: Numismatics; CROWN-SIZE COIN BEING ISSUED FOR ROYAL WEDDING
description: The royal wedding of Britain's Prince Charles and Lady Diana Spencer is still a month away, but souvenirs have gone on sale already, and coin collectors have not been forgotten. Dozens of coins and medals are being struck to mark the happy event.

title: GAY PRIDE PARADE
description: The Gay Pride March will begin on Christopher Street at noon today. Marchers will move east on Waverly Place to Washington Square, north on Fifth Avenue to 79th Street and then to the Great Lawn in Central Park, where a rally will be held.

title: The National Archives
description: To the Editor: In the article by Seth S. King entitled ''Seeking Family History on a Visit to the National Archives'' (Travel Section, June 7), there is a misleading statement regarding ships' passenger lists. Mr. King says there is a gap in them for the Port of New York from 1847 until 1896.

title: Anne Hawthorne Dallas Wed to Gerald Vernon Jr.
description: Anne Hawthorne Dallas and Gerald Angier Vernon Jr., were married yesterday in the Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church in Pleansantville, N.Y. The Rev. Francis Ralph performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: 38 Food Establishments Named Health Violators
description: The New York City Board of Health released the names last week of 38 food establishments cited for violations of the city's Health Code.

title: Cassandra Moseley Is Wed to Jeffrey Berry
description: Cassandra Hamilton Moseley and Jeffrey Savage Berry, 1980 graduates of the University of Vermont, were married at the Governor Dummer Academy in Byfield, Mass., yesterday. The Rev. Robert Bryan performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Moseley Chapel, given by the bride's family in the 1960's in memory of Moseleys who had served as trustees of the academy.

title: Letters; IRAQ HAS NEVER SHEATHED SWORD AGAINST ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Men Die as Single-Engine Plane
description: Falls Near Airport in South Jersey

title: At Home
description: THE Memorial Day parade was just a dress rehearsal for the orgy of national self-congratulation that will flash through thousands of towns next weekend, and I wouldn't eliminate so much as a single baton. The Fourth of July home-grown bash has very nearly everything: hot soldiers savagely poking at mosquitoes buzzing under their helmets as they try to stay in step; fife and drum corps rigged out in Revolutionary tricorns and Adidas sneakers; tuba players whose fiery, swollen faces suggest imminent cardiac arrest; ancient autos backfiring explosively at sleeping babies.

title: Art; CONTRADICTIONS THAT FASCINATE
description: WATER MILL THOUGH he is only 36 years old, John MacWhinnie has been a presence in Long Island painting circles for 15 years. He had his first solo exhibition at the Cord Gallery in Southampton in 1966, followed by a number of shows at Southampton College. He has also been featured at the Parrish Art Museum and garnered a prize at the Heckscher Museum for excellence in painting.

title: 'MIDSUMMER DREAM' STAGED BY PETER HALL
description: On a midsummer's night, the Glyndebourne Festival Opera unveiled its new production of Benjamin Britten's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' in a staging by Peter Hall filled with shimmering magic and melting ravishment.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN NAIROBI
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- GREGORY JAYNES has just concluded a tour as the New York Times correspondent in East Africa, based in Nairobi. By GREGORY JAYNES

title: The Nation in summary; DETROIT BUCKS THE ANTI-TAX TIDE
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young had invoked all the old civil rights images and last week, as in the glory days of the movement, his people responded. By a vote that corresponded exactly with the racial makeup of the city (64 percent black, 36 percent non-black), Detroiters approved a 1 percent increase in the city income tax, a move the Mayor said was crucial to the city's solvency and its continued political and financial independence.

title: PASSION AND PROSE
description: A small boy walking through a school bus ''accidentally'' drops his books on a small girl's head. When the girl reports what that terrible Bobby did, her mother says ''That means he likes you.''

title: MORTGAGES PAY OFF FOR INSURER
description: Max Karl did not really intend to work at the nation's first private mortgage insurance company - the one that he founded in 1957 and that made $82 million last year, after taxes.

title: Libyans Hold Talks in Moscow
description: A Libyan military delegation headed by former Prime Minister Abdul Salam Jalloud held talks with the Soviet Defense Minister, Marshal Dmitri F. Ustinov, the Tass press agency reported today. It did not specify the nature of the talks yesterday beyond saying that questions of mutual interest were discussed.

title: Long Island Journal
description: CULTURE pays off, not just esthetically, but also financially. At least, that is the conclusion of a study conducted by the Suffolk County Office of Cultural Affairs. The office, working with the Economic Research Bureau at the State University at Stony Brook, found that the arts generated $12,960,290 for the local economy last year, when 58 groups got county aid for 69 different projects. The data for the report was gained by scrutinizing applications for funds from a total of 74 organizations.

title: CRUDE TRIUMPH
description: It will take days, even weeks, to figure out what Congress has done to the Federal budget and an array of Great Society programs. The process of ''reconciliation'' - by which thousands of programs were being made to conform to previously determined spending ceilings - has been too complex and hasty for anyone to know what precisely has now been legislated. But there should be no doubt that President Reagan's success in getting a Democratic-led House to follow this all-in-one procedure affirms his dominance in Washington and represents a major triumph for his conservative cause.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: HOLIDAY GENERATES 'SPASM OF PATRIOTISM'
description: WITH myriad fireworks and festivals, this Fourth of July promises to be one of the merriest celebrations in years. As one of the state tours executives puts it: ''People seem to be having a spasm of hometown patriotism -or maybe it's not having the money to travel very far.''

title: Ex-Jersey G.O.P. Chief Is Barred by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former state Republican chairman, Nelson G. Gross, should be barred from practicing law in the Federal courts in New Jersey because of his 1974 conviction for campaign fraud.

title: Editors' Choice
description: IF ON A WINTER'S NIGHT A TRAVELER, by Italo Calvino. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $12.95.) A novel about reading fiction, by the Italian master.

title: CHANGES SOUGHT IN NEW YORK STATE'S NOMINATING PROCESS
description: The state chairmen of New York's major parties are considering possible changes in the complex system of nominating candidates for statewide office.

title: LEARNING TO LIVE AS A WOMAN ALONE
description: SURVIVAL tests are not confined to remote areas of Australia or fringes of the Yukon. It may be that our most typical test of the new decade is being waged in suburbia by women who are, or who recently have become, single.

title: JOE NAMATH HOPES TO SCORE IN THE THEATRICAL ARENA
description: Heavy eyelids, a quick and easy grin simultaneously assured and vulnerable, tanned almost too deeply and evenly to be true, tennis shirt over shoulders bent into a relaxed bow, an amiable shamble of a walk, jeans a bit too long breaking slightly over sneakers, Joe Namath imparts the unmistakable impression that walking through life is a continual gas.

title: No Headline
description: I would like to send congratulations to The New York Times for its in-depth coverage of the hostage crisis, and special praise to A.M. Rosenthal for his compassionate preface. MIRA J. SPEKTOR, New York City

title: Recordings; GREAT TENORS REVISITED
description: It always seems to surprise some people when an opera singer bursts through the narrow confines of the music world and becomes an international celebrity. Luciano Pavarotti is today's example of that phenomenon, now a household word and about to star in a film. Actually, Mr. Pavarotti is just the latest in a line of tenors to make this leap. Enrico Caruso, Beniamino Gigli, John McCormack and Richard Tauber enjoyed equal reclame outside the opera house, and they, too, attracted a large following through the film medium. In their different ways, all four had the ability to take their training and discipline in an aristocratic art and, with little or no compromise in vocal standards, bring their message to the people.

title: Diocese to Require Counseling
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Hartford is planning to require couples who want to be married in a Catholic church to fill out computerized questionnaires and attend counseling sessions. Starting Aug. 1, they will be required to fill out a 161-question form and enter a six-month counseling program. Donald Paglia, a lay counselor, said yesterday: ''It's really an expansion of what we're already doing in marriage preparation, except that it's always been optional in the past.''

title: Architechture View; WHEN AMERICANS DESIGN ABROAD
description: Ihave a profound mistrust of pictures of impressive construction in distant cities of the world. This stems from a visit to Caracas in the 1950's, and coincides with my first published opinion in this paper - a letter to the editor -while I was still a freelance writer. The letter was inspired by a favorable review of an exhibition of photographs of new architecture in Venezuela; the buildings shown were a series of dramatic, high-rise towers of the most stylish modern design, dramatized even more by bold patterns of sun and shadow that highlighted the sophisticated slabs on a handsome Caracas hillside. This was new public housing, and it was meant to be the answer to the favelas, those shanties of cardboard and corrugated iron that housed the poor on another Caracas hillside.

title: Antiques; 10-YEAR PROJECT COMPLETED
description: NEW LONDON IT has taken 10 years of planning, fund-raising and hard work, but the 18th-century stone house -known romantically if erroneously to many as the ''old Huguenot House'' - now is open to the public. The small gambrel roof structure, built in 1759 for Nathaniel Hempsted and his family has been restored, repainted and furnished to appear much as it might have when the Hempsteds lived there more than 200 years ago.

title: THATCHER AIDES FEAR TIME IS GROWING SHORT
description: Month after month, the number of people unemployed in Britain continues its seemingly inexorable increase. Last week, the total reached 2,680,977, according to official figures, highest in the postwar era and more than 11 percent of the work force.

title: STOCKMAN'S PLAN BORE FRUIT
description: President Reagan's victory in the House of Representatives yesterday was the fruit of a strategy that was as audacious as it was far-reaching.

title: Business Conditions; FARM MACHINERY BLUES
description: High interest rates and low farm earnings continue to spell bad news for farm equipment manufacturers, who saw sales plummet last year. The industry's sluggish performance is forcing downward revisions in sales forecasts for 1981.

title: A BOLD POLISH PAPER WINS READERS BUT WORRIES CENSORS
description: Some months ago Maciej Szumowski, the editor of the Cracow daily newspaper Gazeta Krakowska, was having technical difficulties with the press run. The paper was late and still not on the stands when his phone rang. It was a call from Solidarity union leaders in the gigantic Nowa Huta steel mill: They just wanted him to know that they were drawing up strike plans because, they assumed, the censor had stopped publication.

title: SIGNALS POINT TO MOSCOW'S DARKEST HOUR Ogarkov, and Andrei A. Gromyko
description: There are two ways of looking at the Soviet Union from the West. Both invariably are expressed at international conferences and study groups, and they are not necessarily contradictory.

title: Kathy Gore Bride Of Walter Whitney
description: Kathleen Patricia Gore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Gore of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Walter Asa Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Lester Whitney of Washington, Conn. Msgr. R.T. Rastatter performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: POUND RIDGE GROUP HOME IN DISPUTE
description: POUND RIDGE IN the latest development in a two-year dispute between Pound Ridge and a state agency over the placement of a community residence for the developmentally disabled, the Town Board has proposed an alternative site for six autistic young adults, who now live in a residence established by the agency in April on Lower Shad Road.

title: Camera; THERE ARE DIFFERENT WAYS TO STUDY PHOTOGRAPHY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this paper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: Claire Sandifer, an Editor, Bride of J. Tyler Tuttle Jr.
description: Claire Eveleen Sandifer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Sandifer Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Juillac, France, was married in Juillac yesterday to J. Tyler Tuttle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Tuttle of North Chatham, Mass., and West Palm Beach, Fla. Mayor Jacques Mara,can of Juillac performed the ceremony at the Town Hall.

title: IN ISRAEL, CAMPAIGN ADS ENTERTAIN NIGHTLY
description: Some of the best entertainment in Israel now comes on television every evening after the 9 o'clock news. The screen is suddenly filled by the Israeli flag with its big Star of David. The music soars, and a chorus of cheerful voices breaks into the bouncy jingle of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc: ''This time you have to decide/ whether we continue forward/or take a step back.''

title: GUITARIST: ARNAUD DUMOND
description: New York had the exceptional good fortune to welcome Arnaud Dumond to its concert life Thursday evening. Mr. Dumond, a lutist and guitarist from France, enjoys so fluent and articulate a technique that listeners at Carnegie Recital Hall could proceed directly to matters of musicality. Here there was much to enjoy.

title: EGYPTIAN SAYS SADAT IS TRYING TO SPLIT LAW GROUP
description: The head of the Egyptian Bar Association said today that President Anwar el-Sadat's ruling National Democratic Party was trying to dismember the association's governing council because it opposes Mr. Sadat's signing of the peace treaty with Israel.

title: WATERLOO FESTIVAL SEEKS FINANCIAL STABILITY
description: STANHOPE WHEN Percival H.E. Leach and Louis D. Gualandi founded the Waterloo Music Festival in 1968, they envisaged it as another Tanglewood. And indeed, such artists as Jan Peerce, Beverly Sills, Pablo Casals and Eugene Istomin have been among those who have performed in this historic and pastoral Sussex County setting over the years.

title: Photography View; A SOMMER RETROSPECTIVE; WASHINGTON
description: Throughout his career Frederick Sommer has functioned as a gadfly within photography. Instead of a single style and subject, he has seemed to possess four separate photographic personalities, each battling for dominance. There is Sommer the Surrealist, the maker of collages with such odd titles as ''The Eatable Thief'' and ''All Children Are Ambassadors.'' There is Sommer the Purist, whose detailed views of the Arizona desert bespeak Edward Weston and the f/64 tradition. There is Sommer the Symbolist, who sends out messages in the spirit of Alfred Stieglitz. And there is Sommer the Bauhaus craftsman, who has experimented with cliche verre (prints from a glass negative), out-of-focus nudes and studies of cut paper.

title: The World in summary; HAIG'S LIMELIGHT NO FUN TO BASK IN
description: An effort by aides of Alexander M. Haig Jr. to make him look more influential and skillful, at the expense of the American delegate to the United Nations, boomeranged last week.

title: Marcia MacHarg Bride of John McNally 3d
description: At the Community United Methodist Church in Slingerlands, N.Y., yesterday, Marcia Louise MacHarg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. MacHarg of Slingerlands, was married to John Morris McNally 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McNally Jr. of Philadelphia. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Luther Patton, assisted by the Rev. Robert McNally, uncle of the bridegroom and a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Notes; SCUBA-DIVING VACATION PACKAGES IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: A variety of scuba-diving packages is being offered this summer in Tobago, Cura,cao and the Cayman Islands by several tour operators. Scuba Tobago is an eight-day program with accommodations at the Crown Reef Hotel at Store Bay. Participants may choose a five-dive package for $399 a person in double occupancy or a 12-dive package for $474; an accompanying non-diver pays $90 less. Round-trip group air fare from New York, including the 15-minute transfer between Trinidad and Tobago, is $199. Included in each package are ground transfers, two meals a day, use of diving equipment and membership in the Cousteau Society.

title: Turkey Warned by U.S.  On Goods for Pakistanis
description: The Reagan Administration has urged the Turkish Government to end the secret shipment to Pakistan of millions of dollars worth of sensitive equipment that could be used to build an atomic bomb.

title: Theater; PRODUCER TEMPERED BY TOUGH BOYHOOD
description: ''GORDON CROWE is a former juvenile delinquent.'' That's the complete and unexpurgated ''bio'' that appeared in - and was deleted from - the program of the Off Broadway play, ''The Butler Did It,'' which Mr. Crowe produced.

title: POP: GAIL NELSON AT SWEETWATER'S
description: Gail Nelson has so much going for her as a singer - her vocal range, which goes from an easy pop style to the edges of an operatic approach; her appearance, tall and striking, and her presence, easy and gracious - that it is surprising that she does not make a more powerful impression at Sweetwater's, Amsterdam Avenue at West 68th Street, where she is appearing this week and next.

title: The Nation in summary; SMALL IS BEAUTIFUL, BUT BIG IS O.K., TOO
description: ''Monopoly in all its forms,'' John Stuart Mill once sternly stated, ''is a taxation of the industrious for the support of indolence if not plunder.''

title: WORD FROM THE OLD SOUTH
description: THE PAPERS OF FREDERICK LAW OLMSTED Volume II: Slavery and the South 1852-1857. Edited by Charles E. Beveridge and Charles Capen McLaughlin. Assistant Editor, David Schuyler.Illustrated. 503 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $27.50.

title: MOSES IS FIRST AND FOREMOST
description: F OR a fleeting moment track and field history appeared in the making. Edwin Moses was losing a 400-meter hurdles race. After eight of the 10 hurdles in the final of the USA/Mobil outdoor championships in Sacramento, Calif., last Sunday, Andre Phillips led Moses by a meter. Three seconds later, Moses led Phillips by a meter. Moses won by four meters, easing up at the finish. Andre Phillips had become the fourth fastest intermediate hurdler in history, an achievement almost lost in Edwin Moses's 63d consecutive victory in a final (and 69th, including preliminaries) since 1977.

title: CONTRASTING ECONOMIC FORTUNES
description: TORRINGTON EARLY next week, Torrington will be the site of two business events that illustrate the contrasting economic fortunes of northwestern Connecticut. On Tuesday, a sewing-machine needle factory on Field Street will close its doors. This will complete a process that has eliminated more than 300 jobs since the Torrington Company, the largest employer in the region, sold the needle business last year.

title: McEnroe Was Close To Being Defaulted
description: The All England Club was prepared to default John McEnroe from the Wimbledon tennis championships earlier this week for his opening-day outburst, Earl (Butch) Buchholz, the executive director of the Association of Tennis Professionals, said today.

title: The World in summary; IRAQI PRESIDENT PROVIDES GRIST FOR BEGIN'S MILL
description: Saddam Hussein last week supplied the quotation Menachem Begin's speechwriters had been looking for. All peaceloving countries, the Iraqi President said, should help the Arabs ''obtain the nuclear bomb in order to confront Israel's existing bombs.''

title: MILES DAVIS: 'I JUST PICK UP MY HORN AND PLAY'
description: The way Miles Davis tells it, whether dealing with his music or his women, all he needs to do is put aside the past. Sitting in the darkened living room of his West Side brownstone, just after the recent announcement that he will resume his performing career with two appearances next Sunday at the Kool Jazz Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, the acclaimed 55-year-old trumpeter is explaining his philosophy of art as well as life. The two performances will mark his first public appearances in five years.

title: ON HEELS OF DROUGHT, RAINS IMPERIL MIDWEST CROPS
description: Last year Bill Lain was upset because he could not afford to buy an irrigation system to improve the yields of his struggling corn and soybean crops in drought-stricken Lake County. This year the 33-year-old farmer is fretting about how to overcome losses caused by heavy rains and flooding.

title: IN BOOMING TAIWAN, FARMS SUFFER
description: Booming Taiwan is having trouble keeping 'em down on the farm now that they've seen the assembly line, and the Nationalist Chinese Government is advancing what it calls ''a second land reform'' to combat some of the success of its first program, undertaken soon after its retreat from the mainland in 1949.

title: Miss Cunningham Bride of Bruce Minevitz
description: Katherine Rodell Cunningham, daughter of Mrs. Henry M. Irwin of Philadelphia and the late Edward Cunningham Jr. of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Bruce Howard Minevitz of Hingham, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Minevitz of Hull, Mass. Judge Jerome A. O'Neill of the Court of Common Pleas performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Chestnut Hill Academy.

title: PARENTS WING THEIR WAY HOME
description: THE swallows of Capistrano may be harbingers of the warm months to some people, but in Connecticut the period is heralded by birds of quite a different feather: the migratory parent. With the first daffodils, as soon as a no-frost forecast is guaranteed, the senior generation wings its way home from the South. All those grandmothers in golfing skirts and grandfathers in fishing caps return to the bosom of the families they head - weather permitting.

title: Elizabeth M. O'Neil, Teacher Married to John H. Stedman
description: Elizabeth Mary O'Neil was married yesterday to John Hallowell Stedman in St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Farmington, Conn. The Rev. James J. Conefrey performed the ceremony.

title: A RUSSIAN POET'S HOMAGE TO PASTERNAK
description: Copyright c 1980, Andrei Voznesensky. Published by arrangement with V.A.A.P. Page 27 Cornell Capa/Magnum

title: REAGAN'S AIDES SAY A BALANCED BUDGET IS POSSIBLE BY 1984
description: Three of President Reagan's top advisers said today that yesterday's budget vote in the House of Representatives would hold down Federal spending by $100 billion over the next three years and pave the way for a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1984.

title: EX-EPISCOPAL BISHOP IN CALIFORNIA
description: C. Kilmer Myers, the retired Episcopal Bishop of California whose radical social and political views and conservative theological positions earned him influence beyond his church, died yesterday at the University of California Hospital in San Francisco. He was 65 years old and had been hospitalized for more than a week. He lived in Healdsburg, Calif.

title: U.S. AND ITALY BREAK UP HERION SMUGGLING OPERATION
description: United States and Italian authorities say they have broken up what American officials call ''the major organization'' using Italy as the route for smuggling Southwest Asian heroin into this country.

title: 'THE BLAKEY LEGACY,' TRIBUTE TO THE DRUMMER
description: ''The Blakey Legacy,'' a tribute to the drummer Art Blakey and his Jazz Messengers Bands, ignited Friday on the opening night of this year's Kool Jazz Festival with a bang at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Blakey's Messengers have been a tough finishing school for jazz soloists for more than 25 years, and several distinguished graduates, including Freddie Hubbard, Jackie McLean and Johnny Griffin, were on hand.

title: SENATE TO CONSIDER NEW PINELANDS BILL
description: TRENTON THE Senate Natural Resources and Agriculture Committee will meet tomorrow to consider a bill that would wrest principal control of the 1,000-square-mile Pinelands Protection Area from the state's Pinelands Commission and return it to county and local officials.

title: The Week in Business; INFLATION SO FAR THIS YEAR: UNDER 10%
description: Inflation's pace continued to ease in May. The Consumer Price Index increased seven-tenths of 1 percent, or 8.4 percent on an annual basis, which puts the inflation rate at less than 10 percent this year.

title: NEW ORLEANS INSPIRES THE NEVILLE BROTHERS
description: New Orleans looks and feels like a humid Caribbean metropolis, with its colonial architecture, its verdant tropical foliage, and its relaxed pace. The city's music is Caribbean, too. The sounds of rhythmic street drumming drift out of its black neighborhoods on summer afternoons, and at Mardi Gras, black carnival clubs parade in elaborate finery, beating tambourines, beer bottles and other percussion instruments and singing lustily in the call-and-response pattern that is characteristic of much African-derived music.

title: PIZZA FANS SET A STATE RECORD FOR MOZZARELLA
description: The production of mozzarella cheese in New York State rose to a record level last year, suggesting that New Yorkers and others are eating more pizza, according to figures released this month by the State Crop Reporting Service.

title: Ann Thomson Kramer Bride Of Richard Morrow Ross 3d
description: Ann Thomson Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Kramer of Branchburg Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard Morrow Ross 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ross Jr. of Dallas, Pa. The Rev. Stephen Bolle performed the Episcopal ceremony at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: What has shocked me deeply is the incompetence of our military leaders. The failure of the rescue mission shows that no matter how much we raise the military budget and how well-armed we are, if we don't have competent leadership and manpower, we'll fail miserably if a similar situation occurs. JOHN ESPOSITO, New York City

title: Long Island Housing; RECENT HOME SALES
description: Nassau Floral Park Elizabeth St. 4-bedroom, 2-bath Cape Cod $84,000 Walk to railroad. Taxes $1,900 Great Neck Stony Run 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath expanded ranch $180,000 Taxes $5,000 Lynbrook Webster St. 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath Colonial $75,000 Den with fireplace. Taxes $1,700 Oyster Bay Hill

title: At Home Abroad; ISRAEL: THE TWO NATIONS
description: It has been the bitterest election campaign in Israel's history, and possibly the most important. The world sees the issues of peace and of Menachem Begin's provocative personality. But underneath there is something else, involving the very nature of this country. It is symbolized by a politician unknown to the outside world, David Levy, Minister of Absorption and Housing in the Begin Government.

title: UNION VOICES THE GRIEVANCES OF SOUTH AFRICAN BLACKS
description: It started as a dispute over the maintenance of a toffee-wrapping machine at South Africa's biggest candy factory.

title: A CAMPUS BRAIN DRAIN
description: This spring, the 39-year-old plant biologist finally won tenure at his university in upstate New York. After 15 years of teaching and a respected research record, his salary was still $24,000, a sum that the university more than recouped through its share of his outside research grants. When the chance came last month to join a friend in a new start-up company, for almost double the money, he jumped at it. He is breaking the news to the university this month.

title: Ellen Remmer Married
description: Ellen Eugenie Remmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Remmer of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in the First Congregational Church to Christopher Anthony Fox, son of Mrs. Mary Fox of Hamden, Conn., and William Fox of Branford, Conn.

title: Topics; PASSAGES-MARKED TIME
description: Before the fiscal crisis of 1975, New York's Bureau of the Budget was General Staff to the city government. Its officials tramped the corridors of city departments, scrutinized their books, tyrannized hiring and carried themselves as though, like Bismarck's officers, they had red stripes running down their trousers.

title: YUCCA ADDS A TOUCH OF THE SUNNY DESERT
Cynthia M. Weeks Wed To William L. Lawlor
description: The marriage of Cynthia Marie Weeks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Doughty Weeks Jr., to William Lovat Lawlor, son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Lawlor, took place yesterday at the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham, N.Y., where both families live. The Rev. Donald Kocher performed the ceremony.

title: YOUNG FIRM SHAPING FUTURE OF TWO AREAS site
description: For architects, the opportunity to shape a new town or to rebuild vital parts of a major city rarely arises. Yet both tasks are under way at present in New York City - the development of Battery Park City as a new town at the western tip of lower Manhattan, and the redevelopment of 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. One architectural design firm, founded only two years ago, has taken on both of them.

title: REVIVAL FOR STOCK OPTIONS?
description: By KENNETH B. NOBLE

title: The Week in Business; BRONFMAN'S SURPRISE BID FOR CONOCO
description: Seagram, the company that Edgar M. Bronfman (right) heads, is known for its whisky.

title: Investing in Gold
description: Its vaults stocked with gold that it had bought in the era before inflation, the United States Treasury announced in July 1980 that it was in the retail gold business. In competition with South African Krugerrands, it offered two medallions at market prices: a Grant Wood one-ounce for $645, a Marian Anderson half-ounce for $322.50.

title: Pat Bradley Catches Mrs. Melton for a Tie
description: In what shapes up as a rerun of last year's final round in the Ladies Professional Golf Association Sarah Coventry tournament, Nancy Lopez-Melton and Pat Bradley finished the third round today as they started it - tied for the lead.

title: WESTERN STATES GIRD TO FIGHT ATTEMPTS TO LIMIT COAL TAX
description: Angered by suggestions that the tax policies of Western coal-producing states are unfairly driving up energy costs, governors and other officials in the Rocky Mountain region are girding for a major battle over efforts in Congress and the courts to limit the amount of taxes a state may levy on coal mined within its borders.

title: CRIME AND PUNISHMENT IN L.A.
description: THE GLITTER DOME By Joseph Wambaugh. 299 pp. New York: Perigord Press/William Morrow & Co. $12.95. By EVAN HUNTER

title: New Jersey Guide; IT'S HOLIDAY TIME AGAIN
description: The Fourth of July weekend will be marked by all sorts of fare, from the standard parades and outdoor feasts to classical music and, of course, fireworks.

title: No Headline
description: I have studied and taught business strategy and policy at the university level for many years (''Going the Military Route,'' by Drew Middleton). Since the structure and purpose of policy, strategy and operations management are identical in business and the military, I feel qualified to comment on Mr. Middleton's findings from that point of view.

title: Antiques; A FOUR-PART AUCTION OF QUALITY GLASSWARE
description: On a summer day in 1952 while vacationing in the Hague, Jopie and Helfried Krug were caught in the rain and, to escape, ducked into an antiques shop. The visit was fateful, lasting long enough for the couple to become enamored with the period glassware they found there -18th-century European vessels that reminded Mr. Krug of similar glassware that he had inherited from his grandfather but had paid little heed to.

title: R.D. Bewkes Weds Elizabeth S. Howe
description: Elizabeth Storm Howe, daughter of Jean Storm Howe of Millbrook, N.Y., and William Lester Howe of Lincoln, Neb., was married yesterday to Robert David Bewkes, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Garrett Bewkes Jr. of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. E. Clay Frye, uncle of the bride, performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Altamont Inn in Millbrook.

title: City Hall Fire Peril
description: After two big fatal hotel fires in the country - the MGM Grand Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., and Stouffer's Inn in Westchester County, N.Y. - Mayor Koch ordered a check of fire protection in New York City municipal buildings. One result: City Hall was found to be a potential firetrap last January.

title: Building Collapses in Brooklyn
description: An abandoned three-story building collapsed Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn, and the police and the Red Cross relocated 15 people from a building next door, for fear that it would collapse, too. The building that fell was at 147 Skillman Street, near Myrtle Avenue, the police said. One minor injury was reported, but they said no one was hurt in the evacuation of the occupied structure, No. 149.

title: Other Business; E.F. HUTTON'S REGAL REPORT
description: When E.F. Hutton talks, people listen. When E.F. Hutton poses, people are riveted to the page. The investment giant's latest offering is a slick collection of portrait photography, almost $400,000 in the making, that immortalizes in museum-quality black and white E.F. Hutton's executive elite and their photogenic clientele.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: Music; THE SOUND OF MUSIC GRACES THE SUMMER
description: EVEN as Yale in Norfolk and Music Mountain continue their bountiful service to music lovers in northwestern Connecticut, two other major summer festivals are getting ready to cheer residents in midstate and along the shoreline, and a third, Wesleyan's Summer at the Center, is off and running - as of last Thursday.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA - An- nounced the appointment of David Yates as golf coach. Yates, who has been golf coach at Stanford for two years, replaces Lynn Blevins. Blevins will become golf coach at the University of Florida.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS SEE NO RASH OF TRENTONS
description: TRENTON THE decision of the State Supreme Court upholding the state's takeover of the Trenton public schools will have no immediate effect on other New Jersey school districts, state education officials say.

title: Stephanie Pierson, Copywriter, Bride
description: Stephanie Pierson and Thomas Hilbert Connell 3d were married yesterday at their home in Killingworth, Conn. Justice of the Peace Richard Stanley of Deep River, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: LEGISLATORS HEAR DETAILS ON PEEKSKILL REFUSE PLANT
description: IT wasn't long after County Executive Alfred B. DelBello introduced his ambitious plan for conversion of garbage into energy on a countywide scale in 1973 that the Board of Legislators, individually and collectively, began to question its merits. They fought over the sites of transfer stations and of the plant itself, over the technique that was to be used and over the financing.

title: The Region in summary;
description: It seemed, at first blush, not a bad deal for New York City. The Port Authority would spend $500 million over 15 years to expand and improve the city's two major airports; in return, the Koch administration would reduce the authority's rent for the facilities by about $1 million a year.

title: Nostalgia
description: To the Editor: In the recent dissolution of my mother's apartment, I came across the following letter. In the 30 years that have transpired since it was written the letter becomes a monument of American railroading as it once was and no longer has a chance of becoming.

title: Major News in summary; FRENCH COMMUNISTS ARRIVE, HAT IN HAND
description: Just a few years ago, the mere thought of Communists joining a West European government was enough to set off alarm bells on both sides of the Atlantic alliance. But last week, when Francois Mitterrand gave minor Cabinet jobs to four French Communist leaders, the reaction was subdued.

title: Caroline Irwin Walker Bride Of Stephen Housman Kahler
description: In the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church yesterday, Caroline Irwin Walker was married to Stephen Housman Kahler.

title: SELLING THE CAPITAL'S SOCIAL SCENE--WITH CONNECTIONS Poston and Barbara Boggs
description: W ASHINGTON Whirl-Around, a conference planning firm with great connections, didn't exactly start out with a bang. In its first year, 1967, it made an underwhelming $400 for each of the three partners involved.

title: COMPUTER EXPERTS GO TO WORK WITHOUT EVER LEAVING HOME
description: SCARSDALE THEY don't stand around the water cooler any more or daydream in company meetings. They have given up work in high-rise office buildings and plugged their computers into suburban homes from Chappaqua to New Canaan.

title: STATE MUSICIANS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: THE state will be well represented at the Fourth of July party that President and Mrs. Reagan are giving for the executive staff of the White House and their families. In keeping with the theme of a casual turn-of-the-century small-town Fourth of July picnic on the South Lawn, there will be chicken in the basket, draft beer, root beer, ice cream, and badminton and croquet as well as fireworks and musical entertainment by seven ensembles and a name entertainer to be announced. No fewer than five of the musical groups are from the Connecticut.

title: Turbocharging's Joys and Benefits
description: THE car was new and sparkling, as red as a stoplight. It belonged to a friend, and I envied him greatly, particularly since the engine bay held some wild chrome plumbing that boosted performance in what seemed a wonderously ingenious new way.

title: Economic Affairs; HOW TO GET THE CAPITAL FLOWING TO BUSINESS
description: T HE American semiconductor industry is in the process of shifting from technologies with a relatively low demand for capital (plant and equipment) to technologies with a much higher demand for capital. The American way to make this transition is to borrow some of the necessary money (typically 20 to 30 percent) and finance the rest out of retained earnings.

title: LIBERAL GROUP SEES OPPORTUNITY IN REAGAN POLITICS
description: Leaders of Americans for Democratic Action, the nation's oldest liberal political organization, accused the Reagan Administration today of being a threat to the country but also viewed it as an opportunity for themselves.

title: 500 Charged in Morocco Riots
description: About 500 people have been arrested and charged after food riots in Casablanca last weekend in which 66 people were killed and 110 injured, the Moroccan news agency reported.

title: BALLOON FEVER COMES TO BATTLE CREEK, MICH.
description: Ballooning is a sport that runs on hot air and a fairly relaxed attitude about where you're going, so it may be a sign of the times that it is also gaining a lot of new admirers.

title: Westchester Guide; NEW ROCHELLE COUNTRY FAIR
description: Once again, beginning Friday and ending Sunday, a hot-air balloon will float above Ward Acres Park on Quaker Ridge Road in New Rochelle, beckoning an estimated 40,000 people from the New York area to come to munch corn on the cob, buy items from the craftsmen who made them, listen to music, board the horse-drawn trolley for a ride around the 70-acre grounds or just sit on a grassy knoll under an old shade tree and watch the sun set.

title: CHINESE OFFICIAL IN INDIA:
description: Foreign Minister Huang Hua placing a wreath at memorial in New Delhi to Mohandas K. Gandhi, the leader of Indian independence. Mr. Hua is on a four-day visit to India, the first by a Chinese leader since the 1962 war between the two nations. At present, India maintains good ties with the Soviet Union.

title: Boxing Lacks Punch for Davis
description: Howard Davis Jr. won the lightweight gold medal in boxing at the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal. He struck gold again with a lucrative long-term professional contract a year later. Now, though, at 25 years old, he appears to be looking for a silver lining in a career that has stagnated, with only three fights in the last year and a half.

title: Deborah Jones Married to Andrew Merritt
description: Deborah Ann Jones was married yesterday to Andrew Lloyd Merritt at the Harvard University Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Barbara Nielsen-Whitcomb of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Barbara Caldwell Married
description: Barbara Caldwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Caldwell of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday in Dix Hills, L.I., to James R. Phillips, son of Mrs. Alan W. Bell of Dix Hills and John Phillips of Jamaica. The Rev. Leo J. Goggin performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church. The bride teaches at the Yorktown Preschool in Huntington Beach, Calif. Mr. Phillips is a corporate banking officer with the First Interstate Bank of California in Los Angeles.

title: Fourth of July Premiere For Bernstein Flute Work
description: The American premiere of a work by Leonard Bernstein will highlight the Fourth of July program of the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood, the orchestra has announced.

title: SOMETHING FOR EVERYBODY, INCLUDING THE LIKELY LOSERS
description: ''How's it going?'' a caller asked Bernard Rome recently. ''Not well,'' Mr. Rome replied dolefully. He was preparing to withdraw from the mayoral race. So, on the day Republican party leaders announced their endorsement of the Democratic incumbent's candidacy for Mayor of New York City, Mr. Rome, former head of the Off Track Betting Corporation and former friend of Mayor Koch, announced that his pursuit of the nomination had ended.

title: COUNTY PLANS TO SPEND $1 MILLION ON DUNWOODIE
description: WHITE PLAINS BECAUSE of the continued popularity of its five public golf courses, the Westchester County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation plans to spend more than $1 million to rebuild, in its entirety, its Dunwoodie course in Yonkers.

title: OFFICIALS MINIMIZE PIPELINE RUPTURE
description: THERE are 11 sub-oceanic sewage outfall lines along the state's Atlantic coastline. One of them is owned by the Ocean County Utilities Authority, and each day it discharges, at a point approximately 7,000 feet off the coast of South Seaside Park, seven million gallons of secondarily treated effluent.

title: About Westchester
description: The setting is the Scarsdale Pool, and this is the senior class breakfast, a relatively recent addition to a much older tradition, the senior prom. Since 2 A.M., the class of '81 has been swimming in the floodlighted pool and eating scrambled eggs prepared by members of the Parent-Teacher Association, who are running this part of the evening. When the sun rises, those with stamina will drive to Jones Beach.

title: Realty News; WEST SIDE COURTS LEASED FOR 3 YEARS
description: The West Park Racquet Club, on Columbus Avenue between 97th and 100th Streets, had been abandoned since 1979. Weeds and bushes were sprouting on the expanse of green clay that once made up 11 courts.

title: Peter Chiarulli, Deputy Director Of Mechanical Engineers Society
description: Dr. Peter Chiarulli, deputy executive director of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, died Thursday in Los Angeles. He was a resident of New York City and was 59 years old.

title: Westchester Journal
description: MUSIC rose from the electric piano and xylophone, Bugs Bunny in a starry Uncle Sam suit patted children on the head and politicians basked in the Yonkers sun.

title: SPECIAL FUNDS FAVORED IN COLLEGE REMEDIAL STUDIES
description: State officials are considering a proposal to let academically weak college students receive financial aid from New York's $250 million Tuition Assistance Program even though eligibility requirements are being tightened.

title: Dining Out; A NEAR MISS, BUT THE AIM IS HIGH
description: AT THE top of a hill overlooking the hamlet of Upper Black Eddy, in Pennsylvania's Bucks County, stands a sprawling 1950's stone house. It is a bit grander than the houses nearby, there is a tiny white sign on a post and more than the normal quota of cars in the driveway; however, these are the only things that set Tara apart from its residential neighbors.

title: Cycling to Van De Velde
description: Johan Van De Velde of the Netherlands won the third stage of the Tour de France cycling race today by finishing the 158-mile course from Nice to Martigues in 6 hours, 32 minutes, 27 seconds. Luciene Didier of Luxembourg was second in 6:32:33 and Kim Andersen of Denmark finished third in 6:32:49. Gerrie Knetemann of the Netherlands, who finished 23d in today's state, retained the overall lead.

title: GETTING INTO SWING OF THE SPORT CALLED GOLF
description: SOME people consider 13 an unlucky number but my nemesis lately has been 18 - the number of holes on a golf course. Having just taken up the game, I am considered a beginner, a kindly designation that I will undoubtedly deserve (and take refuge in) for years.

title: CZESLAW MILOSZ, CHILD AND MAN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Judy Stone is a critic who writes for The San Francisco Chronicle. By JUDY STONE

title: Adaline Havemeyer Is Married
description: The marriage of Adaline Havemeyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Havemeyer of New York and Islip, L.I., to Stuart N. Siegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Siegel of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Montauk Point, L.I., took place yesterday.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; A RATING SYSTEM THAT'S TOUGHER THAN NIELSEN
description: Whether they were jumping off a sinking ship, jumping on a bandwagon or, as one sponsor's spokesman put it, ''just meeting responsible citizens interested in the corporation's activities,'' some of television's biggest advertisers hied it over to the Memphis area last week to talk to the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon about excessive sex, violence and profanity on television.

title: WARMING UP 'DAMN YANKEES' FOR THE OPENING
description: MEMORY of the sunny life of the mid-1950's is a bit hazy at times. The world was at peace. The pace was slow. Eisenhower was President. But things were bustling in a 10th Avenue warehouse that Hal Prince, the beardless boy producer, had wangled. It was a great place to rehearse ''Damn Yankees.''

title: MAYER, ANDREA JAEGER OUT
description: Tiebreaker victories helped Bjorn Borg achieve his 39th consecutive Wimbledon triumph today and also gave Mima Jausovec a 6-4, 7-6 upset of Andrea Jaeger for a berth in the women's quarterfinals of the $650,000 tennis championships.

title: Carol Hayward Whitney Married to Joseph M. Cudahy
description: Carol Hayward Whitney, daughter of Mrs. John D. Young and George H. Whitney Jr., both of Marion, Mass., was married there yesterday to Joseph Michael Cudahy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Cudahy of Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The World in summary; SPAIN'S DIVORCE BILL ALSO SPLITS POLITICS
description: The Spanish Cortes last week struck down the Franco-era prohibition of civil divorce and more than 500,000 Spaniards were quickly expected to file. But the parliamentary vote exposed such divisions in the Union of the Democratic Center that doubts grew over whether the ruling party's marriage of center-left and center-right was also about to dissolve.

title: AN AMERICAN ARTIST'S UNIQUELY PERSONAL ENVIRONMENT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ESTHER BENSON, an actress and writer, lives in New York. By ESTHER BENSON

title: Fashion
description: WEARING INSIDES OUT It used to be that lingerie was just underwear, functional things to be worn but not seen. But, increasingly, lingerie is coming out of the bureau and onto the street. These fragments of feminine underthings are now made in a variety of pretty shapes and in fabrics suitable for daytime wear.

title: TV View; APPLY THE 'RECOGNITION FACTOR' AND WATCH THE 'PRODUCT' GROW
description: Consider for a moment something called the ''multimedia merchandising program.'' It is examined in absorbing detail in ''The Blockbuster Complex: Conglomerates, Show Business and Book Publishing,'' written by Thomas Whiteside and published by Wesleyan University Press after appearing as a series in The New Yorker magazine last year.

title: Woman Hurls Package At Elizabeth in a Stunt
description: A 19-year-old woman was held briefly yesterday after she threw a package containing a university T-shirt and an appeal for charity into a car in which Queen Elizabeth II was traveling to the Portland Naval Base, the police said.

title: Major News in summary; ATLANTA PUTS THE CUFFS ON A MURDER SUSPECT
description: Wayne B. Williams, who had labeled himself a suspect after he was questioned earlier this month, was arrested last week and charged with murder in the death of Nathaniel Cater, the 28th and latest victim in Atlanta's black youth slayings. While local authorities earlier had been unsure whether they had enough evidence for an arrest, a state judge found the evidence offered at a preliminary hearing sufficient to warrant a grand jury's attention.

title: Letters; WHEN SLING & ARROW STRIKE REALLY DEEP
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN PROMOTES FOUR TO FULL CURATORSHIP
description: In a move that emphasizes the achievements of younger staff members, four associate curators at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, whose ages range from 34 to 40, have been promoted to full curatorship. They are Weston Naef, curator in the department of prints and photographs; Joan Mertens, curator in the department of Greek and Roman art, and Katharine Baetjer and Charles Moffett, curators in the department of European paintings.

title: LEGISLATURE SPEEDS PRE-RECESS ACTIVITY
description: The following article was written jointly by Robert Hanley and Daniel Akst. TRENTON

title: The World in summary; FRATERNAL WARNINGS, NEW MANEUVERS
description: Soviet troops last week were again conducting joint training exercises in Poland and the explanation was ominously bland. The purpose, said the Polish news agency, P.A.P., was ''to deepen the fraternity of arms between the Polish and Soviet armies and to educate soldiers in the spirit of proletarian internationalism.''

title: Billing, Cooing and Boxing
description: MIKE TRAINER, the lawyer who handles the rowdy business of Sugar Ray Leonard, and Bob Arum of the promotional firm of Top Rank Inc., had a peace conference Thursday with Shelly Finkel, a rock concert promoter, as mediator. Trainer and Arum had been gouging and kneeing in the clinches in a quarrel over Arum's fight card in the Houston Astrodome Thursday night and the prospect that Arum would be shut out of a September promotion featuring Leonard and Thomas Hearns, who share the welterweight championship of the world.

title: DEMOCRATIC FOES TESTING STRENGTH FOR PRIMARY RACE TO OPPOSE PURCELL
description: IN their first test of organizational strength, the two Democratic candidates for Nassau County Executive began circulating designating petitions last week for the Sept. 10 primary.

title: Witness in Blanton Trial Is Charged With Conspiracy
description: Jack Ham, who testified against former Gov. Ray Blanton, was arraigned yesterday on Federal charges of conspiracy and mail fraud.

title: Edward Hausner THERE'S STILL BASEBALL AT SHEA STADIUM:
description: Michael London, 10 years old, showing his form as Joe Torre, the Mets' manager, watched during a baseball clinic offered yesterday in place of the usual activities. About 300 youngsters attended instead of the striking major league players.

title: Theater; DIRECTOR WHO PREFERS A CHALLENGE
description: AT the end of his first season as artistic director of the Hartford Stage Company, Mark Lamos looked tired. When I told him this he laughed. ''I know. Somebody the other day said I looked like Peter O'Toole and I nearly slugged him.''

title: MASSAGE-PARLOR BAN EXTENDED
description: WESTBROOK ''HOW gross do we get? There's a silent majority out there and we have to decide just what we want - we've got to speak up,'' said First Selectman Donald P. Morrison after 150 members at last week's Town Meeting voted unanimously to adopt an ordinance banning massage parlors.
