title: Paperback Talk
description: Women's writes. Back in 1963, a suburban woman who took time out from her housewifely chores to write articles for the masscirculation women's magazines published a book with a theme that none of her editors, all of them male, had allowed her to present in their pages. The theme: A great many of the young women who had hurried to get married when Johnny came marching home from World War II were now disconsolate about their roles as housebound wives and mothers. The author: Betty Friedan of Grandview, N.Y. The book: ''The Feminine Mystique.''

title: Pate Gets Lead of A Stroke
description: Jerry Pate rolled in a six-foot birdie putt on the final hole today to complete a round of 66 and take a onestroke lead in the third round of the $300,000 Memphis Golf Classic.

title: Art; A 'BANAL' RAUSCHENBERG
description: LET us now mourn famous artists, to adapt James Agee's famous title. The case in point today is Robert Rauschenberg's print series on view at the Neuberger Museum at Purchase, but the list of contemporary artists who, though continuing to produce work, might legitimately be the subject of a post mortem or an elegy is sadly long. One thinks, for example, of Willem de Kooning, James Rosenquist and Andy Warhol as being among the artists whose recent work has unfortunately fallen so far below their former accomplishments as to cause the viewer to despair of their ever regaining the creative heights they once occupied.

title: MEAT PRICES LIKELY TO REMAIN STABLE
description: For the rest of the summer and well into the autumn, the Department of Agriculture expects beef and poultry supplies to increase and pork supplies to be large enough to hold retail prices near today's levels.

title: The Nation in summary; NEW HAMPSHIRE'S 48-HOUR EPIDEMIC
description: A little government goes a long way in New Hampshire, but last week more than 8,000 state workers took the idea to an extreme. For two days, they called in sick to protest for higher pay.

title: Gardening; NATIVE TREES ENDURE VARIETY OF HAZARDS
description: MAN is so conditioned by tales of 2,000-year-old redwoods and 5,000-year-old bristlecone pines and by poems immortalizing trees that the sight of a dead tree along a street in front of his house or in his garden comes as a shock. Trees are supposed to live forever. Man plants them so that his grandchildren may play in their shade.

title: NEW SINKING SECTION FOUND IN F.D.R. DRIVE
description: Inspectors found another sinking area in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive yesterday morning, but it was described as ''minor'' and engineers said recurring problems with the roadway appeared to be ''localized conditions.''

title: Hempstead Envisioned As 'Another SoHo'
description: The Fine Arts Museum of Long Island would like to add its opinion as to the location of a cultural arts center on Long Island (''Critics Question $200,000 State Study for Arts Complex'' and subsequent Letters to the Editor). We are pleased that the Urban Development Corporation is considering Hempstead as one of the three sites.

title: CANADIANS HONOR 2 FROM MISSION IN IRAN
description: Starting in early November 1979, two wives of Canadian Embassy officials endured almost three months of constant tension in Teheran while they cared for six American diplomats who had escaped the seizure of the United States Embassy and had taken refuge in their homes. This week, almost 18 months after the successful rescue of the Americans, the wives were honored by the Canadian Government.

title: June 28, 1981
description: NONFICTION BETWEEN GENERATIONS: The Six Stages of Parenthood. By Ellen Galinsky. 15 THE DECLASSIFIED EISENHOWER: A Divided Legacy. By Blanche Wiesen Cook. 12 DIPLOMACY OF POWER: Soviet Armed Forces as a Political Instrument.

title: No Headline
description: The special United Nations envoy, Olof Palme of Sweden, arrived in Baghdad from Teheran today with the outline of a comprehensive plan to end the war between Iran and Iraq, the official Iraqi press agency reported. Iran's Supreme Defense Council said it would study the proposal.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photograph on the food page of last week's New York Times Magazine was incorrectly attributed. It was taken by Arnold T. Rosenberg.

title: Dining Out in Tokyo
description: To the Editor: I hope that my letter is only one of several from members of the medical profession concerning Richard Halloran's article, ''500,000 Choices: Eating Your Way Around Tokyo'' (Travel Section, June 7). In discussing his cure for jet lag, Mr. Halloran said that he had rice wine, returned to his hotel, took prescribed sleeping pills and fell off to sleep.

title: Pryor Stops Blackmoore
description: Unbeaten Aaron Pryor knocked down Lennox Blackmoore three times in the first two rounds today and retained his World Boxing Association junior-welterweight title when the referee stopped the fight 58 seconds into the second round.

title: State Official to Escape 3d Trial
description: The former Speaker of the Rhode Island House, Edward P. Manning, will not be tried a third time on extortion and racketeering charges involving a 1977 state furnishings contract, a Federal prosecutor said Thursday. On Wednesday a Federal jury in Boston said it was unable to reach a verdict after a two-week retrial on two counts from an original eight-count indictment against Mr. Manning.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in summary; HOSTAGE DEAL: HOW RARE AN OCCASION?
description: Five months and thousands of miles removed from the fevered negotiations that led to freedom for the American hostages in Iran, the Supreme Court convened in a rare special session last week to hear arguments on whether a key element of the hostage-return agreements was legal.

title: BALTIC STREET WAITING TO MOVE PAST 'GO'
description: The northern edge of Park Slope, long a symbol in Brooklyn of urban desolation, is about to get some help from the city under a program sponsored by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

title: LOUIS MALLE'S FASCINATION WITH LIFE'S TURNING POINTS
description: Two years ago, Louis Malle visited Atlantic City for the first time, and he experienced the shock of recognition a good film director knows when he sees the perfect visual metaphor. Seen from the Boardwalk, it was a glimpse of elegant old hotels coming down, of shiny new casinos going up, a glimpse of that instant in time when ''nothing was finished, when there was no present, only a past and future.'' For Mr. Malle, this image - which was to be registered in his highly praised current film ''Atlantic City'' - not only captured his sense of America as a culture that has gone directly ''from innocence to decadence,'' but also served as an illustration of that rare ''moment of extreme fluidity'' that he has examined in film after film.

title: Bush, Back From Visit, Confers With President
description: Vice President Bush, who returned last night from a brief visit to France and Britain, conferred for more than an hour today with President Reagan before flying to the Philippines for the inauguration of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: REPORT TERMS FUEL CONSERVATION ENCOURAGING
description: BRIDGEPORT THE 25 members of the New England Congressional Caucus held news conferences in their respective states last week to present a report on what they said was the region's exceptional and encouraging record last year of energy conservation and reduced reliance on foreign oil.

title: Devout Tax Evasion
description: Charles Kageler was an airline pilot in Texas when the United States Attorney's office in Houston charged that he had got religion to evade income taxes.

title: ROWLAND HAINES, EX-CHAMPION
description: Rowland Bowne Haines, a former national amateur squash tennis champion and a retired captain of the United States Naval Reserve, died today following a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 8 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 2 2 12 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 3 3 10 GOD EMPEROR OF DUNE, by Frank Herbert. (Putnam's, $12.95.) Leto continues as guardian and savior of the human race in the fourth novel about the planet Dune. 4 12 3 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 5 4 10 FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) Travis McGee investigates the murder of an ailing tycoon. 6 9 24 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $9.95.) An illustrated fable about the Sun, the Moon and a hidden treasure. 7 6 10 THE WHITE HOTEL, by D.M. Thomas. (Viking, $12.95.) Sigmund Freud treats a young woman whose case epitomizes the neuroses of the 20th century.

title: R.L. NYPE FIANCE OF MARTHA FOLEY
description: Mrs. David Carey MacNichol of Cumberland, Me., and Frederick Joseph Foley Jr. of Cape Elizabeth, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Elizabeth Foley, to Russell Lawrence Nype, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell Nype of New York. The wedding is planned for September 12 in Falmouth, Me.

title: BALLET: ROYAL 'SYMPHONIC VARIATIONS'
description: To say that ''The Sleeping Beauty'' has been the Royal Ballet's signature piece is true, but only partly true. For in addition to this 19th-century classic, the British company has had a 20th-century classic as another signature ballet.

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; PUBLIC SCHOOLS DRUM UP BUSINESS
description: Greenwich, Conn., is known well beyond its borders for the excellence of its schools and the expensiveness of its homes. To send your children to the former, you had to be able to afford the latter.

title: HOLLYWOOD WITH MUSIC
description: THE BEAST By Jonathan Fast 290 pp. New York: Random House. $12.95 THE DAY THE MUSIC DIED By Joseph C. Smith 475 pp. New York: Grove Press. $12.95. By NORA JOHNSON

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 28, 1981
description: International Africa's leaders condemned the U.S. for ''collusion with the South African racists.'' The resolution, approved unanimously in Nairobi, Kenya, by the 50 heads of state and government who make up the Organization of African Unity, accused the Reagan Administration of trying to engage in ''sinister'' moves to circumvent efforts by the United Nations to achieve a settlement in South-West Africa that would remove the territory, also known as Namibia, from the control of South Africa. (Page 1, Column 4.)

title: Sally O' Connor Is Married
description: Sally D. O'Connor, daughter of Mrs. William D. O'Connor of Old Saybrook, Conn., was married there yesterday to William L. Vallee Jr., son of Mrs. William L. Vallee of Westbrook, Me., and the late Mr. Vallee.

title: Crafts; A HODGEPODGE OF ECLECTICISM
description: THE word ''gallimaufry'' appears to be one of those esoteric terms limited to the lexicon of crossword puzzle addicts - it means a medley, an assortment, a hodgepodge. But Gallimaufry is also the name of a group of connected shops and galleries at 1 Croton Point Avenue in Croton-on-Hudson. The structure's rough-sawn and hand-split shakes and shingles, as well as the somewhat random landscaping, hints at the casual and friendly interior. The eclectic range of goods inside clearly justifies the name, which the owners, Lore and Vernon Stromberg, selected 17 years ago to christen their then-fledgling business.

title: Ursula Gentile Has Wedding
description: Ursula Keane Gentile, daughter of Isabel McMahon Gentile and Dr. Louis Alexis Gentile, both of Bronxville, N.Y., was married in St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday to Paul Christopher Lowerre, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lewis Lowerre of Manchester, Vt. The Rev. Gary T. Fertig of St. Thomas and Msgr.

title: No Headline
description: The articles on the hostage situation were most revealing and informative. However, I question whether the student militants executed the takeover of the United States Embassy and continued to maintain control independent of support by other interested parties - e.g., the clerics, the military, other revolutionaries. The logistics for the successful takeover and prolonged control by the student militants must have been provided by some outside forces. JAMES COHEN, Howard Beach, N.Y.

title: Protester Acquitted in Buffalo
description: A self-styled neo-Nazi who attempted to stage a rally on Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Day in January was acquitted today of an illegal-weapons charge. Karl E. Hand Jr. won the verdict in Federal District Court after testifying that the shotgun in his home on the eve of the demonstration had been given to him by his father in 1975.
--- Floyd Leads Canadian Classic

title: Politics; NEW POLITICAL MAPS: THE MANEUVERS INTENSIFY
description: THE first public skirmish in that intensely partisan political task known as reapportionment did not seem to bode well for a harmonious redrawing of Connecticut's Congressional and state legislative districts next month.

title: WRITER'S WORKSHOP HELPS HONE SKILLS
description: THE Writer's Workshop, a Westchester group that has been meeting for about 20 years, has begun compiling a list of books published over the years by its members. The project is being carried out by Jean Reidy, a children's librarian at the Primrose Elementary School in Somers and a long-time member of the workshop, and the list is expected to include more than 200 titles.

title: ROSTOW STARTS DIGGING HIS OWN HARDENED SILO
description: Why does Eugene V. Rostow, a longtime, although conservative, Democrat, want to be director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency in an Administration that has put arms reductions on the backburner? ''For a Yankee Puritan Jew like me,'' Mr. Rostow said in an interview, ''this job was irresistible.'' The Senate Foreign Relations Committee apparently agreed. Last week, with one member voting ''present,'' the panel recommended confirmation, 10 to 1.

title: Westchester Housing; ADDING AN ACCESSORY APARTMENT
description: ANNE and Raymond Klemmer had a tiny, 100-year-old building in their garden that used to cover a well, and they thought it might make a cozy cottage.

title: HONOLULU'S MAYOR ENDS PROPOSAL FOR RAIL LINE IN DOWNTOWN AREA
description: Mayor Eileen Anderson has declined to accept $5 million in Federal funds for an engineering survey, ending plans for a commuter rail system through downtown Honolulu.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in summary; ILLEGAL BREAD UPON THE WATER?
description: He may have come to pray, but he stayed to do business. Or so the Justice Department suggested last week as it disclosed that deportation proceedings against the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, founder of the Unification Church seemed in the offing.

title: FIRE COMPANY NO.1: 100 YEARS OF SERVICE
description: IT was more than a year after the home of one of the town's prominent citizens, Sarah Campbell, had burned to the ground, and almost six years after the greatest fire in New Canaan's history had destroyed part of the town that the community's citizens decided the time for action had come.

title: About Long Island
description: BALDWIN THE 60's were Frank Bird's best of times and worst of times; they were the flowering of his talent as an artist and the going to seed of his formal education; they began with his dropping out of high school and wandering the Island, and they ended with his emergence as an artist and artisan.

title: Senator Favors Increase In Daylight Saving Time
description: Extending daylight saving time for up to two months each year could save energy and lives, a Senator from Maine believes.

title: Comment; HIGHWAY, SUBWAY
description: THE future of New York's subways cannot be secured without infusions of enormous amounts of outside money. Cuts in service, higher fares, subsidies from state or local taxes, or any combination of these would exacerbate the transportation, fiscal, and economic problems of the Transit Authority, the city, and the state.

title: Athletic Aid Stirs Debate in Canada
description: Canada's intercollegiate sports system has become deeply divided in recent days, philosophically, politically and financially, over the question of athletic scholarships, which are new here.

title: Personal Finance; BATTLING FOR RETIREMENT INSURANCE
description: A MAJOR marketing battle is being waged by two well-known health insurance companies - the Colonial Penn Group and the Prudential Insurance Company - for the business of hundreds of thousands of retirees. The objective is $270 million in premiums from the group health insurance plan of the American Association of Retired Persons and the National Retired Teachers Association.

title: IN FOREIGN AID, THE POOR GROW POORER
description: They're calling it ''aid fatigue'' in Washington, a pervasive public indifference and active legislative opposition to foreign assistance. Staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee are complaining that as foreign aid shifts away from big infrastructure projects to rural development programs, corporate lobbyists have vanished, leaving church groups to carry the ball. And as one assistant noted, ''They have less clout with Congress.''

title: Man Taunted by Youths Killed by 3d Rail of IRT
description: A man described as mentally disturbed electrocuted himself on the third rail of the Flushing IRT line early yesterday after being taunted by a group of men in their late teens and early 20's in the Times Square area, the police said.

title: AIRPORT FEES HELD EQUITABLE
description: NEWARK THE roar of jet engines and the screeching tires of landing aircraft mean big money for Newark International Airport, as well as for major airlines that use it.

title: PRUDENT WELCOME FOR A PRIZED FISH
description: EAST HADDAM ''WHO's got the head?'' ''Head's down this end, I think.'' ''Watch the tail! Watch the tail!'' ''Here, this end up first.'' ''Arrgh! The water's cold!'' ''Where's the head?'' How do you transport a fidgety, hypersensitive 12-pound Atlantic salmon from Connecticut's Salmon River? Very carefully - considering that you want it to survive the trip to a breeding station so its progeny may one day swim here for the pleasure of fishermen and other nature lovers.

title: Slain Telex Executive Said to Have Carried $996
description: Roger Wheeler, the Telex executive who was slain a month ago at a country club in Tulsa, Okla., was carrying $996 in cash when he was killed, according to an autopsy report.

title: PUBLIC EDUCATION AND PRIVATE FEES
description: AT a meeting punctuated by cheers and catcalls, the voters in Cromwell last week rejected, for the sixth time in less than two months, the proposed school budget. In Wilton, the Board of Education voted to require its high-school students to pay up to $100 to play on school sports teams. In Monroe, where the schools have been charging pupils $6 to $12 to join a team, the fees will be going up by $20 to $25 next fall. Other communities considering the pay-toplay system include Bridgeport and Trumbull.

title: 2,000 YEARS AFTER THE BERSTYN FYR
description: RIDDLEY WALKER By Russell Hoban. 220 pp. New York: Summit Books. $12.95.

title: FOR RAIL COMMUTERS, TIME TO SPEAK
description: I am not an activist. I am an ordinary, rational person. I have no charisma. I am only occasionally witty and even then, I have to think about it. I have no love for cars, except for BMW's, and I will never be able to afford one. (I am a fund-raiser for a children's research hospital and my salary is inversely proportional to my worth.)

title: Wayward Lass, 5-1, Takes Oaks on Foul
description: Real Prize, a Buckland Farm filly trained by Johnny Campo, was disqualified from first place yesterday in the $136,250 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park for impeding Wayward Lass in the stretch.

title: At Home
description: AN ORGY of national self-congratulation will flash through thousands of towns next weekend, and I wouldn't eliminate so much as a single baton.

title: Telly Hoimes Weds Susan McShane, Fine-Arts Student
description: Susan C. McShane, daughter of Patricia E. McShane and Dr. Charles Brian McShane, both of London, was married there yesterday to Telly C. Hoimes, son of Efemia C. Hoimes of New York and C.S. Hoimes of Bethlehem, Pa. Bishop Timotheos performed the ceremony in St. Sophia's Greek Orthodox Cathedral.

title: OLD CROTON AQUEDUCT TO OPEN TO PUBLIC
description: WINDING its way along a 41-mile underground course from the Croton Reservoir to New York City, the red-brick tunnel that is the Old Croton Aqueduct stands as a monument to the determined laborers who completed it in 1842.

title: Heather C. Smith Bride Of Jeffrey Michael Collins
description: Heather Campbell Smith and Jeffrey Michael Collins were married yesterday at the Peace Dale (R.I.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Lawrence Washburn.

title: Q & A
description: The following answers were provided by representatives of MGIC, the West Side Federal Savings and Loan and the Mortgage Insurance Companies of America and the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: THE U.N.'S NUCLEAR COPS COVER A TOUGH BEAR
description: Israeli warplanes scored a direct hit June 7 on something besides Iraq's nuclear reactor. In the most dramatic way, Israel showed its total lack of confidence in the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations body charged with halting the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: HISPANIC GAINS IN SUBURBS FOUND
description: Hispanic Americans, by most evidence the nation's fastest-growing ethnic group, not only make up a significant proportion of the population in large urban centers but also are spreading to towns and suburbs that have had little racial or ethnic diversity.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER NUREYEV'S LEAP TO FREEDOM
description: ''Iremember once, when I was still in Soviet Union, there was a rumor that Nureyev was coming back to dance,'' Alexander Godunov was recalling. ''It caused such excitement. Everybody talk, talk, talk. But that's all it was, just talk. Of course, he never came.''

title: WHEN 73 STATIONS MAKE THEIR OWN SHOWS
description: ''You gonna take my picture,'' observes the old man, who obviously doesn't like the idea. ''You'll break the camera if you take my picture.'' His wife, a heavyset woman clutching a beer can, grunts her assent.

title: FASTEN YOUR LAUGHBELTS, IT'S TIME TO FLY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- BOYCE RENSBERGER, a former Times reporter, is now a senior editor on the staff of the magazine Science 81. By BOYCE RENSBERGER

title: Antiques; 7-DEALER CO-OP OFFERS VARIETY IN LITTLE SILVER
description: LITTLE SILVER IT IS easy to miss Antiques and Uniques at 32 Willow Drive here. The white-clapboard building south of the business section is on a knoll and almost hidden from the road; however, the driveway leads to six rooms filled with country and formal furniture and accessories in a setting that is designed to seem like an attractively decorated house.

title: Elisabeth Reid, R.W. Taylor Jr.  Have Wedding
description: Elisabeth Reid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ogden R. Reid of Purchase, N.Y., was married in the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday to Richard W. Taylor Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor of New York and Orange, Va. The Rev. Dr. Joseph P. Bishop performed the ceremony.

title: AFRICANS CONDEMN U.S. FOR 'COLLUSION' ON NAMIBIAN PLANS
description: The Organization of African Unity adopted a resolution last night condemning the United States for ''collusion with the South African racists.''

title: The Region in summary; IN THE SHORT RUN, SAVING TRANSIT IS LEFT TO THE RIDERS
description: While it may have been, as one legislator called it, ''the most far-reaching and comprehensive transportation measure'' ever to come out of Albany, it won't be comprehensive enough to spare New York bus and subway riders from a fare increase this week. Just how much of an increase, though, remains to be seen.

title: Judge's Ruling Clears Way For Suit in Player's Death
description: The Virginia Tech Athletic Association is not entitled to the protection of ''sovereign immunity'' and can be held liable for acts of negligence, a Superior Court judge in Morristown has ruled.

title: JOSEPH W. DRAKE
description: Joseph W. Drake, a specialist in surrogate law and a partner in the Manhattan firm of Shearman & Sterling, died Wednesday at his home in Rye, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: Music View; HE SERVED AS 'PILOT FISH' FOR FREDERICK DELIUS
description: Great composers, especially in their last years, often attract barnacles, people whose instinct is to attach themselves to genius and feed off it, spiritually or otherwise. But geniuses also, in rare and benign instances, can attract pilot fish, admirers who devote themselves to helping the artist keep on working and producing. Arrigo Boito, with whose aid and encouragement the aging Verdi was able to come out of retirement and write ''Otello'' and ''Falstaff,'' is one of history's fine examples of the pilot fish type.

title: Art; NEWARK MUSEUM: THE HOUSESCAPE AS A TRIBUTE TO LIGHT
description: NEWARK TO MOST of us, the light of day is an unequivocal fact that we take for granted. However, for an artist, light is something like a fountainhead, an essential for his creativity.

title: POLLAK-A TROUBLED HOSPITAL
description: AGE vagrant had run in from the street, eluding the nurses at Pollak Hospital for 40 minutes before one of them found him on the floor of the chapel. The Comprehensive Employment and Training Act security force wasn't there to help search for the man, having been laid off the week before.

title: EISENHOWER REDUX
description: THE EISENHOWER DIARIES Edited by Robert H. Ferrell. Illustrated. 445 pp. New York: W.W. Norton. $19.95.

title: NEW YORK IS FACING 'CRISIS' ON VAGRANTS
description: The problem of what to do about the increasing numbers of homeless and often mentally disturbed people who wander the New York City streets is reaching a crisis point, state and city officials say, as one community after another balks at the prospect of sheltering them locally.

title: Three Powerboats Exceed World Record in Trials
description: Three powerboats have exceeded the world record for an officially surveyed three-mile lap in qualifying runs for tomorrow's unlimited hydroplane races on the Detroit River.

title: Other Business; THOSE RENTABLE WRECKS
description: The peak season in the $2.5 billion rent-a-car business is summertime and Rent-a-Wreck, a Los Angeles-based franchise operation is revving up. Do you hanker for a wheel across town in a fire-applered convertible? How about a cruise along the main drag in an airconditioned '78 Ford compact or a '76 Mercury Cougar XR-87? Rent-a-Wreck will supply it, and cheaply.

title: Prospects; BIG OIL WALKS AWAY
description: Unless African oil exporters like Nigeria and Libya cut their prices soon, a startling sight could emerge next week - a refusal by major oil companies to sign new quarterly price agreements with these producers.

title: FEDERAL LEGAL HELP FOR THE POOR: A DEBATE OVER MEANS AND END
description: THE Legal Services Corporation continued its struggle for survival against the Reagan Administration last week in Congress. The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee voted 9 to 7 to continue funding legal aid for poor people in noncriminal cases for three years, but to cut the budget from $321 million to $100 million a year. The House Appropriations Committee has voted $241 million for the program for next year, in keeping with an earlier House vote to keep the corporation alive but further restrict the activities of its lawyers.

title: BROADHOLLOW GIVES 'SLEUTH' A NEW ANGLE
description: CAN a play that made one of the most successful sea changes in theater annals survive a sex change? At the Broadhollow Theater in Farmingdale through July 5, Patricia Dolce is staging Anthony Shaffer's ''Sleuth'' with two women, instead of two men, in the leads - a ''first'' for the British import that ran for three years on Broadway.

title: TESTIMONY ENDS IN TROTSKYIST PARTY'S HARASSMENT SUIT
description: Testimony has ended in the 12-week trial of a lawsuit charging that the Federal Government improperly investigated, harassed and disrupted the Socialist Workers Party.

title: BOMB INJURES HIGH IRANIAN WHO BACKS EXECUTIONS
description: Hojatolislam Ali Khameini, the spiritual leader of Teheran and a close aide of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was seriously injured by a bomb today at a mosque, the state radio said.

title: Alexandra Gilbert Is a Bride
description: Alexandra Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gilbert of New York, and Charles Steven Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Cohen of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel. The bride teaches at the Hewitt School and her husband, a lawyer, is vice president and general counsel at Cohen Brothers Realty and Development Corporation.

title: PLAN ON ILLEGAL ALIENS TO BE DISCLOSED SOON BY THE ADMINISTRATION
description: The Reagan Administration will soon announce a program to deal with thousands of illegal immigrants in Florida and the Southwest, Attorney General William French Smith said today.

title: IT'S GREAT TO DEREGULATE--FOR THE OTHER GUY
description: ''In recent years, businesses and the public ... have been increasingly burdened by ... (government) agencies. Confusing forms, duplicative reporting requirements and other unnecessary paperwork burdens increase costs to businesses, add to the adverse impact of inflation on the consuming public and detract from the goal of increasing economy and efficiency in government operations.''

title: Dining Out; INVENTIVENESS, YES, BUT...
description: THE pleasure derived from good bread and fine wine is especially keen at Saffron, a new and enormously popular restaurant in Woodmere. The bread, thick satisfying slices of crusty peasant-style loaves, comes from the D & G Bakery in lower Manhattan. The wine list comprises mostly well-chosen French and California reds and whites that are fairly decently priced.

title: Elizabeth Hird Married To Kenneth A. Pisciotto
description: Elizabeth Flower Hird, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Ainsworth Hird of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Anthony Pisciotto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Pisciotto of Los Altos, Calif. The Rev. David C. Van Sickle of the Upper Ridgewood Community Church performed the ceremomy at the Hirds' summer home at Dering Harbor, Shelter Island, N.Y.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Baseball Umpires Get No Respect
description: To the Sports Editor: I would like to make two points regarding umpires (''Protect the Endangered Umpire,'' The New York Times, June 7). First, the most important role the umpire plays in baseball is to give the game a sense of integrity.

title: CONLON NANCARROW- POET OF THE PLAYER PIANO
description: Early this year, Gyorgy Ligeti, who is one of the best known composers in the world, wrote a letter from Vienna to Charles Amirkhanian in Berkeley, Calif. Mr. Amirkhanian is, among other things, the producer of a series of records on the 1750 Arch label by one of the least known composers in the world, Conlon Nancarrow.

title: Dining Out; REFRESHING SIMPLICITY IN AN OLD MILL
description: FARMINGTON IN the summer, many Nutmeggers' dining-out thoughts tilt toward the Sound. Yet one of the prettiest water views is inland. The Reading Room Restaurant, ensconced in an old grist mill on the Farmington River, uses its location well. Big picture windows afford diners a wide-angle view of surging waters and trout fishermen. Nature enhances the view with a spectacular sunset that casts orange and rosy rays until almost 9 P.M. It is a dining bonus.

title: James Mead Weds Cornelia M. Dana
description: Cornelia Marshall Dana and James Gerald Mead were married yesterday in the First Congregational Church in Washington, Conn. The Rev. Lee Neuhaus performed the ceremony.

title: SMALL CARBON-DATER LEADS TO A GIANT STEP
description: WHEN curators at the J. Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan dismantled the 12th-century Stavelot Triptych in 1973, they found an art historian's dream: a secret compartment containing a mysterious silk packet and a strip of parchment.

title: IN COLD IRANINAN BLOOD
description: Having driven former President Bani-Sadr from office, the clerical zealots in Iran are now systematically slaughtering his supporters. About 50 have been executed by firing squads; 30 others have been killed in street battles. But these are only the acknowledged killings; the toll is probably in the hundreds.

title: The Region in summary; RAISING THE RENT--AND A RUCKUS
description: The Rent Guidelines Board did not set out with the impossible goal of pleasing everyone, but it might as well have. In a meeting frequently disrupted by demonstrators, a dozen of whom were arrested, the board ruled last week that the cost of living in a rentstabilized New York City apartment could go up 10 percent for a oneyear lease renewal, 13 percent for two years and 16 percent for three years.

title: LOVE AND HATE
description: A SMILE IN HIS LIFETIME By Joseph Hansen. 292 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $13.95. THE WAR OF THE ROSES By Warren Adler. 263 pp. New York: Warner Books. $10.95. By AVERY CORMAN

title: FOR PRIVATE-CITIZEN RIBICOFF, NO ROOM FOR REGRETS
description: Sitting in his new corner office high above Park Avenue, Abraham A. Ribicoff was savoring Potter Stewart's explanation for retiring from the United States Supreme Court at age 66.

title: Investing independent oil companies; OIL STOCKS AT DISTRESS PRICES?
description: SAN FRANCISCO I T was a great roller coaster run on Wall Street. Oil stocks, which had doubled, tripled and even quadrupled in price between December 1978 and December 1980, took a nose dive that left investors reeling.

title: No Headline
description: If the World Court's judgment had been used as the basis for further negotiations, Iran could have avoided dealing directly with the United States by returning the hostages to the court or to the Secretary General of the United Nations.

title: Barbra Streisand to Direct And Star in Film of 'Yentl'
description: Barbra Streisand will direct and star in a musical film based on ''Yentl,'' the short story by Isaac Bashevis Singer.

description: Development Program Governing Council - 3 P.M.
