description: To the Editor:

title: Fire Destroys L.I. Brake Shop
description: A fire that broke out late last night in a Uniondale brake shop caused an estimated $500,000 in damage, the authorities said. Nassau County fire marshals said today that the fire was suspicious and that they were investigating the cause. The contents of the shop - the Bonded Brake Company at 585 Commercial Avenue - were destroyed in the fire.

title: Joe Namath's Second Life
description: TANNED and husky, he was dressed the way he was in other summers - shorts, T-shirt, sneakers, an elastic bandage wrapped thickly around his right knee. He also had three notebooks with him the way he used to have his playbooks. But now Joe Namath is a 37-year-old actor and singer. Backstage at the Jones Beach Theater, his voice was booming in a baritone.

title: NO INCREASE NECESSARY IN
description: PORT AUTHOURITY TOLLS TIL 1984, AUDITY SAYS By WILLIAM G. BLAIR

title: FOREIGN TOURISM OFF AS THE DOLLAR GAINS
description: The Hilton Hotel in New York is losing 25 percent of its foreign clientele to cancellations. Worse, at the city's five Sheraton hotels, three out of four overseas tour-group reservations are noshows - twice as many as last year. And Thomas Cook & Sons, the British travel agency, notes a ''significant dropping-off'' of overseas tours to the United States.

title: STAGE: CHARLES EASTMAN'S 'HAMSTER OF HAPPINESS'
description: IT'S bad enough for a writer to give a play the unbearably cute title ''The Hamster of Happiness,'' but it's even worse when he then goes ahead and throws in the hamster as well. Charles Eastman, the author of two one-act plays at the Theater for the New City, apparently finds it impossible to resist such fatal touches. When he isn't trying to win over the audience with that symbolic hamster (named Mr. Bluebird, no less), he is providing human characters with such unlikely names as Dinette Dusty Muke and Dot Montgomery Garbee. Or he's giving us home truths that can't go home again. ''There's always something to live for - if you look hard enough,'' says one lost soul in the evening's second play, ''Borders.'' In the curtainraising ''Hamster'' we're told: ''Once you've lost the bluebird of happiness, you can always find it again - if you only look in your heart.'' Say this for Mr. Eastman: He really believes that hope is the thing with feathers.

title: Around The World; Morocco and Mauritania Are Said to Repair Relations
description: Saudi Arabia announced today that it had succeeded in persuading Morocco and Mauritania to restore diplomatic relations and end a feud over the conduct of the six-year war against Polisario guerrillas in Western Sahara.

title: Dr. Perry F. Garber Weds Miss Grayson
description: Sandra Lynn Grayson, a lawyer with the J. Walter Thompson Company, was married yesterday to Dr. Perry F. Garber, an ophthalmologist in Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Norton D. Shargal performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y.

title: HOMESEXUALS PARADE UP FIFTH AVE. IN CELEBRATION
description: Twelve years ago yesterday Morty Manford was 18 years old and a patron in the Stonewall Inn, a homosexual bar in Greenwich Village, when the police raided it in the early morning, setting off a riot by 300 young men in which 13 were arrested and four police officers injured. It marked the beginning of the homosexual rights movement.

title: Dr. R. M. Fuchs Weds Dr. Judith Hochman
description: Dr. Judith Sheryl Hochman and Dr. Richard Martin Fuchs, internists and cardiology fellows at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, were married yesterday at Congregation Sons of Israel in Woodmere, L.I., by Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz.

title: Red Smith A Verray, Parfit Gentil Knight
description: AT first meeting, you recognize Bowie Kuhn as a man of lofty moral principles. His upright bearing, the shine on his shoes and his uncomplaining willingness to pose for photographers combine to tell you that here is a baseball commissioner who, in his own words, believes he is ''doing what's best for the game and everybody in it.''

title: Simmons Interviews
description: The Simmons Market Research Bureau announced Friday that, having polled its clients and finding eight out of 10 of them in favor of the through-the-book method of respondent interviewing as well as more interviews, it will begin increasing the number of those interviews to 35,000 from 27,000.

title: GRAND JURY TO HEAR CASE OF WIFE WHO SHOT HUSBAND AS INTRUDER
description: A 66-year-old Bronx woman who shot her husband to death in the belief that he was an intruder in their apartment, which had been robbed twice this year, has not been charged with a crime, pending a grand jury inquiry set for this week, the police said yesterday.

title: CHESS VICTOR JARS SOVIET SENSIBILITIES ON EMIGRES
description: The awards ceremonies of the Moscow open chess championship today followed the usual pattern of congratulatory speeches, inside jokes and handshakes until the winner, Boris Gulko, asked to speak.

title: Bridge: Birthday of Barnes Recalls Winners of 1935 Reisinger
description: One might suppose that young men who spend much of their time hunched over green-baize tables in crowded smoke-filled rooms would be headed for early obituaries. But judging by the young men who were in the vanguard of the development of the game when contract bridge was young, this is not the case. By and large, their longevity has been quite remarkable.

title: Marilynn K. Yee Sailboat Regatta on Jamaica Bay
description: A spectator used field glasses to keep track of the entrants in yesterday's Mixed Multihull Regatta in Jamaica Bay at Gateway National Park. More than 40 sailboats competed in the race, sponsored by Citycats Sailing Center.

title: INCEST: A CRIME THAT MUST
description: NOT BE BELITTLED

title: THE ROTHSCHILD TOUCH WITH NEW ISSUES
description: Seated comfortably in his downtown office, looking out over Governors Island, Brooklyn and the East River, A. Robert Towbin grimaced at the mention of the thriving market for new issues.

title: RAN IN MARATHON DESPITE CANCER
description: Terry Fox, a college student who lost a leg to cancer and became Canada's biggest contemporary hero by running halfway across the country with an artificial limb to raise money for cancer research, died of the disease today in a Vancouver hospital. He was 22 years old.

title: NEW MACK CANADA HEAD
description: Paul C. Ritter, a 45-year old executive with Mack Trucks Inc., a subsidiary of the Signal Companies, has been elected president of Mack Canada Inc., the Canadian subsidiary of Mack Trucks.

title: Around the Nation; 5 in Crowd Killed by Fire At Louisiana Discotheque
description: Five persons were killed today when a fast-moving fire broke out at the back door of a windowless discotheque today, sending 200 screaming, panicked customers crowding through the only other exit.

title: Still's Art Available, Free for the Asking
description: BALTIMORE (UPI) - A will left by Clyfford Still, the Abstract Expressionist painter, says that any museum willing to house his life's work can have the works for free, the artist's wife, Patricia, said.

title: NCNB BANK LOOKS TO FILL ITS EXPANSION NEEDS
description: As far as the NCNB Corporation was concerned, North Carolina provided just the right climate for an ambitious bank. With statewide banking permitted by law, NCNB moved aggressively to open new branches and increase services. Now, it is looking out-of-state with as much fervor as it had surveyed its North Carolina opportunities.

title: Wriston Cites Better Outlook
description: Walter B. Wriston, the chairman of Citibank, voiced confidence today in President Reagan's economic proposals and said that fears of continued high inflation are being lessened.

title: 4 Goals by Miss Finn
description: Candy Finn's four goals paced the touring United States team to a 10-6 victory over the Australian national team today in the opener of a five-game women's lacrosse exhibition. Sue Billhimer, the American goalie, had 12 saves. Australia's Leonie Parker had six.

title: JEWISH RELIGIOUS LIFE IN LATIN AMERICA WEAKENS WITH A RISE IN ASSIMILATION
description: The number of practicing Jews in Latin America has been declining sharply as they increasingly assimilate into the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic societies around them, according to the American Jewish Committee and many Latin American Jewish spokesmen.

title: The Women's Draft Can't Be Deferred
description: ''The Constitution requires that Congress treat similarly situated persons similarly, not that it engage in gestures of superficial equality.'' So said a 6-to-3 Supreme Court majority in explaining why it is constitutional to register males but not females for the military draft. It was a curt rejection of serious claims by draftage men that excluding women not just from combat but from registration for duty amounts to sex discrimination. Although the Court gave them the back of its hand, their argument is not so easily dismissed.

title: z; U.N.'s Council Assails Killing of 2 Fiji Soldiers
description: The Security Council has condemmed the killing on June 19 of two Fijian soldiers in the United Nations peacekeeping force in Lebanon.

title: Around the World; Major Battle Said to Erupt In Salvadoran Port City
description: A major battle has broken out in the Salvadoran port city of La Union between Government forces and leftist guerrillas, military sources said here today.

title: BALLET: MERLE PARK IN 'SLEEPING BEAUTY'
description: WITH Derek Deane making his New York debut as the Prince and Merle Park seen for the first time this season as Aurora, the Royal Ballet's production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' continued to feature major cast changes Saturday at the Metropolitan Opera House. Miss Park, partnered by Wayne Eagling, danced in the afternoon. Mr. Deane partnered Jennifer Penney in the evening.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adolph Coors Company, Golden, Colo., has named John Devore vice president, material; Bill Eilers, vice president of brewery plant engineering; Lewis Bonner, vice president of transportation; Sandra Woods, vice president of corporate real estate, and Rex Lester, vice president of operations services.

title: Old College Tie
description: Charlie Puleo, a pitcher with the Tidewater Tides, who has one of the lowest earned run averages in the International League (3.05), says he is disturbed by the current strike of major league players.

title: At 121 a Man Doesn't Have Much to Complain About
description: It was a quiet day yesterday in Oakland, Calif., for Arthur Reed except for, as he put it, ''lots of interviews with those reporters who want to know everything.'' The interviews were on the occasion of Mr. Reed's birthday because he turned 121 and is said to be the world's oldest man whose age is authenticated.

title: AN R. F. C. COULD HELP NEW
description: The controversy swirling about New York's transit crisis should not be allowed to obscure two underlying realities. First, a significant portion of Federal budget cuts simply shifts the financial burden to local governments and taxpayers in those parts of the United States already under serious strain. Second, the amounts of capital required to rebuild antiquated urban facilities probably are beyond the capacity of the private markets to absorb on reasonable terms.

title: JAZZ: FESTIVAL SALUTES STYLES OF CHICAGO
description: ''GOIN' TO CHICAGO,'' a survey of Chicago jazz since the 1920's that was presented at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening as part of the Kool Jazz Festival, touched most essential bases - the traditional jazz played by young Chicagoans in the 20's, the blues, the hard-driving swing groups of the 1930's and 40's, the post-bop combos of the 1950's and 60's and the avant-garde musicians of the 70's.

title: Italy-Yugoslav Region Jolted
description: Two moderate earth tremors jolted an area near the Italy-Yugoslavia border today, the Trieste Seismological Observatory said. There were no reports of injuries or damage.

title: 2 STEEL CABLES SNAP ON BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: Two steel cables on the Brooklyn Bridge snapped last evening, severely injuring a pedestrian and causing the bridge to be closed for more than three hours.

title: CHANGES IN PEKING LEADERSHIP SEEN AS COMMUNISTS MARK ANNIVERSARY
description: The Chinese Communist Party celebrates its 60th anniversary this week with leadership changes expected to formally mark the end of more than a quarter century of social experimentation under the doctrines of Chairman Mao Zedong.

title: Pope Gives Recorded Message
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a tape-recorded message from his hospital room today in which he spoke of his illness and thanked those who had offered support ''in consideration of my weakness.'' Sounding stronger than in a similar message broadcast a week ago, the Pope issued an appeal for peace in Lebanon and offered greetings in Polish to his fellow Poles.

title: PHILADELPHIA SUBURBS WORRIED BY THREATENED HALT TO RAIL SERVICE
description: Just before the silver cars of the 8:05 A.M. local from Paoli pulled into the Wayne station on its run to Penn Center in the city, Paul Conway was still selling tickets and still giving customers his cheerful greeting.

title: DRESS MAKER'S FOUNDER ADDS TO OPERATIONS
description: When she could not find clothes that she wanted to sell in her stores, Jane Schaffhausen decided to design and manufacture them herself. The result was Belle France, a company that will probably sell $15 million worth of dresses this year, is licensing manufacturers to produce other clothing and has inspired a score of imitators, according to Mrs. Schaffhausen, its 52-year-old founder and president.

title: SMALL PARTY HEADS NEW ITALIAN CABINET
description: Italy's Christian Democrats lost the post of Prime Minister for the first time in 36 years today as Giovanni Spadolini, secretary of the small Republican Party, was sworn in at the head of a 27-member coalition by President Sandro Pertini.

title: Brothers Battle In Tennis Final
description: The brothers Boyd and Vaughn Bryan, from Lafayette, La., competed today in the singles final in the United States amateur hardcourt tennis championship, and the older brother, Boyd, triumphed by 6-7, 6-0, 6-1.

title: SCHLESINGER'S SURPRISE
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-GENERAL WAS CHIEF OF CITY'S CIVIL DEFENSE
description: Robert E. Condon, former Director of Civil Defense for New York City and a retired Air Force major general, died Friday in Arden Hill Hospital at Goshen, N.Y. He was 85 years old.

title: EIGHT VAGRANTS ARE SLASHED BY KINIFE-WIELDER IN 2 HOURS
description: A man wielding a knife slashed eight homeless men about the neck in a series of apparently unprovoked attacks from the Bowery to Pennsylvania Station Saturday night and early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: The Editorial Notebook; TO A CLOSET OPTIMIST
description: David Ives, assistant editor of Foreign Affairs Magazine, devoted some witty and passionate words on the Op-Ed page the other day to the praise of gloom. He surely has every occupational excuse, spending his days contemplating nation-states that treat each other with all the courtesy of seagulls.

title: TAX BREAK ON SAVINGS: INITIAL VICTORY
description: In a skillful display of how to influence Congress, the savings and loan industry has produced a stunning first-round victory for its bill to create a new type of tax subsidy for savers and financial institutions.

title: Indian State Government Resigns As Left Withdraws Its Support
description: The government of India's northeastern state of Assam, where nearly 300 people have died in anti-immigrant agitation, resigned today, an official announcement said.

title: Addendum
description: * Flower and Gardens magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 20 percent, to 600,000, effective with the December/January issue. The four-color advertising page rate will increase 24.9 percent, to $6,290, and black-and-white 24.5 percent, to $4,495.

title: KOCH AND ALBANY LEADER FOR APART ON TRANSIT TAX
description: Despite pressure to achieve a solution at a meeting today in Albany called by Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and the State Senate majority leader remained sharply divided yesterday on which residents of the state should bear the brunt of new taxes to finance mass-transit operating costs.

title: BEHESHTI WAS SEEN AS NO. 2 FIGURE IN IRAN AFTER THE ISLAMIC REVOLUTION
description: Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti, who was killed last night with at least 23 other highranking Iranian politicians when a bomb exploded at the Islamic Republican Party headquarters here, was widely regarded as the second most powerful figure in Iran. He was 52 years old.

title: HAIG REJECTS MOSCOW CRITICISM OF NEW CHINA ARMS POLICY
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today rejected the Soviet Union's expressions of concern over the Reagan Administration's decision to allow China to purchase American military equipment.

title: Market Place; A Fund Invests In 4 Industries
description: IN the past, when an investor sought appreciation through mutual funds, he usually selected among growth funds that represented a cross section of industries. Few funds concentrated on a specific industry, and some of their investors became unhappy when the chosen group fell out of favor. The problem has grown as market leadership has shifted more frequently in recent years.

title: Weaver Considering Tillis as Title Foe
description: Mike Weaver, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, says he is considering a title bout with James Tillis instead of Gerry Cooney, the No. 1 contender, to prevent the W.B.A. from stripping him of his title.

title: MOUNTAIN CLIMBING GAINS POPULARITY DESPITE DANGER
description: Contrary to the view of George Leigh Mallory, a would-be conqueror of Mount Everest, the people who climb tall mountains do not appear to do so just because they are there.

title: LORDI RETIRES WEDNESDAY FROM JERSEY CASINO POST
description: Joseph P. Lordi, chairman of New Jersey's Casino Control Commission, will retire Wednesday without a replacement, and the vacancy could make it more difficult for the next two applicants to get casino permits.

title: Amy Joan Simons Married To Ruben M. Abramovich
description: Amy Joan Simons, daughter of Superior Court Justice William W. Simons and Mrs. Simons of Pittsfield, Mass., was married there yesterday to Ruben Mario Abramovich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis Abromovich of Bayonne, N.J. Rabbis Arthur D. Rulnick and Sanford D. Shanblatt performed the ceremony at Temple Knesset Israel.

title: A NUCLEAR RUSE BY ISRAEL IS DOUBTED
description: The two Israeli scientists who asked for and received a briefing from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission last October on how much damage bombs could inflict on a nuclear reactor identified themselves as being from the Israeli Defense Ministry, a member of the commission said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS STILL BACKS REAGAN BILL
description: President Reagan's economic plan appears to be holding its own in the business community, despite the unexpected allure of an acrossthe-board reduction in corporate income taxes proposed by the Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: MAXINE GIBNEY NATHAN
description: Maxine Gibney Nathan, a volunteer social worker and former head of the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House of New York City, died Friday at her hone in Manhattan.

title: Dr. Laurie Padolf Married
description: Dr. Laurie Ellen Padolf and Robert T. Oken, an assistant attorney general of Connecticut, were married yesterday by Rabbi David Wortman at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn. The bride, a veterinarian in Wethersfield, Conn., is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Padolf of Pleasantville, N.Y. Mr. Oken is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Leo Oken of Waterbury, Conn.

title: BUBBLING SPRING BECKONS URBANITES TO A PRIMAL SCENE
description: A fresh wind blew off Little Neck Bay, rippling the marsh grass. Traffic rushed east and west on the Long Island Expressway. Unseen birds chirped and tweeted from their places in the leaves. And traffic rushed north and south on the Cross Island Expressway.

title: New Yorker Takes Jersey Tennis Title
description: Ray Disco of Forest Hills, Queens, competing for the first time in the New Jersey State men's tennis tournament, captured the singles championship today at the Arlington Players Club.

title: HAMMOND, INC., RESIDENTS APPEAL FOR ACTION ON ILLEGAL CHEMICAL WASTE DUMPS
description: Delays in efforts to clean up three sites used for illegal dumping of toxic chemicals have brought fear to a quiet neighborhood in Hammond.

title: Harness Hall Adds 3 to List
description: This sleepy 267-year-old town, which has only one traffic light and is about 65 miles from New York City in Orange County, comes alive once a year. That is when the flower of the harness racing industry gathers under a candy-striped tent to pay homage to those installed in the sport's Hall of Fame.

title: STATE UNIVERSITY SEEKS TO EXPAND ITS REPUTATION OUTSIDE NEW YORK
description: Thirty-three years after it began its evolution into the largest university system in the world, the State University of New York is still searching for its place in American higher education.

title: Shoe Imports, Untied
description: President Reagan appears ready to eliminate quotas on shoe imports from Taiwan and South Korea. That is fine news. For while the consumers' stake in shoes may be more modest than in steel or autos, the restriction is an extravagantly expensive way to preserve jobs and profits.

title: UNDOING REAGAN'S PRESIDENCY
description: A singular irony may await President Reagan and prove to be his undoing. The hallmark of his candidacy was his attack on Government. With great skill and perception, he convinced a majority of the voters that he would wrestle ''big Government'' to its knees and that all their troubles would somehow melt away.

title: KINGS OF THE HALFCOURT REIGN IN CENTRAL PARK BASKETBALL TOURNEY
description: Finals of the second annual Michelob citywide three-on-three halfcourt basketball tournament, Saturday afternoon, on the sunny Central Park courts at 84th Street, north end of the Great Lawn:
''Why should people who live in Penn Yan be paying for the ZZ train?'' -Richard Roth, spokesman for the State Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson. (B3:5.)

title: Commodities; Qualifying Corn Yield Forecasts
description: HAS the recent free-fall in corn prices set the stage for a sharp rebound? Or will the bullish fundamentals prove to be a costly trap, as has often been the case since the drought-seared harvest of last year?

title: Around the Nation; Jackson Leads Rights Rally In Thurmond's Hometown
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson led about 2,000 people, marching two abreast, to a voting rights rally in the heart of Senator Strom Thurmond's hometown today as state troopers and local police patrolled nearby.

title: HIS BODY'S IN THE MINORS
description: OMAHA DUSK was settling over Rosenblatt Stadium here and the sinking sun lit the light towers in the outfield red. It was humid, but a wind had picked up - an ill wind, very ill, bringing the unmistakable odor from the sewage plant a half-mile away.

title: The Economy
description: Big business remains solidly behind the President's tax plans, despite Democratic proposals offering broader cuts. But operators of small business are cooler to Reagan depreciation proposals, preferring both the income tax cuts and immediate write-offs for capital outlays outlined in the House. (Page D1.)

title: OUTDOORS: NATURE IS FOREVER HOSTING A FOOD FESTIVAL
description: AFEW days ago when a hundred surf fishermen were crowded along a quarter-mile of beach flailing the water for hungry bluefish that were slashing through schools of squid and young alewives, a pretty, dark-haired young woman with a green plastic bucket walked along the shore seemingly oblivious to the breaking fish, bent rods, crossed lines and screaming gulls.

title: Argentina Complains On Timerman Debate
description: Foreign Minister Oscar Camilion called in the United States charge d'affaires Friday to complain about allegations made on a television program in the United States that there are concentration camps in Argentina.

title: Jane Frederick Wins National Heptathlon
description: Jane Frederick of Santa Barbara, Calif., continued her domination of women's multi-event track and field competition in the United States yesterday by winning the first national heptathlon for women.

title: THE SAUDIS' MONETARY-FUND
description: ''Wealth maketh many friends,'' and no where has this been truer than in the International Monetary Fund, where the doyens of the world banking community have hungrily assented to a special loan from Saudi Arabia. Yet, as has also been observed, riches enlarge rather than satisfy appetites.

title: Vulcan Planning Plant Expansion
description: The Vulcan Materials Company, a producer of chemicals and construction aggregates, announced a major $67 million expansion of its facilities in Wichita, Kan., to increase production of chlorine, caustic soda and hydrochloric acid - three basics used widely in a variety of industries.

title: Goalby Is Victor
description: Bob Goalby shot a one-under-par 70 today and held off the challenges of his playing partners, Art Wall and Dan Sikes, to post a two-stroke victory in a $150,000 Seniors Classic.

title: DIRECTORS REACH AN AGREEMENT
description: Film and television directors reached tentative agreement with producers today on a new three-year contract that provides a salary increase of nearly 40 percent and which could avert a strike.

title: EVANGELICAL GROUP PREACHES ECOLOGY
description: In a remote, thickly forested setting on the shores of Big Twin Lake, an environmental movement has quietly begun that may have broad implications for the nation's evangelical Christians.

title: Index; International
description: Chinese Communist Party marks 60th anniversary this week A2 Haig rejects Soviet criticism on China arms decision A3 Iraq's response to Israeli bombing remains a matter of conjecture A3 Nuclear aide doubts Israeli scien- tists were linked to Iraq raid A4 Beheshti was regarded as Iran's second most powerful figure A6 Sudan leader says efforts to expel Libya from U.N. have begun A7 Labor Party needs a major vic- tory to topple Begin A8 Around the World A11 Government/Politics Country's last state board of cen- sorship fades away A13 City commission's role in plan- ning viewed as diminishing B1 Tolls between N.Y.C. and N.J. should stay stable until 1984 B3 Supreme Court could tip to the right if a conservative is chosen B6 About Washington: Democrats singing the Beltway blues B6 Lordi to step down as head of Jer- sey casino commission D10 General Around the Nation A12 Hammond, Ind., residents appeal for action on chemical dumps A12 Philadelphia area worried by threat to commuter rail service A12 Dangers seem no deterrent to mountain climbers A13 12th annual Gay Pride March held up Fifth Avenue B1 At a park in Queens, city dwellers learn about nature B3 Grand jury to hear case of woman who shot husband as intruder D10 Industry/Labor Hollywood directors and produc- ers reach an agreement C12 Education/Welfare The State University of New York is still searching for its place A1 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Mears wins twice in his return to competition C8 Baseball: Trials of Jim Buckner, a minor leaguer C1

title: Track Coach Runs Into Hoax
description: A doctored newspaper story and headline persuaded the University of Texas track coach, Cleburne Price, to give a scholarship to an African athlete who, when he arrived, could barely reach the sand pit in the triple jump, supposedly one of his specialties.

title: MUSIC: CONLON OPENS CARAMOOR WITH EN EVENING OF MOZART
description: A COOL summer evening, a large audience and music by Mozart conspired to make Saturday evening's opening of the 1981 Caramoor Festival at Katonah, N.Y., a winning one. James Conlon conducted the Caramoor Festival Orchestra in two of Mozart's more interesting symphonies - the No. 34 in C (K. 388) and the ''Prague,'' No. 38 in D (K. 504).

title: U.S. Cyclist Moves Up in Coors Event
description: Dale Stetina of Indianapolis won one of the two men's races today and moved into second place 1 minute 22 seconds behind Yuri Kashirin of the Soviet Union in the overall standing of the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: YALE SENIOR, A VIETNAM MEMORIAL AND A FEW IRONIES
description: ''I don't even know how to draft yet,'' said Maya Ying Lin with a laugh, enjoying one of the many ironies in her first place finish in teh national competition to design a memorial to veterans of the Vietnam war.

title: STIND DEFEATS COSMOS, 6-5
description: The Sting's mastery over the Cosmos continued this afternoon before a club-record crowd of 30,501 at Wrigley Field. The Sting edged the Cosmos, 6-5, in a shootout for its sixth victory against only one defeat in the series that started in 1976. The Cosmos' only victory was in 1977.

title: Laura Ann Parsteck Wed
description: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., yesterday, Laura Ann Parsteck, who attends Douglass College, was married to Howard Robert Buechler, a rabinnical student at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Rabbis Alvin Poplack, Jacob Rubenstein and Julius Funk officiated. The couple's parents are Dr. Bennett J. Parsteck, assistant principal of the John Bowne High School in Flushing, Queens, and Mrs. Parsteck of Floral Park, L.I., and Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Buechler of Rahway, N.J.

title: Mrs. Lopez-Melton Winner by 2
description: Nancy Lopez-Melton won her third event at the Locust Hill Country Club today, shooting a two-under-par 71 and finishing at 285 in the $125,000 Sarah Coventry tournament.

title: Relationships; DISABLED MUST COPE IN 'NORMAL' WORLD
description: Recently several able-bodied members of the New York State Legislature used wheelchairs, canes and blindfolds to try to get some idea of what it was like to be disabled. With them were two Assemblymen who were handicapped in reality, one due to childhood polio and the other from Vietnam war injuries. Meanwhile, scores of other handicapped New Yorkers staged a lobbying effort in the Legislative Office Building.

title: Figures for History
description: Leonard Alley of Richmond, who is the official scorer for the International League, is looking forward with some dread to the day when he receives the official box score of the 33-inning game between the Pawtucket Red Sox and the Rochester Red Wings. The game, the longest in professional baseball history, began on April 18, was suspended after 32 innings at 4:07 A.M. on April 19, and finally completed last Tuesday, with Pawtucket winning, 3-2.

title: For All the Marbles
description: The crowd of 300 people clustered around a 10-foot circle drawn on the sand on the beach at Wildwood, N.J., was tense. A national championship was hanging in the balance.

title: A RELAXED CONNORS IS QUIETLY IMPRESSIVE
description: They are technical points, so subtle that Jimmy Connors may have taken them for granted over the years. But now that he is in the role of challenger instead of champion, Connors listens when colleagues point out flaws.

title: Argentine Sculler Wins Holland Cup
description: Ricardo Ibarra of Argentina won the Holland Cup today, beating Alf Hansen of Norway to the finish line in the single sculls race of an international rowing regatta.

title: About Washington
description: The Democratic minority leader of the Senate, Robert C. Byrd, has a memorable stare, poignant for a politician, that seems to border on melancholia. And never was the time more ripe for it than in the Democrats' harrowing budget defeat last week as the West Virginian raised his eyes from the gray welter of legislation, up beyond the gallery of silent Americans, toward the impervious stone walls of the Capitol, the nation's ultimate arena.

title: LAST STATE BOARD OF CENSORS FADES AWAY AFTER 65 YEARS State Board of Censors
description: The last picture show came before the Maryland State Board of Censors this week. It passed. The three-member board got a free preview of ''The Great Muppet Caper'' (rated G), unanimously gave it a license to be exhibited in the Free State of Maryland and then darkened the house - closing their private screening room here for the last time. They held a coffee-and-cookies reception, exchanged gifts and made jokes designed to lighten the aura of doom that surrounded the last meeting of the country's only state movie censorship board.

title: D'Arcy-McManus Gets Nocturne de Caron
description: D'Arcy-McManus & Masius has become the advertising agency to help introduce Nocturne de Caron in the United States for Parfum Caron of Paris, which is owned by the A.H. Robins Company of Richmond.

title: James S. Vandermade Jr.  Marries Julia K. Jackson
description: Julia K. Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Jackson of Fort Worth, was married yesterday to James S. Vandermade Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vandermade of Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Michael Morris, minister of the First Congregational Church of Montclair, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in New York.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: If a hockey player shoots with one second left in a period, and the puck goes into the net with the clock at zero, is it a goal?

title: Bumble Bee Switch
description: Bumble Bee Seafood, a subsidiary of Castle & Cooke Foods, has switched from Geers, Gross of New York, to the J. Walter Thompson San Francisco office of Soskin/Thompson, direct marketing specialists, under general manager Guy Hitler.

title: Belgian Takes Leg Of Tour de France
description: Freddy Maertens of Belgium won the fourth stage of the Tour de France cycling race today.

title: 4 More Moslems Held by Manila
description: The Government announced the capture today of four more members of a suspected Moslem terrorist group that is accused of plotting to kill President Ferdinand E. Marcos and set off bombs in Manila. An announcement said this brought to 40 the number of suspected plotters now in military custody.

title: WHERE TRADITION AND CONTROVERSY BLEND
description: On the same day that John McEnroe threw a temper tantrum on the No. 1 court, a woman sat in the umpire's chair for the first time on center court at the All England Club.

title: Paying Their Dues
description: A lot of Americans, when they are looking for things to get angry about, sooner or later come around to the expense of their union dues. Among professional athletes, though, that is one complaint that is seldom - if ever -heard. With good reason. Among the five major team sports whose participants are represented by players associations, the annual dues in each sport represent less than 1 percent of the average player income.

title: 'WILD WOMAN,' A BLUES PROGRAM
description: LINDA HOPKINS, who portrayed the great blues singer Bessie Smith in a successful Broadway production, and Nell Carter, who made her reputation as a member of the original ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' cast, performed women's blues from the 1920's (and a few later pieces) separately and together in ''Wild Women Don't Have the Blues,'' the Jazz Festival program Saturday in Avery Fisher Hall. Their presentation was tightly paced and choreographed and made room for interruptions, including period film footage of Louis Armstrong and an appearance by Sippie Wallace, who were singing the blues before Miss Hopkins and Miss Carter were born.

title: Janet Cohen Is Married
description: At the Union Reform Temple in Freeport, L.I., yesterday, Janet Cohen and Eric Bret Zwiebel, both of Oklahoma City, were married by Rabbi Robert Schenkerman. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jonah Cohen of Sunrise, Fla., and Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Zwiebel of Freeport and Chrisiansted, St. Croix, Virgin Islands. The bride was graduated from Hofstra University. Mr. Zwiebel, an alumnus of Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn., received a law degree from Oklahoma City University.

title: 19 Prisoners Killed in Nicaragua
description: Nicaraguan prison guards killed 19 inmates and wounded 28 after several guards were taken hostage in an escape attempt, the Interior Ministry said today. A statement said the prisoners, most of them former National Guardsmen loyal to the ousted dictator, Anastasio Somoza Debayle, offered to exchange the guards for their freedom. Shooting broke out after several hours of negotiations, the statement added.

title: CHIEF TO BE CHAIRMAN OF BANK OF MONTREAL
description: William D. Mulholland, a former Wall Street investment banker, will take over Wednesday as the chairman of the Bank of Montreal, the third-largest bank in Canada and the eighth-largest in North America.

title: Half Marathon to Fanelli
description: Gary Fanelli, a 30-year-old bee-pollen salesman, successfully defended his title today in the sixth annual Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Half Marathon. He completed the hilly 13.1-mile course from White Plains to New Rochelle in 1 hour 5 minutes 18 seconds.

title: Linda Cohen Is a Bride
description: Linda Susan Cohen, a theatrical manager, was married yesterday to Harris Goldman, executive director of the Hartman Theater Company in Stamford, Conn. Cantor Abraham Veroba performed the ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Cohen of Rye, N.Y., is with Emanuel Azenberg, a Broadway producer. Mr. Goldman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Goldman of Woodbridge, Conn.

title: Susan Duke Bride Of D.A. Biederman
description: Susan Deborah Duke, an associate with the New York law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff & Ernst, was married in Princeton, N.J., yesterday to Daniel A. Biederman, executive director of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation in New York. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony in the garden of Prospect House at Princeton University.

title: Jorgensen Cites Power of Faith
description: Mike Jorgensen, first basemen-outfielder for the Mets, spent part of his Sunday off yesterday telling a Queens church congregation how prayer helped him get back to baseball after a major injury.

title: Sherri Helene Timoner Wed To Dr. Neil David Eisner
description: Sherri Helene Timoner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Timoner of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to Dr. Neil David Eisner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lester L. Eisner of Short Hills, N.J. Rabbi Sidney Zimmelman performed the ceremony at the Crest Hills Country Club.

title: Judith A. Blatt, Yale '81, Married to John L. Casey
description: The marriage of Judith Ann Blatt, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Blatt of Woodbridge, Conn., to John Louis Casey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict A. Casey of Cherry Hill, N.J., took place yesterday in Woodbridge. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony at the Oak Lane Country Club.

title: Mears, Back After Indy Fire, Wins Twice
description: Rick Mears won both races of the Kraco Atlanta Twin 125's program for Indianapolis-type cars at Atlanta International Raceway today.

title: NIFFARDLY TAX CUTTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 29, 1981
description: International 24 leading Islamic politicians died in a bombing that destroyed the Teheran headquarters of Iran's governing Islamic Republican Party. Among the dead was the party's leader, Chief Justice Ayatollah Mohammed Beheshti. According to witnesses, the explosion occurred as a group of 90 Cabinet ministers and members of Parliament, including Prime Minister Mohammed Ali Rajai, were listening to Ayatollah Beheshti as he addressed a weekly meeting. The Prime Minister was reported among the injured, but his office said only that he had survived. Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, was the only senior official not present, security sources said. (Page A1, Column 6.) Restoration of Indian-Chinese relations was pledged in New Delhi by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and Foreign Minister Huang Hua of China. They announced after a 70-minute meeting that they would hold talks soon on their long-deadlocked border dispute. Indian officials said the talks would be held in September in Peking. Mrs. Gandhi announced that she had accepted an invitation to visit China. (A1:4.)

title: CHRYSLER PRODUCTION COULD YIELD A PROFIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation has continued to produce cars at an aggressive pace this month, despite a decline in retail sales, in an apparent effort to live up to its prediction of a second-quarter profit.

title: AT GUARDIAN ANGEL WEDDING, WELL-ADORNED BERETS
description: The event may not have generated quite as much gossip and glamour as, say, the forthcoming nuptials of Prince Charles and Lady Diana, but the recent Saturday afternoon marriage of Rocky Pratt and Wanda Ortiz did provide June with one of its more colorful and festive wedding receptions. The guests also displayed a lively fashion sense. The majority wore stylish red wool berets decorated, in personal statements, with glistening studs, dangling medals of both military and religious origin, cascades of colored beads and bushy, furry tails. They also sported T-shirts that read ''Guardian Angels Safety Patrol.''

title: City AND STATE ARGUE ABOUT THE WATER AS LEVELS OF UPSTATE RESERVORIS GO
description: UP By DAVID BIRD

title: Rebecca West Dismisses Some Other Writers
description: Age has its perspective - and a certain freedom of expression. Take Dame Rebecca West, for example.

title: INDIA AND CHINA ANNOUNCE TALKS ON BORDER ISSUE
description: India and China announced their intention today to hold early negotiations on their long-deadlocked border dispute.

title: Hugh Thomas, Broadway Actor Began Career in Juvenile Roles
description: Hugh Thomas, who made his Broadway debut as the juvenile lead in ''Janie'' in 1943, died Saturday at his home in Wallington, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: Robin Sue Tanenbaum Bride Of Steven G. Pollak in Jersey
description: Robin Sue Tanenbaum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Tanenbaum,was married yesterday to Steven Gene Pollak, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Pollak of Oceanside, L.I. Rabbi Helene Ferris performed the ceremony at the Tanenbaum home in Short Hills, N.J.

title: MAN IS SLAIN AFTER TAKEOVER OF F. B. I. IN ATLANTA
description: A gunman forced his way into the headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and took about a dozen employees hostage for several hours today, then was killed in a shootout with local and Federal officers, the authorities said.

title: PERES PARTY NEEDS A MOJOR VICTORY TO TOPPLE BEGIN
description: Strategists of Israel's opposition Labor Party said today that they could not prevent Prime Minister Menachem Begin from forming the next cabinet unless Tuesday's election gives their party a substantial victory - at least seven or eight more seats in Parliament than Mr. Begin's Likud bloc.

title: Harvester Cuts Jobs
description: Citing a drop in world demand for farm equipment, the International Harvester Company of Chicago said it planned further job cutbacks in itain. Employment at the Doncaster factory, which employs 3,500, will be cut by 635 persons, including managers, staff and hourly workers. Its London headquarters will be moved to Doncaster, and about 65 employees will be dismissed, the company said.

title: RUNNER TO PUT PRIZE MONEY IN ESCROW
description: Greg Meyer insists that money cannot substitute for love of the sport, but the $10,000 in controversial prize money he is putting in escrow from his Cascade Run Off victory will be a nice extra benefit.

title: Train Crash in Soviet Reported
description: Seventy people were killed and more than 100 injured in a train crash near a popular Black Sea resort in Soviet Georgia, according to a report reaching Moscow today. Travelers said there was a collision last week between an express and a local train near Gagry, a Black Sea coastal district.

title: Floyd Wins by 6 Strokes
description: Ray Floyd scored a 71, one under par, to win the $100,000 Canadian International Classic today by six strokes.

title: TV: 'CHRISTIANS,' 13-PART BRITISH SERIES, BEGINS
description: PRODUCED several years ago for Britain's Granada Television, ''The Christians'' is now getting a showcase in this country. This 13-part series will be carried, beginning tonight, on WOR-TV on Mondays at 8 o'clock. The programs, written and narrated by Bamber Gascoigne, trace the history of Christianity from the birth of Christ through the Holy Roman Empire and the questionings of modern science, to the state, albeit dated, of the church in 20th-century Russia, Poland and Italy.

title: SURROGATE MOTHERS: WHY WOMEN VOLUNTEER
description: Still filled with remorse over the abortion she underwent two years before, 23-year-old Alice G. answered a personal notice in her local newspaper offering $10,000 plus expenses to women who would consent to conceive and carry babies for childless couples.

title: CITY PLANNING COMMISSION FINDS ITS POWER IS ERODING
description: When the New York City Planning Commission last week detailed sweeping zoning rules and tax incentives designed to shift development from the congested East Side of midtown to the less developed West Side, it attempted to set the tone for Manhattan's midtown growth for the next decade or more.

title: SHARP DROP IN MACHINE TOOL ORDERS
description: Machine tool orders in May showed a sharp drop from the alreadydepressed levels of a year earlier, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday. They declined 47 percent, compared with May 1980.

title: Foreign Affairs; TIME'S RUNNING SHORT
description: West Germany was distressed by Eugene Rostow's statement last week that the United States won't be ready to start strategic talks with Moscow until sometime next year. The new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency was testifying at confirmation hearings, and presumably delay was what he thought the Administration wanted and the Senate majority would like to hear.

title: Article 177259 -- No Title
description: There is a potentially heavy supply of corporate securities scheduled for sale this week, with some investment bankers estimating over $1 billion will be sold. They add, however, that fewer issues will come to market if prices drop significantly and if investors are not buying.

title: Dello Joio Captures Jumpoff on Allegro
description: Norman Dello Joio rode Allegro to a perfect round in 37.741 seconds in a third-round jumpoff today and captured the blue ribbon in the $10,000 Jumper Classic, feature event of the 1981 Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: ISRAEL'S ENEMIES FIND AN ALLY IN WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; New Irish Coalition Emerges With FitzGerald as Leader
description: Former Foreign Minister Garret FitzGerald won the parliamentary backing of the Labor Party today, moving him a significant step toward his goal of becoming Ireland's next Prime Minister.

title: No Headline
description: Brig. Gen. Charles A. Willis Dead; Ex-Assistant Chief of 42d Division

title: ITT Creed Cutbacks
description: ITT Creed Ltd., a British subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said it would eliminate 990 jobs at three manufacturing plants in Britain over a six-month period beginning in September. It cited changes in manufacturing technology, increased competition and a national recession as reasons for the cutbacks. Among other products, the company will stop making its current teleprinter.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:
To the Editor:

title: Washington Watch; Social Security Benefit Changes
description: WASHINGTON LAST week's budget victory still leaves the Administration with some major decisions about what next to hit to get further savings in government expenditures.

title: People
description: * W. Page Thompson named publisher of Scholastics' Co-Ed and Forecast Magazines.

title: Clemson Gains Final
description: Clemson University, the United States representative in the 1981 world basketball championships, defeated China, 101-91, today to reach the final round of the competition. Francana of Brazil defeated Asfa of Senegal, 89-60, in the other preliminary phase game.

title: Sports World Specials; Different Strokes
description: ''I've got golf fever now,'' said Rudy Tomjanovich of the Houston Rockets after carding 137 for 18 holes on the Rock Creek Country Club course outside Portland, Ore. Tomjanovich, for 11 years one of the best forwards in pro basketball, was playing his first round of golf as part of the National Basketball Association Golf Classic, a benefit tournament for the Hearing and Speech League.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Experts Differ on Fed Strategy By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Jill Marion Rosenblatt Is Married to Bradford J. Gordon
description: Jill Marion Rosenblatt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Rosenblatt of New York, was married yesterday at the Central Synagogue to Bradford J. Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Gordon of Glenview, Ill. Rabbi John Haddon performed the ceremony.

title: Lynne Federman, Lawyer, Wed to Joseph A. Korb Jr.
description: Lynne Halli Federman, a New York lawyer, was married yesterday in Clifton, N.J., to Joseph Anthony Korb Jr., who is with the conservation division of the Department of Energy in Newark. Rabbi Bertram Siegel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Federman. Mr. Korb is a son of Katherine Korb of Lyndhurst, N.J., and the late Mr. Korb.

title: Finkel Finds Gold in Ring, Too
description: There were 67,000 rock fans in the Yale Bowl, unaware that backstage the Eagles were telling the promoter they had changed their minds and were not going to play unless they were paid first.

title: Texasgulf Studies Bid by Aquitaine
description: The board of Texasgulf Inc., a leading chemicals and minerals concern, failed to decide yesterday whether to accept Friday's takeover offer from France's Elf Aquitaine group.

title: Nippon Telegraph Seeks Shift in Pact
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation reportedly is seeking revisions to improve its present patent agreement with the Western Electric Company, the manufacturing and supply arm of the Bell System.

title: Aoki's Victory Helps Japan Capture Golf
description: Isao Aoki defeated Greg Norman to lead a Japanese team to a 16-16 tie with Australia today on the final day of the fourth Japan-Australia goodwill golf match.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt COVERING ISLAM. How the Media and the Experts Determine How We See the Rest of the World. By Edward W. Said. 186 pages. Pantheon. Hard cover, $10.95; paper, $3.95.

title: RIP TAYLOR BARGES IN FOR ROONEY
description: IT was an ordinary day at the Mark Hellinger Theater, where ''Sugar Babies'' has been playing for two and a half years. A healthy line stretched away from the box-office window, the patient ticket buyers impervious to the Broadway gypsy teaching another a tap number inside the lobby. In the auditorium, pretty chorus girls sat scattered through the dark house, waiting for their routines to start. And on stage, Ann Miller kicked those long legs high as she danced her way through the ''When You and I Were Young, Maggie Blues.''

title: JOANNE BRACKEN PLAYS SOLO PIANO
description: JOANNE BRACKEEN brought an impressive authority to her Jazz Festival solo piano recital Saturday at Carnegie Recital Hall. Her playing was rich and involved, with 10-finger chordal swells frequently overwhelming her darting single-note lines, but each note and phrase was cleanly and firmly articulated.

title: URBAN GROUPS DISPUTE HESTON ON ARTS CUTS
description: Sixty-two and Spanish-speaking organizational leaders, artists and scholars said yesterday that Reagan Administration figures apparently considered as "expendable" the Federal arts and humanities programs "that are most active in supporting work of minority artists and scholars."

title: HOUSE BUDGET VOTE APPEARS TO AID PRESIDENT 'NEW FEDERALISM 'PLAN
description: As details become available today on the complex budget reduction bill passed by the House, it appeared that President Reagan had gained an important victory on the way to achieving his goal of returning authority to the states from the Federal Government.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BARD IN THE PARK

title: No Talks in View In Baseball Walkout
description: There were no major league baseball games and no baseball negotiations again yesterday. There have to be negotiations before there can be games, but no one knows when either will resume.

title: New W.M.D. Unit Is Close to Home
description: Over the weekend, Harvard & Edrick/WMD, the newly acquired subsidiary of Warren, Muller, Dolobowsky, moved into the floor below its parent at 747 Third Avenue.

title: IRAQ REPLY TO ISRAEL: TOPIC OF CONJECTURE
description: Diplomats in Baghdad and many Iraqis are wondering what further action, if any, President Saddam Hussein is planning now that the United Nations Security Council has passed a resolution that ''strongly condemns'' Israel's attack on an Iraqi nuclear reactor.

title: Exiles From Estonia Say Pastor Has Been Sent to Soviet Hospital
description: An Estonian pastor who voiced nationalist opinions in sermons and underground articles has been committed by Soviet authorities to a mental hospital, Estonian exile sources said today.

title: U.S. Steel Imports Up 9.3% in May
description: United States steel imports in May rose 9.3 percent, to 1.77 million net tons from 1.62 million tons a year ago, the American Iron and Steel Institute said

title: Bansi Chandragupta, 57, Is Dead; Art Director on Satyajit Ray Films
description: Bansi Chandragupta, one of India's leading film art directors, died Saturday in Brookhaven (L.I.) Memorial Hospital after suffering a heart attack while running for a train. He was 57 years old.

title: ADDITION OF CONSERVATIVE TO COURT COULD TIP BALANCE
description: The philosophical balance of the Supreme Court could tip significantly to the right in several important areas of constitutional law if President Reagan appoints someone who shares his conservative views to succeed Justice Potter Stewart, who has announced his plan to retire next month.

title: Sitting Up 52,003 Times for Benefit of the Red Cross
description: Last year Steve Sokol saved a co-worker's life using resuscitation techniques he learned in a Red Cross course. Recently, while casting about for a way to pay back for that valuable training, Mr. Sokol hit upon sit-ups, for which he found he had some aptitude.

title: Lofts and the Law
description: About 20,000 New Yorkers live in lofts - multistory factory buildings - many of them in violation of the Multiple Dwelling Law, which mandates fire exits and other safety measures. The fire risk is real in the large apartments with wooden floors and few exits. But loft owners and tenants are burned up over the issue of how to modify the buildings to make them safe and legal, as the city now demands. A one-year state moratorium on evictions or extraordinary rent increases, enacted in the hope that passions would subside, expires tomorrow, with tempers hotter than ever.

title: Advertising
description: Philip H. Dougherty Cooperative Couponing Is Popular

title: Joan Kennedy a Hit in Italy
description: Wearing a bare-shouldered green chiffon gown, Joan Kennedy stepped in front of a near-capacity audience of 1,500 people at the Regio Theater in Turin, Italy, Friday night.

title: CONOCO: BRONFMAN'S BIG CHANCE
description: Thirteen years ago the late Samuel Bronfman, who had made a fortune in the Canadian liquor business, bought a small oil company in Texas for $50 million in cash and the promise of more on the basis of its future production.

title: Ford Foundation Gives $6 Million For Population-Research Efforts
description: The Ford Foundation has made grants totaling $6 million to two organizations in the population-research field, the foundation announced yesterday.

title: Around the world; Gromyko Visit to Poland Is Announced for July
description: The Soviet Union announced tonight that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko would go to Poland early next month for what was described as a ''brief friendly visit.''

title: PATE'S VICTORY MAKES A SPLASH
description: Jerry Pate scored his first victory in almost three years today, winning the Danny Thomas-Memphis Classic by two strokes. And, just as he promised, he celebrated the end of the dry spell by leaping into the lake in front of the 18th green.

description: NEW JERSEY GUIDE BENEFIT CONCERTS...
