description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN NAMES HIS CHIEF OF STAFF AND HIS COUNSELOR
description: The first appointments of Ronald Reagan's administration were announced today, and key transition officials said work would begin Monday to select no fewer than three names to be considered for each Cabinet post.

title: GUBERNATORIAL RACE IS NEXT ON THE LIST
description: POTENTIAL officeseekers and leaders in both political parties in New Jersey are examining the Reagan landslide, as well as past state election history, for some clue as to what is going to happen next year.

title: Business People; FRANK CAPRA JR. GETS TOP AVCO FILM JOB
description: Frank Capra Jr., 47 years old, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation. He succeeds Robert Rehme, 45, who will leave the film production and distribution subsidiary of the Avco Corporation to become president of distribution and marketing for Universal Pictures.

title: BINKS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CAPITAL PUNISHMENT: WRONG ON ALL COUNTS
description: THE current furor over capital punishment, and efforts to reinstate it in New Jersey, lead my thoughts back to when it first became a moral issue for me.

title: SOME CATHOLIC WOMEN ARE ALTERING MASS TO MEET THEIR CONCERNS
description: Growing numbers of Roman Catholic women are altering the ritual of the mass to meet their concerns and in some cases now gather to share the bread and wine of holy communion without the presence of an ordained priest.

title: TROUBLE FOR START
description: The way things are going, it will be a surprise if the Townes Commission reports to Secretary of Defense Weinberger this week that the Reagan Administration should proceed with plans to deploy 200 new MX missiles in 4,600 shelters in Utah and Nevada.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock spli paid in Jan 1981

title: POWERFUL POTIONS IN TRUTH ARE QUITE HUMBLE
description: Haven't we all wondered how they do it, those products that offer days of desert dryness to underarms, a return to color for graying hair, a microbe-free, kissing-fresh breath, the removal of unwanted hair or the fading of ''age spots'' from skin? And wondered as well what else they do to the body? A glance at the ingredients won't enlighten most consumers. Labels are littered with polysyllabic, hyphenated words full of x's and triple consonants.

title: NOVELS IN BLUE AND GRAY
description: Some Southerners call it the War Between the States; most Northerners call it the Civil War. Whichever, the war is not gone with the wind in the typewriters of contemporary novelists. By happenstance, there seem to be more novels about the Civil War than about the Vietnam War this season. Here are some current titles that feature Johnny Reb and Billy Yank:

title: The Caribbean Rediscovered
description: When Herbert Hoover was President, 50 years ago, the headline read: ''Our Caribbean Policy Again Under Scrutiny.'' Two years ago, similar news: ''Caribbean Still in U.S. Focus.'' So the recent headline was predictable: ''A New Policy on Aid for Caribbean Wins Reagan's Approval.''

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Including $8,419,000 income from discontinued operations and $587,000 pretax charge in connection with the 1980 annual meeti and proxy contest...C-Including $1,975,000 income from disconti operations and $4,391,000 tax credit; 1981 results include oper of Oxford Homes Inc since the date of acquisition Apr 25, 1980; company is listed on the Pacific and Philadelphia stock exchang

title: BROOKLYN BRIDGE TO GET NEW SET OF STEEL CABLES
description: As part of a 10-year citywide bridge rehabilitation program, New York City plans to replace the thousands of steel cables on the Brooklyn Bridge, where two cables snapped Sunday, city officials said yesterday.

title: WANTED: RX FOR NURSING CRISIS
description: AFOREBODING silence hangs over the respiratory-care unit at Bridgeport Hospital these days. All eight of the neatly made beds lie empty. The floor gleams, no longer scuffed and soiled by regular traffic,

title: Window Shades Have Their Ups and Downs, Too
description: WINDOW shades are among those remarkably efficient, but simple, mechanical devices that most people never really give much thought to until they fail to operate properly. Then they become a frustrating nuisance.

title: BEHIND DROP IN GOLD AND SILVER
description: It seems like only months ago that gold and silver prices were climbing to new peaks daily and that investors, eager to profit on the explosion, were lining up across the country to buy those precious metals at almost any price.

title: JAPAN'S DEFENSE CHIEF RESISTS U.S. PRESSURE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger insisted today that Japan rapidly increase its military strength to help cope with a threat from the Soviet Union, but Japan's defense minister firmly resisted the request.

title: ELF'S BENEFITS CITED IN BID FOR TEXASGULF, DESPITE LOSS OF MINE
description: From Elf Aquitaine's perspective, the old cliche that half a cake is better than none is being played out on a grand scale as the huge French oil and chemical company attempts to take over Texasgulf Inc.

title: European Steel Jobs Decline
description: The steel industry in the European Economic Community employed 636,400 workers last year, down 155,700, or 19.7 percent, from 792,100 in 1974, Eurostat, the Common Market's statistics agency, reported today.

title: LIONEL HAMPTON AND NANCY WILSON
description: LIONEL HAMPTON has been a jazz-festival perennial, and he has often performed with alumni from his big bands of the 40's. This year, he tried something different.

title: 3 Doctors Sentenced for Rape
description: Three doctors were sentenced today to six months in prison and one year's probation for raping a nurse. Eugene Sherry, 27 years old, of Boston, Arif Hussain, 30, of Waltham, Mass., and Alan Lefkowitz, 30, of Waterbury, Conn., were convicted in Suffolk County Superior Court last September. The victim testified that they had raped her in a beach house.

title: FROM THE U.N. TO HARLEM, AN UNSTINGING DIPLOMACY
description: In the daytime, Charles Fleming belongs to the diplomatic world, representing the Caribbean island of St. Lucia at the United Nations. At night, he moves in very different circles, teaching in Harlem at Malcolm King College or strolling the streets of the South Bronx. He is happiest when he can fulfill his personal commitment of doing a good turn daily for a New Yorker.

title: DEMOCRATS' '84 PLAY
description: The struggle over control of the Democratic National Committee is like the battle over the Iranian city of Khurramshahr: armies locked in a desperate struggle over a ruin.

title: Economic Scene; Discord Stirs With Allies
description: A STORM is brewing between the incoming Reagan administration and European members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over military spending. President-elect Ronald Reagan, stressing the need to counter the Soviet military buildup, has made proposals that would increase military expenditures by an estimated 7 to 9 percent a year in real terms - that is, after allowing for inflation. This represents a sizable increase over President Carter's proposed real increase of 4 1/2 to 5 percent.

title: SENSITIVITY OF FM TUNERS
description: T he current interest in digital tuners - discussed in this column two weeks ago - should not lead prospective buyers to overlook other important considerationsa in tuner design. Whether or not a particular tuner model is digital, there are several general quality factors that determine its performance. These apply equally to separate tuners and to so-called receivers, in which the tuner and amplifier are combined in a single unit.

title: NORTHEAST SAID TO GAIN IN HOUSE VOTE TO END CAP ON MEDICAID COST
description: In the contrast of last Friday's House of Representatives vote on budget proposals supported by the Reagan Administration, it appeared that the House had imposed a 7 1/2 percent cap on increases in Federal Medicaid spending that would force states to shoulder the burden of increased costs if the Reagan program to control inflation did not work.

title: REAGAN AND THE MIDEAST; by Anthony Lewis
description: A large unknown in the foreign policy outlook of President-elect Reagan is his view of the Middle East. Except for a few campaign simplicities, he has said little about how he would approach the Arab-Israeli conflict or handle United States relations with the region. Among those who have advised him on foreign policy there is no one experienced in dealing with the problems of the Middle East.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 20
MAN GUILTY IN 1980 SUBWAY DEATH
description: A 19-year-old Queens man was convicted yesterday of pushing another Queens man to his death in front of a subway train in the Jackson Heights section last year.

title: Serrano Retains His Title With Unanimous Decision
description: Sammy Serrano of Puerto Rico retained his World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Leonel Hernandez of Venezuela.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK PARTY CHAIRMAN IN BID FOR UNITY
description: The effort to rebuild the Democratic Party on the rubble of its crushing electoral defeats last Tuesday has begun with an intense focus on the future of John C. White, the party's national chairman.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
BALLET: NUREYEV DANCES 'LA SYLPHIDE'
description: ONE of the most beguiling, if occasionally bewildering, spectacles in ballet came to town last night: Rudolf Nureyev, Ghislaine Thesmar and the Boston Ballet opened at the Uris theater in the United States premiere of Pierre Lacotte's production of the French version of ''La Sylphide.''

title: Synthetic Fuels Contract Delay
description: The award of the Federal Government's first major synthetic fuels contract, which had been scheduled to go to the Union Oil Company today, was delayed at the last minute because of a dispute between a Congressional subcommittee and the Department of Energy.

title: Market Place; Wheelabrator: A Closer Look
description: SHARES of Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. have been moving upward ever since the company emerged victorious in its ferocious struggle with J. Ray McDermott & Company for Pullman Inc.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN SHOTGUN SLAYING
description: A Queens man was arrested last night and charged with the June 19 murder of the son of New York City stockbroker, the police said. The suspect - George Tarnovska, 21 years old, of 95-55 115th Street - was arrested near his home in connection with the kidnapping, robbery and shotgun slaying of Noel Cates, 23, who lived in Washingtonville in Orange County, N.Y., a police spokesman said.

title: DOCTORS STILL DEBATE RECONSTRUCTION VALUE
description: THERE is hopeful news today for women faced with the prospect of a mastectomy, one of the most traumatic of all types of surgery. Breast reconstruction is becoming more acceptable and more sophisticated, and it is covered by most insurance carriers. Once looked at rather disdainfully by surgeons, reconstruction is actually being encouraged in some medical circles.

title: CALIFORNIA MAN, 49, FOUND GUILTY IN 1980 ABDUCTION OF BOY, THEN 5
description: Kenneth E. Parnell was found guilty today of the 1980 Valentine's Day kidnapping of Timmy White, who was then 5 years old.

title: RUDENESS IS OUR ONLY HOPE
description: RAY By Barry Hannah. 113 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $7.95.

title: KNOX MARTIN: ANGRY BUT MORE HUMAN
description: IRVINGTON REVIEWERS obliged to devote ever more space to the sponsors of art have as good cause as anyone to wonder what ever happend to independent galleries. The answer is that they are still around, though wielding less influence than before and taking fewer chances. And, to generalize, it looks as if a private gallery now must either have a stable of artists with museum futures (or pasts) or deal in schlock.

title: TO TELL THE TRUTH JUSTICE COULD BE SWIFTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Allen, Ex-Viking Player, Faces Marijuana Charge
description: Nate Allen, a former Minnesota Viking defensive back, is scheduled to appear in court tomorrow to answer charges of possession of marijuana, obstructing traffic and failing to show a Minnesota driver's license, police said.

title: JERSEY WINS F.C.C. SUPPORT FOR A TRANSFER OF CHANNEL 9
description: In an important move toward ending New Jersey's status as one of only two states in the country without a commercial very high frequency television station, the Federal Communications Commission today took a preliminary step toward ordering the transfer of WOR-TV, Channel 9, to the state from New York City.

title: Bridge: New York Players Provide Stiff Nationals Competition
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League started today with a large field of experts from all parts of North America struggling to qualify in the mixed pair championship. New York City is strongly represented, and its players are likely to be in the running for the title when the event ends tomorrow night.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE wheel has come full circle. Discipline, after being denounced as ''oppressive'' in the 1960's, is ''in'' again. It is very much on the minds of teachers, parents and even students, according to virtually every recent report and public opinion poll. Official ''gettough'' policies are receiving widespread support.

title: Mobil Chemical Unit To Sell Crop Assets
description: Rhone-Poulenc Inc. the United States subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the French chemicals concern, said that it had agreed to acquire the crop chemicals assets of the Mobil Chemical Company.

title: FIVE SCHOOL DISTRICTS TO CONSIDER MERGER
description: MERRICK BACK in 1962, an enterprising taxpayer suggested that in the interest of economy the five school districts in the Merrick and Bellmore areas should merge. The suggestion was dismissed on the ground that it would violate traditional local control of school districts.

title: BOOK PUBLISHING AS COTTAGE INDUSTRY
description: FAR from the New York world of blockbuster books and deals that involve hard-cover,paperback and television rights, another world of small, independent publishing companies flourishes. Hidden in the Connecticut hills or on the shoreline, these quiet organizations constitute a cottage industry, turning out books about the environment, gardens, guidebooks and cookbooks indigenous to the state.

title: SINGLE PARENTS MEET TO SHARE A CONTINUING QUEST FOR STABILITY
description: When the daylong event was over, Michael Heft, a marketing researcher and the father of two young children, reflected contentedly that ''Today, perhaps for the first time in their lives, I saw men opening up to each other. It's the whole John Wayne syndrome, but when it comes to kids, emotions spring up and it's a very different story.''

title: Prospector Seeks No. 3
description: Boet Sonneburg, who until recently was just a poor and frustrated South African prospector, has gone back to working his claim with a good deal more cheer.

title: JETS' RECEIVING DUO FINNALY CATCHES ON
description: Before the season started, November was projected as one of the most exciting times of the Jets' season. The anticipated scenario for next Sunday's Jet game was especially fascinating: the Jets, led by the receiving duo of Lam Jones and Wesley Walker, facing the Houston Oilers and Earl Campbell in a conference showdown.

title: BEGIN HAPPY WITH REAGAN, KOCH SAYS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel met with some of his influential American friends yesterday and told them that he was looking forward to a Reagan administration.

title: THE N.B.A. DRAFT BRINGS AWARM GLOW TO UTAH AND SAN DIEGO
description: THE comparisons Paul Silas makes could swell a young man's head. Michael Brooks, says the San Diego Clippers' coach, reminds him of John Havlicek because of his constant motion and of Marques Johnson because of the quickness with which he releases his shot.

title: PETER MARTINS PRINCE OF THE DANCE
description: ''Since I was 14, I have wanted to be the director of a ballet company,'' says Peter Martins, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet. ''Isn't that strange - to be so sure? I must be a fanatic. Some people need a private life, time off, but I don't. I don't really need anything else.''

title: KNETEMANN TEAM TAKES TOUR DE FRANCE 5TH STAGE
description: Gerrie Knetemann of the Netherlands retained the overall lead in the Tour De France cycling race today for the forth consecutive day, and his team captured a 45-mile race against the clock.

title: THEATER: 'THE STREETS OF NEW YORK' AT SO HO REPuf813>
description: ''The Streets of New York'' by Dion Boucicault, who is also the immortal author of ''Rip Van Winkle,'' is playing at the SoHo Repertory Theater, and will continue to do so through Nov. 30. Every now and then, one of the 150 or so plays that the industrious Boucicault wrote in the mid-1850's gets revived, to the general happiness of antiquarians and nostalgia buffs.

title: ISRAELIS VOTE TODAY:
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin being greeted in Tel Aviv. Shimon Peres, left, Labor Party leader, during quiet moment on beach. News analysis, page A10.

title: Market Place; The Appeal of Apple Computer
description: A SURPRISING number of people want a slice of the apple that's due to be dished out next month. The apple, in this case, is Apple Computer Inc., a three-year-old privately owned company based in Cupertino, Calif.

title: President of Dominicans Will Not Seek New Term
description: President Antonio Guzman Fernandez said today that he would not seek reelection next year.

title: MOST BUSINESS AND GOVERNMENT OFFICES TO OBSERVE FOURTH ON FRIDAY
description: With Independence Day falling on a Saturday this year, government offices and businesses are faced with the choice of observing the holiday on Friday, Monday or not at all.

title: JOSEPH H. BILLINGS
description: Joseph H. Billings, a former partner of Cowen & Company, a brokerage firm, died Friday at Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALMOST every cooking utensil has a specific shape or form that is designed to produce one finished dish or another. Souffle dishes, to choose one example, are broader than they are high, because beaten egg whites rise higher when baked in a dish of that shape. An omelet pan is round rather than square and has a smooth bottom to facilitate the tossing and shaping of an omelet.

title: Roast Turkey
description: 1 turkey, 12 to 16 pounds Sausage stuffing (see recipe) 4 tablespoons peanut, vegetable or corn oil Salt to taste 1/2 cup water Giblet gravy (see recipe).

title: No Headline
description: Muhammad Ali, the former heavyweight champion, is recovering from pneumonia at Provident Hospital in Chicago. He expects to be discharged Tuesday or Wednesday.

title: REAGAN GROUP SEEKS SHIFT IN POLLUTION LAW
description: Members of Ronald Reagan's special group on the environment said yesterday that his administration would probably seek to modify or discard antipollution regulations that had no economic or scientific justification.

title: Visich-De Martini Team Wins Metropolitan Golf
description: Dennis Visich and Felix De Martini of Knickerbocker won the Metropolitan Golf Association's net team championship today at the Century Country Club.

title: 4,000 LINE UP TO JOIN BATTLE AGAINST ELECTRONIC INVADER
description: Last year, it is said to have caused the Bank of Japan to triple its production of 100-yen coins to satisfy the demand. Yesterday, it moved Robert Stenzler, a fourth-grade teacher in New Rochelle, to get up at 6:30 on a Saturday morning to drive his son Andrew, 12 years old, to the Citicorp Center at 53d Avenue and Lexington.

title: Sports of the Times; Dan Lloyd's Lonely Season
description: DAN LLOYD had planned to go to Giants Stadium on Sunday and sit in the press box to avoid the chill of the cold and rain. But on his 27th birthday, he stayed instead in his Rutherford, N.J., apartment with his wife, Vicki, and their daughters, Jennifer and one-week-old Marcia.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $400,000 for the latest first qr and $527,000 for the previous first qr

title: JERSEY ADOPTS BILL ON DISPOSAL OF HAZARDOUS WASTES
description: The Legislature gave final approval today to a bill creating a special panel with broad powers to choose sites for the construction of plants to dispose of hazardous wastes. It acted over the objections of the host community.

title: GREENWICH'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE WON 'T SEEK A THIRD TERM
description: Ruth L. Sims, Greenwich's first Democratic chief executive in more than 70 years, announced today that she would not seek a third term in November.

title: DANCE:JOHN CLIFFORD AND HIS LOS ANGELES BALLET
description: ANYONE who wondered what happened to John Clifford, one of the New York City Ballet's most popular and exciting dancers of the 1960's and early 1970's, has a chance to find out this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where Mr. Clifford's Los Angeles Ballet made its New York debut last night.

title: SOMALIA CALLS FOR TALKS WITH ETHIOPIA
description: President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia said here today that he was prepared to meet immediately with the Ethiopian leader, Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, to hold ''peace negotiations'' over the disputed territory of the Ogaden.

title: Beyond the Salt
description: The day we read that the Food and Drug Commissioner wants the food industry to reduce salt in processing and reveal salt content on food labels, we were lunching with a friend who adheres strictly to a lowsodium diet.

title: Britain Consents To Observer's Sale
description: Britain's trade secretary, John Biffen, told Parliament today that he had consented to the Atlantic Richfield Company's proposed sale of The Sunday Observer newspaper to Lonrho Ltd, the British conglomerate.

title: MRS. LLOYD WINS
description: Pam Shriver left center court yesterday with her head high, near tears and more excited than after her runner-up showing at the 1978 United States Open. She had just defeated third-seeded Tracy Austin, 7-5, 6-4, in the Wimbledon tennis championships.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 14
WEISWEILER NOW HAS TOO MANY PLAYERS
description: Coach Hennes Weisweiler's reputation for handling the fragile egos of his international stars will be tested this week. He has to find positions for 16 Cosmos regulars.

title: Market Place; Energy Stocks Still in Favor
description: WHEN Prescott, Ball & Turben held its annual seminar for institutional investors in Cleveland nearly two months ago, the brokerage house emphasized that the basic thrust of its investment policy remained the protection of capital.

title: No Headline
description: ELLENBERGER FRAUD TRIAL OPENS; Pressures Cited as Ellenberger Trial Opens

title: MUSKIE ASKS CARTER TO RAISE GRAIN LIMIT FOR SALE TO POLAND
description: Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie has proposed to President Carter that the United States increase, to about $900 million, the amount of grain that could be sold to Poland in 1980-81 on Government-backed credits, Administration officials said today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard EARTHLY POWERS. By Anthony Burgess. 607 pages. Simon and Schuster. $15.95.

title: Advertising; Black Enterprise Still Growing at 11
description: Earl Graves's Black Enterprise is celebrating its 11th anniversary in very fine shape.

title: PENTAGON BACKS FULL PRODUCTION OF F-18 JET FIGHTERS FOR THE NAVY
description: The Pentagon told the Navy today to go ahead with full production of the controversial F-18 jet fighter and ordered steps to reduce its cost, a record for a fighter.

title: U.N. FINISHES 1980 WITH SIX NEW COMMEMORATIVES; by Samuel A. Towers
description: The Economic and Social Council, dedicated to the advancement of economic and social progress for the peoples of the world and one of the six principal organs of the United Nations, is the subject of the concluding issue of this year from that world organization.

title: MANAGER OF ONLY SHOW IN TOWN
description: ''The senior White House staff is not going to be nine guys from California,'' Edwin Meese 3d said not long ago about the shape of a Reagan administration.

title: MINNESOTA BISHOP TO LEAD CONFERENCE
description: After receiving a rousing round of applause at the news of his election today as president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, a smiling Archbishop John R. Roach quietly resumed his seat to the right of the outgoing president, Archbishop John R. Quinn of San Francisco.

title: GEORGIA TECH IN 3-3- DEADLOCK
description: Georgia Tech, despite having its worst season in 46 years, had one of the biggest days in its 89 years of football today when it ended Notre Dame's chances for a perfect season by achieving a 3-3 tie with the undefeated Irish.

title: DuPont Plans to Lift Plastic Film Output
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said that it planned to increase production capacity for Kapton polymide plastic film by about onethird at its Circleville, Ohio, plant. It said that it had doubled capacity for the film at the plant last year, but did not disclose any figures.

title: A NEW BATTLE OF SOWETO FLARES: HOUSING VS. IDEOLOGY
description: A sharp bureaucratic battle, with major political implications, is being fought among white administrators over the issue of whether to make more housing available in overcrowded Soweto, South Africa's largest black settlement.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. An impending national strike was canceled in a foreign country as a result of a decision by its supreme court. What country is it and what was the court's decision?

title: JUSTICES LET STAND STRICT CURBS ON LEAD IN WORKPLACE
description: The Supreme Court today let stand strict Federal controls on permissible exposure to lead in the workplace, rejecting challenges by the steel, automobile, paint, and dozens of other industries.

title: By Sports of The Times, The Winfield Sweepstakes
description: THE attraction of baseball's free-agent auction is the availability of what general managers call ''a player who can make the difference.'' When the 26 major-league teams determine the negotiation rights to 48 free agents at the Plaza Hotel today, Dave Winfield will tower above the others as that player with the potential to turn a contender into a champion or turn an also-ran into a contender. Ron LeFlore, Darrell Porter, Don Sutton and Tug McGraw will surely improve any team. But because of his ability and his age, 29-year-old Dave Winfield is the only one who might make the difference in a team for the next decade.

title: ON THE SHORES OF INSPIRATION
description: SURROUNDED as it is by ocean, bay and sound, the Island's East End has more than its share of coastline. Whether this is also the reason why it has a double helping of artists is something to consider.

title: ART: THE ZEITGEIST SIGNALS JUST DOWNSTAIRS ON 73RD ST.
description: THE most provocative show of the week is not in one of the bigtime, big-money galleries, but in Art Latitude, which stands a little below street level at 29 East 73d Street. The show is called ''The Image Transformed,'' and its curator is the poet Ann Lauterbach.

title: Market Place; An Analyst's Record of Hits
description: IN a telephone conference call to his brokerage house's Washington office last Monday, Charles J. Nicolosi of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. finished by advising the sales staff: ''Every time you buy one of the stocks I follow, you've got to wait two to five years. So I don't want to hear any sobs for two years, in case the stock doesn't work out right away.''

title: CARTER FORESEEING ONLY LIMITED ROLE IN REBUILDING PARTY
description: President Carter, discussing his personal plans in a subdued, almost melancholy appearance in the White House press room, said today that he would return to Plains, Ga., next Jan. 20 to write his memoirs and ''live the life of a former President.''

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK PLANS SALES
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, whose stock has been trading heavily recently because of takeover rumors, announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell two of its businesses. The company also denied that it was engaged in any merger discussions.

title: Chess: Spassky Leading in Austria After Tourney's 8th Round
description: Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, held the lead after eight rounds of the Tungsram international tournament here in the Kongresshaus with a 5 1/2-2 1/2 score.

title: OIL INDUSTRY IS STRESSING ACCESS TO FEDERAL FUNDS
description: Most oil industry officials regard significantly increased access to federally owned lands as an absolute necessity if there is to be any hope of arresting the decline in domestic production that began in the early 1970's.

title: Fred R. Conrad Vista International Hotel to Officially Open Its Doors Tomorrow
description: Employees making final preparations in the Greenhouse Restaurant at Vista International, the first major hotel to be built in lower Manhattan in 145 years. The hotel, tucked between the towers of the World Trade Center and offering sweeping views of New York Harbor, plans a formal opening tomorrow with 500 of its 825 rooms ready for occupancy. The 23-story hotel's occupancy rate has been about 74 percent since it began accepting guests April 1.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Yr to Apr 30
PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A PHILIP ROTH READER. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95.) Selections from eight novels Philip Roth published during the past two decades (only ''Goodbye, Columbus'' is passed over), as well as a newly revised version of ''The Breast,'' the essay-story ''Looking at Kafka'' and one previously uncollected short story, ''Novotny's Pain.'' They are arranged to point up three themes that have greatly engaged Mr. Roth: the relation of art and life; satiric comedy at the service of serious moral dilemmas; and the consequences of a concern with virtue on personality and feelings. A long introductory essay by Martin Green undertakes to appraise the achievement of one of our major literary figures.

title: LAW GOVERNING FOREIGNERS IN SOVIET LISTS RIGHTS BUT THE THEME IS CURBS
description: Among the pieces of legislation approved at the Supreme Soviet session last week was a new law on the legal status of foreigners in the Soviet Union, a measure hailed by its authors as superior in its ''democratism and humanity'' to any analogous bourgeois legislation.

title: Bridge: Intercollegiate Competition Could Be at a Turning Point
description: A steady decline in intercollegiate bridge, which has lost the Par tournament of the 1940's and 50's, the leagues of the 60's, and the national tournament of the 70's, may have reached a turning point. A Northeastern intercollegiate league has just completed its first season, with victory going to a Columbia team that inherits a tradition that includes Oswald Jacoby and many other internationally famous stars.

title: LOOSE AND PATTERNED, BUT NEAT
description: Neatness still counts in fashion, though these days it's more difficult to achieve. Loose clothes are back for fall, blousing and billowing round wide belts and further embellished with stoles the size of blankets, free-flowing capes and shoulder bags. Not only do dresses and skirts billow: so frequently do pants and jackets.

title: CABLEVISION OF CONNECTICUT IS GIVEN FAIRFIELD FRANCHISE
description: One of the most sought-after cable television franchises in the nation, covering 10 Fairfield County towns, was awarded today to Cablevision of Connecticut, two years after 10 companies applied for it.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: The hippie heritage. What ever became of those young people of the 60's and early 70's who talked a lot about the New Consciousness and counterculture, who experimented with psychedelic drugs and pursued alternate life styles on communes? Some are making their mark in the world of books. Some examples:

title: TAKING UP POLITICAL ARMS AGAINST THE RIGHT TO LIFERS
description: The fat man in the advertisement wears a campaign button. A cigar stub juts from his mouth as he sits in a clutter of folding chairs, bunting and American flags. The legend above the picture reads, in stark black and white: ''Abortion should be between you and a doctor. Not a politician.''

title: CAN A CHILD WITH A WOUNDED SOUL LEARN?
description: AN ELDERLY woman is standing before the counter in the school office. She is wrinkled but twinkling, and she glows from exposure to the sun. To protect herself from the frigid cold, she wears a handknitted cap of many colors.

title: LAWSUIT AGAINST BIG TEN DISMISSED BY U.S. JUDGE
description: A federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit by Dave Wilson, the Illinois quarterback, against the Big Ten Conference. Wilson had sued in an effort to regain his eligibility for the 1981 season.

title: Peter Haughton's Brother
description: IT was a cold winter night, and Peter Haughton was more tired than a man of 25 ought to be. His working day had started at 6:30 A.M. and now it was far past midnight as he headed home from The Meadowlands. Maybe he dozed at the wheel, maybe his car skidded on a patch of ice. At any rate, the car crashed and Peter Haughton died. The date was Jan. 25, 1980.

title: MUSICAL: 'FRIMBO' STAGED AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: INVITED to attend ''Frimbo,'' an Off Broadway musical in Grand Central Terminal, we decided that there was no finer way to go than accompanied by the show's eponymous hero, E.M. Frimbo, the world's greatest railroad buff. Frimbo has been spending his lifetime trying to cover every inch of railroad trackage in the world. By prearrangement, we met just before the stroke of 10 P.M. at Window One in the terminal, being careful to ascertain that this was the window that dispensed theater tickets, not train tickets or Off Track Betting slips. Looking pink and healthy, wearing a black Homburg and, for sheer obstinancy, toting a Freddy Laker kitbag, Frimbo seemed to face this theatrical journey with trepidation. There was a look of wariness in his eyes that he did not have even when passing through Siberia on the Russia Express.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Heublein Inc., Hartford, to UniWorld Group Inc. for its Rhum Saint James imported rum brand. * Town & Country magazine to Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss. * International Paint Company, Union, N.J., to Bozell & Jacobs Inc.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL YANKEES - Named Russ Meyer, for- mer right-handed pitcher for Brooklyn Dodgers and five other major league clubs, pitching instructor for minor league affili- ates.

title: Du Pont Pact in Australia
description: ICI Australia Ltd. said today that it had signed a license agreement with Du Pont of Canada and the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company to build a 100,000-ton-ayear polyethylene plant at Botany, New South Wales. The plant will use Du Pont technology for making low- and high-density polyethylene and is expected to start production in late 1984.

title: BUBBLE BATTLE
description: THE COLA WARS By J.C. Louis and Harvey Z. Yazijian. 386 pp. New York: Everest House. $15.95.

title: REAGAN AIDE VOWS U.S. SPENDING WON'T EXCEED 620 BILLION FOR YEAR
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan's principal budget adviser pledged today that the new administration would hold Federal spending in the current fiscal year to $620 billion, confirming disclosures of substantially larger cuts than the Reagan team had been projecting.

title: LUXURY CONDOMINIUM PRICES SOAR
description: IT has been just over a year since construction workers began transforming the lush woodlands of the former Herbert H. Lehman estate in Jericho known as Picket Farm into a luxury condominium development called the Hamlet, which will eventually house 328 families.

title: 20'S CLASSICS RECREATED IN JERSEY IN A FESTIVE PART OF JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: More than 6,000 jazz fans lugged lawn chairs, coolers, portable barbecues and a few Frisbees to the open fields of Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., Sunday to attend the sixth annual jazz picnic sponsored by the New Jersey Jazz Society and presented as part of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: LYDIA LOPOKOVA, 88, BALLERINA, IS DEAD
description: Lydia Lopokova, a leading ballerina of Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes and a popular figure on the English social and ballet scenes, died June 8 in England. She was 88 years old.

title: Protein Gene Is Transplanted From Bean to Sunflower
description: Scientists have developed a genetic engineering process for moving genes from one plant species to another, opening the way for major improvements in plants, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: The City; 2 Housing Officers Rescue Three at Fire
description: Three persons, including a 1-year-old infant and her 6-year-old sister, were rescued from the top floor of a burning three-story building in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn early yesterday by two Housing Authority police officers, officials said.

title: UNDER STARR, THE PACK TALKS ITS WAY BACK
description: The football season was just three weeks old, but for the Green Bay Packers, it was coming apart. They had just been humiliated in a 51-21 loss to the Los Angeles Rams that could have been worse. They had lost two of the three games, and the one victory came only because of Chester Marcol's kick-the-ball-to-yourself-and-run-aroundleft-en d play. That play had beaten Chicago in the first game of the season, in overtime, but now everyone would be looking for it.

title: No Headline
description: Talking Businesswith Joseph Schlussel of The Diamond Registry The 2 Markets In Diamonds

title: PLATT, FORIDA STATE BACK, GIVEN PROBATION IN THEFT
description: Sam Platt, a star running back from Florida State University, was placed on one-year probation today for buying a stolen television set from a former teammate.

title: IN NEXT LEGISLATURE, A STRONGER G.O.P.
description: HARTFORD REPUBLICAN and Democratic leaders in Connecticut were equally surprised a few days after the Nov. 4 election when Bill Brock, the Republican national chairman, sent a congratulatory message to Ralph E. Capecelatro, the G.O.P. state chairman. Connecticut Republicans had achieved the largest net gain in state legislative seats of any state in the nation, Mr. Brock said.

title: DIGITAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After $21,867 net loss from discontinued operations and $1,723 net gain on the disposal of discontinued operations... C-Including $25,707 net income from discontinued operations and $131,528 net tax credit

title: NIGERIA CUTS PRICES OF OIL TO TRADERS
description: uf813 By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

title: BAD TIMES ARE GOOD FOR TRADE SCHOOLS
description: The ill wind of recession and high unemployment is blowing fair and strong for the country's trade and vocational schools, where record numbers of jobless and underemployed people are learning new skills and looking to new futures.

title: '42 STREET' ALBUM CUT
description: The hottest ticket on Broadway, if it had been for sale, would have been the recording of the original cast album of ''42d Street'' yesterday at the RCA studio just two blocks north of there.

title: Around the World; 10 Reported Dead in Clash In an El Salvador Port City
description: At least 10 people died in a major battle over the weekend in the Salvadoran port of La Union between Government forces and leftist guerrillas, military sources said today.

title: THE GUESSING GAME; by James Reston
description: There's a good feeling here about the changing of the guard from Carter to Reagan. The Governor has been as cautious and courteous in victory as the President has been generous in defeat. Mr. Reagan has even been modest and occasionally funny - a combination that has been sorely missed around here since the days of Harry Truman.

title: by Marcy Benstock
description: Mayor Koch says he may decide by Nov. 15 whether or not to return to his pre-mayoral-election position in favor of trading in Westway for more than $1.7 billion for mass transit and an alternate road. A decision in favor of a trade-in would be the single most significant step that could be taken to reverse the terrible decline in New York City's transit service.

title: A busy week in postwar art
description: THE market for 20th-century art is booming; as an example, there is the Jasper Johns that was sold to the Whitney Museum of American Art six weeks ago for $1 million, believed to be the highest price ever paid for the work of a living artist. In addition, it has been a year of record-breaking art auctions and bullish reports by dealers who say that 1980 has been their best sales year ever. No wonder, then, that the sales next week of post-World War II paintings and sculpture are expected to produce intense activity and more records. The sales begin Wednesday at 2 P.M. at Phillips, Son & Neale, Madison Avenue at 72d Street, with the sale of, among other moderately valued art works, a mixed media sculpture by Robert Rauschenberg (up to $18,000) and ''Portrait of Mick Jagger'' by Andy Warhol (up to $18,000).

title: 2 WHO QUIT OVER BABY FORMULA HAVE NO REGRETS
description: When Stephen C. Joseph and Eugene N. Babb resigned their $50,000-a-year Government jobs last month, they did something that was very rare among Washington bureaucrats: they left over a matter of principle.

title: Boutette Goes To Penguins
description: An arbitrator today awarded Pat Boutette and Kevin McClelland, both wings, to the Pittsburgh Penguins as compensation for the Hartford Whalers' signing of the goalie Greg Millen.

title: Chess: The Best Attack Plans Fail If They Are Not Adaptable
description: No single, fixed plan will work against the diverse formations at the opponent's disposal - when the defense is altered, the attack must flexibly adapt to it. The trouble is that having previously enjoyed success with a given strategy, we strain to use it again even when it is no longer suitable.

title: FOUR MAJOR CAMPUSES OF STATE U. SEEK TO BUILD ON THEIR STRENGTHS
description: The four university centers of the State University of New York - the stars of a system that has sought to become ''the Berkeley of the East'' - have come a long way in a short time but still find it difficult to build a national reputation.

title: SILVERMAN IS EXPECTED TO RESIGN TODAY AS THE PRESIDENT OF NBC
description: Fred Silverman, who was brought to NBC four years ago to improve the network's sagging fortunes but failed to do so, will resign as president today, according to highly placed sources at the network.

title: Adelaide Schulkind Frank Dies; Gave Loans to Social Activists
description: Adelaide Schulkind Frank, founder and director of the League for Mutual Aid that for 50 years provided interest-free loans to young socialists, labor organizers and other activists in causes she deemed important, died last Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 83 years old.

title: ALLIED SEEKING LOWENSTEIN UNIT
description: The M. Lowenstein Corporation, a major American textile manufacturer, yesterday announced the renewal of talks with the Allied Corporation that could lead to the acquisition of the textile company. However, statements by Allied and by analysts indicated that Lowenstein's industrial fiberglass textiles business was the real target of negotiations.

title: A DANGEROUS TAX REVOLT
description: A tax revolt based on bogus mail-order ministries has found its way from California, the land of moonbeams and cults, to the New York area and has quietly taken root here on a grand scale. An investigation by the Manhattan district office of the Internal Revenue Service, which is nowhere near complete, has so far turned up more than 7,000 persons using this clerical dodge to evade income taxes - including 2,600 employees of the New York State government and close to 1,700 employees of New York City.

title: U.S. COURT TO HEAR INDIAN LAND CLAIM
description: An Oneida Indian lawsuit asking for the return of almost six million acres of New York State land -about one-fifth of all the land in the state - will be heard next month in Federal Court in Syracuse.
To the Editor:

title: U.S. REPLACING SERVICE PISTOLS
description: The Army said today that it would gradually replace the .45-caliber pistol, the military's principal sidearm for nearly 70 years.

title: Business People; CHIEF EXECUTIVE NAMED AT GUCCI'S U.S. UNIT
description: Robert A. Berry, 56, has been named chief executive officer of the Gucci Shops, which both owns and franchises stores selling Gucci leather goods, shoes, apparel and other merchandise in the United States. Aldo Gucci, chairman of the parent corporation in Italy, continues as chairman of the United States operation and Marie Savarino remains president.

title: 'SATURDAY NIGHT LIVE,' 'SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER'
description: THERE are a couple of Saturday Night specials, of sorts. ''Saturday Night Live'' returns to NBC at 11:30 tomorrow night for a sixth season. The performers and producers are all new. The host is Elliott Gould. Then, the film ''Saturday Night Fever'' will get its first television showing Sunday at 9 on ABC, although in an edited version considerably tamer than the original. John Travolta, packaged slickly by the producer Robert Stigwood, co-stars with a terrific disco music track by the Bee Gees.

title: JOHN D. BARRETT JR.
description: John D. Barrett Jr., a trustee and former president of the Bollingen Foundation, which sponsored projects in the arts and humanities, died Sunday at his home in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Amin Makes Catholic U.'s Dishonor Roll
description: Only one living person has made the Catholic University of America's list of ''the 10 worst villains of all time.'' During his reign as president of Uganda, the university said in releasing the list of villains in Washington yesterday, Idi Amin was ''thought to have killed more than 90,000 people while expelling 60,000 others.''

title: Commodities; Platinum's Link to Gold Price
description: ONE of the mysteries confronting futures traders in precious metals in recent months has been the closing of the gulf between the prices of gold and platinum.

title: by Susan Quinn
description: Susan Quinn, is a freelance writer who reports frequently about the social sciences. By Susan Quinn he first parting of the ways took place more than four decades ago. Heinz Kohut, a 25-year-old medical student, stood on the platform of the railroad station in Vienna in 1938 and watched Sigmund Freud leave on the first leg of his flight from the Nazis. Though Kohut was an admirer, he had not met the master, but when the student tipped his hat in farewell as the train moved out, Freud tipped his own hat in return. ''I had the feeling,'' Kohut remembers, ''of a crumbling universe.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aeicor Inc. said that it had sold the stock of American Export International, its wholly owned subsidiary, to G. D'Alesio S.A.S. of Livorno, Italy, for $7 million cash.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Batus Inc., Louisville, Ky., has appointed John A. McDonough vice president and treasurer.

title: FED FUNDS PREDICTED ON WAY TO 16% PEAK
description: Short-term rates are climbing, but they have yet to reach their peak. That is the consensus of Wall Street money-market economists on the heels of last week's interest-rate surge.

title: CHINA'S PLAN TO PRODUCE ENERGY NOW CLOUDED BY DRILLING DELAY
description: China's effort to reverse its rapidly declining production of energy has suffered another setback with the disclosure over the weekend that plans to solicit bids from foreign oil companies to begin exploratory drilling in the South China Sea have been shelved for at least another year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Miss Smith, Val de Loire Score
description: She was lucky, Melanie Smith admitted last night, but she'll take victories any way they come. Miss Smith rode Val de Loire to victory in the International Challenge Trophy jumping class at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden, but it required a lapse by Norman Dello Joio, a fellow member of the United States Equestrian Team, to assure her triumph.

title: ISLANDERS LOSE LEAD, TIE NORTH STARS, 6-6
description: Mike Bossy continued his scoring onslaught with four goals tonight in the Nassau Coliseum, but despite his performance the New York Islanders had to rally for a 6-6 tie against the Minnesota North Stars.

title: Washington Watch; The Appointees Prepare to Go
description: WASHINGTON WITHIN a few days the Government Printing Office will begin running off the ''plum book.'' The name derives not from its color (the cover will be sun orange) but from the jobs it lists that President-elect Reagan will be able to fill.

title: A Way to Save e Money
description: A PIECE in the paper recently told what a punishing burden travel costs have become to sports teams. Inflation has, of course, driven all costs up, the soaring prices of fuel have vastly increased the expense of air travel, and the proliferation of teams and leagues has multiplied distances between playing sites.

title: MUSEUM TO ATTCK INDIAN STEREOTYPE
description: TRENTON SAY Indian, and the image that might flash across one's mind, based on what Hollywood has turned out, is that of a loin-clothed, bodypainted tribesman. And it is just such an image that a vast undertaking by the State Museum will try to dispel.

title: U.S. SEES REDUCTION IN SOVIET FEED STOCK
description: The Soviet Union's grain harvest probably will total no more than 185 million metric tons in 1980, a level that will not permit the Russians to sustain current levels of meat production, United States Agriculture Department officials said today.

title: ABSCAM WITNESS SAYS HE WAS TOLD REP. THOMPSON RECIEVED $20,000
description: A prosecution witness said yesterday he had been told that Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton received $20,000 in cash as his share of a $50,000 payment from undercover agents in the Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: Canada Energy Talks Progress
description: Some progress was made in the third attempt this year to settle a major dispute between the federal Government and Alberta over the price of domestic oil and gas and the sharing of revenues, both sides reported today.

title: American Express, Shearson Merged
description: In separate meetings yesterday, shareholders of the American Express Company and Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. approved the merger of Wall Street's second-largest brokerage house into the international credit card giant. The votes complete the transaction by which each share of Shearson stock will be exchanged for 1.3 shares of American Express common stock.

title: STOCKS DROP 17.75, ENDING RALLY
description: Most of the nation's major banks raised their prime interest rates a full percentage point yesterday, to 15 1/2 percent, prompting some economists to warn that the high rates posed a serious threat to the economic recovery.

title: Jersey Playhouse Plans July 9 Groundbreaking
description: Ground will be broken July 9 for the Paper Mill Playhouse's new $4.5 million theater, which will replace the structure destroyed by fire in January 1980.

title: A Hoboken Dropout Sets Up a Scholarship
description: Chicago may be ''My Kind of Town'' in the song often associated with Frank Sinatra, and he also often sings the praises of ''New York, New York,'' but Mr. Sinatra also has a warm spot in his heart for Hoboken, N.J., where he was born 65 years ago.

title: Meeting of N.A.S.L. Postponed
description: The North American Soccer League postponed yesterday its league meeting scheduled for Friday in Chicago. Three reasons were given:

title: NEW ENFORCEMENT CHIEF BACKS S.E.C. POLICY SHIFT
description: John M. Fedders, a Washington lawyer who has defended many corporations before the Securities and Exchange Commission, was named today to head the commission's enforcement division.

title: DANCE IN FULL BLOOM AT THE Y
description: Dance is booming in Westchester, and the dance department of the Mid-Westchester Y.M.-Y.W.C.A. is part of the trend. Its program offers 50 classes to more than 500 enthusiasts from Westchester, Connecticut, Rockland County and the Bronx.

title: Hawks Sign Loughery
description: Kevin Loughery signed a three-year contract today as the head coach of the Atlanta Hawks, the team announced.

title: CITY HALL CELEBRATES MARC CONNALLY AT 90
description: The scene is the Blue Room at City Hall. The time is yesterday morning. Marc Connelly, the distinguished playwright, has been invited there to receive a certificate of appreciation from Mayor Koch on the occasion of his 90th birthday.

title: FEDERAL HANDS OFF, STATE'S HANDS ON
description: To the Editor:

title: FINDINGS ARE IN CONFLICT ON VALUE OF CORONARY BYPASS OPERATIONS
description: EACH year, more than 100,000 persons undergo coronary bypass surgery at a total cost far exceeding $1 billion, more than the entire budget of either Delaware or Maine. But the longterm benefits of the operation remain in doubt for a large proportion of patients.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How is milk tranformed into yogurt?

title: MET OPERA OPENS DEC. 10
description: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that its delayed 1980-81 season would open Dec. 10 with a nonsubscription concert of Mahler's Symphony No. 2 (''Resurrection''). The first opera will be the New York premiere of the complete ''Lulu'' of Alban Berg, on Dec. 12.

title: DIVERSITY IS DEMONSTRATED BY WESTCHESTER DEVELOPER
description: In an eastern corner of Westchester County not far from the Connecticut border, the Lusk Corporation, based in Stamford, Conn., has started to build an architecturally distinctive town house condominium community called Oakridge. Ultimately there will be 330 houses on the 60-acre site in Lewisboro, which includes a five-acre lake.

title: ALBANY LEADERS ABANDON EFFORTS IN RENT DISPUTE
description: Efforts to revise New York City's rent-control and rent-stabilization guidelines have been dropped by legislative leaders here in favor of a two-year extension of the current regulations.

title: IS IT LAKE CHAMPLAIN'S MONSTER?
description: ON July 5, 1977, Sandra Mansi was showing her husband-to-be the countryside around Lake Champlain where she had grown up. They talked and laughed about the legends of a large monster inhabiting the lake. While sitting on the shore, she recalled, they saw something move far out in the water. She thought it was a school of large fish, she said, until a head and then a long serpentine neck emerged from the water, growing bigger and bigger.

title: Still Pending in Albany
description: The work of New York's Legislature will not be finished this week, even if it pulls itself together on an essential transit tax to head off a monster fare increase in New York City and environs. There are at least six other important matters pending:

title: Knicks Roll, 149-118, And Set Club Record For Present Garden
description: The Knicks, in their most productive scoring performance since the present Madison Square Garden opened in 1968, trounced the Detroit Pistons last night by 149-118.

title: THOMPSON SEEN DISCUSSING PLAN IN ABSCAM TAPE
description: The jury at the latest Abscam trial saw a videotape yesterday in which Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of Trenton promises undercover Federal agents that he will help rich Arabs emigrate to the United States, but in which he also says he is ''not looking for any money'' in return.

title: THE MUSICIANS COME ON, TWO BY TWO FOR DUETS
description: THE musicians came on two by two Sunday evening at the Jazz Festival in Carnegie Hall. The subject was duets and, with one minor exception, only two musicians were on stage at one time throughout the evening.

title: SURGE IN STOCK TRADING RAISES QUESTION OF BROKER CAPABILITIES
description: This week's record one-day volume of 84.1 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange raises the question of whether brokerage houses can handle such heavy trading activity on a sustained basis.

title: WEST EUROPEANS TO SEEK SOVIET PULLOUT IN AFGHANISTAN
description: West European leaders will open a diplomatic initiative to obtain the withdrawal of Soviet soldiers from Afghanistan, European officials said today.

title: 'SUPERMAN' BREAKS RECORD
description: ''Superman II'' has shattered the movie industry record for a single week with ticket sales of $24,009,272, $4 million higher than the record $20.3 million set by ''The Empire Strikes Back'' last summer.

title: REAGAN ARRIVES IN CAPITAL TO COURT VARIETY OF U.S. AND LOCAL LEADERS
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan has come to court the Washington establishment. Sensitive to the symbolism of his first venture to the capital since the election, Mr. Reagan will pay his respects to the leadership on both sides of the aisle in Congress, to President Carter, to liberals and moderates as well as conservatives. And he will dine, much to their surprise, with local Washington dignitaries, most of them Democrats, who are often overlooked by national politicians.

title: HEATH QUINTET AT GUGGENHEIM
description: ASERIES of concerts at a new locale for the Kool Jazz Festival, the Guggenheim Museum, 89th Street at Fifth Avenue, began on Sunday afternoon with a performance by the Heath Brothers Quintet.

title: A SPECIAL MEETING OF THE LEGISLATURE IS CALLED BY CAREY
description: Governor Carey last night called the Legislature to return to Albany at 3 P.M. today for a special session that will consider major legislation on banking, the state budget and New York's troubled Mitchell-Lama housing program.

title: Felix Wormser, 86, Dies; A Consultant on Mining
description: Felix E. Wormser, a consulting mining engineer and a former Assistant Secretary of the Interior, died yesterday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 86 years old.

title: AIDES VIEW ANDERSON MAILING LIST AS SEED OF A CONTINUING MOVEMENT
description: John B. Anderson decided to become an independent Presidential candidate at least in part because political technicians convinced him he had a reliable constituency outside strictly Republican ranks that would finance a respectable run for the White House.

title: Crossed Fingers and the Irish Sweepstakes
description: They have never bought an Irish Sweepstakes ticket, and have no idea who bought one for them this year. So Marian and Steve Smolinsky say they will not believe they have won $153,000 in the sweepstakes until they get the offical word.

title: 5.1% Growth Seen for Japan
description: The Japan Economic Research Center predicted today that Japan's economy would grow at 5.1 percent in real terms in the fiscal year 1981, which began in April. That growth, it said, would be supported by an increase in personal spending, brisk exports and corporate equipment investment.

title: TOLBERT ON INDIANA SIGNS MULTI YEAR PACT WITH NETS
description: The Nets signed Ray Tolbert, a 6-foot-9-inch power forward and the third of their first-round draft choises, to a multiyear contract yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Kerr-McGee Corporation registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a $200 million issue of 7 percent debentures due July 1, 2011, underwritten by investment bankers led by Lehman Bros. Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: BARGE FLEETS THRIVE IN CROP SALES BOOM
description: A bumper business in hauling soybeans and corn has helped barge companies to expand their fleets to record levels, and barge industry executives expect the growth to continue.

title: PERKINS: SEARCH FOR TOMORROW
description: RAY PERKINS walked along Fifth Avenue Thursday evening, not far from Central Park, passing window displays on his left and horsedrawn carriages on his right. He wore a trenchcoat over his brown three-piece suit, and he looked much like the well-dressed people headed for a night at the theater and the commuters on their way home. At another time of year, he could pass for one of them, but not now. In autumn, during the football season, the coach of the New York Giants is an alien.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I was reminiscing recently about the number of flavors and ingredients that have been introduced within a relatively recent period into my kitchen. They include basil (and pesto sauce); arugula, which goes into numerous salads in my home; scungili or conch, which I have grown to enjoy in cold salads with oil, lemon and garlic, and, most interestingly, perhaps, fresh ginger.

title: G.&W. Lifts Stake
description: Gulf and Western Industries, a diversified financial services, manufacturing and resources concern based in New York City, said that it had increased its stake in the Mohasco Corporation to 1,320,000 shares, or 20.1 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, G.&W. said that its holdings included 144,100 shares bought on the New York Stock Exchange between June 12 and June 23 for $2,053,601. G.&W. said that its purchases were for investment purposes only.

title: Ray Film Symposium Canceled
description: A symposium on the films of Satyajit Ray, with appearances by Mr. Ray, the art director Bansi Chandragupta and the writer Chidananda Das Gupta scheduled for tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Asia Society has been canceled because of Mr. Chandragupta's death of a heart attack Saturday. Tickets to the symposium will be refunded. Call 288-6400.

title: SOVIET BLOC REACTING WITH CAUTION TO POLCI RULING ON TRADE UNIONS
description: The Soviet bloc has reacted cautiously so far in public comments about the Polish Government's decision on Monday to register the independent union organization, Solidarity, without a clause in its charter recognizing the ''leading role'' of the Communist Party.

title: AN INDUSTRIAL VIEW
description: To the Editor:

title: THE GOOD RIGHT FIGHT; by WILLIAM SAFIRE
description: A colleague of mine - of the liberal persuasion, but willing to give conservatism a chance - poked his head in my office and unburdened himself of a concern. (Liberals have ''concerns''; conservatives have ''resentments.'')

title: AIRLINES' DOMESTIC SALES SLOW
description: Advance summer bookings for domestic travel on trunk airlines are generally weak, airline analysts report, and passenger traffic has been sluggish this month.

title: SWEDISH TROUPE REALIZES DREAM: PLAYING TO NEW YORK AUDIENCES
description: Ever since a successful tour of American and Canadian prisons two years ago of the Swedish comedy ''Behavior Games,'' the play's author, Jan Bergquist, and the cast of his Stockholm hit have longed to play to New York City audiences.

title: ROY ELDRIDGE'S AMBITION: 'TO OUTPLAY ANYBODY'
description: EIGHT months ago Roy Eldridge, the jazz trumpeter, who is often spoken of as a bridge between Louis Armstrong and Dizzy Gillespie, suffered a heart attack that has kept him from playing since then. But, like Mr. Armstrong and Mr. Gillespie, Mr. Eldridge is also a singer - his duet with Anita O'Day on ''Let Me Off Uptown'' was one of his most memorable singing performances.

title: ONE CHARGED WITH SPYING AIDED F.B.I., AFFIDAVIT SAYS
description: An aging project engineer with the Hughes Aircraft Company had begun to cooperate with Federal agents before he and a young Polish national were arrested yesterday on espionage charges, the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed today.

title: The Runner's High
description: A preventive medicine specialist at Loma Linda University in California may have found the reason for the ''addictive'' properties of regular vigorous exercise. The finding may also explain why athletes and ballet dancers often fail to notice an injury until after the competition or performance is over.

title: Around the Nation; Delay Sought in Integration Of North Carolina Colleges
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit was asked today to stop the Department of Education temporarily from signing a proposed consent decree with North Carolina that would establish a desegregation plan for North Carolina's university system.

title: The City; 2 Killed in Shootout At Discotheque
description: An alleged drug dealer and his bodyguard were killed and six persons were wounded in a shootout at a Manhattan discotheque, the police reported.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALMOST every cooking utensil has a specific shape or form that is designed to produce one finished dish or another. Souffle dishes, to choose one example, are broader than they are high, because beaten egg whites rise higher when baked in a dish of that shape. An omelet pan is round rather than square and has a smooth bottom to facilitate the tossing and shaping of an omelet.

title: 2 REAGAN ALLIES IN SENATE PRESS THEIR OWN AIMS
description: A new era began on Capitol Hill today as the top-ranking Republicans on the Senate Finance and Judiciary Committees started setting their priorities and carrying out the conservative mandate they feel they have received from the American electorate.

title: FORMER SYNAGOGUE ON WEST SIDE SOLD TO DEVELOPERS FOR $2.4 MILLION
description: The former Mount Neboh Synagogue, at 130 West 79th Street, owned by Seventh-day Adventists since 1978, has been sold to two developers for $2.4 million -$2 million more than the church group paid for it.

title: Datsun Nameplate Change Reported
description: The Nissan Motor Company Ltd. is planning to drop the Datsun nameplate from its 1982 models sold in the United States and begin selling those cars under the Nissan nameplate, according to a report published in the trade journal Automotive News today.

title: AN IRREPRESSIBLE ECLECTIC IN RETROSPECT
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE art of O. Louis Guglielmi was slipping from us and, if the Rutgers University Art Gallery had not currently mounted an ambitious retrospective, it might have slipped irretrievably.

title: GROUPS SET ASIDE BOYCOTT OF TV SPONSORS
description: The Coalition for Better Television today called off its plans for a boycott of companies that sponsor television programs it considers offensive.

title: Shipping Forecast
description: Nippon Yusen K.K. shipping lines said in a forecast released today that the completion of three large projects, including an expansion of the Suez Canal, would idle at least 5 percent of the world's oil tanker fleet in the next year. It said the projects, which also include a new trans-Arabian oil pipeline and a Louisiana offshore oil port, would leave a total of 17.18 million deadweight tons of tankers unused.

title: SENSIBLE PROOF
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME-DELIVERY BEAUTY SERVICES
description: When Arnold Scaasi, the designer, was in a last-minute rush to leave for a European trip and needed a manicure and pedicure, he called a company named Hair to Go and a manicurist came to his apartment. ''It was great,'' he says. ''I kept on making my telephone calls and didn't waste any time.''

title: DELANEY PROTEST, THEN TESTIFIES DURING A HEARING IN WESTCHESTER
description: The suspended Commissioner/Sheriff of Westchester County, Thomas J. Delaney, was ordered into court today and told to take the stand as the first witness in what is expected to be a lengthy administrative hearing over his alleged misconduct.

title: Canada Permanent Offer Extended
description: The First City Financial Corporation, the Vancouver-based financial services concern controlled by the Belzberg family, said that it had been tendered 71 percent of the common shares of the Canada Permanent Mortgage Corporation of Toronto, Canada's third-largest trust company, under its $300 million (Canadian) share-exchange tender offer that expired Friday.

title: ARMS SALES, TO WHOM
description: 494,0BERKELEY, Calif. - Data on arms trade with the third world are notoriously unreliable and difficult to interpret. But whether measured by sales, deliveries, only major weapons, or the inclusion of assistance, training, and construction, the developing-country arms trade leveled off after the post-1973 boom in the Middle East. Measured in constant, inflation-adjusted dollars, there has been no real increase since 1976. America's share of the market has dropped from 50 percent to about 33 percent, while the Soviet Union's has remained nearly constant, also 33 percent. Our European allies have picked up most of the difference.

title: CHAIN DEVELOPS FILM IN AN HOUR
description: A 70-year-old bride showed off pictures of her reception before the wedding cake was brought in. A mother awoke in a hospital room, eager to examine the photographs of her newborn child, snapped by her husband just hours earlier. A Los Angeles man who evacuated his hillside home as a brush fire encroached, displayed snapshots of the fire to friends before returning to survey his home.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
description: B-Per Class A common shr...C-Per Class B common shr

title: BELMONTE LOSES AGENT LICENSE
description: The New York State Racing and Wagering board yesterday revoked the agent's license of Eddie Belmonte, the former jockey, for allegedly bribing a fellow jockey to fix races at Saratoga in 1974.

title: GREEK SHADOW SHOWINGS
description: Shadow theater, a centuries-old Persian art form adopted by the Greeks 100 years ago, is performed by flat, perforated puppets behind a screen. Light projected behind them shows up details of their faces and clothing, as well as colors. Evgenios Spatharis, a master of Greek shadow theater, will present it at three sites this weekend: tonight at 8 at the Eisner-Lubin Auditorium of New York University's Loeb Student Center; tomorrow at 6:30 P.M., in Fort Hamilton High School, 83d Street and Colonial Road in Brooklyn, and Sunday at 4:30 and 6:30 P.M. at Bohemian Hall, 29-19 24th Avenue in Astoria, Queens. Tickets are $6 ($4 for students and children). Information: 279-9586. 50 RARE BOOKS AT COLUMBIA

title: Mets, Yanks Meet With Sutton
description: Frank Cashen, the Mets' chief operating officer, was operating on two fronts yesterday. He met with Don Sutton, a free-agent pitcher with a reputation for developing victories, and he hired Lou Gorman, a front-office executive with a reputation for developing players. Sutton also was operating on two fronts, meeting with the Yankees for a couple of hours.

title: CHINA'S TURNING WHEEL
description: There is a huge amusement park here, with half a dozen outdoor theaters, a roller-skating rink, shooting gallery, Ferris wheel, aquarium, and in the trees hang gaudy lanterns. Young lovers can be seen kissing in the dark and groups of men kibbitz excitedly around players of Chinese chess.

title: Nigerian Communications
description: Three Japanese companies have won an order totaling approximately $72 million to construct a microwave communications system in Ibadan, Nigeria, the Marubeni Corporation said today. Marubeni, the Nippon Electric Company and Sumitomo Electric Industries will supply equipment and undertake all installation work for the system, which is expected to be completed in two years. The contract was placed by the Nigerian Communications Ministry under Nigeria's five-year development plan, which began last year, Marubeni added.
