title: Talbot to Build Car
description: The Talbot Motor Company, the British subsidiary of Peugeot S.A., said that it had agreed to an approximately $20 million investment program with its parent company to produce the Horizon car in Coventry. It said that work would start shortly to reconstruct the main car assembly areas at the Ryton works, where Horizon production should start at the end of this year. So far, the Horizon has been built at Talbot's Poissy plant in France.

title: No Opposition to Weaver-Tillis
description: Mike Jones, one of Gerry Cooney's managers, and Sam Glass, the man who was to promote Cooney's fight with Mike Weaver, said yesterday that they would not stand in the way of Weaver's defending his World Boxing Association heavyweight championship against James (Quick) Tillis, although Weaver has already signed to meet Cooney.

title: VOYAGER CRAFT DETECTS THICK NITROGEN MANTLE AROUND A MOON OF SATURN
description: As Voyager 1 sped away from Saturn today, scientists analyzing incoming data from the spacecraft determined that the moon Titan has a deep, cold and heavy atmosphere composed primarily of nitrogen, which may liquefy at the surface to form vast nitrogen oceans.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 29
News Analysis
description: Several months ago, a Spanish diplomat involved in organizing the East-West conference here on human rights and cooperation in Europe argued that the 35-nation gathering would be a useful barometer of a stormy international situation.

title: GEOGHEGAN AND MAREK JOIN NEW BOOK HOUSES
description: Aftershocks from a shakeup earlier this month at the Putnam Publishing Group continued yesterday with the appointment of John J. Geoghegan as editor at large for William Morrow & Company. At the same time it was announceed that Richard Marek would join a newly established division at St. Martin's Press.

title: The City; Transit Report
description: During the morning rush hour, there were 10-minute delays on some southbound IRT No. 2 trains because of equipment trouble.

title: FASHION CAREERS: GETTING A START
description: Fashion, an industry described as having the ''shortest shelf life other than dairy and meat products,'' and cosmetics, the business of ''achievable illusions,'' were the subjects of the first annual conference on Opportunities and Challenges held Saturday at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: THEATER IN REVIEW
description: %'BEATLEMANIA' CAPTURES THE PANORAMA OF A DECADE By ALVIN KLEIN HEMPSTEAD A NATIONAL touring production of ''Beatlemania,'' being promoted as ''the first Broadway show to be presented in its original form'' at the Calderone Concert Hall (where it plays through next Sunday), is a note-for-note, image-for-image likeness of the original, which never actually was a Broadway show - except geographically. It was a mixed-media hybrid, combining the components of a rock concert, not a musical play or revue.

title: Careers; Cable TV Beckoning Women
description: ''I THINK the cable-television market is beginning to boom, and the fledgling industry will offer good management opportunities for women,'' Donald Noble told a meeting of more than 100 women last week. ''We are increasingly getting assignments for more marketing people in the cable field,'' he said at the session, which was sponsored by the Association of Women in Radio and Television.

title: RATES LEVEL IN QUIET TRADING
description: Interest rates were little changed in quiet trading yesterday as investors and traders waited on the sidelines for clearer signs that the Federal Reserve would encourage a decline in short-term interest rates.

title: POLISH LEADER SAYS UNIONS ARE ABUSING THE RIGHT TO STRIKE
description: Stanislaw Kania, the Polish Communist Party leader, said in a speech published today that the newly conferred right to strike was being abused and warned against use of the independent trade union movement by counterrevolutionaries to sow discontent and attack Communism.

title: FGI INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Economic Scene; Reagan's Plans In Fiscal Area
description: IN case anyone was wondering whether President-elect Ronald Reagan has changed his mind about his pre-election commitments to huge tax reductions and his other economic proposals, he has now renewed his pledge to do ''what I said during the campaign I was going to do.'' George P. Shultz, the chairman of his 13-member economic policy coordination committee, has indicated that Mr. Reagan will stick to the strategy laid out in his major economic-policy statement of Sept. 9.

title: THE REAGAN TEAM'S CHIEF RECRUITER
description: Ronald Reagan refers to him as the transition team's ''director of personnel management.'' For business executives, this means E. Pendleton James is the man to please during the next two months to land a job in the Reagan administration.

title: SOME BASIS FOR MARKET SURGE SEEN
description: The stock market's surge in the wake of Ronald Reagan's landslide victory -last week's volume on the New York Stock Exchange and the accompanying sharp rise in the Dow Jones industrial average were the second-highest ever - may well be justified in economic terms, many economists say.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1981
description: International A leadership shift in China increased the power of Deng Xiaoping, Peking's strongest leader. Hu Yaobang, a close associate of Mr. Deng, was named chairman of the Communist Party, replacing Hua Guofeng. Party leaders declared that Mr. Hua, who rose to power five years ago as the personally chosen successor of Mao Zedong, was unfit to remain chairman because of ''leftist errors.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) An American-Egyptian nuclear accord that will allow Cairo to buy two large atomic reactors and fuel to generate electricity was signed in Washington. The agreement contains two provisions that State Department officials said were designed to prevent Egypt's possible use of the material and technology for military objectives. (A1:5.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Party history shows that knocking out a comrade once he commits some mistakes would make people overcautious and prevent them from speaking their minds freely.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: ON TOP OF THE MARKET IN CONVERTING CARS TO CONVERTIBLES
description: High-speed freeways and air-conditioning were supposed to have doomed the convertible, but the soft-top automobile seems to be making a small comeback in the hands of a growing number of custom body shops that are converting hardtops into convertibles.

title: NOVELS OF PAIN
description: ANGEL LANDING By Alice Hoffman. 220 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $10.95.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT OPINIONS ON REVOCATION OF PASSPORT ON SECURITY GROUNDS
description: Following are excerpts from today's Supreme Court decision upholding, by a vote of 7 to 2, a President's right to revoke a passport on national security grounds. The majority opinion was delivered by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. The minority opinion was by Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr., with whom Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall joined. From Majority Opinion By Chief Justice Burger

title: by Tony Schwartz
description: TAMING TRAVOLTA The temperature of ''Saturday Night Fever'' seems to be steadily dropping. When the film was first released three years ago, it had an ''R'' rating and was much remarked upon for the gritty realism of its language and the blunt way in which it depicted teen-age sexuality. Then Robert Stigwood, the film's producer, and Paramount Pictures, its distributor, elected to edit out some of the racier scenes so that the picture could qualify for a ''PG'' rating. Fully seven minutes were excised, making it available to a vastly increased audience of young people, but prompting some critics to complain that by eliminating some of the film's heat, some of its heart was sacrificed, too.

title: JOAN COPELAND REMEMBERS MAMA-AND SO DOES HER NROTHER ARTHUR
description: It is no great secret that Arthur Miller's ''The American Clock,'' which opens Thursday at the Biltmore, has pronounced autobiographical elements in it. The story of the Baum family - particularly in the character of Rose Baum - ruined by the Depression, has obvious parallels with the Miller family. And in the cast of the play is Joan Copeland, Arthur Miller's sister who, as Rose Baum, is thus playing her own mother.

title: Lillian Carter Undergoes Mastectomy
description: Lillian Carter underwent surgery yesterday for removal of her left breast after a cancerous lump was found in her chest. ''She withstood the procedure very well,'' said James R. Griffith, administrator of Americus-Sumter County Hospital, in Americus, Ga.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT UP BY 1.6%
description: Powered by strength in two basic industries, steel and autos, industrial production surged ahead by 1.6 percent in October, the largest one-month advance in two and a half years, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard ALICE JAMES. A Biography. By Jean Strouse. Illustrated. 367 pages. Hough- ton Mifflin. $15.

title: RANGERS ARE DEFEATED BY THE CANUCKS, 6-4
description: The Vancouver Canucks beat the Rangers, 7-4, tonight in a game that was another indication that New York is hurting this season.

title: Around the World; Security Agents at Vatican Seize Man With Pipe Bomb
description: Vatican security agents overpowered a 54-yearold Italian today as he tried to light a homemade pipe bomb as 20,000 people were gathered in St. Peter's Basilica for mass, the police reported. A spokesman for the antiterrorist police said that the man would undergo psychiatric testing.

title: Ketchum Ohio Cuts
description: Ketchum & Company, a maker and distributor of pharmaceutical, cosmetic and other products, said that it intended to relinquish some 20 percent of its corporate volume by withdrawing from the Ohio market, which it has served for more than 33 years. In announcing that the company will close its bulk warehouse in Wickliffe, Ohio, and its drug distribution center in Youngstown, Ohio, by July 31, Robert J. Hoyt, president and chief operating officer, said that Ketchum had sustained a pretax deficit in Ohio of about $1 million in the fiscal year 1981.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH, UNEASY OVER IRISH, CANCEL VISIT TO U.S. BY PRINCESS MARGARET
description: Princess Margaret has canceled a visit to the United States next month because of the political controversy surrounding Prince Charles on his recent visit to New York.

title: WELFARE TRIMS EXPECTED TO AFFECT 17% IN PROGRAMS
description: The budget cuts approved by the House of Representatives would mean a $1.1 billion reduction in welfare benefits that will largely affect children and working mothers, according to Congressional analysts and welfare specialists.

title: CRITICS SAY COFFEE STUDY WAS FLAWED
description: THERE were flaws in a study showing links between coffee drinking and a common form of cancer, several medical scientists and physicians said in letters published in the latest issue of The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: U.S. PACT ALLOWS EGYPTIANS TO BUY 2 ATOM REACTORS
description: The United States and Egypt today signed a nuclear cooperation agreement under which Egypt may purchase two large atomic reactors and fuel to generate electric power.

title: PARADOXES AT THE FACTORY
description: EAST FARMINGDALE JOSEPH LIZARDI is a paradox. His plays are up to the minute in their concerns, but a throwback in structure and style. His voice is distinct, yet derivative. The passion and gusto of a talented writer are unmistakably there, but so are the echoes of other playwrights. These encompass Rice, Odets, Miller - even Ibsen - in Mr. Lizardi's current work alone, ''Blue Collars,'' a play about the exploitation of the working class, the possibility of a wildcat strike, the election of a shop steward and tons of other things.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT LOSES APPEAL ON PASSPORT
description: The Supreme Court, ruling that the executive branch has broad legal and constitutional authority to revoke passports on national security grounds, today upheld the State Department's action in stripping a former officer of the Central Intelligence Agency of his passport.

title: ART: SCULPTURED FIGURES OF 70'S AT PRATT GALLERY
description: WE'RE quite accustomed these days to seeing shows of painting about the human figure. But because the figure as a subject regained its current esthetic respectability earlier in painting than in sculpture, it still seems somewhat daring to devote an entire sculptural show to it. And so it's with a certain feeling of adventure that one visits ''Sculpture in the 70's: The Figure'' at the Pratt Manhattan Center Gallery, 160 Lexington Avenue at 30th Street (through Nov. 25). It actually presumes to bring together a group of sculptors whose work we have long been accustomed to seeing separately, as token figurationists in shows almost wholly dominated by abstract modes. Now, in a rewarding mix, we see the figure portrayed by such well-known practitioners of the form as Peter Agostini, Robert Arneson, Leonard Baskin, Willem de Kooning, Mary Frank, Alex Katz, William King, Reuben Nakian, George Segal and Ernest Trova, with lesser knowns such as Judith Brown, Susan Grabel, Isabel McIlvain, Alvin Sher and Timothy Woodman.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
L.I.R.R. AND CONRAIL BRACE FOR WINTER
description: Buffeted by vandalism and mechanical breakdowns, New York's commuter railroads have been bracing recently for yet another assault - the winter snows, which made their first appearance last night.

title: Around the nation; 825Man Slain in F.B.I. Office Termed Ex-Mental Patient
description: A 26-year-old gunman who was shot to death after seizing the headquarters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here and holding nearly a dozen employees hostage had been in an out of mental institutions for several years and believed that someone wanted to kill him, the police said today.

title: RENT-RISING ACT FACING CHALLENGE
description: ANEW regulation that could raise rents on 7,500 to 15,000 apartments in the next 10 months, some by as much as 60 percent, will be challenged in court, either by Westchester County or by tenant groups.

title: D'AMATO ASSERTS HE WOULD KEEP 2 U.S. ATTORNEYS
description: Senator-elect Alfonse M. D'Amato said yesterday that he would seek to retain until the end of their terms the two United States Attorneys for the New York metropolitan area appointed by President Carter.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS TO N.A.A.C.P. DELEGATES
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of President Reagan's speech today to the annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People:

title: CORN ACREAGE UP 2% BUT GROWERS VOICE CAUTION ABOUT CROP
description: American farmers, the Agriculture Department's Reporting Board said today in an eagerly awaited report, are increasing their corn acreage by 2 percent this year, which could raise the harvest of this vitally needed feed grain to 7.6 billion bushels from last year's drought-hampered 6.6 billion bushels.

title: 2.5 Million Registered To Vote Today in Israel
description: About 2,490,000 Israelis will be eligible to vote in tomorrow's parliamentary elections.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WOODY GUTHRIE. A Life. By Joe Klein. 475 pages. Illustrated. Knopf. $15.95.

title: The Region; Hospital Workers Agree to Jersey Pact
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A strike threatened for tonight at 16 state hospitals, most of which serve the retarded and the mentally ill, has been averted by the tentative settlement of a contract dispute with the hospital workers' union.

title: by Jeanne Clare Feron; Old Hat Factory A Discount Outlet
description: ONE-ROOF, direct factory outlet centers have grown in recent years, enabling shoppers to ease the pressure of inflation by going where prices are discounted routinely, not just during sales. Now the former Cavanaugh Hat Company factory at the East Norwalk Station has been transformed into the Norwalk Factory Outlet Center with an official unveiling scheduled for Nov. 22. By then most of the eight main-floor stores will be in business, according to plans of Rand & Company, which is developing the center on the pattern of the Charlestown Mall at Utica, N.Y.

title: NEW CHAIRMAN OF CHINA PARTY
description: In 1941, a 26-year-old Communist political officer named Hu Yaobang was assigned to work in the 11th Army Group of the Red Army, operating in the arid Taihang Mountains in the northwestern part of China. There he was thrown together with another political commissar, 11 years his senior, named Deng Xiaoping.

title: COURT VOIDS RULING THAT GRANTED EXCLUSIVE RIGHTS ON PRESLEY NAME
description: A Federal court ruling involving rights to the late Elvis Presley's image, with significance for the commercial exploitation of other deceased celebrities, was overturned yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

title: The Stakes In Madrid
description: If any of us safe in the West can imagine being a victim of Soviet repression, one of the most terrifying possibilities today would be confinement in a mental hospital. The K.G.B. has done that to many dissidents. Diagnosed as disturbed, they are treated with disabling drugs and physically brutalized.

title: Fire in Tank Car Extinguished
description: A fire that erupted in a tank car carrying a poisonous chemical was extinguished today, allowing crews to clean up a freight-train derailment that had forced the closing of a major highway and the evacuation of some homes. The fire in the tanker carrying methyl alcohol had delayed efforts to clear the scene of the derailment of 19 cars of a Missouri Pacific train that occurred yesterday in north central Louisiana.

title: by Frederick Morton
description: Crossing from the park to the buildings side of Riverside Drive, they staggered through the traffic: a woman steadying herself with wild swings of her handbag; a chunky man, cowboy hat askew, clutching a beer can; a tall man teetering, his shoelaces trailing. They made it to the sidewalk, blind drunk on a mild car-washing kind of Saturday afternoon. The afternoon absorbed them casually. So developed, so sophisticated, is New York's skill in not taking much notice. I was on my way to buy rolls for my 4 o'clock coffee.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES RISE 15.6%
description: Sales of new single-family houses rose by 15.6 percent in May compared with April, the sharpest rise since last summer, the Government reported today. But industry officials said the figures indicated that the nation's housing slump had not ended.

title: UTILITIES' FEUD BLOCKS USE OF FULL RESERVOIR IN JERSEY
description: A long feud between two water companies has prevented the use of a brimming, three billion-gallon reservoir here in the heart of seven northern New Jersey counties where mandatory water rationing has been in effect for six weeks.

title: News Analysis
description: The criminal convictions today of two former officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with illegal break-ins supports the Justice Department's position that even Federal officials conducting national security investigators are not above the law and violate the Constitution only at their peril.

title: REAGAN URGES N.A.A.C.P. TO HELP END 'BONDAGE' OF FEDERAL PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan, declaring that Government programs had created ''a new kind of bondage'' for blacks, appealed today to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to join his effort to let business and industry bring about an ''economic emancipation'' for the deprived.

title: LONG-TERM BOND PRICES SURGE
description: Long-term bond prices rose as much as three points yesterday, a move that startled many securities dealers, who said that the amount of investor buying was not so great as the higher prices would indicate.

title: PROPOSALS ON M.T.A.'S PLIGHT
description: Following are the various proposals under discussion in Albany for dealing with the deficits of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The projected deficit for the authority is $331 million for the fiscal year that begins July 1 and $623 million for the following fiscal year. Governor Carey's Plan

title: CHICKEN IS BIG BUSINESS
description: The Chicken, as usual, was packing them in. This was his first appearance in Omaha, and long lines formed to enter Rosenblatt Stadium, home of the Royals, a triple-A baseball team in the American Association. Cars kept driving into the parking lot, stirring up dust. Soon the ball park would be filled with 13,659 spectators, the third largest crowd ever here. The previous game had drawn 1,803.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many home runs did Jimmie Foxx have washed out by rain in 1932, when he finished with 58, two behind Babe Ruth's record of 60 in 1927? What were his career statistics?

title: UMPIRES' LEGAL MOVE FAILS ON INSURANCE
description: Major league umpires lost again today in their efforts to block payment of $50 million in baseball strike insurance to team owners.

title: Bridge: Life Master Pair Title Won By New York City Teacher
description: Players from New York, Alexandria, Va., and Denver captured major titles here in the early hours of this morning at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals.

title: Hammermill Net Up 30%
description: The Hammermill Paper Company said today that it had earned $13.6 million, or $1.63 a share, in its second quarter ended June 14, up 30 percent from $10.47 million, or $1.33 a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: N.B.A. to Take Role In Cavaliers' Trades
description: The Cleveland Cavaliers have been instructed that they must receive league approval before making any trades and that the restriction will continue for ''a period to be determined.''

title: Giscard d'Estaing Samples the Monastic Life
description: Out of office for only a few weeks, Valery Giscard d'Estaing is really out of the mainstream these days. The former President of France is not only far removed from the current French-American disagreement over Communist participation in the new Socialist Government in Paris, but is also away from world matters in general.

title: U.S. BANS IMPORTED STEEL PRODUCTS OF FRENCH COMPANY AIODING SOVIET
description: The United States has banned the import of certain steel products made by a French company that recently agreed to build a $350 million electric steel plant in the Soviet Union.

title: The Region; Jersey State Senator Facing Tax Charges
description: NEWARK (AP) - State Senator William V. Musto and four political allies were indicted on Federal income-tax charges.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CONGRESS'S ACT FOR WORKER SAFETY WAS NO ACCIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: ROGER STAUBACH'S POLITICAL FOOTBALL
description: NOW that he is no longer a quarterback with a sense of drama, the real Roger Staubach has stood up as a politician with a sense of humor.

title: DOWN THE YEARS, A PHILADELPHIA STORY HOLDS ITS CHARM
description: When ''The Philadelphia Story,'' which officially opens tonight (Friday) at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, previewed on Wednesday, there was one couple in the audience who saw on the stage a world they know well: The life of the privileged in Main Line Philadelphia.

title: Business People; CURTICE-BURNS OFFICIAL TAKING ON THIRD POST
description: Robert L. Hutchinson, 60, senior executive vice president and chief operating officer of Curtice-Burns Inc., has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He will also succeed Hugh E. Cumming as president when Mr. Cumming retires from the Rochester food processing company next March at the age of 60.

title: DOW OFF 8.28 ON WEAK VOLUME
description: Securities of Texasgulf Inc. surged ahead yesterday as the latest center of attention in Wall Street's takeover boom. Despite the interest in acquisitions, stock prices in general continued downward. Airline issues were among the weak sectors.

title: Modell of Browns Testifies At N.F.L. Antitrust Trial
description: Art Modell, president of the Cleveland Browns, testified in United States District Court today that the National Football League plans to assure economic equality among league members.

title: by Moir; Lively brasserie and popular Italian.
description: JOANNA, a new restaurant on the ground floor of an old warehouse building on Fifth Avenue and 18th Street, is a big, lively brasserie. From early in the day until late at night people can come here for any sort of meal, from a rich chocolate dessert and glass of champagne to soup, hamburger, cold lobster, steak or simple choucroute garni. Thus a customer can be a big spender, or leave with a bill of a only few dollars. The idea works because the food is generally good, the atmosphere congenial and lively. The serious problems are noise and the service, which becomes erratic when the restaurant is crowded.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard WITHIN THE WHIRLWIND. By Eugenia Ginzburg. Translated from the Russian by Ian Holand. Introduction by Heinrich Boll. 423 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolff book/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.50.

title: No Headline
description: GRAND PRIX DRIVERS FINED FOR STARTING LINE PROTEST

title: No Headline
description: Mayor of the District of Columbia Erroneously Reported Wounded

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: TERM INTEREST RATES SOAR, 6-MONTH BILLS SELLING AT 13.917% By MICHAEL QUINT

title: WHY PORT WASHINGTON SWITCHED CHIEFS
description: PORT WASHINGTON QUESTIONS about the selection of a Port Washington police chief have been raised after a highly regarded provisional chief was denied a permanent appointment to the job and returned to the rank of captain.

title: COLOMBIAN CITY IS CORRUPTED BY COCAINE
description: The brazen daylight assassinations of two judges and threats to kill 11 more have jolted Medellin, Colombia's second largest city and the country's traditional center of industry, hard work and thrift, into the realization that it has fallen under the influence of narcotics traffickers.

title: 24,745 CITY PUPILS HELD BACK FOR READING DEFICIENCIES
description: A total of 24,745 pupils, including at least one of every five seventh graders, are being held back this year under a new program in New York City's public schools that denies promotion to pupils with reading deficiencies.

title: U.S. CRASH IN EGYPT LAID TO TECHNICAL FAULT
description: The crash of a United States Air Force C-141 transport near here during the night, killing all 13 Americans aboard, was attributed today to ''technical reasons'' by a spokesman of the Egyptian Defense Ministry.

title: ANOTHER FACE OF CHINA
description: It is considerably easier for the authorized traveler to ride the train from China into Hong Kong than to take the subway from East to West Berlin. There is a brief stop at the border, with no apparent fuss, and the next thing you know a Chinese girl in British police uniform is moving through the car in place of the Chinese girl in a Mao suit with a big red star on her cap.

title: Golden Silence at the Microphone
description: WHEN the Jets play the Dolphins in Miami Saturday, Dec. 20, NBC-TV will carry the game unaccompanied by the golden voices of professional broadcasters, retreaded jocks or unemployed coaches. The only voice viewers will hear, unless they choose to tune in radio, will be that of the public-address announcer telling the TV audience what he tells the cash customers.

title: KOCH SAYS HE'S PREPARED TO GET RID OF BICYCLE LANES
description: Acknowledging that he had probably made a mistake, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was prepared to tear up the bicycle lanes in Manhattan that he had championed for months as a possible solution to some of New York's traffic ills.

title: Bonn Criticizes Steel Subsidies
description: A compromise agreement reached by the European Economic Community last week on ending official subsidies to Common Market steelmakers by 1985 is most likely to be approved by the West German Cabinet even though it considers the accord ''disappointing and unsatisfactory,'' a Government spokesman, Kurt Becker, said today.

title: REAGAN AIDE OPTIMISTIC ABOUT U.S. OIL POTENTIAL
description: A top energy adviser to Ronald Reagan said today that the United States could be well on the way to energy self-sufficiency within five years and could free itself from foreign oil imports within a decade.

title: Japan TV Exports Up Sharply in May
description: Continuing a recent trend, exports of Japanese color television sets and home videotape recorders rose by 58.3 percent and 107.8 percent, respectively, in May from May 1980, the Electronics Industries Association of Japan said today.

title: New Sulpetro Offer
description: Sulpetro Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, announced a cash offer to buy the remaining 8 percent of Candel Oil Ltd. common shares it does not own for $44.45 (Canadian) a share.

title: Steel Output Up in Week
description: Steel production rose to 2.419 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of seven-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.403 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ARGENTINE'S INSPIRATION

title: Western Decalta
description: Western Decalta Petroleum Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said that it was considering the sale of its 65 percent interest in the Petrol Oil and Gas Company, which has interests in oil and gas properties in western Canada, the Canadian Arctic and the United States. Based on current securities market values, Western Decalta's holding in Petrol would be worth about $23.4 million (Canadian). Western Decalta is a private company owned by the Mannix family of Alberta.

title: WEBSTER EJECTED
description: With one punch to the chin of Dave Robisch of the Denver Nuggets early in the fourth quarter, Marvin Webster changed the tempo of a game that the New York Knicks had dominated. But the Knicks regained their poise after after Webster was ejected and won, 124-115, tonight at McNichols Arena.

title: THE INDUSTRIAL SPY PERIL
description: The United States has become a soft target for industrial espionage that is costing the nation its technological superiority. The prime weakness is an absence of consistent Government policies to protect trade secrets and stop the flow of technology out of the country.

title: To the Victors Belong What Spoils?
description: IT took the Phillies 98 years to win a World Series, and when they did, it was worth more than ever before - $34,693.18 a man. At $32,211.95 a share, the Kansas City Royals set a record, too, by collecting the sweetest purse ever paid to losers. There is poetic justice in the fact that the club that waited longest received the biggest reward, but it is dead wrong.

title: FEMINISTS TRYING TO DEAL WITH RELIGIONS' CONFINES
description: Speaking as ''one Jewish woman'' to nearly 100 women struggling to practice religion and feminism, Inge Lederer Gibel made it clear this weekend that she did not intend to be robbed by a patriarchal hierarchy of a heritage she treasured.

title: LOITERING BAN STIRS GREAT NECK DEBATE
description: GREAT NECK INDIVIDUALS loitering in Great Neck Plaza may have to account for their behavior under a new and somewhat controversial law adopted by the village several weeks ago. Proponents of the law say it provides an additional law-enforcement resource, while those who oppose it say it could be used as a form of harassment.

title: 93-YARD PLAY BEATS FLORIDA
description: Georgia, its dreams of an unbeaten and untied football season and a national championship seemingly shattered, was down to perhaps its next-to-last play today against Florida. Spectacularly, the Bulldogs scored as Buck Belue and Lindsay Scott combined on a 93-yard pass play that won the game, 26-21.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $616,000 for the qr and $993,000 for the yr...C-Net income...D-Including $202,000 tax credit; sales figures exclude the results of Cardiac Resuscitator Corp; Shr earnings reflect a 20 percent stock divd declared in Mar

title: Saudi Production
description: Saudi Arabia's real gross domestic product rose 10.9 percent in the year ended May 1980 after a 9 percent gain the previous year, the Saudi Arabian Monetary Agency said today. The rise was primarily a result of increased Government spending and higher oil production, the agency said in its 1980 annual report. Oil production rose 6.4 percent in the fiscal year 1980 after a 5.5 percent gain the year before, while total real nonoil gross domestic product grew 15.5 percent, up from 12.7 percent.

title: LITTON WINS $92.3 MILLION IN SUIT AGAINST A.T.& T.
description: A jury awarded nearly $92.3 million yesterday to Litton Systems, a unit of Litton Industries, after a five-month civil trial on antitrust charges that Litton had brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: FUN EXCEEDS STYLE IN 'HAPPY HUNTER'
description: HUNTINGTON STATION IT was Bill Thompson's intention to start his first season as PAF Playhouse's artistic producer with a play that would epitomize his double credo of theater - as a source of celebration and ensemble.

title: ACTION IS EXPECTED ON FOREIGN-AID BILL
description: Foreign-aid legislation, which seemed all but dead in the post-election session of Congress, will be taken up this week with the approval of President-elect Ronald Reagan's transition team, Congressional sources say.

title: Real Estate; Eagerness For Sites in Manhattan
description: THIS man does not lose hope easily. For 50 years Stephen Merjanian and his family have lived in an apartment above a store at 452 Third Avenue, near 31st Street. His mother and sister live in another building next door.

title: EDUCATION
description: AFTER more than a decade of experiments in nontraditional higher education - weekend courses, classes at off-campus sites, independent study, credit for ''life experience'' - the nation's colleges and universities find they need to continue to defend the academic worth of such programs if they are to continue the programs or adopt them for the first time.

title: REAGAN GREETED POLITELY BUT COOLLY BY N.A.A.C.P.
description: President Reagan received a polite but cool reception today at the annual convention of the National Association for the the Advancement of Colored People.

title: COMPUETRS: HERE COMES FUJITSU
description: TOKYO A FTER Toyota and Datsun in automobiles, Sony and Panasonic in consumer electronics, Nikon and Canon in cameras, will it be Fujitsu Ltd. that sweeps the international market in computers?

title: ELEANOR HURWITZ GROSBY
description: Eleanor Hurwitz Grosby, a former member of the Norwalk (Conn.) Common Council and the Norwalk Zoning and Planning Commission, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Norwalk.

title: WILLIAM F. SHERMER
description: William F. Shermer, a producer for WCBS-TV news, died of cancer Saturday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 38 years old. Mr. Shermer had also worked for CBS News in Boston and Philadelphia. He received awards for documentaries on children in Biafra, Vietnam and Boston.

title: Advertising; W.R.G.  Unit's New Chairman
description: BESIDES serving in the mail room of a major ad agency, Kenneth S. Olshan has worked in media and creative departments and in account service. That would seem to help qualify him to run an ad agency, especially an ad agency where, unlike most shops, account supervisors are also responsible for the creative team's advertising output.

title: Sports of the Times; The Winfield Sweepstakes
description: THE attraction of baseball's free-agent auction is the availability of what general managers call ''a player who can make the difference.'' When the 26 major-league teams determine the negotiation rights to 48 free agents at the Plaza Hotel today, Dave Winfield will tower above the others as that player with the potential to turn a contender into a champion or turn an also-ran into a contender. Ron LeFlore, Darrell Porter, Don Sutton and Tug McGraw will surely improve any team. But because of his ability and his age, 29-year-old Dave Winfield is the only one who might make the difference in a team for the next decade.

title: Around the World; Bush, Arriving in Manila, Lauds Filipinos for Support
description: Vice President George Bush arrived in Manila today for the inauguration tomorrow of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, saying the United States would never forget the Philippines for its support.

title: EGYPT CONCERNED BUT HOPEFUL ABOUT REAGAN'S VICTORY
description: Egyptian officials, though deploring the impending departure of President Anwar el-Sadat's ''good friend,'' Jimmy Carter, from the White House, see positive as well as worrying aspects in Ronald Reagan's victory.

title: NEW WAVE BROWNS BEAT COLTS
description: Brian Sipe, the Cleveland quarterback, conducted a seminar at Memorial Stadium today on the New Football that so many professional teams attempt to play but few do with the finesse and success of the Browns. New Football means the offense controls the game by passing.

title: 4 Oil Concerns Cited on Prices
description: The Energy Department said today that it had taken administrative action against four Houston oil companies that allegedly exceeded maximum legal prices by a total of $7.2 million in the resale of crude oil during 1980.

title: FUTURES EXCHANGE HOPES TO SELL C.D.'S
description: If, as expected, the New York Futures Exchange receives Federal approval today to open the first futures market in bank certificates of deposit, it will do so within two weeks, Frank J. Jones, the exchange's senior vice president, said yesterday.

title: KNICKS WIN, 100-95, LED BY 29 FOR GLENN
description: Mike Glenn and Sly Williams combined for 54 points last night and paved the way for a 100-95 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden. Glenn, starting his third straight game in the backcourt while Michael Ray Richardson recuperates from his sprained right ankle, scored 29 points.

title: Market Place; Those High P/E Ratios
description: THE strong demand for shares of high-technology companies has brought extraordinarily high price/earnings ratios. Some of them are so high that many Wall Street people are baffled.

title: Around the Nation; Span of Illinois Bridge Falls, Blocking Mississippi River
description: A fire on an old railroad bridge caused a 400-ton section of the bridge to snap and plunge into the Mississippi River today, cutting off river shipping about 20 miles north of Burlington, Iowa.

title: AETNA ENTHUSIASTIC ABOUT A ROLE IN SPACE
description: No observers were more interested in Saturday's launch of Satellite Business Systems' first communications satellite than the representatives from the Aetna Life and Casualty Company.

title: The Region; Soldier, 25, Charged In 4th Buffalo Killing
description: A 25-year-old soldier already charged with the murders of three black men in the Buffalo area last year was charged yesterday with the killing of a fourth man.

title: Muskie Walks The Deck
description: Secretary of State Muskie still walks the eighth floor deck at the State Department every morning at sunrise. He's taking one last fond look behind. It is some sight, looking up at the Washington Monument and down the Potomac across the Lincoln Memorial.

title: NOTEBOOK: DAY FOR A DEMOCRAT TO SPEAK OUT
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the majority leader, was seeing red as well as wearing it this morning at his customary Saturday morning news conference.

title: BLACKS CRITICIZE CAROLINA VERDICT ON 6 KLANSMEN
description: Black leaders in this city were outspoken today in condemning the verdicts of not guilty returned yesterday in the case of six Ku Klux Klansmen accused of murdering five members of the Communist Workers Party at a ''Death to the Klan'' rally last November.

title: Once Again the Flesh Market
description: BASEBALL'S annual flesh market opened yesterday with Dave Winfield and Don Sutton, as expected, the choice pieces of merchandise but not the most widely coveted. That distinction went to Dave W. Roberts, a .240 hitter who played all over for the Texas Rangers, and Jim Dwyer, a utility outfielder with the Boston Red Sox whose lifetime batting average is .250. Negotiation rights to Roberts were claimed by 12 teams plus the Rangers, and to Dwyer by 11 plus the Red Sox.

title: Braised Cabbage, Mushrooms and Chestnuts
description: 4 tablespoons butter 1/2 pound large mushrooms, quartered 1 cup sliced onion 2 cloves garlic, mashed 2 pounds red or green cabbage, trimmed of tough outer leaves and core and coarsely shredded 2 cups boiling chicken broth 1 cup red wine 1/2 pound chestnuts, peeled and coarsely chopped Salt and freshly ground black pepper 1 bay leaf 2/3 cup sour cream, optional.

title: Greek Aide Is Sworn In As New Deputy Premier
description: Greece's Defense Minister, Evangelos Averoff, was sworn in today as Deputy Prime Minister, marking a political victory for the right wing of the ruling New Democracy and a show of unity before the November elections.

title: CAPITALIST CHINA
description: The following article appeared last week in the Chinese Communist Party newspaper People's Daily and was translated by The Associated Press. The author works at the Huhhot Special Machine Tool Accessories Factory.

title: 5 OUTSIDE DETECXTIVES TO AID ATLANTA'S HUNT FOR CHILDREN
description: Five top homicide detectives from other cities around the country are coming here to help investigate the unsolved murders of 11 black children and the disappearance of four others here in the last 16 months, the city's Public Safety Commissioner said today.

title: Friday; GREEK SHADOW SHOWINGS
description: Shadow theater, a centuries-old Persian art form adopted by the Greeks 100 years ago, is performed by flat, perforated puppets behind a screen. Light projected behind them shows up details of their faces and clothing, as well as colors. Evgenios Spatharis, a master of Greek shadow theater, will present it at three sites this weekend: tonight at 8 at the Eisner-Lubin Auditorium of New York University's Loeb Student Center; tomorrow at 6:30 P.M., in Fort Hamilton High School, 83d Street and Colonial Road in Brooklyn, and Sunday at 4:30 and 6:30 P.M. at Bohemian Hall, 29-19 24th Avenue in Astoria, Queens. Tickets are $6 ($4 for students and children). Information: 279-9586. 50 RARE BOOKS AT COLUMBIA

title: PENSION FUND STRIKE IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that workers have a legally protected right to strike over the issue of management contributions to industrywide pension and welfare funds.

title: NCR Plans to Sell Chips to Outsiders
description: The NCR Corporation, a major producer of integrated circuit chips for use in its own computers, said that it would start selling some of those chips to other companies.

title: PITT'S PASSES CRUSH ARMY, 45-7
description: Army won the coin toss in Michie Stadium before the start of the game today, but that was just about the only thing the outmanned Cadets won. The University of Pittsburgh trounced them, 45-7, before 31,150 fans on a chilly afternoon.

title: HAIG DENIES U.S. ROLE IN BOMBING AS AIDES FEAR NEW ROUND OF DISORDER
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that there was ''absolutely no American involvement'' in the bombing in Teheran yesterday that killed 72 people, including the leader of the ruling Islamic Republican Party.

title: LEONARD IN QUEST OF SWEET REVENGE
description: RAY LEONARD was leisurely cutting down a tree in the backyard of his house in Mitchellville, Md., recently when his wife, Juanita, offered to pin a picture of Roberto Duran on the trunk of the tree.

title: THERAPISTS INSPECT STATE OF THE FAMILY
description: The eight panelists sat on green plush chairs in the hotel conference room and proceeded to address the topic of the morning, ''Sexual Abuse and Family Violence.'' They spoke of child abuse, incest, of spouse abuse and grandparent abuse. They spoke of children who abuse each other, and even of parents who manipulate children to abuse each other.

title: Turbo to Raise Stake
description: Turbo Resources Ltd., a Calgary, Alberta, integrated oil company, said it would offer $13.13 (Canadian) for up to 5 million common shares of Merland Explorations Ltd. The purchase, for a total indicated value of $65.7 million, would raise Turbo's holdings in Merland to 55 percent from 27 percent. Merland is a Calgary-based oil and gas concern engaged in development and production in Canada and the United States.

title: JERSEY BUILDER PUTTING UP HOUSING DESPITE TIGHT CREDIT
description: ''It can't go on like this,'' said Joseph Ochman. ''We've got to have a new game plan.'' Mr. Ochman is chairman of the Inter-Boro Savings and Loan Association, based in Cherry Hill, N.J. With market interest rates at 13 1/2 percent to 14 1/2 percent, most prospective home buyers in this growing area cannot afford a loan. Lending and home-construction activity is down about 50 percent statewide, and the building industry is talking about tax-exempt housing bonds as the only answer.

title: the City; The Police Blotter
description: A suspect in the fatal shooting of a police officer in Bridgeport, Conn., last November was arrested after an early morning chase through Greenwich Village in a stolen car. The suspect, Eugene Powell, 31 years old, was charged in a Connecticut warrant issued April 16 with shooting Officer Gerald T. DiJoseph with the officer's service revolver on Nov. 28, 1980.

title: DEFENSE CONTENDS ABSCAM AGENT SOUGHT TO ENSNARE REP. MURPHY
description: The attorney for Representative John M. Murphy of Staten Island charged yesterday that two months after the Congressman allegedly joined in taking a $50,000 bribe from an Abscam undercover agent, the agent knew he ''didn't have a case against Murphy.''

title: PEMBINA PIPE LINE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
FRUIT PLANTS PROVIDE LATE-AUTUMN COLOR
description: THE changing color of autumn's leaves is a hard act to follow, but nature provides something of interest for every season. After the leaves have fallen, the most striking feature of the landscape is the colorful display of fruits that remain on certain shrubs well into the winter. While their numbers are legion, we will describe a few of the best to whet your appetite.

title: OPERA EBONY TROUPE VISITS HARLEM FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: It took a long time for black singers to break the prejudice that kept them out of established opera companies. A few were accepted in European houses, but none made it into those in the United States until the 1950's. As a recourse, they set up their own organizations, which flourished intermittently the way most precarious opera companies do.

title: CAREY, KOCH AND OTHERS TRY TO DEVISE M.T.A. TAX PLAN
description: A private meeting today among Governor Carey, Mayor Koch, legislative leaders and other officials seeking to assemble a tax program to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and to improve transportation facilities upstate ended after nearly two hours with optimism, but no agreement.

title: TOXIC SHOCK: STUDIES POINT TO CAUSE, BUT QUESTIONS REMAIN
description: TOXIC shock syndrome has begun to fade as a cause of intense concern among American women. The sale of tampons, with which the disease has been linked, is slowly reviving after falling sharply last autumn. By winter, the reported incidence of the disease had dropped to less than half of its peak in the summer, and it has leveled off.

title: PENTAGON APPOINTMENT EXPECTED SOON
description: President-elect Ronald Reagan is expected to move swiftly to name a Secretary of Defense and to organize a shadow Pentagon team that would begin assuming control of the military, Republican officials said today. Over a longer term the Reagan team intends to set up a study commission on military mobilization.

title: EX-P.O. W. SEEKS MONEY PAID TO WIFE
description: When Col. Fred V. Cherry's Air Force fighter was hit by ground fire over North Vietnam in October 1965, one of his last thoughts as he bailed out was that he had signed Form 246.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: Yr ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for compensated absences

title: THE DOCTOR' WORLD
description: THE viral illness that the Vatican says has complicated the recovery of Pope John Paul II from an assassination attempt is one of the most common and baffling of human infections.

title: Market Place; The Outlook For A.T.&T.
description: A DIVIDEND increase by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company always ranks as something of an event in Wall Street. After all, Ma Bell has nearly three million owners, and they constitute by far the biggest stockholder family of any company.

title: CLAUSEN'S WORLD BANK WARNING
description: Alden Winship Clausen, who will take over Wednesday as president of the World Bank, stresses that it is in the ''vested interest'' of the United States to support the institution, which lends to the third world, and warns that the reluctance of Congressional conservatives to provide adequate financing threatens its survival.

title: Yanks Name Russ Meyer Minor League Instructor
description: Russ Meyer, the former pitcher who appeared in the World Series with the 1950 Philadelphia Phillies and the Brooklyn Dodgers of 1953 and 1955, has been named as a roving minor league pitching instructor for the Yankees. He will be responsible for evaluating pitching talent on their seven farm clubs.

title: STRONG SERIES ON BRITONS; WHY PEOPLE DON'T VOTE
description: AS the networks begin bringing back new episodes of their old weekly series, public television and, in at least one instance, cable television provide havens for the more adventurous viewer.

title: SIMPLICITY WITH A WATERFRONT FLAVOR
description: THE Fish Peddler in Huntington is a small, unpretentious place that specializes in good, fresh seafood at reasonable prices. It is the sort of establishment that is sometimes typical of waterfront areas. There should be more restaurants of this sort throughout Nassau and Suffolk.

title: GIANTS HOLD THE LINE AND PROTECT VICTORY
description: Brad Benson, the Giants' left tackle, knew nothing about the weekly bet between Ed (Too Tall) Jones and Harvey Martin of the Dallas Cowboys. Martin, who lined up in front of Benson here yesterday, and Jones, who lines up on the opposite side, compete to see who will have more quarterback sacks, with a six-pack of beer riding on each one.

title: LOST, BUT NOT DEFEATED
description: President Carter is leaving Washington with all his tattered flags flying. He has lost but he is not defeated. He seems reconciled now and even serene because, like most losers, he has convinced himself, with some reason, that he is a casualty of history.

title: Share Account Ceilings Lifted
description: The Government today lifted the limits on dividend rates of share certificate accounts offered by the nation's federally chartered credit unions. The action goes into effect immediately.

title: The U.N. Today; June 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Development Program, Governing Council - 3 P.M.

title: Mortgage-Aid Bonds Cleared
description: The Treasury Department today cleared the way for new tax-exempt mortgage subsidy bonds but excluded mobile home buyers from the subsidy.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard IDEAS AND THE NOVEL. By Mary McCar- thy. 121 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovano- vich. $7.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Sports section on Sunday erroneously identified a horse race under investigation at Belmont Park. The race being investigated is the second on June 22. Further developments are reported today on page C11.

title: COMPUTER HELPS WRITERS TO POLISH TECHNICAL REPORTS
description: ACOMPUTER will never win a Pulitzer Prize, says Nina Macdonald, but it might help you write a better report. At least that is what Dr. Macdonald, who has a Ph.D. in linguistics from the University of Michigan, thinks. She is a member of the Computing Science Research Center at the Bell Laboratories in Piscataway, N.J., and is part of a small group of experts who have created the Writer's Workbench, a series of computer programs that edit and even analyze the writing quality of technical manuscripts.

title: OFFICE TOWER ON 42D STREET REVITALIZED BY NEW OWNER
description: The only office tower on 42d Street in the stretch from Seventh Avenue to Eighth Avenue is the Candler Building, a structure of landmark quality built in a Spanish Renaissance style in 1912 by Asa G. Candler of Atlanta. The 1970's were unkind to Mr. Candler's creation. Office tenants were pulling out of 42d Street, damaging the Candler Building to the point where the owner lost it through foreclosure.

title: STADIUM REVERBERATES AT YANKEES' TRYOUTS C12)
description: Carrying bats and gloves, wearing multicolored uniforms from places like the Gomez Funeral Home and dreaming of pinstripes, about 100 aspiring baseball players turned out at Yankee Stadium yesterday for the first day of a four-day tryout camp.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK LEAFS, 4-2
description: Mike Bossy, the National Hockey League's leading goal scorer with 19, finally was stopped tonight, but the Islanders still came away with a 4-2 victory at Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: Economic Scene; Trying to Guess Reagan's Policy
description: EXCEPT for ''conservative,'' which is the way Ronald Reagan describes himself, economic labels are difficult to pin on the President-elect. One of the best ways to predict what he may do as President is to examine what he did while Governor of California. Since California does not have a central bank, however, Mr. Reagan's attitudes toward monetary policy remain a mystery.

title: SICHUAN CUISINE: ANOTHER SOURCE
description: IN the last year, more than a half-dozen Chinese restaurants have opened in southern Westchester, and every one has been commendable in one way or another. This reassuring record is a testimonial not only to the amplitude and authority of the cuisines of China but also to the wide distribution of culinary skills among the Chinese in America. It all derives from the Chinese passion for food, of course. Not even the French and Italians are such natural-bred, analytic, argumentative food critics as the Chinese. And seeing a group of Chinese in a restaurant makes one wonder whether the Chinese ideogram for happiness, which pictures various less appropriate things, ought not rather show a large family at dinner.

title: SUCCESSOR OF MAO REPLACED IN PEKING AS PARTY CHAIRMAN
description: The handpicked successor of Mao Zedong was replaced today as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party by a protege of the country's present leader.

title: Business Digest; TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1981; Companies
description: RCA will announce today the resignation of Fred Silverman as president of NBC, high-ranking sources at the network say. Grant Tinker, president of MTM Productions and a former NBC executive, is expected to succeed Mr. Silverman. (Page A1.)

title: Notes On Fashion
description: M ILAN, that decorous city, was as gaga last week as it ever gets. A heat wave followed by three days of cold, rainy weather floored nearly everyone. Then Calvin Klein paid a visit to his new boutique on Via @Sant'Andrea, strategically placed right next to the Giorgio Armani boutique and scheduled to open in the fall. Mr. Klein's venture is causing a tumult of speculation among Milan's fashion designers, who, with characteristic contradiction, agreed that his arrival would affect them not a whit, that he was doing it solely for image and, finally, that the Italian woman is a ''znob'' and would rather buy American any day of the week than something made by an Italian. Next, Gianni Versace, viewed by his fellow designers with suspicion and envy, decided to pull out of the Fiera Campionaria, a complex of buldings where the Milanese show in the fall, and to present his collection in his own showroom. After threatening to go on at the same time as several other designers, he finally reached a compromise and agreed to dates that did not conflict.

title: GEORGIA'S THRIVING OKEFENOKEE SWAMP IS TOO WET FOR ITS OWN GOOD
description: DROUGHT now stalks the ancient Okefenokee Swamp. Nobody here fears it, even as the water drops slowly in the boat trails and alligators now find that when they try to swim under little flat-bottomed punts, there isn't really enough room and their backsides gently rub the metal bottoms.

title: NOTRE DAME, GEORGIA WIN, WILL MEET IN SUGAR BOWL
description: You seldom win in any sport without big plays. The University of Georgia football team turned in one big play after another today, made the most of them and defeated Auburn, 31-21.

title: The Four Struggles
description: The correspondents of the New China News Agency have been filing reams of copy to Peking, interpreting the American election. Here is my own submission to The People's Daily:

title: REDUCED BUS FLEET TO CINTINUE IN CITY
description: The New York City Transit Authority, which expects delivery of 1,300 new buses in the next few weeks, is not planning to increase the fleet - the smallest in a decade - that has operated on the city's streets for much of the last year.

title: THE WEST BANK'S FUTURE
description: Both major parties in Israel, Likud and Labor, agree that Palestinian independence on the West Bank, even with demilitarization and other security safeguards, is too disastrous to contemplate. Today, Israel's election day, is a good time to question that consensus.

title: RUDEL MAKING LOCAL DEBUT WITH BUFFALO PHILHARMONIC
description: There is sometimes a certain symmetry to careers. Last Saturday afternoon, Julius Rudel conducted what he said was his last performance with the New York City Opera. And Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, he will lead his first New York concert with the Buffalo Philharmonic since becoming the orchestra's music director a little more than a year ago.

title: by Jack D. Early
description: When Federal regulators said recently that they had changed their minds and would not ban nitrites, the commonly used food preservative that prevents botulism and other forms of food poisoning, the announcement was viewed in some quarters as a cause for rejoicing.

title: FILM: NEW BERGMAN WORK, 'LIFE OF THE MARIONETTES'
description: THE characters in Ingmar Bergman's bracingly angry ''From the Life of the Marionettes'' aren't like the people in other Bergman films. They're just as talkative, but much less articulate or analytical. They're pettier and more quarrelsome. They tend to accept cliched, unimaginative explanations of their troubles, and to underestimate the importance of their feelings - ''You show such little respect for your own fear,'' one tells another. They make no progress, which is part of why the film has a circular structure. They are almost beyond hope.

title: THE EDITORIAL NOTEBOOK
description: The Editorial Notebook Rising Tide, Sinking Boats President Reagan, who likes to find precedents in the spirit of Franklin Roosevelt, also seeks them in the words of John Kennedy: ''A rising tide lifts all the boats.'' Mr. Reagan says the best way to relieve poverty is to revive the economy as a whole, even if that means cutting the very public assistance programs the poor rely on to live. That includes the employment and training programs that have helped low-income families escape their poverty.

title: New Construction Off 7% in May; Pickup Expected
description: New construction activity sagged again in May and will experience a modest recovery in the third quarter, after which ''volatile and high interest rates'' could turn it down again, the F.W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill reported yesterday.

title: D'AMATO PLANS REVIEW OF OFFICEHOLDERS
description: Senator-elect Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, said today that he would not automatically retain the United States Attorneys in New York who had been appointed by the Democrats.

title: TEXT PF COMMUNIQUE BY the Chinese Politvuro , and Mr. Hu, LiXiannian and Zhao Ziyang
description: CHINESE PARTY

title: FAMOUS FACES, FORGOTTEN PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: THE ART OF THE GREAT HOLLYWOOD PORTRAIT PHOTOGRAPHERS 1925-1940 By John Kobal. Illustrated. 291 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: PINELAND PLAN FACING A TEST
description: THE State Assembly, which already has delayed the master plan for part of the Pine Barrens, is scheduled to vote tomorrow on two measures that might, in effect, kill the plan altogether.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Penn Central's Rail Settlement
description: EUPHORIA gripped shareholders of the Penn Central Corporation yesterday in the wake of the announcement that the Federal Government would pay the company $2.1 billion for the assets of its bankrupt railroad, most of which were turned over to the Consolidated Rail Corporation in 1976.

title: GREAT NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-Net loss; yr ago results have been restated for an inventory adjustment

title: REAGAN'S REAL TEST
description: Surviving Democrats are asking, ''Where's the rest of us?'' Triumphant Republicans are hailing the millennium. But G.O.P. Chairman Bill Brock put Ronald Reagan's landslide victory and his winning coalition in clearest perspective.
